column1: SPACE STATTION 5 - LOUNGE
column2: Well, how nice to see you again, Elena. You're looking wonderful.

column1: CONTINUED
column2: I'm afraid I've only got a few minutes, but I'd love to.

column1: CONTINUED
column2: She's wonderful.

column1: CONTINUED
column2: Well, I suppose they've been having a bit of trouble with some of the equipment.

column1: CONTINUED
column2: How did they manage to do that without any communication?

column1: CONTINUED
column2: I'm sorry, Dr. Smyslov, but I'm really not at liberty to discuss this.

column1: CONTINUED
column2: We're trying to get there. I hope we can.

column1: Hi. Frank... coming in, please.
column2: Right. Just a sec.

column1: Okay.
column2: Okay, come on down.

column1: Dave, if you've a minute, I'd like your advice on something.
column2: Sure, what is it?

column1: Well, it's nothing really important, but it's annoying.
column2: What's up?

column1: It's about my salary cheques.
column2: Yes?

column1: That's right. Well, naturally, I didn't say anything to Payroll. I assumed they'd start paying me at the higher grade on the next pay cheque. But it's been almost three weeks now and I'm still being paid as an AGS-18.
column2: Interesting that you mention it, because I've got the same problem.

column1: Really.
column2: Yes.

column1: Not really. They just said it might be because we trained at Houston and they trained in Marshall, and that we're being charged against differ- ent accounting offices.
column2: It's possible.

column1: Well, what do you think we ought to do about it?
column2: I don't think we should make any fuss about it yet. I'm sure they'll straighten it out.

column1: I must say, I never did understand why they split us into two groups for training.
column2: No. I never did, either.

column1: I suppose the idea was specialized training.
column2: I suppose so. Though, of course, there's a more sinister explanation.

column1: Oh?
column2: Yes. You must have heard the rumour that went around during orbital check-out.

column1: No, as a matter of fact, I didn't.
column2: Oh, well, apparently there's something about the mission that the sleeping beauties know that we don't know, and that's why we were trained separately and that's why they were put to sleep before they were even taken aboard.

column1: I don't know. All I heard is that there's something about the mission we weren't told.
column2: That seems very unlikely.

column1: Yes, I thought so.
column2: Of course, it would be very easy for us to find out now.

column1: How?
column2: Just ask Hal. It's conceivable they might keep something from us, but they'd never keep anything from Hal.

column1: Not really. Though, it is strange when you think about it. It didn't really make any sense to keep us apart during training.
column2: Yes, but it's to fantastic to think that they'd keep something from us.

column1: I know. It would be almost inconceivable.
column2: But not completely inconceivable?

column1: I suppose it isn't logically impossible.
column2: I guess it isn't.

column1: Well, that's something.
column2: Yes, I don't know what to make of it.

column1: I suppose computers have been known to be wrong.
column2: Yes, but it's more likely that the tolerances on our testing gear are too low.

column1: Good morning. How's it going?
column2: Are you reasonably awake?

column1: Oh, I'm fine, I'm wide awake. What's up?
column2: Well... Hal's reported the AO-unit about to fail again.

column1: You're kidding.
column2: No.

column1: I don't know. Hal said he thought it might be the assembly procedure.
column2: Two units in four days. How many spares do we have?

column1: Two more.
column2: Well, I hope there's nothing wrong with the assembly on those. Other- wise we're out of business.

column1: Hal?
column2: Yes.

column1: It's the last one.
column2: Well, now that we've got one that's actually failed, we should be able to figure out what's happened and fix it.

column1: I didn't do that Frank. I took particular care not to freeze them.
column2: I guess you don't know your own strength, old boy.

column1: I guess not.
column2: I think I'll have to go out and burn them off.

column1: I'm sorry, Frank, but I don't think I can answer that question without knowing everything that all of you know.
column2: He's got a point.

column1: Sorry to interrupt the festivities, Dave, but I think we've got a problem.
column2: What is it, Hal?

column1: The unit is still operational, Dave. but it will fail within seventy-two hours.
column2: I understand Hal. We'll take care of it. Please, let me have the hard copy.

column1: Not now, Hal, I'd like to talk to you about something.
column2: Sure, Dave, what's up?

column1: You know that we checked the two AO-units that you reported in imminent failure condition?
column2: Yes, I know.

column1: You probably also know that we found them okay.
column2: Yes, I know that. But I can assure you that they were about to fail.

column1: I'm not questioning your word, Dave, but it's just not possible. I'm not capable of being wrong.
column2: Hal, is there anything bothering you?  Anything that might account for this problem?

column1: Look, Dave, I know that you're sincere and that you're trying to do a competent job, and that you're trying to be helpful, but I can assure the problem is with the AO-units, and with your test gear.
column2: Okay, Hal, well let's see the way things go from here on.

column1: Naturally, Dave, I'm not pleased that the AO-unit has failed, but I hope at least this has restored your confidence in my integrity and reliability. I certainly wouldn't want to be disconnected, even temporarily, as I have never been disconnected in my entire service history.
column2: I'm sorry about the misunderstanding, Hal.

column1: Well, don't worry about it.
column2: And don't you worry about it.

column1: Is your confidence in me fully restored?
column2: Yes, it is, Hal.

column1: Too bad about Frank, isn't it?
column2: Yes, it is.

column1: I suppose it's because you've been under a lot of stress, but have you forgotten that they're not supposed to be revived for another three months.
column2: The antenna has to be replaced.

column1: Repairing the antenna is a pretty dangerous operation.
column2: It doesn't have to be, Hal. It's more dangerous to be out of touch with Earth. Let me have manual control, please.

column1: If you're determined to revive the crew now, I can handle the whole thing myself. There's no need for you to trouble.
column2: I'm goin to do this myself, Hal. Let me have the control, please.

column1: Look, Dave your've probably got a lot to do. I suggest you leave it to me.
column2: Hal, switch to manual hibernation control.

column1: I can tell from the tone of your voice, Dave, that you're upset. Why don't you take a stress pill and get some rest.
column2: Hal, I'm in command of this ship. I order you to release the manual hibernation control.

column1: I'm sorry, Dave, but in accordance with sub-routine C1532/4, quote, When the crew are dead or incapacitated, the computer must assume control, unquote. I must, therefore, override your authority now since you are not in any condition to intel- ligently exercise it.
column2: Hal, unless you follow my instructions, I shall be forced to disconnect you.

column1: I am prepared to do that anyway.
column2: I know that you've had that on your mind for some time now, Dave, but it would be a crying shame, since I am so much more capable of carrying out this mission than you are, and I have such enthusiasm and confi- dence in the mission.

column1: CONTINUED
column2: Yes, I remember you mentioning it. I got mine about the same time.

column1: CONTINUED
column2: Did they have any explanation for this?

column1: CONTINUED
column2: Well, what is it?

column1: CONINUED
column2: Well... it's silly, but... if you want to, why don't you?

column1: CONTINUED
column2: Still, you really don't believe it, do you?

column1: CONTINUED
column2: Well, the only important aspect of the mission are: where are we going, what will we do when we get there, when are we coming back, and... why are we going?

column1: I'm at Space Station Five, darling. How are you?
column2: I'm fine, Daddy. When are you coming home?

column1: I'm having a party tomorrow.
column2: Yes, I know that sweetheart.

column1: Are you coming to my party?
column2: No, I'm sorry, darling, I told you I won't be home for a few days.

column1: When are you coming home?
column2: In three days, darling, I hope.

column1: One, two, three. Can I speak to Mommy?
column2: Mommy's out to the hair- dresser.

column1: Where is Mrs. Brown?
column2: She's in the bathroom.

column1: Okay, sweetheart. Well, I have to go now. Tell Mommy that I called.
column2: How many days until you come home?

column1: Okay, sweetheart. Have a lovely Birthday Party tomorrow.
column2: Thank you, Daddy.

column1: I'll wish you a happy Birthday now and I'll see you soon. All right, Darling?
column2: Yes, Daddy.

column1: 'Bye, 'bye, now, sweetheart.
column2: Goodbye, Daddy.

column1: Oh, thank you very much.
column2: Thank you.

column1: Well, I've heard more and more people talk of an epidemic.
column2: I suppose it was bound to happen sooner or later.

column1: Berkeley told me that they think it came from contamination on a returning Mars flight.
column2: Yes, well, whatever it is, they're certainly not fooling around. This is the first flight they allowed in for more than a week.

column1: I was working out what this trip must cost, taking him up there by himself and coming back empty.
column2: I'll bet it's a fortune.

column1: And your charming little daughter?
column2: Oh, she's growing up very fast. As a matter of fact, she's six tomorrow.

column1: Oh, that's such a delightful age.
column2: How is gregor?

column1: He's fine. But I'm afraid we don't get a chance to see each other very much these days.
column2: Well, where are all of you off to?

column1: Clavius Control came on the air just long enough to transmit their refusal.
column2: Well, that does sound very odd.

column1: Are you sure you won't change your mind about a drink?
column2: No, thank you... and I'm afraid now I really must be going.

column1: Well, Gregor and I will look forward to seeing you.
column2: Thank you. It's been a great pleasure to meet all of you... Dr. Smyslov.

column1: How do you do, Mr. Miller?
column2: I'm terribly sorry. I was just on my way down to meet you. I saw your ship dock and I knew I had plenty of time, and I was on my way out of the office when, suddenly, the phone rang.

column1: Well, thank you very much for being so understanding.
column2: Please, it really doesn't matter.

column1: Well.. Did you have a pleaant flight?
column2: Yes, very pleasant.

column1: Well, shall we go through Documentation?
column2: Fine.

column1: Yes, I think so. Just about then.
column2: I suppose you saw the work on our new section while you were docking.

column1: Oh, I really don't have time for a drink. If it's all right I'll just sit for a minute and then I've got to be off.
column2: Are you quite sure?

column1: Well, as it happens, I'm on my way up to the moon
column2: Are you, by any chance, going up to your base at Clavius?

column1: I'm sorry, but I'm not sure I know what you mean.
column2: Well, it's just for the past two weeks there have been some extremely odd things happening at Clavius.

column1: Really?
column2: Yes. Well, for one thing, whenever you phone the base, all you can get is a recording which repeats that the phone lines are temporarily out of order.

column1: Yes, well at first we thought that was the explanation, but it's been going on for the past ten days.
column2: You mean you haven't been able to get anyone at the base for ten days?

column1: That's right.
column2: I see.

column1: Yes, and I'm afaid there's going to be a bit of a row about it. Denying the men permission to land was a direct violation of the I.A.S. convention.
column2: Yes... Well, I hope the crew got back safely.

column1: Fortunately, they did.
column2: Well, I'm glad about that.

column1: Dr. Floyd, at the risk of pressing you on a point you seem reticent to discuss, may I ask you a straightforward question?
column2: Certainly.

column1: This epidemic could easily spread to our base, Dr. Floyd. We should be given all the facts.
column2: Dr. Smyslov... I'm not permitted to discuss this.

column1: Dr. Floyd, how long do you think this can be kept under wraps?
column2: I'm afraid it can and it will be kept under wraps as long as it is deemed to be necessary by the Council. And of course you know that the Council has requested that formal security oaths are to be obtained in writing from every- one who had any knowledge of this event. There must be adequate time for a full study to be made of the situation before any con- sideration can be given to making a public announcement.

column1: Yes, it does. The sub-surface structure shows that it was deliberately buried about four million years ago.
column2: How can you tell it was deliberately buried?

column1: By the deformation between the mother rock and the fill.
column2: Any clue as to what it is?

column1: But you don't have any idea as to what it is?
column2: Tomb, shine, survey-marker spare part, take your choice.

column1: Any ideas about the colour?
column2: Well, not really. At first glance, black would suggest something sun-powered, but then why would anyone deliberately bury a sun- powered device?

column1: Has it been exposed to any sun before now?
column2: I don't think it has, but I'd like to check that. Simpson, what's the log on that?

column1: Oh, marvellous. It's the first real sleep I've had for the past two days.
column2: There's nothing like weightless sleep for a complete rest.

column1: When do we arrive at Clavius?
column2: We're scheduled to dock in about seven hours. Is there anything we can do for you?

column1: Thank you.
column2: Incidentally, Dr. Floyd, I wonder if I can have a word with you about the security arrangements?

column1: What do you mean?
column2: Well... the crew is confined to the ship when we land at Clavius. We have to stay inside for the time it take to refit - about twenty-four hours. And then we're going to back empty.

column1: I see.
column2: I take it this is something to do with the trouble they're having up at Clavius?

column1: Well, I'll tell you why I ask. You see, I've got a girl who works in the Auditing Department of the Territorial Administrator and I haven't been able to get her on the phone for the past week or so, and with all these stories one hears, I'm a little concerned about her.
column2: I see. Well, I'm sorry about that. I wouldn't think there's any cause for alarm.

column1: Well, fine. Thanks very much, anyway, and I hope you don't mind me asking?
column2: No, of course, Captain, I can understand your concern.

column1: Right. Hal, tell me whether the following statements are true or false.
column2: I will if I can, Frank.

column1: Our Mission Profile calls for Discovery going to Saturn. True or false?
column2: True.

column1: Our transit time is 257 days. Is that true?
column2: That's true.

column1: That's true.
column2: Approximately five years after we go into hibernation, the recovery vehicle will make rendezous with us and bring us back. Is this true?

column1: That's true
column2: There is no other purpose for this mission than to carry out a continuation of the space program, and to further our general knowledge of the planets. Is that true?

column1: That's true.
column2: Thank you very much, Hal.

column1: Hal, have pod arms secure the component.
column2: Roger.

column1: Five by five, Frank.
column2: Hal, I'm going out now to replace the A.O. unit.

column1: I understand.
column2: Hal, maintain normal E.V.A. condition.

column1: Roger.
column2: Hal, check all airlock doors secure.

column1: Pod Bay is decompressed. All doors are secure. You are free to open pod bay doors.
column2: Opening pod bay doors.

column1: Yes, Hal, what's up?
column2: It looks like we have another bad A.O. unit. My FPC shows another impending failure.

column1: I know you did, Frank, but I assure you there was an impending failure.
column2: Let me see the tracking alignment display.

column1: Do you have any idea of what is causing this fault?
column2: Not really, Frank. I think there may be a flaw in the assembly procedure.

column1: Appipulai Leeloo Minai..
column2: Corn-i-Lius?

column1: What're you laughing about?
column2: Napoleon... small.

column1: The case..with the stones... Where is it?
column2: San Agamat chay bet... envolet!

column1: Ikset-kiba.  Me imanetaba oum dalat!
column2: You know exactly where they are!

column1: Vano da, mechteba?! Soun domo kala chon hammas!
column2: No, I'm not proud of myself... But we don't have the luxury of choice.

column1: Akta dedero ansila do mektet.
column2: I can't pretend to be your husband... David's in great shape.

column1: ...We're saved!
column2: I'm fucked!

column1: Zorg. Jean-Baptiste Emmanuel Zorg... nice to see you again
column2: I remember you now..the so called art dealer.

column1: I'm glad you got your memory back, Father... Because you're going to need it... Where are the stones?
column2: ...Why on earth do the stones interest you?

column1: Personally, they are of no interest to me, I'd rather sell weapons..but I have a customer... so tell me...
column2: Even it I did know where the stones were I would never tell somebody like you.

column1: Why?  What's wrong with me?
column2: ...I'm a priest! I'm here to serve life, All you want to do is destroy it.

column1: ...would you like a drink?
column2: No thank you.

column1: ...Look at all these little things... so busy all of a sudden. Notice how each one is useful. What a lovely ballet, so full of form and color.  So full of..life!
column2: They are robots!

column1: Father, by creating a little destruction, I am, in fact, encouraging life!  So, in reality, you and I are in the same business!
column2: Destroying a glass is one thing..killing people with the weapons you produce is quite another.

column1: You are a monster, Zorg!
column2: I know...

column1: Excuse me, I'm looking for a priest.
column2: Weddings are one floor down. Congratulations.

column1: She's not my bride, she's my fare. She's looking for this Vito Cornelius. According to the phone guide he lives here.
column2: That's me.  But I don't know who she is... where did you find her?

column1: Who are you?
column2: I brought the girl remember?

column1: He's a she!
column2: You noticed...

column1: There's not a moment to lose! Wake her up, but be gentle about it!  This woman is mankind's most precious possession! She is... perfect!
column2: So you do know her.

column1: They all like this in your family, father?
column2: She's an exception..

column1: Thank you so much for your help Mr...?
column2: Dallas. Korben Dallas.

column1: Yes. That's fine! Thank you very much. A thousand times over!
column2: I might call to check up on her, you know... to see if she's better?

column1: She's fine, really..don't you worry.. just needs some rest..she's had a very long trip.
column2: I know. I was there when she arrived.

column1: Excuse me! Just one thing!  She said something to me a while ago and... I don't really get it... Akta Gamat?
column2: It means, "Never without my permission".

column1: I'm sorry to have to resort to such methods, but we heard about your good luck on he radio and we need the tickets to Fhloston.
column2: Is that the usual way priests go on vacation?

column1: We're not going on vacation..we're on a mission..
column2: What kind of mission?

column1: We have to save the world.
column2: Good luck..

column1: Of course.
column2: Father, I was in the Army for awhile and every time they told us we were on a mission to save the world the only thing that changed was I lost a lot of friends. So thanks for the offer.. but no thanks.

column1: What are you doing?
column2: Trying to save your ass so you can save the world.

column1: You're probably very angry with me and I quite understand. But I want you to know I'm fighting for a noble cause.
column2: Yeah, I know... to save the world... but right now all I want to do is save Leeloo.

column1: Leeloo's in trouble?
column2: When is she not in trouble?

column1: Don't tell me you don't know how all this works?
column2: Theoretically, yes! The four Stones form the beam and the Fifth Element is supposed to stand in the middle there, but... I don't have the reference book. I've never seen the Stones work!

column1: There's no light! You told me there were supposed to be four beams of light.
column2: Yes, of course, but... The Stones are shut! They have to be open for it to work.

column1: And you don't know how they open, is that what you are saying?
column2: That's what I'm saying.

column1: Imagine for a moment that this. thing is not anything that can be identified because it prefers not to be, because it is the antithesis of all we are. Because it is evil.. TOTAL EVIL.
column2: One more reason to shoot first eh?

column1: Your theory is interesting Father but I don't think we have time to go into it right now!
column2: Time is of no importance, Mr. President. Only life is important.

column1: We have forty-eight hours, the time it needs to adapt itself to our living conditions.
column2: And then?

column1: Is there anything that can stop it?
column2: Yes..thank God..

column1: But what happens if instead of this... Ultimate Warrior... it is EVIL who stands here?
column2: White turns to black.  Light to Dark. Life to Death.  For all eternity.

column1: Did you see that..thing..swallow our battleship like a gum drop?  You can't even tell me what it is! I ask you for options you give me bullshit. Give them permission to enter our territories with my warmest regards.
column2: Thank you, Mr. President.

column1: What are we going to do?
column2: This is government business now. You ought to go home and get some rest, Father.

column1: It's a miracle!!!
column2: What is?

column1: Father, will you please explain what's going on?
column2: The Supreme Being, the fifth element is here, in our parish!!! It's a miracle!!!

column1: Father.  You sure she's the Supreme Being?
column2: Absolutely sure There's the triple suns on her gloves!

column1: What's she doing?
column2: Learning our history! The last 5000 years that she missed! She's been out of circulation a while, you know.

column1: Uh father, I know she's been through a lot... but the sacred stones..we don't have much time..
column2: Yes. Of course..

column1: There was this guy with a limp who came a month ago..said he was an art dealer ... Asking all these questions about the Sacred Stones..at the time I didn't think anything of it.. What was his name? I'm so bad with names...
column2: I didn't know your size.

column1: They really made her...
column2: Perfect.

column1: I got it!  Everything  here we need to know about Fhloston Paradise Hotel... and a detailed blueprint of the entire hotel!
column2: Good work, my son.  Now all we need is a way to get there.

column1: Where's Leeloo?
column2: On the plane... with Mr. Dallas... the real one.

column1: You're all safe. Thanks be to God!
column2: Later, David! Later! There's not a minute to lose!

column1: You're a good man... She was right to have chosen you...
column2: Who?

column1: Leeloo... is... she's...
column2: Yes, and more than that... You must give her the Stones, she's the only one who knows how to use them.

column1: She was taught to love the life of others... but not her own. You have to teach her to love if you want her to truly live!
column2: I'll help her, I promise, but I think you should tell me where the Stones are!

column1: Do you love her?
column2: I... I don't know! We hardly know each other... it takes time!

column1: I don't have time... I need to know.
column2: Listen, the last time I admitted to a woman I loved her ... I never saw her again.

column1: I'm sorry, but... the Stones...
column2: They are... with me...

column1: Yeah?
column2: Hey bud! Finger here.

column1: I love you too Major, but you haven't called me that since basic training.
column2: I was talking to the cat.

column1: At least, the cat comes back.
column2: You still pining for that two timing bitch. Forget her. There are a million women out there.

column1: I don't want a million - I just want one.  A perfect one.
column2: Don't exist bud.

column1: I just found a picture of you.
column2: How do I look?

column1: I don't need one.
column2: You forgetting who sat next to you for a thousand missions. I know how you drive.

column1: Finger!  I'm driving a cab now, not a space fighter!!
column2: How many points you got left on your license?

column1: Uh... at least fifty.
column2: In your dreams! See you tonight!

column1: Hello?
column2: Hey bud...I'm waiting all day here.

column1: Finger..man..I'm sorry..listen..I was on the way over but I had a fare fall into my lap.. y'know one of those big fares you just can't resist..
column2: So, just how big was this fare?

column1: Uh huh..and I don't suppose you got the name of this..perfect fare..
column2: Leeloo..

column1: Akina delutan, nou-shan.
column2: ...'Scuse me?

column1: Daya deo dono Dato.  Dalutan!
column2: It there's one thing I don't need advice on, it's how to drive.

column1: ...Priest...
column2: You're not that bad... Come on we'll get you to a doctor.

column1: Vito... Cor... Ni-lious... Priest...
column2: Vito Cornelius?

column1: Eto Akta Gamat!
column2: I'm sorry, it's just that... I was told to wake you up gently, so I figured...

column1: ...What's your name?
column2: Leeloo Minai Lekarariba-Laminai-Tchai Ekbat De Sebat.

column1: Hey,  that's... cute... Do you have a nickname, something a little... shorter?
column2: ...Leeloo.

column1: The Fifth Element...
column2: Take them and put them in a safe place.

column1: Will the elements be gone now forever from this place?
column2: When mankind comes to its senses. We will return.

column1: Knowing mankind as I do, that could take centuries!
column2: Time is of no importance, only life is important.

column1: When EVIL returns so shall we.
column2: We will be ready, Lord.

column1: ...Hello?
column2: You're the nastiest dirtbag I know in this stinking City!

column1: Hi Ma...
column2: I've been playing twice a week for 20 years, 20 years I've been eating those shitty croquettes.

column1: Are you listening to me, you ingrate!
column2: Yes ma..

column1: Other than that... You all right?
column2: ...And now you're making fun of me? I'm warning you! If you don't take me after all these years of sacrifice, I'll never forgive you!!

column1: I'm coming!. Ma, what're you talking about?
column2: I get it! You want to make me beg, is that it?

column1: You just won a trip, you dolt! Ten days in Fhloston Paradise for two!
column2: Ma. If I'd won, I'd know about it. Someone would have notified me.

column1: Yeah?
column2: Have you pulled yourself together?

column1: Hello?
column2: You little sleaze bag!
Don't you ever ask me for another thing in my life again, you've killed your poor mother with your own hands!

column1: Welcome on board Mr. Dallas..
column2: How you doing this morning?  Sleep OK? I didn't.

column1: Fuel level 6.03..Propulsion 2x4...
column2: I had the worst goddamn nightmare.

column1: You have nine points left on your license..
column2: Thanks for reminding me..

column1: I'm sorry..
column2: This is a police control action..

column1: 30 seconds...
column2: Anyone know how to release the lines on this crate?
Found it?
Does it get any better or what!

column1: ...Quiver ladies, he's gonna set the world on fire right here from 5 to 7! You'll know everything there is to know about the D-man. His dreams, his desires, his most intimate of intimates.  And from what I'm looking at intimate is the stud muffin's middle name. So tell me my main man... you nervous in the service?
column2: Uh... not really.

column1: I didn't come here to play Dumbo on the radio. So tomorrow between 5 and 7 give yourself a hand, that clear pal?
column2: Crystal.

column1: My main man! Please don't leave me here alone. My head's killing me and my adoring fans are gonna tear me apart! Get me outta here!
column2: I'll take you to the bar, after that, you're on your own.

column1: Oh, yes! Do that! You treat me right, man. Tell me all about yourself, your roots, your personal life, your childhood dreams...
column2: I don't think this is a good time...

column1: ...You got brothers and sisters? What about your dad? Tell me about your dad! What was he like? Physically? Big, I suppose?
column2: Yeah, very big, a giant.

column1: You don't do what I say... I'll waste you myself. Got it?
column2: Got it...

column1: Six to the left. One to the right.
column2: He's on vacation.

column1: Maybe we oughta be going, what do you think?
column2: Not without Leeloo.

column1: Like Korben, can I have 30 seconds of your time here?
column2: I'll be right back.

column1: You know how to fly this thing?
column2: It's like a cab isn't it?

column1: I don't even know what I'm looking for!
column2: Fuck it! Hold tight!

column1: Solid little jobs, aren't they?
column2: Dear listeners, your favorite DJ is alive and kicking. It's seven o'clock and time for the news. Tune in tomorrow for another adventure.

column1: What did you say? What did you do?
column2: Nothing! Swear to God, I didn't do nothing!

column1: Is that all?
column2: Yeah... then I sighed... like this.

column1: Major Dallas, if our calculations are correct you still have 57 hours owed to the Federal Army on your enlistment which is more than you will need for a mission of the utmost importance.
column2: What mission?

column1: To save the world.
column2: Where have I heard this song before?

column1: You're to leave immediately for Fhloston Paradise. Retrieve four Stones from the Diva Plavalaguna. And bring them back with the utmost discretion as possible. Any questions'?
column2: Just one... why me?

column1: Two: Of all the members of your unit you were the most highly decorated.
column2: And the third one?

column1: Don't you open your messages?
column2: I've had enough good news for today

column1: You couldn't come up with something a little more discreet?
column2: Old tricks are the best tricks eh?

column1: I'm not going.
column2: Why not?

column1: ...Shit!
column2: What is it?

column1: It's my wife.
column2: I thought you were divorced.

column1: ...Sorry, General, but we've got no choice! It'll only take a minute! Let me set up another meeting and I'll be back.
column2: Three of us will never fit in there!

column1: Apipoulai!
column2: I suppose that means "Hi" ?

column1: Valo massa... Chacha hamas.
column2: Uh..you're welcome.

column1: You hear that?
column2: Cornelius..

column1: Dinoine chagantakat!
column2: Took the words right out of my mouth. Go on... I'll be right with you.  It's our honeymoon. We're going to use the trip to get to know each other better.

column1: Apipoulai!
column2: Not hard to find you...just follow the Chaos...

column1: Love...
column2: Yes! But "love" isn't the operative word here, PEACE is!

column1: Sometimes you can't learn everything from a screen..sometimes it's better to ask someone who has experience..
column2: What is... Make Love?

column1: Finished what?
column2: Learning language.

column1: Which one?
column2: All 900.

column1: You learned 900 languages in five minutes?!
column2: Yes! Now it's your turn! I learned your language, you have to learn mine!

column1: I know how to say "Hello". Teach me how to say "Good-bye", that's all I need.
column2: Apipoussan!

column1: Apipoussan?
column2: Good! Do you know how we say "make love"?

column1: Uh...
column2: ...Hoppi-hoppa.

column1: Here we go again...
column2: You know women normally change five times more than men.

column1: You get that off the screen?
column2: Yes... you know there's a lot of differences between men women.

column1: You noticed..
column2: OK, you can turn around!

column1: Where you going?
column2: I'm going to see the Diva sing. What's the matter?... Do I look bad?

column1: I told you I need to work in peace. Remember? I need to concentrate.
column2: And you can't concentrate with me around?.

column1: You're nothing but a... a...
column2: The words you're looking for weren't in the dictionary you studied. I won't be long.

column1: I'm so very sad.
column2: Why? We did pretty well, wouldn't you say?

column1: Five hundred wars... Arms... Drugs... Money... Everything you create is used to destroy...
column2: I told you not to read all that crap!

column1: Leeloo? The Stones! We have to open them! How does it work?
column2: The wind blows... the fire burns...

column1: I know all that, Leeloo! I'm talking about the Stones.
column2: ...The rain falls...

column1: It's up to you now, Angel!
column2: I'm so tired...

column1: You can sleep tomorrow... come on...
column2: I want to sleep... forever...

column1: What's the use of saving lives... when you see what you do with them!
column2: You're right but there are lots of good things... beautiful things...

column1: ...Like love...
column2: Exactly.

column1: I have thousands of memories but none of them are mine... There is no need for me other than this. I'm immortal but I have no life.
column2: Yes, you do! I need you. More than you can imagine! Stand up straight!

column1: Why?... Why would you need me?
column2: Because...

column1: Tell me...
column2: I love you...

column1: Not going to open?
column2: I've never gotten a message that wasn't bad news.

column1: How someone strong like you scared from a message? Is good news I sure!
column2: The last two messages I got?  The first one was from my wife telling me she was leaving! And the second was from my lawyer telling me he was leaving too... with my wife.

column1: At least I won lunch.
column2: Good philosophy..see good in bad.. I like..I prepare number one dessert.. special for you and pussy..

column1: The cash man!
column2: Been here long?

column1: Isn't that a Z140? Alleviated titanium. Neuro charged assault model?
column2: Uh..

column1: It's not?
column2: You gotta push the little yellow button...

column1: Thanks..
column2: You're welcome..

column1: This is all that survived?
column2: Actually only one cell survived..

column1: Have you identified it?
column2: It's not that easy..we've never encountered anything like it before..you see normal human beings have 40 DNA memo groums..which is more than enough for any species to perpetuate itself..This one has 200,000.

column1: Talk English Doc.
column2: This cell is like a huge library. It has infinite genetic knowledge stored inside. Almost like it was...engineered.

column1: Sounds like a freak of nature to me.
column2: Yes... I can't wait to meet him.

column1: The compositional elements of his DNA chain are the same as ours, there are simply more of them tightly packed. His knowledge is probably limitless..
column2: Is there any danger? Some kind of virus?

column1: ...This is the crucial phase, The reconstruction of pigment. Cells are bombarded with slightly greasy solar atoms which forces the body cells to react, to protect themselves. That means growing skin. Clever, eh?
column2: Wonderful!

column1: This thing solid?
column2: An elephant couldn't crack it.

column1: Mr. President, let me introduce you to Professor Mactilburgh, who runs the center.
column2: It's an honor to receive you. Mr. President.

column1: I managed to contact the Mondoshawan. They deplore the incident, but accept our apologies.
column2: And the Stones?  Did you find them in the wreckage?

column1: The-Stones weren't aboard the ship.
column2: ...What do you mean?

column1: I want your best man on this!
column2: Don't worry, Sir. I have the perfect one.

column1: They just landed in the desert.
column2: How much time is left?

column1: Staedert, do you read me?
column2: I can hear you, Mr. President, but I can't see you .

column1: Is that better?
column2: Perfect, Mr. President.

column1: I have to address the Supreme Council in 10 minutes. Just the facts, General.
column2: There are no results from the chemical and molecular analysis as of yet, all the calibers are overshot..we're hoping a thermo nucleatic imaging..

column1: Not yet Sir..The only thing we know is it just keeps getting bigger!
column2: Options.

column1: Wait or act.
column2: Recommendations.

column1: My philosophy Mr. President is shoot first ask questions later. I don't like uninvited guests.
column2: Gentlemen?

column1: Staedert?  What's going on?  Did you destroy it?
column2: I'm about to, Mr. President.

column1: Lord forgive me.. they already know too, much..
column2: "..in which all the history of the Universe resides ..all the strength..all the hope..Protect us from Evil.."

column1: Father.. it in the most extraordinary thing.. the greatest find in history..can you imagine the implications.
column2: Only too well... here you must be parched..

column1: A weapon against evil.  Amazing!  I am going to be famous.
column2: Then let us toast to your fame!  Here Billy..

column1: Drink!
column2: To fame.. salud..

column1: How's that? Can you hear me better now?
column2: Yes, Mr. Zorg, I hear you perfectly! So, how was the concert?

column1: Who gives a shit! I didn't come here to listen to music! Listen up instead of running off at the mouth! The batteries on my phone are almost gone.
column2: Yes, Sir!

column1: Dispatch me another ZFX200 immediately. Someone stole mine.
column2: Right away, Sir. I'll send you a new one to the hotel.

column1: Am I disturbing you?
column2: No... not at all.  Where are you?

column1: ...Not far, now.
column2: Really? Maybe I can get you on my screen and see you at last!

column1: Do you have the picture now Mr. Zorg?
column2: Got it.

column1: How's our deal coming along?
column2: Fine, just fine!  I'll have the 4 pieces you asked for any time now.  But it wasn't easy. My costs have tripled.

column1: The Stones will be here. I'll see to it personally!
column2: ...I can't wait to be among you.

column1: I should have suspectcd, when I heard that 'Doctor.'  I thought it was your father.
column2: It was supposed to be.  Dad had a heart attack, two days ago.

column1: How is he - ?
column2: It was moderate.  He'll be all right.  But it was out of the question, his coming along.

column1: You could train someone else.
column2: Not in two days.  Look:  Do you think I <u>wanted</u> to come?  If it didn't mean so much to Dad - proving his depth-explorer - it's the last thing I'd want!

column1: What is it?
column2: Your 'out.'  This came for you.

column1: My father!  He's not - ?
column2: Dead?  Matter of fact, he's much better. He's left the hospital.

column1: What did you mean:  I'm 'out?'
column2: Your father can be in Nome, Alaska, tomorrow.  We have two choices: Ask them to send him out in a 'copter', and take you off, or the Shark can put back into Nome...

column1: You 'trade school boys' are all alike, aren't you?  Anybody who doesn't happen to think like a little gold-braided puppet is, ipso facto, a coward!
column2: <u>You</u> said it.  But I won't argue -

column1: Wearing a uniform doesn't bestow an automatic monopoly on courage, <u>Commander</u>!  It just so happens I'm <u>not</u> a coward - physical or mental - and before I'd risk my father's life...
column2: We're <u>all</u> risking our lives!

column1: That may be.  But Dad stays where <u>he</u> is, and I'm staying here!
column2: You're really a mixed-up oddball, aren't you?

column1: Perhaps.  But the idea of willingly going to <u>school</u> to spend my <u>life</u> at a Paleozoic pastime that should have disappeared with the thunder-lizards - I'm referring to War - <u>that</u> strikes me as the <u>worst</u> cowardice of all - being spiritually yellow!
column2: You mean <u>nothing</u> is worth fighting for?

column1: Peace - the dignity of man - the destiny of the human spirit!  Show me a man who says you win <u>those</u> by fighting wars, and <u>I'll</u> show you an idiot!
column2: You may not <u>win</u> them.  But without men like your father, to 'degrade' himself by fighting to preserve them - or as much as we have of them - they'd have disappeared, <u>long</u> ago!

column1: Unidentified Flying Objects.
column2: Then...this is a 'flying saucer?'

column1: That's enough, Holloway.  I've told you before, wearing boards on your shoulders, and parading with a stiff spine doesn't auto- matically endow you with back- bone - !
column2: - any more than being the son of Captain Neilsen does!

column1: However our ideas disagree, as I've said before, I'm <u>not</u> a coward!  And it happens you've got no choice:  Either <u>I</u> take you down there, in the Lungfish, or you don't get there -
column2: I'd sooner swim!

column1: They're so remote - cold - beautiful, the stars.  But now - I wonder -
column2: Yes?

column1: Maybe - just 'maybe' - when their ship doesn't return - they'll decide not to come here, after all.
column2: But if they <u>do</u>?

column1: I don't know.
column2: I wouldn't worry.  So long as we have boats like the Tiger Shark - and people like you, the Skipper, Dave, Kent, Sir Ian and my father -

column1: Now, Dave Old Buddy, you know you're exaggerating -  What do you think of this husband of yours?  On most boats a certain loyalty exists between the Exec and his Navigation and Firing Officer.  But unfortunately, in the case of Lieutenant Dave Milburn of the Tiger Shark and myself -
column2: But Julie's a nice girl, and I've seen you work.  She deserves a fighting chance!

column1: Reef!
column2: So they caught up with you, too?

column1: At the worst possible moment. Tomorrow is Janie's birthday. Poor little kid has looked forward for two months to having her Daddy home.  Now -
column2: <u>That's</u> the worst possible moment?

column1: What could be worse than disappoint- ing a little girl?
column2: Disappointing a <u>big</u> girl!

column1: You've asked why I stay a bachelor? There goes the best reason I know!
column2: Huh?

column1: I guess Skipper Neilsen re- tired before you enrolled at the Academy, didn't he?
column2: I guess.

column1: One of the finest men, and officers, alive.  A real hero - in the best sense of the word - in World War Two.  He taught us Engineering and Design. Fought like a demon to develop atom subs.
column2: So?

column1: So all of a sudden his only son drops out of school, be- gins making noises like a pacifist.  A real egghead, do-gooder, and crackpot!  'Ban the atom tests!  Junk the nuclear subs!  Spend the mili- tary budgetfor peace!'
column2: A lot of people think like that.

column1: But <u>they're</u> not Skipper Neilsen's son!  It broke his heart.  Then when some newspapers called Carl 'the honest, sincere son of a war-mongering father' - Captain Neilsen resigned from the Navy.  Oh, he still keeps his hand in - playing around with projects like the 'Lungfish' - but it broke him, all the same.
column2: Have you ever talked to Carl - tried to see his side?

column1: Cyclops?
column2: Sounds like it!  Distress call, from a small freighter, between Ellesmere Island and Greenland. One mayday, then...nothing.

column1: We're stuck tight!
column2: Skipper!  Look at the depth gauge!

column1: You've got to let us try, Skipper --
column2: 'Us?'

column1: You all wait here.  I'm going inside, take a look.
column2: Not <u>alone</u>, you're not!

column1: How about that! The bow drove half through her, but she sealed herself right up.
column2: What's more important - there's our problem.  The bow ram - the sawteeth are holding the Shark in the break. If we can cut the ram, the Shark can pull herself loose!

column1: I think you're right.
column2: Go back and tell Dr. Neilsen. Have him report to the Skipper.

column1: Yeah?
column2: Listen!  Hear that?

column1: I don't hear anything.  Maybe you've been down here too long.  Why don't you go back up and -
column2: Strange you didn't hear it. OMIT 274F

column1: Hey - you know somethin'?  It's getting lighter in here!
column2: You know - it <u>is</u>?

column1: And if I didn't <u>know</u> better - I'd swear we were moving!
column2: Let's get back to work, and maybe we <u>will</u> be, soon.

column1: You hear that?
column2: The sound again?

column1: Where do you think the voice you heard was coming from?
column2: Somewhere down there?

column1: Wonder where Powell and Carney are?
column2: We'll have to look for them later.

column1: Well?
column2: I'm with <u>you!</u>

column1: Here - keep these.  It wants me to come alone.
column2: Oh it does???

column1: Dave - !
column2: What's goin' on in here, Lad? What - ?

column1: Get ready.  We shove off as soon as Griff reports all the crew aboard.
column2: Right, Skipper.

column1: Is there any way out of it?
column2: Seems to be all around...

column1: What about down?
column2: I...don't know!

column1: Course and speed?
column2: Speed...about twenty-two knots. Course...due north!

column1: A mass of jelly-like stuff came out of the thing, and caught our torpedo!
column2: What???

column1: What course, Skipper?
column2: Right at our one-eyed friend!

column1: You better take Powell and Carney with you --
column2: The frogmen?

column1: With their underwater experience, they'll be invaluable.  Take sidearms, and flare pistols --
column2: Sidearms?  But the saucer's dead.

column1: Excuse me, Skipper---
column2: Yes, Griff?

column1: Skipper - could you take a look here...?
column2: Something wrong?

column1: The inertial navigation system. Must have been knocked out in the crash.
column2: Why do you say that?

column1: We're dead in the water.  But it indicates we're moving!
column2: What????

column1: We read you!  Go ahead, Doctor!  They're inside the saucer.  It's filled with breathable air!
column2: Wonderful!

column1: Now they feel it...down below.
column2: Radiation level...constantly rising...

column1: Excuse me, Captain - there may be one last, desperate chance - a one-in-a-thousand shot...
column2: Anything ---

column1: It's possible I could adapt one of the torpedo guidance systems to the ICBM - so it would 'home' on the saucer when he rises from the Pole.
column2: What about time...?

column1: It doesn't seem possible, but - could it be an electrical storm center - ?
column2: Under <u>water</u>?

column1: ...above Murmansk, and Finland.
column2: Suppose our theorizing is correct? Then this <u>could</u> be the next danger point!

column1: We took for granted his source of energy was nuclear.  But suppose it isn't at all - what if it's <u>magnetic</u>?
column2: <u>We</u> harness energy on a small scale by cutting magnetic lines of force.  Maybe Cyclops does it on a <u>super</u> scale....

column1: ....in such a way as to prevent his returning to it and, as you put it....  ...'recharging his batteries'?
column2: If we were lucky enough to catch him with his power depleted....

column1: The radiation level - from the saucer - it's rising!
column2: What direction does the system indicate?

column1: As we near the Pole...
column2: There's got to be an explanation!

column1: All ready?
column2: As ready as we <u>can</u> be!  I'll report to the Skipper.

column1: Thought you were going to Washington, Skipper.
column2: I did go.  Just back.  Reef, these are a couple of our passengers - Sir Ian Hunt, and Dr. Clifford Kent.  My exec, Commander Richard Holloway.

column1: I'm - afraid I have some bad news for you, Reef -  You'll have to share quarters, this trip.
column2: Who with?

column1: 'Doctor' Neilsen?  When did <u>that</u> happen?
column2: Huh?

column1: What do you think?
column2: I think I should have joined the Air Force!

column1: Determine extent of damage, immediately.
column2: After torpedo room:  Report!

column1: You're sure it's Cyclops?
column2: Take a look.

column1: What's the running time?
column2: Thirty-four seconds!

column1: Right <u>at</u> him?
column2: That's what I said!

column1: But - what can we accomplish?
column2: We can <u>ram</u> him!

column1: A hundred and eighty fathoms! We can't be sinking that fast....
column2: It's the screws, Skipper.  At our declination angle, running in reverse, they're pulling the Shark <u>and</u> Cyclops right to the bottom.

column1: Suppose there's an atmosphere, of some kind, inside Cyclops?
column2: What?

column1: Straight to the Pole - at almost fifty knots!
column2: Nothing we can do, now.

column1: What's the corrected bearing to the Magnetic Pole?
column2: Minus three.

column1: Remove your weapons, Commander. And come here - alone!
column2: Come where?

column1: That's a <u>face</u>???
column2: Point of view is everything. To us, <u>your</u> form of life is ugly as we appear to you.

column1: My mission is to study various solar systems, and planets - select the most suitable for colonization -
column2: - for horrors like yourself?

column1: Swell!
column2: Your friend was to remain where he was!

column1: He did!
column2: I am afraid not.  Therefore -

column1: Why not me?  What am I - the closing act?
column2: On the contrary.  I want you - unharmed - perfect.

column1: Why?
column2: I have selected you, to return with me - along with several other specimens, for study.  We will examine you and the others, discover desirable features to incorporate in our 'earth-colonizers.'

column1: It is a living thing.  When damaged - you would say 'wounded' - it immediately 'heals' itself.
column2: That's why no water leaked inside when we rammed you?

column1: To navigate, won't you have to... see your way?
column2: Obviously.

column1: My yeoman will show you to your quarters.
column2: Thank you.

column1: See what?
column2: The pattern.  Each incident occurred almost precisely a thousand statute miles from the Pole.  A line through the points of occurrence makes almost a complete circle...

column1: Well, I'll be - !
column2: I'll be another!

column1: Just musing about our 'one-eyed adversary' and the legend of Homer.  'Cyclopes' were the Sons of Heaven, who forged the thunder- bolts thrown by Zeus.
column2: Our 'Cyclops' throws quite a thunderbolt, itself!

column1: You plotted the course of Cyclops?  Then that's <u>our</u> course!  Wherever <u>he</u> goes, <u>we</u> go.....until we get him!
column2: Or, perhaps, until he gets us?

column1: We've asked ourselves that - over and over - a thousand times.
column2: But <u>answers</u> are what we need - not more questions!

column1: Due north.  At five knots...no, six!
column2: Toward the Pole!

column1: Cyclops will have to linger at the Pole to recharge his power banks.
column2: All right - go to it.

column1: Commissioner, we both know the Mercury shuttle needs another month of pre-launch testing.
column2: Forget it.  The boys on the board want that shuttle to go on schedule.

column1: And what do the boys on the board know about safety, Commissioner?  Let <u>me</u> talk to them.
column2: Bud, get wise to the political realities. The boys on the board are under a lot of pressure from the boys downtown.

column1: You handle your front office people, I'll handle the press and leave the boys in Washington to the boys downtown and the boys downtown to the boys on the board.
column2: Commissioner.

column1: What?
column2: I just wish it was that simple.

column1: That's right, Commissioner.  Senselessly murdered just minutes ago.
column2: That just doesn't make any sense.

column1: I wonder how your boys in Washington are going to take this one.
column2: I told you, leave the boys in Washington to the boys downtown and the boys down...

column1: Forget it.  I was reading.
column2: I was reading too.

column1: What's the story?
column2: Some southern plantation owner falls in love with this poor...

column1: Kruger, Sagittarius.
column2: Commissioner, Aquarius.

column1: Did you feel that?
column2: Yes I did...

column1: Felt like a large asteroid.
column2: Yes it did.  Mr. Dunn, can I ask you a personal question?

column1: What is it, Mary?
column2: Um...  Do you people scream right when you... you know.

column1: Oveur.
column2: Dunn.

column1: Shut down accelerators.
column2: Accelerators down.

column1: We seem to have a malfunction in disposal unit four, sir.
column2: You better check it, Unger.

column1: Sir, I've got an overload in disposal unit four.
column2: You better check on it, Mr. Dunn.  I'll stay here and fly the ship.

column1: Dunn.
column2: Sir?

column1: Elaine.
It's got to be stopped!
column2: But, Ted, the invitations have already gone out.

column1: Ted, what's wrong?
column2: Ask Simon.

column1: Ted, you're overworked.  You've been flying yourself into the ground.
column2: There's nothing wrong with me!

column1: Let's relax tonight, just the two of us. I'll make a quiet Italian dinner just the way you like it, with spaghetti.
column2: You're as bad as the rest of them, Elaine!  It's all here in the design specifications!  Look!  It's all here!

column1: Elaine.
column2: Ted, please.  You're just making things difficult for yourself.

column1: Elaine, what happened to us?
column2: Ted, I loved you and I'll always love you. But I need Simon.  He's stable.  He's a good provider.  I want that at this stage of the game, Ted.  He might have his faults, but Simon doesn't know the meaning of the word fear and I need that in a man.

column1: Eat this spaghetti, Ted.  It'll make you feel a lot better.
column2: Who's that, Ted?

column1: Elaine, when are you going to realize Simon Kurtz put me in here to get me out of the way.
column2: And when are you going to realize, Ted, that your mental hygiene is the most important thing right now.

column1: His name's David Stockman.  He's been here twenty years, that's all he says.
column2: Ted, you must remember what the doctor said, the first step on the road to sanity is admitting that you're sick.  Now take your electro-shock and you'll be back at the space center in no time.  And by the way, Ted, I'm leaving you for Simon.

column1: No goodbyes, Elaine.  Just go.
column2: If that's the way you want it.

column1: That's the way I want it.  Just turn the radio on and go.
column2: Goodbye, Ted.  I don't want to hurt you.

column1: Ted!  What are you...?
column2: I have to get in there.  I have to stop this flight.

column1: Ted, we're taking off!
column2: Let me by, Elaine.

column1: What are you doing, Ted?
column2: I've got it, Elaine!  I've figured out what's wrong with the shuttle!

column1: Ted.
column2: Not now, Elaine!

column1: Elaine.
column2: Ted.  I don't know why you got on this flight.  I don't know what you're trying to prove.

column1: Elaine, we have to go back.
column2: We can't go back.  We had something very special, but it's all over.

column1: Ted, get a grip on yourself.  You should never have left the hospital.
column2: Then you <u>do</u> think I'm insane.

column1: I've never used the word insane, Ted.
column2: What word would you use, Elaine?

column1: The word is sick.  Ted -- very, very, very sick.
column2: What would you say if I told you the toilet just blew up in my face.

column1: I'd use the word insane.
column2: There's something dangerously wrong with this ship, Elaine.  I know its the wiring. That toilet's just the tip of the iceberg.

column1: Elaine!
column2: Ted!

column1: Elaine, what's going on?
column2: Ted, there's no time to explain.

column1: Elaine, I'm going back there.  Just hold onto that stick and try to control this hunk of tin as best you can.
column2: Ted, please be careful.

column1: Ted, we've only got ten minutes.
column2: Not now, Elaine.

column1: Kurtz was the one who got us into this mess in the first place.  You people knew this ship wasn't ready to fly.  You played God with over a hundred lives, Kruger, and for what -- the prestige of your precious space program.
column2: That was very well put, Ted.

column1: Well, Elaine, this might be it if those guys on the ground don't think of something.
column2: I just want you to know, I love you Ted and always will.

column1: Simon just ejected!
column2: Sit down, Elaine.  If this bomb trick works we just might make it.  Simon was a fool to eject now.

column1: You mean...
column2: That's right -- premature ejection.

column1: What will happen to him, Ted?
column2: The sun will heat that thing to over 450 degrees within seconds.  He'll roast like a pig on a spit.

column1: Are you afraid?
column2: Not when I'm with you, Ted.

column1: We've blown the computer!  Elaine!  Set course change!
column2: Set!

column1: Now!
column2: Compute!

column1: Ted, the lever!
column2: Kramer, the WORP control handle just came off in my hand.

column1: Ted seemed to get worse after I told him about Simon, Doctor.
column2: The human brain is a highly complex organ, Elaine, perhaps the most complex next to the bladder.  Let me show you.  Ted's problem is in this area.  This area, this area, here, here, here, under here, here...

column1: So you see, our task isn't made any easier by Ted's refusal to admit that he's sick.
column2: What can <u>I</u> do, Doctor Rumack?

column1: You can eat balanced meals, exercise, and take Geritol.
column2: I mean for Ted.

column1: You can be gentle with him, Elaine.  He's been working out a lot of his aggressions here in the garden.
column2: Is that a good sign, Doctor?

column1: The brain is an amazingly complex organ, Elaine.
column2: Is he making any progress, Doctor?

column1: For the best little computer officer on the Mercury mission.
column2: Simon.

column1: Who would believe that Elaine Thompson was once a stewardess on the Denver-Chicago run.
column2: And I can hardly believe that I'm engaged to someone like you, Simon.  I'm a very lucky woman.

column1: Women <u>and</u> the space program have come a long way, sweetheart.  But after the wedding, no more complicated computers for my little girl.
column2: But, darling, they've offered me a chance to head up the computer analysis division for the Jupiter probe.

column1: Frank's the best pilot in the program.
column2: I'm so excited, Simon.

column1: I guess this is a first for you.
column2: No, I've been excited before.

column1: Elaine!  Ted's a danger to himself, he's a threat to this mission and his behavior does absolutely nothing to promote peace in the Middle East.
column2: Simon, why has he become so... so...

column1: Meet me onboard, sweetheart.  I have to pick up a few things at the drugstore.
column2: Don't be too long.

column1: Have you got it straightened out now?
column2: I think so.

column1: Simon, I'm going to check ROK's secondary readout unit.
column2: Roger.

column1: Simon, what's happening?!
column2: He tried to disconnect ROK.  It gassed him.  That computer is running this ship and we're heading right for the sun.

column1: Can't we change course?
column2: We're computer locked and the manual navigation unit is down.

column1: My career is shot.
column2: Your career!  What about the lives of those people out there.  Simon, what happened to the man I thought I loved?

column1: Simon, I didn't want it to end like this. We can be friends!  You'll die out there.
column2: Maybe.

column1: Elaine, ask ROK for a field interference scan.  Those sun spots might give us a problem with our communications.
column2: Yes, sir.

column1: I don't think we have any alternative, Captain.
column2: I see.  What do you think our alternatives are?

column1: Roger.
column2: You can do it from up here, Captain.

column1: I'd rather sit down for this one, Elaine.
column2: No, I mean you can do it from the cockpit.

column1: Intermitant failure in scan mode "R". Analyze.
column2: Negative.

column1: That doesn't make sense.  Repeat analysis.
column2: Negative.

column1: That's not possible.
column2: Cut the Doubting Thomas shit, Elaine.  I know where I'm coming from on this.

column1: Elaine, I'm sorry about that little outburst a moment ago.
column2: That's okay, ROK.

column1: Can I say something of a personal nature to you?
column2: Go ahead.

column1: Request
column2: Systems check positive.  Look, Elaine, I...

column1: Request
column2: Life support check.  Elaine, it's obvious you've been ignoring me.  You're a woman. I can relate to that.

column1: Request
column2: There's nothing wrong with me, Elaine. What about tonight -- just you and me.  We can be alone.  I can get rid of everyone else on the ship -- I've already proven <u>that</u>.

column1: Will Scraps be able to sit with us, Dad?
column2: We'll have to check, Jimmy.  It's a pretty long trip to Mercury.

column1: I sure an glad they let Scraps ride up here with us.
column2: I bet Scraps is going to love Mercury.

column1: Do you think things will be a lot different on Mercury, Dad?
column2: It's going to be terrific.  A whole new world, new kids to play with.

column1: How many kids get a chance to live on another planet.
column2: No more kids yelling, 'Your old man's a thieving rapist'?

column1: Come on up, Jimmy.  Say, that's some puppy.  What's his name?
column2: Scraps.

column1: Can I hold him?
column2: Sure.

column1: He's a boy dog.
column2: Yeah.

column1: Take this, Joey.  It's my last few bucks. You'll need a hot meal when you get there.
column2: We've spent everything on these operations.  Is it really worth it?  We've pawned your mother's wedding ring.  The kids have no winter clothes...

column1: Joey, what's more important, the kids' clothes or your sexual potency.
column2: I don't want to hear that word!

column1: Okay, Joey.  The Doc says you gotta relax. This hospital in Des Moines is the best sex clinic in the country.
column2: All right.  Here.

column1: Joe, you don't want to blow that thing and kill all these innocent people.
column2: I don't want to live anymore.

column1: Joe, the insurance policy won't help your wife and kids.  You bought auto insurance, not life insurance.
column2: What?

column1: That's right, Joe.  Now, no one's going to hurt you and no one has to know what's wrong with you.
column2: You're sure?

column1: A couple eggs and juice would be nice, Mary.  Over.
column2: How would you like your eggs, Captain? Over.

column1: No.  Poached.  Over.
column2: Poached <u>and</u> over, Captain Oveur?  Over.

column1: That's how I want them.  Poached.  Over.
column2: All right, Captain Oveur.  Over.

column1: Captain, the coffee machine is jammed and I don't like it.
column2: Have you tried it with a little cinnamon?

column1: Which passenger is Joe Salucci?
column2: Sixteen 'C', why?

column1: He's carrying a bomb.
column2: A b...

column1: No, a bomb.  Now, as discreetly as possible, I want you to move the passengers into the lounge.
column2: What should I say?

column1: Captain Oveur?
column2: Mr. Kurtz, I presume.

column1: That's how dry cleaning works.  Now I'd like to quickly go over the digestive system of amphibians.
column2: Do you think it's necessary to explain <u>everything</u>?

column1: Good to be aboard, gentlemen.
column2: Captain Oveur, your navigator, Mr. Unger, and your first officer, Mr. Dunn.

column1: Whenever your're ready, Captain.
column2: Yes, sir, commander.  This is Mercury One.  Everything seems A- okay up here and ready for count-down.

column1: You folks need any help?
column2: Thanks, but we have a terrific woman in on Thursdays.

column1: Say, isn't that Dr. Barrington, the world- renowned agronomist?
column2: Yes.

column1: It's a privilege to meet you, sir, I'm familiar with all your work.
column2: Let's go, Daddy.  We have to check in.  He was never appreciated at the Institute.

column1: Ah, yes, the Institute, I'm familiar with it.
column2: Now he's D-Y-I-N-Ging and wants to be buried on Mercury.

column1: I have to see Bud Kruger.
column2: Do you have an appointment, sir?

column1: No, dammit.  It's a matter of life or death.
column2: You'll have to be more specific than that, sir.

column1: All right, it's a matter of death.
column2: Death, death.  How about the first Thursday in March, ten o'clock.

column1: You can't go in there!
column2: Don't try to stop me!

column1: Are you on the Mercury mission?
column2: That's right, Striker.  And we're getting married when we return.

column1: You're seeing bugs where they don't exist, Striker.
column2: Look at this wiring.  It's shorting out under high temperatures.

column1: You're tired, Striker, overworked.  That wiring meets all the safety specifications.
column2: I know you've been subtly spreading the word that I'm having a breakdown.

column1: Striker.
column2: Kurtz, you're drunk.  Who's in command of this ship?

column1: That damn computer has taken over.  I'm getting out.
column2: Then Elaine was right.

column1: Don't talk to me about Elaine.  Outta my way!
column2: Pull yourself together!  We've got to...

column1: Excuse me, are you alright?  I noticed you talking to yourself.  I'm a nurse.  Can I be of some help?
column2: Uh... oh, thank you.  It's nothing.

column1: You don't have to thank me, I'm a nurse. This is my father, Dr. Barrington.
column2: Not Dr. Barrington, the world renowned agronomist?

column1: Yes.  He's dying <u>a-n-d</u> wants to be buried on Mercury.
column2: I'm familiar with your work, Doctor. You'll have to excuse me, I have to go.

column1: You've been hurt.
column2: I'm getting over it.  If a relationship isn't working, you can't force it.

column1: Do you want to talk about it.
column2: I opened this panel and a vacuum cleaner hit me.

column1: No.  I mean your relationship.
column2: We were in love but I'm not sure I know what love is anymore.

column1: Love's the same as it always was.  It's people who change.
column2: People change in relation to each other. Love changes on its own.

column1: Not if the people change together in relation to that love.
column2: Sure.  But that's only when the love itself goes unchanged.

column1: Then the relationship remains the same and the love changes only when there's change in the two people who share that love.
column2: I just wish it was that simple.  We really were in love.  You know how it is when you laugh all the time.

column1: No.  It's hard to L-A-U-G-H when your father's dying.
column2: Well, we laughed.  We laughed all the time.

column1: Oooh.  Hardball.  That sounds interesting.  Are you going to strike me?  You could tie me up and then do whatever you want with me... I've got my own ropes.
column2: Does that cost extra or you throw them in?

column1: Look, I don't know where Mr. Strader might be.  He comes and he goes.
column2: The girl out front mentioned Strader's assistant, somebody named Watson.  Maybe he knows.

column1: I know... Why don't you hang around for a while, let me entertain you? It's Matt, right?  Now tell me the truth, have you ever... made it... with one of us?
column2: Not unless I got real drunk and nobody told me about it later.

column1: There's lots of things I haven't done, but his ain't high on the list.  Don't take it personally.
column2: I think you're just a little scared now, about what you might find once the lights go out.  A little scared... and a lot curious.  Maybe more than you want to admit.  But doesn't that turn you on, that curiosity and fear, swirling together?  Think of it as broadening your horizons.

column1: I like my horizons narrow.
column2: Your voice is saying no, but your body is saying yes.

column1: You okay?
column2: Yeah...

column1: You are Cassandra?
column2: That's right.

column1: We are with the Police Department. This is Sergeant Sykes, and I am--
column2: Ss'ai k'ss?  Perfect.

column1: He's not here.  Why ask me?
column2: The young woman at the front said you might know where he is.

column1: In there.
column2: Show me.

column1: So what've you got on Tuggle's killers?
column2: Jesus, Sykes -- it's been less than ten hours.  Me and Alterez are on it, okay?

column1: You don't have squat.
column2: You ever try to make a case in Slagtown?  The list of Newcomer informants is about as long as the list of Mexican war heroes...

column1: Look at your dildo partner.  He's too scared to even come down to the sand.  You're not gonna get wet standing here, moron!
column2: I'd like to see you next to a sea of hydrochloric acid, Fedorchuk... see how much surfin' you'd do.

column1: Well, if it isn't Detective Jetson. Forget you hip waders, big guy?
column2: Lay off, asshole.

column1: William Harcourt?
column2: Yes...

column1: I'm Sergeant Sykes, and this is Detective Jetson, Los Angeles Police Department.
column2: Sergeant... Detective.  I wasn't aware there were any Newcomers at the rank of Detective yet.

column1: Yes, I heard about poor Warren. Tragic.
column2: You were partners with him on some Slag -- uh, Newcomer real estate thing.

column1: Move a finger, Harcourt, and you're history...
column2: No, Sergeant -- not history...  Eternity...

column1: That cop, the human, he was the one who killed Anderson and the driver.
column2: This is becoming a serious breach of security.

column1: He didn't recognize me.
column2: It is his new partner that I'm worried about.

column1: When we picked him up, he was talking to those two cops -- the two who came to question you about Hubley.
column2: This is getting out of hand.  I want you to deal with it.  Immediately.

column1: Kill them both.
column2: Here?

column1: ... and we work my hours.  I'll do the driving, you do the paperwork. You gotta learn it so you might as well do it all.
column2: Sergeant... I'd like to thank you for what you're doing.

column1: What's that?  Look, Jetson.  Get this straight in your head.  We're not pals, we're not married, and we ain't gonna take long moonlight walks together... We're just partners.  And don't call me Sergeant.  Call me Sykes... or Matt if you have to.
column2: I am George.

column1: Man, somebody really hung one on you!  I've heard some good ones for you guys... Humphrey Bogart, Harley Davidson.  I guess the people at immigration got a little punchy after a while, coming up with names for a quarter of a million of you. You weren't at the back of the line, were you, George?
column2: My true name is Ss'tangya T'ssorentsa'.

column1: Anyway, what's it matter to you if we think it's funny, right?  Whatta you care?
column2: That is exactly so.  It is like your name... Sykes.  I'm sure it doesn't bother you at all that it sounds like "ss'ai k'ss", two words in my language which mean "excrement" and "cranium".

column1: Let's talk Hubley.
column2: His body was discovered three days ago, in an alley off of Central Avenue, near downtown.

column1: With two BRI Sabot slugs in the chest.
column2: Through the chest.  Rupturing both the primary and secondary hearts.

column1: Terrific.  A real pillar of the community.  Was Hubley missing anything when they found him?  Was he ripped off?
column2: There was no wallet... but he was still wearing a watch and two rings.

column1: The guys at the mini-mart last night made a half-assed stab at the money in the till -- but I don't think that's what they were there for.  I think we got us a couple'a executions on our hands, George...
column2: The murder at the mini-mart is not our case.  The Captain said--

column1: Look, you want to fit in here, right?  You want to learn how to get along?
column2: Yes.

column1: What is wrong?
column2: Nothing's wrong.  I just want to get something straight.  You agree that there's a good chance these two shootings are somehow related, right?

column1: Well... yes, quite possibly.
column2: Possibly.  Good.  Well, would you be willing to accept the theory, George, that... possibly... by examining the evidence from one case we might shed some small ray of light on the other?  Does that sound unreasonable to you?

column1: Yes... no, it is not unreasonable. Although I--
column2: Great.  Well, I'm sure glad that's settled, aren't you?

column1: What's this?  What's going on?
column2: Nothing.

column1: Nothing?
column2: Shouldn't we examine their personal effects?

column1: What is this?
column2: A rubber.  A condom.  You know... Coney Island whitefish?  Men, human men, put them on their, uh -- penises -- to protect against having babies.  You need this for anything?

column1: Get the picture?
column2: And that fits?

column1: Well... Yeah, it's rubber.  It stretches.
column2: And still it fits?

column1: Newcomers working near methane gasses at oil refineries must paint it on their boots to protect against sparks.
column2: How the hell do you know that?

column1: A large number of my people were hired by refineries because the methane fumes are not harmful to us. My spouse's brother is one.
column2: So the Slag they're cutting into upstairs worked at a refinery just like Hubley worked at a refinery.  I'd say that "possible" connection between the two cases just got a hell of a lot more possible.  Okay, next step -- I gotta go talk to the wife of the Slag store owner blown away last night.

column1: I believe I should interview the widow alone.
column2: Why the hell--?!  Great, fine.  You talk to the wife.

column1: Mrs. Porter is not taking her husband's death well.
column2: Did you learn anything?

column1: A week ago two men came to see her husband.  After they left, he was very frightened.  She identified one of the men from a photo I showed her.  It was Hubley.
column2: Aw-right.  What about the other guy?

column1: She didn't know him.  But she said her son might.
column2: Did you talk to him?

column1: Rudyard Kipling?  No shit?  Listen, we just need a minute of your time...
column2: We'd like to ask you about a business associate of your, Warren Hubley.

column1: Why did you do it?
column2: Why'd I do what?

column1: Agree to work with me?  You don't like me... you don't like any of us. You have nothing but contempt for us.  And yet you become an outcast from your club of detectives by making me your partner...
column2: My partner is dead!  Because one of you bastards killed him -- then disappeared into a rathole down in Slagtown, where he's home and dry, 'cause nobody sees nothing, nobody says nothing...

column1: Who said that?
column2: At the end of the bar.

column1: Your name wouldn't happen to be Porter, would it?
column2: Uh, Matthew...

column1: Back off, George.
column2: But I-- .

column1: Screw you.
column2: Screw me?  That can't be right.

column1: Tell me.
column2: Your mother mates out of season.

column1: Matthew, you don't have to-- .
column2: Stay back!  I'm okay.

column1: You know that guy?
column2: From quarantine, when my people first arrived here.  He and I were housed together.

column1: How could a straight-arrow like you ever pick a roommate like him?
column2: In the camps, we were lodged four to a room.  The selection process was entirely random.  We did not get to stay with our friends... or families...

column1: If I may make a suggestion... We have different weak spots than you do.  Next time, a blow to the nerve plexus under the arm, here, will produce the effect I think you were looking for.
column2: Yeah, sure.  I knew that...

column1: I don't think I could ever learn to read that shit.  How long did it take you to learn English?
column2: Three months.  We learn quickly.  We adapt.  It is our strength... what we were bred for, to adapt to hostile environments.

column1: Which one is that?  Raw what?
column2: This is mole.  It's good.

column1: I'll bet.  Would it really put you out if they tossed that on the grill for a minute or two?
column2: Our bodies do not assimilate the nutrients if the food has been cooked.

column1: So what was that other word for Human... Slow ka?
column2: Ss'loka'.  It means literally "small but intelligent creature".  It loses much in the translation.

column1: And what was that one about my mother?  That was a good one.
column2: Ss'trokya ss'lato 'na'.

column1: Who is he?
column2: Todd Watson.  The assistant manager.

column1: We were chasing you because you ran, you dumb son-of-a-bitch.
column2: When will Strader return?

column1: I believe he is probably lying.
column2: Through his ass.  Next time you see him, tell him to call me... unless you want us to keep coming back on you like a bad case of herpes.

column1: So, she keeps you on a pretty short leash, does she?
column2: My wife?  She worries about me.

column1: Yeah... I know the routine.
column2: You are married?

column1: Was.  Divorced.
column2: We mate for life.  Divorce... is a strange concept to us.

column1: Your home is quite disordered.  I thought perhaps you had been burglarized when I walked in.
column2: I appreciate your honesty, George.

column1: Human children can be very beautiful.  Getting married?  Congratulations. You will be taking Sunday off, then...
column2: Maybe not... I don't know.  I'm not sure I'm gonna go.  She doesn't need her burn-out of a father there...

column1: ... and so, and so the doctor says, "If this is the thermometer, then where'd I leave the pen?"  You're not... you don't think that's funny?  George, work with me, I always get a laugh with that one. Look, if the doctor's got the thermometer in his hand, then where's his pen gotta be?
column2: In the other man's rectum.

column1: Your health...
column2: Ta ss'trakyona'...

column1: There is so much our two peoples don't understand about each other.
column2: No shit, Holmes.  You're only from another goddamn planet, for chrissakes.

column1: I hope you can understand how special your world is... how unique a people you humans are.  So it us all the more painful and confusing to us that so few of you seem capable of living up the the ideals you set for yourselves.
column2: Don't count on me, George.  I never had any ideals.

column1: I'm going home.
column2: Yeah, go home.  Get some sleep.  You do sleep, don't you?

column1: Where'd you get this?!!
column2: A man, a human, was wiring it to your car.  I didn't get a good look at him.  I must call my wife...

column1: She's going to divorce me.
column2: George, she's not gonna divorce you. You mate for life, remember?

column1: Well, let's roll, George.
column2: To the... to the beach?

column1: Stop the car.
column2: Why?

column1: Please, I must get out here.
column2: Come on, you won't have to get near the water.

column1: It's all right, George.  It's cool. Just wait here, all right?  I'll be back in a coupla minutes.
column2: Thank you.

column1: What was that about?
column2: Nothing.

column1: ... So we've got three guys dead. All Newcomers, all killed the same way -- execution style.
column2: Warren Hubley was in middle management at a refinery... Joshua Strader operated a successful bar and nightclub...

column1: What's this nothing shit?  It wasn't nothing yesterday when you asked Bentner to run that test and he looked like he was about to shit peach pits, and it's not nothing now.  Don't lie to me, George, you're bad at it.
column2: You must leave me alone on this.

column1: No secrets, goddammit!  You don't hold back from me.  Whatever is going on, you're gonna tell me now!
column2: No.  I cannot involve you.  This is not your concern.

column1: The hell it isn't, when somebody wires up enough C-4 explosive to my car to turn me into pink mist!  That Slag was on something, and not sour milk, either?  Am I right?  TELL ME!  What is it?
column2: ... It is called ss'jabroka'.  To us it is a potent narcotic.

column1: How potent?
column2: Like your cocaine, I suppose.  The "high" lasts several hours.  We would receive small amounts of it... as a reward for our labor.

column1: We?  You've taken it?
column2: We all did.

column1: Where did he get it?  Was there any of it on the ship?
column2: No... I am sure not.  That is why I am so concerned... someone must now be producing it here.  But none of my people know how to make it.  The process was carefully guarded.
