column1: Jesus, this is major.  Why didn't you tell me sooner? Why'd you hold out on me?
column2: Your people don't know about this part of out past.  And they can't know -- It would threaten our entire existence here.

column1: George... look me in the eye... George, you don't ever lie to me again.
column2: I must trust you, Matthew.  I cannot stop this without you.

column1: They had months in quarantine to develop the plan.  Porter, with his chemistry background, must have somehow come up with the formula for the drug.  Hubley manufactured it -- at the refinery.  Strader, through the nightclub, established a distribution network.  And Harcourt--
column2: Harcourt was the brain who brought it all together.

column1: Okay, George -- we gotta play this real smart.
column2: If the drug is here, we must destroy it.

column1: Uh, George...
column2: Where is the drug?  Where have they taken it?

column1: George, uh... you're gonna break his little chest bones...
column2: Stay out of this, Matthew.  Tell me where the drug has been taken or I will crush your lungs against this wall.

column1: George, c'mon -- lighten up.  It's a beauty of a case.  Don't sweat it -- we got him by the short hairs. He ain't gonna make any more of the shit.
column2: The fifty kilos, Matthew.  I have to find it.  I can't let it get out on the street.
Fuck procedure.

column1: Shit!
column2: Ss-ai!

column1: With Harcourt and Kipling dead, I assume you will be requesting reassignment now.
column2: It'd be for your own good.  I think you'd be better off with a partner who's a little more... by the book.  ... Still, I gotta tell you, George, for a quiet guy, you're sure hell on wheels once you get going.  I'd kinda hate to miss your next two days as a detective.

column1: What's this about, George?  I know that look.
column2: There!  Go back.  Down that side street.

column1: No!  We must do this alone.
column2: Do what?!  George-- ?!

column1: What is this?!
column2: ... It's Harcourt.

column1: Harcourt is dead.
column2: No he's not.  Not if he overdosed on the drug.  Massive amounts trigger a... a change.  Your body functions seize up, you appear to be dead, but it's really a state of incubation.  When you emerge you're...

column1: I never thought I'd say this, but -- for once in my life I think I'm willing to wait for back-up.
column2: We can't let him get away.

column1: Why the hell are you so dead set against back-up?
column2: Because... because of what will happen if humans see what we are capable of becoming.

column1: But there's no more drug.
column2: You understand that.  But how many others will?

column1: How do I look?
column2: You look very good.

column1: You said you wanted the biggest thing I could find... Well, this is it.
column2: What is it?

column1: Casull .454 Magnum.  You're talking twice the impact energy of .44 Magnum hot loads.
column2: Only holds five.

column1: Yeah, the shells are too big for six in an cylinder.  Hell, Matt, you don't need but one.
column2: No... two.

column1: Mr. Hubley was an all right guy -- and a damn good manager.  The men liked him.  I'm really gonna have to scramble to fill his shoes.
column2: Well, one of the men didn't like him so much...

column1: You think this is the guy who did it?
column2: We think he could'a been involved, yeah.  You know him?

column1: To be honest, it's hard to say.  I hate to admit it but -- they all still kinda look alike to me.
column2: Who else can I ask around here?

column1: Wait.  You know who it looks like? Yeah.  Anderson.  Uh... James Anderson.  He isn't in today.  He took the afternoon off.
column2: I think you're gonna find he's taken the rest of his life off.

column1: That where Anderson worked?
column2: Yes it is.  Thirty-five percent pure Methane gas in there.  I don't know how these fellas do it.

column1: Don't piss him off, O'Neal.  When he gets like this, I can't control him. I've seen this before.  He got like this once -- I saw him jerk a guy's spine out and show it to him. Nothing I could do.  I hadda go throw up.
column2: ... They took the stuff out, all of it -- this afternoon.

column1: Here's Hubley.  Left Quarantine on November thirtieth, relocated first to Riverside, then moved to Los Angeles early in February the following year.  Field of expertise: chemical manufacturing.  Looks like he passed up several other better paying jobs waiting for that one at the refinery.
column2: Try Joshua Strader, will ya, darlin'?

column1: Released December one.  He and his wife moved first to Modesto, then Coalinga, California -- wherever that is -- settled in L.A. in April.  Field of expertise: organic chemical engineering.  He and his wife have one child, a son.
column2: Yeah -- we met him.  Wonderful boy... close personal friend of George's here.

column1: Can you dig up their Quarantine records in this thing?
column2: Sure.  Just a minute.

column1: Jesus, are the questions too tough for you already?  Let's try again--  Is your name Porter?
column2: Ss'kya'ta'.

column1: One of the two men was Hubley, right?  What about the other one? Did you know him?
column2: Yeah... I seen him around.  High- roller dude named Strader.  Joshua Strader.  Runs a club on the west side.  Encounters.

column1: Yeah, I heard of it.
column2: That's all I know.  You want anything more, you ask somebody else.

column1: You know I've been over all this with Fedorchuk and Alterez this morning...
column2: Come on.  You got nothin' better to do, cushy county job like yours.

column1: Yeah, right.  Don't push your luck. Anyway, according to the sheet, the guy you nailed outside by the car--
column2: The human?

column1: No I.D. on him and -- well, you know, no fingerprints -- so it could be tough.  Your buddies this morning went through the mug book but couldn't make a facial match.
column2: Fedorchuk couldn't find his ass with his hands in his back pockets.

column1: You took this gut out, too, didn't you?
column2: Yeah.

column1: Lucky for you, you got him in both of his... well, what we loosely refer to as... hearts.
column2: Lucky nothing.  I had to empty my damn gun into him.

column1: Oh, here's an extra headshot if you need one.  We're just about to start cutting in.  You're welcome to stick around if you want.  It's really fascinating stuff.
column2: Yeah, I'll bet.

column1: You guys finished the postmortem on Strader yet?
column2: You mean the Blob?  They're finishing up now.

column1: What kind of test?
column2: Looking for some foreign compound in the blood of that alien you dropped the other day.

column1: Yeah, Sykes?
column2: Captain.  I'd like to volunteer for duty with the new detective.

column1: You are to have nothing to do with the investigation into Bill Tuggle's death.  You know that.  Leave that for Fedorchuk.
column2: Departmental policy.

column1: Granger and Pitts are already on it.
column2: Granger and Pitts have one hell of a caseload... and I would have thought with Jetson here being the first Newcomer plainclothes, and Hubley's body being found over in the Newcomer community...

column1: Hope their plumbing's the same.
column2: It is.

column1: How can I go?
column2: Put on your wash-and-wear suit and your clip-on tie, have your landlady tie your shoes for you, and show up at the church.  Simple.  Me and Carol are going.

column1: What?
column2: Hey, look -- we've known Kristin since... since she was conceived in that cabin up in Big Bear. Remember?  You and Edie banged the wall so hard, me and Carol were picking plaster out of our hair for a week...

column1: Goddammit, Tug -- I want to see Kristin get married, okay?  But--
column2: But you're bummed because your ex and her new husband are paying for the whole thing.

column1: Does that look at all suspicious to you?
column2: Whatever gave you that idea?

column1: You got your vest?
column2: Of course.  Right in the trunk of the car.

column1: Watch the driver.  I'm going for a better angle on the door.
column2: I got him.  Don't get pinned.

column1: Get outta there!
column2: I can't!  Do you mind!

column1: This floor's freezing.
column2: Christ.  I never saw such a buncha old women.  You want me to fetch your slippers, Hudson?

column1: Whoooah!  No shit?  I'm impressed.
column2: Let's go...let's go.  Cycle through!

column1: Hey, 'Top.'  What's the op?
column2: Rescue mission.  There's some juicy colonists' daughters we gotta rescue from virginity.

column1: Movement!
column2: Position?

column1: Can't lock up...
column2: Talk to me, Hudson.

column1: ...that's better.  Pan it around a bit.
column2: Awright.  Fire-team A.  Gear up. Let's move.  Two minutes. Somebody wake up Hicks.

column1: Okay, let's do it.
column2: Awright!  I want a nice clean dispersal this time.

column1: Set down sixty meters this side of the telemetry mast.  Immediate dust off on my 'clear,' then stay on station.
column2: Ten seconds, people.  Look sharp!

column1: First squad up, on line.  Hicks, get yours in a cordon.  Watch the rear.
column2: Vasquez, take point.  Let's move.

column1: Flame-units only.  I want rifles slung.
column2: Let's go.  Pull 'em out.

column1: Uh,...Apone, I want you to lay down a suppressing fire with the incinerators and fall back by squads to the APC, over.
column2: Say again?  All after incinerators?

column1: I've isolated a neuro-muscular toxin responsible for the paralysis.  It seems to be metabolizing.  He should wake up soon.
column2: Now let me get this straight. The aliens paralyzed the colonists, carried them over there, cocooned them to be hosts for more of those...

column1: Which would mean lots of those parasites, right?  One for each person...over a hundred at least.
column2: Yes.  That follows.

column1: But these things come from eggs...so where are all the eggs coming from.
column2: That is the question of the hour.  We could assume a parallel to certain insect forms who have hivelike organization. An ant of termite colony, for example, is ruled by a single female, a queen, which is the source of new eggs.

column1: You're saying one of those things lays all the eggs?
column2: Well, the queen is always physically larger then the others.  A termite queen's abdomen is so bloated with eggs that it can't move at all.  It is fed and tended by drone workers, defended by the warriors.  She is the center of their lives, quite literally the  mother of their society.

column1: Could it be intelligent?
column2: Hard to say.  It may have been blind instinct...attraction to the heat of whatever...but she did choose to incubate her eggs in the one spot where we couldn't destroy her without destroying ourselves.  That's if she exists, of course.

column1: That's it.  See it?  Emergency venting.
column2: How long until it blows?

column1: And it's too late to shut it down?
column2: I'm afraid so.  The crash did too much damage.  The overload is inevitable, at this point.

column1: I'll go.
column2: What?

column1: I'm really the only one qualified to remote-pilot the ship anyway. Believe me, I'd prefer not to.  I may be synthetic but I'm not stupid.
column2: All right.  Let's get on it.  What'll you need?

column1: It's going to be closer.  You better get going.
column2: See you soon.

column1: HOW MUCH TIME?
column2: PLENTY!  TWENTY-SIX MINUTES!

column1: Ripley...
column2: She's alive.  They brought her here and you know it.

column1: You did okay, Bishop.
column2: Well, thanks, I --

column1: Fifty-seven...oh, Christ...
column2: You'd drifted right through the core systems.  It's blind luck that deep-salvage team caught you when they...are you all right?

column1: Have they located my daughter yet?
column2: Well, I was going to wait until after the inquest...

column1: Is she...?
column2: Amanda Ripley-McClaren.  Married name, I guess.  Age:  sixty-six ...at time of death.  Two years ago.  I'm sorry.

column1: Amy.
column2: Cancer.  Hmmmm.  They still haven't licked that one.  Cremated.  Interred Parkside Repository, Little Chute, Wisconsin.  No children.

column1: You read my deposition...it's complete and accurate.
column2: Look, I believe you, but there are going to be some heavyweights in there.  You got Feds, you got interstellar commerce commission, you got colonial administration, insurance company guys...

column1: I get the picture.
column2: Just tell them what happened.  The important thing is to stay cool and unemotional.

column1: You had them eating out of your hand, kiddo.
column2: They had their minds made up before I even went in there. They think I'm a head case.

column1: No.  There's no way!
column2: Hear me out...

column1: What about you?  What's your interest in this?
column2: Well, the corporation co-financed that colony with the Colonial Administration, against mineral rights.  We're getting into a lot of terraforming...'Building Better Worlds.'

column1: Yeah, yeah.  I saw the commercial.
column2: I heard you were working in the cargo docks.

column1: That's right.
column2: Running loaders, forklifts, that sort of thing?

column1: It's all I could get.  Anyway, it keeps my mind off of... everything.  Days off are worse.
column2: What if I said I could get you reinstated as a flight officer? And that the company has agreed to pick up your contract?

column1: If I go.
column2: If you go.  It's a second chance, kiddo.  And it'll be the best thing in the world for you to face this fear and beat it.  You gotta get back on the horse...

column1: Yes, and I've read it.  You wake up every night, sheets soaking, the same nightmare over and over...
column2: No!  The answer is no.  Now please go.  I'm sorry.  Just go, would you.

column1: Yello?  Oh, Ripley.  Hi...
column2: Burke, just tell me one thing. That you're going out there to kill them.  Not study.  Not bring back.  Just burn them out...clean ...forever.

column1: You never said anything about an android being here!  Why not?
column2: Well, it didn't occur to me.  It's been policy for years to have a synthetic on board.

column1: I hope you're right.  I really do.
column2: I suggest you study the disks Ripley has been kind enough to prepare for you.

column1: That the atmosphere processor?
column2: Uh-hunh.  One of thirty or so, all over the planet.  They're completely automated.  We manufacture them, by the way.

column1: They're right under the primary heat exchangers.
column2: Yeah?  Maybe the organisms like the heat, that's why they built...

column1: That's not what I mean.  Gorman, if your men have to use their weapons in there, they'll rupture the cooling system.
column2: She's right.

column1: No good.  How do we know it'll effect their biochemistry?  I say we take off and nuke the entire site from orbit.  It's the only way to be sure.
column2: Now hold on a second.  I'm not authorizing that action.

column1: Well, I mean...I know this is an emotional moment, but let's not make snap judgments.  Let's move cautiously.  First, this physical installation had a substantial dollar value attached to it --
column2: They can bill me.  I got a tab running.  What's second?

column1: This is clearly an important species we're dealing with here. We can't just arbitrarily exterminate them --
column2: Bullshit!

column1: You son of a bitch.
column2: Don't make me pull rank, Ripley.

column1: What rank?  I believe Corporal Hicks has authority here.
column2: Corporal Hicks!?

column1: Those specimens are worth millions to the bio-weapons division.  Now, if you're smart we can both come out of this heroes.  Set up for life.
column2: You just try getting a dangerous organism past ICC quarantine. Section 22350 of the Commerce Code.

column1: You've been doing your homework. Look, they can't impound it if they don't know about it.
column2: But they will know about it, Burke. From me.  Just like they'll know how you were responsible for the deaths of one hundred and fifty-seven colonists here --

column1: Now, wait a second --
column2: You sent them to that ship.  I just checked the colony log... directive dates six-twelve-seventy-nine. Signed Burke, Carter J.

column1: You sent them out there and you didn't even warn them, Burke. Why didn't you warn them?
column2: Look, maybe the thing didn't even exist, right?  And if I'd made it a major security situation, the Administration would've stepped in.  Then no exclusive rights, nothing.

column1: I expected more of you, Ripley. I thought you would be smarter than this.
column2: Sorry to disappoint you.

column1: Look, we don't know what's going on out there.  It may just be a down transmitter.  But if it's not, I want you there...as an advisor.  That's all.
column2: You wouldn't be going in with the troops.  I can guarantee your safety.

column1: These Colonial Marines are some tough hombres, and they're packing state-of-the-art firepower. Nothing they can't handle...right, Lieutenant?
column2: We're trained to deal with these kinds of situations.

column1: Still nothing from the colony?
column2: Dead on all channels.

column1: Looks like you company can write off its share of this colony.
column2: It's insured.

column1: What's he scanning for?
column2: PDT'S.  Personal-Data Transmitters. Every adult colonist had one surgically implanted.

column1: We're talking thermonuclear explosion.
column2: Shit.  Apone, collect magazines from everybody.  We can't have any firing in there.

column1: How may drops is this for you, Lieutenant?
column2: Thirty-eight...simulated.

column1: Hold at forty.  Slow circle of the complex.
column2: The structure seems intact.  They have power.

column1: One of us?
column2: Apone...where are your people? Anybody in D-Block?

column1: Where are your parents?  You have to try...
column2: Gorman!  Give it a rest would you.

column1: What is it?
column2: I don't know.

column1: So.
column2: So...then the fusion containment shuts down.

column1: GET THEM OUT OF THERE!  DO IT NOW!
column2: Shut up.  Just shut up!

column1: I told them to fall back...
column2: They're but off!  Do something!

column1: How do you feel?
column2: All right, I guess.  One hell of a hangover.  Look, Ripley... I...

column1: At ease.  I'm sorry we didn't have time to brief before we left Gateway but...
column2: Sir?

column1: Yes, Hicks?
column2: Hudson, Sir.  He's Hicks.

column1: What's the question?
column2: Is this going to be a stand-up fight, Sir, on another bug-hunt?

column1: Are there any questions?  Hudson?
column2: How do I get out of this chicken-shit outfit?

column1: All right, the area's secured. Let's go in and see what their computer can tell us.  First team head for operations. Hudson, see if you can get their CPU on line.  Hicks, meet me at the south lock by the up-link tower...
column2: ...We're coming in.

column1: Sir, the CPU is on-line.
column2: Okay, stand by in operations.  Let's go.

column1: Hah!  Stop your grinnin' and drop your linen!  Found 'em.
column2: Alive?

column1: We're not making that out too well.  What is it?
column2: You tell me.  I only work here.

column1: Save it.
column2: Sure, Hicks.

column1: Let's get the fuck out of here!
column2: Not that tunnel, the other one!

column1: Well that's great!  That's just fucking great, man.  Now what the fuck are we supposed to do, man? We're in some real pretty shit now!
column2: Are you finished?  You okay?

column1: Outstanding.  Then all we need's a deck of cards.  All right, let's move like we got a purpose.
column2: Aye-firmative.

column1: We got problems.
column2: I don't fucking believe this. Do you believe this?

column1: Maybe we got 'em demoralized.
column2: I want you two walking the perimeter. I know we're all in strung out shape but stay frosty and alert. We've got to stop any entries before they get out of hand.

column1: The corner!  Ready?
column2: Do it!

column1: Seventeen meters.
column2: Let's get these things lit.

column1: Well you're not reading it right!
column2: Six meters.  Five.  What the fu --

column1: Let's go!  Let's go!
column2: Fuckin' A!

column1: Removed surgically before embryo implantation.  Subject:  Marachuk, John L.   Died during procedure.  They killed him getting it off.
column2: Poor bastard.

column1: How long after we're declared overdue can we expect a rescue?
column2: About seventeen days.

column1: All right.  There's a fire door at this end.  The first thing we do is put a remote sentry in the tunnel and seal that door.
column2: We gotta figure on them getting into the complex.

column1: They're in the approach corridor.
column2: On my way.

column1: Now many?
column2: Can't tell.  Lots.  D gun's down to twenty.  Ten.  It's out.

column1: Newt time then can walk right up and knock.
column2: But they don't know that.  They're probably looking for other ways to get in.  That'll take them awhile.

column1: They'll get us.
column2: Maybe.  Maybe not.

column1: Hicks, I'm not going to wind up like those others.  You'll take care of it won't you, it if comes to that?
column2: If it comes to that, I'll do us both.  Let's see that it doesn't Here, I'd like to introduce you to a close personal friend of mine.

column1: What's this?
column2: Well, that's the grenade launcher ...you probably don't want to mess with that.

column1: Look, you started this.  Now show me everything.  I can handle myself.
column2: Yeah.  I've noticed.

column1: Wait a minute.  We'd know about it.
column2: The only way it would work is if he sabotaged certain freezers on the trip back.  Then he could jettison the bodies and make up any story he liked.

column1: You know, Burke, I don't know which species is worse.  You don't see them screwing each other over for a fucking percentage.
column2: Let's waste him.  No offense.

column1: It's game time.
column2: Get back here, both of you.  Fall back to Operations.

column1: They learned.  They cut the power and avoided the guns.  They must have found another way in, something we missed.
column2: We didn't miss anything.

column1: Locked.
column2: Stand back.

column1: No!  No!  She's alive!  We have to --
column2: All right!  She's alive.  I believe it.  But we gotta get moving!  Now!

column1: Hicks, don't let him leave.
column2: We ain't going anywhere.

column1: Ellen.
column2: Don't be long, Ellen.

column1: Hey, Vasquez...you ever been mistaken for a man?
column2: No.  Have you?

column1: Somebody said alien...she thought they said illegal alien and signed up.
column2: Fuck you.

column1: All right, we can't blow the fuck out of them...why not roll some canisters of CN-20 down there. Nerve gas the whole nest?
column2: Look, man, let's just bug out and call it even, okay?

column1: Yeah, bullshit.  Watch us.
column2: Maybe you haven't been keeping up on current events, but we just got out asses kicked, pal!

column1: Oh, man.  And I was gettin' short, too!  Four more weeks and out. Now I'm gonna buy it on this fuckin' rock.  It ain't half fair, man!
column2: Hudson, give us a break.

column1: It's inside the complex.
column2: You're just reading me.

column1: Sounds like you, Hicks.
column2: The embryo, the second form, hosts in the victim's body for several hours.  Gestating.  Then it...  ...then it...emerges.  Moults. Grows rapidly --

column1: Looks like it stung him.
column2: Hey...hey!  Look, Crowe and Dietrich aren't dead, man.

column1: You can't help them.  Right now they're being cocooned just like the others.
column2: Oh, God.  Jesus.  This ain't happening.

column1: Man, we're not going to make it seventeen hours!  Those things are going to come in here, just like they did before, man... they're going to come in here and get us, man, long before...
column2: She survived longer than that with no weapons and no training.

column1: This service tunnel is how they're moving back and forth.
column2: Yeah, right, it runs from the processing station right into the sublevel here.

column1: Thanks.
column2: Uh, what's next?

column1: We need the other drop-ship.  The on one the Sulaco.  We have to bring it down on remote, somehow.
column2: How?  The transmitter was on the APC.  It's wasted.

column1: I don't care how!  Think of a way.  Think of something.
column2: Think of what?  We're fucked.

column1: Well then somebody's just going to have to go out there.  Take a portable terminal and go out there and plug in manually.
column2: Oh, right!  Right!  With those things running around.  No way.

column1: They cut the power.
column2: What do you mean, they cut the power?  How could they cut the power, man?  They're animals.

column1: This signal's weird...must be some interference or something. There's movement all over the place...
column2: Just get back here!

column1: Range twenty meters.
column2: Seal the door.

column1: Fifteen meters.
column2: I don't know, an acid hole in a duct.  Something under the floors, not on the plans. I don't know!

column1: Twelve meters.  Man, this is a big fucking signal.  Ten meters.
column2: They're right on us.  Vasquez, how you doing?

column1: Nine meters.  Eight.
column2: Can't be.  That's inside the room!

column1: You remember you sent some wildcatters out to that plateau, out past the Ilium range, a couple days ago?
column2: Yeah.  What?

column1: There's a guy on the horn, mom-and-pop survey team.  Says he's homing on something and wants to know if his claim will be honored.
column2: Christ.  Some honch in a cushy office on Earth says go look at a grid reference in the middle of nowhere, we look.  They don't say why, and I don't ask.  I don't ask because it takes two weeks to get an answer out here and the answer's always 'don't ask.'

column1: So what do I tell this guy?
column2: Tell him, as far as I'm concerned, he finds something it's his.

column1: And how are we today?
column2: Terrible.

column1: Just terrible?  That's better than yesterday at least.
column2: How long have I been on Gateway station?

column1: Bad dreams again?  Do you want something to help you sleep?
column2: No.. I've slept enough.

column1: What did you say?
column2: Newt.  My n-name's Newt. Nobody calls me Rebecca except my dork brother.

column1: Casey.  She's my only friend.
column2: What about me?

column1: I don't want you for a friend.
column2: Why not?

column1: They'd be here if they could, honey.  I know they would.
column2: They're dead.

column1: Newt.  Look at me...Newt.  I won't leave you.  I promise.
column2: You promise?

column1: Cross my heart.
column2: And hope to die?

column1: I was the best at the game. I knew the whole maze.
column2: The 'maze'?  You mean the air ducts?

column1: Yeah, you know.  In the walls, under the floor.  I was the ace.  I could hide better than anybody.
column2: You're really something, ace.

column1: I guess we're not leaving, right?
column2: I'm sorry, Newt.

column1: Now you just lie here and have a nap.  You're exhausted.
column2: I don't want to...I have scary dreams.

column1: Ripley...she doesn't have bad dreams because she's just a piece of plastic.
column2: Oh.  Sorry, Newt.

column1: Yes, there are, aren't there.
column2: Why do they tell little kids that?

column1: Well, some kids can't handle it like you can.
column2: Did one of those things grow inside her?

column1: I don't know, Newt.  That's the truth.
column2: Isn't that how babies come? I mean people babies...they grow inside you?

column1: No, it's different, honey.
column2: Did you ever have a baby?

column1: Yes.  A little girl.
column2: Where is she?

column1: Gone.
column2: You mean dead.

column1: Don't go!  Please.
column2: I'll be right in the other room, Newt.  And look...I can see you on that camera right up there.

column1: Newt.  Newt, wake up.
column2: Wah...?  Where are...?

column1: Mommy...I mean, Ripley...I'm scared.
column2: I know, honey.  Me too.

column1: Burke!  Open the door!
column2: Look!

column1: Come on.  Crawl faster.
column2: DO you know how to get to the landing field from here?

column1: This way.  Come on, we're almost there!
column2: Newt, wait!

column1: I knew you'd come.
column2: Newt, I want you to hang on, now.  Hang on tight.

column1: Mommy...Mommy?
column2: Right here, baby.  Right here.

column1: Are we going to sleep now?
column2: That's right.

column1: Can we dream?
column2: Yes, honey.  I think we both can.

column1: Look, I told you...
column2: It did not, however, contain any entries concerning the hostile life form you allegedly picked up.

column1: The analysis team which went over your shuttle centimeter by centimeter found no physical evidence of the creature you describe...
column2: That's because I blew it out the Goddamn airlock!  Like I said.

column1: Look, I can see where this is going.  But I'm telling you those things exist.  Back on that planetoid is an alien ship and on that ship are thousands of eggs.  Thousands. Do you understand?  I suggest you find it, using the flight recorder's data.  Find it and deal with it -- before one of your survey teams comes back with a little surprise...
column2: Thank you, Officer Ripley.  That will be...

column1: Why won't you check out LV-426?
column2: Because I don't have to.  The people who live there checked it out years ago and they never reported and 'hostile organism' or alien ship.  And by the way, they call it Acheron now.

column1: How many colonists?
column2: Sixty, maybe seventy families.

column1: Can't thank you enough, Mr. Sebastian. If you hadn't come along...
column2: We were worried to death.  It's awfully kind of you.

column1: We're not used to the big city. Where we come from it's not so easy to get lost.
column2: You certainly have a nice place here.

column1: He knows what he's doing.
column2: If he won't cooperate?

column1: I'm sure glad you found us, Sebastian.  What do you think, Mary?
column2: I don't think there is another human being in this whole world who would have helped us.

column1: Let's go while there is still time.
column2: Where?

column1: What's the point?
column2: Not to be trapped.

column1: One man.  He must be good.
column2: Then go get him.

column1: The name is Batty.  Roy Batty.
column2: Oh?

column1: Yeah.  It might be better if we talk in private, Sebastian.  Why don't you go home.
column2: Here's your check, my boy.  Thank you.

column1: I'm surprised you didn't come to me sooner.
column2: It's not an easy thing to meet your maker.

column1: And what can he do for you?
column2: Can the maker repair what he makes?

column1: Would you like to be modified?
column2: Had in mind something a little more radical.

column1: What's the problem?
column2: Death.

column1: I want more life, fucker.
column2: Come here.

column1: The facts of life.  I'll be blunt. To make an alteration in the evolvement of an organic life system, at least by men, makers or not, it fatal.  A coding sequence can't be revised once it's established.
column2: Why?

column1: Because by the second day of incubation any cells that have undergone reversion mutation give rise to revertant colonies -- like rats leaving a sinking ship.  The ship sinks.
column2: What about E.M.S. recombination?

column1: Then a repressor protein that blocks the operating cells.
column2: Wouldn't obstruct replication, but it does give rise to an error in replication, so that the newly formed DNA strand carries a mutation and you're got a virus again... but all this is academic -- you are made as good as we could make you.

column1: But not to last.
column2: Put it this way.  Rolls Royces are made to last -- as least they were. But I'm afraid you're a Ferrari. A high strung racing car -- built to win, not to last.

column1: Also you're too valuable to experiment with.
column2: I am?

column1: I've done some questionable things.
column2: Also extraordinary things.

column1: I like a man who stays put.  An admirable thing to be able to sustain yourself in these times. You live here all by yourself, do you?
column2: Well, no, not really.  There's Mr. Deetchum, he's the watchman, he lives on the first floor.

column1: How about breakfast, I was just going to make some.
column2: If it wouldn't be too much of a bother... a little bite to eat would be...

column1: Oh, no bother, I'd be glad to.
column2: Well, actually

column1: Why are you staring at us?
column2: You're just all so... so different.

column1: What, Sebastian?
column2: You're androids.

column1: What generation are you?
column2: Nexus - 6.

column1: Show me something?
column2: Like what?

column1: We have a lot in common.
column2: You mean that you can't come here and I can't go there?

column1: Not only that, but we have smiliar problems.  Accelerated decrepitude. But we don't want to die quite yet.
column2: Of course not.

column1: You could help us.
column2: I don't know much about biomechanics, Roy.  I wish I did, but you're out of my league.

column1: What about your friend, the man who owns this building?
column2: Dr. Tyrell?

column1: He's not really my friend.  I just do a job for him now and then.
column2: Tyrell could help us, Sebastian.

column1: He could?
column2: His company made us.

column1: I'd be happy to mention it to him.
column2: Be better if I could talk to him in person.  But he's not an easy man to get to.

column1: No.
column2: When do you deliver your project?

column1: You're our best and only friend.
column2: Thank you.

column1: Where are you going, Sebastian?
column2: Just thought I'd...

column1: What's going on down there?
column2: He's not ready yet.

column1: When?
column2: Tomorrow, he says.

column1: This is my Uncle Roy, Sebastian.
column2: Hello, glad to meet you.

column1: Then we're stupid and we'll die.
column2: Not if everybody is doing their job here at home.  How are things at home?

column1: I think, therefore I am.
column2: Very good, Pris.  Now show him why.

column1: I want to do it.
column2: Okay, but don't kill him.  Save a little for everybody.  A masterpiece.

column1: Six, huh?
column2: Five.  Three nights ago one of them managed to break into the Tyrell Corporation.  Killed two guards and got as far as the Genetic Sector before he got fried going through an electro- field.

column1: What was he after?
column2: There wasn't much left of him, so we can't be sure.  But bio- chemical data and morphology records of the Nexus-6 were reported missing.  Going on the possibility they might try to infiltrate we send Holden in to run Voight-Kampff tests on the new employees.  Guess he found himself one.

column1: You got a machine on it yet?
column2: We're using Esper -- a 231 -- that picked up Holden's alarm.  Its guess is that all five are in the city.

column1: The Tyrell Corporation has a demo model.  Check it out on the Voight-Kampff.  There's a chance the Nexus-6 is beyond out ability to detect.  If that's the case, everybody's up shit creek.
column2: What was the cover on the one that got Holden?

column1: Industrial refuse.
column2: Garbage man?

column1: Yeah.
column2: Bryant here.  Regarding the rundown you requested on job applicants, Esper's concluded that the only irregular category that Tyrell's got is the entertainment section.  You better get on it.

column1: I was just about to have my dinner.
column2: If you hurry you'll get back before it gets cold.  I got a spinner on your roof in five minutes.  Good luck.

column1: She was gonna get away.
column2: Then let her get away.  I thought you were a pro -- you're supposed to be a fuckin' tracker!

column1: I didn't like her.
column2: You didn't like her!?

column1: Look, go home.  Get some rest. Take an aspirin.
column2: Yeah.

column1: Yeah.

column1: Yeah.
column2: She's not with you?

column2: Got it.

column1: If you don't, we will.  It has to be total, Deckard.  That's an order from as high as it comes.  Got it?
column2: Yeah.  I got it.

column2: Your customer, eh?

column1: Well, when do you get paid?
column2: Soon as I finish the job.

column1: When might that be?
column2: Day after tomorrow.

column1: Machines can be helpful sometimes, but they can also be a pain in the ass.  Ask for a trace on a forger and you might wind up at a steel- mill.  I don't mind a bum-steer once in a while -- it's their personalities that usually get me.  Somebody once said that man makes machines in his own image.  If that's true, whoever made Esper should have been shot.
column2: This is Esper and I'm ready.  Go ahead please.

column1: You equipped for random questions?
column2: Why, yes, of course.

column1: You start.
column2: The five in question are third generation Nexus Sixes, constructed of skin-flesh culture, selected enogenic transfer conversion capable of self-perpetuating thought, para-physical abilities and developed for emigration program.  Are you with me?

column1: How do I stop one?
column2: Unlike a five, they can sustain massive traumas to several parts of the body without debilitating another.  Sever a leg and it will perform quicker on the remaining leg than the fastest man can run,

column1: Okay, but...
column2: I'm coming to that.  Vulnerable zone is the base of the skull, the occipital bone.  A direct hit is a positive retirement.

column1: Here's something you might find interesting.  They have been built to emulate the human in every way except in its emotional spectrum. However, after a period of time it is only logical that such a 'mechanism' would create its own emotional responses, hate, love, fear, anger, envy.
column2: I know all that.

column1: What about a summary then.
column2: I think we're through for the night.

column1: Yes?
column2: Do you have something against science?

column1: Not if it works.
column2: And what in your estimation works?

column1: Four years.  Which would make her termination date...
column2: Never mind.  Do they have that knowledge?

column1: Okay, gimme a run-down on the three females.
column2: Nexus designated Mary:  incept November 1 2017, domestic conditioning non competitive, trained for day care position.

column1: Next.
column2: Nexus designated Pris:  incept data December 13 2017, competitive, programmed to provide pleasure for long term spacers.

column1: Number three.
column2: Nexus designated Zhora:  incept June 13th 2017, athletic conditioning, highly competitive, special abilities in the entertainment field.

column1: I think I have no money.

column2: Prosit.

column2: I don't know.

column1: I'm great.  I mean, I know I'm not really great, but I feel just great.  How you like my new suit?
column2: Well, you don't have to worry about getting it wrinkled.

column2: Sorry.

column1: Hey, it's okay.  I like to pee. So how are you doing?
column2: I'm doing okay.

column1: Money?
column2: No.  I got a problem.

column1: Let's hear it.
column2: I think I'm starting to empathize with these Nexus-sixes.

column1: What's that?
column2: I'm taking a piss.

column1: Love is just another name for sex. Love is sexy and sex is lovely -- I don't care what you call it, an android can't have it.
column2: These aren't just...

column1: Nerves of steel.
column2: No rust?

column1: I didn't say that.  Your motivity rate checked out a little slower than last time.
column2: Meaning?

column1: During the road test...
column2: Yeah?

column2: Huh huh.

column2: True.

column1: But you haven't put in for emigration.
column2: Nope.

column1: You're going to be over the limit.
column2: Listen, I could make you a long list of complaints about this fucken city but I still rather be here than up there.

column2: They'll change the limit before I change my mind.

column1: You sure?
column2: Never been more sure of anything in my life.

column2: Too old.

column2: Me too.

column1: Taffey Lewis?

column1: I'd like  you to take a look at these pictures.
column2: Of course.

column2: Do you recognize any of them?

column1: This one looks familiar, but I don't know.  Naw.  There's one came in today looks a little like this one but...
column2: What did she want?

column1: Who?
column2: The girl that doesn't look like that girl.

column1: Nothing.  She wanted to know about suck night.
column2: What night?

column1: I didn't know if I wanted to handle her -- I already got a snake act.  But my partner goes down there to the Opera House on suck night to book the good ones.
column2: What's suck night?

column1: That's what we call in the trade, audition free-for- alls and most of it sucks. Bit I don't think that's her.
column2: You talking about the Opera House on the Main?

column1: Book the good ones for where?
column2: Lots of places.  The tours, the clubs, the Silicone shows, private parties.

column1: What shows?
column2: Silicone Valley.  Lots of these science guys never leave that place.  We book two shows a month in there. Those big time techs and bio- guys might be real high zoners up here, but when it comes to the arts, they like it loud and lewd.

column1: Yeah?
column2: I'm with the American Federation of Variety Artists...

column1: There's been reports of management sexually abusing the artists in this place.
column2: I don't know nothing about it.

column1: How do you mean 'exploited'?
column2: Like to get this position.  Did you or were you asked to do anything lewd or unsavory or otherwise repulsive to your person?

column1: Are you for real?
column2: Oh, yeah. You'd be surprised what goes on around here.  I'd like to check the dressing room if I could.

column1: What the fuck for?
column2: For holes.

column1: It that mother real?
column2: Of course he's not real.  You think I'd be working here if I could afford a real snake?

column1: It's a good job.
column2: You mean the snake.

column1: The best.
column2: Does it eat?

column1: Jeezus!
column2: Sorry.

column2: I bet I would.

column1: It seems your department doesn't believe out new unit is to the public benefit.
column2: A humanoid robot is like any other machine, it can be a benefit or a hazard.  If it's a benefit, it's not our problem.

column1: It's artificial?
column2: Of course not.

column1: Are you apprehensive?
column2: Why should I be?

column1: I wouldn't accept it.  Also, I'd report the person who gave it to me to the police.
column2: You have a little boy.  He shows you his butterfly collection, plus the killing jar.

column2: You're watching T.V. and suddenly you notice a wasp crawling on your wrist.

column2: Is this testing whether I'm an android or a lesbian?

column1: In your opinion.
column2: It would be my child.

column2: Ugh.

column1: There's two reasons a man rejects help.  Either because he's so good at what he does he doesn't think he needs it, or he's so insecure he can't admit it.
column2: Sounds like I'm an ass-hole either way, but the answer is still no.

column2: Right.

column1: Don't just stand there looking at me.  It's not polite.

column2: There's a lot I haven't done with a man before.

column2: You did?

column2: Me and my dad.

column2: Dead.

column1: How are you doing?

column2: If they are smart, they take naps.

column2: Yeah.  Sometimes.

column2: Yeah.

column1: Nobody is freer than when he dreams.  I read that.

column1: I don't know... I think I missed something.
column2: Like?

column2: Hmmm?

column1: Have you ever cleaned your apartment?
column2: Don't be fooled by appearances.

column1: They could clean around the arrangement.

column2: Never mind the plug, just go through the motions.

column1: But then how can you...
column2: I don't like the noise.  Just practice.  Practice makes perfect.

column1: This feels stupid.

column1: You're sick, Deckard.

column2: Nothing is infallible, but so far the Voight-Kampff scale bas been foolproof.

column2: Thirteen.

column1: How many questions does it usually take, Mr. Deckard?
column2: Five, maybe six.

column2: Discreetly.

column2: Look, Andrea, I'm sure he'll test negative for brain disorders. But there's something else you can try to monitor his memory.

column2: And the bad news?

column2: Come on, I doubt the answer's that simple.

column1: You'd be surprised how often they are.
column2: Well, he has been pushing me to meet his father, but I've been putting it off.
