column2: Doctor Weir, my crew is not going on your mission because we want to. We were pulled off a well deserved leave, to be sent out to the middle of nowhere, and no one's even told us why.

column1: I've been authorized to brief you and the crew once we reach Neptune space.
column2: Until then, do what you're told and stay out of my way.

column1: It was the ship's maiden voyage, to test the drive. The Event Horizon moved to safe distance using ion thrusters. They received the go-ahead to activate the gravity drive.  And the ship vanished from all our scopes. No radar contact, no enhanced optical, no radio contact of any kind. They disappeared without a trace.  Until now.
column2: Where has it been for the last seven years?

column1: What does it say?
column2: NSA encryption specialists have deciphered some of the message...

column1: That's the engineering containment. And there's the main airlock. We can dock there.
column2: Smith, use the arm and lock us onto that antennae cluster.

column1: Dr. Weir, I need you on the bridge.
column2: Captain, I didn't come out here to sit on your bridge, I need to be on that ship...

column1: Once the ship is secured, we'll bring you on board --
column2: That is not acceptable --

column1: You're in the central corridor. It connects the personnel areas to Engineering.
column2: Peters and I will search the forward decks. Justin, take Engineering. No hot-dogging, not on this one, alright?

column1: I can see that, what're they for?
column2: In an emergency, the charges detonate in series, destroying the central section and separating the personnel areas from the rest of the ship. That way, if the gravity drive malfunctions, the crew could use the foredecks as a lifeboat.

column1: Easy, Peters, we're okay, we're okay. Let's finish the sweep.
column2: Captain Miller, the foredecks are just ahead.

column1: Any survivors?
column2: Negative.

column1: No one?
column2: They're empty, Dr. Weir. Moving forward.

column1: It beats dying, Mister Smith.
column2: Dr. Weir's right. Get on board the Event Horizon. I'll meet you at the airlock.

column1: Yes.
column2: One of my men is down. I want to know what happened to him.

column1: Hold on, what's this "gravitational distortion?"
column2: It's possible that a burst of gravity waves escaped from the Core, distorting space-time. They could be what hit the Lewis and Clark.

column1: What could cause them?  What's in the Core?
column2: It's complicated...

column1: It's insane.
column2: "Insane?" The finest astronauts fought to be posted to this ship. It would take the Lewis and Clark a thousand years to reach our closest star. The Event Horizon could be there in a day...

column1: If it worked.
column2: If it worked, yes.

column1: I want this room sealed. The Second Containment is off limits.
column2: There's no danger. The black hole is contained behind three magnetic fields, it's under control.

column1: You have something, Dr. Weir?
column2: The date.

column1: What about it?
column2: The Event Horizon's computer think's it's 2034.
Exactly. The ship's internal clock is off by seven years.

column1: Explanation?
column2: Intense gravitational fields effect the passage of time, it's possible...  Black holes make sense on paper, it's all math, you see, but as to what really happened...  The Event Horizon has passed beyond our plane of reality, and like Lazarus, returned from the dead.

column1: What the hell is that? Dr. Weir?
column2: I don't know.

column1: We barely have enough power for life support as it is, if we can't stop the drain, we're not gonna make it.
column2: The Core...!

column1: We don't get the power back, our air's gonna go bad.
column2: Check the Core for radiation. Carbon dioxide may be the least of our worries.

column1: We're a long way from home and we're in a bad place. Let's not make it worse. If anyone has any constructive suggestions, now is the time.
column2: I think I can stabilize the fields around the singularity, that should prevent another power drain.

column1: Is that your "expert opinion?" The only answer we've had out of you is "I don't know."
column2: Justin just tried to kill himself. The man is clearly insane.

column1: I want to know what caused that noise. I want to know why one of my crew tried to throw himself out of the airlock.
column2: Thermal changes in the hull could have caused the metal to expand and contract very suddenly, causing reverberations --

column1: That's bullshit and you know it! You built this fucking ship and all I've heard from you is bullshit!
column2: What do you want me to say?

column1: You said this ship creates a gateway...
column2: Yes...

column1: To what? Where did this ship go? Where did you send it?
column2: I don't know...

column1: Where has it been for the past seven years?
column2: I don't know...

column1: The "Other Place," what is that...?
column2: I DON'T KNOW!  I don't know. There's a lot of things going on here that I don't understand. Truth takes time.

column1: We're leaving.
column2: You can't, your orders are specific...

column1: "...to rescue the crew and salvage the ship." The crew is dead, Dr. Weir. This ship killed them. And now it's killing us.
column2: You're insane. You've lost your mind.

column1: Maybe you're right. But it's still my command, and I have leeway to abort when I feel there is an unacceptable threat to my crew. And I think there is.  Starck, download all the files from the Event Horizon's computers. Coop, Smith, finish moving the CO2 scrubbers back onto the Clark.
column2: Don't... don't do this...

column1: What about my ship?
column2: We will take the Lewis and Clark to a safe distance and then launch tac missiles at the Event Horizon until I am satisfied that she has been destroyed.  Fuck this ship.

column1: You... You can't do that!
column2: Watch me.

column1: You can't leave. She won't let you.
column2: Just get your gear back onto the Lewis and Clark, doctor, or you'll find yourself looking for a ride home.

column1: I told you... She won't let you leave...
column2: Son of a bitch!

column1: Your eyes...
column2: I don't need them anymore. Where we're going, we won't need eyes to see.

column1: What are you talking about?
column2: Do you know what a singularity is, Miller? Does your mind truly fathom what a black hole is?  It is NOTHING. Absolute and eternal NOTHING. And if God is Everything, then I have seen the Devil.  It's a liberating experience.

column1: If you miss me, you'll blow out the hull. You'll die too.
column2: What makes you think I'll miss?

column1: Weir is dead.
column2: Then who the fuck are you?

column1: What are you?
column2: You know.

column1: You want me to believe you're the Devil, well, I don't, that's bullshit!
column2: I'm not the Devil.

column1: Then what, what are you? Tell me...
column2: Better if I just show you.

column1: There is no Devil. There is no God. There is only... NOTHING.
column2: You're lying...!

column1: I'm not asking you to believe me. You'll see for yourself... and so will your crew. You're all coming with me.
column2: Starck... Cooper...

column1: You can't have them. Go to hell.
column2: NOOO!

column1: I don't like it either, but you know the rules: we get the call, we go. Is the course locked in?
column2: Locked and cocked.

column1: Jesus...
column2: What is that?

column1: Heading three-three-four...
column2: ...Make your approach vector negative fourteen degrees...

column1: We have a lock on the Event Horizon's navigation beacon. It's in the upper ionosphere, we're in for some chop.
column2: Bring us in tight. Starck, get on the horn, see if anyone's listening...

column1: We're all on edge, Smith. We're a long way out...
column2: That's not it. That ship was built to go faster than light... That's just wrong, it goes against everything we know...

column1: What are you trying to say? "If God had intended Man to fly, he would have given us wings?"
column2: Something like that, yeah.

column1: I guess we're about to find out. Keep us slow and steady.
column2: Yes, sir.

column1: We've got some weather.
column2: I noticed. Starck, anybody home?

column1: 1500 meters. We're getting too close...
column2: Where is it?

column1: Proximity warning! 900, 800 meters, 700... we're right on top of it, we're gonna hit!
column2: Starck...

column1: Put it through TACS. Smith, you up for a flyby?
column2: Love to.

column1: It is now.  We're locked in.
column2: Starck, give me a read.

column1: Captain Miller...
column2: Smith, where the hell have you been?!

column1: Do we have enough time for a weld?
column2: We don't have time to fart.

column1: We're losing pressure at 280 liters a second and our oxygen tanks are cracked. In three minutes, our atmosphere will be gone. We are fucking dead.
column2: No one's dying on my watch, Smith! What about the reserve tanks?

column1: But...
column2: You heard me, Smith. Peters, are you with me?

column1: Captain Miller, you copy?
column2: I'm here, Smith, how's the Clark?

column1: I've found a six inch fracture in the outer hull. We should be able to repair it and re-pressurize, it's gonna take some time.
column2: We don't have time, Smith. In twenty hours we run out of air.

column1: ...you break all the laws of physics, you think there won't be a price? You already killed the first crew...
column2: That's enough!

column1: Sir.
column2: Get outside, go back to work. I'll join you shortly.

column1: Thank you.
column2: Captain, we got a problem.

column1: Now what?
column2: She was right behind me, I turn around, she's gone. She could be anywhere.

column1: Skipper...
column2: What is it, Smith?

column1: Smith, get out of there...
column2: Come again, Skipper?

column1: Get off the Clark now and wait for me at the airlock.
column2: No, no, we just got her back together...

column1: Where is it, where is it...
column2: Smith? Smith! Fuck!

column1: We're past the outer marker, we can engage the ion drive whenever you're ready.
column2: Justin?

column1: Ion drive will engage in... T-minus ten minutes.
column2: Let's go.

column1: Starck, why aren't you on the bridge?
column2: I just finished drying...

column1: Crossing the horizon. Optimum approach angle is fourteen degrees.
column2: Come around to three-three-four...

column1: Something's wrong with the bio-scan.
column2: Radiation interference?

column1: That's an affirmative.
column2: Keep your eyes open.

column1: Everybody okay?
column2: We're all here.

column1: It tastes bad.
column2: But you can breathe it.

column1: The antennae array's completely fried, we've got no radio, no laser, no highgain... No one's going to be coming to help us.
column2: How much oh-two do we have?

column1: Oxygen is not the problem.
column2: Carbon dioxide?

column1: It's building up with every breath we take. And the CO2 filters on the Event Horizon are shot.
column2: We can take the filters from the Clark...

column1: I thought of that, with the filters from the Clark, we've got enough breathable air for twenty hours. After that, we'd better be on our way home.
column2: What about the life readings you picked up?

column1: The Event Horizon sensors show the same thing: "Bio-readings of indeterminate origin." Right before that wave hit the Clark, there was some kind of surge, right off the scale, but now it's back to its previous levels.
column2: What's causing the readings?

column1: I don't know, but whatever it is, it's not the crew.
column2: So where is the rest of the crew? We've been over every inch of this ship and all we've found is blood. Dr. Weir? Any suggestions?

column1: What's the point? I'll just get the same thing...
column2: Not acceptable. I want to know what's causing those readings. If the crew is dead, I want the bodies, I want the crew found.

column1: I can reconfigure the scan for C-12, amylase proteins.
column2: Do it. Dr. Weir...

column1: Maybe one of the original crew?
column2: No. It was someone else.

column1: Who?
column2: Dr. Weir, you were right there, you must have heard something, seen something...

column1: Miller...
column2: What is it, Starck?

column1: ...I ran the bio-scan with the DNA/RNA filter. The results were bio-readings of indeterminate origin...
column2: "...bio-readings of indeterminate origin," don't you have anything useful to tell me?

column1: Go ahead.
column2: There was a another surge in the bio- readings right before you... you saw what you saw. We picked up a similar readings right before the Clarke was damaged. What if there were a connection between the two? The gravity waves, the hallucination, all part of an defensive reaction, like an immune system...

column1: You've got to listen...
column2: To what? What are you saying? This ship is alive?

column1: I didn't say that, I said the bio- readings correspond to what happened to you, the ship is reacting to us...
column2: We're hanging on by our fingernails and you're giving me bullshit stories...

column1: It's not bullshit, it's the only conclusion the data supports...
column2: Starck, do you know how crazy that sounds? It's impossible.

column1: If you knew it was impossible, then why'd you waste my time?
column2: I thought you wanted an answer. And that's the only one I have.

column1: What I want is to survive the next ten hours.
column2: Nine hours and twenty-two minutes.

column1: Miller, come in...
column2: What's going on in there, Starck?

column1: What?
column2: He's awake, he's in the airlock, he's not wearing a suit.

column1: I'm on my way, Starck.
column2: You better hurry. He's engaged the override, we can't open the inner door.

column1: Tuck yourself into a crouched position, shut your eyes as tight as you can!
column2: Five seconds.

column1: Weir can't be alive.
column2: Whatever was on that bridge wasn't Weir.

column1: Weir activated the drive. He's sending us to the Other Place.
column2: We've got to shut it down, we've got to...

column1: BLOW THE FUCKER UP.
column2: Blow it up?

column1: I'll do it --
column2: No. I'll be right back.

column1: We're armed. This fucker's ready to blow...
column2: ...repeat, we're armed...

column1: Weir.
column2: He's dead...

column1: First time in a grav couch?
column2: Yes.

column1: Don't worry about it. He's hard, but he's fair. You're lucky to be shipping out with him. He's one of the few Captains in the service with experience in the Outer Reach.
column2: He's been past Mars?

column1: He served on the Goliath.
column2: Wasn't that ship destroyed?

column1: Claire...
column2: DJ!  It's okay. You're okay. Just breathe.

column1: Here's another one. They're all over the place.
column2: They're explosive charges.

column1: Dr. Weir, what's this the door to?
column2: You're at the Bridge, Ms. Peters. You still haven't seen any crew?

column1: Yes, we can see some kind of mist. What is that?
column2: Blood. Looks like arterial spray.

column1: Can you see a body?
column2: There's no one here.

column1: No. I saw nothing.
column2: I did.

column1: About an hour ago. In medical. I saw my son. He was lying on one of the examination tables and his legs were...
column2: Isn't it possible that you were traumatized by finding the body on the bridge?

column1: There's no one in the corridor but us.
column2: Not according to the computer.

column1: He's engaged the override.
column2: Can you shut it down?

column1: Yes. Yes, Justin, we heard it.
column2: Keep him talking.

column1: Almost got it.
column2: Come on, Baby-bear, open this door...

column1: We have to do something, oh God...
column2: Skipper, Justin just activated the door. It's on a thirty second delay...

column1: You got any coffee?
column2: It's cold.

column1: Hey...
column2: Say this paper represents space-time, and you want to get from "point A" here...  ...to "point B," here.  Now: what's the shortest distance between two points?

column1: Where is she?
column2: Dead ahead, 5000 meters.

column1: Jesus, that is one big ugly fat fucker...
column2: She's not ugly.

column1: Foredecks. Crew quarters, bridge, medical and science labs, hydroponics, what have you. That central section connects the forward decks to the Engineering containment area. Can we move in closer?
column2: Shit, Doc, any closer and we're gonna need a rubber...

column1: What the hell is that?
column2: That's the Core: the gravity drive. The heart of the ship.

column1: The safety circuit's failed!
column2: We're losing atmosphere...

column1: What?
column2: It still has air and reserve power, we can activate gravity and life support.

column1: I didn't see anything and I don't have to see anything. This ship is fucked.
column2: Thank you for that scientific analysis, Mister Smith.

column1: I can't believe this, I haven't gotten more than my hand in six weeks and now this shit. Why not Mars, Cap, Mars has women...
column2: Smith's right. Neptune? There's nothing out there. If something happens, we'll be on our own.

column1: 30 hours to Neptune orbit.
column2: All boards are green, everything's five by five.

column1: You can't do that.
column2: The law of relativity prohibits faster- than-light travel...

column1: This is U.S. Aerospace Command vessel Lewis and Clark, hailing Event Horizon, Event Horizon, do you read...? This is the Lewis and Clark, hailing...
column2: Matching speed... now. Range to target ten thousand meters and closing... Skipper, I got a bad feeling about this...

column1: If they are, they're screening their calls.
column2: Range 3000 meters and closing.

column1: The scope is lit, it's right in front of us...
column2: 1000 meters...

column1: Range 500 meters and holding. Turbulence is dropping off...
column2: Picking up magnetic interference.

column1: What happened to his eyes?
column2: Explosive decompression.

column1: Miller, do you read me, Peters --
column2: Get them back --

column1: What if the air has gone bad? We can't wear these suits forever.
column2: I don't think this is a good idea, we don't even know what happened on that ship...

column1: Relativity, yes. We can't break the law of relativity, but we can go around it. The ship doesn't really move faster than the speed of light
column2: How?

column1: A straight line.
column2: Wrong. The shortest distance between two points...

column1: The reactor's still hot. We've got several small radiation sources, leaks probably. Nothing serious.
column2: Do they have pressure?

column1: Could it be the crew? If they were in suspended animation, wouldn't that effect the scan?
column2: If they were in stasis, I'd get a location, but these readings, they're all over the ship. It doesn't make any sense.

column1: What is it?
column2: Ship's log.

column1: What is it?
column2: I don't know. The life readings just went off the scale.

column1: That's how the gravity drive works, you see: it focuses the black hole's immense gravitational power to create the gateway. That's how the Event Horizon travels faster than light.
column2: I can't believe we built this.

column1: Why Dr. Weir, I think you're in love.
column2: Hmmm. Claire used to tell me I loved the Event Horizon more than I loved her. I told her that wasn't true, I just knew the Event Horizon better, that's all.

column1: Claire is your wife?
column2: Yes.

column1: It must be hard, being so far away from her.
column2: Yes. I miss her. She died. Two years now.

column1: Maybe a power interruption crashed the system...
column2: No, there's no evidence of a surge or spike of any kind. It's as if time just... stopped for seven years.

column1: What are you doing?
column2: It wants me. I have to go.

column1: In our current environment, Dr. Weir, self-control is an asset.
column2: I'm alright. Please.

column1: What is it?
column2: The forward airlock.

column1: Justin said something about, "The dark inside me..." What did he mean?
column2: It means nothing.

column1: I don't think She's real big on hate.
column2: You wouldn't say that, if you could see me.

column1: Such a sad face... You know, sometimes being different isn't a bad thing.
column2: Trust me, this ain't one of those times.

column1: How'd you know it was me?
column2: I'm blind, not deaf. Wanna come in?

column1: I'm not really dressed for a party.
column2: Relax, it's casual.

column1: Those yours too?
column2: My step-dad's. I'm strictly into stone. I was wondering when you'd walk by.

column1: We're going to have to work on your touch.
column2: I like the sound of that.

column1: You know, you could'a run an ad in the personals.
column2: "Sensual blind chick seeks three- ton, rock-hard he-man for deep spiritual relationship."

column1: You don't know what it's like out there. Walking around like some kind of circus freak. People staring, whispering --
column2: I wouldn't know anything about that.

column1: I mean...
column2: Tell me. When you grew up in Brooklyn, how many astronauts did you know?  You went your own way then. You didn't listen to people. So why start now...?

column1: Way to not overthink it.  So when do we leave?
column2: I'll schedule the launch. Call me in the morning to talk about resources and crew.

column1: I can handle the ship. I can even handle Mr. Blonde Ambition. But I don't know if I should be flying or playing Vegas in these suits. Who the hell came up with them?
column2: Victor did.

column1: We can monitor the cloud's approach and observe the tests from here.
column2: Is it safe?

column1: I can only stay for one drink, Ben. I've got to meet with Victor.
column2: Wouldn't want to keep Vic waiting.

column1: We need to give you a physical, so we know what got zapped.
column2: Well why didn't you say so? You want me to lift some weights or something?

column1: You look like an eighties rock band.
column2: The suit will stretch. You should try it --

column1: He didn't.
column2: Oh, he did.

column1: He didn't mean it. You know Johnny. He's always been a hothead --
column2: It's not him. It's them.  I can't live like this.

column1: Just give Reed a little more time. You know how he works -- analyzing every little step before he takes one --
column2: It's easy for you to be patient.

column1: Where is Reed?
column2: Victor must've taken him.

column1: What are you doing here?
column2: I'm worried about you.

column1: About me? How sweet.
column2: Come on. Let me buy you something to eat. Looks like you could use the company.

column1: Ben, come in.
column2: What is this? Where's Reed?

column1: What do you want, Vic?
column2: To help you. I've run every test known to man. And they all yield the same result: the machine is ready.

column1: Reed said it'd be weeks till --
column2: He also said we'd avoid that storm in space. And we know how that turned out.

column1: He couldn't generate enough power for the machine to reach critical mass. Yet another mistake for "Mr. Fantastic."
column2: And you can? Power it up?

column1: I'll be watching over you.
column2: Just get back soon, or I start looking for a new groom.

column1: Soon as I'm back, I'm gonna trade that in for a bigger rock.
column2: I don't care about rocks, I care about you.  You bring him back in one piece, or you can forget being Best Man.

column1: Deb... It's me. I need you to step out front.
column2: Out front? You home, baby? I got a surprise for you.

column1: Ben?
column2: Don't come any closer for a sec. This is gonna be kind of a shock... You remember when we said "together forever no matter what"?

column1: Oh my G-g-g. What did you... do to Ben?
column2: Deb, it's me. It's still me.

column1: What did you wish for, honey?
column2: I already got it. Everything I want.

column1: Good thing it ain't workin... Reed, what are we doing here? This guy's fast-food, strip-mall science --
column2: This wasn't our first stop, in case you forgot NASA. And Victor's not that bad. He's just a little...  Larger than life.

column1: He's financed some of the biggest breakthroughs of this century.
column2: You'd never know it.

column1: I can't take this.
column2: Ben. This is business. Just work.

column1: What about his first born?
column2: Ben, the money's not important. We could save lives.

column1: He knew about NASA. What if he made the call to shut us down --
column2: Ben, think about all the people we can help if this works --

column1: Maybe you should think about yourself for once. You always let this guy push you round --
column2: We got what we wanted. That's enough.

column1: Can't do it. I cannot do it.
column2: External SRBs, orbital system engines. Its just like the shuttles you flew in --

column1: No. I cannot take orders from that underwear model. That wingnut washed out of NASA for sneaking two Victoria Secret wannabes into a flight simulator.
column2: Youthful high spirits.

column1: They crashed it into a wall. A flight simulator.
column2: I'm sure he's matured since then.

column1: When have I asked you to do something you absolutely said you could not do?
column2: Five times.

column1: I had it at four.
column2: This makes five.

column1: Isn't that your speech?
column2: He's made a few changes.

column1: This is your dream, Reed. You should be the one up there.
column2: Victor's better at these things.

column1: The shields on the station should protect us.
column2: Should?

column1: I ain't done arranging your flowers, egghead.
column2: Ben. This is serious. Turn around.

column1: How long was I out?
column2: Three days. I was worried about you. How are you feeling?

column1: I don't know. I just keep going over and over the numbers.
column2: Reed. Even you can't compute every little thing.

column1: You go through something like this, makes you appreciate having the right woman in your life.
column2: Yeah, you and Debbie and perfect --

column1: What? Come on. She's got a good thing with Victor --
column2: I'm sorry, did that cosmic-bath loosen your screws?

column1: He's smart, powerful, successful --
column2: Well maybe you should date him.

column1: Are you alright?
column2: I think I need to lie down. Bad shrimp.

column1: What the --!
column2: Ben. Are you okay?

column1: We had a tough year.
column2: Yeah, nine years straight.

column1: You got a chisel round here?
column2: If we're going to identify the source of the mutation, we need to isolate your recombinant DNA so we can activate positional genomes.

column1: Okay. I've uh, got some questions, from Sue. That she thought might be better coming from me... Can you, you know, go to the bathroom... like normal...
column2: Yeah.  You don't wanna know the details.

column1: Ben, I'm afraid I've got to ask --
column2: Not unless you want that clipboard stretched up your --

column1: It's about to be a broken face.
column2: This isn't permanent, Johnny. We need to be careful until we're normal again.

column1: Ben --
column2: Oh, you remember my name do you? You happen to remember what you swore to do with every breath in your body?

column1: We're working as hard as we can --
column2: Yeah. I can tell. Victor was right.

column1: Glad "nothing" could take you away from your work.
column2: Ben, I don't know if this thing'll change us back or make us worse. I need you to be patient for a little while longe--

column1: Time for your lesson, Vic. Chem 101: what happens when you supercool hot metal...?  Ben...
column2: Got it, teach.

column1: Ben, I've been crunching the numbers on the machine. I think if we can rework the power settings...
column2: Forget it, egghead. I'm good as is.

column1: What the hell you smiling at? Just keep your mouth shut, and your mind on those SMBs --
column2: Actually, the engines are SMEs. Hydrogenbase, carbon propellant. Couple generations past your last ride.  I'm not as dumb as you look.

column1: If you behave, maybe next time daddy'll let you drive.
column2: Keep talking, there won't be a next time.

column1: Please tell me your dawg's not trying to rekindle things with my sister.
column2: 'Course not. Strictly business.

column1: Yeah, well, his eyes say different.
column2: Hey, two hearts got busted last time. Maybe she's not over it either.

column1: Let's see: you got Victor, stud of the year, more coin than God? Or Reed, the world's dumbest smart guy worth less than a postage stamp. Hmmm, it's a toss-up.
column2: Put your tiny little mind at ease.

column1: Where... where am I?
column2: Back on Earth. Victor's medical facility... We're in quarantine.

column1: Reed?... Sue?
column2: They're fine. Everybody else... is fine.

column1: What's wrong with me?
column2: I swear to you they've done everything humanly possible. The best plastic surgeons in the world, Ben. You had the best --

column1: They said that's not such a good idea, the shock alone could --
column2: Give me the god damn mirror!

column1: Hey! That's a prototype!
column2: Go back to the drawing board.

column1: The machine works. And Vic's gone Mister Hyde on us --
column2: Really? With a name like Von Doom? Never saw that one coming.

column1: No more cracks about how I look.
column2: Hey, I'm Mr. Sensitivity now.  Clear the way, wide load coming through.

column1: Your tissue, your organs, your entire biophysical structure is changing. Every system is still functioning, somehow --
column2: And they're changing into...

column1: I don't really know. A compound organic-metallic alloy. Stronger than titanium or carbon steel. Harder than diamonds --
column2: Like the shields Reed said would protect us.  How long?

column1: At this rate, the infection should be complete in two, maybe three weeks --
column2: What do you mean "complete"?

column1: What?
column2: The Center for Disease Control. If this thing is contagious --

column1: But... this disease... is progressive... degenerative...
column2: That's terrible news...

column1: And where do we think we're going?
column2: I don't know if "we've" noticed, but the sickest runs this side of the Alps are right outside that window --

column1: You're hot!
column2: So are you!

column1: I mean, you feel a little feverish.
column2: I've never felt better in my life. When do you get off work?

column1: My shift ends at four, but I couldn't --
column2: Meet me at 4:01, top of the run. That'll give you a minute to freshen up.

column1: Me like-y.
column2: Stay right. Left is trouble.

column1: I though we went over this.
column2: Last one down springs for room service.

column1: You're on fire!
column2: Not this again --

column1: Victor's right. Johnny, get to the command center. Close the shields.
column2: What about you?

column1: He's not responsive --
column2: Ben! Ben!

column1: Now what is up with that?
column2: The cloud has fundamentally altered our DNA.

column1: Oh, you dawg you. Better not be my nurse!
column2: Ben, are you there?

column1: This is wrong in so many ways.
column2: You've been working out.

column1: Ben Grimm is a genuine American hero who's been through a terrible orde--
column2: What he's trying to say is: every team needs a mascot...

column1: Twenty? From outside the place looks a lot taller.
column2: Oh, it is.

column1: We should stay here until we can define the extent of our changes...
column2: This place is deluxe. You got cable?

column1: Back it down, Johnny!
column2: I can go hotter!

column1: Not only could you kill yourself, but you could set fire to Earth's atmosphere and destroy all human life as we know it.
column2: Gotcha. Okay. Supernova bad.

column1: Is there something about flames? About flaming, that you --
column2: What are you trying to say? Just because I dress well and like to dance --

column1: What? No. I'm trying to figure out why we each ended up with different symptoms.
column2: Oh, well that's easy: I'm hot. You're... well, you're a little limp. Sue's easy to see through. And Ben's always been a hardass.  Why aren't you writing this down?

column1: He's right. These costumes are... missing something. I can't put my finger on it --
column2: They're not costumes.

column1: That's what I'm trying to calculate. And it's not rubber. It's muscle, tendon. I seem to have the ability to manipulate the malleability of my molecular structure and redistribute my density to --
column2: Right, whatever, have fun.

column1: You need to control yourself and think before you --
column2: Act. Here we go again. Reed, what if we got these gifts for a reason? What if we have some, you know... like, calling?

column1: Johnny. SUPERNOVA.
column2: But all these people...

column1: The synthetics act as a second skin, adapting to your individual needs to --
column2: Keep the hot side hot, and the cool side cool!

column1: Apparently I can disappear.
column2: Please tell me you go silent too.

column1: Flame on, flame off. Flame on, flame off --
column2: Johnny.

column1: Stop it.
column2: Okay, "mom."

column1: What is that thing?
column2: I think that thing is Ben.

column1: Wait. You mean there's chance we could be full-on-24-7-fantastic?
column2: Grow up, Johnny. You want to run around on fire for the rest of your life?

column1: You're really cramping my style here.
column2: You were at 4000 Kelvin. Any hotter, you're approaching supernova --

column1: Sweet.
column2: That's the temperature of the sun.

column1: Uh, we call my sister the invisible girl... the Invisible Girl.
column2: Girl...?!

column1: I'm driving.
column2: Dude. That's my sister.

column1: You're gonna pay for that, Pebbles.  What?!
column2: You gave us names? What are you, the "face" of the Fantastic Four now?

column1: You two need a time-out.
column2: Blockhead started it!

column1: Johnny? Did you see Ben?
column2: Yeah, for the last time, I hope. I'm done with this freak show. I'm moving back to the real world.

column1: Is that what you call it? "Real"?
column2: At least it beats living in a lab like somebody's science project.

column1: Johnny, slow down. Think. You know mom didn't raise us to --
column2: Look around, sis! She's not here. So you can stop talking to me like I'm your little boy --

column1: I'm sorry, sis, for leaving you guys --
column2: No, I'm sorry, for pushing you out.

column1: What are you doing --
column2: Sis. Let me take care of you for once.

column1: If Reed's right, then this little trip will double our stock offering.
column2: And if he's not...?

column1: They're ready for you, sir.
column2: Showtime.

column1: Our numbers are through the roof. The IPO's tracking at fifty, sixty a share. The bank's five times oversubscribed --
column2: It's not just the money. I could make money in my sleep.

column1: Then what is it?
column2: History, Leonard. History. Everything else is conversation...  How's the other matter?

column1: Leonard, how's the feed?
column2: Recording, sir. We see you perfectly.

column1: How's the IPO?
column2: Stable. We're looking at low twenties. It's a good number, considering the fallout from --

column1: Reed's disaster. You know, I half- think he did this to me on purpose.
column2: Sir, I'm sure he wouldn't put himself --

column1: Get me on the AM shows, Larry King, cover of the Journal...  I've got to do something about this scar. Make sure they only shoot my right side.
column2: Actually, uh, people seem to think the scar "humanizes" you.

column1: You know, maybe you should get some rest --
column2: Later. First, I've got some unfinished business. A deal that needs closing...

column1: Sir, I've always wondered... Why Sue? You could have any woman in the world but --
column2: That's why. Because I could have any other woman... You know, when they asked Caesar "why England," he said, "because it's not mine."

column1: Make sure you find Ben, bring him back here. And keep it quiet. I don't need this to hit the press.
column2: Yes sir. You've got the Mayor at eight, then a nine-thirty interview with the Journal --

column1: Front page?
column2: Top left, like you asked.  Today Wall Street. Tomorrow, who knows... maybe Washington.

column1: You're, you've, I mean, how have you bee--
column2: Never better.

column1: Those solar winds are flaring, but I factored them into my coordinates and --
column2: I was talking about us. Working together.

column1: Well, uh, based on our history... you can handle the biogenetics, and I'll focus on the molecular physics. Or, uhm, maybe I should take the biotech, you work the microscopes, since you have some background in electropho--
column2: Right. That's exactly what I meant.

column1: I, uh, think I remember the number.
column2: It's been changed.

column1: As far as crew, I was hoping Ben could pilot the mission --
column2: Well, he's welcome to ride shotgun, but we already have a pilot on our payroll. You remember my brother Johnny...

column1: Material made from self-regulating unstable molecules. I've been working on a formula for this.
column2: Great minds think alike.

column1: Feeling better?
column2: Yes, thanks.

column1: That's good. That's uh... good.
column2: You always had a way with words.  I should be getting back.

column1: You're happy for me and Victor.
column2: I can tell you guys are enjoying what was the best part of our relationship --

column1: Which was?
column2: Passion.

column1: For science.
column2: You are such a dork, Reed... You never got it and never will unless it's explained to you in quantum physics.

column1: Uh, Sue...? I can't.
column2: What? What do you mean you --

column1: It has to be the cloud. It's fundamentally altered our DNA.
column2: Let's not jump to conclusions, we need a massive amount of evidence before making that leap.

column1: What?
column2: We need to get past them.

column1: Sue. Your clothes. Lose them.
column2: What...?  Oh.

column1: How come Ben can't turn it on and off like us?
column2: That's what we're here to find out.

column1: It's not "invisibility" per se. You're bending the light around you with some kind of malleable force field. That's what you projected on the Bridge.
column2: What about you? You haven't eaten in days. How come you're never on this side of the microscope?

column1: You should be able to bend light around other objects, even people, if you could control your emotional state better --
column2: Excuse me?

column1: I'm saying, if you had a little more self control, you could locate the trigger. Can you remember the exact emotions when --
column2: Anger. Rage. Frustration.

column1: Okay. Is there any way to duplicate that feeling? Some memory or...
column2: I'm sure I can come up with something.

column1: I'm sorry, I'm sorry, I didn't mean to do that... You must think that was some kind of latent hostility or --
column2: What in the world would give me that idea?

column1: I mean, you broke up with me, right?
column2: Are you kidding?

column1: Reed. I was ready for the next step, you weren't, ergo, I walked.
column2: I think it was a little more complicated than --

column1: There were a lot of variables to consider --
column2: No. There weren't. There was you. And me. No variables, no math. It was actually the simplest thing in the world. But your head got in the way... like it always does.

column1: What are you doing?
column2: The plants, from space. Their particles are still charged. With the right amount of energy, those ions could create the elemental profile of the cosmic storm.

column1: If we can build a machine to re-create the storm, we can reverse the polarity --
column2: And reverse the mutations --

column1: But we're the focus, right Reed? Reed...?
column2: Of course. Of course.

column1: And you sure you can control this thing? Last time didn't work out so well.
column2: With the right energy, we can stabilize the storm. Maybe tie into the city grid...

column1: Reed. How close are we to a cure?
column2: No way to know. Without more tests, experiments.

column1: Don't let Victor push you into making a mistake --
column2: He was going to take away all my data, equipment --

column1: Which is why I'm working twenty hours a day, checking every variable --
column2: Every variable but yourself. You don't eat, sleep. You can't live in your head like --

column1: I could get Ben to tap into the Baxter's main power to generate enough voltage --
column2: Reed. Shh. Just be quiet. And look up.

column1: Remember our first date here...? God, I was so nervous.
column2: You were?

column1: You know, I bribed the projectionist ten bucks to keep it open late?
column2: I gave him twenty.

column1: You always talked about how you liked the kind of man who could approach you... speak his mind. One who wasn't afraid to tell you what he wanted.
column2: I did. I did, Reed... but I wanted you to be that man.

column1: When I walked out, I waited ten minutes outside your door. Ten. Waiting for you to come find me.
column2: Why didn't you say something?

column1: I can... make it work.
column2: Reed, stop, you need to rest your --

column1: The power... I need... more power... to control... the storm --
column2: You need a doctor.

column1: Sue, I need some of that anger, rage, frustration --
column2: I'm sure I can come up with something.

column1: I found a broken gasket, from space --
column2: A gasket? Reed, we're at a party.

column1: But dreams don't pay the bills, do they?  Same old Reed, the hopeless optimist. Still reaching for the stars, with the world on your back.
column2: You remember in school we talked about working together. That's what I was about to explain...

column1: This isn't going to be a problem, is it?
column2: Not at all.

column1: You back this mission, and I'll sign over a fair percentage of any applications or --
column2: The number's seventy-five. And it's applications and patents.

column1: Funny how things turn out, isn't it?
column2: Hilarious.

column1: Got it. So take a walk, Ben... I'm going to borrow Susan for a second.
column2: Sure.

column1: We've got minutes until it hits, not hours... Victor, that storm's deadly -- the radiation's lethal. We need to abort.
column2: Get a grip. Reed. We didn't come all this way to lose our nerve at the first little glitch. Just close the shields...

column1: Ben's still out there --
column2: So reel him in. But we came here to do a job. So let's do it. Quickly.

column1: Come on, Ben, come on...
column2: Reed, we're running out of time.

column1: Not until Ben is back inside!
column2: It's too late for him, and soon it'll be too late for all of us.

column1: Just a little banged up. A couple scrapes. Why?
column2: Ben did this.

column1: Ben did this?
column2: He's had some kind of... reaction to exposure from the cloud. And he's not the only one.

column1: I'm starting to wonder the same thing... How much do you know about what happened to you?
column2: Not much. We need to run tests to see the extent of the damage.

column1: Didn't go as planned? It was a catastrophe. You ruined the lives of four people --
column2: I ruined? With all due respect, I told you to abort --

column1: Abort? Reed, I put my company, my name, billions of dollars on the line, and I will not let you make me look like a fool --
column2: Victor, if we could understand what happened to us --

column1: What are you doing here?
column2: What I should have done a long time ago. Applications and patents, Reed. This all belongs to me.

column1: But I'm not done with the machine --
column2: Which is precisely the point. Analysis is over. It's time for action. My men could have mass-produced this by now.

column1: It's just business.
column2: I think you both know my Director of Genetic Research, Susan Storm.

column1: Surprised I agreed to Reed's proposal?
column2: I understand the business reasons.

column1: It's been a good two years, Victor... The company's accomplished so much.
column2: Right, of course, the company... But you see, I've come to realize all the accomplishments in the world mean nothing without someone to share them with --

column1: Uh, Victor, I hope I haven't done something to make you think...
column2: Sue, I've lived my life unafraid of taking big steps. And this is the biggest step yet. If it helps, think of this as a promotion. A merger of sorts...  Four little words that can change our lives...

column1: What are you doing?
column2: Raising the shields.

column1: What's going on?
column2: Victor, are you feeling alright?

column1: Victor, I'm sorry I --
column2: Just find him.

column1: Victor, your scar --
column2: I told you, I'm fine. It's you I'm worried about.

column1: I'm sorry I didn't get a chance to --
column2: Please, no apologies. I've arranged for your things to be moved to one of my condos. You'll have round-the clock care.

column1: You said it was urgent.
column2: It is. There's something we need to talk about. Something I need to ask you...

column1: Victor, wait, slow down a second. I want you to know I appreciate everything you've done for me, but I just don't --
column2: Susan. What are you doing?

column1: He's working round the clock. But the data needs to be tested, analyzed before --
column2: Same old Reed. All analysis, no action. Wasn't that the problem with you two?

column1: If these molecules aren't stable, they could make us worse, maybe even kill us.
column2: Then why is Reed dragging his feet? Maybe he likes having his prize specimen under glass...  It's ironic, isn't it? You're finally the perfect woman for him... because you're his science project.

column1: Please don't make this personal --
column2: Oh, I think you already have.

column1: 'Scuse me.
column2: I know it can't be easy. Life hasn't changed that much for Reed, Sue and Johnny. At least they can go out in public. But for you? People staring. Whispering behind your back...

column1: If you're trying to cheer me up you're doing a helluva job --
column2: I'm just saying, I know what it's like to lose something you love. To see it slip away, and know it's never coming back.

column1: Reed's gonna fix me up --
column2: For your sake I hope you're right. I'm sorry if that sounds a little skeptical.

column1: You were with him at the end.
column2: Yes.

column1: I longed to be with him. But I wanted his final moments to have peace. I could see you were a friend to him.
column2: What is that to you? Evil as you are.

column1: I am as he made me. In his own image.
column2: You drove him to his torment.

column1: And he drove me to mine.
column2: Then why weep for him?

column1: I've never been shown a kindness. Show me one now.
column2: What kindness?

column1: Nice.
column2: The music? Or the fire?

column1: I'm glad you finally came to the door. A man shouldn't have to scurry in the shadows.
column2: Better that way... for me.

column1: Why?
column2: I'm... very, very ugly. People are afraid. Except you.

column1: It can't be as bad as that.
column2: Worse.

column1: You're an outcast.
column2: Yes. I have been seeking my friends.

column1: Friends? Do they live around here?
column2: Yes. Very close

column1: I have been... afraid. Afraid... they will hate me... because I am so very ugly... and they are so very beautiful
column2: People can be kinder than you think.

column1: Come warm yourself if you like.
column2: You speak.

column1: Yes, I speak. And read. And think... and know the ways of Man.  I've been waiting for you. Two months now.
column2: How did you find me?

column1: The letters in your journal. That and a geography book.  Your Elizabeth sounds lovely.
column2: Kill me and have done with it.

column1: Kill you? Hardly that.
column2: Then why am I here? What did you want with me?

column1: More to the point, why am I here? What did you want with me?  What does one say to one's Maker, having finally met him face to face? Milton gave it voice.  Did I request thee, Maker, from my clay to mould me Man? Did I solicit thee from Darkness to promote me?
column2: Fine words from a child killer. You who murdered my brother.

column1: Your crime... as well as mine.
column2: How dare you. You're disgusting and evil.

column1: Evil?  Do you believe in evil?
column2: I see it before me.

column1: Why, Victor? Why? What were you thinking?
column2: There was something at work in my soul which I do not understand.

column1: What of my soul? Do I have one? Or was that a part you left out?  Who were these people of which I am comprised? Good people? Bad people?
column2: Materials. Nothing more.

column1: In which part of me did this knowledge reside? In these hands? In this mind? In this heart?  And reading and speaking. Not things learned... so much as things remembered.
column2: Trace memories in the brain, perhaps.

column1: Stolen memories. Stolen and hazy. They taunt me in my dreams. I've seen a beautiful woman lying back and beckoning for me to love her. Whose woman was this? I've seen boys playing, splashing about in a stream. Whose childhood friends were these?  Who am I?
column2: I don't know.

column1: What can I do?
column2: There is something I want.  A friend.

column1: Friend?
column2: A companion. A female. Like me, so she won't hate me.

column1: Like you? Oh, God, you don't know what you're asking.
column2: I do know that for the sympathy of one living being, I would make peace with all.  I have love in me the likes of which you can scarcely imagine. And rage the likes of which you would not believe. If I cannot satisfy the one, I will demonically indulge the other. That choice is yours.  You're the one who set this in motion, Frankenstein.

column1: And if I consent?
column2: We'd travel north, my bride and I. To the furthest reaches of the Pole, where no man has ever set foot. There we would live out our lives. Together.  No human eye would ever see us again. This I vow.

column1: Soon?
column2: Yes. I want this over and done with.

column1: Why... her?
column2: Her body pleases me.

column1: What is this?
column2: A brain. Extremities.

column1: This was not taken from a grave.
column2: What does it matter? She'll live again. You'll make her.

column1: You will honor your promise to me!
column2: I will not! Kill me now!

column1: She's beautiful.
column2: She's not for you.

column1: GET AWAY FROM HER! SHE'S MINE!
column2: SHE'LL NEVER BE YOURS! SHE SAID MY NAME! SHE REMEMBERS!

column1: Poor William! What indignant tears!
column2: There, there... shhh...

column1: That's the nature of all progress, William. Don't let your brother sway you otherwise.
column2: Quite right!

column1: Elizabeth, really! He's quite mad!
column2: Scandalous! What would your dear mother say?

column1: You dance so beautifully together.
column2: And you look so lovely.

column1: Must've been a terrible row.
column2: He was almost expelled for calling one of his professors a "pompous...  Fellow..."

column1: Nothing. Still nothing.
column2: It's been months. It's not like him.

column1: Something's wrong. I know it.  I've heard rumors of cholera spreading south from Hamburg.
column2: So have I

column1: I should go. I should leave today.
column2: Elizabeth. If it's true, travel into Germany would be banned. You'd never get near Ingolstadt.  Besides, they're only rumors.

column1: And not a word of them to Father. He's agitated enough not hearing from Victor.
column2: Read him one of the old letters and rephrase it. We'll say it came today. It'll set his mind at ease.

column1: Are you all right?
column2: Fine.

column1: He always was opinionated.
column2: He set things right with a proper apology... and now they've put him in charge of dissection lab!

column1: What does it say?
column2: Let this locket be a token of the vow we took the night I left.  He's coming home to marry me.

column1: Have you seen Willie?
column2: Is he not back yet?

column1: Claude rode over there to see if held lost track of time. They say he never arrived.
column2: It's far too late for him to still be out.

column1: Don't cry, Elizabeth.
column2: Aren't you?

column1: Are you sure it can't hurt us?
column2: Nothing can. Not ever.

column1: How could all my father's knowledge and skill fail to save her?
column2: It's not ours to decide. All that live must die. It's God's will.

column1: What kind of God is He to will this?
column2: She was mother to me as well. But ours is the job of the living. It's up to us now to hold this family together. We must think of Father and be strong for him.  I cannot do that alone.

column1: God took her from us.
column2: He left a beautiful gift in her place. A baby boy. To cherish and love as our very own. Your brother

column1: Victor, have a care! You'll make him dizzy!
column2: The world is a dizzying place.

column1: Oh, do give him here! He needs to be comforted and held!
column2: He needs to vent his outrage to the skies! Make yourself heard, Willie! Learning to walk is not an easy thing! Why should it be so?

column1: Don't listen, Willie. Progress is a feast to be consumed. Women would have you believe you must walk before you can run. Or run before you can waltz!
column2: Give me that child before you fill his head with drivel!

column1: Smell the air. Wonderful.
column2: Quite a send-off, isn't it?

column1: Father's so proud.
column2: And you?

column1: Prouder still. You'll be the handsomest student there.
column2: I'll have to do better than that.

column1: You will.  What do you want, Victor?
column2: To be the best there ever was. To push our knowledge beyond our dreams... to eradicate disease and pestilence... to purge mankind of ignorance and fear...

column1: I've loved you all my life
column2: All my life I've known.

column1: This feels... incestuous.
column2: Is that what makes it so delicious?

column1: Brother and sister still?
column2: I wish to be your husband.

column1: I wish to be your wife.
column2: Then come with me to Ingolstadt. Marry me now.

column1: If only I could. But one of us must stay. Father's not strong. Willie's just a child. Who can look after them in your absence? Who can run the estate?
column2: Only you.

column1: You make me weak.
column2: Not as weak as I.

column1: Our decision. Together.
column2: Your decision. For us.

column1: I give you my soul...
column2: ...until our wedding night. When our bodies will join.

column1: Victor. I love you,
column2: Elizabeth. My more than sister.

column1: My mind was not playing tricks. He was there in the storm... gloating over his crimes... challenging me to come.
column2: But why risk yourself? Hasn't this family suffered enough?

column1: I've no choice
column2: If what you say is true, it is a matter for the police!

column1: Do you know this man? Is there something between you?
column2: I know only that he is a killer. And I shall bring back his carcass.

column1: I thought I'd never see you again!
column2: I'm all right. I'm safe,

column1: What sort of task?
column2: It's not something I can explain now. Perhaps someday.

column1: What of our marriage? Victor, we've had so much tragedy. I want this family to live again.
column2: So do I.

column1: We need each other now, I need your comfort and strength, not separation and solitude.
column2: A month at most, that's all I ask.  Elizabeth, please. Things have not yet resolved. I must take steps to see that they do. For our family's sake. For our sake.  You are life itself. We shall seal our vow. The moment I am done.

column1: No. Not tomorrow, not next week, Marry me today.
column2: Why the change? What about your work?

column1: It was misguided and pointless. Is your answer yes?
column2: It is

column1: We'll leave this afternoon, right after the ceremony. Pack only what you need.
column2: Does this have something to do with that man you saw?

column1: Yes. We're in danger here. Every moment we stay.
column2: Victor, tell me why! Trust me!

column1: Brother and sister no more.
column2: Now husband and wife.

column1: I remember the first time I ever saw you. Crossing the floor of the grand ballroom with my parents at your side. So beautiful even then.
column2: I have been waiting for this ever since.

column1: Victor!
column2: Open this door for no-one!

column1: It's going to ram us.
column2: It wouldn't dare.

column1: Captain, I implore you. The men are frightened and angry. They want your assurance.
column2: They knew the risks when they signed on. I've come too far to turn back now.

column1: A warming wind.
column2: This ice will break yet.  How's our guest?

column1: He died. Raving about phantoms. He was mad, poor devil.  Gather a detail. Have the body removed from my cabin.
column2: Aye, Captain.

column1: I'm quite serious. Look at all the charity and clinic work we do. Up until thirty years ago, the concept of vaccine was unheard of.
column2: You're saying all disease will eventually be eradicated?

column1: I'm convinced. Not by treating symptoms, but by diving nature's most jealously-guarded secrets.
column2: Do you foresee this happening in our lifetimes?

column1: No. But someday.
column2: Thank goodness. We'd be out of work.

column1: Professor?
column2: Oh God.

column1: I was just clearing my throat.
column2: Very well then.

column1: I am not mad.
column2: As a march hare.

column1: Are you having me on?
column2: Of course I am. It pays to humor the insane.

column1: Henry Clerval.
column2: Victor, Victor Frankenstein.

column1: Do you really think I'm mad?
column2: Come now. Magnus? Agrippa? Next thing you know, you'll be teaching toadstools to speak.

column1: Rich old ladies and their daughters?
column2: Can you think of a better reason?

column1: Quite a few.
column2: Do me a favor then...  ...keep them to yourself.

column1: The entire school heard it. It wasn't something one could miss.
column2: You're a comfort to me, Henry.

column1: What now? Writing about it in your journal won't help.
column2: It's a letter to my father.

column1: Now you've got him started.
column2: These are exciting times, Henry. We're entering an era of amazing breakthroughs. Look at Edward Jenner. He wasn't content to bleed people with leeches, he pioneered a new frontier of thought

column1: ...yes, and thanks to him, smallpox has been virtually eliminated. I've heard this speech before.
column2: But you haven't listened, Never in history has so much seemed possible. We're on the verge of answers undreamt of... but only if we have the courage to ask the questions.

column1: Only you would think of that!
column2: Somebody has to!

column1: And here's to Him. Everything in moderation, Frankenstein.
column2: Nothing in moderation, Clerval.

column1: They just caught the man who did it.
column2: He was a frightened soul who acted out of fear and ignorance.

column1: They'll hang him all the same.
column2: Good. I'll be there to hear his worthless neck snap.

column1: Keep your voice down. You don't know what you're saying.
column2: It was wrong, Henry! It shouldn't have happened! The bastard deserves to die.

column1: You're making a scene!
column2: Why Waldman? He of all people should have cheated death!

column1: You can't. Death is God's will!
column2: I resent God's monopoly.

column1: That's blasphemy!
column2: Blasphemy be damned! Waldman spent his life trying to help people!

column1: All the more reason for us to continue his work with the poor!
column2: No. He had more important work.

column1: Victor. This has got to stop.  Nobody's seen you in months. You haven't attended a single class.
column2: I've been preoccupied.

column1: We all know how hard you took Waldman's death. Even Krempe is sympathetic. But it is time to move on. It is time to concern yourself with life.
column2: That is my concern.  I'm involved in something just now. I want to finish it in Waldman's memory.

column1: How much longer?
column2: Few months perhaps. I'm gathering the raw materials even now.

column1: This is a bad time, Henry. I'm busy just now. What do you want?
column2: Things have gone worse with this cholera outbreak. Thousand new cases a day now. Classes have been suspended. University's shut down.

column1: Yes? And?
column2: Listen to what I'm saying. The militia's arriving to quarantine the city. Most of us are getting out while we still can.

column1: Thank God your fever broke.  Slowly, now. Just a sip.  I've been worried we might lose you. It's been touch-and-go for a week.
column2: A... week?

column1: We feared cholera. Turned out to be pneumonia, brought on by nervous exhaustion and some idiot running around in a storm.
column2: Is that your diagnosis?

column1: Mine and Professor Krempe's.  We've been trading off nursing you in shifts. The rest of the time we're out working with the cholera victims. It's his turn for that just now.
column2: You've been going round-the-clock?

column1: We catch a few hours sleep where we can. Usually here at your bedside.
column2: Everything in moderation, Clerval.

column1: It's the down-and-outs I pity most. Those who can't fend for themselves. They'll be dead by the thousands before this is done. They don't stand a chance out there.
column2: No. They don't.

column1: Quite a place.
column2: Thank you, Henry.

column1: For what?
column2: This. My home. My family.  If not for you, I'd be dead in a burial pit somewhere.

column1: What happened up there?
column2: I didn't find what I was looking for.

column1: Are you sure you'll be all right?
column2: Yes, don't worry. I'll look after your father. You look after her.

column1: I'll be back as soon as I've got her far away and safe. We'll hunt this fiend down together.
column2: Only if you'll tell me who he is.

column1: All that I once loved lies in a shallow grave. By my hand.
column2: Let it go.

column1: Yes. I took refuge in the barn. Wouldn't you? Lost in the storm? Freezing and wet? I was exhausted and could search no longer.
column2: And is it true, Miss Moritz, that you love Victor Frankenstein? That your heart was broken?  Answer the question. Do you love Victor Frankenstein?

column1: I have always loved him.
column2: Is it also not true that you murdered his brother William in a misdirected crime of passion?

column1: Murder Willie? In my heart, he was our child. Victor's and mine. Such a thing could never have entered my mind.
column2: So you have claimed. Yet you have no explanation for this.  The locket last seen in the hands of the poor murdered child was found hidden in your dress the morning following the murder. The locket you so coveted.  How did it come to be in your possession?

column1: In science, the letter of fact is the letter of law. Our pursuit is as dogmatic as any religious precept. Think of yourselves as disciples of a strict and hallowed sect. Someday you may be priests... but only if you learn the scripture chapter and verse.  Any questions?
column2: But surely, Professor, you don't intend we disregard the more... philosophical works.

column1: Philosophical?
column2: Those which stir the imagination as well as the intellect. Paracelsus, for one.

column1: Paracelsus?
column2: Or Albertus Magnus. Cornelius Agrippa...

column1: What is your name?
column2: Victor Frankenstein, sir.  Of geneva.

column1: You seem to be adapting well to the approved curriculum.
column2: Despite the lack of challenge.

column1: Professor Waldman.
column2: Victor, explain yourself.

column1: Krempe has a way of provoking my temper.
column2: You have a way of provoking his.  I've been watching you. You seem impatient with your studies.

column1: To say the least. I came here to expand my mind, but honest inquiry seems strangled at every turn. All we do is cling to the old knowledge instead of seeking the new.
column2: You disdain accepted wisdom?

column1: Preposterous.
column2: I once saw it done, as a boy in Canton. My parents were missionaries. The cure was nothing short of miraculous.  I've never forgotten it. Been fascinated ever since.

column1: Electricity.
column2: It's utterly fantastic! This is the sort of thing I'm talking about! We should be learning this!

column1: Why? God alone knows what it means. Until it has proven value, it's nothing more than a ghoulish parlor trick. Hardly fit for the classroom.
column2: But the possibilities. Combining ancient knowledge with new? Something like this could change our fundamental views!

column1: It is a thrilling direction to explore. Thrilling and dangerous.  Nature can be wonderful and terrible. Science is not a realm for the reckless
column2: I doubt that decision is still mine to make.

column1: "...a sincere and heartfelt apology which you will then read aloud to him before the assembled student body and faculty.
column2: Why?

column1: Re-configure the leads?
column2: Numbers four and twelve directly into the nervous system?

column1: Victor. He was trying to be gracious.
column2: The strain was evident.

column1: I tell you what we need, my friends. Forget the symptoms and diseases. What we need is a vaccine for death itself.
column2: Oh, now you have gone too far. There's only one God, Victor.

column1: You're awake. I've prepared some broth. It'll help restore you.
column2: I'm... dying.

column1: Frostbite. Gangrene. A simple diagnosis.
column2: Are you a physician?

column1: How is it you come to be here?
column2: There's a startling question, coming from you.  I'm captain of this ship. We sailed from Archangel a month ago, seeking a passage to the North Pole.

column1: Ah. An explorer.
column2: Would-be. I'm plagued with my share of difficulties just at the moment.

column1: I heard.
column2: I can't say I blame them. We're trapped in this ice and bedeviled by some sort of... creature.

column1: Creature? A... human like creature?
column2: You know of it?

column1: Your men are right to be afraid.
column2: Then explain it, whatever it is. It could save the voyage. I've spent years planning this. My entire fortune.

column1: You'd persist at the cost of your own life? The lives of your crew?
column2: Lives are ephemeral. The knowledge we gain, the achievements we leave behind... those live on.

column1: Do you share my madness?
column2: Madness?

column1: We are kindred, you and I. Men of ambition. Let me tell you all that I have lost in such pursuits. I pray my story will come to mean for you all that is capricious and evil in man.
column2: Who are you?

column1: That's cuz I'm married to you.
column2: Shut up. How can you eat like that?

column1: I'm telling you he's dirt. He's a douche bag, gutter slime, dog crap, puke chunks...
column2: Hey, hey! I'm eating here!

column1: Audrey's going to stay with us tonight.
column2: Great. See ya then.

column1: Who the hell are all these people?
column2: What? I just couldn't just let them sleep in the street.

column1: Where's Audrey?
column2: In the bedroom. Crying her eyes out because of you.

column1: What?
column2: All that "you gotta be vicious" stuff you filled her head with.

column1: Me!? You where the one...
column2: Go in there. Talk to her.

column1: I like that image.
column2: You know how I spent last weekend? Walking his damned dog.

column1: Animal, you don't think that's true, do you?
column2: Nice guys finish last. First rule of the jungle.

column1: That why you dumped him?
column2: No! I just couldn't see myself with some boring egg head who spends his summer picking apart cockroaches. I wanted to have some adventure, some fun...

column1: How long where you and dis guy goin' steady?
column2: Nearly four years...

column1: Great stuff, Animal. Weren't you scared?
column2: Sure I was. I thought Lucy was gonna kill me.

column1: He stole my report! That's my report!
column2: We know, Audrey.

column1: You okay?
column2: It's all my fault. What have I done, Animal? What have I become? Look at me. This isn't me. I don't do things like this.

column1: Yeah, I just screwed up with the only man who ever really cared about me.
column2: Didn't you tell me he left for the airport?

column1: Yeah. Why are you asking?
column2: I just saw him. He's with a bunch of guys who want to sneak into the city tonight.

column1: My God. He's going after the nest.
column2: Perfect! You wanted a story, well, baby, you got one.

column1: Animal, I can't.
column2: Look, you want to make it up to your friend? Well if he's right, this is your chance.

column1: What are you doing?
column2: Lucy'd kill me if she knew.

column1: What are you doing?
column2: It's the maintenance entrance. Runs along the side of the tunnel. When they repaired it last year I worked on a piece about it.

column1: Don't you think we have enough?
column2: Yes. Definitely. Definitely enough.

column1: Think we can fit up in there?
column2: Only one way to find out.

column1: He's not going to do it.
column2: Oh yes he will.

column1: Cut uptown, take 8th to 57th then cut up Broadway.
column2: You're crazy, go to the east side and take the park avenue to the JFK.

column1: What are you talking about? The east side is always faster.
column2: But we can get to the west side faster.

column1: Audrey, did you take the tape out of the camera?
column2: No.

column1: I'll take them all.
column2: You must have quite some harem.

column1: Audrey?! Is that you? Hi, hello. You look, wow, uh, how've you been?
column2: It's good to see you, Nick.

column1: So you made it.
column2: What?

column1: You're a reporter. That's what you always wanted to be, right? I'm happy for you. Really, I am.
column2: Yeah, well...

column1: So, you still picking apart cockroaches?
column2: No, I'm into earthworms now. You wouldn't be interested. They're real "boring" creatures. Very reliable, dependable, no surprises...

column1: You're still mad at me, aren't you?
column2: You just left me without a phone call, a letter, nothing. All this time. Yeah, I guess I'm still a little mad.

column1: That was eight years ago. Some people change, you know.
column2: Most people don't.

column1: Wait. I'm sorry. You're right. Eight years is a long time. Can I offer you a cup of tea?
column2: Sure. I'd like that.

column1: I still can't believe it. How does a guy go from an anti-nuke activists to working for the Nuclear Regulatory Commission?
column2: When you and I use to attend rallies in college, we helped to create awareness. But from the inside now I can actually effect change.  I never lost my idealism.

column1: And exactly what changes are you trying to effect?
column2: I have this theory that we're inadvertently creating new species as a direct result of what we've done to nature.

column1: And you think this creature is one of them?
column2: Yes. The first of its kind. I found this blood sample earlier this evening...

column1: Blood sample? How close did you get to that thing?
column2: I got pretty close.

column1: ...he's pregnant.
column2: Are you sure?

column1: Well, obviously these tests weren't designed for this but fundamentally they're looking for the same hormonal patterns that would indicate pregnancy.
column2: I don't get it. If it's the first of its kind, how can it be pregnant?

column1: The ultimate expression of evolution, it reproduces asexually. Think about it, all kinds of creatures have been known to travel great distances for reproduction. That's why he came to New York. Like every species of insufficient progenitors, he's nesting!
column2: Nesting?

column1: Is this cause of me? Because of the story?
column2: Well what the hell did you think was going to happen?

column1: You never said it was off the record.
column2: I shouldn't have to, Audrey. You're supposed to be my friend. I trusted you.

column1: I didn't mean for it to turn out like this.  Look, I lied to you. I'm not a reporter. When we broke up and I came out to New York I was so sure I'd make it. But I haven't. That's why I needed this story so bad. I just couldn't tell you I'm a failure.
column2: So you thought that made it okay to steal my tapes?

column1: What are you doing here?
column2: I thought you said there'd only be a dozen eggs.

column1: Circuits are overloaded.
column2: I know a way. I know how you can get a message out of here.

column1: Come on, the broadcast booth is right over here.
column2: How do you know?

column1: The network is on an intranet. It's a direct feed into our computer system.
column2: Your station won't have any easier time contacting the military than I did.

column1: If the military are listening, they must immediately destroy this building before they can escape.
column2: Oh my God! They're coming!

column1: Are you okay?
column2: Somehow I never thought your life was this exciting.

column1: You'd be surprised.
column2: Really? I'd like to find out.

column1: Who was that French guy, anyway.
column2: Oh, just some insurance guy.

column1: And I'm supposed to remind you to call him on all of Caiman's expense p.o.'s.
column2: Speak of the devil.

column1: My life sucks.
column2: Oh, please, your life doesn't suck. His life sucks.

column1: I can't believe he put the moves on me. After everything I've done for him.
column2: He's scum! As far as he's concerned you're just a pair of breasts that talk.

column1: It's Nick! I know that guy. I know him!
column2: Who is he?

column1: Did Romeo have a name?
column2: Nick Tatopoulos.

column1: Four years. Girl, I'm surprised he didn't ask you to marry him.
column2: That's the problem. He did.

column1: What the hell are you doing?
column2: Remember my friend we saw on t.v.?

column1: Your old sweetheart?
column2: Yeah, well he just turned up in New Jersey at the military command post. Somehow all this is related to what happened down in Panama. There's a story here. I know it. You got any tape or glue?

column1: Wish me luck!
column2: Audrey, I don't think this is a very good idea. Caiman finds out and he'll have your job.

column1: Hey, do you have any glue in your bag?
column2: What's it to you?

column1: Can I use some?
column2: What do I get?

column1: The warm feeling of helping your fellow man.
column2: Five bucks.

column1: Did you talk with Humphries?
column2: This is not the place...

column1: Just tell me, did you talk with him?
column2: He said he'd consider it. It's between you and Rodriguez.

column1: Mr. Caiman, you're married.
column2: And you're beautiful...

column1: Mr. Caiman...
column2: Call me Charlie.

column1: Mr. Caiman, I've been doing extra research for you after hours and weekends for nearly a year. And I've never asked for anything but this job is really important to me. I'm too old to be an assistant anymore. I need to know this job is going someplace.
column2: So have dinner with me tonight.

column1: I can't.
column2: It's your choice.

column1: Caiman, wait. Take me with you.
column2: What?

column1: I've got something on this. I know a guy on the inside with the military...
column2: Not now. You got my bag?

column1: You don't understand, I can get us information...
column2: Listen, this is the time when the big boys have to go to work, okay Honey?

column1: We did it! We've got the exclusive! Way to go, Audrey!
column2: We? I don't think so.

column1: I want that story, Audrey. Remember you work for me.
column2: Not anymore. Mr. Caiman, I quit.

column1: Hi. Nick Tatopoulos...
column2: Ah, Elsie Chapman, paleontologist.

column1: Three years digging up worms in Chernobyl? How did Mrs. Tatopoulos handle it?
column2: Oh, I'm not married.

column1: Really? A girlfriend then?
column2: No. Perhaps I work too much.

column1: Not for a long time, now.
column2: Well, I think you're cute.

column1: Hence the radiation.
column2: More than that. I believe this is a mutated aberration, a hybrid from the fall out in that region.

column1: Evacuate Manhattan? That's over three million people. Has that ever been done before?
column2: I don't think so.

column1: I'm sorry about all this.
column2: Me too.

column1: Make sure they find that nest before it's too late.
column2: I'll try.

column1: Merde!
column2: Allez, allez!

column1: They will set the trap at thirty minutes to ten.
column2: That is when we will go in.

column1: We've secured the doors on both levels.
column2: Where's Luc and Pierre?

column1: They didn't make it.
column2: Nick, my men and I will hold them here. You will have to go and get help!

column1: When we learned he could burrow his way through the tunnels we realized he could be out of the quarantined zone.
column2: Christ. How many tunnels lead off the island?

column1: Only five, Sir. We've checked them all. He hasn't used any of them.
column2: Have them sealed off.

column1: And how should we do that, Sir?
column2: Fill them with cement, brick them up, put land mines in them, bombs, I don't know, just make sure that goddamned thing doesn't leave the island!

column1: Who are they? Lieutenant, get those people away from there.
column2: They are with me!

column1: CHARGEURES, property and casualty insurance. We are preparing a report.
column2: You're fast.

column1: That is our job.
column2: Well your people are getting in the way of my job.

column1: Major, what do you think could have done this?
column2: Get your people out of there or I will.

column1: Dr. Niko Topopolosis?
column2: It's Tatopoulos.

column1: Right. The worm guy.  Can someone get those people off the beach?
column2: Excuse me, would you mind telling me what the hell I'm doing here?

column1: You didn't answer my question. In fact, for the last 18 hours no one has answered any of my questions.
column2: We have a situation on our hands that requires your particular expertise.

column1: Look, I may work for the Nuclear Regulatory Commission but accidents and spills are not my field.
column2: We know.

column1: Do you know that you just interrupted a three year study of the Chernobyl earthworm?
column2: Yeah, you're the worm guy.

column1: The radioactive contamination in that area altered the earthworm's DNA! You have any idea what that means?
column2: No, but I have the feeling I'm about to find out.

column1: Seventeen percent, huh? Sounds big.
column2: They're enormous! A new species created by man's recklessness. That's what I've been trying to tell you, I'm only a biologist. I take radioactive samples and study them.

column1: What sample?
column2: You're standing on it.

column1: That was a footprint. I was standing inside a footprint.
column2: That's right.

column1: But there's no animal in the world that can make prints like that? Is there?
column2: We're hoping you're going to help us figure that out.

column1: Somebody must have seen it.
column2: It happened so fast no one knew what hit them 'til is was over.

column1: The radiation is not an anomaly, it's the clue. This creature is far too unique on every level to be some lost dinosaur.
column2: Don't tell me why it's not, tell me what the hell it is.

column1: You know, he's not an enemy trying to evade you. He's just an animal.
column2: What are you suggesting?

column1: Well, yes. I did. Clearly he was injured and bled.
column2: You see, all we need to do is get a better shot at it with weapons that don't rely on heat seeking...

column1: No, it reproduces asexually. That's why we must find the nest. If we don't, dozens will be born, each one capable of laying eggs of its own. Very quickly we could be looking at an enormous population.
column2: So after we kill the creature we'll begin a search for the nest.

column1: You gave them the tape?
column2: No, it's still in my tent. It's...oh my God, she took it.

column1: We think there's a strong reason to believe it may be hiding inside one of the buildings within the sequestered area.
column2: But you don't know for sure!

column1: General Anderson, the problem was the terrain. If we lure him out into a more open area such as this portion of Central Park...  We should be able to take him down.
column2: Last time you didn't even scratch it!

column1: Do you have any idea what's going on out there? The phones are ringing off the hook with people screaming to be let back into the city.
column2: We're sending divers into the river now to retrieve the body.

column1: Organize a search party. I want a complete sweep of the entire city and subway system.
column2: You don't have the authority to do that.
