column1: Are you looking for this?
column2: Thanks.

column1: Do I know you?
column2: We've met before.

column1: SDECE, Service de Documentation Exterieure et de Contre-Espionnage. Agent Phillip Raymond.
column2: Sounds like a big company.

column1: It's the French Secret Service.
column2: Oh.

column1: We have learned that your American friends have decided not to look for the creature's nest.
column2: Are you sure? How do you know?

column1: We know.
column2: Why are you telling this to me?

column1: I need you to trust me.
column2: Why do you need that?

column1: I need your trust if you're to help me find the nest.
column2: Oh, my bags. I've checked them in.

column1: How did you get all of this stuff into the country?
column2: This is America. There is nothing you can not buy.

column1: So why all the secrecy? Why aren't you guys working with the US military?
column2: I am not permitted to speak of such things.

column1: I am a patriot. I love my country. Can you understand that?
column2: Sure.

column1: It is my job to protect my country. Sometimes I must even protect it from itself. From mistakes we have made. Mistakes that we do not want the world to know about.
column2: Your talking about the nuclear testing in the Pacific.

column1: Here. 23rd street subway station. Where we first found the fish. With a little luck, this will lead us right to it.
column2: So you're in?

column1: What's with the chewing gum?
column2: Makes us look more American.

column1: They've turned off the ventilation system. They're calling him to dinner.
column2: Let's hope we are not the hors d'oeuvres.

column1: Three eggs. I thought there would be more.
column2: You were right.

column1: I think we should leave now.
column2: Good idea.

column1: Contact the military and get them to send a bomber to blow up this building before these things escape.
column2: How do I do that?

column1: What'd they say?
column2: I can't get through. I don't know what's wrong.

column1: Who the hell are you?
column2: It's okay. I know her.

column1: Hello?
column2: It's Raymond.

column1: I understand.
column2: I just wanted to say, au revoir and thank you for your help, my friend.

column1: Dr. Lazarus... I hope that I'm not breaching protocol but.. I am so very humbled to stand in your presence... I have studied your missions extensively... Though I am Thermian, I have lived my life by your philosophy, by the code of the Mak'tar.
column2: Well good, that's very... nice.

column1: By Grabthar's Hammer, Dr. Lazarus, I-
column2: Don't do that. I'm not kidding.

column1: I'm sorry, sir, I was only-
column2: Just don't.

Our people are being systematically hunted and slaughtered by Roth'h'ar Sarris of Fatu-Krey. Sarris wants the Omega 13. We are to meet in negotiation. However our past efforts in this regard have been nothing short of disastrous. The flames, the death...  Please Captain, you are our last hope.  We have secured a limousine.

column1: But what if Sarris survives?
column2: Oh, I don't think so. I gave him both barrels.

column1: He has a very powerful ship. Perhaps you would like to wait to see the results of-
column2: I would but I am REALLY running late and the 134's a parking lot after 2:00.  But listen, the guy gives you any more trouble, just give a call...

column1: An interstellar vox.
column2: Thanks

column1: How can we thank you, Commander. You- You have saved our people.
column2: It was a lot of fun. You kids are great.

column1: Weapons storage...
column2: It's perfectly safe. I promise.

column1: To our brave guests.  Few in this universe have the opportunity to meet their heroes.  We are blessed to count ourselves among them.
column2: Wherever a distress signal sounds among the stars, we'll be there, this fine ship, this fine crew. Never give up, never surrender!

column1: Mathesar?. .. Has Sarris seen the.. historical records?
column2: NO, Thank God he has not.

column1: Then how did he find out about the device?
column2: Our former Commander was not... Strong.

column1: Former Commander?
column2: I'm sorry. You deserve to be shown.

column1: Commander...
column2: Mathesar, I need you to prepare pods for my crew.

column1: Mathesar? What is that?
column2: It's the Tothian mine field left standing from the Great War of 12185.

column1: A thousand apologies. We have failed you.
column2: You what?.. What are you talking about?

column1: "Deception..." "Lies."
column2: Well... Sort of...

column1: I'm not a Commander, there is no National Space Exploration Administration. There is no snip.
column2: But there it is!...

column1: A model, only as big as this.
column2: But... Inside, I have seen-

column1: Sections of rooms made of plywood. Our Beryllium Sphere was painted wire and plaster. The digital conveyor was Christmas lights... Decorations.  It's all a fake.  I'm not him...  I'm a nothing. A nobody.
column2: But...Why?

column1: The ship is a model... As big as this!... A very clever deception indeed! He oan't oontaln hIs lauchter.  A belle-----TOMMY Set a course for home, lommander?
column2: You can oc that?

column1: You said we do appearances together, or not at all.'
column2: I didn't say that.  I said "wouldn't it be great if we could always, work together." That's what I said.

column1: ... to make sure craft service keeps those little butter cookies, and plenty of them-
column2: And determination.

column1: That's right... Just keep shaking it out... Here, have some gum, It helps.
column2: Wh... Where are we?

column1: What's going on?
column2: I think we're going to exit the space port.

column1: Excuse me?
column2: They designed the ship from watching you. So... Take her out, Lieutenant...

column1: Well, it's... This was a device we...  discovered on an alien planet.  We don't know what it does either.
column2: Why don't you just turn it on and see?

column1: Where?
column2: Just GO! GO! DAMMIT PUNCH GO!

column1: Faster Tommy. Get us out of here!
column2: It's as far as it goes!

column1: Could be this.
column2: Push It. Hold it down.

column1: Do your best, Tommy...
column2: Oh god...

column1: All right, Gwen, Alex, Fred, follow me.  Guy, set up the perimeter. Tommy, you keep a lookout, make a signal if they come back.
column2: What kind of signal?

column1: Anything.
column2: Okay, I'll do this...  "Caw Caw!"

column1: Oh, right, sorry.
column2: Okay, let's go.

column1: Sorry Guys... It just went off.
column2: Good work, Tommy.  Let's go!

column1: Okay... On what?
column2: How about the pig-lizard?

column1: Go for the eyes. Like in episode 22 with-
column2: It doesn't have eyes.

column1: The throat, the mouth... Its vulnerable spots.
column2: It's a ROCK. It doesn't HAVE vulnerable spots!

column1: NO NO NO.
column2: We've got to get out of here.  C'mon, hurry

column1: All right guys... Uh... Gwen and I are going to have to get to the core and shut it down manually. Fred, you and Guy need to get that air valve back on.  Alex, see if you can get the prison doors open downstairs in case Fred and Guy can't get the oxygen back in time.
column2: Jason? What about me? What do I do?

column1: Pedal to the metal Tommy...
column2: Pedal to the metal...

column1: Let's do it, Tommy.
column2: Commander?... Call me Laredo?

column1: Hold course, Laredo!
column2: I'm trying Commander... Everything's a blur, but as long as I stay locked to that vox signal...

column1: Continue forward, sir?
column2: Patience, Lt. . Patience.

column1: Lieutenant Lathe, I confess I am beginning to feel a bit foolish myself. Chasing across the universe to obtain what is, I am now certain, a bauble of fiction. Tell me how best to obliterate this vessel? I would like nothing to remain.
column2: The core could be hardwired to overload without much effort.

column1: Find them.
column2: But sir, my MEN. The core implosion is not reversible...

column1: enerao, I've host them. The maanetlsm o: the field Is disrupting our onstru- ~ait. There they are
column2: Get oacK on their tail.

column1: WHAT? WH
column2: Because they're coming right at us.

column1: Oh, yes, I got in a little late this morning, Janosz.
column2: You know, you are really doing very good work here.  I think soon you may be ready to assist me in some of the more important restorations.

column1: We'll be very sorry to lose you.  Perhaps I could take you to lunch today?
column2: Actually, I'm not eating lunch today.  I have an appointment.  In fact, I'd better go.

column1: Every day I ask you, and every day you've got something else to do.  Do I have bad breath or something?
column2: I'm sorry.  Perhaps some other time.

column1: Janosz?
column2: Hello, Dana.  I happened to be in the neighborhood and I thought I'd stop by to see if everything's all right with you -- you know, with the blackout and everything? Are you okay?  Is the baby all right?

column1: Do you need anything?  You want me to come in?
column2: No, everything's fine.  Honestly.  Thanks anyway.

column1: Okay, just thought I'd check.  Good night, Dana.  Sleep well.  Don't let the bedbugs bite you.
column2: Good night, Janosz.

column1: Dana, aren't you going to introduce me to your friend?
column2: Oh, I'm sorry.  This is Peter Venkman. Peter, Janosz Poha.

column1: What do you want with my baby?
column2: No harm will come to the child.  You might even say it's a privilege.  He will be the vessel for the spirit of Vigo.  And you -- well, you will be the mother of the ruler of the world.  Doesn't that sound nice?

column1: If this is what the world will be like, I don't want to live in it.
column2: I don't believe we have the luxury of choice.

column1: Everybody has a choice.
column2: Not in this case, my dear.  Take a look. That's not Gainsborough's Blue Boy up there. He's Vigo!

column1: Time is running out, Dana.  Soon it will be midnight and the city will be mine -- and Vigo's.  Well, mainly Vigo's.  But we have a spectacular opportunity to make the best of our relationship.
column2: We don't have a relationship.

column1: I know.  Marry me, Dana, and together we will raise Vigo as our son.  There are many perks that come with being the mother of a living god.  I'm sure he will supply for us a magnificent apartment.  And perhaps a car and free parking.
column2: I hate and despise you and everything you stand for with all my heart and soul.  I could never forgive what you've done to me and my child.

column1: Many marriages begin with a certain amount of distance, but after a while I believe we could learn to love each other.  Think about it.
column2: I'd rather not.

column1: Hundreds of people.  Believe me, I didn't imagine this.
column2: I'm not saying you did.  In science we always look for the simplest explanation.

column1: What are you working on, Egon?
column2: I'm trying to determine whether human emotional states have a measurable effect on the psychomagnetheric energy field.  It's a theory Ray and I were working on when we had to dissolve Ghostbusters.

column1: We'll do the happiness index next.  I'd like to bring Ray in on your case, if it's all right with you.
column2: Okay, whatever you think -- but not Venkman.

column1: Oh no.
column2: Do you ever see him?

column1: Occasionally
column2: How is he these days?

column1: Venkman?  I think he was borderline for a while there.  Then he crossed the border.
column2: Does he ever mention me?

column1: This is my address and telephone number. Will you call me?
column2: Certainly.

column1: Egon, I'd rather you didn't mention any of this to Peter if you don't mind.
column2: I won't.

column1: Frank, do you think you could give me a hand with these bags?
column2: I'm not a doorman, Miss Barrett.  I'm a building superintendent.

column1: You're also a human being, Frank.
column2: Okay, okay.  It's not my job, but what the hell.  I'll do you a favor.  He takes the grocery bags from her.

column1: Hiya, Oscar.  What do you say, slugger?
column2: That's a good-looking kid you got there, Ms. Barrett.

column1: Thank you, Frank.  Oh, are you ever going to fix the radiator in my bedroom?  I asked you last week.
column2: Didn't I do it?

column1: No, you didn't, Frank.
column2: Okay, that's no problem.

column1: Hello, Peter.
column2: You know, Dana, I'm very very hurt that you didn't call me first.  I'm still into all this stuff, you know.  Haven't you ever seen my show?

column1: I have.  That's why I didn't call you first.
column2: I can see that you're still very bitter about us, but in the interest of science, I'm going to give it my best shot.  Let's go to work, boys.

column1: So what happened to Mr. Right?  I hear he ditched you and the kid and moved to Europe.
column2: He didn't "ditch" me.  We had some problems, he got a good offer from an orchestra in England and he took it.

column1: He ditched you.  You should've married me, you know.
column2: You never asked me, and every time I brought it up you'd get drowsy and fall asleep.

column1: Men are very sensitive, you know.  We need to feel loved and desired, too.
column2: Well, when you started introducing me as "the old ball and chain," that's when I left.

column1: What do you think?
column2: There's no doubt about it.  He's got his father's looks.  The kid is ugly -- extremely ugly.  And smelly.  You stink!  It's just horrible.  You are the stinkiest baby I ever smelled.  What's his name?

column1: His name is Oscar.
column2: Oscar!  You poor kid!

column1: Peter, this is serious.  I need to know if you think there's anything unusual about him.
column2: Unusual?  I don't know.  I haven't had a lot of experience with babies.

column1: I'll do it.
column2: I'll supervise.

column1: Brings back a lot of sweet memories, doesn't it?  There's our old cash machine.  And the dry cleaners we used to go to.  And the old video store.  We really had some good times, didn't we?
column2: We definitely had a moment or two.

column1: That's where the buggy stopped.
column2: Okay, let's take a look.

column1: I wish I could stay.  I feel personally responsible for you being here.
column2: You are personally responsible.  If I can get conjugal rights, will you visit me at Sing Sing?

column1: Please don't say that.  You won't go to prison.
column2: Don't worry about me.  I'm like a cat.

column1: You mean you cough up hairballs all over the rug?
column2: I'm El Gato.  I always land on my feet.

column1: Good luck.
column2: Thanks.

column1: So this is what you do, huh?
column2: Oh, hello, Peter.

column1: You're really good, you know.
column2: I didn't paint it.  I'm just cleaning it. It's an original Ver Meer.  It's worth about ten million dollars.

column1: I'm sure you didn't come here just to talk about art.
column2: As a matter of fact, I stopped by to tell you that I haven't forgotten your problem and that we're still on the case.

column1: He was also a lunatic and a genocidal madman. I hate this painting.  I've felt very uncomfortable since they brought it up from storage.
column2: Yeah, it's not the kind of thing you'd want to hang in the rec room.  You know what it needs?  A fluffy little white kitten in the corner.

column1: I may be wrong, but I think you've got a little crush on this guy.
column2: Good-bye, Peter.

column1: I'm sorry.  Were you on your way out?
column2: No, I just got in -- a couple hours ago. Come on in.  Are we having a pajama party?

column1: You know, if anyone else told me that, I'd have serious doubts.  But coming from you, I can't honestly say I'm surprised.
column2: I must be losing my mind.  At the museum today I could have sworn that terrible painting of Vigo looked right at me.

column1: Who could blame him?  Were you wearing this nightgown?
column2: I don't know what to do anymore.

column1: This is Joe Namath's old number, you know. You could get a lot of chicks with this. Just don't pee in it.
column2: Peter, what about the bathtub?

column1: We'll take care of that.  Ray, Pete.  Listen, get over to Dana's right away ... Her bathtub pulled a fast one -- tried to eat the kid.
column2: It was full of this awful pink ooze.

column1: Bathroom's right here -- let me just tidy up a few things.
column2: Peter, this is very nice, but you don't have to do any of this, you know.

column1: Be careful on that sofa -- it's a butt-biter. But the bed's good and I just changed the sheets so if you get tired, feel free.  In fact, I think you should definitely plan on spending the night here.
column2: Really?  And how would we handle the sleeping arrangements?

column1: For me it's best if I sleep on my side and you spoon up right behind me with your arms around me.  If we go the other way I'm afraid your hair will be getting in my face all night.
column2: How about you on the sofa and me in bed with the baby.

column1: Or we could do that.
column2: Thank you.  Poor baby.  I think I should put him down now.

column1: Are you all squeaky clean now?
column2: Yes, I'm very clean.  Did they find anything at my apartment?

column1: They didn't find anything?  In the bathtub ... the pink ooze ... nothing?  So, what do I do now?
column2: Now you get dressed and we go out.  I got a babysitter and everything.  Trust me, you need it.

column1: I'm not here to date.  I can't leave Oscar in a strange place with someone I don't know.
column2: It's Janine Melnitz, from my staff.  She's one of my most valuable employees.

column1: Does she know anything about babies?
column2: Janine Melnitz, are you kidding?  Do I have a vase?  I brought some of your clothes.  Wear something intriguing.  I brought along some interesting possibilities.

column1: Did you happen to see some shirts on the floor in here?
column2: I put them in your hamper.  I thought they were dirty.

column1: So -- are you making any New Year's resolutions?
column2: I want to stop getting involved with men who aren't good for me.

column1: Does that start exactly at midnight tomorrow, or could you hold off for a few days maybe?
column2: For one night in your life, do you think it's possible for us to be completely real?

column1: All right, you want to be real?  So tell me why did you dump me?
column2: Oh, Peter, I didn't dump you.  I just had to protect myself.  You really weren't very good for me, you know.

column1: I'm not even good for me.
column2: Why do you say things like that?  You're so much better than you know.

column1: Thank you.  If I had that kind of support on a daily basis, I could definitely shape up by the turn of the century.
column2: So why don't you give me a jingle in the year 2000?

column1: Maybe I should call Janine.
column2: Don't worry.  Janine has a very special way with children.

column1: I think he likes you.  I think I do too.
column2: Finally came to your senses, huh?

column1: That's not true.  It was 1620.
column2: Same difference.

column1: That's a terrible thing to say.
column2: So what?  It's a free country.  Thanks, Lib.

column1: Hi, Ray.  It's good to see you.  Thanks for coming.
column2: No problem.  Always glad to help -- and hug.

column1: Is this the spot?
column2: A little to the left.  Right there!  That's where it stopped.

column1: I think we hit the honeypot, boys.  There's something brewing under the street.
column2: Peter, do you think maybe I have some genetic problem or something that makes me vulnerable to these supernatural things.

column1: Sorry!
column2: Maybe we should discuss this somewhere else.

column1: According to my sources, the world will end on February 14, in the year 2016.
column2: Valentine's Day.  That's got to be a bummer. Where did you get that date, Elaine?

column1: I received this information from an alien.  I was at the Paramus Holiday Inn, I was having a drink in the bar when he approached me and started talking.  Then he must have used some sort of ray or a mind control device because he made me follow him to his room and that's where he told me about the end of the world.
column2: Your alien had a room in the Holiday Inn?

column1: It may have been a room on the spacecraft made up to look like a room in the Holiday Inn.  I can't be sure, Peter.
column2: No, you can't, and I think that's the whole problem with aliens

column1: Can I help you?
column2: Yeah, you can get your hand off my chest.

column1: I'm Jack Hardemeyer.  I'm the mayor's assistant. What can I do for you?
column2: I'm an old friend of the mayor's.  I just want to say hello to him.

column1: I know who you are, Doctor Venkman.  Busting any ghosts lately?
column2: No, that's what I want to talk to the mayor about.  We did a little job for the city a while back and we ended up getting sued, screwed and tattooed by deskworms like you.

column1: That's quite a story.
column2: Yeah, I think the Times might be interested, don't you?  The Post might have a lot of fun with it, too.

column1: Before you go running to the newspapers with this, would you consider telling this slime thing to some people downtown?
column2: Now you're talking.

column1: Look, I've had it with you.  Get your stuff together, get back in that clown car and get out of here.  This is a city matter and everything's under control.
column2: Oh, you think so?  Well, I've got news for you.  You've got Dracula's brother-in-law in there and he's got my girlfriend and her kid.  Around about midnight tonight, when you're partying uptown, this guy's going to come to life and start doing amateur head transplants.  And that's just round one.

column1: What is it, honey?
column2: It's that darn ghost again!  I don't know what to do anymore.  He just won't leave us alone.  I guess we'll just have to move.

column1: Who are you going to call?
column2: Ghostbusters.

column1: Oh migod!  I'm sorry.  I didn't mean to do that.  It was an accident.
column2: What are you doing up here?

column1: I was trying to get that smelly green thing. The guys asked me to help out.  I'm like the fifth Ghostbuster.
column2: Why would you want to be a Ghostbuster if you're already an accountant?

column1: Have you made any plans yet?  You know tomorrow is New Year's Eve.
column2: No, I celebrate at the beginning of my corporate tax year which is March first. That way I beat the crowds.

column1: Well, good night, Louis.
column2: Janine, do you feel like maybe getting something to eat on the way home?

column1: I'd like to, but I told Dr. Venkman I'd babysit.  Do you want to babysit with me?
column2: Oh, sure, that sounds great.

column1: I can't believe a person could actually live like this.
column2: So these dwarfs had a limited partnership in a small mining operation and then one day a beautiful princess came to live with them.

column1: It's really not a bad place.  It just needs a woman's touch.
column2: So they bartered room and board in exchange for housekeeping services, which was a good deal for all of them because then they didn't have to withhold tax and social security, which I'm not saying is right but it's just a story, so I guess it's all right.  I can finish this later if you're tired.

column1: You're really good with children, Louis.  I can tell.  Why don't you come here and sit with me?
column2: Okay.

column1: Motherhood is a very natural instinct for me.  I'd like to have a baby myself. Wouldn't you?
column2: Tonight?

column1: Should we go?
column2: I don't think we should leave her alone.

column1: I'm not sure this is such a good idea?  Do they know you're doing this?
column2: Oh, yeah, sure -- no.  But there's really not much to do here and they might need some back-up at the museum.

column1: Pleasure to meet you.  I've seen you on television.
column2: How are you?  What's that you're working on, Johnny?

column1: It's a painting I'm restoring for the new Byzantine exhibition.  It's a self-portrait of Prince Vigo, the Carpathian.  He ruled most of Carpathia and Moldavia in the 17th Century.
column2: Too bad for the Moldavians.

column1: We don't go around altering valuable paintings, Dr. Venkman.
column2: Well, I'd make an exception in this case if I were you.

column1: I'll let you get back to it.  Nice meeting you.
column2: My pleasure.

column1: Dr. Venkman?  Dana is not here.
column2: I know.

column1: Then why have you come?
column2: We got a major creep alert and we're just going down the list.  Your name was first.

column1: You know, I never got to ask you.  Where you from, Johnny?
column2: The Upper West Side.

column1: This is the one that looked at Dana.
column2: It must be the chemical fumes in the studio. People start imagining things --

column1: So you see, everything is in order, is it not?
column2: Not.  Don't leave town and report any change in your address to the proper authorities. We'll be back.

column1: You pitiful, miserable creatures!  You dare to challenge the power of darkness?  Don't you realize what you are dealing with?  He's Vigo!  You are like the buzzing of flies to him.
column2: Oh, Johnny.  Did you back the wrong horse.

column1: I, Vigo, the scourge of Carpathia, the sorrow of Moldavia, command you.
column2: Command me, lord.

column1: I, Vigo, the scourge of Carpathia --
column2: Yes, the scourge --

column1: -- the sorrow of Moldavia --
column2: -- the sorrow --

column1: I command you.
column2: I await the word of Vigo.

column1: The season of evil begins with the birth of the new year.  Bring me the child that I might live again.
column2: Lord Vigo, the mother, Dana, is fine and strong.  I was wondering -- well, would it be possible -- if I bring the baby, could I have the woman?

column1: Keep that up, mister, and I'll find you in contempt.
column2: Sorry, your Honor, but when somebody sets me up like that I can't resist.

column1: You've got to do something!
column2: Who are they?

column1: They're the Scoleri Brothers.  I tried them for murder.  They were electrocuted up at Ossining in '48.  Now they want to kill me.
column2: Maybe they just want to appeal.

column1: These boys aren't playing around.
column2: You've got to stop them.  Please!

column1: The witness is leading him.  Sustained.
column2: Okay, let me rephrase that question.  Didn't you once coach a basketball team for underprivileged children?

column1: Sustained.  Mr. Tully, do you have anything to ask this witness that may have some bearing on this case?
column2: Do I?

column1: Your honor, may I approach the bench?
column2: Yes.

column1: Can I have some of your water?
column2: Get on with it, counselor!

column1: That's it?  That's all you have to say?
column2: Did I forget something?

column1: Come on, Sherm.  You're my cousin.  Do this for me.  I'm begging you.
column2: I can't do it, Louis.  It isn't ethical.  I could lose my license.

column1: Why can't you just have them released? You're a doctor.
column2: I'm a dermatologist.  I can't write orders on the psych ward.

column1: Sherman, I've done lots of favors for you.
column2: Like what?

column1: I got you out of those bad tax shelters.
column2: You were the one who got me in.

column1: I fixed you up with Diane Troxler and she put out, didn't she?
column2: Yeah, I had to give her free dermabrasion for a year.  Forget it, Louis.  I could get in a lot of trouble.

column1: I'm telling you, we're all going to be in big trouble if we don't do something fast. That ghost guy came and took my friend's baby and we got to get it back.  It's just a scared little baby, Sherm.
column2: Then you should go to the police.  I don't believe in any of that stuff.

column1: This is my cousin Sherman.  Sherm, say hello to the Ghostbusters.  I promised him a ride in the car if he got you out.
column2: Hi, it's really great to meet you guys.  I know this sounds weird but once I had a dream that my grandfather was standing at the foot of my bed, but I knew it was impossible because he died and he started to tell me that --

column1: Hey!  Wait!  Okay, I'll meet you there.
column2: I thought you were like the fifth Ghostbuster.

column1: Hi, welcome back to the 'World of the Psychic,' I'm Peter Venkman and I'm chatting with my guest, author, lecturer and of course, psychic, Milton Anglund.  Milt, your new book is called The End of the World.  Isn't that kind of like writing about gum disease.  Yes, it could happen, but do you think anybody wants to read a book about it?
column2: Well, I think it's important for people to know that the world is in danger.

column1: Okay, so can you tell us when it's going to happen or do we have to buy the book?
column2: I predict that the world will end at the stroke of midnight on New Year's Eve.

column1: This year?  That's cutting it a little close, isn't it?  I mean, just from a sales point of view, the book just came out, right?  So you're not even looking at the paperback release for maybe a year.  And it's going to be at least another year after that if the thing has movie-of-the-week or mini-series potential. You would have been better off predicting 1992 or even '94 just to be safe.
column2: This is not just some money-making scheme!  I didn't just make up the date.  I have a strong psychic belief that the world will end on New Year's Eve.

column1: Yes, I did.  We were city champs.
column2: Objection.  Irrelevant and immaterial.

column1: So, Dr. Venkman, please explain to the court why it is you and your co-defendants took it upon yourselves to dig a big hole in the middle of the street.
column2: Seventy-seventh and First Avenue has so many holes already we didn't think anyone would notice.

column1: I'll ask you again, Dr. Venkman.  Why were you digging the hole?  And please remember that you're under oath.
column2: I had my fingers crossed when they swore me in, but I'm going to tell you the truth. There are things in this world that go way beyond human understanding, things that can't be explained and that most people don't want to know about anyway.  That's where we come in.

column1: So what are you saying?  That the world of the supernatural is your special province?
column2: No, I guess I'm just saying that shit happens and somebody has to deal with it.

column1: Egon!
column2: Hello, Venkman.

column1: How've you been?  How's teaching?  I bet those science chicks really dig that big cranium of yours, huh?
column2: I think they're more interested in my epididymis.

column1: I'd like to have a stool specimen
column2: Yeah, you would.  Is that for personal or professional reasons?

column1: What now, Brainiac?
column2: I think we should see if we can find anything abnormal on the street.

column1: That's a thousand million electron volts.
column2: I knew that.

column1: You were supposed to help me with this.
column2: You need the exercise.
