column2: Close -- but definitely wrong.

column1: Nervous?
column2: Yes.  I don't like this.

column1: Well, just 75 more to go.  What's this one?
column2: Two wavy lines?

column1: Hey!  I'm getting a little tired of this.
column2: You volunteered, didn't you?  Aren't we paying you for this?

column1: Yeah, but I didn't know you were going to give me electric shocks.  What are you trying to prove?
column2: I'm studying the effect of negative reinforcement on ESP ability.

column1: I'll tell you the effect!  It pisses me off!
column2: Then my theory was correct.

column1: Hey, Mister!  Can I see those guns?
column2: They're not guns.  They're particle throwers.

column1: Yeah, yeah.  I just want to see 'em.
column2: I couldn't do that.  You might hurt someone.

column1: Wait!  Wait!  Let me ask you something.  If you like shot Superman with those guns, would he feel it or what?
column2: On Earth -- no.  But on Krypton we could slice him up like Oscar Mayer Bologna.

column1: Yes?
column2: Were you recently in the bathroom?

column1: What on earth gave you that idea?
column2: The wet towels, residual moisture on your lower limbs and hair, the redness in your cheeks indicating ...

column1: You're a regular Sherlock Holmes.  Now what do you want?
column2: When you were in the bathroom, did you notice anything that was yellow and unusually smelly?

column1: Oh!  You're here.
column2: What have you got, Egon?

column1: Oh, this is big, Peter.  This is very big. There's definitely something here.
column2: Egon, somehow this reminds me of the time you tried to drill a hole in your head.  Do you remember that?

column1: Spengler, are you serious about actually catching a ghost?
column2: I'm always serious.

column1: Just for your information, Ray, the interest payments alone for the first five years come to over $75,000.
column2: Will you guys relax?  We are on the threshold of establishing the indispensable defense science of the next decade - Professional Paranormal Investigations and Eliminations.  The franchise rights alone will make us wealthy beyond your wildest dreams.

column1: Generally, you don't see that kind of behavior in a major appliance.  What do you think, Egon?
column2: She's telling the truth -- or at least she thinks she is.

column1: Did you see anything?
column2: Didn't see anything,  Didn't get anything. Nice girl - no ghost.  I'm starting to worry.  You said your graph was pointing to something big.  You told me things were going to start popping.

column1: Something was definitely here.
column2: Yeah, I can smell it.

column1: Wait!  Wait!  There's something I forgot to tell you.
column2: What?

column1: Don't cross the beams.
column2: Why not?

column1: Trust me.  It will be bad.
column2: What do you mean "bad?"

column1: It's Peter, Egon.  I've got a problem.
column2: What is it?

column1: I'm with Dana Barrett and she's floating three feet off the bed.
column2: Does she want to be?

column1: I don't think so.  It's more of that Gozer thing.  She says she's the Gatekeeper.  Does that make any sense to you?
column2: Some.  I just met the Keymaster.  He's here with me now.  Venkman?  Are you there?

column1: Yeah, yeah.  I was just thinking.  It probably wouldn't be a good idea for them to get together at this point.
column2: I agree.

column1: All right.  I'll try.
column2: I'll spend the night here and get back first thing in the morning.

column1: He wants to shut down the storage grid.
column2: If you turn that thing off we won't be responsible for the consequences.

column1: Where's the Keymaster?
column2: Oh, shit!

column1: Of course!  Ivo Shandor,  I saw his name in Tobin's SPIRIT GUIDE.  He started a secret society in 1920.
column2: Let me guess -- Gozer Worshippers.

column1: Yes.  After the First World War Shandor decided that society was too sick to survive.  And he wasn't alone.  He had close to a thousand followers when he died.  They conducted rituals, bizarre rituals, intended to bring about the end of the world.
column2: She said he was "the Destructor."

column1: Who?
column2: Gozer.

column1: You talked to Gozer?
column2: Get a grip on yourself, Egon.  I talked to Dana Barrett and she referred to Gozer as the Destructor.

column1: What now?
column2: Full-stream with strogon pulse.

column1: On the count of three!  One ... Two ...
column2: No!  Them!  Shoot them!  Cross the beams.

column1: No!  You said crossing the beams would be BAD.  It'll kill her!  And us!
column2: Life is just a state of mind.

column1: You know, Peter, this could be a past life experience intruding on the present.
column2: Or even a race memory, stored in the collective unconscious.  And I wouldn't rule out clairvoyance or telepathic contact either.

column1: I just realized something.  We've never had a completely successful test with any of the equipment.
column2: I blame myself.

column1: Sorry, Buddy!
column2: We'd better adjust our streams.

column1: Ray!  Where are you?  Are you all right?
column2: God, it's ugly!

column1: It's working!
column2: Easy ... Easy ... I'm going to throw in my trap now.

column1: Set entry grid.
column2: Neutronize.  System shut.

column1: I've got to sleep.
column2: I need two new purge valves.  How's the grid around the storage facility holding up?

column1: What happened??!!!?
column2: The storage facility blew.  This one ...  ... shut off the protection grid.

column1: Look at the structure of the roof cap.  It looks exactly like the kind of telemetry tracker NASA uses to identify dead pulsars in other galaxies.
column2: And look at this, Peter  Cold-riveted girders with selenium cores.

column1: You mean if I stand here and concentrate on the image of Roberto Clemente, Gozer will appear as Roberto Clemente and wipe us out?
column2: That appears to be the case.

column1: Excuse me for a minute.  Ray, I'm right in the middle of something here.  Can you come back in about an hour?
column2: Peter, at 1:40 this afternoon at the main branch of the New York Public Library on Fifth Avenue, ten people witnessed a free-roaming, vaporous, full-torso apparition.  It blew books from shelves at twenty feet away.  Scared the socks off some poor librarian.

column1: Sure.  That's great, Ray.  I think you should get down there right away and check it out.  Let me know what happens.
column2: No, this one's for real, Peter.  Spengler went down there and took some PKE readings. Right off the top of the scale.  Buried the needle.  We're close this time. I can feel it.

column1: Spengler and I have charted every psychic occurrence in the Tri-State area for the past two years.  The graph we came up with definitely points to something big.
column2: Ray, as your friend I have to tell you I think you've really gone around the bend on this ghost stuff.  You've been running your ass off for two years checking out every schizo in the Five Boroughs who thinks he's had an experience.  And what have you seen?

column1: What do you mean by "seen?"
column2: Looked at with your eyes.

column1: Well, I was at an unexplained multiple high-altitude rockfall once.
column2: Uh-huh.  I've heard about the rockfall, Ray. I think you've been spending too much time with Spengler.

column1: What is it?
column2: It looks like a big pair of breasts and a pot belly.

column1: I told you it's real.
column2: What do we do now?

column1: I don't know.  Talk to it.
column2: What do I say?

column1: Anything!  Just make contact.
column2: Hey, Lady?  Lady!  Can you talk?  Who are you?   This is not working.  Think of something else.

column1: "Get her?"  That was your whole plan?  You call that science?
column2: I guess I got a little overexcited.  Wasn't it incredible!  I'm telling you, this is a first.  You know what this could mean to the University?

column1: If you guys are right, if we can actually trap a ghost and hold it somehow, I think I could win the Nobel Prize.
column2: If anyone deserves it, it's Spengler and me. We're doing all the hard research and designing the equipment.

column1: You said you floored 'em at the Regents' meeting.
column2: Ray, I apologize.  I guess my confidence in the Regents was misplaced.  They did this to Galileo, too.

column1: This is like a major disgrace.  Forget M.I.T. or Stanford now ... they wouldn't touch us with a three-meter cattle prod.
column2: You're always so worried about your reputation.  We don't need the University. Einstein did his best stuff while he was working as a patent clerk.'They can't stop progress.

column1: Do you know what a patent clerk makes?  I liked the University.  They gave us money, they gave us the facilities and we didn't have to produce anything!  I've worked in the private sector.  They expect results. You've never been out of college.  You don't know what it's like out there.
column2: Let me tell you, Ray, everything in life happens for a reason.  Call it fate, call it luck, Karma, whatever.  I think we were destined to get kicked out of there.

column1: For what purpose?
column2: To go into business for ourselves.

column1: You'll never regret this, Ray.
column2: My parents left me that house, I was born there.

column1: You're not going to lose the house. Everybody has three mortgages these days.
column2: But at nineteen percent interest!  You didn't even bargain with the guy.

column1: But most people are afraid to even report these things.
column2: Maybe.  But no one ever advertised before.

column1: Wow!  Does this pole still work?
column2: This might do ... I don't know ... it just seems kind of "pricey" for a fixer-upper, don't you think?  We're trying to keep our costs down.  You know how it is when you're starting a new company.

column1: Everybody can relax.  I found the car.  How do you like it?
column2: Do you think it's wide enough?  How much?

column1: Why don't I check out the building?  It may have a history of psychic turbulence.
column2: Good idea.  Were any other words spoken that you remember?

column1: How was your date?
column2: It wasn't a date.  It was an investigation.

column1: They will.
column2: Do you know when that might be?  We're on the brink of a very serious cash-flow problem.

column1: So do I.
column2: No sense worrying about it now.

column1: I'm getting high readings near the air vents.  It must be using the duct system to get around.  See, I told you we'd get something.
column2: So far all we got is a shit smell on the twelfth floor and we almost fried a Puerto Rican bellboy.

column1: Ray -- Something's here.
column2: Where are you, Pete?

column1: Third floor.  Get down here,
column2: Sit tight.  I'm on my way.

column1: It's here, Ray.  It's looking at me.
column2: Don't move.  It won't hurt you.

column1: How do you know?
column2: I don't know.  I'm just guessing.

column1: Boy, that was a rough one.
column2: I can't take much more of this.  The pace is killing me.

column1: Egon, how's the grid around the storage facility holding up?
column2: It's not good, Pete.

column1: I guess they don't build them like they used to, huh?
column2: No!  Nobody ever built them like this!  The architect was either an authentic whacko or a certified genius.  The whole building is like a huge antenna for pulling in and concentrating psychokinetic energy.

column1: Who was the architect?
column2: He's listed on the blueprints as I. Shandor.

column1: It doesn't seem to have slowed him down any.
column2: I don't think it's Shandor.

column1: As a duly-constituted representative of the City of New York, and on behalf of the County and State of New York, the United States of America, the Planet Earth and all its inhabitants, I hereby order you to cease and desist any and all supernatural activity and return at once to your place of origin or next parallel dimension.
column2: Well, that ought to do it.

column1: Agile bastard, isn't he?
column2: Forget the trapping!  Just blast him!

column1: I couldn't help it!  It just popped in there!
column2: What?  What popped in there?

column1: AND YOU CAME UP WITH THAT?
column2: The Stay-Puft Marshmallow Man!  He was on all the packages we used to buy when I was a kid.  We used to roast Stay-Puft marshmallows at Camp Waconda!

column1: Very impressive resume.  Electronic countermeasures, Strategic Air Command ... Black belt in Karate ... Small arms expert ... Mr. Zeddemore, as you may have heard, we locate ghosts and spirits, trap them with streams of concentrated quantum energy and remove them from people's homes, offices and places of worship.
column2: Yeah, I heard that.  Now tell me what you really do.

column1: Hey man.  What is it you're so involved with there?
column2: Uh ... Oh these are blueprints of the structural ironwork in Dana Barrett's apartment building ... And they're most unusual.

column1: Are you a Christian, Ray?
column2: Mmmhmmm.

column1: Me, too.
column2: Boy!  Solid cores of shielded Selenium .325.

column1: Do you believe in God?
column2: No.  But I liked Jesus' style.

column1: Me, too. Parts of the Bible are great.
column2: The whole roof cap was fabricated with a magnesium-tungsten alloy.

column1: Ray, do you remember something in the Bible about a day when the dead would rise up from their graves?
column2: And the seas would boil ...

column1: Right.  And the sky would fall ...
column2: Judgement Day ...

column1: Yeah, Judgement Day.
column2: Every ancient religion had its own myth about the end of the world.

column1: You don't have to worry about that with us, sir.
column2: Right.  We'll believe anything.

column1: Stantz?  You okay in there?
column2: LATER, MAN!!

column1: What's he talking about?  Choose what?
column2: What do you mean "choose?"  We don't understand.

column1: You -- think I am -- I'm --  -- an animal.
column2: No.

column1: I can't live like you do -- all your machines and -- cold metal and sharp corners --
column2: You lived like this once.

column1: That is not now, human!
column2: My name is Robert.

column1: It is not arguing to speak the truth.
column2: Listen to me, my blood somehow... helped you.  It could help all of you.  We could find some way to --

column1: Are you all right?
column2: Yes.

column1: How much do you remember?
column2: It comes back.  Flashes.  My name.

column1: Do you remember where you lived?
column2: It was warm.  I was outside.  The ocean?

column1: What about... now?
column2: With them?

column1: Yes.
column2: We move.  Place to place.

column1: When you're here, in the city, where do you live?
column2: Dark and large.  With vines -- no, not vines.  Not alive.

column1: Who is this?
column2: My wife.

column1: Was this -- "beautiful?"  Before?
column2: Yes.

column1: Do you remember where it is?
column2: What?

column1: You want to find them.
column2: Yes.

column1: Why don't you start with me?
column2: You're not them.

column1: What choice did I have -- ?!
column2: You hunt us like animals -- do you know how many you have slaughtered?!

column1: I only protect myself -- !
column2: You are The Human.  The Hunter.  The thing that comes in the day and kills --

column1: What do you want?
column2: What do you mean?

column1: Will you keep feeding me?  How long can you live like that?  Until it kills you?  Until I kill you? Without your blood I'll go back.
column2: We don't know that --

column1: Mine.
column2: Have you always had it?

column1: I don't know.
column2: Have you looked inside?

column1: Yes.
column2: What's inside?

column1: Humans.
column2: Who?

column1: That's who you are too, Emma.
column2: Before... when I was one of them. I would look at this and it was just strangers.  Now I... remember.

column1: You want me to stay?
column2: Yes.

column1: Do you still want me to stay?
column2: Yes.

column1: Emma...
column2: He wanted me to see -- he thinks I was -- infected by you.

column1: Shhh... don't talk.
column2: I want to talk.  I just learned again.

column1: You have to go.  He'll never stop. Leave this place.  Find another.
column2: I'll go.  We'll both go.  Far away.

column1: Good evening.  Did you have a pleasant day today?
column2: Busy.  I went swimming and prepared a new vehicle.  A big vehicle.

column1: That sounds charming.  Did you meet any interesting people today?
column2: Yesterday.  They're back.  Haven't seen them for a few months.  I have to be careful.

column1: Tell me about the interesting people you met, won't you?
column2: They are... sinister.  They want to kill me.

column1: That sounds charming.  What are you planning to do tomorrow?
column2: Stay alive.

column1: I remember the first time we met. Do you remember that?
column2: Yes.

column1: You and that damned garden.
column2: Yeah, but when your mother came what's the first thing you showed her?

column1: I surrender --
column2: Besides, if we get a lot of work done this summer it'll be done.

column1: It's never gonna be done.  You love puttering out there too much.
column2: Well, it's not supposed to be done anyway.

column1: The more we plant, the more that'll grow, and the happier --
column2: Virginia...?

column1: Need some gas?
column2: Please.

column1: Only got one kind.
column2: That's fine.

column1: Hell of a night.
column2: You got that right.

column1: So, what do you do?
column2: I'm am architect.  I'm working on a site back in --

column1: You built things.
column2: I guess you could say that.

column1: Bathroom?
column2: Round back.

column1: Son ... are you awake?
column2: Yes.

column1: We're going to be moving, son.
column2: Do we have to?

column1: I know, son.  But you'll like it where we're going.  I'm getting a good job.  It's a pretty part of the country.
column2: I'll have to go to a new school -- again.

column1: What's that, Dad?
column2: That's the Air Force Base.

column1: Wow.  Look at the mountains.
column2: This can be your room if you want it. What do you say?

column1: Is the hill ours too?
column2: If we want it, it is.

column1: Wow.  There's the town.  And there's the air base.  This is a great hill.
column2: It's got a name.  Copper Ridge. There used to be a copper mine near here.

column1: A meteorite, Dad, look!
column2: It's that time of year again. We should get a pretty good show out here.

column1: Why, Dad?
column2: Because the sky is so clear out here.

column1: There are more this year than last.
column2: This should be the heaviest shower of the year.

column1: ... and Rigel.
column2: And that one -- to the right of Rigel?

column1: Which one's that?  The dull, red one.
column2: That's Mars.  The closest planet to us, now.  That's why it's more than just a point in the sky.

column1: Well, son?  Should we call it a night?  I for one have had a long day.
column2: Okay.

column1: Jim -- what's wrong?!
column2: You've got to come see -- a big thing went down over the hill!

column1: It was big -- and it glowed -- and it went down over there -- behind the hill.
column2: What did it look like?

column1: Are you sure you saw that?  In the rain -- it may have <u>looked</u> like it changed shape --
column2: I don't know, Dad.  But it was big.

column1: Are you all right, Dad?
column2: Sure ... fine.

column1: I lost it.  It's kind of muddy out there.
column2: Was there anything over the hill?

column1: I had an awful dream.
column2: What, Jim, what?

column1: ... And then everything blew up. And then I woke up.
column2: That's a doozy of a dream, son.

column1: It was so real, Dad.
column2: It was all made of stuff that's happened to you in the last few days.  The sand pit in back of the house, and the meteor shower, and meeting your teacher and the colonel at school, and being afraid of the new kids because you don't know them ...

column1: I know, Ellen.  We'll settle down soon.
column2: I was so scared.

column1: I have to go over to the town this morning and do a lot of shopping. This house needs just <u>everything</u>. I'll probably be gone all day. Jimmy, hurry up and eat or you'll be late.
column2: I'll take you to school.

column1: It's probably the solenoid.  Take it back to Gleason's, they said they'd fix it if we found anything wrong.
column2: I will.  But isn't that odd -- about my dream ... ?

column1: What happened to you?  Who was that?
column2: That's Ed.  Ed works with the Bell Telephone switching division.

column1: Where's your car?
column2: I left it at work.

column1: I'm home now.
column2: Yes -- but ...

column1: You know, it really is beautiful up there.  Let me show you.  We'll take a walk after dinner.
column2: George, you're acting very strangely.

column1: What's wrong, Ellen?
column2: It's his nightmare.  He still hasn't gotten over it ... about the other side of the hill.

column1: Better get some sleep, son, or you'll be pretty tired at school tomorrow.
column2: Good night.

column1: We'll be by to pick him up in ten minutes.
column2: Yes, Mr. Gardner.

column1: What do you mean -- gone?  What the hell kind of a nurse are you, anyway?
column2: I'm sorry, Mr. Gardner.  I was out of my office for a minute and when I got back -- he was gone.

column1: What did he talk to you about?
column2: He was upset with moving, I believe.

column1: Is that all he said?
column2: Why, yes.  Why?

column1: Hello, this is Ms. Magnuson speaking.
column2: I understand, Miss, that you have my son in your office.

column1: Yes, I do, Mr. Gardner.
column2: May I ask why?

column1: We were having a little talk.
column2: About what?

column1: Children often have trouble adjusting to a new school.
column2: I don't know what he's told you --  What <u>has</u> he told you?  Would you like to tell <u>me</u> -- ?

column1: Mr. Gardner, I --
column2: You people have a lot of nerve, taking it on yourselves to encourage young children to speak out of turn. I'm of a mind to pull him out of school if this is your idea of how to handle ... What sort of training do you have anyway?

column1: Mr. Gardner, I don't think this is the place to discuss this matter.
column2: I'm not particularly interested, <u>Ms.</u> Magnuson, in what you think is correct. My wife and I are going away on a business trip this afternoon and we want Jimmy with us.  Keep him in your office until we arrive.

column1: This is a new town for you.  Do you like it here?
column2: No.

column1: Why not?  Moving is hard for anybody.  Was it hard for you to leave all your friends?
column2: I don't have many friends.  Dad's all the time moving.

column1: That's quite a story.  You know that, don't you?
column2: Yes.

column1: How did it get Mrs. McKeltch?
column2: She said the frog came from around the Copper Ridge.  She must've been behind the hill.

column1: What would you think if somebody told you a story like this?
column2: I'd believe him.

column1: Why?
column2: 'Cause he wouldn't lie.

column1: Do you know how to follow a map?
column2: Yes.  I can even read star maps.

column1: Jimmy, calm down!  What happened? Tell me what happened!
column2: I got trapped in Mrs. McKeltch's van -- and she went to the tunnel and went down there with them -- behind my house.  I saw them.

column1: Where, Jimmy?
column2: Behind my house, up on the ridge.

column1: This is where it was -- the tunnel opening.
column2: I don't see anything.

column1: I swear it was here.
column2: But it's not, Jimmy.

column1: No.
column2: Let's go look at the sand pit behind your house.

column1: They'll get us.
column2: We'll be very careful.  But we have to see.  If something landed there, there would be a big scar in the ground. Wouldn't there?

column1: Does it look to you like anything landed here?
column2: Maybe -- it landed in the bushes.

column1: Stay here.  I'm going to make a phone call.
column2: Who are you calling?

column1: Did you call the State Police?
column2: All their lines were busy.

column1: No one comes here after dark.
column2: Hide the car.

column1: Damn.
column2: I know a way.

column1: What is it?
column2: I don't know.  I don't know what I'm doing here --

column1: But you saw -- the men go under the sand ...
column2: Yes ... yes, but I'm not sure what I saw anymore.

column1: Don't go in.
column2: I'm not.  They must be tunneling under the whole town.

column1: We can't do this alone.  We've got to get help.
column2: There was a man named Colonel Wilson, from the Air Force Base.  He was talking in our class.  He said we could visit him any time we wanted.  I'll bet he could do something.

column1: You're looking for life?
column2: They didn't find any signs of life on the Viking missions.

column1: Well, come on, you two.  Time to go to bed.
column2: Mom -- this is the best show all year.

column1: What do you think he saw?  Could it have been something from the air base?
column2: No, Mom.  It wasn't a plane.

column1: George, where have you been?
column2: What happened to your other slipper?

column1: Your father asked you a question.
column2: What? -- I...

column1: Hi.  Sorry I'm late.
column2: The back door was open.

column1: Mom.  I gotta talk to you.
column2: What?

column1: When?
column2: This afternoon.  It's wonderful up there -- you still haven't seen the best part.

column1: I have school.
column2: I'll pack us a lunch.  Hamburgers. You always like that, don't you.

column1: It's all this moving from place to place.  We're never settled.  I'm having nightmares myself.
column2: What kind, Mom?

column1: What's the story on Jimmy Gardner?
column2: Gardner?  Oh, um -- he's a new student. Just moved here.  Why?

column1: His teacher brought him in to see me. Said he'd been acting up in class. Creating a disturbance.  I couldn't get a thing out of him.
column2: Oh?

column1: What's his family background?
column2: They're from out of state.  Father's an engineer at the nuclear power plant. I really don't know much about them.

column1: Ms. Magnuson, is Jimmy Gardner with you?
column2: Why, yes.

column1: Jimmy's father is on the phone.  I wonder if you'd take the call.
column2: All right.  I'll be right back.

column1: Penicillin. At least it will help keep his fever down.
column2: It's really nice of you to help us.

column1: I wish I could do more but we're moving out.
column2: We're going with you. I mean, we're going too.

column1: This could be our last night on Earth. I don't want to die a virgin.
column2: If we do, we'll both die virgins. But at last we'll be together.

column1: What do you want?
column2: You have to leave the White House.

column1: This is not the time or the place to have this same old discussion.
column2: You don't understand. You have to leave Washington.

column1: In case you haven't noticed, we're in a little bit of a crisis here.
column2: I've worked with embedded loading. They're communicating with a hidden signal. They're going to attack...

column1: You're being paranoid.
column2: It's not paranoia. The embedding is very subtle. It's probably been overlooked...

column1: What?
column2: Connie, don't hang up.

column1: David? How'd you get this number?
column2: Walk to the window. Right in front of you.

column1: And when is the countdown supposed to expire?
column2: Fifty six minutes, forty five seconds.

column1: What do you want me to do?
column2: I want you to leave with us. Right now.

column1: I can't leave. We have to tell this to the President.
column2: He's not going to listen to me.

column1: You can't be seriously considering firing nuclear weapons?
column2: David, don't...

column1: Just my luck, no ice.
column2: I take it you've heard.

column1: You still believe in him.
column2: He's a good man.

column1: Better be. You left me for him.
column2: I wanted a career. Didn't you ever want to be part of something special?

column1: Thirty seconds? Isn't that cutting it a little too close?
column2: We'll be well on our way out of there before we shoot that thing off.

column1: With you? I don't understand why you can't just show someone how to plant the virus, somebody trained for this kind of mission?
column2: If anything goes wrong I'll have to think quickly, adjust the signal, who knows?

column1: Are you all right?
column2: Did it work?

column1: David thought I was having an affair, which I wasn't.
column2: Punched the President? Oh my god.

column1: Moishe Martinsburg, Mr. President.
column2: My ex-husband works in satellite communications.

column1: He still gets air sick, huh? In all of this I didn't get the chance to thank you two.
column2: Think nothing of it, Spanky.

column1: Spunky. He told you about that?
column2: All he could think about was getting to you. There's still love there I think.

column1: Love was never our problem.
column2: All you need is love. John Lennon. Smart man. Shot in the back, very sad.

column1: Can we expect the same kid of panic here as in Russia?
column2: More than likely.

column1: I don't know how you put up with him.
column2: He used to run the NASA. He knows where all the bones are buried. Comes in handy.

column1: You saved a lot of lives.
column2: I could have evacuated the cities hours ago.  You know, when I flew in the Gulf War everything is simple. We knew what we had to do. It's not simple anymore, Connie. A lot of people died today. How many didn't have to?

column1: We're losing them.
column2: Then get them out of there.

column1: What the hell is the point of having a beeper if you don't turn it on?
column2: It was turned on. I was ignoring you. What's the big emergency?

column1: What the hell is this?
column2: So sue me.

column1: Did you try to switch to transponder channels?
column2: Please, would I be this panicked if it was that simple?

column1: Let's retrofit the dish to another satellite.
column2: We've tried. It's not working. It's almost as though they weren't even there.

column1: There's good news and bad news.
column2: What's the bad news?

column1: You're in meal penalty for disturbing my lunch.
column2: And the good news is you won't charge me.

column1: No. The good news is I found the problem and it's not our equipment. There's some weird signal embedded within the satellite feed.
column2: That's the good news?

column1: Yes, because the analog signal has a definite sequential digital patterns embedded within it. When I find the exact binary sequence and I apply a phase reversed signal to that calculated spectra analyzer I built you last Christmas, we should be able to block out the overlay completely...
column2: ...and we'll be the only guys in town with a clear picture? That's my man.

column1: I've got a lock on the signal pattern. We can filter it out.
column2: Huh? Oh, good, good.

column1: Strange thing is, if my calculations are right it'll be gone in approximately seven hours anyway. The signal reduces itself every time it recycles. Eventually it will disappear. Are you listening?
column2: Can you believe this?

column1: What're you talking about?
column2: Haven't you been watching?

column1: Tell her to get the kids and leave town.
column2: What happened?

column1: Okay, why did I just send my family to Atlanta?
column2: Remember I told you that the signal hidden within our satellite signal is slowly recycling down to extinction.

column1: Not really...
column2: That signal. It's a countdown.

column1: A countdown to what?
column2: Think. It's like in chess. First you strategically position your pieces. Then, when the timing's right. You strike.

column1: Then what?
column2: Checkmate.

column1: What are you waiting? My social security will expire, you'll still be sitting there.
column2: I'm thinking.

column1: You have any idea how long it takes for those things to decompose?
column2: You don't move soon. I'll begin to decompose.

column1: David, I've been meaning to talk with you. It's nice you've been spending so much time with me, but...
column2: Dad, don't start.

column1: I'm only saying, it's been what? Four years, you still haven't signed your divorce papers.
column2: Three years.

column1: Pops!
column2: The television said they've started with the looting already. Vultures.

column1: You still got the Olds?
column2: You want to borrow the car? You don't have a license.

column1: It's the White House, for crying out loud. You can't just drive up and ring the bell.
column2: Can't this thing go any faster?

column1: You think they don't know what you know? Believe me, they know. She works for the President. They know everything.
column2: They don't know this.

column1: And you're going to educate them? Tell me something, you're so smart how come you spent eight years at M.I.T. to become a cable repairman?
column2: Dad...

column1: What the hell is that?
column2: This, pops, is every phone book in America.

column1: You think an important person like Constance is going to be listed?
column2: She always keeps her portable phone listed, for emergencies. Sometimes it's just her first initial, sometime her nickname...

column1: Not listed, huh?
column2: I just haven't found it yet. I tried C. Halbrook, Connie Halbrook, Spunky Halbrook...

column1: Spunky?
column2: College nickname.

column1: You try Martin?
column2: She didn't take my name when we were married.

column1: Perfect, she's using it.
column2: It's perfect the line is busy?

column1: Yes. I can use he signal to triangulate her exact position in the White House.
column2: You can do that?

column1: Sure he'll listen. Why wouldn't he?
column2: Because last time I saw him I punched him in the face.

column1: You punched the President in the face?
column2: He wasn't the President then.

column1: It's Air Force One for crying out loud. Still he gets sick?
column2: Moishe, please, don't talk.

column1: Dad, please...
column2: What was it, Roswell? You had the space ship, the bodies, everything locked up in a bunker, the what is it, Area fifty one. That's it! Area fifty one. You knew and you didn't do nothing!

column1: David, David! What the hell are you doing!?
column2: I'm making a mess.

column1: This I can see.
column2: We've gotta burn the rain forest, Pops. Dump toxic waste, pollute the air, rip up the ozone. Maybe if we screw this planet up enough they won't want it anymore.

column1: Pops, you're a genius!
column2: What'd I say?

column1: Thanks, Pops.
column2: I want you should know, I'm very proud of you, son.

column1: I'll see how they're doing with the radio transmitter.
column2: Oh shit, we're late.

column1: I have a confession to make. I'm not real big on flying.
column2: Great.

column1: What the hell are you doing?
column2: Just getting a feel for her.

column1: Must be thousands of them. What are they doing?
column2: Looks like they're preparing the invasion.

column1: Get us out of here!
column2: I can't shake her free.

column1: What're you doing?
column2: It's not me. They're overriding the system.

column1: Nice meeting you.
column2: You as well.

column1: We're loose!
column2: Doesn't matter. Game's over.

column1: With your permission, Mr. President, I'd like to remain my your side.
column2: I had a feeling you would.

column1: Sir, what happens if they do become hostile?
column2: Then God help us.

column1: General Grey, co-ordinate with Atlantic Command. Tell them they have twenty five minutes to get as many people out of the cities as they can.
column2: But Mr. President...

column1: Is my wife in the air?
column2: She should be shortly.

column1: Any news on my wife?
column2: The helicopter never arrived at Nellis and there's been no radio contact.

column1: Where are they?
column2: ETA with target

column1: Atlanta, Chicago and Philadelphia, destroyed?
column2: And there are scattered reports of sightings over Miami, Ft. Worth, And Memphis.

column1: And our forces?
column2: We're down to approximately fifteen percent, Sir.  If you calculate the time it takes them to destroy a city and move on, we're looking at world wide destruction of every major city within the next thirty six hours.

column1: Organize every plane you can find and get some Goddamned pilots to fly them.
column2: Yes, Sir.

column1: How're we doing?
column2: Better than we thought.

column1: We have confirmed divisions of troops from different armies all around the world. Most of Europe, the Middle East and Asia are battle ready.
column2: And our troops here?

column1: We've been collecting planes from all over but...
column2: But what, General?

column1: Pilots, sir. We don't have enough people to get them in the air.
column2: Then find them.

column1: Mr. President, just what do you think you're doing?
column2: I'm a pilot, Will. This is where I belong.

column1: Grey, you read me?
column2: Roger, Eagle One, our primary target has shifted course.

column1: Where's it headed?
column2: I think our secret is out. They're headed right for us.

column1: Do not engage until we've confirmed the package has been delivered.
column2: Roger.

column1: Get on the horn with Atlantic Command. Let's upgrade the situation to DEFCON 3.
column2: That's not your call to make, Mr. Nimziki.

column1: Organize a military escort to Crystal Mountain.
column2: Sir, I strongly recommend we move you to a secured location immediately.

column1: More ships keep arriving, fifteen in total so far.
column2: This is crazy. We're loosing our first strike capabilities!

column1: That's impossible...
column2: My God, the Vice President and the Joint Chiefs...

column1: You were the head of the National Intelligence Agency! You knew all about this. When were you planning on informing the rest of us!?
column2: It had been deemed classified.

column1: This is ridiculous.
column2: How long would their shields be down?

column1: With their shields down it might be possible.
column2: Please, you're not buying into any of this nonsense, are you? We don't have the manpower or the resources to launch that kind of a campaign.  Not to mention that this whole cockamamie plan is dependent on a machine that no one in the world is qualified to operate.

column1: A meteor?
column2: No Sir. Definitely not.

column1: How do you know?
column2: Well, er... it's slowing down.

column1: It's doing what?
column2: It's... slowing down, Sir.

column1: He's trying to impress you.
column2: He's doing a good job.

column1: You can't go. Call them back.
column2: Baby, you know how it is. I have to report to El Toro right away.

column1: You said you were on leave for the Fourth.
column2: They cancelled it. Why are you acting like this?

column1: Wait. I have to tell you something.
column2: What?

column1: Be careful.
column2: Look, after your shift tonight, why don't you grab Dylan and come stay with me on base.

column1: Really? You don't mind?
column2: Naw. I'll just tell my other girlfriends they can't come over tonight.

column1: You know, you're not as charming as you think you are.
column2: Yes, I am.

column1: Dick-weed!
column2: Butt-munch.

column1: You're late.
column2: You know how I like to make a big entrance.

column1: You're late.
column2: You know me...

column1: Before we do this, I want you to know I'm sorry.
column2: Sorry for what?

column1: You scared the hell out of me.
column2: Yeah, but what an entrance!

column1: Dick-weed.
column2: Butt-munch.

column1: Your son.
column2: He's my angel.

column1: Was his father stationed here?
column2: He wasn't his father. I was kinda hoping he'd want the job, though.

column1: So, what do you do for a living?
column2: I'm a dancer.

column1: Really? Ballet?
column2: No. Exotic.

column1: Oh. Sorry.
column2: Don't be. I'm not. It's good money.  'Side, he's worth it.

column1: And when the dancing's over? What about your future?
column2: Funny, it used to scare me when I thought about the future.  Guess it doesn't really matter anymore.

column1: Dylan, come here. I want you to meet the First Lady.
column2: I thought you didn't recognize me.

column1: I don't believe it. They make you learn how to fly everything from an Apache to a Harrier and still they turn you down? What else do they want you to learn?
column2: How to kiss ass.

column1: Jasmine has this thing for dolphins. I had them make it...
column2: I thought you said you were doing to break it off.

column1: That is an affirmative. I have victory dance. Mmmmmmm.
column2: Don't get premature on me, Jimmy. We don't light up 'til the Fat Lady sings.

column1: I shouldn't have left her.
column2: Don't worry, big guy. I'm sure she got out of here before it happened.

column1: Damn it!
column2: I didn't even see them fire!

column1: Jimmy, kick it! They're gaining.
column2: We're already over Mach 2!

column1: Stevie... I can't...
column2: Jimmy, stay with me.

column1: Stop it.
column2: It's all fuzzy.

column1: I don't need it.
column2: Just take it, dick head.  Alicia! Make sure he takes his medicine.

column1: He's got that SEGA Saturn CD, 64 bit, right?
column2: Yeah. What would you think if we went there to live for a while?

column1: But I gave you some this morning.
column2: I didn't take it. I thought I didn't need it anymore.

column1: Just what the hell do you think you're doing?
column2: I'm bringing home the bacon. Earning my keep. And doing a fine job if I do say so myself.

column1: It's the wrong field, you idiot! Lucas' farm is on the other side of town.
column2: You sure?

column1: They let you out?
column2: Just what the hell do you think you're doing?

column1: We're leaving, don't try and stop us.
column2: You're not going anywhere. You hear me? I'm still your father.

column1: Troy's still my son no matter how you feel about me.
column2: For once in your life think about what's best for Troy. Who has to beg for money to buy him medicine when you screw up? Who?

column1: I couldn't find anything. Everyone is packing up, they're leaving. Word is a space ship is heading this way.
column2: We should leave too.

column1: How' he doing?
column2: Just fell asleep. He's gonna be just fine. Join me in a little celebration?

column1: I'm not leaving.
column2: We must maintain a working government in a time of crisis...

column1: I want the Vice President, Secretary of Defense, the whole Cabinet and the Joint Chiefs taken to a secured location. I'm staying here. I am not going to add to a public hysteria that could cost lives.
column2: But, Mr. President...

column1: What the hell's going on?
column2: We're leaving.

column1: I spoke with the Joint Chief when they arrived at NORAD. They agree, we must launch a counter offensive with a full nuclear strike. Hit 'em with everything we've got.
column2: Above American soil?

column1: Why the hell wasn't I told about this place?
column2: Two words, Mr. President. Plausible deniability.

column1: Mr. President?
column2: Deploy.

column1: Call them back.
column2: The other bombers might have more luck. We shouldn't just give up...

column1: Mr. President, a real pleasure. They don't let us out much, you know.
column2: Yes.

column1: See, we can't duplicate their type of power so we've never been able to experiment. But since these guys started showing up, all the gizmos inside turned on. The last twenty four hours have been really exciting!
column2: People are dying out there. I don't think "exciting" is the word I'd choose to describe it!

column1: What can you tell us about the enemy we're facing?
column2: Not all too dissimilar to us. Breathes oxygen, comparable tolerances to heat, cold... probably why they're interested in our planet.  Hey, you wanna see them?

column1: Can they be killed?
column2: These three died in the crash. Their bodies are as frail as our own. You just have to get past their technology, which is, I'm sorry to say, far more advanced.

column1: Why did you people come here?
column2: Air... water... your "sun."

column1: Where do your people come from?  Where is your home?
column2: Here... now.

column1: And before here?
column2: Many worlds...

column1: Can we negotiate a truce? Is there room for co-existance?  Can there be peace between us?
column2: Peace? No peace.

column1: What do you want us to do?
column2: Die.

column1: I said something.
column2: I know you did!

column1: No, not her. Me.
column2: Who's you?

column1: My name is AL.
Where are you,...Al?
column2: You're not gonna believe this...

column1: Try me.
column2: I'm...inside you.

column1: I'm reporting you to the .....transit authority!!!
column2: What's going on?

column1: ...reporting....him... ventriloquism...On a bus
column2: Don't do that.

column1: Arrrgh!
column2: It wasn't him.

column1: Who was it?
column2: Me.

column1: Who?
column2: Al.

column1: Al.
column2: Yes?

column1: You're in my head...
column2: Yes.

column1: Your name is Al...
column2: Yes.

column1: No...no...it's nothing.. Rehearsing a play...  What light through yonder window breaks...It is Al... and he's in my head.
column2: What is your name?

column1: You're in my head? You don't know my name?
column2: I just got here.

column1: What??? You lose your lease on a condo?
column2: Where are we?

column1: Where are we? We're on the street. We're walking down the street. We're talking to ourselves. People are staring at us.
column2: What street?

column1: What street?! We're walking down QUEER STREET. We coming to Dopey Drive. We're about to be put somewhere quiet where they won't mind that we talk to ourselves.
column2: Why don't we go home?

column1: Go home. Good idea. Get some rest.
column2: ...I need to make a phone call.

column1: Do me a favor, Al.
column2: Yeah?

column1: Somebody's been here.
column2: Where are we now?

column1: My place, can't you see?
column2: No.

column1: You're in my head, you can talk to me and hear what I say, but you can't see anything.
column2: Right.

column1: Kind of an oversight, wouldn't you say.
column2: I'm working on it. Soon as I find the right nerve bundle.

column1: Who are you?
column2: Who am I?

column1: Yeah...Who?
column2: Well...If you're in my head... to you, I'm...GOD!

column1: Quit screwing around, this is important.
column2: It's my head, I'll be the judge of that. Anyway, who are you?

column1: I told you, my name is Al.
column2: What are you doing in my head, Al?

column1: You've heard of the PEM114...
column2: That a new Datsun?

column1: Are you threatening me?
column2: I'm trying to get you to listen to reason.

column1: Look! I didn't ask to be in you. Don't blame me for it. You did it.
column2: Me? What'd I do?

column1: Yeah. What did you do? You explain it. ...why I'm not at the lab right now, in my tube, with my crew. Explain that!
column2: I don't know what you're talking about.

column1: The Nicholson Node. I suppose you haven't heard of that either.
column2: No.

column1: You've heard of U.S.T.?
column2: I just went there for a job.

column1: I know...it sounds insane.
column2: You said it.

column1: What are you doing?
column2: Loading a gun.

column1: What for?
column2: Kill myself.

column1: Are you crazy?
column2: Yep.

column1: Don't do it.  Don't aim at the head.
column2: Used to be, things were bad. No job...no money...no girl. Now I got all that and I'm crazy too.

column1: You're not crazy.
column2: Hear voices don't I.

column1: Of course you do!
column2: Then I'm crazy.

column1: You're not crazy. Don't...wait a minute, just let me explain.
column2: You're gonna explain.

column1: Yeah JOE Why there's a little man in my head?
column2: Yeah.

column1: Why he's argumentative?
column2: Yes...Yes...I'll explain it all. Just put the gun down.

column1: You'll be alive.
column2: With a man in my head...

column1: What was that?
column2: Who was that? Somebody out there?

column1: You weren't listening!
column2: Sorry...all this...buzzing in my head.  Why don't I just take you back to UST?

column1: No they won't.
column2: Why not?

column1: I'll talk to them.
column2: Oh...Gooood!

column1: I'll tell you what to say.
column2: If I get you back to the lab, will you get out of my head?

column1: Anyone there?
column2: No one. Maybe I dreamed it all up.

column1: Behind us?
column2: Still clear. Just a motorcycle.

column1: What's that?
column2: Nothing. Just the cyclist. He's passed us.

column1: What'd he look like?
column2: He's not the problem. It's the van in the back.

column1: What do I do?
column2: Outrun them.

column1: Now what?
column2: Whatever you do, just...don't stop.

column1: I wouldn't say that.
column2: Then what are you stopping for?

column1: Get your breathing down. You sound like a cement mixer.
column2: Can't see a Goddamn thi..

column1: I want out.
column2: Too late...They want you.

column1: Why? AL  You know too much.
column2: I don't know anything. I just want to go home.

column1: Calm Down! Act rational.
column2: How do you act when someone trys to kill you?

column1: I don't know...To get Al.
column2: No. Don't tell the guards.

column1: Did you hear that?
column2: Yeah.  Al wants to talk to you!

column1: It can't take that long.
column2: Why?

column1: JOE Or what?
column2: I don't know. I don't want to find out.

column1: They could put you back in the tube..
column2: I'd be helpless and useless. They don't have the PEM. Without that...there's no chance.

column1: Well...they sure as hell aren't gonna get it for you.
column2: They're busy covering their asses. They're not the type of people we need."

column1: Yeah...Who is?
column2: I am. You are.

column1: You are CRAZY!
column2: You're the one talking to a little guy in your head.  ...We'll have to do it on our own.

column1: What do you mean we.
column2: You gotta help.

column1: I did. I brought you back here.
column2: We're a team...My...talent. Your... mobility.

column1: Thanks.
column2: Think of the scientific data we'll gain. Come on, lets get out of here.

column1: Ever think of what they might have to do to find me?
column2: Find You?

column1: They'll have to take you apart. ...piece by piece.
column2: Why don't you just get out, leave me alone.

column1: Sue them.
column2: I'll sue.

column1: I don't like the sound of that.
column2: We have to get out of here.

column1: Door's locked.
column2: See the codelock? Punch this in. 26993

column1: Now what.
column2: Go out, take your first left.

column1: Just walk down the hall?
column2: With Authority!

column1: Which way do I go?
column2: What does it say.

column1: Corridor A.
column2: Take a left and your next right.

column1: A lab and equipment.
column2: Is it familiar? Have you been here before.

column1: I was thirsty. He told me to get a drink.
column2: Who did?

column1: Oh my God...What did he look like, the man?
column2: I can't remember..

column1: Like the guys that attacked us.
column2: What do you mean?

column1: Black suits and helmets.
column2: That's it. They know I'm in here. We've got to find them.

column1: That's not a good idea.
column2: They think we're safe here. They don't really need us. They're probably long gone.

column1: Gone where?
column2: Don't know.

column1: You need ID in there?
column2: You do. To get out of here. You're gonna be me.

column1: I don't wanna be you. I wanna go home.
column2: You can't go home. When UST finds we're gone, they'll come after you and put us away.

column1: Anything...A feeling...a smell..?
column2: Nothing!

column1: Wait a minute. The fight. Where did he get you?
column2: Just scratched my arm, why?

column1: I'll be out of touch for a while. Just get to the airport.
column2: The airport! Hey, wait a minute.

column1: I'm back.
column2: I'm at the airport.

column1: Who is it?
column2: Not who. A data bank. Just keep your ear to the phone and don't make a sound.

column1: Don't talk, I told you. You just screwed it up.
column2: What am I supposed to do?

column1: What is it?
column2: Composition of the sand, ...trace elements..unique...

column1: What do we do?
column2: Send a man there. A secret agent.

column1: Who?...  Wait a minute! I'm no agent, secret or otherwise. And..I'm alone.
column2: You are not alone. But you are incon- picuous...and, with our abilities...

column1: You mean...just leave.
column2: We get on a plane.

column1: What about money?
column2: What about it?

column1: I don't have any.
column2: Use my credit cards.

column1: I can't do that.
column2: Why not?

column1: It's illegal.
column2: Who cares?

column1: I'll get in trouble.
column2: You are in trouble. Now do it.

column1: ...and a license to kill...
column2: Well, if not to kill, then to bother and annoy.

column1: They'll know who I am.
column2: We'll change your appearance.

column1: It's just not enough.
column2: It's attitude...how you carry yourself.

column1: What's wrong with how I carry myself.
column2: Nothing, but it's yours. Change it. Change your whole persona.

column1: Oh yeah, to what?
column2: You'll be me.

column1: I don't want to be you. I don't even like you, why would I want to be you?
column2: Because you got my ID. Now brace yourself. I'm gonna try something with your glands.

column1: Now what?
column2: The beach.

column1: The beach?
column2: How else do you get seaweed under your nails?

column1: Eating sushi?
column2: Just get there.

column1: Holy shit!
column2: What is it?

column1: Do you notice anything.
column2: The sky, the sun, the sea... There's no one here. It's deserted. What now?

column1: Swim.
column2: Good Idea!

column1: Take it easy, now. Don't want you in over your head.
column2: Little late for that.

column1: Here...all the seaweed you want. Now, what?

column1: What?

column1: I'm sorry I got you into this.
column2: It was my choice.

column1: Don't blame yourself, I didn't have to come along.

column1: I encouraged you to come here. My fault as much as yours.
column2: I was...crazy...desperate. I took it out on you. I didn't mean it. I know what she sees in you. You're kind and you're brave. If I ever get out of you, I'll be glad to call you my friend.

column1: How?
column2: What?

column1: Now what?
column2: I've never met anyone like you.

column1: Uh...wonderful. I know I'm strange, but in my own way, I love you
column2: I love you too.

column1: Don't worry.
column2: Why not, what are you going to do?

column1: Just like that?
column2: I'll come back for you.

column1: You son of a bitch! You conned me!
column2: You're gonna laugh.

column1: Kiss her you fool.

column1: Who are you? Who do you work for?
column2: Doesn't matter. I'm on your side.

column1: I knew it. I told him.
column2: Now what?

column1: He can't help us.
column2: Do something!

column1: Do what? I don't know. I'm no good at this.

column1: It wasn't me. It was him.
column2: It was you.

column1: He told me what to do.
column2: But you did it. It was you.

column1: It was me. He just told me how...I wish he could tell me now.

column1: Come on.
column2: That's twenty feet high.

column1: Riuji?
column2: I told you, I work for him.

column1: What is it?
column2: We're not moving fast enough for him.

column1: He wants to apologise.
column2: He should do it in person ...I mean ex person.

column1: Yeah...I have to get away.
column2: I know a nice island.

column1: Must be a fulfilling occupation.
column2: It keeps me busy. Everybody always wants something.

column1: What could you find in this place?
column2: ...Piece of mind.

column1: Excuse me?
column2: Could have been drunk a little sooner, but excellent...good character...What is it?

column1: I can't. He didn't do anything. Thanks to you.
column2: Why are you on to him?

column1: We've had thefts of our new stuff ...GRUNER deals in this... A big deal is going down now. I went to see if GRUNER had anything to sell. But he didn't make any moves...And when you arrived, he backed off.
column2: Why'd you invite me here?

column1: Someone is selling. You followed us. If it's not him, it must be you. If it's not you, it must be him... You scared him off.
column2: What about the others.

column1: Joe Doakes? It's quarter to 10...
column2: I'm sorry. We're running behind. So many applicants...so few jobs... If you'll just have a seat.

column1: I have a seat. I've had it since nine.
column2: ...Mr. Athol will be with you as soon as possible. Will you be able to wait?

column1: Is there anything else?
column2: A drink...

column1: Water fountain's through that door, down the hall.
column2: Thanks.

column1: Wait.
column2: Why?

column1: You can't take that.
column2: Why not?

column1: It's alright.
column2: It is?

column1: It will be fine. You have another.
column2: Just one. The back up.

column1: Could I have it, please.
column2: I can't get it out. It would take hours.

column1: That's alright. Just tear it apart.
column2: Tear it apart?

column1: Yes.
column2: Ahhh...Okay?!!!

column2: Leaving, now go to sleep. ...all of you.

column1: Right there.
column2: Thank you.

column1: This the only spare?

column1: The other working.
column2: Perfectly.
It'l be alright.

Where the hell were you?!!
