column1: He's dead! Everyone's dead! Old Earth is dead!
column2: Old Earth?

column1: What have you done?
column2: What have I done?! Idiots.

column1: So, you're saying thse guys have like, lasers and stuff? They could hack him to pieces?
column2: Exactly.

column1: Yes!
column2: Listen up duck fuckers, you can't kill this thing.

column1: Listen to me. Please. Let's get off thsi ship. Come with me.
column2: Rizzo, a shuttle out in the middle of space? We'll die oout there.

column1: Can we get through these?
column2: Sure but what good will that do?

column1: Guys, he's right behind us!
column2: It's okay.

column1: I'm sorry. I couldn't help it.
column2: I don't have to go through with it either.

column1: You don't understand. I'm just so <u>relieved</u>. I was <u>sure</u> you'd turn out to be short and fat and gimpy.
column2: Oh. That.  I know what you mean.  I had nightmares all week.

column1: Me too.
column2: Last night was the worst. I dreamt you had one leg shorter than the other, and walked like a penguin.

column1: Mine was worse: I dreamt you picked your nose in public.
column2: That's worse.

column1: You're really not bad looking. Almost handsome.
column2: Well, you're beautiful.

column1: You <u>might</u> be handsome. I can't tell through all that grime. Besides, you reek of sweat and horses.
column2: If you're going to marry a warrior, you'd best get used to it.

column1: Take off your clothes. I'm going to scrub you down.
column2: <u>What</u>?

column1: We're almost married.
column2: We're not married <u>yet</u>.

column1: I don't trust you to wash behind your ears.
column2: Never mind my ears! Go away!

column1: There. Now you look like someone I might want to marry.
column2: Maybe you'd better look around for another candidate. I don't think my skin is tough enough to survive a lifetime of you and your brush.

column1: I don't have to look around. I've found the husband I want. You can kiss me now.
column2: Thank you, but I can wait.

column1: I lied.
column2: About what?

column1: Lyssa ... Lyssa ...
column2: Colwyn.

column1: Have they harmed you?
column2: No. They watch me closely, but they haven't harmed me.

column1: Lyssa. Where are they keeping you?
column2: In a great fortress in the mountains. Wait. Something's happening.

column1: Lyssa ...
column2: Colwyn ...

column1: Where is the Fortress?
column2: I don't know. It's a maze of tunnels. I can't see out.

column1: I will find you. I will be with you.
column2: I know it.

column1: I love you, Lyssa, I love you ...
column2: Colwyn. Colwyn.  I love you, Colwyn.

column1: Colwyn ...
column2: You must move away from the Center.

column1: Will your power outward.
column2: I don't know how.

column1: Take the western passage.
column2: All directions are the same here.

column1: Yes.
column2: Move quickly. We are coming for you. We are in the Fortress.

column1: Lyssa ...
column2: Come quickly, Colwyn. I can see the eyes of the Beast.

column1: In the Arctic ice.
column2: That way. I can feel the cold.

column1: That's a better one.
column2: Yes.

column1: You'll both wait. At least for five hours. The wedding is at three.
column2: It was a platonic kiss, Father.

column1: They have Lyssa!
column2: You can't reach her!  Through the door.  Quickly!

column1: You will go alone.
column2: I won't leave you here.

column1: You will do as I tell you. You will try to reach Ynyr, the old one.
column2: I must follow the Slayers. They've taken Lyssa.

column1: The White Castle has fallen.
column2: Does the Queen live?

column1: The new Queen lives.
column2: Turold's son was to marry her.

column1: We were married. Then she was taken by the Slayers. You must help me.
column2: I have lived in this place, like my fathers before me, guarding the old knowledge. I knew, when I had no son, that the Great War would come in my time, and that I would be the one to pass on the old knowledge to a new king. Come.

column1: This is not the first time the Dark Ones have attacked our world. They came once before, a thousand years ago. A young king and queen, with extraordinary powers, were given to us then, to lead the struggle. My fore-father was their Councilor, as I will be yours.
column2: I have no extraordinary powers.

column1: Your powers are greater than you know.  Have you ever seen one of these?
column2: In the old books. It's called a glaive.

column1: With two or three days' practice, you'll be able to use it as well as I can. Then we'll have a chance of fighting our way out of here.
column2: Two or three days! While Lyssa is in their hands?

column1: There is no other way.
column2: But there is another entrance to this place.

column1: But it opens onto the sheer wall of the Needle. There's no way down.
column2: You have rope?

column1: I am too old to climb down a rope.
column2: You won't have to.

column1: There is nothing.
column2: Reach out farther. Call to her.

column1: You must break when the strain becomes too great, or you will harm yourself. And you must concentrate your powers for when they are needed most. What did she answer?
column2: She was in a great fortress, first in the mountains, then in the jungle. How is that possible?

column1: It is the Fortress of Krull. I know it only from the stories of wars on other worlds. They did not use it on our world in the first great war, for it costs them enormous power. This time they mean to conquer, at all costs.
column2: The Fortress moves?

column1: Yes. Each dawn it rises in a different land: sometimes in the mountains, sometimes in the jungle, sometimes the desert, sometimes the sea. Never in the same place twice.
column2: Then even if Lyssa tells us where she is, we'll never be able to reach her, for they will never allow the Fortress to rise near us.

column1: No. They occupy the Fortress, but they cannot control its movement. It is moved by Fate. And, sooner or later, Fate will place it near us.
column2: Then we must be ready. Five leagues from here is the Eastern Tower. I know the Barons who hold it. Good men, and brave. They will help us.

column1: You have not slept in two days.
column2: Nor will I, till my bride is beside me.

column1: You choose these?
column2: Yes. They will be more help than high-born barons.

column1: They know when they're going to die?
column2: Everyone of his race is born knowing the day of his death.

column1: I can't reach her.
column2: What do you see?

column1: She can't see out. She can't tell us where the Fortress is.
column2: Yes, they knew of your first contact, so they drove her below.

column1: She was very faint. I was barely able to reach her.
column2: The deeper she goes, the harder it is to contact her. Once she is below the second level, you will not be able to reach her at all.

column1: I cannot reach her.
column2: She is too deep. The curved tunnel we saw is part of the Vortex, the place of The Beast.

column1: The first time, when they attacked long ago, was The Beast here?
column2: No. Then they were led by his underlings. But I knew he had come this time, from the ferocity of their onslaught, from their use of The Fortress. They use up much of their strength to do these things. They are taking great risks.

column1: <u>Why</u>?
column2: I'm not sure.

column1: But you suspect.
column2: You will know, in good time.

column1: No. We will find another way to locate the Fortress.
column2: There is no other way. You asked me why the Beast had come this time.

column1: Yes.
column2: He has come for Lyssa.

column1: Lyssa? <u>Why</u>?
column2: Like you, she has extraordinary powers. He would make her his Queen.

column1: Can she be forced?
column2: No. She must agree of her own free will.

column1: Never.
column2: You are young. You don't understand the attraction of great power, and you forget the pain of long waiting.

column1: Then we must reach her before she feels that pain.
column2: Yes.

column1: Traitor! She'll marry you in hell!
column2: He thinks you betray him with Lyssa.  Colwyn! The waters deceive you!

column1: I will melt that gold and pour it down your throat, old man!
column2: He sees betrayal everywhere. He will attack us so long as he is conscious.

column1: From here, I must go alone.
column2: You will tell me her name and we will go together.

column1: He ran a great risk, helping us today. If he opposes his fate, his death will be terribly painful.
column2: Let us wish him peace.

column1: They will hold Lyssa in the Center of the Vortex, the place of the Beast, where its power is greatest. No man can match it there. Lyssa must try to move toward us. For as we enter the Vortex and move closer ...
column2: The Beast will kill her.

column1: She must make a glaive.
column2: Lyssa, your bracelets. Bend them straight and cross them.

column1: The spiral begins in the west.
column2: Where the spiral begins.

column1: She's on the other side of this wall. I can feel it!
column2: I chose the wrong passage.

column1: She can see the Beast!
column2: Use your sword.

column1: What use is my sword? I can't reach her!
column2: Cut. <u>Cut</u>!

column1: You must move quickly. The Beast will stop at nothing now.
column2: You're coming with us.

column1: It is my fate to die in the Fortress.
column2: No! You cannot know that!

column1: I can. Because I choose it.
column2: I forbid you!

column1: How did you know?
column2: I found the body of the Seer in the stream.

column1: Slayers!
column2: We must enter the swamp.

column1: Do not let the waters touch you.
column2: What will happen?

column1: They can be saddled.
column2: You have done it?

column1: I road them often in my youth.
column2: Saddles.

column1: It is today?
column2: Yes. It is today.

column1: Each to his fate.
column2: Each to his fate.

column1: I know the cruelty of such a fate.
column2: Perhaps you think no man would return to me.

column1: Am I not worth returning to?
column2: Yes.

column1: Am I not beautiful enough to be loved?
column2: Yes.

column1: Even by you?
column2: Yes.

column1: You too are lonely.
column2: I ache with it.

column1: Let me comfort you.
column2: I cannot take comfort when she has none.

column1: Then give me comfort. Sleep with me tonight.
column2: I cannot betray my bride.

column1: I feel your pain, but I cannot betray her.
column2: You will not, then?

column1: Help! Help! I'm drowning!
column2: I doubt it. The water is only an inch deep.

column1: It could have been quicksand! I might have been sucked to my death.  Where is this place?
column2: A forest near the Valley of Needles.

column1: Blast! A thousand miles off course. Well, I was rushed. There was a certain difference of opinion concerning a venison pie. The foolish man left it sitting on his windowsill. What did he expect?
column2: Perhaps he expected to eat it.

column1: I just remembered I have urgent business in this direction.
column2: What business?

column1: Once is enough, thank you.
column2: He saved our lives.

column1: Your kingship ... your lord high mightiness ... when I called you a ... a ... whatever I called you, I didn't realize that you were ... were ...
column2: I was hoping I might be your friend.

column1: My <u>friend</u>.
column2: I have need of friends.

column1: Not yet, my friend. It's your tomato that's dying.
column2: <u>What</u>? Oh no! Better it was me. There isn't another good tomato within a hundred leagues.

column1: Try your tricks on me and I'll turn myself back into a snake and bite you.
column2: You and I will guard the fire.

column1: I don't think you'll grow careless.
column2: Smart as well as quick. Now what do you have to give us?

column1: Fame.
column2: Fame?  Thank you, no. Fame is the burial ground of contentment. Eat it and go hungry

column1: Fame is what you leave to your sons.
column2: How did you know I had sons?

column1: Because you would not rob if you had no children to provide for.
column2: Hah! You don't know me, boy.

column1: They stand at the edge of the grave and make jokes.  Do you know who I am, sprout? I am Torquil, Lord of the forest. My men follow no man but me, and I follow no man at all.
column2: You will follow me.

column1: And in the few seconds before I dice you to crow-food, tell me why I am going to follow you.
column2: So your sons will speak of you to your grandsons, and your grandsons to their grandsons.

column1: And where do you lead, boy?
column2: To the place where Death lives.

column1: It should be an interesting journey, then.
column2: That I promise you.

column1: When did you last sleep, boy?
column2: I'm all right.

column1: They burn many villages. Even walled cities fall to them.
column2: Why do they burn the villages? There's nothing to gain.

column1: I'm not hungry.
column2: Not sleepy, either?

column1: Forgive me. It's childish to cry.
column2: Those are not child's tear. A child cries for himself, a man cries for those he loves.

column1: Well, I'm not impressed.
column2: I knew you would not be. That's why I chose you.

column1: You've eaten nothing.
column2: We must try to get horses.

column1: Yes. It will double our range.  I know at least a dozen ways to get horses. All cheap.
column2: These we'll pay for.

column1: Lad, you have an unnatural desire to pay for things. It stunts the mind and shrivels the imagination.
column2: Hand over your dinner.

column1: Forgive me, my friends. I saw terrible things.
column2: They do not exist, except in the waters of the Swamp, where they will remain.

column1: Go, join them.
column2: What kind of friend do you think I am?

column1: The best. But my unhappiness is not made lighter by adding your's to it.
column2: Well, it is true that if I received a royal command I couldn't very well disobey it, could I?

column1: Go. I command you.
column2: Yes, my lord.

column1: We could reach it on fire-mares.
column2: Those beasts cannot be saddled by mortal men.

column1: We must cover a hundred leagues before sunrise.
column2: At the gallop!

column1: You're resourceful, my lad.  I tell you, one year under my tutelage and I could make you the Prince of Thieves.
column2: Subject to the King, no doubt.

column1: A good thrust, my friend. Another second and there'd have been nothing between my head and shoulders but bad memories.
column2: I intend to keep you alive, your majesty. So you can abdicate your throne and become my Warlord.

column1: Make for the wall. I'll catch up.
column2: Colwyn, don't be a fool. You can't do battle with that thing.

column1: Nothing worse than lower-class boors with upper-class morals.
column2: Would you settle for a boar?

column1: You!
column2: Me.  May I eat with you tonight?

column1: Tonight and every night, my friend, for this is the second time you've saved my life.  I am Ergo the Magnificent, short in stature, tall in power, etcetera, etcetera.
column2: I am Quell.

column1: What is that awful looking place?
column2: The Swamp of Betrayal. Be glad we don't have to cross it.

column1: Where are you going?
column2: We'll meet you at the inn.

column1: Can't I come, too?
column2: No.

column1: A venison pie as big as a house.
column2: A small house.

column1: Quell?
column2: I cannot go with you, my friend.

column1: My heart stays here.
column2: And mine goes with you.

column1: Bread is for peasants, and wine makes me sneeze. Got any gumdrops?
column2: No.

column1: Sugarballs?
column2: No.

column1: What kind of a boy are you? Boys always have candy.
column2: I have a cinnamon bar.

column1: You do?
column2: You can have half.

column1: I am Ergo the Magnificent ...  ... short in stature ...  ... tall in power ...  ... narrow of purpose ...  ... wide of vision.
column2: I ...  ... am Titch.

column1: I'm hungry.
column2: Smart lad.  Bring me my spices!

column1: If I could wish ...  ... for anything, I'd wish for a venison pie the size of a ...  ... mountain. No, that's too greedy. I'd settle for one the size of a house.
column2: I'd wish for a puppy.

column1: One puppy? Why not wish for a hundred?
column2: I only want one.

column1: Sir Ergo? ... My honorable Lord Ergo? ...
column2: First, you desert me, and now you mock me. Go back to your one-eyed friend.

column1: What? Now you poke me in the nose as well?
column2: I don't think it's working.

column1: Not working? This nose? This nose works day and night. This nose has never loafed an hour in its life. This nose ...  What?  Impossible. This nose asleep while venison fills the air?  Where is it, boy? Tell me where it is and I forgive you everything.
column2: It's right behind you.

column1: We meant only to please you.
column2: And do you think I'm not going to eat myself to death this very night? Huh?

column1: Oh, she was so beautiful - and I was so <u>ugly</u>.
column2: Would you desert your friends?

column1: But also very young. Six to one is no odds, boy.
column2: Get me down from here you louts or I'll turn you all into pigs!

column1: Put me down, you lout!
column2: You had better manners as a pig.

column1: What are you doing with my dear? Stop! Thieves!
column2: Many villagers are hiding in the forest. They need food.

column1: And do you think I live on air?
column2: We have plenty of hares.

column1: Food for crows.
column2: Surely a sorcerer of the sauce pan can make rabbit taste like venison.

column1: I am being exploited! Where are you going?
column2: I must take the old man to see some sick children. Kegan will guard you.

column1: Oh, my poor stew!
column2: Oh, my poor stomach.

column1: Passable, pimple, very passable.
column2: The greatest boon of your otherwise worthless life, blockhead, is the privilege of dining on boar roasted by the hand of Ergo the Magnificent.

column1: I can't hold the weight of both of you!
column2: Hush!

column1: Look at its beauty. Look at its grace.
column2: Look at its insides.

column1: My spells always go wrong when I am observed. Be gone!
column2: The forest is not safe these days. You'd best travel with us.

column1: One with red eyes, the other with one eye, both trying to kill me.
column2: The one with red eyes was a Dark One, the other was a Cyclops, and it was not you he meant to kill.

column1: He was aiming a huge spear right at me!
column2: If that were so, you'd be dead now. He was aiming at the Dark One, for there is ancient hatred between them. Once his race had two eyes, like other men, until his forefathers bargained with the Dark Ones: they gave up one of their eyes in return for the power to see the future. But they were cheated, for the only future they were permitted to see was the time of their own death.

column1: He didn't join them. They joined him.
column2: And who is <u>he</u> that they should join <u>him</u>?

column1: He is the King.
column2: Well, at least I'm glad to see you have a sense of humor. That's the first smile I've seen on that gloomy face of your's ...  ... isn't it? It isn't. Oh no. Oh dear. Oh now I've gone and done it.

column1: They'll trample him to death!
column2: No. He will master the leader.

column1: I do not want your power. It is hideous.
column2: You know nothing of power, you foolish girl. You think power is a mighty sword, or a strong castle, or the paltry magic of an Emerald Seer. Power is none of these.

column1: I do not want your worlds or your slaves.
column2: Then look!

column1: It's a lie!
column2: These walls do not lie! He will betray you.

column1: He will not!
column2: Then he will die!

column1: He will come for me.
column2: He will not come. You will be my queen.

column1: What news from our friends?
column2: Barak is still strong in the north, and Tendo holds the high passes. But the great desert forts have fallen.

column1: Freylag's stronghold?
column2: It has been taken, Freylag and all his people slaughtered.

column1: It is only a few weeks and already half our strong places have fallen.
column2: The attacks are unceasing: by night, the Dark Ones

column1: It is the way of all invaders. Those they would conquer they divide, buying allies with promises of land and power.
column2: We will hold. Their power is not unlimited.

column1: Lord Rowan is one of Lyssa's godfathers. He will defend her in the ceremony. I wish that Lord Modred were here. He is a godfather of her own blood.
column2: Modred has treated with the Dark Ones.

column1: For some, the lure of power is stronger than the ties of blood. No matter. I had hoped to have the wedding next spring, Lord Turold, with all the nobles of the kingdom in attendance. But Fate and this war have ordained otherwise.
column2: It is important to assure the succession.

column1: I will tell you something you did not know, Turold. Had it been my choice, all those years ago, I would have chosen you for my king. But my parents chose otherwise.
column2: I knew.

column1: You knew! You are a rude bumpkin!
column2: That I am, my lady.

column1: A girl of some spirit, your daughter.
column2: A match for your son, I think.

column1: A fine match.
column2: They will have the life that you and I might have had.

column1: You were attacked in the forest?
column2: Yes. We lost five.

column1: I tried to reach Ynyr, the old one. I led a hundred men to his place in Granite Needle, but it was surrounded. The Dark Ones guard it by night and by day they call out the Slayers. Ynyr cannot get out and no one can get in.
column2: How many did you lose?

column1: Sixty at the needle, another thirty in the forest. Only ten of us made it back.
column2: We will have to try again. His knowledge is great. Without it, we cannot hope to win.

column1: Modred! Impossible!
column2: He leads a group of Slayers, under the leopard banner.

column1: We seek the Fortress of Krull.
column2: Such a vision will be opposed. Who seeks it?

column1: The new King.
column2: With an old voice?

column1: You know the voice.
column2: Yes. You have left your place in the Needle. It is the time, then.

column1: It is the time.
column2: I will seek the Fortress for you.

column1: Can you see?
column2: Yes. It is the Western Ocean.

column1: The Dark Ones will appose you with all their power.
column2: They will fail for, during the day, the power of the Circle is greater than theirs. Only at night can they pierce the Circle.

column1: Knowledge I wouldn't want.
column2: No. They are sad, solitary creatures, rarely seen.

column1: We'll seek an Emerald Seer. They have great powers of vision.
column2: There's an Emerald Circle a few leagues from here.  We'll find her.

column1: We can save half a day by crossing the Stone Lake.
column2: Many have perished in that maze.

column1: The leader of the Dark Ones?
column2: Yes.  Like you, a King. A King of many worlds. All enslaved.

column1: I must go to the widow. Perhaps she will help.
column2: The Widow of the Web?

column1: Yes.
column2: That creature helps no one. And none who go there return.

column1: She has the power of vision.
column2: She has the power to kill.

column1: Perhaps she will not kill me, for I know her name.
column2: Her name is Death.

column1: Few have survived it.
column2: Fewer will survive them.

column1: Each to his fate, lad.
column2: Each to his fate. Wait for me at the inn. If I am not back by dawn, you will know my fate, and you must go on without me.

column1: We must reach the Valley of Reeds before the next dawn.
column2: It's a hundred leagues from here.

column1: I'll stay behind and keep them busy.
column2: It is not necessary. They will not follow.

column1: Look.
column2: Yes, they are weakening. It takes great power to maintain the Fortress, and they have expended much.

column1: Kegan!
column2: It is too late. He has drunk.

column1: Go now.  Quell was wise. He knew that a man cannot ask more of his death than it help his friends.
column2: That is true.

column1: Who speaks that name!
column2: Ynyr!

column1: It is fifty years since I heard that name.
column2: It is fifty years since I spoke it to you.

column1: I was beautiful then.
column2: The most beautiful woman in the world.

column1: But you would not stay with me.
column2: Could not. Could not betray the girl to whom I was betrothed.

column1: She was not as beautiful.
column2: No, she was not as beautiful.

column1: She bore you many children?
column2: We had no children.

column1: You had a son.
column2: You said nothing. You told me nothing.

column1: You had left me! I kept silent out of rage.
column2: Where is he? My son.

column1: Do not try your trickery on me!
column2: It is no trickery.

column1: You see?
column2: Yes.

column1: Memory is no trick, it is a power. The power to see.
column2: Power you have given me. What can my power give you?

column1: Knowledge.
column2: Of what?

column1: The Fortress of Krull. When will it come near here?
column2: Why must you know?

column1: There is a girl there. Her name is Lyssa.
column2: You lie!

column1: Could I lie to you and still see your beauty?
column2: No.

column1: A young man seeks her. A young man about the age I was when I met you.
column2: Tomorrow, the Fortress of Krull will rise with the sun in the Valley of Reeds. But the knowledge is of no use to you. No man has ever escaped the Web. And soon the creature will come for you, even here.

column1: It will not help.
column2: Then the other Lyssa will share your fate. She will grow old in the Fortress as you have grown old here.

column1: I cannot stop the sand.
column2: You cannot stop time. Go now, before it runs out.

column1: You will come with me.
column2: There is sand enough for only one life. Go now, save the other.

column1: I'm a Sandman!
column2: I cut up a Sandman yesterday. They said I'd never get him... but I cut him up good, I did.

column1: For me? Better feel sorry for yourself, Sandman!
column2: No, for you! How old are you, Billy?

column1: Fourteen? Fifteen? Your days are running out. How long can you last? A year. Six months?  What happens when you're sixteen and you go green?
column2: Nothing will happen! I make the rules as I go!! Cubs do what I say! Always have! Always will! I got Cathedral and I'll never let go!

column1: No cubs over fifteen, Billy! Ever heard of a cub with a green flower? You'll leave Cathedral then, Billy, when you're on green, because they won't let a green stay here.  If you try to stay the young ones will gut-rip you apart!
column2: Shut up! Shut up your damn mouth!

column1: Are you too startled? Am I too removed from your ken?  I'm neither machine nor man... but a perfect fusion of the two... and better than either.  No human sculptor could match this greatness... don't you agree?
column2: All right -- what are you?

column1: We're hungry do you have anything to eat?
column2: Anything to eat?

column1: How do you think we got here??!!
column2: You walked in. I saw you. Don't you remember?

column1: Where do you think we came from?
column2: From? From? From?

column1: Hiding? Yes! Hiding, hiding.
column2: Where do we go?!  Where do we go from here??!!

column1: Is that the wind?  Not yet...  You must hear my birds sing.
column2: You know about Sanctuary! I know you do! You have to help us! You don't have a choice! It isn't your decision!! Tell us.

column1: Never a pair. I have never had a pair.
column2: Where do you send them?

column1: Answer the question!
column2: Do you know how long all this will last? Not thirty years... or thirty thousand years... but thirty thousand years... and you'll be part of it. Ages will roll... Ages. And you'll be here... the two of you... eternally frozen... frozen... beautiful.

column1: There must be somebody else up here. I can't believe that he's --
column2: Let me sculpt you and I will show you where the others have gone.

column1: That's better.  How do you want us?
column2: Nude. Imagine, a pair.

column1: How do you want us?
column2: Up there.

column1: All right. Now you keep your bargain.
column2: Wait for the wind! Wait and hear the birds sing over you!

column1: How did they get in here?
column2: Regular storage procedure... the same as the other food... The other food stopped coming and they started.

column1: What other food?
column2: Fish and plankton, sea greens and protein from the sea.  It's all here -- ready -- fresh as harvest day. Fish and plankton, sea greens and protein from the sea... And then it stopped coming and they...  ...came instead. So I store them here. I'm ready. And you're ready. It's my Job -- protein, plankton, grass from the sea.

column1: It's a real privilege, Sandman.
column2: Thanks.  I thought you'd be older. I expected a Red.

column1: I am.
column2: Your own work?

column1: I designed it myself.  What'll it be... a face job or a full-body job?
column2: Just the face.

column1: Do you have anything special in mind?
column2: I don't care... Just get it over with.

column1: You are here. I couldn't believe it when they told me. What are you doing?
column2: Turn this way.  No, no... not you... YOU!

column1: You should've seen me take my last Runner... perfect.  I backed him up against a residence pool and when he terminated... his hand...  So now you've seen him... what's the difference awake or asleep?
column2: Open your eyes once, idiot.  It's not every day that a Sandman son is born. I'm telling you, Francis -- that's him!

column1: Had enough?
column2: Even the alarm didn't wake him.

column1: You need a lift. Let's go to Arcade and celebrate...  your alert successor... Logan-6.
column2: Has anyone ever broken in to where the babies are?

column1: Why?
column2: Just wondered... what happens?

column1: But you don't know, you just say what everyone says. "One for one. One for one."
column2: Well, why not!? That's exactly how everything works. How else could the city stay in balance -- You have a better idea?

column1: No, but at least I wonder sometimes -- instead of doing that "one for one" song of yours. You sound like a sleepteacher with a stuck tape.
column2: Well the minute you get a better idea you can stop wondering.  You know, Logan -- you wonder a lot. Too much for a Sandman.

column1: Did you ever see Francis-8?
column2: I never even visited Nursery before tonight.  When you wonder, it slows you up -- you know?

column1: I don't know what makes you so curious. You have any idea who his seed-mother was?
column2: Of course not! I'm curious, not sick.

column1: You missed something special.
column2: Well... you can't have them all.

column1: The damned Yellows are getting out of hand. Those three ought to be in Cathedral. No business scrambling in Arcade...
column2: What an old, old man you're getting to be, Francis. Weren't you ever a Yellow? I bet you were even wilder than --  come on, Sandman.

column1: You should have been with us in Nursery, Daniel. I'm positive I recognized him --
column2: Come on. I don't want to miss the filing-in. There'll be some I know tonight, I think...

column1: Now there's a few who could have been his seed-mother.
column2: Only a few? You're just not trying.

column1: Who invited you?
column2: I'm in my party mood.

column1: That was a great shot you made.
column2: Yes.  But you look a little rusty to me -- what were you doing, wondering?

column1: I just might look in on New You 483 myself.
column2: You? Why? You're already beautiful.

column1: What the hell took you so long?
column2: Did you ever see anybody renew?

column1: I think you've been skulling out too much. First Nursery and now stupid questions.
column2: Did you?

column1: Of course.
column2: Anybody we know?

column1: Look... why don't you get into the water... you need it... more than I do.
column2: I'm fine...  See you...

column1: What's going on, Logan?!
column2: It has nothing to do with you.

column1: Why did you do that??!!
column2: I didn't do anything, Francis! They've made us believe that...

column1: It's him! The first Sandman. He killed... Doc.
column2: No, Holly -- wait! He's running. Tell them the rest!

column1: He's the one. You too. I remember. He was in a hurry. Just a face job. Dark hair, I said. Then he killed Doc and you grabbed me -- and the machine blew up and I ran... I ran.
column2: Holly. Holly! Please... The other Sandman. Remember the one who came after --

column1: That's right. The other one came after. The older one. Smashing, killing, burning!
column2: ...and he was hunting the first one, this one. Wasn't he? Wasn't he? This one was running, the other one was hunting him...

column1: What's your name?
column2: I'm Mary 2.

column1: Where do you live, Mary?
column2: Here.

column1: Why aren't you in Nursery?
column2: I'm very smart.

column1: When do you go up?
column2: I never go upstairs. You're a nice old lady.

column1: What's wrong, Available?
column2: Please... No.

column1: Please... no?  You mean "not here" -- that's it? You're a private Available but particular.  Don't worry. There's no one here but me. And you.
column2: No.  Just no.

column1: You prefer women?
column2: No.

column1: Well then...?
column2: Nothing. I felt sad, I put myself on the circuit. It was a mistake.

column1: Sad? What made you sad?
column2: A friend of mine went on Carousel tonight. Now he's gone.

column1: Yes... probably he was renewed?
column2: He was killed.

column1: Killed? Why do you use that word?
column2: Isn't it right? Isn't that what you do? Kill.

column1: I never 'killed' anybody in my life. Sandmen terminate Runners.  Who brought you?
column2: Nobody. I felt sad... I put myself on the circuit.

column1: You felt sad. What's your name?
column2: Jessica.

column1: You're beautiful. Let's have sex.
column2: No.

column1: Later.
column2: No.

column1: But you put yourself on the circuit!
column2: I thought I had to do something.

column1: And?
column2: I changed my mind.

column1: And now?
column2: Curious.

column1: About what?
column2: How a Sandman lives.

column1: Let's have sex.  I thought you were curious.
column2: Not about that.

column1: I'm listening.
column2: I'm afraid to tell you.

column1: I'm not armed.  Well?
column2: Why is it wrong to run?

column1: You shouldn't even think such things...  And you picked a strange person to say them to --
column2: I suppose. But what if you want to live?

column1: But if you're one of the misfits... that's where I come in.
column2: I didn't say that I would run... I just...

column1: Are you a 5 or a 6?
column2: Six. I go red next year.

column1: What Quad do you live in?
column2: K.

column1: You could have called me yourself.
column2: But I wasn't sure you'd come.

column1: I couldn't get you out of my mind.
column2: I'm the most beautiful woman you've ever seen, I suppose?

column1: Maybe... sure...
column2: Thanks... but I have the choice.

column1: Of course.
column2: Then it's still no.

column1: You can have any woman in the city. What do you really want?
column2: You know.

column1: I don't believe you. There has to be more.
column2: All right.

column1: Why show me?
column2: I'm going to run.

column1: Why tell me?
column2: You know something.

column1: About running, dying what?
column2: Both... running's what I'm interested in.

column1: I know what everyone knows. Try like hell for Renewal. You have the same chance everyone else has.
column2: It's different now. Help me.

column1: Where did you get that?
column2: A Runner gave it to me.

column1: And then you killed him, right?
column2: I let him go... believe me.

column1: I don't..
column2: Speak to your friends for me, Jessica... please...

column1: Please? What friends?
column2: I don't have much time.

column1: I never heard of a Sandman running... ever...
column2: And I never heard of Sanctuary.

column1: Are you here to help me?
column2: What do you need?

column1: What're you going to do?
column2: That's tomorrow.

column1: I wish I could help you.
column2: Maybe you'll think of something...

column1: If you did know, you'd tell me.
column2: Of course --

column1: If you trusted me, you'd know.
column2: We're coming to Arcade.  Shall we Relive together?

column1: A Runner... Cathedral. A woman.
column2: You're not going, are you?

column1: I'd rather be with you.
column2: That's nice.

column1: They're like beasts. Wild.
column2: Maybe they're angry because they're grown in meccano-breeders.

column1: Instead of what? Nine months inside a woman:  We're all raised the same but most of us don't become cubs in Cathedral.
column2: Some people say children need human mothering.

column1: Insane. Nurseries are better than any mother could be.
column2: I'm only telling you what I've heard...  Haven't you ever wondered what your seed-mother was Like...?

column1: Uh-uh.
column2: I have.

column1: When did you begin to question Lastday?
column2: I don't remember exactly... except I was a Green.  What would you like to relive, Logan?

column1: Just follow -- no matter how it seems...
column2: But what is this -- why?

column1: The Cubs. When they're flying on muscle there's no way to catch up. Without the dazzle, they'd just go past us --  -- too fast
column2: Muscle? I don't know that one.

column1: I'm ashamed. I was bringing you to be killed.
column2: Where? Sanctuary? Can you take me there?

column1: Logan, I don't know where Sanctuary is. But if I take you to them, they'll kill you.
column2: All right. But why? I didn't kill the Runner.

column1: Yes, but they won't know that... or care. They're hunting you, Logan. Maybe me too, now...
column2: That's nothing... there's a Sandman behind us, too and there'll be more soon. Take me to them.

column1: I -- I can't.
column2: Then -- why don't you leave me -- go to them -- explain

column1: Are you taking me to them?
column2: Yes.  I don't know what else to do -- with him following us.  Why do you keep running from your --

column1: Because he's my friend --  and I don't want to be killed by him -- or anyone.
column2: He's good, isn't he?

column1: Will he find us and kill us? Yes... or one of the others.  You know there's only one place to go now...
column2: They won't believe us.

column1: I'd rather take my chances with them... than with Francis.
column2: They won't listen.

column1: You think Sandmen will?  There's no other way for me,
column2: We'll convince them.

column1: Exactly four steps now. Let me lead you.  Now to the right. It's narrow here, you'll have to get behind me.
column2: How will they know we're coming?

column1: Will you take me with you?
column2: Why, Jessica? You're still a green.

column1: How do we know this is the right way?
column2: It's the only way.

column1: What do you suppose this was...?
column2: Some kind of breeding pens... I suppose... They say people used to breed animals, fish, anything...  ...to eat, of course.

column1: I'm afraid.
column2: It's brighter there... besides, we can't go back.

column1: I don't know what's going to happen to us Logan but --  Are you glad you didn't kill him?
column2: It doesn't make any difference anymore.

column1: You're really one of us now, aren't you?
column2: You knew that I wasn't before, didn't you?  Why did you stay with me?

column1: I wanted to...  ...And you... what made you kill Sandmen?
column2: I had to. I did kill... for the first time in my life I killed.

column1: Because you felt like a Runner, didn't you.
column2: I guess so... I know I felt something I never felt before... and I didn't like it... not a bit.  I'll tell you one thing... Sanctuary better be worth it. That's the last place for me to live now.

column1: What's that?
column2: It feels like breath. It makes everything move. Your hair is moving.

column1: I hate outside! I hate it!
column2: We'll be all right...  We will...

column1: Don't!
column2: Sooner or later, we'll have to try something.

column1: It's getting dark and cold. I'm tired.
column2: Why don't we rest here? We know we can eat these.

column1: Do you think everything's going to turn to ice?
column2: I doubt it.

column1: Don't ever let go.
column2: I won't.

column1: It all seemed to make sense until Box.
column2: Do you think he was telling the Truth?

column1: Maybe we're the first ones to get through...  Maybe Sanctuary is near, now... another protected place. It couldn't be outside.
column2: How would anyone know? Even if we find it -- we can never go back.

column1: You're right... it must be near now. We'll find it.
column2: Thirty thousand years didn't last very long, did they?

column1: What does it mean?
column2: The Lifeclocks have no power outside.

column1: You can have any woman in the city. What do you really want?
column2: You know, Jessica.

column1: ...But I still have the choice...?
column2: Of course.

column1: I have never seen a face like that before. It must be the look of great age. Whoever he was he was terribly old.
column2: Yes, do you think that's why he looks so sad?

column1: They all have names and numbers on them. I wonder what they are?
column2: "Beloved Husband". "Beloved Wife". What can all that mean?

column1: Look at his face... and his hair...  Is that what it is to grow old?
column2: It could be...

column1: That sweet madman -- how could he come to exist?
column2: He had a mother and father -- and he knew them.

column1: There's a Sanctuary... there is!
column2: You want there to be one... that doesn't...

column1: There has to be! I know it exists! It has to!!
column2: No, there doesn't. Not really -- just so many want it to exist... so many who don't want to die... want it so much that a place called Sanctuary becomes "real". But it doesn't exist. It never existed. Just the hope.

column1: What are we promising him? What can we possibly give him?
column2: He asked if we would bury him when his time comes.

column1: We can't. We're going back.
column2: To what?

column1: I'm going to try and tell people what we've seen and --
column2: You're lying! You'll never have the chance to tell anybody anything! You'll be killed the moment you're seen!

column1: Do you expect me to let things go on without trying to change them?!
column2: Things won't change... you know that! We can live here together, Logan... have a life as long as his... together!

column1: Things change!
column2: You want to go back to kill, is that it?! Now, you'll want to kill your own!!! Kill Sandmen!!! Killing's all you ever...!!!

column1: Jessica... listen to me... listen to me...  The Lifeclocks made me kill Francis. They make people die or be killed every day. If I didn't try and destroy that... I couldn't live here or anywhere. Do you understand?
column2: I want to be alive and with you, that's all I want.

column1: "Beloved son"...  So people stayed together for that feeling of love... They would live and raise children together and be remembered.  I think I feel that way, Logan. Can we be that way?
column2: Yes. You and I, Jessica.

column1: And Sanctuary?
column2: Sanctuary is the right to live... nothing more. But nothing less, either...

column1: Beloved husband...
column2: Beloved wife...

column1: What does that water do?
column2: It's part of the hydrogalvanic system. The ocean tides are changed into energy somehow.

column1: Is it inside the city?
column2: Of course.  I don't know where...  I just took them for granted.  It's our only chance.

column1: Yes, cats, of course. What else could they be? Cats. Of course each one has his own name too.
column2: But there are so many of them. Do you know each one separately.

column1: And... and how were you grown? Inside your mother?
column2: Yes...

column1: Are you sure?
column2: Mother and Father said so... you know?

column1: What kind of jewel is this?
column2: I don't know.

column1: You're both full of secrets like Macavity.  Did you steal this?
column2: No.

column1: What belongs to the people?
column2: All this. All of it.

column1: What people?
column2: I don't know... but it does.

column1: We'll have to bury him.
column2: What's that?

column1: I'll make the arrangements.
column2: At least it's over...

column1: Of course... that's settled then. But just you remember your promise...
column2: We'll remember. But that's a long time off...

column1: Come with us.
column2: Where are you going?

column1: Goodbye.
column2: Oh, my...

column1: Hello, Sandman.
column2: Hello.

column1: We don't get many Sandmen. I think we've only had one other since I've been here.
column2: A Sandman can get as sick of his face as anyone else. Where's the doctor?

column1: I like your face. Would you mind if Doc took a picture? I'd like him to give your face to somebody else.
column2: It's all right with me. Is he here?

column1: My name's Holly... Holly 13. In ancient times they said my number was unlucky. Do you believe in luck?
column2: No -- Look, I'm in a hurry.

column1: How long have you been living here?
column2: For as long as I can remember.

column1: What kind of place is this?
column2: Just a place, I suppose... who knows?

column1: How did you get here?
column2: I have always been here...

column1: Are there any other humans?
column2: Gracious... no.

column1: But there may be a few around somewhere.
column2: What makes you think so?

column1: My parents thought so. Mother and Father. You know?
column2: Mother and -- ? You knew your mother and father?

column1: Where are they?
column2: Dead... they're dead... and buried.

column1: They're beautiful. May I have one too please?
column2: No -- I'm sorry. It's not possible.

column1: It isn't fair. I'll give you one of my favorite cats... a Jellicle cat.  "Jellicle cats have cheerful faces, Jellicle cats have bright black eyes
column2: I'm sorry but I don't have anything to give you.

column1: What's beyond this place -- do you know?
column2: No, no, no

column1: Did your Mother or Father ever mention another place?
column2: Never, never, ever. Nothing.

column1: May we stay here for a while? We'd like to rest.
column2: Of course you can stay. This belongs to the people.

column1: Are you ready to put him in?
column2: Not yet.

column1: We're leaving.
column2: What a pity. I was hoping you'd be here to bury me.

column1: To a city with thousands and thousands of people.
column2: Alive?

column1: Thousands and thousands... as many as my cats?
column2: More... many more.

column1: Is that really it? It doesn't seem very far. Will we be there soon?
column2: I promise. We'll go on as soon as it's light.

column1: That's better than gold when it's cold.
column2: Thank you.  Tell me -- what do those words mean? "Beloved husband"... "Beloved son"... "Beloved wife"...

column1: My father was the husband and my mother was the wife. "Beloved" is a word they used -- to stay together.
column2: Stay? They lived together all their years?

column1: I know...  We're going to try and get in this way. I don't think you can make it.
column2: Oh... I did so look forward to seeing all those people.

column1: I'm sorry.
column2: Yes...

column1: Can you make it back?
column2: Oh my... I'll try.

column1: Break-in scanners report intrusion, identify.
column2: Logan-5... Francis-7, authorized duty quadrant. Intrusion accidental.

column1: I don't know who you are. I'd like to thank someone.
column2: It doesn't matter who we are. Follow the tunnel to the end.

column1: Someone will follow. When you come to the lock, he will tell you how to go on the other side. Jessica may go with you as far as the lock.
column2: No. Jessica goes back now. Take her back.  Now! Go on back. Back outside, Jessica.

column1: Well? How do you like it?
column2: I don't know. The cheeks maybe... look a little --

column1: Cheeks? Cheeks? Right. Too much, you think?
column2: Too little.

column1: No -- just there -- on the first level.  Don't look for us. We'll see you.
column2: You don't seem quite sure, Jessica.  Can you do it? Will you?

column1: The hell happened?
column2: Hesitated, sir.

column1: You shot an eight year old girl.
column2: Uh... yes.  Apparently I did, air.

column1: The hell were you thinking?
column2: Well, I dunno.  I mean, when you looked at all the other options... it just seemed sorta obvious.

column1: Sir, before you boot me, I just want to explain.  I mean, okay, you got a goat-guy with a hook for a head...
column2: Cowan--

column1: Wait.  Uh-- sir.  Please.  Anyway.  Hook-head-guy.  I'm thinking "how can he think with a hook for a head?" Answer: that's not his head. Then I think--
column2: Cowan--

column1: of course not, cause his head is that thing way on the other side of the road, cause, if you looked at it, the entire sidewalk full of stuff was actually ONE GUY and--
column2: Cowan-- will you shut your god damed mouth?

column1: Yes.  That's true.  Actually, at this point, I just want A job.  Wait. What do you mean... yet?
column2: It means I know you think you got a beat on things.  But trust me, you don't.  You don't even have an inkling of a hint of a clue as to what's really going on in the world.    And if you want to find out even a little, you'll shut up and come with me. And if you don't, fine.  Go with them. Cause I'm not interested in breaking in another little hot-shot only to have him wig or die on me just when I'm starting to count on him.  So forgive me if you don't exactly hear me ringing little bells and whistling welcome aboard, but this isn't the Love Boat.  And I'm not Captain Fucking Stubing.  Now I'm sorry.  But this has been one long, bad day.

column1: So... this door.  It's... not an exit...  ?
column2: It's not even a fucking door.

column1: ...touch that.
column2: What the hell...

column1: Kids' game a couple galaxies over.
column2: I guess I lost:

column1: We have one motto: Peace on Earth.
column2: And Goodwill Toward Man?

column1: No. just peace on Earth.
column2: I gotta be honest about something.

column1: Once I thought the biggest thing I'll ever do was guard the president.
column2: Oh, you'll still, be guarding him.

column1: It's easy.  You work your way up the secret service, one day stand with the President, meet the most important people on the planet, fulfill your dreams, live happily ever after.
column2: And if I say yes?

column1: ... think that maybe my supervisors referred me here because of certain issues which I assure you I have spent a good deal of time working very hard to correct--
column2: Your supervisors have no idea why you're here.

column1: They don't?
column2: They don't.  Now, son.  If you get the job, you're going to be working with some very particular people who like to do things in some very particular ways.  Here's a little piece of advice:    Don't use this so much.

column1: What's so funny, cadet Cowan?
column2: I... I don't know, air.  This guy. Mr. "Best of the best of the best... " I don't know.  It's just still find it a little...  humorous.  I'm sorry.  Sir.

column1: Well... you know, when you say "normal," what, exactly...
column2: For instance...  It says here you lost your parents at 15, and, since then...

column1: Sir.  I thought those records were sealed.
column2: We're the government, Cowan.

column1: You think we're nuts.
column2: No-- it makes sense.  Cause I gotta tell ya, when I was in third grade they told me I was crazy cause I swore that our teacher was from, like, Venus or something.

column1: Only the damn guy won't know it.
column2: What happens if I say no?

column1: From now on, you'll respond only to the name "Jay." You'll dress in appropriate attire specially sanctioned by the INS Special Services. You're not to stand out in any way.  Understand?
column2: Yes, sir.

column1: Everybody, listen up: we've had a tremendous amount of movement lately. Be aware.  Be safe.  Have a good day.  Oh, uh... Cowan?
column2: Yes, air? -- OOOMPH.

column1: Hell of an assistant, isn't he?  Damn guy moves so fast, he actually gets there before you even ask for him.
column2: Sorta literally gets ahead of himself.

column1: So... wait.  You just asked... but he goes so fast, he actually brought what you asked for before you asked for it.
column2: His physics are a little different than ours.  Don't worry

column1: It'll make sense later?
column2: No. But You'll get used to it.    Welcome to the Men in Black.

column1: Sorry, Cowan, I found out literally just before the ceremony.' Apparently you're to report for further review.
column2: Further... what are you talking about, air?  That makes no sense-- I hold three cadet class records--

column1: Bull... loney- Sir.  I'm sorry.  Sir, I'm sorry. Sir.  I just, I find it hard to believe that it didn't come from you.  I mean, everything here comes from you.
column2: Well this didn't.

column1: Look. I don't know why.  I could guess, however.  Maybe it's your attitude.  Or that you're not even close to a team player.  Or that you always seen to think you know more than your supervisors.
column2: Actually, sir--

column1: Cowan.  Do you ever think that maybe, just maybe, other people might be right and you might be wrong?
column2: All the time, sir.

column1: You do?
column2: Yes, air.  But I'm usually wrong. Sir.

column1: Which do you have your money on, Dee?
column2: I'd go with number three.

column1: Mikey.  Hold it, Mikey-- I want you to talk to me.  Mikey.  I'm telling you.. don't make me... Mikey   Gimme the 140.
column2: Oh. Shit. it's in the car--

column1: Little more burn on the perimeter-they weren't roasting smores here. Dig out this hole a little.  Cmon, I know it's late, but the sooner we get it right, the sooner we'll all be home.
column2: Kay, I'm sorry...

column1: Kay, listen, I dunno what got into--
column2: Don't worry about it.  It's been a long night.  Speaking of which-- you owe me a cup of coffee, remember?

column1: I wasn't scared...
column2: Oh yeah?  The hell you weren't. Little pither just out of school...

column1: Grab the coffee, will ya?  I told Zed I'd give him a buzz.
