column1: Somebody named Leo Crow.
column2: And who the hell is that?

column1: I have no idea.  I've never heard of him.  But I'm supposed to kill him in less than thirty-six hours.
column2: All right, John, just take a breath, let's think about this...

column1: I'm out of breath!  I'm a fucking fugitive!
column2: Then come to my house.  We'll talk --

column1: I can't.  They're following me right now.  They'll meet me there. They'll halo me.
column2: How could Witwer have accessed the case file?

column1: Can you fake the cerebral output?
column2: We're years from that.  John, I'm asking you: please, come in, we'll shut down the system until we get this thing figured out.

column1: You know I can't do that.  You can't do that...  Lamar, I need you to talk to Wally, see if Witwer's gone inside the temple again.  Then ask Jad for any off hour EYEdents into the analytical room --
column2: John.  Just tell me, who's Leo Crow?

column1: John.  Please.  Listen to me --
column2: I'm not getting halo'd.

column1: You can't run --
column2: Everybody runs.

column1: John --
column2: I just wanted to congratulate you. You did it.  You've created a world without murder.  So what if you had to kill someone to do it.

column1: People want to believe in the system.  That's the beauty of it...
column2: Beauty?  The precogs don't even always agree with each other!

column1: No doubt the Precogs have already seen this.
column2: No doubt.

column1: Seventeen minutes.
column2: Armor up -- sick-sticks and concussion guns -- this is gonna be close.

column1: Chief, the investigator from the Fed is here.
column2: You're kidding, that's today?

column1: I wrote it down in your calendar, then left a message at your house --
column2: All I need, some twink from the Fed poking around right now.  Check again with the paper, they had it forwarded.  See if the neighbors know where they went, check all relations --

column1: Uh, sir...
column2: Get him some coffee and tell him to wait outside.

column1: What he's doing now, we call "scrubbing the image", looking for clues as to where the murder's going to happen.
column2: The brick has been repointed, the glass is original with new glazing bars.  I show composite mouldings with dentils.  Someone took care in the renovation.  Let's find the architect...

column1: Victims are pronounced here. Killers here.  We never touch anything.
column2: I show a cop on horseback.

column1: Don't run, Chief.  You know we'll catch you.  You trained us.
column2: Everybody runs.

column1: You don't have to do this, Chief.
column2: You don't have to chase me, Fletcher.

column1: Okay, Jad, what's coming?
column2: Red Ball -- double homicide: one male, one female.  Killer's male, white, 40's.

column1: We need confirmation on the time frame.  Location still uncertain. Remote witnesses are hooked in...
column2: Case #1108, previsualized by the Precogs and recorded on holoshpere by Precrime's q-stacks.  My fellow witnesses for case #1108 are Dr. Katherine James and Chief Justice Frank Pollard.

column1: We can't grab it...
column2: Run the subscription list...

column1: Got him in the Foxhall.  4421 Gainsborough.
column2: Send a DCPD blue & white out there, set up a perimeter and tell 'em we're en route.  What's our confirmed time?

column1: Somewhere near the capital?
column2: No maglev system.

column1: The mall?
column2: Georgetown.

column1: Look at the kid.  In this one, he's on the left of the man in the suit.
column2: Yeah?  So?

column1: Go ahead.
column2: Did he close the front door?

column1: What?
column2: Did Marks close the front door?!

column1: You guys are nodding your heads like you actually know what the hell he's talking about.
column2: Come on, Chief, you think about it, the way we work -- changing destiny and all -- we're more like clergy than cops.

column1: Uh-huh.  Jad?
column2: Sir?

column1: Jad.  How come you're not out there with Father Witwer?
column2: We're in motion on something.

column1: Red Ball?
column2: Nope.  Somebody's thinking about this one.

column1: The victim's name is Leo Crow.
column2: Start a location run and a contact search for future victim Leo Crow.  And, Jad, I'll need a Last Known Sheet when you get it.

column1: I've got no address -- last known or otherwise -- no tax returns for the last five years.
column2: Check NCIC, maybe he's got a record.  Then send a protection team as soon as we lock the location.

column1: I show time of occurrence, Friday at fifteen-zero-six hours.
column2: That was easy.

column1: Confirm with trig and image.
column2: Any ID on the shooter yet?

column1: Uh, yeah, you mind getting me a piece of that cake they're eating down there?  I'm starving.
column2: Sure, Chief.  I think I'll grab one for myself while I'm at it...

column1: I'm sorry Danny, but I'll have to give you the full tour later on.
column2: Your secretaries were all kind enough to give me a look around the office...

column1: As I recall, they outlawed compression firearms in the District ten years ago.
column2: They did.  Make yourself comfortable.  We'll be back in an hour.

column1: But it's not the future if you stop it.  Isn't that a fundamental paradox?
column2: Yes, it is.

column1: Why did you catch that?
column2: Because it was going to fall.

column1: You're certain?
column2: Yes.

column1: The fact that you prevented it from happening doesn't change the fact that it was going to happen.
column2: You ever get any false positives? Someone intends to kill his boss or his wife, but they never go through with it.  How do the precogs tell the difference?

column1: The Precogs don't see what you intend to do, only what you will do.
column2: Then why can't they see rapes, or assaults... or suicides?

column1: It was Iris Hineman.  She developed the Precogs, designed the system and pioneered the interface.
column2: Speaking of interfacing, I'd love to say hello.

column1: To them.
column2: Cops aren't allowed inside the temple.

column1: Really?  You've never been inside?
column2: We keep a strict separation so that no one can accuse us of tampering.

column1: So I'll be the first one to go in then?
column2: Maybe you didn't hear me.

column1: If it's a question of authority.
column2: There's no question.  You don't have any.

column1: I find it interesting that some people have begun to deify the precogs.
column2: The precogs are pattern recognition filters, nothing more.

column1: But you call this room the "temple".
column2: Just a nickname.

column1: Sorry.  Old habit.  I spent three years at Fuller Seminary before I became a cop.  My father was a minister.  Lutheran.
column2: What does he think of your chosen line of work?

column1: At least now you -- and I -- have the chance to make sure that kind of thing doesn't happen to anyone ever again.
column2: Why don't you cut the cute act, Danny, and tell me exactly what it is you're looking for?

column1: Flaws.
column2: There hasn't been a murder in six years.  There's nothing wrong with the system.  It's perfect.

column1: You set me up...
column2: I'll write the paranoia off to the whiff you been doping on all night.

column1: It seems I've found a flaw, John  You.
column2: You gonna tell on me?

column1: I can't touch you!  And John, you can't be in here!  You'll confuse them!
column2: Wally.  This is Danny Witwer.  He's from Justice and we're to give him a full run of the farm.

column1: They're not in any pain.  We keep their heads pretty well stocked with dopamine and endorphins. Plus, we maintain careful control over their serotonin levels -- don't want 'em to drift off to sleep, but they can't be kept too awake either.
column2: It helps if you don't think of them as human.

column1: Her pituitary dumped a week's worth into her system... What did you do to her?
column2: Nothing... she grabbed me, and then there was an image on the screen...

column1: She was looking right at me.
column2: It could have been a nightmare... Sometimes they dream about the old murders.

column1: She spoke to me.
column2: To you?  I don't think so...  What'd she say?

column1: Wally, listen to me...
column2: Do I know you?  Who are you?

column1: I like you, Wally, so I'm not gonna kick you, or hit you with anything, but only if you promise to help me...
column2: Oh... Hi, John.

column1: Are these all of her previsions?
column2: There's no way of knowing for sure. She could've forgotten whatever it is you're looking for...

column1: Just go to the beginning!
column2: Okay.  Fine.  Where the hell is that?

column1: Detective.  Nice of you to come down here.  Seeing as every cop in the world is looking for you right now.  Jesus, what's up with your eye?
column2: I need your help.

column1: Well, hey, you didn't have to come all the way down here.  For you, Chief, I make housecalls...
column2: I need help with her.

column1: I'm impressed, Anderton.  You're on the lam, but you still got the time and energy to slice off a little jerky for yourself.
column2: Rufus.  She's a precog.

column1: She's a precog?
column2: That's right.

column1: Are you reading my mind right now?
column2: Rufus, for Christ's sake, get up.

column1: She's got information inside of her.  I need you to get it out.
column2: No.  No way.  I wouldn't even know where to begin!  Those thoughts about my cousin Elena -- they were just thoughts. I would never --

column1: C'mon, Rufus, you've been busted twice for felony hacking.
column2: So?

column1: I tell you what.  I do this, I get to keep whatever images I get from her head.
column2: They don't belong to anybody.

column1: Stop --
column2: Tell me how.

column1: What happened?  Where's the rest?
column2: I guess that's all of it.

column1: Rufus, play it back...
column2: Uh, I'll try...

column1: I scored a goal!
column2: That's great.

column1: I won!
column2: What a big boy.  How old are you?

column1: Four.  Wow.  What a big boy.  I love you, Sean.
column2: I love you, too!  I love you daddy.  Love ya, dad.

column1: Okay... now let me time you.
column2: Are you kidding?  There's absolutely positively no way, on my best day, I could ever beat twelve seconds!

column1: Come on!
column2: All right, I'll try...

column1: Sean -- you're not real.
column2: You gotta have faith, Dad.

column1: It's a little late for that.
column2: Wanna hear something funny?

column1: What the hell.
column2: I lived for a year with a man who was pretending to be my father.  He took me all over the world.

column1: You're alive?
column2: No.  He got tired of pretending.

column1: Oh, Sean --
column2: The funny thing is, I started to believe he really was my Dad.

column1: Sean --
column2: I feel bad about that.  I need you to forgive me.

column1: I forgive you.
column2: Once I even told him I loved him.

column1: I forgive you...
column2: The more you want to believe something, the easier it is to be fooled.

column1: I was looking for you...
column2: I know that.  I know you would have done anything to find me.  I know you would have died for me.

column1: I wanted to.
column2: Good-bye, Dad...

column1: Who are you?
column2: I'm your son.  I'm you.

column1: Sean, wait...
column2: Hold your breath, Dad...

column1: Six years ago.  Baltimore.  You grabbed a kid at Francis public pool in the West End.
column2: Did I?  I don't recall... I got lots of kids from that place --

column1: Do you know who I am?
column2: Some -- somebody's father?

column1: ... and that I needed his help.  It wasn't so bad really.  I sang him a song, made him laugh, bought him a pretzel.  I took care of him.  I made him happy.
column2: He's alive?

column1: Where've you got him?  Is he all right?  Tell me, you fuck -- WHERE IS HE?!
column2: I put him in a barrel and sunk him in the bay.

column1: It floated back up.  I had to take him out and --
column2: NO!

column1: You're not gonna kill me?
column2: No.

column1: But you have to.  They said you would.
column2: The precogs were wrong.

column1: You're supposed to kill me.  He said you would.
column2: Who said I would?

column1: Look, I've put my family through enough misery.  You gotta kill me! This way I can leave 'em something.
column2: Crow.  I'm not gonna kill you.

column1: Look, believe me, I know it's hard, but you gotta do it --
column2: I'm asking you again, who made you do this?

column1: I don't know -- I never saw his face.  All I know is, the next day I was out, so the guy must've had juice somewhere.  Look, man, you gotta go through with this.
column2: What the fuck is going on?

column1: What about the picture --
column2: Fake.  He gave it to me.  Now --  -- shoot me, Goddammit, before I lose my nerve!

column1: Tell me, who was it, set this up?
column2: If I tell you, my family gets nothing.

column1: Who made you do this?
column2: Kill me!

column1: Let go of the gun.
column2: You're not gonna kill me...

column1: Something wrong?
column2: I'm a little dizzy...

column1: Yes, I'm afraid that would be from the Doll's Eye.
column2: The what?

column1: You have three minutes to tell me what you're doing here before I feed you to a few of my more predacious plants.
column2: I'm... not... a... killer.

column1: Just what is it you think I can do for you?
column2: You can tell me how someone... could fake a prevision.

column1: What's so funny?
column2: If the unintended consequences of a series of genetic mistakes and science gone haywire can be called invention, then yes, I invented precrime.

column1: You don't seem all that proud.
column2: I'm not.  I was trying to heal them, not turn them into... something else.

column1: Heal who?
column2: The innocents we now use to stop the guilty.

column1: You're talking about the precogs...
column2: You think the three in the tank come from a test tube?  They're merely the ones who survived.

column1: It began as play.  A guessing game like you play with any toddler, except these children always guessed right.  And then the nightmares started. They were all different, but all the same.  They were all about murder.  And the murders were all happening.
column2: And how did Lamar become involved?

column1: Back then, he was still a DA, and quite a few parents of my patients had passed through his courtroom. You have to understand, these people were the dregs of society. But once they saw their children... he decided he would do whatever he could for them.  He's that way, you know, paternal about certain things.  Precrime.  The precogs. You.
column2: You say some of the children died?

column1: So many of them... despite what we did for them.  Or maybe because of what we did to them.  It doesn't matter.  It's a perfect system now, isn't it?
column2: I'm not a murderer.  I've never even met the man I'm supposed to kill.

column1: And, yet, a chain of events has started.  A chain that will lead inexorably to his death.
column2: Not if I stay away from him.

column1: How can you avoid a man you've never met?
column2: So you won't help me?

column1: What?
column2: Most of the time, all three Precognitives will see an event in the same way.  But once in a while, one of them will see things differently than the other two.

column1: Jesus Christ -- why didn't I know about this?
column2: Because these Minority Reports are destroyed the instant they occur.

column1: Why?
column2: Obviously, for Precrime to function, there can't be any suggestion of fallibility.  After all, what good is a Justice system that instills doubt?  It may be reasonable, but it's still doubt.

column1: You're saying that I've halo'd innocent people?
column2: I'm saying that every so often those accused of a precrime might, just might, have an alternate future.

column1: Does Burgess know about this? About the Minority Report?
column2: I used to joke with Lamar that we were the mother and father of Precrime.  Well, in my experience, parents often see their children as they want them to be, not as they are.

column1: Answer my question.  Did Lamar Burgess know about the Minority Report?
column2: Yes, of course, he knew, but at the time, he felt -- we both felt their existence was... an insignificant variable.

column1: Insignificant to you maybe, but what about those people I put away with alternate futures?  My God, if the country knew there was a chance they might not --
column2: The system would collapse.

column1: I believe in that system...
column2: Do you?  Really?

column1: You want to bring it down.
column2: But you will bring it down if you kill Leo Crow.  Why, that will be the most spectacular public display of how Precrime... didn't work.

column1: I'm not gonna kill anybody.
column2: Hold that thought.

column1: Why should I trust you?
column2: You shouldn't.  You shouldn't trust anyone... certainly not the Attorney General who wants it all for himself.  Not the young federal agent who wants your job.  Not even the old man who just wants to hang onto what he's created.  Don't trust anyone.  Just find the Minority Report.

column1: You said they're destroyed.
column2: I said the record is destroyed. The original report exists for all time.  I designed the system so that whenever a report occurred, it would be stored in a safe place -- but not declared.

column1: What safe place is that?
column2: The safest place of all.

column1: Where?
column2: Inside the Precog who predicted it.  All you have to do is download it.

column1: That's all, huh?  Just walk right into Precrime, go into the Temple, somehow tap into the Precogs, and then download this Minority Report...
column2: If... you have one.

column1: -- and then walk out.
column2: Actually, I think you'll have to run out, but yes, that's what you have to do.

column1: I'll get EYEscanned a dozen times before I get within ten miles of Precrime.  They'll pick me up...
column2: Sometimes in order to see the light, you have to risk the dark.

column1: How do I even know which one has it?
column2: It's always in the more gifted of the three.

column1: Which one is that?
column2: The female.

column1: John?
column2: He's dead, Lara.

column1: Oh, God, what did you do?
column2: Nothing.  I didn't kill him.

column1: Then how did he --
column2: Lara, I don't know why this is happening.  I just know they're setting me up.  I can't trust anybody.  I don't know who to talk to or where to go...  Lara?  Are you there?

column1: This is all my fault.
column2: No, it isn't, Lamar.  There was nothing anyone could do.

column1: I haven't worn this damn thing in years.  I just wanted to make sure it fits before tonight.
column2: You look great.

column1: It's insanity around here.
column2: I thought you were retiring?

column1: Who?
column2: Anne Lively.  John was talking about her right before they took him.

column1: John said something about him being set up because he "found out about her."
column2: We know why John was tagged.

column1: Lamar, do you know the reason why John came here to work with you?
column2: Sean --

column1: I understand.
column2: No.  I don't think you do.  The other day, when he came to the cottage, he talked about a lot of things, but Danny Witwer, the man he was supposed to have just killed?  He didn't mention him.  He didn't say his name even once.

column1: But I also know why he married you: you're as stubborn as he is.
column2: Lamar --

column1: All right.  Tell you what I'll do. First thing Monday, I'll look over the Witwer evidence and I'll have Gideon run the Containment files, see if anyone drowned a woman named -- what did you say her name was?
column2: Anne Lively... But I never said she drowned.

column1: The guy from USA Today is here.
column2: Tell him not now.

column1: He just wanted a few minutes before --
column2: Not.  Now.

column1: Sir, the press conference is starting.
column2: I'll be right there.

column1: Congratulations, sir.
column2: My God...

column1: How did you get this?
column2: I padded your expense account for the last six months.

column1: You have an emergency call on your private line.
column2: Thank you.  This is Burgess.

column1: He came to see you yesterday. Right before he got tagged.  What did you talk about?
column2: The Mets.  John doesn't think they've got a deep enough pitching roster this year, and I'm inclined to agree.

column1: Why are you protecting him?  You knew he was doping, yet you did nothing about it.
column2: The man lost a child, for Christ's sake...

column1: Six years ago.  What did you two talk about yesterday afternoon?
column2: None of your damn business.

column1: Oh, it's all my damn business now, Lamar.  Investigation of a supervising office for a capital crime falls under federal jurisdiction... so as to rule out any possibility of conspiracy.  He's my suspect.
column2: He's my subordinate!

column1: Shall we call the Attorney General? I'm sure he'd be happy to clarify the issue for you.
column2: I don't want John Anderton hurt.

column1: Lamar, I found something.
column2: What?

column1: I don't wanna say over the phone, but I think we may be chasing the wrong man.
column2: Where are you?

column1: Good God.  What was that?
column2: Wait, just a second...

column1: He told me about this.  You got this from Containment?
column2: Yes.  This is from the twins, Arthur and Dashiel.  Agatha's stream was missing.  Now this one is from the cyberparlor.  Anderton downloaded it directly from Agatha. Watch...

column1: It's the same prevision.
column2: Not quite.

column1: Now the second image.  Watch the water.  The wind's changed.  The ripples are going the other way.
column2: I don't understand --

column1: According to the Sentry, Anderton was watching this at Containment right before he was tagged.
column2: I know.  He came to me, told me about the missing data stream.  He was concerned that you might find it.

column1: I did find it.  It was inside of Agatha all this time.  So the question is, why would someone want this erased from the data file?
column2: Danny, tell me what you're thinking.

column1: I'm thinking someone got away with murder.
column2: How?

column1: By fooling the system.  All someone would have to do is wait for Precrime to stop the murder from taking place, then, a few minutes later, commit the crime in exactly the same way.
column2: Yes... It's called an echo.  The act of murder is such a violent disturbance in the future continuum that it sometimes repeats to the Precogs.

column1: Precog Deja Vu...
column2: We teach the tech's to identify them and disregard...

column1: So there is a way to fool the system?
column2: Yes.

column1: Of course, it would have to be someone with access to the Prevision in the first place, someone fairly high up --
column2: Shhh.  You know what I hear?

column1: What?
column2: Nothing.  No footsteps coming up the stairs.  No hovercraft out the window.  No clickity click of little spyders.  No one crashing through that door.  And do you know why I don't hear any of those things, Danny?  Because right now, the Precogs can't see.

column1: Near Death's real popular right now, which includes everything from getting hit by a car, to falling off a high building to plane crashes.  It's a big rush, you come out the other side without a heart attack.
column2: I wanna kill my boss.

column1: Uh-huh.  Okay.  You got some images I can work with?
column2: Right here.

column1: Uh, yeah, being concert master of the Philadelphia Symphony Orchestra is one of our most popular choices...
column2: No, I wanna kill my boss!

column1: This is Evanna, the team pilot.
column2: Nice to meet you.  Gum?

column1: So if you wanna kill someone, you take him to Miami.
column2: Not after the vote next week.  Once the Amendment passes, we go national, there's gonna be nowhere to run.

column1: Can't they shut that off?
column2: That's the Red Ball Alarm.

column1: Crime of passion.  No premeditation.  They show up late. Most of our scrambles are flash events like this one.  We rarely see anything with premeditation anymore.
column2: People have gotten the message.  Gum?

column1: The information we need is embedded in the grain of wood.  And since each piece is unique, the shape and grain is impossible to duplicate.
column2: I'm sure you've all grasped the legalistic drawback to precrime methodology.

column1: Because of the nature of murder.  "There's nothing more destructive to the metaphysical fabric that binds us than the untimely murder of one human being by another".
column2: Somehow, I don't think that was Walt Whitman.

column1: Don't worry.  I'll bring him in unharmed.
column2: Actually, Gordon, you're not gonna do that.  I'm taking control of the team.

column1: Sir, the team's gonna be light without those men.
column2: Yes, I know.

column1: Here's where we're at.  Three men in a room.  The victims here. Anderton here, and this unidentified male out the window. The exterior of the adjacent building suggests public housing, but I can't make out the location. Government architecture is modern/conformist which means --
column2: There's thousands of units like this one.

column1: Anderton's smart enough to go where electronic billboards and other media can't ID him to pick his pocket.  There's fewer consumers down there, which means fewer scanners to target him.
column2: No offense, sir, but why wouldn't he just run?

column1: There are two others in the room besides Anderton and Crow.
column2: Two?

column1: It doesn't matter.  He wins.
column2: We can stop him.

column1: He's trying to prove his innocence.
column2: He can't download her without a lot of technical help.

column1: There a maid in this hotel?
column2: I don't know, why?

column1: If you were a child killer, you took these pictures, would you leave them out on the bed for anyone to find?
column2: They could have been put away. Anderton could have found them.

column1: What kind of cop were you before this?
column2: I was a Treasury Agent for eight years.  Why?

column1: I worked homicide before I went federal.  This is what we would've called an "orgy of evidence".  Do you know how many orgies I had as a homicide copy, Gordon?
column2: How many?

column1: That's why you asked to partner with me on this little sortie, isn't it?
column2: I think you're swell company, Knott.

column1: People, if you don't let the spyder scan you, we'll have to come in and arrest you.
column2: Knott!

column1: Why don't I feel like celebrating?
column2: Cause all of a sudden you got no one you can fucking brown nose anymore.

column1: John Anderton was my friend!
column2: You "friend's" a murderer and he ruined our perfect record.  Six years, not one damn murder...

column1: He looks familiar.
column2: Who?

column1: The man across the street.  I've seen him before...
column2: How can you even tell?  You know how blind you are without your glasses.

column1: What about your meeting?
column2: I'll reschedule.  I've been working too much anyway.

column1: We could have lunch together.
column2: I'd love to, but I've got an open house today at the Ressler place.

column1: Raincheck?
column2: Sure.  Raincheck.

column1: Howard --
column2: I forgot my glasses.

column1: My name is Danny Witwer.  I'm --
column2: I know who you are.

column1: This your work?
column2: Yes.

column1: I like it.
column2: Thanks.  You take anything in your coffee?

column1: Cream and sugar.
column2: I don't have any cream.  Sorry.

column1: Just sugar then.  You and John ever come here?
column2: We used to, every summer.

column1: I don't have any sugar either.
column2: Thank you.  He hasn't tried to contact you?

column1: No.
column2: You ever heard him mention the name Leo Crow?

column1: No, but then I don't talk to John that much anymore.

column1: It was nobody's fault.

column1: What was it then?

column1: He took out his gun and sat down to watch his home movies.  This is all in your statement, Lara...

column1: Lamar Burgess thinks that you left John because he lost himself in Precrime instead of you.
column2: I left him because every time I looked at him, I saw my son.  Every time I got close to him, I smelled my little boy.  That's why I left him.  And now you can leave.

column1: You know I need to use you.

column1: To prevent a murder.  Sooner or later, he's going to contact you.

column1: They've never been separated before.
column2: What does he want with a precog?

column1: What do you think?  So he can kill whoever he wants to without anyone knowing about it.
column2: But there's still the other two.

column1: Wally, the other two can still function, right?
column2: You don't understand... they're a hive mind.  It takes all three for their predictive abilities to work.

column1: Are you telling me they can't see murders anymore?
column2: Maybe if he'd taken one of the males.  But the female, she's the key.  She's the one they listen to, the one with the most talent.  The one who takes care of the other two.

column1: This is Halden.
column2: Halden, how nice to hear your voice.

column1: What do you want?
column2: I have found in life that what one wants isn't nearly as important as what one needs.

column1: What do you need?
column2: I need to take back what's mine.

column1: There are two million people in there with you.
column2: Yes.

column1: They have nothing to do with this --
column2: -- Two million people lost in the digital night.  What do they seek?

column1: God-Damn you!
column2: Yes, I believe he has --

column1: System's running on auxiliary.  Only seven hours before it crashes.
column2: True.

column1: You're in there.  Everybody dies, you go with them --
column2: -- But don't you remember?  I'm already dead.

column1: It's okay.
column2: Okay...

column1: Why?
column2: To live forever.

column1: She said I have a son...
column2: No, she said she had a son.  In a dream she once called life.

column1: How come I can't remember?

column1: Why --
column2: -- Because there'll be no remorse. Not in my world.

column1: As long as it's not 'what's your sign?'

column1: This is how you pick up women --
column2: -- No.

column1: But this is impossible.

column1: Divinity?
column2: Yes.

column1: You are not a God.

column1: The new world.

column1: Unlimited energy out there.  Enough to run this world for all eternity --
column2: -- But you'll never be able to get it through the maze.

column2: Only up there in the dream they called life.

column2: -- He won't.

column2: -- Yes.

column1: You're jumping to conclusions.

column1: Try harder.

column1: Because why the hell would you be interested in a program that allows people to live inside your machines?  I mean how much profit could there possibly be from owning the universe and selling space in it to people who are dying, or people who are just God-Damned sick of this world --
column2: -- Come on, you know F.C.O. regs. Anyone caught with their R and D hand in the bio-digitization cookie jar spends the rest of their life in federal penitentiary.  It's not worth it.

column1: The only way to eject it is from the inside.

column1: One condition.
column2: What?

column2: That's right.

column1: Then what's with all the staffing programs in his account?
column2: Good question.

column2: Listen to yourself.  Digitization.  You know that officially that's a pure fantasy --

column1: So you just came up to visit this Hobbes and you found them like that?
column2: Oh, no. I haven't seen Dr. Hobbes since I was in medical school. He taught me... he was my prof in urology and... I think he conducted a few seminars in psychopharmacology. That was it. I had no idea he'd ever set foot in Starliner Towers until today.

column1: It was very strange. He called me at six this morning. Hobbes called me. I thought I was dreaming. I haven't heard that voice for so long. He told me who it was, then he said something like, 'Meet me at apartment 1208 at noon. I want you to go out for lunch with me. It's time you furthered your education.' Then he laughed and hung up. I went back to sleep. He called me again at eight to remind me to come.
column2: How did he sound this time? Was he nervous? Depressed?

column1: And that was her. Annabelle Horse... field.
column2: Far as I know, yeah, that was her.

column1: Is that the man who called you up here?
column2: Yeah, that's Dr. St. Luc. He's the head of our little medical clinic here.

column2: Yeah. This is an island, you know? Takes too long to get into the city. We gotta have everything right here or somebody complains.

column1: Mrs. Ementhal's ready and waiting, Doctor.

column1: OK, Roger. Here's the stuff you wanted. Files on Horsefield, Tudor, Swinburne, and Velakofsky. Papers published by Hobbes, Linsky, and Lefebvre in a couple of issues of the Bulletin of the Canadian Medical Association and also the Journal of the American Medical Association. And, as an added extra, a couple of odds and ends from the files I helped compile before your time here, Doctor. I thought they might interest you.
column2: That's great, Forsythe, great. Thanks.

column2: Uh, OK. Sure.

column2: I think I... I think I killed him. I stabbed him with something and he fell.

column2: I hit it. I hit it with my cane. Then I carry it on the cane and I throw it down to the incinerator, down to the garbage.

column1: Right. It's crazy. But here's the beauty part. Ready?  Who cares?
column2: I don't get it.

column1: Rog, I gotta talk serious to you. Really. Listen. Ya listening? OK. I want you to come into this with me. To tell the honest-to-God truth, I'm lonely.  All Hobbes ever did was run around getting money and phone me in the middle of the night. He wanted you in anyway. That's why we were gonna get together, the three of us. We would have enough to keep us going for at least five years, even with inflation.

column1: You want to help sick people for the rest of your life? God forbid I should talk you out of it.

Ah, I don't want to panic you or anything, but, I mean, the way Hobbes designed them, they're supposed to get out of hand real quick, so you don't have much time to think about what's happening to you. Once they decide to start pumping all those dynamite juices into the old blood stream... I dunno. But if you see some people doing kind of compulsive, maybe even bizarre sexual things...

column1: Is it a planet?
column2: Not exactly.  It exists in a continuum that wasn't proven until ten years ago, a higher mathematical dimension superimposed on top of the Universe. An infinite number of them, in fact. It was a violation of all of our various laws regarding the Universe, Space, or Space-Time.  It was completely counter-intuitive.  We had to unlearn everything.

column1: Is it intelligent?
column2: Intelligent beyond our comprehension.

column1: Then it's God, right?

column1: You still don't believe in God?
column2: The whole idea of God was dreamed up by a silly animal with a small brain called Man.  Even the limits we put on it are human limits.  It can do this, it can do that!  It designs, it creates!

column1: Even a God that wasn't active, that just created something and stood back and watched?
column2: You're talking about a man in a white beard again.  You're ascribing human characteristics to something that isn't human.  Human beings look for causes and patterns.  How could we know what Solaris is up to, if anything?

column2: As I said, it is beyond our comprehension.

column1: I would have these -- I don't know how to describe them -- visions, when I was younger.  Maybe not visions, but like these waking dream states.  Time would just collapse, I would be inside time.  I would stare at a second hand on a clock until it stopped.  Freaky stuff.
column2: How old were you?

column1: Seven, eight.  So one day my mother catches me sort of staring off into space, and she asks me what I'm doing, and I start trying to explain to her, about this state that I can put myself in, and this look comes over her face.
column2: What kind of look?

column1: Scared.  No, not scared.  Wary. Like I was something to be... her guard went up.  I was a threat.  Now I know why.  She was afraid she'd be seen.  That I would see her for the self-obsessed neurotic that she was. I think she thought she had a few more years of being on a pedestal. But that's the cycle, right?  I knew a little more than she did, she knew a little more than her mother, and on and on.  I guess that's part of the reason why --
column2: I know.  I know.  We don't have to talk about that.

column1: Thinking what you were doing and saying, just being consumed by thinking of you.  I loved it so much, that feeling.

column2: I mean, I suddenly have immense physical power, and the ability to crawl up walls--

column2: Let's talk in the hall.

column1: In this obsolete little cyclotron, I'm solving the greatest physics problem of the 20th Century.  With more power, I could--
column2: I've had an extremely bad day, Octavius.  A sophomoric prank in the library and punitive measures.

column1: Then the alumni reports came in-- fund-raising is down this year.
column2: I couldn't care less.  What I've done is--

column1: What you've done is make the entire physics department look foolish. You compare yourself to Einstein
column2: This is the unified field!  All the forces of the universe tied together-- perfectly!

column1: You've used up your grant. The electric bills alone exceed your annual salary.  Not to mention the potential hazards of your radioactive fuel.
column2: I don't care.  Cretin.

column1: That Nobel Prize will just have to wait.
column2: No!

column1: Then you'll be glad to know the University has decided not to press criminal charges against you. Breaking and entering the minor matter of the total destruction of a 23 million dollar cyclotron
column2: I will finish what I've begun

column1: Otto, I don't like Thorkel any more than you do.  But he has got a point.
column2: Rosomoff, I have better things to do than teach Introductory Physics to mindless adolescents.

column1: No.  No thank you.  I have work.
column2: I heard about Thorkel's order--

column1: A bit melodramatic but if you could prove it that would tie in your unified field theory, the Big Bang, Kaluza-Klein--
column2: Ach, theories!  This was first hand, experiential knowledge, the essence of the universe.

column1: My self.  I don't matter.  This human life, all life- insignificant.  Bodies-- bags of sleepy, sluggish flesh.
column2: All right, we may be insignificant, imperfect creatures-- but we're all we've got.

column1: Creation? Or its opposite?
column2: Truth. Pure, eternal.  Beyond the boundaries of mere mortality.

column1: Otto, we are mere mortals. You must never forget your own limits--
column2: I'll repeat the experiment.  I will hold the truth. That's the only thing that matters.

column1: Life and death matter. Yours-- everyone's.  By comparison, our search for truth is only a product of curiosity, a game--
column2: Oh, Roz.  My mind is so far beyond yours now.  I could beat you at chess now.

column1: My God, Otto, you have to hear me! The world we know will collapse! Everything we have devoted our lives to-- all patterns, all harmonies-- will be destroyed!
column2: Truth.  Truth alone exists. Truth must be released...

column2: Bonkers.

column1: Loonytunes.  And yet...

column1: According to our information, the ribbon is a conflux of temporal energy which travels through our galaxy every 39.1 years

column1: Data?
column2: Sorry, Captain. The ribbon has already entered the galaxy. It will pass through this sector in approximately thirty-one hours.

column1: Guinan said Soran was trying to get back to the ribbon. If that's true, then there must be some connection with the Amargosa star.
column2: The star's destruction has had numerous astro-physical effects within this sector. However, none of them appear to have a connection to the energy ribbon.

column1: Give me a list of those effects. I want to know every single thing which has been altered or changed, no matter how insignificant.
column2: It will take a few moments for the computer to compile the information.

column1: Data, are you all right?
column2: No, sir. I am finding it difficult to concentrate. I believe I am overwhelmed with feelings of remorse and regret concerning my actions on the observatory.

column1: What do you mean?
column2: I wanted to save Geordi. I tried. But I experienced something I did not expect.  I believe it was fear.

column1: Fear is a very difficult emotion to overcome. It's something we all have to learn to deal with.
column2: But I did not deal with it, sir. I let it prevent me from helping my friend.  Does that make me a coward?

column1: No. And what you must try to avoid is becoming consumed by another emotion which I believe you're beginning to experience: guilt.
column2: Guilt. It is a most unpleasant feeling.

column1: According to our current information, the destruction of the Amargosa star has had the following effects in this sector: gamma emissions have increased by .05 percent, the starship Bozeman was forced to make a course correction, a research project on Gorik IV was halted due to increased neutrino particles, ambient magnetic fields have decreased by-
column2: Wait. The Bozeman,why did it change course?

column1: This is its current position.
column2: Can you project its course?

column1: Courage is an emotion too, Data.  Now, can you project the course of the ribbon?
column2: I believe so.

column1: Now, you said the gravitational forces in this sector have been altered, could that also affect the course of the ribbon?
column2: I believe so.

column1: He can't go to the ribbon, so he's trying to make the ribbon come to him.  Data, is it going to pass near any M-Class planets?
column2: Yes, sir. There are two in the Veridian system.

column1: That's where he's going.

column1: Are any of them inhabited?
column2: Veridian III is uninhabited, but Veridian IV supports a pre-industrial humanoid society.

column1: Population?
column2: Approximately two hundred thirty million.

column1: "Lifeforms tiny little lifeforms. Where are the lifeforms-"

column1: Approximately forty-seven minutes, sir.
column2: I have to find a way to get to Soran.

column2: No, but I'd stay out of Sickbay for a while if I were you. I still don't know why you dropped her in the water.

column1: Data, you're not thinking about using that thing are you?
column2: It has occurred to me on several occasions. But I believe this may be the appropriate time.

column1: Wait a minute. I thought you've always been afraid it would overload your neural net.
column2: That is true. However, I believe my growth as an artificial lifeform has reached an impasse. For thirty-four years I have endeavored to become more "human"- to grow beyond my original programming. And yet I am still unable to grasp such a simple concept as humor. This emotion chip is the only answer.

column1: But at the first sign of trouble, I'm going to deactivate it. Agreed?
column2: Agreed.

column1: Well?
column2: I believe the beverage has provoked an emotional response.

column2: I am uncertain. I have had little experience with emotions. I am unable to articulate the sensation.

column2: You get what?

column1: What?
column2: During the Farpoint mission. We were on the Bridge and you told a joke. That was the punchline.

column1: Do you remember him?
column2: Oh yes. I remember everyone who was on the Lakul, every face. Even the ones who didn't make it.

column1: Guinan. It's important that you tell me what you know. We think Soran's developed a weapon...a terrible weapon. It might give him enough power to-
column2: Soran doesn't care about power or weapons. All he cares about is getting back to the Nexus.

column1: That ribbon isn't just some random energy phenomenon travelling through space. It's a doorway. It leads to another place- the Nexus. It doesn't exist in our universe and it doesn't play by the same rules either.
column2: What happened to you?

column1: It took a long time, but eventually I learned to live with it. And I began to realize that my experience in the Nexus had changed me.  I knew things about people, about events, about time.
column2: Your "sixth sense"- I've always wondered where it came from.  And what about Soran?

column1: Soran may still be obsessed with getting back. And if he is, he'll do anything to find that doorway again.
column2: But why destroy a star?  Thank you, Guinan.

column1: Guinan, what's going on? Where am I?
column2: You're in the Nexus.

column1: This is the Nexus?
column2: For you. This is where you wanted to be.

column1: But I never had a wife, children, a home like this.
column2: Enjoy them, Jean-Luc.

column1: Guinan, what are you doing here? I thought you were on the Enterprise.
column2: I am on the Enterprise. I am also here.  Think of me as an "echo" of the person you know. A part she left behind.

column1: Left behind?
column2: When the Enterprise-B beamed us off the Lakul, we were partially in the Nexus. The transporters locked on to us, but somehow everyone left a part of themselves behind.

column1: Soran?
column2: All of us.

column1: Where is he now?
column2: Wherever he wanted to be.

column1: These are my children...my children.
column2: Yeah. They're great, aren't they? You can go back and see them born, go forward and see your grandchildren. Time has no meaning here.

column1: Guinan, can I leave the Nexus?
column2: Why would you want to leave?

column1: Can I?
column2: Yes, where would you go?

column1: I don't understand.
column2: I told you, time has no meaning here. If you leave, you can go anywhere, any time.

column1: I know exactly where I want to go, and when. Back to that mountaintop on Veridian III, before Soran put out the star. I have to stop him.
column2: What makes you think things will be any different this time?

column1: You're right. I'll need help.  Guinan, will you come back with me? Together, we could-
column2: I can't leave. I'm already there, remember?

column2: It's our pleasure.

column1: Well, may we have a look around?
column2: Please, please.

column2: No, no. Thank you.

column2: I hadn't planned on it.

column2: You could say that.

column1: I'll find a way to contact the Enterprise. You're going to be all right.

column1: Yes.  Thank you.

column1: Oh
column2: I've warned ye about that back of yours. You should have a doctor take a look at it.

column1: You know, Scotty, it amazes me.
column2: And what would that be, sir?

column1: Sulu. When did he find the time for a family?
column2: It's like you always said- if something's important enough, you make the time.

column1: Their life signs are are phasing in and out of our space-time continuum.

column1: The first thing you learn as captain is how to cheat death.  Scotty?
column2: There's just no way to disrupt a gravimetric field of this magnitude!

column2: I thought you might.

column2: I always do.

column2: Captain, I don't know how much longer I can hold her together!

column1: A remarkable piece of equipment, but a little inelegant, wouldn't you say?  Have you ever considered a prosthesis that would make you look a little more...normal?
column2: What's normal?

column1: Normal is what everyone else is, and what you are not.
column2: What do you want?

column1: I don't want a science lecture. You were on that observatory looking for trilithium. Why?
column2: I was ordered to by the Captain.

column1: Let's try to move beyond the usual prisoner-interrogator banter, shall we? You have information and I need it.  Did the Captain explain his orders to you? Did he say why you were searching for trilithium?
column2: No.

column1: What about Guinan? What has she told you about me?
column2: Guinan? I don't know what you're talking about.

column1: Oh, I forgot to tell you. While you were unconscious, I injected a nano-probe into your bloodstream. It's been navigating your cardiovascular system, and right now I've attached it to your left ventricle.  A little trick I picked up from the Borg.
column2: Yeah, they're full of great ideas.

column1: I just stopped your heart for five seconds. It felt like an eternity, didn't it? Did you know that you can stop the human heart for up to ten minutes before the onset of brain damage?
column2: No, I didn't know that.

column1: We learn something new about ourselves every day.  Now. Maybe I didn't make myself clear. It is very important that you tell me exactly what Captain Picard knows.
column2: I told you everything. You might as well just kill me right now.

column1: Don't you think you're taking this a little too far, Number One?
column2: When we went to ancient Rome for Deanna's promotion, we threw her to the lions, remember?

column1: Well, now that we're all aboard=8A  Number One, bring the ship before the wind.  Let's see what's out there.
column2: Aye, aye, sir.  Take the wheel, Commander.

column1: Imagine what it was like, Will. No engines, no computers, just the wind, the sea and the stars to guide you.
column2: Bad food, brutal discipline.  No women.

column1: Sir?
column2: Make it so.

column1: There's still no indication of why they attacked the station?
column2: We think they were looking for something- they practically tore the place apart.

column1: Hmm,  Inform Starfleet Command. This could indicate a new Romulan threat in this sector.
column2: You want me to contact Starfleet?

column1: Is there a problem?
column2: No, sir.

column1: There is something else, Captain. One of the scientists, a Doctor Soran,has insisted on speaking with you.  I told him you were busy, sir, but he said it was absolutely imperative that he speak with you right away.
column2: Understood. That will be all.

column1: Sir, is there anything wrong?
column2: No. Thank you.

column1: Report.
column2: A quantum implosion has occurred within the Amargosa star. All nuclearfusion is breaking down.

column1: Maybe they're not out there.
column2: They're just trying to decide whether a twenty year-old Klingon Bird of Prey is any match for the Federation flagship.

column1: That's a pretty big margin of error.
column2: Too big. How long until the ribbon arrives?

column1: I always thought I'd have a crack at this chair one day.
column2: You may still. Somehow I doubt this will be the last ship to carry the name Enterprise.

column1: Captain, are you all right?
column2: Yes. Fine. If you'll excuse me.

column1: Counselor. What can I do for you?
column2: Actually, I'm here to see if there's anything I can do for you.

column1: I'm afraid I can't just leave it at that. The commanding officer of this ship is clearly distraught about something. As ship's counselor, it's my duty to-
column2: As ship's counselor, it's your duty to know not only when you're needed but also when you're not.

column1: Well, with all due respect to your Betazoid senses, I prefer to be alone right now.
column2: Very well. I suppose I could make out my weekly report to Starfleet Command without your input.  "Admiral Lusby, regarding the unusual behavior of Jean-Luc Picard: I find him increasingly irritable, remote and uncooperative. I recommend forced shore leave at a Starbase facility in order to-"

column1: Captain, Im sorry.  I know there were a lot of unresolved conflicts between you and your brother.
column2: What I can't get out of my mind is the image of Rene- my nephew. I just can't believe he's gone.

column1: It's only natural to feel a heightened sense of tragedy when a child dies.  But it goes deeper than that, doesn't it? I can sense that Rene meant a great deal to you.
column2: In a way, he was as close as I ever came to having a child of my own.

column1: Your family history is very important to you, isn't it?
column2: Ever since I was a little boy, I remember hearing about the family line. The Picards that fought at Trafalgar, the Picards that settled the first Martian colony. When my brother married and had a son...

column1: You felt it was no longer your responsibility to carry on the family line.
column2: My brother had shouldered that burden, allowing me to pursue my own selfish needs.

column1: Or perhaps they're on the surface.
column2: Mr. Data, scan the planet for lifeforms.

column1: Doctor Soran?
column2: Yes, yes, Captain. Thank you for coming.

column1: Nothing for me.  I understand there's something urgent you need to discuss with me.
column2: Yes. I need to return to the observatory immediately. I must continue a critical experiment I was running on the Amargosa star.

column1: Doctor, we're still conducting an investigation into the attack. Once we've completed our work, we'll be happy to allow you and your fellow scientists back aboard the observatory. Until then-
column2: The timing is very important on my experiment- if it is not completed within the next twelve hours, years of research will be lost.

column1: You must think I'm quite the madman.
column2: The thought had crossed my mind.

column1: I've spent eighty years looking for another way, Captain. This is the only one.  Of course, you could always come with me. You fancy yourself an explorer. Here's a chance to explore something no human has ever experienced.
column2: Not if it means killing over two hundred million people.  I wonder, did your wife Leandra know that she married a man who was capable of mass murder?

column1: We're all mortal, Soran. It's one of the truths of ou existence.
column2: What if I told you I found a new truth?

column1: The Nexus.
column2: Time has no meaning there. The predator has no teeth.

column1: Careful, Captain. That's a fifty gigawatt forcefield. I wouldn't want to see you get hurt.
column2: Thank you.

column1: The royal...studs?
column2: You see the top yardarm, now look to the-

column1: It looks like we're too late.
column2: There are no other ships in the system.

column1: These blast patterns are consistent with Type III disruptors.
column2: Well, that narrows it to Klingon, Breen or Romulan.

column1: One of the dead Romulans had a tricorder. We analyzed its sensor logs and found they were scanning for signature particles of a compound called trilithium.
column2: Trilithium?

column1: An experimental compound the Romulans have been working on. In theory, a trilithium-based explosive would be thousands of times more powerful than an anti-matter weapon. But they never found a way to stabilize it.
column2: Why were they looking for it on a Federation observatory? It doesn't make any sense.

column1: Have Geordi and Data go over with the next Away Team. Tell them to scan the observatory for trilithium.
column2: Aye, sir.

column1: Sensor records show a solar probe was launched from the observatory a few moments ago.
column2: The star's going to collapse in a matter of minutes.

column1: I have spoken to the Klingon High Council, sir. They identified the Bird of Prey as belonging to the Duras sisters.
column2: Lursa and B'Etor? This doesn't make any sense. A renowned stellar physicist somehow uses a trilithium probe to destroy a star, kidnaps Geordi and escapes with a pair of Klingon renegades. Why? What the hell's going on?

column1: They have found a way to penetrate our shields.
column2: Lock phasers and return fire!

column1: It is a Class D-12 Bird of Prey. They were retired from service because of defective plasma coils.
column2: Plasma coils...is there any way we can use that to our advantage?

column1: As their cloak begins to engage, their shields will drop.
column2: Right. And they'll be vulnerable for at least two seconds.  Data,lock onto that plasma coil.

column1: Worf, prepare a spread of photon torpedoes. We'll have to hit them the instant they begin to cloak.
column2: Aye, sir.

column1: Status!
column2: All automates ready and functioning. Automatic moorings retracted. All speeds available through transwarp drive.

column1: Enterprise maintaining full impulse power...
column2: And we are gaining... Stand by, tractor beam!

column1: Tractor beam, aye!
column2: If he tries to get away with Warp Drive, he's really in for a shock...

column1: Transwarp at your command, Sir!
column2: Execute!

column1: Steady... Steady, boys. Keep scanning...  I thought you people were reliable... Where the hell is he!
column2: He has been here for some time. I can feel his presence.

column1: Don't give me your Klingon mumbo- jumbo -- there ain't another vessel in this whole damn quadrant.
column2: Put me on the hailing frequency.

column1: What's going on? When do we get paid off...?
column2: Soon, Captain... Quite soon.

column1: Mr. Chekov -- ?
column2: An energy reading from 'C" deck -- from inside Mr. Spock's quarters...

column1: Mr. Chekov, I ordered Spock's quarters sealed!
column2: Yes, sir, I sealed the room myself. Nevertheless -- I am reading a life form there.

column1: Will we get another ship?
column2: I can't get an answer. Starfleet is up to its brass in galactic conference. No one has time for those who only stand... and wait.

column1: Shall I alert Dr. McCoy?
column2: Yes. He has a long journey ahead.

column1: Unit two, this is One. The Kobayashi Maru has set sail for the promised land. Acknowledge.
column2: Message acknowledged. All units will be informed.

column1: Calm yourself, Bones.
column2: Sir. Commander, Starfleet on emergency channel. He orders you to surrender this vessel.

column1: Excelsior closing to 4,000 meters, sir.
column2: Mr. Scott, we need everything you've got now.

column1: You did great, Bones... Just great.
column2: Sir, Starfleet calling Grissom again. A warning about us.

column1: Response?
column2: Nothing. As before.

column1: What's Grissom up to?... Will they join us, or fire on us...?  Chekov, break radio  silence. Send my compliments to Captain Esteban.
column2: Aye, sir.

column1: Admiral, there is no response from the Grissom on any channel.
column2: Keep trying, Chekov. At regular intervals.

column1: Still no response, sir.
column2: Bones... Can you give me a quadrant bi-scan?

column1: I'd swear something was there sir, but I might have imagined it.
column2: What did you see, Chekov?

column1: For an instant... A scout class vessel.
column2: Could be Grissom.  Patch in the hailing frequency.  U.S.S. Grissom, this is Enterprise calling. Come in, please.

column1: Nothing on my scanner, sir.
column2: Short range scan, Mr. Chekov... On screen, Mr. Sulu.

column1: Sir, the shields... Non- responsive.
column2: Scotty...?

column1: Aye sir, coding now.
column2: Dr. Marcus, it's your planet.

column1: Do you wish to advise Starfleet, sir?
column2: Wait a minute...! We don't know what we're talking about here...

column1: Sir... Something's jamming our transmission. An energy surge.
column2: Locate.

column1: Surge from astern, sir. Aft quarter!
column2: On screen.

column1: Could it be Spock's?
column2: It has to be. Gravitational fields were in flux... It must have soft landed...!

column1: I don't believe it...
column2: What is it?

column1: Why don't we beam it up?
column2: Oh no you don't! Regulations specifically state: "nothing shall be beamed aboard until danger of contamination has been eliminated." Can you guarantee that?

column1: All right -- get your gear. I'll put you down next time around.
column2: Thank you... <u>Sir</u>!

column1: Hello, sir. It's David.
column2: David... Sorry I'm late.

column1: It's okay -- I should have known you'd come... Saavik's right: this planet is unstable. It's going to destroy itself in a matter of hours.
column2: David!... What went wrong?

column1: David, I don't understand...
column2: I'm sorry, sir. Just don't surrender. Genesis doesn't work! I can't believe they'll kill us for it --

column1: This is where the fun begins, Saavik!
column2: Like your father... so human.  All units functional, recorders are on... Scanning sector one. Foliage in fully developed state of growth. Temperature, twenty- two point two Celsius.

column1: Sector two... Indicating desert terrain. Minimal vegetation, temperature thirty-nine point four.
column2: Sector three... Sub-tropical vegetation... Temperature --  Temperature decreasing rapidly --

column1: It's snow. Snow in the same sector. Fantastic!
column2: ... Fascinating.

column1: All the varieties of land and weather known to Earth within a few hours walk!
column2: You must be very proud of what you and your mother have created.

column1: Same sector. Metallic mass.
column2: Underground deposit?

column1: Negative, on surface... A manufactured object.
column2: There's only one thing it could be... Short range scan.

column1: Approximately two meters long... Cylindrical in form...
column2: A photon tube...!

column1: New orbit commencing... Coming up on sector three...
column2: Short range scan.

column1: As before... Metallic mass... Verifying triminium photon tube... No new data.
column2: Check for trace radiation. Infrared enhancement.

column1: There <u>shouldn't</u> be any. Only plant forms were built into the Genesis matrix.
column2: Cross referenced and verified. An unidentifiable life form reading.

column1: Captain, please -- we'll take the risk. We've <u>got</u> to find out what it is...
column2: ... Or <u>who</u>.

column1: Saavik to Grissom. Request computer study of soil samples for geological aging.
column2: I'll handle that later.

column1: My readings indicate great instability.
column2: We're not here to investigate geological aging, we're here to find life forms!

column1: .          .. Spock's tube...
column2: David --

column1: Well. There's your life form reading. These were microbes on the tube's surface. We shot them here from Enterprise.  They were fruitful, and multiplied.
column2: But... How could they have evolved so quickly...?

column1: What is it?
column2: Spock's burial robe.

column1: Later. Let's go...
column2: Grissom, your message acknowledged. Will advise... Out.

column1: Saavik... My god, what happened to them?
column2: It would seem that Grissom was destroyed by an enemy attack.

column1: You mean, we're stranded down here?!
column2: Logic indicates that is the case.

column1: How can you be logical at a time like this?! We have to get thee hell off this planet!
column2: That may be difficult...

column1: Why don't you just call for <u>help</u>!
column2: I have already made one transmission too many...

column1: It's time for total truth between us.  This planet is not what you intended, or hoped for, is it?
column2: Not exactly.

column1: Why?
column2: I used protomatter in the Genesis matrix.

column1: Protomatter. An unstable substance which every ethical scientist in the galaxy has denounced as dangerously unpredictable.
column2: It was the only way to solve certain problems --

column1: Did your collaborator know?
column2: My mother knew nothing about it. That's why I asked her to leave Genesis in my hands.

column1: So, like your father, you changed the rules...
column2: If I hadn't, it might have been years -- or never!

column1: This planet is aging in surges.
column2: And Spock with it. They are joined together.

column1: The Genesis wave started a life clock ticking for him and the planet. But at the rate things are going now...
column2: ... How long?

column1: Days... Maybe hours... Protomatter has made the situation unpredictable.  I'm sorry.
column2: It will be hardest on Spock. Soon he will feel the burning of his Vulcan blood.

column1: I don't understand.
column2: Pon Farr. Vulcan males must endure it every seventh year of their adult life.

column1: Whoever they are, they're getting closer.
column2: I'll go...

column1: If equipment is functioning properly, indications are -- an animal life form.
column2: You said there wouldn't be any.

column1: Captain... the logical alternative is obvious... beaming down to the surface is permitted...
column2: "... If the Captain decides that the mission is vital and reasonably free of danger." I know the book, Saavik.

column1: Grissom to landing party. We have you approaching radioactive indications. Do you concur?
column2: Affirmative, Captain. Our readings are well below danger level.

column1: Very well. Exercise caution, Lieutenant. This landing is Captain's discretion and I'm the one who's out on a limb.
column2: I'll try to remember that, Captain.

column1: Captain, this is Saavik. We have strong life sign readings bearing zero-one-five relative, and we are proceeding to investigate.
column2: We concur, Saavik. And Saavik... be advised we are reading a severe and unnatural age curve on the planet. I'm getting nervous...

column1: Captain, this is Saavik. Come in, please...
column2: Yes, Saavik, go ahead...

column1: Ah, Saavik, that's, ah, extroadinary. What would you, ah, like to do next?
column2: Request permission to beam aboard immediately.

column1: Saavik... Does Dr. Marcus think there could be -- any chance of -- ah -- radioactive contamination?
column2: None that I can detect, sir.

column1: I'm sure Starfleet would approve, sir.
column2: I know, but -- let's do it by the book. Stand by on this channel.  Go.

column1: Captain, what's happening?!
column2: We are under attack! Stand by for evasive -- stand by for --

column1: I'm almost done, sir. You'll be fully automated by the time we dock.
column2: Your timing is excellent, Mr. Scott. You've fixed the barn door after the horse has come home. How much refit time till we can take her out again?

column1: Eight weeks, sir.  But you don't have eight weeks so I'll do it for ya in two.
column2: Mr. Scott. Have you always multiplied your repair estimates by a factor of four?

column1: Certainly, sir. How else can I keep my reputation as a miracle worker?
column2: Your reputation is secure, Scotty.  Mr. Sulu, take the con. I'll be in my quarters.

column1: Mr. Scott...
column2: I'm sorry, sir, but as far as I'm concerned, there's nothin' needed for space travel that this old girl doesn't already have.

column1: As promised, she's all yours, sir. All systems automated and ready. A chimpanzee and two trainees could run her.
column2: Thank you, Mr. Scott. I'll try not to take that personally.  My friends... I can't ask you to go any further. Dr. McCoy and I have to do this. The rest of you do not.

column1: Mr. Scott?
column2: I'd be grateful, Admiral, if you'd give the word.

column1: Steady... Steady... All right, Mr. Scott.
column2: Sir...?

column1: Aye, sir, she's got her second wind now.
column2: Scan for vessels in pursuit!

column1: Mr. Scott, all power to the weapons systems --
column2: Aye, sir!

column1: Mr. Scott: two photon torpedoes at the ready. Sight on the center of the mass.
column2: Aye, sir!

column1: Good shooting, Scotty.
column2: Aye, those two hits should stop a horse, let alone a bird.

column1: I'm all right -- stand by to return fire! Mr. Scott, transfer power to the phaser banks --
column2: Oh, God, sir, I dinna think so...

column1: What's wrong?
column2: They've knocked out the damn automation center.  I've got no control over anything!

column1: How many more?
column2: Just him, sir!

column1: Admiral, this is Lieutenant Saavik.
column2: Saavik... Is... David with you?

column1: Yes, he is. And someone else. Vulcan scientist of your acquaintance.
column2: This Vulcan -- is he alive?

column1: What happened...?
column2: He gave his life to save us. That is all I know.

column1: Is there <U>anything</U> we can do?!
column2: Only one thing, Sir... Get him off this planet... His aging is part of what's going on around us...

column1: The Genesis planet is gone.
column2: Goodbye, David.

column1: Yes, Admiral. But that may not be possible.
column2: What? What are you saying?

column1: The Katra ritual is meant to deposit Spock's consciousness in the Hall of Ancient Thought - not in his body.
column2: But we have Spock alive! That's more than we bargained for!

column1: Or less. What you describe is called Fal Tor Pan - the refusion. It is very dangerous. The elders may not choose to attempt it.
column2: And if they don't.? What will Happen to Spock?

column1: My God...
column2: Much is at stake...

column1: I know you... Do I not?
column2: Yes. And I know you.

column1: My father says you have been my friend... You came back for me.
column2: You would have done the same for me.

column1: Why would you do this...?
column2: Because... the needs of the one outweighed the needs of the many.

column1: Yes, yes, Spock...
column2: The ship... Out of danger...?

column1: On course, Admiral. Estimating Spacedock in two point one hours.
column2: Very well.  Mr. Chekov, I need pre-approach scan... Take the science station, please.

column1: ... Admiral, what's going to happen to Enterprise?
column2: She's to be decommissioned.

column1: The word, sir?
column2: The word is no.  I am therefore going anyway.

column1: Count on our help, sir.
column2: I'll need it, Sulu.

column1: ... We have cleared Spacedoors.
column2: FULL IMPULSE POWER!

column1: Warp Speed, Mr. Sulu...
column2: Aye, sir, Warp Speed...

column1: Excelsior, the great experiment, is adrift in space.
column2: Mr. Scott: as good as your word.

column1: Estimating Genesis 2.9 hours, present speed.
column2: Can we hold speed, Mr. Scott?

column1: We are secured from Warp Speed... Now entering Genesis Sector of Mutara Quadrant.
column2: What about Grissom, Mr. Chekov?

column1: See! That shimmering area.
column2: Yes, sir. It's getting larger as we close in.

column1: That distortion is closing rapidly... Opinion, Sulu?
column2: I think it's an energy form, sir...

column1: Yes. Enough energy to hide a ship, wouldn't you say?
column2: ... A cloaking device?

column1: Klingon Bird of Prey, sir! She's arming torpedoes...!
column2: Fire, Mr. Scott!

column1: Mr. Sulu, what is the crew complement of a Bird of Prey?
column2: About a dozen officers and men.

column1: Sir, planet core readings unstable... Changing rapidly...
column2: What about surface life signs...?

column1: Close... There --
column2: Come on!

column1: If I read this right, sir, we have full power.
column2: Go, Sulu!

column1: We are clear and free to navigate.
column2: Best speed to Vulcan. Mr. Chekov, take the prisoners below.

column1: The planet Vulcan. In hailing distance, sir.
column2: Saavik. Send to Ambassador Sarek. Tell him we're coming in.

column1: Mr. Sulu, you're on manual.
column2: It's been a while, sir. Here we go... Retrothrusters!

column1: Uhura, any response from Starfleet on our Project Genesis inquiries?
column2: No, sir, no response.

column1: Standby automatic approach system ... Advise approach control.
column2: Approach control... this is Enterprise. Ready for docking maneuver.

column1: Would you look at that?
column2: My friends, the great experiment: Excelsior, ready for trial runs...

column1: How is Doctor McCoy, sir?
column2: That's the good news. He's home in bed, full of tranquilizers, and he promised me he'd <U>stay</U> there... They say it's exhaustion...  We'll see.

column1: Gentlemen. Good evening.
column2: Good evening, Commander. Everything ready?

column1: Will you be able to handle that...?
column2: Oh, I'll have "Mr. Adventure" eating out of my hand. And I'll see you at the rendezvous.  All my hopes.

column1: Welcome aboard, Admiral.
column2: Welcome home, Jim.

column1: Where's Doctor McCoy?
column2: Indisposed, sir.

column1: Admiral, I don't understand. The Enterprise --
column2: Jim, the Enterprise is twenty years old. We think her day is over...

column1: But, we had requested -- we were hoping to take her back to Genesis...
column2: Genesis?! Whatever for?

column1: Why -- a natural desire to help finish the work we began!
column2: That's out of the question. No one is going to Genesis!

column1: May I ask why...?
column2: Jim, in your absence, Genesis has become a galactic controversy... Until the Federation Council makes policy, you are all under orders not to discuss with anyone your knowledge of Genesis... Consider it a quarantined planet. And a forbidden subject.

column1: Jim... You are my best officer and if I had a best friend, you'd be that too. But I am Commander, Starfleet, so I don't break rules!
column2: Don't quote rules, Harry! We're talking about loyalty. And sacrifice. One man who died for us, another who has deep emotional damage --

column1: Now wait a minute! This business about Spock  and McCoy... Honestly, I have never understood Vulcan mysticism -- I'm sorry! But part of me doesn't want you to make a fool of yourself... Understand?
column2: Harry, you don't have to believe! I'm not even sure I believe. But if there's even a chance that Spock has an eternal soul -- then that is my responsibility.

column1: Yours...?!
column2: As surely as if it were my own!  Harry, give me back the Enterprise! With Scotty's help...

column1: No, Jim! Enterprise would never stand the pounding.
column2: Then I'll find a ship -- I'll hire a ship.

column1: Out of the question! The Council has ordered that no one but the science team goes to Genesis!
column2: Then let me speak to the Council! Harry, <U>please</U>! I can <U>make</U> them understand!!

column1: Yes... I hear you.  I just had to try.
column2: Of course... Now take my suggestion, enjoy your leave -- and let all this tension blow away.

column1: You're right.  Thanks for the drink.
column2: Any time.

column1: I say again: Grissom, this is Enterprise. Admiral Kirk calling Captain Esteban or Lieutenant Saavik. Come in!
column2: Report status!
Torpedoes coming in -- !

column1: Do not lecture me about treaty violations. The Federation, in creating an ultimate weapon, has become a gang of Intergalactic criminals. It is not I who will surrender, it is you.  On the planet below, I have three prisoners from the team who developed your doomsday weapon. If you do not surrender immediately, I will execute them, one at a time, as enemies of galactic peace.
column2: Who is this?! How dare you --

column1: David?... David!
column2: Admiral, your young friend is mistaken. I meant what I said. And now, to show my intentions are sincere... I am going to kill one of the prisoners.

column1: Wait! Give me a chance --
There are two more prisoners, Admiral. Do you want them killed too?  Surrender your vessel!
column2: All right, damn you! All right!  Give me a minute to inform my crew.

column1: Commander, Klingon vessel. Stand by to board this ship on my next signal.
column2: No tricks, Kirk. You have one minute.

column1: Maltz. Prisoners are at beam coordinates. Standby...
column2: You should take the Vulcan, too.

column1: No.
column2: But, why?

column1: Genesis, I want it.
column2: Beam the Vulcan up -- And we talk.

column1: Give me what I want -- and I'll consider it...
column2: You fool -- look around you! This planet is destroying itself!

column1: Yes. Exhilarating, isn't it!
column2: If we don't help each other, we'll all die here!

column1: Give me your hand and we both live.
Ambassador, I -- I had no idea you were here...  I think you know my crew...
column2: I will speak with you alone, Kirk.

column1: Sarek... I would have come to Vulcan... to express my deepest sympathies...
column2: Spare me your human platitudes, Kirk. I have been to your Government. I have seen the Genesis information, and your own report.

column1: Then you know how bravely your son met his death.
column2: "Met his death"?  How could you, his friend, have assumed that? Why did you leave him on Genesis! Spock trusted you -- and you denied him his future!

column1: I -- saw no future --
column2: You missed the point, then and now... Only his body was "in death," Kirk! And you were the last one to be with him.

column1: Yes, I was...
column2: Then you must know that you should have come with him to Vulcan.

column1: But -- why?
column2: Because he asked you to! He entrusted you with his very essence -- with everything was not of the body. He asked you to bring him to us -- and to bring that which he gave you: his Katra. His living spirit.

column1: Sir. Your son meant more to me than you can know. I'd have given my life if it would have saved his. You must believe me when I tell you that he made no request of me!
column2: He would not have spoken of it openly.

column1: Then, how --
column2: Kirk, I must have your thoughts. May I join your mind?

column1: ... He spoke of your friendship.
column2: Yes...

column1: He asked you not to grieve...
... The needs of the many outweigh...
column2: ... The needs of the few...

column1: ... Or the one.
column2: ... Spock...

column1: I have been... and always shall be... your friend. Live long... and prosper!
column2: ... No...! ` Kirk, bathed with sweat, suddenly shudders in pain. Sarek opens his eyes, removes his hands. He touches Kirk with gentleness as Jim recovers, opens his eyes.

column1: Forgive me. It is not here. I assumed he had mind-melded with you. It is the Vulcan way when the body's end is near.
column2: But he couldn't touch me...! We were separated!

column1: Please wait!... Surely he would have found a way! If there was so much at stake -- Spock would have found a way!
column2: Yes... But -- how...?

column1: Bones!...
column2: One alive, one not. Yet both in pain.

column1: What must I do?
column2: You must bring them to Mount Selaya -- on Vulcan. Only there is the passage possible. Only there can both find peace...

column1: What you ask is difficult.
column2: You will find a way, Kirk. If you honor them both, you <U>must</U>.

column1: What about Spock?
column2: I am not sure. Only time will answer.  Kirk. I thank you. What you have done is --

column1: What I have done, I had to do.
column2: But at what cost? Your ship... Your son.

column1: So!  Speak!
column2: Great power... to control... dominate... destroy. If it works.

column1: Share this with no one.
column2: Understood, my lord.

column1: We are going to this "planet." Even as our emissaries negotiate for "peace" with the Federation, we will <U>act</U> for the preservation of our race! We will seize the secret of this weapon. The secret of ultimate power!
column2: Success, my lord.

column1: Sir, may I suggest --
column2: Say the wrong thing, Torg, and I will kill you too!

column1: I ordered no interruptions.
column2: But sir! Federation Starship approaching.

column1: We are cloaked. Enemy closing on impulse power. Range, 5,000 Kellicams.
column2: Good.  This is the turn of luck I have been waiting for.

column1: Why haven't they finished us?... They outgun me ten to one
column2: Perhaps they wish to take you prisoner.

column1: How can you tell that?
column2: I trust my instincts.  Admiral Kirk. This is your opponent speaking.

column1: I give two minutes. For you, and your gallant crew.  Take every last man: form a boarding party, armed heavily!
column2: They outnumber us, my Lord --

column1: I'll be in my quarters. Execute course to the Federation Boundary.
column2: Yes, my lord!

column1: Range: 3000 Kellicams.
column2: Steady. Continue on impulse power.

column1: Firing range, sir.
1,000 Kellicams, closing!
column2: Wait!... Wait...

column1: 500 Kellicams!
My Lord, enemy commander wishes a truce to confer.
column2: Put him on screen!  Study him well.

column1: My Lord... what are your orders?
column2: I underestimated him... He did the one thing I didn't anticipate ... He destroyed himself...

column1: Sir, may I --
column2: Killing his son was <U>stupid</U>! It made Kirk willing to die.

column1: We still have the prisoners, sir. Perhaps their information --
column2: They are useless! It was Kirk I needed. And I let him slip away.

column1: But surely, our mission has not failed -- ?
column2: Our mission is over. I have failed... A human has been bolder and more ruthless than I...  That -- is the real dishonor.

column1: You amaze me, Commander.
column2: How is that...?

column1: A twenty year space veteran, yet you ask for the worst duty station in town. I mean, look at this place: the hind end of space.
column2: Peace and quiet appeals to me, Lieutenant.
