column1: Well, maybe that's okay for someone like you whose career is winding down. But me: I need some challenge in my life. Some adventure... Even just a surprise or two.
column2: You know what they say, Lieutenant. Careful what you wish for: you may get it.

column1: Commander, these are some of the most famous people in Starfleet! Admiral Kirk, my God!
column2: Good for you, Lieutenant.

column1: But it's damn irregular. No destination orders, no encoded i.d...
column2: All true.

column1: Well -- what are we going to do about it?!
column2: I am going to do nothing about it. <u>You</u> are going to sit in the closet.

column1: The <u>closet</u>?! Have you lost all sense of reality?
column2: This isn't reality. This is fantasy.

column1: But dear Lord, are we intelligent enough to -- Suppose, this thing were used where life already exists?
column2: It would destroy such life in favor of its new matrix --

column1: It's new -- have you any idea what you're saying?
column2: I was not attempting to evaluate its moral implications, Doctor. As a matter of cosmic history, it has always been easier to destroy than to create --

column1: Not anymore! Now you can do both at the same time! According to myth, the earth was created in six days. Watch out: here comes Genesis
column2: I don't dispute that in the wrong hands --

column1: Are you out of your Vulcan mind? No human can tolerate the radiation loose in there!
column2: But, as you are so fond of observing, Doctor, I'm not human.

column1: You're not going in there -- !
column2: I'm afraid I can't stop to discuss this logically --

column1: Physician, heal thyself.
column2: That's all you have to say?

column1: Wouldn't it be easier to put an experienced crew back on the ship?
column2: They'll learn. Galloping about the cosmos is a game for the young, doctor.

column1: Bless me, doctor
column2: 'Beware Romulans bearing gifts.' Happy Birthday...

column1: Romulan Ale! Bones, you know this stuff is illegal --
column2: I only use it for medicinal purposes. Don't be a pring...

column1: Twenty-two, eighty-three...
column2: Takes the stuff a while to ferment. Gimme.

column1: I'm almost afraid to. What did you bring me, contraband Klingon --
column2: More antiques for your collection -- Cheers!

column1: Cheers. Bones, these are... charming.
column2: Four hundred years old. You don't find many with the lens still intact.

column1: Uh -- what are they?
column2: For your eyes. For most patients of your age, I generally administer Retlax Five to restore flexibility of the lens.

column1: But I'm allergic to Retlax.
column2: Exactly. Happy birthday.

column1: Slide them down your nose. Now look at me over the top. And you read printed matter through the bottom.
column2: Amazing! I don't know what to say --

column1: Say thank you.
column2: Thank you.

column1: Damn it, Jim, what the hell's the matter? Other people have birthdays. Why're we treating yours like a funeral?
column2: Bones, I don't want to be lectured.

column1: What DO you want? Damn it, why isn't there a girl here? You know this has nothing to do with age. This is about you flying a goddamn computer console when you wanna be out hopping Galaxies.
column2: Spare me your notions of poetry, please. We all have our assigned duties and...

column1: Bull. You're hiding -- hiding behind the rules and regulations --
column2: And who am I hiding from?

column1: Don't mince words, Bones
column2: I'm your doctor and I'm your friend, Jim. Get back your command. Get it back before you really do grow old. Before you turn into part of this collection.

column1: Shore leave, Admiral.
column2: Ah.

column1: What about the rest of the inspection, Admiral?
column2: The inspection will continue once we're underway, Doctor.

column1: It never rains but when it pours --
column2: As a physician you of all people should appreciate the danger of re-opening old wounds.

column1: I've got the sick bay ready. Will someone please tell me what is going on?
column2: Computer. Request security procedure and access to Project Genesis Summary.

column1: Doctors lose patients sometimes. Damn. I'm <u>still</u> in the dark: How'd he know about Genesis?
column2: At the moment that question takes a back seat to preventing him from laying his hands on it. You said it yourself

column1: There may still be time... you gave as good as you got.
column2: I got beat. We're only alive because I knew something about these ships that he didn't.

column1: Khan could be down there!
column2: He's BEEN there and hasn't found what he wants. Can you spare someone? There may be people hurt.

column1: They even killed the galley chief.
column2: This one looks like a Steward. They're not warm, but rigor hasn't set in. This didn't happen all that long ago, Jim.

column1: Go? <u>Where</u> are we going?
column2: Where <u>they</u> went. Saavik.

column1: But what if they went -- nowhere?
column2: Then this will be your big chance to get away from it all.

column1: Do you have anything to eat? I don't know about anyone else, but I'm starved.
column2: How can you think of food at a time like this?

column1: Now that's what I call a meal.
column2: It's like the Garden of Eden...

column1: Lieutenant, you are looking at the only Starfleet cadet who ever beat the no-win scenario --
column2: And almost got tossed out of the Academy...

column1: Until now.
column2: We each face death every day we're alive, Saavik.

column1: Hours instead of days, Saavik
column2: I'm taking this bunch to sick bay.

column1: You okay, Jim? How do you feel?
column2: Young. I feel young, Doctor.

column1: ... come in, please. This is Reliant calling Regula I. Repeat. This is USS Reliant --
column2: Commander, we are receiving. This is Regula I. Go ahead.

column1: Dr. Marcus... good. We're en route to you and should be there in three days.
column2: En route? Why? We weren't expecting you for another three months. Has something happened?  <u>Has something happened</u>? Do you read us?

column1: I still don't under --
column2: We have received new orders. Upon our arrival at Regula I, all materials of Project Genesis will be transferred to this ship for immediate testing at Ceti Alpha VI.

column1: <u>Will you please be quiet</u>!  Commander Chekov, this is completely irregular. Who gave the order you are quoting? Who gave the order?
column2: The order comes from Starfleet command, Dr. Marcus, direct from the General Staff.

column1: But Genesis is a civilian project, under my control --
column2: I have my orders.

column1: This is completely improper, Commander Chekov. I have no intention of allowing Reliant or any other unauthorized personnel access to our work or materials.
column2: I'm sorry you feel that way, Doctor. Admiral Kirk's orders are confirmed. Please prepare to deliver Genesis to us upon our arrival. Reliant out.

column1: Jim... read me? Can you read me?
column2: Message breaking up, Carol. What's wrong? What's wrong?

column1: ... Can't read you... repeat...
column2: Repeat... what's wrong? What's wrong?

column1: ... taking Genesis away from us...
column2: Taking Genesis? Who? Who is taking Genesis?

column1: ... see you but can't hear. Did you... order...?
column2: What order? Who's taking Genesis?

column1: ... Please help us, Jim... won't let them have... without proper... repeat... on whose authority...
column2: Carol!

column1: Wait --
column2: Stage One of our experiments was conducted in the labora- tory. Stage Two of the series will be attempted in a lifeless underground

column1: David was right, wasn't he? It's just to keep them busy.
column2: Why? Why didn't you tell me?

column1: You did this -- in a day?!
column2: The matrix formed in a day. The life forms grew later -- at a wildly accelerated rate. Can I cook or can't I?

column1: It is a far far better thing I do than I have ever done before... a far better resting place I go to than I have ever known...
column2: Is that a poem?

column1: How can you let them pull that stuff on you? They're just lazy.
column2: And bored. I know. But maybe it IS something they can...

column1: Come on, Mother, that's just the military mentality. Never put off tomorrow what you can put off today. If there's one atom of life...
column2: I know, I know...

column1: Well, don't have kittens. Genesis is going to work. They'll remember  you in a wreath with Newton, Einstein, Surak...
column2: Thanks a lot. No respect from my offspring --

column1: Par for the course... you teaming up with me for bridge after dinner?
column2: Maybe...

column1: Does that about do it?
column2: I don't think there's another piece of information we could squeeze into the memory banks. Next time, we'll design a bigger one.

column1: Will you please be quiet! We must have order here.  This has to be some sort of mistake.
column2: Mistake? We're all alone here. They waited until everyone was on shift-leave to do this. Reliant is supposed to be at our disposal, not vice-versa.

column1: I've tried to warn you. Scientists are always pawns of the military --
column2: Starfleet has kept the peace for a hundred years, I cannot and will not subscribe to your interpretation of this event.

column1: David --
column2: Mother, go back!

column1: Jim --
column2: Go back. I'm going to kill him.

column1: So are we, it looks like.
column2: I don't understand. Who's responsible for all this? Who is Khan?

column1: This? It took the Starfleet corps of engineers ten months in space suits to tunnel out all this. What we did in there -- we did in a day. David, why don't you show Dr. McCoy and the Lieutenant our idea of food.
column2: But we can't just sit here -- !

column1: David. Please.
column2: This is just to give us something to do, isn't it?  Come on.

column1: Don't tell me you've got something.
column2: We've picked up a minor energy flux reading on one dyno scanner.

column1: Damn! Are you sure? Maybe the scanner's out of adjustment --
column2: I suppose it <u>could</u> be a particle of preanimate matter caught in the matrix...

column1: All right, let's get on the Comm-pic to Doctor Marcus. Maybe it's something we can transplant.
column2: You know what she'll say...

column1: Are you sure these are the coordinates?
column2: Captain, this is the garden spot of Ceti Alpha VI --

column1: You're crazy -- !
column2: I saw it -- !

column1: I told you! I told you I saw a --
column2: Ssssh!

column1: <u>Botany Bay</u> -- oh no!
column2: What's the matter -- ?

column1: But the child --
column2: Never mind! Hurry!

column1: A criminal, Captain -- a product of the late 20th Century genetic engineering --
column2: What do you want with us? I demand --

column1: He left us.  We were no longer of use. SAAVIK Where is  the Reliant crew? Dead?
column2: Marooned on Ceti Alpha V. He's completely mad, Admiral. He blames you for the death of his wife...

column1: You lie! On Ceti Alpha V there was life, a fair chance to --
column2: <u>This is Ceti Alpha V</u>! Ceti Alpha VI exploded six months after we were left here. The shock shifted the orbit of <u>this</u> planet and everything was laid waste. <u>Admiral</u> Kirk never bothered to check on our progress. It was only the fact of my genetically engineered intellect that enabled us to survive! On earth, two hundred years ago, I was a prince, with power over millions -- now, like Prometheus I have been left by Admiral Kirk to digest my own entrails.

column1: Captain Kirk was your host! You repaid his hospitality by trying to steal his ship and murder him.
column2: And I'll wager he never told you about his shipmate, the beautiful and courageous Lieutenant McGiver, who gave up everything to join me in exile. OUT OF LOVE. And see how <u>Admiral Kirk</u> requited her devotion -- She's dead as earth!

column1: Khan, listen to me! Captain Kirk was only doing his duty! You --
column2: There is some pain at first, I am told, and then the effects are quite benign -- until the end. That was what I learned from watching my wife.

column1: Beyond what I told you, sir, it is classified information.
column2: Umm. And would Admiral Kirk have access to such information?

column1: I would think so, sir. He's on the Fleet General Staff.
column2: Then to whom do you report directly regarding Genesis?

column1: To Doctor Marcus, the civilian director of the experiments on Space Laboratory Regula I.
column2: I see. Helmsman?

column1: Well done, Commander.
column2: You realize, sir, that they will attempt to contact Admiral Kirk and confirm the order.

column1: I'm Admiral Kirk...
column2: <u>We were still there</u>, you dumb bastard! We could hear the screams all the way to the transporter room --

column1: Where's Dr. Marcus --
column2: I'm Doctor Marcus!

column1: Why didn't you tell me?
column2: She's making it up! My father was Professor --

column1: It's a long story.
column2: We appear to have plenty of time.

column1: It's the Genesis Wave!
column2: What?

column1: He's on a build up to detonation!
column2: How soon --

column1: We encoded four minutes --
column2: We'll beam aboard and stop it --

column1: I don't mean to intrude.
column2: Uh, no...  I should be on the bridge.

column1: I suppose I was.  I poured a drink. Would you like it?
column2: No. I -- I guess I'm not what you expected.

column1: I didn't expect anything.
column2: That makes two of us.  Lieutenant Saavik was right: you never have faced death --

column1: Not like this -- no. I haven't faced death, I cheated death. I tricked my way out of death and patted myself on the back for my ingenuity. I know nothing.
column2: You knew enough to tell Saavik that how we face death is at least as important as how we face life --

column1: It was just words.
column2: But good words. That's where ideas begin. Maybe you should listen to them.

column1: I'm trying, David.
column2: So am I. My friends were killed, too.

column1: I was wrong about you. And <u>I'm</u> sorry.
column2: Is that what you came here to say?

column1: Let go -- he can't -- !
column2: Only half of you would get there.

column1: What are you looking at?
column2: The Admiral's son.

column1: Don't you believe it.
column2: Oh, I believe it.

column1: What are <u>you</u> looking at?
column2: I don't know.

column1: Steady on course. All systems normal.
column2: It's not much different from Enterprise.  When I was a guest aboard her some years ago, Captain Kirk kindly allowed me to memorize her technical manuals. And now, Mr. Chekov, let us review: You say you have no details of Project 'Genesis' ?

column1: They're requesting visual communications, sir.
column2: Let them eat static.

column1: They're still running with shields down.
column2: Of course. We're one big happy fleet. Ah, Kirk, my old friend, do you know the Klingon proverb that tells us revenge is a dish that is best served cold?  It is very cold in space.

column1: Careful: Not all at once. <u>The</u> <u>engine room</u>. Lock on target and prepare to fire.
column2: Locking phasers on target.

column1: Sir -- our shields are dropping!
column2: Raise them --

column1: They won't --
column2: <u>Where's the over-ride</u>??

column1: At them! At them! FIRE! FIRE! Why can't you?
column2: We can't fire, sir

column1: No!
column2: Sir, we must!  We must repair the damage. Enterprise will wait

column1: Well?
column2: Warp drive still inoperative. All other systems should be restored shortly.

column1: Departing dark side, Regula.
column2: Visual --

column1: We'll lose them if they go in there.
column2: Rake her.

column1: No sir! We have Genesis -- Whatever you want --
column2: <u>Full power damn you</u>!

column1: Tactical!
column2: Inoperative.

column1: Yours... is... the superior...
column2: I shall avenge you --

column1: You still remember, Admiral. I cannot help but be touched. Of course, I remember you.
column2: What is the meaning of this attack? Where is the crew of the Reliant?

column1: -- But I wanted you to know first who it was who had beaten you: I, Khan Noonian Singh, the eagle you attempted to cage forever.
column2: Khan, listen to me -- if its me you want, I'll have myself beamed aboard. All I ask is that you spare my crew.

column1: Genesis, what's that?
column2: Don't play with me, Kirk, my hand is on the phaser control --

column1: Give me some time to recall the data on our computers --
column2: I give you sixty seconds, Admiral.

column1: Thirty seconds...
column2: ... to prevent an enemy from doing just what we're attempting

column1: Khan, how do I know you'll keep your word?
column2: I've given you no word to keep, Admiral. In my judgment, you simply have no alternative.

column1: Time's up, Admiral...
column2: Here it comes. Now, Spock.

column1: Kirk! Kirk, you are still alive -- my old friend...
column2: Still, 'old friend.' You've managed to kill just about everyone else, but like a poor marksman, you keep missing the target.

column1: Goodbye, Admiral. Oh, and don't count on Enterprise. She can't move. My next act will be to blow her out of the heavens.
column2: KHAN!

column1: I don't know you. But you. I never forget a face. Mister Chekov, isn't it?  I never thought to see your face again.
column2: Chekov, who is this man?

column1: You are in a position to demand nothing, sir. I, on the other hand, am in a position to grant nothing. What you see is all that remains of the ship's company and the crew of the <u>Botany Bay</u>, marooned here fifteen years ago by Captain James T. Kirk.
column2: Listen to me -- you men and women --

column1: Save your strength, Captain, these people have sworn to live and die at my command two hundred years before you were born. Do you mean he...  ... never told you the tale? To amuse you, Captain? Never told you how the <u>Enterprise</u> picked up the <u>Botany Bay</u>, lost in space from the year 1996, myself and the ship's company in cryogenic freeze?
column2: I've never even met Admiral Kirk --

column1: Captain... We're waiting. What's the delay?
column2: All is well, sir. You have the coordinates to beam up Genesis...

column1: An emergency situation has arisen. By order of Starfleet Command, as of now, 1800 hours, I am assuming command of this vessel. Duty officer so note in the ship's log. Plot a new course: for Space Laboratory Regula I.  Mr. Scott?
column2: Aye, sir.

column1: We'll be going to warp speed --
column2: Aye, sir --

column1: Scotty -- what's left?
column2: Just the batteries, sir. I can have auxiliary power in a few minutes --

column1: We don't have minutes. Can you give me phaser power?
column2: A few shots, sir.

column1: Just barely, sir.
column2: I'm going down to the station.

column1: I'll need ten minutes, sir, 'til the radiation dissipates.
column2: Uhura, send to Commander, Reliant: prepare to be boarded.

column1: Uhura. Can't you augment?
column2: I'm trying, sir. Stand by...

column1: She's not responding...
column2: Try the emergency channels...

column1: Enterprise to Reliant. Come in, Reliant.
column2: Picture, Mr. Saavik.

column1: I'm getting a voice message... wait ... short range band. They say their Chambers coil is shorting their COMM system.
column2: Spock?

column1: Mr. Scott on discrete.
column2: Scotty, let's have it.

column1: On screen.
column2: Admiral --

column1: ... No response, sir.
column2: Sensors, Captain?

column1: Saavik, for God's sake, tell her we're all right.
column2: I say again. This is Enterprise. Please acknowledge signal. Please --

column1: Enterprise to Reliant: you are ordered to surrender your vessel. Respond!  Nothing, sir.
column2: We'll beam aboard. Alert transporter room --

column1: Mr. Scott, you old space dog. You're well?
column2: I had me a wee bout -- but Dr. McCoy pulled me through.

column1: Midshipman, you're a tiger.
column2: My sister's youngest, Admiral. Crazy to get to space.

column1: Every young boy's fancy. I seem to remember it myself.  Very well. Mr. Scott, are your engines capable of handling a minor training cruise?
column2: Give the word, Admiral.

column1: Mr. Scott, the word is given.
column2: Aye, sir.

column1: <u>WHY</u>?
column2: He wants to kill me for passing sentence on him 14 years ago -- and he doesn't care who stands between him and his vengeance.

column1: The energizer's bypassed like a Christmas tree -- so don't give me too many bumps.
column2: No promises, Mr. Scott. On your way.

column1: Admiral, I've got to take the mains off the line. The energizer's shaken loose and I can't get in there to fix her -- radiation --
column2: All right, we'll do the job with auxiliary power.

column1: No, sir! You'll flood the whole compartment...!
column2: He'll die -- !

column1: If he hadn't, we'd be space by now.
column2: Admiral, this is Spock.

column1: Yes, Spock.
column2: Engine room reports auxiliary power restored. We can proceed at impulse power.

column1: Kirk to Enterprise. Damage report, Spock?
column2: Admiral, if we go by the book, like Lieutenant Saavik, hours could seem like days.

column1: Meaning you can't even beam us back?
column2: Not at present.

column1: Spock, this is Kirk. It's two hours. Are you about ready?
column2: Right on schedule, Admiral. Just give us your coordinates and we'll beam you aboard.

column1: And who is this?
column2: Midshipman First Class Peter Preston, engineers mate, SIR.

column1: Your first training voyage, Mr. Preston?
column2: Yes, SIR.

column1: I believe you'll find everything shipshape, Admiral.
column2: Oh do you? Have you any idea, Midshipman Preston, how many times I've had to listen to Mr. Scott on the Comm, telling me his troubles? Have you any idea the ribbing I've had to endure in the officers' mess to the effect that the Enterprise is a flying death trap?

column1: Is the word given?
column2: The word is given: warp speed.

column1: I assume you are loitering here to learn what efficiency rating I plan to give your cadets.
column2: I am understandably curious.

column1: They destroyed the simulator room and you with it.
column2: The <u>Kobayshi Maru</u> scenario frequently wreaks havoc with students and equipment.  As I recall you took the test three times yourself. Your final solution was, shall we say, unique?

column1: It had the virtue of never having been tried.
column2: Yours was not a solution which would have occurred to a Vulcan mentality.

column1: So you said at the time. Speaking of which, your protg's first rare -- a trifle emotional --
column2: She's half Romulan, Jim. The admixture makes her more volatile than -- me, for example.

column1: I know of your fondness for antiques.
column2: 'It was the best of times, it was the worst of times...' Message, Spock?

column1: Hrummm... and where are you off to, now?
column2: The Enterprise. I must check in before your inspection. And you?

column1: Permission to come aboard, Captain?
column2: Welcome aboard, Admiral. I believe you know my trainee crew. Certainly they have come to know you.

column1: There's a first time for everything, Admiral.
column2: To be sure, Captain.

column1: Something may be wrong at Regula I. We've been ordered to investigate.
column2: Regula I is a scientific research laboratory, if memory serves...

column1: I told Starfleet all we had was a boatload of children but we're the only ship in the quadrant. Spock: those cadets of yours -- how good are they? How will they respond under real pressure?
column2: Like all living beings, Admiral each according to his gifts. The ship is yours.

column1: That won't be necessary: just take me to Regula I.
column2: Excuse my presumption, but I do not agree. As a teacher on a training mission, I am content to command a Starship. If we are to go on actual duty, it is clear that the senior officer aboard must assume command.

column1: But it may be nothing
column2: You proceed from a false assumption. I am a Vulcan. I have no ego to bruise.

column1: You are going to remind me that logic alone dictates your actions.
column2: I was going to remind you of nothing, least of all that which you know well.  Your mistake, if I may be so bold, was promotion. Commanding a Starship is your first best destiny. Anything else is a waste of material.

column1: I would not presume to debate you.
column2: That is wise. In any case, were I to invoke logic, logic clearly dictates that the needs of the many outweigh the needs of the few.

column1: Will you accompany me to the bridge?
column2: I'd best talk with Mr. Scott, first so that he may, in his own words, explain the situation to his cadets.

column1: There are two possibilities, sir they are unwilling to respond, they are unable to respond.
column2: How far?

column1: Twelve hours and forty-three minutes, present speed.
column2: Give up Genesis, she said. What in God's name does that mean? Give it up to whom?

column1: Carol Marcus --
column2: Yes.

column1: It literally is Genesis...
column2: The power of creation --

column1: Have they proceeded with their experiments?
column2: The tape was made a year ago. I can only assume they've reached Phase Two by now --

column1: Gentlemen, this isn't --
column2: Really, Dr. McCoy

column1: What's she doing here?
column2: Chekov's on Reliant, isn't he?

column1: Is it possible their COMM system has failed -- ?
column2: It would explain a great many things --

column1: Their coil emissions are normal... Wait: their shields are going up. They're locking phasers -- !
column2: Raise shields! Energize phasers, stand by to --

column1: They knew just where to hit us.
column2: WHO? Who knew just where to hit us? And <u>why</u>?

column1: One thing is certain
column2: Visual!  Mr. Sulu, divert everything to the phasers --

column1: Not enough against their shields.
column2: Who the <u>hell</u> are they?

column1: Admiral, you can't give him Genesis...
column2: At least we know he hasn't got it. Just keep nodding as though I'm giving orders. Saavik, punch up the data charts of Reliant's command console -- hurry...

column1: The prefix code?
column2: It's all we've got.

column1: You've got to learn WHY things work on a Starship.  It's coming through now, Khan...
column2: The prefix code is 16309. All commands from each Starship bridge are relayed electronically

column1: Let's hope he hasn't changed the combination. He's quite intelligent...
column2: Wait for my signal, Spock -- too soon and he'll have time to figure it out and raise them again.

column1: Scanners and sensors still inoperative. There's no way to tell what's  inside the station.
column2: And no way of knowing if Reliant is still in the area...

column1: Affirmative, Admiral.
column2: ... Blind as a Tiberian Bat. What do you make of the plantoid beyond?

column1: Regula is class "D'. It consists of various remarkable ores. Essentially, a great rock in space.
column2: Reliant could be hiding behind that rock.

column1: A distinct possibility.
column2: Engine room... Scotty, do we have enough power for the transporters?

column1: All right, join the party. Mr. Spock, the ship is yours.
column2: Aye sir --

column1: Establish a parking orbit around the station and send me a complete damage report when you've talked with Mr. Scott.
column2: Be careful, Jim...

column1: What IS working around here?
column2: Not much, Admiral. We have partial main power...

column1: That's it?
column2: Best we could do in two hours.

column1: Uh oh.
column2: She can out-run us and out-gun us. But there is the Mutara Nebula at 153 mark four.

column1: I think we can guarantee she'll follow us, Mr. Saavik. Remind me to explain to you the concept of human ego.
column2: Best speed, Scotty...

column1: Estimating nebula penetration in two minutes. Reliant is closing.
column2: Steady as you go...

column1: Admiral, they're reducing speed.
column2: Uhura, patch me in --

column1: Sporadic energy readings port side, aft. Could be an impulse turn.
column2: He won't break off now. If he followed me this far he'll be back. But from where...?

column1: Spock!
column2: The ship -- out of danger?

column1: ... the good of the few...
column2: Or the one.

column1: I never took the <u>Kobayashi Maru</u> test -- until now. What do you think of my solution?
column2: Spock...!

column1: Kirk here.
column2: I have an urgent CommPic from Space Lab Regula I for the Admiral. Dr. Carol Marcus.

column1: In my quarters, Uhura.
column2: Yes, sir.

column1: Uhura! What's happening? Damn it...
column2: Transmission jammed at the source, sir.

column1: Captain Spock, if you do not hear from us within <u>one hour</u> your orders are to restore what power you can, take the Enterprise to the nearest Star Base and alert Starfleet command when you are out of jamming range.
column2: Sir -- we won't leave you behind...!

column1: Any suggestions, Admiral?
column2: Prayer, Mr. Saavik. The Klingons do not take prisoners.  Captain.

column1: Well, Mr. Saavik, are you going to stay with the sinking ship?
column2: Permission to speak candidly, sir?

column1: Very well.
column2: I don't believe this was a fair test of my command capabilities.

column1: And why not?
column2: Because... there was no way to win.

column1: A no-win situation is a possibility every commander may face. Has that never occurred to you?
column2: ... No, sir. It has not.

column1: How we deal with death is at least as important as how we deal with life, wouldn't you say?
column2: As I indicated, Admiral, that thought had not occurred to me.

column1: Lieutenant, are you wearing your hair differently?
column2: It is still regulation, Admiral.

column1: May I speak, sir?
column2: Lieutenant, self-expression does not seem to be one of your problems.

column1: I wish to thank you for the high efficiency rating.
column2: You earned it.

column1: I did not think so.
column2: You're bothered by your performance on the <u>Kobayashi Maru</u>.

column1: I failed to resolve the situation.
column2: There is no correct resolution. It is a test of character.

column1: May I ask how <u>you</u> dealt with the test?
column2: You may ask, Lieutenant.

column1: That was a little joke.
column2: Humor... that is a difficult concept ... it is not logical...

column1: Yes.
column2: Take the test again.

column1: This is damned peculiar.  Yellow alert.
column2: Energize defense fields.

column1: Khan!
column2: Who?

column1: Reliant's command...
column2: HURRY.

column1: On screen...
column2: We're finding it.  Please, <u>please</u> -- you've got to give us time -- the bridge is smashed, computers inoperative...

column1: Begging the Admiral's pardon: General Order 15: 'No  flag officer shall beam into a hazardous area without armed escort.'
column2: There is no such regulation.

column1: Indeterminate life signs.
column2: Phasers on stun. Move out.

column1: That's true, Admiral. All the memory cells have been emptied.
column2: Erased...

column1: It doesn't make sense. These coordinates are well within Regula -- a plantoid we know to be lifeless and airless.
column2: If Stage Two was completed, it was underground -- she said it was going to be underground.

column1: Admiral?
column2: As your teacher Mr. Spock is fond of saying: I like to think there always are possibilities.

column1: What's on your mind, Lieutenant?
column2: The <u>Kobayashi Maru</u>, sir.

column1: Are you asking me if we are playing out that scenario now, Lieutenant?
column2: On the test, sir, will you tell me what you did? I'd really like to know.

column1: How?
column2: I reprogrammed the simulation so it was possible to rescue the ship.

column1: <u>WHAT</u>?
column2: I changed the conditions of the test. I received a commendation for original thinking.  I don't like to lose.

column1: But the damage report -- we were immobilized...
column2: Come, come, Lieutenant, you of all people go by the book. Hello, Spock. You remember Dr. Marcus...

column1: Regulation 46-A: 'If transmissions are being monitored during battle...'
column2: '... no uncoded messages on an open channel...'

column1: That was close --
column2: They just don't want us going in there.

column1: Hold your course. Look sharp...
column2: At what.

column1: Mr. Saavik, all stop.
column2: All stop, sir.

column1: Cease fire. Look sharp.
column2: Power levels quite low, sir.

column1: Saavik, get us out, best speed!
column2: Aye, sir.

column1: Time from my mark...
column2: Two minutes, ten seconds.

column1: Time!
column2: Three minutes, thirty seconds.

column1: After you dismiss the company, you will take the watch. Set course for Ceti Alpha V and we'll pick up survivors.
column2: Aye, sir.

column1: I'll be in my quarters if needed, but I would prefer...
column2: Understood, sir.

column1: Admiral on the bridge!
column2: As you were, Mr. Saavik.

column1: Aye, sir. On course to Ceti Alpha. All is well.
column2: Good, I believe you already know my, uh, son --

column1: Yes, well, why don't you show him around and...
column2: Aye, sir --

column1: I really must thank you.
column2: I am delighted

column1: I cut your new orders personally. By the end of the month, you'll have your first command: USS EXCELSIOR.
column2: Thank you, sir. I've looked forward to this for a long time.

column1: Stop engines.
column2: Stop engines.

column1: Course plotted for Regula I, Admiral...
column2: Engage warp engines --

column1: Reliant in our section this quadrant, sir, and slowing --
column2: Visual.

column1: Mr. Sulu... The shields!
column2: Trying, sir!

column1: I can't get power, sir!
column2: Scotty!

column1: Mr. Sulu, lock phasers on target and await my command...
column2: Phasers locked...

column1: Sir, you did it.
column2: <u>I did nothing</u> -- except get caught with my britches down. I must be senile. Mr. Saavik, you just keep right on quoting regulations. Meantime, let's find out what the hell is going on and see how bad we've been --

column1: Approaching Regula and Space Lab Regula I.
column2: Try again.

column1: Admiral on the bridge --
column2: Battle stations.

column1: Phaser lock inoperative, sir.
column2: Best guess, Mr. Sulu. Fire when ready.

column1: Leaving Section Fourteen for Section Fifteen.
column2: Project parabolic course to avoid entering Neutral Zone.

column1: May I remind the Captain that if a Starship enters the zone --
column2: I'm aware of my responsibilities, Mister.

column1: Shields activated!
column2: Inform the Klingons we are on a rescue mission...

column1: We're over our heads. Mr. Sulu, get us out of here.
column2: I'll try, Captain.

column1: Aft thrusters, Mr. Sulu.
column2: Aft thrusters, sir.

column1: We are clear and free to navigate.
column2: Course heading, Captain?

column1: Prepare for warp speed.
column2: Ready, sir.

column1: We commend the soul of our brother departed. We love we commit his body to the depths of space.
column2: Honors -- hup!

column1: Fire all phasers...!
column2: No power to the weapons system, sir.

column1: He's not what I expected, Sir.
column2: What did you expect, Lieutenant?

column1: He's very human.
column2: We can't all be perfect, Saavik. You must control your prejudices and remember that as a Vulcan as well as a Romulan you are forever a stranger in an alien land. Around you are humans, and as a member of the Starfleet you are unlikely ever to escape their presence or their influence. You must learn to tolerance in addition to all else I have taught you. Tolerance is logical.

column1: Very well, Mr. Saavik, clear all moorings.
column2: Aye, sir.

column1: All moorings are clear, Captain.
column2: Thank you, Mr. Saavik.

column1: Lieutenant, how many times have you piloted a Starship out of Spacedock?
column2: Never, sir.

column1: Take her out, Mr. Saavik.
column2: Aye, sir.

column1: Sir, may I quote General Order 12: 'On the approach of any vessel, when communications have not been est --
column2: Lieutenant, the Admiral is aware of the Regulations.

column1: Certainly...
column2: By the book...

column1: You lied.
column2: I exaggerated.

column1: I do not understand the final question...
column2: You are half human. The Computer knows that.

column1: The question is irrelevant.
column2: Spock... The retraining of your mind has been in the Vulcan way, so you may not understand feelings. But as my son, you have them. They will surface.

column1: As you wish, since you deem them of value. But I cannot wait here to find them.
column2: Where must you go?

column1: To Earth. To offer testimony.
column2: You do this -- for friendship?

column1: I do this because I was there,
column2: Spock. Does the good of the many outweigh the good of the one...?

column1: I would accept that as an axiom.
column2: Then you stand here alive because of a mistake -- made by your flawed, feeling, human friends. They have sacrificed their futures because they believed that the good of the <u>one</u> -- you -- was more important to them.

column1: Humans make illogical decisions...
column2: ... They do, indeed.

column1: Heard there was some excitement.
column2: Just a couple of kooks...

column1: How're you doing?
column2: Fine. Just fine.

column1: Don't tell me fish stories, kiddo. I've known you too long.
column2: Bob... it's tearing me apart.

column1: I know. I feel the same thing. But we're between a rock and a hard place. We can't keep them without risking their lives and we can't let them go without a taking the same chance.
column2: Yeah.

column1: And finally, they're not human beings, you know. Their intelligence has in no way been proven comparable to ours --
column2: I don't know about you, but my compassion for someone is not limited to my estimate of their intelligence.  I mean whales may not have painted the Mona Lisa or invented the dirt bike but they didn't ravish the land either.

column1: Sorry if I spoke out of turn.
column2: Not at all. You gave me things to think about. You always do. You do sound a little wrecked, why don't you go home and stare at the ceiling?

column1: You -- sent them away. Without even letting me say goodbye?
column2: Gillian --

column1: Professor Scott, I'm Dr. Nichols, plant manager. I'm terribly sorry but there's been an awful mix-up Would you believe I was never told about your visit?
column2: I tried to clear things up, Professor Scott. I explained you'd come all the way from Edinburgh on appointment to study manufacturing methods here at Plexico, but they don't seem to know anything about it.

column1: Well, so much for the tour of our humble plant. I must say, Professor your knowledge of engineering is most impressive.
column2: Back home, we call him the miracle worker.

column1: He never jokes... Perhaps the professor could use your computer.
column2: Please...

column1: No!  No... What did you have in mind...?
column2: A moment alone, please.

column1: You'd think they could at least send a ship. Bad enough to be court marshaled and spend the rest of our lives mining borite -- but to come home in this Klingon flea trap...
column2: We could learn a thing or two from this flea trap. It has a cloaking device that cost us a lot.

column1: You sure this is such a bright idea?
column2: What do you mean?

column1: I mean <u>him</u>, back at his post, like nothing happened. I don't know if you'd got the whole picture but he isn't exactly working on all thrusters.
column2: It'll come back to him.

column1: Are you sure?  That's what I thought.
column2: Mr. Sulu... Take us home...

column1: Bones --
column2: Dammit, Jim, they've made him into a goddam green-blooded computer!

column1: Bones, stay here.
column2: No way -- somebody has to keep an eye on him!

column1: Now wait just a damn minute.
column2: Spock, start your computations for time warp.  Come on, Bones. Let's pay Scotty a visit.

column1: You're really going to try this time travel in this rust bucket?
column2: We've done it before.

column1: Sure, slingshot around the Sun. If you pick up enough speed you're in time warp. If you don't, you fry..
column2: Would you prefer to do nothing?

column1: I prefer a dose of common sense. you are proposing to head backwards in time, find Humpback Whales, then bring them forward in time, drop them off - and hope they tell this Probe what to do with itself!
column2: -- That's the general idea.

column1: That's crazy!
column2: If you have a better idea - now's the time.

column1: It doesn't look all that different.
column2: Let's hope so, Bones. Mr. Sulu, set us down in Golden Gate Park.

column1: Oh, joy.
column2: Captain Spock and I will attempt to trace these whale songs to their source.

column1: Jim, you've got to let me go in there! Don't leave him in the hands of Twentieth Century medicine.
column2: What do you think, Spock?

column1: What did you say she was getting?
column2: Cramps.

column1: An experimental device, doctor.
column2: Tearing of the middle meningeal artery...

column1: Wake up, man, wake up!
column2: Come on, Pavel...

column1: He's coming 'round, Jim...
column2: Pavel, can you hear me? Give me your name and rank...

column1: Congratulations, Jim. I think you've saved the Earth.
column2: Not me, Bones... They did it.

column1: Hi... Busy?
column2: Uhura is busy. I am monitoring.

column1: Umm. Well, just wanted to say -- nice to have your katra back in your head, not mine.  I mean, I may have carried your soul, but I sure couldn't fill your shoes.
column2: ... My shoes...

column1: Forget it...  How 'bout covering a little philosophical ground? Life, Death, Life... Things of that nature?
column2: I did not have time on Vulcan to review the Philosophical disciplines.

column1: Spock, it's me, Bones! I mean our experience was unique. You really have gone where no man has gone before. Can't you tell me what it felt like?
column2: It would be impossible to discuss the subject without a common frame of reference.

column1: You're joking...!
column2: A joke is a story with a humorous climax.

column1: You mean I have to die to discuss your insights on death?
column2: Pardon me, Doctor, I am hearing many calls of distress.

column1: Most unusual. An unknown form of energy of great intelligence and power. I find it illogical that its intentions are hostile...
column2: Really? You think this is its way of saying "Hi there" to the people of the Earth?

column1: There are millions of other species on Earth, Doctor. Only human arrogance would assume the message was meant for man.
column2: I liked him better before he died.

column1: Specifically, Humpback Whales.
column2: That's crazy! Who would send a probe hundreds of light years to talk to a whale?

column1: 10 million years earlier. Humpbacks were heavily hunted by Man. They have been extinct since the 21st Century... It is possible that an alien intelligence sent the probe to determine why they lost contact.
column2: ... My God...

column1: You just said there aren't any except on Earth of the past.
column2: That is what I said, Doctor.

column1: Angels and ministers of grace, defend us.
column2: Hamlet, Act I scene 4.

column1: You, ah...  You present the appearance of a man with a problem.
column2: Your perception is correct, Doctor... In order to return us to the exact moment at which we left the 23rd Century, I have used our journey back through time as a referent, calculating the coefficient of elapsed time in relation to the acceleration curve.

column1: Naturally.  So what is your problem?
column2: Acceleration is no longer a constant.

column1: Well, you're gonna have to take your best shot.
column2: ... Best shot...?

column1: Guess, Spock. Your best guess.
column2: "Guessing" is not in my nature...

column1: ... I don't think he understands...
column2: No, Spock. It means he feels safer about your "guesses" than most other peoples facts.

column1: You're saying... It is a compliment.
column2: It is.

column1: Who are you? Doctor Adams was supposed to assist me.
column2: We're just -- observing.

column1: What the hell do you think you're doing?
column2: Reading the patient's vital signs.

column1: What's your degree in, dentistry?
column2: How do you explain slowing pulse, low respiratory rate and coma?

column1: Fundoscopic examination --
column2: Fundoscopic examination is unrevealing in these cases!

column1: A simple evacuation of the expanding epidural hematoma will relieve the pressure.
column2: My God, man, drilling holes in his head is not the answer. The artery must be repaired without delay or he will die! So put away your butcher knives and let me save the patient!

column1: What's causing that!?
column2: Captain, their call is being carried on an amplification wave of enormous power!

column1: Can you isolate the wave?
column2: Negative. It's impacting on all our systems!

column1: Damage report!
column2: Captain... All systems have failed... We are functioning on reserve power only.

column1: Find it?
column2: Yes, under "U.S. Government." Now we need directions.

column1: Team leader, this is team 2.   Come in, please...
column2: I have the coordinates of the reactor...

column1: ... It gives me a great sense of history.
column2: It gives me a great sense of danger. We have to beam in next to the reactor room, not in it.

column1: How long?
column2: Depends on how much shielding is between us and the reactor.

column1: All right, Commander, you wanna tell us anything?
column2: Like what?

column1: My name is Pavel Chekov. I am a Lt. Commander in Starfleet, United Federation of Planets, service number 656-5827b.
column2: All right. Let's take it from the top.

column1: The top of what?
column2: Name?

column1: My name?
column2: No, <u>my</u> name.

column1: I do not know your name.
column2: You play games with me and you're through

column1: Okay... Make nice and give us the ray gun.
column2: I varn you. If you don't lie on the floor, I vill have to stun you.

column1: Go ahead. Stun me.
column2: I'm wery sorry, but --

column1: Operational, Admiral. Cloaking Device now available in all modes of flight.
column2: I'm impressed, Mr. Chekov. A lot of effort for a short voyage.

column1: We are in an enemy wessel, sir. I didn't wish to be shot down on thee way to our own funeral.
column2: Most prudent.  Engine room. Report, Scotty.

column1: No, sir. And no Federation wessels on assigned patrol stations.
column2: That's odd. Uhura, what's on the Comm channels...?

column1: Shields, Mr. Chekov.
column2: Shields, aye.

column1: No choice now, Scotty!
column2: Sir, heat shields at maximum!

column1: Yes, sir.
column2: Dr. McCoy, you, Mr. Scott and Commander Sulu will convert us a whale tank.

column1: Ah, well done, team 2.
column2: And Admiral, it's the Enterprise.

column1: Cloaking device is stable... All systems normal.
column2: Stabilize Energy Reserve!... Report helm:

column1: The mains are down, sir! Aux power is not responding.
column2: Mr. Sulu, switch to manual control!

column1: Status report, Admiral!
column2: Mr. President, the Probe has passed through all quadrants. The starships Shepard and Yorktown and three smaller vessels have been neutralized.

column1: "Neutralized?" How?
column2: We don't know. It's using forms of energy our best scientists do not understand...

column1: Can you protect us?
column2: We are launching everything we have.

column1: To hunt a species to extinction is not logical.
column2: Whoever said the human race was logical?  Now if you'll follow me, I'll introduce you to the Institute's pride and joy.

column1: Attempting the hell to communicate.
column2: Communicate? Communicate what? You have no right to be here!

column1: They like you very much. But they are not the hell your whales.
column2: I suppose they told you that...?

column1: So you were at Berkeley.
column2: I was not.

column1: Are you sure it isn't time for a colorful metaphor?
column2: You're not one of those guys from the military, are you? Trying to teach whales to retrieve torpedoes, or some dipshit stuff like that?

column1: You sure you won't change your mind?
column2: Is there something wrong with the one I have?

column1: You mean man...
column2: To put it mildly. Since the dawn of time, men have harvested whales for a variety of purposes, most of which can be achieved synthetically at this point. A hundred years ago, using hand-thrown harpoons, they did plenty of damage -- but that was nothing compared to what they've achieved in this century.

column1: They are mature humpbacks, weighing 45,000 pounds each. They wandered into San Francisco Bay as calves and were brought here. We call them George and Gracie.
column2: It's perfect, Spock: a male, a female, together in a contained space can beam them up together and consider ourselves damn lucky...

column1: Despite all the things they are teaching us we have to return George and Gracie to the open sea.
column2: Why's that?

column1: Well, for one thing, we simply don't have the money to keep feeding them a couple of tons of shrimp a day!
column2: How soon?

column1: Ohhh<u>kay</u>. I don't know what this is about, but I want you guys outta here right now or I call the cops.
column2: I assure you that won't be necessary. We were only trying to help...

column1: Back to San Francisco.
column2: Came all the way down here to jump in and swim with the kiddies, huh?

column1: There's really very little point in my trying to explain.
column2: I buy that. What about him?

column1: He's harmless.  Back in the sixties he was part of the Free Speech movement at Berkeley. I think he did too much LDS.
column2: LDS?? Are you dyslexic on top of everything else? Come on, Lemme give you a lift. I have a notorious weakness for hard luck cases -- that's why I work with whales.

column1: We don't want to be any trouble.
column2: You've already been that. C'mon.

column1: Thanks.
column2: Don't mention it. And don't try anything, either. I got a tire iron right where I can get at it.

column1: Memory problems, too.
column2: Uh huh. What about you? Where you from?

column1: Iowa.
column2: A landlubber. Come on, what the hell were you boys really trying to do back there? Was it some kinda macho thing? If that's all, I'm gonna be real disappointed. I hate that macho type.

column1: Can I ask <u>you</u> something?
column2: Go ahead.

column1: They're gonna hafta take their chances.
column2: What does that mean, exactly? Take their chances.

column1: No, ma'am. No dipshit.
column2: Well, that's something. I'da let you off right here.

column1: All right. Who are you? and don't jerk me around any more. I want to know how you know that.
column2: We can't tell you.  Please, just -- let me finish. I can tell you that we're not in the military and that we intend no harm to the whales.

column1: Then --
column2: In fact, we may be able to help -- in ways that, frankly, you couldn't possibly imagine.

column1: Or believe, I'll bet.
column2: Very likely. You're not exactly catching us at our best.

column1: Just a little joke. See you later, old friend.
column2: How did you know Gracie's pregnant? Nobody knows that.

column1: He's just going to hang around the bushes while we eat?
column2: It's his way.

column1: Do you trust me?
column2: Implicitly.

column1: So how did a nice girl like you get to be a cetacean biologist?
column2: Just lucky, I guess.

column1: You're upset about losing the whales.
column2: ... You're very perceptive.

column1: How will that be done, exactly?
column2: They'll be flown in a special 747 to Alaska and released there.

column1: Flown... And that's the last you'll see of them?
column2: See, yes. But we'll tag them with radio transmitters on a special frequency so we can keep tabs on them.

column1: You know, I could take those whales somewhere they wouldn't be hunted.
column2: You? You can't even get from Sausalito to San Francisco without a lift.

column1: Thanks. Cheers.
column2: If you have such a low opinion of my abilities, how come we're having dinner?

column1: Where could you take them?
column2: Hm?

column1: My whales? Where could you take them where they'd be safe?
column2: It's not so much a matter of a place as of time.

column1: Sorry, the time would have to be right now.
column2: What do you mean now?

column1: What's that?
column2: What's what?

column1: Wanna try it from the top?
column2: Tell me when the whales are going to be released?

column1: ... Who are you?
column2: Who do you think I am?

column1: Don't tell me: you're from outer space.
column2: No, I'm from Iowa. I just work in outer space.

column1: Well, I was close. I knew outer space was going to come into it sooner or later.
column2: All right. The truth?

column1: I'm all ears.
column2: That's what you think.  Okay...Truth... I'm from what, on your calendar, would be the late 23rd Century. I've been sent back in time to bring two Humpback Whales with me in an attempt to... repopulate the species.

column1: Well, why didn't you say so? Why all the coy disguises?
column2: You want the details?

column1: Are you kidding? I wouldn't miss this for all the tea in China.
column2: Then tell me when the whales are leaving.

column1: Jesus, you are persistent.  Okay, your friend was right. Gracie is not only pregnant, she is very pregnant... At noon tomorrow -- in what is sure to be a media circus -- the whales get shipped out.
column2: Noon tomorrow...?!

column1: Well, "Admiral," that may be the strangest dinner of my life and the biggest cockamamie fish story I've ever heard.
column2: You asked.  Now, will you tell me something?  George and Gracie's transmitter. What's the frequency?

column1: Sorry, that's classified.  I don't really have a clue who you are... You wouldn't want to show me around your space ship, would you?
column2: It wouldn't be my first choice, no.

column1: So. There we are.
column2: Lemme tell you something. I'm here to bring two humpbacks into the 23rd Century. If I have to, I'll go to the open sea to get them, but I'd just as soon take yours -- better for me, better for you... and better for them.

column1: I bet you're a damn good poker player.
column2: Think about it -- but don't take too long because I'm out of time. If you change your mind, this is where I'll be.

column1: Here... In the park?
column2: Right.

column1: It's true... what you said...
column2: Yes... And I'm glad you're here. Though I'll admit, you picked a hellova time to drop in...

column1: Steady, now. We need your help.
column2: Have I flipped out? ... Is any of this real?

column1: It's all real. Look.  The storage tanks for the whales.
column2: But Kirk...

column1: We'll bring them up just like we brought you. It's called a transporter beam...
column2: Kirk. They're gone.

column1: ... Gone?!
column2: They were taken last night. I wasn't told. They're in Alaska by now.

column1: What kind of spaceship is this, anyway?
column2: A spaceship with a missing man.

column1: If we keep going up, they'll catch us!
column2: Calm yourself, Nurse.  Scotty, get us out of here!

column1: Gillian... Would the whales be at sea by now?
column2: Yes... If you have a chart on board, I can show you.

column1: All I need is the radio frequency to track them.
column2: What are you talking about? I'm coming with you.

column1: You can't. Our next stop is the 23rd Century.
column2: What do I care? I've got nobody but those whales...

column1: I have no time to argue, Gillian. Or even tell you how much you've meant to us... The <u>frequency</u>.
column2: All right. The frequency is 401 megahertz.

column1: You tricked me.
column2: You need me.

column1: Oh my God, we're too late!
column2: Mr. Sulu: full power descent!

column1: ... What does that mean?
column2: He means our chances of getting home are not very good. You might have lived a longer life if you'd stayed where you belong.

column1: I belong here.  Suppose by some miracle you do get them through.  Who in the 23rd Century knows anything about Humpback whales?
column2: ... You have a point...

column1: Hey! -- Where you going?!
column2: You're going to your ship, I'm going to mine. Science Vessel. I've got 300 years of catch-up learning to do.

column1: You mean this is -- goodbye?
column2: Why does it have to be goodbye?

column1: Well, I... As they say in your century -- I don't even have your phone number. How will I find you?
column2: Don't worry. I'll find <u>you</u>.  See you around the galaxy...

column1: Permission to come aboard.
column2: Permission granted.

column1: Thank you, Admiral.
column2: Jim, Spock, Jim. Remember...?

column1: It would be improper to refer to you as Jim while you are in command, Admiral... Also, I must apologize for my attire.  I seem to have misplaced my uniform.
column2: Well, I... find that understandable  I mean, you've been through a lot.  Station, please.

column1: Spock -- you're suggesting the transmission is meant for life form other than man?
column2: A distinct possibility, Admiral. The President did say the transmission was directed at the Earth's Oceans

column1: Where are you going?!
column2: To the on-board computer room. To confirm my suspicion.

column1: Spock...?
column2: As suspected, the Probe's transmissions are the songs sung by whales.

column1: Spock, could the Humpback's answer to this call be simulated?
column2: The sounds, but not the language. We would be responding in gibberish.

column1: Is there any other planet where this species exists?
column2: The Humpback was indigenous to Earth. Earth of the past.

column1: That leaves us no choice. We must destroy the probe before it destroys Earth.
column2: That would be futile, Admiral. The probe would neutralize us easily.

column1: But we can't turn away! Is there no alternative?
column2: There is one, but I cannot guarantee its success. We could attempt to find some Humpback Whales.

column1: Mr. Spock, your computations?
column2: In progress, Admiral.

column1: Ready to engage computer, Admiral.
column2: What is our target in time?

column1: The late 20th Century.
column2: Surely you can be more specific...

column1: Not with this equipment. I have had to program some of the variables from memory.
column2: What are the variables...?

column1: Availability of fuel components
column2: You've programmed that from memory...?

column1: Earth... But when?... Spock?
column2: Judging by the pollution content of the atmosphere, I believe we have arrived at the late 20th Century.

column1: Home in on the strongest signal. Descend from orbit.
column2: Admiral, if I may: we're probably already visible to the tracking devices of the time.

column1: There is a 20th Century possibility.
column2: Explain.

column1: If memory serves, there was a dubious flirtation with nuclear fission reactors resulting in toxic side effects. By the beginning of the fusion era, these reactors had been replaced, but at this time, we should be able to find some.
column2: But you said toxic.

column1: We could rig a device to collect their high energy photons safely
column2: Where would we find these reactors... Theoretically.

column1: Weren't those a birthday present from Dr. McCoy?
column2: And they will be again, Spock. That's the beauty of it.  How much?

column1: Well, Spock, thanks to your restored memory and a little bit of luck, we are in the streets of San Francisco looking for a pair of humpback whales.  How do you propose to solve this minor problem?
column2: Simple logic will suffice. We need a map.  That one should do.

column1: I think we'll find what we're looking for at the Cetacean Institute in Sausalito. Two Humpbacks called George and Gracie.
column2: How do you know this...?

column1: As you observed, a primitive Culture.
column2: Yes.

column1: Admiral, may I ask you a question?
column2: Spock, don't call me Admiral. Don't you remember: you used to call me Jim... Now what's your question?

column1: Your use of language has altered since our arrival. It is currently laced with -- shall I say -- more colorful metaphors: "Double dumb ass on you" -- and so forth...
column2: You mean profanity. That's simply the way they talk here. Nobody pays any attention to you if you don't swear every other word. You'll find it in all the literature of the period.

column1: Oh, the complete works of Jacqueline Susan, the novels of Harold Robbins....
column2: Ah... The giants.

column1: Come on, fellah -- speak up!
column2: Admiral, if we were to assume these. whales are ours to do with as we please, we would be as guilty as those who caused their extinction.

column1: Spock...
column2: Yes?

column1: About those colorful metaphors we discussed. I don't think you should try to use them.
column2: Why not?

column1: Well, for one thing, you haven't quite got the hang of it.
column2: I see.

column1: And another thing... It is not always necessary to tell the truth.
column2: I cannot tell a lie.

column1: You don't have to lie... You could exaggerate.
column2: Exaggerate.

column1: You've done it before. Can't you remember?
column2: The hell I can't

column1: What else did you learn from your mind meld?
column2: They are very unhappy about the way their species has been treated by man.

column1: They have a right to be...  Do you think they'll help us?
column2: I believe I was successful in communicating our intentions.

column1: It's her -- from the Institute. If we play our cards right, we may learn when those whales are really leaving.
column2: How will playing cards help?

column1: I meant --
column2: He meant what you were saying on the tour: that if things keep on the way they're going, humpbacks will disappear forever.

column1: Status?
column2: The tank will be finished by morning...

column1: That's cutting it closer than you know. What about team two?
column2: No word since beam-in. We can only wait for their call.

column1: Damn.... Damnit! We've been so lucky. We have the two perfect whales in our hands, but if we don't move quickly, we'll lose them!
column2: In that event, the probabilities are that our mission would fail.

column1: Admiral. Full power is restored.
column2: Thank you, Spock.

column1: Admiral, may I suggest that Dr. McCoy is correct. We must help Chekov.
column2: Is that the logical thing to do, Spock...?

column1: No, Admiral... But is the human thing to do.
column2: Right.  Will you help us?

column1: Mr. Spock, where the hell is the power you promised me?
column2: Admiral, you must wait one damn minute.

column1: Mr. Sulu, take the con. I'm taking our guest down to see her whales.  Mr. Spock: have you accounted for the variable mass of whales and water in your time re-entry program?
column2: Mr. Scott cannot give me exact figures, Admiral. So I will...  Make a <u>guess</u>.

column1: Can we make breakaway speed!?
column2: Hardly, Admiral, I cannot even guarantee we will escape the Sun's gravity! I will attempt to compensate by altering our trajectory.

column1: Spock... Did braking thrusters fire?
column2: They did, Admiral.

column1: Spock: Condition report!
column2: No data, Admiral. Computers are non-functional.

column1: You got us to the right place, Spock. Now all we have to do is get the whales out before we <u>sink</u>.  Mr. Scott, come in!... Scotty...?!  Damn... Mr. Spock, see to the safety of all hands.
column2: I will, Admiral.

column1: Guidance is functional. Onboard Computer will interface with Federation memory bank...
column2: Weapons systems?

column1: Estimating Planet Earth one point six hours present speed.
column2: Continue on course. Chekov, any signs of Federation escort?

column1: Warp two... three...
column2: Steady as she goes...

column1: Warp Nine... Nine point two... Nine point three...
column2: Mr. Sulu, we need breakaway speed!

column1: Hang on, sir... Nine point seven... point eight... Breakaway threshold...
column2: Steady!!...  Now, Mr. Sulu!

column1: Mr. Sulu...? ... Mr. Sulu?!
column2: ... Aye sir...?

column1: What is our condition?
column2: Sir... Braking thrusters seem to have fired.

column1: Aye, sir. Descending.
column2: We'll divide into teams. Commanders Chekov and Uhura are assigned to the Uranium problem.

column1: Ready sir.
column2: Go, Mr. Sulu.

column1: Maintaining impulse climb. Wing five by zero, helm steady.
column2: Advise reaching 10,000. Steer three-one-zero.

column1: Three-one-zero, aye!
column2: Uhura, scan for the whales. 401 megahertz!

column1: 10,000 M.S.L., Admiral.
column2: Wing to cruise configuration... Full impulse power.

column1: 10 seconds, sir!
column2: Hover on my mark, Mr. Sulu! Mr. Chekov, stand by de-cloaking -- Scotty, ready for power build up!  Mark, Mr. Sulu...

column1: I have no control, sir!
column2: Picture, Uhura!

column1: Sir -- I've got some back pressure on manual --
column2: Ground cushion! Keep the nose up if you can --

column1: Let's see what she's got, Mr. Sulu.
column2: Aye, sir!

column1: Systems report.  Communications?
column2: Communications Systems ready. Communications Officer -- ready as she'll ever be.

column1: What is it?
column2: Overlapping distress calls. Some from Starships... others...

column1: Then, this is what it would sound like underwater?
column2: Yes, sir.

column1: Admiral, I am receiving whale songs.
column2: On speakers.

column1: Individual whale song getting stronger... This is strange, Admiral. The song is directly ahead. It's coming from San Francisco.
column2: From a city? That doesn't make sense....

column1: I'll have bearing and distance for you, sir.
column2: Right.  Now look: I want you all to be very careful. This is terra incognita. Many customs will doubtless take us by surprise. It's a forgone conclusion these people have never seen an extra-terrestrial before.

column1: We'll stick together till we get orientated. Bearing to the whales?
column2: 283 degrees... 15.2 kilometers...

column1: Any luck...?
column2: Nothing... I should never have left him...

column1: I've found Chekov, sir: he's in emergency surgery right now.
column2: Uhura!... Where!

column1: Bearing!
column2: Bearing 327, range 600 nautical.

column1: Admiral, I have a signal closing on the whales. Bearing 328 degrees.
column2: On screen.

column1: Estimate range, ship to whales!
column2: Sir... Estimating one nautical mile.

column1: Unidentified aircraft, 40,000 feet MSL, range 30 miles, bearing 010.
column2: Mr. Scott -- how soon?

column1: I can't, sir -- Nothing!
column2: Out of control, and blind as a bat!

column1: Mr. Scott, how soon can we get underway?
column2: Give me one more day, sir. The damage control is easy. Reading Klingon is hard.

column1: We're ready, sir. I've converted the Dilithium Sequencer to something less primitive. And Admiral -- I've replaced the Klingon Food Packs. They was givin' me sour stomach.
column2: Appreciated by all, Mr. Scott.  Prepare for departure.

column1: Scotty, how long is this bay?
column2: About 60 feet, Admiral.

column1: That should be enough. Can you enclose it to hold water?
column2: I suppose I can, sir

column1: Scotty, we have to find some Humpbacks.
column2: Humpbacked - people.?

column1: Whales, Scotty. 45 to 50 feet long
column2: Admiral - how am I going to handle all that weight?

column1: You'll work it out, Scotty. And remember: two of them.
column2: Two?

column1: They're giving out. De-crystallizing.
column2: Give me a round figure, Mr. Scott.

column1: I can't believe we've come this far only to be stopped by this!  Scotty, is there any way dilithium can be re-crystallized?
column2: Sorry, sir. We can't even do that in the 23rd Century.

column1: What is it? I thought I told you never to call me --
column2: Sorry, Admiral. We just thought you'll like to know, we're beaming them now.

column1: It's going slow, sir. It'll be well into tomorrow.
column2: Not good enough, Scotty. You've got to do better!

column1: I'm ready Spock. Let's go find George and Gracie...
column2: Mr. Sulu?

column1: Scotty: Are the whale tanks secure?
column2: Aye. But I've never beamed up 400 tons before.

column1: Stay with me, sir -- I need more power curve...
column2: How long, Scotty?

column1: Admiral! There be whales here!
column2: Well done, Mr. Scott. How soon can we be ready for warp speed?

column1: I'll have to re-energize.
column2: Don't take too long. We're sitting ducks for their radar systems...  Mr. Sulu, impulse climb.

column1: Stand by, sir. Miracle worker at work...
column2: Mr. Scott, don't make jokes, we are in danger of -

column1: Full power, sir.
column2: Mr. Sulu, if you please.

column1: Ironic. When man was killing these creatures, he was destroying his own future...
column2: The beasties seem happy to see you, Doctor. I hope you like our little aquarium.

column1: You better get up there, sir. We're having some power fall-off...
column2: On my way...!

column1: The whales...?!
column2: No power to the bay doors.

column1: The explosive override -- ?
column2: It's under water! There's no way to reach it...

column1: Go on ahead... Close the hatch!
column2: Admiral, you'll be trapped!

column1: Excelsior? Why in God's name would you want that bucket of bolts?
column2: Scotty, don't prejudge. A ship is a ship.

column1: Admiral, I'd like to continue my work on the ship until you leave.
column2: Thank you, Lt. Saavik.

column1: And... Here is a deposition I have made. If it is not sufficient, I will return to Earth to testify.
column2: Don't concern yourself, Saavik. Your leave has been granted for good and proper cause.  How are you feeling?

column1: I am well, Admiral.
column2: You will be in good hands here.

column1: Well, Saavik. I guess this is goodbye.
column2: Yes, Admiral.  Sir. I have not had the opportunity to tell you about your son.  David died most bravely. He saved Spock. He saved us all... I thought you should know.

column1: Even as the Federation negotiated a peace treaty with us, Kirk was secretly developing the Genesis torpedo! Conceived by Kirk's son and test detonated by the Admiral himself!  The result of this awesome energy was euphemistically called "The Genesis Planet..." A secret base from which to launch the. annihilation of the Klingon people!  We demand the extradition of Kirk! We demand justice!
column2: Klingon justice is a unique point of view, Mr. President.

column1: Genesis was perfectly named: The creation of life not death. It was the Klingons who had first blood while trying to possess its secrets.
column2: Vulcans are well known as the intellectual puppets of the Federation!

column1: Your vessel did destroy U.S.S. Grissom. Your men did kill Kirk's son. Do you deny these events?
column2: We deny nothing! We have the right to preserve our race!

column1: Don't know anything about it? I find it difficult to believe that I've come millions of miles --
column2: Millions?

column1: Professor Scott, if you'll --
column2: I demand to see the owners! I demand --

column1: With pleasure.
column2: Well, that's different.

column1: If you'll follow me, Professor --
column2: I will. Can my assistant come, too?

column1: Doctor Nichols, I might have something to offer <u>you</u>.
column2: ... Yes?

column1: I notice you're still working with polymers.
column2: Sill? What else would I be working with?

column1: Ah, what else indeed? Let me put it another way: how thick would a piece of your plexiglass need to be at 60 feet by 10 feet to withstand the pressure of 18,000 cubic feet of water?
column2: That's easy: 6 inches. We carry stuff that big in stock.

column1: Yes, I noticed. Now suppose -- just suppose -- I could show you a way to manufacture a wall that would do the same job but was only an inch thick. would that be worth something to you, eh?
column2: ... Are you joking?

column1: Hello? Computer...?
column2: Just use the keyboard...

column1: Transparent aluminum?
column2: That's the ticket, laddie.

column1: Hi.
column2: Hi. Huey 205, isn't it?

column1: Right on. You fly?
column2: Oh, here and there.  I flew something similar in my Academy days.

column1: All right, then this is old stuff to you.
column2: Old, yes. But interesting.  Do you mind if I ask a few questions...?

column1: Father...?
column2: I will be returning to Vulcan within the hour... I wanted to take my leave of you.

column1: It is kind of you to make this effort.
column2: It is not an effort. You are my son.  Besides

column1: As I recall, I opposed your enlistment in Starfleet... It is possible that judgment was incorrect.  Your associates are people of good character.
column2: They are my friends.

column1: Yes, of course... Do you have any message for your mother?
column2: Tell her I feel fine...

column1: Ojichan? Akira ojichaan dewa naino? Koko de nani shiteru no?
column2: Gomen nasarei. Hito chigai de gozaranuka na.  I'm sorry, my son. You have mis- taken me for someone else.

column1: Chotto omachi nasarei. Namae wa nanto moosareruka na.  Wait my son. What is your name?
column2: Sulu Hikaru.

column1: Ah, sorenara mazu mazu nagaiki wo sareru to mira.  Ah... Then I am sure that you will have a long and happy life.
column2: Arigato. Sayonara.  Thank you, honorable sir.

column1: We were under the impression they were being held against their will.
column2: It's not our custom to have guests here at all, let alone hold anyone against their will.

column1: My people have a strict policy of non-interference with other cultures. In fact, it's our Prime Directive.
column2: Your directive apparently doesn't include spying on other cultures.

column1: You have warp capability?
column2: Capability, yes. But where can warp drive take us, except away from here...?

column1: I understand how you feel. We just want to retrace Data's movements that day...
column2: Why?

column1: I don't like to leave questions unanswered.
column2: Then you must spend your life answering questions.

column1: I know what a hologram is, Captain. The question is -- why would someone want to create one of our village?
column2: Data, if you were following the boy and discovered this ship...

column1: Deceive us?
column2: To move you off this planet. You go to sleep one night in your village... wake up the next morning in this flying holodeck transported en masse. A week later, maybe a month, you've been relocated on a similar planet without ever realizing it.

column1: Don't panic...
column2: I've been shot at... thrown into the lake out of an invisible ship that's come to abduct us all... what's there to panic about?

column1: There's an unusual metaphasic radiation coming from the planet's rings. It continuously regenerates the cells in our bodies. You must have noticed the effects by now.
column2: We've... just begun to.  I suppose you're seventy-five.

column1: Clearly, the architects of this conspiracy have tried to keep it a secret. Not just from you, but from my people as well.  I don't intend to let them.
column2: We've always known that to survive, we had to remain apart. It hasn't been easy. Many of the young people here want to know more about the offland... they're attracted to stories of a faster pace of life...

column1: Most of my people who live that faster pace would sell their souls to slow it down.
column2: But not you.

column1: There are days.
column2: You don't live up to your reputation as an offlander, Picard.

column1: In defense of offlanders, there are many more like me...
column2: ... who wouldn't be tempted by the promise of perpetual youth? I don't think so.

column1: The craftsmanship is extraordinary.
column2: This is a school... that's a student's work.  She'll be ready to become an apprentice soon. Then, in thirty or forty years, she'll take her place among the artisans...

column1: An apprentice for thirty years.  We've noticed your people's mental discipline. Did that develop here?
column2: More questions. Always the explorer. If you stay long enough, that'll change.

column1: Will it?
column2: You'll stop reviewing what happened yesterday... stop planning for tomorrow... until you find...  Let me ask you a question -- have you ever experienced a perfect moment in time?

column1: A perfect moment?
column2: When time seemed to stop... and you could almost live in that moment...

column1: Seeing my home planet from space for the first time...
column2: Yes. Exactly. Nothing more complicated than perception.  You explore the universe. We've discovered a single moment in time can be a universe in itself... full of powerful forces... most people aren't aware enough of the now... to ever notice them...

column1: I wish I could spare a few centuries to learn.
column2: It took us centuries to learn that it doesn't have to take centuries to learn.

column1: There's one thing I don't understand.  In three hundred years...you never learned to swim?
column2: I just... haven't gotten around to it yet.

column1: I wonder if you're aware of the trust you endanger, Jean-Luc Picard. In my experience, it's unusual for...
column2: ... an offlander?

column1: When we're forced away by the terrain, we'll use transport inhibitors to compensate. The mountains have the highest concentrations. Once we're there, transport will be virtually impossible...
column2: There are caves in those mountains.

column1: Jak'tahla?
column2: Roughly translated: puberty... although for a Klingon that's not doing it justice...  Any severe mood swings, unusual aggressive tendencies -- be sure to let me know right away...

column1: Right beyond that ridge is where the caves begin... we can hide for days...
column2: By now the Son'a have scanned the area and know that just as well as we do.

column1: How is it a woman like you never married? And don't tell me you "just haven't gotten around to it yet"...
column2: What's the rush?

column1: There's a cavern at the base of the next hill...
column2: This way!

column1: You're Ro'tin, aren't you...? There's something in the voice.  Would you be his friend Gal'na?  I helped your mother bathe you when you were a child. She still speaks of you.
column2: You've brought the Federation into the middle of a blood feud, Admiral. The children have returned to expel their elders... just as they were once expelled. Except Ru'afo's need for revenge has now escalated to parricide.

column1: Mother and son. You arranged this...?
column2: I thought it might begin the healing process.

column1: But I have three hundred and eighteen days of vacation time coming. I plan on using them.
column2: I'll be here.

column1: Do you really think your mighty Federation would be interested in protecting six hundred people?
column2: The "mighty" Federation could learn a few things from this village...

column1: There is no need for concern. I am operating within normal parameters now.
column2: You're what?

column1: My father told me I shouldn't talk to you.
column2: I understand.

column1: Not everyone here agrees with him. I mean, you know, about machines. There was even a big fight about it once.  Do you like being a machine?
column2: I aspire to be more than I am.

column1: I know why.  So people like us won't be afraid of you any more.
column2: Perhaps, that is true.

column1: Don't you ever get tired?
column2: My power cells continually re- charge themselves.

column1: Perhaps it would surprise you to know that I have often tried to imagine what it would be like to be a child...
column2: Really?

column1: Really.
column2: For one thing, your legs are shorter than everyone else's.

column1: But they are in a constant state of growth. Do you find it difficult to adapt?  A child's specifications are never the same from one moment to the next. I am surprised that you do not... trip over your own feet.
column2: Sometimes I do.

column1: But you've never had adults telling you what to do all the time... or bedtimes... or having to eat food you don't like...
column2: I would gladly accept the requirement of a bedtime in exchange for knowing what it is like to be a child.

column1: Do machines ever play?
column2: I play the violin... and my chess routines are quite advanced...

column1: Chase me!
column2: For what purpose?

column1: Because you're it. And if you tag me... then I'm it.
