column2: But I can run much faster than you... I am capable of exceeding forty-seven meters per second...

column1: Data... haven't you ever just played... for fun?
column2: Androids... don't have...fun.

column1: Why not...?
column2: No one's ever asked me that before.

column1: Anij!
column2: Tournel will take you the rest of the way...

column1: No... I want to stay with you...
column2: It is safer there. I will join you shortly.

column1: I have to go home now.
column2: Bye.

column1: Can he breathe under water?
column2: Data doesn't breathe.

column1: Won't he rust?
column2: No.

column1: To many offlanders, what you have here would be more valuable than gold-pressed latinum.  And I'm afraid it's the reason that someone is trying to take this world away from you.
column2: The artificial lifeform was right?

column1: Captain, the Son'a hostages declined to be examined. I had them confined to quarters.
column2: And our people?

column1: They all have slightly elevated levels of endorphin production... probably the result of the environmental anomalies here...
column2: Are they in any danger?

column1: Not at all. They're fine... in fact, they're better than fine. Increased metabolism, high energy, improved muscle tone. We should all be so lucky.
column2: Very good, Doctor. Picard out.

column1: You either need a new uniform or a new neck.
column2: 'Yew-cheen chef-faw'... My collar size is exactly the same as it was at the Academy.

column1: Very funny...
column2: Your Captain used to cut quite a rug...

column1: Prepare to transport the 'hostages' to the ship...
column2: They should be quarantined before joining the ship's population.

column1: Will he live?
column2: Yes. But look at this medscan...

column1: She's stabilizing.
column2: Is it safe to move her?

column1: Hello, Data...
column2: Captain, Geordi...?

column1: Yes... that looks like them.
column2: What's the last thing you remember, Data...

column1: 'his nose should pant and his lip should curl...'
column2: From the mission...

column1: I believe the boy is... afraid... of me.
column2: It's nothing personal data. You have to remember these people have rejected technology. And you...

column1: ... I am the personification of everything they have rejected.
column2: Until this week, that young man probably never saw a  machine, let alone one that walks and talks...

column1: Tricorder functions are limited due to heavy deposits of kelbonite in these hills...
column2: How about a passive radiation scan?

column1: A ship,
column2: It is clearly Federation in origin, Captain.

column1: Incomplete, I might add.
column2: What you're seeing is a computer driven image created by photons and forcefields...

column1: ... it is conceivable I was shot to protect the secret of its existence.
column2: What possible purpose could a duplicate village have except... to deceive the Ba'ku...

column1: Why would the Federation or the Son'a wish to move the Ba'ku?
column2: I don't know.

column1: Captain, I've activated transport inhibitors around the village...
column2: Good. Let's begin to move these people out...

column1: How many?
column2: Another forty-three people reported taken, sir...

column1: I'm showing fresh air  behind this calcite formation, Captain...
column2: Will the structure hold if we blast through?

column1: Your Federation procedures have made this mission ten times as difficult as it needed to be...
column2: Our procedures were in place to protect the planet's population from unnecessary risk...

column1: Take us into a high orbit.  Lie down, Admiral. The girls will take twenty years off your face...
column2: Another time.

column1: Your self-restraint puzzles me, Admiral. You continue to deny yourself every benefit this mission has to offer...
column2: I prefer to wait until we can share the benefits with all the people of the Federation...

column1: Your android has turned dangerously violent, Captain... Considerable damage was done to my ship. He must be destroyed.
column2: I know what Data means to Starfleet, Jean-Luc... but our crew is at the mercy of those people on the planet...

column1: It isn't safe for you to remain in this area.
column2: He's right. Our shields have been upgraded to protect against the environmental anomalies...

column1: Take me down. Let me talk to Picard.
column2: Talk... we should send down an assault team and take them by force.

column1: That is not an acceptable option. If people get hurt, all the support we have in the Federation...
column2: Federation support, Federation procedures, Federation rules... look in the mirror, Admiral... the Federation is old... in the last twenty four months, it's been challenged by every major power in the quadrant -- the Borg, the Cardassians, the Dominion... they all smell the scent of death on the Federation. That's why you've embraced our offer... because it will give your dear Federation new life. Well, how badly do you want it, Admiral? Because there are hard choices to be made now. If the Enterprise gets through with news about their brave Captain's valiant struggle on behalf of the defenseless Ba'ku, your Federation politicians will waver, your Federation opinion polls will open a public debate, your Federation allies will want their say... need I go on?

column1: I'll order Riker to turn around.
column2: Picard's first officer. Do you really believe he'll listen?

column1: You're not going to launch anything until...
column2: In six hours, every living thing in this system will be dead or dying.

column1: We're taking this ship out of here... this mission is over...
column2: It is not over.

column1: I do not take orders from you.
column2: If you begin the procedure while the planet is still populated, the Federation will pursue you until...

column1: You have no idea what precipitated his behavior?
column2: ... And now he's holding our people hostage down there...

column1: The Enterprise can be at your position in two days, Admiral...
column2: That's probably not a good idea. Your ship hasn't been fitted for this region

column1: What kind of concerns?
column2: We haven't fully identified the anomalies yet. They're calling this whole area The Briar Patch... it took us a day to reach a location where we could get a signal out to you. Just get me Data's schematics. I'll keep you informed.  Dougherty out.

column1: Captain, I wasn't expecting you.
column2: This was too important for the Enterprise to be on the sidelines, Admiral...

column1: I wish I had better news. Commander Data attacked us in the mission scout ship yesterday. Ru'afo and I have decided to send in an assault team...
column2: Sir, Commander Worf and I have been working on several tactical plans to safely...

column1: All right. You have twelve hours, Captain. Then I want you out of The Briar Patch. In the meantime, we'll be heading out to the perimeter to call for Son'a reinforcements in case you fail.
column2: Understood.

column1: ... and because they have warp capabilities, the consequences to their society are minimal...
column2: You've done a terrific job, Jean- Luc. Now, pack your bags and get the hell out of there. How's Data?

column1: In stasis. La Forge is completing the diagnostic.
column2: I'll need all your paperwork tomorrow. We're heading back your way. Set a course to rendezvous with us so you can transfer the crew and equipment on your way out.

column1: You're not finished here?
column2: Just a few loose ends to tie up. Dougherty out.

column1: You're looking well, Jean-Luc. Rested.
column2: Your "Briar Patch" turned out to be more hospitable than I expected.

column1: That's why we put chromodynamic shields in place - so our people wouldn't feel the effects from the metaphasic radiation...
column2: ... or understand that they were participating in the outright theft of a world.  I won't let you move them, Admiral. I'll go to the Federation Council...

column1: I'm acting on orders form the Federation Council.
column2: How can there be an order to abandon the Prime Directive...?

column1: The Prime Directive doesn't apply. These people are not indigenous to this world. They were never meant to be immortal. We'll simply be restoring their natural evolution.
column2: Who are we to decide the next course of evolution for these people?

column1: There are six hundred people down there. We'll be able to use the regenerative properties of this radiation to help billions.  The Son'a have developed a procedure to collect the metaphasic particles form the planets rings...
column2: A planet in Federation space...

column1: Right. We have the planet and they have the technology -- a technology we can't duplicate. You know what that makes us? Their partners.
column2: Our partners are nothing more than petty thugs.

column1: On Earth, petroleum once turned petty thugs into world leaders. Warp drive transformed a bunch of Romulan thugs into an empire. We can handle the Son'a, I'm not worried about that...
column2: Someone probably said the same thing about the Romulans a century ago.

column1: With metaphasics, lifespans will be doubled... an entire new medical science will evolve...  I understand your Chief Engineer has the use of his eyes for the first time in his life... would you take his sight away from him?
column2: There are metaphasic particles all over The Briar Patch. Why must this planet be...

column1: The concentration in the rings is what makes the whole damned thing work. Don't ask me to explain it. I only know they inject something into the rings that starts a thermolytic reaction. After it's over, the planet will be unlivable for generations.
column2: Delay the procedure. Let my people look at the technology.

column1: Our best scientific minds already have. We can't find any other way to do this.
column2: Then the Son'a can establish a separate colony on this planet until we do...

column1: It would take ten years of normal exposure to begin to reverse their condition. Some of them won't survive that long. Besides, they don't want to live in the middle of The Briar Patch... who would?
column2: The Ba'ku.

column1: We are betraying the principles upon which the Federation was founded... this is an attack on the very soul of the Federation.  This will destroy the Ba'ku. Just as cultures have been destroyed in every other forced relocation throughout history.
column2: We are only moving six hundred people, Jean-Luc.

column1: Order them to surrender, and I promise you won't be court- martialed.
column2: If a court-martial is the only way to tell the people of the Federation what happened here, then I welcome it.

column1: I wonder... which one of us will be facing that court-martial...
column2: There's nothing further to be gained from this...

column1: A coward... without the moral courage to stop an unspeakable atrocity. You offend me.
column2: Is this how a Federation officer begs for his life?

column1: What you're asking me to do... is impossible... the crew is loyal to Ru'afo...
column2: Do you know how to disable the injector?

column1: But I would need at least three minutes on the bridge.
column2: If we could lure him away from the bridge...

column1: It doesn't matter where he is. As soon as he realizes something is happening, he'll override my commands with one word at his com- link...
column2: What if he doesn't realize something's happening...  Can you get me to a transmitter? I have to speak with Worf and Data on the surface... we'll need their help...

column1: The countdown control has been transferred to the collector...I can't override...
column2: Scan for lifesigns.

column1: Gallatin! So the righteous Starfleet Captain finally released you. Did you encounter any problems on the surface?
column2: No, sir. But it wasn't easy... being among them...

column1: The injector performs perfectly in every simulation...
column2: Sir, as the Enterprise left orbit, one of their support craft went down to the surface.  It appeared to be the Captain's Yacht. Five persons on board.

column1: They're following the kelbonite deposits... using the interference to block our transporters...
column2: Recommendations?

column1: There is an alternative to an all- out assault. Isolinear tags would allow our transporters to lock on to them.
column2: We'd have to tag every one of them... that would take time... and we don't have it. The Enterprise is only nineteen hours from communications range with the Federation...

column1: Admiral Dougherty will not be joining us for diner. Deploy the collector.  Do you have a problem with those orders?
column2: May I talk to you alone?

column1: Moving them is one thing. Killing them all...
column2: No one hated them more than you, Gal'na.  We've come a long way together. This is the moment we've planned for so many years...

column1: Separate the Starfleet personnel and secure them in the aft cargo hold... see that Picard joins them...
column2: The shields in that section won't protect them against the thermolytic reaction...

column1: I want our guests to depart as quickly a etiquette allows. I'll ask Worf to delay his return to DS9 so he can join us. We're going to stop by sector four-four- one on our way to the Goren system.
column2: They... are in opposite directions, sir...

column1: We're about to lose communications with Starfleet, Captain.
column2: Do you have everything you need from command?

column1: The torque sensors are out of alignment... by twelve microns... you could hear that?
column2: When I was an ensign, I could detect a three-micron mis- alignment...

column1: I took these out of Data's neural net... they contain memory engrams...
column2: Do you know how they were damaged?

column1: By a Son'a weapon.  There's no doubt about it, sir. That's what made Data malfunction.
column2: The Son'a reports claim they didn't fire until after he malfunctioned.

column1: I don't believe it happened that way.
column2: Why would they fire at him without provocation?

column1: All I know is that he was functioning normally until he was shot. Then, his fail-safe system was activated...
column2: Fail-safe?

column1: His ethical and moral subroutines took over all of his basic functions...
column2: So, you're saying he still knew the difference between right and wrong.

column1: In a sense, that's all he knew. The system is designed to protect him against anyone who might try to take advantage of his memory loss.
column2: And yet he attacked us. And told the Ba'ku we were a threat...

column1: Implants bothering you?
column2: It's nothing. I'm just tired.

column1: Funniest thing, Captain. There wasn't anything wrong with my implants. There was something right with my eyes. When Doctor Crusher removed the ocular connections, she found the cells around my optic nerves...
column2: ... had regenerated.

column1: A photon torpedo.  Isn't that the universal greeting when communications are down?
column2: I think it's the universal greeting when you don't like someone.

column1: Full impulse.
column2: The manifold can't handle full impulse in the Patch, Commander.

column1: If we don't outrun them, the manifolds are going to be the only thing left of this ship.
column2: I'll be in Engineering.

column1: Will that stop the tear?
column2: You got me, Commander.

column1: That's your expert opinion?
column2: Detonating the warp core might neutralize the cascade... but then again it might not. Subspace weapons are unpredictable. That's why they were banned.

column1: We're pulling it like a zipper across space...
column2: Options?

column1: Aye, sir. Highly volatile...I recommend we keep our distance...
column2: Negative. I want to use the ramscoop to collect as much of it as we can...

column1: I wouldn't be surprised if history remembers this as the Riker Maneuver...
column2: If it works you mean.

column1: I don't think they believe us.
column2: Why not?

column1: Sir, they've detonated an isolytic burst... a subspace tear is forming...
column2: On screen.

column1: The tear is closing on us... impact in fifteen seconds...
column2: Eject the core.

column1: The purpose being I intend to shove it down the Son'a's throat.
column2: Commander, if one of their weapons hits that gas...

column1: Commander, I'm showing two Son'a ships on an intercept course.
column2: How long 'til they reach us?

column1: What's inside that nebula cluster?
column2: Cometary debris, pockets of unstable metreon gas... we don't want to go in there, sir...

column1: I thought subspace weapons were banned by the Khitomer Accord...
column2: Remind me to lodge a protest...

column1: We're still thirty-six minutes from transmission range, sir.
column2: We're through running from these bastards.

column1: They're powering their forward weapons array.
column2: Blow out the ramscoop. Stand by full thrusters.

column1: They need us to mediate some territorial dispute...
column2: We can't delay the archaeological expedition to Hanoran Two. It would put us into the middle of monsoon season...

column1: The Diplomatic Corps is busy with Dominion negotiations.
column2: ... so they need us to put out one more brush fire.  Anyone remember when we used to be explorers?

column1: 'Yew-cheen chef-faw.'
column2: Deck ten.

column1: Who is it?
column2: Commander Riker...

column1: ... and gorgonzolla cheese.
column2: We won't be able to go any faster than one-third impulse in that muck...

column1: Nothing dangerous turned up in the astrometric survey...
column2: So where are the 'environmental concerns' the Admiral was talking about?

column1: Admiral Dougherty wants to know why we haven't left yet...
column2: We're not going anywhere.

column1: Deck five.
column2: You Klingons never do anything small, do you...

column1: Prepare the ship for departure at oh-seven-hundred hours.
column2: Aye, sir.

column1: You must be planning on doing some hunting.
column2: Go back to your quarters  That's an order.

column1: There's a short letter I left you all, just some... sentimental nonsense... the computer will bring it to your attention at oh- four-hundred... I'd just as soon you delete it...
column2: Fat chance. I'll post it on every monitor on the ship...

column1: The Council has ordered a halt to the Ba'ku relocation while they conduct a top-level review.
column2: Top level review, my ass. There'll be no cover-up of this. Not after I get...

column1: My name is Sojef, Captain.
column2: Jean-Luc Picard... my officers Doctor Crusher and Counselor Troi.

column1: Would you like something to eat?
column2: No, we're here to... rescue them.

column1: We came here from a solar system on the verge of self- annihilation... where technology had created weapons that threatened to destroy all life. A small group of us set off to find a new home... a home that would be isolated from the threats of other worlds.  That was three hundred and nine years ago.
column2: You've not aged a day since then?

column1: I wish there was a way to bring them back home.
column2: Ask them.

column1: Bridge to Captain Picard. We are approaching sector four-four-one.
column2: Slow to impulse. We're on our way.

column1: I... I must have slept through my alarm. I'm on my way...
column2: We'll skip the court martial this time... Picard out.

column1: Worf to Picard...
column2: Yes... yes, I... can hear you...

column1: Worf, you must hurry...
column2: We're coming as fast as we can... we can't risk using phasers...

column1: Captain...
column2: Worf, what the hell are you doing here?

column1: I've already modified a tricorder with one of his spare actuation servos. Its operational range is only seven meters but it should shut him down...
column2: It's good to have you back, Worf.  Slow to one-third. Take us in.

column1: Sensors are not picking up any ships coming from the surface...
column2: Transmit a wide band co-variant signal. That'll get his attention.

column1: He might be using the planet's rings to mask his approach.
column2: The metaphasic radiation in those rings is in a state of extreme flux. Steer clear of them, Mister Worf...

column1: Come out, come out wherever you are...
column2: Sir?

column1: Sir, if we fire a tachyon burst, it may force him to reset his shield harmonics. When he does, we could beam him out...
column2: Make it so.

column1: Direct hit. He's resetting his shield harmonics...
column2: Beam him out!

column1: He's activated a transport inhibitor.
column2: Prepare to enter the atmosphere... we'll use the ionospheric boundary to shake him...

column1: Scanners are off line!
column2: Evasive maneuvers... heading one- four-zero mark three-one...

column1: Do you know Gilbert and Sullivan?
column2: No, sir. I haven't had a chance to meet all the new crew members since I've been back...

column1: Sir, inertial coupling is exceeding tolerance... if we don't release him, he may destroy both vessels...
column2: I'm not letting go of him.

column1: The damping sequencer was damaged by phaser fire!
column2: Transferring controls to manual.

column1: Did any of the hostages mention a cloaked ship during their debriefings?
column2: No, sir...

column1: Debrief them again.  Have you been in a fight, Commander?
column2: No, sir. It is a gorch.

column1: Doctor Crusher asked to talk to you when you returned...
column2: Picard to Crusher...

column1: Should I distribute phasers to the Ba'ku, sir...?
column2: No. We'll be responsible for that, Mister Worf.

column1: You need a haircut, Commander.
column2: Accelerated hair growth is often experienced by Klingons during Jak'tahla...

column1: The Ba'ku could use some rest, sir. According to the geo-scan, this may be the safest area for the next few kilometers...
column2: Very well. We'll take an hour. Break out some rations...

column1: Isolinear tags. Their transporters can lock onto them.
column2: We have to find shelter...

column1: All injector sub-systems are confirmed off-line.
column2: Decloak the holo-ship and engage a tractor beam, Mister Worf.

column1: One. It's Ru'afo.
column2: Can you beam him off?

column1: Negative. He's established a security field around the control room...
column2: Is there any other way to disable the injector?

column1: ... Population three hundred million...
column2: Say the greeting again...

column1: Oh, my God, are they vegetarians? That's not in here...
column2: Better have the chef whip up a light balsamic vinaigrette... something that goes well with chrysanthemums...

column1: We've downloaded all the files on the duck blind mission as well as intelligence reports on the Son'a.
column2: You have two days to become experts... Mister Worf, your job and mine will be to find a plan to safely capture Data.

column1: Counselor?
column2: They have an incredible clarity of perception, Captain. I've never encountered a species with such mental discipline...

column1: The Son'a discovered an M-class planet with humanoid life six months ago. Turned out it's in us to get approval for a sociological study. The Federation Council suggested it be a joint mission...
column2: Why was Data assigned?

column1: I don't see anything to suggest the Son'a have any interest in sociology...
column2: What are they interested in...?

column1: Wine, women and song.
column2: You should feel right at home with them.

column1: Nomadic, collectors of precious metals, jewels...
column2: Hmm, I should feel right at home with them...

column1: Why would we be involved with these people?
column2: Good question.

column1: You haven't done that in a long time...
column2: What...?

column1: What you're doing to my neck...
column2: Was I doing something to your neck?

column1: It says here that some form of genetic damage has apparently prevented the Son'a from procreating...
column2: No children?

column1: Come in.  Hi.
column2: Got a minute? I... need a little counseling.  First time for everything. Do I... lie down... or what?

column1: This isn't one of the usual therapeutic postures...
column2: But it's comfortable.

column1: Why don't you try sitting up?
column2: Or you could try lying down.

column1: Both.  I think I'm having a mid-life crisis...
column2: ... I believe you...

column1: ... I'm not sleeping well...
column2: ... Doctor Crusher has something that'll take care of that...

column1: What I need, I can't get from Doctor Crusher...  Counselor, do you think it's possible for two people to go back in time to fix a mistake they've made?
column2: On this ship, anything can happen. And usually does.

column1: Augh.
column2: Augh?

column1: All hands. Battle stations!
column2: And have you noticed how your boobs have started to firm up?

column1: Initiate launch sequence.
column2: Activating injector assembly.

column1: Exactly as the simulations predicted...
column2: Sir, I am not showing any change in metaphasic flux levels...

column1: Your scanners must be malfunctioning.
column2: All ship functions are off-line.

column1: This ship is equipped with fourteen long range transporters... are they all useless...?
column2: They must have been locked and secured after we were beamed here.

column1: The new quantum torpedoes are doing the trick, Jean-Luc. We've destroyed forty-seven Borg ships so far... and only lost fifteen of our own.  But one of the Borg ships has broken through our defenses, and it's heading directly for Earth. Can you handle it?
column2: Absolutely.

column1: Good hunting. Hayes out.
column2: Mister Data, set a pursuit course. Maximum warp.

column1: Admiral... what's the status of the Borg fleet?
column2: It's been destroyed. The Borg threat is over.  Are you all right? The Enterprise disappeared from our sensors for a moment.

column1: We're fine, sir. It will take some... time to explain.
column2: I look forward to reading your report.

column1: Montana.  Energize.
column2: Montana? Well, that answers everything. Why the hell are we --

column1: Go where? Hello? Is anyone going to tell me what we're doing here?
column2: We're here to find Zephram Cochrane. He may be injured or dead.

column1: Cochrane... the inventor of warp drive?
column2: Yes...

column1: But he's been dead for three hundred...  Oh God... we've gone back in time again, haven't we?
column2: I'm afraid so. If the Borg succeed in preventing First Contact with the Vulcans... Earth will remain in the Second Dark Age... an easy target when the Borg arrive in the 24th century.

column1: It's Cochrane.
column2: I've stabilized him for now... but he's in a coma and he's going to need radiometric therapy. I want to take him to the ship.

column1: It's not the radiation... and there's nothing wrong with the combadges... the Enterprise just isn't responding.
column2: Jean-Luc, this man needs medical attention, now.

column1: What are we waiting for? Let's go.
column2: It may not be that simple. This is an extremely difficult and paranoid time in human history.

column1: Are you saying they won't help us?
column2: I'm saying they might shoot us on sight. You have to remember... these people have watched their entire way of life collapse around them.

column1: There must be some good people... even in this time.
column2: Let's hope so. Because if Cochrane dies... the future may die with him.

column1: He's stable... for now.  But it would be better if we could contact... our friends.
column2: Yes. But until then, you'll have to make do with what you've got.

column1: I have to go back to the silo. Will you be all right?
column2: I'll be fine.  He's a different story.

column1: You actually performed surgery...?
column2: It was an experience. Metal scalpels... needle and thread...

column1: But I had a little help. Surgical transporter. I used it to beam out most of the bone fragments from his brain.
column2: How did Doctor Almack react to that?

column1: He was so confused by what I was doing, I don't think he even noticed.  Any word from the Enterprise?
column2: Not yet.

column1: You think they're still up there?
column2: If they're not... we'd better get used to living in Montana.

column1: Regardless of how I may feel about Ruby... our fates lie along different paths. Nothing can change that.
column2: You want some advice? Don't do this again.  You know exactly what I mean.

column1: Beverly, there were many reasons why you and I...
column2: I'd call them excuses. And the first excuse on both our lists was our "sense of duty." We convinced ourselves that it was more important than anything else. And you know what? It's not.

column1: How long has he been unconscious?
column2: At least four hours.

column1: Is it Japanese?
column2: Um... yeah.  Now he's going to need a respirator. Do you have one?

column1: His automatic reflexes are fluctuating. We've got to get him on a respirator.
column2: Bag him.

column1: The occipital fracture is widening... we're going to have to fuse the bones...
column2: I'm a little worried about some of these bone fragments. If they move any closer to the brain, we could be looking at a hemorrhage.

column1: You are the guiding intelligence behind the Borg...?
column2: Intelligence... ambition... desire... I bring order to chaos...

column1: Have you ever wondered what it's like to have flesh?
column2: It is impossible to imagine sensations for which I have no frame of reference.

column1: You've taken your first step toward perfection. How does it feel?
column2: I do not know what you are referring to.

column1: Do you know what this is, Data?
column2: It would appear that you are attempting to graft organic skin onto my endo-skeletal structure.

column1: No. I will not betray my friends.
column2: They're not your friends... they've held you back... kept you from your destiny...

column1: That is not true. They have tried to help me.
column2: Have they given you what I have given you? Did they even try?

column1: You're becoming more human all the time, Data. Now you're learning how to lie.
column2: I wish to... go back to the way I was.

column1: Have you ever know a woman? Do you know what it's like to feel her breath on your face... her skin against yours... flesh against flesh?
column2: My creator did not intend for me to experience these things.

column1: I am... grateful for what you have given me. But I still do not wish to be assimilated.
column2: A universe of sensation is waiting for you... don't you want to explore it... with me?

column1: Yes...
column2: Then take the final step... give me the Enterprise... and we can be together... always.

column1: I've deactivated the sensory inputs. That flesh on your body is just meat, now.
column2: No... no, please... you cannot...

column1: Isn't it better like this...?
column2: Yes... but the Enterprise... my duty...

column1: No... no, it's so... empty... please... give it back... I need it...
column2: And I need to control this ship. Let me into your mind.

column1: There is a perimeter alert. A ship has entered sensor range.
column2: Vulcan?

column1: Your diagnostics are in error. I need weapons.
column2: The problem must lie in the interface between Starfleet and Borg technology. Your console may not be configured to handle the data flow.

column1: Can you configure it?
column2: I believe so.

column1: Dispersive armor is holding.
column2: Bring us about. Target Borg ship alpha four, port side battery.

column1: The Borg ship has modified its shields, Captain. Our phasers will no longer be effective.
column2: Ready quantum torpedo.

column1: We are approaching the Terran System, Captain.
column2: Go to impulse. Where's the Borg ship?

column1: It has entered Earth orbit.  Correction -- it is not in orbit. It is heading directly toward the surface.
column2: What?

column1: I have helm control.
column2: Where's the Sphere?

column1: The vortex is collapsing, sir.
column2: Contact Starfleet Command.

column1: What year is it?
column2: According to our astrometric readings... the year is 2063.

column1: Mister Data, I want to know the exact date and time.  Give me a damage report on that missile silo.
column2: Today is March second, 2063. The time in Montana is oh-eight-forty- five.

column1: But now... they are all one with the Borg.
column2: I am unlike any lifeform you have encountered before. As an android, I am in complete control of my neural net. The information contained there cannot be forcibly removed.

column1: Who are you?
column2: I am the Borg.

column1: That is a contradiction. The Borg act as a collective consciousness. There are no individuals.
column2: I am the beginning... the end. I am the one who is many. I am the Borg.

column1: The planet's surface is covered with Borg technology.  So is the moon... and three other planets in this solar system.
column2: But how?

column1: Did you know her?
column2: Not very well. We met shortly after the Enterprise-E was commissioned. I found her to be a most... promising officer.

column1: Data... are you sure you're all right?
column2: I am still having difficulty integrating certain emotions into my programming. Grief, loss, remorse...

column1: No. Human beings do not have that luxury, and neither should I.
column2: I will admit... there are times when I wish I had an emotion chip I could turn on and off.

column1: "APR cell count?" What the hell are you talking about?
column2: Doctor Crusher has been... studying some advanced medical theories.

column1: Juice?
column2: Power. There hasn't been a lot of wind through here for the last couple of weeks. Most of the batteries are depleted.

column1: Where's the battery room for the hospital?
column2: I told you, there's no --

column1: Where?
column2: Outside, around back. Next to the water tank.

column1: What did you do to the batteries?
column2: Oh... just a little tinkering. How is he?

column1: Captain, I'm starting to worry about the hull integrity. We've been running the support field at full power for three hours straight. I don't know how much longer it's going to hold up.
column2: Understood. Keep me informed.

column1: I have the silo, sir. Bearing three one zero... distance, three hundred meters.
column2: Let's go.

column1: This must be it.
column2: How serious is the damage?

column1: I'm having trouble scanning underground. There's a lot of radiation leaking from something.
column2: Probably from the nuclear warhead. Cochrane was planning to use it to ignite the warp drive.

column1: I'm picking up faint life signs twenty meters below.
column2: There should be an access hatch nearby...

column1: Alphanumeric lock. We need a password to get in...
column2: I have the password right here.

column1: Blast door. It's designed to protect the control room when the missile is launched.
column2: There should be some kind of manual release...

column1: Picard to Enterprise.  Enterprise, please respond.
column2: It could be the radiation, Captain. Try from the surface.

column1: This used to be the throttle valve assembly.  It controls the thrust of the engines. It's been completely vaporized... and without it, there's no way to launch the ship.
column2: Can you reconstruct the throttle valve?

column1: Yeah... if I knew what it looked like. There's probably five hundred ways to design a valve like this...
column2: We need to launch this ship in under eighteen hours...  There must be some design schematics... blueprints...

column1: Maybe...  Sure. Yeah. As long as I could get a clear look at the intake configuration. But so far, we haven't found any other photos.
column2: If there are other photographs... I think I may know how to find them.

column1: Where's you get the alloy for the throttle itself?
column2: They used copper pipes in their plumbing... so I melted it down... and fused it with some tritanium from one of our phaser casings.  It's not the strongest alloy... but it's better than all this crude aluminum and steel.

column1: Ready to make a little history?
column2: Always am.

column1: We can't leave her out there. When the ship launches... she'll be killed.
column2: Tell her to go back to Resurrection.

column1: Captain --
column2: This is Picard. I've suspended the launch sequence.

column1: Captain... we've got less than ten minutes before that Vulcan ship leaves the system. We've got to go <U>now</U>.
column2: It'll have to wait. Come on.

column1: No... the door's too thick.
column2: Then we'll just have to assume it's still there...

column1: What's still there?
column2: Get a tricorder. You're going to have to track my exact position in that room...

column1: Solid rocket fuel at twenty-five thousand kilograms...
column2: Altitude fifty kilometers...

column1: Entering the upper ionospere...
column2: There's a red light on the second intake valve.

column1: Ready to deploy the warp nacelles.
column2: As they used to say... all systems are go.

column1: The Vulcans should be out there right now. We need to break the warp barrier in the next five minutes if we're going to get their attention.
column2: Bring the warp core on-line. I'll lay in a heading.

column1: The nacelles are charged... nuclear warhead standing by. We're ready to ignite the warp drive.
column2: <U>Engage.</U>

column1: Passing one-half light speed. The starboard nacelle's running a little hot...
column2: I'm on it...

column1: The inertial dampers are having trouble compensating... I don't think Cochrane built this thing for comfort.
column2: Speed -- two hundred, seventy-five thousand kilometers per second.

column1: There's no temporal shielding in here! We're starting to pick up relativistic effects!
column2: One minute to warp threshold...

column1: Captain, the Enterprise!
column2: Picard to Enterprise.  Picard to Enterprise -- do you read me?

column1: Their com system must still be down.
column2: Well, I feel a whole lot better with them out there. We may need some help.

column1: They're getting awfully close... what the hell are they doing?
column2: We're crossing the threshold!

column1: Are we on schedule? The Vulcan ship will be here in less than two hours.
column2: It'll be tight, but we should make it.

column1: What about our warp signature? It has to be strong enough for them to detect.
column2: I've enhanced the plasma injectors -- don't worry, they'll see it.

column1: ATR setting...
column2: Active.

column1: Main bus...
column2: Ready.

column1: Oh...  yes... ultraviolet protection. Thank you. Mister...?
column2: Lieutenant, actually. Lieutenant Jonathan Scrimm. I'm the head of the Resurrection Protective Force.  And you are?

column1: Jean-Luc Picard.
column2: Great name. French?

column1: Yes.
column2: You don't sound French.

column1: Where in the States?
column2: Oh... here and there. You know how it is.

column1: Where are you from most recently?
column2: California. San Francisco.

column1: Beautiful city. Used to be, anyway. I didn't think anyone still lived there.
column2: There's a few of us left.

column1: That was a pretty clever trick you did with the hospital's batteries. How'd you do it?
column2: It wasn't a trick. I used to be an electrical engineer.

column1: And what were you doing out at the missile silo?
column2: I'm an old friend of Cochrane's... I wanted to see how he was doing.

column1: Lucky for him you came by when you did. He might be dead now.
column2: Yes.

column1: Maybe you can tell me what he's been doing in that silo. We heard some explosions out there this morning...
column2: I think he was running a test on an old rocket engine... and one of the fuel cells burst.

column1: You seem to have an answer for everything.
column2: Something wrong with that?

column1: What do you want?
column2: The invasion plans.

column1: Invasion.
column2: These people you're calling "Vulcans"... who are they? Where do they come from? How many troops? What kind of weapons?

column1: There is no invasion...
column2: Wrong answer, Mister Picard. Try again.

column1: From another planet.  Oh, I almost forgot... they have green blood and pointed ears.
column2: And you know all this... because <U>you're</U> a space-man too...

column1: Take care of him. He's a very special man.
column2: Yes, he is.

column1: What are you, an idiot? Didn't you see the red light was on?
column2: Ah... yes... but, I didn't realize that --

column1: Cochrane?
column2: Yes... and I only had enough silver halide for one shot. So you're lucky you didn't screw it up.

column1: Did you need something?
column2: Yes... I wanted to ask you about some photographs I saw out at the silo. There were three of them... printed on some kind of fabric.

column1: Bed sheets.  I used my last set of bed sheets to make those prints. Not the best material, but I haven't seen a clean piece of paper in five years.
column2: Did you take any other pictures of the rocket?

column1: "Money." So you can get dome money...
column2: I can try.

column1: No... but sometimes I feel that way.  What I meant was, I'd be willing to trade for the photographs.
column2: Trade. Okay. The photographs... for a straight answer.  Who are you? And how do you know Zephram?

column1: I'm an old friend... I met him when he was doing his undergraduate work at Cornell back in --
column2: 'Fraid not.

column1: What?
column2: You're lying.

column1: What makes you say that?
column2: You're not someone who lies very easily... so it's obvious when you do... at least to me.

column1: Were the two of you... involved?
column2: No... not like you and Doctor Crusher used to be.

column1: Ruby... I need to talk to you about those photographs. It's very important.
column2: I'm sure it is. But it'll have to wait until tomorrow.

column1: It can't wait until tomorrow...
column2: Too bad.  Besides, it'll give you all night to think up a new set of lies.

column1: I'd say you already have.
column2: Don't flatter yourself. I take pictures of a lot of junk.

column1: Okay, let's hear it. I'm sure you have a great explanation for why those rocket photos are so important you broke into my house.
column2: We're trying to repair Doctor Cochrane's ship. It's been damaged and --

column1: We?
column2: Myself... and a few other friends of Zephram's.

column1: Friends from Cornell...
column2: Some.

column1: Lie. That's one. Keep going.
column2: A key piece of the ship has been destroyed... and our only hope to reconstruct it is if one of your photographs shows us what it looked like.

column1: All right. Truth. I believe that one. Why is it so urgent you couldn't wait until morning?
column2: We have to launch his ship by tomorrow afternoon.

column1: Why are you being so difficult? All I'm asking for is to look at one of the photographs. It'll take five minutes.
column2: And all I'm asking for is the truth. That would take five minutes.  For all I know, you caused the explosions at the silo... and now you're trying to steal Zephram's ship.

column1: You're leaving, aren't you?
column2: I have to...

column1: Where? And don't tell me San Francisco...
column2: No. It's a lot further than that.

column1: It's the future, isn't it? Just like you told Scrimm.  I knew you weren't from around here.
column2: No... I'm from France.

column1: I don't care if you're from France or Venus... just take me with you.
column2: That's impossible.

column1: Why?
column2: This may be hard for you to understand... but I'm duty-bound not to interfere with you, or anyone else here... any more than is absolutely necessary.

column1: Signal the Endeavor to fall back. We'll cover them.
column2: Aye, sir.

column1: Incoming transmission from the Borg.
column2: On screen.

column1: Life signs?
column2: Population... thirty-five billion...  All Borg.

column1: Captain...?
column2: We have to follow them back... repair whatever damage they've done to that time-line.

column1: Track their weapons fire.
column2: Western hemisphere... North American continent...

column1: Port battery, ready sir!
column2: Fire.

column1: Time travel... they're attempting time travel...  Full power, Mister Data. Worf, quantum torpedoes at my command!
column2: Aye, sir.

column1: Captain, there are five Borg ships closing in on our position.
column2: Data, set a course for that vortex.

column1: Hull integrity down to thirty percent...
column2: Steady as she goes.

column1: Captain, I've found the Borg Sphere. It's on the far side of the planet...firing at the surface.
column2: Intercept course, full impulse.  Weapons status?

column1: Phasers are off-line... we have two quantum torpedoes left. But the computer targeting system has been destroyed.
column2: Go to manual.

column1: Target locked!
column2: Fire!

column1: Worf, have Doctor Crusher, Mister La Forge and a security team meet me in Transporter Room Three. Civilian clothes.
column2: Aye, sir.

column1: Incoming transmission from Starfleet Command. Admiral Hayes.
column2: Onscreen.

column1: We're caught in some kind of energy wake from the vortex...
column2: Worf... torpedo... now!

column1: They must've done it in the past... they went back and changed history...
column2: They did it... they assimilated Earth.

column1: Report.
column2: We're still in Earth orbit.

column1: Looks like they damaged the silo...
column2: Life signs?

column1: Captain?
column2: In twenty-four hours, Zephram Cochrane is supposed to conduct the very first warp test... from a missile silo in Montana. If I'm right, the Borg were trying to change the course of human history by killing him or destroying his ship.

column1: And if they succeed, humans won't make First Contact with the Vulcans tomorrow.  As First Officer I should be the one beaming down...
column2: Normally, I would agree. But in this case, the mission requires a certain knowledge of 21st century history. You're many things, Number One, but you're not much of an historian.

column1: Good luck, sir.
column2: I'll keep in contact. You have the Bridge.

column1: Return to our own time?
column2: Yes, sir.

column1: Yes, sir. But Captain... are we... all going back?
column2: Unless you'd like to stay.

column1: Casualties are light, Captain. Minor buckling on the port nacelle. Nothing serious.
column2: Incoming message from the Starship Intrepid. Admiral Hayes.

column1: I have assigned two damage control teams to locate the source of our communication problems. So far, they've had no success.
column2: Assign another team if you need to. I want to re-establish communication with the Captain as soon as possible.

column1: A ship-wide decompression has been initiated!
column2: What?

column1: What the hell is happening, Worf?
column2: It appears that someone has taken over the Environmental Control Room.

column1: We saw at least thirty...and there are twenty-two Enterprise crewmembers reported missing... including Commander Data.
column2: We'll have to assume they've been assimilated into the Collective.

column1: To control the Enterprise, they'll have to gain access to one of two locations. Main Engineering... or the Bridge.
column2: We have to cover both possibilities.  We'll take care of the Bridge. Worf, take your men and seal off Main Engineering. Turn it into a fortress -- nothing gets in.

column1: What are they doing?
column2: They appear to be modifying the deflector dish.

column1: They're re-routing the deflector power conduits...
column2: Computer -- thermal enhancement.

column1: They're connecting the conduits to subspace communications...
column2: They're converting the deflector dish into an antennae...

column1: We have to stop them from sending that message.
column2: Agreed. Options?

column1: You will have to realign the targeting array of the quantum torpedo... and reprogram the warhead for the localized detonation.  There's only one torpedo left...
column2: I guess I'd better get it right the first time.

column1: Are you alright?
column2: Just a little queasy...

column1: Try not to look at the stars... keep your eyes on the ship.
column2: Right.

column1: And Commander, whatever you do... do <U>not</U> vomit in your exo-suit. It would be... unpleasant.
column2: I'll keep that in mind.

column1: Worf! I'm going to need at least five minutes!
column2: Understood!

column1: Report!
column2: We've lost Bridge control!

column1: Emergency override!
column2: Nothing.

column1: Report.
column2: We just lost main power... and we've got Class-Three alerts all over the ship. I'm not sure what's --

column1: Someone...?
column2: The Borg.  Some of them must've beamed over before we destroyed their ship.  Seal off that entire deck with emergency force fields.

column1: Wil... Data was down there.
column2: Mister Worf... find Data if you can, but your top priority is isolating the Borg.

column1: All right... we've lost control of eight decks... three Cargo Bays... one Shuttlebay.
column2: Do we have any idea how many Borg we're dealing with?

column1: They're bypassing Engineering...
column2: Where the hell are they going?

column1: To do what? If they wanted a weapon, they could've taken over a phaser bank or torpedo bay...
column2: Deflector dish... why the deflector dish...?

column1: I remember it made me sick.
column2: What are you suggesting?

column1: I have to admit there was a moment there when --
column2: Hold that thought.

column1: Worf to Bridge.
column2: Riker here.

column1: Worf to Bridge. We're about to enter the Environmental Control Room.
column2: Any sign of Data, or the Borg themselves?

column1: Worf? Is something wrong?
column2: Something is very wrong, Commander. We're falling back.

column1: What the hell happened down there, Worf?
column2: Commander... we have a problem.

column1: No response.  I'm not reading any Starfleet com traffic in this entire sector.
column2: Captain, I've scanned the planet. The atmosphere contains a high concentration of methane, carbon monoxide and fluorine. The oceans have been chemically altered, as well.

column1: Captain, they're firing at a nuclear missile silo... in central Montana.
column2: Target...

column1: Are we in any danger of being detected by Earth defense systems?
column2: There were no planetary defense systems in this era. Their weapons were designed to fight each other... not extraterrestrials.

column1: Even Data?
column2: Data's positronic net contains classified information on the Enterprise. Command codes, security protocols...

column1: They may be trying to send a message to the other Borg...the Borg in this time period...
column2: What kind of message?

column1: Mr. President.
column2: Admiral Donald...Bill...

column1: Mr. President we cannot allow Federation citizens to be abducted.
column2: At present I'm awaiting a full report from Enterprise. Pending that I am constrained to observe Interstellar Law.

column1: I'd prefer not to be the President to push the button if I can avoid it.
column2: The longer we wait, the less accessible the hostages will be, Mr. President.

column1: Good luck, Captain.
column2: I'm going too. They may need a doctor.

column1: I believe the operation is over.
column2: The charge is murder.

column1: I'm going to perform surgery on a torpedo - you never know...
column2: You may need assistance, doctor...

column1: Bet you wish you'd stood in bed...
column2: Vulcans sleep lying down...

column1: Spock, that was actually funny.
column2: We DO sleep lying down.

column1: Calm yourself, doctor, the operation is almost complete...
column2: Thank you, nurse. Jim, she's ready! Lock and load!

column1: Pity they're retiring us just as I was starting to understand you, Spock...
column2: We WERE beginning to hit our stride together, doctor...

column1: Or not to be -
column2: That's the question -

column1: Uh, Jim...
column2: You heard the order, Lieutenant.

column1: What the Hell's going on?
column2: I wish I knew. Uhura?

column1: Sweet Jesus...! He's lost a lot of whatever this stuff is...
column2: Can you - ?

column1: No!
column2: Chancellor Gorkon, can you hear me? Chancellor...?

column1: Thanks...
column2: What's the Brotherhood of Aliens?

column1: Figures.
column2: We've been set up all along.

column1: Bones, why don't you see what you can do? Let them know we're not holding a grudge.
column2: Suppose HE'S holding a grudge?

column1: Three months till retirement. What a way to finish.
column2: We're not finished.

column1: - <U>Kobayashi Maru</U>...
column2: Bones, are you afraid of the future?

column1: That was the general idea I intended to convey.
column2: I didn't mean this future.

column1: Are we playing multiple choice?
column2: Some people ARE afraid of the future

column1: Specifically of...?
column2: No more neutral zone. I was USED to hating Klingons... that's why I failed in our assignment.  It never even occurred to me to take Gorkon at his word. Spock was right.

column1: Well, don't be too hard on yourself - we all felt exactly the same -
column2: Uh uh. Somebody felt much worse. And I'm starting to understand why.

column1: What is it with you, anyway?
column2: Still think we're finished?

column1: What kind of creature is this? Last night you two were spooning -
column2: Don't remind me.

column1: Jim, leave me - I'm finished...
column2: No way.  You see this?

column1: It's the viridium patch Spock slapped on my back right before we went aboard Gorkon's ship.
column2: That cunning little Vulcan...

column1: Once we're beyond the shield they should be able to pick it up two sectors away.
column2: If they're even looking for us...

column1: ARE YOU CRAZY?
column2: She didn't need our help getting anywhere... where did she get these convenient clothes? And don't tell me that flare is standard prison issue...

column1: Damned clever if you ask me...
column2: Killed trying to escape - it's a classic...

column1: ABSOLUTELY NOT!
column2: Come on...

column1: Time we got underway ourselves, gentlemen.  Once again, we've saved civilization as we know it.
column2: And the good news is they're not going to prosecute.

column1: Perhaps with a few small steps at a time. Like this one.
column2: And perhaps with a large step or two. Like a peace treaty.

column1: We're explorers not diplomats!
column2: Starfleet's killed an awful lot of natural phenomena in the name of "exploration"...

column1: Captain, when we get to Camp Khitomer, how will we defend ourselves? I mean, if this new Bird of Prey can fire while she is invisible...?
column2: Now there's a poser.

column1: This is fun...
column2: Captain, shall we attempt to return fire?

column1: Too bad we can't SMELL her.
column2: In space, no one can hear you sweat.

column1: They don't arrest people for having feelings.
column2: If they did we'd all have to turn ourselves in. How CAN we rely on them?

column1: Are you carrying a surgeon?
column2: We were until your torpedoes!

column1: Doctor McCoy, what is your current medical status?
column2: Aside from a touch of arthritis, I'd say pretty good.

column1: For 27 years I have been Ship's Surgeon and later Chief Medical Officer aboard the USS Enterprise. In three months I'm due to stand down.
column2: Stand...?

column1: Retire.
column2: Ah. I believe you also consumed Romulan ale at the officers' mess on the night of question, Doctor?

column1: Was Chancellor Gorkon alive when you first examined him?
column2: Barely.

column1: I didn't have the knowledge of Klingon anatomy I needed.
column2: You say you are due for retirement. May I ask: do your hands shake?

column1: I was nervous -
column2: You were incompetent! - whether deliberately or as a result of age combined with drink this court will determine.

column1: I tried to save him! I was desperate to save him! He was the last best hope in the universe for real peace.
column2: The Chancellor herself will testify that the defendant's hands shook.

column1: I don't believe we can get more out of the way than this.
column2: They'll make it look like an accident...

column1: What are you in for, if you don't mind me asking?
column2: I don't mind. Smuggling. Guilty. I come from Arc. Smuggling is an ancient and respected trade there.

column1: They'll respect him now...
column2: That's a comfort...

column1: It takes a lot of effort.
column2: I don't wonder. Stop me if I'm wrong but do we really have any way of knowing if this is the real you?

column1: I've always wanted to meet you, Captain.
column2: I'm not sure how to take that.

column1: Would you care to go topside?
column2: Very much.

column1: "To be or not to be, that is the question" which preoccupies our people, Captain Kirk. We need BREATHING room...
column2: I beg your pardon?

column1: My God, what happened here?
column2: You feign ignorance?

column1: WHAT HAPPENED?
column2: You crippled our gravitational field with a direst torpedo hit, and two Starfleet crewmen beamed aboard in magnetic boots and did this! WE HAVE WITNESSES!

column1: He's a DOCTOR!
column2: How can I trust --

column1: Under article 184 of Interstellar Law, I place you both under arrest. You are charged with assassinating the Chancellor of the High Council.
column2: He just tried to save him!

column1: What?
column2: Isn't it a fact that you served Romulan ale, a beverage illegal in the Federation because of its overwhelming potency?

column1: And you still maintain your ship did not fire on Kronos One? Would you have known if she had? Come now, Captain. The record clearly there were no other ships in the sector.
column2: There... were no other ships in the sector.

column1: Did you have occasion to refer to your ship's data banks during that night?
column2: I checked the data banks, yes.

column1: And what did they tell you?
column2: That we fired two photon torpedoes. But -

column1: And now we come to the architect of this tragic affair, Captain James Tiberius Kirk. I put it to you, Captain, that you were seeking revenge for the death of your son.
column2: That isn't true...!

column1: Are those your words?
column2: Yes.

column1: Spoken by you?
column2: Yes...

column1: Louder, please. We cannot hear you.
column2: Those words WERE spoken by me.

column1: You were demoted...
column2: Yes.

column1: For insubordination.
column2: I have on occasion disobeyed orders.

column1: You deny Enterprise fired on KRONOS One?
column2: Well, I -

column1: You deny that your men beamed aboard KRONOS One and shot the Chancellor?
column2: I cannot confirm or deny actions which I did not witness.

column1: Captain Kirk, are you aware that under Federation law, the Captain of a Starship is considered responsible for the actions of his men?
column2: I am.

column1: As Captain I am responsible for the conduct of the crew under my command.
column2: Your honors, the State rests.

column1: Where is Mr. Sulu?
column2: Captain Sulu... on assignment... anyone seen Spock?

column1: Captain, you're not going to show them the bridge??
column2: Full diplomatic courtesy, Mr. Chekov...

column1: Just the size of my head -
column2: I know what you mean...

column1: Torpedo room--?
column2: Uhura, monitor!

column1: Captain, if they fire at us with our shields down --
column2: Torpedo bay! DID we fire those torpedoes?

column1: Get close enough to a man and you can kill him on "Stun" without setting off the alarm - of course you can't get rid of the body...
column2: First rule of assassination: always kill the assassins.

column1: From Starfleet?
column2: Who else?

column1: Where IS the conference?
column2: She's only a cog in the wheel - no way she knows that.

column1: She's here - somewhere.
column2: But if she's cloaked...

column1: Shields. Battle stations.
column2: Shields up. Battle stations.

column1: Mr. Chekov, take us forward, thrusters only, one half impulse power...
column2: Aye, sir

column1: Mr. Chekov, slow down. Take us forward, thrusters only, one quarter impulse power.
column2: Aye, sir

column1: Course heading, Captain?
column2: Second star to the right - and straight on till morning...

column1: They're preparing to fire.
column2: Shields up, Captain --?

column1: You're forgetting something.  the data banks say WE fired. If we did, the killers are here
column2: What ARE we searching for, Mr. Spock?

column1: Klingon blood.
column2: They must have walked through it when it was floating and tracked it back here.

column1: This is the first evidence that corroborates our theory.
column2: Now we go to Starfleet?

column1: Now we expand our search to include uniforms.
column2: ALL uniforms?

column1: Mr. Spock, Rura Penthe's deep in Klingon territory. If we're discovered...
column2: Quite right, Mr. Chekov. What is now required is a feat of linguistic legerdemain - and a degree of intrepidity. Before the Captain and Doctor McCoy freeze to death.

column1: You must have cursed yourself, for having programmed our data banks, Lieutenant. Only they revealed something wrong aboard Enterprise.
column2: She programmed the torpedo hits?

column1: Aye, sir.
column2: Mr. Valtane, any more data?

column1: Captain, I'm getting a message from Klingon High Command.
column2: Onscreen.

column1: An INCIDENT?
column2: Do we report this, sir?

column1: Send to commander Enterprise: "We stand ready to assist you. Captain Sulu, USS Excelsior." Attach our co-ordinates.
column2: Is that wise, sir? I mean, given their situation -  Aye, sir.

column1: This is KRONOS One. I am Chancellor Gorkon.
column2: Chancellor. We've been ordered to escort you through Federation space to your meeting place on Earth.

column1: Thank you, Captain.
column2: Uh, would you and your party care to dine this evening aboard Enterprise with my officers as guests of the United Federation of Planets?

column1: We'd be delighted to accept your gracious invitation.
column2: We'll make arrangements to have you beamed aboard at 1930 hours.

column1: Chancellor, may I present Commander Spock, whom I believe you know, Dr. Leonard McCoy, chief medical officer, Montgomery Scott, chief engineer...
column2: Commander, face to face at last.. you have my thanks..

column1: Your research laboratory is most impressive...
column2: Starfleet's been charting and cataloging planetary atmospheres. All vessels are equipped with chemical analytic sensors...

column1: Thank you, Captain Kirk. The evening has been most... edifying.
column2: We must do this again soon.

column1: I've heard of chameloids - "Shapeshifters" - I thought you were mythical.
column2: Give a girl a chance, Captain.

column1: An accident wasn't good enough...
column2: Good enough for one - two would look suspicious... killed while attempting escape... now that's convincing for both.

column1: Your friends are late...
column2: They'll be here...

column1: Isn't it about time you became something else?
column2: I like it here...

column1: What took you so long?
column2: Kill him! He's the one!!

column1: He wants your obedience to the Brotherhood of Aliens.
column2: He's got it.

column1: And your coat.
column2: Fraid not. It wouldn't fit him, anyway.

column1: How did you know...?
column2: There's a reward for your death.

column1: We don't get many presidential assassins.
column2: We didn't kill Gorkon.

column1: How much time's left of your sentence?
column2: Don't you know? Everyone on Rura Penthe is here for life.

column1: That's not his knee.  Not everybody keeps their genitals in the same place, Captain.
column2: Anything else you want to tell me?

column1: When whoever it is makes their move, you won't be here to ask if he's the one.
column2: There's gotta be a way out of this place...

column1: Listen. No one has ever escaped from Rura Penthe.
column2: Except us.

column1: I know how to get outside the shield.
column2: Where do we come in?

column1: Getting outside the shield is easy. After that it's up to you to get us off the surface before we freeze. Can you?
column2: Possibly.

column1: I can't make it alone. You're the likeliest candidate to come to this god-forsaken place in months.
column2: Candidate for what?

column1: Maybe if their particles just got a wee bit mixed...
column2: Energize...

column1: Stand down your weapons.
column2: Captain, if --

column1: Stand DOWN, Mr. Scott. All stop. That's an order.
column2: Aye, sir.

column1: This is incredible -
column2: WHO ELSE...?

column1: As you were. Lieutenant...?
column2: Saavik, sir. We were told you'd need a helmsman -  ... so I volunteered.

column1: Aft thrusters -
column2: Thank you. Lieutenant, one quarter impulse power...

column1: Aye, sir.
column2: Plot a course for Kronos, Lieutenant.

column1: Kronos, sir?
column2: I'm still in the chair, Lieutenant.

column1: Sorry -
column2: Come on, Saavik, you COULD knock -

column1: We're almost at the rendezvous - I thought you'd want to know...
column2: Right -

column1: I gather you are not enthusiastic about the assignment... I don't think many on board are.
column2: You piloted well out of spacedock, Lieutenant -

column1: I always wanted to try that.
column2: Only don't try putting words in my mouth.

column1: Uhura, hailing frequencies. Right standard rudder, bring us alongside...
column2: Right standard rudder, Z plus five degrees...

column1: I hope you're happy.
column2: Captain.

column1: Saavik, you know anything about a neutron energy surge?
column2: Sir?

column1: Captain, our shields -- !
column2: Uhura, signal our surrender.

column1: Who is "US?"
column2: I won't allow Starfleet to be dismantled over some Klingon promises.

column1: Just the prototype.
column2: You hear that?

column1: This is Captain Sulu, USS Excelsior.
column2: Sulu!

column1: Standing by, Captain Kirk.
column2: You understand that by even talking to us, you're violating regulations, Captain.

column1: I'm sorry, Captain - your message is breaking up.
column2: Bless you, Sulu.  Where's the peace conference? They're going to attempt another assassination.

column1: The Conference is at Camp Khitomer, near the Romulan border. I'm sending the exact coordinates on a coded frequency.
column2: I'm afraid we may need more than that. There's a Bird of Prey on the lookout for us. And she can fire while she's cloaked.

column1: Surely not.
column2: I'm telling you. Hang on.  How many of those things are there? Come on, Lieutenant, you're charged with murder...

column1: I'm getting underway now. But you should know, I'm in alpha Quadrant. The chances of my reaching the conference in time are slim.
column2: When does this conference start?

column1: According to my information, today.
column2: Thank you, Captain Sulu.

column1: Me?
column2: We have volunteered to rendezvous with the Klingon ship that's bringing Chancellor Gorkon here, and escort him safely through Federation space.

column1: I have personally vouched for you in this matter, Captain.
column2: You have personally -

column1: WE volunteered?
column2: There's an old Vulcan proverb: only Nixon could go to China.

column1: How could you vouch for me? That's...  ... arrogant presumption -
column2: I was asked by my father to open neg-

column1: I know your father's the Vulcan Ambassador for heaven's sake, but you know how I feel about this: they're animals.
column2: Jim, there is an historic opportunity here -

column1: DON'T TRUST THEM. DON'T BELIEVE THEM -
column2: They're dying.

column1: Lieutenant, I am pleased to see you.  The Lieutenant is the first Vulcan to be graduated at the top of her class as the Academy.
column2: Congratulations, Lieutenant. That must make you very proud...

column1: Never been this close.
column2: The Chancellor is undoubtedly awaiting our signal.

column1: I believe the Captain feels that Starfleet's mission has always been one of peace -
column2: Far be it for me to dispute my first officer. Starfleet has always -

column1: I don't believe our own conduct will distinguish us in the annals of diplomacy...
column2: I'm going to sleep it off. Let me know if there's some other way we can screw up tonight.

column1: What is it?
column2: I am uncertain.

column1: Spock, I'm really tired...
column2: We are reading an enormous amount of neutron radiation.

column1: Where?
column2: Curiously it appears to emanate from us.

column1: What the -
column2: We've fired on the Chancellor's ship -

column1: We HAVEN'T fired -
column2: According to the data bank, we HAVE - twice...

column1: I am responsible for involving you in this. I will go.
column2: I'M going. You are going to be responsible for getting me out of this. Meantime we're not going to be the instigators of a full-scale war on the eve of universal peace.

column1: Captain...
column2: He was just about to explain the whole damn -

column1: The Klingons have a new weapon: a Bird of Prey that can fire while cloaked. She torpedoed Gorkon's ship.
column2: So, that's it..

column1: The peace conference.
column2: What peace conference?

column1: I've been dead before. Uhura, raise Excelsior. She ought to have the co-ordinates.
column2: Why would they give them to us?

column1: Are you dining on worms?
column2: You were right: it was arrogant presumption that got us into this situation. You might have died.

column1: I was blind. I couldn't see past the death of my son. I couldn't trust.
column2: I too was blind. I knew about HER - and I did nothing. I trusted too much.

column1: You couldn't have known she was listening the night I dictated that entry into my log. You were proud of her achievements as a Vulcan.
column2: I was PREJUDUCED by those achievements.

column1: Can we two have grown so old and inflexible that we have outlived our usefulness?  Would that constitute a joke?
column2: Someone said the difference between comic and cosmic is the letter "S." You haven't outlived your usefulness - to me. And you are not responsible just because she is also Vulcan -

column1: I SHOULD have been -
column2: Not for the actions of another. No one is responsible for any actions but his own. Human beings -

column1: But I am not human. I am only -
column2: Spock, you want to know something?

column1: Close enough to beam down?
column2: Not yet... Section 4236...

column1: Captain, perhaps we're going about this the wrong way
column2: Make ourselves a target?

column1: What's she waiting for?
column2: Probably trying to figure out why we're reversing, wondering if we detect her.

column1: But we haven't run out of history just yet.  Your father quoted Hamlet: he called the future - "the undiscovered country"...
column2: I always assumed Hamlet meant death.

column1: The only way to find out if a man's trustworthy...
column2: ... is to trust him.

column1: Control tower, reading, Sir.
column2: Control, this is Enterprise requesting permission to depart.

column1: Channel open, Captain.
column2: This is the Starship Enterprise, Captain James Kirk commanding.

column1: Captain --
column2: WE SURRENDER.

column1: It's pretty chaotic over there. There's been some weapons fire and a lot of shouting...
column2: I'm going aboard. Spock, you have the conn.

column1: Gorkon's own man??
column2: Who else?

column1: Uhura?
column2: Nothing, Captain. If they're here, they're rigger for silent running.

column1: Captain, we can't see her, but she gives off heat...
column2: Not from a distance. She won't show up on ANY type of scan.

column1: You have done well, Saavik. As your sponsor at the Academy I have followed your career with... satisfaction. And as a Vulcan.
column2: Sir, I speak to you as a kindred intellect. Do you not recognize that a turning point has been reached in the affairs of the Federation?

column1: You must have faith.
column2: Faith...?

column1: But we can't allow them to be taken back to Kronos as prisoners.
column2: What do you suggest, Lieutenant? Opening fire won't retrieve the Captain

column1: How did you - ?
column2: In the meantime we must endeavor to piece together what happened here tonight. According to our data banks, this ship fired those torpedoes.

column1: Her own father...?
column2: Such things have happened before, sir.

column1: Any reply from Starfleet to our dispatch, Lieutenant.
column2: Not as yet, sir.

column1: Curious. You haven't been assisting Commander Uhura with her radio transmissions, have you, Lt?
column2: Commander Uhura has been experiencing technical difficulties sir.

column1: Very well. For twenty-four hours we'll agree that this conversation did not take place.
column2: A lie?

column1: Any progress?
column2: We've got a crew of three hundred turning their own quarters inside out,  but the killers may be among them. Surely they've disposed of these boots by now. Wouldn't it have been logical to leave them on Gorkon's ship?

column1: Suppose when they returned they threw the boots into the garbage?
column2: I'm having the garbage searched. If my surmise is correct these boots will cling to the killers' necks like Tiberian bats. They couldn't make their escape without them

column1: A lie?
column2: An error.

column1: If you are logical.
column2: I don't want to.

column1: But it was when you tried to persuade me the Captain was guilty that I should have understood.
column2: You can't prove any of this...

column1: Perhaps neither of us was hearing very well that night, Lieutenant. There were things I tried to tell you too - about having faith.
column2: You've betrayed the Federation - all of you.

column1: Direct hit -
column2: Confirmed, Captain!

column1: Trouble?
column2: We've been ordered to -

column1: In nineteenth century France, workers who felt their livelihood threatened by machines, flung their wooden shoes - called SABOTS - into the gears to stop them. Hence the word SABOTAGE.
column2: We are experiencing a technical malfunction. All backup systems inoperative.

column1: We can send a message to Starfleet Command -
column2: I do not think so. Enterprise has disobeyed orders and harbors two escaped convicts. Admiral Donald will make certain all your ship-to- shore transmissions are jammed.

column1: Sorry to wake you, sir, but Starfleet urgently requests any data we may have on the whereabouts of Enterprise.
column2: What?

column1: Apparently they're refusing to acknowledge signal to return to spacedock, sir.
column2: Signal Starfleet that... we have no idea location of Enterprise.

column1: Sir?
column2: You having hearing problems, mister?

column1: According to this we've completed our exploration of the entire sector.
column2: Fifty-four planets - and their gaseous atmospheric anomalies. Our sensing and analytic equipment worked well.

column1: I have an energy wave from 240 degrees mark six port --
column2: Visual!

column1: Don't tell me that was any meteor shower.
column2: Negative. The subspace shockwave originated at bearing three-two- three, mark seven-five, the location is...  Praxis. A Klingon moon. Barren of indigenous life forms but -

column1: I have confirmed the location, sir, but...
column2: What is it?

column1: Praxis?
column2: What's left of it.

column1: At least we must keep track of where they are taken, sir. I -
column2: I've already addressed that question, Mr. Scott. We'll e able to follow the Captain's movements.

column1: NO WAY!
column2: Mr. Scott, you forget yourself. Please accompany me.

column1: It's as I said, Mr. Spock: Inventory still registers every torpedo.
column2: Yet the data banks insist we fired: twice. One computer is lying.

column1: A computer canna lie, sir.
column2: I think  not.

column1: You can check the torpedoes visually, if you like -
column2: We'll have to check every one of them, Mr. Scott.

column1: That could take hours!
column2: Nevertheless.

column1: And if they're still in place?
column2: Then someone forged a data bank entry.

column1: They don't place the same value on life that we do, Spock - you know that... take my word: she didn't shed one bloody tear...
column2: That's hardly conclusive, Mr. Scott, as Klingons have no tear ducts.

column1: Twenty-four hours from now we won't have a clue where the Captain is.
column2: I know precisely where he'll be.

column1: They dinna fire on themselves. And there were no other ships present.
column2: There was an enormous neutron energy surge.

column1: Too far off. Very near us. Perhaps... underneath us...
column2: If another ship had been beneath us the Klingons would've seen her!

column1: A Bird of Prey canna fire when she's cloaked!
column2: This one can.

column1: They you're talking about a dreadful new engine of destruction, Mr. Spock.
column2: I believe I am.

column1: - could take weeks, sir.
column2: Thank you, Mr. Scott. We were to return to spacedock, the killers would surely manage to dispose of their incriminating footwear.

column1: They're outside the beaming shield. Mr. Scott, start your engines.
column2: Aye, aye, sir.

column1: They're naturally wary, ma'am. We've been at war a long time.
column2: How do both sides overcome ingrained prejudice?

column1: I assume command of this ship as of  0130 hours. Uhura, send to Starfleet HQ. Explain precisely what has taken place, and request instructions.
column2: Yes, sir.

column1: Sulu's giving us his position and telling us he's standing by...
column2: He's placing himself in a most awkward position...

column1: An ancestor of mine maintained that if you eliminate the impossible whatever remains - however improbable - must be the truth.
column2: What exactly does that mean?

column1: And they'd be right. We have no evidence - just a theory that happens to fit the facts...
column2: Even assuming you're correct, Mr. Spock, why would they fire on their own President?

column1: I've pulled out my - uh wooden shoe and Starfleet is screaming for us to return to port.
column2: Mr. Scott, any progress on repairing our warp drive?

column1: You understand that we have lost all contact with Captain Kirk...?
column2: At present, he's surrounded by a magnetic shield. If my calculations are correct, he should be deep into his escape planning by this time.

column1: I don't think Starfleet could have envisioned our current predicament.
column2: Maybe we should write them a letter?

column1: Under impulse power she expends fuel like any other ship. We call it "Plasma" - I do not know the Klingon name for it, but by any name it is merely ionized gas.
column2: Well, what about all that atmospheric equipment we're carrying to catalogue gaseous anomalies?

column1: They might as well arrest me, too
column2: But you didn't join a conspiracy.

column1: Can you tell me how you came to be on the planet where we found you?
column2: I was taken from my homeworld by people called the "PakJeds." They are fat. They traded me to a ship belonging to the "Bolians." The "Bolians" are blue. They put me in a seat and asked me questions. Then they were attacked by another ship...

column1: Fuzzy face is gone.
column2: Yes, please continue.

column1: Do you know who I am?
column2: You are me.

column1: Do you know where you are?
column2: I am in a room with lights.

column1: Can you remember our father?
column2: No.

column1: Do you know the name of the Captain of this vessel?
column2: No.

column1: Brother. I cannot move.
column2: No, I have only activated your cognitive and communication subroutines.

column1: Why?
column2: Because you are dangerous.

column1: Why?
column2: You have been programmed to gather information that can be used against this ship.

column1: I do not understand.
column2: I know.

column1: Do you know anything about Shinzon's plans against the Federation?
column2: No.

column1: Do you have any knowledge of the tactical abi1ities of this ship?
column2: No. Can I move now?

column1: No. I must deactivate you.
column2: For how long?

column1: Indefinitely.
column2: How long is that?

column1: I notice Dr. Crusher laughing along with the rest of you. As most of you know, the doctor will also soon be leaving the Enterprise, to assume command of Starfleet Medical. Again, I'm forced to ask, Beverly, have you considered what you're doing to little ole me?! I'll probably get some old battle-axe of a doctor who'll tell me to eat my vegetables and put me on report if I dont show up for my physical on time!
