column2: It'll serve you right.

column1: Sort of like losing a son and gaining an empath, isn't it?
column2: Please, Beverly, this is hard enough.

column1: When was he... created?
column2: About twenty-five years ago. They probably used a hair follicle or skin cell.

column1: It has the ability to consume organic material at the subatomic level. I can't overestimate the danger of Thalaron radiation, Jean Luc. A microscopic amount could kill every living thing on this ship in a matter of seconds.
column2: Understood. Keep on it. I need to know what he has and how to neutralize any threat. Give me options.

column1: Beverly, come in.
column2: You're working late.

column1: Remember him?
column2: He was a bit proud as I recall.

column1: He was a damn fool. Selfish and ambitious. Very much in need of seasoning.
column2: He turned out all right.

column1: I so wanted to believe Shinzon. But the Thalaron radiation can't be explained away. Whatever he's after, it's not peace.
column2: Is he very much like you were?

column1: Jean Luc, Whatever you were... Right now you're the man you've made yourself. He's someone else.
column2: I wish I could believe that, Doctor.

column1: Aside from slightly elevated adrenalin and serotonin levels, you're completely normal.
column2: Can you describe it, Deanna?

column1: The more I studied his DNA the more confusing it got. Finally I could only come to one conclusion... Shinzon was created with temporal RNA sequencing. He was designed so that at a certain point his aging process could be accelerated to reach your age more quickly, so he could replace you.
column2: But the Romulans abandoned the plan.

column1: As a result the temporal sequencing was never activated. Remember, he was supposed to replace you at nearly your current age. He was engineered to skip thirty years of life. But since the RNA sequencing was never activated, his cellular structure has started to break down. He's dying.
column2: Dying?

column1: How long does he have?
column2: I can't be sure but the rate of decay seems to be accelerating.

column1: But we do have one advantage.  He needs your blood to live. He might come after you first.
column2: I'm counting on it... We've been ordered to head to sector 3274. Starfleet is diverting the fleet to meet us there.

column1: To seek out new life and new civilizations. Zephyr. Cochrans own words. When Charles Darwin set out on the H.M.S. Beagle, on his journey into the unknown... he sailed without a single musket.
column2: That was another time.

column1: You can' t imagine them, Jean Luc. They're kids! All with advance degrees in xenobiology and out to conquer every disease in the quadrant.
column2: Reminds me of a young doctor I used to know...

column1: They're running me ragged. Nothing but question day and night... I love it! Come to dinner and 1'1 tell you all about it. There's a Bajoran band at the officer's mess.
column2: Not tonight, I have work here.

column1: So... To happy endings.
column2: To happy endings.

column1: Sir.  I noticed an interesting confluence of emotion at the wedding. I am familiar with the human concept of tears through laughter and its inverse, laughter through tears, but I could not help wondering about the human capacity for expressing both pleasure and sadness simultaneously.
column2: I understand why it would seem confusing. Certain human rituals... like weddings, birthdays or funerals evoke strong and very complex emotions. These rites carry great weight with us because they denote the passage of time.

column1: And you were particularly aware of this feeling because Commander Riker will be leaving to assume command of the Titan?
column2: Will and Deanna joining the Titan. Dr. Crusher going to Starfleet Medical...

column1: And this makes you "sad"?
column2: Well. I suppose it does a bit. I'm very happy for them, of course, but I'm going to miss them. The ship will seem... incomplete without them.

column1: That is because you have a familiarity with them. You can predict specific reactions and behavior and are comfortable in that knowledge.
column2: Yes. And, frankly, I envy them as well. They've made important choices

column1: The choices I made have led me here as well. This is the only home I have ever known. I cannot foresee a reason for leaving.
column2: You never know what's over the horizon, Data. Before too long you'll be offered a command of your own.

column1: If I were... I believe my memory engrams would sense the absence of your specific reactions and behavior. I would "miss you."
column2: Now, you make a toast.

column1: To new worlds...
column2: New worlds. Yes Data, brave new worlds...

column1: The closest signature is two kilometers to the west... that direction, sir.
column2: Thank you, Data.  Let's see what she can do.

column1: The final signature is approx- imately 300 meters up that incline.
column2: Mister Worf, accompany Data please.

column1: He is very observant.
column2: I can see that.

column1: Data!
column2: Sorry, sir.

column1: Starfleet intelligence was only able to provide a partial account of his military record. We can infer he is relatively young and a capablecommander. He fought seventeen major engagements in the war. All successful. Beyond that, we know nothing.
column2: Well... it seems we're truly sailing into the unknown. Keep at it. Anything you can give me would be appreciated. Dismissed.

column1: Data to Captain Picard. Geordi and I have identified the source of the unauthorized computer access. And, I believe, we have also discovered an opportunity to gain a tactical advantage.
column2: On my way.

column1: My mission was a success, sir. I have discovered the source of the Thalaron radiation.
column2: Good work. The download?

column1: A bit less florid, Data.
column2: Aye, sir... This way.

column1: A weapon.
column2: It would appear so.

column1: Geordi equipped me with the prototype for the Emergency Transport Unit. I recommend you use it to return to the Enterprise.
column2: It'll only work for one of us.

column1: Yes, sir.
column2: We'll find a way off together. Recommendations?

column1: Alacrity would be appreciated, Commander.
column2: They are trying to override the access codes. Reman is really a most complex language with pictographs representing certain verb roots and...

column1: What do you imagine this is?
column2: Port thrusters, sir. Would you like me to drive?

column1: Can you open the shuttlebay doors?
column2: Affirmative, sir. Negative, sir. They have instigated security overrides and erected a force field around the external portals.

column1: Do you think this is a wise course of action?
column2: We're about to find out... Power up disruptors and fire on my mark.

column1: Ready, Captain.
column2: Fire!

column1: How long until we reach the fleet?
column2: At our current velocity we will arrive at sector 3274 in approximately 40 minutes.

column1: "For now we see but through a glass darkly..." He said he's a mirror.
column2: Of you?

column1: Yes.
column2: I do not agree. Although you share the same genetic structure, the events of your life have created unique individual.

column1: But so much is the same. On a biological level he is... and I will not accept the idea that there is nothing I can do. I have a responsibility to try to make a human connection with him.
column2: He would deny a "human" connection is possible. He considers himself entirely Reman.

column1: He may have already rejected my humanity, but you also have a twin
column2: No, sir, it is not possible. The B-9 is physically identical to me, although his neural pathways are not as advanced. But even if they were, he would not be me.

column1: How can you be sure?
column2: I aspire, sir. To be better than I am. The B-9 does not. Nor does Shinzon.

column1: We are passing through the Bassen Rift. The projections will return when we have cleared it.
column2: It's interfering with our uplink from Starfleet cartography?

column1: Yes, sir. The Rift effects all long-range communications.
column2: Commander Riker, evasive maneuvers!

column1: We are losing dorsal shields.
column2: Full axis rotation to port! Fire all ventral phasers!

column1: Captain, we have lost ventral shielding on deck twenty nine.
column2: Divert power and compensate.

column1: We are being hailed.
column2: Deanna, stand by.  Open a channel.

column1: Sir, allow me to go. You are needed here.
column2: Negative.

column1: Why am I looking at me?
column2: You are not looking at your- self. You are looking at me.

column1: You have a red shirt.
column2: This is not an appropriate time for a conversation.

column1: Why?
column2: Because the captain has to concentrate on piloting the vehicle.

column1: Since positronic signatures have only been known to emanate from androids such as myself, it is logical to theorize that there is an android such as myself on Kolarus III.
column2: How many of you did Dr. Soong make?

column1: Isolated pockets of humanoids. It appears to be a pre-warp civilization at an early stage of industrial development.
column2: Captain, I don't recommend transporting, that ion storm doesn't look very neighborly. -It could head this way with- out much warning .

column1: Well, he seems to have the same internal mechanics as Data but not as much positronic develop- ment.  The neural pathways aren't nearly as sophisticated. Id say he's a prototype. Something Dr. Soong created before Data .
column2: Do you have a name, sir?

column1: At present he serves no useful function. Dr. Soong created us to become active and useful members of society. I do not believe he would have wanted the B-9 to live out his life in his present state.
column2: I can't believe the Captain went along with a memory download.

column1: Captain Picard agrees that the B-9 was probably designed with the same self-actualization parameters as myself. If my memory engrams are successfully integrated into his positronic matrix, he should have all my abilities.
column2: He'd have all your memories too. You feel comfortable with that?

column1: I feel nothing, Geordi. It is my belief that with my memory engrams he will be able to function as a more complete individual.
column2: An individual more like you, you mean.

column1: Yes.
column2: Maybe he's not supposed to be like you. Maybe he's supposed to be just like he is.

column1: What purpose does this serve?
column2: It seems to be a redundant memory port.  Maybe it's for provisional memory storage in case his neural pathways overload?

column1: Dr. Soong must have found it unnecessary in later versions.
column2: It's possible the extra memory port is interfering with the engram processing. Mind if I keep him here and run some diagnostics?

column1: But I believe he will prove incapable of performing higher functions.
column2: Don't give up hope, Data. I know, I know, you're not capable of hope.

column1: We have lost structural integrity on decks twelve through seventeen, sections four through ten.
column2: Emergency force fields are holding.

column1: What is our approximate distance?
It appears to be...  ... an arm.
column2: Why is it moving?

column1: It's you.
column2: The resemblance is... striking.

column1: No.
column2: I would like to pick you up now. May I do that?

column1: If you wouldn't mind.
column2: Thank you.

column1: Really, Captain, it was a lovely toast.
column2: The least I could do for you, Deanna.  Besides, you know me... Im a talking head.

column1: And you needn't worry. I'll brief your new counselor on everything she needs to know.
column2: The hell you will. You know too much about me as it is ... Now you promised there are no speeches during the ceremony on Betazed.

column1: May I have this dance?
column2: With pleasure, Captain.

column1: Counselor.
column2: Do you have a moment, sir?

column1: It's about Data  I've watched him with the B-9 and I'm troubled. Data's desire for a "family" is very strong. I'm afraid he may be investing too much in the B-9.
column2: You're speaking of emotional investment?

column1: The B-9 is like a slow child, sir. And Data, in his own way, has assumed the position of a parent or guardian. I'm afraid he has expectations based on his own experiences. He'll be disappointed when the BI-9 cannot meet those expectations.
column2: As much as we care for him, Deanna... we have to remember that Data isn't capable of disappointment.

column1: I'm going to miss you.
column2: And I you.

column1: I would say he's been trained to resist telepathy. What I could sense of his emotions were erratic, very hard to follow.
column2: Is he sincere about wanting peace?

column1: Sir, the strongest sense I had was that he's more than urious about you. He very much wants to know you.  The same way you want to know him.
column2: How could I not?

column1: Captain, don't assume he's anything like you are. You should resist the urge to think you know him.
column2: I not only know him, Deanna, I am him.. and he is me!

column1: Shinzon's Viceroy seems to have the ability to reach into my thoughts. I've become a liability... I request to be relieved of my duties.
column2: Permission denied. If you can possibly endure any more of these assaults.  I need you at my side. Now more than ever I...

column1: How can you be certain?
column2: I know how he thinks.

column1: Captain -- I might have a way to find them.
column2: Counselor?

column1: The one thing he may have forgotten in the course of battle: me.
column2: Make it so.

column1: But how can he? He'll kill you.
column2: This isn't about me anymore.

column1: I'm only half human.
column2: Deanna Troi of Betazed. Empathic and telepathic abilities, ship's counselor. All of this I knew... But I didn't know you were so beautiful.

column1: Imzadi. This is so good.
column2: No!

column1: He can never know you as I know you... He can never touch you as I touch you.
column2: This isn't real.

column1: I'll always be with you now. Now and forever.
column2: You sick bastard!

column1: You're not here.
column2: Very logical, Deanna... But your heart doesn't constrain itself to mere logic.  To leave all of this behind and be with me.

column1: No.
column2: I can feel your desire, Deanna.

column1: Captain Picard, Commander Donatra of the Warbird Valdore. Might we be of assistance?
column2: Your timing is impeccable, Commander.

column1: The Empire considers this a matter of internal security. We regret you've become involved.
column2: When this is over, I owe you a drink.

column1: I'm afraid that drink will have to wait, Captain.
column2: Do you have life support?
Understood.

column1: Open a channel.
column2: This is Commander Donatra of the Valdore. We're dispatching shuttles with medical personnel and supplies.

column1: It's very faint but I've isolated it to the third planet in the Kolarin system.
column2: What do we know about the planet?

column1: Uncharted. We'll have to get closer for a more detailed scan.
column2: Theories?

column1: I read six distinct positronic signatures, spread out over a few kilometers on the surface.
column2: What do we know about the population?

column1: Cannon fodder.
column2: Then how did a Reman get to be Praetor? I don't get it.

column1: It's going to take some time to find out -- the data stream was rerouted through substations all over the ship.
column2: What programs were accessed?

column1: That's what I don't get -- it's mostly basic stellar cartography: star charts
column2: Set up a security program to detect any unusual data stream rerouting. If it happens again, we want to be ready.

column1: I thought Thalaron radiation was theoretical.
column2: Which is why our initial scans didn't pick it up. But he's got it, Captain.

column1: It's called a Cascading Bio- genic Pulse. The unique properties of Thalaron radiation allow the energy beam to expand almost without limits. Depending on the radiant intensity it could encompass a ship... or a planet.
column2: And that's exactly what he's going to do.

column1: He's getting his cloak back. We have exhausted our compliment of photon torpedoes. Phaser banks are down to four percent.
column2: What if we target all phasers in a concentrated attack?

column1: What's he doing?
column2: He wants to look me in the eye.

column1: He thinks he knows exactly what I'm going to do.
column2: Sir?

column1: Geordi, put 211 power to the engines.  Take it from life support if you have to -- everything you can give me.
column2: Aye, sir.

column1: Deanna, on my mark.
column2: Ready, sir!

column1: How long until he can fire?
column2: The targeting sequence should take about four minutes.

column1: Prepare for a site-to-site transport.
column2: Sir, we wont be able to bring you back. Its a one way trip. Captain, I don't know if the transporter...

column1: You have the bridge, Commander. Use all available power to move away from the Scimitar.  Now, Mister La Forge.
column2: Aye, sir.

column1: Sir, we're being hailed.
column2: On screen.

column1: Geordi... prepare the shuttle- bay for arrivals. They don't know our procedures so just... open the doors.
column2: I'll take care of it, sir.

column1: Admiral Janeway. Good to see you.
With or without the rest of the fleet?
column2: A diplomatic mission. We've been invited, believe it or not. Seems there's been some kind of internal political shakeup. The new Praetor, someone called Shinzon, has requested a Federation envoy.

column1: New Praetor?
column2: There's more... as always. He's Reman.

column1: Believe me, we don't under- stand it either. You're the closest ship so I want you to high tail it over there and hear what he has to say. Get the lay of the land, If the Empire becomes unstable, it could mean trouble for the entire quadrant.
column2: Understood.
Not with the Romulans.
Just lucky, Admiral.

column1: Enterprise. We are the Reman Warbird Scimitar.
column2: Praetor Shinzon, I'm pleased to...

column1: So, human... you've met your better self!
column2: What are you doing to Counsellor Troi?

column1: I'm preparing her for Shinzon. To sooth him as she soothes you. To stand at his side as she does at yours.
column2: That will never happen.

column1: It would take me but an instant to tear that valiant heart from your chest.
column2: There'll be another after me. And another after that. You'll find we're a resilient species.

column1: I won't do it.
column2: Wont do what, Mister Worf?

column1: Captain. I think it is inappropriate for a Starfleet officer to appear...  Naked.
column2: Come now, a big, strapping fellow like you? What are you afraid of?

column1: I'm picking up an unusual electromagnetic signature from the Kolarin system.
column2: What sort of signature?

column1: To find the head, sir?
column2: If you don't mind.

column1: Sir, I recommend we raise shields.
column2: Not yet, Mister Worf.

column1: No!
column2: Captain!

column1: Tactical analysis, Mister Worf.
column2: Fifty-two disruptor banks, twenty-seven photon torpedo bays, primary and secondary phased shields.

column1: We're being hailed.
column2: On screen.

column1: Sir, we've had an unauthorized access into the main computer.
column2: Who was it?

column1: Worf, prepare a full phaser spread, zero elevation. All banks on my mark. Scan for shield impacts and stand by photon torpedoes.
column2: Aye, sir

column1: Sir, we're being hailed.
column2: On screen.

column1: Coordinate our attack with the Valdore's tactical officer. Triangulate fire on any shield impacts.
column2: Aye, sir.

column1: Captain, the Hemingway has arrived to tow us to spacedock.
column2: On my way. Please notify Commander Riker.

column1: What's this?
column2: Your new chair, sir.

column1: Diverting to the Kolarin system takes us awfully close to the Romulan Neutral Zone.
column2: Still well on our side...

column1: I think it's worth a look. Don't worry, Number One, we'll get you to Betazed with time to spare.
column2: Thank you, sir...

column1: Captain, I hope I don't have to remind you --
column2: I appreciate your concern, Number One, but I've been itching to try out the Argo.

column1: Sir --
column2: Captain's prerogative, Will. There's no foreseeable danger... and your wife would never forgive me if anything happened to you.

column1: Captain, you have an Alpha Priority communication from Starfleet Command.
column2: Acknowledged ...  ...I'll talk to Data.

column1: We have to assume he had Romulan collaborators.
column2: A coup d'etat?

column1: Why don't they answer our hails?
column2: It's an old psychological strategy, Number One. To put him in a position of dominance and make us uneasy.

column1: It's working.
column2: Counselor?

column1: Captain, with all due respect to diplomatic protocols  -- the Federation Council's not sitting out here, we are.
column2: Patience. Diplomacy is a very exacting occupation. We can wait.

column1: She's not out for a pleasure cruise.
column2: She's a predator.

column1: Not very chatty.
column2: Away team. Transporter room four.

column1: He wasn't designed to live a complete, human life span.
column2: Can anything be done for him?

column1: Sir?
column2: His hatred of the Federation is apparent. He would have built a weapon of that scope for one reason. He is going after Earth.

column1: Oh boy. Destroy humanity and the Federation is crippled.
column2: And the Romulans invade.

column1: Strength in numbers?
column2: We can only hope so.

column1: Report.
column2: He's firing through his cloak. We can't get a lock.

column1: Counselor Troi, report to the bridge.
column2: Unless we can disable his cloak we're just going to be firing in the dark.

column1: The Titan's a fine ship, will. And she's getting a captain worthy of her.
column2: She's the most beautiful ship Ive ever seen.

column1: But she's not the Enterprise.
column2: I promise you in time, she'll become your home ...If I could offer you one piece of advice?

column1: Anything.
column2: When your first officer insists that you can't go on away missions... Ignore him.

column1: Serving with you has been an honor.
column2: The honor was mine. Captain Riker.

column1: I hope you'll forgive the darkness... we're not comfortable in the light.
column2: Praetor Shinzon?

column1: And you're not as we imagined you.
column2: No?

column1: Praetor?
column2: I've never met a human woman.

column1: I am, Commander Riker...  May I touch your hair?
column2: Praetor, we've come to Romulus on a matter we were -- assured was of great importance. If you have anything to say to us as representatives of the Federation, I suggest you do so now.

column1: On the world I come from there's no light. No sun. Beauty isn't important. I see now there's a world elsewhere.
column2: Praetor Shinzon. Were not here to discuss your lack of a social life.

column1: Yes, I'm sorry, Captain.  There's so much we have to talk about.
column2: I would be interested to know what we are talking about.

column1: I want to end the centuries of mistrust. I want to be your ally, not your enemy. As a first step I propose we eliminate the Neutral Zone and begin a free and open exchange of goods and ideas.
column2: And the Senate supports you?

column1: Right now, youre thinking this all sounds too good to be true?
column2: Yes.

column1: But you're also thinking the chance for peace is too promising to ignore. Above allyou're trying to decide if you can trust me.
column2: Yes.

column1: No one knew what to do. Finally I was taken to a doctor who had some experience with Terran illnesses and I was finally diagnosed with Shalaft's syndrome. Do you know of it, Captain?
column2: You know I do.

column1: We need to talk, just you and I.
column2: Come to dinner on Romulus tomorrow. Just the two of us. Or just the one of us.

column1: You know I need to verify this.
column2: I know.

column1: And when I was ready they were going to replace you with me, an exact biological duplicate. Put a Romulan agent at the heart of Starfleet to.influence your command structure. It was a bold plan.
column2: What happened?

column1: Romulan ale -- I'm surprised. I can't stand it.
column2: You'll acquire a taste for it.

column1: It's not quite the face you remember.
column2: Not quite. I envy the hair- line.

column1: A lifetime of violence will do that. My nose was broken four times. And my jaw... But so much is the same. The eyes, you recognize the eyes.
column2: Yes. The eyes have it.

column1: Our eyes reflect our lives, don't they? Yours are so confident.
column2: How did you end up on Remus?

column1: For thousands of years the Romulan Senate has met in this chamber and dictated the fate of its sister-planet... But the time has come for us to live as equals.
column2: You're doing this to liberate the Remans?

column1: You don't trust me.
column2: I have no reason to.

column1: Of course you do. If you had lived my life and experienced the suffering of my people... youd be sitting where I am now. At least I hope you would.
column2: And if you had lived my life you would understand that there is a great respons- ibility in representing the Federation. I can't let my personal feelings unduly influence my decisions.

column1: I want to know  where I come from. The Remans gave me a future. You can tell me about my past.
column2: There's so much, and so much of it is dull...

column1: Were we always explorers?
column2: No. I was the first Picard to leave Earth.  It caused quite a stir, In fact. But I had spent my whole life...

column1: Looking up at the stars.
column2: Yes.

column1: And you dreamed about what was up there. About...
column2: New worlds.

column1: After you, Praetor.
column2: Age before rank, Jean Luc.

column1: So I'm not as tall as you expected?
column2: I always hoped I would hit two meters.

column1: With a full head of hair.
column2: There is that.

column1: Shinzon... I'm trying to believe you.
column2: I know.

column1: If there's one ideal the Federation holds most dear it's that all men, all races, can be united. From the first time the Vulcans came to Earth we've sought a future of peace. Nothing would make me more proud than to take your hand in friend- ship. In time. When trust has been earned.
column2: I'm honored to think I might someday speak with such eloquence.

column1: In time, Jean Luc.
column2: In time.

column1: Hello, Jean Luc.
column2: Why am I here?

column1: What are you doing?
column2: I need a sample of your blood. What do your Borg friends say? Resistance is futile.

column1: All of this so you could capture me?
column2: Don't be so vain. After we found it, we made a few modifications. An extra memory port, a hidden transponder. Perhaps your eyes will be a bit less confident when you learn I've gained access to Starfleet's communications protocols. I now know the location of your entire fleet ...  You may go.

column1: Maybe I'll train it to do little tricks for me like your robot does.  Or maybe Ill snap its ugly head off.
column2: What's this all about?

column1: It's about destiny, Picard. About a Reman outcast who...
column2: You're not Reman.

column1: And I'm not quite human. So what am I? What do you see?  Do you see a life you might have led? Lost youth never to be recaptured?
column2: I see a young man trying desperately to deny who he is.

column1: I see an old man, set in his ways, afraid to live without a uniform to prop him up and a Starfleet regulation to tell him what to do. I see the man I will never be.
column2: I won't defend my life to you.

column1: My life is meaningless as long as you're alive. What am I while you exist? A shadow? An enigma?
column2: If your issues are with me... This has nothing to do with my ship and nothing to do with the Federation.

column1: Oh, but it does.  We will no longer bow like slaves before anyone. Not the Romulans and not your mighty Federation. We're a race bred for war. For conquest.
column2: Think about what you're doing, Shinzon. Are you ready to plunge the entire quadrant into war to satisfy your own personal demons?

column1: It amazes me how little you know yourself.
column2: I'm incapable of such an act, and so are you.

column1: You can't trace my holographic emitters, Captainn. So don't bother. And you can't contact Starfleet. We're quite alone.
column2: We are.

column1: It's just the two of us now, Jean Luc, as it should be... Your ship and mine... You and me.
column2: Why are you here?

column1: To accept your surrender. I can clearly destroy you at any time. Lower your shields and allow me to transport you to my ship.
column2: And what of the Enterprise?

column1: I have little interest in your quaint vessel, Captain. If the Enterprise will withdraw to a distance of one hundred light years, it will not be harmed.
column2: You know that's not possible.

column1: I know... you'll all gladly die to save your home world.
column2: Look at me, Shinzon! Do you feel the blood pumping inside you? Your hands, your eyes, your nature, are the same as mine. Buried deep inside you beneath the years of pain and anger is a capacity you've forgotten. It's the one way our mirror can reflect the two of us exactly because it's the very thing that truly defines us. To be human is to try to make yourself better than you are.

column1: I know you as well as I know myself, Shinzon. There was a time you looked at the stars and dreamed of what might be.
column2: Long ago.

column1: Not so long.
column2: Childish dreams, Captain. Lost in the dilithium mines of Remus. I'm what you see now.

column1: The man who is Jean Luc Picard and Shinzon of Remus won't exterminate the population of an entire planet! He is better than that!
column2: He is what his life has made him!

column1: Yes.
column2: So if I gave you my life, what would you do with it? Would you spend the years in a blaze of hatred as you are now? Or could you change? Could you try to remember a mother's touch you never felt? A father's words you never heard? Could you do that?

column1: I don't know.
column2: But you want to.

column1: That's your life... not mine.
column2: Please.

column1: Its too late.
column2: You can still make a choice! Make the right one now!

column1: I hope you're still alive, Jean Luc.
column2: I am.

column1: Praetor, we've received the transponder signal.
column2: On my way.

column1: Report!
column2: Two ships decloaking, sir! Romulan!

column1: Target disruptors. Destroy them.
column2: Disruptors are off-line, sir.

column1: Deploy the weapon. Kill everything on that ship. Then set a course for Earth.
column2: What about Picard?

column1: Our greater goal is more important, brother.
column2: But, Praetor, you won't survive without him...

column1: Well, that sounds relaxing too.
column2: It is... invigorating.

column1: So theyve got him up and running.
column2: He's a very unusual android.

column1: My God...
column2: Should I raise shields?

column1: Minimal damage to the Scimitar.
column2: Defensive pattern Kirk Epsilon. Geordi, get those shields online.

column1: Believe it or not, I think the cavalry has arrived.
column2: We're being hailed.

column1: Intruder alert!
column2: Let's go.

column1: Are we prepared?
column2: Yes, Praetor.

column1: This is a mistake.
column2: He's gentler than I thought. And he has a sense of humor.

column1: Don't forget our mission, Shinzon. We should act. Now. Time is running out.
column2: My time. I'll spend it how I choose.

column1: The bond is broken.
column2: Find her again.

column1: No -- this is wasting time.
column2: Do as I tell you!

column1: It's accelerating. You have no more time for games.
column2: Have the doctors prepare. I'll be on the bridge.'

column1: How long?
column2: A matter of hours now.

column1: How long until we reach the Rift?
column2: Seven minutes.

column1: Let her pursue -- drop cloak on the aft port quadrant and prepare for full emergency stop.
column2: What?!

column1: Praetor...
column2: FULL STOP AND FIRE !

column1: What is it?!! Focus on your job!!
column2: She is here.

column1: Join us, Commanders.  Now what's the disposition of the fleet?
column2: They're holding position.

column1: And?
column2: They will obey, Praetor.

column1: How many Warbirds will you need?
column2: None.

column1: Praetor. You have the whole fleet at your disposal. They supported the coup, they'll follow you.
column2: The Scimitar will serve my needs.

column1: But surely...
column2: I came this far alone ...

column1: Then I don't understand the reason for the delay!
column2: You don't have to understand.

column1: And bringing the Enterprise here?! What possible purpose could that serve?
column2: I have a purpose.

column1: Then perhaps you will enlight- en us?
column2: Silence, Romulan!

column1: You must learn patience, Commander. Do you know where I learned it? In the dilithium mines of Remus. Spend eighteen hours every day under the ash of a Romulan guards whip and you'll soon understand patience.
column2: Praetor.

column1: The Enterprise is immaterial! They won't make it back to Federation space.
I thought we discussed patience, Commander.
column2: And mine is wearing thin, young man! We supported you because you promised action. And yet you delay and you waste your time playing games with Picard while--

column1: Commander Suran, the games are over. In two days the Federation will be crippled beyond repair. Does that satisfy you?
column2: For the moment.

column1: Benny, God, take it easy...
column2: I don't want to scare them away.

column1: Right in line with that burning tree.
column2: I don't see anything.

column1: Benny, there's nothing there.
column2: There is. They came out of the belly of the ship and then went to the first terrace and flew down into the houses.

column1: What did I tell you?
column2: Probably kids.

column1: Don't you think you should call a backup?
column2: No, we can handle this.

column1: Mike, call for back-up.  Benny, you all right?
column2: I don't think so...

column1: Gate three. It's boarding now.
column2: Thank you.

column1: What can I do for you folks?
column2: How much are your rooms?

column1: You have one with two beds?
column2: Sure.

column1: I'll take that.
column2: Fill this out.  Will this be cash or credit card?

column1: Credit card.
column2: I'll have to run your card off now.

column1: We're only going to be here a few hours...
column2: It's still the full price.

column1: Do you have a good map of Death Valley?
column2: We should have. Let me see.

column1: Food. Eat. I prepare food. I work as a cook. That's how I make money.
column2: I understand.

column1: What do you do?
column2: I make maps.

column1: Hey, that sounds interesting. You like it?
column2: Eh... yes.

column1: Make any money?
column2: No.

column1: Do you have children?
column2: No.

column1: What do you think of America?
column2: It is beautiful.

column1: Well, here we are... You go down that ramp there, you're sure to get a ride.
column2: Thank you.

column1: No!!! No!!!
column2: He's got a gun!!

column1: Where did you stop last?
column2: What the hell do you think you're doing?

column1: Where did you stop last?
column2: Stay right there...

column1: What was your last stop?
column2: Elmo's...

column1: Where's that?
column2: About five miles back.

column1: We're going... Damn!  We'll tell the press that there was an accident. Chemical warfare spill. That cover cannot be violated in any way. Understand me, Shermin?
column2: Major Bell here, sir. We have to tell these people that we're friendly. That this whole thing was a mistake. Is anyone trying to contact the ship?

column1: Recognize this?
column2: It's a copy of the plaque NASA sent into space on the Pioneer probes.

column1: Houston found it in the extraterrestrial's suit.
column2: They must have picked it up in space.

column1: It's real, George.
column2: There's no mistake? You're absolutely sure?

column1: I saw it with my own eyes. We've killed an extraterrestrial and...
column2: Is there any possibility that it's a hoax? Could you be mistaken?

column1: None. And there's another one in the area that's alive. I don't know if it's the only one. I don't know if it was left here by accident or it's part of an inva...
column2: Get the body out of there. Load it on the Air Force chopper and get it to Wright Patterson. They'll take it from there... We didn't expect this, Shermin.

column1: We'll need a lot of help, George. You could hide an army up here.
column2: I'm going to the White House right now. I'll try and get you everything you need.

column1: Contain it and get back to me.
column2: What do you mean by 'contain?'

column1: Then it's not an accident that they found us.
column2: We don't think that's necessarily bad. At least it's a point of contact.

column1: Not necessarily bad! If they knew we were here why didn't they let us know they were coming?
column2: We'll get those answers when you find the one you're looking for.

column1: That's not going to happen, George, unless you get us the help you promised us.
column2: We've been back and forth on this all day and keeping in mind the panic that would occur if this got to the general public, it's been decided not to expand the search at this time.

column1: Don't let them do it this way, George. It's too important. We can't find this thing alone.
column2: You have to. We're trying to contact the ship. If we do, I'll let you know immediately. Good luck.

column1: George, we've just confirmed the existence of the live extraterrestrial.
column2: When can we expect containment?

column1: Well, we're in pursuit of a green Mustang...
column2: It's in a green Mustang?

column1: Why did you let it get into a populated area?
column2: It's taken on a disguise.

column1: Clarify that.
column2: It's made itself look like the woman's dead husband.

column1: The extraterrestrial now looks like this.
column2: Oh shit!!!

column1: You sure you want this, because... that's putting an awful lot of faith in people we have no control over...
column2: I'm afraid the situation demands that kind of risk.

column1: I don't like it, George...
column2: Dammit Shermin. Earlier you were asking for help. What's changed?

column1: It's messy... the thing's got a gun... We're just asking for somebody to get killed...
column2: We don't know what else to do. We need results.

column1: You'll get results one way or the other, that's for sure... Okay.
column2: I'm gonna be here if you need anything.

column1: We're growing very concerned back here. There's no use pretending otherwise. We're rapidly approaching a 'condition red.' People are beginning to ask difficult questions.
column2: I'll make this as simple as I can, George. They disappeared.

column1: I don't care where you're from you just can't disappear into thin air.
column2: George, listen to what you're saying. This thing's changed itself into a man. Disappearing may not be that big a deal.

column1: Maybe... look, this is just something to think about... from what I got at the shopping center, it was more scared than anything else... I don't feel it's as big a threat as you think it is...
column2: Is that what's affecting your performance?

column1: I'm not being unpatriotic, and I'm doing my damndest to catch them. Bell's up on 80 and I'm down here on 70 past Grand Junction. They're heading west. If they're not flying we have a damn good chance of getting them. All I'm asking is that you people think about it.
column2: You just do your job, Shermin. We'll make the policy.

column1: Hello George.
column2: Shermin...

column1: What's all this for?
column2: We have a new directive. I'm taking over.

column1: We don't have to do it that way. We can catch him this time.
column2: Washington thinks it's too late for that.

column1: I've never been taken off an assignment in my life. Give me twenty- four hours and I'll have him for you.
column2: You're not hearing me.

column1: You can change a directive, George. You've done it before. Listen to me. He's going somewhere in Death Valley. Lathrop Wells was never anything but a bus stop. East is the nuclear site. There are no roads in there. She was teaching him to hitchhike. I'm telling you. We block the four roads into Death Valley and we got him.
column2: We'll do that. But how are we going to hold him? He can change himself into a man. He can disappear.

column1: That's the chance we have to take.
column2: No, we don't.

column1: Then you're going to have to do it without me.
column2: You're a career intelligence officer, Shermin. You'll be in the air with us.

column1: No deal.
column2: I'm afraid we can't let you go.

column1: George... Do you hear me, George?
column2: What?

column1: I just retired.
column2: Shermin!! Shermin!!!

column1: Mrs. Haydn...
column2: This is George Fox...

column1: I want to speak to Marc Shermin.
column2: You can speak to me, Mrs. Haydn. I'm in charge of this operation now.

column1: If I don't speak to Mr. Shermin, I'm hanging up.
column2: Okay...

column1: I won't let anyone hurt you.
column2: Watch it. They're coming out.

column1: This is Marc Shermin. Where are you, Mrs. Haydn?
column2: I don't know. Someplace called Elmo's. Look, I just wanted to tell you that I'm all right and I'm on my way home.

column1: You've been through quite an ordeal, Mrs. Haydn. Why don't you stay where you are and let us pick you up? We'll fly you home.
column2: No. You'll want to ask a lot of questions I don't want to answer right now. I already have a ride.

column1: Is the man who kidnapped you there now?
column2: I told you. He let me go. I'm on my way home.

column1: Mr... I'm sorry, what was your name again?
column2: Marc Shermin.

column1: Mr. Shermin, I'm hanging up now. If you want to ask me any questions, call me at home in a couple of days. I'm in the book.
column2: Do you know what you were kidnapped by?

column1: Mrs. Haydn...
column2: He doesn't want to hurt anybody. Please leave him alone.

column1: Please...
column2: Don't... don't do this... please...

column1: Please.
column2: Why are you doing this to me? I'll give you whatever...

column1: Please...
column2: Which way do you want to go?

column1: What?
column2: What.

column1: Ah... no...
column2: Ah no.

column1: Steering wheel...
column2: What.

column1: Steering wheel.
column2: Steering wheel.

column1: Gear shift.
column2: Gear shift.

column1: Dashboard.
column2: Dashboard.

column1: What?!
column2: Eh... police.

column1: Steering wheel... gear shift... dashboard...
column2: Good.

column1: Which way?
column2: That way.

column1: What?
column2: Flashlight.

column1: What?
column2: Coupons.

column1: What?
column2: Pancakes.

column1: What?
Money.
column2: Money.

column1: Mi-chi-gan driver li-see-ens... Jennyhaydn... Money?
column2: We're going to have to stop for gas soon.

column1: What?
column2: Smile.

column1: Smile... good?
column2: Yes.

column1: What?!
column2: Minneapolis.

column1: Minneapolis... Minneapolis...
column2: What are you doing?

column1: Minneapolis... good.
column2: You're full of tricks, aren't you?

column1: No gas.
column2: No gas.

column1: No gas... car dead.  We need gas. I don't want to get shot for running out of gas.
column2: Gas good?

column1: Go.
column2: It's closed... closed. We need one that's open.

column1: Closed?
column2: You'll see.

column1: What?
column2: Not what. Who. What is for things.  What? What? What? What? For people you use who. Who is he?  Who is she?  Who are you?  Who am I?

column1: Who is he? Who is she? Who are you? Who am I?  Who are you?
column2: I am Jenny Haydn.

column1: Who are you?
column2: I am...

column1: That's a big help. Where are you from?
column2: From?

column1: Are you from up there? Space?
column2: Space?

column1: Gas.
column2: Closed.

column1: No gas.
column2: I know.

column1: Who?
column2: My... husband.

column1: I am husband?
column2: No. I don't know what you are, but you're not Scott.

column1: Shit.
column2: Shit?

column1: No, no... don't say that. Bad word.
column2: Shit... shit... what shit?

column1: Who?
column2: Attendant. He'll give us gas. Put the gun down. Under the seat. Under the seat...

column1: No.
column2: Oh God! You're going to get us both killed. Okay... in your pocket...

column1: In your pocket, please...
column2: You. Mouth closed.

column1: Satisfied? Now get out. Out.
column2: No.

column1: Money.
column2: Yes.

column1: What?
column2: Candy.

column1: What is...  ...Coke?
column2: A drink.
You want to try it?

column1: I want to try it.
column2: This stuff could kill...  Be my guest.

column1: What's the matter?
column2: Shit!

column1: Horses.
column2: Horses.

column1: What?
column2: Music.

column1: That was a red light!! I told you you have to stop at a red light!!
column2: It was yellow.

column1: I will see it next time.
column2: You better.

column1: Why are you going here? What is here?
column2: My...  ...car will take me...  ...up there... home.

column1: When do you have to be here?
column2: I do not understand.

column1: Sun...
column2: Yes.

column1: Sun... day. No sun... night. You understand?
column2: Yes. Day... night.

column1: How many days and nights do you have to go...  ...here?
column2: Three nights... two days.

column1: That's not much time. I'll just slow you down. I have to sleep. I'm very tired. And I have to wash and eat. You don't...
column2: I need you.

column1: I won't tell anybody if that's what you're worried about. I promise. You'll keep...
column2: No.

column1: You'll keep the car. I'll take a bus...  Am I going up there with you... in your ship... up there?
column2: No.

column1: Then let me go. You don't need me.
column2: No.

column1: Do you understand what I'm saying to you? You can keep the car.  That should be enough for gas from here to there. Please let me go.
column2: When we get here.

column1: The closest I was able to get you was Lathrop Wells...
column2: Is that a baby?

column1: Yes.
column2: A baby is a new person?

column1: Eh... yes...
column2: Do you have a baby?

column1: No... The closest...
column2: Why?

column1: I'd love to have a baby. But I can't...
column2: Why?

column1: But I must go here.
column2: I know that. But the buses don't go there.

column1: What is hitchhike?
column2: That's easy. I'll explain that in a minute. This is your ticket. When you get on the bus here, the driver will take this part. You will ride to Omaha. When you get to Omaha, ask the driver. 'Salt Lake City, please. I do not speak English.'

column1: Say it.
column2: 'Salt Lake City, please. I do not speak English.'

column1: The driver will...
column2: But I speak English.

column1: Will you please do it my way? You'll get into trouble if you don't. If anybody talks to you, tell them... I do not speak English.
column2: I do not speak English.

column1: Right. In Omaha the driver will put you on the bus for Salt Lake City and the new driver will take...  ...this part. When you get to Salt Lake City, ask the driver, 'Las Vegas, please'...
column2: 'Las Vegas, please. I do not speak English.' What is hitchhike?

column1: You want this ticket?
column2: Yes.

column1: 'Lathrop Wells, please. I do not speak English.'
column2: You keep this. Now this is hitch- hike...  You stand on the side of the road, the highway... you understand? And you face the cars going in the direction you want to go. When you see a car or a truck coming, you stick out your thumb like this...

column1: Your thumb tells the driver that you want a ride.
column2: The car will stop?

column1: When do I get to Lathrop Wells?
column2: Tomorrow morning. Start hitch-hiking right away and...

column1: Don't worry. They're not going to hurt you. Come on.  Only show this to the driver. Nobody else. And don't lose it.
column2: Can I have the gun?

column1: Don't be afraid. Do what I told you and you'll be okay.
column2: Yes.

column1: Well... I'm going to go now.
column2: Go?

column1: Yes. I have a long ride ahead of me...  Goodbye.
column2: Goodbye.

column1: Jennyhaydn.
column2: Yes?

column1: Goodbye.
column2: What?

column1: What happened?
column2: I was afraid.

column1: Why did your ship land on this planet... on Earth?
column2: It was a mistake.

column1: You thought we were a different planet?!
column2: No. My ship was doing a map of all the suns and...

column1: Stars... When a sun is far away, we call it a 'star.'
column2: We were doing a map of the stars and all the other things up there when we saw a small ship. My... eh... we kidnapped it. On it there was a map that said how to come to Earth. This was very important. Before then, we thought we were the only people in all the stars.

column1: You did? That's funny. So did we.
column2: Yes?

column1: Yes.
column2: We told our home, and the people who tell us what to do on my planet said to come and look but not to talk, not to land, not to shoot. Just to look from up there. We came and... the driver of my ship...

column1: The captain...
column2: The captain wanted to land to see close and to get some things from Earth to take home. The police came and shot at us. One of the people from my ship was killed.

column1: Oh, that's terrible. I'm sorry. Was he a good friend?
column2: I don't understand 'friend.'

column1: A friend is a person that is good to you... someone you like to be with... someone you like to laugh with...
column2: He was a good friend... The captain took the ship away fast and I was not in the ship.

column1: The police shouldn't have started shooting. But you can hardly blame them. You surprised them. They didn't know you were up there. When they saw you, they thought you were here to hurt us.
column2: I understand.

column1: Sounds like your captain's going to get hell when he gets back home.
column2: What is hell?

column1: It's bad.
column2: He will.

column1: What are you doing?
column2: Are you my friend?

column1: Yes.
column2: I am your friend.

column1: Nobody knows.
column2: Why?

column1: I like this music.
column2: I've noticed... Do you understand what they're saying?

column1: Do you have music up there?
column2: Yes.

column1: I'd like to hear it. Can you sing something?
column2: I do not want to.

column1: I am not a good singer.
column2: That was beautiful.

column1: You liked my singing?
column2: Yes. Sing some more.

column1: Put that back.
column2: But I have never seen this before. I am not complete.

column1: You shouldn't drink so much of that stuff. It's bad for you.
column2: On the radio they say it's good.

column1: The machine gave me two. Should I put one back?
column2: No. Get in.

column1: You can have one.
column2: I'm not sleepy anymore. Let's drive for a little while longer.

column1: Are you angry at me?
column2: No. I'm just not tired. Let's go.

column1: I told you goodbye. Why are you here?
column2: The police are waiting for you up ahead. There's a roadblock. You have to go back.

column1: This car will take me to Las Vegas. I cannot go back.
column2: The police know about Lathrop Wells. We have to go another way. Come on.

column1: If I don't meet the ship, my people will go home without me.
column2: Please understand. If you go this way, you'll never get to your ship. The police know about Lathrop Wells. We have to go another way. I'll get you to your ship. I promise.

column1: I will go. But not you.
column2: You shit! I'll decide if I go or not. Not you. I don't know what you do on your planet, but I didn't think that was very nice walking out on me like you did.

column1: I don't want you to be hurt.
column2: Come on.

column1: Where are you going?
column2: I must meet my ship.

column1: Why can't we wait here for a ride?
column2: I feel better if I move.

column1: Asshole!!
column2: Where did you learn that?

column1: We're not going to get a ride tonight.
column2: I can't stay on this planet.

column1: No one's traveling in this weather.
column2: You promised you would get me to my ship.

column1: I will. I will. We still have another day.
column2: You promised.

column1: What are you saying?
column2: You can stop. I will go on alone.

column1: Why don't you send one of your radio balloons and tell your captain that you might be late?
column2: I used the last one to jump off the cliff...

column1: Let's find a place out of the rain. I'm sure we'll get a ride in the morning.
column2: I can't be late. I don't know if the radio balloons work above your planet. I don't know if my words went to the ship. If I'm not there, the captain will think I'm dead and go.

column1: You are cold.
column2: You're damn right I am.

column1: What?
column2: Nothing.

column1: Good morning.
column2: Horses.

column1: You don't forget anything, do you?
column2: No.

column1: Hello... hello. How are you this morning?
column2: Do they talk?!

column1: No, they don't talk... We talk to them.
column2: I understand.

column1: Oh, you're pretty...
column2: I gave you a baby last night.

column1: They are beautiful.
column2: Yes, they are.

column1: You have been very good to me, Jennyhaydn.  You said you wanted a baby, so I gave you one.
column2: But...

column1: It will be human and it will look like this.  But when it comes it will know everything I know and everything you know. That is something from my planet that I want your baby to have.
column2: I told you it's impossible for me to have a baby.

column1: The cowboys were right. You can make money fast gambling.
column2: You don't make money gambling. You lose it.

column1: May I have twenty-five cents, please?
column2: What for?

column1: Here are two quarters. When you lose these, you're not going to get anymore.
column2: I understand.  Thank you.

column1: This is crazy. We don't have time for this.
column2: I know how to gamble now.

column1: You won ten dollars. Big deal. If we don't get a good ride before dark we could miss your ship.
column2: I want to get money for you and the baby.

column1: I don't need any money for the baby. I'll be fine.
column2: Inflation, tuition, college. Children are damned expensive. I know.

column1: The cook again?
column2: Yes.

column1: It'll tell you pretty much everything about us...
column2: This is very interesting. We are born knowing our history. We have other books. But not a book like this.

column1: Any words you don't know you can find in the dictionary.
column2: I understand.

column1: It'll give you the different countries, how they came to be, what they are now, how America came to be, the governments, the languages... everything.
column2: Many of my people will not believe those things are possible. On my planet there is only one government, one people, one language. I will be asked a lot of questions.

column1: What will you say about us?
column2: I will say that we can be friends.

column1: This is yours...
column2: If you want to keep it, you can.

column1: Would you put some of your singing in this for the baby?
column2: You want the baby to laugh at me.

column1: How long will it take you to get home?
column2: Many, many days and nights...

column1: I'm sure we could find a country and western station.
column2: No, thank you.

column1: There.
column2: Where?

column1: The yellow one.
column2: Oh, wow... I'll tell you what. When the baby is born, we'll go out in my back yard and wave to you.

column1: Where do you think you're going?
column2: Thank you, Jennyhaydn. You are good. I must go alone now.

column1: Well...
column2: I must go.

column1: What do I do now?
column2: You say you love me and kiss me 'goodbye.'

column1: I love you.
column2: I'm never going to see you again, am I?

column1: Tell the baby about me.
column2: I will.

column1: Help me!!
column2: You could have killed us both!!

column1: Jesus Christ!! You crazy people...
column2: Call the police!!

column1: Help me!!!
column2: Hey, she doesn't want to go with you. Come on.

column1: Oh God, man... don't shoot me... My mistake... I'm sorry...
column2: He doesn't understand... just walk away...

column1: You sure this is your car?
column2: My grandmother's rich.

column1: Slow down, slow down.
column2: Geez, Mrs. Haydn, we just got going.

column1: I told you I'm looking for someone.
column2: In the cars, too?!

column1: I don't know where he is.
column2: This is going to be a real drag. I thought you wanted to go fast.

column1: They after you?
column2: What? No, of course not.

column1: I'm telling you, you're going to find him at the roadblock, or right after, or not at all.
column2: If he didn't want to go through the roadblock, is there any other way to get to Vegas?

column1: The five-fifty. We already passed it. But it'll take him way out of his way.
column2: Pull over. I've got to get back there.

column1: Why wouldn't he want to go through the roadblock?... What did you guys do?... I won't tell anybody.
column2: It's easier not to tell if you don't know.

column1: Wait. Could I have your autograph?
column2: Sure.

column1: I have nothing to do. I'd like to help you.
column2: Don't worry. I'll be all right.

column1: Is it for real?
column2: Get Fox.

column1: Aghh... I'm supposed to umpire a little league game tomorrow.
column2: I wouldn't worry about it... There might not be any little league tomorrow.

column1: This is crazy. What were we going to do if that had been the ship? We have two thirty calibre machine guns, three M16's and some handguns.
column2: Give it a rest, Lyman.

column1: That's because the ones that were hurt, died. They couldn't talk to you.
column2: Any reports about monsters, people in Halloween masks, anything like that?

column1: Good... It looks like we might be the welcoming committee, so I think we should try and figure out what we're gonna do if we have to come face to face with this creature.
column2: Bell wants us to get down on our knees and bow.

column1: I know. She bought him a ticket for Lathrop Wells and put him on the bus. He didn't stay on though and they drove off together.
column2: Doesn't make sense.

column1: Tell him I'm not here.
column2: I did.

column1: You get that, Lyman?
column2: We're ready.

column1: I'm telling you they're probably friendly.
column2: Then why did they try and sneak in the back door? Tell me that. Why didn't they contact us first and say...

column1: They're gonna let some local cop blow him away.
column2: Save us all a lot of trouble.

column1: Jesus Lyman, you're an ignorant fool.
column2: Bullshit!

column1: You have no conception of this, do you?
column2: You jerk! You look at all the sweetness and light and goodness you think'll come out of this. You know what's gonna come out of this... The end of religion, the end of civilization, the end of the earth. We could become slaves, we could become a colony of these things. Don't you see that? Are you too stupid to see that?

column1: This has always been my favorite time of day.
column2: Very beautiful country up here...

column1: Any signs of biological contamination, excessive radiation, anything like that?
column2: Not on the landscape. We're trying to get a tube under the faceplate for a reading on possible deadly lifeforms but it's hard going.

column1: Can you see under the faceplate?
column2: No.

column1: There's a good chance you could be wrong about this thing then...
column2: Wait'll you see it.

column1: We had a flight of F16's play tag with the spaceship over Michigan for an hour. Then it shot straight up and disappeared.
column2: Was there visual contact?

column1: No, sir. Radar.
column2: It could have been anything.

column1: After I called in, I had a chance to sit down with the three locals. They swear there's another one that didn't make the ship... It might be alive.
column2: People have made mistakes in these situations before.

column1: Oh, Jesus.
column2: We better get it into the box. Come on...

column1: There's nothing... No reports of sightings or landings or anything... in the other parts of the country or overseas... Seems like a totally isolated incident.
column2: It was only an accident that we discovered them.

column1: You married, Major?
column2: Twenty-eight years.

column1: To the same woman?
column2: Yes.

column1: How would you describe the sounds we heard coming out of that thing's helmet?
column2: It was kind of like clicking, maybe a language wasn't it?

column1: Listen to this.  A woman was kidnapped in Eau Claire this morning. When a citizen went to her rescue the kidnapper threatened him with a gun and shouted at him in a strange 'clicking gibberish'...
column2: It was a man though... right?

column1: Nothing up there... The grass is matted down in a few places, but that could have been anything.
column2: It was the husband. The police finally got a hold of the witness at work and showed him a picture of the woman.

column1: Where are you going?
column2: Las Vegas, please. I do not speak English.

column1: I don't understand.
column2: Parlez vous Francais?... Habla Ingles?... Sprechen zie deutsch?

column1: Good job, neither do I. What do you do for a living?
column2: I don't understand.

column1: I'm a cook. Do you understand 'cook?'
column2: No.

column1: I told you...
column2: Judy, that's stupid.

column1: Well, maybe these men won't think so. We were asleep when a helicopter woke me up. It made me so nervous I went into the kitchen for something to eat. I happened to look out the window and there was Scott Haydn with this green thing draped over his arm pulling Jenny down the walk to the car.
column2: You know that's impossible!

column1: I know what I saw. I've seen him enough times.
column2: Scott Haydn is dead. He died about three months ago. We went to the funeral.

column1: Is there a reward in this?
column2: Huh?... Eh... no, there isn't

column1: Because I'm the one who called the police, you know.
column2: Yeah, thanks. We appreciate that.

column1: Hey, it's none of my business why you're chasing a retard... You want my opinion, it's the girl. She had to hold the guy's hand all the way to the car like he was a kid.
column2: You saw that?

column1: Eh... the store tells you to call when there's trouble, so they won't get sued... But that shouldn't matter if there's a reward, right?
column2: I wouldn't think so.

column1: That's what I thought. So remember it was me because sometimes rewards come late, you know.
column2: We will.  Something's wrong here. She's helping him now.

column1: Hello...
column2: I must get to my ship, Mr. Shermin.

column1: We can't let you do that.
column2: I don't want to hurt anybody. I just want to go home.

column1: All the roads into Death Valley are blocked. We'd like to talk to you.
column2: If I talk to you, I will miss my ship.

column1: Yeah, that's right.
column2: I saw you play, man.  You were good. Like a fucking freight train I remember saying.  So what happened, injuries or what?

column1: Bullshit politics.
column2: It's always politics.  Like this thing we're in here, he's paying you to tune me up, right?  But I could pay you more not to.  See what I mean?  I could write you a check right now--

column1: Come on, let's go, I got to get back.
column2: Okay cash!  Logical.  Here's everything I have on me, what do you say?  How about a Rolex?

column1: I already got a real one.  Come on, it won't be too bad.  It's not personal.
column2: Just not the eyes.

column1: Okay, let's get you wired up.  I hope this axle grease you got in your hair doesn't screw up the squid receptors.
column2: What's all this squid shit?

column1: Superconducting QUantum Interference Device.  SQUID.  Got it?  There's gonna be a test.
column2: Hey, fuck you, man.

column1: Easy, Eduardo, easy.  Preserve a sense of humor at all times.  Okay, the receptor rig... what I'm putting on your head... sends a signal to the recorder.  See we call it "being wired," but there's no wire.  You gotta keep the recorder close... five, six feet away max, like in your jacket pocket by the bed or wherever you're going to close escrow, know what I mean?
column2: Yeah, right.

column1: Some tips.  Don't dart your eyes around.  Don't look in the mirror or you'll ID yourself.  OK?  You got a half hour of tape, so give me some lead-in to the main event.  But don't wait too long, I don't want to be going out for popcorn.  And don't act natural.  Don't act at all. Just forget the thing is on.  Got it?
column2: No problem.

column1: We have nothing to talk about, Lenny.
column2: Joey, make sure Mr. Nero gets safely to his car.

column1: Lenny the loser.  Panhandler of stolen dreams.
column2: Leave him alone, Tran.

column1: He's no concern of mine, as long as you don't talk to him.  Don't talk to anybody.  You understand?  Not with everything that's going on right now.
column2: You're too goddamned paranoid.

column1: Look, Tran... Lenny just came by to give me some bad news.  An old friend of mine has been murdered. You remember Iris?
column2: A tragic story, no doubt.  How'd you get up here?

column1: I made my choice, Lenny.
column2: You're going down.

column1: You said you were going to get her out of this.
column2: Maybe now you appreciate the danger we're in.  It was touching the way you stood by me in there.  "Stand by your man". I was moved.  You were very good.  I don't think he even understands that you did it for him.

column1: He doesn't know what's going on. Leave him alone.
column2: I'd love to.  But he keeps showing up.  And you keep talking to him.  I can't have that--

column1: The only time a whore should open her mouth is when she's giving head.
column2: Fuck you.

column1: Well, I'm certainly in the mood for a party.
column2: Take her up to the suite.  Have a glass of champagne... or six... I'll be up in a while to help you ring in the New Year.

column1: This piece of puke hired me to kill you, baby.  Do you believe that? Isn't that right, Tran?  You pinhead.
column2: Oh my God.  I don't believe this is happening.

column1: Believe it.  Now bring me the trodes, baby.  Come on, quick.
column2: What're you going to do?

column1: You can't just... kill him.
column2: I'm not.  Just a little poach job.

column1: Jesus.
column2: Hey, he was going to kill you.  And this ratfuck paid to have Iris killed, to save his own sorry ass.

column1: Look, baby, it's now of never... the guy is a known input junkie, so a little OD won't surprise anybody. It's the only way we can be together.  You know it's true.
column2: My God.

column1: You were supposed to go downstairs, baby.
column2: I know.  I don't always do exactly what I'm told.  So I said, 'Do you enjoy watching me?'  And you said -- come on Max.

column1: I said, 'Yeah.  I'd even do it for free.'
column2: Uh huh.  And I said, 'That's good, because I like the feeling of someone watching me.  I acquired the taste from Lenny.'

column1: And then she said, 'Since we're going to be spending so much time together--'
column2: 'We might as well make the best of it.'

column1: Hey, you going to watch or you going to do?
column2: Watch and see.

column1: I feel like you're turning me into a VCR.
column2: I just want to see what we're like together through your eyes.

column1: I don't feel anything.  Is it on?
column2: Forget it's there.

column1: Cut it out, Tran.
column2: Too bad about your guy Jeriko. Tough break.

column1: I don't think that's a good idea, Lenny.
column2: I just got to talk to you for one second.

column1: Faith, call me, okay?
column2: No, Lenny.

column1: Hi, baby.  I've missed you.
column2: I know.  Lenny, if Tran finds you talking to me he'll hurt you.

column1: You have to go.  I mean it.
column2: Yeah, OK, whatever you say.  Just answer one question.  Is anything wrong?  Iris said you might be in trouble.

column1: You talked to Iris?  When?
column2: Tonight.

column1: Well I haven't seen her in months. Who knows what's going on in her head.  You're really running out of excuses to come around, aren't you?
column2: I know you Faith.  You're afraid of something.  What's going on?

column1: Let it alone, Lenny.  It'll take care of itself.
column2: It's Tran, isn't it?  This guy is poison, Faith.  Listen to me.  He's got you walled in on all sides.  And he uses the wire too much, he gets off on tape, not on you.

column1: That's a good one, coming from you.
column2: Why don't you just split?  You don't love him, anybody can see that.  And to him you're just some kinda possession, like a Ferrari, something to show the other guys.

column1: He has his uses too.
column2: What?  He gonna record you on his label?

column1: Maybe.
column2: Come on, Faith!  He's just toying with you.  And when he gets bored, you'll be yesterday's papers.

column1: Look, baby, I've watched you create yourself out of nothing.  You're like a goddamn cruise missile, targeted on making it.  And you will.
column2: Damn right.

column1: You have to get out of here.  If Tran catches you he'll... he's acting crazy.  He's doing way too much playback and he's getting completely paranoid.  He's such a control freak, he's even paying Max to follow me around.
column2: Max Pelcher?  You're kidding?

column1: Yeah, for about a month now.  Lenny, just stay away from Tran, okay?  And stay away from me.  Stop trying to rescue me.  Those days are over. I'm a big girl now.  Stop trying to save me, okay, because I don't need saving... Just... give up on me.
column2: Can't do it.

column1: You're crazier than I thought, Lenny.  Coming here... Tran's just in there.
column2: Iris is dead.  She was murdered.

column1: Who did it?
column2: Don't know.  But this guy's real damaged goods.  Iris knew someone was after her... and she said you were in danger too.  Now no more games, Faith.  Whatever you're hiding, whatever's going on, you have to get out of here now. Come with me right now.  Don't even think about it.

column1: Then what?  Then what, Lenny?!  You going to protect me?  Big tough guy. You're a talker, Lenny.  You don't even have a gun.
column2: I have a gun.  It's under my bed.

column1: You don't know what you're fucking with here.
column2: Tell me.

column1: What's going on?
column2: Faith, we know about Jeriko.  Iris made me a copy of the tape.

column1: How did it happen?  What was Iris doing riding around with Jeriko wearing a wire?
column2: We should talk alone.

column1: So finally he gives Iris some cash and tells her to check into the hotel under a wrong name till he figures out what to do.
column2: Yeah... he figured out what to do all right.

column1: You think Tran killed her?
column2: The killer knew right where she was. Because he put her there.

column1: I understand.  No, I'm not.
column2: You understand?  Attorney!  Right? Am I right?

column1: No.
column2: A virgin brain!  Well we're going to start you off right.  So what do you know about this?  Save us some time...

column1: Just what I've read.  That the technology was developed for the Feds, to replace the body wire.  And now it's gone black market.  So, uh, do I get the deck from you?
column2: I'll set you up, get you a deck at my cost... since my thing is the software.

column1: Clips.
column2: That's right.  Clips.  Look, I want you to know what we're talking about here.  This isn't like TV only better.  This is life.  It's a piece of somebody's life.  Pure and uncut, straight from the cerebral cortex.  You're there. You're doing it, seeing it, hearing it... feeling it.

column1: What kind of things exactly?
column2: Exactly anything.  Whatever you want.  Whoever you want to be.  Fabri, get us another round, would you.

column1: Sounds good.
column2: I can get you what you want.  You just have to talk to me.  I'm your priest, your shrink, your main connection to the switchboard of souls.  I'm the Magic Man, the Santa Claus of the Subconscious.  You say it, you even think it, you can have it.  You want a girl, you want two girls?  I don't know what your thing is or what you're curious about... you want a guy?  You want to be a girl... see what that feels like? You want a nun to tie you up?  It's all doable.

column1: Talk to me about costs, here.
column2: Listen, before we get into numbers, I want you to try a taste.  I got a deck with me.

column1: What?  Right Here?
column2: Step into my office.

column1: Yeah, I'm interested, but can we get someplace a little less public?
column2: You nervous?  Forget it.  The cops have more to worry about in this city than the squid-trade, believe me--

column1: You see the look on that preppy puke's face?  Fuckin' pissed in his Topsiders.
column2: Okay.  It was funny.  But it cost me money.

column1: Come on, amigo, the world's full of marks.  And nobody knows how to work 'em like you do, pal.  You could sell a goddamn rat's asshole for a wedding ring!  Let me buy you a drink.
column2: Least you can do.

column1: Bobbyyyy!  Tequila por favor! Double shots.  Make it Tres Generaciones, huh.  Nothin' but the best for my good friend Lenny, the finest cop that ever got thrown off the vice squad.  Hey, nice tie.
column2: Thanks, Max.

column1: D'you always have to dress like a fuckin' pimp?
column2: This tie cost more than your entire wardrobe.

column1: That's not sayin' much.
column2: It's the one thing that stands between me and the jungle.

column1: You were lucky, Max.
column2: Yup.  So darn lucky.  I wake up with a .22-short floating in my brainpan, and a cop pension I can't live off of.  Good thing I wasn't any luckier.  Bobby!  Another shooter right here!

column1: Naw.  She won't call me.
column2: Just as well, Lenny.  You gotta get past it.  I mean sure, Faith was by far the most outstanding woman a guy like you could ever hope to get, I mean it's completely and deeply humiliating that she's gone, but it's over, campadre.

column1: I just hate to see you pining away. It makes me want to vomit, frankly.  Broken hearts are for assholes.
column2: Hey, Iris, you okay?

column1: See, if you packed your piece you could've made the guy see sense.
column2: Uh unh, carrying a gun wrecks the line of a fine jacket.

column1: I'm telling ya, it's over.  We used it all up--
column2: Shutup a second!

column1: Shoulda told me about your new gig, buddy.
column2: I was gonna tell ya.  Hey, it's just a job.  I feel like shit about it.

column1: You should feel like shit.
column2: I figured, what the hell, I could take the prick's money and make sure Faith was OK at the same time.  Do us both good.  Right?

column1: Fairly twisted logic, Max, even for you.  Hey, at least you got a job!  Watch her for me.  Stay on her.
column2: I'm on her.

column1: You alright?  Y'okay?
column2: Yeah.  No, not really.

column1: Let's work it.
column2: Not now... I don't want to think about it--

column1: Come on, Lenny.  You used to be good at this stuff.  Play it down. What's the perp doing?
column2: He stalks her.  He rapes her.  Then he does her...

column1: And he records it.  Thrill kill. Wants to see it again.  And again.
column2: He records himself raping and killing her--

column1: But at the same time he's sending the signal to her--
column2: So she feels... what he feels... while he's in her.  The thrill while he's killing her... is sent to her, heightening her fear... which in turn heightens the turn on for him.  I've seen a lot, Max.

column1: So've I.  Too much.
column2: But this is a bad one.

column1: Top ten.
column2: He makes her see her own death, feeds off the reaction... killer and victim merging... orgasm and agony merging.  And he records it all.

column1: That's right.  He wants to share. Needs an audience.  This is one sick puppy.
column2: Why me?

column1: Hey, the last day of the world and you spend it in bed.
column2: W'sup, Max?

column1: Faith OK?
column2: Yeah.  She's leaving with Tran so I got to boogie.  Real quick... Iris checked into the Sheraton last night under a false name.  Paid cash.

column1: Looks like she was holding out.
column2: Yup.  Hey, so I heard you dropped in on Tran last night.  Another slick Lenny move.

column1: He's in this somehow... I don't know how.  Just stay close to Faith.
column2: I'm on her, amigo.  No worries. Gotta jam.

column1: Sounds like Tick's already celebrating.
column2: You may be a little overdressed for this party.  Yo, Tick!  It's Lenny.  Open up!

column1: He's been cooked-off
column2: Is he dead?

column1: Whattya mean?
column2: All I'm saying... you don't know how high up the food chain this thing goes.  I've heard stuff.

column1: What stuff?
column2: Smoke.  Rumors.  I've heard stuff about a death squad.  A group a guys loyal to the hardline school.  Guys that've had too many years of city hall and the review boards and the goddamn media pissing down their necks, suspending cops right and left, tying their hands... while outa the other side a their mouths these same people're squealing save us, save us, do something you fucking morons, crime is totally out of control.

column1: Jesus.
column2: Yeah.  So don't walk near me in public, alright.

column1: Mace... no disrespect... but you run this on the 11 o'clock news, by midnight you got the biggest riot in history.  They'll see the fucking smoke from Canada.
column2: Okay... what about Strickland?

column1: He's got her up in the room, under guard.  And he's still working the party... acting smooth like nothin's nothin'.  So buddy... I say we work a trade.
column2: What do you mean?

column1: Give him the tape.  See?  It's fucking brilliant!  The tape for Faith.  I know he'll go for it.  I can set it up.
column2: This is what we laughingly refer to as a plan, right?

column1: 2-2-0-3.  Got it.  Stay on her.
column2: I intend to.

column1: No.  I suppose not.  I didn't know you were colorblind, Max.
column2: Only way I could stand your ties.

column1: I'll have that.  Glock 22.  Nice.
column2: Where's Faith?

column1: I sent her to the party.  I figured I'd wait up here until you killed Tran.
column2: What makes you think I'm gonna kill Tran?

column1: You just did.
column2: Jesus!

column1: So... I killed Tran.  Then you ran in, being on his payroll, and shot me.
column2: That's pretty much the way it happened.

column1: Wait a minute.  Now I'm remembering. I killed Iris too, didn't I?
column2: That's right.  They'll find the original of her snuff clip in your apartment.  The one I left for you at the club was a copy.

column1: Was I a really busy guy?  Did I do Tick too?
column2: You bet.  Did you like it?

column1: Picture it... I feel like I gotta share this with somebody.  It's too perfect.
column2: I won't say anything.

column1: Only he doesn't know about me and Faith.  So I say to myself, if I turn the job down, he just gets somebody else.  And I lose Faith... to coin a phrase.  So to buy time, I do the skank.  I still gotta do something about Tran... I figure it's him or me... but I can't cap him without a chump to take the fall.  And who better than his girlfriend's loser ex-boyfriend... a known criminal... who has been seen hassling them in public numerous times.
column2: And who was, regrettably, also your best fucking friend.

column1: No plan is perfect, Lenny.  Hey, cheer up.  World's gonna end in ten minutes anyway.
column2: You must be so pleased, I followed your jellybean trail right here, like a good little chump.

column1: So there never was a death squad.
column2: Naawww.

column1: Just those two loose-cannon cops running around covering their butts.
column2: Yeah.  Pretty zany, huh?  All this shit caused by a random traffic stop.  Hey... nothing means nothing. You know that.  Look around... the whole planet's in total chaos.  You gotta take what you can, while you can.  Cause some shitbird can come up and put a fuckin' .22 in the back a your head any second.

column1: How did you hook up with Faith?
column2: This dink hires me a month ago to eyeball her, right?  But Faith knows me from you, right, so she comes up to me and says, 'Hey Max why you following me?' I say, 'I'll buy you a drink and explain.' And she says...

column1: Don't have a fucking coronary, Lenny.
