column2: Well you could've at least warned me.  You know I hate the zap... when they die.  It just brings down your whole day.  Jeez, Tick.

column1: How'd you get the tape?  Why didn't the cops put it in evidence?
column2: With all the blood I guess they didn't see the rig.  Guy had it under a wig.

column1: Yeah, but how'd it get to you?
column2: I got ways, Lenny, I got ways.  Okay, okay... I got a deal with some a the paramedics.  My guy pages me and I pick it up at the morgue.  So whaddya think?  This clip's gotta be worth at least a grand.  Right?

column1: Tick.  Not to dash your hopes, but I don't deal this kind of product, you know that.  I'll give you four for it, cause I've gotta cut off the last bit.  And my customers want uncut.
column2: Fuck that!  The last part's the best.  You dry-dive six stories and blammo!  Jack right into the Big Black.

column1: I don't deal black-jack clips!  It's policy.  I got ethics here.
column2: Yeah, when did that start?  Come on, man!  It's what people want to see, and you know it.

column1: So lay it off to somebody else.
column2: Come on, Lenny.  I got expenses.  I got to get this rig fixed.  Look at it...

column1: Give me six at least.  This's a good clip, here.  Gets you pumpin'.
column2: Yeah, well, the first part's okay. Better than the usual soaps you bring me.

column1: Sure, like this low-grade shit here, some girl in a fight with her boyfriend... it's a test-pattern. Nothing happens.  I'm snorin'.
column2: Hey, you're always saying, 'Bring me real life.  Bring me street life. And, like, one man's mundane and desperate existence is another man's Technicolor.'

column1: I said that?  Look, I'll take it for five, and you'll make out okay, because in this case it's pure cream, you don't have to cut anything back to the wearer.
column2: Ha!  That's for fucking sure.

column1: Whoa.  That is one unbelievable piece of eyefuck.
column2: Skip the art criticism, Tick, what can you tell me about the wearer.

column1: Lookit, you see the peak period ratios there?  Could be some kind of tumor or brain lesion or something. Some kind of trauma  This is not good.  I don't like this at all...
column2: What?

column1: Well, it's cutting awful close to me.  I mean she was just here.
column2: Who was just here?

column1: Iris, man.  Pay attention.
column2: Wait, wait... wait a minute.  Iris was here?!

column1: Yeah, she came by last night. Shaking like a junkie, wanting me to make a copy of some clip.
column2: What clip?  What was it?

column1: I don't know, man, she wouldn't let me see it.  Said I wouldn't want to see it.  She said she was going to give it to you to hold for her. Like insurance or somethin'
column2: She never gave me a tape.

column1: You come to peddle me some tapes, Lenny?  For old time's sake?  Make a couple bucks for the holidays?
column2: You're not a client anymore, Tran. I wouldn't sell you the sweat off a dead dog's balls.

column1: Show a little respect, Nero.  The man was an important artist.
column2: Yeah, important for your label. Which no doubt is why you're in mourning.  Don't worry, his records'll sell out now he's dead. You'll make out.

column1: I always do.
column2: Faith, can I talk to you a second?

column1: About what?
column2: That would be between me and Faith, wouldn't it?

column1: Charm.
column2: Uh huh.  Look, Nero.  I'll make you an offer.  Take her.  Right now.  If she wants to go, if she's unhappy here, she can go.  I'll let her choose.  Faith always knows what she wants.  Hands off.  See?

column1: It's alright.  He means it.
column2: I do mean it.  And I mean this... if Faith stays you go away and never come back. You scuttle back into your cockroach hole and never cross my vision again.  You understand?

column1: Nero.
column2: Strickland.

column1: Commissioner Strickland.
column2: Sure.  Whatever.  See, since you shitcanned my career, I don't even have to call you sir.  One of life's small pleasures.

column1: Aren't you peddling your wares a little far from your usual gutter?
column2: I was invited here by a close friend, Mr. Fumitsu, see he's right over there.

column1: I don't like disappointments, Nero. And do you know what disappoints me very much?
column2: Your sex life?

column1: Greetings, gents.  So let's hear this week's sad story.
column2: They jerked my wheels, d'you believe it?  I mean it's outrageous, the computer errors the banks are making lately.  Have you noticed?

column1: Thanks for giving me a ride.  I just have a few stops, mostly on the west side--
column2: Whoa, whoa, whoa.  I said I'd drop you home, but I'm not taking you on your sleazoid rounds.  I've already pulled twelve hours today.

column1: Come on, Mace.  This is gonna be a big night.  Can't you feel it?  The energy in the air?  There's money to be made, dreams to sell.
column2: Sleaze to peddle.

column1: Just a couple of hours.  It'll be fun--
column2: Excuse me.  What part of NO don't you understand?

column1: Mace, you're my friend.  I need you. Plus I'll give you 25% of what I make tonight.
column2: Lenny, this may be a hard concept for you, but friends don't have to pay their friends.

column1: Jeez, you're pathetic.  Okay, I got a pickup at the St. James.  I'll take you there, you can get a cab.
column2: Mace!  You're a life-saver.

column1: So, what's up with you?  Another busy night selling porno to wireheads?
column2: No, wrong... I sell experiences. Sex is only part of it.

column1: Buncha techno-perv jerkoffs.
column2: Way I look at it, I actually perform a humanitarian service.  I save lives.

column1: Uh huh, I wanna hear this part.
column2: Okay, take some executive... bored with his life, bored with his wife... he picks up a hooker or some girl at a bar.  Then he goes around for months, torn up worrying that he's got AIDS, that he'll infect his wife.  And maybe he really does catch something--

column1: Price he pays for being a scumsucking pig.
column2: Everybody needs to take a walk to the dark end of the street sometime, it's what we are.  But now the risks are outa line.  The streets are a war zone.  And sex can kill you.  So you slip on the trodes, you get what you need and it keeps you from jumping your tracks.

column1: Lenny, this shit's illegal.
column2: Define illegal.

column1: Me bailing your sorry pale ass out of jail twice in the last six months.
column2: Yeah, but that was for love.

column1: What's his name?
column2: Fumitsu.

column1: What the fuck are you doing?
column2: Coming with you.

column1: Are we having a bad night?
column2: Let's talk in the car.

column1: Hey, careful on the jacket.  This is Armani.  You angry?
column2: I've had enough of this shit.  You're on foot, Lenny.

column1: I need my case.  It's still in the back.
column2: Get it.

column1: That would be no.
column2: I've had it.  No more wirehead shit in my car.  You understand?  You want to poach your lobes, do it somewhere else.

column1: I thought we were friends.
column2: No, see a friend is more than one person constantly doing favors for another.  You just suck people along with your schemes and your scams and your slick act.  Well I'm out.  I got a kid, I got rent, I got an ex- husband someplace who doesn't send me a dime of support... I'm just trying to hold on here.

column1: So am I.  Just trying to get by.
column2: No, you're just trying to get off.

column1: Macey... I've never seen you like this.
column2: Lenny, you're turning into some kinda squid-head low-life.  You're always broke, you just go from one score to the next.  And you're getting strung out... you don't even see it.  Getting high on your own supply like some crack dealer.

column1: I know you wouldn't be saying all this if you didn't care about me. Thanks, Mace.  Really.
column2: Look, I gotta get some sleep.

column1: Yeah.  I don't see a way out of it.
column2: Macey, I know you're tired, but can you drop me at the Retinal Fetish? It's on your way.

column1: Jesus, Lenny.
column2: Begging?  Groveling?  Any pathetic behavior at all?  Will that help? Faith's there tonight, and I've got to talk to her.

column1: Who's the new side of beef in Tran's posse?
column2: Guy named Wade Beemer.  Used to be a running back for the Rams in '96 and '97.

column1: Forget her.
column2: She still loves me.

column1: She thinks you're a bucket of dog vomit.  Trust me on this.
column2: She's my destiny.

column1: Destiny?  You living in a perfume commercial?  She's a hard-climber that dropped you like a used tampon when she got a better ride.
column2: You'll see.

column1: You're some piece of work, you know that.  Just calmly backstroking around in the big toilet bowl, and somehow you never let it touch you. I mean, between Vice and this so- called occupation you're in now, you must've seen it all.
column2: I have crawled through the gutter... through every wrinkle in the human brain.

column1: What I'm saying.  But you still come out this goofball romantic.
column2: It is my sword and my shield, Macey.

column1: What's that?  Present from Faith?
column2: No idea.

column1: What is it?
column2: Go to the Sunset Sheraton.  RIGHT NOW!  Just go!  GO!

column1: My God, Lenny.  What is it?
column2: Black.  Jack.

column1: Blackjack?  I don't understand--
column2: Snuff clip.  It was Iris.  She said she needed my help and I... aw Jesus, Mace... the sick fucker killed her.

column1: And gives it to you.
column2: Wants to share.

column1: Cause you're the man, right?  The Magic Man.  If it's got something to do with the wire, sooner or later it washes up on your beach.
column2: I've never dealt in black-jacks. Never.  Everybody knows that.

column1: Jesus, Mace.  Back off.
column2: This guy is someone you know, one of your squid-head contacts.

column1: Uh unh.  No way!  They'd crucify me.
column2: So some psycho wire-freak gets to keep running around--

column1: Is this great fabric or what?
column2: You ever wonder why you get beat up a lot?

column1: He knows what he's doing.  He's worn before... a lot.
column2: So that gives you something.

column1: Don't crank the gain any more. You're gonna fry yourself.
column2: I need to see more... get more detail.  Something.  I feel his presence, so strong...

column1: No more, Lenny.
column2: Yeah.  I'm ghosting pretty bad.

column1: She came to me for help.  I should have read it better... I just figured, y'know... another strung- out hooker having a bad night.
column2: It's not your fault.

column1: See, it's all about what they see walking in.  A dead hooker, handcuffs, penetration... they'll see a trick gone wrong.  Random kill.  The kind you never solve.
column2: But that doesn't add, does it.

column1: No it doesn't.
column2: Because Iris knew somebody was after her.

column1: She said "If they get me".  They. Which means the whole sex-killer thing is a cover, which means somebody whacked her for a reason.
column2: So the guy's not a sicko.

column1: If he could do what's on that tape, he's a sicko.
column2: Okay, so he's a freak who thinks he's sane pretending to be a freak. The point is, he was a hitter. Somebody wanted to shut her up.  But why not just put a little lead in her ear?

column1: Because it had to look random.  Not connected to anything or anyone.  But then why give the rape to me?
column2: That's where it gets a little strange.

column1: And what about the guy that was following me?
column2: Now you're really getting paranoid.

column1: The question is not whether I am paranoid, but whether I am paranoid enough.  You want to rub my neck?
column2: Sure.

column1: How's Zander?
column2: OK.  He asks about you all the time. It's been weeks since you've seen him.

column1: I'm sorry about getting on your case earlier.  I just see you getting sucked in deeper and deeper, and I -- anyway.  I'm sorry.
column2: S'okay.  I know you still love me.

column1: Whatup Lenny?
column2: Jesus, Mace!

column1: Where we going?
column2: Anywhere.  We'll talk about it in the car.

column1: What is it?
column2: This tie doesn't go with blue!

column1: Will you relax.  There's nobody back there.
column2: Mace, the guy had a knife.  To my throat.  In my living room. Relaxing might be right out, okay?!

column1: You better keep a low profile for a while.
column2: No shit.  You got someplace in mind?

column1: Lenny, have you lost it completely?
column2: Easy, there, Mom.  Easy.  This is audio only.  John Coltrane.  "A Love Supreme." Give it a listen, let me know what you think, maybe you won't go for it now, but it'll get in your head and grow like a seed into something really beautiful.

column1: Think back about what she said. Exactly what she said.
column2: She wanted to go out to my car, something about my car...

column1: Lenny, give them the tape.
column2: It's in my case.  Okay?  I'm going to open my case...

column1: Shit!
column2: Take it easy.  The glass is bullet resistant.

column1: Bullet resistant?  Whatever happened to bullet proof?
column2: Lenny.  Calm down.  This is what I do.

column1: Goddamnit!!  911 is busy!
column2: It's okay, Lenny  They'd never get here in time anyway.

column1: This is bad.
column2: The gas tank's going to go any second!

column1: Are you out of your fucking mind?!
column2: Fire's out, isn't it?

column1: I can't believe we had to give them the damn tape.
column2: Yeah, me neither.  It was one of my favorites.  Me and Faith in a hot tub on my birthday.  I'm going to really miss it.

column1: Those two guys were cops.
column2: You sure?

column1: Tell me.
column2: I can't tell you.  You've got to see.

column1: Uh unh.  I won't do it.
column2: Mace.  I know what you think about the wire.  But I'm asking you to do this.  It's that important.

column1: Hang on.  Hang on, Max.  You see?
column2: I see.  I see the earth opening up and swallowing us all.

column1: We got to make another copy of this. Little life insurance.
column2: You know what this tape could do if it gets out.

column1: I've got a good idea, yeah.
column2: People finding out... seeing... that the LAPD just flat out executed Jeriko One.  Jesus.  Maybe they ought to see.

column1: So, let's see, I've got Tran's goons, some squidhead psycho and the LAPD all trying to kill me.  Happy new year, Lenny.
column2: Well, look at the plus side.

column1: There's a plus side?
column2: Yeah.  You gave up your hot tub tape to save me.  That's real progress for you.

column1: It was a tough call.
column2: I still can't square the psycho smarts of whoever did Iris with those two cops.

column1: I don't think those cops did Iris. I think whoever Iris was wearing for killed her.
column2: Why?

column1: He's totally cut off from the outer world.
column2: How long does it last?  Oh.

column1: The only card we have to play is the tape.  You know, we get it to the media somehow...
column2: Yeah, right, blow it open.

column1: Who's Strickland?
column2: Deputy Commissioner Palmer Strickland.  The sanctimonious prick who busted me out.  His ass is so tight when he farts only dogs can hear it.  I know this guy.  If there's one cop who's not dirty it's him.

column1: Kinda guy you can count on in a pinch.
column2: Why didn't he just go public with the tape?  Save himself that way.

column1: Okay, we gotta get over there.  Can you borrow a dress from Cecile or something--
column2: I'm not going.

column1: Whatya mean?  We're going!  Tran's gonna do her right there unless--
column2: Lenny... shutup.  Just park your mouth and listen.  It's a set-up. Think about it!  Why's he been sending you tapes?  To freak you, get you to rush in without thinking. Then they put one in you, put one in her, put the gun in your hand... crime of passion.  This guy's bent enough to think of that.

column1: Yeah.  Lenny.  I have.
column2: It didn't stop you from loving them. Right?  Or understanding them, or being able to forgive them...

column1: I guess.
column2: And it didn't stop you from wanting to protect them.  Did it?

column1: I worked Vice, Narcotics... Violent Crimes... and I saw every known depravity.  I was lost, Mace.  In outer darkness.  Then I busted this strung-out little teeny-hooker. When I met Faith she was just another runaway giving twenty dollar blowjobs to buy crank.  Another lost soul.
column2: You never told me.

column1: But she was different.  There was a light in her eyes... and she had this voice.  It was scary, all that pain coming out of that little body. Like she could take all the hurt and rage of the entire world and lift it up to heaven in one voice.  I helped her.  And I promised her that I'd always be there... to protect her.  See?  It's not about what's in her head.  It's what's in mine.  I can't let go of the promise.  It's... like... it's all I have left.
column2: No, it's not.

column1: Mace... you're a girl.

Fooled around with the letter "Z," turned it on it's side, got "N" -- there Ng, he's Vietnamese. The only thing that came to mind was zero, not Zorro. Remember Suspect Zero?

column1: No.
column2: Before your time. It was Richard Low's brainchild, or, lack-of-brain child. The Behavioral Sciences Unit at Quantico is essentially the product of three men: David Koessler, Dick Low and myself. Low was a field agent, Koessler administrative, I was teaching criminology. Low came up with the concept of a serial killer's signature. He invented profiling. Everything we know about profiling started with Richard Low...

column1: ...well, there was some friction: I wanted to write up my work, educate the public, but Koessler wouldn't allow it. Low felt Koessler was more interested in career advancement than catching killers. Koessler had Low reassigned to the Pacific Northwest, Seattle. You know when they say, stick it where the sun don't shine? That's where they stuck Dick Low.

column1: That gasbag. I can imagine what he said. I'm not ashamed to admit that most of what I know about criminal profiling started with Richard Low. I have also, over the years, I admit, taken credit for many of his accomplishments. He was the most brilliant law enforcement individual I ever met.

column1: We had every reason to believe he was on that plane. He was supposed to be on the plane. Everything was incinerated, it was two weeks before we reached the crash site. We, the Director and I, decided it was in everyone's best interest to declare Dick Low dead. That way he could exit a hero.

Put yourself in his mother's place, desperate, imagining the worst is happening as she pleads, back there at the rest stop, for someone, anyone, to listen to her. This is not hypothetical, this is real. It is happening now and you can do something about it.

column2: Setting up. Technically, anyone in a chat room can be traced back to a screen address. But, by using punters, a correspondent literally punts his address around the world, through computers in countries that have no communication treaties. The correspondent becomes "ghosted," invisible.

column1: What about the chat rooms themselves?
column2: That's the beauty of the system. This is a fugitive chat room. It moves from place to place, chat rooms that are normally empty at certain hours: a gardening website, Chaucer buffs, a dating service. A pre- arranged code shows up in one of fifty porn rooms -- that's where I stumbled across it -- notifying "friends" to meet at a certain time, usually midnight to three Eastern Standard, at a certain website -- a deserted chat room, say, "How to Plant Perennials." Come Tuesday, twelve a.m., bingo, these like-minded deviates log on and start yakking it up: explicit sex crime gossip, who did what to whom, who wants to do what, when, why and how.

column1: That's part of the reason I dropped by. I need to learn this stuff.

column1: Working the net isn't that different from ordinary undercover work. You go into the community, walk their walk, talk their talk, gain their confidence.

When I came across this fugitive chat room, listened in, I started to think some might actually be real, that they'd gone live. The challenge was to figure out which was which. Then I had my disagreement with Koessler.

column1: Every cop has a story and every story has a girl. The girl in my story was fifteen years-old. She wore a pink angora sweater -- I can still see it -- one day, she disappeared. I told the police she wouldn't run away, I told them who to look for, but I was just a kid. I sat in the police station crying and crying. My parents took me home. The girl was my cousin and the man who abducted her was a teacher I'd had. He kept her alive a week before he killed her. The police could have saved her. Every time I see a photo of a victim I see her. That's what I want to do. I want to save her.

column1: We got an UNSUB walking around with four feet?
column2: We did find these, however.

column1: Jesus.
column2: We're trying to match them with dump site bodies.  This we know is Carol Delview from Tampa, found her last Spring. This one --

column1: The tattoo?
column2: Sue Ann Hanson.

column1: You mean --
column2: You found the body. She was one of Harold Speck's victims. In El Paso.  They're not just talking to each other, Mack, they're trading souvenirs.

column1: Did they disconnect Testa's computer?
column2: Not yet. This time they're waiting for you.

column1: You should have seen the store manager at Parade of Shoes. She was inconsolable.
column2: Murman and Imelda had been slipping into a private chat room. Low had poor old Testa drooling on the keyboard. Abduction fantasies, voyeurism, mutilation, teasing him with fetish elements. He is very good. I think it's safe to say Richard Low is Murman.

column1: Mack, I'm sorry. I apologize. I should have called. I had no right to sneak in on you like that.
column2: No, Jaime, I apologize. I didn't... I had no right to speak to you like that.

column1: I came over because I couldn't sleep and was lonely. I wanted to see you. I thought I'd surprise you.
column2: You did.

column1: Maybe we should back off a bit.
column2: I can't. They trust me, they accept me. I've got their confidence.

column1: No, I mean maybe we should back off a bit, you and me.
column2: Oh.

column1: There's the Agency issue. I think Koessler may suspect something already. We're not on the best footing with him as it is.
column2: That's true.

column1: Then there's the other issue.
column2: What's that?

column1: You need time to think. About the case, about you and me.
column2: I found a peephole into Deviant World. I'm gonna reach in and yank some of those creeps out.

column1: And nobody else can do that?
column2: Not the way I can.

column1: That's my point. Remember, you're a cop pretending to be a deviant. It's not the other way around.
column2: Don't confuse what we do with who we are.

column1: Hello?
column2: Jaime? Where are you?

column1: Where are you? Everybody's looking for you.
column2: What's up?

column1: My watch. He toyed with me. He sent me to Chicago.
column2: You want to get him? Find something he wants. Get him to come to you.

column1: Start killing people for real?
column2: Suspect Zero.

column1: That's a crackpot theory. Everybody says so.
column2: But he believes in it. That's all that matters. He toyed with you, you toy with him. Convince him you've got a lead on Suspect Zero. Use Zero, you'll find Low.

column1: This feels like something out of a spy novel.
column2: I guess I'm a little paranoid.

column1: I met with Richard Low.  These are names of missing persons he has flagged. I'm double-checking every case, but I don't want to be too obvious about it. I marked the ones I'd like you to work on.
column2: Slow down a second, you met with Low --

column1: You were right. He found me.
column2: And you're working with him?

column1: I need something tangible. To hook him. I told him I'd found the confidential file on the Suspect Zero theory.
column2: Does one exist?

column1: Probably. I told him Koessler had ordered the report, kept it secret.
column2: Koessler doesn't know any of this?

column1: I'd be real careful if I were you.
column2: It's too late for that. I've gone ahead of the curve on this one. There's no turning back. When this is over, Koessler is going to be right or Low is going to be right or I'm going to be right, but not all of us.

column1: It's okay to be wrong, just don't be dead wrong.
column2: They say Richard Low is wrong, but because of him, women, innocent women, are alive who would be dead.

column1: You're putting me in a difficult position.
column2: I got an autopsy report from El Paso that doesn't seem right. A girl on Low's list. Karen Sumpter. We're getting a court order to exhume to body. I'd like you to come and look at it.  Don't worry, I've cleared it.

column1: Jaime, do you think, when this is all over, when we're in different divisions, you think maybe you and me, we could try again?
column2: Mack, I'm just trying to keep up with now.

column1: But why this pattern?
column2: Could be a lot of things. Depends on the freezer.  I'm sorry, Mack, but I don't think this is the answer.

column1: Tom, you okay?
column2: Hardly anyone calls me Tom. Everybody calls me Mack. I always liked that.

column1: You okay?
column2: Yeah, of course.

column1: It's quite advanced.
column2: Burn marks. The original M.E. listed it as "burn residue." Same place, the outer thigh, as Karen Sumpter. The UNSUB is able to abduct, kill, transport and bury without detection.

column1: All the same killer?
column2: Low calls him Suspect Zero.

column1: Suspect Zero is a crackpot theory. You said so.
column2: That's what Koessler wants us to believe. To discredit Low.

column1: You're assigned, we're assigned, to apprehend Richard Low, not Suspect Zero. I have to tell you, Mack, I'm not comfortable where you're going.
column2: But it was your idea: "use Zero," you said, use Zero to get Low.

column1: I haven't changed anything.  Damn.
Jaime --
column2: It's a truck. A refrigerated truck.

column1: Zero abducts victims all over the country, kills them, keeps them refrigerated for days, weeks, even months, then buries them hundreds, thousands of miles away. Karen Sumpter was buried, washed up in a flood. Evans was buried. When we get Zero, we'll find boneyards all across the country.
column2: How are we going to find him?

column1: What happened?
column2: I'm going to Amarillo.

column1: Agent...
column2: Kulok.

column1: Unlock these cuffs.
column2: Sit back.

column1: Mack must think Zero has a police band.
column2: Of course he does. Now get the key, get these things off me.  Unhook me.

column1: Uncuff me. What's wrong with you? Don't you want to save the boy?
column2: I want to protect the boy. I also want to protect Suspect Zero -- from you.

column1: Okay, I'll unhook you. No weapon.
column2: No weapon.

column1: Bitch! Cunt! Please, please, please don't do this, Agent Kulok. You need me.
column2: I'll be back.

column1: How did you know Speck was a killer?
column2: The little piggie speaks.

column1: Who are you?
column2: I'll give you a little hint. You're a smart guy, figure it out.

column1: Agent Mackelway?
column2: Yes.

column1: This is Richard Low. Stay on the phone. Do not disconnect. I'm watching you. I will instruct you where to drive.
column2: Yes, sir.

column1: Dave Koessler must have you jumping through hoops.
column2: I believe it is you, sir, who has us jumping through hoops.

column1: How's the arm?
column2: I've been reading, hearing about you. I spoke to Koessler, Professor Daitz.

column1: He couldn't break an egg with a hammer. He still writing those crime porn books?
column2: He's moved on to TV.

column1: What was your weakness, sir?
column2: I'm not sure, exactly. I had monsters on the brain. I wanted to get these guys, every one of them. I got obsessive.

column1: Suspect Zero?
column2: Deputy Director Koessler opposed the theory because it meant pressing the legal envelope, risking high-profile failure. Better to get rid of me. Then he could be Mr. Serial Killer, Mr. Authority on Deviant Behavior -- no embarrassing questions about the contribution of one Richard Low. Do you really think that plane crashed by accident? Do you really think I wasn't on it by accident? I've always had a good sense of intuition.

column1: So you went underground?
column2: Was I afraid of Dave Koessler? Not likely. I told you, I'd gotten a bit obsessive. It was an opportunity to back off, think things through.  Where's the file?

column1: I don't carry it with me.
column2: You're a smart guy. Tell me what it says.

column1: Hum a tune and I'll sing to it.
column2: The file, however, was kept open after your death. NPE disappearances, No Plausible Explanation, were sometimes filed there, deleted if the bodies were found.

column1: It's my master list of missing persons: men, boys, girls, children over the last ten years. Two hundred and eighty-five names. A pool of possible victims.
column2: Zero killed them all?

column1: Of course not. They're possibles. I've checked them against Bureau records, check them against your file. How did you get it?
column2: Daitz hinted it existed. It was a matter of forming the request in the proper terms.

column1: After my hiatus, after I got my priorities readjusted, I drifted online, started tracking porn chat rooms, looking for Zero. Got accepted, came across these boys swapping stories, pictures, downloads. Never found Zero, but I did come across some Class A scumbags.
column2: How do you know who's real and who's not?

column1: And who else did I find? Agent Thomas Mackelway, crackerjack FBI techie. I was greatly disappointed when you were re-assigned.
column2: You knew it was me all along?

column1: There's someone out there, Mack, I know, some man killing for the fun of it, sniffing human glue, without regard to age or sex, without predicable M.O. Someone who has a way to dispose of the bodies. You have access, you can call up local authorities, check morgues, conduct interviews. Be my man.
column2: I already have an employer.

column1: If you won't do it for me, do it for your cousin, Nadine, right? The girl in the pink sweater.
column2: Who told you about her?

column1: You did. You were with her when she disappeared, right? She took you to the mall or the movies, you turn around and she's gone.
column2: It was the mall.

column1: I know you, Lionheart. I watched your mind work, heard your dirty thoughts --
column2: Those were just fantasies.

column1: We're alike. We are hunters. We have the gift. It's ancient times all over again. We stand between order and chaos. I need help. I can't carry on alone.
column2: Maybe you should back off.

column1: This guy, Zero, he drifts around, that's how they all start, drifting around, their minds filling up with fantasies. He thinks he's real smart, laughs at us, laughs at his victims. But he has left a trail, and the trail is somewhere in those names. You know how to reach me.  Take my advice, when dealing with these FBI tight-asses, go by the book. That's what I did.
column2: You? You went by the book?

column1: Is he dead?
column2: Yeah.

column1: Was it Zero?
column2: Yeah.

column1: [Fantasy time, girls, give it up, give it up.]
column2: Lionheart here. I'm back. Sorry about the absence. I had to do some therapy at the crossbar hotel.

column1: [Reality very risky.]
column2: Whatever happened to MyDick?

column1: [Lionheart, what happened?]
column2: Something came up, Murman, my man.

column1: [You want to talk, Lionheart, or you want to take this a little more personal?]
column2: Lead the way, Murman.

column1: I've been to Chicago.
column2: [Not this way. Call it a little favor, call it a little thing I'm going to do for you. I'm going to make Chicago come alive for you. You'll owe me one.]

column1: If I owe, I will go.
column2: [The address is 147 South Rane. It's a lively address. You got a problem with dark meat?]

column1: Haven't had any, but I'm willing to try.
column2: [Ask for Leslie. Eight days from tonight, exactly one a.m. Be there if you dare. You cannot fool the Murman.]

column1: [If you wanted a good steak, you should have gone to Omaha.]
column2: Let's go someplace private, Murman, I have something for you.

column1: Let's talk about Zero.
column2: [Hello, Agent Mackelway. How's the watch? Maybe you can do one of those TV commercials, I found my watch under a serial killer's heart and it was still ticking.]

column1: I want to help you.
column2: [Not the heart, the watch.]

column1: I've located the Suspect Zero file. Did you know there was one? Koessler ordered it as part of your evaluation.
column2: [Don't jerk a jerk-off. There's nothing in the Bureau mainframe.]

column1: Not everything is imputed to memory. The most confidential stuff is kept top secret hard copy. Why would the Zero file be kept secret?
column2: [You tell me.]

column1: George Sheldon? The second serial killer killed in the manner of his killings. The crime scene profile was never entered into VICAP. At whose request? David Koessler.
column2: [What does the file say?]

column1: I want to go live with you.
column2: [And I want to go back to Needlepoint.]

column1: Leave this room, I'll go back with you, blow your cover.
column2: [I don't think so. We want the same thing. See ya.]

column1: Good morning, sir. Agent Salinas, sir.
column2: So you're the new meat?

column1: Yes, sir.
column2: What did you do to end up here?

column1: I believe it's in my file, sir.
column2: Johnny, get this man's file. Mackelway, right?

column1: Thomas Mackelway.
column2: Hot enough for you, Agent Mackelway? Hell's doorknob. What they got you doing?

column1: Updating the condition of all Bureau- owned vehicles in the southwest sector, sir.
column2: Sounds like fun.

column1: "Computer Investigation and Infrastructure Assessment Center." Quantico out of MIT -- you're a techie?  Okay, you screwed up once. So did half the guys here. That's why they're here.
column2: I screwed up twice, sir.

column1: I see that. Washington to Philadelphia to here. Philly's a nice station. How many agents?
column2: Four hundred and sixty, sir.

column1: "Attitude Adjustment Issues" -- what the fuck is that supposed to mean?
column2: I wished to be reinstated at Computer Crimes. I was undiplomatic in my request.

column1: This is a first. You criticized the Deputy Director to his face and you still have a badge? You must have some one-of-a-kind skills.  Why don't you just quit? I mean, you're not going to get promoted, not wearing this jacket.
column2: I like working for the Bureau, sir. I like catching bad guys. It's all I care about.

column1: Agent Mackelway, you want to get off your ass and do something for a change?
column2: Yes, sir.

column1: Headed there now. The same shift will be on at noon.
column2: This case has sent bells and alarms ringing all the way to Washington. Your old boss is coming out.

column1: Koessler?
column2: The same.

column1: No.
column2: Hope you never do. At first it feels like a sauna, by the time you hit victim four it's a fucking burning shirt factory.

column1: "MyDick?"
column2: MyDick. As in my dick. That was his screen name.

column1: I don't...
column2: Eight, nine months ago. When I was at Computer Crime. I got into a chat room with someone named MyDick. I'd talked to him before. Everything I saw yesterday, everything in the autopsies, it's identical. The forensics are dead on. MyDick's fantasies involved a hog-tie rig, nylon cord, torture with pliers, rip the nipples -- when the "item" screams, she chokes. He had a thing about eyes, always the eyes -- stab their eyes. It's the same guy. Speck was MyDick.

column1: Speck is dead.
column2: I talked to him.

column1: But why attack an Agent?
column2: He wants us to know he's out there, what he's doing. It's not enough just to kill somebody like Speck, he wants us to know he did it.

column1: How far is Amarillo?
column2: 350 miles.

column1: Locate a jet, we're going to Amarillo.
column2: Excuse me, Agent Mackelway?

column1: I don't think you understand.
column2: What is it exactly I don't understand, Agent Mackelway?

column1: Deputy Director Koessler doesn't want Zero. All he cares about is Low.
column2: Perhaps you can explain it to him.  It's Agent Mackelway.

column1: I'm Agent Thomas Mackelway, FBI. There is no way you will escape. Assistant Deputy Director Richard Low is en route with another Agent.  You may know Low by another name. You may know him by the name Murman. I am Lionheart.
column2: Murman!

column1: He's a brilliant man. Brilliant enough to catch you.
column2: Brilliant? You think he caught any of them because he was brilliant? Hardboy? MyDick? Imelda? Ripper? Think about it, how did he locate them?  He found them as Murman. And how did Murder Man find them? With sweet talk and brains? No. He did it with souvenirs. He took them into private rooms, swapped goodies: pictures, panties, jewelry, body parts. Snuff downloads. As bait. That's why I never exchanged with him. He killed girls, oh yeah, harvested them. He had the best stuff. Richard Low is Murman and Murman is one of us.

column1: You want to "profile" me? Find out what makes me "tick"? Write about me, go on a talk show, give me a nickname?
column2: It's over for you.

column1: You should see it, Professor Barnhardt! You should go out and see it for yourself!
column2: Thanks -- I'm enjoying it right here.

column1: The whole city has stopped. People are running around like ants!
column2: What a brilliant idea. I never would have thought of it.

column1: What about the people who are coming to the meeting tonight? Have they all arrived?
column2: I talked to most of them this morning... They were all very curious about the meeting.

column1: Good. Did you speak to our friend Mr. Carpenter?
column2: He'll be there at 8:30.

column1: Tell me, Hilda -- does all this frighten you -- does it make you feel insecure?
column2: Yes, sir -- it certainly does!

column1: You wrote this?
column2: It was a clumsy way to introduce myself -- but I understand you're a difficult man to see.  I thought you'd have the solution by this time.

column1: Yes -- that will reproduce the first- order terms. But what about the effect of the other terms?
column2: Almost negligible... With variation of parameters, this is the answer.

column1: How can you be so sure? Have you tested this theory?
column2: I find it works well enough to get me from one planet to another.  I understand you've called a meeting to study our space ship.

column1: As though unsure of what he's heard) Yes -- yes, I have.
column2: My name is Klaatu.  I spent two days at your Walter Reed Hospital. Room 309. My doctor's name was Major White -- and I had a very attractive nurse called Ruth, who's getting married next Wednesday.  If you are not interested -- or if you intend to turn me over to your Army -- we needn't waste any more time.

column1: You have faith, Professor Barnhardt
column2: It isn't faith that makes good science, Mr. Klaatu. Its curiosity.  Sit down, please. I have several thousand questions to ask you.

column1: I would like to explain something of my mission here.
column2: That was my first question.

column1: It was my intention to discuss this officially -- with all the nations of the Earth -- but I was not allowed the Opportunity. I have come to realize since that your mutual fears and suspicions are merely the normal reactions of a primitive society.  We know from scientific observation that you have discovered a rudimentary kind of atomic energy. We also know that you are experimenting with rockets.
column2: Yes -- that is true.

column1: In the hands of a mature civilization, these would not be considered weapons of aggression. But in the hands of your people--  We've observed your aggressive tendencies, and we don't trust you with such power.
column2: If you mean that you are afraid of us--

column1: We want to be sure you don't make -- let us say -- an unfortunate mistake. We know the potentiality of these developments and we are disturbed to find them in the hands of children... You see, we've had atomic energy for five thousand of your years.  We discarded instruments like this many centuries ago.  So long as you were limited to fighting among yourselves -- with your primitive tanks and planes -- we were unconcerned. But soon you will apply atomic energy to space ships -- and then you become a threat to the peace and security of other planets. That, of course, we cannot tolerate.
column2: These other planets -- do they have peace and security?

column1: We had our atomic wars -- thousands of years ago.  After that we fought with bows and arrows. Then, slowly, we learned that fighting is no solution -- that aggression leads to chaos.
column2: We scientists understand this. Even we primitive scientists.  What exactly is the nature of your mission, Mr. Klaatu?

column1: I came here to warn you that, by threatening danger, your planet faces danger -- very grave danger. I am prepared, however, to offer a solution.
column2: Would you care to be more specific?

column1: I gather that your efforts on the official level were not entirely successful.
column2: I come to you as a last resort -- and I confess that my patience is wearing thin.  Must I take drastic action in order to get a hearing?

column1: What -- what sort of action do you mean?
column2: Violent action -- since that seems to be the only thing you people understand.  Leveling the island of Manhattan, perhaps -- or dropping the Rock of Gibraltar into the sea.

column1: Would you be willing to meet with the group of scientists I am calling together?. Perhaps you could explain your mission to them, and they in turn could present it to their various peoples.
column2: That's what I came to see you about.

column1: It is not enough to have men of science. We scientists are too easily ignored -- or misunderstood. We must get important men from every field. Educators -- philosophers -- church leaders -- men of vision and imagination -- the finest minds in the world.
column2: I leave that in your hands.

column1: You'd have no objection to revealing yourself at this meeting?
column2: No -- not at all.

column1: What about your personal safety in the meantime? What about the Army -- and the police?
column2: My name is Carpenter and I'm a very earthy character living in a respectable boarding house.

column1: I'm afraid I can't offer you any real protection. I have no influence in cases of inter-planetary conspiracy.
column2: I'm sure I'll be quite safe until the meeting.

column1: One thing, Mr. Klaatu. Suppose this group should reject your proposals. What is the alternative?
column2: I'm afraid you have no alternative. In such, a case the planet Earth would have to be--  --eliminated.

column1: Such power exists?
column2: I assure you such power exists.

column1: The people who came to the meeting must be made to realize this. They must understand what is at stake.  You mentioned a demonstration of force--
column2: Yes.

column1: Would such, a demonstration be possible before the meeting?
column2: Yes -- of course.

column1: Something that would dramatize for them and for their people the seriousness of the situation. Something that would affect the entire planet.
column2: That can easily be arranged.

column1: I wouldn't want you to harm anybody -- or destroy anything.
column2: Why don't you leave it to me? I'll think of something.

column1: Maybe a little demonstration.
column2: Something dramatic -- but not destructive.  It's quite an interesting problem.  Would day after tomorrow be all right? Say about noon?

column1: Bet he is, Mom. Bet he's out looking for that space man.
column2: I think we've all been hearing too much about "space men."

column1: Can I help you look for the space man? Can I?  I know what he looks like! He's got a square head -- and, three great big eyes!
column2: That's enough, Bobby. I think it's time you went to bed.

column1: Hi Mom!
column2: Hello, darling.  Good evening, Mr. Carpenter.

column1: Did you have a nice day, dear?
column2: Boy, we had a swell time. Didn't we, Mr. Carpenter?

column1: Come on, Bobby. Time to go to bed.
column2: Mom -- why does Mr. Carpenter have to go down to the police station?

column1: We sure had fun today. We saw the space ship and we went to see Professor Barnhardt -- and--
column2: Professor Barnhardt.

column1: Yeah, sure. Mom, do I have to go to school tomorrow?
column2: Of course, dear.

column1: Go to bed, darling. You can finish that in the morning.
column2: Okay.

column1: Bobby -- I think it would be better if we didn't see quite so much of Mr. Carpenter
column2: Gee, why, Mom? He's my best friend... And he's awful good in arithmetic. He even helps Professor Barnhardt.

column1: Did you and Mr. Carpenter really go to see Professor Barnhardt?
column2: Sure we did! He wasn't there but we went to see him. And Mr. Carpenter showed him how to do his arithmetic.

column1: Mom -- is there something wrong with Mr. Carpenter?
column2: What do you mean, dear?

column1: I mean -- on account of that policeman last night.  You think he's a bank robber, maybe? Or a gangster?
column2: No, dear, of course not. He's a very nice man. I Just think he might prefer to be left alone. Now you get to bed and forget about it.  'Night, darling.

column1: Bobby--! What are you doing up at this hour?
column2: I couldn't go to sleep, Mom. I had to tell you!

column1: Tell me what?
column2: I followed Mr. Carpenter -- right after you left -- and, gee, Mom, where do you think he went? Right into the space ship!

column1: Now, Bobby, just a minute--
column2: Honest, Mom, I saw him. It just opened up and he walked right in. And that great big iron man was moving around!

column1: Bobby, you've been dreaming again.
column2: No, I haven't, Mom. I promise you... I saw it!

column1: Now think back hard. You didn't follow Mr. Carpenter at all, did you? You haven't even been out of the house.
column2: Yes, I have!

column1: He gave these to you?
column2: Well, not exactly. I gave him two dollars.

column1: Gee, Mom, do you think maybe he's a diamond smuggler?
column2: Come on, darling -- we're going up to bed.

column1: Oh, boy -- can I, Mom?
column2: Yes, dear. Come on now.  Bobby, your shoes are soaking!

column1: Are you an FBI man?
column2: No -- I'm afraid not.

column1: Bobby -- who's the greatest man in America today?
column2: Gee -- I don't know... The space man, I guess.

column1: Well -- Professor Barnhardt, I guess. He's the greatest scientist in the world.
column2: He lives here in Washington, doesn't he?

column1: Sure. Right near where my mother works.
column2: Where is that?

column1: Boy, I'll bet he's strong. I bet he could knock down a whole building.
column2: I shouldn't be at all surprised.

column1: Gee, I'd like to get inside and see how it works. What do you think makes it go?
column2: Well -- atomic power, I would imagine.

column1: I thought that was only for bombs.
column2: No. It's for a lot of other things, too.

column1: You think it can go faster than an F- 36?
column2: Yes -- I think so.

column1: Maybe four thousand miles an hour. And outside the Earth's atmosphere a good deal faster.
column2: Gee! How could they make a landing?

column1: You think they'll ever find him?
column2: I don't know, Bobby. I'm inclined to doubt it.

column1: Mr. Carpenter -- what does velocity mean?
column2: Velocity is the time rate of change of position.

column1: Bobby -- I have an idea. Let's go see Professor Barnhardt and find out how he talks.
column2: You're just kidding, aren't you?

column1: Wouldn't you like to meet him?
column2: Well, sure I would, but --  Aw, I'll bet you'd be scared.

column1: What does that mean?
column2: It's a problem in celestial mechanics.

column1: Bet he's the only one in the world knows the answer.
column2: He doesn't know the answer. And he'll never get it that way.

column1: Did all these people die in wars?
column2: Sure. Didn't you ever hear of Arlington Cemetery?

column1: No -- I'm afraid not.
column2: Mr. Carpenter" -- you don't seem to know about anything.

column1: I'll tell you, Bobby -- I've been away for a long time. Very far away.
column2: Is it different where you've been?  Don't they have places like this?

column1: Go to the movies.
column2: All right.

column1: No foolin'? Will you?
column2: Certainly.  Tell me, Bobby -- do you have to have money to go there?

column1: I've got some money. My mother gave me two dollars.
column2: No -- I want to take you to the movies.  Do you think they'd accept these?

column1: Gee -- those look like diamonds!
column2: Some places that's what people use for money. They're easy to carry -- and they don't wear out.

column1: Bet they're worth about a million dollars.
column2: Would you give me your two dollars for a couple of them?

column1: Let's not say anything to my mother about this, Mr. Carpenter.
column2: Why not, Bobby?

column1: Mrs. Benson -- this is Mr. Brady.
column2: Mr. Brady's a cop.

column1: We certainly did.
column2: We went to the movies -- and we had ice cream cones -- and we went to see Daddy--

column1: Aw, gee -- we didn't finish our story.
column2: We'll finish it tomorrow... Goodnight, Bobby.

column1: All you have to remember is, first find the common denominator -- then subtract.
column2: Thanks, Mr. Carpenter.

column1: Bobby -- have you a flashlight?
column2: Yeah -- sure.  It's a real Boy Scout flashlight.

column1: What do you want it for, Mr. Carpenter?
column2: Why -- the light in my room went out.  Thank you, Bobby. Goodnight.

column1: The skeletal structure is completely normal.  Same for the major organs - heart, liver, spleen, kidneys.
column2: And the lungs are the same as ours. Must mean a similar atmosphere -- similar pressure.  How old do you think he is?

column1: Oh, I'd say forty-five.
column2: He told me this morning when I examined him. He's seventy-eight.

column1: I don't believe it.
column2: Their life expectancy is a hundred and thirty.

column1: How does he explain that?
column2: He says their medicine is that much more advanced.  He was very nice about it. But he made me feel like a third-class witch doctor.

column1: My name is Harley -- Secretary to the President  I've been told that you speak our language -- that your name is Mr. Klaatu.
column2: Just Klaatu.

column1: The President asked me to convey his deepest apologies for what has happened. We all feel--
column2: Sit down, Mr. Harley.

column1: I'm sure I don't have to point out that your arrival was something of a surprise.  Had you been traveling long?
column2: About five months -- your months.

column1: You must have come a long way.
column2: About 250 million of your miles.

column1: Naturally we're very curious to know where it is you come from.
column2: From another planet. Let's just say that we're neighbors.

column1: It's rather difficult for us to think of another planet as a neighbor.
column2: I'm afraid, in the present situation you'll have to learn to think that way.

column1: The present situation?
column2: I mean the reasons for my coming here.

column1: We're very curious about that, too. Would you care to talk about it?
column2: I'd be glad to.  Not now, of course -- with you alone.

column1: Perhaps you'd rather discuss it personally with the President--
column2: This is not a personal matter, Mr. Harley. It concerns all the people on your planet.

column1: I -- I'm not sure I understand--
column2: I want to meet with representatives from all the nations of the Earth.

column1: I'm afraid that would be a little awkward. It's -- it's completely without precedent. And there are practical considerations -- the time involved -- the enormous distances.
column2: I traveled 250 million miles. What about your United Nations?

column1: You know about the United Nations?
column2: We've been monitoring your radio broadcasts for a good many years. That's how we learned your languages. Lately, we've been getting your television also.

column1: You must have a rather strange impression of us.
column2: The first two years of television we were convinced that all you did was wrestle.

column1: I'm sure you recognize from our broad- casts the evil forces that have produced the tension in our world. Surely you would agree--
column2: I am not concerned, Mr. Harley, with the internal affairs of your planet. I consider that to be your business -- not mine.

column1: I was only hoping to make you understand.
column2: My mission here is not to solve your petty squabbles. It concerns the existence of every last creature who lives on Earth.

column1: Perhaps if you could explain a little--
column2: I intend to explain. To all the nations -- simultaneously.  How do we proceed, Mr. Harley?

column1: We could call a special meeting of the General Assembly... But of course the UN doesn't represent all of the nations.
column2: Then why not a meeting of all the Chiefs of State?

column1: I will make that recommendation to the President.  I must tell you in all honesty that I'm extremely dubious about the results.
column2: Apparently I'm not as cynical about Earth's people as you are.

column1: Good afternoon.  I'm glad to see you up and around.
column2: Thank you... Have you any news?

column1: I tried to make you understand. The suspicions -- the jealousies -- the mistrust--  Surely you realize that my government has done everything in its power--
column2: It's not your government I'm thinking about. It's your world.

column1: Now that you understand the situation more clearly, perhaps you'd like to discuss the matter with the President
column2: I will not speak to any one nation or group of nations.  I don't intend to add my contribution to your childish jealousies and suspicions.

column1: Our problems are very complex, Mr. Klaatu. You mustn't judge us too harshly.
column2: I can judge only by what I see.

column1: Your impatience is quite understandable.
column2: I am impatient with stupidity. My people have learned to live without it.

column1: Before making any decisions, I think I should get out among your people -- become familiar with the basis for these strange, unreasoning attitudes.
column2: Under the circumstances I'm afraid that will be impossible.

column1: We're all set. I picked up some sandwiches and put gas in the car. And the radio's still busted, so me can forget about the space man for today.
column2: There's only one thing -- I haven't been able to arrange for anyone to stay with Bobby.  I don't suppose we could take him with us?

column1: Well, we could--
column2: There's always somebody here, but today of course they've all got plans.

column1: It was a wonderful day.
column2: You still haven't answered my question.

column1: You know how I feel, Tom. I just want to think it over.
column2: The boss is leaving for Chicago tomorrow. If I could tell him I was getting married -- with two dependents--

column1: You're a good salesman -- but I've got to think about it.
column2: A good insurance salesman wouldn't give you time to think.

column1: Hello--
column2: You ready?

column1: I will be in just a minute.
column2: The picture starts at eight-fifty.

column1: I was talking to Mr. Carpenter.
column2: I hope Mr. Carpenter won't think I'm intruding.

column1: Oh, Tom, that was awful.
column2: I'm sorry. I guess I'm just tired of hearing about Mr. Carpenter.  I don't like the way he's attached himself to you and Bobby. After all, what do you know about him?

column1: He's not there.  But look what I found in his room
column2: Is it real?

column1: I wonder if we ought to--
column2: Bobby and I have had enough excitement for tonight.

column1: You think it's all right for you to stay here?
column2: I've got a good lock on my door.  And Bobby's going to sleep in my room tonight.

column1: I'm at Bleeker's getting an appraisal on that diamond. I thought we might have lunch together.
column2: I -- I'm afraid I can't -- not right now. Can I talk to you later?. Yes, that'll be fine. 'Bye.

column1: Tom -- I've been trying to get you all afternoon--
column2: Come on in.

column1: I've got some terrific news about your friend, Mr. Carpenter.
column2: What about him?

column1: Helen, he's the man from the space ship!  I had that diamond checked at three different places. Nobody on earth's ever seen a stone like that! After what Bobby told us, that's enough for me. Why is it nobody knows anything about him? Why hasn't he got any money?
column2: All right, Tom -- it's true. I know it's true.

column1: How do you know?
column2: Never mind about that.  You've got to promise me you won't say a word to anybody.

column1: Are you crazy? After what happened today?
column2: You don't understand. You don't realize how important it is.

column1: Important? Of course it's important. The point is we can do something about it.
column2: That's what I'm trying to tell you. We mustn't do anything about it. Believe me, Tom, I know what I'm talking about.

column1: He's a menace to the whole world! It's our duty to turn him in.
column2: But he isn't a menace! He told me what he came here for.

column1: He told you... Don't be silly, honey -- just because you like the guy.  You realize what this'd mean for us? I'd be the biggest man in the country. I could write my own ticket.
column2: Is that what you're thinking about?

column1: Tom, you mustn't -- ! You don't know what you're doing! It isn't just you and Mr. Carpenter. The rest of the world, is involved!
column2: I don't care about the rest of the world!

column1: You'll feel different when you see my picture in the papers.
column2: I feel different right now.

column1: You wait and see. You're going to marry a big hero!
column2: I'm not going to marry anybody.

column1: I don't know how to thank you.
column2: I enjoyed every minute of it.

column1: Everyone seems so--
column2: Jittery is the word.

column1: Bobby's the only person I know who isn't -- Jittery.
column2: He has his homework to keep him occupied.

column1: He's a fine boy, Mrs. Benson.
column2: Naturally I think so.

column1: Mr. Carpenter -- this is none of my business, but -- why did that detective come here last night?
column2: Oh -- they just wanted to ask me a few questions. Bobby and I tried to see Professor Barnhardt in the afternoon, but he wasn't in. Apparently they thought I was looking for secrets of some kind.

column1: Excuse me. I was just going up to my room.
column2: Goodnight, Mr. Carpenter.

column1: Mr. Carpenter, I--  Goodnight.
column2: Goodnight, my dear.

column1: Oh -- hello--
column2: May I see you for a minute?

column1: I -- I was Just going to lunch.
column2: May I walk out with you?

column1: I saw Bobby this morning before he went to school--
column2: Yes--?

column1: I want to know what he told you last night.
column2: I -- I didn't really pay much attention--  Bobby has such an active imagination.

column1: What is it you want?
column2: Before I ask you to be honest with me, perhaps I should be completely honest with you--

column1: What happened?
column2: What time is it?

column1: Just twelve.
column2: We'll be stuck here for a little while -- about thirty minutes.

column1: We could try pushing the other buttons.  I have a flashlight in my purse.
column2: It won't work.

column1: Why not?
column2: You see -- the electricity's been neutralized -- all over the world.

column1: You hold great hope for this meeting.
column2: I can see no other hope for your planet. If the meeting should fail, then I'm afraid there is no hope.

column1: It must be twelve-thirty.
column2: Yes -- Just exactly.

column1: Where are you going now?
column2: Back to the boardinghouse. I'll be safe there for the afternoon -- and I can keep an eye on Bobby. He's the only other person who knows anything about--

column1: No, wait a minute -- there's someone else.
column2: Who?

column1: I'm sure Barnhardt can arrange to hide me until the meeting.
column2: Where is the meeting going to be?

column1: It's only a few blocks to Barnhardt's.
column2: I'm worried about Gort. I'm afraid of what he might do -- if anything should happen to me.

column1: Gort?  But he's a robot. I mean -- without you, what could he do?
column2: There's no limit to what he could do. He could destroy the Earth.  If anything should happen to me, you must go to Gort. You must give him this message: "Klaatu barada nikto." Please repeat that.

column1: "Klaatu barada nikto."
column2: Remember those words.

column1: Hello.
column2: I -- I thought you were--

column1: I was.
column2: You mean he has the power of life and death?

column1: No -- that is a power reserved to the Almighty Spirit.
column2: This technique, in certain cases, can re-stimulate life for a limited period. It's a refinement of scientific principles known to your own people.

column1: But how -- how long--?
column2: How long will I live?  That no one can say.

column1: We'll miss you very much -- Bobby and I.  He won't have anyone to play with.
column2: He'll have you -- and Tom.

column1: No. That's all finished.
column2: I'm sorry.

column1: How dare you write on that blackboard!  Do you realize the Professor has been working on that problem for weeks?
column2: He'll catch on to it in no time now.

column1: How did you get in here? And what do you want?
column2: We came to see Professor Barnhardt.

column1: Well, he's not here. And he won't be back till this evening.  I think you'd better leave now. Unruffled, Klaatu turns to the desk and scribbles something on a scratch pad. He tears off the piece of paper and hands it to Hilda.
column2: You might keep this.  I think the professor will want to get in touch with me.

column1: Is it worth anything?
column2: I have never seen such a stone. Will you please tell me where it came from?

column1: That's what I wanted you to tell me.
column2: There are no diamonds like this -- any place in the world.

column1: You sure about that?
column2: Would you like to sell it?

column1: No -- no, thanks.
column2: I'd give you a very good price.

column1: The Professor's secretary says she found you in Barnhardt's room, making marks on his blackboard.
column2: I was only trying to be helpful. He was having difficulty with a problem.

column1: Oh, I see. He was having trouble and you were helping him out.
column2: That's right.

column1: I suppose you know that Barnhardt does a lot of secret work for the Army.
column2: In this case the secret wouldn't be worth much. He doesn't know the answer himself.

column1: But I suppose you know the answer.
column2: It's really quite simple... The three- body problem, you know.

column1: Your name's Carpenter -- that right?  Any identification, Mr. Carpenter? Driver's license -- social security number?
column2: No -- I'm afraid not.

column1: Well, how do I know who you are?
column2: You don't.

column1: Okay -- book him and get him fixed up.  Looks like everybody's goin' nuts.
column2: They would have killed this man?

column1: People get hysterical enough, they do anything.  Look, Mr. Carpenter -- if you can't identify yourself, I got to send you over to the Army.
column2: How long will that take?

column1: May I suggest that you call the Professor?
column2: Get going, will you, Brady -- before I get mad!

column1: Sixteen.
column2: And the horse you rode in on. Sixteen for how long?!  You can't predict this time of year...

column1: What do you want from us?
column2: Just listen.

column1: Pretty nasty out, Mac.  Thirty-five knots.
column2: Screw it, I'm going up anyway.

column1: All right... Box of dynamite... box of thermite... three shotguns... box of flares... two flare guns... thirty cans gasoline... and a case of alcohol.
column2: Let's load 'em.

column1: Maybe dinner.
column2: Dogs don't eat each other.

column1: Where these tracks headed?
column2: Nowhere... Just straight to the ocean.

column1: What do you mean "got" to the dog?
column2: It was a life form that was able to imitate and reproduce, whatever it ate or absorbed, cell for cell.

column1: Clark, did you notice anything strange about that dog?  Just anything at all?  Any little thing?
column2: No.  Just that he recovered real quick... That night when I found him in the rec room, he had already scraped off his bandage.  Before I put him with the others, I redressed his wound and noticed it had healed up real good...

column1: That night?
column2: Yeah.

column1: What was he doing in the rec room?
column2: Well, after I worked on him -- thought I'd let him rest.  Left the room for a bit.  When I came back, he was gone.

column1: Well, where was he?  Where did he go?
column2: Don't know.  Looked for him for a bit... couldn't find him.

column1: How long were you with the dog? Alone, I mean?
column2: Ah... He was hurt bad.  Bullet nicked an artery... I don't know... An hour... hour and a half...

column1: What the hell you looking at me like that for?
column2: Nothing.  Nothing at all.

column1: Was that dog, the Norwegian dog?
column2: I just can't comprehend any of this. It was just a dog.

column1: Couldn't make much of it myself.
column2: I've asked him to try and locate the site.  Okay with you?

column1: Sure.  You think there's a connection?
column2: Maybe.

column1: Look, I know it's hard to believe...
column2: So what's our problem?

column1: ... It could have gotten to somebody...
column2: Anybody sick?

column1: Listen to me, Garry.  Please...
column2: If the weather clears enough before we reach anybody -- I'm sending you and Doc up to MacMurdo...

column1: Don't you understand?!  That Thing didn't want to become a dog...
column2: Damn you, Blair!  You've already got everybody half-hysterical around here.

column1: You can't let anybody leave!
column2: I've got six dead Norwegians on my hands, a burned up flying saucer, and we've just destroyed the scientific find of the century.  Now fuck off!

column1: Whatever that Norwegian dog was... It... It was capable of changing its form...  ... when it attacked our dog... it somehow was able to digest... or... absorb it... and in the process shaped its own cells to imitate our dog's cells exactly...  ... This for instance isn't dog at all -- it's imitation... We got to it before it had time to finish or...
column2: Finish what?

column1: What you doin'?
column2: Nobody's getting in here.  You can tell them all that!

column1: Now why'd you go and...
column2: And I don't want any more food with sedatives in it.  I know what you're up to.  Don't think I don't.  And if anyone tries to get in here -- I've got rope.  I'll hang myself before it gets to me.

column1: Too damn dangerous.
column2: ... You think this Thing wants to become an animal?  Dogs can't make it 1000 miles to the sea.  No skua gulls to imitate this time of year... No penguins this far inland... Don't you understand?!  It wanted to become us!

column1: ... Can't you see...?  If one cell of this Thing got out it could imitate every living thing on Earth. Nothing could stop it!  Nothing!
column2: Look Blair, maybe you're right about this.  But we've got to be rational. We've got to talk this over.  I'm unarmed and I'm coming in.

column1: How you doin', old boy?
column2: I don't know who to trust.

column1: Know what you mean, Blair.  Trust is a tough thing to come by these days. Just trust in the Lord.
column2: Watch Clark.

column1: What?
column2: Watch him close.  Ask him why he didn't kennel the dog.

column1: I've changed my mind... I'd... I'd like to come back inside... I don't want to stay out here any more... Funny things... I hear funny things out here.
column2: Have you come across Fuchs?

column1: Fuchs...?  No, it's not Fuchs... You must let me back in... I won't harm anyone... I promise...
column2: We'll see...

column1: Happens all the time, man.  They're falling out of the skies like flies. Government knows all about it... Chariots of the Gods, man... They practically own South America.  I mean they taught the Incas everything they knew...
column2: Cool it, Palmer!!

column1: Childs, where's that magneto from Chopper One?
column2: Ain't it there?

column1: What?
column2: Don't walk behind me.

column1: Auxiliary light cables...?  Been cut.
column2: Cut, bullshit.  Been pulled apart.

column1: Somebody broke in.
column2: Now who'd go and do...

column1: Childs!!
column2: Let go of me...

column1: Don't get near 'em.  The plants! They're alive.  Those things can imitate anything...
column2: What's it going to do, being a plant?

column1: We got to burn 'em.
column2: Now hold on, you dumb...

column1: Why didn't it imitate Fuchs?  Isn't that its number -- to get more recruits.
column2: Wasn't enough time.  Generator was out, what...?  Thirty minutes. Takes the bastards an hour, maybe two to absorb somebody.

column1: Could have been anytime.  Anywhere.
column2: If it did get to him.

column1: Let's open it.
column2: Hell no.

column1: Let's open it.  Now...
column2: Why you so damn anxious to let him in here...

column1: He's so close.  Maybe our best chance to blow him away.
column2: No.  Just let him freeze out there.

column1: You catch anything he was saying?
column2: Am I starting to look Norwegian to you, Bwana?

column1: I suppose... well, it's possible someone might have lifted it from me.  But...
column2: That key ring of yours is always hooked to your belt.  Now how could somebody get to it without you knowing?

column1: I said where?  Where'd you go?!
column2: Was dark... find a light...

column1: Lighten your load, sucker.  You ain't the judge and executioner around here!
column2: Who you trying to protect, mutherfucker?  I'm telling you this S.O.B. could be one of them.

column1: Childs!  That a fuse?
column2: No.  The generator.  You got the auxiliary box just off the kitchen. Get to it.  Where's the damn flashlight?  You fellas okay over there?

column1: Cut that out, Copper.  Nauls?  What's taking you?!
column2: I'm working it!  Nothing's happening!

column1: That's impossible, man!  Okay, Clark, out of the john where I can see you!
column2: It's shorted out or something!

column1: Somebody's taken it.  I can't find it!
column2: Clark, you want me to come in after you?!

column1: Cut him loose of the line up by his shack.
column2: Cut him loose?

column1: What's happening?
column2: Childs, you got the torch?  You get your ass in here!!

column1: Torch it over there!
column2: The dogs?

column1: MacReady!
column2: Look, I'm just guessing...

column1: ... So it crashes, and this guy, whoever he is, gets thrown out, or walks out, and ends up freezing.
column2: I just can't believe this voodoo bullshit.  You believe this voodoo bullshit, Blair?

column1: Yeah, they dig him up and cart him back.  He gets thawed out, wakes up and scares the shit out of them. And they get into one hell of a brawl...
column2: Now how's this motherfucker wake up after thousands of years in the ice, huh?

column1: I don't know how.  Because he's different than we are.  Because he's a space guy.  What do you want from me, anyway.  Go ask Blair.
column2: You buy any of this, Blair?

column1: I can get maybe another five or six feet out of it.
column2: That's good enough.

column1: Where's the other half?
column2: Probably the next meal.

column1: What we going to do?!
column2: How the fuck do I know?!

column1: Torch them!!
column2: But...

column1: What do we do about those three?
column2: We got morphine, don't we.

column1: MacReady!
column2: What?

column1: Garry's missing!
column2: Oh, shit!  Well, hang on!

column1: Well, who says I want you going with me?!
column2: Cut the bullshit... Okay, Sanchez, you come with us.  Norris... you stay here...  Any of them move -- you fry 'em. And if you hear anything, anything at all you let loose the siren.  We all meet back here in twenty minutes regardless.  And everybody watch whoever you're with.  Real close.

column1: ... Nothing human could have made it back here in this weather without a guideline...
column2: ... Where is everybody?!  I'm half frostbit!

column1: What are you doing?
column2: You're a dead man, MacReady -- or a dead whatever the hell you are!

column1: We found your clothes -- the ones you tried to burn.
column2: What clothes?

column1: ... Ever occur to the jury that anybody could have gotten to some of my clothes and stuck them up...
column2: We ain't buying that.

column1: Palmer, you and Copper tie everyone down.  Real tight.
column2: What for?

column1: You ain't tying me up.
column2: Then I'll have to kill you.

column1: We should have jumped his ass.
column2: Now Copper, you tie Palmer up.

column1: Load of bullshit.
column2: We'll see.  Let's try Clark.

column1: Spaceship of some kind.
column2: Smart S.O.B.  He put it together piece by piece.

column1: I think so.
column2: What do you mean "you think so?"

column1: Not the only one.
column2: The fire's got the temperature way up all over camp... won't last long though.

column1: Neither will we.
column2: Maybe we should try and fix the radio... try and get some help.

column1: Maybe we shouldn't.
column2: Then we'll never make it.

column1: Maybe we shouldn't make it.
column2: If you're worried about anything, let's take that blood test of yours.

column1: Screw regulations!  Four guys could be crawling around on their bellies out there!
column2: So, I don't want to end up crawling around with them when we go down.

column1: My God, what in hell happened here?
column2: Come on, Copper.

column1: Hey, Sweden!!!
column2: They're not Swedish, goddamn it, they're Norwegian, MacRe --

column1: Anything?
column2: All in Norwegian.

column1: What are you doing?
column2: Could be important work.  Might as well bring it back.

column1: Well, who's got access to it?
column2: I guess I'm the only one.

column1: Would that test have worked?
column2: I think so.

column1: Now hold him.
column2: I'm a real light sleeper, Childs...

column1: And if anyone tries to wake me...
column2: Damn you, MacReady!

column1: I guess you're okay.
column2: Thank you.

column1: ... Guys as crazy as that could have done a lot of damage to their own before they got to us.
column2: Nothing we can do about that.

column1: Yes, there is.  I'd like to go up.
column2: In this weather?

column1: Goes on like that quite awhile.  What do you gentlemen make of it?
column2: Could be anything... Men in isolation... some beef that snowballed... got out of hand...

column1: Hold on, damn it.  We're getting nowhere... If this bit of Blair's about absorbing and imitating is true... then that dog could have gotten to anybody.
column2: And if it got to Clark... Clark could have gotten to anybody.

column1: How long will it take you to prepare this?
column2: A couple of hours.

column1: Can there be... some kind of test? To find out who's what?
column2: A serum test possibly.

column1: I don't see how... when I'm finished I return it right away.
column2: When was the last time you used it?

column1: I'm getting worried about you.  You ought to have a checkup.
column2: Let's just not get worried about anything just now.

column1: After all this mess then.
column2: After all this mess.

column1: Gotta be from the Norwegian camp.
column2: How far's that?

column1: 'Bout eighty kilos southwest.
column2: That far?

column1: How many in their party?
column2: Started with six.  There'd be four others left.

column1: Right.  Why not?
column2: What's that?

column1: Hey, man...!
column2: You reach anybody yet?

column1: We're a thousand miles from anybody else, man.  It's going to get a hell of a lot worse before it gets better.
column2: Well, stick to it.

column1: Couple seconds of an Argentine disco station.
column2: Well, stick with it.  I want you at it round the clock.  We got to get help in here...

column1: Put that down!
column2: No.

column1: Look, if you're going to keep bitching, MacReady -- Palmer's offered to take him up...
column2: What are you talking?!  He's had two months training in those choppers!

column1: We're on fire!
column2: Don't let up, Childs!

column1: You're not thinking of going after them, are you?
column2: I am going after them.

column1: Get these things out of supply and meet me over by the snowmobiles.
column2: You're not going to catch them in one of those with the start they got.

column1: Ah... no one... I give it to Copper when he needs it...
column2: Could anyone have gotten it from you?

column1: Let's rush him.  He's not going to blow us all up.
column2: Damn if I won't.

column1: Pure nonsense.  This won't prove a damn thing.
column2: Thought you'd feel that way, Garry. You were the only one who could have gotten to that blood plasma...  ... we'll do you last...

column1: Looks good.
column2: One thousand volts.  Should be enough.

column1: How long's it been?
column2: Little over two hours.

column1: Four!
column2: What is it out there, anyway? Forty-five knots?

column1: What's...
column2: Blair.  He's gone berserk.

column1: Oh, I got you.  Not too long.
column2: Then get a move on.  Childs, come with me.

column1: How's that Thing get to the dogs?  I though we stopped it in time.
column2: Copper thinks they swallowed pieces of it during the fight.

column1: No it ain't there.  Would I be asking if it were there?
column2: Move it, Palmer.

column1: Sanchez...?  Hey, who...
column2: Mac, where the hell is that pump!!

column1: Somebody definitely messed with it.
column2: We going to make it?

column1: Sanchez, you and Palmer search the inside...
column2: I ain't going with Sanchez.

column1: What kind of test?
column2: I'm sure a lot of you already know.

column1: Tie up Clark, too.
column2: He's dead.

column1: How we going to try and find out who's... you know, who's who?
column2: Can you think of any other tests?

column1: Where were the flashlights?
column2: Screw the flashlights.  Where the hell were you?

column1: We've got to find Fuchs.  When we find him -- we kill him.
column2: Why?

column1: What if it doesn't come?
column2: It'll come.  It needs us.  We're the only thing left to imitate...  Give me a hand.

column1: He might just wait us out.
column2: I'm going to blow the generator when you get back.  He'll have to come for us -- or freeze.

column1: That thing's too smart to be hiding any more of its clothes, MacReady.
column2: Just keep looking.

column1: This storm do that?
column2: Couldn't be possible.  Must have weighted a ton and a half...

column1: ... Hey, somebody!  Open up, it's me, MacReady...  ... Come on, damn it... The towline snapped.  Been crawling around like a seal out here...
column2: Bullshit!  He's got to know damn well I cut it!

column1: We're going to draw a little bit of everybody's blood.
column2: What are you going to do?  Drink it?

column1: What is it?
column2: Everything that's been missing.

column1: Where was he trying to go?
column2: Anyplace but here.

column1: What about Childs?
column2: Forget about Childs.  He's over.

column1: You and Nauls got to block off the west side bunks, the mess hall and the kitchen.
column2: You crazy?  He might be inside already?

column1: Get back!!
column2: The generator!

column1: Got Sanchez... World War Three wouldn't mess with this fucker... Can go through walls... And it's like all over the place...
column2: Calm down and get in your position.

column1: Maybe it ain't coming.
column2: Then we go after him.

column1: You jerking off or just pissed?
column2: We got any more of those electronic chess things down in supply?

column1: Get your gear on.
column2: What for?

column1: Magnesium of some type... or some kind of strange alloy.  And those poor dumb bastards had to go and blow the hell out of it.
column2: So what do you make of it?

column1: You know damn well what we both make of it.
column2: No chance it could have been some new kind of test craft?

column1: Somebody else sure as hell thought so.
