column2: Who else could have used that key?

column1: We should sleep in shifts.
column2: Right.  Half of us awake at all times.

column1: What's happened?!
column2: MacReady, that you?

column1: Yeah!
column2: It's the generator I think!  No power.

column1: ... Made sure I got ahead of him on the towline on the way back... cut him loose.
column2: MacReady...?

column1: He's one of them.
column2: When do you think it got to him?

column1: You hear that?
column2: Hear what?

column1: It's got into the pub!  It's turned on the stereo!
column2: What?!

column1: It's in between us and them!!  How we going to get back?!
column2: Can't hear you.

column1: It must have been hard, leaving your work.
column2: The journey is part of my work.

column1: Now how did you get hurt?
column2: I had an accident.

column1: What do you do on the towers?
column2: On the towers?

column1: Ah... no.
column2: Don't tell me you're a mud carrier.

column1: ... Thousands and thousands of people.  And sometimes we live in great buildings that reach up five or ten stories.
column2: And everyone looks like us?

column1: She didn't want me to be a climber. She wanted me to be a planner like her.
column2: I'm so sorry, Kalen.

column1: How can they just go back to work as if nothing happened?
column2: What else can they do?

column1: Kalen... Do you have any idea where they take them?
column2: We're not supposed to think about it.  But I dream about it sometimes...

column1: There's a place that might help... we could try going there.
column2: Where?

column1: The Hall of Books.
column2: You have books?!  Kalen, you've got to take me there.  There might be history.  Records.  Something to help us find where the Morlocks took --

column1: No one ever comes here.  My mother told me stories about it late at night.  They tell all the children.
column2: What kind of stories?

column1: I had a friend who came here once. Sort of a dare.
column2: What happened?

column1: I think we should go on by ourselves.
column2: No...

column1: Please, just listen to me... Your mother would be very cross with me if you got hurt.  I'll find her.
column2: But you're only a mud carrier.

column1: ... Well, you wanted to see it.
column2: This is it?

column1: Yes.  Just about here.
column2: But there's nothing here.

column1: Right up your alley, I would think. You are from the past, yes?
column2: How did you know?!

column1: I can smell carcinogens and industrial pollutants on your skin that have not been known here for --  -- 800,000 years perhaps.  Don't keep me in suspense.  What year?
I must say, you look remarkably good.  You don't want a book then?
column2: What are you?

column1: I'm the librarian.  I've always been the librarian.
column2: I know you -- you're an automaton of some sort that --

column1: Sir... have you a name?
column2: I am called Vox...  ... Now you are Eloi.

column1: Please, we need your help.  The Morlocks have taken --
column2: Morlocks --

column1: You know of them?
column2: Who doesn't know the Morlocks?

column1: Do you know where they live?
column2: Oh yes... They found our knowledge useful for a time.  They used us much as your people did.  Then they decided they had learned enough so they tore us up for spare parts.

column1: But you escaped.
column2: I was lucky.  The others weren't.

column1: Regenerating fission reactor, you wouldn't understand.  It's power is well beyond your neanderthal cranial capacity.
column2: Can you show us where they live?

column1: We need your help.
column2: Why should I help you?  You primates -- you great, lumbering, hairy animals, drenched in blood from the moment of your hideous conception -- what have you ever used knowledge for but destruction and bloodshed!  A little bit of learning and you lay waste to the world!  You're no better than the Morlocks!

column1: Because you'll never die.
column2: Excuse me?

column1: So, Relic, you want to open Pandora's box, do you?  See all the mysteries exposed?
column2: Yes.

column1: And if the truth is so horrible that it will haunt your dreams for all time?
column2: I'm used to that.

column1: When was his mother taken?
column2: Last night.

column1: Send him away.
column2: What?

column1: Send him home.  You don't want him to see it.
column2: Kalen... hold on a minute.

column1: My God... I saw this.
column2: It frightens you.

column1: Yes...
column2: It was meant to.

column1: So, do we go on?
column2: Yes.

column1: Aren't you a plucky little -- ?
column2: Oh, shut up.

column1: It's what they want you to see.
column2: This is the way in?

column1: Yes... Are you sure you want to do this?
column2: Yes.  But you've done enough. Thank you for your help... I hope someday people read your books again.

column1: In for a penny, in for a pound.  Do you know that saying?
column2: Yes... Thank you.

column1: Machines?
column2: Yes.

column1: Vox?
column2: This way.

column1: What's it all for?
column2: The air... the power.

column1: Why did they built it?
column2: The Morlocks didn't build this.

column1: Alexander... Listen to me, it was wrong to bring you.  You're not going to find what you're looking for.
column2: What do you mean?

column1: They raise them like cattle... Feed them until they're ready and then hunt them.
column2: No...

column1: This has to end.
column2: End...?

column1: Vox --
column2: Imagine that... seems that little devil got my power relays...

column1: Takes a licking but keeps on ticking...  ... For a while anyway.
column2: What can I do?  Tell me what to do.

column1: Nothing to do, I'm afraid.  I'm just a librarian after all.  Wasn't exactly made for all this swashbuckling.  Very Byronic end, though.  I appreciate that.  Do you know Byron?
column2: Vox...

column1: I'm babbling.  Good to have someone to talk to for a change... But you need to go.  Take her out of here...  ... I don't have long.
column2: I won't leave you like this.

column1: Go back to the light.  You weren't made for this.  I was... I was made for this moment.
column2: I don't understand.

column1: Now get out of my sight, you hideous primate.
column2: I'll never forget this.

column1: I should hope not...  ... Alexander... Make them read my books.  Tell them who they are. Who they could be.
column2: I will...

column1: What's your name?
column2: Alexander.

column1: Well, Alexander, as a fellow scientist I know you have a thousand questions --
column2: You came underground when the world was ending above.  And you evolved. Some into the Morlocks and others --

column1: No, we created the Morlocks.
column2: Created?

column1: You wouldn't understand.  We genetically engineered the Morlock class to serve our needs.
column2: As slaves.

column1: And centuries later when we tried to emerge into the sun again, we couldn't.  Our adaptation was too successful.  We survived... we endured... for this.
column2: How do you control the Morlocks?

column1: We make them see what we wish.
column2: How?

column1: And what of the Eloi?
column2: They survived above.  Became what they are.

column1: No... they didn't survive only to be your food.  You did that.
column2: I'm afraid your indignation is lost here.  I have no more "human" response to the Eloi then you would have to a carrot.  It's just how we live now.

column1: But this is barbaric!  Have you completely lost all sense of --
column2: And who are you, Alexander?  Who are you to question thousands of years of evolution?  This is the world now.  I am fact.

column1: What?
column2: Go back to where you came from.  Or die here.

column1: Why would you let me go back?
column2: Because the past is immutable. Frozen.  Dead... And you are the past.

column1: Say I just come back again?
column2: Alexander, yours is a world of brocade and velvet, not tooth and claw.  Why would you come back to this?  To save a few cattle?  No.

column1: Why?
column2: We have lost the capacity to reproduce.  But the species must continue.

column1: So you take their best...
column2: When a creature shows too much independent thought we remove them from the gene pool.  We're breeding them for submission.  Soon they will be fully domesticated.

column1: You took her because she helped me.
column2: Yes.  Initiative and daring are not desirable traits in the Eloi.  But you should be happy for her.  She won't remember the creature she was.  She will... become.

column1: She won't remember you.  None of them will.  You will be forgotten. That is how history works.
column2: A man can change his history.

column1: Now will you go?
column2: No...

column1: If I can only find the right door... the lady or the tiger...
column2: No...

column1: That was a foolish thing to do.
column2: I'm a foolish man.

column1: I could have a hundred Morlocks here in thirty seconds.
column2: I know.

column1: I'm tired of running.
column2: Oh, you won't be running for long...

column1: But you've earned a reward for your valor.  I think you should become. You'll like it here.  Once you get used to the darkness.
column2: I don't think that's going to happen.

column1: And why not?
column2: Because...

column1: It's spectacular...
column2: Thanks.  Old Nell's my girl all right.  Al least when she decides to move, stubborn beast.

column1: I've only read about them -- and the new internals.
column2: Now that's what I call plain crazy -- internal combustion is just too dangerous, all those little explosions, never catch on.

column1: How do you keep the water temperature stable?
column2: There's a cantilevered gasket on the --

column1: God -- could have killed me -- bad girl, Nell!  How did you know to do that?
column2: I just love mechanical things.

column1: Well, much obliged -- I'm always forgetting the confounded brake -- say, if you wait until I get her up and running I'll give you a perambulation.  Tell you all about her.
column2: Ahhh... I'm afraid I've got a prior commitment.

column1: Next time then.  We perambulate here most every night.
column2: You have my word...  ... She's just a beauty.

column1: May I help you?
column2: I -- what are you?!

column1: I am the Fifth Avenue Public Library informational kiosk.  VOX registration NY-114.  May I help you?
column2: What's happening to the moon?!

column1: The 2005 terraforming demolitions for the lunar excavations sent the moon into a diminishing retrograde orbit resulting in global gravitational fluctuations, increased seismic activity and tidal anomalies.  Can I tell you more?
column2: No -- wait -- the moon's falling out of orbit -- that's not possible!

column1: Well, considering it is, in fact, happening, I would assume it's possible.  The retrograde orbit began in 2005 when the demolitions for the lunar colonies --
column2: Why is it -- breaking up?

column1: You're late.
column2: Got here as soon as I could.

column1: Dance with me...
column2: You know I can't.

column1: You promised me flowers.
column2: What?

column1: You promised me flowers tonight, don't you even remember?
column2: Sorry... I was distracted.

column1: Well there's something new.
column2: I need to... um... talk to you.

column1: Talk away, Professor.
column2: Not here... alone.  May we? Please?

column1: ... Orion's belt, pointing to the earth.  You see it over the rocks there?  Sailors consider that an omen of good fortune
column2: What?  Yes -- Orion -- good fortune -- sailors.

column1: All right, what is it now?
column2: Emma, you know I have great... admiration for you.

column1: Admiration?  My my.
column2: I mean... well... affection.

column1: Oh dammit, I love you!  I can't eat, I can't sleep, I can't think, all I do is moon over you and -- hum, apparently.
column2: And what do you propose, Professor? Shall we hold a seminar to study the problem?

column1: You know, the moment is rather dying here.
column2: Hold on... I know I have it...

column1: I know it's not a diamond but --
column2: A moonstone.

column1: You're late.
column2: Got here as soon as I could.

column1: Dance with me...
column2: You know I can't.

column1: Alex, what is it?
column2: Holding you... again.

column1: Darling.
column2: I need... to talk to you.

column1: All right...
column2: Not here... alone.  Please.

column1: Let's walk through the park...
column2: No... let's walk through the city.

column1: Alex, what is it?
column2: Nothing -- let's just get out of the park.

column1: Alex...?!
column2: Shhh.  Let's just hurry on here. We don't have to talk, all right?

column1: Why do we have to race for heaven's sake?!
column2: I want to get into the light, that's all.  Please...

column1: My God...
column2: Alex, it's just the zoo.

column1: You're so pale... I hope you're not coming down with something.
column2: No, I'm fine.  I'm...  ... wonderful.  Just walking down the street with you again.

column1: We took a walk three days ago.
column2: Not like this.  Never like this. Emma, I swear to you -- if I've learned one thing, it's that moments like this are rare.  And I will thank God for them every moment of every day.

column1: They are rare...  ... Orion's belt, pointing to the earth --
column2: The sailor's omen of good fortune. The hunter watching over him on his travels.

column1: Heavens, look at that now!
column2: I've seen it.

column1: Now I know you're ill -- passing up the chance to explore some new gadget.
column2: It's only a machine.

column1: Alex... people are staring.
column2: Let them.

column1: Let them.
column2: I have something for you...

column1: ... The point is I know it will work once the, um, numbers and such are in order.
column2: Do you know you were humming?

column1: I was not.
column2: Somewhere around "D+2xy something something."

column1: Damned if I can keep her out of my equations.
column2: Tonight's the night?

column1: ... One day he'll be discovered by some future archeologists and they won't know what to make of him. The thick brow, so lacking in imagination.  The dim little eyes, devoid of curiosity.
column2: You know generally teachers are supposed to teach real equations that add up to real numbers.

column1: Where's the challenge in that?
column2: Alex, this is your first year as an associate professor.  You might want to play things a little more conservatively.

column1: Look at them, Philby, all alike, everyone in an identical bowler hat.  Do you want your students to turn out like them?
column2: I want my students to emerge with theoretical and practical knowledge.

column1: I don't.  I want them to run along this street and knock off every bowler they see.
column2: You may not like it, but this is the world we live in, Alex.  Little grey men with little grey hats.

column1: In the future, we'll be better.
column2: What?

column1: Emma actually likes chalk dust -- says it smells like me.
column2: How romantic...

column1: The most able inventor I know and you can't tie a simple four-in- hand.
column2: That's how I knew we were destined to be together.  When I met her parents for the first time I came right from class and I was covered in chalk.  They sniffed and snorted, but she just smiled.  At that moment -- I just knew.  How did you know with Molly?

column1: She made the best Shepherd's pie I ever tasted.
column2: Do you have a romantic bone in your body?

column1: Alex, really... good luck tonight. She's a fine girl, and she's done wonderful things for you.
column2: Oh?

column1: All these clocks -- how can you constantly be running late?!
column2: Perseverance.

column1: I've been working.
column2: I came by the house every day after the funeral.  And then every week. Then every other month.  Then I stopped coming.  Did you even notice?

column1: I'm sorry, David.
column2: It hurt me, Alex.  Very much.

column1: It's my Jamie's birthday today. Your godson.  He's nine years old. At his party he asked me if Uncle Alex was coming.  I told him no. Then he asked me if you didn't like him anymore.
column2: For God's Sake, David --

column1: There are some things I need to say to you.  You may not like hearing them, but I don't know if I'll ever get another chance --
column2: You care for me.  And you're concerned.  And I have to start living my life again.  I hear it from Mrs. Watchit every day.

column1: But you won't listen.  You won't see me, you won't see anyone.  What would you like me to tell Jamie? That Uncle Alex is busy?  That Uncle Alex is hiding up there in his laboratory --
column2: Hiding?

column1: You know that's what it is.  Mrs. Watchit tells me you're here at all hours -- day and night --
column2: That's because I'm working.  You remember that?  You used to care about your work.

column1: What happened to Emma will never go away.  It's part of you now and it always will be.  But you have to learn to live with it...
column2: I live with it every minute of every day.

column1: I know that --
column2: You don't know that.  You couldn't possibly.  If I'd only done this, or that, if I'd arrived ten minutes earlier, or later.  If we'd taken a different path or I hadn't fought the man for the ring.  You have no idea what it is to relive every moment of that night -- consider every action you made -- and every one of them wrong.

column1: It wasn't your fault, Alex.
column2: Wasn't it?... I have a dream almost every night now.  The Lady and the Tiger, you remember that story?  In the dream I'm alone in a huge chamber with a thousand doors. Behind every door, save one, is a tiger.  I have to make the decision.  Which door conceals Emma?  And I just stand there... looking at the doors...

column1: Alex, nothing will ever change what happened, but --
column2: That's where you're wrong.  I will change it.

column1: David... I appreciate your concern, I do.  But I ask you to have faith in me.  Just for a little while longer.  I'm working on something now.  Something... extraordinary.
column2: What is it?

column1: You wouldn't believe me.
column2: I would.

column1: I'll tell you what... come by for dinner in a week and I'll show you.
column2: Why don't you come to our house instead?

column1: I can't do that --
column2: When's the last time you were outside this house --  -- or this room?

column1: I can't leave when I'm so close.
column2: There are trains leaving Grand Central every then minutes.  A dozen liners leaving the harbor. Get on one of them.  Go to Singapore, Scotland, Manchuria, anywhere, just away from here --

column1: That's absurd --
column2: You're dying here.  Don't you see that?!

column1: You won't say that in a week.
column2: I pray to God that in a week you're not here.

column1: All right.  I'll come for dinner. And in the meantime... you'll think about what we discussed?
column2: In a week... we will never have had this conversation.

column1: Good night, David.
column2: Good night, Alex.

column1: And this would be my study.  There was an elm tree outside the window then.
column2: I'm glad.

column1: This... was my home.
column2: His home.

column1: Couldn't help but overhearing.  Two fine young people starting out on the road of life.  I wish you the very best.
column2: Thank you...

column1: I hope it's a happy journey for you both -- and much as I hate to do this, moved as I am by your protestations of love, I'll be needing your money now.
column2: Sir...?

column1: And your jewelry too.  I guess we could consider this your first little bump on the road to married bliss.
column2: I don't understand.

column1: Did you hear me, lad?
column2: All right, all right -- here -- everything --

column1: You're up!  You must be feeling better --
column2: Yes...

column1: How long did you travel?
column2: Well it seems like a long time -- but it wasn't really.  It's rather hard to explain.

column1: Yes.
column2: Thank you.

column1: Is there a lot of illness?
column2: Some.  But I mean we aren't all so... handsome.

column1: His curiosity is amazing.
column2: Mm.

column1: Kalen will tire you out if you let him.  He's always been curious. His father was firm with him but... it's just his way.
column2: Your husband is dead?

column1: It's hard for me to imagine a better place.  Where I come from there's so much... frenzy.  Day and night.  It seems we're all running faster and faster...  ... All in identical bowler hats.
column2: You're not from beyond the valley.

column1: We don't have anything like this. Or the machine where Kalen found you.  And I doubt they do beyond the valley... Now where do you come from?
column2: You might find the truth rather hard to understand.

column1: Oh, that explains everything.
column2: I know it's hard to believe, but it's true.

column1: That machine --
column2: Allowed me to travel from my time to yours.

column1: How long ago?
column2: More than 800,000 years.

column1: Why?
column2: Why not?

column1: I might find the truth rather hard to understand?... Can you go back?
column2: Yes.  Or forward into the future. I suppose I really should check on the machine, see that it hasn't been damaged...

column1: I'll take you tomorrow... You must have seen a lot on your journey.
column2: For a time it was astounding.  I saw the years spinning by, I was in the years spinning by.  We made such advances.  I don't understand half of them.  There was a machine that talked to me and others that flew through the sky... We must have been incredible thinkers and artists --

column1: Is he all right?
column2: Just a dream.  You should sleep too.  You're still not well.

column1: I'm going to sit with Kalen.  Keep the fire burning if you can.
column2: I will...

column1: I'll take you to your machine tomorrow.
column2: Thank you...

column1: You seem fascinated by the stars.
column2: You can see so many here.

column1: Don't then have stars where you come from?
column2: Not like this... They don't seem so bright with all the city lights.  I never really noticed them much...

column1: Good night, then.
column2: Good night.

column1: Mara, I had a strange dream last night.  I was here, walking through a forest very much like this, and then...
column2: Then you came to a desert and mountains...

column1: Yes.
column2: And you saw a shape ahead of you...

column1: Yes!
column2: We all have that dream.

column1: All of you?
column2: Every night.

column1: You share dreams?  That's incredible.
column2: We share everything.

column1: This is magnificent...
column2: Thank you.

column1: And this is your "work"?
column2: Yes.

column1: The mud carriers.
column2: I can see Kalen's point.

column1: Want to be a high climber now, do you?
column2: What you need is an engineer.  If you set up a system of pulleys and counterweights, some basic block and tackle mechanism, you could to this a lot more easily.

column1: It's not supposed to be easy, it's supposed to be beautiful.
column2: What's it all for?

column1: I don't understand.
column2: I mean, why do you do it?  What purpose does it serve?

column1: It has no purpose.  It's just beautiful... Does everything have a purpose where you come from?
column2: Most things.  We're very high on purpose.

column1: It's always been this way here.  We work on the towers all our lives. When we're young we train to be planners or climbers or sculptors...
column2: Or mud carriers.

column1: And there's no shame to that.  It's all the same here.  Everyone has an important job to do.  We all work together and couldn't survive without each other.
column2: What are you?

column1: I'm a planner.  I help decide where the new towers go and what they should look like.
column2: How do you decide?

column1: ... It was a great city.  The greatest city in the world.
column2: You liked it there.

column1: Oh, very much...  ... I used to work somewhere in that direction, I think.  A huge university where we taught everything from botany to history to literature.
column2: Learning was important?

column1: Oh very.  Learning, commerce, the arts -- the whole place was buzzing all the time.  Night and day.
column2: Did you have fires at night?

column1: Only to keep warm.  For illumination we had gaslights on most of the streets and a new invention called electrical lighting that made it seem like daylight all through the night.
column2: It must have been safe.

column1: Oh, it was...  ... Most of the time.
column2: It sounds like a wonderful place to live.

column1: Alexander...?
column2: Orion's belt...

column1: Those rocks, over there... they're the same... this is... Central Park.
column2: You know this?

column1: This is where my journey started... right here.
column2: You lost someone.

column1: Yes.
column2: Someone you loved very much.

column1: Yes... After her death, it was intolerable for me here... The future had to be better.
column2: Is it?

column1: You've welcomed me into your home. Into your lives.  Everyone has... For the first time in a long time it doesn't hurt quite so much.  I thank you for that.
column2: I know what it is to lose someone. When my husband was taken from us... I thought the pain would never end.

column1: Good -- it looks fine.  We had quite a ride together...
column2: It's undamaged?

column1: Yes... a little scorching on the upholstery but otherwise all ship- shape.
column2: So you can use it now?

column1: Yes... I suppose so.
column2: Go back to your own time?

column1: Alexander, take my son away.  Take him back to your time.  Will you do that?
column2: Mara --

column1: Kalen...
column2: Mara...?

column1: Mara -- what -- ?!
column2: Kalen -- we have to get Kalen -- !

column1: It was different then.
column2: My laboratory was about... here. And the kitchen was over there, where that tree is.  Mrs. Watchit wouldn't allow me in much... but, yes, this is about the kitchen.

column1: Oh huzzah, the master's home.
column2: Do you have it?!

column1: Don't torture me -- do you have it?
column2: I have it, but don't you think for one moment I'll be letting you go out in that filthy coat -- now go upstairs and change.  I've laid out your green coat.

column1: Now that's more like it.  You look a proper gentlemen for once.
column2: Then if Emma turns me down will you marry me?

column1: Oh, I'm already swooning.
column2: Ouch -- all right, wish me luck.

column1: Sir, Mr. Philby is here.
column2: Here?

column1: Yes, sir, he --
column2: Tell him to go away --

column1: All right, Mrs. Watchit.  You can go.
column2: May I get you some --

column1: Dr. Philby, Dr. Hartdegen.  I received the most extraordinary letter last week.  From a parent. We are always pleased to receive letters from parents.  They are our employers, after all.  This gentleman's son is in your class, Dr. Hartdegen.
column2: I see.

column1: As I recall the syllabus the name of your tutorial is "Applied Mathematics and Engineering", am I correct?
column2: Exactly correct, sir.

column1: Well, just as I thought.  Surely it's all been a terrible mistake. This parent actually suggested that your freshman course in applied mathematics has somehow become a seminar on theoretical physics!
column2: Imagine that.

column1: But I know that none of my faculty would ever deviate from the assigned curriculum.
column2: Well... perhaps I have "deviated" the tiniest bit.

column1: Might I ask why?
column2: Because the assigned curriculum is boring.

column1: Sir, that curriculum is forty years out of date.  The students today are looking toward the new century -- they want to be challenged and inspired, not spoon-fed dusty old equations that have been proved a thousand times.  They want to explore.
column2: Do they?

column1: And roosters.
column2: No, Dr. Hartdegen, they are not just chickens and roosters.  They are science.  Perhaps they aren't "inspiring" to you.  Perhaps they don't "challenge" you --

column1: No, sir --
column2: Animal husbandry is science, Dr. Hartdegen.  I have been breeding these fowl for fourteen years.  I have filled a library with information on their feeding patterns, social behavior and breeding.  Empirical, exacting, quantifiable records.

column1: With respect, sir, would we have the telegraph without fantasy? Would we have radium and X-rays without someone first dreaming we could?
column2: The advances you speak of were the result of countless years of study and empirical experimentation, a careful evolutionary process, not chalkboard parlor-tricks.

column1: My equations are not parlor-tricks!
column2: Abstract mathematics, relativity of dimensions, geometrical "durations" -- even allowing for the uses of speculation, what is the point?

column1: Yes, sir.
column2: Very good.  Now if you will excuse us for a moment.

column1: And hungry, I'd say.  You had such a long journey.
column2: I did...

column1: "Eloi"?
column2: What are your people called?

column1: Well, I guess you'd call us... New Yorkers.
column2: New Yorkers.

column1: We had another visitor from beyond the valley about four years ago. His name was Moren.  Do you know him?
column2: No...

column1: He said he traveled for two months.
column2: I took a different route.

column1: Oh, very different.  But not entirely... I mean we have lots of, um, trees and such.  But not everywhere.  And more roads.  And buildings.
column2: Why?

column1: To live in.  There's a lot of us... beyond the valley.
column2: New Yorkers.

column1: I am the oldest.
column2: No, I mean someone considerably older.  Your father perhaps?

column1: My father has gone to a better place.
column2: I'm sorry, I didn't mean to...

column1: Good morning, Alexander.  Feeling up to some work?
column2: I suppose so.

column1: Where do they take them?!
column2: We don't know.

column1: We have to go after them, find where -- !
column2: Alexander, I know you're trying to help.  But they don't come back.

column1: What do you mean?!
column2: They've gone to a better place.

column1: You know that's not true.
column2: We choose to believe it.

column1: This is out life, Alexander.  It's a hard life but it is how we have always lived.
column2: Then it's time to change that --

column1: You won't even try?
column2: We can't change the day and the night, Alexander.  This is the world.

column1: My fowl have polluted the yard.
column2: Dean Fulton...

column1: Sir, if I may --
column2: Young man, we have a way of doing things here.  Radical theorizing is not acceptable.  Have I made myself understood?

column1: If I might explain, sir --
column2: You supported his application, Dr. Philby.  You are his senior, advisor.  I depend upon you to restrain his... excesses.  Any repetition of the behavior I witnessed in his classroom today and there will be consequences for you both.

column1: Yes, sir.
column2: Now you are upsetting my fowl. Please go.

column1: How did you get hurt?
column2: Kalen...

column1: I found you.  I saved your life. You were bleeding all over the place!
column2: That's quite enough, Kalen.

column1: What did you do at night?
column2: What's it like where you come from?

column1: We'll see about that.
column2: I am.  Are you a climber?

column1: I want to see your home.  Will you take me?
column2: Kalen, right now you need to go up to bed.  You're exhausting Alexander.

column1: Kalen, it's all right, I'm here --
column2: They're here!  They're inside the house -- !

column1: No, you're safe --
column2: They're inside --

column1: Hello, Mrs. Watchit.  You're looking in the pink.
column2: Must be all the exercise I get scampering up and down these stairs like a wee lamb.

column1: I wonder if that poor girl has any idea what she's in for?
column2: For our sake, I hope not.

column1: I don't know what to tell you, sir. He's been gone this whole week.
column2: And you've no idea where he went?

column1: Sir?
column2: I'm glad he's gone.  Maybe he's finally found a place where he can be happy.

column1: I think I might be.  But there'll be some changes made.  I run a tight house.
column2: I have no doubt of that.  I'll come by in the morning and we'll arrange it.  Goodnight, Mrs. Watchit.

column1: You ok?
column2: I'm fine.

column1: [Beat] Listen, I hate to bother you...
column2: Then don't.

column1: But... what about Starks?
column2: What about Starks?

column1: Should we be...
column2: Should we be what? Trying to change him any way we can? [Beat] Yes.

column1: Don't get all worked up, Justin. I expected some common sense on your part and clearly I was expecting too much. [Beat] Just open the drawer.
column2: We never should have done this to him...

column1: Well, your condition's pretty serious.
column2: [Beat] So they say. [Off Becker's steady gaze] What?

column1: I'm just looking at you. Does that make you uncomfortable?
column2: Depends on what you're seeing.

column1: You said you couldn't remember killing Officer Harrison. Correct?
column2: [Beat] You don't believe me, do you?

column1: He's recovering on the third floor.
column2: Are you kidding me? He's not psychotic!

column1: I don't know better. All I know is that you left me in there.
column2: In where?

column1: We were forced to use restrains if that's what you're referring to.
column2: That wasn't a fucking restraint.

column1: Relax.
column2: Don't act like I don't know what's real. [Beat] I'm not the one that's crazy here.

column1: You're just suffering from delusions that are unfortunately part of your condition.
column2: Don't give me that. I know what's real, goddamnit! You strapped me in something and stuck me in a drawer.

column1: I didn't dream it. I may have been asleep but it wasn't a dream. BECKER sits down in a CHAIR, half-shrouded in the light.
column2: I had a patient a few years ago. His name was Ted Casey...

column1: I don't give a shit about your patient!
column2: I wasn't pausing to see if you did. [Beat] But, incidentally, you should, because you're birds of a feather.

column1: We are not birds of a feather.
column2: Maybe not. [Beat] But I do think you're in a tree... woofing like a dog. And I'm just trying to help you the only way I can think of.

column1: Long live the Organization for the Organized!
column2: Sit down, Mr. Starks! Sit down, Mr. Starks!

column1: Hello, William. I understand you've been asking for me almost every hour. I would've been here sooner but you gave our little state visitor quite a bit to talk to me about.
column2: That's too bad.

column1: It is. But when it comes down to it, you just have to patient with them. They'd rather have their vacation, too, so they just push dealing with our "practices" off to the New Year.
column2: They make it hard for you to get away with your business, huh?

column1: And what's that?
column2: My business?

column1: Yes.
column2: Getting away with things. Like whatever I may or may not have gotten away with Officer Harrison.

column1: I'll say a prayer for you in Church today, Starks. Maybe the Gods can pick up where the medicine left off.
column2: You sure you know where to find one?

column1: I've managed to every Sunday of my life. [Beat] Some of us are God- fearing men, Starks.
column2: And what does that mean?

column1: Becker, how do you sleep at night?
column2: You in here. [Beat] Works like a drug.

column1: Who are you?
column2: I think you know. Your eyes say you do.

column1: [Beat] You're his son?
column2: No. I'm not his son. I'm him. [Beat] What? You look like you've seen a ghost. You can come here and touch me, old man. I'm the real thing.

column1: You died, Starks. Years ago, in the hospital.
column2: I know. [Beat] You killed me, didn't you?

column1: No. I didn't. I swear I didn't. I probably helped push you to kill yourself, but I didn't do it.
column2: I didn't kill myself. I died from a blow to the head. How'd it happen? I have to know.

column1: I don't know how you died. The last time I put you in the Jacket was just after you told me you remembered killing that police officer...
column2: I didn't say I remembered killing him. I just repeated some words to get myself back in there.

column1: I know. [Beat] I knew that when you came out.
column2: How?

column1: Of people like you. People I was just trying to help. They couldn't get worse so I thought, with medication, they might get...
column2: Medication? What kind of meds do you chase with nights in a cadaver drawer?

column1: It was part of the treatment I intended...I didn't know what the effects would be...
column2: So, what, you guinea pig sick people to find out?

column1: The three of you weren't regular patients. You were criminals that ended up at Alpine Grove.
column2: No, we were patients.

column1: How did you come to know their names?
column2: You just told me. The last time I was with you was when I was in the Jacket. I'm in it right now, Dr. Becker.

column1: I don't understand...
column2: I'm in it as we speak. [Beat] You're haunting yourself right now. [Beat] I guess sometimes we indict ourselves if no one else does. You didn't make history like you wanted to, huh, Dr. Becker. It turned out different, didn't it?

column1: I didn't put you in Alpine Grove.
column2: No. [Beat] You put me on drugs and then you put me in the Jacket.

column1: Do I know you from somewhere?
column2: You may have known my father, William Starks.

column1: That's right! Goddamn, you're the spitting image. I didn't know he had a son.
column2: He didn't either.

column1: Did you know my father?
column2: Oh yeah, sure. He killed a cop, right?

column1: My father used to talk about you.
column2: Oh yeah, what'd he say?

column1: Look here, I don't like you getting in my face and saying this bullshit to me...
column2: That's too bad.

column1: I thought you said you never knew your father.
column2: I didn't. [Beat] Did you have anything to do with his death?

column1: He died because he bled to death from a blow to his head. Someone had to have given him it.
column2: I never touched your father! I swear!

column1: We're late.
column2: I wish they'd skip the formality of this annual review and just cut our budget. Our silence on the matter should be enough to appease the civic conscience without wasting an hour we don't have.

column1: It's the ticking of a box on a sheet of paper no one cares about.
column2: They don't care about all the things we do right. [Beat] But they might ...they might care about what we're doing wrong. [Beat] That's what they should come here to look for.

column1: What should they be looking for?
column2: They should just be looking harder.

column1: Where? [Beat] It's Becker isn't it? He's doing stuff, isn't he?
column2: Later. I'll tell you about it later. We got a session to catch now.

column1: You look like you've lost some weight. Are you eating?
column2: I am. One of the few things I remember doing is eating. So I guess I must be exercising it off in my dreams.

column1: You done with your small talk?
column2: Sure.

column1: This is really happening, isn't it?
column2: [Beat] What do you need me to do?

column1: I need to get this letter to someone.
column2: I can't take you out of here in your condition...

column1: And I can't stay here in my condition. I am going to die tonight. It's already been decided.
column2: No, it hasn't.

column1: I'm sorry I can't tell you more about your father's death, Mr. Starks. Our own medical examiners determined only that he died from a blunt trauma to the head but that was right around the time the Alpine Grove's staff changed and I'm afraid we didn't have the best record system before then.
column2: His body was found on January 1, 1993, but do you know if that was long after he had died?

column1: No, I don't. I'm sorry. I wish I knew more.
column2: What about Dr. Thomas Becker or Dr. Loel Lorenson? There was also a Dr. Gries, I think.

column1: Well, Dr. Lorenson is still here at the hospital. If she was here at the time your father was, then I'm sure she'd be of more help to you.
column2: What about Dr. Becker and Mr. Gries?

column1: Get your fucking hands off my daughter!
column2: Mom, he just fixed our car.

column1: I'm sorry? Your face looks awfully familiar, I just can't quite place it...
column2: Mom, this is the guy that drove us home that afternoon we were stuck on the highway. The guy you yelled at for no good reason...

column1: Jackie, go play in the snow.
column2: Why?

column1: Come on, mom. Don't fall asleep...
column2: You two ok?

column1: Your mom take anything before this happened?
column2: Yeah, but I don't know what.

column1: [Beat] What's your name?
column2: Jackie.

column1: But I like it I guess.
column2: Hey, can you reach the gas pedal?

column1: You're just gonna walk?
column2: Yeah, I'll hitch a ride or something. [Beat] Let her throw it all up before she gets back behind the wheel.

column1: What're those?
column2: Dog tags. [Off her blank look] They've got your name and date of birth for identification.

column1: What for?
column2: [Beat] In case you get lost, or can't remember who you are.

column1: I think I can remember what's on them.
column2: William Starks. [Beat] Thanks.

column1: What'd you do? Snoop all over the place? You had no right. You had no right to go through anything.
column2: [Beat] I know it doesn't make sense. It doesn't even make sense to me.

column1: Jackie, I'm William Starks. I can prove it.
column2: What? Now you're gonna show me some kind of driver's license?

column1: No, I don't have anything to show you. I'm here from a mental hospital.
column2: Well, you belong in one.

column1: Stop it! Stop it! JACKIE covers her ears and looks at him, pleading with her eyes. STARKS' eyes plead right back.
column2: I'm sorry for upsetting you, [beat] but I'm not lying to you.

column1: You can't be William Starks. He's dead.
column2: [Beat] What?

column1: William Starks is dead... [Beat] I've been to his grave.
column2: [Beat] What?

column1: I looked it up.
column2: How?

column1: I gave you my dog tags.
column2: No, you didn't. They found William Starks' body dead in the snow.

column1: How'd he die?
column2: I don't know. But he did die. STARKS falters under the news. JACKIE looks around, through her now blurred eyes, like she might find some help in the apartment. She settles for the BOTTLE of VODKA on the table, lowers the iron fork and takes a long heavy drink, then laughs nervously as she looks up.

column1: I know what this is...I picked you up when I was drunk and you probably thought I'm just fucked up enough to fall for this. But the thing is I know what I'm doing when I drink. I just usually don't care. Right now, I do though. And I want you out. Now.
column2: It's December 25th, 1993 today.

column1: I'm telling you I don't care what time you think you're in. You're not William Starks. [Beat] I don't believe in many things, but I believe in death. And it doesn't give back what it takes. So whoever you are...I did a nice thing, you've made me regret it enough already, so please, just leave.
column2: I'll leave. But look at me. Look at my face, Jackie. I'm not lying. I met you and your mother. I told you then that I'd lost my memory. [Beat] There was no one for miles around so I know you know there's no way I could have known that from a pair of dog tags you had lying around.

column1: The Jacket. That's what they call it, right?
column2: Yeah.

column1: But no one knew until after...
column2: After I...

column1: [Beat] You bled to death.
column2: What?

column1: Do you really believe me?
column2: I don't know. [Beat] I thought I was crazy after you left that day. I died. I still think I could be crazy. But then I replayed that night in my head -- the parts of it I could remember -- and it was like...I don't care if I was, or am. I haven't felt that way in a room with someone my whole life. [Beat] And when you left, all I wanted was...

column1: [Softly] I want to trust you. Should I trust you?
column2: Yes.

column1: Then we need to figure out what happened to you. It's the only thing we can do.
column2: I know.

column1: Alpine Grove still exists. I looked it up on the net. We should go there and see if there's still anyone around who might have known what happened to you.
column2: If they don't take me out before then. [As an afterthought] What's the net?

column1: I didn't kill Officer Harrison.
column2: I know.

column1: How? Did they figure it out after I died?
column2: No. They never figured it out. I did. Most murderers don't stop to help a drunk woman and her little girl on the side of the road. Not without hurting them.

column1: I don't believe a thing she just said.
column2: Me neither. Who was the boy she was talking about, Eugene?

column1: I have no idea.
column2: You think Lorenson kills you?

column1: Maybe. I don't know. Seems more likely Becker does, but at the very least she knows how I died.
column2: Let's see if they have an address for Becker. I also want to figure out more about the kid you helped her with.

column1: Why?
column2: Because that's the part I believe is true. You probably did help her somehow with the boy and Eugene's name did come up over and over again on the abstracts I pulled.

column1: How long do we have?
column2: I don't know.

column1: What about Captain Medley? He never told them what happened to you over there. His testimony...that coward wanted them to think you were crazy.
column2: I know. It was perfect. [Beat] Erase my sanity and you erase anything I'll ever say.

column1: Of course it makes me mad. It makes me more than mad. Just like remembering the face of the man who killed that officer and knowing nothing more about him. But what's it gonna do for me to find them now? I can't fix everything in three days.
column2: You've got to get yourself out of that place. They're going to kill you if you don't.

column1: I might not be able to.
column2: It's not a prison, it's a hospital. There's got to be some way out of there and you've got to find it...

column1: Me, too.
column2: Here, drink this. I'll get the heat going.

column1: You're sure?
column2: Yeah. I called the number yesterday to make sure. Thomas Becker, retired M.D.

column1: They're not here.
column2: They're not.

column1: What? What are you thinking?
column2: There're no cars on this street.

column1: I don't know. Maybe that's because this whole thing is a dream. How can you have a street with no cars on it?
column2: I don't know. But this isn't a dream. I'm real, and so is where we are.

column1: Then why isn't there anyone around?
column2: [Beat] I don't know.

column1: Of course he will. [Beat] What day of the week is it?
column2: It's Sunday.

column1: They've got lives to be grateful for.
column2: William, you're not making sense.

column1: That's all you got from him? That bastard helped take your life away from you.
column2: No, he didn't.

column1: If everything hadn't happened the way it has, then I wouldn't be here right now, sitting in a car with you, touching your face.
column2: Why are you saying that? [Beat] We don't have long, do we?

column1: Where are we going?
column2: To the hospital.

column1: What's happening to me? Why am I getting so much weaker?
column2: Because your body can only take so much of what they're putting you through.

column1: Lorenson's the only one that could let me out of there. I need something to persuade her that I was there. Get me something to take to her.
column2: Ok. Ssh. Rest.

column1: What?
column2: When we first met, when you were 7, where was the house you lived in with your mother? Do you remember your address?

column1: You gotta stop thinking like that.
column2: Then, where are you going?

column1: I've been ok.
column2: Good. How's your mom?

column1: [Beat] You be good to yourself, Jackie.
column2: Ok.

column1: I think so.
column2: You're bleeding pretty bad there.

column1: It's ok. It's ok. Relax. It's just a cut. We can get it fixed. But we need to get you to the hospital now. How'd you get that?
column2: I fell down. [Beat] But I'm alive.

column1: How you doin'?
column2: I'm doing fine.

column1: Just a little, when we were looking up information about William's father. How did he help?
column2: It's complicated, but [looking at Starks] in a way, your father let me know how I'd get through to him.

column1: How?
column2: He just said...that I'd shock Eugene and then things would change for him.

column1: I don't understand.
column2: I still don't either, even after all these years.

column1: Because Becker resigned after the charges brought against him by State Patient Advocacy Groups.
column2: I see you've done your homework. [Beat] Alpine Grove's undergone a lot of changes since then. At the time, we didn't have the...resources to help our patients the way we needed to. [Beat] Now, we do. And things are different.

column1: And if I didn't want to come?
column2: I guess I'd ask you why.

column1: Because I don't think I'm crazy.
column2: You're not crazy.

column1: You were convicted of the crime.
column2: That conviction doesn't convince me of anything. Until I know that I did it, I'm not going to accept that I did.

column1: You may never remember at all. [Beat] Your mind's grasp of reality and the real events that have happened to you has been damaged.
column2: No. The real events that have happened to me have been fucked up. Not my mind.

column1: Why, what would you do?
column2: I could try to...make it stop.

column1: No. I don't want it to.
column2: So it's helping?

column1: You should be careful. You could be killed if they found you out here.
column2: Believe me, I know.

column1: My God you look exactly like him.
column2: I never knew my father. Did you?

column1: Yeah, I did. [Beat] He was my most memorable patient.
column2: Why?

column1: At the end, he made me change my mind about a lot of things.
column2: You thought my father was crazy?

column1: What case?
column2: I was working with a boy named Eugene.

column1: How'd he get it?
column2: [Beat] I don't know.

column1: But Dr. Morgan said you were around when my father was...
column2: I was. But I saw a lot of cuts and a lot of blows. I'm sorry I don't know more about your father's. [Sincerely] I didn't know about everything that went on here.

column1: Well, do you think Dr. Becker would have any idea?
column2: How do you know about Dr. Becker?

column1: So maybe Dr. Becker would know. [Beat] But, as I'm sure you know, the statute of limitations has run out for charging the hospital with any liabilities.
column2: Why would we do that?

column1: It's important for you to know who your father was, isn't it?
column2: [Beat] Yeah, it is.

column1: Exactly.
column2: Well... [beat] let me know how your search turns out.

column1: You'll die if you keep smoking those in your condition.
column2: I'll die either way.

column1: What do you mean?
column2: You have no idea what's going on.

column1: No, I do. That's what I'm saying to you.
column2: Listen to me! You don't! The Jacket is my only chance in this place.

column1: You don't understand.
column2: Then help me understand. You know, you're not alone. A lot of Gulf Vets have begun to experience curious symptoms. What you have might well be a syndrome and, if so, it's not one we know enough about to be treating it this vigorously.

column1: I don't know. [Frustrated] Remember?
column2: Come on. Tell me what you do know.

column1: [Beat] I've seen a time that's not this time. And I'm only able to see it when I'm in the Jacket.
column2: Well, what time is it?

column1: Ok fine. Tell me about it. Tell me about the future. 2004. What does it look like?
column2: It doesn't look all that different.

column1: The future doesn't look different?
column2: No. Not for people like me. [Beat] Not in the places I come from.

column1: What about the world?
column2: I didn't see that much of it -- same as now. I only saw it as part of my own life.

column1: [Beat] Like who? Like MacKenzie maybe?
column2: Maybe.

column1: Why don't you help me?
column2: Because I don't have time.

column1: Why not?
column2: I'm about to die unless I do something to stop it.

column1: And how do you know that?
column2: Because of the future. I know what's going to happen.

column1: How do you know about Eugene?
column2: You told me about him. I saw you and I think you thought I knew something about him. So you told me.

column1: Some part of you suspects -- even if you don't know for sure -- that what I'm saying is true.
column2: I don't know how you know about Eugene, but these ideas are part of your delusions.

column1: I know. I know it all. Save your strength. I already know everything you're going to say. [Beat] You're in the Jacket right now, aren't you?
column2: How...how do you know?

column1: You told me this was how it happened.
column2: I did?

column1: Who...who kills me?
column2: You have nothing to fear, William.

column1: You're going to be ok, William. We just need to get your fever down and we'll be able to hopefully stabilize you.
column2: Who are you kidding, Doc? You or me?

column1: Can I get some paper and something to write with.
column2: What for?

column1: I'm not gonna let that happen.
column2: You still don't believe me, do you?

column1: I do believe you...
column2: No. Listen to me...the kid, Eugene...

column1: William, I can't indulge these delusions, even when you're in this state.
column2: Listen to me. That's all I ask.

column1: He's having absence [pronounced "absance"] seizures when he stares off into space like he does. He has them so often that that's why he hasn't learned to speak properly.
column2: Who told you this?

column1: I don't know when it'll happen but soon I think, you'll shock the boy and it'll wake him up.
column2: What are you talking about?

column1: You know how to get there?
column2: Sure. It's an easy address. A little far out there, but easy enough.

column1: That's Kingsley. Old bastard hears us, I'm sure. He just doesn't want to bother answering so he makes us think he can't talk. I know. I tried it on my mother for two months once before she fished out my tongue. Literally. [Beat] You're the cop killer, right?
column2: Yeah, guess so. How'd you know?

column1: I tried to kill my wife.
column2: Don't you go to jail for that?

column1: Yeah, well 30 times probably would make you seem crazy.
column2: Or just plain stupid. You'd think by the twentieth time, I'd have found an alternative method. Maybe a more effective one, if you know what I mean.

column1: What were you talking about the other day?
column2: I wasn't talking about anything.

column1: I know you need one when it's really cold.
column2: [Cutting in] MacKenzie, listen to me. Listen. I'm going to die.

column1: Mortality's actually a great thing to be familiar with. It means you're sane on some level.
column2: [Gravely] No, I mean in four days, I'm supposed to die.

column1: [Beat] How do you know?
column2: The Jacket.

column1: Oh no, you're pretty young. Your body'll be able to handle a lot more of it than you think...
column2: No. [Beat] I mean I found out while I was in it that my body's gonna be found in four days.

column1: It's gonna be sticky.
column2: Why?

column1: 'Cause Lorenson's got her claws in it now. When she started getting suspicious about me was when they stopped using it on me. Women!
column2: So what am I supposed to do?

column1: Geez, how's that for a fucking "thank you"?
column2: Is it true?

column1: MacKenzie, [beat] what if we are crazy?
column2: [Shrugging] What if we are? There're crazier things than thinking up fictions for yourself. [Beat] Everyone does it, don't they? Even Becker. That roller coaster car pops more pills than all of Ward 3.

column1: Becker does? Are you sure?
column2: I've been here for 11 years. It's my neighborhood. 'Course I'm sure. He's as drugged up as the rest of us...I guess he has to be to put up with all this.

column1: You ever been to jail?
column2: No.

column1: It's worse than war. It's worse than anywhere you've ever been.
column2: I doubt it. [Beat] I don't think prison's so bad you don't want to remember it...

column1: Hey, Mister, you need a ride?
column2: Where are you going?

column1: Can you drive?
column2: Sure.

column1: If you're deaf, read my lips...I don't need a psycho following me today.
column2: [Beat] I'm not deaf.

column1: In case you hadn't figured, it's Christmas Eve. You're never gonna get a cab here.
column2: [Beat] Thanks.

column1: All right. [Beat] You got somewhere you need to go, Mister?
column2: I'm not sure.

column1: I'm not sure.
column2: You don't have anywhere to stay?

column1: Well, where are you from?
column2: I'm not sure. [Beat] I don't really know.

column1: Of course you don't know.
column2: Why "of course"?

column1: Because in my life, it wouldn't make sense for me to pick up some normal guy with a place where he's from and a place where he's going to. It'd be too simple. I probably wouldn't know how to handle a situation like that.
column2: Well, you definitely didn't pick normal or simple this time either.

column1: Well, how'd you get here?
column2: [Beat] I was dropped off.

column1: No.
column2: Well, don't you somewhere? Stuff? Belongings?

column1: Great. That was our last option. What am I going to do with you?
column2: Nothing. [Getting up] Thanks for bringing me this far.

column1: Where are you going? You'll freeze out there. You don't even have a coat.
column2: I'll manage.

column1: No, you won't. You'll die of cold out there and then I'll have to feel guilty. And I've already got more guilt than I know what to do with. [Beat] Do you want something to drink?
column2: No, I'm ok.

column1: [Beat] Yeah, I'm fine.
column2: You know what? It's Christmas Eve. And you look clean -- I mean, you're normal-looking. [Resolutely, for her own benefit] It's Christmas Eve, and I have a couch.

column1: What's this?
column2: The best I could do with what was in your fridge.

column1: I only lit it because it was so cold in here. I'm sorry if...
column2: No, it's fine. [Beat, swallow] Thanks.

column1: You want a drink?
column2: Sure.

column1: This is pretty good. Considering...
column2: Thanks.

column1: So you're a waitress, right? I mean...from the uniform you were wearing.
column2: Yup. That's me.

column1: You like it?
column2: [Beat] I do it.

column1: [Beat] Why'd you stop?
column2: Shit happens, and your life changes. 'Bout the best explanation of a lot of things that happen. [Beat] So how come you don't know where you're coming from?

column1: Well, good for you.
column2: [Beat] Why?

column1: You don't think that's crazy?
column2: Maybe. [Beat] Maybe not.

column1: This is a great song.
column2: You remember it?

column1: But hey, who can forget those words? The man just wants simple and good things for his woman -- that she be warm and happy. How hard can that be to remember?
column2: May be easy to remember, but not easy to get. Being warm, maybe -- but, look, you don't even have a coat and I still have to chop wood to make a fire. [Beat] And, being happy...you tell me if that's simple.

column1: They told me I joined the army when I was seventeen. That's when my father died and, before that, it was apparently just me and him since I was born 'cause my mom split.
column2: So you never knew your mother?

column1: I guess not. But, as of now, I never knew either.
column2: I'm sorry.

column1: Yeah. [Beat] How about you?
column2: Never knew my father. I grew up with my mother. Actually, I grew up around my mother. She was great though. I mean, the way she was with her friends... She was this woman who had so much life in her, she had to find ways to kill some of it just to be like the rest of us. [Beat] She died young.

column1: How?
column2: She fucked herself up day after day and then, one day, she fell asleep with a burning cigarette. [Beat] I came home from work and she was gone.

column1: I'm sorry.
column2: Yeah, me too. [Softly] Every day for the last ten years.

column1: What's wrong with this one?
column2: He ain't got five kids to feed.

column1: Where's yours?
column2: Over there man.

column1: Welcome to Mars.
column2: What was that?  An accident?

column1: What to the rebels want?
column2: Oh, the usual.  More money, more freedom, more air.

column1: So, where to?
column2: The Last Resort.

column1: First time on Mars?
column2: Yeah...Well, actually no...Sort of.

column1: Tell me something
column2: Freaks?...'Fraid so, man.  Goes with the territory.

column1: What happened to them?
column2: Cheap domes.  And no air to screen out the rays.

column1: Well, there it is
column2: Why not?

column1: I know a much better place down the block -- the girls are clean
column2: And you get a kickback.

column1: Lemme ask you a question.  Ever fuck a mutant?
column2: Take me to the hotel.

column1: What happened to number five?
column2: Ah, shit.  You got me.  I ain't even married.  Now put your fucking hands in the air!

column1: Need a ride?
column2: The Last Resort!  Quick!

column1: Shut up and drive!
column2: Whatcha doin' to me, man?!  I got six kids to feed!

column1: And if you wanna breathe, you gotta but his air.
column2: But maybe you can change all that.

column1: How could you do this?  You're a mutant.
column2: Hey, I got four kids to feed.

column1: What do you want?
column2: They've got you bugged, and they'll be busting down the door in about three minutes unless you do exactly what I say.

column1: Don't bother looking.  It's in your skull.
column2: Who are you?

column1: Never mind.  Wet a towel and wrap it around your head.  That'll muffle the signal.
column2: How'd you find me?

column1: Nice to have you back with us, Mr. Brubaker.
column2: Thank you.

column1: Would you like the same suite?
column2: Definitely.

column1: Hmm.  It seems you left something in our safe.
column2: Get it, please.

column1: I'll go encode your room key.
column2: Thank you.

column1: There you go, Mr. Brubaker.  Suite 610 in the East Wing.
column2: May I use your pen?

column1: Well, my boy, you're a hero.
column2: Fuck you.

column1: You see, Quaid, none of my people could get close to Kuato.  The fucking mutants could always sniff us out.  So Hauser and I sat down and invented you: the perfect mole.
column2: He's lying.  Hauser turned against you.

column1: That's what we wanted you to think. The fact is, Hauser volunteered to become Doug Quaid. It was the only way to fool the psychics.
column2: Get your story straight.  This idiot's been trying to kill me since I went to Rekall.  --You don't kill somebody you're trying to plant.

column1: He wasn't in on it.  You set him off by going to Rekall.
column2: So why am I still alive?

column1: The guy with the suitcase
column2: Sorry.  Too perfect.

column1: Well, Cohaagen, I have to hand it to you...This is the best mindfuck yet.
column2: Don't take my word for it, Quaid. Someone you trust wants to talk to you.

column1: The guy's a fucking asshole.
column2: Not true, he's one of my best friends...He's got a big house and a Mercedes.  And you like Melina, right?  Well, you'll get to fuck her every night.--That's right.  She's gonna be Hauser's babe.

column1: Come on, Cohaagen!  You got what you want.  Give these people air!
column2: My friend, five minutes from now, you won't give a shit about the people.  Fire it up, Doc.

column1: What are you afraid of?  Turn it on.
column2: Impossible.  Once the reaction starts, it'll spread to all the turbinium in the planet.  Mars will go into global meltdown.--That's why the aliens never turned it on.

column1: Do you expect me to believe you?
column2: Who gives a shit what you believe? In thirty seconds, you'll be dead. Then I'll blow this place up...

column1: I didn't want it to end this way.  I wanted Hauser back.  But nooo.  You had to be Quaid.
column2: I am Quaid.

column1: What the fuck is going on down there?!
column2: I'm trying to neutralize a traitor.

column1: If I wanted him dead, you moron, I wouldn't have dumped him on Earth.
column2: We can't let him run around.  He knows too much.

column1: Lori says he can't remember jack shit!
column2: That's now.  In an hour, he could have total recall.

column1: Richter, do you know why I'm such a happy person?
column2: No, sir.

column1: He had help.  From our side, sir.
column2: I know that.

column1: But I thought...
column2: Who told you to think?!  I don't give you enough information to think!  You do what you're told!!  That's what you do!

column1: Now let's get down to business.  Kuato wants what's in Quaid's head.  And he might be able to get it, cause they say he's psychic.  Now I have a little plan to keep this from happening.  --Do you think you can play along?
column2: Yes, sir.

column1: Stop fighting and get out.
column2: They've got Quaid!  They're protecting him!

column1: Perfect!...Get out of Sector G.  Now. Don't think.  Do it.
column2: Yes, sir.

column1: I say we throw the switch and see what happens.
column2: Don't be an idiot.

column1: Kill him.
column2: It's about goddamn time.

column1: Bob?
column2: What is it?

column1: I'm with an very important client.
column2: Looks like another schizoid embolism.

column1: What the fuck is going on here?!  You can't install a simple goddamn double implant?!
column2: It's not my fault.  We hit a memory cap.

column1: Listen to me!  He's been going on and on about Mars.  He's really been there.
column2: Use your head, you dumb bitch!  He's acting out the secret agent role from his Ego Trip!

column1: I'm afraid that's not possible.
column2: Why not?

column1: Oh shit....Oh shit...
column2: I've been trying to tell you.  Someone erased his memory.

column1: Okay, this is what we're gonna do. Renata, cover up any memory he has of us or Rekall.
column2: I'll do what I can.  It's getting messy in there.

column1: Ernie, dump him in a cab.  Around the corner.  Tiffany, you help him.  I'll destroy his file and refund his money.  And if anybody comes asking...we've never heard of Douglas Quaid.
column2: Come on...put his head in place.

column1: Good evening...  Doug.  I'm Dr. Lull.
column2: Nice to meet you.

column1: Two-headed monsters?
column2: Don't you keep up with the news?  We're doing alien artifacts now.

column1: So, been married long?
column2: Eight years.

column1: I see.  Slipping away for a little hanky-panky.
column2: Not really.  I've just always been fascinated by Mars.

column1: Your sexual orientation?
column2: Hetero.

column1: Blonde, brunette, redhead?
column2: Brunette.

column1: Demure, aggressive, sleazy?  Be honest.
column2: Sleazy...and demure.

column1: What do you want?
column2: This is going to be very difficult for you at accept, Mr. Quaid.

column1: I'm listening.
column2: I'm afraid you're not really standing here right now.

column1: Ya know, Doc, you could have folled me.
column2: I'm quite serious.  You're not here, and neither am I.

column1: Amazing.  Where are we?
column2: At Rekall.

column1: You're strapped into an implant chair, and I'm monitoring you at a psycho-probe console.
column2: Oh, I get it

column1: Not exactly.  What you're experiencing is a free-form delusion based on our memory tapes.  But you're inventing it yourself as you go along.
column2: Well, if this is my delusion, who invited you?

column1: I've been artificially implanted as an emergency measure.  I'm sorry to tell you this, Mr. Quaid, but you've suffered a schizoid embolism. We can't snap you out of your fantasy. I've been sent in to try to talk you down.
column2: How much is Cohaagen paying you for this?

column1: Think about it.  Your dream started in the middle of the implant procedure. Everything after that--the chases, the trip to Mars, your suite here at the Hilton--these are all elements of your Rekall Holiday.  And Ego Trip: You paid to be a secret agent.
column2: Bullshit.  It's all coincidence.

column1: What about the girl?  Brunette, athletic, sleazy and demure
column2: She's real.  I dreamed about her before I even went to Rekall.

column1: Mr. Quaid, can you hear yourself? "She's real because you dreamed her?"
column2: That's right.

column1: You open it.
column2: No need to be rude.  I'll do it.

column1: Suppose I do...then what?
column2: Swallow this.

column1: What is it?
column2: It's a symbol.  Of your desire to return to reality. --Inside your dream, you'll fall asleep.

column1: Mr. Cohaagen wants to see you right away.
column2: Any news of Quaid?

column1: Not since you lost him.
column2: Watch your mouth, Captain.

column1: Quaid!  That's Quaid!
column2: Where?

column1: HER!
column2: Arrest that woman!

column1: Richter!  Call from Cohaagen.
column2: This is Richter sir...I've got them pinned down.

column1: Pull them out.
column2: O.K., everybody pull out!

column1: Hey, hey Tony.  Give the big guy a break.
column2: Relax, you'll live longer.

column1: If we don't hand you over, everybody in the sector'll be dead by morning.
column2: We don't have much choice then, do we?

column1: Sit down.
column2: Where's Kuato?

column1: On his way.
column2: You heard the rumors about the Pyramid Mine?

column1: Yeah.
column2: Cohaagen found something weird inside, and it's got him scared shitless.

column1: What, aliens?
column2: You tell me.

column1: I don't know.
column2: Yes, you do.  That's why we brought you here.  --  Cohaagen's big secret is buried in that black hole you call a brain.  And Kuato's  gonna dig it out.

column1: You're Kuato, right?
column2: Wrong.  Kuato's a mutant.  So don't get upset when you see him.

column1: Shit!
column2: C'mon!

column1: They found us!  Everybody out!
column2: Melina!

column1: Hey Harry...Harry!  You ever heard of Rekall?
column2: Rekall?

column1: They sell fake memories.
column2: Oh, Rekall.

column1: Yeah.
column2: "RekallRekallRekall."  You thinkin' of goin' there?

column1: I don't know.  Maybe.
column2: Well don't.

column1: Why not?
column2: A friend of mine tried one of their "special offers"...Nearly got himself lobotomized.

column1: No shit...
column2: Don't fuck with your brain, pal.  It ain't worth it.

column1: Hey, Quaid!
column2: Harry!

column1: What trip?
column2: You went to Rekall, remember?

column1: I did?
column2: Yeah, you did.  I told you not to but you did anyway.

column1: What are you, my father?
column2: Let me buy you a drink.

column1: Harry, what the hell is this?
column2: Come on, let's go have that drink.

column1: What the fuck did I do wrong?!  Tell me!
column2: You blabbed, Quaid!  You blabbed about Mars!

column1: You shoulda listened to me, Quaid. I was there to keep you outta trouble.
column2: Harry, you're making a big mistake! You've got me mixed up with somebody else!

column1: Where?
column2: Up to the right.

column1: I want that fucker dead.
column2: I don't blame you man.  I wouldn't want Quaid porkin' my old lady.

column1: Are you saying she liked it?
column2: I'm sure she hated every fuckin' minute of it.

column1: What was that?  I couldn't hear you.
column2: I've got Quaid.

column1: Where is he?
column2: Level 2.  Galleria.

column1: Shit!
column2: What is it?

column1: That son of a bitch got to be around here somewhere.
column2: I've got him.  The guy in the turban.

column1: I've got a weak signal over there.
column2: Split up.  Find him.

column1: He's not at ground level.
column2: Up!

column1: I've got a lock!  There!
column2: Come on!

column1: Look at this shit.
column2: What the hell is this?

column1: I'm sorry.  Would you please rephrase the question.
column2: How did I get in this taxi?!

column1: Welcome to JohnnyCab.  Where can I...?
column2: Drive!  DRIVE!!

column1: Would you please repeat the destination?
column2: Anywhere!  Go!..Just go -- OH SHIT!! SHIT!!

column1: The fare is eighteen credits, please.
column2: Quit while you're ahead.

column1: Is that better?
column2: Mmmm.....

column1: Who?
column2: The brunette.  The one you told me about.

column1: Who is she?
column2: Nobody.

column1: Nobody?!  What's her name?
column2: I don't know.

column1: It's not funny, Doug.  You dream about her every night.
column2: But I'm always home by morning.

column1: Let me go!
column2: Aw, come on, baby...You're the girl of my dreams.

column1: ...You mean it?
column2: You know I do.

column1: Lori...
column2: Yeah, sweetheart?

column1: Let's do it.
column2: Do what?

column1: Honey, do you have to spoil a perfectly wonderful morning.
column2: Just think about it.

column1: Sweetheart, we've been through this a million times.  You'd hate it on Mars. It's dry
column2: Cohaagen says it's just a few extremists.

column1: And you believe him?
column2: All right, forget about it.

column1: Doug, maybe we should take a trip.
column2: Lori, move.

column1: Well...What do you say?
column2: I'm late.

column1: Sweetheart...I know it's hard being in a new town, but let's at least give it a chance here.  Okay?
column2: Lori, don't you understand?  I feel I was meant for something more than this.  I want to do something with my life.--I want to be somebody.

column1: You are somebody.  You're the man I love.
column2: Bye.

column1: What are you doing?
column2: Some men just tried to kill me!

column1: Muggers?!  Doug, are you all right? What happened?
column2: No!  Spies or something.  And Harry from work...Get down!

column1: Harry from work...He was the boss.
column2: Take it easy.  Tell me exactly what happened?  Why would "spies" want to kill you?

column1: I don't know!  It had something to do with Mars.
column2: Mars?  You've never even been to Mars.

column1: I know it sounds crazy, but I went to this Rekall place after work, and...
column2: You went to those brain butchers?!

column1: Let me finish!
column2: What did they do to you?  Tell me!

column1: --I got a trip to Mars.
column2: Oh God, Doug.

column1: Forget Rekall, will you!  These men were going to kill me...
column2: Doug, nobody tried to kill you.

column1: You call this a paranoid delusion?!
column2: Doug...

column1: Not talk!  I said TALK!!
column2: I'm not your wife.

column1: The hell you're not.
column2: I swear to God!...I never saw you before six weeks ago!  Our marriage is just a memory implant -- agghh!

column1: You think I'm an idiot?  Remember our wedding?
column2: It was implanted by the Agency.

column1: And falling in love?
column2: Implanted.

column1: Our friends, my job, eight years together, I suppose all this was implanted too?
column2: The job's real. -- But the Agency set it up.

column1: O.K. then.  If I'm not me, then who the hell am I?
column2: Beats me.  I just work here.

column1: But Doug...There's something I want you to know.  You're the best assignment I ever hand.  Really.
column2: I'm honored.

column1: You sure you don't wanna...?  For old time's sake.  If you don't trust me, you can tie me up.
column2: I didn't know you were so kinky.

column1: Clever girl.
column2: Doug...You wouldn't shoot me, would you?  After all we've been through?

column1: I suppose you're not here either.
column2: I'm here at Rekall.

column1: I love you.
column2: Right.  That's why you tried to kill me.

column1: Nooo!  I would never do anything to hurt you.  I want you to come back to me.
column2: Bullshit.

column1: Then I can pull this trigger, and it won't matter.
column2: Doug, don't!

column1: Doug...Bob McClane.
column2: Nice to meet you.

column1: Now help me out here, Doug.  You were interested in a memory of...
column2: Mars.

column1: Right.  Mars.
column2: That a problem?

column1: To be perfectly honest with you, Doug, if outer space is your thing, I think you'd be much happier  with one of our Saturn cruises.Everybody raves about 'em.
column2: I'm not interested in Saturn.  I said Mars.

column1: Let's see...the basic Mars package will run you just eight hundred and ninety-nine credits.  That's for two full weeks of memories, complete in every detail.  --A longer trip'll run you a little more, cause you need a deeper implant.
column2: What's in the two week package?

column1: First of all, Doug, when you go Rekall, you get nothing but first class memories: private cabin on the shuttle
column2: How real does it seem?

column1: As real as any memory in your head.
column2: Come on, don't bullshit me.

column1: I'm telling you, Doug, your brain won't know the difference.  Guaranteed, or your money back.
column2: What about the guy you lobotomized...Did he get a refund?

column1: All right.
column2: Smart move.  Now while you fill out the questionnaire, I'll familiarize you with some of our options.

column1: No options.
column2: Whatever you say...Just answer one question.  What is it that is exactly the same about every vacation you've ever taken?

column1: I give up.
column2: You.  You're the same.  No matter where you go, there you are. Always the same old you.  Let me suggest that you take a vacation from yourself.  I know it sounds wild, but it's the latest thing in travel. We call it an "Ego Trip".

column1: I'm not interested in that.
column2: You're gonna love this. --We offer you a choice of alternate identities during your trip.

column1: Secret agent...How much is that?
column2: Aaah, let me tantalize you.  You're a top operative, back under deep cover on your most important mission.  People are trying to kill you left and right. You meet a beautiful, exotic woman...

column1: Go on.
column2: I don't wanna spoil it for you, Doug. Just rest assured, by the time the trip is over, you get the girl, you kill the bad guys, and you save the entire planet.  Now you tell me.  Is that worth three hundred measly credits?

column1: They'll be here any minute!  They'll kill you all!
column2: What's he talking about?

column1: I love you.
column2: I love you.

column1: Ooo, whatcha been feeding that thing?
column2: Blondes.

column1: I thought Cohaagen tortured you to death!
column2: I guess he didn't.

column1: ...What?
column2: There's something I have to tell you...

column1: I don't remember you.
column2: What are you talking about?

column1: What, did you get amnesia?...How'd you get here?
column2: Hauser left me a note.

column1: Hauser?  You're Hauser.
column2: Not any more.

column1: Hauser, you're lost your mind.
column2: I didn't lose it.  Cohaagen stole it. He found out that Hauser switched sides,-so he turned him into somebody else.  Me.

column1: This is too weird.
column2: Then he dumped me on Earth with a wife and a lousy job and ...

column1: She wasn't really my wife.
column2: Oh, she isn't really your wife.  How stupid of me...She was Hauser's wife.

column1: Forget I said wife.
column2: No. Let's forget everything!  I've had it with you and your goddamn lies.

column1: Why would I lie to you?
column2: Because you're still working for Cohaagen.

column1: Don't be ridiculous.
column2: You never loved me, Hauser!  You just used me to get inside.

column1: I think you better leave.
column2: Melina, Hauser sent me to do something.

column1: I'm not falling for it.
column2: He said there's enough in here to nail Cohaagen for good.

column1: I said get out!
column2: Melina, please...People are trying to kill me.

column1: I thought you didn't like me.
column2: If Cohaagen wants you dead, you might be okay.

column1: So you dropped by to apologize?
column2: Kuato wants to see you.  Come on!

column1: Now what?
column2: Jump!

column1: By the way...ever heard of a company names Rekall?
column2: I used to model for 'em, why?

column1: Not bad, for a hooker.
column2: I'm not a hooker!  That's my cover.

column1: The first settlers are buried here. They worked themselves to death, but Cohaagen ended up with all the money. He built cheap domes and watched their kids turn into freaks.
column2: I saw them.

column1: What can I do?
column2: Kuato's gonna make you remember a few things you knew when you were Hauser.

column1: Like what?
column2: All sorts of things.  You might even remember you loved me.

column1: I don't need Kuato for that.
column2: Oh, since when?

column1: He's lying.
column2: You two-faced-bastard.

column1: Are you all right?  Are you still you?
column2: I'm not sure dear?  What do you think?

column1: Where are you going?!
column2: The reactor.
