column1: What reactor?!
column2: The one in the mine!

column1: Where's this "reactor" come from?
column2: Aliens built it.

column1: You sure about this?
column2: It's just up ahead.

column1: Cohaagen knows it makes air.  But the bastard won't turn it on.
column2: Of course not.  If Mars had an atmosphere, he's lose control.

column1: The whole core of Mars is ice.  The reactor melts it and releases oxygen.
column2: Enough for everybody to breathe?

column1: What's wrong?
column2: I just has a terrible thought...What is this is all a dream?

column1: This is the suitcase you gave me.
column2: I gave you?

column1: Wait!
column2: What?

column1: ...Who are you?
column2: We were buddies in the Agency back on Mars.  You asked me to find you if you disappeared.  So here I am, good-bye.

column1: Looks almost cold now, don't it?
column2: That won't start no more fires.  We might's well go home.

column1: Yeah.  No sense stayin' out here.
column2: Let's go.

column1: It's an enemy sneak attack.  Let's get outta here!
column2: Wait a minute - wait a minute!.... Bombs don't unscrew.

column1: It's no meteor, that's for sure!
column2: Darnedest thing I ever saw - the way that's unscrewing!

column1: We'd be the first to make contact with 'em -- see?
column2: We'd be in all the papers!

column1: Hey, how about that!
column2: We could show 'em we're friendly, huh?  Walk out there with a white flag!  Here - I got an old sugar sack in my car!

column1: Hey, there - open up!
column2: Come on out!  We're friends!

column1: That explains why communication is cut the moment their machines begin to move.
column2: Madrid has just blacked out!! Nothing more coming through.

column1: Mister Secretary - if they link up with those others near Fresno...
column2: All right - I've seen enough!

column1: There's only one thing that will stop the Martians!  We've held back pre- viously because of the danger of radiation to civilians.  Now there's no choice.  The United Nations has voted authority to the United States.  The White House will confirm an order to use the Atom bomb.
column2: Then our first target will be the initial landing place outside Los Angeles.

column1: Hey, you!  Better get outa here!
column2: I'm looking for some Pacific-Tech professors...

column1: There's nobody left around here now.
column2: We had a chance...We could have stopped them!  The mob stole the trucks and smashed everything up.  The fools!  They cut their own throats!

column1: Hurry up!  Jump in!
column2: There was a girl with them...If I could find her....

column1: You look kinda lost yourself.
column2: But I think I know where she'll be....

column1: Is that it over there?
column2: Yes...ugly looking, isn't it.

column1: Did you see it come down?
column2: Yes...I was fishing up in the hills.

column1: You must have caught plenty with all that tackle!
column2: Oh - there were three of us.  The others flew back in my plane.  I don't understand why a meteor this size didn't make a bigger crater.

column1: What's that fellow over there trying to do - dig it out?
column2: He's top man in astro and nuclear physics.  He knows all about meteors!

column1: You seem to know a lot about him.
column2: Well, I did a thesis on modern scien- tists - working for my Masters degree.

column1: Did it do you any good?
column2: Why, sure -- I got it!  Do you have a match?

column1: I'm sorry.  I don't smoke.
column2: Forrester's the man behind the new atomic engines.  They had him on the cover of 'Time'.  You've got to rate to get that!

column1: Aw, he isn't that good...!
column2: How can you say that when you don't know him!

column1: I do know him...slightly.
column2: What's he like?

column1: Well, you certainly don't look like yourself in that get-up!  But I am happy to meet you anyway. I'm Sylvia Van Buren.  I teach Library Science over at USC.
column2: I didn't know how to stop you...!

column1: I might have recognized you without the beard.  And you didn't wear glasses on the 'Time' cover!
column2: They're really for long distance. When I want to look at something close...  I take them off.

column1: They've all stopped at the same time.
column2: There's only about one explanation for a thing like this..Got a pin?

column1: How does it happen cars are running?
column2: Automobile ignitions are insulated.

column1: The troops are certainly moving in here!
column2: Didn't you have something to do with this?  I know you sent word to the Sixth Army Command!

column1: I just told them the local situation. Colonel Heffner's in full charge now.
column2: You never know where you're going to wind up when you go to a square dance!

column1: Good to see you, General.  This is Pastor Collins, director of Civil Defense.  Sheriff Bogany, head of the local forces ... Miss Van Buren.
column2: Would you like some coffee, General?

column1: We can't go into town - everybody's getting out of there!  I'll fly you over to Pasadena.
column2: Can you handle one of these?

column1: You'll hit something!  Can't you go higher?
column2: No.  The air's going to be full of Jets in a minute...And there they are!

column1: I never noticed before - that's a cowboy tie....
column2: I bought it for the square dance. I thought I ought to wear some- thing Western.

column1: Is that... machine...?
column2: It's gone now.

column1: Where are we?
column2: Southwest of Corona, somewhere. There must have been another cylinder down here.  They've been through this whole area and cleared everybody out.  There's a farmhouse.  Let's see if we can find something to eat...!

column1: I almost forget when I ate last.  It looks so good.... You know, mostly I get my meals in coffee shops and restaurants.
column2: Don't you live at home?

column1: No, on the campus.  I haven't any family.
column2: I come from a big one.  Nine of us. All in Minnesota, except me.

column1: A big family must be fun...I imagine it makes you feel you belong to something.
column2: It does...Maybe that's why I feel kind of lost right now.

column1: We'll get safely out of here, don't worry.
column2: But they seem to murder everything that moves...!

column1: I've been as close to them as anyone. But not close enough for real observation...
column2: I feel like I did one time when I was small.  Awful scared and lonesome...I'd wandered off - I've forgotten why - but the family and whole crowds of neighbors were hunting for me.  They found me in a church.  I was afraid to go in any place else.

column1: I stayed right by the door - praying for the one who loved me best to come and find me.  It was Uncle Matthew who found me.
column2: I liked him.

column1: He liked you ... I could bawl my head off!
column2: But you're not going to.  You're not the kind.  You're tired, anyway.  You've been up all night.  You cracked up in a plane.  Slept in a ditch.  But you want to know something?  It doesn't show on you at all.

column1: How long was I out?
column2: Hours.  I've been so scared...!

column1: Nothing there now.
column2: It was...  ...one of them!

column1: What was it like?
column2: I couldn't see much in the dark - but it was one!

column1: Maybe they aren't too sure we're here.
column2: They could be as curious about us as we are about them.

column1: They've blocked it!
column2: It's blocked here, too!  They've pushed up earth or something all around outside.  Here, this way...!

column1: Is it possible to go in right after the explosion?
column2: Yes, with these suits.  We've used them before on atomic tests... Odd- looking, aren't they?

column1: Very futuristic.  Yours doesn't really go with that butch haircut!
column2: I could wear it longer -- but it's less trouble this way.

column1: My kid brother has one.  You know why?
column2: Yes ...  Fits better in a football helmet.

column1: How'd you guess?
column2: That's the kind of a kid brother you'd have!

column1: The Rockies...!  You'd rather get back to that big family of yours in Minnesota, wouldn't you?
column2: I wonder if they're going through this too...?

column1: I probably wouldn't be able to get to them if I tried...
column2: You'll be all right with us....  ...for as long as anybody's got!

column1: That's what knocked the phones out, too.
column2: How could it happen to everybody's watch together?

column1: That needle ain't pointing north!
column2: It's pointing out to the gully - where that meteor came down.

column1: What is that gizmo?!
column2: I think that - gizmo - is a machine from another planet.

column1: This Martian blood...  Let's make a quick analysis and see what we've got!
column2: It might give us something.

column1: A forlorn hope - but there is a chance.
column2: It might give us time to search out some weakness in the Martians.

column1: We know now that we can't beat their machines -- but we can beat them!  They are mortal beings...The only question is whether we have time enough to do anything!
column2: If we get what transportation we can, and pick up instruments and books from Pacific-Tech...

column1: Gratzman! -- Gratzman!  Did you get those biotics?
column2: No.  I thought you had them.

column1: I got a message for you.  You're the guys from Pacific-Tech, ain't you?
column2: Right.

column1: It's about that meteor.  They say it's a whopper.  The District Officer phoned us at the lookout up on the summit. Thought you might be interested... It's ten or twelve miles from here - over by Linda Rosa.
column2: Are they sure it's a meteor?  It didn't come down like one.

column1: That's right - came down in kinda spurts, didn't it?  You fellers'll have to figure it out.  You're scientists  All I know - they say it's as big as a house and practically red hot.
column2: I'd like to borrow your car and take a look at it in the morning.

column1: There's one - there's the other, and we're right between them!
column2: So is the town, I notice!

column1: I warned you Civil Defense people to be ready if you have to evacuate.
column2: I just came to tell you - everyone has been alerted.

column1: Colonel - shooting's no good!
column2: It's always been a good persuader.

column1: General Mann -- I was told to expect you, sir.  I'm Colonel Heffner.
column2: I'm here to make up a report, not to interfere with the operations you've set up.  You're still in command.  Clayton Forrester!  I haven't seen you since Oak Ridge.

column1: That's their position?  You've certainly got them surrounded.  I suppose they've neutralized all communications here.
column2: Not all.  Radio is out.  But our field phones are okay so far.

column1: We will, sir!
column2: From the data - and from that picture the Air Force took earlier tonight ...  ... what we've got in the gully out there is a guide ship.  One lands ... Others follow later.  They appear to clear an area, then drop in groups of threes, joined magnetically.  Is that possible?

column1: My orders are not to go into action unless they make a move out of there.
column2: That's because we want a chance to observe them.  This is the only place we've had time to surround them with sufficient force to contain them.  What happens here will be a guide to all other operations. The minute action begins and a pattern of defense develops, I'll get my report to Washington.  You've deployed your forces well.

column1: Thank you, sir.  If they start anything, we can blast them right off the earth!
column2: They'll probably move at dawn.

column1: That probably dropped half way to Pomona!...What do you think?
column2: It was nearer than that.

column1: Uncle Matthew...this is Dr. Clayton Forrester.  My uncle - Dr. Matthew Collins, pastor of the Community Church.
column2: Well-l...how do you do, Dr. Forrester!

column1: They don't do much of anything...!
column2: There's a square dance at the social hall this evening.

column1: They are living creatures out there.
column2: But they're not human!  Dr. Forrester says they're some kind of an advanced civilization --

column1: Let's go back inside, Uncle Matthew.
column2: I've done about all I can do here. You go back in.  Sylvia - I like that Doctor Forrester.  He's a good man.

column1: Number three to. D.O....Number three to D.O.
column2: D.O. to number three..come in.

column1: We're getting this under control. Won't need any more help.  Over.
column2: Okay.  Send the tanker in, but you stand by until that thing cools off. Over.

column1: I think somebody ought to check on it. Over.
column2: Well, there's some fellows fishing at Pine Summit might be interested.  They probably saw it come down.  I'll let 'em know...What's it look like?

column1: Better'n a lion farm or a snake pit. We won't have to feed it!
column2: We sell the tamales, enchiladas - hot dogs!

column1: Must be somebody in there.
column2: Who?  Where d'you think they come from!

column1: Maybe these are not men - not like us.
column2: Everything human don't have to look like you and me....

column1: What'll we say to 'em?
column2: Welcome to California!

column1: They'll understand us, all right!
column2: Sure, sure!  Everybody understands you wave the white flag, you wanna be friends.

column1: Goddamnit!  D'you tell him we need it right now?
column2: I told him we had to get the umbilical unhooked ASAP.

column1: This ain't no drill, slick.  Make me proud.
column2: Piece of cake, baby.

column1: Right through the brainpan.  Deader'n dogshit, boss.
column2: Where're you?

column1: Gimme a three-eighths socket on a long extension.  So there you were--
column2: There we were, side by side, on the same ship, for two months.  I'm tool-pusher and we're testing this automated derrick of hers.  So, we get back on the beach and... we're living together.

column1: Doesn't mean you had to marry her.
column2: We were due to go back out on the same ship. Six months of tests.  If you were married you got a state-room.  Otherwise it was bunks.

column1: Okay, good reason.  Then what?
column2: It was alright for a while, you know.  But then she got promoted to project engineer on this thing, couple years ago.

column1: She went front-office on you.  Tighten that for me, right there.  That's it.
column2: Well, you know Lindsey, too damn aggressive-- Son of a--!!

column1: You done impressing yourself, ace?
column2: No way that could just be seawater.

column1: She-hit.
column2: We're being asked to cooperate in a matter of national security.  Now you know exactly as much as I do.  So just get your gear off and get up to control.  There's some kind of briefing in ten minutes.

column1: How you guys doing?
column2: I'm alright, I'm dealing.

column1: You got it?!  You got it?
column2: Yeah, yeah... yeah.  It's turning.

column1: Benthic Explorer, Benthic Explorer.  Do you read, over?  This is Deepcore--
column2: Forget it, Sonny.  They're gone.

column1: Nice shot, Lins.
column2: What is that?  You drop your dive light?

column1: Bud!  Hippy's on the bitch-box.  It's a call from topside.  That new company man.
column2: Kirkhill?  That guy doesn't know his butt from a rathole.  Hey, Perry!

column1: What's goin' on, Boss?
column2: Folks, I've just been told to shut down the hole and prepare to move the rig.

column1: Okay so far.
column2: How deep's the drop-off here?

column1: Where are we?
column2: Missile compartment.  Those are the launch tubes.

column1: Lord Almighty.
column2: Hey, you okay?

column1: Deep and slow, big guy.  Deep and slow.  Just breathe easy.
column2: I... they're all dead, Bud.  They're all dead. I thought... some of them... you know...

column1: I'm taking you back out.
column2: No!  I'm okay now.  I just don't... I can't go any further in.

column1: Okay, Jammer.  No problem.  You stay right here. I have to go there to the end... you'll see my lights.  We'll stay in voice contact.  Just hold onto the rope.  Five more minutes.  Okay?
column2: Yeah, okay.  Okay.

column1: Thanks.  How you feeling, big guy?
column2: Figured I was dead, there, when I seen that angel comin' toward me.

column1: I can't believe you let them do this!
column2: Hi, Lins.  I thought you were in Houston.

column1: I was, but I managed to bum a ride on the last flight out here.  Only here isn't where I left it, is it, Bud?
column2: Wasn't up to me.

column1: We were that close to proving a submersible drilling platform could work.  We had over seven thousand feet of hole down for Chrissake.  I can't believe you let them grab my rig!
column2: Your rig?

column1: My rig.  I designed the damn thing.
column2: Yup, a Benthic Petroleum paid for it.  So as long as they're hold the pink slip, I go where they tell me.

column1: You wimp.  I had a lot riding on this.  They bought you... more like least rented you cheap--
column2: I'm switching off now.

column1: Well, well.  Mrs. Brigman.
column2: Not for long.

column1: You never did like being called that, did you?
column2: Not even when it meant something.  Is that One Night up in Flatbed?

column1: I can't believe you were dumb enough to come down.  Now you're stuck here for the storm... dumb, hot-rod... dumb.
column2: Look, I didn't come down here to fight.

column1: You need me.  Nobody knows the systems on this rig better than I do.  What is something was to go wrong after the Explorer clears off?  What would have you done?
column2: Wow, you're right!  Us poor dumb ol' boys might've had to think for ourselves.  Coulda been a disaster.

column1: You wanna know what I think?
column2: Not particularly.  Jeez, look where this is set! Morons.

column1: I think you were worried about me.
column2: That must be it.

column1: No, I think you were.  Come on, admit it.
column2: I was worried about the rig.  I've got over four years invested in this project.

column1: What are you still wearing that for?
column2: I don't know.  Divorce ain't final.  Forgot to take it off.

column1: I haven't worn mine in months.
column2: Yeah, what's-his-name wouldn't like it.  The Suit.

column1: So what about "Michael" then... Mr. Brooks Brothers... Mr. BMW.  You still seeing him?
column2: No, I haven't seen him in a few weeks.

column1: What happened?
column2: Bud, why are you doing this?  It's not part of you life any more.

column1: I'll tell you what happened... you woke up one day and realized the guy never made you laugh.
column2: You're right, Bud.  It was just that simple. Aren't you clever?  You should get your own show... Ask Dr. Bud, advice to the lovelorn from three hundred fathoms.

column1: Did you get anything on the cameras.  Video or anything?
column2: No.  Look, forget it.  I don't want to talk about it.

column1: Fine.  Be that way.
column2: I don't know what I saw.  Okay?  Coffey wants to call it a Russian submersible, fine.  It's a Russian submersible.  No problem.

column1: But you think it's something else.  What?  One of ours?
column2: No.

column1: Jammer saw something in there, something that scared the hell out him--
column2: His mixture got screwed up.  He panicked and pranged his regulator.

column1: But what did he see that made him panic?
column2: What do you think he saw?

column1: Hippy, just relax.  You're making the women nervous.
column2: Cute, Virgil.

column1: What's the scoop, ace?
column2: I can get power to this module and sub-bay if I remote these busses.  I've gotta get past the mains, which are a total melt-down.

column1: Need some help?
column2: Thanks.  No, I can handle it.  Bud... there won't be enough to run the heaters.  In a couple hours this place is going to be as cold as a meat locker.

column1: What about O-2?
column2: Brace yourself.  We've got about 12 hours worth if we close off the sections we're not using.

column1: The storm's gonna last longer than 12 hours.
column2: I can extend that.  There's some storage tanks outboard on the wrecked module.  I'll have to go outside to tie onto them.

column1: Hey, Lins...  I'm glad your here.
column2: Yeah?  Well I'm not.

column1: Come on, you guys... look, this is the little one right here.  You can see how it's kind of zigging around.
column2: If you say so.  It could be anything.

column1: Jesus, Lindsey--
column2: Bud, something really important is happening here.

column1: Look.  I'm just trying to hold this situation together.  I can't allow you to cause this kind of hysteria--
column2: Who's hysterical?  Nobody's hysterical!

column1: All I'm saying is when you're hanging on by your fingernails, you don't go waving you arms around.
column2: I saw something!  I'm not going to go back there and say I didn't see it when I did.  I'm sorry.

column1: God, you are the most stubborn woman I ever knew.
column2: I need you to believe me, Bud.  Look at me.  Do I seem stressed out?  Any of the symptoms of pressure sickness, any tremors, slurred speech?

column1: No.
column2: Bud, this is me, Lindsey.  Okay?  You know me better than anybody in the world.  Now watch my lips... I saw these things.  I touched one of them.  And it wasn't some clunky steel can like we would build... it glided.  It was the most beautiful thing I've ever seen.

column1: It was a machine, but it seems almost alive. Like a... dance of light.  Bud, you have to trust me... please.  I don't think they mean us harm.  I don't know how I know that, it's just a feeling.
column2: How can I go on a feeling?  You think Coffey's going to go on you 'feeling'?

column1: Look, goddamnit, if you won't do something about it, I will.
column2: Lindsey!  Wait a second--

column1: You dumb jarhead motherf--
column2: Chill out, Lindsey!!

column1: He's got the shakes?
column2: Look, the guy's operating on his own, cut off from chain of command.  He's exhibiting symptoms of pressure-induced psychosis.  And he's got a nuclear weapon.  So, as a personal favor to me... will you put your tongue in neutral for a while?

column1: I think it likes you.
column2: It's trying to communicate.

column1: They must've learned how to control water... I mean at a molecular level.  They can plasticize it, polymerize it... whatever.  Put it under intelligent control.
column2: Maybe their whole technology is based on that. Controlling water.

column1: He's jammed the mechanism.
column2: Now what?

column1: Okay, I'm gonna free-swim to hatch six... get inside, get the door open from the other side.
column2: Bud, that water's only a couple degrees above freezing.

column1: You owe me one, Virgil.
column2: Can we negotiate later?  There's Big Geek.

column1: You did okay, back there.  I was fairly impressed.
column2: Not good enough.  We still gotta catch Big Geek.

column1: You totaled it, huh?
column2: Yeah.  So sue me.

column1: It's flooding like a son of the bitch.
column2: You noticed.

column1: Try again.
column2: Deepcore, this is Cab One.  We need assistance, over.  Deepcore, this--

column1: Well, that's that.
column2: Wonderful.  There's some light from somewhere...

column1: Good hundred yards, I'd say.
column2: They'll come out after us.

column1: You see where it's coming in?
column2: Somewhere behind this panel.  Hold this.

column1: Can't get to it.  Have to pull this panel off. You go any tools?
column2: I don't know, look around.

column1: Son of a bitch!
column2: Calm down, Bud.

column1: Okay... okay.  We gotta get you out of here.
column2: How?

column1: I don't know how!
column2: We've only got one suit.

column1: I know!  I know!  But we better come up with something.
column2: Aaargh!!  I'm freezing!

column1: Okay, look, you swim to the rig and come back with another suit.
column2: Seven, eight minute swim each way... not enough time.  Look at this...  Time I get back you'll be--

column1: Alright, put this on.
column2: What, you growing gills all of a sudden?  You got it on, keep it on.

column1: Don't argue, goddamnit, just--
column2: No way!  Forget it.  Not an option.

column1: Lindsey, just put the thing on and shut up--
column2: NO!!  Now be logical, Bud, you're--

column1: Listen... will you listen to me for a second!? You're for the suit on and you're a better swimmer than me.  Right?  So I got a plan...
column2: What's the plan?

column1: I drown, you tow me back to the rig--
column2: WHAT KIND OF PLAN IS THAT!??

column1: It is insane.
column2: It's the only way, Bud.  Now trust me.

column1: Oh God, Lins... I--
column2: Tell me later.

column1: Hey... big boys don't cry, remember?
column2: Hi, lady.

column1: Hi, tough guy.  I guess it worked, huh?
column2: 'Course is worked.  You're never wrong, are you? How d'you feel.

column1: No, Bud, no... not you.
column2: Who then?

column1: Hello, Brigman.
column2: Hello, Mrs. Brigman.

column1: We'll take reading as we go.  If the reactor's breached or the warheads have released radioactive debris, we'll back away.  Simple.
column2: Okay... Hippy's not going... McWhirter, you can run Little Geek.

column1: Okay, I'm out of here!

column1: See that sheathing on the suspension? Eaten away.  Same thing with the pumps on the base air purifiers.  The algae out here just isn't good on these new plastics.
column2: We haven't used Big Bertha since we relocated the generator module. That was four months ago.  I can't ask for them to keep bringing spares in on the shuttle, it's already costing too much as it is.

column1: Hey, boss.  Wondered where you'd gotten to.
column2: I just... wanted to be put on my own for a while.  Clear my head.

column1: I've got a lot of thinking to do.  'Sides, the room was getting too crowded for me.
column2: Not too much of the socializing type, then?

column1: I'm serious.  That's why I switched from orbiting to planetary installations.
column2: Is that a fact.

column1: Uh-huh.  Used to get it pretty bad.  I'd wake up in a cold sweat and want to claw open a vacuum hatch.
column2: How long you been out here for now, anyway?  Three months?

column1: Four.
column2: And before that?

column1: Six month stint on Datus.
column2: Only six?

column1: What is this?  'Twenty Questions'?
column2: Just curious.  There's a lot of talk goes around.

column1: What is that?
column2: Real man' drink.

column1: Seltzer?
column2: Want some?

column1: Any luck raising Ackland's party?
column2: Nothing.  With the satellite down, we can't transmit over the mountain range. He's most likely sitting there wondering why he can't raise us.

column1: First light, we'll take a chopper out there and tell them to head back.
column2: 'We'?  You wanna fly out there with me?

column1: Don't worry about it.  If the Network goes by the book, like everyone figures they will, a Marine gunboat from Powell'll drop-by for a look- see in four-or-five days.  They can go poke around out there and find whatever it was hit us.  All we've gotta do is sit tight.
column2: Do you think Ackland'll sit tight?

column1: Yeah.  Somebody won.
column2: Check out the tent.

column1: I've found Ackland!
column2: Hold on...

column1: I'm going to need you to co-sign the report.  Until we come up with something, this'll be treated as first degree murder.
column2: Agreed.

column1: When we get the link back, and I send this in, I.C.C.'ll throw a fit.
column2: Ah, don't worry about I.C.C.  They're the least of your problems right now.

column1: Think I spoke too soon...
column2: Again?  How long before we start noticing the difference?

column1: Do you believe him?
column2: Ackland?  I don't know him well enough to say.  If we were back on Earth we could run him though an Aldhoven test and find out for sure. There's not much we can do out here.

column1: Cornering it shouldn't be a problem.  Each part of this station is basically a self-sufficient deep-space transport module running off external couplers.  If we disconnect them and seal off every section, we've got a ceiling of about thirty-six hours on internal power.  That should give us ample time to find it.
column2: Alright.  Pull some trackers and headsets out of stores, and I'll sign a release for the weapons.  Cassie, organise a team roster and put it on the board.

column1: So, what do you think?
column2: What do I think?  I think if those Marines from Powell don't shift their butts getting here, we're gonna get caught up to our necks in the middle of something we shouldn't.

column1: What?
column2: I'm out of ammo.  Get inside, get inside!

column1: That's the wrong way!
column2: Detour.  Other way's blocked...

column1: Hurry it up.
column2: Don't wait for me!

column1: They...they snapped my legs to fit... fit me in here.  I don't...remember what happened next.
column2: What can I do?

column1: I can... feel it moving around inside me. You've got to kill me.
column2: I... I can't!

column1: You have to...
column2: No!

column1: Where'd you leave them?
column2: Camped out by the navi-beacon out on Linson's Range.  They're making their own way back tomorrow.

column1: Jesus.
column2: Yeah, exactly.  Those're pre-programmed course adjustments you're looking at.

column1: How's it going?
column2: Yeah, 'Good Evening' to you, too.

column1: Today's party's finished their sweep, the relief team's out there now. Everybody else is either asleep or running shift in the auto-shop.
column2: You should hit the sack, too.

column1: Nah, I'll stick it out for another hour or so.
column2: What time's sundown?

column1: 'Bout five minutes.
column2: Give me a yell is something happens.

column1: Well, well, he smirked when Marty opened the door. If it isn't the neighborhood bootlegger, Al Capone McFly?
column2: What do you want, Biff?

column1: Show me some respect, you little asshole. It's Special Officer Tannen to you.
column2: The day I show respect to Biff Tannen will be the day I win a million dollars... What's the matter, Biff, they're not showing you any respect down at the golf course? Don't they realize what a tough job it is keeping the criminal element away from the country club?

column1: Listen you little Asshole, I oughta --
column2: What do you want, Biff?

column1: This... is the number one single?
column2: Yes, sir!

column1: I don't get it. How come there's no rock 'n roll?
column2: I beg your pardon?

column1: This is 1952....?
column2: Uh, yes, sir...

column1: And you never heard of rock 'n roll?
Morning Dick.
column2: Marty. What's for breakfast?

column1: Hot tip,  Rubber Biscuit in the third race at Arlington.
column2: Dick, what's with those guys out there in the gutter?

column1: What's N.R.C.?
column2: I don't know. National Cash Register?

column1: I've been calling you for five minutes! Didn't you hear me?
column2: I was practicing. I've got an audition next week -- I gotta practice. How am I gonna get famous if I don't practice?

column1: How was school today?
column2: Fine.

column1: Learn anything?
column2: Oh yeah.

column1: You mean you're going to stay up all night?
column2: Mom, how else are we gonna see the sunrise?

column1: How old are you?
column2: Seventeen.

column1: Here's your jacket!
column2: Uh, thanks...

column1: It's polyester.
column2: Poly-what?

column1: Huh?
column2: Have we ever met before?

column1: Hi, Marty.
column2: Uh, hi....

column1: You remember me...?
column2: How could I forget?  Oh, sure, I remember you.

column1: Well, I was on my way to school, and I just wanted to stop by and see if you were feeling okay.  You seemed like you were in pretty bad shape the other night.
column2: Oh, I'm feeling much better now.

column1: Then you'll be going to school here....?
column2: School? I never thought of school! If I went to school I could blend in with everybody else, couldn't I?

column1: What time does school start around here?
column2: Nine o' clock.  Oh, I'm late! Maybe I'll see you later.

column1: George! He's supposed to ask you to the dance!
column2: But he didn't ask me.

column1: He comes out of the cafeteria line, he's nervous, he spills his corn, and he asks you to the dance!
column2: Marty, you haven't been listening. Nobody's asked me to the dance...yet.

column1: Hi, Marty!
column2: Listen,  Professor Brown told me you called last night and gave me your message...

column1: Are you all right, Marty? You seem a little...nervous.
column2: Oh, no, I'm fine...fine.

column1: I'm usually nervous myself on first dates...but not tonight. It's funny, but somehow, I feel like....like I know you.
column2: Uh, yeah, well, believe me, I sure feel like I know you!

column1: Well, Eileen...jeez, that's hard for me to say. Have you ever been in a situation where -- well -- you know you have to act a certain way, but when you get there, you don't know if you can go through with it?
column2: You mean like how you're supposed to act with someone on a first date?

column1: I think I know exactly what you mean.
column2: You do?

column1: Now, George! Dinner's ready now!
column2: Coming, Eileen...

column1: By the way, that reminds me...  Saturday night we're taking Grandma Stella out for Chinese food.
column2: Eileen, Chinese food again?

column1: Is that what you were going to ask me, George? To go to the dance?
column2: No!

column1: Uh, hi, Eileen.
column2: How are you?

column1: Dad, you seen the drill?
column2: What drill?

column1: Fine..
column2: Learn anything?

column1: Oh yeah.
column2: Good.

column1: No, Chinese food is fine.
column2: Saturday night's the 'Springtime in Paris' dance. I'm taking Suzy Parker.

column1: The sunrise? What for?
column2: Jeez, what do you think? To see it!

column1: You've gotta ask her to the dance!
column2: Not now....

column1: George, she's beautiful, right? She's nice, she's decent, she's the kind of girl you'd like to marry, right? And there's nothing in the world you'd like more than to take her to that dance, right?
column2: Well... yeah...

column1: What do I say?
column2: Say what you were supposed to say in the cafeteria.

column1: Oh, no! That was for the cafeteria! This is different!
column2: Christ, it's a miracle I was even born!

column1: Huh?
column2: Nothing. Look, I'll write it down for you, okay?

column1: What is that? A pencil that writes in ink?
column2: It was Marty's turn to be confused. Huh?

column1: 'Bike fine point?'
column2: Bic... It's a Bic pen.

column1: I don't want to hit you in the stomach!
column2: You're not gonna hurt me. Just hit me in the stomach.

column1: How many times do I have to explain it to you?... We know you're not a fighter. You know it, I know it... but she doesn't know it. That's why we gotta make you look like a fighter, somebody who'll stand up for her, somebody who isn't chicken. And you're not gonna look like a fighter if you can't hit me in the stomach.
column2: But I've never picked a fight in my entire life!

column1: You're not picking a fight, you're coming to her rescue. Maybe we'd better go over the plan again. Where are you gonna be at 8:55?
column2: I'm going to be at the dance.

column1: And where am I gonna be?
column2: In the parking lot, with her.

column1: Okay. So right around 9:00 she's gonna get very angry with me -
column2: Why?

column1: Why what?
column2: Why is she gonna get angry with you?

column1: You mean, you're gonna --
column2: George it's not your concern. Don't worry about it. Just remember that at 9:00, you'll be strolling through the parking lot and you'll see us -- struggling in the car, you'll run over, open the door and say....?

column1: Your line, George!
column2: Oh. Uh... 'Hey, you! Get your damn hands off her!'  George paused. You really think I should swear?

column1: Maybe if I used my left....
column2: No, George, just concentrate on the anger. Anger.

column1: You'd like to see a nuclear holocaust?
column2: Not a holocaust --

column1: You know damn well that's not what I meant.
column2: All I can say is, that's one helluva attitude, Mr. McFly. 'Let's explode a hundred megaton Geothermal nuclear device, just to see it.'

column1: Yeah, explode it up your ass!
column2: Unfortunately, the way things are going, you may get your wish. You may see the entire annhiliation of the world. If not, you'll certainly see the destruction of all out natural resources. We can already see the air we breathe, not to mention the pollution in our rivers and lakes. We'll  see all of our oil reserves depleted, in fact, all of our energy sources. Yes, you people have a lot to look forward to -- a lot to see.

column1: Yes, that's my name. Who are you, young man? Are you supposed to be here?
column2: Uh -- yeah. I'm new here, and I'm supposed to be in this class.

column1: You have a name?
column2: Marty. Marty Lewis.

column1: Who, me?
column2: You're the only Mr. Lewis in this class.  If you have something to say, say it so the whole class can hear.

column1: Well, yeah, I was thinking, if cars are gonna be going two or three hundred miles an hour, they're gonna be using an awful lot of gas. Like, what if we run out?
column2: Run out of gas?

column1: Operator...
column2: Operator! Listen, this is an emergency! I have to make this call, but I don't have a dime -- all I got is a nickel -- but you gotta connect me --

column1: Sir, it only costs a nickel.
column2: What?

column1: Oh -- right! Uh, Madison 3489.
column2: Five cents, please.

column1: I'm sorry, there's no answer.
column2: Operator, what's today's date?

column1: March 11th.
column2: What year?

column1: Good evening, one said. Agents Reese   and Foley, from the Nuclear Regulatory Commition.  Mind stepping over here?
column2: What's this all about?

column1: What, am I radioactive or something?
column2: No, no, not beyond an acceptable level. Have you been X-rayed recently, Martin?

column1: Been any place unusual in the past twelve hours?
column2: Home, school, here...

column1: Okay, Martin. You have a good evening now.
column2: Yeah,  Right.

column1: What?!
column2: Pro! Release the rope!

column1: Professor Brown! It's almost eight thirty -- I'm outta here!
column2: Shhhhhhhh!

column1: The power of a million hydrogen bombs!  ...and we get twenty four measly volts. It's not fair! I've been working on this power converter since 1949, and you'd think in all that time, I could find the right chemicals that would efficiently convert radiation into electric energy! But no! Thirty three years of dedication and research, and all I've got to show for it is a bootleg video operation!
column2: That reminds me, if we could scrape up enough for a 35 film chain, I've got a connection with a projectionist in a first run house -- we could be sellin' new movies on the street before they're even in the theater.

column1: Did you ever consider that some doors are locked for a reason?
column2: Nope. The way I figure it, doors are made to be opened. See you after school.

column1: Eight thirty.
column2: AM or PM?

column1: Pro, the sun's out!
column2: Oh, right, right...

column1: Catch you later!
column2: ...To be traveled through

column1: But Professor --
column2: Get behind the shield! I'm about to release radiation!

column1: No, Marty. Shemp's molecular structure is completely intact!
column2: Then where the hell is he?

column1: The appropriate question to ask is when the hell is he! You see, Shemp has just become the world's first time traveller. I've sent Shemp into the future -- two minutes into the future to be exact.
column2: The future? What are you talking about? Where's Shemp?!

column1: Shemp is right here in this room...two minutes from now, and at exactly 9:02PM, we'll catch up to him.
column2: Now hold on a minute, Professor! Hold the phone. Are you trying to tell me that this -- all of this here -- that this is -- it's a -- a --

column1: A time machine! Because of that Coke?!
column2: Precisely!

column1: The plutonium! That's what I came over here for! Professor, where did you get that stuff?
column2: Why?

column1: Exactly two minutes difference...  and it's still ticking!
column2: Is Shemp all right?

column1: Of course. Shemp is unaware that anything even happened, other than his stool suddenly falling over. We had to wait two minutes to catch up to him, but for Shemp the trip was instantaneous.
column2: Professor, can this thing send Shemp back in time?

column1: A gold mine?
column2: Sure! Listen -- we take the racing results from today's paper...

column1: Marty, that would alter history.
column2: So what? We'd be rich!

column1: All I know is you're throwing away an awful lot of money.
column2: The future, Marty, the future is everything! I built this machine to see the future. So I am going to send Shemp twenty-four hours into the future. You can assist me, if you like.

column1: Professor? Professor Brown?
column2: You know me?

column1: Professor, you time machine works! It works! It sent me back in time! I'm from 1982!
column2: Ssshhhhh!

column1: He will be. Simple inebriation, is all. The young man must have a rather low tolerance for alcohol... something that runs in the family. You see, he's a second cousin of mine on my mother's side. Came quite a distance to visit me, he added. His name's Lewis.
column2: Marty.

column1: Jeez -- this is where you used to live, huh? You must have been rich!
column2: Must have been? Used to live? I do live here.

column1: Well, there's a mall here now -- I mean, there will be.
column2: A mall?

column1: You've convinced me that you must be who you say you are. No living human has ever seen this machine.  But why? Why even in my twilight years would I remotely consider sending someone back in time?
column2: You didn't, Professor. It was an accident! You see, what happened --

column1: Pardon me?
column2: Oh. That expression probably hasn't been invented yet... I can get behind -- I agree with you.

column1: On second thought, there may be some things you'll have to tell me.
column2: The power converter...

column1: Well, Professor, are you sure you want me to tell you? You know, changing the course of history and all....
column2: Blast it -- no, I suppose you're right.... You do know the proper chemical formula?

column1: How did you know?
column2: Just a guess. I figured kids would still be drinking Coke in 1982.

column1: Professor. Well, not exactly, Professor. You see, we don't point it at the sun.
column2: We don't....

column1: 4200 rads...  That certainly can't be generated under controlled conditions in this day and age.
column2: That's just great!

column1: You answered the door!
column2: You were ringing the doorbell!

column1: I told you not to interfere with any of the events of this time! Nobody's supposed to see you here! What if I was a mailman? Or a salesman?
column2: What if you lost your keys?

column1: Then I would have figured out to get back in through the events in the natural course of history! Don't you understand? The fabric of history is very delicate. Anything you do could have serious consequences!
column2: Hey, look, gimme a break! All I did was answer the door! How's that gonna change history?

column1: Let me put it on a level you can understand. You don't belong here. You don't know anything about this world. You don't know the customs, you don't know how to talk, how to act -- you don't even look like you belong here. And if you walked out on the street, you wouldn't get 100 yards without being arrested. Then there would be questions, and where would we come up with the answers?
column2: Okay, Professor, I get where you're coming from. The way I look, the way I'm dressed...  I'd stick out like a sore thumb.

column1: An atomic bomb.
column2: Professor, be serious, would you?

column1: I am serious. If we could get you, the time machine, and the power converter in the vicinity of an atomic blast, we could send you back to the future.
column2: You're talking crazy! An atomic blast would melt me and the time machine in a matter of seconds!

column1: Say, where did this guitar come from?
column2: Oh -- that -- I found it in the closet.

column1: I don't recall ever seeing it before.
column2: Well, it was there.

column1: I know.
column2: You did what?!?

column1: Look, it's not a big deal! I can fix it! All I gotta do is get 'em together and make sure my old man asks her out!
column2: You better make sure your old man asks her out, because if he doesn't, they may never have a first date. And if they don't have a first date, they won't have a second date. If they don't have a second date, they won't fall in love. If they don't fall in love, they won't get married, and if they don't get married, you'll never be born!

column1: Where did you get this?
column2: I brought it with me from 1982. It's from my science book.

column1: The test is this Monday! 15 megatons... Let's see, we need 4200 rads...  You'd have to be...exactly 800 yards from ground zero... You realize that what we're going to do could be extremely dangerous.
column2: Believe me, Professor, running around on a nuclear test site can't be any more dangerous than what I've been doing.

column1: Your 'mother' wanted me to tell you that she was very impressed by what you did this afternoon, and that if you were interested in going to the dance Saturday, she's available.
column2: But that's impossible!! George asked her out! He had to! I saw him walk her home! Oh, God!

column1: My guess is that she turned him down.
column2: But why? Why would she do that? She's supposed to marry the guy!

column1: Apparently, what has happened is that the maternal instinct has transcended the gap of time and this has caused an alteration in your mother's emotional behavior.
column2: Are you trying to tell me that my mother's got the hots for me?

column1: In a manner of speaking, yes. And because of that, she's no longer interested in your father.
column2: Jesus!

column1: That's all taken care of.
column2: Good. Professor Brown tested the tarp, noting in satisfaction that it was secure. I'll pick you up in front of the school at midnight. Don't be late -- we're cutting it close as it is. We've got a long drive ahead of us.

column1: Look. I'm a little worried about this -- this whole thing with my mother, he admitted to the Professor. I mean, I don't know if I can do it -- I mean, hitting on my own mother, that's pretty heavy.
column2: Nobody said anything about hitting her! You're just going to take a few liberties with her.

column1: That's exactly what I said! I mean, a guy and his mother -- that's illegal, isn't it?
column2: Look, Marty, she's not your mother yet. And if you don't go through with this, she may never be. I know it's hard, but there are some things we must do in life that are unpleasant. Some choices must be made that are difficult. Nonetheless, we must make them. Besides, this may be more than a simple question of your own existence, he added. The fate of the entire space-time continuum may rest on your shoulders . Marty tried to smile at him.

column1: That's just what I needed to hear.
column2: It'll be fine, Marty.  You'll be fine. Good luck. He stuck his hand out and Marty shook it. But there was still a question that was nagging at him...

column1: There's no way of knowing.
column2: Perfect...

column1: You didn't?
column2: Nope. My father's never clenched a fist in his entire life!

column1: It was sure nice of Uncle Sam to put those yardage markers up for us.
column2: We're at one and a half miles, so you're just a little over a mile from where you want to be,  Wait until minus 3 minutes before you go -- that should give you plenty of time, and it should be close enough to zero hour that they can't do anything to stop you. Park the truck at 800 and get in the refri-- the time chamber. Just be sure the nose of the truck is pointed at the bomb....the power converter will do the rest.

column1: Thanks for everything, Pro.
column2: Professor Brown grinned. I guess I'll see you in... about 30 years.

column1: Marty,  I know I've repeatedly asked you not to tell me anything about the future, but....well, those loud bangs on the tape recorder....are they....
column2: Professor -- there are some doors that shouldn't be opened, Marty said softly, without turning around.

column1: What year is this?
column2: 1982! March 18, just like we planned! My calculations were absolutely correct! Thirty years! God, I cannot believe it's been thirty years! Sure, it was a long time ago -- longest I've ever had to wait for the results of an experiment!

column1: Hop in, Marty, . We've got a long drive ahead of us.
column2: What do you call this?

column1: You see, I never rebuilt the time machine after it was destroyed in 1952. I decided that experimenting with time and possibly changing history was too risky. Anyway, experiments in time travel were banned in all 87 states after the governor of Cuba caught Dr. Felstien fooling around in the Bermuda Triangle -- that was back in '64.
column2: 87 states? Time travel bans? What the hell?

column1: But if you didn't rebuild the time machine, how did I go back in time in the first place?
column2: According to your girlfriend, Suzy Parker, you and she were at the movies. You went to the restroom and you never came out. Obviously, you stepped through an inter-dimensional time warp, created by the original operation of the time machine.

column1: Obviously!
column2: But I told everyone your disappearance was due to a teleportation experiment you were helping me with. So don't mention anything about time travel to anyone.

column1: What theater was I at?
column2: The Orpheum.

column1: Pretty, isn't it?
column2: It's the most beautiful city I've ever seen! What is it?

column1: Uh, yeah... Gimme a Tab.
column2: What?

column1: Sweet and what?  Maybe you'd better pay for this first.
column2: Sure,.

column1: Look, maybe I'd better talk to Dick. Is he around?
column2: Dick? Dick who?

column1: Now who's being stupid? The guy who runs this place.
column2: I run this place!

column1: What happened to Dick Wilson?
column2: Dick Wilson? Dickie Wilson? Dickie Wilson runs this place? That's a laugh!

column1: ...He just lets himself get pushed around all the time! People walk all over him and he never fights back, never stands up for himself.
column2: No self confidence, I guess... At least you don't take after him.

column1: Can you imagine your parents in bed together?
column2: No way!

column1: Me neither. I've always wondered whether they slept together before they got married. You think yours did?
column2: Hell no! The way my mom carries on about sex -- you even mention the word and she goes into cardiac arrest. You shoulda seen her face when I told her we were gonna stay up all night Saturday, he added. Always afraid something is going to happen.

column1: Suzy!
column2: Hi, Marty!

column1: What did you do to your hair?
column2: What did you do to yours?

column1: So we'll help.  Let's get crackin'!
column2: Who're you?

column1: All these people applied for drivers' licenses in the same town in New Jersey on the exact same date.
column2: New Jersey?

column1: November 1, thirty days have September, April, June, and November...when short February's done, all the rest have thirty-one. October 31st!  Halloween!  Don't you get it?  Orson Welles!
column2: You mean the guy from the old wine commercials?

column1: Halloween. 1938..."War of the Worlds"...that fake radio news broadcast that got everybody scared, thinking that real live Martians were landing in Grover's Mill, New Jersey!  But then it all just turned out to be a hoax.
column2: Then that's it!

column1: Forgive the butterfingers, Buckaroo.  Casper Lindley, Knight of the Blue Shield, at your disposal.  And my son, Scooter.
column2: Nothing to apologize for, Casper.  You've gone beyond the call of duty tonight.  Mind if I get on the horn and radio the Cavaliers--?  They'll be worried.

column1: She gotta be kiddin', right? Vaporize the whole damn planet--?
column2: You wanna take the chance, Casper?

column1: Not me. No way.
column2: Rawhide, go find out how Professor Hikita's coming with that formula. Mrs. Johnson, take Casper and Scooter, gas up the Jet Car.

column1: There's another one we owe 'em.
column2: They're stealing my chopper!

column1: See 'em?  They about had me and the whole damn car for breakfast. Broke my windshield...
column2: The creatures?  They attacked you?  They tried to possess you?

column1: Smells fermented.  Check in with the Institute, Reno, see if everything's kosher.
column2: Buckaroo, I've done an advanced spectrograph analysis on the specimen you pulled off the Jet Car drive shaft.

column1: Rawhide tells me Dr. Lizardo escaped...
column2: I'm assigning a couple Blue Shields to protect you around the clock, just in case.

column1: We at the Banzai Institute have at last found that way: an alternating gradient synchronizer that softens solid matter by attenuating its electroweak forces!
column2: Which we all know are the forces that tend to pull objects part, right, professor?

column1: Buckaroo!  What the Sam Hill!
column2: Careful...don't make noise and don't touch me.  I'm hotter than flapjacks.

column1: What?
column2: I'm a giant semi-conductor, and there's alien creatures all around us. Form the Eighth Dimension, I think.  Look...

column1: Ever since that phony phone call from the President.  Look at this. What is it?
column2: It's your hand, Buckaroo.

column1: Antidote to what?  Whose disguises?
column2: Arachtoids.  From Planet Ten.

column1: Planet 10?
column2: There's a Harley behind those bushes.  Get back to the laboratory and start working on the formula.  We don't have time to ask questions. Just synthesize it-

column1: I'm starving...somebody, help.
column2: Got a half a tuna sandwich.

column1: Then what?
column2: Vanished. Thin air.

column1: Dr. Lizardo's a raving lunatic, Perfect Tommy, a vicious psychopath with crazy eyes and flaming orange hair that once upon a time was mousy brown like yours.
column2: Have you warned Professor Hikita?

column1: The professor and Dr. Emilio Lizardo were actually the first to discover the Eighth Dimension.  Almost fifty years ago.  Before Buckaroo's parents even knew each other.  But there was trouble, a rocket catapult failed and Dr. Lizardo got sucked half in, half out...when they hauled him back ,he wasn't the same guy.  His hair was orange...
column2: And his soul black as the Ace of Spades.

column1: Go back to the bus and reroute the call.
column2: And try the President's private number at the hospital.  Make sure this is on the level. We're busy people here.

column1: That's me. I've been ionized, but I'm okay. I'm, switching on the homing beacon, mark two minute intervals.
column2: Buckaroo, somebody shanghaied the Professor!

column1: What crate?
column2: I think I'm on to something. You and the guys go back to the house and dig up everything you can on an outfit called Yoyodyne.

column1: You okay?
column2: Yeah. Just grazed me.  The Professor's under the floor too...with the Overthruster...

column1: You're a welcome sight...
column2: Just 'grazed' you, huh?

column1: Apache?
column2: Arachtoid.

column1: We will, old fried, we will.
column2: Sure do pack a mean wallop...let's go...

column1: Anybody we know?
column2: Who put this dirty picture in Buckaroo's viewer?

column1: Buckaroo, you got a minute--?
column2: Not really.  This is pretty important.

column1: Everybody ready?  How do we look?  Do we look okay?
column2: I look great.  Let's rock 'n' roll.

column1: Hey, any lock can be picked.  So what's he up to?
column2: I'm sure we'll find out soon enough.

column1: Running a little late, Buckaroo.
column2: Let her out. In my custody.

column1: Planet 10?  The same Planet 10 you postulated beyond Pluto, Perfect Tommy?  The invisible body?
column2: Yeah, but most of 'em blasted in through the Eighth Dimension in 1938 at Grover's Mills, New Jersey...

column1: It wouldn't tell us the whole story until you got here.  It wasn't to talk to the head honcho.
column2: It?  Who does?

column1: Buckaroo--! Sorry--
column2: What is it, Tommy?

column1: Dead.  Damnit!
column2: Where's the professor?

column1: It's Whorfin, Buckaroo.  Line 3.
column2: Whorfin?  Does he know we're coming?

column1: All accounted for?  Where's Penny?
column2: New Jersey brought her back to the bus through heavy fire.  Quite a guy if you want my opinion.

column1: These antidote filters the Professor's whipped up will let you to see them like I have since yesterday, as arachtoidal creatures. They won't be pretty, nothing personal, John Parker.  But just remember...if we fail tonight, there's no tomorrow.
column2: They will never surrender.  They will fight to the end.

column1: What is this thing?  A fighter?
column2: Don't look at me, Buckaroo Banzai.  I failed flight school.

column1: We're going down!  Onto the runway!
column2: The door's locked.

column1: I lack the authority, Buckaroo Banzai.
column2: At least tell them I'm trying!  Tell 'em something--!

column1: Does this thing have guns, John Parker?
column2: Boy, I hope so, Buckaroo Banzai.

column1: Pull up!  We did it!  Holy shit, we did it!  Pull up!
column2: Now, Buckaroo Banzai?

column1: And there's a two-hundred-dollar deductible we have to eat on that crack in her windshield.
column2: Figures.  Anybody seen my scope?

column1: They're arachtoids, Buckaroo, from Planet 10!
column2: What? How do you know that?

column1: ...where there was some kinda giant crash landing, a huge explosion and they fooled Orson Welles into covering it up!  And then they founded Yoyodyne Propulsion Systems and hid there for...
column2: Orson Wells?  What about Doctor Lizardo?

column1: ...but he wasn't the real Doctor Lizardo...just this arachtoid creep that stole the good doc's body the year before in the Eighth Dimension when Prof. Hikita's lab exploded...
column2: Stole his body?  When Doctor Lizardo's hair turned red and his mind snapped?  Of course!  What else?

column1: Where're you goin'?
column2: To get my guns.

column1: And they got Penny!  Look!
column2: Don't shoot!

column1: They're armed for bear, Buckaroo.  Check out those radiation levels.
column2: John Parker, tell them we're doing our best.  Stall.

column1: Got a casualty list?
column2: Just their side.  What're we gonna do with these people?  They're illegal aliens, the way I figure, been here forty years, you could throw the book at 'em...

column1: Raise your hand...where?
column2: This is so embarrassing...

column1: Somebody get her a mike? Can we manage that?  And a spotlight.  What's your name?
column2: Penny.  I'd rather not reveal my last name or my age.

column1: Did you say..."Peggy"?
column2: My name is Penny. Penny Priddy.  There I've said it, but it won't mean anything to you.  I'm a nobody.

column1: Nobody's a nobody.  Why're you crying?  What's wrong?
column2: Did I say anything was wrong? I just sponged up a little too much Vat 69, okay? I'm down to my last nickel in this lousy town, I can't get my luggage outta hock 'cause I met this jerk who said he was a record producer when all he had was a record.  He offered to set me up for life, and like a fool, well, I...

column1: He offered you money?
column2: Do I look like that kinda girl?  I lost my room this morning.  I don't know where I'm gonna sleep tonight, but I keep going.  What the hell else can I do?  I've still got my figure, and like this bozo said, as long as there's a sidewalk, I'll always have a job.

column1: This song's for Peggy.  And all you others out there a little down on your luck.
column2: My name's, Penny!  But who cares?

column1: Let me go, let me go, you creeps...
column2: Everybody okay up here?

column1: What're you doing here? Why're you looking at me like that?
column2: I guess 'cause you remind me of someone I once knew, long ago before any of this craziness.

column1: Go away.  Let me rot?
column2: Who were you really trying to kill last night?

column1: You.  Like the papers all say.
column2: Pretty terrible shot.

column1: Was she pretty?
column2: Who?

column1: The girl I remind you of.
column2: She was the Queen of the Netherlands.

column1: I'd turn around, but I'm afraid you'd strangle me.
column2: The Netherlands.  Whew, that's a long way from Wyoming.

column1: Wyoming? Not Cody, by any chance?
column2: No.  Laramie.  Except I was born in Cody. How did you know that?  Oh, right, sure, I forgot: you know everything.

column1: Having a little trouble with that knot, aren't you?
column2: Which?  The one in my throat.

column1: Did you have family there--? A sister?  In Cody?
column2: I don't know. I always felt like I did, like there was another me...

column1: Another 'you'?
column2: Somewhere.  See I was taken away by the Priddies when I was a baby.  I was adopted.

column1: Adopted.  I should have know. Of course. If it was a snake, it'd bit me!
column2: What?  I don't understand you.  I don't understand anything anymore.

column1: You keep an eye on it.
column2: Any time.

column1: Open up or I'll shoot it off.
column2: I'll shoot yours off if I had a gun, you double-dealing Casanova!  I thought you liked me for myself.  But why should you, huh?  A jerk like me.

column1: She must've been a bigger fool than me if she ran out on a guy like you...
column2: She was killed, Penny.

column1: Oh, my.
column2: Don't go to pieces.  I haven't got time tonight.

column1: Looks like you're the one might go to pieces.
column2: Where's my damn ammo?  Nothing is ever where it's supposed to be around here!

column1: How did she die?  I wanna know.
column2: You don't wanna know.

column1: Yes, I do.  Gimme a chance.  I'm stronger than you think.
column2: She was murdered by Hanoi Shan on our wedding night.

column1: Hanoi Shan--?  The guy in your comic books.  Boss of the World Crime League?  Supreme Commander of the Legion of Death?  The Pivot of Mystery himself?  You're putting me on.  He's a cartoon character.
column2: I wish he was.  He's real enough.

column1: Never.
column2: I gotta be honest with myself and not repress these feelings-I've got mixed emotions-I don't know if I can handle this.  Oh, boy...

column1: I gotta go.  We're on borrowed time.
column2: Go where?  Where're you going?

column1: Please, Penny.  You just gotta trust me now.  Okay?  And don't panic. Because it's gonna be all right.
column2: What?  If we just believe in Buckaroo Banzai?

column1: Yeah...and maybe more important, if you believe in yourself.
column2: Believe in Penny Priddy?

column1: You've got your six guns strapped on.  You're ridding off on another adventure?  Oh, my God, it's all real...it really is real.  I should go with you.  Please...
column2: It's too dangerous.

column1: Stay here, I'll be back.
column2: Sure.  I won't hold my breath.

column1: I'm not worth it, Buckaroo! Forget me!
column2: Penny--?!  Are you all right?

column1: World Watch One.  Direct incoming transmission.
column2: Hello, Mr. President.  How's my favorite patient?  Any tenderness?

column1: Not too terrific, sir.  I apologize for the interruption but something very unusual has reared its ugly head in outer space, and it looks like the Earth's caught in a crossfire.
column2: You're gonna have to repeat that, I think, Buckaroo.

column1: ...hit Smolensk and precipitate a thermonuclear war, Mr. President.
column2: A what?

column1: A thermonuclear holocaust, sir.  These creatures from Planet 10 are ready to exploit Soviet-American tensions and get us to blow each other off the face of the earth, sir, if necessary.
column2: You're quite serious about this, aren't you, Buckaroo.  We know each other pretty well, I think.

column1: What? A black ship?  Where?  A black thermopod's been shot down ten miles back.
column2: A black thermopod here?  On Earth?!  Why, John Gomez?  Why?

column1: Where was it, John O'Connor? How far back?
column2: I have a radio fix...

column1: Not here!  No Overthruster!
column2: John Whorfin will kill us!

column1: But John Whorfin said kill her.
column2: Damn John Whorfin--!

column1: Buckaroo, come in...over.  How does this damn thing work?  Can anybody figure this lighter out?
column2: No, sir.  I think the flint...

column1: What's happening with my call to SAC?
column2: Still no confirmation either from SAC or Strategic Space Command.  They report all surveillance satellite communication jammed.

column1: Jammed--? By who? Whom by?
column2: Possible atmospheric condition, sir...solar.  It's unusual, but no cause for alarm.  Intelligence reports the Soviets are having the same problem.

column1: How long you been riding with Buckaroo, Reno?
column2: Nigh on ten years.  Been through a lotta scrapes together.

column1: What'd you do before?  Can I ask?
column2: Government work.  Had my own think tank.  Got tired of thinking-wanted some action.  Seen plenty of it too.  So will you if you stick around.

column1: Where's Buckaroo?  Is he alive?
column2: Course he's alive.  He's Buckaroo Banzai.

column1: What's his problem?
column2: Perfect Tommy's just threatened by smart women.  Can you play that thing?

column1: Better see what's keepin' the boss, Reno.
column2: Why me?

column1: Pick those up, Reno.
column2: I didn't drop 'em.

column1: It's a spittin' image.
column2: Doesn't look anything like her to me.

column1: Pictures don't lie.
column2: Hell they don't. I met my first wife that way.

column1: Doctor Lizardo. Wasn't he on TV once?
column2: You're thinking of Mr. Wizard.  This guy's an eccentric genius.

column1: The name's Reno.  This here's Perfect Tommy.
column2: Where do you hail from, Doc?

column1: Reno, how's about you take New Jersey's gear, mosey on over to the bus and introduce him to the rest of the hands.
column2: Why me?

column1: Any sign of Buckaroo?
column2: No!  Ditto the professor-

column1: We're waiting for the Jet Car.  Billy's bringing it.
column2: Asshole probably got lost.

column1: So where's Buckaroo?
column2: Whadda you need Buckaroo for?

column1: Unscheduled surgery.  He'll be waltzing along momentarily.  What're you doing tonight?
column2: Flying to Cambodia.

column1: That's why I wear a fifty dollar hat.  Was a two hundred dollar hat, I hadda kill you.
column2: Bet you say that to all the girls, Perfect Tommy.

column1: Now twenty seconds downrange...Perfect Tommy, how on earth is Buckaroo able to keep that thing on the ground?
column2: She's just a damn road hugger, Allison.  Plus the man can drive.

column1: How long has it been, Uncle Alfred?
column2: Ten years.  Barbara isn't really me niece, sir. She's Joanna Clark's daughter.

column1: Joanna and I were in love in London. But when I realized our age difference was too extreme -
column2: Uncle Alfred left for America.  Much to my mother's dismay -

column1: You certainly will not.
column2: Oh no, those things frighten me.

column1: I'm sorry, Uncle, I came to tuck you in.  And...
column2: You came to tuck me in.  That's quite a switch.  I am looking for my brother, Wilfred. He is first butler to the Maharajah of Mirajanpore.  But Mirajanpore is a floating court, it travels across India, so Wilfred can be rather difficult to find.

column1: I guess they don't have fax machines on elephants.
column2: I have been trying to reach Wilfred with no success.  As one grows older, one yearns for family.

column1: It's good to see you again, Uncle. I've missed you.
column2: As I've missed you.  Sleep well, child.

column1: I'm sorry.  I was too late.
column2: Too late for what, dear child?

column1: I came to give you your freedom, a chance to live the life you choose. The same gift you gave me.
column2: I have been part of the greatest adventure ever know.  I have found purpose here, and the family I could never have.

column1: Find my brother Wilfred.  Give him This.  I have duties he must fulfill in my stead.  Only family can be trusted.
column2: What is it?

column1: Uncle Alfred?
column2: In spirit only, I'm afraid.

column1: He's over-eager, impulsive.  I can't trust him not to get hurt.
column2: Perhaps the truth is you don't really trust anyone.

column1: Don't tell me you're on his side. Again.
column2: Despite all your talents, you are still a novice in the ways of family. Dick follows the same ends as you but gets there by his own course.  You must learn to trust him.  For that is the nature of family.

column1: I must have dozed off.  My sincerest apologies, sir.
column2: No apology necessary.  That's the first time in thirty years.

column1: You have?
column2: Secrets are a virtual prerequisite in this house, don't you think?

column1: Well, I hope you'll stay with us.
column2: There's a lovely inn just down --

column1: Oh, but, sir.  So much goes on-
column2: Don't be silly, Alfred. After all, she's family.

column1: Congratulations on your apprehension of Mr. Freeze.  Batman monopolized the evening news.
column2: Thanks.

column1: Is there something wrong, sir?
column2: Alfred, am I pigheaded?  Is it always my way or the highway?

column1: But I can't can I?
column2: No, my boy.  I'm afraid none of us can.

column1: I am as well as can be expected.
column2: Alfred, I know you're sick -- I can get you the best doctors.

column1: Have you ever regretted your life working here, Alfred?
column2: Attending to heroes?  No sir.  My Only regret is that I was never able to be out there with you.

column1: Alfred, if I've never told you...I just want to say...
column2: Yes?

column1: I've spent my whole life trying to beat back death.  What good are all my heroics now if I can't save you?
column2: Everyone dies, Master Bruce.  There's no defeat in that.  Victory comes in fighting for what we know is right while we still live.

column1: I love you, old man.
column2: Remember this.  And remember it always.  I'm proud of you.  And I love you too, son.

column1: Alfred, old friend, I could use your help right now.
column2: Right here, sir.

column1: It's good to see you.
column2: What seems to be the problem?

column1: Women.
column2: That, sir, does not compute.

column1: First Ivy had an intoxicating effect on both Dick and me.  Tonight my feelings spread to someone else.
column2: Specify, please.

column1: Pamela Isley.  I was so attracted to her I couldn't reason clearly.  I still can't.  She used to work for Wayne Enterprises.  Find a file.
column2: Coming on line now, sir.

column1: Advanced botany.  DNA splicing. Recombinant animal plant patterns. Pheromone extractions.
column2: Pheromones?

column1: Glandular secretions from animals. Scents that create powerful emotions.  Fear.  Rage...
column2: Passion.  Of course.  Find the photo of Ivy after the flower ball.

column1: What is it?
column2: It appears, sir, that someone has stolen the batsignal.

column1: Alfred, are you...?
column2: Rather disappointed at how poorly I taught you proper housekeeping.  And quite well, it seems.  Thanks to you, son.  Thanks to you all.

column1: I'm on break from-
column2: Oxbridge Academy?

column1: Their new computer sciences division.  How did you know?
column2: I recognized the accent.

column1: Sometimes counting on someone else is the only way to win.
column2: Hey, I'm the one who kicked Ivy's botanical butt.  Personally.  Me.  I did.

column1: Please be looking for me.
column2: I'm so sorry to trouble you, but-

column1: Al's main squeeze.  Is she here?  I'm about to scrape the bottom of my shoe off my tongue, right?
column2: My parents were killed in an auto accident ten years ago.  Alfred has been supporting me ever since.

column1: I could have made it, you know.  I didn't need your help.
column2: Whatever you say, lady.  It's all in a day's work for me.

column1: This is to replace the bike I lost. I'll get you the rest.
column2: Keep it.

column1: Of course, Dick Grayson, ward of the fabulously wealthy Bruce Wayne. Why would you need a few hundred dollars?
column2: Hey, what's your problem?

column1: I started racing after my parents died.  There was something about the speed, the danger, that took me out of myself, that made the hurt go away.  You wouldn't understand.
column2: You'd be surprised.

column1: Street racing isn't exactly an acceptable major at Oxbridge.  They kicked me out.  it doesn't matter. I've won enough money to do what I've always dreamed.
column2: Just don't tell me you're hoping to run away and join the circus.

column1: Alfred has supported me my whole life.  Now I'm going to pay him back. I'm going to liberate him from his dismal life of servitude.
column2: What are you talking about?

column1: Servants, Masters, it's  ridiculous. Alfred is the sweetest, most noble man alive and he's subjugated all his life and dreams to someone else.
column2: Alfred and Bruce are like family.

column1: Paying someone to prepare your meals and do your laundry and clean your dishes, you call that family?
column2: Alfred's happy here.

column1: Alpha.  Got it.  What the hell is attack plan Alpha?
column2: Divide and conquer.

column1: Youwsa!  Nothing but air.
column2: Batgirl, Baatgirl, Baatgirl.

column1: This is easy.
column2: Crimefighter's rule number one: never say that.

column1: Crimefighter's rule number two.
column2: I'm afraid to ask.

column1: Pow!  What!  Kazow!
column2: What exactly are you doing?

column1: It'll take the satellites about a minute to re-align, but...damn!
column2: Damn?  Damn is not good.

column1: You were a great scientist once. Don't squander your genius on evil.
column2: I hate being lectured.

column1: After you have frozen, your icy tomb will plummet back to Gotham.
column2: Freeze, you're mad.  This capsule will slaughter thousands.

column1: Mr. Bane, I'll finish off the city. You, as they say in showbiz, are on.  Take the boys and kill the kids. But bring me the Bat.
column2: We have eleven minutes to stop Freeze And thaw the city.

column1: You're loosing your cool
column2: I think not.  There'll be no hot time in this old town tonight.  You'll get a charge out of this.

column1: Go on, kill me too.  Just as you killed my wife.
column2: I didn't kill your wife.

column1: Nice suit.  And today you are?
column2: Nightwing.  Scourge of darkest evil.

column1: This is all about fashion for you, isn't it?
column2: It's the gear.  Chicks love the gear.

column1: ... A giant drilling truck burrowing under the city ...
column2: Mr. Freeze.

column1: The batcomputer tracks him heading for the Gotham Museum.
column2: The new antiquities exhibit.  The Second Sun of the Sudan.

column1: Of course.  He's going to steal the giant white diamond.
column2: No, Robin.  He's going to jail.

column1: I was just hanging around.
column2: I thought you were going to stay in the museum and round up the thugs.

column1: Watch the first step.
column2: Surf's up.

column1: You think Freeze will take the bait?
column2: He'll be here.

column1: You don't have two million.  Three million - -
column2: I'll borrow it from you.  Four million - -

column1: Pull back.  You can't make the jump.
column2: I can make it.

column1: She's definitely part of this.  It's weird, for a while Ivy was all I could think about.  But then...
column2: I know.  The feeling just vanished.

column1: I can't believe we were fighting over a  bad guy.
column2: Bad, yes.  Guy, no.  This is one majorly beautiful evil person.

column1: I'm totally over her.  Positively.
column2: Me too.  Great stems, though.

column1: Umm-hmmmm.
column2: Definitely.

column1: How did you...?
column2: Open Sesame...Chicken.

column1: She's still alive.  He's adapted his freezing technology to reverse McGregor's Syndrome.  He's even found a cure for the early stages of the disease.
column2: Can he save her?

column1: No beauty...
column2: Just the beast.

column1: Remember the victim at the airport. Toxins introduced through the mouth.
column2: What are you talking about?

column1: Why is she so desperate to kiss us? I'm betting her lips are poison.
column2: A poison kiss?  You have some real issues with women, you know that?  You just couldn't stand that she was about to kiss me.  Couldn't stand that something might be mine and not yours.  Could you?!

column1: We gotta get those locks changed.
column2: She knows who we are.

column1: I guess we'll just have to kill her.
column2: Kill her later.  We've got work to do.

column1: No sign of the snowman.
column2: Maybe he melted.

column1: If we could relay the sunlight-
column2: From the other side of the equator-

column1: Winded, old timer?
column2: Don't make me kill you in front of the girl.

column1: They're overly protective.  You're Not going to hurt me are you, Ms...
column2: Dr. Pamela Isley.

column1: What can I do for you, Doctor?  A research grant?  A hospital wing?
column2: Actually, I already work for you. Or did.  Your arboreal preservation project in South America.

column1: We cut our support.  A conflict of ideologies.  Dr. Woodrue was a lunatic.
column2: I see you knew him.

column1: That lab was consumed by fire last week.  how did you manage to escape?
column2: I have here a proposal showing how Wayne Enterprises can immediately cease all actions that toxify our environment.

column1: Forget the stars.  Look here, at the Earth, our mother, our womb.  She deserves our loyalty and protection. And yet you spoil her lands, poison her oceans, blacken her skies. You're killing her.
column2: Your intentions are noble, but no diesel fuel for heat.  No coolants to preserve food.  Millions would die of cold and hunger alone.

column1: Acceptable losses in a battle to save the planet.
column2: People come first, Dr. Isley.

column1: Tell me, billionaire, would you warm faster to my pleas if I looked more like Ms. January here?
column2: Although the Wayne Foundation is hosting the event, sadly I will be unable to attend.  Thank you all.  Good day, Doctor.

column1: Physical perfection, charm and wealth tossed over for a dowdy spinster. How do you explain your behavior?
column2: I can't.  But perhaps tonight, over dinner...I've just had an opening.

column1: No!?
column2: Umm.  What I mean is...no plans at the moment...

column1: And?
column2: Can I get some help over here?

column1: You're not even listening to me.
column2: What?  I'm sorry.  You were saying...

column1: Julie, I'm not the marrying kind. There are things about me you wouldn't understand.
column2: I know you're a dedicated bachelor. That you've had a your wild nights.

column1: Wild doesn't exactly cover it.
column2: But there's nothing you've done under the cover of darkness I couldn't learn to understand.

column1: I wouldn't bet on that.
column2: I'm betting on you.  You'll make someone a good husband one day. But I can't wait around forever. Don't answer now.  Just think it over.  Here's some food for thought.

column1: Who's Ivy?
column2: What?

column1: You just called me Ivy.  Who's Ivy?
column2: I wish I knew.

column1: Dr. Isley.  it was like I could feel you in the room.  You're...enchanting. Gorgeous.  The most beautiful woman I've ever seen.  If you're..um... free...this evening.
column2: Bruce?  What are you doing?

column1: Make a choice, Bruce.  Her or me.
column2: Well...um...her.

column1: That's gotta hurt.
column2: Somehow he survived.  But the cryoslution mutated his body.

column1: What happened to his wife?
column2: Presumed dead.  No one knows.

column1: He needs extreme cold to survive. His cryo-suit uses diamond enhanced lasers to keep him at zero degrees.
column2: Let me get this straight. A brilliant citizen, disfigured by a horrible accident, re-emerges as a psychotic super-villain bent on theft, revenge and destruction. You see a pattern here?

column1: I need the Wayne Diamonds.
column2: We gonna trap ourselves a snowman?

column1: Absolutely.  Just as soon as you take ten hours training in the simulator.
column2: Whoa, I made a mistake.  I'm sorry. Don't go all protective on me.  It won't happen again.

column1: Dick, you were reckless.  You could have been killed.
column2: I'm fine.  See.  Me.  here.  Alive. How are we gonna work together if you're never going to trust me?

column1: I got the diamond.  Quell problemo, Bruce?
column2: You left your back wide open.  Freeze could have killed you.

column1: Of course.  Alfred still keeps your mother's picture in his room.
