column2: Anybody want to tell us kids in the cheap seats who Joanna Clark is?

column1: He's dying.  And I can't deal with it.
column2: But he's never said a word-

column1: You know Alfred.  He'd never say Anything.  But I can tell.  Until you came along, Alfred was the only family I ever had.  Without him, I don't know how I would have survived.  He saved my life, Dick.  And I've never told him.
column2: Talk to him, Bruce.  There's nothing worse than losing someone without telling them how you feel.

column1: McGregor's Syndrome.  That's what Freeze's wife had.
column2: Yes.  But Alfred's condition is less severe.  Freeze's research says he cured a case like Alfred's.  It just doesn't say how.

column1: I checked the medical database.  No one else is even close.
column2: I'm late for the dedication.  Then I go after Freeze and Ivy.  Alone.

column1: Like hell you do.
column2: Dick, don't push me right now.

column1: Or what?  No one can capture Ivy but the big bad Bat.  Crap!  You just want her for yourself.  Don't you?  Answer me, damn it!
column2: Yes!  Yes, I want her so badly I can taste it.  That's the whole point. Look at us.  Orphans.  Isolated. Obsessed to the exclusion of life, love, family.  We're perfect targets. She's done something to us, got us fighting over her somehow.

column1: Hail the all-knowing Bruce Wayne. Here's what I know, she loves me, Not you and it's driving you crazy. It's why you stopped us from kissing. Because if you can't have her, nobody can.
column2: She's clouded your mind.  You're not thinking straight.

column1: That's no batlight, it's a birdcall.
column2: Her name is Pamela Isley.  I saw her talking to Gordon.  She must have stolen his keys, altered the signal-

column1: And she did it all for me.  For love.
column2: She's infected us with some kind of pheromone extract-

column1: Is that it, Bruce?  I'm under some magic spell?
column2: She wants to kill you.

column1: You'd say anything to keep me away from her.  To keep her for yourself.
column2: You once said to me that being part of a team means trusting your partner.  That sometimes counting on someone else is the only way to win.  DO you remember?

column1: One question.  When Batgirl and I rolled off the telescope, how come you didn't try and save us? It was the first time I fell and you weren't there to catch me.
column2: I knew you could handle it.

column1: Let me guess, Plant Girl? Vine Lady? Ms. Moss?
column2: Listen, Captain Cold, the suit, maybe, even though silver went out in the 70's.  But those boots are unforgivable. What is it with men?

column1: Impressive
column2: Well, I, my most unabominable snowman, have been impressed by you. In fact I propose a pairing.  So I'm here to set you free.

column1: An enticing offer.  But what does the lady want in return?
column2: Let's cool it for now.  There's someone I want you to meet.

column1: I love that belt.  What are you, about a fifty Big and Tall?
column2: I always go a size smaller.  Makes me look slimmer.

column1: No gun.  How disarming.
column2: I wonder if I can get a cell with a view of the gardens?

column1: My reserves are exhausted.  I must have the gems that power my suit.
column2: You are looking unseasonably hot. Let's go inside and grab your rocks.

column1: In my weakened state I am no match for the bat and the bird.
column2: You leave Batman and Robin to me.

column1: Trust me.  Vegetable magnetism.
column2: Fine.  While I retrieve my diamonds, you and meatloaf will bring my wife to your lair.  She's frozen in -

column1: You will rescue my wife
column2: OK, OK.  Ms. Ivy to the rescue.  Now where do I find your brittle bride?

column1: Make yourself right at home.
column2: Where is my wife?

column1: There was nothing I could do.  Batman deactivated her.  She's dead.
column2: You lie!

column1: Their bones will turn to ice.  Their blood will freeze in my hands.
column2: Kill them.  Of course.  But why stop there?  Why should only Batman and Robin die while the society that created them goes unpunished?

column1: Yes.  I shall replay the world for sentencing me to a life without the warmth of human comfort.  I will blanket the city in endless winter. First Gotham and then the world.
column2: Just what I had in mind.  Everything dead on Earth except us.  A chance for mother nature to start again.  Plants and flowers are the oldest species on the planet yet they are defenseless against man.  Sorry hon, this is for science.  Behold the dawn of a new age.

column1: I have created a race of plants with the strength of the deadliest animals.  Once you have frozen mankind, my mutants will overrun the globe.  The Earth will become a brave new world of only plants. And we shall rule them.  For we will be the only two people left in the world.
column2: Adam and Evil.

column1: You will distract the bat and bird while I prepare to freeze Gotham.
column2: Can't we just ice them along with the rest of the citizenry?

column1: That is far too merciful.  Batman will watch his beloved Gotham perish, then I will kill him.
column2: As a team, the duncely duo protect each other.  But the Robin is young. Impetuous.  If I could get him alone-

column1: One kiss and you could lift the mask from his lifeless face.  Their secret identities would be revealed.  But how best to bait a brid?
column2: The way to a boy's heart is through his ego.  What strapping young hero could resist his very own...signal?

column1: Inspired, Ms. Ivy.
column2: I'm hungry.  I think I'll have poultry.

column1: Prepare for a bitter harvest. Winter has come at last.
column2: Not good.

column1: Freezy, I'm feeling...hot.
column2: I find that unlikely.

column1: Okay, my hair is brittle, my skin is dry and I don't care.  I'd weather blizzards to have you. You're the most perfect man I've ever known.
column2: To be frozen.  To never change.  A life of perpetual ice-olation. There is little perfection in that.

column1: What say we turn up the heat?
column2: You're skating on thin ice.  My passion thaws for my bride alone.

column1: Forget your frosty femme.  These lips are wet and ready to get frostbite.
column2: Hop away little bunny.  Before I cool your jets.  Permanently.

column1: Give it up.  If you threw yourself-
column2: At you?  Polly want a kiss?

column1: I'm glad you came.  I can't breathe without you.
column2: I want us to be together.  But I need to know you're serious about turning over a new leaf.  I need a sign.

column1: How about dangerous curves?
column2: Of trust. Tell me your plan.

column1: Kiss me and I'll tell you.
column2: Tell me and I'll kiss you.

column1: Freeze has turned the new telescope into a freezing gun.  He's about to turn Gotham into an ice cube.
column2: I've got to stop him.

column1: Bad luck, I'm afraid.  It's time to die, little bird.
column2: What do you mean?

column1: You should have heeded your pointy- eared pal.  These lips can be murder.
column2: Then you never loved me?

column1: You're too late.  Say bye-bye birdie.
column2: Sorry to disappoint you.  But rubber lips are immune to your charms.

column1: What do we have here?  A lovely new supply of Venom.  I'll just take this to my laboratory for further study.
column2: What exactly are you working on in there?  What are those screams?

column1: You have to tell me what you're doing with my Venom.
column2: You must show me your secrets, blossom, before I show you mine.

column1: ...Our original sponsor had no stomach for military applications. he cut the funding for our work -
column2: Our work?

column1: Join you?  I've spent my life trying to protect plants from extinction and now you corrupt my research into some maniacal scheme for world domination. When I get through you won't be able to get a job teaching high school chemistry, do you hear me, you psycho?
column2: Well, I can respect your opinion.

column1: Dr. Isley?  Pamela?  You look great. Especially for a dead woman.
column2: Hello, Jason.  I think I've had a change of heart.

column1: ...ervices.
column2: Uh - what? - I ...

column1: ...Be back.
column2: Thank you.

column1: ...ergency procedures.
column2: I haven't got an emergency. Get out of here.

column1: ...your ducts?
column2: I fixed it myself.

column1: ... And then some.
column2: What have you done to my flat?

column1: You telephone, sir.
column2: ...elephoned sir.

column1: Trouble with your air-conditioning.
column2: ...ditioning.

column1: ...ixed itself.
column2: Machines don't fix themselves.

column1: ... fix themselves.
column2: He's tampered with it, Dowser.

column1: I think we'd better have a look.
column2: ... have a look.

column1: What have you got there?
column2: Got there!

column1: Mumble ... mumble ... mumble ... Tuttle
column2: Mumble ... Tuttle ...

column1: Tuttle! ... mumble!  You've had that scab Tuttle here, haven't you?
column2: ...aven't you?

column1: Oh yeh? Where'd you get this from eh  out yer nostril?
column2: ...Yer nostril?

column1: Central Services don't take kindly to sabotage!
column2: ...sabotage!

column1: ...ven't you?
column2: You're putting your talents to very odd use Mr Lowry - yes, odd use - to pit wits against Central Services -

column1: Sign here, please.
column2: ... ere please.

column1: This is what you get when you have cowboys round yer ducts.
column2: ... yer ducts.

column1: I think you've got your T41 crystal inductor wired up to a reverse bobbin- threaded-solenoid-control. It's either that or a new washer.
column2: ... new washer.

column1: Sign the form so we can get to it.
column2: ... get to it.

column1: Ah ha ... there you are, Sam.
column2: What? How do you know my name?

column1: We know everything here. This is the Storeroom of Knowledge.
column2: Then perhaps you can help me. I've lost someone who ...

column1: Oh, yes. We've got everything here. Every bit of knowledge, wisdom, learning ... every experience, every thought neatly filed away.
column2: What? You mean you've got ...

column1: Well not exactly. But, if you help us we'll help you. The Forces Of Darkness have won the day ... but, tomorrow is another one
column2: What do I have to do.

column1: Er ... Thanks ...
column2: It's reply paid.

column1: Oh ...  Thank you very much, mother, but actually -
column2: You don't have to sing it.

column1: Aren't you a bit late? - the party started half an hour ago.
column2: Yes, I know. It's the backlog, everybody complains. Was it all right otherwise?

column1: Yes, it was ... very nice ... thank you.
column2: Do you mind if I use your bathroom?

column1: Go away.
column2: Her name is Jill.

column1: What? ...Jill? Jill who? Jill who?
column2: Layton.

column1: Jill Layton ...  You're a very good little girl. What are you doing here?
column2: I'm waiting for my daddy.

column1: Deputy minister, what do you believe is behind this recent increase in terrorist bombings?
column2: Bad sportsmanship. A ruthless minority of people seems to have forgotten certain good old fashioned virtues. They just can't stand seeing the other fellow win. If these people would just play the game, instead of standing on the touch line heckling -

column1: In fact, killing people -
column2: - In fact, killing people - they'd get a lot more out of life.

column1: Mr. HELPMANN, what would you say to those critics who maintain that the Ministry Of Information has become too large and unwieldy ...?
column2: David ... in a free society information is the name of the game. You can't win the game if you're a man short.

column1: And the cost of it all, Deputy Minister? Seven percent of the gross national produce ...
column2: I understand this concern on behalf of the tax-payers. People want value for money and a cost-effective service.

column1: Do you think that the government is winning the battle against terrorists?
column2: On yes. Our morale is much higher than theirs, we're fielding all their strokes, running a lot of them out, and pretty consistently knocking them for six. I'd say they're nearly out of the game.

column1: But the bombing campaign is now in its thirteenth year ...
column2: Beginner's luck.

column1: Thank you very much, Deputy Minister.
column2: Thank you, David ... and a very merry Christmas to you all.

column1: Thanks very much Sam.
column2: That's all right Mr Helpmann. Glad to help.

column1: If I can help you ...
column2: Well, I ...

column1: Sorry ...
column2: Your father and I were very close. Of course Jeremiah was senior to me but we were close friends ... especially after the bombing  and I  keep his name alive at the office every day.

column1: I know he would have wanted me to help you ... And I promised your mother I'd take you onto the team at information Retrieval. But I gather that ...
column2: Mr Helpmann. I've changed my mind. I'd like to accept the transfer - am I too late?

column1: Too late? That's for me to say.
column2: Well ... well, I ...

column1: Sam, what are we going to do with you? Can you hear me, Sam?
column2: Where's Jill? What have you done to her? Where is she?!

column1: Gillian Layton?
column2: Yes, you've got to get me out of here. I've got to find her.

column1: Help me!
column2: I assure you, Sam, I'm doing everything within my power. But the rules of the game are laid down, and we all have to play by them - even me.

column1: This is all a mistake! Don't you understand?!
column2: Yes, well, from the Department's point of view you're certainly a bit of an own goal, but ...

column1: I'm not a terrorist! You must know that! I'm not guilty! Get me out of here!
column2: Sam, if you've been going out there and playing a straight bat, all the way down the line, you've got absolutely nothing to worry about.

column1: Please, I've got to find Jill.
column2: Sam, I think I ought to tell you ... I'm afraid she's upped stumps and retired to the pavilion.

column1: Yes, it's all a bit confusing but, it seems she was killed resisting arrest.
column2: No, no ... I did that...

column1: Sam!
column2: Jack!

column1: Long time no see!
column2: Well, since you disappeared up the ladder of Information Retrieval ... I don't expect to see you slumming in Records - what's the problem?

column1: Problem? - No problem - yes, everything's going fantastically well, wonderful, marvelous, great career prospects, Alison in great shape, kids fine, beautiful home, I'm on Security Level Five now, and Mr Helpmann relies on me more and more, yes, couldn't be better, I feel terrifically motivated and job- rewarded -
column2: You sound worried.

column1: What's the matter?
column2: Sorry. Nothing.  See you - I'm going to be late.

column1: You are late.
column2: Even later.

column1: Sam, your life is going wrong - let your friends tell you - Records is a dead end department, no Security Level worth a damn, it's impossible to get noticed -
column2: Yes, I know, fantastic, marvellous, wonderful - remember me to Alison - and the - er - twins.

column1: Triplets.
column2: Really? - God, how time flies!

column1: Hello, Jack!
column2: You remember Alison?

column1: {winking at Sam) She doesn't like me telling anyone but she's pleased as anything really.
column2: Er, I knew you looked different.

column1: Remember how they used to stick out?
column2: What? - Oh, yes - vividly. I used to wonder if they were real.

column1: Dr. Jaffe has pinned her ears back.
column2: Quite, absolutely - I always thought they were false.

column1: Jack!!
column2: SAM! What a surprise!

column1: Sorry about that ... Mr Helpmann told me you were coming aboard - congratulations!
column2: Thanks. Are you officer 412/L?

column1: For my sins. Are you settling in alright?
column2: Yes, thanks.

column1: Terrific. I'm really glad you dropped by. Unfortunately, I don't have any time right now I've got a queue of customers to deal with - er, why don't we have a drink tonight?
column2: Ah ...

column1: What?
column2: I don't want to take up your time now, but I was hoping you could give me some information on somebody. It's a security level three matter and Information Retrieval records says to refer to you.

column1: OK. Come back this afternoon, about four o'clock. If you give me the number of the case, I'll have the dossier here waiting.  My tailor,... well worth the investment.
column2: I've got numbers all over these - I'm not sure which is the one you want.

column1: Layton! Oh shit!
column2: What is it?

column1: You clever bastard! I might have guessed. You only moved in today and you're already hot on the bloody trail.
column2: Am I?

column1: Please, Sam, we're going to have to be open to each other on this one. If you make a reputation with this case, it'll be at my expense.
column2: How do you mean?

column1: How much do you know?
column2: Not much.

column1: Enough though, eh?
column2: Not really, no.

column1: OK. OK. Let's not fence around ... This is the situation. Some idiot somewhere in the building, some insect, confused two of our clients, B58/732 and T47/215.
column2: B58/732, that's A. Buttle isn't it?

column1: Christ! You do know it all!
column2: No, no, I don't. I'm just beginning Honestly. Sorry, carry on.

column1: Well, your A. Buttle has been confused with T47/215, an A. Tuttle. I mean, it's a joke! Somebody should be shot for that. So B58/732 was pulled in by mistake.
column2: You got the wrong man.

column1: I did not get the wrong man. I got the right man. The wrong man was delivered to me as the right man! I accepted him, on trust, as the right man. Was I wrong? Anyway, to add to the confusion, he died on us. Which, had he been the right man, he wouldn't have done.
column2: You killed him?

column1: Sam, there are very rigid parameters laid down to avoid that event but Buttle's heart condition did not appear on Tuttle's file. Don't think I'm dismissing this business, Sam. I've lost a week's sleep over it already.
column2: I'm sure you have

column1: There are some real bastards in this department who don't mind breaking a few eggs to make an omelette, but thank God there are the new boys like me who want to maintain decent civilized standards of terrorist eradication. We've got the upper hand for the moment, but they're waiting for us to slip up, and a little slip- up like this is just the chance they're looking for.
column2: So how ...?

column1: What I've got to do now is pick up Tuttle, interrogate him at the same voltage as Buttle, to the same meter reading to the last penny, and juggle the books in electrical banking.
column2: What has Tuttle done?

column1: We suspect him of freelance subversion.
column2: He's a freelance subversive?

column1: What's she done?
column2: You didn't know as much about this business as you pretended to, did you?

column1: Er ... no.
column2: Very smart.

column1: Er ... but I would've found out anyway.
column2: Yes. I'm impressed.

column1: Tell me about Layton.
column2: She witnessed the Tuttle arrest - the Buttle arrest - and since then she's been making wild allegations, obviously trying to exploit the situation - she's working for somebody, and she's not working for us.

column1: But surely, I mean, perhaps she just happened to live above the Buttles, and ...
column2: Look after that suit, eh. Barbara chose it for me.

column1: Right. Er, you're not going to keep calling her Barbara, are you?
column2: Barbara's a perfectly good name, isn't it?

column1: Look, about the Layton woman - maybe she's just trying to help the Buttle family.
column2: Why?

column1: Why? Hell, not for any reason ...
column2: {baffled) I don't follow you.

column1: Out of kindness.
column2: Kindness? What's the purpose behind this line of enquiry?

column1: So what are you going to do about her?
column2: Get her out of circulation - I've put her on the detention list.

column1: You mean you're going to invite her in so that she can spill the beans inside the department?
column2: Well, I ... Good point. What do you suggest?

column1: Let me try to get to her. I'll deactivate her.
column2: What does that mean? I don't want to be involved in anything unsavoury.

column1: Trust me. You do trust me, don't you?
column2: Of course. We went to school together. You're my oldest friend.

column1: And you're mine.
column2: You're the only person I can trust.

column1: Then we'd better keep this business just between the two of us.
column2: Right! Just between as and the Security Forces.

column1: They weren't at school with us.
column2: But, I've already put her on the search and detain list.

column1: Take her off the list.
column2: There's no procedure for that until she's been arrested.

column1: Say it was a mistake.
column2: We don't make mistakes.

column1: Well, I'd better get out there and try to get to her before security does. Let me borrow her dossier for a while.
column2: Er ... alright. For Christ's sake don't lose it. Here, you'd better sign for it.

column1: Thanks, Jack. I'll be in touch.
column2: Do you know what you're doing.

column1: Trust me.
column2: Sam ... we're proud to have you at Information Retrieval. Merry Xmas.

column1: Come off it, Jack! Of course you can check to see if she's been arrested.
column2: I'm sorry, Sam, I'm afraid this whole case has become much more complicated since last we talked.

column1: She's innocent, Jack --- she's done nothing wrong.
column2: Tell that to the wives of the Security men she blew up this afternoon. Listen, we've also had a report just in from Central Services that Tuttle has wrecked an entire flat and sabotaged adjacent Central Services systems - as a matter of fact, in your block. I'd keep my eyes open if I were you, Sam. Bye.

column1: You don't really think Tuttle and the girl are in league?
column2: I do. Goodbye.

column1: It could all be coincidental.
column2: There are no coincidences, Sam. Everything's connected, all along the line. Cause and effect. That's the beauty of it. Our job is to trace the connections and reveal them.  This whole Buttle/Tuttle confusion was obviously planned from the inside. Bye bye.

column1: Jack, she's innocent!
column2: Sam - we've always been close, haven't we?

column1: Yes we have, Jack!
column2: Well, could you stay away from me until this thing blows over.

column1: Jack?... Jack?
column2: Shut up!

column1: Jack, I'm innocent! Help me.
column2: Bastard!!!

column1: You stupid bastard!
column2: What?

column1: How could you do this to me?
column2: Help me, Jack! I'm frightened!

column1: How do you think I feel? You shit!
column2: Jack ...

column1: I want to report a wrongful arrest.
column2: You want Information Adjustments. Different department.

column1: I've been to Information Adjustments. They sent me here. They told me you had a form I had to fill in.
column2: Have you got an Arrest Receipt?

column1: Yes.
column2: Is it stamped?

column1: Stamped?
column2: No, there's no stamp on it. You see! I can't give you the form until it's stamped.

column1: Where do I get it stamped?
column2: Information Adjustments.

column1: But you've stamped this form before! Why won't you stamp it now?
column2: You've just said yourself, Miss, we've already stamped it. Why should we stamp it twice?

column1: You're a stupid, fat arsed, obstructive, fascist moron aren't you?
column2: If you say so.

column1: You think these are tits don't you?
column2: Ah.

column1: I bet you'd like to touch them?
column2: Oh.

column1: Are you alright?
column2: It's you ... it's you ...

column1: Who are you? Let go!
column2: Don't look back! Act naturally!

column1: Ow! That hurt!
column2: Good!

column1: What are you doing? For Christ's sake! Get moving!
column2: Who are you?

column1: Bloody hell! Do as I say!
column2: No.

column1: Alright! Alright! Alright! I'm Information Retrieval Officer -  DZ/015, and I'm arresting you for - your own good! Now start up and get moving before I hand you back to them!
column2: Them?

column1: Don't litter my cab!
column2: Oh, sorry.

column1: ... This is amazing ... for me ... being here with you. I mean, in my dreams you ...
column2: I don't want to hear about your fucking dreams!

column1: Oh. But ... Look, I'm sorry I shouted at you.
column2: Why are they all pigs at Information Retrieval?

column1: You know, smoking's bad for you.
column2: It's my fucking life.

column1: Yes, of course. Sorry.
column2: I know you. I saw you through the floor, didn't I?

column1: Yes. Ceiling. Why did you run away?
column2: I didn't run away. I left the flat.

column1: Why?
column2: I didn't like it.

column1: Why not?
column2: It had a hole in the floor. Where are we going?

column1: Where are you taking me?
column2: What?

column1: Where are you taking me?
column2: Ah ... Er ... It looks as if you're taking me.

column1: It does doesn't it?
column2: Where are you taking me?

column1: What's going on here?
column2: What does it look like ... I'm collecting empties.

column1: OK. What's in the parcel?
column2: What parcel?

column1: It's heavy.
column2: A heavy Christmas present.

column1: What are you doing in Information Retrieval?
column2: Looking for you.

column1: No, really.
column2: Really.

column1: I mean, it doesn't suit you.
column2: Suit me?

column1: Don't you know the sort of thing that Information Retrieval does?
column2: What do you mean? Would you rather have terrorists?

column1: We've got both.
column2: Things would be worse without Information Retrieval.

column1: Why don't you say, no system is perfect.
column2: Well, no system is.

column1: Say, all wars have innocent victims.
column2: Well, all wars do -

column1: Who is this war against, Sam?
column2: Well, terrorists of course.

column1: How many terrorists have you met? Actual terrorists?
column2: Actual. terrorists? Well ... it's only my first day.

column1: Look at that - right on time.
column2: What? I thought you were free to come and go as you please.

column1: Well, almost ... unfortunately I do have to punch in by 5.00 every day.
column2: Every day?

column1: Turn around!
column2: What?

column1: They'll be there waiting.
column2: Who will?

column1: Security.
column2: You're joking.

column1: No. Please. They're going to arrest you.
column2: I thought you arrested me.

column1: Yes ... but, this is real. Now, stop!
column2: Cut it out, Sam.

column1: Will you please turn back.
column2: Get away!

column1: Turn!
column2: Stop it ... damn you!

column1: I was right! Step on it!
column2: Let go! We've got to stop!

column1: Now you're the one that's out of your mind.
column2: Sam ... we can't outrace them. You'll kill us!

column1: Come on, let's go! Let's get out of here!
column2: Oh God! What have we done?

column1: We? Don't blame me!
column2: It wasn't supposed to happen like this.

column1: Shit! The house is on fire!
column2: "And your children all gone."

column1: What?
column2: "Lady bird, lady bird, fly away home, your house is on fire and your children all gone" ... Do you think anyone's hurt?

column1: This is a hell of a time to buy a nightie.
column2: Are you still following me?

column1: Please, Jill ... I love you.
column2: Go away.

column1: There are plenty of other safe places. Why don't we go back to my flat?
column2: Leave me alone!

column1: You've got to trust me. It sounds silly but I know we were meant to meet.
column2: You mean you were meant to hijack my truck, make me crash it, and have every security man in town looking for me?

column1: I vas just trying to help. I decided to trust you. Maybe I was wrong. Whose side are you on really? Who are your friends? Who was the man who gave you the parcel? What's in it? It's the only thing you saved from the lorry .... It must he something very special.
column2: I saved you from the lorry and you're not very special.

column1: ........... It's a bomb isn't it?
column2: Oh ... Jesus!

column1: I'm going to open it!
column2: No you're not!

column1: Jill! What are you do ... I mean ... how did you ... Are you alright?
column2: Yes.

column1: What happened to you after ...
column2: Your face ... are you hurt?

column1: They're gone.
column2: Are you sure?

column1: Don't you like parties?
column2: C'mon. We've got to get out of here.

column1: Make yourself at home. Don't answer the phone or open he door to anyone. I won't be long.
column2: Where are you going?

column1: I'm going to pull some strings. It's our only hope.
column2: Don't do anything silly.

column1: Thanks for the vote of confidence.
column2: Take care.

column1: What do you think? ... is it me?
column2: You don't exist any more. I've killed you. Jill Layton is dead.

column1: Perhaps the machine's on the blink! It keeps picking up old films. That can't he right, can it?
column2: It's not the machine. There's a mismatch on the personnel code numbers... Ah there we go! That's a B58/732 when it should be a T47/215 ... Tuttle ... he should have 31.06, debited against his account for electrical procedures, not Buttle.

column1: Oh my God, a mistake!
column2: It's not our mistake!

column1: Isn't it? Whose is it?
column2: Information Retrieval.

column1: Oh, good!
column2: Expediting has put in for electrical procedures in respect of Buttle, Archibald, shoe repair operative, but Security has invoiced Admin for Tuttle, Archibald, heating engineer

column1: What a relief! I don't know what I'd do if you ever got promoted.
column2: Don't worry.

column1: But if they did promote you
column2: I've told you before. I'd turn it down.

column1: Would you really, Sam?
column2: Really.

column1: It's your mother isn't it? Pulling strings again.
column2: What a BITCH!

column1: A cheque.
column2: The refund for Tuttle!

column1: Tuttle?
column2: I mean, Buttle! It's been confusion from the word go! He's been wrongly charged for Electromemorytherapy and someone somewhere is trying to make us carry the can!

column1: I've never seen a Ministry cheque before.
column2: We've got to get rid of it! There's been a balls-up somewhere, and when the music stops they'll jump on whoever's holding the cheque!

column1: Send it to somebody else. Send it to Buttle. It's his cheque.
column2: I've tried that! Population Census have got him down as dormanted, the Central Collective Storehouse computer has got him down as deleted, and the Information Retrieval have got him down as inoperative ... Security has him down as excised., Admin have him down as completed

column1: He is dead.
column2: Dead! Oh no! That's terrible! We'll never get rid of the damned thing! What are we going to do?

column1: Try next of kin.
column2: Next of kin!

column1: There we go. Mrs. Veronica Buttle. What's the number on the cheque?
Problem. She doesn't have a bank account.
column2: Well, that's it! I may as well go and hang myself! This sort of thing couldn't have happened before the stupid seventh tier reorganization! That was Simmons doing! And he and Jeffries always sit together at lunch! The bastards!  Ow!  Perhaps we can lose it ... behind the filing cabinet ... or destroy it ... burn it ... eat it ...

column1: You'd never get away with it. Besides, you can't do that to somebody's refund. It's Christmas. There is one more option.
column2: What?

column1: Here. What do I do next?
column2: Call the motor pool and authorise personal transport.

column1: Of course, of course. Leave it to me. How do I authorize a cheque?
column2: Here we are. Pink and blue receipts. All you've got to do is sign these and the back of the cheque.

column1: Oh God! I think I've broken a bone. What a pathetic thing I am.
column2: Here.

column1: That's it.
column2: You are good to me Sam.

column1: Is it all right about Mrs Buttle's cheque?
column2: I delivered it.

column1: Can I forget it?
column2: Yes.

column1: Damn! Blast!
column2: What's the matter?

column1: You don't happen to know how I can get around an IRQ/3 do you?
column2: All information on 3rd Level Suspects is classified.

column1: I know that.
column2: All enquiries to Information Retrieval. Which is hopeless, of course. They never tell you anything. But come the time they want something from us ...

column1: I've go to accept that promotion to get behind this, haven't I?
column2: Yes.  NO! You can't! You've only just turned it down!

column1: I never signed the form.
column2: I did it for you.

column1: What! Shit!
column2: It's what you wanted isn't it?

column1: No, you can't have any more chairs! There's only one left in here now, and I need that to sit on!  Oh ... er, sorry. Who are you?
column2: Sam Lowry.

column1: Ah, yes, you're the new boy from next door, ha ha!  My name's Lime. Harvey Lime. Welcome to Expediting.
column2: Ah.  Would you mind if I borrowed your computer console?

column1: What?
column2: I'll bring it back in ten minutes.

column1: You want to take my console into your office?
column2: Yes.

column1: Alright. There's someone I want to check out. A woman called Gillian Layton.
column2: A woman eh? I see.

column1: I know her age and distinguishing marks. But I need an address or a place of work or something
column2: This is your dream girl, is it?

column1: What?  Look, let me use the console for a few minutes.
column2: You must be joking -  When there's a woman involved - there's no stopping me. Now, let me have that sheet.

column1: Sod it, it's broken!
column2: You haven't switched it on.

column1: Hey - that's my desk!
column2: Gillian Layton - Suspect S/5173. Truck driver! All enquiries, reference officer 412/L - Room 5001.  That's what I wanted to know. Thank you very much.

column1: Lime, I need to use your computer
column2: Sorry, a bit busy at the moment.  You seem to have quite a lot to do yourself.

column1: My mother said it would be all right.
column2: She didn't say anything about it to me.

column1: Well, she's my mother, not yours.
column2: I won't be held responsible.

column1: How long will she he away?
column2: There are some who go to Dr. Jaffe's clinic who never come back at all.

column1: Hello, Spiro. Merry Christmas.
column2: I'm sorry but ...

column1: You remember Samuel, my son.
column2: {suddenly unctious) Oh, but of course ...

column1: Oh, to hell with the diet, a number eight, please.
column2: A most perceptive choice, Madam, if I may say so.  Monsieur?

column1: Numero une, crevettes  la mayonaaise.
column2: I'm sorry Alma, I didn't mean to sound so ...

column1: I just wish you would stop interfering, mother! I don't want promotion. I'm happy where I am.
column2: No you're not. Jack Lint is a lesson to you - he never had your brains but he's got the ambition. You haven't got the ambition but luckily you've got me. And Mr Helpmann. Mr Helpmann was very close -

column1: Mr Helpmann was very close to your poor father. He was very close to me. Still is. He'll take you under his wing at Information Retrieval. You'll like it when you get there.
column2: You're not listening, mother.

column1: I hope you like it. It's very exclusive.
column2: What is it?

column1: What were we saying?
column2: This isn't rare!

column1: Actually, Alma, that's one of the little things I was dying to tell you ... Sam's been promoted to Information Retrieval.
column2: Mother!

column1: Sam ... you haven't had dessert.
column2: I'm sorry. I don' t want dessert. I don't want promotion. I don't want anything.

column1: Mother? Is that you?
column2: Of course. Isn't it wonderful? The bandages came of this afternoon. Come and join the fun. Everybody's here.

column1: Is Mr Helpmann here?
column2: Yes he is - he wants to talk to you.

column1: It seems you're the first person ever to turn down a promotion. He thinks you should see a doctor.
column2: Actually, I've decided ...

column1: Sam!!!
column2: Mother? ... What ... what's ... you've got to help me ...

column1: It's a refund ... I'm afraid there was a mistake.
column2: Mistake?

column1: My husband's dead, isn't he?
column2: Er ... I assure you Mrs Buttle, the Ministry is always very scrupulous about following up and eradicating error. If you have any complaints which you'd like to make, I'd be more than happy to send you the appropriate forms.

column1: What have you done with his body?
column2: Um ...

column1: Uh ...
column2: He hadn't done anything ... He was good ... What have you done with his body?

column1: Really, Sam - when are you going to do something about these terrorists?
column2: What? Now? It's my lunch hour.

column1: Whatever happened to you?
column2: There was a slight complication. Dr. Chapman says it often happens with a delicate skin like mine. Nothing to worry about. He's promised me I'll have these bandages off in a ...

column1: Actually, there's someone I want to meet ...
column2: I know, I know ...!

column1: Here we are! I'm going to leave you two lovebirds in peace.
Ah ... hello, Mrs Terrain. SAM lets go of the parcel and pushes JILL away. She moves off.
column2: I think that'll hold it.  Hello Shirley. Just helping someone tie up a Christmas present. How are you?

column1: My complication had a complication, but Dr Chapman says I'll soon be up and bouncing about like a young gazelle. Are you buying a Christmas present for your mother?
column2: Er, yes ...

column1: I can't make up my mind whether to have a number one or a number two. What do you recommend, Spiro?
column2: Between you and me, Madam, today the number two.

column1: Numero huit, braised veal in wine sauce.
column2: It's too exciting. I've left Dr Jaffe and gone to Dr. Chapman.

column1: That's all right Ida ... it's just that he's such an artist. To him, cutting is so crude ... so primitive.
column2: Numero trois, steak.  Monsieur, Mesdames, Bon appetit.

column1: Hello - Central Services - I'm at 579B Block l9, Northwestern Section D - that's exit 1 on Green Pastures Highway at the Orange Blossom Flyover - and I've got trouble with the air- conditioning
column2: Thank you or calling Central Services. am sorry, due to temporary staff shortage, Central Services cannot take service calls centrally between 2300 and 0900 hours - have a nice day - this has not been a recording, incident-

column1: This is an emergency!
column2: Thank you for calling Central Services. I am sorry, due -

column1: Yes, but. I've got to have a heating engineer
column2: Thank you for calling Cen -

column1: Hello ... hello ...
column2: Hello. Mr Lowry?

column1: Put the phone down and your hands up.
column2: What? Who is this?

column1: My name is Sam Lowry. I have to report to Mr Warren.
column2: Thirtieth floor, sir. You're expected.

column1: Er, don't you want to search me?
column2: No, sir.

column1: My I.D. cards.
column2: No need, sir

column1: But I could be anybody.
column2: No you couldn't, sir. This is Information Retrieval.  the lift's arrived, sir.

column1: Excuse me, Dawson, can you put me through to Mr Helpmann's office?
column2: I'm afraid I can't, sir. You have to go through the proper channels.

column1: And you can't tell me what the proper channels are, because that's classified information?
column2: I'm glad to see the Ministry's continuing its tradition of recruiting the brightest and best, sir.

column1: Are we?
column2: Ah yes, the lady is waiting.

column1: A steak, please. Rare.  Mother, I need to ...
column2: Monsieur. Quel numero.

column1: I don't know which numero.
column2: Numero, trois.

column1: what? ... Oh ...
column2: Madam ... CUT to WOMAN turning, half in flirtatious conversation. It is SAM's MOTHER, but miraculously another twenty years younger and ... a parody of SAM's Dream Girl.

column1: Yes?
column2: Central Services.

column1: No, not at all. I mean, it's all right. It's fixed.
column2: Fixed?

column1: I mean it fixed itself.
column2: Fixed itself.

column1: Now look what you've done to him.
column2: Have you got one or haven't you?

column1: But we can get one.
column2: It's all right, Terry, it's all right, everything's all right.

column1: I'm sorry, but I'm a bit of a stickler for paper work. Where would we be if we didn't follow the correct procedures?
column2: We'll be back.

column1: What the - ? How did you - ?
column2: Emergency procedures.

column1: Sign here please.
column2: What is it?

column1: What?
column2: Who fixed your ducts?

column1: Hang on! Wait a minute! You can't just go and leave it like this!
column2: Why not? All you've got to do is blow yer nose and fix it, haven't you?

column1: For God's sake, what's happened?
column2: Thermostat's gone. And then some.

column1: What is it?
column2: It's a 27B/6 of course.

column1: Nice and easy now. Keep your hands where I can see them.
column2: What is this?  Who the hell are you?

column1: Harry Tuttle. Heating engineer. At your service.
column2: Tuttle! Are you from Central Services?

column1: Ha!!
column2: But ... I called Central Services.

column1: They're a bit overworked these days. Luckily I intercepted your call.
column2: What?

column1: A little precaution, sir. I've had traps set for me before now. There are people in Central Services who'd love to get their hands on Harry Tuttle.
column2: Are you saying this is illegal?

column1: Well, yes ... and no. Officially, only Central Service operatives are supposed to touch this stuff ... Could you hold these.
column2: ... but, with all the new rules and regulations ... unncgh, c'mon, c'mon ... they can't get decent staff any more ... so ... they tend to turn a blind eye ... as long as I'm careful.  ... Mind you, if ever they could prove I'd been working on their equipment ... well, that's a different matter ... up a bit with the torch, sir.

column1: Sorry. wouldn't it be easier just to work for Central Services?
column2: Couldn't stand the pa - ah - we're getting warm -

column1: The pace?
column2: The paperwork, couldn't stand the paperwork.  Over to the left please, if you don't mind sir. Hold it there. Yes, there's more bits of paper in Central Services than bits of pipe - read this, fill in that, hand in the other - listen, this old system of yours could be on fire and I couldn't even turn on the kitchen tap without filling in a 27B/6.... Bloody paperwork.

column1: Well I suppose one has to expect a certain amount
column2: Why? I came into this game for adventure - go anywhere, travel light, get in, get out, wherever there's trouble, a man alone. Now they've got the whole country sectioned of and you can't move without a form. I'm the last of a breed. Ah ha! Found it!  There's your problem.

column1: Can you fix it?
column2: No. But I can bypass it with one of these

column1: Are you expecting anyone?
column2: No. Wait here.

column1: Listen .. um ... I don't want to get involved in any of this. But I work at the Ministry of Information, and I happen to know that Information Retrieval have been looking for an Archibald Tuttle, Heating Engineer. You wouldn't by any chance be -
column2: My friends call me Harry. Information Retrieval, eh? Interesting!

column1: What do they want you or?
column2: Time to go.

column1: Thank you very much. How much will it...?
column2: On the house. You did me a favor. Check the corridor.

column1: Hello Lucy, had a busy night? Puts money in machine.
column2: We've been working hard too. Takes glass.

column1: Pardon me. Luce. He raises glass to breast, pulls red handle between her legs. Milk spurts into glass. Dim joins the others. Alex looks at a party of tourists.
column2: There was some sophistos from the TV studios around the corner, laughing an govoreeting. The Devotchka was smecking away, and not caring about the wicked world one bit. Then the disc on the stereo twanged off and out, and in the short silence before the next one came on, she suddenly came with a burst of singing, and it was like for a moment, O my brothers, some great bird had flown into the milkbar and I felt all the malenky little hairs on my plott standing endwise, athe shivers crawling up like slow malenky lizards and then down again. Because I knew what she sang. It was a bit from the glorious 9th, by Ludwig van. Dim makes a lip-trump followed by a dog howl, followed by two fingers pronging twice in the air, followed by a clowny guffaw. Alex brings his stick down smartly on Dim's legs.

column1: What did you do that for?
column2: For being a bastard with no manners and not a dook of an idea how to comport yourself publicwise, O my Brother.

column1: I don't like you should do what you done. And I'm not your brother no more and wouldn't want to be.
column2: Watch that... Do watch that, O Dim, if to continue to be on live thou dost wish.

column1: Yarbles, great bolshy yarblockos to you I'll meet you with chain, or nozh or britva, any time, not having you aiming tolchocks at me reasonless. It stands to reason, I won't have it.
column2: A nozh scrap any time you say. Dim weakens.

column1: He are here! He have arrived! Hooray!
column2: Welly, welly, welly, welly, welly, welly, well. To what do I owe the extreme pleasure of this surprising visit? Georgie rises.

column1: Sorry about the pain. Using the gulliver to much like, eh? Giving orders and disciplining and that perhaps, eh? You sure the pain's gone? You sure you'll not be happier back up in bed.
column2: Lets get things nice and sparkling clear. This sarcasm, if I may call it such, does not become you, O my brothers. As I am your droog and leader, I am entitled to know what goes on, eh? Now then, Dim, what does that great big horsy gape of a grin portend?

column1: One minoota, droogie. Dim smashes Alex in the face with a full milk bottle. He goes down. The others run away, laughing.
column2: You bastards... bastards.

column1: Well, well, well, well, well, well, well, if it isn't little Alex. Long time no viddy, droog. How goes? Surprised are you?
column2: Impossible... I don't believe it.

column1: Come on, Alex. Come for walkies. Hahahahaha.
column2: Come, come, my little droogies. I just don't get this at all. The old days are dead and gone. For what I did in the past I've been punished.

column1: Been punished, yeah?
column2: I've been cured.

column1: Been cured, yeah, that was read out to us. The Inspector read all that out to us. He said it was a very good way.
column2: I just don't get this all. It was them that went for me, brothers. You're not on their side and can't be. You can't be Dim. It was someone we fillied with back in the old days... Trying to get his own malenky bit of revenge after all this time. You remember, Dim?

column1: Dear, dear, dear. Whatever happened to you, my boy? Mr. Alexander, now confined to a wheelchair, pushes himself away from his desk, and rolls up to Julian. The water drips off Alex's clothes. They look at each other.
column2: The police... The horrible ghastly Police. They beat me up, sir. The Police beat me up, sir. Mr. Alexander stares at him. It becomes apparent he is insane.

column1: I know who you are! Isn't it your picture in the newspapers? Didn't I see you this morning on the video? Are you not the poor victim of this horrible new technique?
column2: Yes, sir, that's exactly who I am, sir... and what I am... a victim, sir. Mr. Alexander becomes frenzied as the speech progresses.

column1: Good evening, sir.
column2: Good evening.

column1: It was very kind of you to leave this out for me, sir. There was no-one around when I finished my bath, so I started. I hope that's alright, sir.
column2: Of course. Food alright?

column1: Great, sir. Great.
column2: Try the wine!

column1: Thank you very much, sir. Cheers Suddenly the thought occurs to Alex that the wine may be drugged or poisoned.
column2: Won't you join me, sir?

column1: No, my health doesn't allow it.
column2: And you, sir?

column1: I'm so pleased you appreciate good wine. Have another glass!
column2: Thank you, sir.

column1: My wife... Alex freezes.
column2: ... used to do everything for me and leave me to my writing.

column1: Your wife, sir? Has she gone away?
column2: No. She's dead!

column1: I'm sorry to hear about that, sir. His face contorted in rage.
column2: She was very badly raped, you see. We were assaulted by a gang of vicious young hooligans in this house, in this very room you're sitting in now. I was left a helpless cripple. The doctors said it was Pneumonia, because it happened some months later during the 'flu epidemic. The doctors told me it was Pneumonia, but I knew what it was. A victim of the modern age, poor, poor girl. Suddenly his mood changes. He wheels right up to Alex.

column1: And now you, another victim of the modern age. But you can be helped. I phoned some friends while you were having a bath.
column2: Phoned some friends, sir?

column1: Yes. They want to help.
column2: Help me, sir?

column1: Help you.
column2: Who are they, sir?

column1: They're very, very important people and they're interested in you. Bell rings. Julian rises,
column2: Julian. This will be these people now. Alex gets up.

column1: Look, sir. I'm sorry to have troubled you. I think I ought to be going, sir. Julian bars the way.
column2: No, no my boy. No trouble at all. Alex slowly sits.

column1: Excuse me, missus, can you please help? There's been a terrible accident. Can I please use your telephone for an ambulance?
column2: I'm frightfully sorry. There is a telephone in the Public House about a mile down the road. I suggest you use that.

column1: But, missus, this is an emergency. It's a matter of life and death. Me friend's lying in the middle of the road bleeding to death.
column2: I... I'm very sorry, but I never open. I'm very sorry but I never open the door to strangers after dark.

column1: Hi, hi, hi there, at last we meet.
column2: What the bloody hell d'you think you're doing?

column1: Our brief govereet thru the letter hole was not, shall we say, satisfactory, yes?
column2: Now listen here, you little bastard, just you turn around and walk out of here the same way as you came in. Alex eyes a giant white, fibreglass phallic sculpture on the table beside him.

column1: Naughty, naughty, naughty, you filthy old soomaka.
column2: No! No! Don't touch it. That's a very important work of art. What the bloody hell do you want?

column1: You see, madam, I am part of an international student's contest to see who can get the most points for selling magazines.
column2: Cut the shit, sonny, and get out of here before you get yourself in some very serious trouble. He rocks the giant phallus which has a special weight swinging inside causing it to swing up and down an eccentric motion.

column1: So this is the young man?
column2: How do you do, sir?

column1: Hullo.
column2: Missus. Very pleased to meet you.

column1: Very kind of you, sir. Thank you very much.
column2: I understand that you had a rather unfortunate encounter with the Police tonight.

column1: Yes, sir. I suppose you might call it that, sir.
column2: Hahaha, and how are you feeling now?

column1: Much better, thank you, sir.
column2: Feel like talking to us. Answering a few questions?

column1: Fine, sir, fine.
column2: Well, as I've said, we've heard about you. We are interested in your case. We want to help you.

column1: Thank you very much, sir.
column2: But first we'd like to find out a few things about you.

column1: What would you like to know, sir?
column2: Well, shall we get down to it?

column1: It's past eight, Alex, you don't want to be late for school, son.
column2: Bit of pain in the gulliver, Mum. Leave us be and I'll try to sleep it off... then I'll be as right as dodgers for this after.

column1: You've not been to school all week, son.
column2: I've got to rest, Mum... got to get fit, otherwise I'm liable to miss a lot more school.

column1: Eeee... I'll put your breakfast in the oven. I've got to be off myself now.
column2: Alright, Mum... have a nice day at the factory.

column1: Hi. Hi. Hi, there my Pee and Em. All three look up startled.
column2: Alex.

column1: Why didn't you let us know what was happening, son?
column2: Sorry, Em, I wanted it to be like... a big surprise for you and pee.

column1: Ah, Alex boy, awake at last, yes? I met your mother on the way to work, yes? She gave me the key. She said something about a pain somewhere... hence not at school , yes?
column2: A rather intolerable pain in the head, brother, sir. I think it should be clear by this afterlunch.

column1: Oh, or certainly by this evening, yes? The evening's a great time, isn't it, Alex boy?
column2: A cup of the old chai, sir?

column1: No time, no time, yes. Sit, sit, sit. Alex sits next to him.
column2: To what do I owe this extreme pleasure, sir? Anything wrong, sir? Deltoid "playfully" grabs Alex's hair.

column1: Wrong? Why should you think of anything being wrong, have you been doing something you shouldn't. Yes? He shakes Alex's hair.
column2: Just a manner of speech, sir.

column1: Well, yes, it's just a manner of speech from your Post Corrective Advisor to you that you watch out, little Alex. He puts his arm round Alex's shoulder.
column2: Because next time it's going to be the barry place and all my work ruined. If you've no respect for your horrible self, you at least might have some for me who'se sweated over you. He slaps Alex on the knee.

column1: A big black mark I tell you for every one we don't reclaim. A confession of failure for every one of you who ends up in the stripy hole.
column2: I've been doing nothing I shouldn't, sir. The millicents have nothing on me, brother, sir, I mean. Deltoid pulls Alex down on the bed.

column1: Cut out all this clever talk about milicents. Just because the Police haven't picked you up lately doesn't, as you very well know, mean that you've not been up to some nastiness. There was a bit of a nastiness last night, yes. Some very extreme nastiness, yes. A few of a certain Billyboy's friends were ambluenced off late last night, yes. Your name was mentioned, the word's got thru to me by the usual channels. Certain friends of yours were named also. Oh, nobody can prove anything about anybody as usual, but I'm warning you, little Alex, being a good friend to you as always, the one man in this sore and sick community who wants to save you from yourself. Deltoid makes a grab for Alex's joint but finds his hand instead. Alex laughs. Derisively and rises. Deltoid distractedly reaches for a glass of water on the night table, and fails to notice a set of false teeth soaking in them. He drinks from the glass. The clink of the teeth sounding like ice-cubes.
column2: What gets into you all? We study the problem. We've been studying it for damn well near a century, yes, but we get no further with our studies. You've got a good home here, good loving parents, you've got not too bad of a brain. Is it some devil that crawls inside of you?

column1: Nobody's got anything on me, brother, sir. I've been out of the rookers of the milicents for a long time now.
column2: That's just worries me. A bit too long to long to be reasonable. You're about due now by my reckoning, that's why I'm warning you, little Alex, to keep your handsome young proboscis out of the dirt. Do I make myself clear?

column1: You are now a murderer, little Alex. A murderer, yes.
column2: Not true, sir. It was only a slight tolchock. She was breathing, I swear it.

column1: I've just come back from the hospital. Your victim has died.
column2: You try to frighten me, sir, admit so, sir. This is some new form of torture. Say it, brother, sir.

column1: The newspapers mentioned that in addition to your being conditioned against acts of sex and violence, you've inadvertently been conditioned against music.
column2: Well, er, I think that was something that they hadn't planned for, you see, Missus, I'm very fond of music and always have been, especially Beethoven, Ludwig van... Beethoven. B... E... E... He leans over and looks at her writing in notebook.

column1: It's alright, thank you.
column2: And it just so happened that while they were showing me a particularly bad film, of like a concentration camp, the background music was playing Beethoven.

column1: So now you have the same reaction to music as you do to sex and violence?
column2: Oh well, it's... it's not all music you see, Missus. It's just the 9th.

column1: You mean Beethoven's 9th Symphony?
column2: That's right. Er... I can't listen to the 9th any more at all. When I hear the 9th, I get like this funny feeling.

column1: When you say this funny feeling, you mean the state of mind brought on by the treatment they gave you?
column2: That is correct, sir. And then all I can think about is like trying to snuff it.

column1: I beg your pardon?
column2: Snuff it, sir... um... death, I mean, missus... Er... I just want to die peacefully like with no... pain.

column1: Do you feel that way now?
column2: Um... oh no, sir, not exactly, I still feel very miserable, very much down in spirits.

column1: Do you still feel suicidal?
column2: Um... well, put it this way... I feel very low in myself. I can't see much in the future, and I feel that any second something terrible is going to happen to me. He pitches forward, face into the plate of spaghetti.

column1: We got worried. There we were waiting and drinking away at the old knify Moloko and you had not turned up and we thought you might have been like offended by something or other, so around we come to your abode.
column2: Appy polly loggies. I had something of a pain in the gulliver so had to sleep. I was not awakened when I gave orders for awakening.

column1: All right, no more picking on Dim, brother. That's part of the new way.
column2: New way? What's this about a new way? There's been some very large talk behind my sleeping back, and no error. Let me hear more.

column1: And what will you do with the big, big, money? Have you not everything you need? If you need a motor-car, you pluck it from the trees. If you need pretty polly, you take it.
column2: Brother, you think and talk sometimes like a little child. Tonight we pull a mansize crast.

column1: Good. Real horrorshow. Initiative comes to them as waits. I've taught you much, my little droogies. Now tell me what you have in mind, Georgie Boy.
column2: Oh, the old moloko-plus first, would you not say

column1: Not tonight - not this nochy.
column2: Come, come, come, Georgie Boy. You're a big strong chelloveck like us all. We're not little children, are we, Georgie Boy? What, then, didst thou in thy mind have? Confrontation. Georgie backs down.

column1: It's this Health Farm. A bit out of the town. Isolated. It's owned by this like very rich ptitsa who lives there with her cats. The place is shut down for a week and she's completely on her own, and it's full up with like gold and silver and like jewels.
column2: Tell me more, Georgie Boy.

column1: Who said that?
column2: I did, sir.

column1: What crime did you commit.
column2: The accidental killing of a person, sir.

column1: Thank you very much for this chance, sir.
column2: Let's hope you make the most of it, my boy.

column1: She came towards me with the light like it was the like light of heavenly grace, and the first thing that flashed into my gulliver was that I would like to have her right down there on the floor with the old in-out, real savage. But quick as a shot came the sickness, like a detective that had been watching around the corner and now followed to make his arrest. Alex retching. Minister rises.
column2: Thank you very much. Thank you my dear. Girl bows and exits to loud applause.

column1: Not feeling too bad now are you?
column2: No, sir, I feel really great.

column1: Good.
column2: Was I alright, sir? Did I do well, sir?

column1: Good evening, my boy.
column2: Hi, hi, hi there, my little droogies.

column1: Yes, sir, and a very lovely place it is too, sir, when I wake up in the middle of the night with my pain.
column2: Yes... well good to see you on the mend. I've kept in constant touch with the hospital, of course, and now I've come to see you personally to see how you're getting along.

column1: I've suffered the tortures of the damned. The tortures of the damned, sir.
column2: Yes I can... Oh look, let me do that for you, shall I?

column1: Thank you, sir.
column2: I can tell you that I... and the Government of which I am a member are deeply sorry about this, my boy. Deeply sorry. We tried to help you. We followed recommendations had been made to us that turned out to be wrong. An enquiry will place the responsibility where it belongs. We want you to regard us as friends. We've put you right, you're the best of treatments. We never wished you harm, but there are some that did and do, and I think you know who those are. There are certain people who wanted to use you for political ends. People who would have been glad to have you dead because then they would have been able to blame it all on the Government. I think you know who those are. There is also a certain man - a writer of subversive literature - who has been howling for your blood. He's been mad with desire to stick a knife into you, but you're safe from him now, we've put him away. He found out that you had done wrong to him - at least he believed you had done wrong. He had formed this idea in his head that you h

column1: Where is he now, sir?
column2: We put him away where he can do you no harm. You see we are looking after your interests. We are interested in you, and when you leave here you will have no further worries. We shall see to everything... a good job on a good salary.

column1: What job and how much?
column2: You must have an interesting job at a salary which you would regard as adequate. Not only for the job which you are going to do and in compensation for what you believe you have suffered, but also because you are helping us.

column1: Helping you, sir?
column2: We always help our friends, don't we?  It is no secret that the Government has lost a lot of popularity because of you, my boy. There are some that think that at the next election we shall be out. The press has chosen to take a very unfavourable view of what we tried to do.

column1: Well, who can blame them, sir?
column2: Mmmm, possibly. Yes. But public opinion has a way of changing and you, Alex, if I may call you, Alex?

column1: Certainly, sir. What do they call you at home?
column2: My name is Frederick. As I was saying, Alex, you can be instrumental in changing the public verdict. Do you understand, Alex? Have I made myself clear?

column1: As an unmuddied lake, Fred. As clear as an azure sky of deepest summer. You can rely on me, Fred.
column2: Good... good boy. Oh yes, I understand you're fond of music. I have arranged a little surprise for you.

column1: Surprise?
column2: One I think you will like... as a, how shall I put it, as a symbol of our new understanding. An understanding between two friends.

column1: Hullo lad. What a surprise, good to see you.
column2: Keeping fit then?

column1: Fine, fine.
column2: Well, how are you then?

column1: Oh fine, fi. Keeping out of trouble, you know.
column2: Well - I'm back.

column1: That's right, Dad they did a great job on my gulliver, I'm completely reformed.
column2: Aye.

column1: Well, still the same old place then, eh?
column2: Oh, aye, aye.

column1: Hey, Dad, there's a strange fella sitting on the sofa there munchy- wunching lomticks of toast.
column2: Aye, that's Joe. He... ummmm, lives here now. The lodger. That's what he is... he... he rents your room. Alex confronts Joe.

column1: No thanks, Mum. It'll pass in a minute...  ... What have you done with all my own personal things?
column2: Well. That was all took away, son, by the Police. New regulation about compensation for the victim.

column1: What about Basil? Where's my snake?
column2: Oh well, he met with like an accident. He passed away. Alex becomes a bit weepy.

column1: What's gonna happen to me then? I mean that's my room he's in - there's no denying that. This is my home also. What suggestions have you, my Pee and Em, to make?
column2: Well, all this needs thinking about, son. I mean we can't very well just kick Joe out... Not just like that, can we? I mean Joe is here doing a job. A contract it is, two years. Well, we made like an arrangement, didn't we Joe? You see, son, Joe's paid next month's rent already so, well, whatever we do in the future, we cant just say to Joe to get out, now can we?

column1: What gives, O my Pee and Em, what makes you think you are welcome? Em sobs. Pee comforts her.
column2: There, there mother, it's alright. He doesn't mean it. You were in the papers again, son. It said they had done great wrong to you. It said how the Government drove you to try and do yourself in... and when you think about it, son... maybe it was our fault too in a way... your home's your home when it's all said and done, son. Em sobs.

column1: Hello, heap of dirt. Pooh, you don't wash much do you, judging by the horrible smell.
column2: Why do you say that, brother? I had a shower this morning.

column1: Oh, he had a shower this morning. You trying to call me a liar?
column2: No, brother. What d'you want?

column1: What do I want?
column2: Sorry, brother. I didn't mean any offence.

column1: Oh. Oh, you're sorry are you, well you must think I'm awfully stupid. He slaps Alex in the face.
column2: Why did you do that, brother? I've never done wrong to you.

column1: You want to know why I did that, well you see - I do that... He stamps on Alex's foot.
column2: ... and this... He pulls Alex's nose.

column1: ... and that... He pulls Alex's ear, pushes him off balance and plants his foot on his chest.
column2: ... because I don't like you horrible type, do I, and if you want to start something... if you want to start... go on... well, you just start. Please do. Alex retching.

column1: I'm gonna be sick.
column2: You're gonna be sick are you?

column1: I wanna be sick.
column2: You wanna be sick?

column1: Let me get up.
column2: You wanna get up? Well, you've gotta you see... well I want you to lick it. Go on... Lick it. Alex, gagging and coughing, licks the sole of his shoe.

column1: ... And again... Go on!!! Again! There's a good boy.
column2: And, O my brothers, would you believe your faithful friend and long suffering narrator pushed out his red yahzik a mile and a half to lick the grahzny, vonny boots. The horrible killing sickness had wooshed up and turned the like joy of battle into a feeling I was going to snuff it. Minister rises.

One address book - imitation red leather. One ten penny piece. One white metal wristlet watch, "Timawrist" on a white metal expanding bracelet. Anything else in your pockets?

column2: Right. Sign here for your valuable property. Alex signs.

column1: The next morning I was taken to the Ludovico Medical Facility, outside the town centre, and I felt a malenky bit sad having to say goodbye to the old Staja, as you always will when you leave a place you've like gotten used to. Chief Guard briskly leads the way for Alex and escort. They move into reception hall where the Doctor stands.
column2: Right. Halt the prisoner. Good morning, sir, I'm Chief Officer Barnes. I've got 655321 on a transfer from Parkmoor to the Ludovico Centre, sir!

column2: Good Morning, Missus. Lovely day, isn't it?

column1: Indeed it is. May I take this She removes his tray.
column2: How're you feeling this morning?

column1: Fine... fine.
column2: Good. In a few minutes, you'll meeting Dr. Brodsky and we'll begin your treatment. You're a very lucky boy to have been chosen.

column1: I realise all that, Missus, and I'm very grateful to all concerned.
column2: We're going to friends now, sir.

column2: What's the hypo for then? Going to send me to sleep?

column1: Oh no, nothing of the sort.
column2: Vitamins will it be then?

column1: Something like that. You are a little undernourished, so after each meal were going to give you a shot. Roll over on your right side please, loosen your pyjama pants and pull them half-way down. He does, somewhat reluctantly. She gives him a shot in the bum.
column2: What exactly is the treatment here going to be then?

column1: It's quite simple really. Were just going to show you some films.
column2: You mean like going to the pictures?

column1: Something like that.
column2: Well, that's good. I like to viddy the old films now and again.

column1: Well, that was a very promising start. By my calculations, you should be starting to feel alright again. Yes? Dr. Brodsky's pleased with you. Now tomorrow there'll be two sessions, of course, morning and afternoon.
column2: You mean, I have to viddy two sessions in one day?

column1: I imagine you'll be feeling a little bit limp by the end of the day. But we have to be hard on you. You have to be cured.
column2: But it was horrible.

column1: Well, of course, it was horrible. Violence is a very horrible thing. That's what you're learning now. Your body is learning it.
column2: I just don't understand about feeling sick the way I did. I never used to feel sick before. I used to feel like the very opposite. I mean, doing it or watching it, I used to feel real horrorshow. I just don't understand why, how what.

column1: Are you referring to the background score?
column2: Yes!!!

column1: You've heard Beethoven before?
column2: Yes!!!

column1: How are you feeling today?
column2: Fine. Fine.

column1: Good. I'm doctor Taylor.
column2: I haven't seen you before.

column1: I'm your Psychiatrist.
column2: Psychiatrist? Huh, do I need one?

column1: Just part of hospital routine.
column2: What are we going to do? Talk about me sex life?

column1: No... I'm going to show you some slides and you are going to tell me what you think about them Alright?
column2: Ohhh... jolly good. Perhaps you can explain me something to me first.

column1: Yes?
column2: Well, when I was all like ashamed up and half awake and unconscious like, I kept having this dream like all these doctors were playing around with me gulliver. You know... like the inside of me brain. I seemed to have this dream over and over again. D'you think it means anything?

column1: Patients who've sustained the kind of injuries you have often have dreams of this sort. It's all part of the recovery process.
column2: Oh.

column1: Now then, each of these slides needs a reply from one of the people in the picture. You'll tell me what you think the person would say. Alright?
column2: Righty, right. The doctor reads aloud the dialogue printed in the cartoon balloon - a peacock.

column1: Isn't the plumage beautiful?
column2: I just say what the other person would say?

column1: Yes. Yes, well don't think about it too long, just say the first thing that pops into your mind.
column2: Right... Knickers... Cabbages... It doesn't have a beak. Alex laughs. Slide of woman speaking to boy.

column1: Good. The boy you always quarrelled with is seriously ill.
column2: That's right and I'll smash your face for you, yarblockos. Slide of watch shop.

column1: Good. It wa your fault... you sold me a crummy watch. I want my money back.
column2: Bollocks. You know what you can do with that watch? You can stick it up your arse. Slide of nude woman in bed, a man at the window.

column1: Good. What do you want?
column2: Excuse me, missus. No time for the old in-out, I've just come to read the meter. Slide of bird's nest with eggs.

column1: Good. You can do whatever you like with these.
column2: Eggiwegs. I would like to smash 'em. Pick up th elot and f... owww... He slams his hand down and cries out with pain.

column1: Fucking hell...
column2: Fine. Well, that's all there is to it. Are you alright?

column1: I hope so. Is that the end then?
column2: Yes.

column1: I was quite enjoying that.
column2: Good. I'm glad

column1: How many did I get right?
column2: It's not that kind of a test. But you seem well on the way to a complete recovery.

column1: And when do I get out of here then?
column2: I'm sure it won't be long now.

column1: Very soon now the drug will cause the subject to experience a death- like paralysis together with deep feelings of terror and helplessness. One of our earlier test subjects described it as being like death, a sense of stifling and drowning, and it is during this period we have found the subject will make his most rewarding associations between his catastrophic experience and environment and the violence he sees. Alex retching violently and struggling against his strait jacket.
column2: Let me be sick... I want to get up. Get me something to be sick in... Stop the film... Please stop it... I can't stand it any more. Stop it please... please.

column1: You needn't take it any further, sir. You've proved to me that all this ultra-violence and killing is wrong and terribly wrong. I've learned my lesson, sir. I see now what I've never seen before I'm cured, praise Bog!
column2: You're not cured yet, my boy.

column1: You must take your chance boy. The choice has been all yours.
column2: But, Sir... Missus... I see that it's wrong! It's wrong because it's like against like society. It's wrong because everybody has the right to live and be happy without being tolchocked and knifed.

column1: One thing I could never stand is to see a filthy, dirty old drunkie, howling away at the filthy songs of his fathers and going blerp, blerp in between as it might be a filthy old orchestra in his stinking rotten guts. I could never stand to see anyone like that, whatever his age might be, but more especially when he was real old like this one was. The boys stop and applaud him.
column2: Can you... can you spare some cutter, me brothers? Alex rams his stick into the Tramp's stomach. The boys laugh.

column1: Oh-hhh!!! Go on, do me in you bastard cowards. I don't want to live anyway, not in a stinking world like this.
column2: Oh - and what's so stinking about it?

column1: Can you spare me some cutter, me brother? Can you spare some cutter, me brother? Alex, without looking at him, reaches in his pocket and gives him some money.
column2: Oh, thankyou, your honour. The Tramp takes a second look at Alex.

column1: Jamey Mack! Be the hokey fly! Holy Mother of God! All the Holy Angels and blessed saints in Heaven preserve us. Alex breaks away but the Tramp toddles alongside him.
column2: I never forget a face! I never forget any face, be God!

column1: Leave me alone, brother. I've never seen you before. Tramp shouts to other Meths drinkers and Tramps.
column2: This is the poisonous young swine that near done me in. Him and his friends beat me and kicked me and thumped me. Alex breaks away again.

column2: They laughed at me blood and me moans. This murderous young pig is a prize specimen of the cowardly brutal young. He is in our midst and at our mercy. Give it to him. That's it. Old Tramps begin to beat at Alex.

column1: If thou lose hope being weary in the days of distress, thy strength shall be diminished.
column2: Fine, my boy, fine, fine.

column1: Father, I have tried, have I not?
column2: You have, my son.

column1: I've done my best, have I not?
column2: Indeed.

column1: And, Father, I've never been guilty of any institutional infractions, have I?
column2: You certainly have not, 655321. You've been very helpful, and you've shown a genuine desire to reform.

column1: Father - may I ask you a question in private?
column2: Certainly, my son, certainly. Is there something troubling you, my son? Don't be shy to speak up. Remember, I know all the urges that can trouble young men deprived of the society of women.

column1: No Father. It's nothing like that, Father. It's about this new thing they're all talking about. About this new treatment that you out of prison in no time at all and makes sure you never get back in again.
column2: Where did you hear about this? Whose been talking about these things?

column1: These things get around, Father. Two Warders talk as it might be, and somebody can't help overhearing what they say. Then somebody picks up a scrap of newspaper in the workshops and the newspaper tells all about it. How about putting me in for this new treatment, Father?
column2: I take it you are referring to the Ludovico Technique?

column1: I don't know what it's called, Father, all I know is that it gets you out quickly and makes sure that you never get in again.
column2: That's not proven, 655321. In fact, it is only in the experimental stage at this moment.

column1: But it is being used, isn't it, Father?
column2: It has not been used yet in this prison. The Governor has grave doubts about it and I have heard that there are very serious dangers involved.

column1: I don't care about the danger, Father. I just want to be good. I want for the rest of my life to be one act of goodness.
column2: The question is weather or not this technique really makes a man good. Goodness comes from within. Goodness is chosen. When a man cannot chose, he ceases to be a man.

column1: I don't understand about the whys and wherefores, Father. I only know I want to be good.
column2: Be patient, my son, and put your trust in the Lord.

column1: Instruct thy son and he shall refresh thee and shall give delight to thy soul.
column2: Amen. They cross themselves.

column1: Is it possible...?

column1: You don't believe it to be... tell me something, Doctor.  Why do you think they would go to all this trouble... bring you tens of thousands of light years, and then send you home without a shred of proof?  Sort of bad form, wouldn't you say?  What was their intent?

column1: -- Or 'you're our kind of people --'
