column1: Now I remember why I went into theoretical work.  Kent.
column2: Glad to have you, David.  How's the new office?

column1: Nothing.  Okay.  Some of us have been a little... not concerned, exactly, but...
column2: Tell me.

column1: Last week, about 3 A.M., Fish -- Dr. Fisher -- was on a late shift, and he found her doing laundry.
column2: So?

column1: I'm sorry, Miss Arroway, not only is it too Speculative a subject for a doctoral dissertation, at this point in your career it'd be tantamount to suicide.
column2: I'm willing to take that risk.

column1: I'm not.  You're far too promising a scientist to waste your considerable gifts on this nonsense --
column2: Dr. Drumlin, we are talking about what could potentially be the most important discovery in the history of humanity.  There are over four hundred billion stars out there --

column1: And only two probabilities:  One: there is intelligent life in the universe but they're so far away you'll never contact it in your lifetime --
column2: You're --

column1: Two:  There's nothing out there but noble gasses and carbon compounds and you'd be wasting your time.
column2: What if you're wrong?  No -- I'll grant you probabilities but as a scientist without all the evidence -- you can't deny the possibility -- and I believe even the remotest possibility of something this profoundly... profound is worth investigation -- and worth taking a few risks.

column1: I disagree.
column2: Then disagree but don't stand in my way!

column1: Pepsi?  Tequila?
column2: No, thanks.

column1: Peter sends his regards.
column2: Oh?  How's he doing?

column1: Very well
column2: Really?  Congratulations, by the way.

column1: I'm surprised you even knew it was an election year.
column2: 'President's Science Advisor' -- so what, you just spend all your time jetting around on Air Force One now...?

column1: Now exactly.  It's... complicated.
column2: No doubt.

column1: Ellie...
column2: Did I tell you we've expanded the search spectrum?  We're including several other possible magic frequencies -- not just the hydrogen line anymore.  I was trying to get inside their heads, y'know?  And I started thinking, what other constants are there in the Universe besides hydrogen, and then suddenly it was so obvious -- transcendantals, right?  So we've been trying variations of pi...

column1: You know why I'm here.
column2: It's not enough having my search time systematically cut down -- you know I'm down to three hours a week now.

column1: Ellie, I should have done this a long time ago, certainly before I left the N.S.F., but I wanted to give you every benefit of the doubt --
column2: You can't just pull the plug, David.

column1: It's not like you've given me much choice.
column2: Meaning...

column1: Meaning I have to go defend a budget to the President and to Congress and you're out here listening to washing machines.
column2: I'm searching for patterns in the noise, that's all.  Order in the chaos.  I'm practicing listening --

column1: The point is, this isn't just scientific inquiry anymore -- it's turned into some kind of personal obsession.
column2: The difference being what -- that I refuse to adopt the standard line, that I don't care about the results of my work?  Well, I do care.  Of course any discovery has to be verifiable, of course it must be subject to all rigors of scientific method, but I refuse to go around pretending I'm some kind of dispassionate automaton when it's obvious to anyone with a brain I'm just not.

column1: No... You're not.  But the price has just gotten too high.
column2: Goddamnit, they are out there, David --

column1: Then why haven't you detected any signals?  If, as you claim, there have been thousands, millions of advanced civilizations out there for millions of years then why hasn't one signal gotten through?  It'll take a month or two for the paperwork to go through
column2: David --

column1: Mathematics is the only truly universal language, Senator.  We think this may be a beacon -- an announcement to get our attention.
column2: If it's attention you want I'd say you've got it.  Just one thing:  Why Vega? Everyone's looked at Vega for years with no results, and now, yesterday, they start broadcasting primes. Why?

column1: ... could it be a nested code of some sort?
column2: You must have checked the signal for polarization modulation already...

column1: Throw a gray scale on it
column2: Rotate 90 degrees counterclock wise.

column1: ... Arrangements also have to be made for the V.I.P.s coming in, mostly religious leaders...
column2: What?  Why?

column1: The theological ramifications of all this are obvious
column2: With me.

column1: Apparently he's genuinely interested in science.  This could be a chance to win him over.
column2: I'm going to convert Mr. Science-is- the-root-of-all-evil?  This is absurd, David.  We have work to do here, I don't have time to play babysitter to the God Squad.

column1: I want you to listen to me, carefully.  The minute the implications of this message became clear, this stopped being simply a scientific matter and became a political one -- an extremely complex, extremely volatile one. There are forces at work here you don't understand
column2: Are you threatening me?

column1: Ms. President, this is communist paranoia right out of War of the Worlds.  There is no reason whatsoever to believe the ETIs intentions are hostile.  We pose no threat to them -- it would be like us going out of our way to destroy microbes on a beach in Africa.
column2: Interesting analogy.  And how guilty would we feel if we happened to destroy some microbes on a beach in Africa?

column1: What is it?  What's happened?
column2: We've cracked it.  Lunacharsky found it.

column1: You mean --
column2: You were right, Ellie.  You were right all along.

column1: David --
column2: Ellie.

column1: Do you have a minute -- ?
column2: Actually I'm running late --

column1: David... I know we've had our differences... but I've always thought of you as a fair man, even when we've disagreed -- and It's in that light I'm hoping you'll consider my request...
column2: I don't understand.

column1: I'm asking for your help, David.  I want to go.  They'll need someone relatively young, unattached -- and probably a scientist.  As the President's Science Advisor you have enormous weight... I'm asking if you'll support my candidacy.
column2: Ellie... you should know that I'm no longer the President's Science Advisor.

column1: What?
column2: As of three o'clock this afternoon. I submitted my resignation.

column1: You...
column2: Excuse me, I'm late for a meeting.

column1: ... Two years is still a hell of a long time -- and as far as we can tell there aren't any provisions in the machine design for storing food, water, even air...
column2: ... I can't believe they wouldn't take something as basic as our biological needs into account...

column1: They knew our level of development. If, as you say, they've done this many times they'd be well aware of the implications.
column2: Maybe they are.  Maybe this is all part of the package.  The building of the machine has demanded international cooperation on an unprecedented scale.  Maybe requiring us to come together in this way was, in effect, part of the plan.

column1: You aren't staying?
column2: This... seemed best.

column1: Right.  Well.
column2: Good luck, David.

column1: Ellie... we both know that if I was any kind of a man, I never would've entered this race.  That I would have told the President straight out:  Helen, Eleanor Arroway is naive and strident and an enormous pain in the ass... but she's got more courage and intelligence than the rest of us put together.  That more then anyone else on the planet, she's earned this.  And that she should be the one to go because she's the best we have.  But that's not who I am.  I like to think it's who I might've been if things had gone a different way
column2: What would you have me say, David?

column1: Nothing.  I guess I just wanted to thank you.
column2: Thank you?

column1: What does it say?
column2: It could be anything.  The first volume of some Encyclopedia Galactica...

column1: Because you cut it from the budget three years running.
column2: How soon will you be able to decode it?

column1: ... And while its function remains, for the moment, a mystery, my best guess is that it represents a transport of some kind.
column2: A transport.  So are they coming or are we going?

column1: Mr. Rank's organization represents the point of view of tens of millions of families, Dr. Arroway. Feel free to disagree, but there won't be any suppressing of opinions here today.
column2: Yes -- of course -- all I'm saying is, this message was written in the language of science -- mathematics -- and was clearly intended to be received by scientists.  If it had been religious in nature it should have taken the form of a burning bush, or a booming voice from the sky...

column1: What's the status of the decryption effort?
column2: Well --

column1: Dr. Lunacharsky...?
column2: Analyzing signal polarization shifts.

column1: What...
column2: In ancient times when parchment was in short supply people would write over old writing... it was called a palimpsest.

column1: There's no way of knowing.  Without a key -- a primer, to help us, maybe never.
column2: Maybe it'll be at the end of the data when the message recycles.

column1: What?
column2: We've repeated.  A few minutes ago the message cycled back to page one.

column1: And?
column2: No primer.

column1: How can that be?
column2: I don't know.  Maybe there is a fourth layer in there somewhere, but if there is, I sure as hell can't find it.
Been there, done that, got the T-shirt.

column2: I'm not sure.  You mind checking right ascension 18 hours, 34 minutes

column2: 1919+21.  Found a glitch in the timing

column1: Here, right around Centaurus A.
column2: This is how you see the sky?

column2: It's beautiful.

column1: You've only searched -- what is it, sixteen hundred stars without a peep?  Try not to take it too personally.
column2: Thank you, Mr. Sensitive.  I'm coming at this wrong... missing something... something...

column2: It can't be coming from Vega, the system's too young.

column2: It's a civilian facility.

column1: I think we just hit the cosmic jackpot.
column2: It's incredibly rich.  We've been cataloging it in frames or 'pages'

column2: This isn't a person to person call, Mr. Kitz.  I don't really think the civilization sending the message intended it just for Americans.

column1: I'm saying you might have consulted us
column2: You want to classify prime numbers?

column1: -- which we'll also need the network's help to receive and decode!
column2: You don't seem to understand that it's your interests I'm trying to protect -- !

column2: And a hundred mile airspace.

column1: Pardon me, but you can't do -- !

column1: ... I don't understand it.  All I can think is that maybe because the video gear wasn't accounted for in the original plans it somehow violated the integrity of the design.
column2: Is that your official response?

column1: There is no direct evidence, no.
column2: And current theory holds that to sustain the sort of wormholes you're talking about, even for a fraction of a second, would require more energy than our sun produces in a year, is that correct?

column1: I don't have the figures in front of me, but yes, that sounds about right.
column2: In fact, by all the laws of physics we know what you claim to have experienced is simply impossible.

column1: Please answer the question, Doctor.
column2: Is it possible.  Yes.  But --

column1: Thank you, Doctor.  Now --
column2: -- but I don't believe it to be the truth.

column1: So why don't you admit what by your own standards must be the truth: that this experience simply didn't happen.
column2: Because I can't.

column1: Small moves, Captain, small moves.
column2: I can't move any smaller.

column1: Talk to him.
column2: But what do I say?

column1: Could we hear to China?
column2: On that old shortwave?  Maybe on a clear night.  Come on now, under the covers.

column1: Could we hear to the moon?
column2: Big enough radio, I don't see why not.

column1: Could we hear God?
column2: Mmm, that's a good one.  Maybe his echo...  Okay, no more stalling.

column1: Pensacola.
column2: That's a beauty, Captain.  Now get some sleep.

column1: Time to sleep now, Captain.  But you can ask more questions in the morning, okay?
column2: Okay.

column1: I used... I used to dream you were alive... and then I'd wake up and lose you all over again.
column2: I'm sorry I couldn't be there for you, sweetheart.

column1: You're not real.  None of this is.
column2: That's my scientist.

column1: So.  Are you an hallucination?  Or are little gear trains and circuit boards under your skin?
column2: Am I artifact or dream?  You might ask that about anything.

column1: But you're so... I mean how could you possibly...?  When I was unconscious.  You... downloaded... my thoughts, my memories, even...  This beach.  I've never been here but I remember... it's how I always imagined...  Pensacola.
column2: We thought this might make things a little easier.

column1: So who -- what -- are you?
column2: Originally just another species like yourselves.  Well, not like you at all actually, but...

column1: Can you show me?
column2: Small moves, Captain, small moves.

column1: Why did you contact us?
column2: You contacted us.  We were simply listening.  We've been listening for millions of years.

column1: And those other docking ports I saw... I mean... there are others?
column2: Many others.

column1: And they all travel here through this wormhole subway system you built.
column2: Oh, we didn't build it.  The transit system has been in place for billions of years

column1: So who...?
column2: We don't know.  Whoever they were, they were gone long before we ever got here.

column1: The scale... it's just...  So all the civilizations you detect
column2: Not all.  Some choose to stay at home and dream their dreams.  Some never make it this far.

column1: So we passed some kind of test?
column2: You have your mother's hands...  There are no tests, Ellie.  We don't sit in judgment.  Think of us more as... librarians.  Curators of the Universe's rarest and most valuable creation...

column1: ... life is unspeakably rare.  So whenever we do find another civilization, especially one that's... struggling... We send a message.  Sometimes we can offer help.  Sometimes we can't.  But we always try.  Life is simply too precious not to.
column2: Can you help us?

column1: Am I one... or many?
column2: The librarian... or the library...?

column1: ... all those voices... you gather them all together.  Millions of intelligences in one consciousness... and now we're a part of it.
column2: You always have been.  We're all descendants of the same stars, Ellie.  All made of the same primordial atoms.

column1: So.  What happens now?
column2: Now... you go home.

column1: No!  I mean... why so soon?
column2: If we don't engineer a consistent causality it'll work itself out on its own, and that's almost always worse.  Ellie, according to your physics none of this is possible.  A lot of it you're simply not capable of understanding, not yet.  No offense.

column1: Eventually you'll get here on your own.  This was just the first step
column2: But -- other people from our planet should see what I've seen -- they should witness this for themselves.

column1: That isn't the way it works.
column2: But you said you wanted to help -- don't you see what it would mean?

column1: No more stalling, Captain.
column2: Please -- if you... downloaded... everything about us you know the problems we face, the impact it could have -- it could make the difference --

column1: It's time to go home now.
column2: No.  Please.

column1: S.R. Hadden...  You compromised our security codes.
column2: Once upon a time I was a hell of an engineer.  Please, sit, Doctor.  I have guests so rarely, it's important to me they feel welcome in my home.  Did you know this was once Yeltsin's flying dascha?  That dent is where he threw a bottle of vodka at the pilot.  At least that's what the people who sold me the plane said...

column1: You live here.
column2: I find it convenient to keep my interests... mobile.  Anyway, I've had my fill of life on the ground. After spending much of this century pursuing the evils and pleasures the world has to offer -- after outliving three wives and two children...  I find I've had quite enough of planet Earth.

column1: Why am I here, Mr. Hadden?
column2: The infamous, unfashionable bluntness.  You're here so we can do business. I want to make a deal.

column1: What kind of deal?
column2: The powers that be have been quite busy lately, falling over each other to position themselves for the game of the century, if not the millennium.  Perhaps you've noticed.  Perhaps I could help deal you back in.

column1: I didn't realize I was out.
column2: Oh, maybe not out -- but definitely looking for you coat.  I understand you've had some difficulty locating the -- what are you calling it?  The 'primer' that will make decryption possible...  I've found it.

column1: You've... found it.  What could I possibly have that you would want, Mr. Hadden?
column2: I've had a long time to make enemies, Dr. Arroway.  There are many governments, business interests, even religious leaders who would like to see me disappear. And I will grant them their wish soon enough... But before I do, I wish to make a small contribution -- a final gesture of goodwill toward the people of this little planet who've given -- from whom I've taken so much.

column1: If I knew you any better I'd say that doesn't sound like you.
column2: That's my girl...  Lights.

column1: Page after page of data -- over sixty-three thousand in all, if I'm not mistaken... and at the end of each...
column2: A page-break signal.  A period.

column1: Not if you think like a Vegan.
column2: You're saying... there is no separate primer in the message -- because it's on every page so the recipient can decipher it wherever he is --

column1: Some kind of circuitry...?
column2: Very good, Doctor.  I've also detected structural elements, back references, a general movement from the simple to the complex -- all of which would seem to indicate instructions -- an enormously complicated set of instructions -- for building something.

column1: A machine.  But a machine that does what?
column2: That would seem to be the question of the hour.  I want to build it, Doctor.  Of course I'm already lobbying through the usual channels of influence and corruption -- but as I said, my colorful past has made many of those channels... difficult to navigate. I need someone on the inside.

column1: And in return?
column2: In return... you get the primer -- and with it the power to stay in the game.  Do we have a deal?

column1: Mr. Hadden, I'm a scientist
column2: That's my girl.  Done.

column1: A sunrise and a sunset every forty- five minutes.
column2: It's so... small.

column1: What's that?
column2: Japanese squid fleet.  They use lights to attract them to the surface... then turn them into sushi.

column1: It looks like pixie dust...  Kent would've given anything to see this.  David, too.
column2: Yes.  A shame.  Still... it'd be worse if they died for nothing.

column1: What are you talking about?  It's over.
column2: Oh, not quite yet.  At least for their sake...  ... I hope it's not.  Because they're running out of time.

column1: You sound like Joseph.  You think the world ends with the millennium?
column2: I think whoever sent the message did it because they're worried about us.

column1: The gods sent us the machine because they took pity on us.
column2: Wouldn't you if you saw Hitler on TV?  Come

column1: Hokkaido Island.
column2: The systems integration site.

column1: As each component was tested and shipped off to Texas a duplicate was maintained and assembled in Hokkaido -- for backup purposes, of course. We've been right behind you the entire time.  You see my problem:  I couldn't appear to control too large a percentage
column2: -- of Hadden Industries.

column1: Why don't you come back with me?
column2: Can't.  Doctor's orders.  The low oxygen/zero gravity environment is the only thing keeping the cancer from eating me alive.  It's all right -- I like it here. Ever try sex in zero-G?

column1: Very well.  Assume this is true. Assume they have only the best of intentions.  Suppose they decide to just step in and solve all our problems for us.  You have no objection to them so flagrantly intervening in human affairs?
column2: We've just lived through a century of incredible violence and self- destruction.  Do you call it 'interventionist' when you stop a toddler from walking in front of a truck?

column1: I'd say this is slightly different.
column2: Perhaps.  But on the off-chance that it is a 'doomsday device' of some kind, I plan to be very far away from your lovely Texas when it is activated.

column1: I thought you were here because you want to go.
column2: I do.  More than anything.  But I am also a realist.  Soon this... what is your charming term -- ?  Dog and pony show will finally be over, and I will go home.

column1: You're implying that the whole selection process is a sham?
column2: I think it is your naivete I like best about you, Eleanor.  Oh, there'll be a worldwide protest, but we all knew it from the very beginning.  You Americans discovered the signal, you led the decryption effort.  The machine is being built on your home soil... Of course the passenger will be an American, chosen by Americans.  Anyway, it is what the whole world wants, no?  This is the big show. The sort you put on better than anyone.  It's good marketing.  It's good casting.  It's the American way.

column1: ... Drumlin said you're been down at Arecibo for the last year.
column2: It's beautiful but it does get a little lonely.  Sometimes I think the reason we build these things in such godforsaken places isn't to avoid excess radio traffic but because we're all such pathetic antisocial misfits... Speaking of which:  How're you getting on with the old man?

column1: He's an incredible prick but I never learned so much in my life.
column2: That's what they all say.

column1: Ellie.  Arroway.
column2: Peter Valerian.

column1: Sounds like a Russian general.
column2: Yavol.

column1: I read your paper on ETI's.  It's brilliant.
column2: Keep it down, okay?  Drumlin thinks I'm enough of a flake as it is.  Look -- everyone here has their little fetishes.  Caven goes to topless bars, Vernon's got his carnivorous plants... mine just happens to be extraterrestrial intelligence.

column1: ... I'm just so sick of feeling defensive about the things I care about!  Or being lumped in with the lunatic fringe by people like Drumlin, when if they'd just put aside their preconceptions for two seconds and look at the facts...
column2: They can't.  I think it's against human nature to admit to that level of... insignificance

column1: It's like the pre-Copernicans who swore the sun revolved around the Earth, or the Victorians at the end of the last century who concluded that all major discoveries had now been made.  I mean... try to imagine civilization a thousand years ahead of us -- then imagine trying to explain... I dunno, a microwave oven -- to someone even a hundred years ago -- I mean the basic concepts didn't exist...
column2: 'Any sufficiently advanced technology...'

column1: ... I keep telling myself okay, that's just the price, you have to do your time doing shitwork before you're allowed to get to the good stuff... but if I have to catalog one more quasar...  God, I've missed you.
column2: Any luck on the grant money?

column1: Please.  Any chance of that died the day David Drumlin was appointed head of the N.S.F.  I have been in contact with a few other SETI people
column2: And?

column1: ... We've been going after some of the big multi-nationals but without much luck
column2: Ellie... even if you do manage to raise the money, have you thought about what it would really mean to follow through on this?  I mean a college fetish is one thing, but we're talking about your career. You won't be publishing.  You won't be taken seriously... and you could spend your entire life looking and never find anything at all.

column1: If we lived at any previous time in human history we wouldn't even have the option of failing -- we'd have to wonder our whole lives, unable to do anything about it.  This time, right now, is unique in our history, in any civilization's history -- the moment of the acquisition of technology.  The moment when contact becomes possible.  We've already beaten incredible odds by being lucky enough to be alive now.
column2: How close are you to getting this funding put together?

column1: It's almost there.  The hardest part is getting someone to sell us the telescope time.
column2: What if I said I could get Drumlin to agree to sell you time in New Mexico?

column1: The V.L.A.?
column2: Thirty-one linked dishes.  You could search more sky there in a day than you could in a year here.

column1: Peter -- if you can get him to do that for me he'd obviously do the same for you -- we could -- !
column2: Actually --

column1: We could be together again --
column2: -- I'm moving to Washington.

column1: Greenbank?
column2: I'm going on staff at the N.S.F.  To work for Drumlin.

column1: But what about your research -- ?
column2: This is a chance to be of enormous help to other people's research -- to have the power to be a real advocate where David's got blind spots --

column1: But the work --
column2: 'The work,' Jesus, Ellie, can't there just once be more to life than the work?  Okay, maybe that's the only way to get the recognition, win the prizes --

column1: Please, you're just as ambitious as I am, more --
column2: Maybe that's the problem.  I want... a family, Ellie.  I want kids.  A townhouse on L street instead of still living like a college kid.  A real life.  Maybe that makes me a sellout but I don't care anymore. It's what I want.

column1: And you think I don't want those things?  You think I don't stay up half the night wondering if I've made the right choice living half a world away from you, wondering if any of this is worth what I'm giving up for it everyday?  Let's get married.
column2: Jesus --

column1: Right now -- we'll drive down to Ramey and get the base chaplain to marry us.
column2: Ellie --

column1: I'm serious about this, Peter --
column2: Ellie -- I'm getting married.  Her name's Laura.  She came up to Owens Valley to do her post-doc about six months after you left.

column1: You sonofabitch.
column2: That is true.  But it's also true that if I really thought we wanted the same things, I'd follow you anywhere... but the truth is I don't think you want the company.  Be honest, El.  There's nowhere you'd rather be than sitting out at some remote corner of the world searching for the answers to the mysteries of the universe.  And call me crazy, but I just can't compete with that... I'm sorry.

column1: Ellie.
column2: Peter.

column1: It's good to see you, Ellie.
column2: You too.

column1: Someone tell me this is really happening.
column2: It's really happening.

column1: That you, Valerian?
column2: Like it or not.

column1: Ellie -- are you okay?
column2: I'm -- I'm fine.

column1: Thank God.  When we lost contact, I thought -- we thought... but you're okay.  We're still trying to determine the nature of the malfunction.  Did you notice anything at all that --
column2: Wait -- hold on a minute --

column1: It's all right, the important thing is you're safe --
column2: Peter, what are you talking about? What malfunction?  What day is this?

column1: What day?
column2: How long was I gone?

column1: Peter... What is going on?  Has everyone gone completely insane?
column2: That's one way of putting it.  Kitz, the President, the I.S.C. have shut down all official communications

column1: I agree with Mr. Rank that there are unavoidable religious implications here -- but I don't think it justifies taking an alarmist position.  Dr. Arroway is right -- their chosen means of communication was a scientific one, and a scientific approach is probably appropriate, at least until the theological dimensions of the problem become more apparent.
column2: And where exactly does that put your position...?

column1: Champagne please.
column2: Make that two.

column1: ... What I'm curious about are the wilderness years.  You're out there all alone, no money, mocked by the skeptics.  It must have taken tremendous faith.
column2: I'd say logic more than faith.  The odds were on my side.

column1: And what would you have done if the odds had gone against you?
column2: I guess I would've felt sorry for the universe.

column1: Spoken like a true believer.
column2: What about you?  Doesn't all of this shake your faith at all?

column1: How do you mean?
column2: Well it's been a while, but I don't recall the Bible saying too much about alien civilizations.

column1: 'My father's house has many mansions.'
column2: Very smooth.  It's Palmer, right? Where I came from a palmer was a person who cheated at cards.  Really though... the Bible describes a God who watches over one tiny world a few thousand years old.  I look out there and see a universe of hundreds of billions of galaxies, each with hundreds of billions of stars... I mean burn me for a heretic, but your God seems awfully small.

column1: Your 'faith' tells you that the distance a pendulum swings from the vertical can never get bigger, only smaller.
column2: That's not faith, it's physics.  The second law of thermodynamics.

column1: And you believe this law with all your heart and soul.
column2: And mind, yes.  What are you --

column1: I flinched.
column2: Only a tiny bit.  Even the most devout believer is allowed a little doubt.

column1: That's not doubt.  That's four hundred years of science fighting a billion years of instinct.  I always wondered what you religious types did with your free time.
column2: Now you know.

column1: ... It's an old story.  I grew up in South Boston, more or less on the streets.  By the time I was thirteen I'd tried my first hit of heroin, by fifteen I'd stopped using but I was dealing full-time.  By the time I was nineteen I decided I didn't want to live any more, at least not in a world like that.  One day I got on a bus
column2: Can you try?

column1: I had... an experience.  Of belonging.  Of unconditional love. And for the first time in my life I wasn't terrified, and I wasn't alone.
column2: And there's no chance you had this experience simply because some part of you needed to have it?

column1: Look, I'm a reasonable person, and reasonably intelligent.  But this experience went beyond both.  For the first time I had to consider the possibility that intellect, as wonderful as it is, is not the only way of comprehending the universe. That it was too small and inadequate a tool to deal with what it was faced with.
column2: You may not believe this... but there's a part of me that wants more than anything to believe in your God.  To believe that we're all here for a purpose, that all this... means something.  But it's because that part of me wants it so badly that I'm so stubborn about making sure it isn't just self-delusion. Of course I want to know God if there is one... but it has to be real.  Unless I have proof how can I be sure?

column1: Do you love your parents?
column2: I never knew my mother.  My father died when I was nine.

column1: Did you love him?
column2: Yes.  Very much.

column1: So.  Is this kosher fraternizing with the enemy like this?
column2: Some of my best friends are scientists.

column1: I was referring to the selectees mingling with the selectors.
column2: Some of my best friends are scientists.  They're saying the machine is alive.

column1: Not exactly.  It has organic qualities, but we don't really understand how they're integrated with the mechanical systems.
column2: Maybe you're creating a monster.

column1: I don't think so.
column2: Why?

column1: It's too... elegant.  The degree of economy is extraordinary
column2: In other words, God is one hell of an engineer.

column1: Relativity.  Explain this to me one more time... even if you traveled near the speed of light, when you came back --
column2: If you came back.

column1: If you came back... you'd only be four years older -- but over 50 years would have passed on Earth.
column2: Something like that.

column1: If you came back.  If you survived at all.  Which it's pretty certain you wouldn't.
column2: You're willing to die for this.

column1: I read your book.
column2: Really.

column1: Losing Faith:  The Search For Meaning In the Age of Reason. Catchy.
column2: What'd you think?

column1: I'm more interested in the story behind the story... How a young man goes from living on the streets of South Boston to being the best- selling media figure rubbing elbows with the President.
column2: I won't deny I was ambitious.  When I had my... experience... I wanted to tell my story to as many people as possible.  I'm the first to admit that process included making some compromises.  You didn't answer my question.

column1: I thought it was well-written. Heart-felt.  And a little bit naive... But that's just the enemy's perspective.
column2: I don't consider you the enemy, Ellie.  I'm not 'out to get' technology.  I only ask the question:  Does it have to have all the answers?  I look out there and I see so much emptiness... People are so starved for meaning, and it's something they just don't seem to be getting from science.

column1: Did you ever stop to think that maybe that isn't science's fault, but meaning's?
column2: I don't follow.

column1: Do you really believe your life is meaningless?
column2: I don't know.  But as a scientist I have to consider that possibility.

column1: And yet you're willing to die for this cause, the one thing that's given your life a sense of purpose. Don't you see the contradiction here -- ?
column2: It's getting late...

column1: Ellie --
column2: It's late.  We should go back.

column1: ... Another question I would ask would be a very simple one.  How did you do it?  How did you evolve as far as you have and not destroy yourselves?
column2: An excellent question, Doctor.  But what if we don't like the answer?

column1: How do you mean?
column2: What if their answer is, 'Oh, that's easy.  A thousand years ago our world was in terrible shape, our population out of control, violent crime, no food... so we called a general council and decided to eliminate the anit-social.  The weak.  The sick.  The unwanted.  And ever since we've been doing great.'

column1: Ellie... the last time we spoke... I said some things...
column2: I remember.  You were indelicate, indiscreet and entirely less than tactful... Sound like anyone you know?

column1: So.  The final countdown.
column2: The final countdown.

column1: During the crusades -- pilgrims who made the journey to the holy land brought back a palm frond to show they'd actually been there.  I thought it sort of made sense that Earth is now your holy land, so...
column2: Thank you.

column1: You're trembling.
column2: I do seem to be... Maybe because I'm just a little bit terrified about tomorrow.

column1: What...?
column2: I'm sorry.

column1: Ellie, what is it?
column2: I'm sorry -- I can't --

column1: What?
column2: I can't do this --

column1: What are you so afraid of?
column2: Please, Palmer -- if you care for me at all, don't push this now --

column1: What are my other options?  In fifty years?  Never?
column2: Please --

column1: I'm in love with you, Ellie.
column2: Don't you understand?  I just have to hold it together -- just until tomorrow --

column1: And then what?  Then you'll be safe?
column2: -- I don't know --

column1: Do you really think your life is meaningless, Eleanor?  Is that why you're so quick to risk it -- because if your life means nothing then you have nothing to lose?
column2: I can't hear this now --

column1: Ellie, there is no reason you have to be alone.
column2: And yet that's always how I seem to end up, isn't it?  If you really do love me, Palmer, you'll leave.  Now.  Please.

column1: Hi.
column2: Hi.

column1: I'm assuming you read my deposition.
column2: It was quite a page turner.

column1: So.  I'm assuming they sent you here to administer last rites?
column2: I'm not sure it's come to that.

column1: They don't believe me.
column2: I do.

column1: You're sure you want to?  In the universe I saw we're not exactly the stars of the show.  What happened to me makes us all seem pretty damn small.
column2: It also makes God enormous.  I think of the scope of your universe, Ellie... and it takes my breath away.  As it will everyone else's.

column1: I don't have any proof, Palmer.
column2: Ellie, you're the proof.  You tell them your story.  Ultimately they'll have no choice but to believe you.

column1: It's not enough, don't you understand?  I know it happened -- but by every standard of science, by every standard I've lived my life by that fact is utterly beside the point.  It may be true but it doesn't matter because I can't prove it's real.
column2: Ellie, the only one holding you to that standard is you!  The people want to hear your story, they need to hear it!

column1: But --
column2: Have you seen what's happening out there?  The terror, the despair? The world is on fire, Ellie.  People need something they can believe in, something worthy, and you can give it to them!

column1: I want to, Palmer -- more than anything.  But it has to be real. It has to be true.
column2: Ellie... if you go out there like this -- if you admit to even the possibility that what you experienced didn't actually happen -- I'm afraid they really will crucify you.  Please.  For your own sake, for the sake of the world... tell them what you know to be the truth.  Tell them it really happened.

column1: ... but it is a good question, and I suppose I'll always wonder about the answer:  Why would they send me back without proof?
column2: Maybe what you experienced can't be reduced to images on a videotape. Maybe they still plan to grant your request, only in their own way, in their own time... Or maybe it's just like you said:  ultimately their motives may be as incomprehensible as their technology.

column1: In other words, God works in mysterious ways...
column2: In other words.

column1: I don't know.  If it was a god, it was searching for a greater one.  It was still searching for meaning...
column2: Does that mean you think it doesn't exist?

column1: I'm not sure...  Maybe it simply exists in the search for it.  Maybe its something we have to make for ourselves.
column2: Meaning...

column1: You have a question, Dr. Arroway?
column2: I question the thinking behind sending the first ambassador to another civilization in armed -- basically announcing our intentions are hostile.

column1: It's designed purely as a defensive device.  Call it a reasonable precaution.
column2: Call it xenophobic paranoia.  Don't you see the absolute absurdity of this?  This isn't about them, it's about us -- our violence, our fear and mistrust --

column1: Dr. Arroway, you are entitled to your opinion.  But we feel quite strongly that it would by both irresponsible and naive to send a human being into a completely unknown, completely uncontrollable situation absolutely defenseless.
column2: Y'know what?  Fine.  I guess if we want them to know the truth about who we are there's no quicker way to show them.

column1: You kill me, you really do.  The first truly global, a-political event in history and you can't wait to spin it.
column2: How would you propose we handle it, Doctor?

column1: I guess I'd say I trust us enough to believe our response would be something to the effect of, thanks for the advice, but no thanks.  But to dilute or censor the truth, for whatever reason --
column2: Nobody is proposing we censor the truth here, Doctor.  We're simply talking about putting a mechanism in place --

column1: Oh my God...
column2: What is it?

column1: Well.  That would seem to decide it. Like it or not, for the moment, anyway, it looks like we're all in this together.
column2: But --

column1: ... as have all attempts at internal analysis.  We've tried sonargrams, magnetic resonance, gamma rays
column2: Recommendations?

column1: I don't know.  Maybe we built the damn thing wrong.  Maybe it was all a hoax...  The safest thing would probably be to do a Chernobyl
column2: Have your department make a full report.

column1: It all starts with them going to the bathroom together.
column2: That many women in one place -- nothing good can come from that.

column1: Sorry about Frida. She's been friends with Jen forever.
column2: What's with her? If they're not bleeding they're PMSing. If they're not PMSing, they're warning you about the impending doom. If you're lucky, you get a sane person one week a month. Then you gotta date three or four women just to get some normalcy in your life.

column1: I'm lucky Jen's not like that.
column2: I don't believe in PMS. Women made it up just so they can be bitchy.

column1: My brother has an answer to PMS. A-S-S: Abundant Sperm Syndrome. A man gets sperm build-up, and if his woman isn't givin' it to 'em, he's gotta get it elsewhere.
column2: Yeah and when your woman says you're an ass, say yes, I have Abundant Sperm Syndrome.

column1: Waiter! She needs more water.
column2: Can we get some service here?

column1: No way is that the same chick. The other one was a dog.
column2: Jennifer gave her a make-over.

column1: Guess you like those Coyote Ugly steaks now, huh?
column2: Sorry, don't mean to be wolfing down. I'm just starving.

column1: No one I've run into knows what "coyote ugly" means.
column2: Maybe that bartender made it up. I mean I think coyotes are rather beautiful. Maybe "coyote ugly" is really a compliment. Like someone who's conventionally "ugly" but is really beautiful.

column1: Sorry I didn't recognize you earlier. You look so different.
column2: I've changed a lot lately.

column1: You shouldn't smoke. It'll kill you.
column2: Yeah yeah I know. Smoking kills. I'll quit someday. Doesn't it seem like all the cool people smoke?

column1: No.
column2: James Dean, Humphrey Bogart...

column1: Yul Brynner. They're all dead.
column2: Yeah but they looked cool...

column1: What?
column2: Your lips look delicious.

column1: Wow your body's really hot.
column2: I've been working out.

column1: I mean body temperature. Do you have a fever?
column2: Never felt better.

column1: A bite... Where'd you get bitten?
column2: At Victoria's Secret.

column1: There was a sale.
column2: I mean where on your body?

column1: A dog at Victoria's Secret?
column2: No, it was another woman.

column1: How's the rest of your health?
column2: Good. Except for PMS.

column1: PMS. What symptoms are you experiencing?
column2: It's hard to describe. I get really bloated and irritable and emotional and depressed and...

column1: That's just part of being a woman. Diet and exercise should help. Avoid salt, sugar, starches, caffeine, alcohol...
column2: What else is there?

column1: And keep a journal of your symptoms to make sure it's related to your period and not just in your head.
column2: It's not just in my head.

column1: That bite healed up quickly. It's been about three weeks?
column2: Nearly four.

column1: How have you been feeling?
column2: Okay, but I'm worried about the next PMS bout. It's gotten worse. I'm not myself during it. I get bloated, irritable, my breasts get huge, my nails turn into claws, my teeth get sharper and I have more facial and body hair.

column1: Sounds all stress related. Your teeth may feel sharper if you're grinding them at night. You don't seem hairy to me. Is that all?
column2: I get crazy dreams and I black out.

column1: Diet and exercise, that's all there is. I'm not a big proponent of the PMS craze, but there's a book my wife mentioned called "The PMS Diet," which may be helpful.
column2: Does she have PMS?

column1: Jennifer?
column2: No it's mom.

column1: We're worried about you. "60 Minutes" was on same-sex couples.
column2: What does that have to do with me?

column1: You haven't mentioned dating anyone since Mark and, well you're not a lesbian are you?
column2: No, I'm not a lesbian. Geez mom.

column1: I have cramps. I can't believe I let you talk me into this.
column2: Come on, we've been double dating since the fourth grade.

column1: Yeah even then look what happened: Michael Mortenson kissed you and Billy Sullivan threw a worm at me.
column2: Well that's not going to happen tonight. George said Carlton's a nice guy.

column1: Translation: a total geek.
column2: Anything's better than Mark.

column1: My shrink says he's not so bad.
column2: Your shrink always gives you bad advice. He only hears what you choose to tell him. Mark's an asshole, he cheated, he borrowed money and never paid it back, he's never had a regular job.

column1: He's a very talented musician.
column2: Every woman at some point has to date a musician. I wish you'd get rid of Mark for good. Every time you break up you see him more than when you were going out.

column1: I guess I have a weakness for him. It's those big brown Bambi eyes.
column2: So don't look in his eyes.

column1: I wonder what it's like being you. Being noticed all the time.
column2: People notice you Frida.

column1: He hasn't said one word to me.
column2: Maybe he's just shy.

column1: My date always pays more attention to you than to me.
column2: Frida, I don't mean this as a criticism, but you might not want to talk about PMS around men.

column1: Sorry. It's just so bad lately. You're so lucky you never get PMS.
column2: I get a little bloated sometimes.

column1: How about I give you a make-over? You'll feel better about yourself. You're actually pretty, you're just not bringing it out.
column2: You're just saying that.

column1: Do you really need these?
column2: Only to see.

column1: Can't you get contacts?
column2: No, it grosses me out even thinking of putting something in my eye.

column1: Or if there's a full moon.
column2: Or if your boyfriend's an asshole.

column1: Okay, just one more stop and you'll be all set. Victoria's Secret.
column2: What do I need overpriced fancy underwear for? Shouldn't a guy have already decided that he likes me before he sees me in lingerie?

column1: It's not about him seeing you in it. It's how you feel. You'll feel sexy in lingerie and it'll show. It's an inner thing.
column2: I don't know.

column1: Where are all the mediums?
column2: Frida, grab that red one.

column1: Can you believe she fuckin' bit me?
column2: And she got the medium.

column1: I think she broke the skin.
column2: What a bitch. You should see a doctor. That can be dangerous. George bit me once and I had to go to the emergency room.

column1: George bit you?
column2: I kind of asked him to. We were, you know... he got a little carried away...

column1: Why did Gregory ask me out? I mean he's cute -- he probably just wants to pitch his screenplay idea.
column2: Maybe he likes you, ever think of that? It's good for you to go out -- get your mind off Mark.

column1: You're so lucky you have George and don't need to go on dates anymore.
column2: What I really hated about dating was the lines guys used to get into my apartment. "Can I use your phone?" "How about a nightcap?" "I want to meet your cat." And my all-time favorite, the old standby, "I have to use your bathroom."

column1: Maybe they have to pee.
column2: Are you kidding? He might as well say, "Can I date rape you?"

column1: I never thought of it like that. I never know what to do on dates. Do guys still pay?
column2: They better. Of course, trouble is, you never know what they'll expect for it. You gotta know what to order, and what you're willing to do. Like if a guy spends a fortune on you, he's gonna feel like you owe him something.

column1: Where?
column2: Where? Where do you think a mustache would be. Look!

column1: I don't see anything. Maybe just a little.
column2: Holy shit, I'm a freak.

column1: Hey, did you get contacts?
column2: Oh, my glasses! Maybe my eyes got stronger from not wearing them.

column1: He's dead? Am I bad luck or what?
column2: There you go, blaming yourself for everything again.

column1: And he was ripped limb from limb?
column2: I'm sure they were exaggerating.

column1: Why would they exaggerate?
column2: To sound like big macho cops. He was probably just found with a knife in his back.

column1: So did you do it?
column2: Did I kill him? Of course not!

column1: No, did you fuck him?
column2: No. I don't think so.

column1: You don't think so? You either did or your didn't.
column2: I don't remember. We kissed at my door and next thing I knew I woke up with my period. Alone.

column1: Did you get smashed or what? You have to eat if you're drinking. And not just those little salads.
column2: I ate a burger in the afternoon and a steak and a half with Gregory.

column1: I guess you're off that vegetarian kick you've been on for ten years.
column2: I couldn't stop eating steak. I felt out of control -- like I was making up for all those years being a vegetarian. I couldn't get enough. And then Gregory walked me home... and he peed in front of me.

column1: What? Why the hell did he do that?
column2: He was trying to get into my apartment and... I know this sounds gross but I was so turned on. I grabbed him and kissed him!

column1: And then?
column2: I think I went in and fell asleep. I guess Gregory walked home and got killed! I blacked out.

column1: At least your PMS is over.
column2: And my bra finally fits again.

column1: I thought you were going to stop wearing your glasses.
column2: My vision got worse again.

column1: Are those Mark's?
column2: No, Mark wears boxers. They must have been in the dryer already.

column1: He was cute, huh? Of course whenever I meet a guy, I'm wearing no make-up.
column2: Rule one: always wear make-up.

column1: I wonder if he's married.
column2: He wasn't wearing a ring. But you don't want to date a cop Frida. They're so blue collar.

column1: Gross, so this is Mark's flesh? When did you see him?
column2: Um, he stopped by yesterday before you came over.

column1: Why didn't you tell me? You said you hadn't seen him for a month.
column2: I'm sorry. I didn't want you to think I was still a doormat.

column1: I don't think I've ever actually liked anyone I've dated before. Peter even likes me without makeup.
column2: Hmmm. Sounds suspicious.

column1: I don't know much about him. How do you know if a guy is decent?
column2: Give him the tampon test.

column1: What the hell is the tampon test?
column2: You're at his place, and you come out of the bathroom looking all shy and say, "I'm so embarrassed but could you run out and get me some tampons?" If he says no, he's too embarrassed, then you know he's a wus. If he says he's got some in the bathroom, then you know there are other women around a lot. But if he says yes and goes to get you tampons, well then he's a decent guy. Then, while he's out...

column1: I'm freaking out. I'm like an animal and totally out of control. My arms keep getting really hairy.
column2: You have to stop being so self- critical Frida.

column1: How'd it go with the cop?
column2: We almost slept together... and... then the hair started and I booked.

column1: Frida, this hair thing is all in your head. You're using it as an excuse not to get close to anyone.
column2: It's just as well. I'm afraid of getting hurt again. Mark seemed great at first too. I don't want to get too attached to Peter and then find out he's a creep.

column1: No he didn't. Come on, I don't want to be alone with those two. All they talk about is basketball and it bores the hell out of me.
column2: Okay. I guess so.

column1: I started out on that eye-of-newt diet the doctor gave me and wound up in the tub covered in chocolate.
column2: Well whatever it was, seems to have worked cause you look great.

column1: What did he say?
column2: I think he called you beautiful.

column1: Charming Carlton.
column2: It is so hot in here.

column1: Bag means condom now? I can't keep up with the word "bag." It used to be "No, that's not my bag" -- meaning not my thing. But now "my bag" means "my fault."
column2: I still thought it was a purse.

column1: You might want to tape your nipples down next time. It's really distracting.
column2: I can't help it. My bra wouldn't even fit. I've been going to Victoria's Secret and exchanging bras for bigger ones and still I'm busting out. It's this PMS.

column1: Geez, I wish I'd get it like that.
column2: No you don't, believe me.

column1: Oh my god, look. My arms are so hairy!
column2: No they're not.

column1: Yes they are! Look how much more hair I have than you!
column2: It's just cause mine is finer. A little bleach'll fix that.

column1: Frida, this is a bad time. We're having sex and George actually answered the phone.
column2: There is a man's arm in my bed.

column1: Jennifer. A severed arm. It's bloody and... I'm not sure but it may be Carlton's.
column2: You fucked Carlton? See I told you he liked you.

column1: Please come over. I'm begging you. What should I do with the arm? Should I call the cops or... Peter?
column2: Frida, you're not making sense. I can't come over right now.

column1: So where's this infamous arm now?
column2: I put it down the garbage disposal.

column1: And what makes you think you killed a man?
column2: Because of PMS, I get hairy, my nails turn into claws, I eat raw meat, I roam the city hunting for flesh. I've become a werewolf!

column1: You're a PMS werewolf. Of course. Frida, are you on drugs?
column2: No, last night I think I chased Carlton around as a wolf and killed him. I woke up with a taste of blood in my mouth and a severed arm in my bed. And my throat hurts.

column1: You're delusional. Maybe you had a bad dream and bit your lip -- so you tasted blood. And the severed arm... well I don't see it and... maybe this is all in your head.
column2: It took me an hour to clean it up. That was not in my head!

column1: Maybe the blood was from your period like before.
column2: I haven't gotten it yet.

column1: Frida, listen to yourself. If I said I was a werewolf, would you believe me?
column2: I don't know. You have to take Sammy. He's afraid of me.

column1: Hello?
column2: Frida? I was worried to death about you. I've called you for two days. Where have you been?

column1: I've been here. What day is it?
column2: Tuesday. Are you okay?

column1: Shit, I guess I missed work.
column2: Frida, Carlton's dead.

column1: Oh no.
column2: And he was missing an arm.

column1: Oh my god Jennifer. I should go to confession.
column2: Relax. Carlton was torn apart. No way could you have done that. Maybe you saw someone kill him and blocked it out... or...

column1: Get rid of him!
column2: Okay, I gotta go.

column1: Holy shit, I don't know.
column2: Did you get rid of Mark?

column1: I don't know... I'm spaced out... he was taking a shower... He must be still in there.
column2: He's been here all night?

column1: What happened to his tooth?
column2: I should call the police. Oh no Peter. Peter is the police!

column1: DON'T call the police.
column2: Why not? There's been a murder.

column1: First of all, you're my alibi. I told George I was with you last night.
column2: What? Why'd you do that?

column1: There's kind of this guy I'm seeing.
column2: You're cheating on George? Jennifer, how could you?

column1: How could I? I'm helping you clean up Mark's remains and you ask how could I cheat on George?
column2: You're right. It's just, I can't cover up a murder so George won't know you're cheating.

column1: You say murder, but you have no idea what happened. You don't remember doing it, so it's out of your control.
column2: I think I turned into a werewolf and killed him.

column1: Why the fuck would you do that?
column2: I could smell another woman on him.

column1: If you ask me, the fucker got what he deserved. I'm glad he's dead.
column2: That's a terrible thing to say. Frida goes back to scrubbing the floor.

column1: At least I finally saw the reason you couldn't get over Mark.
column2: You should have seen it erect.

column1: You expecting someone?
column2: No.

column1: Fuck it's the cops. Peter saw me, now I have to let him in.
column2: Tell them you'll meet them outside.

column1: What the fuck are we going to do?
column2: Hide him.

column1: Peter knows something.
column2: Well if he does, he didn't give you away. He must really like you.

column1: I think I just got my period.
column2: Does that mean this whole thing is over?

column1: Probably for three weeks or so anyway. I'm not sure -- I don't get how it works.
column2: Let's do some research. I'll check the libraries. You surf the web.

column1: You're such a good friend.
column2: So are you. Look, go about your life. Act like nothing's wrong. We'll get to the bottom of this.

column1: Symptoms include loss of emotional control, compulsive behavior, cravings, crying spells...
column2: Peter keeps asking me out.

column1: Maybe you should go out with him. If you keep avoiding him he'll get suspicious. Besides, what better way to not get busted than to date the cop who's investigating you.
column2: The thing is, I really like him. I finally meet a guy I really like and I'm a fuckin' werewolf.

column1: "Paranoia, insecurity, depression, changes in vision, feelings of losing control
column2: Check out what I found.

column1: This is from a scientist in France, Madame Sconce. "The original werewolves were females. They became werewolves on the lunar cycle because it corresponded to the woman's cycle. My suspicion is that the only cure is true love."
column2: Great so all I have to do is fall in love? Like I haven't tried that for the past 24 years.

column1: "The female-cycle werewolf will only kill men and never kills someone she truly loves." See I knew you never loved Mark.
column2: Who is this Madame Sconce? Let's find her and talk to her.

column1: She died at age 34 in the 1800's. They thought she was crazy. She was banished from her town. Seems her husband shot her.
column2: Guess she never found true love.

column1: The weird thing is... he shot her with a silver bullet.
column2: So... she was a werewolf. Do you think we can believe all this?

column1: What choice do we have?
column2: So what do I do?

column1: Fall in love.
column2: I think I already have.

column1: I'm cleaning my stove.
column2: You scared the shit out of me. I thought you were killing yourself.

column1: I tried to kill myself -- earlier. It doesn't work. I think I need silver bullets. So I got depressed and when I'm depressed I clean.
column2: You'll get through this. You were fine for over three weeks.

column1: I'm just afraid I'll hurt Peter. I think I love him.
column2: Remember what Madame Sconce said. If you love him he'll be fine.

column1: But how do I know if I really love Peter? And if he really loves me?
column2: I guess you'll find out.

column1: No. I can't take that chance. I'd rather kill myself.
column2: No. I won't let you do that.

column1: I think George knows.
column2: About Mark? Carlton?

column1: About Benito.
column2: Did I kill a guy named Benito?

column1: I thought you and George were getting married.
column2: We were -- I was just so tempted... It was sort of a test. I think after sleeping with Benito I know I want to be with George. But now George knows about Benito and he doesn't want to be with me!

column1: I wish I only had your problems.
column2: Sorry -- I shouldn't go on about myself at a time like this. Are you sure you're going to be okay?

column1: Hello?
column2: Frida? You okay?

column1: Never been better. Peter spent the night. I must really love him. He's still alive.
column2: Oh thank god. Maybe this whole thing is really over.

column1: God I hope so. Hey can I call you later? Peter's still here. He's in the shower.
column2: Sure. See ya.

column1: I know.
column2: So you're Grant's secretary?

column1: I do development for TV movies.
column2: Oh, a D-Girl. You know... I have a really great idea for a screenplay.

column1: You're kidding, really?
column2: No, I'm serious. How about we have dinner and I tell you about it?

column1: You hungry?
column2: Starving.

column1: Man I'm starving too, I think I'll go for the Surf and Turf.
column2: I'm not really hungry after all.

column1: So there I was, hanging from the edge of a bridge, when my mom said, "Son, you got into Harvard!" It took three of them to pull me back! Frida keeps eating.
column2: Well, whattdaya think?

column1: I'd really feel more comfortable paying for my half of the dinner.
column2: Hey, how about a little nightcap?

column1: I'm really tired.
column2: Come on, didn't all that steak make you thirsty?

column1: No. Really, I'm... I don't feel well. I've got terrible PMS.
column2: They say sex is great for cramps.

column1: What?
column2: I really gotta pee.

column1: You should have gone at the restaurant.
column2: I didn't have to pee then.

column1: My apartment's just such a mess.
column2: That's okay. I just have to use the bathroom and then I'll leave.

column1: Oh come on. Knock it off.
column2: Knock what off?

column1: You don't have to pee.
column2: Yes I do have to pee!

column1: You're just saying that to get into my apartment and then you're hoping that'll turn into something else.
column2: I wouldn't mind doin' something else, but I do really have to pee.

column1: Uh huh. So pee.
column2: So pee? Here?

column1: What, you got a date or somethin'?
column2: Since when do you care?

column1: You look different. I mean you look good.
column2: You never say that.

column1: You do though. You look really... is that a wonderbra?
column2: No.

column1: Look what you did!
column2: Oh my god, I'm sorry!

column1: Shit. And you're eating my burger? You don't eat meat.
column2: I can't help it, it smells so good.

column1: OUCH that stings! Damn, what am I going to do with my back like this?
column2: Worried about what all your girlfriends might think?

column1: Frida, you know you're it for me.
column2: Yeah right... You better go.

column1: Hey wait, I paid three bucks for that burger. You owe me...
column2: You haven't even paid me back the thousand bucks you owe me!

column1: Where'd you get the bike?
column2: I'm kinda borrowing it. Who's this, Mr. Date-Guy?

column1: Frida? I hear you talking. I know you're in there. Let me in.
column2: It's Mark.

column1: It's a matter of life and death.
column2: This really isn't a good time.

column1: I did something stupid. I had a courier job -- picking up a package from the airport. It turned out to be money -- so I kind of borrowed it to pay my rent and now these dudes are after me.
column2: So pay them back and apologize.

column1: These guys aren't the kind that'll take an apology. They're the kind that'll break my thumbs.
column2: You think that story's gonna make me loan you money?

column1: It's the truth. If you'd just loaned me the money last time this never would have happened.
column2: Somehow this winds up being my fault? You always blame me.

column1: Come on, I'm your biggest supporter.
column2: My bra is my biggest supporter.

column1: Mark.
column2: Yeah?

column1: Wow.
column2: Take your shower.

column1: The Nielson's?
column2: On your desk.

column1: Script coverage?
column2: On your desk.

column1: Coffee and...
column2: Your desk.

column1: How about a "Man in Jeopardy" story?
column2: Did you change your hair?

column1: I can't read any more crap. These women are all victims.
column2: Yes, that's what we're looking for.

column1: I think we should do something with strong female characters...
column2: I'll make a note of that. Put the coverage on my desk.

column1: Mr. Grant. Did you read that script I was talking about?
column2: Uh... yes. Not for us. No woman in jeopardy. Find me Dr. Quinn Medicine Woman. Find me a true story about a crazed killer stalking beautiful women.

column1: No.
column2: No?

column1: No. I quit. Take your lame ass ideas, your fake ass toupee, your fat ass wife and your ugly ass kids and shove them.
column2: Very well then. Is that all?

column1: When's the last time you saw him?
column2: We... he walked me home and... we said goodnight. Um, he kissed me goodnight and that was it.

column1: I wish I could help but last I saw Gregory was outside my front door.
column2: Okay, if you think of anything else, please give us a call.

column1: You busted me.
column2: Are you following me?

column1: No... no... this is embarrassing. I was returning your pillowcase... and I saw you cross the street... and I sort of started following you. I just find you really intriguing. I don't know why.
column2: Intriguing?

column1: I gotta get going. Peter gets the pillowcase out of his bag.
column2: At least let me give you this back. I washed it.

column1: Being a cop has such a warm effect on people.
column2: That's my ex. He's an asshole. In case you couldn't tell. I think he's been following me.

column1: You wanna get some coffee?
column2: I'm trying to stay away from caffeine.

column1: Some decaf then? That was stupid. Obviously you said you were staying away from caffeine as a nice way of blowing me off.
column2: No. Really. I don't drink coffee anymore. I used to love it but my tastes have changed recently.

column1: Okay well. Maybe some other time. They continue walking together.
column2: So what book did you buy?

column1: Oh, it's nothing.
column2: No really, I love knowing what people read.

column1: It's stupid.
column2: I can forgive you a bestseller.

column1: My mom used to get PMS too.
column2: Used to? Did it stop finally?

column1: No, she died when I was twelve.
column2: I'm sorry.

column1: I've had time to get over it. She was killed by wolves they think.
column2: Oh my god, by wolves?

column1: We lived in northern Minnesota. She went for a walk one night and they never found her body -- just her torn apart clothes with her blood and wolf blood on them. Then the town rounded up bunch of hunters and shot all the wolves in the area.
column2: I'm so sorry Peter. Gee, that sure puts my problems in perspective.

column1: I've read scripts about detectives, but never met one. Must be wild.
column2: Sometimes it's frustrating. Like this Gregory Jameson case. We don't even know what killed him. I'm putting together little details to see if we're missing something.

column1: Like what?
column2: You know how moms always tell you to wear clean underwear in case you're in an accident? Well this guy wasn't wearing any underwear.

column1: A lot of people don't wear underwear.
column2: Yeah but a guy hung like a horse would need briefs to keep things in line.

column1: How about you? Briefs or boxers?
column2: Briefs.

column1: Cool. I don't get guys who wear boxers. My ex wore boxers. I never got how he could wear khakis and not have his boxers bunch up.
column2: Me neither. That's why I wear briefs... So why did you and... Mark break up?

column1: I really gotta get going.
column2: Thanks for the walk. Maybe we could... get a bite sometime?

column1: Yeah. Maybe.
column2: Goodnight.

column1: What are those?
column2: Silver bullets. A collectors item. These are very valuable. They were melted down from a crucifix.

column1: What are they for?
column2: Oh just my wolf paraphernalia. Some people collect beanie babies... I collect silver bullets.

column1: I'm a cop -- I notice everything. That drawer's ajar, that picture's been moved about an inch, the closet wasn't closed when I left...
column2: Okay, you busted me.

column1: What's wrong?
column2: Oh, nothing's wrong. Just... well don't you have your period?

column1: I mean we can still... whatever... Maybe I should get a towel?
column2: No. No, I'm fine. Maybe I should go. I mean... I don't want our first time to be like this.

column1: Oh my god, you scared the shit out of me. You following me again?
column2: No. I was doing my laundry.

column1: Was there anything in that washer?
column2: No. Nope, nothing in it.

column1: You sure? It's my favorite shirt, mind if I check?
column2: NO! I... I checked when I put my stuff in. I always look through the washer first.

column1: Everything okay?
column2: A man killed in Central Park.

column1: Uh.... hi!
column2: Frida, can we come in? We need to talk to you. It's important.

column1: You had a date with Carlton?
column2: It wasn't a date. Jennifer invited me along to dinner with them.

column1: No, no... But Mark -- a jealous boyfriend gone mad. Maybe he kills men you date.
column2: Mark wouldn't hurt a fly.

column1: But you said the bodies were ripped to pieces?
column2: Still haven't figured out how he or anyone else pulled that off. Never seen anything like it.

column1: No, why?
column2: He was ripped to shreds also. In his apartment.

column1: Frida. I was looking for you. You changing jobs?
column2: Yeah sort of. Where's Lloyd?

column1: I need to talk to you. About us. Frida... I... Can I carry your box?
column2: No, I got it. It's okay.

column1: What happened?
column2: I thought we were starting something... and then... I know it's unorthodox, I mean with you being involved in the case and all.

column1: I just don't know if I should be dating anyone right now.
column2: Yeah, every guy you date winds up dead.

column1: Except Mark of course.
column2: What's that supposed to mean?

column1: Did I tell you I have the worst sense of humor and I make bad jokes at totally inappropriate times?
column2: No, but thanks for the warning.

column1: Speaking of Mark -- we've tried to track him down and there's no sight of him. Vanished into thin air. I got a hunch he fled the country.
column2: Interesting possibility.

column1: That's it? Hell my mom chased my dad around with a knife when she had it. She made us call her a different name. She'd say, "You're talking to Betty now" and we'd leave the house for a few days.
column2: This is a lot worse than "Betty."

column1: You can't mean that. I'm sure your bark is worse than your bite.
column2: No, my bite's a lot worse.

column1: Is it that funny?
column2: No, it's just... no one's ever said that. And I thought if someone did ever say it, I'd have to say it first and then they'd sort of say "I love you too" cause they felt they had to after I'd said it.

column1: Is that how you feel?
column2: Like I had to say it? No, I wanted to say it.

column1: You didn't say it.
column2: I love you too.

column1: What's with the squirt guns?
column2: They're for my cat. I use them to train him not to rip up paper.

column1: You know, I've never seen your cat.
column2: I loaned him to Jennifer. George moved out and she was lonely...

column1: Your breasts feel larger.
column2: They do? Oh no...

column1: I did shave... Do I seem hairy? Peter laughs.
column2: No. But I don't mind hairy. Are you okay?

column1: Hello?
column2: Frida? You okay? Look, I think I know what happened to Mark. I want to help. I'm coming over.

column1: NO! Don't come over. Peter... I... I don't want to see you anymore. Ever.
column2: What? Is there someone else?

column1: Yes, sort of. I mean no, not really.
column2: Yes or no? Frida, can't you just be honest with me?

column1: You at least owe me the truth.
column2: You want the truth? Remember I tried to tell you something the other day?

column1: Yes, your PMS. Frida I can deal with that.
column2: No you can't. It... it gets so bad that I become a werewolf.

column1: If you don't like me, just say so. You don't have to make up some bullshit like you're a werewolf.
column2: I knew you wouldn't believe me! Just go away. Go very far away!

column1: Go away. I might hurt you.
column2: I'm not afraid. Frida! I love you.

column1: Peter I love you too but...
column2: I don't think you'll hurt me.

column1: How do you know?
column2: I don't think you would. No matter what form you take.

column1: I can't take that chance... I couldn't live with myself if I did anything to you.
column2: I have the silver bullets in case I need to protect myself. Does that make you feel better?

column1: Be careful!
column2: Can't you bite me and then I'll be like you?

column1: No. It doesn't work that way. Men can't get PMS. Unfortunately.
column2: I'm staying here with you tonight. There's no getting rid of me.

column1: I knew you wouldn't kill me.
column2: Maybe we should have children. I don't think I'd kill the father of my child.

column1: We can work this out. Other couples have worse problems.
column2: Worse than this?

column1: Sure. Cheating, lying. What's a little werewolf a few days a month? We can move out to the country where you can feed off deer.
column2: What about... those guys... I might have...

column1: No way can anything be proved. All they have are some wolf hairs. No one believes in werewolves.
column2: I'm so sorry... I... I couldn't help it. You know I didn't mean to... to do any of that.

column1: I'm going to take a shower.
column2: Okay.

column1: Here's a towel.
column2: Thanks.

column1: That I'm a doormat of course. The shrink makes more notes.
column2: Oh, I see... interesting theory.

column1: I think I'm a werewolf.
column2: Let's explore this. What makes you feel you're a werewolf?

column1: I ate a guy last night.
column2: And how did you feel when you ate this guy?

column1: Dreams about killing usually signify feelings of guilt. You had sex last night and you feel guilty.
column2: We didn't have sex.

column1: You say you killed a man and don't remember it. Couldn't you have had sex and not remember it? It's sexual. Why did you choose "eating him" as the method of killing?
column2: Cause I'm a fucking werewolf!!

column1: It's about Gregory Jameson. He's dead.
column2: Oh my god, what happened?

column1: Yes... I... we had dinner.
column2: Did he come home with you? Did you go to his apartment?

column1: No, it was our first date.
column2: Looks like it was your only date. Unless you go to his funeral.

column1: A kiss? Did you have sex with him?
column2: No, I said it was our first date.

column1: We can get a warrant if you like.
column2: No, take it.

column1: You heard about Carlton Fraser?
column2: Yes, Jennifer told me. What does that have to do with me?

column1: Seems you were the last to see Carlton alive. And the last to see Gregory alive.
column2: What makes you think I was the last one?

column1: No. We left the restaurant, and... and I felt sick... so... so I took a cab home. Alone.
column2: You got a dog?

column1: No, I have a cat.
column2: How big?

column1: No he's not. He's a courier. He picks up packages from the airport.
column2: Packages of money.

column1: So I asked the bartender what "coyote ugly" meant. It's like the "bagger" system. You know, a two- bagger -- someone so ugly that you need two bags -- one bag to put on their head and another one in case it blows off. Or a three-bagger...
column2: Two bags for them, and one bag for your head in case her two fall off.

column1: He was saying that when women are close friends they get their periods at the same time.
column2: Yeah and when we're mad at each other we're out of sync. It only works if you're on good terms.

column1: Come on, I've been working with Frida. Carlton won't even recognize her now. She's really coming out of her shell.
column2: She's just so... pathetic.

column1: She's just insecure. Once you get to know her she's fabulous.
column2: She'll talk about PMS and stare at her salad.

column1: I wonder how Frida and Carlton are getting along?
column2: Carlton insisted on leaving with her. Maybe he got lucky.

column1: It's for you. Frida.
column2: Tell her I'm eating.

column1: I'm supposed to put up with a fuckin' cat I'm allergic to cause your friend's got PMS?
column2: It's so bad she becomes a werewolf.

column1: You have some weird friends. What does her thinking she's a werewolf have to do with us having the cat?
column2: Don't be stupid George. Obviously if she's a werewolf, she can't be around a cat. She might eat it and besides, cats are afraid of wolves.

column1: Oh great. What the fuck am I supposed to do?
column2: Take some allergy medicine.

column1: You can't believe this bullshit.
column2: She's my best friend. I gotta be there for her -- no matter how crazy it sounds. I've been in some bad relationships and she's been there for me. She's lonely. If pretending she's a werewolf helps, then more power to her.

column1: Jesus Christ she got her period. Relax guys. It happens.
column2: Yeah, sorry. Uh... Gregory's roommate told us you were out with him last night.

column1: How the hell is that your business?
column2: We're just trying to figure out what happened.

column1: You want her sheets?
column2: We can just take this pillowcase.

column1: I was thinking about becoming a cop myself. Do you take a test or something or just sign up?
column2: Why would you want to be a cop?

column1: See he was cheating from the get go.
column2: He's been running money for the Mafia.

column1: Nah, I don't wanna break up with Wanda, I just wanna see Carmen too.
column2: Man, you're livin' dangerously. Let me ask you somethin', you always have to get women drunk before they'll sleep with you?

column1: You kiddin'? They try to get ME drunk.
column2: You're some catch Lloyd.

column1: He was found a few blocks away.
column2: Torn apart. Limb from limb. A bloody gruesome mess.

column1: I didn't trust her. All that blood on the sheets. She may look sweet, but she could be a wolf in sheep's clothing. Something's weird.
column2: That dude was torn limb from limb. No way a woman like that could have done it. You never seen blood on a chick's sheets from her period?

column1: Hell no, I'm not into that shit. The sight of blood makes me sick.
column2: Oh, so you decide to be a cop? Seriously? You don't have sex with a woman cause she's on the rag?

column1: No man. Blood is not a turn on. You sure let that Frida off the hook. You weren't even going to take the sheets. If I didn't know better, I'd think you liked her.
column2: I can tell she's not a killer. You just don't like her cause you have a hang up about menstruation.

column1: Frida's sheets checked out fine. It was just her own blood. From her... you know.
column2: I told you she was innocent.

column1: Hey, there was a lot of blood.
column2: She was never a suspect Lloyd. Some animal must have done this.

column1: Maybe. What about all those hairs they found on his body?
column2: Waiting for DNA tests. He was hairier than Madonna in Penthouse.

column1: Madonna's in Penthouse?
column2: Back in the '80's. You didn't see the pictures? They were from before she got famous. She was hairy as hell. Her pits, her bush.

column1: What?
column2: And you think I'm sick?

column1: He was found nearly ripped to shreds in Central Park.
column2: And he was missing an arm.

column1: I still don't get when you gave her back the pillowcase.
column2: We only live a few blocks apart.

column1: This is more than fishy, this chick dates a dude and he winds up dead.
column2: Okay Lloyd, you tell me how she killed them.

column1: She's got a hidden pitbull. Maybe she hired someone to kill them.
column2: She's not a suspect. What is her motive? There's nothing, NOTHING connecting her to either crime except that she dated both guys.

column1: Sounds like you got a conflict of interest.
