column2: You take the cake Lloyd. Come on, she's not here. Let's check out her psycho ex.

column1: Nah, East Village poseur was grosser than the dude in the park.
column2: The park dude was missing an arm.

column1: Poseur was missing a chunk of his neck. And his eyes were open. That always bugs me out. Do me a favor, if some mutherfucker's about to blow me away, remind me to close my fuckin' eyes.
column2: Deal. And if some mutherfucker's about to blow me away, shoot him.

column1: Yeah okay. I still say Frida's involved. She's the last one to see two dudes alive...
column2: She wasn't the last one to see them alive. Whoever killed them was.

column1: He means the last that we know of.
column2: This one walk you home too?

column1: Seems he's stolen money from them. He's desperate and our only lead.
column2: One of our only leads... You had dates with both men right before they were killed.

column1: Spencer's the key here. Frida is in no way associated with him. And her blood hasn't matched with any of the killings.
column2: It's a bit farfetched that Mark would rip guys to shreds just outta jealousy. This makes no sense.

column1: It's like some fucking monster dropped out of the sky and killed these dudes.
column2: Like a vampire or some shit?

column1: You think mafia hit?
column2: Hard to tell. Looks like he's been cleaned up and he's decomposing as we speak. This case gets weirder by the minute.

column1: It has to be Frida. This makes three guys ripped apart who are tied to her ass.
column2: Okay Lloyd. First, no way does Frida have the physical strength to tear a guy to shreds. Second, why would she be so obvious and let it be known she was the last one to see these guys? Third, she's the one in danger. She's a woman in jeopardy and you're layin' a murder rap on her. Fourth, I look in her eyes and know she's no killer.

column1: What are you talking about?
column2: I know. I followed you. To the zoo, to her house, to your house...

column1: What the fuck are you following me for? I'm not a suspect here.
column2: Which brings up an interesting point. I wasn't following you. I was following the suspect. And you just happened to be there...

column1: My girlfriend's predicting another murder in the next few days.
column2: What makes her think that?

column1: So... they're on some cycle. The murders... Gregory... then 28 days later... Carlton.
column2: And that was 28 days ago today.

column1: Did we get those DNA tests back?
column2: Just this morning. Animal hairs were found all over the victims.

column1: What kind of animal?
column2: Can't figure out the species. Similar to a wolf. They're jokin' at the lab that a werewolf probably killed him. Ain't that the stupidest thing you ever heard?

column1: I need something to keep me awake.
column2: Looks like you need a haircut to me.

column1: Thanks.  Just some pills.
column2: Only two bucks.  Shave as well...

column1: Sell maps?
column2: What of?

column1: The city.  I need to get to the ocean.
column2: Nope.  No maps.  Ocean, huh?  On vacation?

column1: Mnunn.  Cold lately.  That night, couple weeks ago.  That was <u>real</u> cold.  Remember that?
column2: Not really...

column1: How long have you been here?
column2: Maybe ten minutes...  Thats strange.

column1: What's he doing here?
column2: Says he is the man's doctor...  You know...

column1: All the same entry wounds.  It's definitely him.  She lives...  lived here.  A prostitute.
column2: The other one?

column1: His wife.
column2: Jesus.  Small world.  Where's the photographer?

column1: They don't speak English...
column2: How will we interrogate them?

column1: Police.  Nobody move.
column2: He tried to kill me!

column1: Doctor!  What brings you here?
column2: Just visiting my patient.

column1: Really?  And how is his state of mind?
column2: He's seriously disturbed...

column1: You seem a little edgy.  Everything okay?
column2: Yes, of course.  Everything's fine...

column1: To tell you the truth, I'm glad we've run into each other like this.  Maybe you can help me tidy some loose ends.
column2: Loose ends?

column1: I met a friend of yours the other night, doctor.  Tall fellow.  No hair.  Rather pale skin...
column2: I don't know what you're talking about.

column1: That's surprising.  He was leaving your office at the time...
column2: You are mistaken.

column1: Please, they'll kill me...
column2: I think it's time you introduced us to your little friends.

column1: In there.
column2: Just like that?

column1: What is this place?
column2: You wouldn't believe me if I told you, Inspector.  Have patience  - you'll see for yourself.

column1: Was that for real down there?
column2: I'm afraid so.

column1: Good evening, sir.
column2: Yes.  This way.

column1: Why are you wearing that thing on your face?
column2: Germs, sir.  These places are full of them.

column1: What about Thompson, sir?  Wasnt this his case?
column2: Thompson suffered a kind of severe delusion or some damn thing.  Anyway he isnt with us any longer.  The case is yours.  Go through his files. Take what you need.  By the way, hows your mother?

column1: Why do you want to speak to him?
column2: A hunch.  He might be able to...

column1: Its extremely important to my investigation...
column2: Ill be the judge of that.  Anything else?

column1: Lost something?
column2: What makes you think that!  If you would learn to concentrate on facts, not get so side-tracked  -  you might get things done faster, Bumstead...

column1: Yes.  That's right.  He's ill  -  he needs expert help.
column2: I see...

column1: Yes, sir.  I'm sorry...  But I don't understand how it was possible.  The only window was twenty feet up a vertical wall, he was cuffed...
column2: How could you have been so stupid?

column1: Bumstead, you're starting to annoy me.  This case is very important to me.  Just a little warning:  I've got my eye on you inspector, remember that.
column2: Yes, sir.

column1: Dammit!
column2: Sorry, sir.

column1: Dont ever sneak up on me like that! Who are you?
column2: Patricia Crenshaw.

column1: Im your new assistant.
column2: I didnt requisition a secretary.

column1: Ive taken the liberty and had Inspector Thompsons office searched, as I believe you instructed.  All clear now, sir.  They found several more traps and things were filed under pretty strange categories... Poor man.
column2: Good.

column1: You wont regret this, sir.
column2: Fine.

column1: You typed this report?
column2: Yes, sir.  Anything wrong?

column1: It seems fine.
column2: <u>Fine</u>?  Look here!

column1: How can I submit this?
column2: Im sorry...

column1: Do you wash your hands before you type things?
column2: Why, yes.

column1: Who is it?
column2: Won't say.  Says he must talk to you.

column1: I need everything on the Jonathan White case.
column2: Yes, sir.  <u>Everything</u>?

column1: Where are we going?
column2: Shut-up.

column1: Why give yourself up?
column2: I  -  ah - couldn't think of anything else to do.  I thought maybe you know something...  I'm scared.

column1: That was a pretty good escape act at the station.  How did you do that?
column2: I woke up in a subway.  I don't know how I got there.

column1: People...  after me.
column2: Who?

column1: I don't know who they are.
column2: Why are they after you?

column1: Don't know that either.
column2: Don't know much, do you?

column1: They didn't have faces.
column2: What?

column1: Go on.
column2: Well.  The only thing I've been certain of, all this time, is that I need to get to the ocean.  The point is no one seems to know how to get there.

column1: Where do you think this goes?
column2: It sure isn't the fun-fair.

column1: What now?
column2: This ocean business...  I know where I can find a map.  I need to go back to the station.  Where will you be?

column1: Can't let you in...  sorry.
column2: I'm on the serial killer case, need to talk.

column1: They've taken my mind, my memories...
column2: What?  Who has?

column1: Is that your idea of a joke?  I don't remember...  Take my advice, Bumstead.  Get off this case.  Now.
column2: What is going on?

column1: Jesus!  We have to get you to a doctor...
column2: No...  No doctor...

column1: But...  How long has this been happening?
column2: A few days...  a few weeks  -  dunno, I can't remember.  Worse thing is, I never know if it will change back again...  Now, please leave me alone.

column1: Look!  This is a good one!
column2: What is that door?

column1: Which one?
column2: There.  Behind the cabinet.  Where does it go?

column1: Such a joker!  Like your father.
column2: No.  Have a look.

column1: You see it?
column2: Yes.

column1: Where does it lead?
column2: It must be a closet or something.

column1: A fanciful idea, Mister White.
column2: Everyone has a job  -  a function.  Each one teaches you more about your invention.  I'm what is called a <u>murderer</u>.

column1: A book of delusions.  Anything else?
column2: But I...

column1: I see.  The verdict, yes...
column2: Wait, this isn't fair...

column1: I didn't realise...
column2: Shut up, freak!  Monster!  You are insignificant.

column1: No.  I, ah...
column2: You seem restless.

column1: Someones after me.
column2: Then we must call the police.

column1: I see.  Then who is after you?  What sins have you committed?
column2: Just let me sit here for a moment? Ill go soon, and stop bothering you.

column1: Dont kill me!
column2: Shut up!

column1: You remember nothing?  Who you are? What you've done?
column2: You know something about me?

column1: Ah, that would be cheating, wouldn't it?  Is there nothing <u>you</u> remember?  Not even a detail?   You must try.
column2: You think I haven't been trying!  It's like there was never anything there.  Just water.

column1: Water?
column2: Waves...  A beach.  A woman whispering.  That's all.  I need to stay awake.  Do you have any pills?

column1: What does she say?  The woman.
column2: Asks my name.  Over and over.  Just like a broken record.  Only thing is, I can't answer.  I've no idea what my name <u>is</u>.

column1: Your name is John White.
column2: That's what people keep telling me.

column1: Bad dreams?
column2: Yes.

column1: If you like.
column2: You're supposed to be my doctor, right?

column1: Known me for long?
column2: Well...

column1: I cannot say...  You don't know the answer to that?
column2: I told you, I can't remember a thing!

column1: Did she drown?  The woman you told me about?
column2: Not exactly.  She was found in a canal, disembowelled.  Throat cut. Blood drained.  The body wrapped in a bed-sheet.

column1: Horrible...
column2: You remember nothing, eh?  Let me show you something.

column1: We are little more than a sum of memories.  From them we reference who we are, where we're going.  Without a past we are nothing.  This is why you are so interesting.
column2: I'm nothing then.

column1: Can I get my life back?
column2: Maybe.

column1: I'm sorry.  About before.
column2: I don't blame you for getting angry. You are in a frustrating situation. You must be patient though.  Trust me completely.  I'm here to help.

column1: What are you doing?
column2: I have to go...

column1: You're a liar!
column2: No, it's the truth.

column1: If you would only take this, inject it in your brain, everything would be much clearer.
column2: Not that again...

column1: You've been working too hard.
column2: Please!  Don't be foolish!  Time is short.  Let me show you something. Look at this syringe.

column1: Why?
column2: Don't ask stupid questions.  Look at it.

column1: It's a trick.
column2: No it isn't.  <u>You</u> are doing it!  Now raise it over the glass and...

column1: What are you hiding?
column2: Nothing.  I don't know anything!

column1: What happened to you?
column2: I'm...  being...  punished.

column1: What is it?
column2: We are...  living in their dreams...

column1: I thought it would make more sense. I'm getting the pieces, but when I put it together it feels like... Like you're telling me about somebody else's life...
column2: It's the truth...  I need you.  I know you're innocent.

column1: How do you know I'm innocent?
column2: Of course you are.  You couldn't do those terrible things.  Come home with me  -  maybe things will make sense then...

column1: I can't do that.  It's dangerous. What about my parents?  Do you know where I can find them?
column2: They're dead, John.

column1: How do I get there?  Tell me.
column2: That's easy.  You...

column1: Please...senor...destroy me...one bullet...please.
column2: Maybe. We'll have a little talk first. Then....maybe...I can help you out. String him up.

column1: Please....shoot me.
column2: And if I don't? If I don't you'll come back after your death. You'll come back and find yourself hanging there...wanting to eat...needing to eat human flesh. You hate that thought, don't you? That's the ultimate sin for most of you fools, isn't it?

column1: After hanging up there a few days you will be mad for food...crazed! You will lust for it! YOU WILL BE WORSE THAN ANY OF THEM!
column2: NO...NOOOOOOO...SHOOT ME! SHOOT ME! SHOOOOOOOOOT MEEEEEEEEE!!!

column1: I'll bargain with you. How many of you are on the island?
column2: Two of us...only two of us...me...and him.

column1: I don't believe you, rebel. Where are your headquarters? On the mainland?
column2: The mainland...is dead...a dead place...nobody there...

column1: Where are your headquarters, rebel? Tell me or I'll let you hang there forever...FOREVER!
column2: There are no...headquarters. There are no...rebels. Only the walking dead. Don't you see. They have won.

column1: Then why did you come here?
column2: To look...look for a place...a place to live in...an empty place...a... new...place...

column1: How did you know we were on this island? Do others know? Will others come?
column2: Nooooo. Believe me. There are no others...no rebels...nobody...it's over...it's ooooo....

column1: Help me get him to the boat.
column2: Leave him.

column1: His madness....could be from shock.
column2: No. I didn't stop the infection in time. I know.  Don't worry. When he dies, I won't be like Maria. I'll shoot him.

column1: What is it?
column2: I dunno. Landing pad for a helicopter? I dunno.

column1: It's some kind of....elevator. There must be something under the ground here....maybe....military.
column2: Look.

column1: What do we do? Let'em know we're here....or what?
column2: Let's just....wait a minute. Get a better look.

column1: It can't be. Are we truly in hell?
column2: Come on.

column1: What is it?
column2: The tunnel.

column1: Are you alright, Doc? You look... you look real bad.
column2: I have looked bad for four years. Everyone in the world has looked bad for four years. Thank God looks don't matter as much as they once did.

column1: I know it hurts. But it won't be long. Then all the pain will be over. Oh, I wish you could hear me. GOD, GIVE HER THE EARS TO HEAR ME SO SHE KNOWS I DON'T WANT HER TO HURT SO!
column2: Quiet!

column1: You'd hold us back. We have to go on.
column2: Hmmmmmm? Oh, yes. Go on.

column1: Well, Miss Henried, what a coincidence. You're just in time fer a case that seems ta concern you. Guess you didn't care about the other proceedin's we been dealin' with here this mornin'.
column2: I'm sorry. I was...busy. In the lab.

column1: Miss Henried, I think you better...
column2: ...Captain Rhodes is trying to...

column1: Sir. It's quite clear that...
column2: SHUT UP, MISS HENRIED! I TOL' YA B'FORE!

column1: THIS IS A TRAVESTY! CAPTAIN RHODES IS...
column2: SIDDOWN, YOUNG LADY! I DONE YUP A SHIT-LOAD O' FAVOURS AND I AIN'T NEVER YET ASKED FER NOTHIN' IN RETURN! NOW HOW'D YOU LIKE TA SPEND TWO WEEKS UP T'THE VEGETABLE FARM YERSELF? THAT'S WHAT IT'LL BE IF YA DON'T SIDDOWN AN' SHUT THE HELL UP!

column1: Now I think Captain's punishment is fair, considerin'. In fact I think you ain't got shit ta complain about.
column2: I'm sorry, General, if I...spoke out of turn. It's just that...Mr Tyler is not here to defend himself. He has no representation. I don't believe due process is being served by...

column1: Listen, Missy. I am the only due process that has ta be served aroun' tyere and one of the people doin' the servin' from now on is gonna be you. Now you been prancin' aroun' the Cave like yer ass was glass fer long enough! All that's
column2: gonna change, young lady. Now if you still got a statement you'd like ta make, you can jus' hold onto it 'til tonight.

column1: Tonight?
column2: That's right. 'Bout eight, if that suits. We'll start out in my gymnasium an' progress on from there...to various other forms o' physical therapy.

column1: The great state of Florida. People came here fer years ta die. Retire and expire. The rest o' the country used ta think we was nothin' but a bunch o' farts and fogies. Hah! Now this here's the new Capital o' the World! Hah! They came here...died...went to hell...and the Devil sent 'em back as an army. Hah! General Gasparilla's army...MY ARMY!
column2: We think there are other cities surviving. We think maybe Detroit... there's some signalling out of Philly.

column1: There's no place like this place. Warm climate. This facility. Christ, there ain't nothin' like this no-damn-where! Even the Feds knew that. That's why they stored so much o' their shit down here. It's all mine now. All mine. Just let 'em try ta come after us down here, which they will some day...take a likin' ta what all we got an' come after us. They'll hafta get past my army! An army that ain't afraid ta die...ha ha ha...'cause it's awreddy DAID! HA HA HA HA....
column2: It's not a very big army. And small as it is you won't be able to continue feeding it for very long. We've got to find ways of getting them to respond without relying on...

column1: Bees. That's what we call the dead... the walking dead...here on Gasparilla's island.
column2: Gasparilla?

column1: He was a pirate who sailed these waters long ago. His name is bein' borrowed these days by the long lost Henry Dickerson.
column2: Governor Dickerson? Of Florida?

column1: That's the man. He's been holed up here ever since the shit hit the fan. Him and his family owned these islands 'round here. They was leasin' this one to the Fed. The whole underneath is dug out. There was missiles here and laboratories and bomb proof housing, nuclear power, all o' that. Now this is Dickerson's....Gasparilla's... private fortress. Him and a bunch o' his cronies from all the best golf courses in Tallahassee...and his private army, of course.
column2: We ran up against a platoon of soldiers. There were actually walking dead...in uniform...with guns.

column1: Thanks. I can fight my own battles.
column2: I know you can. Like I said, we been watchin' you.

column1: The man I was with...until today... believed that praying was for blind men who couldn't see the truth.
column2: How we gonna break the curse without a prayer or two.

column1: Curse?
column2: What is it if it ain't a curse?

column1: It's a disease. It's a...a bug...a parasite that infects the brain.
column2: That sounds like a curse to me.

column1: We thought we were escaping here. We thought we'd found an uninhabited island. Christ! This place is a worse nightmare than anything I've seen yet!
column2: I'm sure that's true, miss. And that's why we're doin' what we're doin'. What's happenin' underground here is just what Lucifer planned for this sinful race o' man. But we're gonna beat Lucifer. We're gonna put an end to what's happenin' here.

column1: Oh, what did I run into? A bunch o' Jesus nuts? Religiosos? Prayer won't stop a bullet from one of those storm troopers and prayer won't keep one of those monsters from eatin' your liver for lunch.
column2: That's why we didn't use prayers on this here white coat 'til after he was destroyed. We ready to fight when we have to. And we gotta fight now.

column1: Look. I BEEN fightin', mister. I been fightin' for what feels like a hundred years and I'm finished. I don't need religion. I don't need prayers. I need a couple guns and a couple hands. We can sail on outa here. Find another island where there ain't so much....traffic.
column2: You think you can find your boat? There's a thousand little inlets and backwaters all through here. You remember all the ways you turned to get where you are now? You leave yourself a trail?

column1: I can find it myself. I didn't come that far.
column2: Farther than you think. You'll get lost. You will. And there's Bees all through the jungle. I ain't lyin' to ya. Religiosos don't lie.

column1: They seem to be havin' a good time. Some punishment.
column2: You disappear in here, darlin'. You get a knife in yer belly or too much shit in yer veins. You get lost out here and nobody's gonna notice. Rhodes, he counts on that. It all makes for food in the freezers.

column1: Let me go! I'm the one he wants. This is all happening because of me. If I turn myself in...
column2: He's just finding another reason for bumpin' us off. Don't ya see. He needs us ta die. He needs our bodies.

column1: Toby's right. They're not gonna sit around with their fingers up their asses while we bust up their toys.
column2: Datura.

column1: What?
column2: Datura Metel. The Devil's Trumpet. Don't worry. I ain't goin' religioso again. It's a flower that grows on these islands. Where I come from the voodoo priests used it whenever they needed a Mickey Finn. It's toxic. Ground up you can put it in a drink or inject it...or...in a sealed area it might be introduced through the ventilation system.

column1: Datura! Miguel knew it! Datura, he was shouting! Datura Metel!
column2: We always planned to use it. We got some ground up already...but we could never find enough.

column1: Looks like just two. We can take 'em when the time comes.
column2: We're only about a quarter-mile from Cave entrance number five.

column1: What is it?
column2: It's...he was...one who came to the island with me.

column1: How long do we have to watch him?
column2: Forever, darlin'. Forever. 'Til he turns ta dust and blows away on the wind.

column1: It's alright. I'm a friend. I need help and so do you. What's a safe place to talk?
column2: Ain't no place safe.

column1: I'm gonna have this stuff sent over to the hospital...
column2: The hospital?

column1: Yeah. My stuff's all marked with red crosses so nobody gets too nosey. Meet me at the hospital after the supplies come in. Maybe we can find a place there to talk.
column2: Maybe.

column1: What'dya tell that soldier, soldier? You tell him we was rebels?
column2: He's my contact for Chrissake! There's two crates. Can you get me into the hospital?

column1: There ya go. Complete with air canisters...little motors.
column2: We got a boat.

column1: What?
column2: I say we got a boat. Can you get other stuff?

column1: It won't work. That's pure nitro you're dealin' with there. That stuff can blow if you look at is funny. What're you gonna do, walk into the Cave carryin' those tubes on feather pillows? You don't have a complete layout of the place. Even if you manage to avoid a fight you won't know where to go.
column2: We're hopin' you can show us where ta go, Toby.

column1: Oh, no. I'm tryin' to get off this island alive. I'll help you all I can but I'm not goin' in there on a suicide mission. What can you hope to accomplish? Some radios maybe? A supply room or two? You'll all be killed and in a few weeks they'll be back to business as usual. That place was built to withstand nuclear attack! What are you gonna do with a half-dozen guns and a few sticks of nitro?
column2: We're gonna blow up the powder magazine.

column1: What?
column2: We know what's down there. We did the loading' and unloadin' when the stuff came ashore in the early days. A direct hit oughta do more than a few weeks worth o' damage.

column1: This stuff really works? No shit?
column2: Quicker than gas. And it smells a lot prettier. It usually don't kill but it puts ya under fer a good night's sleep.

column1: If you could knock out the central communications room you could foul up their whole intercom system. Then, if you move fast enough, stay ahead of 'em...without bein' able to signal each other, they might have a hard time catchin' you.
column2: I say it's poetic. Pure calypso, brother. The Devil's Trumpet blowin' the notes o' doom for the Devil's troops. Ha ha ha ha ha...

column1: That entrance is closest to the labs and the Bee cages.
column2: Come on. Let's go.

column1: That's the general alarm. Jesus! They musta got in!
column2: What you wanna do?

column1: I didn't realise! Those were de-caps! I didn't know that....de-caps... revived!
column2: Any dead whose brains are intact will revive.

column1: But...we bury the heads. Oh. God! It must be torture for them!
column2: They are brutes without feeling. Though I admit that I've requested cremation for myself. Burial is an archaic tradition, even more ridiculous now than it ever was. To say nothing of the...spacing problem...on a small island like this.

column1: I thought the purpose of decapitation was to...to...
column2: The purpose of decapitation is to preserve as much...food...as possible. The purpose for feeding is to keep the beasts on our side. The fact that they can be taught to clean up our garbage or to fire a gun is a convenient side benefit, not the primary goal. The primary goal is to keep ourselves from becoming their supper. Keep them fed and they behave. Keep them hungry and they revert back to being the animals that they have always been. You saw them in there.

column1: He is dying. He knows it.
column2: You are dying, too.

column1: Prayers have no power to save. The knife can save. It can cut the disease away. The bullet. It can shatter the brain where the evil takes seed. These are saviours...our new saviours...our only saviours.
column2: We must wait. One day the curse will pass. One day a dead man will... will...

column1: One day a dead man will refuse to return, and that man will be a saint. The first saint of our century. That's a prayer, too. A catechism. Something the priests tell us to believe.
column2: You can believe this, Miguel. I'll kill you if you shoot. We must wait. I'll....I'll do it....I'll do it myself....when it needs to be done.

column1: Dios mia.
column2: I tol' him. I tol' him this is a dead place. Like all the others.

column1: TONY....TONY....
column2: PULL IN! GET THE OTHERS.

column1: Aaaaaaah...my God...my God...I am heartily sorry...for having offended Thee....offended Thee...
column2: Shhhhh....Tony. Rest, rest.

column1: NOOOOOOOOO!
column2: ...but most of all because...they offend Thee, my God...Who art all good...and deserving...deserving of all my love...

column1: Come, come, Miss Science. You've seen worse.
column2: God....damn you, Rhodes!

column1: God has damned us all. Are my atrocities worse than yours?
column2: You have ruined weeks of work here! We've been trying to wean these specimens onto alligator meat!

column1: You gave them a fresh taste of blood!
column2: They will never be satisfied with anything else, Miss Henried. They want human flesh. I'm prepared to take whatever steps are necessary to see to it they don't get mine! Not while I'm still using it!

column1: You can't run away from the planet, Miss Science. You can't even run away from the island, heh heh.
column2: Leave me alone, you...COCKSUCKER!!!

column1: You're....you're disgusting! You're....FILTH!
column2: And you're the one who builds the bomb and they says, 'I hope it'll never actually be used'.

column1: Julie Grant is a behaviouralist. She's not medical. She hasn't been as...exposed to...to things...as some of the rest of us. She'll be alright. I'll talk to her. She'll be alright.
column2: Oh, I have no doubt.

column1: If you put her on the shit list because of her reaction here tonight I'll go to Dickerson.
column2: Ah, yes, our noble Gasparilla does seem to favour you lately. I understand he assigned you a roommate of your choice. The rest of us have to pick names out of a hat.

column1: I had an unfortunate little run-in with him today. In fact...you might say that Mr. Tyler is in big trouble with the...authorities.
column2: You better not mess with me, Rhodes. I'd love to serve your balls to those Red Coats for lunch! Think about it!

column1: Sir. In the matter of the State versus Private Tyler, I don't want to...
column2: Sir, Tyler is innocent of any crime against the State. Captain Rhodes is...

column1: Toby...thank God...wait here. I gotta find out what's goin' on.
column2: Hey. Slow down. What is it?

column1: Some of Rhodes' men. At the door.
column2: That bastard. I didn't think he'd make his move so fast.

column1: It's because of me.
column2: Oh, bullshit, Mary. It's because Rhodes is a prick.

column1: I want you to leave. Then maybe...
column2: We're both gonna leave. Leave the island. I've been talkin' to Tricks. We think we can smuggle out one of those inflatable rafts. They're crated up real small. They've got air canisters. There's food inside. Even a little motor.

column1: I am not...a guerilla fighter, Toby. I'm not a pioneer. I'm not...I'm not strong that way. I need...
column2: Need what? Civilised order like we have down here? Christ!

column1: I can work here. Maybe my work can help...help everyone. I can do more good with access to this equipment than I can off in some wasteland.
column2: For the good of mankind. That's what every monster-maker says.

column1: Mary.
column2: I'll have somebody's ass for this. I'll have your ass, soldier. I'm not gonna stand here and...

column1: Where are you going, Tyler?
column2: My..."detail", sir. We're going to bury the heads.

column1: No time for that. I'll take care of them.
column2: Just....following procedure, sir. They're entitled to burial.

column1: Step up here, Tyler.
column2: Sir!

column1: You fired that shot, didn't you?
column2: No, sir.

column1: It's been fired.
column2: In the battle, sir.

column1: Hey, Tricks. Some detail they got you on.
column2: Not as bad as yours, pal.

column1: What'dya get?
column2: Rafts. Two 38s. A little ammo.

column1: Tricks...Jesus...
column2: I'm alright. Let's go.

column1: You the Captain?
column2: Yes.

column1: How do we get out of here?
column2: We have to make it to the third deck...

column1: Who are you?
column2: He's the owner...

column1: It's not going to help us!
column2: We're going to die here! We're going to die!

column1: They are...they are everywhere.
column2: All right, be cool, everybody, nice and slow, no sudden moves.

column1: Who?
column2: Someone...maybe they sent an SOS!

column1: We don't even know if his boat is still there...you saw Billy!
column2: Boat or no boat...I'm going...

column1: Nobody's shooting nobody...come on, just let us through the hatch!
column2: I'll kill you!! I'll fucking kill you!! I'll do it! I'll do it! I'm not playin' around here!

column1: I once saw a guy put a fish in a bottle, then he corked it, sealing it tight, and threw it to a baby octopus. The little sucker felt its way around that bottle, and in less than two minutes, got that cork off, slid inside, and ate that fish.
column2: What the hell are you talking about?

column1: And what? These things are octopusses?
column2: I don't know what these things are ...all I know is...

column1: You remember the first time we met Finnegan? I think you were just starting out...smuggling gold off Sumatra for those two Chinese...what did we use to call them?
column2: Fok Yu and Fok Yu Two...are we strolling down memory lane for any particular reason?

column1: No, it just struck me as odd...I don't see you for all these years and you've still got the same tape stuck in the box.
column2: You know what they say...the classics are eternal.

column1: Right here...middle of nowhere...
column2: And where is our point of arrival?

column1: Right here...middle of nowhere...and the answer to your question is yes.
column2: Which question is that?

column1: The one you came up to ask...are we on schedule?
column2: Take note Mr. Mason...this is why you hire a professional...No whining. No excuses.

column1: Don't mind him Finnegan...you remember 25...balls of steel... splashing around in a sea of testosterone.
column2: I don't mind him...but I do think it's time for him to get back down below with the rest of the playgroup.

column1: This isn't right Finnegan. I've got a contract.
column2: 20 hours on the clock. Out and back. Double for overtime.

column1: And no questions asked.
column2: Who asked any?

column1: He did...with a crowbar...you know the rules on a broken contract.
column2: I know it...but you want to get where you want to get, and back? I need a chief engineer, and unless you got a replacement, I'd highly recommend overlooking the indescretion.

column1: Speedboat in the middle of the ocean...
column2: How soon can we get up and running?

column1: We can't...we got one engine dead, and the other limping badly.
column2: I have a schedule...

column1: We were talking about my schedule...
column2: You're going to have to get a new one.

column1: Not an option.
column2: Then you better start swimming.

column1: Great woman your mother. Real foresight.
column2: And she could do a hell of a barbie to boot! Belt up. You'll find all the parts you need up there.

column1: I assume somebody up there has made sure no distress signal can be sent.
column2: I'd say that's a pretty good assumption.

column1: Where are my men?
column2: Dead.

column1: Hanover, listen...
column2: Shut up!

column1: Now, where's Mulligan? Where's Vivo?
column2: I told you...

column1: Shut up! Shut up all of you! Now here's what we're doing... Mamooli is going to take you back to fix your engines, Chin and I are staying here to finish the job...
column2: Did you clear this?

column1: Who gives a shit about aft?
column2: That's where my boat's moored.

column1: You trying to take over my show Finnegan, that what you trying to do?
column2: Just trying to get to my boat...

column1: Maybe we lost them.
column2: Or maybe we're exactly where they want us to be.

column1: I'm not staying here!
column2: It ain't any better out there!

column1: Now look what you did!
column2: I saved your life is what I did!

column1: What other bunch?
column2: The thieves.

column1: I'm not a thief.
column2: Then who are you?

column1: Unless you collected on the insurance...
column2: What are you people talking about?

column1: I was born in a City housing project in the Bronx OK? It's not in the cards that I die on a luxury cruise ship...now which way up?
column2: You hear that?

column1: Noooo!
column2: Jesus Christ lady...

column1: What are those things?
column2: I don't know...

column1: Hey! Hey! Where are you going?
column2: ...there's got to be a way to access out back there...

column1: But what makes you think there aren't more of those...things...back there?
column2: Nothing...you want to come, come... you don't...

column1: You don't have to be so touchy.
column2: Look lady, I know you people are used to getting your way...

column1: What's that supposed to mean? You people.
column2: You people...rich people...

column1: I'm not rich people.
column2: Well, you sure do a good imitation.

column1: So this boat of yours...that's what you do? Give people...rides.
column2: That's what I do.

column1: Seen a lot of islands?
column2: Quite a few.

column1: Since I'm a kid, I had this dream... I want to own my own tropical island... Beaches, warm ocean, lots of food, little clothes...population of one...
column2: Anti social?

column1: Self sufficient...
column2: With the emphasis on SELF, and in selfish, right?

column1: I don't know where it is!
column2: On the side!!

column1: Got it?
column2: Hey! I didn't have to come back.

column1: Yeah you did...
column2: Right... You have a boat.

column1: Boat or no boat... You woulda come back anyway. You're that kind of gal.
column2: Oh yeah? What kind is that?

column1: The "come back" kind.
column2: How do you know that?

column1: Like cattle...
column2: You're saying they can think?

column1: What's the matter?
column2: The quiet...

column1: What is it?
column2: A meat locker.

column1: Looking good...
column2: You should talk...

column1: So how do you get from the Bronx to the South China sea?
column2: You quit high school, lie about your age, join the navy, and next thing you know, four years are up and you need a way to make a living...

column1: I was so goddamn close, Finnegan! So goddamn close to my island... I could almost taste the sand...
column2: Keep tasting...

column1: It's not them...it's it...
column2: What?

column1: Oh my god! Oh my god! How do we do it? How do we get there?
column2: Not like him.

column1: Finnegan...
column2: Yeah...

column1: There's not much horsepower left in the engines, but there's enough noise...once this baby's set...I'll rev it up...that slimy bastard will come for it like candy...
column2: If you blow up your boat, how are we going to get to the island?

column1: How about noise? Can you get noise? We don't need speed, just noise, right?
column2: Right...

column1: You want ME to go up there?
column2: Not unless you can wire a missle or fix an engine.

column1: I don't mean to drop in unannounced ...you ready...
column2: Soon as I get over the heart attack...

column1: Three minutes...I'm not back...no matter what...you go...
column2: No...

column1: You don't take orders very well, do you?
column2: I don't take orders at all.

column1: Where's you friend?
column2: He's not coming...

column1: Let's just keep going.
column2: You ain't giving the orders here!

column1: The hulls of these things are supposed to be impregnable...
column2: So?

column1: So...If the hull's impregnable why are my feet wet?
column2: Why don't you just stop figuring and keep working so we can get the hell out of here?

column1: Hanover!! Hanover!!
column2: Forget them...

column1: Shut up! You hear me!!
column2: ...we gotta get outta here -- NOW.

column1: Can we use our indoor voice please...
column2: I'm flying blind here God damn it!

column1: If I told you once...I told you a thousand times...
column2: I know...I know...if the cash is there we don't care...  Finnegan this is as mean a pile of shit as we ever carried...

column1: Here's what I think...I think these mokes below are a hit sqaud.
column2: I saw these guy perform...at Altmont ...you know that? They opened for the Stones...

column1: ...Jagger was here...I was here...
column2: You don't give a shit about anything do you?

column1: Sure I do...I give a shit that at 0300 hour we reach our point of dentination. I give a shit that those mojos got to do what they got to do, and 45 minutes later we are turn around and gone. I give a shit that by the time the sun comes up we are all safely tucked in bed.
column2: That's it? That's all you give a shit about?

column1: What did you do the my kids!!
column2: Me??

column1: I think he knows that Joey.
column2: Good! So maybe he also know where the hell am I going to get the parts I need...

column1: You know what I'm gonna do after this...I'm gonna get a normal life...
column2: Joey...

column1: Joey...it's okay...
column2: What? You don't think I can have a normal life?

column1: It's okay...come on...
column2: I'm stuck...

column1: Finnegan, what the hell was that?
column2: I don't know...you got what we need?

column1: Joey... Which way's aft?
column2: That way.

column1: Don't shoot!! Don't shoot!!
column2: Just the man I wanted to see. On this puppy here, you remember if it's red to blue or blue to red...

column1: Not even a Joey, I'm glad to see you? Joey, what happened to your leg?
column2: Joey, you want to get sucked out by a giant fucking mutated squid?

column1: Red cross over to blue double blue ...is that what it is? A squid?
column2: Squid...squid like...squid type... it's got tentacles, a feed sac... probably one central nervous processor somewhere...what the hell do I know is going on deep down in the ocean...there's all sorts of shit we've never seen...eighty foot clams...60 foot sharks...I'm just guessing...can you get me more juice out of Hercules...fast?

column1: Can somebody tell me what the object of the exercise is here?
column2: Seafood salad.  You ever operate a jet ski?

column1: I've never seen you so congenial with a mamber of the opposite sex... The two of you got a nice patter going...got a nice rapport...
column2: And you got 10 minutes before this thing livens up a boring evening.

column1: You know what I think? I think our luck has just about run shit out...
column2: A little to the left...

column1: I think we gotta stop floating from one fucked up situation to the next...
column2: Line it up now, nice and easy...

column1: I'm telling you, man, we got to give the future some serious thought.
column2: I have been.

column1: And what have you come up with?
column2: How does an island sound to you?

column1: Man, don't go up there...
column2: One whistle... Start the engine...

column1: She's gone...
column2: Second whistle you make it to the deck and get ready to jump...

column1: All you're gonna do is get yourself killed...and for what? Some chick?
column2: You're beautiful what you're jealous, you know that, Joey?

column1: Was it the water in my eyes or were you guys about to...
column2: Joey...

column1: Because it's cool, you know, I can always take a walk or something down the beach...
column2: Joey...

column1: Or maybe not.
column2: Where is everybody?

column1: I mean...where is everbody?
column2: Poolside?

column1: You tell it straight or I pull the trigger. Who are you?
column2: A passenger...

column1: Where are you going?
column2: Nowhere...

column1: Why don't you back off?
column2: You want some too?

column1: You know what my goal is? Before I die I want to make love to a woman from every country on earth.
column2: You mean countries that are acknowledged by the UN...or like made up countires too?

column1: What the hell does that mean?
column2: Like Mamooli's country...

column1: I thought the plan was we'd evacuate them after we got through.
column2: Maybe plans changed...

column1: What was that?
column2: Nothing.

column1: Someone's back there.
column2: Hey! Come out here!

column1: Check it out!
column2: Hey! You hear me? Come out!

column1: I'm not screwing around with you man...I hate the cold water.
column2: What is it man?

column1: Maybe it's the wrong ship.
column2: Shut up!

column1: Hey! What are you trying to pull!
column2: John...

column1: Why don't you help us so we can get done faster so we can get the hell out of here?
column2: 'Cause grease monkey ain't in my job description dick head...

column1: Don't shoot, man, don't shoot!
column2: What happened to Vivo?! What the hell happened to Vivo?

column1: What's there to think about?? That THING back there...
column2: There ain't no thing here!! No thing!! There's you him and me!! Got it! You him and...

column1: Looks like ya gonna take office just in time, Chief.  Things need straightening up in this city.
column2: What'cha got, Bennett?

column1: Witnesses say some wacko went Judge hunting with a late model.  I got an artist working on a computer composite now.
column2: Technothugs?

column1: No chance.  Not their sector.  They ain't even into things this big. Our zone-boy's performing out of a horror show.  Something else.  Unit nine found a couple cold ones in Hollywood.  One Manny Turner.  Gun runner. Sounds like a connection to me.
column2: I can smell it.

column1: That's him.  Simon Doucet.
column2: Jesus.  Sweet Jesus.  We've got trouble.

column1: This monster escaped from Cryo- Prison this morning.
column2: Well, he's sure working fast ain't he?

column1: Yeah?
column2: Wade's here.

column1: Talk fast.  Polls open in half an hour.
column2: Wade did a little reminiscing.

column1: Michael called yesterday.  He wants to take Willy for the summer.
column2: What did you say?

column1: Mr. Murphy asked about you again at work yesterday.
column2: He just wants me to make him cinnamon cookies like I made for you.

column1: I think he wants more than your cookies.
column2: Kimberly!

column1: Who is it?
column2: Avon Lady!

column1: My man Dubbs.
column2: Who are you?  What the fuck do you want?

column1: I want to ask you a few questions.
column2: No, you're not model material.  Anything else?

column1: Funny guy.
column2: Fuck you - fuck you.

column1: You helped set up my partner, Sergeant William Wade.  I want to know who put you up to it.
column2: Your mother.

column1: Speak up.
column2: It was Wade's old partner... Gallagher. He was behind it all.

column1: I worked for him... still do.  Said he'd make sure I was left alone if I helped put Wade away.  He kept his promise for twenty years.
column2: Prepare for a change in lifestyle.

column1: It was Wade's old partner... Gallagher. He was behind it all.
column2: Put that on your political resume.

column1: Looks like you did more than jackoff while I was gone.
column2: Maybe re-animating you wasn't such a bright idea.  You look like shit.

column1: Twenty years have passed, Wade. Lay it to rest.
column2: I was set up and you know it... but you swore under oath I was dirty. You helped bury me.

column1: I'm not on the force anymore.
column2: Well, you've just been taken off the bench.

column1: I want to see my wife and kid.
column2: Later.  I want Doucet first.

column1: I told you.  I'm out of the cops and robbers business.  Retired twenty years ago.  I've been trained as a bus driver.  Got a whole route planned and everything.  Even nailed down the lingo - '<u>Exact change, please</u>'.
column2: I'm going to bring this down hard. I've got an A-1 badass killer loose, an election day after tomorrow, and I'm risking everything on you. You're going to bring him in.  I don't care how.  If you do, you'll get your freedom.  An official pardon from me.  A clean slate.  A good job.  A chance to get back with your family.  If you don't want to, I'll put your ass back in the freezer so fast, you'll forget you were ever defrosted.

column1: What's this?
column2: Fill it out.  Standard issue mal- practice insurance.  All Cops carry it.

column1: Mug sheets.
column2: I remember what he looks like.  I can't forget.

column1: Edicon system made these.  Ages, photographs.  We use it to find missing children.
column2: He's not that old yet.  You've lost confidence in me.

column1: You son-of-a-bitch.  How do you stop it?
column2: We have an antidote that'll retard the aging process.

column1: Give it to me.
column2: When you bring in Doucet.

column1: The faster you get Doucet, the younger you'll be.
column2: I'm going to kill you when this is all over.

column1: You're working a partner on this.
column2: I've been alone for twenty years. I don't feel very sociable.

column1: Hello Wade.
column2: Out of the room.

column1: Tell Frick and Frack that means them too.
column2: I'll be alright.

column1: You can't kill me.  I'm going to be Mayor tomorrow.
column2: I'm not voting for you.

column1: I want to stop aging.
column2: And I want Doucet.

column1: This is a war, Wade.  You against him.  Vengeance time.  The City's just in the way.  Kill the fucker. You and me.  We'll work things out when the time is right.
column2: Remember my promise.

column1: Don't threaten me.  I tend to take these things seriously.  And get a couple hours sleep.  You look like day old shit.
column2: Got compliments coming outta your ass, don't ya?

column1: Just got the call.  Took him from school.  Bastard nailed the Vice- Principal and a teacher.
column2: Where?

column1: I'm wasting time.
column2: You can't win like this.  You'll only get older.  This is what you wanted!

column1: What is it?  I'm about to go on.
column2: We have to talk.

column1: I heard about today.  Good job.  I'm all for capital punishment.  Why don't you go home and see your family?
column2: That wasn't your plan, was it?

column1: You were planning to send me back to the ice house.  You set me up.
column2: You're crazy.

column1: I don't want to hear anymore.
column2: You stole the heroin out of the evidence room and planted it on me.  I was iced.  What better way to keep me from talking.  Stop me if I'm wrong.

column1: That's not your zone.  Stick to data entry.
column2: I was part of the escort team that re-animated him.  My partner's dead because of this guy.

column1: Wade's in Cryo-Prison.
column2: He could be brought back.

column1: Kill him... kill him.
column2: Simon Doucet.  You are under arrest. Please come out with your hands in the air.

column1: Doucet's just offed two of the jurors who put him away.  I'm rounding up the rest of them and putting them in police custody.  What's your status?
column2: We seem to've come across a 211, sir.

column1: You two fucks listen up.  Doucet's killing people and you're wasting valuable time busting two-bit Technothugs.
column2: But sir, Sergeant Wade saved the hostages.

column1: Sir, your transmission's fading.
column2: What the hell are you talking about?

column1: You have no evidence.  Arrest this man.
column2: You want evidence.  I'll give you evidence.

column1: What do you mean he's escaped?! They're not supposed to escape!
column2: It's a real mess down here.  Some- thing must a'gone wrong.  No man could possess that kind of strength after being frozen for twenty years.

column1: Tell Doucet that.  What was his rehabilitation training?
column2: Telephone repairman.

column1: Just great.
column2: NPA syndrome will hit 'im fast.  Have your men gear up the Edicon system at a twenty-year ratio in fractions of fives.  Saying a prayer won't be bad either.

column1: Sir, your dinner with the union leaders begins in an hour.  Your wife will meet you there, so we can leave whenever you're ready.
column2: Fine.

column1: Sir, your limo's here.
column2: Kill me if you want.  Hard line me with that 'I ain't got nothing to lose' bullshit.  But you've got plenty to lose 'partner'.  You've got a family.  I'm giving you a chance to see them.  I kept in touch.  She never married. All these years.  Maybe she loves you.  I wouldn't know why.

column1: You okay?
column2: How do I look?

column1: Okay, that's all folks.  Commissioner Gallagher has to go.
column2: Keep 'em busy.

column1: Sir---
column2: Shut up!  Drop it.

column1: Need help?
column2: I got it.  I got it.

column1: You sure?  I can help you.
column2: Ah Mom, you're embarrass'n me.

column1: Nobody's looking.
column2: Go in the house.

column1: Maybe I should put on the training whe---
column2: Not the 'T' word.

column1: You my partner?
column2: Officer Hector Sanchez, Sergeant. Hillside Academy.  Status G-8. Security Clearance 3.  One year Advance Technical Crime Analyst. Weapons Assistant.  FDA Junior Captain, Hollywood division---

column1: Are you a cop?
column2: Yes.

column1: I drive.
column2: Commissioner Gallagher gave me specific orders not to let you drive until you re-familiarize yourself with the process and territory.

column1: I'm ready.
column2: But Sergeant...

column1: Does it drive itself, too?
column2: You have to use the steering wheel to turn.  The pedal for gas...

column1: Got it.  Ejection seat?
column2: Whoa.  Don't touch that.  <u>Pursuit</u> <u>Mode</u>.  Auto pilot.  Computerized steering and driving system used in high speed pursuits.  Installed Fall 2006.  Underground rumor has it they modeled it after you, sir.

column1: I have to go home, Sanchez.
column2: Commissioner Gallagher said...  ...twenty years is a long time.

column1: No offense, but why'd they partner me with a rookie?
column2: Doucet killed my partner.

column1: See those guys?
column2: Technothugs.

column1: They're going to rob that bank.
column2: How do you know?

column1: I'll inform dispatch.
column2: There's no time.  There are civilians in there.  It's about to go down.

column1: We don't know that for sure.  We'll have to wait until they move.
column2: Well, I'm sure.  You're a cop.  I'm a cop.  Let's do what cops do.

column1: You can't turn him off.  He's the Commissioner.
column2: I'm not fond of television comedies.

column1: Wanna come?
column2: My insurance won't cover it.

column1: Thanks.  Want'a bite?  McDonald's vegiroll.
column2: Pass.

column1: Can I ask you something?
column2: Yes.

column1: Then what goes on in there?  What I mean is, what are you thinking about?
column2: Bacon cheeseburgers.

column1: Give me a break.  I'm serious. What's it like to be dead?
column2: Trust me.  You don't want to know.

column1: Hey, buddy...
column2: Relax, let technology do the work.

column1: NPA metamorphosis should biologically slow him down.  That's when we'll get him.
column2: You can't catch this man with a computer.

column1: How then?
column2: You don't follow the bodies, and you don't follow procedure.  You do it by instinct.  Think like him.  Do what has to be dane.

column1: Sir, I took the liberty of running a GCI scenario on a TM-1 earlier today...
column2: GCI.  TM-1.  What language are you talking?

column1: I also PVC'd you.  Youngest Officer promoted to Sergeant. Two CMs.  Four honor medals...
column2: Drop it.

column1: Why?
column2: I was set up.

column1: You're saying you were put away for a crime you didn't commit?
column2: 'Bout the same time I busted Doucet I tried to nail this big-time dealer. I didn't have an ID, but I was close. Too close.  Gained the confidence of a badass named Dubbs.  He was going to turn me onto the big man.  He made me for a cop.  Mysteriously my fellow officers discovered ten pounds of heroin in my cruiser.

column1: It doesn't make sense.  Who would want to do that to you?
column2: Nothing makes sense when you're a cop.

column1: Married?
column2: Engaged.  Plan on doing it this summer.  You still married?

column1: What's this place?
column2: This is where I found Doucet twenty years ago.  Thought maybe he'd come back.

column1: Yeah.
column2: Hey, Rip Van Winkle, maybe we'd better call it a night.

column1: She's pretty.
column2: Thanks.

column1: You need anything else?
column2: I'll be okay.

column1: Good night, Wade.
column2: Good night.

column1: I'll have a cup of coffee?
column2: Never use it.  Stuff'll kill ya.

column1: No.  Talk English.  Then I'll understand.
column2: We get to peek into Doucet's brain.

column1: Hey, I'm eating.
column2: I'm serious, Wade.  This case is important to me.

column1: You want to be a good detective?
column2: Yes, sir.

column1: Two lousy smokes.  You're a real sport.
column2: That cost me two weeks' pay.

column1: Maybe I should turn myself in.
column2: Lighten up.  You're going to give yourself an ulcer.

column1: Part of Doucet's cerebellum, a portion called the vermis is under- developed.  This area rates response to outside stimuli.  Com- pare it to that of a normal law- abiding citizen.  It could be why he kills.
column2: Great.  My partner's Marcus Welby.

column1: I'm just doing it by the book. Analyze then vaporize.  Crime's a science.  Everything's analyzed.
column2: With all this technology you don't even have to show up for work.  Who needs cops when you've got gizmos.

column1: Wanna try?
column2: No thank you, sir.  Smoking causes lung cancer, heart disease, emphysema, and may complicate pregnancy.

column1: You're not pregnant, are you?
column2: No, sir.

column1: Let's roll.  We got a guy who swears his car was stolen by a suspect identical to Doucet. 0800 this morning.
column2: What else did he get?

column1: Wallet, cash, I.D...
column2: Fire up that thing of yours and tell me all credit card trans- actions after eight o'clock.

column1: Kid, you ever been in a high speed chase before?
column2: Simulated one.

column1: Get us some fuck'n back-up now!
column2: <u>Comwatch Dispatch System</u>.  Can't assimilate voice stress.  Code priority only.

column1: Rip Van Winkle.
column2: How ya feeling?

column1: How do I look?
column2: Not too good.

column1: What's this?
column2: We're partners, aren't we?

column1: Sanchez...?
column2: I'm here.

column1: You treat her nice.
column2: ...What are you talking about...?

column1: Your girl.  Being a cop will be rough on her.
column2: ...Have you been drinking?

column1: Yeah.
column2: This should make your day.  The guy who testified against you... Dubbs... was arrested a total number of twenty- four times.

column1: So, he's got a thing for prison clothes.
column2: That's just it.  He never did time. Seems each arrest was botched for one reason or another.  Judge threw out the cases each time.  Either he's got a horseshoe up his ass or powerful friends.

column1: You okay?
column2: Aaah... Mother of Jesus.

column1: What is it?  Your legs?  Hands?
column2: Hospital food.

column1: What are you doing this for, Sanchez?
column2: If you were set up, I want to find out who did it.

column1: I just heard.
column2: He's got my grandson, Sanchez.

column1: You be careful.
column2: I'm signing off.

column1: No.  I want to be with you.
column2: No you don't.

column1: You should be in hospital.
column2: And you should be with your family.

column1: Jesus, Sanchez... what do you think you're doin'?  That's flatfoot data. You're not supposed to have access to that.
column2: This is the guy that killed my partner.

column1: You startin' a fan club or some- thin'?
column2: Says here one of our boys brought him down.  You ever heard of a badge named Wade?

column1: Demolition Man.
column2: What's it mean?

column1: You never want to find out.
column2: Take a look at this.

column1: He had a partner.  Our own Ray Gallagher.  He tagged Wade dangerously defiant. Psychotic.  Reckless.  Seems our Commissioner didn't like him much. Busted his buns on a narcotic's violation.  Wade was sentenced to twenty-five years.
column2: He went dirty and they made an example of him.

column1: But he was such a good cop.
column2: They always are.

column1: You all right?
column2: Yeah.

column1: Seat's too high.
column2: My mom says I'm gonna grow.

column1: Yes.
column2: My granddad was a policeman.

column1: I'm going to be a policeman.
column2: What's your name?

column1: William Simpson.  I like Willy.
column2: Good to know you, Willy.

column1: Bye.  Thanks.
column2: Remember, get the seat fixed.

column1: Hi.
column2: Hi.

column1: Funny.  Would you like to buy me a drink?
column2: This little thing says I can't.

column1: You could always take it off.
column2: It's stuck, but thanks for the offer.

column1: Papers.  Last Medcheck two weeks ago. A-1.  Disease free.  Guaranteed by the State.
column2: I don't care if you've got the Good Housekeeping seal of approval... I'm not looking for company.

column1: My Lord!
column2: Piter.

column1: The Atreides will be leaving Caladan soon, Baron, and I have here your answer from Duke Leto.
column2: What does Leto say, Piter?

column1: He wishes to inform you that Vendetta -- as he puts it, using the ancient tongue, the art of Kanly -- is still alive. He does not wish to meet or speak with you.
column2: I made my peace gesture... the forms of Kanly have been obeyed.

column1: It was Feyd?  It was Feyd!  Where is the ducal signet ring?  I must have his ring.
column2: The ring?... he was brought to us as is, Baron.  I...

column1: So you are Dr. Kynes, the Imperial Ecologist?
column2: I prefer the more ancient term, planetologist... Noble Born.

column1: I understand we have you to thank for these stillsuits, Doctor.
column2: They are Fremen suits. I hope they fit well, my lord.

column1: My thanks.
column2: With your permission...

column1: What happens now?
column2: The carryall will come and lift off the spice harvester. Try and get in close over the harvester... you'll find this interesting Sire. -- The Duke accelerates the ornithopter in the direction of the harvester. Paul can SEE...

column1: What's that you're saying?
column2: Nothing.

column1: A Third Stage Guild Navigator will be here within minutes!
column2: We felt his presence.

column1: I shall want telepathy during his visit and a report when we're finished.
column2: Their minds are so.... They move in strange directions....

column1: Yes?
column2: Forced spice evolution of humans changes many things.... I must sit close to him.

column1: He will not permit anyone but me to see him. You must be outside this room.... Do what you can.
column2: I am your Truthsayer, my lord...  He is here, my lord.

column1: Yes, my Lord.
column2: We are alone...

column1: We have just folded space from Ix...
column2: Yes?... How was your journey?

column1: Many machines on Ix... new machines.
column2: Oh yes? -- NAVIGATOR Better than those on Richesse.. You are transparent... I see many things... I see plans within plans.

column1: I see two Great Houses -- House Atreides, House Harkonnen -- feuding... I see you behind it.
column2: Yes.

column1: You must share with us. -- EMPEROR The Atreides house is building a secret army!... using a technique unknown to us... a technique involving sound. The Duke is becoming more popular in the Landsraad... he could threaten me.... I have ordered House Atreides to occupy Arrakis to mine the spice... thus replacing their enemies the Harkonnens.... House Atreides will not refuse because of the tremendous power they think they will gain. Then, at an appointed time Baron Harkonnen will return to Arrakis and launch a sneak attack on House Atreides... I have promised the Baron five legions of my Sardaukar terror troops.
column2: So the Harkonnens will rid you of House Atreides...

column1: Can you hear me?... If this visit has anything to do with spice... -- The Guild Navigator shudders and swishes quite violently in his tank.
column2: LISTEN TO ME!! The spice must flow... the spice has given me accelerated evolution for four thousand years... it has enabled you to live two hundred years... the spice helps make the sapho juice, which gives the red-lipped mentats the ability to be living computers... the secret side of spice... the water of life.

column1: I can assure you...
column2: Do not interrupt!!! Do not speak lightly of the spice... ONE SMALL POINT...

column1: So, this is Leto the Just...
column2: I hope I made myself clear. You may call him "The Duke," "My lord," or "Sire." And there is a more ancient term you might keep in mind -- "Noble Born."

column1: The Duke is to be addresses as... -- Kynes comes forward and adjusts the Duke's suit, checking seals and pulling on straps.
column2: Basically...

column1: Yes, Sire.
column2: It's a high-efficiency filter and heat exchange system. Perspiration passes through the first layer and is gathered in the second. The salt is separated. Breathing and walking provide the pumping action. The reclaimed water circulates to catchpockets from which you can drink through this tube at your neck. Urine and feces are processed in the thigh pads. Should you be in the open desert, remember to breathe in through your mouth, out through the nose tubes.

column1: Dust cloud ahead, Sire.
column2: That's it... spice mining... no other cloud quite like it. See the spotters over it? They're watching for wormsign... the telltale sand waves. Seismic probes on the surface, too Sire... worms can travel too deep for their waves to show... Looks like a good patch of spice.

column1: No music. I'm packing this for the crossing. Shield practice.
column2: Shield practice? Gurney... we had practice -- this morning..... I'm not in the mood.

column1: Not in the mood?! Mood's a thing for cattle and love play... not fighting.
column2: I'm sorry Gurney.

column1: What's gotten into Gurney? He's not faking. Paul presses forward and the fight moves quickly around the room. The smell of ozone grows stronger as the shields hit and SPARK off one another. Paul directs a parry downwards, turns, and leads Gurney against the table, plunging at just the right moment to pin Gurney against the table top with his blade right at Gurney's neck.
column2: Is this what you seek?

column1: We'd have joined each other in death. However, you did seem to finally get the "mood".
column2: Would you really have drawn my blood?

column1: Things have been so serious here lately.
column2: Yes. I sensed the play in you lad, but this can no longer be play. Tomorrow we leave for Arrakis! Arrakis is real. The Harkonnens are real.

column1: You've no need of your weapons with me Gurney Halleck.
column2: Paul!!  Paul!!

column1: Don't you trust your own eyes.
column2: They said you were dead.  They said...

column1: Gurney... I see Thufir Hawat among the captives.  Let him stand free.
column2: My Lord?

column1: This is a Harkonnen animal.  Let me, please, my Lord.
column2: The Emperor's blade.

column1: Perhaps these are the ones Mapes told us of.
column2: Are you trained in the ways of the desert?

column1: No, but many consider my training valuable.
column2: I will take the boy-man... he shall have sanctuary in my tribe... -- A LOW NOTE on a dip stick is blown by one of the Fremen tribe.  Jessica shifts, Paul sees it, and just as Stilgar begins a reach for his weapon, Jessica turns, slashes out, utters a SOUND, whirls again and with rock behind her holds Stilgar helpless in front of her -- her hand at his throat. Paul moves on her first move.  He races up a rocky incline.

column1: Stop!  Get back!!  She has the weirding way.  Why didn't you tell us!  Great gods... if you can do this to the strongest of us you're worth ten times your weight of water.  As a leader of my people I give you my bond: teach us this weirding way and you both shall have sanctuary.  Your water shall mingle with our water.
column2: Then I will teach you our way of battle....  you have the word bond of a Bene Gesserit.

column1: Sayyadina.  Our Reverend Mother tells me she is too old... She has been calling through space and time for you to come and let her rest.  She asks that you pass within.
column2: They want me to take the Water of Life... the Truthsayer drug... so dangerous, yet... we must move swiftly if we're to secure our place among these Fremen.  I will try to pass within.

column1: Death may be the result....  Are you sure?
column2: I must do this for Paul, but what of my unborn child?

column1: You know the ancient tongues?
column2: I know the Bhotani Jib and Chakobsa, all the hunting languages.

column1: As the legend says.
column2: That's it! The Missionaria Protectiva has been here planting protective legends against a day of Bene Gesserit need. And that day has come. I must play out this sham.  I know the Dark things and the way of the Great Mother. Miseces prejin.

column1: Do you know this my lady?
column2: It could only be one thing....  It's a crysknife.

column1: Say it not lightly...  Do you know its meaning?
column2: Here is why this Fremen has taken service with me, to ask that one question. Delay is as dangerous as the wrong answer. Shadout is Chakobsa... knife, in Chakobsa is... maker of death.  It's a maker...

column1: Maker?... Maker is the key word... the tooth of the worm? That was close...  Did you think that I, knowing the mysteries of the Great Mother, would not know the maker?
column2: My lady, when one has lived with prophecy for so long, the moment of revelation is a shock.

column1: Paul, this is the Reverend Mother Gaius Helen Mohiam. She is going to... observe you...  Please... -- REVEREND MOTHER Jessica, you know it must be done. I enjoin you to stand guard at the door and practice the meditation of peace.
column2: Your Reverence.

column1: What does she fear?  What about my Father?
column2: Paul... please, Paul... listen to the Reverend Mother and do what she tells you.

column1: Don't touch my mother...
column2: Oh great mother!  He's trying the voice. The Reverend Mother said it could save him.

column1: Remove her gag!
column2: Excellent!

column1: I can't maintain any altitude... we'll never reach the safety of rock.  Maybe that small rock.
column2: Where are we do you think?

column1: A million deaths are not enough for Yueh...
column2: Where are my feelings... I feel for no one...

column1: Listen to me!... you wanted to know about my dreams... and I've just had a waking dream... do you know why?... -- JESSICA Calm yourself/
column2: The spice!  It's in everything here.  The air, the soil, the food...  It's like the Truthsayer drug.....  It's a poison!!!! You knew the spice would change me.  But thanks to your teachings it's changed my consciousness.  I can see it... I can see it.

column1: Is he....?
column2: You carry my unborn sister in your womb!

column1: He knows.
column2: You and your Bene Gesserit sisterhood... I'm not your Kwisatz Haderach...  I'm something different, something unexpected!  I'm a seed.  I am so much more...  You don't begin to know me...

column1: It's further than I thought... a worm is sure to come....  I'll plant a thumper, that should divert it. -- Paul moves off into the shadows.  Suddenly, Jessica SEES a burst of LIGHTNING illuminate the mountain of rock in the distant and the vast dunes before them.
column2: ...the night is a tunnel... a hole into tomorrow... if we're to have a tomorrow...

column1: Remember... walk without rhythm and we won't attract a worm... it'll go to the thumper.
column2: I'm ready.

column1: Run!
column2: I can't... I can't.

column1: Cinnamon... the spice!  Do you smell it?
column2: Yes...

column1: What's happened?...  Why did it leave?
column2: Someone started another thumper....  We're not alone.

column1: Man-carved steps.
column2: Yes...

column1: Stop him yourself.
column2: You saw a part of what the race needs in the beginning.  In time you perverted the truth.  You sought to control human breeding and intermix a select few according to a selfish master plan.  How little you understand.

column1: Are you a Fremen?
column2: I am a servant of the His Majesty the Emperor. I have served His Majesty on Arrakis long enough for my eyes to change.

column1: You've worn a stillsuit before?
column2: No.

column1: Your suit is fitted desert fashion. Who told you how to do that?
column2: No one. It... seemed the proper way.

column1: Will we see a worm?
column2: Where there is spice and spice mining there are always worms.

column1: Always?
column2: Always.

column1: Why do they come?
column2: To protect their territory. Vibrations attract them. -- PAUL  I've registered him now... a knife is a sheath on his left arm... He's strong... a person born to command... He's hiding many things.  Is there a relationship between the worms and the spice?

column1: Spice!... pure un-refined spice!
column2: Bless the Maker and his water... Bless the coming and going of him.  May his passage cleanse the world.

column1: Liet?
column2: You are about to witness something few have seen -- watch!  Watch!

column1: You have strength... real strength... You shall be known as Usul, which is the strength of the base of the pillar.  This is your secret name in our troop.  But you must choose the name of manhood which we will call you openly.
column2: What do you call the mouse shadow in the second moon?

column1: We call that one Muad'dib.
column2: Could I be known as Paul Muad'dib?

column1: Water on Arrakis!!! I have seen this place in a dream.  A treasure.
column2: Greater than treasure, Usul.  We have thousands of such caches.  Only a few of us know them all.  When we have enough... we shall change the face of Arrakis. Listen!...

column1: The Water of Life.
column2: The most lethal poison in the Universe.

column1: My own name is a killing word.  Will it be a healing word as well?
column2: Usul... these are fifteen of our fiercest fighters to serve you as your guard... the Fedaykin.

column1: We surprised a band of smugglers.
column2: Too bad... thought they were Harkonnen.

column1: Long live the fighters!
column2: Long live the fighters!

column1: What's in the box?
column2: Pain.

column1: The Voice again.
column2: I hold at your neck the gom jabbar. Don't pull away or you'll feel that poison. A Duke's son must know about many poisons -- this one kills only animals.

column1: Are you suggesting a Duke's son is an animal?
column2: Let us say I suggest you may be human. Your awareness may be powerful enough to control your instincts. Your instincts will be to remove your hand from the box. If you do so you will die. You will feel an itching -- there... see? Now the itching becomes burning... heat, upon heat, upon heat.

column1: It burns.
column2: SILENCE... SILENCE.

column1: I must not fear. Fear is the mind-killer. Fear is the little death that brings total obliteration. I will face my fear... I will permit it to pass over me and through me. -- The Reverend Mother moves her face up to his. Her ancient face with its metal teeth gleaming inches away breathes hotly. She is smiling.
column2: You feel the flesh crisping?

column1: THE PAIN!
column2: NO!! ENOUGH!! Kull wahad! No woman child ever withstood that much. I must have wanted you to fail. Take your hand out of the box and look at it, young human.... Do it!

column1: Pain by nerve induction... A human can resist any pain. Our test is crisis and observation.
column2: I see the truth of it. -- REVEREND MOTHER  Could he be the one?... Maybe... but will he be ours to control?  You know when people speak the truth?

column1: Your mother wants you to tell me about your dreams. I only want to know one thing.... Do they come true?
column2: Not all of them... I know which ones will.

column1: Perhaps you are the Kwisatz Haderach.
column2: What is it?

column1: The person who can be many places at once... the one who bridges space and time.... He will look where we cannot.
column2: Where?

column1: Do you know of the Water of Life?... the Truthsayer drug?
column2: I have heard of it. -- REVEREND MOTHER It is very dangerous... very painful. The Bene Gesserit sisterhood drink it to see within.... There is a place terrifying to us... to women. It is said a man will come... the Kwisatz Haderach... he will go where we cannot... Many men have tried...

column1: Did they try and fail?
column2: They tried and died....  Jessica!

column1: I sense your teachings in him. Ignore the regular order of training. His safety requires The Voice.
column2: I've heard enough of my safety... What about my father?... I heard you talking. You speak as if he was dead. Well, he isn't!

column1: Well he isn't... and he won't die... Tell me he won't die!
column2: What can be done has been done.

column1: ... Many men have tried.
column2: Did they try and fail?

column1: Don't try your powers on me.  Try looking into that place where you dare not look. You'll find me there staring back at you!! You Bene Gesserit have waited ninety generations to produce the one person your schemes required.  Here I stand.  But... I will never be yours.
column2: Stop him, Jessica!

column1: You mustn't speak of...
column2: SILENCE!

column1: I heard you, Dr. Yueh and Gurney coming down the hall.
column2: Those sounds could be imitated.

column1: Yes. Perhaps he would at that.
column2: My father sent you to test me. Music then?

column1: Many dangers exist on Arrakis. For one, we know the Harkonnens would not have given up their CHOAM company contract so easily.
column2: The Harkonnens are our enemies, yes... but behind them, I suspect, is the Emperor. -- THUFIR You will make a formidable Duke!

column1: Now remember... the first step in avoiding a trap is knowing of its existence.
column2: I know.  But if it is a trap then why are we going?

column1: Did you call the Zoo?
column2: Yes, sir.  We're in luck.  The sick bay's almost empty except for a mauled fox cub, a deer with pneumonia, and a depressed gorilla. The Apes will be hidden from the public.  They'll be quarantined. If they want medical attention, it's available on the spot.  And the experts can start giving them the once-over first thing in the morning. General Brody's very pleased.

column1: Me, too.  Can't have a lot of monkeys making messes in the Guardhouse.  Have we fed them?  Like raw steak or something?
column2: The Zoo tells me that chimpanzees, like all apes, are vegetarian, sir.

column1: Good God.
column2: They suggested oranges.

column1: Excuse me.  I didn't mean to disturb....  What am I saying?
column2: They're...pretending to dress.

column1: So am I.  And I mean you no harm.
column2: We know that.

column1: Do you have a name?
column2: My name is Cornelius.  And this is Zira -- my wife.

column1: Nobody's going to believe it.
column2: Believe what?

column1: In some fashion -- and I lack the intellect to know precisely how -- we have traveled from Earth's future into Earth's past.
column2: But we saw Earth destroyed.

column1: Zira, are you mad?
column2: Dr. Milo, please don't call my wife mad.

column1: To a lot of psychiatric small talk --
column2: And we can watch ...

column1: What, Lewis?
column2: There was a sort of carpetbag in the ship.

column1: With food?
column2: No -- clothes.  Stevie, they changed into them.

column1: What are they doing here?
column2: Security.  Join the Marines and see the Zoo ...

column1: Go easy, Stevie.
column2: They look pretty docile.

column1: We shall want a full autopsy ...
column2: With particular emphasis on the cranial and oral areas.

column1: But he isn't us.  He's your own kind.
column2: He's a gorilla.

column1: I mean he's of your race. He's an Ape.  Look.  You don't have to be afraid.  We've put him in chains and under sedation. Do you understand that?
column2: I should.  I've been doing it half my life to Humans.

column1: Humans?
column2: I'm a psychiatrist.

column1: Primitive?
column2: I mean that in our 'primitive' civilization, apes just don't talk. I mean I think it's important that, when our 'primitive' security precautions are lifted, the first time you say something in public you should talk to what we 'primitively' call the Right People.

column1: May I say something personal?
column2: Please

column1: ComStat did a psychosearch on him. Used a database of 5 million sociopathic personalities. He hit the bottom of the curve.
column2: Perfect for the mission. Nobody else can pull it off - not an army, not a man.

column1: Somehow during the tour, she came into possession of a prototype transmitting device. We don't know how.
column2: Utopia became depressed after her mother's suicide, began to withdraw into her virtual reality simulator. She'd punch up her own little world in cyberspace and stay in it for days at a time.  Somebody else was in there with her.

column1: The cigarette girl in New Vegas was an undercover cop. She injected you with incentive toxin. Right now it's swimming in your bloodstream. It'll start to take effect in 9 hours.
column2: It's a strain of the Plutoxin 7 virus. Genetically engineered. 100% pure death. Complete nervous system shutdown. You crash and bleed out like a stuck pig. Not a pretty sight.

column1: L.A. is in a constant state of warfare. Gangs fighting for the right to rule.
column2: Heavy Third World connections. They get weapons, drugs, fuel, choppers - everything is pumped into the island from the south.

column1: His reactor's starting to overheat.
column2: Plissken, slow down the sub. You're overloading the power plant.

column1: You were injected with glucose. There is no Plutoxin 7 virus. You were never going to die - at least not from anything we gave you.
column2: C'mon, Snake - it's L.A. Everything's phony, you know that.

column1: Who's that?
column2: You never heard of Snake Plissken?

column1: He doesn't look like his picture.  I bet he's fake.
column2: Now go get dressed. We have things to do.

column1: Ooww!
column2: Go on now. Do as I say.

column1: Cuervo...?
column2: You're my woman, you understand? You don't let anybody take you away from me without a fight.

column1: I tried...
