column2: Nobody leaves Cuervo Jones. Not unless you give your life. You fight till you're dead. Then I forgive you.  Understand?  Understand?

column1: Come on, Cuervo. I delivered him, didn't I? All I'm asking for is what you promised.
column2: We'll see.

column1: Where is he?
column2: He jumped. Down there.  He's dead, Cuervo. I did it. I killed Plissken.

column1: Give it to me.
column2: You said I could be Vice-President, Cuervo. Your right-hand man.

column1: Give it.
column2: Sure, Cuervo, but look here. I've done it all, man. I killed Plissken, I got your girl back, I got it all. Just for you, Cuervo. Just for you.

column1: You're about to get hit, Cuervo. It's Plissken.
column2: You told me he was dead.

column1: I thought he was, but he came back.
column2: Where?

column1: Oh Cuervo...
column2: What?

column1: It's so good to see you again.
column2: Where's Plissken?

column1: He's... near.
column2: You're stalling, Eddie.  Talk, you little gringo!

column1: I wouldn't be doin' that, Snake.
column2: We have a little arrangement. Anything happens to me, you're dead.

column1: Wait a minute. All right. Hold on.
column2: Cuervo Jones has more firepower than two armies. No one gets near him.

column1: Why should we leave? I love L.A. Where we gonna go? What's the payoff?
column2: I'd like to get out but I don't have enough money.

column1: Shit.
column2: You always were a loser, Plissken. Makin' things up as you go along. That's why I cut out on you in Cleveland. You're just a bum like the rest of us.

column1: Where'd you get these rigs, Carjack?
column2: My name is Hershe Hernandez, do you understand, cowboy?

column1: I need a favor.
column2: What's in it for me?

column1: Wait a minute. I know that voice.  You're Carjack Malone.
column2: Not anymore.

column1: I was called away on urgent business, Snake.
column2: Don't lie to me.

column1: All right, so I made another deal.
column2: I got a new deal for you.

column1: I'm already dead.
column2: I see your point. What's the favor?

column1: Get me to Cuervo Jones. Get me to the Kingdom. I got one hour.
column2: Dream on, blue eye.

column1: So what's the deal, gorgeous?
column2: We get the girl and the prototype. And we get out.

column1: I don't know, sounds thin to me.
column2: You want to stay here, while Cuervo Jones rules the world?

column1: No, that sucks.  How are we getting out?
column2: I don't know yet.

column1: See you in hell, Snake.
column2: If I'm late, Carjack, don't start without me.

column1: She's overloaded! We're too heavy.
column2: Somebody get off!

column1: I think we've burned off enough fuel. We may be lighter enough to hover. Just barely.
column2: Can you land?

column1: No. The right skid's broken. If I try to set it down she'll crash. I have to stay in a hoverwhile you jump off.  Hey, Carjack. We gotta hide the girl. Give her your dress.
column2: My name is no longer Carjack. Will you please get that through your fucking head?

column1: How you doin' Plissken?  You like the watch?
column2: You assholes didn't bring me here to give me this for 20 years of dedicated service. What'ya want?

column1: Shut up, Plissken.
column2: What's the little black box do?

column1: Top secret. Only on a need to know.
column2: And I don't need to know. So fuck you, I'm goin' to Hollywood.

column1: That's right, big shot. Unless you do what we want you're not coming back.
column2: So what's the deal, huh? Go into L.A., find the President's daughter, secure the box, and bring 'em both out - and I'm free?

column1: That's the deal.
column2: Tell the President to adopt. I think I'll like L.A.

column1: Wait a minute, what are you talkin' about?
column2: Having second thoughts?

column1: Maybe. But you're not putting any shit in me this time.
column2: You don't understand. It's already in you.

column1: Get this crap out of me.
column2: I guess we have a deal. Nice to be working with you, Plissken.

column1: I'll need to know more about this thing.
column2: Only a handful of people are aware of its existence. Let's just say it's the ultimate defensive weapon.

column1: Defense against what?
column2: There's a war about to be declared, or didn't you know?

column1: Third World wants to live like we do - and they plan on taking what they want. The Cubans and Brazilians are ready to invade Miami. If the Africans and Colombians make a run at the border, we got a full scale attack on the United States.
column2: So what does this thing do?

column1: Where do I put ashore?
column2: Cahuenga Pass. Make your way up through the mountains toward the Hollywood Bowl. You should be able to pick up Utopia's tracer there.  Once you go inside, you're on your own.  You know what you have to do with the girl, don't you?  We have to spare this nation her trial - for treason.

column1: So you want me to take her out?  Is that an order from the President?
column2: Let's just say it's what's best for the country.

column1: By the way - who gives me the anti-toxin?
column2: A medical team will be standing by.

column1: Not you?
column2: No.

column1: She's in the green.
column2: Lock fuel rods.

column1: Locked.
column2: Nuclear turbine to 75% power.

column1: 75% power.
column2: Hands on switches and counting. 5...4...3...2...1. Launch.

column1: Plissken...?
column2: I'm here.

column1: Where's the submarine? It's disappeared off our screens.
column2: It's history. I gotta go.

column1: Plissken - this is Malloy. Do you have the prototype?
column2: Yeah, I got it.

column1: Got a smoke?
column2: You're gonna have to learn to respect the law, Snake. The United States is a no- smoking nation. No smoking, no drinking, do drugs, no women unless you're married, no guns, no foul language. It's a brand new day for you, Snake.

column1: It's the President, for Christ's sake!
column2: I give you my word. Put the prototype into my hands, and you're a free man.

column1: Getting ready to invade.
column2: So where's Plissken?

column1: The prototype appears to be armed, Mr. President.  Shall I begin evacuation?
column2: Does he know how to activate it?

column1: Relax, war hero. We took you for a ride, and you came through. Not bad for a dirtbag like you.
column2: You're free, Plissken. But if you even so much as break wind on a country road I'll crush you like a bug.

column1: You're a star in your own right, you know that? Hey, I'm Map To The Stars Eddie. How you doin'?
column2: Where'd they go?

column1: Where are they?
column2: Who? You mean Cuervo Jones? He's the man with the juice, Snake. Got the President's daughter. Setting up a citywide truce. Big doings.

column1: Location.
column2: Cuervo's got a place near Venice, where the big birds fly. Nice digs, too. I've been there, y'know.

column1: Too many people know where you're going, Snake. That's not good. Delgado and his men were back there waiting for you.
column2: Delgado?

column1: Stop the damn car.
column2: No way.

column1: I said pull over.
column2: All right. Anything for you, Snake.  Although I was going to take you to Cuervo Jones' place.

column1: Where is it?
column2: Right over there.

column1: Where are they going?
column2: Oh, man... You didn't have to hit me, Snake. I can help you.

column1: Not yet.
column2: I could've helped you. We coulda made a deal with Cuervo. If you'd listen...

column1: Listen up. I need directions. Downtown. Somebody named Hershe.
column2: Sure, Snake. No problem.  You gonna kill me?

column1: Later.
column2: I couldn't help it, Snake. I had to shoot you. Cuervo made me do it, I swear to God, man.

column1: Cease fire with the bullshit.
column2: Right. Keep goin' straight. Two blocks down, turn right.

column1: How do you know all this?
column2: I used to represent the guy who invented it. I swear to God, Snake. No bullshit.

column1: Me too?
column2: We'll see.

column1: Aw, come on, Snake.
column2: Bluebacks. I'm not bullshittin'. I swear to God.

column1: I don't know about this thing.
column2: Don't like it, don't come.

column1: I got an idea, Snake.  This looks like the prototype, right?
column2: Yeah, kinda.

column1: So maybe we can pull off a Texas switch on Cuervo.
column2: If he lets you get close enough.

column1: Is that what I think it is?
column2: Yeah. The place kept changing owners. Finally went bankrupt. That thing in Paris killed 'em.

column1: What're you doing in here?
column2: Looking to get out.

column1: Good. I want you out. This is my sewer.
column2: Which way?

column1: Say, you need anything, Snake? Guns? Explosives? I can get you a crate of hellfire grenades, no problem - five hours.
column2: Yeah. So how do I get to Venice?

column1: Kind of a bad neighborhood, Snake.
column2: Which way to the Hollywood Bowl?

column1: Could be a big one comin' any minute now...
column2: Where's... Cuervo Jones...?

column1: Long gone. You'll never catch up with him now, Snake.
column2: Where?

column1: You ain't doin' so good, Snake. You need help.  You should talk to Hershe. She hates Cuervo. They used to be partners, but they split up.
column2: Who?

column1: Hi, Snake. It's so great to meet you. My name's Taslima. I'm a fan of yours.
column2: Are you crazy?

column1: What are they?
column2: They live here, used to be like us. But after too many silicon implants, their muscles turned to jelly. The only way they survive is to have body parts transplanted over and over again.  Snake, nobody who comes into Beverly Hills gets out alive.

column1: No screamin' shit.
column2: Oh no, it's the Doctor.

column1: Who?
column2: The Surgeon General of Beverly Hills.

column1: Don't follow me.
column2: You need help.

column1: This is a dead end.  You took us into a dead end!
column2: I just thought you wanted to get away. I didn't know you wanted to go someplace.

column1: Be careful of the bald cats. They live in these buildings.
column2: The what?

column1: How do we get out of here?
column2: Sewers. Come on.

column1: Snake - what is it?
column2: How the hell am I supposed to know? This is your damn city.

column1: Why don't you get out of L.A.? Take a boat to China, take an airplane to Brazil?  Earthquakes, death, shit. Why do you stay?
column2: I don't know. Somehow, I just can't leave.

column1: I changed my mind. I'm going with you, wherever you're going.
column2: What the hell is this?

column1: The freeway.
column2: I know that. There are people in some of these cars.

column1: What are you gonna do in Venice?
column2: Find Cuervo Jones.

column1: Run, Snake...They're coming.
column2: Who?

column1: I can see you're real concerned about your daughter.
column2: Utopia is lost to me. My daughter is gone.

column1: Well, I'll think it over.
column2: You're running out of time.

column1: Get ready, shitheads. We're comin' in.
column2: Thank God.

column1: Where's the anti-toxin...?
column2: Give me the prototype.

column1: Hey, what's going down, Snake?
column2: I'm looking for somebody.

column1: You owe me. You left me holdin' everything back there in Cleveland.
column2: Hershe, you were in Cleveland?

column1: All of us?
column2: Yeah.

column1: The President's promised to give whoever helps me 1 million dollars.
column2: Yeah? Greenbacks? I got ten million of them.

column1: Waxy Wright.  Didn't Jon Archer bust you for poisoning five members of the Canadian parliament?
column2: They never should've voted against U.S. statehood -- the scumbags.  We heard you got wasted.

column1: Do I look wasted -- asshole?
column2: You look great, Castor. Really.  Here -- I got a shot of your favorite -- Mescal.  Even has the worm.

column1: Don't they ever let us take these boots off?
column2: Not unless you're sent to the "Clinic."

column1: You mean if I get sick?
column2: They don't give two fucks about your health.  The Clinic's where they send the real hard-cases for attitude adjustment.  Look at O'Neill --

column1: What did he do?
column2: He hit a guard.

column1: Fine work, Jon.
column2: Yeah, real fine.  Especially all the casualties.

column1: I'm complimenting you. Can't you ever just say "thanks"?
column2: ... Thanks.

column1: Try to kiss my butt just once before I'm transferred.
column2: Sorry, Admiral.  It wasn't mentioned in the job description.

column1: He's lying.
column2: Jon, he's hooked up to a full-spectrum polygraph. No one has ever beaten --

column1: I don't care -- he's manipulating it.  That bomb has been built and it's out there, somewhere.
column2: What do you expect us to do -- shut down the city, evacuate two million people on a hunch?

column1: Uh-oh, somebody's in trouble.
column2: Yeah -- me.

column1: Jesus Christ, Castor.
column2: Drive.

column1: Where am I?
column2: My place.

column1: You shouldn't have brought me here ... it's dangerous.
column2: Better than you bleeding all over my car upholstery. Trust me, Caz, you won't be here long.

column1: I hear you're a manicurist now -- got your own business and everything.  I'm glad you've stayed clean.
column2: Like I had a choice with that anal-retentive Jon Archer rising my ass at the probation hearing.  At least he took an interest. You took off without leaving so much as a Post-it.

column1: Perfect fit.
column2: Should be.  It's yours.

column1: Nice-looking kid.
column2: Of course he is ...  -- He's yours too.

column1: Go on, Adam ...  I'm not asking you for anything -- I was never even going to tell you. But hell, I never thought I'd see you again, either.
column2: How old is he?

column1: Yes ... someone might want to tear him apart -- snuff him out -- for revenge.
column2: You're not holding him right ... Caz ...

column1: And this thing can grow it?
column2: Yes.  Pollux bought one along with the original batch.  Obviously, he found a way to make more.

column1: Why would he need more?
column2: He's your brother, you figure it out.  Maybe he made another bomb.

column1: Or reactivated the first one.
column2: Right ... like Jon Archer would ever let that happen.

column1: Hey, bro ...
column2: You're not my brother.  The brother I knew would never have been caught by that dumb fuck Archer.  At least tell me the bomb is still going off.

column1: Pollux ...
column2: Shut up.

column1: So?
column2: So?  The procnias averano is a South American bird.  The flight here was only three hours!  And yesterday a European swallow flew by! Where the fuck are we?

column1: What do you mean?
column2: You shoot hoops like a chick, you smoke like a wuss, and -- I don't know -- you're different.

column1: I was in a coma, Pollux. I still feel like shit.
column2: Let me have a look.

column1: Do you know what it is to be in a coma?  It fucks up everything -- including your memory! I can't even tell you why Dobbs jumped me yesterday!
column2: You porked his wife the day he was arrested.  How could you forget that?

column1: I don't know.  Everything's jumbled -- so you're going to have to help me fill in a few blanks.
column2: A few blanks?  Like what?

column1: Oh, God -- Mom OD'd at County General.
column2: Retching and convulsing while those bastards didn't even try to save her sorry ass.  You gave her mouth to mouth -- man -- even then you had some constitution.

column1: Uh -- to kill the doctors?
column2: After that.  You promised you'd always take care of me.

column1: And I bet I've kept that promise ...
column2: Only one you've never broken.

column1: That's not the worst part.
column2: What's worse than losing five million bucks?

column1: Thanks, Pollux.
column2: For what?

column1: For being one helluva guy.
column2: "Thanks?"  I guess they really did fuck you up.

column1: Well, you tried.  You failed miserably, but you tried.
column2: Everything I say is wrong. I can't talk to her anymore.

column1: She's only 12.  Some day she'll understand that apathy and absence are just special ways of saying "I love you."
column2: Is that what you think?

column1: Jon ... we just remember how it used to be.  You staying for a while or is this just a piss-stop?
column2: We need to talk.

column1: I'm late for surgery.
column2: It's important.

column1: ... I was dreaming ...
column2: Something good?

column1: We were back in high school. You wanted to join the sky diving team, but I wouldn't let you.
column2: Must've been after we got engaged.

column1: Actually -- in this dream -- I was your mother.
column2: So you had a nightmare.

column1: Totally -- you were being very, very bad.  You went up in the plane and jumped out.  You had a parachute, but it didn't open.
column2: Were you there to catch me?

column1: No.
column2: How come?

column1: Five years ... I still can't get it out of my head -- an inch to the left, Matty would still be alive.
column2: And you wouldn't be.

column1: What are you saying?  Oh, God -- you're going on assignment again ...
column2: One last time.  It's important ...

column1: You said you'd be here! You promised me -- you promised Jamie!  What could be more important than that?
column2: I can't tell you ... except only I can do it.

column1: Is someone there?
column2: Eve, listen carefully.  The man you think is your husband -- isn't.

column1: Who is this?
column2: Never mind that!  Just take Jamie and get out of that house.  Don't tell anyone where you're going -- especially not him -- just GO.

column1: Okay, you're having an emotional crisis.  You need to seek the help of a trained --
column2: Think about it, Eve! Everything he's done recently has been peculiar, right?  He's said and done things your husband would never do ...

column1: Whoever you are, don't call again.
column2: Don't hang up ...

column1: I know you -- you're the one who called.  You're Castor Troy.  You killed my son --
column2: -- I called, but I'm not Castor.  I'm your husband.

column1: How did he expect to do that?
column2: An NSA surgeon gave me Castor's face.  He handled the transplant, the vocal implant, everything.  But somehow Castor came out of his coma -- and killed everyone who knew about the mission. But not before he was transformed into me.

column1: I took it from my fake husband.
column2: Why point it at me?  I'm the real thing.

column1: I don't know that.  Maybe Jon's already dead.
column2: What more proof do you need?

column1: Christ, Jon!  How could you do this to yourself? How could you do this to us?  Do you know -- do you know what he did to me ...?
column2: Whatever happened, whatever he did -- I know it's my fault and I know I can never make it up to you --

column1: He freaked out when he thought I had seen this stuff.  I think it's a list of cities -- Santiago, Ho Chi Minh City, Nandi ...
column2: Our Pacific Rim stations. These numbers must be bounties. Castor's not wasting any time.

column1: What do you mean?
column2: He's going to kill off our bureau chiefs -- one-by-one.

column1: You can't go.  You can't be anywhere near that place.
column2: Jon, what is it?

column1: The bomb.  He's reactivated it.  And everyone there is going to die.
column2: Can't we call someone? Admiral Lazarro?

column1: I know Lazarro -- the first person she'd call is "me." We can't take the chance of tipping Castor off.
column2: Jon, if I'm not there, he will be tipped off.  I'll get rid of Jamie -- but you and I are in this together.

column1: How is he?
column2: No life signs at all. He's a turnip.

column1: I started wondering -- if you couldn't switch back -- would it make a difference?
column2: Would it?

column1: How's Loomis?
column2: Apparently, fine.  He's coming into work.  That's the good news ...

column1: Go on.
column2: Castor's still alive --  Technically.  He's a turnip, on total life-support ...

column1: We can send in a plant -- try to get Pollux to spill the location.
column2: He'd see that a mile away.  The only person he'd talk to about that bomb is his brother.  Unfortunately, turnips can't talk.

column1: Which ear was it?
column2: The left, I think.  Those surgeons in Witness Protection can fix things nobody's even broken yet.

column1: Jon, this is goddam insane. You can't go through with it.  What about Eve?
column2: She doesn't know -- and she never will.

column1: You haven't got a chance in hell of fooling Pollux. Castor drinks, smokes and walks around with a 24-hour hard-on.  He's nothing like you.
column2: Don't worry.  I've done my homework.  I'll get Pollux to talk.

column1: Now what?
column2: Call Lazarro.  Castor just came out of his coma.

column1: This is it, Jon.  For the next 72 hours -- you're on your own.
column2: Just make sure you're there.  On time.

column1: How is the "date night" idea going over with Eve?
column2: Like gangbusters, doc.  Okay, I missed the last one.

column1: You missed the last three, including her birthday.  Your wife's gripe sheet.
column2: I've been working night and day.  I haven't had time.

column1: One of my informants spotted him -- right here in the city.
column2: I just asked you about making love to your wife, and you started talking about your job.

column1: I'm not hiding in my work, if that's what you're saying.
column2: You said it, Jon, not me.

column1: Jon, I'm getting a little annoyed by your obsessive need to spoil my fun.
column2: And how much will your "fun" net you this time?

column1: What's it to you?  I declare it.  Here I am, back in the States for less than a month --
column2: You're under arrest. Incredibly, you still have the right to remain silent --

column1: What're you gonna do with me gone?  You'll drive your wife and kid nuts! I bet your daughter is just about ripe by now. What's her name, Janie?
column2: Mention my family once more and you're dead.

column1: You can't kill me, Jon. I've got something going this Saturday night ... it's gonna be worse than anything God ever dumped on the Pharaohs -- and only I can stop it.
column2: You can tell me all about it -- from your prison cell.

column1: -- Castor?
column2: Not anymore.

column1: It can't be.  It's impossible.
column2: I believe the phrase Dr. Hoag used was "titanically remote."  Who knows?  Maybe the trauma of having my face cut off pulled me out.  Or maybe God really is on my side after all.  By the way, I know you don't get the papers in here.

column1: You killed them?
column2: Of course I killed them, you DUMB FUCK.  And torched every shred of evidence that proves who you really are.  Swallow this one, Commander. You are going to be in here for the rest of your life.

column1: What are you going to do, Castor?
column2: Let's not confuse things anymore.  I'm Archer. You're Castor.  But if you need proof --

column1: What are you going to do!
column2: You've given me the freedom I haven't had in years, and the power to make it pay off in ways I never thought possible.  But hell -- this is America.  One day a pauper, the next day, a prince. And I owe it all to you. Now if you'll excuse me, I've got an important government job to abuse, -- and a beautiful wife to fuck.  Excuse me -- I mean "make love to."

column1: Stay away from my family!
column2: Too late, your kid worships me.  And your wife -- she's an animal.  Even I can't keep up with her.

column1: What -- what are you doing?
column2: Vacuum-sealed globe ... shouldn't take long.

column1: I don't know.  How long before it kills us?
column2: Five seconds.

column1: Give up, Castor.  People are going to find out.
column2: Not if I kill you first ...

column1: Jamie ...
column2: Shoot him!

column1: They're too tight.
column2: So's a noose.  Now keep your mouth SHUT.

column1: You'll what?
column2: I'm going to have you fired.

column1: You better be nice, Castor. You could get mighty lonely now that Pollux is gone.
column2: Pollux is -- what?

column1: Archer cut him a deal for turning state's evidence. He's free.
column2: Walton, you have to let me see the warden --

column1: SFPD?  Castor isn't stupid enough to come back to the city.
column2: Trust me, he's already here. Get going!

column1: We've got him sighted. Okay, Pollux, pull out.
column2: What makes you so sure this guy's gonna set up his own brother?

column1: Just saving the tax-payers the cost of a trial.  So take a hike.
column2: What's the matter with your voice, Commander?

column1: Screw your boundaries, Janie.  You have something I want.
column2: Janie?

column1: Clarissa left those here.
column2: I won't tell mom if you don't.

column1: When did you start smoking?
column2: You'll be seeing a lot of changes around here. Daddy's a new man.

column1: Get a higher arc on the ball, Jamie.  And for Chrissake, square your shoulders to the basket.
column2: Like you know anything about it.

column1: What are you -- stupid?
column2: You haven't changed at all! Some guy tries to rape me -- and you side with him!

column1: Did it look like I was siding with him?  Did it?  You want to play with the bad boys, you better be prepared.  Do you have protection?
column2: You mean like ... condoms?

column1: There's my little darling.  The night wouldn't be complete without you.
column2: Yeah, mom cut me some slack -- but I decided ... I'd like to be here for you.  Here, mom.  You can have it back.  Thanks, though.

column1: Oh -- Commander.  I didn't see you ...
column2: Well, I saw you -- Kim.

column1: Kim?
column2: That's your name, isn't it?

column1: You always call me Miss Brewster.
column2: Let's try to be a little less formal from now on, shall we?

column1: You've got someone in your office.
column2: Get rid of them.

column1: You picked a helluva day to leave your beeper off!
column2: What happened?

column1: Castor's escaped!
column2: Escaped?  From Erewhon?  I want everyone on this -- our entire force and the SFPD.

column1: What happened?
column2: What the fuck do you think happened?  Castor Troy just shot him!  What are you waiting for?  GO!

column1: Commander, what are you doing here?
column2: Where should I be?  Where's everyone else?

column1: Backing you up!  Didn't you track Castor to the Army Street Terminal?
column2: What?

column1: It was confirmed by your personal security code. Nobody knows that code but you!
column2: Obviously someone else knows it!  Get everybody back to their posts -- NOW!

column1: You're both in custody until there's a DNA fingerprinting and we can prove who's who. Now put the gun down.
column2: You can't blame me for trying.

column1: You merciless bastard!
column2: Business first.  I went into the "Warrants" system and erased your records.  You're clean.  In fact, you're now on the informant payroll.

column1: I can't even look at you without wanting to vomit.
column2: You better get used to it. That bitch Lazarro is getting kicked upstairs. Guess what white-bread family man is going to replace her?

column1: -- I'll be one of the most powerful men in the country. Didn't matter how much cash I made pulling wet jobs -- I was still too low on the food chain -- always with somebody like Jon Archer after me.  The best part is -- I'm the GOOD guy.
column2: No -- the best part is, since it's a government job -- they can't fire you!  But how can you be sure you'll get the appointment?

column1: Don't get mad, but I just went for a little stroll through the company switches.
column2: You're supposed to be snitching, making me look legit.

column1: Don't worry, nobody knows I'm inside.  Check it out.  Remember that fat fuck agent who roughed us up in Thailand?  He's being treated for bone cancer at the V.A.  Thanks to the miracle of NSA grid-technology ...  -- Ooops!  His radiation does just quadrupled.
column2: Are you TRYING to give us away? For somebody with such a big brain, you think awfully small.

column1: I'm just having some fun.
column2: There's fun, bro.  Then there's FUN.

column1: Eight pocket stingers ... seven piper uzis ... six cobra carbines ...  five - net - launch-ers ...
column2: Yeah -- it's Santa's Magic fucking Village.  Your present's in here.

column1: We gut the organization -- and rebuild it with more reliable friends.
column2: Most of the current chiefs -- they must have pretty hefty prices on their heads.

column1: All of them do.  We'll kill twelve birds with one bomb.  And we'll be rich.
column2: Good, because I checked your salary -- and it bites.  How the everyday working-class stiff survives in today's economy is something I'll never ...

column1: You'll need to recultivate that virus.
column2: No problem.

column1: What about me?
column2: A lot of people think you're a snitch.  It's dangerous ...

column1: Look at you, Jon -- at your age -- an American hero!  I'd buy you a drink but I know you'd just turn me down.
column2: Normally, I would.  But today ...

column1: You're the only person in this place who can see right through me.
column2: You've made us look pretty good in the past week.  And the way you handled the press --

column1: Just following your example.
column2: D.C.'s very high on giving you the promotion.  There's just one problem.

column1: What's that?
column2: Me.  I have doubts about your ability to stick with what is essentially a desk job.

column1: You'd have to start immediately.
column2: Done.  In fact, I was already plotting about the best way to meet the foreign bureau chiefs.

column1: I just heard about Castor's fratricide -- rather poetic, don't you think?
column2: What is it, Admiral? I'm under the gun here.

column1: I just thought that -- under the circumstances -- you might want to postpone the meeting with the station chiefs.
column2: No.  Most of them are in transit by now.  I'm heading over to the hotel to personally oversee security.

column1: What happened to your big "assignment"?
column2: What do you know about it?

column1: As much as ever.  Nothing.
column2: It didn't work out as planned. Where are you off to?

column1: The hospital.
column2: The hospital?  Oh, that's right -- you're a doctor.  Ha-ha.

column1: Jon -- I don't have time to play games.  There're leftovers in the fridge.
column2: Have fun at work.

column1: What is with you tonight?
column2: Don't I usually kiss my wife?

column1: Hurry up -- the salad's getting warm and the pasta's getting cold.
column2: -- I've got to study.

column1: Why do I feel like I'm on a blind date?
column2: They say love is blind. Do you think that's true?

column1: I think -- you're trying to get me drunk.
column2: Wouldn't be the first time -- or would it?

column1: So -- how long will you be gone this time?
column2: Gone?

column1: Isn't that what all this is about?  Letting Jamie go out, cooking me dinner, -- your next assignment?
column2: I'm not going anywhere.

column1: You always say that -- then you leave.
column2: Can't you see I'm trying to change?  I sent Jamie off because I wanted to be alone with you.  I wanted to see the candle-light dance in your beautiful --

column1: -- what?
column2: I'm replacing Lazarro. Nice, safe desk job -- just like you wanted.

column1: ... That's great.
column2: So you see, I'm not going anywhere.  Unless it's upstairs with you ...

column1: You're wearing your suit --
column2: Call me spontaneous.

column1: What's on your mind?
column2: Jon, it's the tenth.  I know how difficult it is for you, but we still have to go.

column1: I'm late.  Gotta protect and serve the world, y'know.
column2: The world can wait, Jon. You're going.

column1: I think Jamie's been seeing Karl again.
column2: Great.

column1: Great?  He's 17 -- you told her to stay away from him.
column2: Oh, that Karl.

column1: Yes, Jon.  That Karl.
column2: I'll have a talk with her. By the way, you never said anything about last night ...

column1: What are you doing?
column2: -- Studying.

column1: Nothing.
column2: I disagree.  You think I've been acting strange.  Like a completely different person.

column1: -- Yes.
column2: Okay, I have a confession to make.  But you aren't going to like it.

column1: Where's Jamie?
column2: That's what I'd like to know.  She stole fifty dollars from my purse and took off.

column1: I'll deal with her later.
column2: Good.  Because I'm fed up.

column1: I'm going to the powder room.
column2: Sure, baby -- go anywhere you want.  But I have to give you an escort.  Security reasons.

column1: Remember this from our junior prom?  Boy, were you ever mad for Madonna.
column2: Back then -- who wasn't?

column1: You know, you could'a run an ad in the personals.
column2: "Sensual blind chick seeks three-ton, rock-hard he-man for deep spiritual relationship."

column1: You don't know what it's like out there.  Walking around like some kind of circus freak.  People staring, whispering --
column2: I wouldn't know anything about that.

column1: I mean...
column2: Tell me.  When you grew up in Brooklyn, how many astronauts did you know?  You went your own way then.  You didn't listen to people.  So why start now...?

column1: I don't think She's real big on hate.
column2: You wouldn't say that, if you could see me.

column1: Such a sad face... You know, sometimes being different isn't a bad thing.
column2: Trust me, this ain't one of those times.

column1: How'd you know it was me?
column2: I'm blind, not deaf.  Wanna come in?

column1: I'm not really dressed for a party.
column2: Relax, it's casual.

column1: Those yours too?
column2: My step-dad's.  I'm strictly into stone.  I was wondering when you'd walk by.

column1: We're going to have to work on your touch.
column2: I like the sound of that.

column1: Good thing it ain't workin... Reed, what are we doing here?  This guy's fast-food, strip-mall science --
column2: This wasn't our first stop, in case you forgot NASA.  And Victor's not that bad.  He's just a little...  Larger than life.

column1: He's financed some of the biggest breakthroughs of this century.
column2: You'd never know it.

column1: I can't take this.
column2: Ben.  This is business.  Just work.

column1: What about his first born?
column2: Ben, the money's not important.  We could <u>save lives</u>.

column1: He <u>knew</u> about NASA.  What if he made the call to shut us down --
column2: Ben, think about all the people we can help if this works --

column1: Maybe you should think about <u>yourself</u> for once.  You always let this guy push you round --
column2: We got what we wanted.  That's <u>enough</u>.

column1: Can't do it.  I cannot do it.
column2: External SRBs, orbital system engines. Its just like the shuttles you flew in --

column1: No.  I cannot take orders from that underwear model.  That wingnut washed out of NASA for sneaking two Victoria Secret wannabes into a flight simulator.
column2: Youthful high spirits.

column1: They crashed it into a wall. A flight simulator.
column2: I'm sure he's matured since then.

column1: When have I asked you to do something you absolutely said you could not do?
column2: Five times.

column1: I had it at four.
column2: This makes five.

column1: Isn't that <u>your</u> speech?
column2: He's made a few changes.

column1: This is your dream, Reed.  You should be the one up there.
column2: Victor's better at these things.

column1: The shields on the station should protect us.
column2: <u>Should</u>?

column1: I ain't done arranging your flowers, egghead.
column2: Ben.  This is serious.  <u>Turn around</u>.

column1: How long was I out?
column2: Three days.  I was worried about you. How are you feeling?

column1: I don't know.  I just keep going over and over the numbers.
column2: Reed.  Even <u>you</u> can't compute every little thing.

column1: You go through something like this, makes you appreciate having the right woman in your life.
column2: Yeah, you and Debbie and perfect --

column1: What?  Come on.  She's got a good thing with Victor --
column2: I'm sorry, did that cosmic-bath loosen your screws?

column1: He's smart, powerful, successful --
column2: Well maybe <u>you</u> should date him.

column1: Are you alright?
column2: I think I need to lie down.  Bad shrimp.

column1: What the --!
column2: Ben.  Are you okay?

column1: We had a tough year.
column2: Yeah, nine years straight.

column1: You got a chisel round here?
column2: If we're going to identify the source of the mutation, we need to isolate your recombinant DNA so we can activate positional genomes.

column1: Okay.  I've uh, got some questions, from Sue.  That she thought might be better coming from me... Can you, you know, go to the bathroom...like normal...
column2: Yeah.  You don't wanna know the details.

column1: Ben, I'm afraid I've got to ask --
column2: Not unless you want that clipboard stretched up your --

column1: It's about to be a broken face.
column2: This isn't permanent, Johnny.  We need to be careful until we're normal again.

column1: Ben --
column2: Oh, you remember my name do you?  You happen to remember what you <u>swore</u> to do with every breath in your body?

column1: We're working as hard as we can --
column2: Yeah.  I can tell.  Victor was right.

column1: Glad "nothing" could take you away from your work.
column2: Ben, I don't know if this thing'll change us back or make us worse. I need you to be patient for a little while longe--

column1: Time for <u>your</u> lesson, Vic.  Chem 101: what happens when you <u>supercool</u> hot metal...?  Ben...
column2: Got it, teach.

column1: Ben, I've been crunching the numbers on the machine.  I think if we can rework the power settings...
column2: Forget it, egghead.  I'm good as is.

column1: What the hell you smiling at?  Just keep your mouth shut, and your mind on those SMBs --
column2: Actually, the engines are SMEs. Hydrogenbase, carbon propellant. Couple generations past your last ride.  I'm not as dumb as you look.

column1: If you behave, maybe next time daddy'll let you drive.
column2: Keep talking, there won't <u>be</u> a next time.

column1: Please tell me your dawg's not trying to rekindle things with my sister.
column2: 'Course not.  Strictly business.

column1: Yeah, well, his eyes say different.
column2: Hey, two hearts got busted last time. Maybe she's not over it either.

column1: Let's see: you got Victor, stud of the year, more coin than God?  Or Reed, the world's dumbest smart guy worth less than a postage stamp.  Hmmm, it's a toss-up.
column2: Put your tiny little mind at ease.

column1: Where...where am I?
column2: Back on Earth.  Victor's medical facility... We're in quarantine.

column1: Reed? ... Sue?
column2: They're fine. Everybody else...is fine.

column1: What's wrong with me?
column2: I swear to you they've done everything humanly possible.  The best plastic surgeons in the world, Ben.  You had the best --

column1: They said that's not such a good idea, the shock alone could --
column2: Give me the god damn mirror!

column1: Hey!  That's a <u>prototype</u>!
column2: Go back to the drawing board.

column1: The machine works.  And Vic's gone Mister Hyde on us --
column2: Really?  With a name like Von <u>Doom</u>? Never saw <u>that</u> one coming.

column1: No more cracks about how I look.
column2: Hey, I'm Mr. Sensitivity now.  Clear the way, wide load coming through.

column1: I'll be watching over you.
column2: Just get back soon, or I start looking for a new groom.

column1: Soon as I'm back, I'm gonna trade that in for a bigger rock.
column2: I don't care about rocks, I care about <u>you</u>.  You bring him back in one piece, or you can forget being Best Man.

column1: Deb... It's me.  I need you to step out front.
column2: Out front?  You home, baby?  I got a surprise for you.

column1: Ben?
column2: Don't come any closer for a sec.  This is gonna be kind of a shock... You remember when we said "together forever no matter what"?

column1: Oh my G-g-g.  What did you...do to Ben?
column2: Deb, it's me.  It's still me.

column1: What did you wish for, honey?
column2: I already got it.  Everything I want.

column1: What are <u>you</u> doing here?
column2: I'm worried about you.

column1: About me?  How sweet.
column2: Come on.  Let me buy you something to eat.  Looks like you could use the company.

column1: Ben, come in.
column2: What is this?  Where's Reed?

column1: What do you want, Vic?
column2: To help you.  I've run every test known to man.  And they all yield the same result: <u>the machine is ready</u>.

column1: Reed said it'd be weeks till --
column2: He <u>also</u> said we'd avoid that storm in space.  And we know how that turned out.

column1: He couldn't generate enough power for the machine to reach critical mass. Yet another mistake for "Mr. Fantastic."
column2: And you can?  Power it up?

column1: Way to not overthink it.  So when do we leave?
column2: I'll schedule the launch.  Call me in the morning to talk about resources and crew.

column1: I can handle the ship.  I can even handle Mr. Blonde Ambition.  But I don't know if I should be flying or playing Vegas in these suits.  Who the hell came up with them?
column2: Victor did.

column1: We can monitor the cloud's approach and observe the tests from here.
column2: Is it safe?

column1: I can only stay for one drink, Ben. I've got to meet with Victor.
column2: Wouldn't want to keep Vic waiting.

column1: We need to give you a physical, so we know what got zapped.
column2: Well why didn't you say so?  You want me to lift some weights or something?

column1: You look like an eighties rock band.
column2: The suit will stretch.  You should try it --

column1: He didn't.
column2: Oh, he did.

column1: He didn't mean it.  You know Johnny. He's always been a hothead --
column2: It's not him.  It's <u>them</u>.  I can't live like this.

column1: Just give Reed a little more time. You know how he works -- analyzing every little step before he takes one --
column2: It's easy for you to be patient.

column1: <u>Where is Reed</u>?
column2: Victor must've taken him.

column1: Your tissue, your organs, your entire biophysical structure is changing. Every system is still functioning, somehow --
column2: And they're changing into...

column1: I don't really know.  A compound organic-metallic alloy.  Stronger than titanium or carbon steel.  Harder than diamonds --
column2: Like the shields Reed said would protect us.  How long?

column1: At this rate, the infection should be complete in two, maybe three weeks --
column2: What do you mean "complete"?

column1: What?
column2: The Center for Disease Control.  If this thing is contagious --

column1: But...this disease...is progressive... degenerative...
column2: That's terrible news...

column1: Victor's right.  Johnny, get to the command center.  Close the shields.
column2: What about you?

column1: He's not responsive --
column2: Ben!  Ben!

column1: Now what is up with that?
column2: The cloud has fundamentally altered our DNA.

column1: Oh, you dawg you.  Better not be my nurse!
column2: Ben, are you there?

column1: This is wrong in so many ways.
column2: You've been working out.

column1: Ben Grimm is a genuine American hero who's been through a terrible orde--
column2: What he's trying to say is: every team needs a mascot...

column1: Twenty?  From outside the place looks a lot taller.
column2: Oh, it is.

column1: We should stay here until we can define the extent of our changes...
column2: This place is deluxe.  You got cable?

column1: Back it down, Johnny!
column2: I can go hotter!

column1: Not only could you kill yourself, but you could set fire to Earth's atmosphere and destroy all human life as we know it.
column2: Gotcha.  Okay.  Supernova bad.

column1: Is there something about flames? About flaming, that you --
column2: What are you trying to say?  Just because I dress well and like to dance --

column1: What?  No.  I'm trying to figure out why we each ended up with different symptoms.
column2: Oh, well that's easy: I'm hot. You're...well, you're a little limp. Sue's easy to see through.  And Ben's always been a hardass.  Why aren't you writing this down?

column1: He's right.  These costumes are... missing something.  I can't put my finger on it --
column2: They're not costumes.

column1: That's what I'm trying to calculate. And it's not rubber.  It's muscle, tendon.  I seem to have the ability to manipulate the malleability of my molecular structure and redistribute my density to --
column2: Right, whatever, have fun.

column1: You need to control yourself and <u>think</u> before you --
column2: Act.  Here we go again.  Reed, what if we got these gifts for a <u>reason</u>?  What if we have some, you know...like, calling?

column1: Johnny.  SUPERNOVA.
column2: But all these people...

column1: And where do we think we're going?
column2: I don't know if "we've" noticed, but the sickest runs this side of the Alps are right outside that window --

column1: You're hot!
column2: So are you!

column1: I mean, you feel a little feverish.
column2: I've never felt better in my life. When do you get off work?

column1: My shift ends at four, but I couldn't --
column2: Meet me at 4:01, top of the run. That'll give you a minute to freshen up.

column1: Me like-y.
column2: Stay right.  Left is trouble.

column1: I though we went over this.
column2: Last one down springs for room service.

column1: You're on fire!
column2: Not this again --

column1: The synthetics act as a second skin, adapting to your individual needs to --
column2: Keep the hot side hot, and the cool side cool!

column1: Apparently I can disappear.
column2: <u>Please</u> tell me you go silent too.

column1: Flame on, flame off.  Flame on, flame off --
column2: Johnny.

column1: Stop it.
column2: Okay, "mom."

column1: What is that thing?
column2: I think that thing is Ben.

column1: Wait.  You mean there's chance we could be full-on-24-7-fantastic?
column2: Grow up, Johnny.  You want to run around <u>on fire</u> for the rest of your life?

column1: You're really cramping my style here.
column2: You were at 4000 Kelvin.  Any hotter, you're approaching supernova --

column1: Sweet.
column2: That's the temperature of the <u>sun</u>.

column1: Uh, we call my sister the invisible girl...the Invisible Girl.
I'm driving.
column2: Dude.  That's my sister.

column1: You're gonna pay for that, Pebbles.  What?!
column2: You gave us <u>names</u>?  What are you, the "face" of the Fantastic Four now?

column1: You two need a time-out.
column2: Blockhead started it!

column1: Johnny?  Did you see Ben?
column2: Yeah, for the last time, I hope.  I'm done with this freak show.  I'm moving back to the real world.

column1: Is that what you call it? "Real"?
column2: At least it beats living in a lab like somebody's science project.

column1: Johnny, slow down.  <u>Think</u>.  You know mom didn't raise us to --
column2: Look around, sis!  <u>She's not here</u>.  So you can stop talking to me like I'm your little boy --

column1: I'm sorry, sis, for leaving you guys --
column2: No, <u>I'm</u> sorry, for pushing you out.

column1: What are you doing --
column2: Sis.  Let <u>me</u> take care of <u>you</u> for once.

column1: If Reed's right, then this little trip will double our stock offering.
column2: And if he's not...?

column1: They're ready for you, sir.
column2: Showtime.

column1: Our numbers are through the roof.  The IPO's tracking at fifty, sixty a share.  The bank's five times oversubscribed --
column2: It's not just the money.  I could make money in my sleep.

column1: Then what is it?
column2: History, Leonard.  <u>History</u>. Everything else is conversation...  How's the other matter?

column1: Leonard, how's the feed?
column2: Recording, sir.  We see you perfectly.

column1: How's the IPO?
column2: Stable.  We're looking at low twenties.  It's a good number, considering the fallout from --

column1: Reed's disaster.  You know, I half- think he did this to me on purpose.
column2: Sir, I'm sure he wouldn't put himself --

column1: Get me on the AM shows, Larry King, cover of the Journal...  I've <u>got to</u> do something about this scar.  Make sure they only shoot my right side.
column2: Actually, uh, people seem to think the scar "humanizes" you.

column1: You know, maybe you should get some rest --
column2: Later.  First, I've got some unfinished business.  A deal that needs closing...

column1: Sir, I've always wondered... Why <u>Sue</u>? You could have any woman in the world but --
column2: <u>That's</u> why.  Because I could have any <u>other</u> woman... You know, when they asked Caesar "why England," he said, "because it's not <u>mine</u>."

column1: Make sure you find Ben, bring him back here.  And keep it quiet.  I don't need this to hit the press.
column2: Yes sir.  You've got the Mayor at eight, then a nine-thirty interview with the Journal --

column1: Front page?
column2: Top left, like you asked.  Today Wall Street.  Tomorrow, who knows...maybe Washington.

column1: But dreams don't pay the bills, do they?  Same old Reed, the hopeless optimist. Still reaching for the stars, with the world on your back.
column2: You remember in school we talked about working together.  That's what I was about to explain...

column1: This isn't going to be a problem, is it?
column2: Not at all.

column1: You back this mission, and I'll sign over a fair percentage of any applications or --
column2: The number's <u>seventy-five</u>.  And it's applications <u>and</u> patents.

column1: Funny how things turn out, isn't it?
column2: Hilarious.

column1: Got it.  So take a walk, Ben...I'm going to borrow Susan for a second.
column2: Sure.

column1: We've got <u>minutes</u> until it hits, not hours...Victor, that storm's <u>deadly</u> -- the radiation's lethal.  We need to abort.
column2: Get a grip.  Reed.  We didn't come all this way to lose our nerve at the first little glitch.  Just close the shields...

column1: Ben's still out there --
column2: So reel him in.  But we came here to do a <u>job</u>.  So let's do it.  <u>Quickly</u>.

column1: Come on, Ben, come on...
column2: Reed, we're running out of time.

column1: Not until Ben is back inside!
column2: It's too late for him, and soon it'll be too late for all of us.

column1: Just a little banged up.  A couple scrapes.  Why?
column2: Ben did this.

column1: <u>Ben</u> did this?
column2: He's had some kind of...reaction to exposure from the cloud.  And he's not the only one.

column1: I'm starting to wonder the same thing... How much do you know about what happened to you?
column2: Not much.  We need to run tests to see the extent of the damage.

column1: Didn't go as <u>planned</u>?  It was a <u>catastrophe</u>.  You ruined the lives of four people --
column2: <u>I</u> ruined?  With all due respect, I told you to abort --

column1: <u>Abort</u>?  Reed, I put my company, my name, billions of dollars on the line, and I will <u>not</u> let you make me look like a fool --
column2: Victor, if we could understand what happened to us --

column1: What are you doing here?
column2: What I <u>should</u> have done a long time ago.  Applications and patents, Reed. This all belongs to me.

column1: But I'm not done with the machine --
column2: Which is precisely the <u>point</u>. Analysis is over.  It's time for <u>action</u>.  My men could have mass- produced this by now.

column1: You're, you've, I mean, how have you bee--
column2: Never better.

column1: Those solar winds are flaring, but I factored them into my coordinates and --
column2: I was talking about us.  Working together.

column1: Well, uh, based on our history...you can handle the biogenetics, and I'll focus on the molecular physics.  Or, uhm, maybe I should take the biotech, you work the microscopes, since you have some background in electropho--
column2: Right.  That's exactly what I meant.

column1: I, uh, think I remember the number.
column2: It's been changed.

column1: As far as crew, I was hoping Ben could pilot the mission --
column2: Well, he's welcome to ride shotgun, but we already have a pilot on our payroll.  You remember my brother Johnny...

column1: Material made from self-regulating unstable molecules.  I've been working on a formula for this.
column2: Great minds think alike.

column1: Feeling better?
column2: Yes, thanks.

column1: That's good.  That's uh...good.
column2: You always had a way with words.  I should be getting back.

column1: You're <u>happy</u> for me and Victor.
column2: I can tell you guys are enjoying what was the best part of our relationship --

column1: Which was?
column2: Passion.

column1: For science.
column2: You are such a dork, Reed... You never got it and never will unless it's explained to you in quantum physics.

column1: Uh, Sue...?  I <u>can't</u>.
column2: What?  What do you mean you --

column1: It has to be the cloud.  It's fundamentally altered our DNA.
column2: Let's not jump to conclusions, we need a massive amount of evidence before making that leap.

column1: What?
column2: We need to get past them.

column1: Sue.  Your clothes.  Lose them.
column2: What...?  <u>Oh</u>.

column1: How come Ben can't turn it on and off like us?
column2: That's what we're here to find out.

column1: It's not "invisibility" per se. You're bending the light around you with some kind of malleable force field.  That's what you projected on the Bridge.
column2: What about you?  You haven't eaten in days.  How come you're never on this side of the microscope?

column1: You should be able to bend light around other objects, even people, if you could control your emotional state better --
column2: Excuse me?

column1: I'm saying, if you had a little more self control, you could locate the trigger.  Can you remember the exact emotions when --
column2: Anger.  Rage.  Frustration.

column1: Okay.  Is there any way to duplicate that feeling?  Some memory or...
column2: I'm sure I can come up with something.

column1: I'm sorry, I'm sorry, I didn't mean to do that... You must think that was some kind of latent hostility or --
column2: What in the world would give me that idea?

column1: I mean, <u>you</u> broke up with <u>me</u>, right?
column2: Are you kidding?

column1: Reed.  I was ready for the next step, you weren't, ergo, I walked.
column2: I think it was a little more complicated than --

column1: There were a lot of variables to consider --
column2: No.  There weren't.  There was <u>you</u>. And <u>me</u>.  No variables, no math.  It was actually the simplest thing in the world.  But your head got in the way... like it always does.

column1: What are you doing?
column2: The plants, from space.  Their particles are still charged.  With the right amount of energy, those ions could <u>create</u> the elemental profile of the cosmic storm.

column1: If we can build a machine to re-create the storm, we can reverse the polarity --
column2: And reverse the mutations --

column1: But <u>we're</u> the focus, right Reed? <u>Reed</u>...?
column2: Of course.  Of course.

column1: And you sure you can control this thing?  Last time didn't work out so well.
column2: With the right energy, we can stabilize the storm.  Maybe tie into the city grid...

column1: Reed.  How close are we to a cure?
column2: No way to know.  Without more tests, experiments.

column1: Don't let Victor push you into making a mistake --
column2: He was going to take away all my data, equipment --

column1: Which is why I'm working <u>twenty</u> hours a day, checking every variable --
column2: Every variable but <u>yourself</u>.  You don't eat, sleep.  You can't live in your head like --

column1: I could get Ben to tap into the Baxter's main power to generate enough voltage --
column2: Reed.  Shh.  Just be quiet.  And look up.

column1: Remember our first date here...?  God, I was so nervous.
column2: You <u>were</u>?

column1: You know, I bribed the projectionist ten bucks to keep it open late?
column2: I gave him twenty.

column1: You always talked about how you liked the kind of man who could approach you...speak his mind.  One who wasn't afraid to tell you what he wanted.
column2: I did.  I did, Reed...but I wanted <u>you</u> to be that man.

column1: When I walked out, I waited <u>ten</u> <u>minutes</u> outside your door.  Ten. Waiting for you to come find me.
column2: Why didn't you say something?

column1: I can...make it work.
column2: Reed, stop, you need to rest your --

column1: The power...I need...more power...to control...the storm --
column2: You <u>need</u> a doctor.

column1: Sue, I need some of that anger, rage, frustration --
column2: I'm sure I can come up with something.

column1: I found a broken gasket, from space --
column2: A <u>gasket</u>?  Reed, we're at a party.

column1: It's just business.
column2: I think you both know my Director of Genetic Research, Susan Storm.

column1: Surprised I agreed to Reed's proposal?
column2: I understand the business reasons.

column1: It's been a good two years, Victor... The company's accomplished so much.
column2: Right, of course, the company... But you see, I've come to realize all the accomplishments in the world mean nothing without someone to share them with --

column1: Uh, Victor, I hope I haven't done something to make you think...
column2: Sue, I've lived my life unafraid of taking big steps.  And this is the biggest step yet.  If it helps, think of this as a <u>promotion</u>.  A merger of sorts...  Four little words that can change our lives...

column1: What are you doing?
column2: Raising the shields.

column1: What's going on?
column2: Victor, are you feeling alright?

column1: Victor, I'm sorry I --
column2: Just <u>find</u> him.

column1: Victor, your scar --
column2: I told you, I'm fine.  It's <u>you</u> I'm worried about.

column1: I'm sorry I didn't get a chance to --
column2: Please, no apologies.  I've arranged for your things to be moved to one of my condos.  You'll have round-the clock care.

column1: You said it was urgent.
column2: It is.  There's something we need to talk about.  Something I need to ask you...

column1: Victor, wait, slow down a second.  I want you to know I appreciate everything you've done for me, but I just don't --
column2: Susan.  What are you doing?

column1: He's working round the clock.  But the data needs to be tested, analyzed before --
column2: Same old Reed.  All analysis, no action.  Wasn't that the problem with you two?

column1: If these molecules aren't stable, they could make us <u>worse</u>, maybe even kill us.
column2: Then why is Reed dragging his feet? Maybe he <u>likes</u> having his prize specimen under glass...  It's ironic, isn't it?  You're finally the perfect woman for him...because you're his <u>science project</u>.

column1: Please don't make this personal --
column2: Oh, I think you already have.

column1: 'Scuse me.
column2: I know it can't be easy.  Life hasn't changed that much for Reed, Sue and Johnny.  At least they can go out in public.  But for you?  People staring. Whispering behind your back...

column1: If you're trying to cheer me up you're doing a helluva job --
column2: I'm just saying, I know what it's like to lose something you love.  To see it slip away, and know it's never coming back.

column1: Reed's gonna fix me up --
column2: For your sake I hope you're right. I'm sorry if that sounds a little skeptical.

column1: Grant's uniquely qualified for this mission. He's a Communications Expert and was a Frogman during the War. Besides, he brought Benes into this country, and the fewer people who know about him, the better. At any rate, you'll find Grant invaluable, should anything go wrong once you're under way.  Okay, Don.
column2: Here's the overall Target Area...

column1: Benes' natural defenses. White Corpuscles -- Antibodies. Once you begin to grow -- and become a menace to the body -- you'll trigger them off... MICHAELS With all the unknown factors in the body, I still say risking five lives for one is something we should reconsider --
column2: We understand your concern, but we've made our decision, Doctor. Any questions? Anybody?

column1: Where do we stand?
column2: Medical's ready.

column1: Okay to proceed.
column2: Phase Two.

column1: They've crossed over into the Jugular Vein!
column2: That can't be -- there's no direct connection between the two --

column1: But we have no choice! We've got, to take them out!
column2: No...

column1: We still have fifty-one minutes. Leave them in.
column2: But it's hopeless! They can't go back and they can't go on. I tell you there's nothing else we can do but remove them!

column1: Doctor...without killing him -- how long could we stop his heart?
column2: The less time, the better.

column1: I know that. But what's the maximum?
column2: In his comatose state...and everything slowed down...no more than sixty seconds.

column1: At topspeed...and adjusting distance for Degree of Miniaturization --  The sub should get through the Heart in fifty-seven seconds.
column2: That would give us only three seconds to revive him...

column1: What are the problems in stopping the Heart?
column2: Nothing -- compared to starting it up again.

column1: <Cardiac Red Alert> we're stopping the Heart.
column2: Message to Proteus.

column1: They're in the Pulmonary Artery.
column2: They'll make up some time, once they get through that and reach the Pleural Cavity.  Respiration Post...

column1: Another delay... With only forty-two minutes left.
column2: It'll be close -- but there's still a margin of safety.

column1: I told you to cut down on the sugar.
column2: I can't help it. I'm just weak, I guess.

column1: Time's up... We'll have to take them out immediately.
column2: It means killing Benes...  And for all we know, they may have completed the operation!  Damn it to hell!

column1: What is it?
column2: That blip we're picking up might only be the radio-active particle. The Proteus may already be destroyed...

column1: What're you getting at?
column2: If I were in their place and I'd run out of time, I'd abandon the ship before I grew to dangerous size... and use the few extra minutes to get out the quickest way possible, on my own...

column1: Now how soon can we try Sodium Pentathol?
column2: I'd hold that off awhile.

column1: Hello, Grant. Good to see you again.
column2: The Pentagon, wasn't it, General? Only you weren't in that uniform...

column1: Benes... What the devil happened?
column2: The Other Side got to him.

column1: How bad off is he?
column2: Brain injury.

column1: Before or after what he wanted to tell you?
column2: Before he could breathe a word. He's the only scientist who knows the answer to what we're after. That's why we have to operate --

column1: -- and why we need you.
column2: <Me>?

column1: I can't even put a Band-Aid on my finger.
column2: Here's the Surgeon.

column1: Duval. Dr. Peter Duval. Top brain man in the country. Ever hear of him?
column2: Sorry, but I'm rusty on surgeons. Who's the girl?

column1: Cora Peterson, his Technical Assistant. You'll join Duval and the others --
column2: What can I do? Except maybe pass out?

column1: Wish I knew why.
column2: Tell him where he fits in, will you? I've got a few things to check out.

column1: But why take the chance, when there must be other doctors?
column2: We have no choice. Duval's the most skillful brain surgeon in the country, and he's right here, at hand.

column1: Right, sir.
column2: Come along, they'll be operating shortly.  See you later, Mike.

column1: His technician okay? In addition to the Looks Department?
column2: No question of her loyalty.

column1: I don't mean to be inquisitive. But this <CMDF> -- for all I know it could stand for <Consolidated Mobilization of Female Delinquents>?
column2: <Combined Miniature Deterrent Forces>.

column1: General, I've heard some wild ones. But this takes it.
column2: We can shrink an Army -- with all its equipment -- and put it in a bottle cap. That's why we call it <Combined Miniature Deterrent Forces>.

column1: If the Other Side ever gets hold of a thing like that...
column2: They have...  But we've both got the same problem -- lack or control. We can only keep things Miniaturized for exactly sixty minutes. Arter that, everything starts growing back to its original size.

column1: I assume Benes knows how to control it.
column2: That's right. He wanted us to have the secret, and not them. Which is why they tried to kill him.

column1: They're bound to try again. No wonder they want me to stand by during the operation.
column2: And take a little trip with them...

column1: Trip? Where to?
column2: Well, the only way to reach that clot is from inside the Brain. So we've decided to put a Surgical Team and a Crew into a submarine -- reduce it way down in size, and inject it into an Artery --

column1: You mean <I'm> going along?
column2: As part of the Crew.

column1: Wait a minute! They can't shrink <me>!
column2: Grant, our Miniaturizer can shrink anything.

column1: But I don't want to be Miniaturized -- !
column2: It's only for an hour --

column1: This is Dr. Duval, our Head Surgeon.
column2: Oh yes, I've heard of you, Doctor.

column1: There'll be a team of Surgeons standing by. We're prepared to remove you immediately, should anything go wrong. In any event, you must be out within sixty minutes. After that, you'll be in danger of attack.
column2: Attack? Who -- or should I say what from?

column1: Just one, General...
column2: Yes?

column1: Oh yes, great. The only problem is, he can't remember what he came to tell us.
column2: Can't remember?... What do you mean?

column1: Yes, we'd like to get moving.
column2: Why don't you go on. We'll meet you at the Clearance Desk in a few minutes.

column1: Yes, Alan.
column2: Meet Grant. This is Dr. Michaels, Chief of the Medical Section.

column1: [LINE OF DIALOGUE CUT OFF]
column2: I don't agree. Just because he's often difficult --

column1: Difficult? He's impossible!
column2: That's no reason to suspect him of disloyalty.

column1: I'll be standing by. <I'll> know.
column2: And no matter what happens, you're to take orders <only> from Dr. Michaels, understand?

column1: Listen...the Heart.
column2: Yes...slowed down agreat deal.

column1: I can't imagine how it possibly could have come loose. I distinctly recall fastening it with all four bolts --
column2: It must have been jarred loose during the whirlpool.

column1: But we just can't leave him in there! What'll happen to him?
column2: We'll know -- in the next breath...

column1: That's beside the point now.  I don't see the sense of going on.
column2: We must!

column1: You're going out there? With those Antibodies --
column2: No danger of attack, as long as you don't trigger them off by any injury to the System.

column1: Wouldn't it be quicker if we all helped?
column2: Yes, there's no time to spare. And those fibers can be quite tenacious.

column1: Doctor...
column2: Yes, Cora.

column1: What is it?  Anything wrong?
column2: I just wanted to thank you for taking me along.

column1: Never saw <that>. Not even under an electron-mrcroscope.
column2: They're much smaller than bacteria...

column1: Yes, a fistula too small to show up on the X-rays.
column2: But big enough for us...

column1: Doctor...you can't mean that! Not when we've come this far. And if we give up, there'll be no way of saving Mr. Benes --
column2: Dr. Michaels is right. We have no choice.

column1: Air bubbles!... Doctor --
column2: No danger of an embolism. At our reduced scale, they're much too minute to prove fatal to Benes.

column1: Cora, is something wrong with the laser?
column2: I don't know yet, Doctor. And I won't know until I test it.

column1: He's making a fine recovery.
column2: He certainly is. He should be up and about in no time.

column1: Bet you're pretty handy around the house... Can you cook?
column2: We're pushing oxygen today.

column1: I'll take some Laughing Gas, ma'am.
column2: You sound as if you're not looking forward to it.

column1: Well, it's not exactly a pleasure cruise.
column2: I think it's the most exciting --  We're going to see things no one ever saw before. The actual physical process of Life itself -- not something under a microscope... Just think of it --

column1: That's the trouble. I am. Being shrunk...
column2: You may learn to like it.

column1: That'll teach you where to keep your hand.
column2: Now I know...

column1: That could be quite a lethal weapon... It could kill, not cure.
column2: Not in the hands of a great surgeon like Dr. Duval. The beam of this laser can be regulated to one millionth of a millimeter.

column1: I understand you've been Dr. Duval's Assistant for quite some time... He must've snatched you out of the cradle.
column2: I've been with him since I got out of school. He brought me into the CMDF, over five years ago.

column1: A long time, with one man.
column2: Not working for someone like Dr. Duval --

column1: I never...never imagined it could be anything...like this.
column2: I always thought it was nothing but red.

column1: -- at which point the Heart will be stopped by electric shock.
column2: And if it should take more time to get through --

column1: Look at that...they're changing color...
column2: Doctor -- is it possible? That we're seeing it happen before our eyes?

column1: Looks like you didn't batten it down too well.
column2: But I did. I'm positive!

column1: Then how come it worked loose?
column2: I have no idea.

column1: Shouldn't you answer that?
column2: Not now. We need air, not greetings!

column1: I'll try to hold it from the other side of the wall, while you push from out here. Maybe that'll do it.
column2: You can't --it's too dangerous --

column1: You must carry spare parts --
column2: Not anything built into the chassis.  If it hadn't come loose --

column1: If you had a transistor about this size and power output, and a thin enough wire --  -- could you piece it together?
column2: No, it requires such absolute precision --

column1: A surgeon might...
column2: Oh yes, I'm sure Dr. Duval could. If we had the parts.

column1: Open it! Open it before they get here!
column2: I can't till the hatch is flooded!

column1: No need to get up --
column2: I feel much better now...

column1: Thank you for saving my life.
column2: That's what they pay me for.

column1: Such as?
column2: Keeping an eye on Dr. Duval...

column1: That's why you're really here. I knew it from the start.
column2: As obvious as that? Our Security people will jump for joy.  I suppose Duval's onto me, too?

column1: You're not the first, but he's much too innocent, much too involved with his work, to realize what's going on around him.
column2: Under a cloud without cause, I take it.

column1: Oh, no. Plenty of cause. He won't follow the herd, or change his convictions -- even when they're not popular. And he believes in an absolutely free interchange of information between scientists of different countries -- and these days, there's nothing more suspicious than that.
column2: Depends on which end of the telescope you look through.

column1: What do you mean?
column2: Well, if you happen to be very fond of him -- even in love with him -- it would certainly affect your point of view.

column1: We better get back to the sub. Every second counts now.
column2: Look! They follow the direction of her glance, are startled to see:

column1: Doctor, what's wrong?
column2: I can't breathe!... I've got to get out!

column1: Looks like the molecular structure of proteins.
column2: I don't agree. I think we ought to stop and take a sample.

column1: But that isn't possible.
column2: Not in a sealed vessel like an Artery.  Captain -- something must be wrong with your controls!

column1: We can't take a second more.
column2: Captain -- head in the d1rection of the flow and drift with it.

column1: Nothing miraculous about it. Just an interchange of gases. The end product of five hundred million years of Evolution.
column2: You can't believe all that's accidental? That there isn't a Creative Intelligence at work --

column1: What can we do?
column2: Nothing -- against all that force.

column1: That puts us right here... Which means we can head straight for the Sub Arachnoid Cavity.
column2: Yes...

column1: It's against my better Judgment...
column2: Better Judgment?! To wait until the actual operation -- when it may be too late?

column1: I've done all I could with the laser.
column2: All I'm asking is you test it beforehand!

column1: If it won't work, it's beyond my power to fix it. But if it does, there's no telling how long it will hold up. It's a jury rig, at best, and we'll need every second of use we can get out of it. That's why I don't want to put any extra strain on the connections by running unnecessary tests.
column2: Dr. Duvall I insist you test the laser.

column1: I'll do nothing of the sort! The operation is <my> responsibility! I won't do it, and that's final!
column2: As usual, you want everything your way. Except this time there's more than your damned ego at stake.

column1: The Soul? The finite mind cannot comprehend Infinity. And the Soul which comes from God is Infinite.
column2: Take a close look at your Soul, and your Infinity, and your God out there --

column1: --and certain chemicals involving proteins --
column2: You left something out.

column1: What's that?
column2: The Breath of God...

column1: Removal Point? What're you talking about!
column2: We have no alternative. With only six minutes left, we'll just barely make it.

column1: Dr. Duval, you are not going through with this! I absolutely forbid it! I'm responsible for the lives of everyone here! I will not allow you or anyone else to leave this ship!
column2: I'm going to do what I can to save Benes.

column1: The Medieval Philosophers were right... <Man> is the center of the Universe... We stand in the middle of Infinity, between Outer and Inner Space. And there's no limit to either.
column2: You mean Inner Space is endless?

column1: Only to the naked eye.  Those corpuscles -- carrying oxygen -- give the stream its color. But the rest of the plasma's very much like sea water. An ocean of life...
column2: Quite a piece of plumbing.

column1: I'd hate to get lost on that Freeway...
column2: They all lead to the same place -- the Lungs.

column1: Mind letting me in on what's going on out there?
column2: A simple exchange, Mr. Grant. Corpuscles releasing carbon dioxide -- the moment they touch the Wall of the Lung -- in return for oxygen coming through from the other side.

column1: Don't tell me they're refueling...
column2: Oxygenation...

column1: Just a few cells away from a vast air chamber -- one of the countless Alvioli of the Lung -- and we can't get enough to fill a microscopic tank.
column2: Maybe we can...  Skipper, is there a snorkel on this sub?

column1: Isn't there another surgical procedure you can try?
column2: No, there's no other way.

column1: We'll never get there in time, at this rate.
column2: Isn't there another route? So we can by-pass all this?

column1: Yes...  We can transfer over to the Inner Ear, and go by way of the Endolymphatic Duct.
column2: Then why not take it?

column1: "Yet all the suns that light the Corridors of the Universe shine dim, Before the blazing of a Single Thought -- "
column2: "Proclaiming in incandescent glory The myriad Mind of Man..."

column1: How does it look, Doctor?
column2: If I can relieve the pressure on a few key vessels...

column1: Doctor, we've just about had it.
column2: It I can clear this Central Nerve, that <may> be enough...

column1: The ship's good as finished. We'll have to get out on our own! Is there a quick way out?
column2: We could follow the Optic Nerve to the corner of the Eye.

column1: You said there was a quick way out!
column2: What about Dr. Michaels?

column1: We need you for Security purposes, Mr. Grant.
column2: At an operation?

column1: They know they failed to kill Benes. Security thinks they'll try again, first chance they get. We're afraid of medical sabotage -- or surgical assassination.
column2: Surgical assassination?! But that means you suspect --

column1: Miss Peterson, his Technical Assistant.
column2: How are you, Miss Peterson?

column1: About forty miles an hour.
column2: Well, it seems to me if you reduce a ship to microscopic size -- and the stream remains constant -- we'd take quite a beating.

column1: A what?
column2: A forced joining of an Artery and Vein. Must've happened when Benes was hurt.

column1: If we can't go back, is there an alternate route?
column2: Yes... We can go forward on this course, but it means going directly through the Heart.

column1: That's just dandy. We can't go forward -- and we can't go back.
column2: I'm afraid there's only one thing we can do. Call off the mission.

column1: Tell them to take us out.
column2: If there's any chance --

column1: Sounds like heavy artillery...
column2: It lays down quite a barrage in a lifetime. Forty million beats.

column1: There it is!
column2: Fasten yourselves in. There should be a tremendous surge when the Heart starts up again.

column1: At this size, I would certainly think so.
column2: If those Corpuscles can take on air, no reason why we can't.  All we have to do is hook up the snorkel to that air chamber you were talk1ng about, and when Benes inhales, there should be plenty of pressure to force the oxygen into the tank.  How's that sound to you, Skipper?

column1: In a way -- yes. Those are impurities imbedded in the Lung after a lifetime of 'Civilization.' Carbon from smoke and smog -- specks of dust --
column2: Well, we better get on with it.

column1: Yes -- with all that pressure, and suction within --
column2: There's no other way. Tie my safety line to the sub.

column1: All right now -- push the snorkel through as soon as I get inside.
column2: Walt for the lull -- between the time he inhales and exhales.

column1: Grant -- wait a minute -- you're not going to dismantle the wireless?
column2: Just one little transistor and a circuit wire is all it takes.

column1: But that'll knock out our communications! We'll be cutting ourselves off from the outside.
column2: They'll still be able to track us by radar, because of the radioactive fuel.

column1: Well, sir? Which is it? The wireless, or Benes' life?
column2: Send the following message...

column1: Looks like the sea, at dawn.
column2: We're safe -- long as it remains that color...  We're in the Pleural Sac.  It keeps the Lungs from rubbing against the Wall of the Chest up there. When those membranes become inflamed, we wind up with Pleurisy -- and a wracking cough.

column1: Cough? If he can kick up a storm by just <breathing> --
column2: His Pleura's in fine condition. It should be clear sailing through this area.

column1: Sabotage? I don't understand...
column2: I saw the laser just before we started. It was fastened down securely. You don't suppose what happened was an 'accident?' Any more than my safety line snapping after it was tied off to the sub?

column1: You have no right to blame Duval --
column2: That line was tampered with...

column1: I -- I don't know what to say. I know he's under a cloud, but there's not a more dedicated man in the entire medical profession.
column2: You still never know what's going on in anyone's mind...

column1: I can't believe it. Whatever happened was an accident.
column2: Two in a row?

column1: We're entering the Lymphatic System. Those are nuclei of cells, lining a Duct.
column2: I always had an idea there was only one System. The Circulatory.

column1: Skipper, you're picking up seaweed -- or whatever it is.
column2: Reticular fibers. We ought to be clear of them soon.

column1: Looks like somebody declared war.
column2: Just what it is. Antibodies, destroying Bacteria -- or any other foreign invader that threatens the System.

column1: They're tracking us Topside. Once they see where we're going, I'm sure they'll take every precaution.
column2: Let's hope they realize the danger.  Captain, I'll give you a new compass heading.

column1: Looks like quite a way to go...
column2: No, we should reach the base of the Brain shortly. And from there, it's not far to the site of the injury.

column1: Hold it, Skipper.  What happens if we overstay?
