column2: Once time's up, De-Miniaturization begins. In a matter of seconds the ship will grow big enough to become a danger to the System. Then White Corpuscles will swarm to destroy it, as they would any invader.

column1: I'm in charge of this mission! You were instructed to take orders from me, not give them!
column2: Sorry, but the situation has changed.

column1: I don't believe that.
column2: Why not? Because of his gibberish about GOd and the Soul? Camouflage -- that's all it is -- to blind the gullible like you! And to hide his real identity -- a fanatic whose only purpose is to kill Benes! And you made it possible!

column1: Sorry we had to get you up at this hour, Mr. Grant.
column2: I thought I was on my vacation... What's it all about?

column1: I can't tell you.
column2: Where we going?

column1: May I?
column2: Go ahead.

column1: What'd you do that for?
column2: I'm married.

column1: Out of your element, aren't you, Captain?
column2: Sort of.

column1: Atomic fuel?
column2: Nothing you could see with the naked eye. But there's a microscopic radio-active particle inside.

column1: If it's no military secret, how can a sub run on a microscopic particle?
column2: They can't reduce nuclear fuel. But once the Reactor's Miniaturized -- along with the submarine -- a microscopic particle should emit enough energy to activate it.

column1: That's cutting it mighty close -- for a perfect fit.
column2: It should work -- theoretically. If it doesn't, the mission's off. The craft's nuclear-powered. Except for your wireless.

column1: All in all, quite a canoe...
column2: Designed for Piscatorial Research -- the Spawning Habits of Deep Sea Fish.

column1: 'Prepare for Miniaturization'...
column2: Positions, please. And strap yourselves in.

column1: Any reserve air?
column2: Enough to breathe, but that's all.

column1: I've come up against fanatics before, and Duval just doesn't fit the pattern.  I'm going out there, Skipper. Maybe I can be of some help...
column2: Remember -- we can't take more than five minutes to get out.

column1: What happened?
column2: Dr. Michaels... He went berserk...

column1: Come on -- it's no use!
column2: We can get out through the Lab Section.

column1: Who, me? Oh, no! Don't bother about me! We're not hurt! Isn't that right, Skipper?
column2: Uh -- what?

column1: We feel great, don't we? Just <great>?!
column2: Oh -- sure, sure! Never better!

column1: What is it, Skipper?
column2: We're losing pressure in the Flotation Tanks. Check the Manual, right over there.

column1: Yes, there is.
column2: Could I run a tube through that Wall, without harming Benes?

column1: Thirty-two minutes left...  But chances are we won't have to wait that long for try-number three.
column2: Look at those Walls up ahead!

column1: What's wrong, Skipper?
column2: What I was afraid would happen. The stuff we passed through -- that looked like seaweed --

column1: How's it look?
column2: I could use a lawnmower...

column1: Even so, because of our size -- I mean lack of it -- we'll still be cruising mighty fast. We'll be smashed to bits if there's any turbulence --
column2: The only danger of turbulence is in the Heart -- and we're not going through it.  Once in the Carotid Artery, we'll remain in the Arterial System... until we reach the point of damage --  -- where Dr. Duval will attempt to dissolve the clot with a laser beam. After the operation, we'll return by way of the Venous System --  -- until we reach the base of the neck --  -- where we'll be removed right here -- with a hypodermic.

column1: Captain, how will you be able to follow my charts --  --from up there?
column2: On the Repeater.

column1: That's it...
column2: Looks simple to operate.

column1: I'll never find my way through that.
column2: I'll guide you, once we're in the Heart.

column1: Well, that takes care of the valve. It was probably caused by that electric shock.
column2: Was there any damage?

column1: It's a dangerous procedure. If I miss the timing, we could explode the tanks... But I'm willing to try it.
column2: Yes, by all means. We must try it.

column1: We could never fight that current it's physically impossible.
column2: Then don't drift down further.

column1: Doctor -- the channel's getting awful narrow.
column2: We're entering a Capillary. Remain in the middle.

column1: The Wall's transparent...
column2: It's less than one ten-thousandth of an inch thick. And porous.

column1: There seems to be something wrong with the Escape Hatch...
column2: What do you mean?

column1: That was over thirty years ago.  I paid for that and then some.
column2: You go to Xavier High School, Daryl?

column1: Yeah.
column2: You remember Mary Finelli?

column1: What are you saying?
column2: You know what I'm saying.

column1: No, I don't.
column2: Well, I think you do.

column1: Sexual assault, Daryl.  Five years.  But you got lucky, right?  You got away with something else.  Something you figured nobody knows about.
column2: What I know is what I told you.

column1: Let me tell you what I know, Daryl.  You went to Saint Xavier with Mary.  You lived five blocks from her.  You liked her.  But she ain't interested.  That must've hurt, huh?
column2: So what?

column1: So, what'd you do about it, Daryl?
column2: Nothing.

column1: Oh, my God!  What is that?!  Why you showing me this shit!?  JESUS!  JESUS! Get those away from me!
column2: Nicky Moore.  Patty Ryan.  Mary Finelli. These names mean anything to you, asshole?  Julia Sullivan!  She mean anything?  She means something to me!

column1: You got a collar in here for the Nightingale murders?
column2: Yeah.

column1: I'm working with one of the victims outta Brooklyn North.  You mind I take a shot at him?
column2: That's Deleon and Hayes' collar.

column1: They around?
column2: Just missed Deleon.  Hayes is up in the squad.

column1: Where's the collar, in the cells?
column2: No, I think he's up in interrogation.

column1: Why haven't they killed the juice?
column2: Switches are shorted out.

column1: You're shitting me!
column2: Wish I was.  Oldest part of the system down there.  We're on it, but it's gonna take awhile.

column1: We gotta go underground.  Get those guys out, now.
column2: We tried.  Bulkhead door's rusted shut. Won't budge.

column1: How do we get to the vault door?
column2: There's a manhole at Canal and Bowery.

column1: Oh, man.  Hope it ain't like this in Baltimore tomorrow.
column2: Baltimore?

column1: Oh, yeah.  Damn.  My watch is busted.
column2: Hey, Rookie.  Be cool.  Just stay with me.  This is what we do.

column1: Frank.  We gotta go back.  Frank...
column2: Stay with me, Gib.  We're gonna do this.

column1: Frank.  Hey, man.  You alright?
column2: I'm alright, Gibby.

column1: It looks open on the other side.
column2: Don't know what's behind it.

column1: Gotta be another way up, Frank.
column2: Then fuckin' find it.  I'm going for the girl.

column1: You okay, man?
column2: Elvis has left the building.

column1: Hey, bud.
column2: Hey, bud.

column1: How about a little of the King?
column2: Well, why not a little of the King?

column1: Damn.
column2: You alright?

column1: What's the matter, Jules?  Trouble workin' an eight hour shift, watching the kid and whipping up a little bolognese?
column2: You didn't marry Donna Reed.

column1: How was your tour?
column2: The usual.

column1: Butch called.
column2: Did he?

column1: He did.
column2: It was under control, Bud.  Butchy's just getting tight in his old age.

column1: Frankie, Johnny wants to say goodnight.
column2: Sure.

column1: Frank...what's wrong?
column2: Nothing.  I just wanted to see you.

column1: Where's Johnny?
column2: I tucked him in at Gordo's.

column1: You give him his drops?
column2: One in each ear.  What would you do without me?

column1: I love you, Bud.
column2: I love you more.

column1: Boy is he excited about the game tomorrow.
column2: He ain't the only one.

column1: I'm off.
column2: Wish you weren't.

column1: There's something I gotta take care of. Something I need to tell you about.
column2: Okay...

column1: I've been talking to this...guy...this cop...on the HAM...and, uh, he...
column2: Honey, what is it?  Just tell me.

column1: I've been talking to Johnny...on the radio.
column2: I know.  He loves that thing.

column1: I'll be upstairs...if you want to play.
column2: I'm serious.

column1: Jules, I want you to say hello to somebody...  I'm on with John - that guy I told you about.
column2: The future guy?

column1: Then you gotta hide it somewhere. Somewhere where nobody's gonna find it...for 29 years!  Put it under the loose floorboard by the window!
column2: I gotcha, I gotcha Chief!

column1: Hey, bud.
column2: Frank...

column1: Lucky throw, fire boy.
column2: Luck, my ass.

column1: Okay, I'm on it.  Hey.
column2: Hello, Frank.

column1: Frank, we need to talk...
column2: John, hold on a second.  I'm in the middle of something important here.  You mind if...

column1: Satch, you gotta just give me...Satch is here John.  You hear me?  Satch is here.
column2: I'm sorry, Frank, but you need to come outside.

column1: What is going on here, Satch?  What are those guys doing out there?
column2: I think you know, Frank.

column1: No, I don't.
column2: Let's go outside and talk.  We need to do that.

column1: About what?
column2: Let's go.  Do us both a favor.

column1: What do you mean?
column2: Do you know where I found this?

column1: 415 Greenwich St.  #302.  Under the body of a murdered woman.
column2: No.  This isn't what you think.

column1: I wanna be wrong here.  But we need to go to the precinct and talk about it.
column2: Okay, okay.  I need to go say something to Julia and finish up with the guy on the radio.

column1: I swear, Satch.
column2: Uh, huh...  Uh, huh.  And you got this from the guy you were talking to on the radio when I came in?

column1: As nuts as that sounds, yes.
column2: Uh, huh.

column1: Frank, this is not the time to be worried about covering up if you had a thing with this girl.
column2: He's not gonna stop, Satch.  He's gonna keep on...

column1: What if I could prove it to you, Satch?
column2: How's that?

column1: What if I told you that in the bottom of the 6th we're gonna be down 3-0.  And Cleon Jones is gonna get hit in the foot. It's gonna leave a scuff mark on the ball.
column2: Frank, please...

column1: The next batter, Clendenon, hits one outta the park.
column2: Frank, this is insane...

column1: In the bottom of the 7th, Weis is gonna hit a solo home run.  Jones and Swoboda are gonna score in the 8th.  The Mets are gonna win 5-3.  Go watch the game, Satch.
column2: Go watch the game?  Go watch the fucking game?  Frank, they're gonna make you for Sissy Clark's murderer.  It matches the Nightingale's profile.  You understand what that means?

column1: Deleon.
column2: Satch, you gotta listen to me...

column1: Frank.  We know.  We know it's Shepard.
column2: No kidding.  I'm on the corner of 65th and CPW.  Come get me.

column1: You missed a hell of a game, Frank.
column2: Next time lets put some money on it.

column1: Looks like two weeks worth of allowance, Chief.
column2: I know.  Sorry, Dad.

column1: Okay, start pedaling.
column2: Daddy put the wheels back on.  I'm gonna fall.

column1: Don't think about falling, just keep pedaling.
column2: Daddy, I'm scared.

column1: Daddy, come up and sing the baseball.
column2: I'll be up soon, Little Chief.

column1: I'm scared.
column2: Don't be scared.  This time I'm right behind you if you fall.

column1: Daddy, Daddy, I can't.
column2: No, but we can.  We can do it together. Spirit and guts, Chief.

column1: You ready?
column2: Wait...

column1: Yes!  That's it!  You got it, you got it! Way to go, Chief!
column2: I'm doing it!  I'm doing it!

column1: Uh, hello?
column2: WB2YKXB, who've I got?

column1: Are you licensed to broadcast, buddy?
column2: Look, I don't really remember how this thing works.

column1: Listen, you can't broadcast without a license.  Unless this is an emergency, you gotta get off the band.
column2: Pal, my whole life's an emergency.

column1: Where are you transmitting from?
column2: Queens, New York.

column1: Whatta ya know.  Bayside, born and raised.
column2: I thought these things were for talkin' around the world.

column1: 15-band closes down at night.  During the day you can chew the band with China if you want.
column2: I can't believe people are still using these things.

column1: Sorry 'bout that.  So Queens, you psyched for the Series?
column2: I don't really follow baseball anymore.

column1: What?
column2: I got fed up with all the bullshit.

column1: I'm right with you, man.  He's got the heart of a lion.  Hey, how 'bout the first game of the Series?
column2: Yeah.  It was all over after Buford nailed Seaver's first pitch outta the park.

column1: ...WB2YXB calling unidentified station, Queens.  CQ 15.
column2: Hello?

column1: I been Q-ing you all night.  How the hell did you do it?
column2: Huh?

column1: The World Series.  You called Buford's homer.
column2: Wasn't too tough, buddy.  Game happened almost thirty years ago.

column1: What are you talking about?  I'm talking about this afternoon.
column2: This afternoon?

column1: Sorry 'bout that.
column2: What'd you just say?

column1: You call your son Little Chief?
column2: Uh huh...

column1: What'd you say your name was?
column2: Frank...Frank Sullivan.

column1: Is this some kind of joke?  Gordo is that you?  Are you fucking with me?
column2: Look pal, I'm just askin' how you...

column1: You're telling me your name is Frank Sullivan, you live in Queens and you just saw the first game of the '69 Series...live?
column2: Right...and I'm asking how you called the game.

column1: Gordo, if this is you, so help me...
column2: What the hell does Gordy have to do with it?

column1: What'd you say your station...uh, your call letters were?
Now you listen to me.  My name is John Francis Sullivan, I live at 1060 41st, where I've lived my whole life.  And I saw the first game of the '69 Series at my Uncle Butch's house with my father...
column2: What?

column1: 29 years...?
column2: My dad's name was Frank Patrick Sullivan, he was a fire fighter and a die-hard Mets fan.  And every night when I went to bed he sang to me...  Take me out to the ball game, take me out with the crowd...

column1: What the hell...
column2: I'm dreaming this.  Shit, this is a dream.

column1: What's going on?
column2: Nothing...I just spilled something.

column1: Oh my god.
column2: What?

column1: You just burned the desk.
column2: What's happening?

column1: That's impossible.
column2: What if it's not...

column1: Dad...?
column2: Johnny...?

column1: How could this be happening?
column2: I don't know.

column1: We gotta be bouncing off the mother sun spot of all time.
column2: Sun spot?

column1: Yeah, that's how Hams work.
column2: Wait a sec...there was something on the news.  Something about this space anomaly.  I think they said it was connected to some storm in '69.

column1: You sound...ground up...?
column2: I'm thirty-five years old.

column1: Thirty-five?  That would make it...
1998...?  This is wrong.  Who are you? Why are you doing this?
column2: I'm not doing anything.  Look, I don't know what's going on.  But I swear on my life, I"m here at your old desk, on your Ham, in our house, right now...in 1998.

column1: It's really you, isn't it?
column2: Yeah...I think so.

column1: No, not yet.
column2: Too busy playin' ball, huh?

column1: You're still my Little Chief, right?
column2: I'm trying to be, Dad.  I'm tyrin'.  It's good to hear your voice.  I missed you...so much.

column1: What's that?
column2: I think I'm losing you.

column1: No wait, don't go!
column2: It's okay.  I'm still here, Chief.

column1: What are you talking about?
column2: I lost you.

column1: What?
column2: I never knew you, Dad.

column1: Why?
column2: Fire.

column1: On the job?
column2: It was an abandoned warehouse - hit by lightening.  Butch told Ma it was just one wrong turn. Said it wasn't your fault.  You went with the training, with your instincts.  If you'd just gone left instead of right, you would've made it.

column1: That can't be...that's not gonna happen.
column2: It did, Pop.  It did.

column1: When?
column2: October 12, 1969.

column1: But that's tomorrow.
column2: Tomorrow.  Jesus...it hasn't happened. It doesn't have to happen.

column1: Don't go.  Don't go in that warehouse...
column2: I don't understand.

column1: Dad...?
column2: Chief?!  Is that you?

column1: Yeah, it's me.
column2: You're the voice of an angel, Johnny.  If you hadn't told me, no way I would'a ever made it.

column1: Dad, you there?  You okay?
column2: Yeah.  I'm okay.  What about you?  I want to know.  About you.  And your mom.

column1: We're doing all right, Dad.  We're doing good.
column2: Tell me.

column1: It's hard to explain.  Something happened today.  It was like a dream.  And when I woke up I had all these new memories. Good times.  Times we never had before.
column2: I'm glad.

column1: Dad, I gotta tell you this...cause you should know.  Cause I still remember.
column2: What, Johnny?  What is it?

column1: Right here, Chief.  Sorry I lost you last night.  Damn thing keeps cutting out.
column2: Dad...Dad... There's... I need to...

column1: Are you alright"?
column2: Something happened, something...

column1: What?  Johnny, what's wrong?
column2: It's Mom.

column1: What?  What is it?
column2: She's not here.

column1: Whatta you mean she's not here?
column2: She...she died.  It's like it just happened.

column1: She just died, your mother just died?
column2: No Dad, it happened a long time ago, a long time ago for me.

column1: When?
column2: October 22, 1969.

column1: Murdered?  Why?
column2: There was this case.  A serial.  He murdered three women, all nurses, between '68 and '69.  The papers called them the Nightingale Murders.  They never caught him.  But the killings just stopped.

column1: What kinda twisted animal.
column2: Dad, we did something.  Something to make it worse.

column1: Whatta you mean...
column2: He didn't just kill three women anymore. He killed ten.

column1: What are you talking about?
column2: Something we did changed the case...changed history.  Mom wasn't dead.  But then after you didn't die in the fire something must have happened.  And this guy, this Nightingale guy, he kept on killing...it was like a spree...seven more women.

column1: I gotta take her away, John.  I'm gonna take your mother away.  He can't hurt her if I take her away.
column2: I don't know...  What about the other women?

column1: I'll warn them.
column2: That'll never work.  They'll just think you're crazy.

column1: What can we do?  You don't even know who this guy is.
column2: No.  Nobody got...  Wait a minute.  I might not know who he is, but I know where he's gonna be.  I got the case file.  We know what he's gonna do before he does it.

column1: So what should I do?  Call the police? You think they'll believe me?
column2: They will if they catch him in the act. You can make that happen, Dad.  You can tail the victim and call it in at just the right moment.

column1: I don't know, John.  I'm a fire fighter. This is...this is different.
column2: I do know.  I'm a cop.  This is what I do.

column1: You ever talk to a victim's family?  The one's left behind?  They don't act like what you'd think.  There's panic and fear.  But mostly, it's like there's this logic problem.  And if they could only solve it, everything would be okay.  But if you look real close - look at their eyes - you can see it.  Just a glimmer.  But somewhere they know.  They know their world is never gonna be the same.
column2: What if the radio stops working?  Christ, what if I can't reach you again?

column1: Why not just get the cops to watch the bar?
column2: They'll question her.  Whatever they tell her could change what happens.  No, I want you to follow her.  See if anybody's watching her, hittin' on her. I'm betting somebody's gonna walk outta that bar with her.  When they do, you call the cops.

column1: What do I tell them?
column2: Tell 'em there's a homicide in progress... cause by the time they show up there will be.

column1: I'll be damned.
column2: Did you see him?  Do you know who he is?

column1: No.  I just kept talking to her.  There was a lot of guys in that bar - could'a been any of 'em.
column2: It's okay.  This is working.  This is gonna work.

column1: Whatta we do now?
column2: Sissy Clark, 190 Riverside Dr., apartment 3C.  Tomorrow.  She's a nursing student.  Paying her way as a cocktail waitress at the Peppermint Lounge, on west 63rd.  Left work at two A M...killed in her apartment, between two thirty and five.

column1: Got it.
column2: Dad, I think I may be able to get you enough information to make sure the DA can nail this bastard.

column1: How?
column2: Coupla days ago they dug up a body in Washington Heights - Mary Finelli.  Girl disappeared in '68.  Turns out she was his first kill.  Which means he probably knew her.  Most serials know their first victim.  I'm gonna do some checking - see if I can put any of this together...

column1: Tell me something good, Chief.  Tell me about the future.
column2: Well they found out cigarettes give you lung cancer.

column1: What else, John.  It must be different, huh?  Are people living on the moon?
column2: Didn't happen, we got enough problems down here.

column1: What are we like in...1998?
column2: We're okay...we're good, Dad.

column1: Hey, what about the Amazin's?  They pull it off?
column2: You really wanna know?

column1: Yeah, you betcha.
column2: Well, game five was the big one.  It turned in the bottom of the 6th.  We were down 3-0.  Cleon Jones gets hit on the foot - left a scuff mark on the ball. Clendenon comes up.  The count goes to 2 2.  High fastball.  He nailed it.  Weis slammed a solo shot in the 7th to tie. Jones and Swoboda scored in the 8th.  We won, Pop.

column1: Hang on a sec, John.
column2: You there?

column1: John, say hello to my wife...Julia.
column2: H-hi.

column1: John, you still there?
column2: I'm right here, Dad.

column1: You all right?
column2: Yeah, I think so...

column1: He killed her John.  He killed her and I didn't do a thing to stop it.
column2: It's not your fault, Dad.

column1: Yes it is...we did this.  We changed everything.  I've been having bad dreams, Johnny. Dreams where I die...in the fire.  I was supposed to die in that warehouse.
column2: No.

column1: This is wrong...it's like we cheated...
column2: I know...  But Dad, you can't go back.  You didn't die in that fire.  And no matter what you do, nothing is gonna change that.  So all we can do is deal with this...and try to make it right.

column1: I don't think I can.  I'm not a cop.  I can't.   I can't stop this guy.
column2: But we can, we can do it together. Spirit and guts, remember?

column1: I need you to believe in me.  To believe that we can do this.
column2: John, he's got my driver's license.

column1: What?
column2: He took my driver's license, John, he knows where we live.

column1: He took your wallet?
column2: No, he tossed the wallet, but he kept the license.

column1: He touched your wallet!  Where's your wallet?
column2: In my pocket.

column1: We got him!  Dad you got him!
column2: What?

column1: His prints.  You've got his prints.  I'll run them through criminal index.  You gotta get me that wallet.
column2: How the hell am I gonna do that?

column1: Listen to me, very carefully, take your wallet out, just touch it on the corners.
column2: What...

column1: Please, Dad, just do it.
column2: Okay, okay...

column1: I got it.
column2: Right, now I need you to tape it up on the outside, where he touched it, so the prints keep.

column1: It's gonna work, Dad.  We're gonna stop him.
column2: Hang on.

column1: You're telling me this maniac is a cop? What the hell am I supposed to do with that one?
column2: Call the FBI.  Use a pay phone.  Don't give 'em your name, Dad.  Just tell 'em that it was Shepard who killed Finelli and Clark and the others.  That he's the Nightingale.

column1: What are you doing here, Satch?  You off today?
column2: Dad, you there?

column1: Dad, what the hell is going on?
column2: Just a minute, John...okay?  Don't go away.

column1: John, you there?
column2: Yeah, Dad.  What the hell is going on?

column1: I'm here, Dad.  I'm here.
column2: We did it, John.  We stopped him.

column1: Wait.  Something's wrong.  I don't...
column2: What's wrong?

column1: I'm not your uncle, kid.  Gordo, what are you doing here?
column2: Sully!  Is that you?

column1: Hey, Sull.  My cable's out again.
column2: What the hell is that smell?

column1: Hey, OK if Gordy uses your old gear?
column2: I think it's somewhere in the closet... if you can find it.

column1: Sull!  What the hell!
column2: I talked to him Gordo.  I talked to my Dad.

column1: C'mon, man.  Get inside.  I'll come over. We'll play some Nintendo.
column2: No.  I gotta tell him the address, so he doesn't go in.

column1: Go in where?
column2: The warehouse.  Buxton seeds.  It's tomorrow.

column1: How you feeling?
column2: Better.

column1: John.  John, you all right?
column2: Longbranch...?

column1: My father didn't die in a fire?
column2: Huh?

column1: My father didn't die in a fire?
column2: Fire?  What are you talking about?  He had cancer, John.

column1: Cancer.  It was the cigarettes.  Right? The cigarettes?
column2: Yeah, lung cancer.  Ten years ago.

column1: Huh?
column2: The Ham radio.  That's how come he didn't die in the fire.

column1: This is the Space Cowboy.  I'm an intergalactic traveler from the Federation planet earth.
column2: Gordo?

column1: I better give you my address then.
column2: Oh don't worry kid, I know where you live.  Now I want you to go upstairs and write this down, buy Yahoo. You got that Space Cowboy.  Y-a-h-o-o. It's a magic word and I never want you to forget it.

column1: Don't choke on your pride, Sull.  You ain't ever gonna catch another one like that.
column2: She made up her mind.  Nothin' I do is gonna change it.

column1: You're not looking too good.
column2: Whoa, I just...I just...

column1: Maybe you outta lay off a little...
column2: Gordo, I wasn't dreaming.  I talked to him, it was real.

column1: Another rough night, huh?  That it?
column2: Yeah.  That's it.

column1: This is getting real old, John.  And I'm tired up to here with it...
column2: I'm sorry.  I just...you know...I...

column1: She makes ten.
column2: Ten?  No.  I remember this case.  Three. He killed three women.

column1: That's what we need here, Satch.  A lucky break.
column2: That wasn't luck, Johnny boy.  That was smarts and ten plus on the job.

column1: Our lucky break.  Mario ID'd the dental. Mary Finelli...reported missing April 16, 1968.
column2: April 16...?  That means she was the first.

column1: Which means he probably knew her.
column2: This case just got hot.  We pull on this string...

column1: Okay, lemme walk you through it.
column2: Mind if I shake it off first...so's I can concentrate better.

column1: I ran him through BCI...got a hit. Busted for sexual assault: March 22, 1970.  Eight days after the last Nightingale murder.
column2: So you figure the murders stop 'cause he's off the street.  Then by the time he gets paroled, he's smartened up enough to control himself?

column1: Not the first time that's been true.  I'm telling you, I got a feeling about this guy.  This is the guy, Satch.
column2: Uh, huh.

column1: What?
column2: I'm just trying to figure what interests me more: the possibility that Daryl is the guy, or you making him absolutely the guy.

column1: Got a minute?
column2: Yeah.  Sure.

column1: He ain't our guy, John.
column2: Just cause he didn't want to look at the photos doesn't mean he isn't the doer. Not everyone fits the profile.

column1: Hi, this is Julia.  Please leave a message after the tone.
column2: Hey, Ma, it's me.  Checking in.  Probably at work.  Anyways, I'll see you tomorrow night.  Love you.

column1: I thought it'd be nicer to eat here.
column2: Sounds good.

column1: I'm sorry Sam couldn't make it.
column2: Yeah, those grad school applications are driving her crazy.

column1: I'm sure everything'll work out.  She really loves you...
column2: So how are things at the hospital?

column1: Fine.  You know Dr. Schwartz retired last month?
column2: No kidd'n, he musta been pushing 90!

column1: So how'd you like LION KING?
column2: Oh, I loved it.  I wish you'd gone.

column1: I know.  I'm sorry.  Work.
column2: You work too hard, John.

column1: Hey, future boy.  Frank tells me you're a cop?
column2: Yeah, that's right.

column1: My six year-old here keeps telling me he wants to be a policeman.  Right after he retires from the majors.  We just gave him a badge and a whistle for his birthday.
column2: Yeah...I remember.  I used to play cops and robbers but y-- ...my mom wouldn't let me have a toy gun.

column1: You're mom sounds like she's got some smarts.
column2: She's pretty special.

column1: Are you a good cop, John?
column2: I try to be.

column1: Then I'll bet she's real proud of you, huh?
column2: Yeah.  I just wish I'd told her how proud I was of her.

column1: Just came by to wrap up over there. Thought I'd say "hello."
column2: Glad you did.  Come on in.  Buy you a cup of coffee?

column1: Wife around?
column2: No.  No.  Well, sort of.  In my heart. Been dead 29 years.

column1: You used to be on the job?
column2: Yeah, long time ago.  I know you?

column1: I look familiar?
column2: No.  What house you work?

column1: The 2-3.  Homicide.
column2: A hot shot, huh?

column1: Nah, just working the job.
column2: I hear that.

column1: No kiddin'?
column2: No.  Missing teenager.  Disappeared thirty years ago.  Found her bones last week.  Buried behind some old diner, up by Dyckman street.  Mary Finelli.

column1: Huh.
column2: Talk about dumb luck.  Odds of anybody finding that girl, thirty years later. And then the chances of hitting a dental...forget about it.  Bets part is she's the first victim.  She knew the doer.  I'm betting those bones are gonna do a lot of talking.

column1: Who are you?
column2: I'm the train wreck you didn't see coming.  And I'm gonna steal your life away.  You went down 30 years ago.  You just don't know it yet.

column1: Hell-
column2: You have the right to remain silent.  If you give up that right...

column1: Who the fuck is this?
column2: Anything you say can and will be used against you in a court of law.

column1: Sullivan?
column2: You have the right to speak to an att --

column1: Fuck you, asshole.
column2: It's a small world, Carl.  And I'm gonna find you.  Real soon.

column1: You almost sound like you believe that.
column2: Come with me now, Vincent.  You've gone as far as you can go.

column1: There are a few million miles to go yet.
column2: It's over.

column1: Is that the only way you can succeed, Anton, to see me fail?
column2: It's for the best.

column1: Well?  You have all the answers.  How is that possible?
column2: You didn't beat me that day. I beat myself.

column1: Who are you trying to convince?
column2: I will prove it to you.  Come swim with me now, Vincent.  Now--tonight.

column1: How are you doing this, Vincent? How have you done any of this?
column2: Now is your chance to find out.

column1: Vincent, where's the shore?  We're too far out. We have to go back!
column2: Too late for that.  We're closer to the other side.

column1: We were wondering if we should leave some things to chance.
column2: You want to give your child the best possible start. Believe me, we have enough imperfection built-in already. Your child doesn't need any additional burdens. And keep in mind, this child is still you, simply the best of you. You could conceive naturally a thousand times and never get such a result.

column1: Is there any reason you'd want a left-handed child?
column2: Er, no...

column1: Some believe it is associated with creativity, although there's no evidence.  Also for sports like baseball it can be an advantage.
column2: I like football.

column1: How much extra?
column2: It would be five thousand more.

column1: I'm sorry, there's no way we can.
column2: Don't worry.  You'll probably do just as well singing to him in the womb.  We can implant the most successful pre-embryo tomorrow afternoon.

column1: So you've finally seen sense and come back to your old job, Vincent.
column2: Not yet, I'm afraid.

column1: No?  What's keeping you?
column2: I guess I'm a slow learner.

column1: I guess so.  Well, while you're up there, maybe you could tidy the place up a bit.
column2: I'll see what I can do.

column1: And don't go getting everybody lost out there. You'll give us a bad name.  You won't have me to keep an eye on you, you know.
column2: By the way, I left some trash in your locker.

column1: I don't understand why you were dragged out here, Sir.  It's hardly worth wasting your time--a no-nothing case like this.
column2: A man's dead, Detective.

column1: Of course, Sir.  We're checking the entry log, alibis, grudges...
column2: Grudges?

column1: I look around, I see a lot of dry eyes. The Director was not...  ...universally loved.  He was leading the cut-backs in the program.  You're looking at a room full of motives.
column2: No, this is your man.

column1: With respect, Sir--it may be the only unaccountable specimen but the profile suggests--
column2: --What about his profile?

column1: According to this, he's a sick man.  Congenital heart condition.  Who knows how long the specimen has been here but there's an 80 percent chance the owner of that eyelash has already died himself from natural causes.
column2: So there's a 20 percent chance he's not dead.

column1: Even if this Vincent Luca is alive, is it likely he could bludgeon a man to death?
column2: No. Not likely.

column1: Of course that doesn't jibe with what we found.  This was an angry killing.
column2: Who knows with these "deficients"?  His profile indicates a proclivity for violence.

column1: I'll run a crossover on the eyelash for any family or associate connections--
column2: --I've already run it.  There's no record of any living relative.

column1: What a pity.
column2: Detective Hugo, it's a simple case of lost and found.  All we have to do is locate the man who's minus an eyelash and this murder will solve itself.

column1: We're in the wrong place.  We're wasting time.
column2: This is the most likely location--

column1: --There's that word again.  I have a feeling This man doesn't play the odds, Detective.  Not exactly a slave to probability.  Is it "likely" that a man who has successfully eluded authorities for fifteen years--a brutal killer--is going to come to us now like a lamb?
column2: Is there something more we should know about this suspect, Sir?  I mean besides what's on his sheet.

column1: Since going underground, traces of this In-Valid have shown up at the scene of four serious felonies.  Do you need any more than that?
column2: With respect, Sir, many perfectly innocent citizens have left specimens at as many crime scenes.  Maybe he's just unlucky.

column1: I don't like anybody this unlucky. Widen the sweep. The West side. Draw a five mile radius around Gattaca. Hoover some of the classier establishments. Random car stops.
column2: We're already getting complaints about frivolous search.

column1: The skin flake was found in Michael's Restaurant. The employees are all accounted for.
column2: A customer?  Does this Michael's cater to misfits?

column1: Of course.  He's a "de-gene-erate".  He works at Gattaca.  Why else would we find the eyelash near the washroom?  Nobody stops to take a leak during a murder.
column2: It's still possible the eyelash specimen came from a janitor, delivery man--it could have blown in through an open window.

column1: He was afraid of being exposed.  That's why he did it.
column2: It is hard to believe he could be one of their elite workers.  You've seen their security system.  They know who works there.  Even if you ignore the man's expiration date, his profile suggests that he doesn't have the mathematical propensity let alone the stamina to pass their physicals.

column1: Don't underestimate these imposters.
column2: None of the ID photos match the enhancement.

column1: You know their workforce.  Two-thirds at least fall into the category.  We'll be closing down their operation for days.  At least go with a fingertip sample or urine.
column2: Blood.  From the vein.

column1: That's the last.
column2: Something's not right.

column1: He's not here.  It's a blind alley.
column2: No, we've missed something.  We Hoover again.

column1: We don't have the manpower.
column2: Get it.  From outside, if you have to.

column1: From what budget?
column2: I'll take it out of your damn pension if you question my authority one more time!

column1: What are you waiting for?
column2: Where do we start?

column1: Positive saliva match.  The cup was definitely used since the original sweep.
column2: So we have two choices. Either our suspect came back to the murder scene for a drink of water and I don't know anybody that thirsty or... ...he is here. We test again. You're right, Hugo, this was a desperate act. Someone had a lot to lose that night--perhaps their place in line. I'd like the profiles of everyone with an upcoming mission.

column1: We found his spit in the dead director's eye. He's signed a confession--supplied us with the suit he wore on the night.  What more do you want?
column2: Luca could still be an accomplice.

column1: It's not exactly him.
column2: Where did you get this?

column1: How often do you test, Director?
column2: Often.

column1: Surely you know what you have.
column2: We have to be certain.  Once they're up, we can hardly turn the boat around.

column1: We believe we have a suspect.
column2: What a relief.

column1: Would you care to look--in the telescope?
column2: Thank you, no.

column1: One look through there and you would know why I can't possibly allow you to disrupt operations any further.
column2: You're so unconcerned that you have a killer in your midst.

column1: Right now, your presence is creating more of a threat. I don't think you have any concept of what we do here--how meticulous our preparations must be. We are about to send twelve people through 140 million miles of blackness to rendezvous with an object the size of a house and the color of coal. So it's rather critical to point them in the right direction. And we certainly don't need you looking over our shoulders. Besides, I don't believe there is any evidence that the killer is amongst us. I don't see too many other dead bodies littering the place.
column2: No, but since there aren't too many live ones tonight either, you won't mind us conducting one further sweep. If he does not work here, then there should be no other trace of him. I think you'd better get some people out of bed, Detective. In the meantime we can re-check his favorite haunt.

column1: Twelve have a mission within the week.
column2: This time I will supervise each test personally.

column1: At least it's nothing contagious.
column2: I will not permit any further testing on the eve of a mission.  We're already counting backwards.

column1: Hello.
column2: Jerome--?

column1: Good to see you're feeling better.
column2: Now you're here. Who are your "friends"?

column1: It's about the Director.
column2: Again?

column1: That's where we get rid of the traces of him although we never truly succeeded.
column2: I've been looking for him.  Do you know where he is?

column1: Don't be deceived, Irene.  These are just the clothes.  He has to wear them. Something I could never do.
column2: What's wrong with him?

column1: Okay, how tall did you used to be?
column2: Six one.

column1: You okay, Jerome?
column2: Yeah.  You want to go dancing tonight?

column1: What's wrong with it?
column2: I think I'd better choose the menu. After all, you're learning how to be me, I'm not learning how to be you.

column1: Suit yourself.
column2: Listen, I don't want you to think I'm ungrateful --I know you and that little broker--what do you call him?

column1: German.
column2: You're both going to a lot of trouble-- Maybe you can con somebody into believing you're me to get your foot in the door--but once you're inside, you're on your own. I'm sure you're sincere... ...but I was being groomed for something like this myself. Even without the accident I don't think I would have made it. My point is--how the hell do you expect to pull this off?

column1: I don't know exactly, Jerome.
column2: At least you're honest.  Call me by my middle name--Eugene--If you're going to be Jerome, you may as well start getting used to it.

column1: I have to know where you come from.
column2: If anybody asks, tell them the truth-- your family disowns you.  You are a disappointment, Jerome.

column1: What about this?
column2: Wrong color.  It's silver.  It's not easy living up to this.

column1: It needs work.
column2: You had to be a right-hander.

column1: You really need that much?
column2: More than that. You'll get used to it.

column1: God, what wouldn't you do to leave the planet?
column2: Leave?  Just a few million years ago every atom in this hair--in our bodies--was a part of a star. I don't see it as leaving.  I see it as going home.

column1: It's not too late to back out.
column2: You don't know what a relief it is not to be me. Are you sure you want the job?

column1: What about you?  What's in this for you, Eugene?
column2: Listen, I bag this stuff anyway.  It may as well pay my rent.

column1: Who died?
column2: The Mission Director.

column1: You wish.
column2: They found him in his office this morning-- beaten so bad they had to check his nametag.

column1: What an act of benevolence--a service to the community.  So that's it.  Now there's nothing between you and ignition.
column2: He was still warm when they confirmed.

column1: This calls for a celebration.  Doesn't it?
column2: The place is crawling with Hoovers.

column1: That's not the point.
column2: Hey, how much of you can be there?  Even if the "J. Edgars" do find something, in a week--  you'll be slightly out of their jurisdiction.  Come on, we've got to get drunk immediately.

column1: Let's get out of here.
column2: You're right, there's more atmosphere where you're going.

column1: I gotta stop!!  I gotta stop!!
column2: Keep going!!  Keep going!!

column1: At least up there your piss will be worth something.  You'll all be showering in it, right?
column2: And drinking it.  It's like Evian by the time it's filtered.

column1: 11.15 to the port.  A maintenance crew.
column2: How long do you stay up there before you go?

column1: A day or so.
column2: I still can't believe they're sending you to the Belt--you of all people--never meant to be born, on a mission to discover the origin of life.

column1: Up there they wouldn't be a problem.
column2: You know I'm scared of heights.

column1: I'm sorry.  I'm sorry.
column2: It's okay, Eugene.

column1: You know I wasn't drunk--I knew what I was doing when I walked in front of that car--
column2: --What car?--Go to sleep.

column1: It's all right.
column2: I'm proud of you, Vincent.

column1: Call German.
column2: Any particular reason?

column1: We can't stay here.
column2: What are you talking about?

column1: What makes them think that?
column2: They found my eyelash.

column1: Where?
column2: In a corridor.

column1: Come on--we're taking off.
column2: I'm not going anywhere.  Less than a week to go. Not on your life--

column1: --You don't understand, they'll make the connection, they'll hoover again.  We should cut our losses.
column2: Where is your head, Jerome?  You're acting like a guilty man.  They won't marry the eyelash to you.  They won't believe that one of their elite navigators could have suckered them for the last five years.

column1: They'll recognize me.
column2: How could they recognize you? I don't recognize you. Anyway, you don't have a choice. You run, you may as well sign a confession, turn us both in right now. No, we stick this out-- find out what we can but change nothing. This is a minor inconvenience is all it is. We've taken worse heat than this. Jesus, if I'd known you were going to go belly up on me at the last fucking gasp, I wouldn't have bothered. You can't quit on me now. I've put too much into this. Besides, this stuff is mine. I had other offers, you know. I could have rented myself out to somebody with a spine. You want me to wheel in there and finish the job myself? We'll take off all right, from pad 18 just like we planned.

column1: And keep your lashes on your lids where they belong.  How could you be so careless?
column2: I'm sorry.  I think I was crying.

column1: You really had other offers?
column2: I'm sure I could have.

column1: So it's not just the Hoovers who've got you rattled.
column2: You're the one who said not to change anything. She's my ear to the investigation.

column1: Is that all?
column2: I've got enough on my mind without that.

column1: If you say so.  The stripe.
column2: Good choice.

column1: Not thirsty?  We've got enough virgin samples to last us the week.
column2: I don't feel too good.  I think I'm still drunk from last night.

column1: Never stopped you before.  And for God's sake stop plucking your hair. Someone went to a lot of trouble to make sure you wouldn't go bald.
column2: If I were you I'd worry about myself.  Haven't you forgotten something?

column1: How was your evening?
column2: Complicated.  I couldn't stop her apologizing.

column1: You are a catch. No doubt she's worried that she would lower the standard of your offspring. Everybody wants to "breed up". What's wrong with her?
column2: You know how it is with these altered births --somebody told her she's not going to live forever and she's been preparing to die ever since.

column1: You're not thinking of telling her, are you?
column2: Of course not.  But she's have to know eventually.

column1: Where are we going?
column2: I'm sorry.  I've got plans.

column1: Again?
column2: She's already got her doubts.  I have to act like nothing's wrong.

column1: Where are you taking her?
column2: Michael's.

column1: Everybody goes there.
column2: You may as well invite her here.

column1: Will you be okay?
column2: Don't worry about your little pin cushion. To be honest, I'm looking forward to having the place to myself.

column1: We'll still be able to talk when I'm away. The conversation will just keep getting longer.
column2: How long?

column1: By the time I'm at the Belt, you phone and say, "How are you?"  Forty-five minutes later I reply, "Not bad.  How are you?"
column2: I guess I'd better have something important to say if it takes that long to get an answer.

column1: Hello?
column2: How would you like to be yourself for the day?

column1: How are you, Jerome?
column2: Not bad, Jerome.

column1: How the hell did you get here.
column2: I could always walk.  I've been faking it.

column1: I have your samples ready.
column2: Have you forgotten?  I don't need any samples where I'm going.

column1: Why have you done this?
column2: In case you get back before I do.

column1: Where are you going?
column2: I'm travelling too.

column1: Thank you.
column2: I got the better end of the deal.  I just lent you my body--you lent me your dream.

column1: First, we may as well decide on gender. Have you given it any thought?
column2: We would like Vincent to have a brother... you know, to play with.

column1: You've already specified blue eyes, dark hair and fair skin.  I have taken the liberty of eradicating any potentially prejudicial conditions - premature baldness, myopia, alcoholism and addictive susceptibility, propensity for violence and obesity--
column2: --We didn't want--diseases, yes.

column1: Anything I've forgotten?
column2: We want him--we were hoping he would get married and have children.  We'd like grandchildren.

column1: I understand.  That's already been taken care of.  Now you appreciate I can only work with the raw material I have at my disposal but for a little extra...I could also attempt to insert sequences associated with enhanced mathematical or musical ability.
column2: Antonio, the choir...

column1: What will happen to the others?
column2: They are not babies, Maria, merely "human possibilities".

column1: What do you think?
column2: I think I could do something  provided you know what you're doing and you can meet the terms.

column1: Vincent...Vincent...
column2: German, is that you?

column1: He has the heart of an ox.  He could run through a Goddamn wall--if he could still run. Actually, he was a big college swimming star.
column2: I hope he's not just a body.

column1: No problem.  Before he dropped out he was an honor student, the right majors--
column2: How do I square the accident?
That's the hair color in his profile?

column1: Yeah.
column2: I'd have to bleach my hair.

column1: Why are you inventing problems?  You two are a couple of goddam clones.  You look so right together, I want to double my fee.
column2: How tall are you?

column1: You can wear lifts.
column2: Even with lifts I'm never that tall.

column1: My wife and I--we're thinking of starting a family.
column2: Why not?

column1: These new personality corrections I've been reading about.
column2: You worried about the cost?

column1: Not that.
column2: They said the same thing about myopia and obesity. You think your children would be less human if they were less violent, angry, spiteful? Maybe they'd be more human. From where I sit the world could stand a little improving.

column1: Hugo!  I've found him!
column2: I've found him too.

column1: No bother.
column2: I've been asked to compile a log for the investigators--they want to know everyone's whereabouts last night.

column1: Can that be, er, verified?  Were you alone?
column2: No it can't be verified.  Yes I was alone.

column1: Looks bad, doesn't it, Irene? What about you? Where were you last night?
column2: I was at home.

column1: Were you alone?
column2: Yes.

column1: So we don't know for sure about you, either.
column2: No.

column1: Why don't we say we were together?
column2: Why would we do that?

column1: I'm sorry.  I didn't mean anything.
column2: We were just looking.

column1: Have they found our friend?
column2: Friend?

column1: It was a mercy-killing after all.
column2: They found an eyelash.

column1: Where?
column2: In the South Wing.

column1: Does it have a name?
column2: Just some In-Valid.  Vincent--  --somebody.

column1: Perhaps we ought to celebrate, Irene.
column2: You celebrate, Jerome?

column1: You didn't know?
column2: Yes...yes...

column1: You're angry--
column2: Why would I be angry?  It was beautiful.

column1: I envy you, Jerome.
column2: You'll be next.

column1: It's here.  My heart.  I'm careful--weekly check-ups.  I'm on a drug maintenance program, blood thinners, diet--  I just want you to know what you'd be getting yourself into.
column2: What exactly is wrong?

column1: Of course I think about it every day.
column2: Of course.

column1: So you didn't do it after all.
column2: I guess somebody beat me to it.

column1: What is this place?
column2: You've never been here?  Let me order for you.

column1: Why are we leaving?
column2: Those checks take forever.

column1: What about the car?
column2: Let's walk.

column1: Who are they?
column2: It's not safe.  I shouldn't have brought you here.

column1: I can't.
column2: Come on.

column1: My medication.  I left it back there.
column2: We'll get it later.  Irene, please.

column1: What happened?
column2: You remember the '99 Chrysler LeBaron? It's the exact height of the front fender.  Looked right instead of left.

column1: So you're not so smart after all. I want you to know--if it ever came to it-- I'd be willing to get an ovum from the Egg Bank. In fact, I'd rather use a donor egg-- --if it came to it.
column2: But "if it came to it" then it couldn't have your--  --nose.  How perfect does your child have to be?

column1: You hypocrite. Do you think for one moment you'd be doing what you're doing if it wasn't for who you are--what you are? Don't you get any satisfaction knowing that your children will be able to live to a ripe old age unless they do something foolish?
column2: That's precisely what scaresme--that they won't do anything foolish or courageous or anything--worth a Goddamn.

column1: What is it?
column2: I forgot something--something at home. I'll see you later.

column1: --when you go away.
column2: We could go together one day.

column1: A year is a long time.
column2: Not so long--just once around the sun.

column1: Jerome...never shy.  Pisses on command. You've got a beautiful cock.  I ever told you that, Jerome?
column2: Only every time I'm in here.

column1: If everything goes to plan, this could be the last time I see you for a while.  One week to go.  Please tell me you're the least bit excited.
column2: I'll tell you at the end of the week.

column1: I've got enough here.
column2: Need any more, you can always get it off his shoes.

column1: What's this, Lamar?
column2: New policy.

column1: Flight got you nervous?
column2: There's a problem, Lamar.

column1: Just remember, Lamar, I could have gone up and back and nobody would have been the wiser--
column2: --Unfortunately my son's not all that they promised.  But then, who know what he could do.

column1: What are you doing?
column2: I can't do this.

column1: I told you, the government pays.  It's all taken care of.
column2: No, you don't understand. I can't.

column1: The doctor will give you something.
column2: I'm not doing it.

column1: --I've read your profile.  I don't know about the father but you carry enough hereditary factors on your own.  You can have other children.
column2: Not like this one.

column1: The name?  For the certificate.
column2: Antonio--

column1: What the hell.  What is this?  A joke?
column2: No joke, Lieutenant.

column1: Where's the guy we saw in the beginning -- what's his name...?
column2: Parker.  We found him knocked out in the can.

column1: Hey, I don't have answers for this. I just brought you down here because of the sword.
column2: Am I supposed to believe that this guy got shot in the chest six times at point blank range and just got up and walked out?

column1: Lieutenant Bedsoe?
column2: Not now.  I'm busy.

column1: Lieutenant?
column2: What?  Who are you?  What do you want?

column1: My name is Jennifer Hillman.  I'm an archaeologist.  I read in the paper about the murder yesterday and I thought I should come talk to you.
column2: Talk to me about what?

column1: What do you think?
column2: They appear to be authentic.

column1: Why are people walking around New York with swords, dressed in mid evil clothing?
column2: Well, technically it's not mid evil - - it's Renaissance.

column1: You didn't see this.  Understand?
column2: Yes.

column1: Did you find a sword?  An old sword?
column2: Yeah -- how'd you know that?

column1: Hey Lieutenant, the boys in robbery have something I think you should look at.
column2: What is it?

column1: A tape from the surveillance camera at the First National Bank.  It was robbed this morning.
column2: Really?  I want to make sure that I understand what you're telling me, Greley.  A crime was committed in New York City?  That is news.

column1: That's not all, Lieutenant.  Wait until you see the tape.  It's unbelievable.
column2: I'd like you to see this.

column1: Good -- also, give it to the papers and TV.
column2: Y'know, the guys in robbery are gonna get kind of upset.  We're stepping on their toes of this one.

column1: Tough.
column2: It's not a homicide, Lieutenant.

column1: This ties in with Nash.
column2: We don't have any proof of that.

column1: Anything from the bank?
column2: We sent the prints we lifted from the counter at the bank to the State computers, the FBI and interpol. Nothing.

column1: He had to come from somewhere.
column2: I think it was England.

column1: I asked the State Department to check with our Embassies and Interpol to see if there were any similar occurrences like the bank.  Two weeks ago in London Charles Redder from the Bronx was mugged in Hyde Park.
column2: So?

column1: I'm in the middle of an interrogation, Captain.
column2: Interrogation's over, Bedsoe.

column1: What?
column2: Cut him loose.  The D.A. says you ain't got shit on this guy.

column1: You don't understand.  About seven years ago we found the body of a guy named Vasilnic in Jersey.  A week later in the parking lot of Madison Square Garden we found Iman Fasil. Three days after that Luman Castageer was found in an alley.  The fourth body we've never been able to identify.  All four men died from decapitation.  Nash was our primary suspect -- but he disappeared.
column2: It's circumstantial.

column1: For Chrissake!  Gimme a break.  The guy disappears for seven years and as soon as he comes back it starts again.
column2: I see your point, Bedsoe, but I have to look at this from the law's point of view.  There's something missing here.  It's something I'm sure you've come across many times in your career.  It's called evidence.  Get me a murder weapon with his fingerprints on it.  Find me an eye witness.  Dig up a motive.  Until then we don't have a case against him.

column1: Detective Bedsoe.
column2: Lieutenant.

column1: When did you get back?
column2: A few days ago.

column1: Where were you last night around nine?
column2: I already told you.  I took a walk.

column1: Tell me again.  Where'd you go?
column2: Central Park.

column1: Doesn't it scare you walk through the park at night?
column2: No.  I don't scare easy.

column1: Where have you been for the last seven years?
column2: Around.

column1: She was a good woman.
column2: You didn't bring me here to talk about her.

column1: I brought you here to talk about him. Do you know him?
column2: No.

column1: You sure?
column2: He doesn't look familiar -- but then he'd probably be easier to identity with his head.

column1: I'm gonna nail you, Nash.  That's a promise.
column2: Is that it?

column1: No.  I'm telling you right now, the next person's head that comes off is gonna be yours.
column2: Lieutenant, you're really frightening me.

column1: Good evening, Lieutenant.
column2: No -- it isn't.  A cop died today and the other is barely holding on.  I want some answers, Nash.

column1: I'm sorry about that -- but I had nothing to do with it.
column2: That doesn't mean you don't know what's going on.  You're connected to this guy somehow.  He's after you -- just like the others were.

column1: Seven years ago I interviewed a guy. He said he saw two men fighting in an alley with swords.  One cut off the others head.  He shot the surviving guy twenty times and he got right back up and stabbed him.
column2: Maybe he was a lousy shot.

column1: Most people would show some sign of fear with a gun in their face.
column2: Most people are afraid of death.

column1: Yes -- I think it is.
column2: Hey -- somebody want to gimme a hand here?

column1: You'll have no need for that, Highlander.
column2: Since we hardly know each other, I'm sure you'll understand if I hold one to it for awhile.

column1: I know that weapon.  It belonged to Juan Romeriz.  He's dead?
column2: Aye.

column1: You?
column2: No.  He was my brother.  He died at anothers hand.

column1: We too are brothers, Macleod.  In fact, you have more family than you think.
column2: Who are you?

column1: Thomas Cavenaugh.  I am a teacher of sorts.  Like Romeriz I help those newly acquainted with our life.
column2: I learned my fill from Romeriz.

column1: The prize?  So much blood so that in the end the one that remains will be mortal again.  So much pain so that the winner can grow old and have children.  The prize hardly seems worth the cost of it.
column2: There will be more to the prize than that.  Power will come with it -- and it must be used for good.

column1: The days of magic are ending.  The world is changing.
column2: Aye -- yet one such as I who has wandered this world for nearly nine centuries can remember back to other days of change.  Days of Robin of the Hood and Arthur Pendragon.  They were real enough once, but they drifted into men's dreams and became legend - - as we shall do one day.

column1: You cannot run from your destiny, Conner.
column2: Perhaps -- but if I must face it, let it find me, for I shall search for it no more.

column1: Must you do that?
column2: What?

column1: Sing.
column2: It is a beautiful day.  I am merely enjoying it.

column1: Can't you enjoy it quietly?
column2: Are you always this pleasant?  You know what you're problem is?

column1: Life.  You've stopped living it.  You look, but you do not see.  You listen but, you do not hear.
column2: I hear you.

column1: The river.
column2: That's all?

column1: Do you not hear the wind in the trees?  The songs of the birds.  The horses breath?  There is a whole world around you. Alive.  Living.  Feel it -- become part of it.  Live your life, Highlander.  It's going to be a long one.
column2: That is what bothers me.

column1: I'm leaving.
column2: Leaving what?

column1: England.  There is nothing for me here anymore.
column2: And what do you think you will find in another land?

column1: Maybe myself.
column2: Then it's worth the journey.

column1: Thank you, Thomas.
column2: For what?

column1: For being a friend when I needed one. I hope our paths cross again.
column2: I'm sure they will.

column1: As friends -- always as friends.
column2: We cannot write our destiny, Macleod. In the end it could be you and me.

column1: That is a thought that doesn't please me.
column2: If it came down to it what would you do?

column1: You're looking a wee bit green, Thomas.
column2: The sea and I don't agree with each other.  Where we off to?

column1: France.
column2: How long is the voyage?

column1: Not long.  We should arrive in the morning.  Are you going to be alright?
column2: Me?  Of course.

column1: What are we doing here?
column2: Living.  Remember?

column1: To ask her to dance.
column2: She's the King's cousin.

column1: Yes.
column2: What worries you?

column1: You've been seeing her for over a month now.  Have you learned nothing from the past?
column2: I've learned that a man can only go so along living alone.

column1: That was two hundred and fifty years ago -- and the pain still scars your heart.  Would you live that pain again?
column2: No.  What am I to do?

column1: Well?
column2: It's done.

column1: I'll go first.
column2: No -- I will.

column1: I stood up first.
column2: That doesn't matter.

column1: You can go first.
column2: No -- after you.

column1: It will be a good harvest this year.
column2: Can you really tell from doing that?

column1: What do you think?
column2: I think you just like to eat dirt.

column1: I think my Sarah fancies you, Conner.
column2: She's a treasure she is.

column1: Your words are kind and they flatter me -- but I think of her as a sister. Besides, you hardly know me.
column2: I know that for six months you've worked hard and asked for little. That you're a good and honest man. What more need I know?

column1: This cannot be.
column2: It is.  Do not ask me how.  I do not know.  I must leave, for if I stayed others would surely hear of this and worse than they will come.

column1: Agreed.
column2: I would like to say goodbye.

column1: How comes it your are not afraid?
column2: Would'st you harm one who comes to aid you?

column1: I've come to strike a bargain with you.  I wish to learn the power of changing.
column2: And what would'st I gain from this bargain?

column1: Your life.
column2: How?

column1: We had a bargain.  You promised.
column2: I lied.

column1: Aye?
column2: Where do you go when your mind drifts?

column1: Different places.
column2: The past?

column1: Sometimes.
column2: Why is it you never talk to me about Scotland -- your life there.

column1: I cannot stay.
column2: Why not?

column1: Leaving?  For how long?
column2: You'll no see me again.

column1: Why?
column2: I cannot explain.

column1: Do you love me, Conner?
column2: Aye.

column1: Then take me with you.
column2: Where I'm going you cannot follow.

column1: Why are you doing this?
column2: Because, it's for the best.  There are somethings that are better left unexplained.

column1: Electro magnetic soundings indicate we've only got a few inches of rock left before we reach the main chamber.
column2: Any idea how big the cavern is on the other side?

column1: Huge.
column2: What are you hoping to find inside?

column1: You guys are from the British museum, right?
column2: No -- we're from Strange facts and mysteries.  It's a syndicated show out of..

column1: My name is Jennifer Hillman.  I was at the police station earlier today--
column2: I remember you.

column1: I was wondering if I could talk to you?
column2: Are you a cop?

column1: No.  I'm an archaeologist.
column2: What do you want?

column1: To talk to you.
column2: I don't think we have anything to talk about, Miss Hillman.

column1: Corpses?
column2: Yes.  We found another man outside a site we were working at in Scotland.

column1: Yes.  How did you know?
column2: A lucky guess.

column1: I don't think so -- but then, maybe you've can guess how a guy with a sword could rob the First national Bank this afternoon -- and get shot six times in the chest by the guard and still get up and walk out?
column2: He was wearing a bullet proof vest.

column1: Bullet proof vests don't bleed.
column2: You got me.

column1: Why do I feel that you know what's going on?
column2: Are you the type of person who takes advice, Miss Hillman?

column1: If it's good advice.
column2: This is.  Go home.  Stay out of this.

column1: Where did you get it?
column2: It's mine.  It's been in my family for years.  It belonged to my great, great, great grandmother.

column1: You're hurt.
column2: I'll be fine.

column1: What's going on?  Why did he call you Macleod?
column2: Because it's my name.

column1: Then who's Russell Nash?
column2: I don't know anymore.

column1: You are a very persistent woman, Miss Hillman.
column2: Jennifer.

column1: Why do you stare at me like that?
column2: You remind me of someone I used to know.

column1: I don't have any answers for you.
column2: Who was that man last night?

column1: I don't know.
column2: Then how did he know your name?

column1: Do you always walk around with a sword?
column2: New York is dangerous place.

column1: You talk to me -- but you don't answer my questions.  I guess I'll have to talk to Lieutenant Bedsoe.
column2: About what?

column1: It probably wouldn't interest you. It's something I read in a mythology book.
column2: I'm interested in mythology.

column1: No.
column2: You look like you have.

column1: Yes.
column2: Meet me Tratino's at nine.

column1: Why?
column2: I told you I'm interested in mythology.  We can talk about it more.

column1: Good evening.
column2: You're twenty minutes late.

column1: You didn't answer my question.
column2: I know.

column1: You have an interesting accent. Where are you from?
column2: Why?

column1: I'm just trying to place you.
column2: I've lived all over the world.

column1: You're not an easy person to get to know.
column2: Why?  Because I don't give up all my secrets?

column1: How come you wanted to meet tonight?
column2: I wanted to get to know you better.

column1: That makes you uncomfortable?
column2: A little -- yes.  My interest in coming here is profession.

column1: Is it?
column2: Yes -- it is.

column1: Alright.  In the shop you mentioned something about--
column2: --the Calan.  Do you know who they are?

column1: Have you told Lieutenant Bedsoe your theory?
column2: No.

column1: Why not?
column2: Because I don't feel like sitting in a rubber room for forty-eight hours.

column1: Let me ask you something else.  At the excavation site in Scotland, the tunnel leading into the cavern had collapsed.  The day we found the body someone had moved the rocks, making a hole in the collapsed section.  What bothers me is that we found the rocks from the hole on our side of the tunnel wall.
column2: So?

column1: Why would someone pull on the rocks to get in the cavern?  They were wedged in tight.  They couldn't get a grip on them.  They would have had much more strength pushing on them.
column2: If they pushed the rocks you would have found them on the other side of the cavern wall.

column1: That would mean they'd been trapped in there--
column2: --for three hundred years.

column1: How could that be?  People don't live for three hundred years.
column2: Not unless they're immortal.

column1: Would you like to see it?
column2: I've seen it.

column1: On the back it has--
column2: --the crest of a lion and a dragon and a single word:  Courage.

column1: It came from your great, great, great grandmother, Isabelle Tourez, who lived in Paris and died on the guillotine in 1789 -- alone -- and unmarried.  The ring was given to her by someone who loved her -- but knew that it could never be.
column2: You?

column1: You wanted the truth -- now you have it.
column2: And the other one -- he is like you?

column1: Where will you go now?
column2: It will end tonight.

column1: Must you fight him?
column2: He will not stop until it is over.

column1: He's in there!
column2: Get out.

column1: Be careful, Conner.
column2: Conner?

column1: What now?
column2: Now I can start to live.  To feel. To grow old and live each day without the promise of another.

column1: Just a little.  Who knows what we're going to find in there.  It could be a huge excavation.  A little friendly PR never hurt.
column2: Where is the film crew from the British Museum?

column1: They've had a little car trouble. I'm afraid they won't be here until after dark.
column2: Then we shouldn't break into the cavern until tomorrow morning.  This could be a very important find.  I want it documented.

column1: We're holding the workers down below.
column2: Why?

column1: Someone broke into the cavern last night.
column2: What?  How?

column1: He's fine.  He swears he never left his post for a moment.  He heard a noise and when he went back to look they were already inside.
column2: How could they get by him?

column1: We found him this morning.
column2: What's that next to him?

column1: Incredible.  The cloth -- the buttons -- it looks to be mid sixteen hundreds.  It's a remarkable duplication.
column2: I don't think it is a duplication.

column1: It has to be.
column2: And this?

column1: You stayed here again last night?
column2: I was working on the cataloging.

column1: Jennifer, there is more to life than work.
column2: I know, Paul.

column1: Do you?  Then why don't you go out? Meet someone.  Make a life for yourself instead of hiding away in the past?
column2: I like my work.

column1: I'm having some people over tonight for dinner -- I'd like you come.
column2: We'll see.

column1: It flatters me you remember, old one. It's been what... two hundred years?
column2: It's not been long enough.  What witchcraft is this?

column1: Impressive -- is it not?  The problem is I can only keep the illusion for a few minutes.  I need more power to hold the form longer.  I need the Highlander.  Where is he?
column2: I do not know -- and even if I did...

column1: Oh -- I almost forgot.  Your head.
column2: It does not come off as easily as the young ones.

column1: Highlander -- I had hoped it would be you.
column2: This cannot be.

column1: I am stronger than you, Highlander.
column2: That's what the Kurgan said.

column1: Fine -- I've waited over three centuries.  I can wait a little longer.
column2: Why did you wait?

column1: It was not by choice.  A small matter of a mountain falling down on us.  We were trapped inside.  When the time of the Gathering came the urge to go was so strong we tried to claw through rock with our bare hands.  What you thought was the end -- was not.  This is the end.  We are the last of our kind, Macleod.
column2: It will not end tonight.

column1: You know it's not safe here for you.
column2: I know.

column1: The police still have a lot of questions for Russell Nash.
column2: I can take care of myself.

column1: It isn't over, is it, Conner?
column2: No.

column1: How can that be?
column2: I don't know.

column1: Is there anything else you need?
column2: No -- I'm fine.  Thank you.

column1: I'm glad you've come home, Conner.
column2: Me too.

column1: Would you care for some water, Conner?
column2: Aye -- that I would, lass.

column1: Don't leave us, Conner.
column2: It's not for me to decide.

column1: Don't cry, wee one.  It's a better place I go to.
column2: I love you, Conner.

column1: Aye -- I know, Las -- and I have never loved anyone more.
column2: I'll no forget you.

column1: You kept it?
column2: Yes.

column1: What are you doing?
column2: I shouldn't have come back here.  It was a mistake.

column1: Is it a mistake for someone to go to the ones who love them when they're in trouble?
column2: Yes -- when their troubles can harm them.

column1: I heard voices downstairs.  Is everything alright?
column2: Fine.

column1: What will you do?
column2: There's nothing I can do.  I'll wait. One way or another soon it will all be over soon.

column1: I could have ended it tonight, but I didn't.
column2: Why?

column1: I don't know.  He is the stronger one.  He has a power--
column2: You also have a power, Conner.  It is why you have survived.

column1: Do not underestimate the power of your heart.  Your dreams live there.
column2: My dreams died long ago.

column1: Did they?  You are only a man, different than most -- but still a man.  You feel the same -- want the same.  You want to live.
column2: I haven't lived life -- I've hidden from it.  I've existed in the shadows.

column1: Dear, sweet, Rachel.  Men's lifes are measured by the good they do.
column2: If you search your heart you know all the good you have done.  Your strength comes from your heart -- because in your heart you know what you are fighting for is good and just.  This room is filled with memories. If you search through them you can find the good -- the difference you have made.  And now, it is for you to make the greatest difference of all. Look in your heart, Conner -- and you will see the good that you have done.

column1: Good afternoon, Mr. Parker.
column2: Good afternoon...  ... Shirley.

column1: Would you like to deposit this in your account?
column2: No.  The money, please.

column1: This check is for sixteen thousand dollars.  That's a lot of cash to be carrying around.
column2: I can take care of myself.

column1: ERRR-IIIC!
column2: And tell your wife to stop making so much noise! We're food to these damn animals.

column1: Still, you have survived the dinosaurs before. You saved those kids.
column2: A few of us survived. A lot more died. And we were better prepared and better armed.  How many days have they been missing?

column1: After what you've seen today, you really think your son could be alive?
column2: He's smart, Dr. Grant. And he knows so much about dinosaurs.

column1: Eric!
column2: Quiet!

column1: This is how you make dinosaurs?
column2: This is how you play God.

column1: Do you think it goes all the way across?
column2: One way to find out.

column1: Oh, my God.
column2: What is it?

column1: First off let me say as a dinosaur enthusiasts, Amanda and I have admired your work for years.
column2: It is truly, whats the word? Inspiring.

column1: Amanda and I, well, we just love the outdoors. Heck we've been on pretty much any adventure tour they can come up with: Galapagos, K2, the Nile...
column2: We even have two seats reserved aboard the first commercial moon flight.

column1: ...once-in-a-lifetime.
column2: We've arranged for a private airplane to take us flying over Isla Sorna. And we want you to be our guide.

column1: Well, I'm no aviation specialist. But I do know it's hell of a lot lower than anyone else.
column2: From what I understand, it's pretty much whatever we want.

column1: Amanda, Honey! Dr. Grant says it's a bad idea!
column2: What?

column1: He says it's a bad idea!
column2: What's a bad idea?

column1: We can't just...
column2: Don't worry, honey. We'll circle around and come back.

column1: Her new boyfriend.
column2: A friend. We were vacationing. Eric wanted to see the island and the dinosaurs, so Ben found a guy who would take them parasailing. They never came back.

column1: Sorry.
column2: Nothing you haven't seen before.

column1: How much weight have you lost?
column2: Twenty, twenty-fire pounds. I've been swimming at the Y.

column1: You hate to swim.
column2: People change.

column1: You look good.
column2: So do you.

column1: Stop that. Dr. Grant says this is dangerous territory.
column2: Well we should split up or something. We can cover twice the area.

column1: No, Dr. Grant says...
column2: Dr. Grant says this, Dr. Grant says that...

column1: Well what's the use of hiring an expert if your not going to listen to him?
column2: Because "Dr. Grant" isn't looking for Eric. Dr. Grant is looking for the coast.

column1: Fine...and when the Tricyclatops comes after you, don't come crying to me.
column2: Oh, don't worry about that.

column1: What?
column2: Nothing.

column1: What did you say?
column2: Nothing.

column1: What did you say!
column2: Just drop it Paul!

column1: Young adult.
column2: Eric...

column1: That's him. Thats Eric!
column2: I filmed this the morning they left.

column1: I'm sorry Amanda. I am. And I'm sorry for the things I said about him.
column2: No, it's...

column1: I know you liked Ben. I had no right to...
column2: Its not about him. It's Eric. He's alone out here somewhere. Our baby is all alone.

column1: Eric! Are you here?
column2: Eric!

column1: Udesky.
column2: He's this way.

column1: It's not safe.
column2: We have to help him.

column1: We can't just stop looking. Eric and Dr. Grant are out there somewhere.
column2: I want to find them too, but we can't do a bit of good right now. For every scary thing we saw in the daylight, I'll bet there ten times more of 'em at night.  Am I right?

column1: Well what?
column2: Well damn it. I don't speak ill of the dead. What I'm trying to say is, its was just a crazy accident. The exact same thing could have happened if he was with me. You can't go beating yourself up about it.

column1: This wouldn't happen if he was with you. I mean, you drive five miles below the speed limit. I totaled three cars in fives years.
column2: That one time was just the bumper.

column1: I don't know. I don't have it with me.
column2: When did you have it last?

column1: I don't remember
column2: Think.

column1: What?...WHAT!?
column2: I loaned it to Nash. He must have had it on him when he...

column1: Sweetheart, you're okay.  You're okay.  You're okay.
column2: Never had a doubt. Never did. Us Kirby men, we stick around, huh?

column1: Eric, its okay. You'll be right behind me.
column2: We're not going anywhere, I promise.

column1: Paul! Where is he? Can you see him?
column2: I'm trying! That thing took him down this way!

column1: My own kid was right in front of me and I didn't do a damn thing.
column2: You couldn't have made that jump.

column1: I should have tried. It should have been me on that beach back there, not Billy.
column2: How would you have helped Eric?  He needs you, Paul. He needs us.

column1: He could have died.
column2: But he didn't. And neither did you. And I'm glad about that.

column1: We should try fishing again.
column2: You mean it?
