column1: Either that, or the government will firebomb it back to the Stone Age.
column2: I would completely support that.

column1: You see, that's just the thing. Paul and I have special permission to fly low.
column2: How low?

column1: He's with a man named Ben Hildebrand.
column2: Who's that?

column1: I thought we weren't suppose to yell.
column2: Here!

column1: He's right. A predator wouldn't leave a kill wounded.
column2: He's not a kill, he's still alive.

column1: We need to stick to the plan. Head for the coast.
column2: What about Eric and Dr. Grant?

column1: Going to the coast was Alan's idea. If he's alive, thats where he's headed.
column2: What about Eric?

column1: You had the phone the whole time?
column2: Where is it?

column1: PAUL!
column2: DAD!

column1: Where's Dad?
column2: Just hold on.

column1: We have to keep looking for Dad. We have to.
column2: I know. I know. I want to look for him too.

column1: Let me tell you a few things about you Dad, okay? He's very very very clever, very very brave, and he loves you ever very much.
column2: He loves you too.

column1: That was Isla Nublar. This is Isla Sorna. The second island.
column2: I didn't know, there were two islands.

column1: So Mr. Kirby, tell me, when you climbed K2, did you base camp at 25- or 30,000 feet?
column2: Thirty-thousand, I think. Closer to the top.

column1: They couldnt climb up, so they were trying to get us to come down.
column2: They set a trap  They actually set a trap.

column1: I dont know.
column2: I thought you were an expert.

column1: He's probably has a better chance by the coast as it is. Figures that all the big dinosaurs would live in the center of the island.  Right?
column2: Sure.

column1: Eric!
column2: It won't hold!

column1: How was your trip? Profitable?
column2: We'll be broke in four weeks.

column1: You rented an automated litter box.
column2: It's a rapid prototyper. I feed in the scan data from the raptor skull, than the computer breaks it into thousands of slices which this thing prints, one layer on top of the other. It's the future of paleontology.

column1: Absolutely not.
column2: They're here.

column1: Even with what I pay you, you could get a better bag.
column2: No way. This is lucky. Couple years ago some buddies and I went hang gliding off these cliffs in New Zealand. Updraft sent me right into the side. BOOM!

column1: That does sound lucky.
column2: It was this strap alone that saved my life. Got caught on a rock as I was falling.

column1: Listen Alan, I really appreciate you bringing me along.
column2: The bones will be there when we get back. That's the nice thing about them. They never run away.  And besides, you got me into this. I don't intend to be alone with these people.

column1: I'm so use to seeing bones. It's weird to see skin.
column2: Mr. and Mrs. Kirby! If you look out the right you can see...

column1: Is it a rex?
column2: I don't think so.

column1: How would you classify it?
column2: Obviously a superpredator.  Suchimimus. that snout.

column1: They never got that big.
column2: Baryonyx?

column1: Not with that sail.  Spinosaurus Aegypticus.
column2: I don't remember that on InGen's list.

column1: It looks intact.
column2: We should take it with us to signal any planes.

column1: We could co-write a paper.
column2: Ah yes, the first rule of academics. Publish or perish.

column1: ALAN!
column2: KEEP GOING!

column1: We need to keep moving.
column2: Alan, I want to tell you that I'm so sorry about the...

column1: You have to believe me. I did it with the best intentions.
column2: Some of the worst things imaginable have been done with the best intentions. You rushed in with no thought to the consequences, to yourself or anyone else.  You're no better than the people who built this place.

column1: I CAN GET HIM!
column2: NO!

column1: Hmm?
column2: He's three. Why don't you wait till he's a little older?

column1: He used to know me.
column2: Sorry, Alan it's been six years.

column1: So, Mark's working at the State Department now.
column2: Really?  What do you do there?

column1: Anything good?
column2: Raptors, mostly.

column1: You remember the sounds they made?
column2: I try not to.

column1: We've done cranial scans, and raptors actually had a quite sophisticated resonating chamber. I have a theory that their ability to vocalize is the key to their social intelligence. The way they can work together as a team.
column2: You think they could talk to each other?

column1: Good luck with the fund raising.
column2: It was never easy, but before Jurassic Park, you could find money. Somewhere. Now fossils are out. Everyone wants to see a real live dinosaur.

column1: Times change Alan. But you're the still the best. I mean that.
column2: The last of my breed.

column1: I'd better get going.
column2: Let me know if I can help, Alan. Youre bad about asking for help, but please ask me. Anything, anytime.

column1: Okay. Goodbye, Ellie.
column2: Goodbye, Alan.

column1: When I met you, I thought that one day millions of years ago, all the dinosaurs became extinct. Wiped out. But you told me otherwise. When conditions changed, dinosaurs changed. They became other things. They evolved.
column2: A well-accepted theory.

column1: Eric, your parents are both here.
column2: In Costa Rica?

column1: They'll never make it. I mean, they can't manage when the cable goes out.
column2: You'd be surprised what people can do when they have too.

column1: You're Alan Grant, aren't you?  I read both of your books.
column2: Which one do you prefer?

column1: The first one. Before you where on the island. You liked dinosaurs back then.
column2: Back then, they hadn't tried to eat me.

column1: When InGen cleared out, they left a lot of stuff behind.
column2: Any weapons, radios?

column1: Found this, but the battery's dead.
column2: It's a wonder you aren't. I'm amazed, Eric. I barely lasted 30 hours. You lasted eight weeks.

column1: Is that all it's been? I thought it was longer.
column2: The important thing is we both made it. That's something we have in common.

column1: Did you read Malcolm's book?
column2: Yeah.

column1: What did you think?
column2: I dunno. I mean, it was kind of preachy. Chaos-this, chaos-that. And like, to me, the guy seemed kind of high on himself.

column1: Know what this is?
column2: A raptor claw. I use to have one. A fossil.

column1: How much of this island have you explored?
column2: I stayed pretty close to the compound, Figured if anyone came to look for me, that's where they'd start.

column1: We need to head for the coast.
column2: Are you sure?

column1: Why?
column2: Closer you get to the water, the bigger things get.

column1: We climb down to the barge and follow the river out to the ocean. With any luck, the Costa Rican coast guard will pick us up.
column2: Then we go home?

column1: Do you have any kids?
column2: No. Although I've studied them in the wild.

column1: I have a theory that there's two kinds of boys. Those who want to be astronomers and those who want to be astronauts.
column2: I want to be an astronaut.

column1: See, I was the opposite. I never understood why anyone would want to go into space. It's so dangerous. You do one thing wrong and you're dead. The astronomer -- or the paleontologist -- get to study these amazing things from a place of complete safety. And truthfully, everything you really need to learn, you can learn it from the ground.
column2: But then you never get to go in space.

column1: Bonitas.
column2: Something must've scared them.

column1: The lady you called, how do you know she can help us?
column2: She's the one person I could always count on. And she's saved me more times than she realizes. I owe her everything.

column1: It's strikes me now I never told her that.
column2: You should.

column1: Eric, do you know what happened to the boat? that brought you here? Why did it crash?
column2: No. I couldn't see.

column1: We're safe!
column2: No we're not.

column1: What do you think is going to happen with the dinosaurs?
column2: The population will Stabilize eventually. They'll adapt to fit different roles.

column1: What can I do for you, Mr. Kirby?
column2: Well sir, I am a great admirer of yours, and I have an extremely interesting proposition to discuss. Would you let my wife and I take you to have dinner tonight? Our treat.

column1: You know, I've been traveling and I'm very tired. Maybe some other time.
column2: I guarantee it'll be worth your while.

column1: Hmmm.
column2: Now, for our wedding anniversary this year we wanted to do something really special, something...

column1: That's a very nice offer, Mr. Kirby, but I'm afraid I'm much to busy. If you like I can refer you to a number of highly qualified...
column2: No, no, see Dr. Grant, you're the best. You've seen these animals in the flesh. No one else has come close to you.

column1: That's hard to believe.
column2: Let's just say that through my business -- imports/exports, emerging markets -- I've made some friends in high places. In this case, the Costa Rican government.

column1: Dr. Grant if you'd just sit tight, we'll explain this all in a jiffy.
column2: This plane can not land!

column1: What the hell is going on? What are they doing?
column2: Establishing a perimeter. Making it safe. These guys are really good. One of them was a Green...

column1: We needed somebody who knew the lay of the land. Somebody who'd been to this island before.
column2: I have never been on this island!

column1: No, I'm sorry, but no. We'll savage what we can from the plane. Then we head for the coast. There may be a boat left, something to get us off this island.
column2: Dr. Grant, we're not leaving without our son.

column1: There is no Kirby Enterprises, is there?
column2: There is. I own a place called Kirby Paint and Title Plus. We're out in the Westgate Shopping Center in Enid, Oklahoma. The "plus" is for bathroom fixtures, fireplaces accessories, patio furniture. Stuff like that.

column1: Well that's good.
column2: But you never came across just one.

column1: Amanda!
column2: Back out! Move!

column1: Billy!
column2: It's no use, Dr. Grant. No use.

column1: Whatever you do, don't call the U.S. Embassy. They won't do a God Damn thing.
column2: Well, we don't exactly have a Costa Rican phone book here, so it will have to be somebody we know in the states. Someone we can absolutely count on to send help.

column1: How did you know?
column2: That cheap aftershave I send you every Christmas, you actually wear it.  I'm touched.  Sit down, sit down, what brings you to Mombassa?

column1: You.  Tell me, Roland, when was the last time you answered your phone?
column2: Last time I plugged it in, I suppose. Why?

column1: I got a call from a gentleman who's going to Costa Rica, or thereabouts. If he's to be believed, it's a most, uh, unique expedition.  And very well-funded.
column2: Well, I'm a very well-funded old son of a bitch.  You go.

column1: But alone?  We always had great success together, you and I.
column2: Just a little bit too much, I think.

column1: How do you mean?
column2: A true hunter doesn't mind if the animal wins.  If it escapes.  But there weren't enough escapes from you and me, Ajay.  I've decided to spend a bit less time in the company of death.  Maybe I just feel too close to it my--

column1: Sorry.  We were saying?
column2: You broke that idiot's jaw for no reason other than your boredom.  Tell the truth, Roland.  Aren't you even interested in knowing this expedition's quarry?

column1: It matches the pictures.
column2: It certainly does.

column1: Make a blind here?  Wait for the buck to return?
column2: If the nest is upwind, so are we. When he comes back, he'll know we're here before we have a chance.  The truck --

column1: You hear something?
column2: No.  I feel something.

column1: Any damage?
column2: Minimal.

column1: "Minimal" is too much.   It has to be light, it has to be strong --
column2: Light and strong, light and strong, sure, why not, it's only impossible. God save me from academics.

column1: You are an academic.
column2: Former academic.  Now I actually make things.  I don't just talk.

column1: You think I'm all talk, Eddie?
column2: It doesn't matter what I think.

column1: Is there an antidote?
column2: Like if you shoot yourself in the foot?  Wouldn't matter.  You'd be dead  before you realized you'd accidentally pulled the trigger.

column1: Why didn't you tell us about these guys, Ian?!
column2: Because I didn't know!  I don't have the faintest idea what they're doing here.

column1: Resentful.
column2: When you have a lot of time to think, it's funny who you remember.  It's the people who challenged you.  It is the quality of our opponents that gives our accomplishments meaning.  I never told you how sorry I was about what happened after we returned.

column1: I didn't know you -- weren't well.
column2: It's the lawyers.  The lawyers are finally killing me.

column1: They do have motives.  Why did you want to see me?  Your message said it was urgent.
column2: You were right -- and I was wrong. There!  Did you ever think you'd hear me say that?  Spectacularly wrong. Instead of observing those animals, I tried to control them.  I squandered an opportunity and we still know next to nothing about their lives.  Not their lives as man would have them, behind electric fences, but in the wild.  Behavior in their natural habitat, the impossible dream of any paleontologist.  I could have had it, but I let it slip away.  Thank God for Site B.

column1: What?
column2: Well?  Didn't it all seem a trifle compact to you?

column1: What are you talking about?
column2: The hatchery, in particular?  You know my initial yields had to be low, far less than one percent, that's a thousand embryos for every single live birth.  Genetic engineering on that scale implies a giant operation, not the spotless little laboratory I showed you.

column1: I don't believe you.
column2: Isla Nublar was just a showroom, Ian, something for the tourists, Site B was the factory floor.  We built it first, on Isla Sorna, eight-some miles from Nublar.

column1: No, no, no, no, no, no . . .
column2: After the accident at the park, a hurricane wiped out our facility on Site B.  We had to evacuate and leave the animals to fend for themselves. And they did.  For four years I've fought to keep them safe from human meddling, now I want you to go there and document them.

column1: Are you out of your mind?  I still have nightmares, my reputation's a joke, my leg is shot -- you think I need more of that?
column2: It would be the most extraordinary living fossil record the world has ever seen.

column1: I've been putting this together for over a year.  I have personal suggestions for your entire team, phone numbers, contact people.  They won't believe you about what they're going to see, so don't bother trying to convince them.  Just use my checkbook to get them there. I'll fund your expedition through my personal accounts, as such money and equipment as you need, but only if you leave immediately.  If we hesitate, all will be lost.
column2: John . . .

column1: I'm not going, John.
column2: Ian, you are my last chance to give something of real value to the world. I can't walk so far and leave no footprints

column1: Oh --
Do you have chromium tapes?  The others fog in high-
column2: -humidity, I know.  Highest lead density on the market.

column1: InGen is a genetics corporation, isn't it?
column2: Is that who we're really working for?!  Gene splicers?!

column1: But he's the head of InGen!
column2: You gotta be kidding.  You dragged me out of Greenpeace to be a corporate stooge?  You couldn't get anybody else?

column1: Are you looking for a problem?
column2: Everyone, keep your voices down!

column1: That was a pair bond!  A family group, even, long after that infant was nestbound!
column2: I want to see the nesting ground!

column1: The empty shells are crushed and trampled.  The young stay in the birth environment, that's conclusive!
column2: Not without a shot of the nest.

column1: Ian, you're not insane!  I'm so glad!
column2: Dr. Malcolm -- the world -- owes you an apology.

column1: And let's forget about the high hide. We can't do this kind of work up in a tower, we need to be out in the field, as close to the animals as possible.
column2: I'm not surprised stegosaur lived in a family group, but there's never been anything in the fossil record to prove the carnivores did.

column1: Why wouldn't they?  Look at hyenas, jackals, nearly all species of predator birds --
column2: That doesn't say a thing about T-rex, they could have been rogues.  Robert Burke certainly thinks they were.

column1: Hi, Dad.
column2: Kelly!  What are you doing here?

column1: Okay, Karen is expecting you in half an hour.  You only have to stay with her one night, she'll put you on a bus in the morning and your mother will be at the station when you get there.
column2: I don't even know this woman.

column1: Well, I do, and she's fantastic. She'll take you to the museum, maybe to a movie if you play your cards right.  You're going to have a fantastic time.
column2: Stop saying fantastic.  Where are you going?

column1: I can't tell you.  But I'll be back within a week.
column2: My vacation is over in a week.

column1: I'll make it up to you this summer. I promise.
column2: I'm your daughter all the time, you know.  Not just when it's convenient.

column1: Very hurtful.  Your mother tell you to say that?
column2: No, Dad.  I have thoughts of my own once in a while.

column1: Is that kid still bothering you?
column2: Which one?

column1: You know, at the bus stop.  With the hair?
column2: That was about a year ago.

column1: Well, is he?
column2: No.  Richard talked to his parents.

column1: I could come with you.
column2: Out of the question.  You'd miss the gymnastics trials.  You've been training for that for a year.

column1: I don't care about the trials, I want to be with you.  I could be your research assistant, like I was in Austin.
column2: This is nothing like Austin.  Forget about it.

column1: How could you possibly?
column2: Because you said so.  Maybe nobody else believed you, but I always did.

column1: "InGen."  What's InGen?
column2: Where does it say that?

column1: What are you guys gonna do?
column2: Exactly what John Hammond wanted us to do.

column1: Are you all right?!  Anything broken?
column2: I'm fine, I'm fine, I was scared, I thought you, are you okay?!

column1: Dad!
column2: Come on!

column1: Cancel that, Dieter.
column2: What?  Why?

column1: Carnivores hunt near stream beds.  Do you want to set up base camp or an all-you-can-eat people bar?
column2: You heard his, Dieter.  Find a new spot.  And remember, we're after herbivores only -- no unnecessary risks.

column1: Peter, if you want me to run your little camping trip, there are two conditions.  First -- I'm in charge, and when I'm not around, Dieter is.  Your job is to sign the checks, tell us we're doing a good job, and open your case of scotch when we have a good day.  Second condition -- my fee.  You can keep it.  All I want in exchange for my services is the right to hunt one of the tyrannosaurs.  A male.  Buck only.  Why and how are my business. If you don't  like either of those conditions, you're on your own.  Go ahead and set up your camp right here, or in a swamp, or in the middle of a rex nest, for all I care.  But I've been on too many safaris with rich dentists to listen to any more suicidal ideas.  Okay?
column2: Okay.

column1: Where do you think you're going?!
column2: To collect my fee.

column1: What kind of gun is that?
column2: My father's .600 Nitro Express.  Made in 1904.  Karimojo Bell gave it to him after he took down his last elephant.  8700 foot pound striking force.

column1: How close do you have to be?
column2: Forty yards.  Less, maybe.  I assume it'll take a slug in the brain case to bring him down.

column1: You rally think this'll draw the parent?
column2: I once saw a bull elephant die charging a jeep.  All the jeep had done was startle the bull's calves. I saw a lioness carry wounded prey four and a half miles, all the way back to its den, just to teach its cubs how to finish off a kill.

column1: Killing lessons?  Heartwarming.
column2: Rex won't be any different.  It'll come.

column1: What?
column2: I hadn't planned on bringing carnivores back because of the liability risk, but I only thought of adults, it never occurred to me --  You are a billion dollar idea, my little f-

column1: Had to.  To keep him still for the trip.
column2: You've broken its leg!

column1: What in Christ's name is going on?!
column2: Isn't it obvious?

column1: What is?
column2: The velociraptors.

column1: What is that?
column2: Piss.

column1: Where's the power and radio setup?
column2: Operations building.  Far end of the street.

column1: The radio rig is inside.  It runs directly from the geothermal generator, so power shouldn't be a problem.
column2: Good.

column1: Do you think the rex might have the infant with it?
column2: Possible.

column1: We took to the rock.
column2: Why?

column1: It's... behind... us.
column2: It's just fed.  It won't attack unless it's threatened.  Don't move.

column1: If I don't move, I can't shoot it.
column2: Let it go, Peter.  The animal won.

column1: So, you two were just, uh, telling old campfire stories, were you?
column2: Do me a favor.  Don't pretend for a second that you and I don't know the truth.  You can convince Time magazine and the Skeptical Inquirer of whatever you want, but I was there.

column1: You signed a non-disclosure agreement before you went to the island that expressly forbade you from discussing anything you saw.  You violated that agreement.
column2: You cost me my livelihood.  That on which I relied to support my children.

column1: If your university felt you were causing it embarrassment by selling wild stories to Hard Copy, I hardly see how I am to--
column2: I didn't tell anything, I told the truth.

column1: You version of it.
column2: There are no versions of the truth! This isn't a corporate maneuver, it's my life.

column1: We made a generous compensatory offer for your injuries.
column2: It was a payoff and an insult.  InGen never--

column1: What's he got in there?
column2: Piss.

column1: Trespassing, sabotage -- you could go to jail just for being here, did you know that?
column2: Don't start a legal argument with me, this island isn't your property, and neither are these animals!

column1: Their what?
column2: Oh, God.

column1: What?
column2: Don't ask me.  The guy's completely out to lunch.

column1: You know how to work a radio, don't you?
column2: You're going too?

column1: She's gutty.
column2: She's nuts.

column1: No way.
column2: Oh, my God.

column1: Do you see any family resemblance here?
column2: You can't stay, Kelly, that's it. It's too dangerous.

column1: Then this is our chance.
column2: Our chance to do what?

column1: There' no reason for name calling.
column2: Dr. Juttson, please take Kelly back to camp right away.  Leave the other car for us and we'll meet you there in an hour or so.
It has a broken leg!

column1: So do it a favor and put it out of its misery!
column2: No!  Get in the car before they hear us!

column1: What do they want?!
column2: What do you think they want?!

column1: No.
column2: No way.

column1: Lava?
column2: No.

column1: What are they?
column2: I don't know.

column1: Come on!
column2: Where's Kelly?

column1: We can't stay in here!
column2: We're sure as hell not going back out there"

column1: This is single-wall construction! It's just a shack!
column2: It'll hold!

column1: Head for the roof!
column2: I have to find Kelly!

column1: I think she's with Sarah!
column2: DAMN IT, BE SURE!!

column1: Something's wrong.
column2: Look!  Sarah!

column1: No.  I'm quite certain you can't.
column2: Look, we have two choices.  We can hike back down to the lagoon, where we can sit for two days, in the open, next to a heavily used water source while we're waiting for your boat to arrive, or we can head for the village, where we might find some shelter and we can call for help.

column1: You ever heard of Gambler's Ruin?
column2: What's that?

column1: A statistical phenomenon.  Says everything in the world goes in streaks.  It's real, you see it everywhere -- in weather, in river flooding, in baseball, in blackjack, in stock markets.  Once things go bad, they tend to stay bad.  Bad things cluster.  They go to hell together.
column2: Feeling a bit blue, are we?

column1: Just -- flawed.  Very deeply flawed.
column2: Why did you come here?

column1: So that others would know about this place?
column2: Why should they?

column1: Because it exists.
column2: It'll still exit if they go on not knowing, won't it?

column1: Yes.  And people will live in the absence of truth.
column2: So the truth is more important to you than your life?

column1: Somewhere on this island, there exits the greatest predator that ever lived.  And the second greatest predator must take him down.
column2: But why?

column1: You remember that guy, about twenty years ago, I forget his name, but he climbed Everest without any oxygen, came down almost dead.  And they asked him, "why did you go up there to die?"  And he said "I didn't.  I went up there to live."
column2: It's called self-testing.  But in your case, it sounds more like self-destruction.  A uniquely human characteristic.  In fact, human beings destroy things so well that I sometimes think that's our function. Maybe every few sons, some animal comes along that kills off the rest of the world, clears the decks, and lets evolution proceed to his next phase.  Maybe death and destruction are our job, maybe we're supposed to destroy ourselves and every other living thing that-

column1: How many rounds did you find for that weapon?
column2: Four, counting the one in the chamber.

column1: You gentlemen feel you have to do this now?
column2: Now's the perfect time.  The animal just fed, so it won't stalk us for food.  Predators don't hurt when they're not hungry.

column1: No more smoking.  We leave no scent of any kind.  No hair tonics, no cologne, seal all our food in plastic bags.  We will observe and document, but we will not interact.
column2: That's a scientific impossibility, you know.  Heisenberg uncertainty principle.  Whatever you study, you also change.

column1: You know you were putting yourself in a potentially dangerous situation, but you didn't bother to find out how dangerous before you leapt in. You don't have the faintest idea what's going on on this island!
column2: What do you want to do, Ian, lock her up for curiosity?  Where do you think she gets it?

column1: You're going home.  I'm sending a radio call for the boats.  We'll all go down to the lagoon and wait for them.
column2: Lighten up, Ian, you sound like a high school vice-principal.

column1: No!  We're an independently funded expedition.
column2: Funded by whom?

column1: Can you set up?
column2: It has to be temporary, something that'll break apart and fall off as the animal grows...

column1: That's impossible, they can't have the sensory equipment to track it all the way here!
column2: Current evidence seems to be to the contrary, wouldn't you say?!  GIVE IT TO THEM!

column1: Born free, as free as the wind blows. As free as the grass grows --
column2: Are you insane?!

column1: All right.  I'm satisfied with the evidence we have right now. I feel vindicated.  John Hammond will too.  Do you have enough to publish?
column2: They will come after me.  But I can collect some stool samples, for DNA with that, Nick's tapes, and the rest of you to back me up, it should stand when we get back.

column1: Oh, God.
column2: What?!

column1: You know, even if we do get those tapes back, people are going to say it's just another hoax.  Ian Malcolm's alien autopsy.
column2: Maybe.  Maybe not.

column1: Ian.  It's guano.
column2: What?

column1: These formations.  They're dried --
column2: Birdshit?

column1: So what's your story, Nick?
column2: I was a cameraman for Nightline for six years, been freelance since '91. Do a lot of work for Greenpeace.

column1: That must be interesting.  What drew you there?
column2: Women.  'Bout eighty percent female in Greenpeace.

column1: Hey, I wouldn't want to spook the woolly mammoths.
column2: You think this is all a joke?

column1: Oh, please.  How am I supposed to keep a straight face when --  -- Johnny Cash here tells me I'm going to Skull Island?
column2: Ian's a very good friend of mine.

column1: He doesn't need a friend, he needs a shrink.
column2: I believe in him.

column1: -- way we could safely --
column2: Oh, no!

column1: The kid scores with cheap sentiment.
column2: Ian, if we recall the boat now, we've made two invasive landings in one day.  That'll have to go in any paper I write, and it will leave room for people to say our findings were contaminated.  You know the academic world as well as I do, once they smell blood in the water, you're dead.  Our presence has got to be one hundred percent antiseptic.  That means if we bend a blade of grass, we bend it right back the way it-

column1: Ruining everything, that's what they're doing.  You could choke on the diesel smoke already!
column2: Ian, nothing we observe will be valid if we're trailing along in the wake of an army.

column1: That little black line?
column2: That little black line means death for this infant.  The fibula won't heal straight, so the ankle joint can't pivot when he stands on his hind feet.  The baby won't be able to run, and probably can't even walk. It'll be crippled, and a predator will pick it off before it gets more than a few weeks old.

column1: Give it more morphine!
column2: We'll kill it with too much, we'll put it into respiratory arrest!  I'm almost done.  Damn it, I need another adhesive, something pliable I can --

column1: Hold it down, Nick!
column2: I'm trying!

column1: There's, uh -- there's an unwritten rule when a news crew is in a war zone.  You stop the van every two miles and decide whether or not to go on.  Whether or not you feel lucky. One "no" from anybody in the group and you turn around right there, no question asked, nobody embarrassed.  Well?  Do we go on? Immediately:
column2: No.

column1: WHAT ARE YOU-
column2: JUMP!

column1: Where's Kelly?
column2: Where's Ian?

column1: Hey, we came here to observe, you came here to strip-mine the place! It's a looter mentality, all you care about is what you can take.
column2: None of that matters.  Our communications equipment's been destroyed.  If your radio and satellite phone were in those trailers that went off the cliff, and I'm guessing by the look on his face --

column1: If we can't stay in the rex's territory, we have to move tonight.
column2: Move where?  Our boat's not coming for two days, your airlift is waiting for an order you have no way to send --

column1: We have to send someone to look for him!
column2: You go if you like, but we're not waiting for you.  MOVE IT OUT!!

column1: Ask her.
column2: Can the kid walk?

column1: You've got to be kidding.
column2: Runs against my nature to hole up in a cave and wait.

column1: Uh - - Mr. Hammond - -
column2: Stop the program!  Stop the program!

column1: That storm center hasn't dissipated or changed course. We're going to have to cut the tour short, I'm afraid. Pick it up again tomorrow where we left off.
column2: You're sure we have to?

column1: Ladies and gentlemen, last shuttle to the dock leaves in approximately five minutes.  Drop what you are doing and leave now.
column2: Damn!

column1: I found a way to re-route through the program.  I'm turning the cars around in the rest area loop.
column2: Rotten luck, this storm.  Get my grandchildren on the radio will you?  I don't want them to worry about a wee bit of rain.

column1: Visitor vehicles are on their way back to the garage.
column2: So how much for our first tour.  Two no-shows and one sick triceratops.

column1: What?
column2: The door security systems are shutting down.

column1: Woah, woah, woah, what the hell, what the hell?
column2: What now?

column1: Fences are failing, all over the park!  A few minor systems, he said!
column2: Find Nedry!  Check the vending machines!

column1: Phones are out too.
column2: Where did the vehicles stop?

column1: We're talking, my dear, about a calculated risk, which is the only option left to us.  We will never find the command NEDRY used.  He covered his tracks far too well, and I think it's obvious he's not coming back.  So shutting down the system - -
column2: I will not do it.  You'll have to get somebody else, because I will not.

column1: - - shutting down the system is the only way to guarantee wiping out everything he did. If I understand correctly, all the system will come back on their original start-up modes correct?
column2: Theoretically, yeah , but we've never shut down the whole system.  It may not come back at all.

column1: Are we getting anywhere with these procedures of yours? I mean, what's hanging us up?
column2: I ran a key check on every stroke Nedry entered today. It's all pretty standard stuff, until this one - -

column1: How many lines of code are there?
column2: Uh - - about two million.

column1: No, no, no, that's crazy, you're out of your mind, he's absolutely out of his mind - -
column2: Wait a minute.  What exactly does this mean?

column1: But would we get the phones back?
column2: Yeah, again, in  theory, but - -

column1: The lysine contingency - it's intended to prevent the spread of the animals is case they ever got off the island, but we could use it now.  Dr. Wu inserted a gene that makes a single faulty enzyme in protein metabolism. Animals can't manufacture the amino acid lysine.  Unless they're continually supplied with lysine by us, they'll go into a coma and die.
column2: How would we cut off the lysine?

column1: How long will this take?
column2: 'Bout thirty seconds.

column1: You shouldn't use my name.
column2: Dodgson, Dodgson.  We got Dodgson here!  See, nobody cares.  Nice hat. What are you trying to look like, a secret agent?

column1: Oh, I'll get 'em all.
column2: Remember - - viable embryos.  They're no use to us if they don't survive.

column1: What?  No menthol?
column2: Mr Nedry, Mr Nedry.  The embryos have to be back here in San Jose by then.

column1: That's up to your guy on the boat.  Seven o'clock tomorrow night, at the east dock. Make sure he got it right.
column2: I was wondering, how are you planning to beat the security?

column1: Paleo-DNA?  From what source?  Where do you get 100 million year old dinosaur blood?!
column2: Shhhhh!

column1: Please - - let's hear something from the others.  Dr. Grant?  I am sorry - - Dr. Sattler?
column2: The question is - - how much can you know about an extinct ecosystem, and therefore, how could you assume you can control it?  You have plants right here in this building, for example, that are poisonous.  You picked them because they look pretty, but these are aggressive living things that have no idea what century they're living in and will defend themselves.  Violently, if necessary.

column1: Alan?  Where are we going?  You see something?
column2: Uh - - anybody else think we shouldn't be out here?

column1: Yours was fully illustrated, honey.
column2: Anybody at all.  Feel free to speak up.

column1: Doctors, if you please - - I have to insist we get moving.
column2: Oh, you know, if it's alright, I'd like to stay with Dr. Harding and finish with the trike.  Is that okay?

column1: Imbalance, disorientation, labored breathing.  Seems to happen about every six weeks or so.
column2: Six weeks?

column1: Yes, mitotic, pupils should be constricted.
column2: These are dilated.  Take a look.

column1: They are?  I'll be damned.
column2: That's pharmacological.  From local plant life.

column1: Yes.  We know they're toxic, but the animals don't eat them.
column2: Are you sure?

column1: Pretty sure.
column2: There's only one way to be positive.  I need to see some droppings.  I have to see the dinosaur's droppings.

column1: Sure.  I've got a gas powered jeep.  I can drop her at the visitor's center before I make the boat with the others.
column2: I'll catch up with you.  You can go with the others.

column1: Did I say jerk?
column2: I'm sorry for the dramatic entrance, but I'm in a hurry. Will you have a wee bit of a drink now and then?

column1: I have samples all over the kitchen.
column2: Come along.  I know my way around a kitchen.  Come along.

column1: There you are.  Out you come.
column2: Oh my God.

column1: Fascinating animals, fascinating.
column2: Oh my God.

column1: Alan, these aren't bones anymore.
column2: We're - - still perfecting a viewing system.  The raptors seem to be a bit resistant to integration into a park setting.

column1: Malcolm's okay for now.  I gave him a shot of morphine.
column2: They'll all be fine.  Who better to get the children through Jurassic Park than a dinosaur expert?

column2: Even the so-called New Town isn't so new.  Only the people.  People of the future living in buildings of the past.  Has anyone seen Eduard?

column1: You work in the insurance department?
column2: You have been hearing the sordid side then.

column1: Where do you live?
column2: Up there.

column1: It's only majestic from here. When you get closer you see it for what it really is.
column2: What is it really?

column1: A glorified office block.  They keep all the old records there -- the final resting place for facts and figures that have ceased to matter in the world of the living.
column2: Well, as long as I admire it from afar it shouldn't worry me if it's hollow.

column1: My assistants, I presume.
column2: Yes -- that's us.

column1: You look like brothers.
column2: Yes -- we do.

column1: Have you worked here long?
column2: No, no, no -- quite a long time, yes.

column1: Fine -- terrible.
column2: What was the matter with it?

column1: Heralds of a new age -- does that sound immodest?
column2: You could say we represent the <u>un</u>official view of a well-ordered society.

column1: Preliminary investigations may already be underway.
column2: You were his friend.  One link is all they need.

column1: -- Merely in the interests of order.
column2: The formality of a trial would be too costly for them.  They're beginning to understand that it's the ensuing news of our actions that incites support.

column1: -- Ah, but what if it <u>wasn't</u>?
column2: -- Small.

column1: Yours is a very powerful and important firm -- it has a lot at stake.
column2: Perhaps Eduard was closer than he knew to discovering it and so had to be silenced.

column1: I've read your stories.  They're fantastic.
column2: I don't know what you could have read.

column1: Just what you've published.
column2: -- In magazines nobody reads.

column1: I read the one about the penal colony.
column2: Did you?

column1: Gabriela was right -- it's easier for me to understand suicide. I'm a practicing suicide.
column2: -- In what sense?

column1: These strange stories you write -- they come naturally, do they?
column2: Naturally? -- that's not the word I would have chosen.

column1: Where do you get your ideas?  Only joking -- I'm just joking.  Let's go to a brothel then, Kafka, come on.
column2: I haven't got the energy.  I mean, I have to conserve my energy.

column1: That would be even worse -- it would be a compromise.
column2: Success or nothing?

column1: You work in the cemetery.
column2: A man must eat --  And drink.

column1: -- I'm flattered, of course, to be considered a friend -- even without knowing all the details.  -- To see such determination is reward enough for me.
column2: The Kafka men are famous for it, you know.  Delivering meat barefoot in the depths of winter, picking up sacks of flour with their teeth --

column1: -- Oh, yes, determination runs in the family.
column2: There is <u>one</u> thing I'd like you to tell me.

column1: I'm trying to find things out myself -- that's the whole point.
column2: What made you think <u>I'd</u> be able to get you into the Castle?

column1: The cemetery is nearer the Castle than anywhere else -- wasn't it part of the Castle originally?  -- I always assumed there'd be a gate or something.  Isn't there?
column2: In a manner of speaking.

column1: I was restoring some stones here in the upper section one day -- and I found this.
column2: An empty tomb?

column1: The Castle gates were blockaded in the time of the great plague -- it's an escape route.  Don't get stuck.
column2: Not a chance.  I'm the thinnest person I know.

column1: -- You appreciate my writing.
column2: Yes.

column1: Will you do me a favor then?
column2: Another one?

column1: If I don't see you later -- go to my house and find my notebooks -- and destroy them.  All my manuscripts -- just burn them. Please.
column2: What an extraordinary request!

column1: It's my last and final one.
column2: Then its authority is in doubt.

column1: A true friend would do it.
column2: Not necessarily.  A <u>wife</u> would.

column1: The keeper of the files is still waiting for your final summation of the Erlanger claim.
column2: I gave it to him yesterday.

column1: You didn't give it to <u>me</u>.
column2: No, I left it in his office.

column1: Did you see him?
column2: I've never seen him.  I don't believe there is a keeper of the files.

column1: He's usually in the storage room sorting things out.  He can't close the file on a case until he has the concluding report.
column2: He has it, he just hasn't noticed it yet, all right?

column1: In an organization as efficient as ours, if a document once in a great while gets lost it might never be found at all.
column2: Burgel, I thought it would be easier, as long as I was passing --

column1: But <u>I'm</u> the messenger.  An error like this damages my credibility.
column2: Your credibility -- yes, it's well known.

column1: When I deliver a message the very act of delivering it, you might say, gives it an official stamp, and only in this way are both the sender and the receiver satisfied that it was delivered at all.
column2: I'll commit that to memory.

column1: Are you looking for Gabriela Rossmann?
column2: Yes.

column1: Good morning --  Or should I say good afternoon?
column2: Say what you like -- no one pays the least attention.

column1: Oh, don't they?  I think you underestimate my station in this office and overrate your own.
column2: Not today, Burgel.  Send one of your memos, write up one of your communiques, but for God's sake don't bother me today.

column1: It's my place to offer advice, not yours -- and by advising the Chief Clerk of your unpunctuality it's certainly not my situation that's compromised, if that's what you're implying.
column2: You're just doing your job.

column1: It's what I'm paid to do.
column2: You're detestable.

column1: You wanted to see me, sir.
column2: Sit down, Kafka.

column1: You've been with the firm for nearly nine years.  You've done your work diligently, there are no complaints on that score.  But there's more to the job than the work -- there are other people to consider -- and frankly, Kafka, we eel your social situation could bear improving.
column2: ... My ... social situation?

column1: To do my work well, I have little time for --
column2: You must make the time.  Where do you go off to in the lunch hour?

column1: I usually take lunch by the River.
column2: It's not healthy, Kafka -- not for you and not for your workmates.  At the annual dinner this month you again failed to make an appearance.

column1: I did not realize it was obligatory.
column2: Have you never wondered -- and I mention this only in passing --  why other clerks have advanced to more responsible positions while you, who have been here longer, have not?

column1: No, sir.
column2: Attitude, Kafka.  It doesn't matter how well you do your work -- you still see it as something to be gotten on with rather than something to take an active interest in.

column1: Well, I --
column2: Oh, I know you got along with that poor fellow -- what was his name?

column1: -- Eduard --
column2: -- Yes -- Raban -- but he was too much like you -- even more so perhaps.  He wasn't here as long as you, so I didn't know him as well -- but I could see the influence he was having.  I simply want you to be aware of this because you'll be happier for it.

column1: I understand you fancy yourself an author.
column2: In a small way.

column1: Excuse me, sir -- I understand you have Eduard Raban's file.
column2: I do.

column1: Was there something else?
column2: No -- I just -- I feel a sense of obligation.  He was my friend -- if I can be of any help -- closing his affairs.

column1: No, there's only one report to complete.  I'll be doing it myself and submitting it to the Castle today or tomorrow.
column2: I see -- it's just the Erlanger claim then.

column1: The <u>Orlac</u> claim.
column2: Sorry, yes -- well -- thank you, sir.

column1: I'm Kafka -- I work upstairs in Accident --
column2: I know.

column1: You're a friend of Eduard Raban's.
column2: Why would you suppose so?

column1: Oh -- well, I thought he once mentioned --
column2: One of you must be mistaken.

column1: I'm sorry, but I just wondered --
column2: Excuse me, I have to copy this for Central Docketing by 2:30.

column1: Hello again.
column2: I've never seen you here before.

column1: Well -- nice to know life exists outside the office.
column2: Yes.

column1: I was having an affair with Eduard.  He didn't tell you?
column2: No.

column1: He would have.  You were his best friend.  A better friend than me.
column2: I suspected that he -- well.

column1: What?
column2: That he was -- satisfied in that regard.  I didn't want to pry.

column1: What's funny?
column2: This morning it was suggested to me that my own sense of office fellowship could bear improving.

column1: How long were you and Eduard --
column2: Two or three months, that's all.  -- I seduced him.

column1: No, I don't.  I'm amazed that anyone is able to bear life with any assurance at all.
column2: Eduard didn't see it as something that needed bearing.

column1: The police would know the difference, wouldn't they?
column2: Do you think people in the New Town care what happens over here?  This will always be the ghetto.

column1: He wasn't robbed.  He was identified by his wallet.
column2: And you believe everything the authorities tell you.

column1: When I have no reason to doubt.
column2: The very fact that they're authorities should give you reason. People will do anything to protect their own interests.  For all you know he was killed at the <u>hands</u> of the police.

column1: Are you free tonight?
column2: Tonight?

column1: There are some people I'd like you to meet.  Can you come to the Musil district at eight o'clock?
column2: ... All right.

column1: You almost married recently, didn't you?
column2: Last year.  I -- it was broken off.

column1: Eduard wanted to marry me.
column2: And you ...?

column1: -- I don't know the Musil district.
column2: You won't have any trouble finding it.

column1: Ah -- we're back to the "authorities" you spoke of.
column2: They're ubiquitous.  What we try to do ... is make them a little less so.

column1: I nominated you as a possible candidate.  You were Eduard's good friend.  He read me some of your work.
column2: I've hardly published enough for anyone to draw conclusions from.

column1: The day he died, Eduard was called up to the Castle.  Did you know that?
column2: What of it?

column1: And you still maintain -- what? That he was murdered.
column2: He was murdered.

column1: You're shocked at the thought of Eduard tossing a bomb through a window.
column2: I have no right to be, I know.  My experience with real life  is practically nil.

column1: When you only see someone sitting at a desk all day, it's liable to create a false impression.
column2: People must think the same of me -- a quiet, dependable person.

column1: You think what we're doing is so wrong?  And what are you doing? Pursuing goodness?  For what?  To answer to some supreme tribunal?
column2: My only concern is the human tribunal.  Isn't it yours?

column1: Yes -- which is why "quiet, dependable people" have to take charge of their own lives.
column2: At the cost of others?  You accuse people of murder without trial -- apparently without irony.  Did you go to the Castle with Eduard?  Then you have no idea what really might have happened that night at all -- even before or after he got there.

column1: I'm collecting Eduard's things. If there's anything you want, take it or I'll give it to charity.
column2: Burgel gave me this -- what does it mean?

column1: Burgel! -- I didn't leave it with him.
column2: Why were you given notice?

column1: They're not obliged to tell.
column2: It couldn't be for that incident with Burgel the other day.

column1: Of course it could -- Burgel's been trying to get me thrown out as long as I can remember.  <u>He</u> could've killed Eduard.
column2: You don't believe that.

column1: You might think -- I thought so myself at first -- that Burgel's too insignificant to be dangerous. But that's the very reason to beware! It's the small men to watch out for -- the ones who substitute method for character.
column2: Now you've fallen into his trap. When he goes to bed at night Burgel dreams of inspiring as much fear in others as they inspire in him.

column1: That street down there -- I always used to call it the approach road for suicides.  It leads straight down to the bridge and the River.
column2: Burgel hated Eduard.  And me.  I'm sure he knew about us -- and I'm sure it drove him mad.

column1: Burgel doesn't like anybody!
column2: He used to like me -- very much more than I liked him.

column1: Of course he is -- the Castle precincts are not the safest part of the city after dark.  People disappear up there regularly.   If you want to lie in wait for someone, that's the place to do it.
column2: Now you're saying Eduard was lured there?

column1: How often does one of our clerks have business in the house of records?
column2: I've heard of it happening.

column1: And Burgel is the bringer of messages, isn't he?
column2: Usually.

column1: Or what if there really <u>was</u> an error? -- I don't know what kind -- any kind that needed correcting -- and what if Burgel was responsible for it?  One mistake -- even a small one in a firm like ours -- it could cost him a promotion.
column2: First these nameless authorities were the root of all evil, now it's insignificant Burgel.  If indeed there was a mistake -- and a minor one at that -- you're suggesting someone went to a lot of trouble over something so trivial as to not matter at all.

column1: What seems important to these people is not determined by the amount of work it entails -- you're far from understanding the authorities if you believe that.
column2: Now Burgel's one of the authorities?

column1: Gabriela! -- you did get away.
column2: I knew you walked this way to work.  I wanted to find you before they did.

column1: -- I've just come from the Castle.  It's over.
column2: Over?  It's only over when you can crawl to a clean little spot on earth where the sun sometimes shines and you can warm yourself a bit.

column1: Gabriela ...?
column2: Should I tell you why I joined our late lamented nihilists? Why I became a murderer? Because murder ... is bliss.  It's easier than you might think to absorb and assimilate Evil -- once you've adopted its procedure.

column1: Only two steps back?  Even the man they left to guard me retreated further than that.
column2: I -- I found your jailer.

column1: This is the result of their elixir of youth.  They were to come and check on it during the night.  I contrived to miss the appointment.
column2: They're dead now.  We can get help.

column1: I know how they reward failure. If they saw this I'd be rotting in the quarries by the afternoon -- with all the others.
column2: There's a new potion -- he said it was perfected.

column1: I know there is.  And you're what I have to bargain with. For now you're the last one in their way.
column2: I told you, they're <u>dead</u>.  It's finished.

column1: I think you've just escaped for the moment.  Just as I did.  As Eduard did.  As they let us do. But only for the moment.
column2: No -- not this time.

column1: I know better than you what people will say when they have to.  When they brought me in for questioning I informed on my friends the very first day.
column2: -- Listen to me --

column1: Kafka -- is that your real name?
column2: Yes.  Yes, of course -- why wouldn't it be?

column1: When was the last time you saw Mr. Raban?
column2: Wednesday.  We left the office together.

column1: Did you go anywhere afterwards -- to have a drink perhaps?
column2: No, we said goodbye outside the building.  He went off, as usual, toward his house.

column1: Your office is the Workmen's --
column2: -- Accident and Compensation Association.

column1: Where you've been employed for seven years.
column2: Eight -- and seven months.

column1: Engaged in the manufacture and distribution of ... pills and so forth.
column2: Well -- other departments are, yes.

column1: Would you describe your relationship with the dead man as close?
column2: Yes.  Since he came to the office, almost three years ago, we've been quite good friends.  How was Eduard ...

column1: He was found in the River.  Could he swim?
column2: I don't know.

column1: Was he depressed?
column2: No.  He didn't seem to be.  Do you think he drowned himself?

column1: Grown men don't normally fall into the river, do they?
column2: No, I suppose not.

column1: He might have had a drink or two, despite what you think.
column2: Can I ask -- how you found me?

column1: His landlady knew of no other friends to refer us to.
column2: I don't think he really had any. He had no family either.

column1: He wasn't a lonely man, though.
column2: What makes you think so?

column1: Probably not.
column2: Anyway, I'd like you to reflect that in me you have -- I won't say a friend, because we're complete fencers, of course -- from distinctly incompatible social classes -- but to some extent, shall we say, an interested third party.

column1: I'll bear that in mind.
column2: -- Should you happen upon anything that might be relevant.

column1: But that's just my point -- she was more than upset, she was livid. She slammed every door on her way downstairs -- except that one.  I was just behind her and I didn't even hear that one <u>shut</u> -- not at all.
column2: That's not what I call conclusive evidence of an abduction.

column1: You told me to contact you if anything relevant came up -- Gabriela is relevant.  When I spoke to you before I didn't know she'd been seeing Eduard.
column2: That's been noted.  But where does it lead us?  Unless you have something more to add.

column1: Maybe it's true then what she said.
column2: What did she say?

column1: Do you?
column2: We saw her naked once -- didn't we.

column1: I didn't realize you'd been here that long.
column2: You mean because it's been a while since there was a sunny day?  What a good detective you are.

column1: -- I was just trying to finish some work!
column2: You mean you've actually begun some?

column1: What's the matter with you?
column2: I can't make a simple statement without him taking issue with it

column1: For all your incompetence I was beginning to think you were at least loyal to me.  You're very good ham actors.
column2: -- Just doing our job.

column1: Still, we're probably closer to you at the moment than any of your fellow human beings.
column2: Close only by virtue of antithesis.

column1: My assistants.  I should have known. Nothing is given to me.  I have to acquire everything.
column2: It's all right to be sarcastic in private to us -- because we have a sense of humor -- but when we're up at the Castle we suggest you don't make a fuss.  It would spoil the not unfavorable impression you make in other respects.

column1: ... Why take me into your confidence?
column2: That's obvious, isn't it?  We have an opening for a new member.

column1: That's <u>mad</u>.
column2: -- Oh, yes, it's mad.

column1: -- You said so yourself the firm is large and powerful.  If the discrepancy really was something big, Eduard's responsibility would still have to be small.  No poor young <u>clerk</u> could find himself in such a fix.
column2: When a scapegoat is needed, my friend ...

column1: Why are you so aggressively unimaginative?  Eduard is no longer the only casualty.
column2: Then why haven't I been --

column1: -- Gabriela, on the other hand, had made an enemy of this man Burgel.
column2: Oh, Burgel!  Gabriela was having an affair with Eduard.  They were both members of <u>this group</u>.  If any crime's been discovered and people are paying for it, I'd look to <u>yourselves</u>!

column1: ... A piece of paper ...
column2: A mere slip.  Your friend Mr. Raban dealt only with claims that came <u>in</u>, another department being responsible for compensation that goes out -- this is correct?

column1: Through a very unfortunate -- and I might add extremely rare -- mishap, a document intended for the one department was sent to the other.  And for the first time -- though your friend wasn't aware of it -- two and two could have been put together to make one.
column2: ... A piece of paper ...

column1: -- You seem amused.
column2: It only amuses me in that it gives me an insight into the ludicrous bungling that in some circumstances may decide the life of a human being.

column1: -- If an obscure official up there in the distant mountains so far away from civilizing influences happens to meet with an unfortunate accident -- and should he tragically die in spite of the District Medical Officer's strenuous efforts to save him -- the firm wants to see the next of kin pacified and the disposition of the remains handled with the greatest possible ... efficiency.
column2: "Accident and Compensation" -- no one can accuse the firm of not supplying exactly what it promises.

column1: I believe we've exceeded his expectations.
column2: I had the grandest of financial plots in mind, the most malevolent of personal motives, conspiracy theories extending to every ... authority I could see.  And I find you.  A body snatcher.

column1: And I suppose Dr. Murnau didn't die in a cave-in.  You killed him to free the Position of Orlac Medical Officer for your own ends.
column2: Yes, well -- we're looking for a new village now.  If we stay too long at one source ... people become suspicious.

column1: May I ask where your two warders are?
column2: Lying in the gutter where they belong.

column1: The fact that it's live bodies you practice your trade on doesn't seem to matter to you.
column2: On the contrary, it matters a great deal.  We're engaged in immensely important research here.  I'm a revolutionary too, you know -- but a much more pragmatic one.

column1: -- And the new patients they bring me aren't usually as dexterous as you've been in evading us.  Not perfect specimens by any means, but not the type of person who'll be missed either.
column2: What have you done with Gabriela Rossmann?

column1: "Raban" -- that'll be nearly at the back of the alphabet.
column2: It usually is.

column1: I'm overworked as it is.  "Raban" did you say?
column2: Yes.  Isn't it there?

column1: Wait a minute.  "Raban?"  Where have I heard that name?
column2: He's the clerk who died last week. From the insurance department

column1: What's the matter?
column2: Why would we keep files on <u>dead</u> employees?  All old files are sent up to the Castle.  Do you think we have room for two hundred years worth personnel records?

column1: It's gone out so quickly?
column2: Whenever an employee departs, shall we say, it's up to the head of his department to requisition his file, reassign any outstanding claims, and send it off.

column1: If it was Accounts you wanted why did you ask for Employees?
column2: Orlac is an account?

column1: All these in the last year?
column2: You must have read about it in the papers -- there was a terrible cave-in.  It wouldn't have been so bad, but even the Medical Officer for the district was killed!

column1: I did read that.  They gave him a posthumous medal.
column2: Dr. Murnau was the bravest of men. He spent an entire career in those backwaters with no regard for personal gain.  A great loss.

column1: This is the cross-reference of clerks who've worked on Orlac claims?
column2: Is your friend's name among them?  Then he only worked on the one case.  Your Chief will send me the final summation when he's finished with it.

column1: Once a file's been sent to the Caste, is it possible to recall it for review?
column2: Of course not.  Only by a Director of the firm.  Who'd want to let in all kinds of riff-raff off the streets?

column1: What good are records if they're not open for public inspection?
column2: These laws have been with us for centuries -- how can you doubt them?

column1: What if I petitioned one of the Directors?
column2: You do not summon them -- they summon you -- and this, of course, hardly ever happens, if at all. The Directors are an eccentric lot and by nature cautious.

column1: Where do our records go to in the Castle?
column2: We're a medical firm, aren't we? They go to the Medical Records Section.

column1: I could always apply there.
column2: It so happens, my dear simple sir, that the Head of Medical Records at the Castle <u>is</u> one of the Directors of this firm.

column1: Ludwig.
column2: Oskar.

column1: He can't sit still.  Just when we arrive at a nightclub he wants to go to another one.
column2: You look tired.

column1: Women are all you have on your mind!
column2: She went to the roof to sunbathe one lunch hour -- we watched her changing.

column1: They keep switching us from department to department.  He doesn't mind because he can't sit still.
column2: We used to be in the supply section, carrying boxes of medicine about but we dropped too many of them.

column1: It's not our fault.  We're naturally nervous.
column2: And we're upset too.

column1: We've been together too long.  His personality is overflowing into mine and vice versa.
column2: -- How would <u>you</u> like to be in a horrible situation like that?

column1: But your goal is so hard to reach. Do you think the official network would surrender to one man?  We would never think of attempting anything remotely as difficult.
column2: My mother used to tell us of the young man who decided to ride to the next village and how she was afraid that -- not even mentioning accidents -- the span of a normal happy life might fall far short of the time needed for such a trip.

column1: Oskar!
column2: Ludwig?

column1: This is filed incorrectly!
column2: Here too!  They're all in a dreadful muddle!

column1: We could go back to the office. Explain ourselves to the Chief Clerk.
column2: They'd drive us away.  That Kafka's made things very hot for us.

column1: I understand he was wounded in the lung.
column2: It doesn't matter.  It's too late for all of us.

column1: Then that's the place for us!
column2: Amerika for us!

column1: Are you planning on working tomorrow?
column2: Well, I'll be on the golf course in the morning.  Then, if I don't have any babies to deliver--

column1: You mind if I take a look at this?
column2: Be my guest.

column1: What do you want me to say? That it all sounds mysterious?
column2: These observers were doing something. A test...I think they sank that ship on purpose to cover up their mistakes.

column1: What's wrong?
column2: Pretty good imitation of a hangover and I ought to know.

column1: Dead?  This morning you said he had some skin disorder.
column2: He did.

column1: Here.  Put this on.  You examine him.
column2: I'm not a doctor.

column1: The mask is because you think it might be...catching?
column2: I don't know.  I've been back and forth with Narragansett Naval all day, consulting with the best people in maritime medicine, the best people in viruses...

column1: And?
column2: And they didn't believe the symptoms I described...

column1: Why Sixpack?
column2: It could be a million things, something in the air, food....  But he went on that ship and so did Williams...  I want to examine the crew.

column1: They found this?
column2: No.  I think they isolated him in genetic engineering. Homo aquaticus...

column1: Was there such a thing?
column2: Danakil man?...one of our ancestors.  Named for the Danakil Alps in Ethiopia.

column1: Not exactly a big ocean country.
column2: It was when it counted a couple of million years ago when the seas came in and drove us into the water.  Most homo sapiens didn't make it...Danakil man... <u>adapted</u>.

column1: Some say that's why we're basically hairless, for less water resistance, faster swimming speeds...
column2: But what about those scales... or that leech-like thing that bit Cobb?

column1: Why stop with just one aspect of marine life?  Why not incorporate the best genetic components the ocean has to offer?...
column2: Well, if they were perfecting an aquaman, then why's there a dead one onboard that Russian ship?  Why isn't he out swimming around?

column1: That it acquires intelligence from its victims?
column2: Intelligence may not be the right word...

column1: Be careful with it.
column2: Don't worry, I don't want to give up any more.

column1: DeJesus!  A readout!
column2: He don't need a readout, man, he needs help!

column1: Doc eat already?
column2: The good doctor hasn't showed yet.

column1: I've been looking at the duty roster...at the shack hours outstanding...
column2: Uh, oh...I see where this is going...

column1: Bullshit...I was just talking to him.  I saw him move.
column2: What?...

column1: We're getting out of here just in time.
column2: There's now a problem with the weather for pickup.  There's a typhoon in our sector... ...We're going to be delayed twelve hours...

column1: It's got Hazy!
column2: What has?

column1: I thought they were your friends?
column2: Were, Doss <u>were</u>.

column1: No, it's not going through. The intercom's busted.  I thought DeJesus fixed that?
column2: He did.

column1: That's why there's a dead one on the ship.  It ran out of blood.
column2: What dead one on the ship?

column1: We don't have much choice... without air, the internal pressure will fall and--
column2: Crunch...Implosion.

column1: Jesus Christ...
column2: Can you fix it?

column1: No way...
column2: Think!  Can we stop it?! Block it up?!  Shut down the line somewhere?!  Think!

column1: I hit it.  But I can't see it!  Can you see it?!
column2: No.

column1: Go on!
column2: No!

column1: That's an order!
column2: Fuck your orders!

column1: Where the hell've you been?
column2: I got hung up!  Try this!

column1: Your suit, Becky!
column2: Just get in yours!

column1: Cobb, Jones, I want you to do something about that damn rattle in the air system...  Bowman and Sixpack...living quarters...
column2: Shit...

column1: Look at my foot, sir!  This bitch put a goddamn sea monster in my bunk!
column2: How do you know it was Williams?

column1: Huh?  I...uh...uh...
column2: All right, Sixpack, you and Williams are gonna pull water duty tomorrow--

column1: You did good...
column2: What?

column1: Today...with DeJesus.  That was smart thinking to get him inside...
column2: There probably wasn't anything wrong with his suit...

column1: I need more light on that, Four.
column2: Roger...  More light, Sixpack...

column1: That's great.  Now let's move 35 degrees southwest.
column2: You screw around like that again and--

column1: Sixpack?
column2: Why can't we pick up his signal?

column1: That was a loud one wasn't it?
column2: After a month of it you'd think I'd be used to it.

column1: How's astronaut training?
column2: Why?  You going to give me hard time like the others?

column1: No.  I'm just being friendly.
column2: Good...It's going good.

column1: Whatever made you want to do a tour down here?
column2: I need electrical field experience on my resume. Everything helps...  Why are you here?

column1: Everybody in corporate training serves a tour on the line.  Sup- posed to hone leadership skills or something.
column2: Has it helped?

column1: You think I should hang around more with the crew?
column2: Well, I always heard you don't "learn" leadership, you earn it.  How did you know they'd get into the vodka?

column1: I guess I figured if I was in their shoes that's what I would've done.
column2: Maybe you're more one of us than you think...sir.

column1: What can we do?
column2: Our only chance is to lure it to the Swamp and flush it like we did the other.

column1: Shit!  He sent them all.
column2: The escape bubbles?

column1: They know, don't they?
column2: Yeah...I think they're just deciding what to do with us.

column1: What are you doing?
column2: Seeing how my stock's doing...

column1: We're on backup air.
column2: How much time does that give us?

column1: Less than an hour.  It's ruptured an air duct.
column2: Can't we fix it?

column1: We made it!
column2: Where's Jones?

column1: It hit me!  Where are they?!
column2: I can't see them!

column1: The internal monitors read normal.
column2: Where's Doc?!

column1: What about our quota?
column2: You're only twenty-five tons off quota.  Barring an unforeseen problem you should reach it easily on the last day.  It's just a day off.  You don't have to take it, I just thought it might help.

column1: Something wrong, Cobb?
column2: Uh..Excuse me sir, it's the air recirculating system, sir...

column1: What's wrong with it?
column2: ...I'd really have to show it to you.

column1: Excuse me, sir...
column2: Is this a contract violation, Mr. Cobb?

column1: Shut up, all of you.
column2: Mr. Beck, the contract states that no body can be disposed of without authorization of---

column1: No!
column2: It bit me!

column1: Oh, God, she's out there...
column2: Jones...come with me.  Cobb, you and Doc check the rooms.

column1: Charge set?
column2: Charge set.  Backing off.  C'mon Rover let's get out of here.

column1: I'm going inside.
column2: What's your air reading?

column1: Twenty minutes...
column2: Twenty minutes!...Who had tank duty?

column1: Wait till you reach thirty- five before you blow your suit...
column2: Roger.

column1: Give me a readout, DeJesus.
column2: Ahhhh!

column1: How do you feel, DeJesus?
column2: Okay.

column1: Okay, number 23's full.
column2: Let's get it out of here and bring in a new one.

column1: I can't tell you much about it, except that none of you show any symptoms.
column2: And it killed Bo?

column1: Two hundred and fifty-two tons of Magnesium and 15 tons of Sodium.
column2: Sounds like a good week, Beck. In fact...I put your folder in front of the Vice President of District Operations last night...

column1: Thank you, Martin.
column2: Don't thank me, yet, but it is important to know where you're going and who your friends are... 'Know what I mean?

column1: ...as long as you know it's not in your contract.
column2: I know that.

column1: How's the weather for pickup tomorrow?
column2: Beautiful.

column1: Well, according to Maritime law, you, as commander of the Shack have the authority to dispose of the body.  However, the company doesn't want you to do that.
column2: What you don't understand is that my crew is in jeopardy.

column1: But you don't have any proof at this point to assume that this disease is contagious, do you?
column2: I'm not anxious to find out, either.

column1: Beck, trust me.  If the company felt that you or your crew were in any danger we would authorize an immediate emergency pickup. We could be there in a few hours.
column2: Do it.

column1: What're you saying?  That we're not even going to be picked up tomorrow?
column2: It shouldn't be a long delay.

column1: But it's a delay!  How long? A day?  Two days?!
column2: Twelve hours, no big deal.  We should know something first thing in the morning.  Don't worry.

column1: Forty-eight hours!
column2: I realize you must have gone through hell--

column1: Made your million, yet?
column2: Not yet.

column1: You got money in this tub?
column2: I signed-up for the stock option.

column1: You take your money, too seriously, Bo.
column2: You're damn right I do.  Five years down here and I'll pull in more than 15 topside.  I'm not down here for the fun, I'll tell you that.

column1: Personal effects...
column2: Timex...

column1: I'm telling you, it's the suits!
column2: Fuck the suits, it's the people monitoring them.  It Doc had been there like he's supposed to it never would've happened!

column1: Hey, Bo...when're you going to be off that thing?  I want to find out tonight's NBA scores and check the weather.
column2: The weather's good, I already checked, but I'll be off in a minute.

column1: If he had his blinkers on--
column2: It wouldn't make any difference in there...He could be two feet away and on fire and she'd still not see him!

column1: Who else...Sixpack.
column2: The man is unbelievable... I say, leave him in there.

column1: Cute, DeJesus...Specimen cups?
column2: Aw, loosen up, Bowman...  Hey, Willie, I got one served up for you.

column1: Yes sir...
column2: Hook's on 24...

column1: What the?...
column2: Russian.

column1: You read Russian?
column2: Russian, French, Italian, Spanish, Greek, German, a little Hindu, some Serbo Croat and a smattering of Swahili...standard pre-med background...

column1: Bullshit.
column2: ...and a Russian grandmother...

column1: What happened?
column2: It...almost got you.

column1: Still bothering you?
column2: Itches like hell.

column1: No way, Mister Beck!  <u>No</u> <u>fucking way</u>!  We just did a full shift, you can't call Shack duty on top of a full shift.  It's a contract violation!
column2: Whooo!  Right on, Cobb!  Let's hear it for our shop Steward!

column1: Listen to it for Christsake.
column2: Ah, it's just old, like me. You don't see the Doc opening me up every time I get a new creak in my joints...I say, as long as it's recycling the air let the next shift deal with it. But, 'long as we're here...

column1: So that's all you do?...
column2: Shhhh...don't tell no one.  Job security.

column1: Oooooh.  Damn!  Not so loud. Turn down the music.
column2: What music?  There ain't no music.

column1: Yeah?  How'd the kid hold up?
column2: Pretty good.  He sent them out videotaping outcrop.

column1: "Routine," my ass!  Ain't nothin' "routine" about no physical check- up 10,000 feet down...especially when we're getting picked up the next day!
column2: He didn't say it was a "routine check-up," he said it was a "routine <u>precaution</u>."

column1: At least we get time and a half.  That's in the contract.
column2: Fuck double pay, man!  I want out of here!

column1: What's going on?
column2: It's Hazy...It's got him! Stay here and don't let him out.  I'm going to get the Doc.

column1: You let him get away!
column2: I ain't doing nothing for that thing without something to defend myself.

column1: I say we should go get in the escape bubbles and get the hell out of here!
column2: And hit the surface in the middle of a typhoon?...No, thank you. I'll take my chance down here.

column1: Hey, man, you know that in Switzerland--and this country's the size of East L.A., okay?--they speak 54 different dialects? Fifty-four!
column2: Who cares?

column1: Hey, Cobb...Man, why don't you take off your shirt and pants, man?  You should do that wearing what you're going to wear at the beach.
column2: This is what I wear at the beach, goddamnit.

column1: You guys are crazy.  What the hell you play that stupid game for?
column2: What game, Cobb?...I'm on my way to Nirvana...

column1: You're on your way somewhere all right...the looney bin.
column2: I'm on the way to the looney bin?  Hey, man, I'm not the dude sun bathing in his clothes.

column1: Bad as he is there's no way we can make our quota with- out his sad self out there. You just can't do it.
column2: He's tanking on us...

column1: C'mon, Cobb...you're slacking...
column2: I ain't, goddamnit...It's Jones!..

column1: Hey!...I feel something. It's moving!  He's alive!
column2: I feel it, too...Someone's trying to get out.

column1: It's Sixpack!
column2: I'm going to kill it!

column1: Burritos...Enchiladas...
column2: Oh, gag, man, how can you eat that stuff?...

column1: Typhoon?!
column2: Twelve hours!

column1: Serves his ass right to get it.  Motherfucker brings that shit onboard.  I hope his fucking ass rots in the sea and is shit upon by the fish.
column2: 'Fucker could have gotten us all killed.

column1: How'd you do that?
column2: What?  That?...I've done this one before.  You hungry?  I'm hungry.

column1: Getting some food.
column2: Under there?

column1: Look.  Water.
column2: Probably the plumbing.  You gonna make me finish that puzzle by myself, or what?

column1: How far away is she?
column2: Two hundred meters.

column1: Excuse me, sir...Bowman's sick.  She's downstairs in the infirmary.
column2: The infirmary?...

column1: Yes sir, ain't that where we usually go when we're sick?
column2: We're simply concerned about her...proximity to...

column1: We've got to get him to the infirmary.
column2: What are you going to do to him?

column1: I'm going to try to remove it.
column2: I've got Cobbie downstairs watching the door.

column1: Bigger than DeJesus?  How?
column2: It's had a meal.

column1: It would explain the suction- like appendages.
column2: Like a leech.

column1: The monster appears to be a genetic aberration...
column2: No fuckin' lie...

column1: Fuck semantics, Doc! You saying its like part DeJesus, part Sixpack, part Bowman?!
column2: I don't know.  I'm guessing.

column1: Clear for pickup.
column2: Let's hope it holds.

column1: Hey, Jonesy, who's the best power forward in the NBA...Jameson?
column2: Jameson?  Who're you trying to con?

column1: What is it?
column2: "Debbie Does Dallas"...  Hell, it's in Russian.  I can't read it...

column1: No...he's really sick.  I heard him last night.  The company will take that into consideration...
column2: Honey, the company don't give a flying fuck about "whys," they just look at the numbers and the contract says if we miss our quota they only got to pay us half-pay for the entire month.

column1: Who were you talking to?
column2: Sixpack...

column1: How is he?
column2: Sleeping.  No sign of Doc, though.  I'll check the control room.  You look in the shower room...

column1: What on earth's the matter with you?
column2: I ought to smack your face!

column1: What's wrong?
column2: DeJesus...It's got him.

column1: It needs blood?
column2: Fucking great...You telling me we got a fucking dracula in here with us?

column1: Cobb's cut...It was in him! It got Doc...
column2: Oh man, that's just great...

column1: What is it?
column2: The good doctor signed our death warrant.

column1: What is it?
column2: The air's stopped.

column1: The shack...
column2: She's wondering what's happening.  We're losing air faster than I thought.

column1: Don't spend all day down there.
column2: Don't fuckin' worry, I ain't.

column1: Are you sure you saw something?
column2: How many times I got to tell you.  I saw a ship.

column1: Are you okay, Jonesy?
column2: Tip top, Willie...tip top.

column1: Who's the best power forward in the NBA...Jameson?
column2: Jameson?  Who are you trying to con...?

column1: It saw us!
column2: Answer them and quit kicking me!

column1: My pocket.  Check my pocket, will ya, honey?
