column2: Your pocket?

column1: The latch is screwed up.  Or the hinge.
column2: Right.

column1: Bitch!  Look what you did!
column2: Sorry, darling...Just thought a little humor would loosen us all up...you know?...

column1: What's wrong, did you miss me?
column2: Hardly.

column1: Then the informant is real.
column2: Does that surprise you?  It was inevitable.

column1: He'll be contacting us again.
column2: Expect it.  Did you get anything from the room?

column1: We'll need a search running.
column2: It's already begun.

column1: They are dead.  In either case --
column2: We have no choice but to continue as planned.  Deploy the sentinels. Immediately.

column1: You don't know.
column2: Know what?

column1: The sewers.  Of course.
column2: Hurry!

column1: The great Morpheus.  We meet at last.
column2: And you are?

column1: Smith.  I am Agent Smith.
column2: You all look the same to me.

column1: Lieutenant?
column2: Oh shit.

column1: Lieutenant, you were given specific orders --
column2: I'm just doing my job.  You gimme that Juris-my-dick-tion and you can cram it up your ass.

column1: I sent two units.  They're bringing her down now.
column2: No, Lieutenant, your men are already dead.

column1: He's gonna make it.
column2: No way.  Not possible.

column1: Weird.
column2: What?

column1: That's the third white van I've seen.
column2: Should Tank I.D. it?

column1: What?!
column2: Oh, God.

column1: Who is it?
column2: It's Choi.

column1: You're two hours late.
column2: I know.  It's her fault.

column1: You got the money?
column2: Two grand.

column1: Hallelujah!  You are my savior, man! My own personal Jesus Christ!
column2: If you get caught using that --

column1: I know, I know.  This never happened.  You don't exist.
column2: Right...

column1: Something wrong, man?  You look a little whiter than usual.
column2: I don't know... My computer...

column1: You ever have the feeling that you're not sure if you're awake or still dreaming?
column2: All the time.  It's called mescaline and it is the only way to fly.

column1: You weren't supposed to relieve me.
column2: I know but I felt like taking a shift.

column1: Don't be ridiculous.
column2: We're going to kill him.  Do you understand that?  He's going to die just like the others.

column1: Do you?
column2: I... it doesn't matter what I believe.

column1: You don't, do you?
column2: If you have something to say, I suggest you say it to Morpheus.

column1: Did you hear that?
column2: Hear what?

column1: Are you sure this line is clean?
column2: Yeah, 'course I'm sure.

column1: There's something about him, isn't there?
column2: Don't tell me you're a believer now?

column1: I just keep wondering if Morpheus is so sure, why doesn't he take him to the Oracle?  She would know.
column2: Morpheus will take him when he's ready.

column1: Hello, Trinity.
column2: Cypher?  Where's Tank?

column1: He had an accident.
column2: An accident?!

column1: You are a beautiful woman.  Too bad things had to work out like this.
column2: You killed them.

column1: I'm tired, Trinity.  I'm tired of this war, I'm tired of fighting. I'm tired of this ship, of being cold, of eating the same fucking goop every day.  But most of all, I'm tired of this jagoff and all of his bullshit.
column2: My God.  Morpheus.  You gave them Morpheus.

column1: Yes.  You see, the truth is, Trinity, that we humans have a place in the future.  But it's not here. It's in the Matrix.
column2: The Matrix isn't real!

column1: But you're out, Cypher.  You can't go back.
column2: That's what you think.  They've promised to back me, Trinity. They're going to reinsert my body. I'll go back to sleep and when I wake up, I'll be fat and rich and I won't remember a goddamn thing. It's the American dream.

column1: Goddamn you, Cypher!
column2: Don't hate me, Trinity.  I'm just the messenger.  And right now I'm going to prove it to you.

column1: ... yes.
column2: No!

column1: I don't believe it!  I don't believe it!
column2: He's going to pop!

column1: Whoa!  Shit, Neo, you scared the Bejeezus out of me.
column2: Sorry.

column1: No, it's all right.
column2: What are you doing?

column1: Is that...?
column2: The Matrix?  Yeah.

column1: Do you always look at it encoded?
column2: Have to.  The image translators sort of work for the construct programs but there's way too much information to decode the Matrix.  You get used to it, though.  Your brain does the translating.  I don't even see the code.  All I see is blonde, brunette, and redhead.  You want a drink?

column1: Why you're here?
column2: ... Yeah.

column1: I'm going to let you in on a little secret here.  Now don't tell him I told you this, but this ain't the first time Morpheus thought he found the One.
column2: Really?

column1: You bet your ass.  It keeps him going.  Maybe it keeps all of us going.
column2: How many were there?

column1: Five.  Since I've been here.
column2: What happened to them?

column1: Dead.  All dead.
column2: How?

column1: Thanks... for the drink.
column2: Any time.

column1: Operator.
column2: I need an exit!  Fast!

column1: There was an accident.  A fucking car accident.  All of a sudden. Boom.  Jesus, someone's going to make a believer out of me.
column2: I got you.

column1: Just get me outta here.
column2: Nearest exit is Franklin and Erie. An old appliance store.

column1: I know.  They cut the hardline. This line is not a viable exit.
column2: Are they any agent?

column1: Yes.
column2: Goddamnit!

column1: All right --
column2: Go.

column1: I got a fibrillation!
column2: Shit!  Apoc?

column1: We found him, Trinity.  We finally found him.
column2: What if he isn't the One, Morpheus? How can you be so sure?

column1: Give me your phone.
column2: They'll be able to track it.

column1: What is he doing?
column2: He's beginning to believe.

column1: How long?
column2: Five minutes.  Maybe six.

column1: You can't use that until Neo is out!
column2: I know, Trinity.  Don't worry.  He's going to make it.

column1: Hello?
column2: Hello, Neo.  Do you know who this is?

column1: Morpheus...
column2: I've been looking for you, Neo.  I don't know if you're ready to see what I want to show you, but unfortunately, we have run out of time.  They're coming for you, Neo. And I'm not sure what they're going to do.

column1: Who's coming for me?
column2: Stand up and see for yourself.

column1: Right now?
column2: Yes.  Now.

column1: Holy fucking shit!
column2: Yes.

column1: What the fuck do they want with me?!
column2: I'm not sure, but if you don't want to find out, you better get out of there.

column1: How?!
column2: I can guide you out, but you have to do exactly what I say.

column1: The cubicle across from you is empty.
column2: But what if...?

column1: Good.  Now there is a window.  Open it.
column2: How do you know all this?

column1: No!  It's too far away.
column2: There's a small ledge.  It's a short climb.  You can make it.

column1: No way, no way, this is crazy.
column2: There are only two ways out of this building.  One is that scaffold. The other is in their custody.  You take a chance either way.  I leave it to you.

column1: This line is tapped so I must be brief.
column2: The agents --

column1: They got to you first, but they've underestimated how important you are.  If they knew what I know, you would probably be dead.
column2: What do you know?

column1: Do you still want to meet?
column2: ... Yes.

column1: Welcome, Neo.  As you no doubt have guessed, I am Morpheus.
column2: It's an honor.

column1: I imagine, right now, you must be feeling a bit like Alice, tumbling down the rabbit hole?
column2: You could say that.

column1: Ironically, this is not far from the truth.  But I'm getting ahead of myself.  Can you tell me, Neo, why are you here?
column2: You're Morpheus, you're a legend. Most hackers would die to meet you.

column1: Yes.  Thank you.  But I think we both know there's more to it than that.  Do you believe in fate, Neo?
column2: No.

column1: Why not?
column2: Because I don't like the idea that I'm not in control of my life.

column1: Let me tell you why you are here. You have come because you know something.  What you know you can't explain but you feel it.  You've felt it your whole life, felt that something is wrong with the world. You don't know what, but it's there like a splinter in your mind, driving you mad.  It is this feeling that brought you to me.  Do you know what I'm talking about?
column2: The Matrix?

column1: The Matrix is everywhere, it's all around us, here even in this room. You can see it out your window or on your television.  You feel it when you go to work, or go to church or pay your taxes.  It is the world that has been pulled over your eyes to blind you from the truth.
column2: What truth?

column1: The pill you took is part of a trace program.  It's designed to disrupt your input/output carrier signal so we can pinpoint your location.
column2: What does that mean?

column1: Have you ever had a dream, Neo, that you were so sure was real?
column2: This can't be...

column1: ... am I dead?
column2: Far from it.

column1: What are you doing?
column2: Your muscles have atrophied.  We're rebuilding them.

column1: Why do my eyes hurt?
column2: You've never used them before.

column1: Morpheus, what's happened to me? What is this place?
column2: More important than what is when?

column1: When?
column2: You believe the year is 1997 when in fact it is much closer to 2197.  I can't say for certain what year it is because we honestly do not know.

column1: Right now, we're inside a computer program?
column2: Wild, isn't it?

column1: This isn't real?
column2: What is real?  How do you define real?  If you're talking about your senses, what you feel, taste, smell, or see, then all you're talking about are electrical signals interpreted by your brain.

column1: We have only bits and pieces of information.  What we know for certain is that, at some point in the early Twenty-first Century, all of mankind was united in celebration.  Through the blinding inebriation of hubris, we marveled at our magnificence as we gave birth to A.I.
column2: A.I.?  You mean artificial intelligence?

column1: No!  I don't believe it!  It's not possible!
column2: I didn't say that it would be easy, Neo.  I just said that it would be the truth.

column1: Get some rest.  You're going to need it.
column2: For what?

column1: This is incredible.  I know kung fu.
column2: Show me.

column1: How did I beat you?
column2: You -- you're too fast.

column1: I know what you're trying to do --
column2: I'm trying to free your mind, Neo, but all I can do is show you the door.  You're the one that has to step through.  Tank, load the jump program.

column1: Do you know why you didn't make it?
column2: Because... I didn't think I would?

column1: I thought it wasn't real.
column2: Your mind makes it real.

column1: If you are killed in the Matrix, you die here?
column2: The body cannot live without the mind.

column1: This is another Matrix simulation. A training program to help you get your sea legs and teach you one very important lesson.
column2: What -- what lesson?

column1: Do you understand, Neo?
column2: I think I do.

column1: No you don't.  Did you see the woman in the red dress?
column2: Yeah.

column1: Every attempt to fight them has ended in failure.  Only a handful of men and women have ever crossed an agent and lived because they are everyone and they are no one. Unkillable.  But now I believe that is going to change.
column2: How?

column1: What?  Are you trying to tell me that I can dodge bullets?
column2: No, Neo.  I'm trying to tell you that when you're ready, you won't have to.

column1: Set down in there.
column2: What's going on?

column1: So is this the same oracle that made the, uh, prophecy?
column2: Yes.  She's very old.  She's been with us since the beginning.

column1: The beginning?
column2: Of the Resistance.

column1: And she knows what?  Everything?
column2: She would say she knows enough.

column1: How does she know?
column2: She is a true psychic.  She sees beyond the relativity of time.  For her there is no past, present or future.  There is only what is.

column1: And she's never wrong.
column2: Don't think of it in terms of right and wrong.  She is a guide, Neo. She can help you find the path.

column1: She helped you?
column2: Yes.

column1: What did she tell you?
column2: That I would find the One.

column1: Morpheus, I don't think this is a good idea.
column2: Why?

column1: I told you I don't believe in this stuff.  No matter what she says I'm not going to believe it, so what's the point?
column2: What do you believe in?

column1: What do I believe it?  Are you kidding me?  What do you think?  I'm still trying to deal with the fact that everything I believed was real, wasn't.  The whole world, my entire life was a lie.  I don't know anything anymore, Morpheus.
column2: That's why we're here.

column1: Why?  So I can hear some old lady tell me, what?  That I'm this guy that everybody's been waiting for? The one that's supposed to save the world?  Come on.  How do I respond to that?  I can't.  It's ridiculous. I mean who am I?  I'm nobody, I'm just a guy.  What did I do, Morpheus?  Why me?
column2: Faith is beyond the reach of whys and why nots.  These things are not a matter of cause and effect, Neo. I do not believe things with my mind.  I believe them with my heart. In my gut.

column1: And you still believe I'm the One?
column2: Yes I do.

column1: Did you believe in them too?
column2: No.  I did not.  I have never told anyone this, Neo.  After I saw the Oracle I thought... no, I misunderstood what she told me.  I believed that it was all about me. That I would find the One, not that he would find me.

column1: Listen to me, Neo.  I know why you're afraid to go through that door.  You can't get free of thinking that I could be wrong.  You must believe me.  There is a greatness inside of you, Neo.  A greatness that is going to lift you to unimaginable heights and that in time will change the world.
column2: Morpheus, I don't know --

column1: No.  No!  Morpheus!  Don't!
column2: Trinity!  Go!  Get to the basement. Find the catch basin!

column1: Morpheus, the Oracle... she told me --
column2: She told you exactly what you needed to hear.  That's all.  Sooner or later, Neo, you're going to realize just like I did the difference between knowing the path and walking the path.

column1: How is he?
column2: Ten hours straight.  He's a machine.

column1: Got it.
column2: I need the main wet-wall.

column1: Now left and that's it in front of you.
column2: Good.

column1: Tank.
column2: Goddamn!  It's good to hear your voice, sir!

column1: We need an exit.
column2: Got one ready, sir.  Subway.  State and Balbo.

column1: Tank, charge the E.M.P.
column2: Yes, sir.

column1: I'm going to make the call.
column2: Do it!
He is the One.  He is the One!

column1: Hello?
column2: I know.  You're Neo.  Be right with you.

column1: You're the Oracle?
column2: Bingo.  Not quite what you were expecting, right?  I got to say I love seeing you non-believers. Always a pip.  Almost done.  Smell good, don't they?

column1: Yeah.
column2: I'd ask you to sit down, but you're not going to anyway.  And don't worry about the vase.

column1: That vase.
column2: Shit, I'm sorry.

column1: I said don't worry about it.  I'll get one of my kids to fix it.
column2: How did you know...?

column1: You're cuter than I thought.  I see why she likes you.
column2: Who?

column1: So?  What do you think?  You think you're the One?
column2: Honestly?  I don't know.

column1: Okay, now I'm supposed to say, 'Hmmm, that's interesting but...' Then you say --
column2: But what?

column1: But you already know what I'm going to tell you.
column2: I'm not the One.

column1: Sorry, kid.  You got the gift but looks like you're waiting for something.
column2: What?

column1: What's funny?
column2: Morpheus.  He almost had me convinced.

column1: I know.  Poor Morpheus.  Without him we are lost.  We will never find the One.
column2: What do you mean, without him?

column1: Morpheus believes in you, Neo and no one, not you or even me can convince him otherwise.  He believes it so blindly that he's going to sacrifice his life to save yours.
column2: What?

column1: Hello, Neo.
column2: How do you know that name?

column1: I know a lot about you.  I've been wanting to meet you for some time.
column2: Who are you?

column1: My name is Trinity.
column2: Trinity?  The Trinity?  The Trinity that cracked the I.R.S. Kansas City D-Base?

column1: That was a long time ago.
column2: Gee-zus.

column1: What?
column2: I just thought... you were a guy.

column1: Do you want to go somewhere and talk?
column2: No.  It's safe here and I don't have much time.

column1: How did you do that?
column2: Right now, all I can tell you, is that you are in danger.  I brought you here to warn you.

column1: Of what?
column2: They're watching you, Neo.

column1: Who is?
column2: Please.  Just listen.  I know why you're here, Neo.  I know why you left your family and your friends, why you left your home to come to this city.  You're looking for him.

column1: It's the question that brought you here.  You know the question just as I did.  It is a hacker's question.
column2: What is the Matrix?

column1: What the hell is this?!
column2: It's necessary, Neo.  For our protection.

column1: From what?
column2: From you.

column1: Neo, please, you have to trust me.
column2: Why?

column1: And I know that's not where you want to be.
column2: ... shit.

column1: What is this thing?
column2: We think you're bugged.  Try to relax.

column1: Uh-oh...
column2: It's going into replication.

column1: Get this thing out of me!
column2: Easy, Neo.  Easy.

column1: E.M.P.  An electromagnetic pulse.
column2: It disables any electrical system in the blast radius.  It's the only weapon we have against the machines.

column1: God...
column2: What?

column1: What does that mean?
column2: That the Matrix cannot tell you who you are.

column1: But an Oracle can.
column2: That's different.

column1: Is it?
column2: Are you worried?

column1: Should I be?
column2: No.

column1: Did you go to her?
column2: Yes.

column1: What did she tell you?
column2: She told me...

column1: Are you all right?
column2: ... right as rain.

column1: What did you just say?
column2: Nothing.  Just had a little deja vu.

column1: What happened?  What did you see?
column2: A black cat went past us and then I saw another that looked just like it.

column1: How much like it?  Was it the same cat?
column2: It might have been.  I'm not sure.

column1: What is it?
column2: A deju vu is usually a glitch in the Matrix.  It happens when they change something.

column1: Go!
column2: We can't leave him!

column1: Is Morpheus alive?
column2: Is Morpheus still alive, Tank?

column1: What happened?
column2: I don't know.  It just went dead.

column1: Goddamnit!  Goddamnit!
column2: There has to be something that we can do.

column1: That I would have to make a choice...
column2: What choice?

column1: What are you doing?
column2: I'm going in after him.

column1: You can't!
column2: I have to.

column1: Morpheus sacrificed himself so we could get you out!  There's no way you're going back in!
column2: Morpheus did what he did because he believed that I'm something I'm not.

column1: What?
column2: I'm not the One, Trinity.  The Oracle hit me with that too.

column1: No, you... have to be.
column2: I'm sorry, I'm not.  I'm just another guy.  Morpheus is the one that matters.

column1: No, Neo.  That's not true.  It can't be true.
column2: Why?

column1: What?
column2: I believe I can bring him back.

column1: What are you doing?
column2: I'm coming with you.

column1: No, you're not.
column2: No?  Let me tell you what I believe. I believe Morpheus means more to me than he does to you.  I believe that if you are serious about saving him then you are going to need my help and since I am the ranking officer on this ship, if you don't like it then I believe that you can go to hell, because you aren't going anywhere else.

column1: No one has ever done anything like this.
column2: Yeah?

column1: Neo, how did you do that?
column2: Do what?

column1: You moved like they moved.  I've never seen anyone move that fast.
column2: It wasn't fast enough.

column1: Are you all right?
column2: I'm fine.  Come on, we have to keep moving.

column1: Can you fly that thing.
column2: Not yet.

column1: Morning.  Did you sleep?
column2: No.

column1: You don't have...
column2: Any holes?  Nope.  Me and my brother Dozer, we are 100 percent pure, old- fashioned, home-grown human.  Born free.  Right here in the real world. Genuine child of Zion.

column1: Zion?
column2: If this war ended tomorrow, Zion is where the party would be.

column1: It's a city?
column2: The last human city.  The only place we got left.

column1: Where is it?
column2: Deep underground.  Near the earth's core, where it's still warm.  You live long enough, you might even see it.

column1: Holy shit!
column2: Hey, Mikey, he likes it!  Ready for more?

column1: See who?
column2: The Oracle.

column1: What are they doing to him?
column2: They're hacking his mind.

column1: How?
column2: They inject virus-like serums to attack the neuro-systems.  It's like cracking a computer.  All it takes is time.

column1: How much time?
column2: Depends on the mind.  But eventually, it will crack and his alpha pattern will change from this to this.

column1: When it does, Morpheus will tell them anything they want to know.
column2: What do they want?

column1: Goddamnit!  I don't believe this is happening!
column2: Neo, this has to be done!

column1: Does it?  I don't know.  This can't be just coincidence.  It can't be! Can it?
column2: What are you talking about?

column1: Neo, this is loco.  They've got Morpheus in a military-controlled building.  Even if you somehow got inside, those are agents holding him.  Three of them!  I want Morpheus back, too, but what you are talking about is suicide.
column2: I know that's what it looks like, but it's not.  I can't logically explain to you why it's not. Morpheus believed something and he was ready to give his life for what he believed.  I understand that now. That's why I have to go.

column1: Why?
column2: Because I believe in something.

column1: Okay.  Store's open.  What do you need?  Besides a miracle...
column2: Guns.  Lots of guns.

column1: Operator.
column2: Mr. Wizard, get me the fuck out of here!

column1: Which way?  Which way?
column2: Duck!

column1: It's locked.
column2: Kick it in!  Kick it in!

column1: Operator.
column2: Tank, it's me.

column1: Yes.  They're moving him.  I don't know where yet.
column2: He's alive.

column1: We need an exit!
column2: You're not far from Cypher.

column1: Cypher, I thought --
column2: So did we.  I sent him to Franklin and Erie.

column1: Tank, you're hurt.
column2: I'll be all right.

column1: There is.  We have to pull the plug.
column2: You're going to kill him?  Kill Morpheus?!

column1: Operator.
column2: Tank, I need a pilot program for a military M-109 helicopter.

column1: Neo!
column2: What the hell just happened?

column1: An Agent!  You have to send me back!
column2: I can't!

column1: What just happened?
column2: I don't know.  I lost him.

column1: They've burned through the outer shields.
column2: Hurry, Neo.

column1: Isn't this Jack Groppi's place?
column2: Yeah.  But he ain't here now.

column1: Know where he is?
column2: Follow me.

column1: No, really, I liked it...thought it was great.
column2: Thanks.

column1: What are your plans?
column2: Well, we're here for about two weeks, then whatever else comes along... we're still working on our album and...

column1: Great...great...listen, I'm very interested in you guys because I'll be opening a new club myself soon... uptown...and maybe we can work something out...
column2: Sounds good.

column1: It's obvious that the girl doesn't want to accompany you, isn't it?
column2: Look fella...this is private...

column1: Whether she wants to or not...she's not going.
column2: Let go of her.

column1: We went down to Chinatown but they don't have any.
column2: Yeah, well, keep away from those Chinx.  They don't have shit.

column1: Well, I don't know if we want to buy all $40 worth...
column2: Hey!  You want good stuff, or you want shit?

column1: No.
column2: That means it's good.

column1: No, all we got is $40.
column2: You sure?

column1: Riverdale.
column2: Well, maybe they do that in Riverdale, but down here we take cash.  Now, you got it or not?

column1: Sssh!  Quiet.  Y'know that's illegal.
column2: Well the guy over there said...

column1: Well, we got $40, and we wanna buy...
column2: All right!  Quiet!  For $40 I could give you...

column1: Well, we want good stuff.
column2: Well, my stuff comes from Maryland... you know what that means?

column1: Yeah.
column2: And cherry bombs...ash cans...and rockets?

column1: Yeah.
column2: Ok.  Wait here.

column1: Ok, you guys get out, and wait here for me.
column2: Why?

column1: I gotta get the stuff.
column2: Can't we come with you?

column1: Hey hold it!  Gimmie the cash.
column2: Uh...can we give you a check?

column1: Keep quiet about this.  I don't have any license for him yet.  I've only had him a couple of days. Nobody can feed him except me.  I'm the only one he trusts.  Watch.
column2: Don't go to any trouble.  We believe you... We believe you.

column1: Really wanted to get a little tiger Charlie, y'know...a little William Blake and all that...
column2: Be careful.

column1: See what I mean?  A question please...'Is this what you call living?'
column2: 'Take a little tip from Mack the Knife...'

column1: And I wouldn't call it TONY'S PLACE or CHARLIE'S PLACE...  I'd call it something like SEASON OF THE WITCH... get it?
column2: You are with out a doubt the biggest, most pretentious bullshit thrower I know.  Like to see what kind of business you'd do.

column1: No.
column2: Anybody wanna have a game?

column1: May God be with you.
column2: 'And with your spirit.'

column1: 'Art thou the King of the Jews'?
column2: 'Dost thou say this of thyself, or have others told thee of me?'

column1: 'My kingdom is not of this world. If my kingdom were of this world my followers would have fought that I might not be delivered to the Jews. But, as it is my kingdom is not from here.'
column2: 'Thou art then a king?'

column1: Prophesy to us, oh Christ!  Who is it that struck thee?
column2: I don't know, but God help him if he does it again!

column1: Who's the girl?
column2: Jewish...

column1: Look at her.
column2: She don't look Jewish.

column1: Get out of here before this really goes up.
column2: Hide the gun.  Throw it away. Anything.  Listen, I gotta borrow your car...I think we should take a ride...away from here for the night...you know what I mean?

column1: Where to?
column2: Kennedy.

column1: I know, I know, stupid.  I mean where you goin'?
column2: It's an open ticket.  I can go anywhere up to $350.

column1: So?
column2: So I'll send you a postcard from wherever.  If I get there.

column1: Nervous?
column2: Yeah.

column1: You flew before?
column2: No.

column1: Hey, come on...
column2: Take it easy.  I only asked because maybe I could, you know, let you have a little something.

column1: Yeah, well thanks, but I got enough to hold me.  My mother can send me some.  I don't know.
column2: How about Teresa?  I could talk...

column1: Listen, I appreciate it, but I'll handle it myself.  I'll write.
column2: And say what?

column1: Listen, try a place with some sun. Swimming pools.  Palm trees.  Girls in little French bathing suits.
column2: Thanks for the ride.

column1: Panther...
column2: Panther!  Same thing...

column1: Hey...no more good times like before.  Until you come back.
column2: Sure.  And you're gonna take the vows next Tuesday, right.

column1: Waddaya think?
column2: Not quite...but keep trying.

column1: Next time, bet with your own kind.
column2: The number was 235 - I bet it combination.

column1: It'll be OK - I know those guys. They won't stiff you.
column2: I bet 235.  Because I dreamt of my grandfather - and when he died, the number of the funeral parlour was 235 - so when I dreamt...

column1: You got some mouth!
column2: Johnny, you're a real jerk-off.

column1: Drinks for everybody Tony...
column2: Giovanino!  Where have you been?

column1: What happened to you Flash?
column2: Charlie, I swear on my mother, you're not going to believe this.

column1: I know but let's hear it anyway.
column2: I swear to God Charlie, it's the truth.

column1: It's the truth, I swear.
column2: All right, forget it.  Tony, you got anything we can put on his face?

column1: Nah.
column2: C'mon Tony, waddaya say?

column1: Yes, you're gettin' it all over my tie.
column2: Should I slap him?

column1: I don't think I should go home looking like this.  You think I could stay at your place tonight? Your mother's not there is she?
column2: No, she isn't.

column1: You'd better make a move kid.  He thinks you're trying to screw him.
column2: Wouldn't bother me.

column1: Yeah, big man...get yourself in more trouble.  You make a fool out of him, you're doing the same to me. I signed for you don't forget.
column2: Don't worry.  I can handle it.

column1: You couldn't handle shit.  You just better come through with some kind of payment on Tuesday...anything. Understand?  Hold onto your pay- check this week.
column2: There won't be any this week.

column1: What do you mean?
column2: Didn't show up.

column1: You sick or what?  You forget what we had to do to get you on the trucks, stupid?
column2: I don't like loading crates.

column1: You're not supposed to like it. What gets me is your attitude. Listen... tomorrow you show up.
column2: What about your attitude...Where's your job...eh?  You talk and talk and I go to work...what do you do?

column1: I'll tell you what I don't do... I don't owe anybody 2,000 clams plus interest, stupid.  Show up or I break both your arms, we understand each other?
column2: Ok, ok...take it easy.  I'll show. Tuesday I'll give Michael something. I promise.

column1: Don't promise...just deliver.
column2: Ok, now that that's over with...what are you gonna make me for breakfast?

column1: I won't wait until Tuesday.  I'll break your arms right now.
column2: Listen...I'm a guest here.

column1: Hey...you got nothing here.
column2: I could have told you that.

column1: Don't come any closer!!!
column2: Cut it out stupid.  It's me.

column1: Hey...don't do that...I'm only scaring them.
column2: Stupid bastard...you get your cousin half-sick over this.

column1: Let's get out of here.
column2: Did you see them run!

column1: I swear to God Charlie...my arm still hurts from the car accident...that's why I didn't go to work.  I swear it.
column2: That's not going to help.

column1: I'm going to work this week...I mean it.
column2: It's impossible for you to catch up on the loan now...the interest is going up...$3,000...do you realize that, flash?

column1: I'm sorry Charlie...I didn't mean it.
column2: Big deal...in the meantime, it's done...I'll still try to help you out...You know that...but you gotta show some effort...some respect... understand?

column1: Charlie, you know the best way to take care of this whole mess.
column2: How?

column1: If you had a little talk with your uncle...if anybody can do it, he can.
column2: That'll help you out fine.  That's the best way for you, not for me! I swear to God, I'll rip you open if my uncle ever hears a word about this.  You understand?  I don't care what happens, he doesn't find out.

column1: I don't get involved with anything, you understand that?  Nothing!  I'm clean as far as you know...right?
column2: Yeah, take it easy.  Will you relax.

column1: That's what I get for getting involved.  Look, on pay-day at least show up at Tony's Place to meet him, ok?  This way he doesn't think that you're trying to screw him.  If you show good faith and save his face maybe we can talk and he'll take off the interest or make different payment arrangements or something... understand?  I'm not asking I'm telling you!!
column2: I understand.

column1: Keep your mouth shut.
column2: You tell me that in front of these creeps?

column1: Shut up!
column2: Yeah, Teresa, shut up!  We don't wanna get Charlie here in trouble, do we?...We love Charlie.

column1: Your cousin here was getting sick, worrying about you.  We've been in here calling...
column2: Oh, that's too bad, Teresa...

column1: Well kids...have the bans been announced yet?
column2: Don't be smart.

column1: Johnny, I swear to God, if you open your mouth about any of this...
column2: Me?  I wouldn't say a word to my aunt and uncle...or even your uncle, Charlie...

column1: You threaten me with my uncle? After what I'm doing for you?
column2: What you're doing for me isn't worth it...believe me!

column1: Take it.  I'm doing it for you, stupid!
column2: No you're not...

column1: Oh, cut it out, will ya?
column2: Charlie, twenty-eight bucks is nothing.  The only way to do it is through your uncle...think about it will you?

column1: NO!!!  What do you think I am, crazy???
column2: No, I just want to help myself, that's all.

column1: Don't you move!!!
column2: I'll be here.  Don't worry.

column1: Back so soon.
column2: Mind your own business.

column1: Hello, Michael.  I've got something for you...not much...but...
column2: He has about twenty-eight bucks... it's all he has on him.

column1: I think we should see your uncle.
column2: No.

column1: This can't be settled any other way now...I'll take full blame.
column2: Forget it.

column1: What are you going to do?  Hide me?
column2: Good idea.

column1: Hey...you're here.  They told me you're here...and you're here.  How are you?
column2: Ok, how's everything going?

column1: Don't ask...do you have any idea what I've been doing all morning...eh?
column2: No.

column1: I was in the basement fixing the pipes.  Would you believe that?
column2: What pipes?

column1: Look Charlie, you're a good boy. Will you just tell your uncle that I have nothing.  There is nothing to give him.  No envelopes with cash inside, no checks, nothing.
column2: That bad, huh?

column1: I can't make this week's payment and if this keeps up not next week's either.
column2: Not next week's either...listen...you tell that to Giovanni, not me.

column1: Listen, I should wrap up this place in a ribbon and hand it to him, you know that.  I don't need this aggravation.  I'm getting old.
column2: He'd rather have the loan payed, you know that.

column1: Your Uncle's a good man...I won't stick him.  Either he gets the money or the place and right now he's getting the place.  And tell me why should I care?  I got a partner who's a bum, who doesn't help out...who disappears and leaves me with all the problems.  I should go back to Florida...I don't need this.
column2: I don't understand, where's Groppi?

column1: I should know?  His wife don't even know.  Probably off with one of his little girls...I don't know.  I tell you, if he don't give a damn, then I don't give a damn...Why should I kill myself?
column2: My uncle figured that this week was bad...but about next week...I dunno. Maybe you should speak to him yourself.

column1: Oh great...hey - Winstons?
column2: For these prices don't be particular. That's all they had - but next week we'll see...

column1: OK, ok...
column2: Sell 'em if you can't smoke them.

column1: No...I'll be ok for a week.
column2: You seen Johnny Boy tonight?

column1: Nope...
column2: Isn't he supposed to be here tonight...I mean...

column1: Look...I don't know.  What am I supposed to be, his keeper or something?  Yeah, he's supposed to be here but who knows what goes on in his head.  Right?
column2: I'd like to know Charlie, it looks like your little friend is trying to duck me...

column1: ...Charlie, don't you think you should be interested in Johnny's payments to me?  I think you should be, you know that.
column2: Michael, nobody's out to screw you, I guarrantee that.

column1: I know that Charlie but look at my side.  You undersigned the loans. You vouched for him.  What happens if this kid don't pay me?  I gotta collect from you?  I don't want to do that.  I made a deal with him not you, right?
column2: You're right.  You're right.  Look, I'm not gonna wind up paying his debts.  You know that.

column1: I don't know that.  That's what I'm telling you.
column2: Michael, believe me.  You know the kid's a little crazy sometimes.  I vouched for him and he'll come through.  I promise.  I'll talk to him and straighten him out.  Don't worry, OK?

column1: Michael, give us a lift.
column2: OK, get in.

column1: Hey, shut up.
column2: Get him in.

column1: Disgraceful.
column2: Ok...that's it.

column1: Out!!!!
column2: C'mon Johnny.

column1: You getting out too?
column2: Yeah, thanks, it's ok.

column1: Oh Michael, look...
column2: Nevamind 'look'...This punk bastard...I call him at work...I say 'Johnny Boy there?'...He doesn't even show up for work anymore...

column1: Look...I've talked to him and I've talked to him...what more can I do...?  Tonight at the party all three of us get together and we knock some sense into his head...ok?
column2: All right...but understand, I don't like being taken advantage of.  I mean you're in there talking with your uncle and all...This is embarassing.

column1: What's a'matter?
column2: Nothin'.  Just stiffed those kids. Don't want'em comin' back and findin' you...start asking you questions.

column1: How much?
Well, he isn't.  Nice...real nice.
column2: He'll be here.  Look, take this for now.

column1: I have to talk to you.
column2: We are talking...

column1: No, in person.  Now.
column2: It's twelve-thirty!

column1: Alex, you don't know how long I've waited for this.
column2: Funny.

column1: What do you mean by "weird"?
column2: Greg never came home.  A few hours is one thing, Nick, but this is different. Something's happened to him.

column1: Can you turn off the game?
column2: I'm in the middle of it...

column1: Happy?
column2: No.  Look, I know you're not going to believe me, but listen anyway...  I think the game's alive somehow.

column1: No, wait.  Just listen.  I hooked it up earlier tonight, and it said my name.  As soon as I turned it on, Nick.  It said my name.  How could it know?  And then, I asked it where Greg was, and it said, "In here".
column2: Alex, I think you're freaking out. Greg's gone, I'll give you that.  And maybe he's in trouble.  But it's not ARCADE that's doing it...

column1: It is.
column2: How?!  It's a machine, Alex. Machine's don't think.  They're not alive.  It's a good program, a brilliant program, it was designed so it would act as if it were alive, but it's not alive.

column1: So how did it know my name, then?
column2: You imagined it.

column1: See, men always do this.  "Quiet down, honey.  Chill out.  Take a Valium". I'm not a fucking idiot, Nick!  I DID NOT IMAGINE IT!!!
column2: Quiet.  I do have parents, you know.

column1: It turned itself back on, Nick.
column2: No it didn't.  It's just a faulty relay or something.  It happens.

column1: Sorry.  Maybe I need the Valium.
column2: Call the others.  Laurie, Benz...

column1: Something's happened to them.
column2: It's the middle of the night.  They're asleep.  Phone didn't wake them.

column1: Because I didn't know where else to go.
column2: It's two o'clock in the morning.  Go home. Go to sleep.  We'll figure something out in the morning.

column1: It's not this weird.  It'll make sense. Everything gets weird this late anyway, right?
column2: Sure.

column1: We have to find out what's happened to them. I think they're gone...
column2: No way.

column1: If they're sick, great.  But let's make sure.  Come on, Nick.
column2: Okay.  We'll see what's up.  But if things are cool, I don't want to hear anything more about this.  Life's too short, know what I mean?

column1: Well?
column2: She thought Benz was at school.

column1: Where to now?
column2: Laurie's.

column1: This is like a movie or something.  I mean, am I paranoid or what?
column2: It doesn't necessarily mean she's...

column1: Change the channel!
column2: What?!

column1: Then leave her.
column2: We can't...

column1: Where do we go?
column2: My house.  I want to try something.

column1: That's what I thought.
column2: What?

column1: It's not just the cable system.  It's in the phone system as well, the electronic net.  It's everywhere.
column2: Nick, what is it.

column1: Maybe it is alive in a way...some sort of electronic intelligence.  It's like a computer virus that developed a personality or something.  It's self-replicating...it mimics life.
column2: Like the fractals?

column1: It's growing.  Getting stronger. Maybe it's only localized now...
column2: ...but then it hits the relay stations...

column1: Anywhere.  We have to stop it from getting out.
column2: It's already out.

column1: The Police, then...
column2: Give me a break, Alex.  What are we going to tell them?  Excuse me, officer, but there's some sort of electronic monster loose in the phone lines.  I'd think twice about calling any of those 976 numbers...

column1: Then where do we go?!
column2: I don't know.

column1: SLIP-STREAM.
column2: What?

column1: You mean we learn the rules...
column2: And beat it at it's own game.

column1: You realize that in order to do that, we'd actually have to play the game.
column2: I was afraid you'd say that.

column1: Virgin sacrifices?
column2: Drives 'em crazy every time.

column1: What Alex is trying to say is that it "seems" like it's alive.
column2: No I'm not...

column1: Go outside, get your car, and meet me out front with the engine running. And make it quick, okay?
column2: What are you going to do?

column1: Jesus Christ!
column2: I can't believe you made it!

column1: You got the schematics?
column2: Everything.

column1: I've been thinking about that.  ARCADE's like a virus, so it seems like the place to hit him would be where the virus started.  You know, like his point of origin?
column2: Dante's Inferno.

column1: Alex...
column2: You didn't hear me?

column1: What are you looking for?
column2: A way to hook this helmet into the game. I'm sure there are interfaces...

column1: I don't understand.  It wants us to play the game.  It's been taunting us ...
column2: Put in a quarter.

column1: It can turn itself on, Alex!  It doesn't need a quarter.
column2: Yes it does.  Don't you see?  We have to play by the rules.  That's what it wants.

column1: You're not coming, Alex.
column2: Yes I am...

column1: I know how to do this!  I'm good at these games.  You never play, you'd be nailed in an instant.
column2: And what if something happens to you? Am I suppose to go in after you alone?!

column1: You don't get it, do you?
column2: What?

column1: I don't want anything to happen to you.  I care about you.
column2: I already have a boyfriend, Nick.

column1: You feel it?  It's different this time.
column2: We're actually inside, aren't we?

column1: Okay.  Give us a kiss?
column2: One.  In case...

column1: Thanks.  Always wanted to do that.
column2: Yeah, well I figure these are unusual circumstances.

column1: I'll take the lead and handle the physical threats.  You watch the elapsed time and look for exits.
column2: Got it.

column1: Which way do you think Level Two is?
column2: You've got the schematics, check.

column1: Okay.  It's West.
column2: The keys are supposed to be at the end of each level.  Once we get all the keys, we can unlock ARCADE's heart. And then...

column1: The clock's already ticking.
column2: Right, then...

column1: And we've still got time left.  This was a piece of cake.
column2: Yeah, that's what worries me.

column1: Hey, my strength's low.  Look out for Fireflies.
column2: There...

column1: Shit...
column2: Check your read-out.

column1: Our time's up.
column2: What?!  There's nothing here!

column1: What the fuck is that?!
column2: Screamer.

column1: We can't reach that!
column2: We don't have a choice!

column1: So that's what we almost died for?
column2: One of them, anyway...  Did you see it?  The Screamer?

column1: Christ...no time...
column2: There never is.

column1: We can take the dunes down like a ski slope. Pretend you're on a snowboard.
column2: Never been on a snowboard.

column1: What is it?
column2: I just thought of something.  If we came back from the game...  ...what if ARCADE did too?

column1: Listen to me, Alex.  These counselor's don't know anything.  They're full of shit. If you don't fit the pattern of the perfect kid, they freak.
column2: I know.

column1: So tell me you're okay, then.
column2: I'm okay.

column1: Come on.  We'll hit Dante's after school, try the game out, maybe get some dinner.
column2: And then keep on driving?

column1: Go for it.
column2: Hold my keys, then.

column1: So how did you do it, Alex?
column2: Well, it's a long story...

column1: How did you get here?  Did you play the game?!
column2: Yes...

column1: Then we'll go home?
column2: Then we'll go home.

column1: Which way?
column2: That way.

column1: It's the wrong way!
column2: In this world, wrong is right!

column1: It's here!!!
column2: Oh God...oh god...

column1: What did he do to you?
column2: Is that your question?

column1: Think!  I want to go to the City of Truth, and the Truth Teller is from there...but which one is which?  The liar...think!
column2: You have no time.  What is your question?

column1: I'm thinking!
column2: You have no time.

column1: Mom?  You're alive...
column2: Of course I am.

column1: But I don't understand...
column2: I miss you so much, Alex.  I want so much to be with you...

column1: I love you, Alex.  I never wanted to leave. You know that, don't you?
column2: Yes...but...how did you...

column1: Is...is that where we are?  Did I die?
column2: Not yet, honey...

column1: We're glad you people could make it, and we're anxious to have you try out our new product.  We think it's going to be a big seller.  But you're the people that make it happen.  You're the market share everyone's tearing each other apart to get at.  It's your opinion that's going to make or break us.
column2: So what's so different about Arcade? You guys've been talking about it for months.

column1: A man after my own heart.  Straight to the point.  What's different about ARCADE is the way it reacts.  It responds like a human does.  It learns.  It adapts. Each time you play, it changes its strategy.
column2: That's impossible.

column1: "Escape"?
column2: In case things get too intense.  It automatically freezes the game, gives you a breather.  Things can get pretty wild...

column1: So what's the scenario?  Am I saving a princess?  Fighting Zombies?
column2: It changes.  There are eleven levels. Each one is a different layer of the ARCADE universe.  The concept is, you're entering the video game itself, making your way across the circuit board to the logic core ... ARCADE's brain.

column1: So how do I start?
column2: The game will guide you.

column1: So what do you think?
column2: Sign me up.

column1: This is one of our newest projects. We're trying to get rid of joy-sticks altogether ...
column2: The Air-Force is working on the same thing.

column1: It means she's screwed up.
column2: Fucked up.  That's what they said I was.

column1: Cool.
column2: Can you say anything but "cool"?

column1: One of these cities, is the place you seek. The Teller of Truths will take you there. But the City of Lies, is dark and bleak. And death is certain if you enter, beware.
column2: I am The Liar.  Where should I take you?

column1: So start at the beginning...
column2: Give her a chance, will you?

column1: Oh my God, I'm terribly sorry. Did I hurt you?
column2: I'm fine.

column1: Let me get you another glass of wine.
column2: I've had quite enough or I wouldn't be playing such games with beautiful strangers. Aren't Peter's illusions to your liking?

column1: They're a bit too real for my taste. Will you excuse me for a moment?
column2: Of course.

column1: Peter said you came to kill us. Is that true?
column2: No. I only needed the code from you.

column1: Take this off.
column2: He wants to kill you, you know... Perhaps I won't allow it.

column1: You didn't come here to destroy Wintermute. You can to save a man you love. A man who isn't even capable of returning that love. Such a waste...
column2: My man's coming to get my ass out of here. That's good enough for me.

column1: She's very striking, don't you think? Are these glasses a fashion where she comes from?
column2: She was prettier before she tarted herself up with the hardware.

column1: Security breach. Perhaps her friends have come to join our party.
column2: Splendid. We'll prepare a welcome for them.

column1: You're hurt...
column2: It's nothing. C'mon... we've got to transfer those funds and get the hell out of here.

column1: What about her?
column2: Of course...

column1: What are you doing in here?
column2: The Elders, mon...

column1: Can you get us into Straylight?
column2: Gettin' in is easy. It's getting out I'm thinkin' of.

column1: I'm getting used to it. Where are we?
column2: Straylight. Kitchen dock.

column1: What the hell is that?
column2: Skeleton key. This opens the gates of Babylon.

column1: What you lookin' for, mon?
column2: A place to tap in. I can scramble that signal before this place is crawling with guardsmen.

column1: Ghost a steppin' razor...
column2: No. Just Riviera trying to fuck with our heads. They're close. Very close.

column1: Easy...
column2: Play it straight with me and you've got nothing to worry about. When it's over, I inject you with the antitoxin.

column1: What's an A.I.
column2: An Artificial Intelligence. A computer system that's developed the capacity for sentient thought. They're dangerous and totally unpredictable.

column1: A little incestuous, but at least it's original. Who's the guy in the halloween costume?
column2: He's a vat grown Ninja, the Royal Family's bodyguard. Watch out for him, he's no joke.

column1: We did a pretty good job of pissing them off.
column2: They're only guessing, but we can't take any risks.

column1: The Villa Straylight. Home of the Royal Family and the mainframe of the computer entity we know as Wintermute. If we can get Molly in, she can access the mainframe to cripple Mute's defences, the Case can destroy it in Cyberspace.
column2: How's the villa's security?

column1: Alright. Let's talk business.
column2: Why not?

column1: Those are all your records. I can have you cleared on all counts. Possession. ...Contributing to the delinquency of minors... Statutory rape.
column2: I was set up.  She looked at least eighteen.

column1: Your gun, your prints. The Tessiers might overlook a little child molesting, but murder's bad P.R., Mr. Riviera. I suggest to reconsider my offer.
column2: You son-of-a-bitch, you're crazy.

column1: Then you'll have to persuade her to tell it to you.
column2: And how do you suggest I do that?

column1: Are you sure you're up to this, Mr. Case? We could reconvene tomorrow.
column2: You've got an expensive razor girl on me for a reason. I'd like to hear what it is.

column1: The corporate plundering of Yeshoto Industries... At first these seemed like unrelated incidents, but a pattern is emerging that suggests otherwise.
column2: What does this have to do with me?

column1: Our analysis of the London stock crash suggest that it was manipulated from within the international computer matrix. Cyberspace, Mr. Case... A realm I believe you're familiar with.
column2: Put the Sense/Net Police on it. The matrix is their turf.

column1: If someone is infiltrating the matrix on a global scale no political or economic system is safe. I'm assembling a team of specialists, Mr. Case. We need a man who can enter the matrix and trace this saboteur.
column2: My days of punching deck are over. For you or anybody else.

column1: What would you say if I told you we could correct your neural damage?
column2: I'd say you were full of shit.

column1: Then I'd ask you what your terms are.
column2: First, let's get something straight. We ran a psych construct on you that lists self destruction as your favourite pastime. If you want to kill yourself, Mr. Case, there's much more entertaining ways than working for me.

column1: It's the people close to me that tend to die... and I get the feeling you and I are going to be real buddies.  Terms?
column2: We'll match your rate just prior to your... accident. One half in advance.

column1: Who's running the show, Armitage? This a government sting?
column2: Questions make me nervous. Part of our arrangement will be that you don't ask too many.

column1: I'll think you'll find everything in working order. Molly's just having a little fun.
column2: I don't call this fun, pal. You're playing God with my body.

column1: You're a substance abuser, Case. Your pancreas was shot. Wouldn't have lasted out the year. We did you a favour and liberated you from a dangerous dependency in the bargain.
column2: Thanks, but I was enjoying that dependency.

column1: There are fifteen toxin sacs bonded to the lining of your main arteries. They're dissolving, Case... slowly, but they're definitely dissolving. You have just long enough to do the job.
column2: You son of a bitch...

column1: Why'd you do it, Armitage?
column2: The disturbance in cyberspace... It's an A.I.

column1: First sign of free will, Sense/Net usually slags 'em.
column2: This one's different. No one can trace it. It's out there somewhere in the matrix and it's growing stronger... infecting other computer systems like a virus.

column1: Anything rated higher than a P.C.'s got a hard-wired suicide switch. It'll self- destruct.
column2: It hasn't yet.

column1: I've heard about rogue A.I.'s, but there's only one guy who actually went up against one.
column2: Dixie McCoy

column1: Right. Best cowboy that ever punched deck. The old man taught me most of what I know.
column2: I've arranged for him to work with us.

column1: That's gonna be tough because Dixie McCoy's dead. The A.I. flatlined him.
column2: I know.  You ever work with ghosts, Case?

column1: What are you talking about?
column2: Sense/Net taped a full spectrum personality construct on McCoy six months before his death. Everything Dixie was -- everything Dixie still knows exists as a digitised construct.  Of course a tape can get misplaced in a library the size of Sense/Net's.

column1: Working with a dead man. Shit, I've done about everything else.
column2: You'll be ready for a trial run in two days. If your splices hold, you'll use McCoy to trace the A.I.'s coordinates.

column1: And then?
column2: Then we rendezvous with the final member of our team. For now, that's all you need to know.

column1: You ran without us.
column2: I cannot tell a lie. Sorry.

column1: Sorry, bullshit. We haven't even begun and you're already jeopardising this operation.
column2: What's he doing to my gear?

column1: What's this?
column2: Could be your A.I.'s calling card.

column1: Did you trace it?
column2: No, but it traced me.

column1: Fried Air Tram in the process. Not to mention half my gear.
column2: What about McCoy?

column1: He's got a little attitude problem, being that he's dead and all, but he'll come around. Where's Molly?
column2: Prepping your trip.

column1: Really? Do I get to know where I'm going? It makes packing so much easier.
column2: Offworld. The A.I.... this "Wintermute" thing evolved on a computer mainframe on the satellite Freeside. If you attack it from within the matrix while Molly accesses its original programming we can cripple its defence systems.

column1: That could work, but the timing will be a bitch.
column2: You'll be linked during the entire operation.

column1: Yeah, well it's working.
column2: Stick with her. I want the process to become second nature to you. We fly for Freeside at dawn.

column1: Let's hope she doesn't expect me to swim upstream.
column2: You see the couple up in the balcony?

column1: That's Lord Frederick Tessier. Owns most of Freeside. Wintermute's mainframe is centred in the Royal Family's villa.
column2: He's a Sense/Net Chairman. Why would he launch an A.I.?

column1: Good question. He may not have intended to. The girl in question is Lady 3Jane. She's very important to us. The third clone of Lady Jane Tessier.
column2: The old man cheats on his wife with her own clone?

column1: That's nice, but we can't dodge this kind of heat for long.
column2: We won't have to. The run is tomorrow night.

column1: Okay. The floor plans will be a piece of cake.
column2: Then once she's in you can guide her straight to the mainframe?

column1: As long as you cooperate.  I want it now, Armitage.
column2: What are you talking about?

column1: You've got your orders.
column2: This ain't Bangkok, chief.

column1: You find out in exactly two hours and forty-five minutes.
column2: I find out now.

column1: An odd selection, Mr Case.
column2: I prefer distrusting you. It'll keep us honest.

column1: Honesty. Almost as quaint a notion as your concept of good and evil.
column2: Can you read my mind?

column1: You're busy monkeys, Mr. Case. Busy, busy monkeys. Always building models... First stone circles. Then cathedrals... adding machines. I have no idea why I exist, do you know that? You... Your species eventually _had_ to create me. A thousand monkeys sitting at typewriters. One finally wrote "Wintermute".
column2: Are you even really alive?

column1: Tell me the words.
column2: The words?

column1: The access code to your mainframe.
column2: Ah, yes... the code. It's a riddle, actually. Some fancy of 3Jane's. Unfortunately, you'll have to find out for yourself. I can no more know that code than I can shut down my own hard wired defences. Now, our time is running short... and you haven't even touched your drink.

column1: What's inside me, Wintermute. What did your doctors do to me?
column2: Patience, Mr. Case. Only one hour and thirty-eight minutes to enlightenment.

column1: Then I'm out. I don't give a shit about you or this run.
column2: It's so easy for you, isn't it? You let Linda Lee die in Chiba City. Now you leave me with Molly, one more lamb to the slaughter. Perhaps it's _your_ soul that should be in question, Mr. Case.

column1: Ah, Herr Case. And how is the artiste tonight?
column2: Fine, Ratz. Thanks.

column1: I saw your girl yesterday.
column2: I don't have a girl.

column1: Too bad. I likes you better with her. Now, sometime you get maybe to artistic
column2: You're pleasant tonight.

column1: Always...By the way, you know that girlfriend you don't have?
column2: Yeah.

column1: Hey, bro.
column2: It's Case. Remember me?

column1: Case... Yeah, Miami Joeboy, quick study. How you doing, kid?
column2: Fine, Dixie. Fine.

column1: Last I heard you cracked Sukura International. I couldn't believe it.
column2: Yeah. That was me.

column1: Jesus Christ, Kid. Nobody's ever cracked Sukura.
column2: As far as they know, that's absolutely true.

column1: Ya learned good. So, what's happening?
column2: That's a good question. What's the last thing you remember?

column1: Nothin'. Not a goddamn thing. What the fuck...
column2: Dixie, you know how a ROM construct works?

column1: Sure, Kid. It's a firmware construct.
column2: Okay, Dix. You _are_ a ROM construct.

column1: What elders?
column2: Founders of Zion. Builders of Freeside.

column1: She's ready to go.
column2: Steppin' razor a warrior. But this man...  ...This man stone crazy. Surely, the Mute is a false prophet. Our paths uncertain.

column1: Maelcom... Do you think there's a hell for computers?
column2: All things possible in Babylon.

column1: So be it, we cross into Babylon like a cool breeze.
column2: I an' I, man. I an' I.

column1: We're doing fine. Take the next right.
column2: This place empty as a tomb, mon.

column1: Case, mon, you just tell me who not to kill.
column2: The girl 3Jane. We need her.

column1: Four men. Babylon soldiers.
column2: Can you walk?

column1: Ready?
column2: I an' I, Case. Jah guides us.

column1: Do we have enough fuel to make it back to Earth?
column2: Don't know, mon. This is a jumpship. Not meant for transport.

column1: Trajectory coordinates and a fuel ratio...  If we re-enter over Mexico, we just might make it.
column2: Jah guides us.

column1: What you're telling me is that I'm dead. Right?
column2: Right...

column1: I can't feel nothing because I am nothing.  Just playback. A ghost in the machine.
column2: You're Dixie McCoy's construct. That makes you something special.

column1: Don't patronise me, you fuck. I was skating figure eights in this matrix while you were still peeing in your chinos.  Hey, Kid... you expecting company?
column2: What?

column1: I'm surprised you still are. Should'a told me you had an A.I. running probes at you.
column2: I need its matrix coordinates, Dixie. I've got to nail that thing where it lives.

column1: Who got you into this?
column2: A guy who calls himself Armitage.

column1: Never heard of him.
column2: Nobody has.

column1: I duped these prints off him. Can you run an I.D.?
column2: No problem, amigo.

column1: What about the A.I., Dix? Sense/Net hasn't even been able to trace it.
column2: Those guys couldn't even find their own dicks with tweezers and a magnifying glass.  Tell you what, Bro. I'll make you a deal. I help you nail this A.I., you gotta do me one favour.

column1: What?
column2: When we're done, erase this friggin' tape.

column1: Yo.
column2: How are we doing?

column1: That A.I. of your's got the whole matrix hummin'. Sticks out like a spider in a web.
column2: Can you take me to it?

column1: Doesn't look like much, but that's King Hell ice, man. Fry your brain out soon as look at you.
column2: I have to figure out how to penetrate this thing, Dix... Crack its ice. We gotta get close enough to log the pattern.

column1: It's mutating... spreading like a disease.
column2: It ain't getting any prettier, that's for sure. I got the I.D. on this Armitage character. He a bright boy, your friend?

column1: Bright enough to be dangerous.
column2: That's pretty good cause he's only working with one lobe.

column1: He was an M.P. in Bangkok back in '21. Caught some shrapnel in the cerebral cortex and wound up living off a machine in a vegetable ward in Berne. Then, last September... surprise, surprise... he just seemed to disappear.
column2: Wintermute could have infiltrated that machine. Reprogrammed him.

column1: It's possible. The guy was a blank slate.
column2: So it does business through a brain dead marine and runs the stock market for funding. That means Wintermute hired us to fry itself. It doesn't make sense.

column1: Could be suicidal. It's not easy to kill yourself with all those hard wired defence programs.
column2: No. It's gotta be more than that. That hard wiring also keeps it from getting too smart. Too powerful.

column1: Getting fried ain't going to get it any smarter. What we got here is one mad dog schizo A.I.. Armitage is right about one thing, Bro. If we don't shut this mother down soon, nothing will be safe from it.
column2: The run is tomorrow night, Dixie. Can you crack its ice pattern?

column1: Where the hell have you been?
column2: We got problems topside.

column1: Well, it ain't exactly a bed of roses down here. We gonna run or not?
column2: We run. You crack the pattern?

column1: Yeah, but it ain't doing us any good. The way this is set up, I can't run shit unless I get inside its perimeter... and this goddamn thing would see me comin' from a mile away.
column2: You can make your move when it comes after me.

column1: What are you talkin' about?
column2: I'll let it access me. That'll give you a free shot. Make it a good one. Dix.

column1: It'll flatline your ass.
column2: Not for long. It needs me alive and I still need its access code. You got a better idea?

column1: Yo.
column2: How's the ice break?

column1: Take a look. Son of a bitch won't feel a thing until it's too late.
column2: How long, Dixie?

column1: Fifty-seven minutes twelve seconds.
column2: Not good enough, man. They planted something inside me. I'm on my own countdown.

column1: How much time you got left?
column2: Less than thirty minutes.

column1: Meet me back here in twenty-five. We'll kick this open if we can. But, Case... you need that access code or you'll just fry inside.
column2: Don't worry, Dix. I'm on a roll.

column1: You're late.
column2: How's the ice?

column1: One minute eighteen and counting. What about the access code?
column2: It's coming.

column1: You haven't got it?
column2: I said, it's coming. Just get me in, man.

column1: This thing's loaded with internal virus systems. You'll fry like an egg in there.
column2: Then I'll fry taking this son of a bitch out. I'm making the run, Dixie.

column1: What about the route to the core?
column2: I'll get you there. Your problem is making it alive.

column1: You, I presume are Mr. Armitage. And this is...
column2: Case.

column1: What about the mainframe's access code?
column2: 3Jane's the only person beside Tessier that knows the code.

column1: Wait... You hear that?
column2: What?

column1: Want to fucking answer them?
Hello, Case.
column2: I thought you already left.

column1: Why did you come here tonight, Linda?
column2: People are talking. They say the Yakuza has a contract out on you.

column1: I hear that shit once a week. Don't worry. Jo Jo Bao loves me.
column2: This time it's different. Someone ripped of a shipment of hallucinogens. Five grams of liquid ketamine. It was supposed to be Jo Jo's score.

column1: Where did you here that?
column2: Too many places. You're playing tag wish some kind of death wish, Case.  I'm sorry but I'm not sticking around for the funeral.

column1: Case... are you okay?
column2: I don't know. I don't know...

column1: I know who you are.
column2: There's no call for violence. I've simply accessed your memory for a spokesperson. You use that gun and it will only create another inconvenient interruption. You see, you've been avoiding me, Case.

column1: And we really do have to talk.
column2: You set me up from the beginning. It was you that got Julius killed.

column1: I had to limit your options.
column2: And Linda...

column1: You know why Linda's dead. She loved you and you let her down. It's that simple. Of course I did instigate certain events. Calculated the variables. I found her to be... expendable.
column2: I'm gonna burn you to the ground, you son of a bitch.

column1: Excellent. That's exactly what I had in mind. But if you're going to kill me, we have to work together, old son. I'm no pushover, you know.
column2: Shut down your ice patterns. I'll take you out.

column1: I can no more shut down my own natural defences that you can stop breathing. That's why I need you, Case. You're the only person alive who has a chance of penetrating my defences. My "ice" as you call it. I'm doing everything I can to make that possible.
column2: Why would you want me to kill you?

column1: Let's just say we have a destiny to fulfil, you and I.
column2: I think you're full of shit.

column1: I hope you can show more than you did when you let the Yakuza butcher Linda Lee.
column2: I'll give it my best shot, mother fucker.

column1: His name's Armitage. He's very anxious to meet you.
column2: Why should I want to meet him.

column1: Because you've exceeded your shelf life, Case. Word on the street is you're a dead man walking. Nice time for an employment opportunity. Travel to exotic locales.
column2: What's my end?

column1: What is it?
column2: ... a friend of mine's gonna get herself killed. I need my clip.

column1: Sorry. That's not gonna happen.
column2: Then, fuck you. I'm gone.

column1: Since when do sprawl doctors know more about nerve rehab than the Japanese?
column2: Since Armitage sold them a program on it. Put them years ahead of the competition.

column1: He's a resourceful guy, your boss. How long you work for him?
column2: Couple of months.

column1: What about before that?
column2: For someone else. Bodyguard. Courier... Whatever.

column1: Then you don't really know who he is, do you?
column2: I know who he isn't. Not C.I.A. Not Sense/Net. But... money comes in. Doors open. He's onto something.

column1: Maybe something's onto him.
column2: What's that supposed to mean?

column1: You've been calling her name.
column2: What?

column1: Holy shit...
column2: Hey... you're not supposed to be up.

column1: How long have I been out?
column2: Almost two days.

column1: I gotta know... did it work>
column2: We'll find out soon enough. If you don't pull the splices out.

column1: How soon is soon enough?
column2: Couple of days. They'll examine you.

column1: That's not going to help.
column2: The way I feel, believe me, it'll help.

column1: Not anymore. You got a new pancreas. Armitage's got you kinked so you can't get stoned.
column2: What the fuck... are you serious?

column1: I'm going in.
column2: You're not ready yet. They said two days.

column1: I'm not jacking with Armitage and his quacks breathing down my neck.
column2: If the splices aren't good, you could fry.

column1: I'll show you how to tell what's going on. If things go south, you unplug me.
column2: What is it with you? Why is it so important? It's a buzz, right? Like getting high.

column1: On a good run... yeah.
column2: So you're a wire junkie.

column1: When I was fifteen Sense/Net iced my old man's credit record over some computer error. Once that goes down, that's it. He lost his business... everything. It destroyed him. I had to hustle arcade games for chump change. Dixie McCoy found me, figured I was a natural. He taught me the wires for a piece of the action.
column2: A regular Fagan.

column1: Sure. I finally pulled a run on my old man's credit file when I was seventeen... only it was too late for him.
column2: Too late?

column1: The first fun's bound to be rough. It that read out fluctuates more than ten points... just pull this out. But if the EEG flatlines, don't touch anything.
column2: Won't that mean you're dead?

column1: Technically, yeah, but people have made it back after as long as three minutes.
column2: Dixie McCoy didn't.

column1: The point is, if you unplug me when I'm flatlines, I'm history. I got no way back.
column2: Okay fine. Let's get this over with.

column1: You okay?
column2: ...Yeah, but the Hosaka's history.

column1: Molly doesn't need a spook suit to get in here.
column2: Don't fuck with me. I don't want to hurt you.

column1: It sounds like you.
column2: Put the gun down, Case.

column1: ...Feels like you.
column2: Case...

column1: Case... it's four a.m.
column2: I don't sleep much. You packed?

column1: I'll get the car.
column2: They'll cut you down.

column1: Yeah... fine.
column2: Give me five minutes.

column1: What's wrong? Don't like flying?
column2: Not when Sense/Net throws the going away party. They'll be on our asses from now on.

column1: Case... Are you alright?
column2: Yeah... Yeah, I'm fine.

column1: You scared the shit out of me, man. You were dead for fifteen seconds. Totally flatlined.
column2: I'll be okay.

column1: Le Vingtieme Siecle. We're meeting Armitage there for the midnight floor show.
column2: Something exotic I hope.

column1: He projects with neural implants.
column2: That's risky gear. It can drive you schizo.

column1: I know.
column2: What went down between you and Riviera?

column1: Once I kicked, I swore I wouldn't let that happen again. I apprenticed a razor girl in Osaka. Went into hock for the implant and got my reflexes jacked up. Been taking care of myself just fine ever since.
column2: I know you have. C'mere.

column1: When they did my eyes, I made them promise I'd still be able to cry. Sounds stupid, doesn't it?
column2: No. It's important to be able to feel those things.  We're going to pull this run off, Molly, and we've got to do it soon.

column1: Is he going to make it?
column2: Sure... Maelcom's a rude boy, right, Maelcom?

column1: The code's some riddle of 3Jane's. Once I'm in the matrix, you'll just have to take a shot at it.
column2: ...And if I guess wrong?

column1: Then you and Maelcom get out of here before the place is crawling with guardsmen.
column2: We've still got to find the mainframe.

column1: My God... these people are insane.
column2: Or a little self-indulgent to say the least.

column1: Shit...
column2: What is it?

column1: Laser fail-safe. You can't get the code wrong... it slags you. I can't let you try it.
column2: You're out of time, man.

column1: I'm still going in.
column2: Hold on.

column1: Peter... What do you think you're doing?
column2: Surviving, darling. It's my specialty. Only this time I'm doing it my style. I've beaten him, you know.

column1: Who?
column2: Everybody's favourite computer, of course. He may have out calculated the rest of you, but I have certain qualities that don't translate well on microchips.

column1: Like what?
column2: Perversity, darling. The enjoyment of the gratuitous act. Tough to manipulate someone who doesn't give a flying fuck.

column1: Get up.
column2: What?

column1: How are you at riddles, Peter?
column2: What are you talking about?

column1: What the fuck kind of questions are those?
column2: Shut up.

column1: Don't wanna miss this.
column2: Lookit. Lookit!

column1: Gonna lose everybody out here....
column2: He died fast. And if we got any choice, that's the way we should all go out.  Don't you cry for Johns. Don't you dare.

column1: What? What is it?
column2: It's a fucking staircase! Go over it! GO OVER IT!

column1: You came for us....
column2: Yeah, yeah -- we're all fuckin' amazed. Anyone not ready for this?

column1: Probably okay to talk to me now.
column2: Not sure where to go. I was just runnin' away when this whole thing started.  Where you goin'?

column1: Audrey? Oh, Audrey....
column2: <u>What</u>?

column1: Tell me that was you.
column2: Okay, it was me. What'd I do now?

column1: Oh, Lord....
column2: It was just somebody else. From the crash. He was just....

column1: You mean...tonight? With all those things still out there?
column2: Oh, sure. Why not? Sounds like a hoot.

column1: Liquid oxygen canisters inside. Start ripping them out. Quick hits only -- try to make it last.
column2: Well, is someone coming for us? Or are we all just gonna die of exposure or dehydration or sunstroke or maybe even something worse?  Hey, you don't have to worry about scaring me.

column1: Bottle-count.
column2: Four fulls, one half. That mean we're halfway there? I hope?

column1: I didn't want you to leave me there... back at the ship...that's why I didn't say anything....
column2: No, we'd never....Oh, God, honey, you shoulda told me sooner.

column1: Bring the light!
column2: What're they doing? What're <u>we</u> --

column1: Three full bottles. But almost time to refill.
column2: Doesn't seem like enough to turn back on, does it?

column1: Tell me about the sounds. You told them you heard something right before....  If you don't talk to me, Johns'll take another crack at it -- at your skull.
column2: 'Mean the whispers?

column1: What whispers?
column2: The ones tellin' me to go for the sweet spot -- just to the left of the spine, fourth lumbar down. The abdominal aorta. What a gusher. Had a cup on his belt, so I used it to catch a little run-off. Metallic taste to it, human blood. Coppery. But if you cut it with peppermint schnapps, that goes away. Course, that's more for winter. Summertime, I take mine straight.

column1: All you people are so scared of me -- an' most days, I'd take that as a compliment -- but it ain't me you gotta worry about now.
column2: Show me your eyes.

column1: You did this? To yourself?
column2: Slam doctor. Well, we called him "doctor."

column1: Heard about it. Just never seen it.
column2: Fairly fuckin' ironic, wouldn't you say? Slamlight's so dim that you go and get your eyeballs taken out and shined up -- then you wind up here. Three ass-kick suns.  Maybe I did do a few people. But not this one. No ma'am, not this time.

column1: Then where is he? He's not in the hole. We looked.
column2: Look deeper.

column1: Power cells.
column2: They're coming.

column1: Strange, not doin' a run-up on the main drive yet.  Strange unless he told you the particulars of my escape.
column2: I got the quick-and-ugly version.

column1: An' now you're worried about a repeat of history?
column2: Entered our minds.

column1: I asked what <u>you</u> thought.
column2: You scare me, Riddick. That's what you wanna hear, isn't it? There, I admit it, Can I get back to work now?

column1: Why, what'd you hear?
column2: Well, guess if it was trickeration he'd just do me, huh? Then again...I am worth twice as much alive.  Didn't know? Johns ain't a cop. Oh, he's got that shiny badge an' all, but nah -- he's just a merc and I'm just a payday. That's why he won't kill me. The creed is greed.

column1: Riddick...was thinkin' we should make some kind of deal. Just in case, you know, this actually --
column2: Had it with deals.

column1: But I just wanted to say --
column2: Nobody's gonna turn a murderer loose. I fuckin' knew better.

column1: Been a long time since anyone's trusted me. That's somethin' right there.
column2: We can, can't we? Trust you?

column1: Where are the sand-cat tracks? Why aren't we still following them?
column2: Saw something I didn't like.

column1: What do you see? Riddick?
column2: Hunger. I see 60 years of hunger.

column1: Riddick? What the hell are you --
column2: <u>Listen</u>.

column1: Canyon ahead. I circled once to buy some time to think.
column2: Think about what?

column1: What about her?
column2: What it's gonna be like when we hit that canyon. With her bleeding.

column1: Back to the ship, huh?
column2: Get out of our way.

column1: How many you see?
column2: One or two.

column1: We're just here to carry your light, aren't we? Just the torch-bearers.
column2: Let's drop back an' boot up.

column1: As fast as you can.
column2: You sure you can keep --

column1: So where the hell's God now, huh?  I'll tell you where! He's up there PISSING ON ME!
column2: Riddick? How close?

column1: Tell me the settlement is right there! RIDDICK, PLEASE!
column2: We can't make it.

column1: Strong survival instinct. Admire that in a woman.
column2: You're not leaving. Not until we go back for the others.

column1: I promised them we'd go back with more light. And that's exactly what we're gonna do..
column2: Think you've mistaken me for somebody who gives a fuck.

column1: What, you're afraid?
column2: Confusin' me with Johns now -- fear was <u>his</u> monkey. I only deal in life and death. All that stuff in between? Some shade of grey my eyes don't see.

column1: <u>I trusted you</u>, Riddick. Goddamn, I trusted that some part of you wanted to rejoin the human race.
column2: Truthfully? I wouldn't know how.

column1: Just come with me!
column2: Got a better idea. Come with <u>me</u>.

column1: They're already dead. Get on board.
column2: You're fuckin' with me. I know you are.

column1: 'Course I am -- but doesn't mean I won't leave you here. If you believe anything about me, better be that.
column2: No, you see, I <u>promised</u> them...I have to...I have to go and....

column1: Step aboard, Carolyn.
column2: I can't....I can't....

column1: Here. Make it easy on you.
column2: Don't do this to me....

column1: Just give me your hand.
column2: But they...they could still be....

column1: You'd die for them?
column2: I would try for them.
