column1: You barely know them.
column2: But I'm human. I know you view that as a weakness, but I'm sorry -- I <u>do</u> feel fear, theirs too. Goddamnit, Riddick -- yes. I would die for them.

column1: This is it? Booze? <u>That's</u> what you have to drink?
column2: 200-year-old single-malt scotch is to "booze" as foie gras is to "duck guts."

column1: What do my eyes see?
column2: It's starting....

column1: Just a suggestion, but perhaps we should flee.
column2: Cargo hold, everyone in the cargo hold. lesgo, lesgo, lesgo.

column1: Christ, you don't know what's out there!
column2: I know what's in here!

column1: There....
column2: Like the light is scalding it.

column1: ...one cutting torch...one handlight here, two more in the cabin...I <u>think</u> two more....
column2: Spirits. Anything over 45 proof burns well.

column1: How many bottles?
column2: Not sure. Ten?

column1: Those umbrellas, the ones that mist. Would they burn?  If you got a receipt?
column2: Possibly.

column1: I hate to kill a beautiful theory with an ugly fact, but that sand-cat won't run at night.
column2: We'll have to carry the cells...drag them...whatever it takes.

column1: Let's move.  Just a detour. He'll get us there.
column2: Can we switch?

column1: What, switch what?
column2: I think I twisted my ankle running backwards like that. And I'm not sure I can....  Okay, that's a lie. I just don't want to be alone back there anymore. If you could just give me a few minutes up front here --

column1: Hey.
column2: Hey, who?

column1: Amazing. I'm Johns.
column2: Carolyn Fry. I'd shake hands, but...

column1: And him?
column2: Big Evil?

column1: We just keep him locked up forever?
column2: Be my choice. Already escaped once from the max-slam facility on --

column1: I don't need his life story. Is he really that dangerous?
column2: Only around humans.

column1: S'matter?
column2: Little swamp-flu from the Conga system. Never shook it with all this cryo-sleep.

column1: A very good sign.  That's Riddick's direction. You do <u>not</u> wanna be caught in the dark with this guy.
column2: Thought you found his restraints over there. Toward sunset.

column1: What?
column2: Tell me it's not a mirage.

column1: Probably makes it worse. Dehydrates you even more.
column2: Probably right.

column1: No, no, I wanted to get away.
column2: So I noticed. Never seen a "captain" quite so ready to leave her ship.

column1: Better keep moving....
column2: What'd Owens mean? 'Bout not touching the switch?

column1: Hey. You can tell me, Carolyn.
column2: Promise me. Swear to me you won't --

column1: You see anybody else here? Just between you and me.
column2: During the landing...when things were at their worst...Owens was at his best. He's the one who wouldn't let the pilot dump the passenger cabin.

column1: So now you know.
column2: Fuck. Guess I'm more glad to be here than I thought.

column1: Didn't bite.
column2: What?

column1: No juice, looks like it's been laid up for years. But we might be able to adapt --
column2: Shut up.

column1: Sorry. Thought I heard something.
column2: Like what?

column1: ...I don't play that...I don't play that so just try again. C'mon, Riddick, tell me a better lie....
column2: Ease up, ease up. JOHNS! Just tell me what....

column1: He used that?
column2: Sir Shiv-a-lot. He likes to cut.

column1: So why isn't it all bloody?
column2: I assume he licked it clean.

column1: I <u>know</u> what happened -- he went off on the guy, buried him on the hill somewhere, and now he's trying to --
column2: Let's just be sure.

column1: I <u>am</u> sure. Look, murders aside, Riddick belongs in the Asshole Hall of Fame. He loves the jaw-jackin', loves making you afraid, 'cuz that's all he has. And you're playing right into --
column2: <u>We're gonna find the body</u>, Johns. Christ, you're a cop. Why am I tellin' you this? We gotta go down and find it.

column1: Well, don't ask me to.
column2: Thought you didn't believe his story.

column1: Nobody else is going down but me, okay?
column2: Hey. Bein' ballsy with your life now doesn't change what came before -- it's just stupid.

column1: What, you think I'm doin' this to prove something?
column2: You said it, not me. Let's just not let one bad call lead to another.

column1: Little ratty-ass.
column2: Nothing we can't repair -- so long as the electrical adapts.

column1: Okay, that should buy us a sys-check. But we'll need more cells.
column2: How many?

column1: 15 6-gigs here...90 gigs total...other ship carries 20-gig cells, so...five. Five total to launch.
column2: 25 kilos each, huh?

column1: Rag it, Riddick. Nobody wants your theories on --
column2: So what happened? Where are they, then?

column1: Let's board this up and get the hell gone. They seem to stick to the dark, so if we stick to daylight, should be all --
column2: 60 years ago.

column1: ...need those cells from the crash ship. Shit, still gotta check out the hull, patch the wings --
column2: Let's wait on the power cells.

column1: Wait for what? Until it's so dark we can't even find our way back to --
column2: We're not sure <u>when</u> it happens, so let's not --

column1: He can pilot?
column2: Hijacked a prison transport, made a helluva good run 'fore I tracked him down.

column1: Okay, maybe that's a <u>good</u> thing. Maybe I can use him to help with --
column2: He also figured out how to kill the pilot, Fry.

column1: You said we were going to trust him now. You said there was a deal.
column2: That's what I said.

column1: Oh, this is a dangerous game you're playing, Johns.
column2: May've noticed chains don't work on this guy. Only way we're truly safe is if he believes he's goin' free. But if he <u>stops</u> believin' --

column1: You mean, if he learns that you're gonna royally fuck him over.
column2: -- we need a fail-safe. Bring the cells over at the last possible minute -- when the wings are ready, when we <u>know</u> we're ready to launch.

column1: You know, he hasn't harmed any of us. Far as I can tell, he hasn't even lied to us. Just stick to the deal, Johns. Let him go if that's what it --
column2: He's a murderer. The law says he's gotta do his bid.

column1: Dancin' on razor blades here...
column2: I won't give him a chance to grab another ship -- or to slash another pilot's throat.

column1: You're not a real cop, are you? Just some mercenary who goes around talkin' about the law like --
column2: I never said I was.

column1: You have a little caffeine in the morning, I have a little morphine. So what?
column2: And here you got two mornings every day. Wow, were you <u>born</u> lucky?

column1: Not a problem unless you're gonna make --
column2: <u>You</u> made it a problem when you let Owens die like that. When you had enough drugs to knock out a fucking mule-team.

column1: Owens was already dead. His brain just hadn't caught on to that fact.
column2: Anything <u>else</u> we should know about you, Johns? Christ, here I am lettin' you play games with our lives when --

column1: My first run-in with Riddick. Went for the sweet-spot and missed. They had to leave a piece of the shiv in there. I can feel it, sometimes, pressing against the cord.  So maybe the care and feeding of my nerve-endings is my business.
column2: You coulda helped. And you didn't.

column1: Stop it, stop it, STOP IT!
column2: 'Sokay, 'sokay. I killed it.

column1: Oh, lady. If you're in your right mind, I pray you go insane.
column2: We can stick to the plan. If we get four cells back to the skiff, we're off this rock.

column1: Look, we gotta think about everyone now -- the kid especially. How scared is she gonna be out there?
column2: Oh, don't use her like that, for a smoke screen.

column1: Smoke screen for what?
column2: For your own fear.

column1: How much you weigh, Johns?
column2: What the hell's it matter?

column1: How much?
column2: 79 kilos.

column1: He'll lead you over the first cliff. You know that, don't you?
column2: We're just burnin' light here.

column1: You give him the cells and the ship -- and he will leave you. He will leave you all out there to die.
column2: I don't get it, Johns. What is so goddamn valuable in your life that you're worried about losing? Huh? Is there anything at all? Besides your next hype?  Got no right to be so scared. Neither one of us.

column1: So you noticed too?
column2: Riddick. <u>Riddick</u>.

column1: We aren't completely stupid.
column2: Stay in the light! Everybody! Stay in the fucking --

column1: Hey, <u>you're</u> the one who got me out here, turned me into a goddamn sled dog. An' now you 'spect me to go back like a <u>whipped</u> dog?
column2: I was wrong. I admit it. My bad, okay? Now let's just go back to the ship.

column1: I dunno. Nice breeze, wide open spaces -- you know, I'm startin' to enjoy myself out here.
column2: Are you fucking high again? Just listen to --

column1: This does not help us, Johns.
column2: -- she tried to blow the whole fucking passenger cabin, tried to kill us --

column1: Just shut up, okay?
column2: -- tried to kill us in our sleep. Paris had it right -- we <u>are</u> disposable. We're just walking ghosts to her.

column1: We cannot go through there....
column2: How much you weigh right now, Fry? Huh?

column1: It's the atmosphere. Too much pressure, not enough oxygen. Might take a few days to --
column2: So what the bloody hell happened, anyways?

column1: Well? Is it just the pump?
column2: Ask if anyone has anything in cargo! Anything to drink!

column1: Imam. We should leave soon. Before nightfall but while it's cooler.
column2: What, you're goin' off, too?

column1: Why did I fall on you?
column2: He's dead. Cap'n's dead. Christ, I was looking right at him when --

column1: I mean, I mean, chrono shows we're 22 weeks out, so gravity wasn't supposed to kick in for another 19. I mean, I mean, I mean, why did I fall <u>at all</u>?
column2: You hear me? Captain's dead. Owens too.

column1: 1550 millibars, dropping 20 MB per minute, shit, we're hemorrhaging air. <u>Somethin'</u> took a swipe at us.
column2: Just tell me we're still in the shipping lane. Just show me all those stars, all those bright, beautiful, deep-space....

column1: Fry?
column2: Can't get my nose down...too much load back there....

column1: You mean that "load" of passengers?
column2: So what, we should both go down too? Out of sheer fucking nobility?

column1: Look, Fry. Company says we're responsible for every one of those --
column2: Company's not here, is it?

column1: When captain went down, you stepped up -- whether you like it or not. Now they train you for this, so --
column2: And there wasn't a simulated cockroach alive within 50 clicks of the simulated crash site! <u>That's</u> how they train you! On a fucking simulator!

column1: Owens!
column2: 70 seconds! You still got 70 seconds to level this beast out!

column1: I don't suppose....
column2: One of the Christian habits we <u>didn't</u> adopt -- perhaps unfortunately. We'll have to wait.

column1: So quiet. You get used to the sounds of the ship, then....
column2: You know who Muhammad was?

column1: Some prophet guy?
column2: "Some prophet guy." And a city man. But he had to travel to the desert -- where there was quiet -- to hear the words of God.

column1: You were on a pilgrimage? To New Mecca?
column2: Chrislam teaches that once in every lifetime should there be a great hajj -- a great pilgrimage. To know God, better, yes, but to know yourself as well.

column1: Frightening thought.
column2: We're all on the same hajj now.

column1: One is all?
column2: For now.

column1: I saw the cut-marks on the bones. Wasn't a natural die-off.
column2: Quiet, please. Everyone.

column1: Hasan?
column2: Riddick?

column1: They're afraid of our light. That means we don't have to be so afraid of them.
column2: And you're certain you can find the way back? Even in the dark?

column1: Imam. Slow down.
column2: What?

column1: Don't stop, just slow down.  Little more space 'tween us and them.
column2: I would rather we all stay--

column1: The sled as a shield....
column2: And what about the cells?

column1: Oh, no. No, no, no....
column2: Rain.

column1: Has anyone seen the young one? Ali?
column2: Has anyone checked the coring room?

column1: Well...we must keep her close, then. Here, she'll be safe if we put her between --
column2: There is no "safe."

column1: Where's Mr. Johns?
column2: Which half?

column1: What're you doin'?
column2: Blessing you like the others.  It's painless.

column1: And pointless.
column2: I see. Well, even if you don't believe in God, it doesn't mean He won't be --

column1: 'Cuz you don't spend half your life in lock-down with a horse-bit in your mouth and not believe. And you surely don't start out in a liquor store trash bin with an umbilical cord wrapped around your neck and not believe. Oh, absolutely I believe in God. And I absolutely hate the fucker.
column2: He will be with us. Nonetheless.

column1: Suleiman!
column2: Get the girl back under. Keep going.

column1: SULEIMAN!
column2: KEEP GOING OR I WILL!

column1: New Mecca....
column2: Think a soul could get lost there? With all those pilgrim-types?

column1: For what? There is no water. You understand that, don't you?
column2: All deserts have water, somewhere. God shall lead us there.

column1: "God is Great," yes?
column2: I'm born-again.

column1: We got you...it's okay, it's okay...we got you now....
column2: The child heard you before any of us could even....

column1: I had the impression...from the model... that the two planets were moving as one. That there would be...a lasting darkness.
column2: Those suns gotta come back <u>sometime</u>. And if these animals really are phobic about light, we just sit tight till then.

column1: Oh, Trash Baby, you're gonna regret this.
column2: Please...this solves nothing...please....

column1: We crossed our own tracks.
column2: He's running us 'round in circles. Look for yourself. Look!

column1: She's the captain, we should listen to --
column2: Listen to her? <u>Her</u>? When she was willing to sacrifice us all?

column1: ...then we saw this.
column2: Anyone else having breathing problems? Aside from me?

column1: King Tut's tomb....
column2: Be surprised what these will fetch in the Taurus system. Here. This Wooten here -- easy, easy. Very rare.

column1: A toast to whatever he just said.
column2: I'll need a receipt for that.  For all these.

column1: What the hell are these?
column2: Maratha crow-bill war-picks from Northern India. Very rare.

column1: So just like that. Wave your little wand and he's one of us now.
column2: Didn't say that. But least this way I don't have to worry about falling asleep and not wakin' up.

column1: Well, just a skiff. Disposable, really.
column2: Like an emergency life-raft, right?

column1: Very big beads.
column2: Not staying in here another....

column1: She's the pilot, she should stay close to the cells.
column2: Oh, so I'm disposable?

column1: Found somethin' worse than me, huh?
column2: We're movin'. And I'm just wondering if I shouldn't lighten the load right now.

column1: Want you to remember this moment, Riddick. The way it coulda gone and didn't.
column2: Say that again.

column1: Here's the deal. You work without the chains, without the bit -- without the shivs. You help us get off this rock....
column2: For what? The honor of goin' back to some asshole of a cell?

column1: You'd cut me loose, Boss?
column2: Only if we both get outta this alive. And there may be a way.

column1: My recommendation: Do me. Don't take the chance that I'll get shiv-happy on your wannabe ass. Ghost me, Riddick. Would if I were you.
column2: If you were me, I'd kill us both. C'mon, you wanna sit at the grown-up table or not?

column1: Are you fuckin' kidding me?
column2: Not afraid of the dark, are you?

column1: I'd rather piss glass.
column2: Well, you got the big gauge.

column1: Think about that reward, Johns.
column2: I'm willing to take a cut in pay.

column1: <u>Fuck me</u>. You said "clear."
column2: Said "looks clear."

column1: Well, what's it look like now?
column2: Looks clear.

column1: Such as.
column2: Hard to tell, sometimes...even for me... but looked like a bunch of those big boys chewin' each other's gonads off. Thought we'd swing wide. Okay by you?

column1: About how to kill us and still get these cells to the skiff. Goddamnit, we're just doin' the heavy lifting for this prick!
column2: About the girl.

column1: What're you jaw-jackin' about? Girl's not cut.
column2: No. She's not.

column1: Aw, this can't be happening to me....
column2: They been nose-open for her ever since we left. They go off blood.

column1: Ain't all of us gonna make it.
column2: Just realized that, huh?

column1: Six of us left. If we could get through that canyon and lose just one, that'd be quite a fucking feat, huh? A good thing, right?
column2: Not if I'm the one.

column1: Look, it's hellified stuff -- but no different than those battlefield doctors when they have to decide who lives and who dies. It's called "triage," okay?
column2: Kept calling it "murder" when I did it.

column1: Either way, figure it's something you can grab onto.
column2: Sacrifice play. Hack up one body, leave it at start of the canyon. Like a bucket of chum.

column1: <u>Trawl</u> with it. There's a cable on the sled. We can drag the body behind us.
column2: Nice embellishment.

column1: Don't wanna feed these land-sharks -- just keep 'em off our scent.
column2: So which one caught your eye?

column1: What's her name, anyway?
column2: What do you care?

column1: Then let's not name the Thanksgiving turkey, okay? I assume you still got a shiv.
column2: What, you 'spect <u>me</u> to do it?

column1: What's one more to you? Like <u>this</u> is the one that sends you to Hell?
column2: Oh, you're a piece of art, Johns. They oughtta hang you in a museum somewhere. Or forget the museum -- maybe they should just hang you.

column1: Aw, don't tell me you're growin' scruples.
column2: Just wonderin' if we don't need a bigger piece of chum.

column1: An' this?
column2: Blow-dart hunting stick from Papua New Guinea. Very <u>very</u> rare, since the tribe's extinct.

column1: 'Cuz they couldn't hunt shit with these things, be my guess.
column2: Well, what's the need, anyway? If he's gone, he's gone. Why should he bother us?

column1: So much for your nightfall.
column2: So much for my cocktail hour.

column1: Amazing how you can do without the essentials of life -- so long as you have the luxuries.
column2: Well, just keep your bloody-fuckin' eyes open. Don't want that ratbag sneakin' up on me bloody-fuckin' arse.

column1: Not a star-jumper.
column2: Doesn't need to be. Use this to get back up to the Sol-Track Shipping Lanes, stick out a thumb. You'll get picked up.  Right?

column1: What, you don't really think they left with their clothes on the lines? Photos on the walls?
column2: Maybe they had weight limits, you don't know.

column1: You were tryin' to kill him too.
column2: Just wanted his O-2.  Though I notice he tried to ghost my ass. When he shot up that stranger instead.

column1: Take it.
column2: What, it's broken?

column1: Cornelius, if you have a moment today, I'd like to discuss this expedition of yours in more detail.
column2: Certainly, sir. I'll get my notes and come right over.

column1: Dr. Zaius --
column2: Did you forget our appointment, Cornelius?

column1: Oh., no., sir. I was just assembling my notes.
column2: You know Dr. Maximus, our Commissioner for Animal Affairs?

column1: He exceeded his orders. His travel permit was promptly revoked.
column2: Yes, sir, so it was -- thanks to you. But not before I discovered evidence of a simian culture that existed long before the Sacred Scrolls were written ...

column1: How did you know we'd come here?
column2: It wasn't difficult. Only an apostate or a lunatic would flee to the Forbidden Zone.  I see you brought along the female of your species.  I didn't realize a man could be monogamous.

column1: I ask you to reconsider the rash course you've taken. If you're convicted of heresy, the most you'll get is two years. But if you persist in pointing guns in my direction, you'll hang for high treason.
column2: We've never meant to be treasonable, sir.  But up there, in the face of that Cliff, is a vast cave -- and in that cave a fabulous treasure of fossils and artifacts.

column1: Indeed, the very fact that these tools are unknown to us could suggest a culture in certain ways almost equal to our own. Some of the evidence is uncontestable ...
column2: Don't speak to me in absolutes. The evidence is contestable.

column1: I apologize.
column2: To begin with, your methods of dating the past are crude, to say the least. There are geologists on my staff who would laugh at your speculations.

column1: A doll alone proves nothing. True. But the doll was found beside the jawbone of a man -- and no trace of simian fossils has turned up in this deposit.
column2: Your conclusion is premature. Have you forgotten your Scripture? The Thirteenth Scroll?  'And Proteus brought the upright beast into the garden, and chained him to a tree, and the children made sport of him.'

column1: No sir, I haven't forgotten.
column2: Well? For a time the ancients kept humans as household pets.

column1: Seal the cave?
column2: That's correct. And you will both stand trial for heresy.

column1: Well, Taylor -- we're all fugitives now.
column2: Do you have any weapons?

column1: The best. But we won't need them.
column2: Just the same, I want one.

column1: As you wish.
column2: Zaius seems to think there might be another jungle beyond the Forbidden Zone. That's what  we'll try for. What about you?

column1: To the diggings I worked at a year ago. It's a three day ride across the eastern desert, near where you claim you landed from that planet of yours.
column2: You still don't believe me, do you?

column1: Nothing much. The remnants of a life raft. Maybe a small flag. The emblem of my countrymen.
column2: Sorry, Taylor. The terrain around that lake is poisonous. There is no fresh water, no vegetation. Nothing.

column1: Where does the river lead?
column2: It empties into a sea some miles from here. That's where the cave is.

column1: You've never told me why this region's called the Forbidden Zone.
column2: No one really knows. It's an ancient taboo. Set forth in the Sacred Scrolls. The Lawgiver pronounced the area deadly.

column1: When are you going to show me what's in the cave?
column2: Right now, if you like.

column1: If there's any shooting, Dr. Zaius, you'll be the first to die. Depend on it.
column2: Taylor, you're not in command here. Put down that gun.

column1: Taylor, I'd rather you -
column2: No. You saved me from this fanatic. Maybe I can pay you back.

column1: Yes. I have to agree. From all you've found so far, his position's as good as yours.
column2: What are you doing there?

column1: That was different. We thought you were .... inferior.
column2: And now you know the truth.  Cornelius has beaten you, Doctor. He proved it. Man preceded you here. You owe him your science, your language, whatever knowledge you have.

column1: They can't convict us of that. You proved our innocence. Besides...  ... his culture is our culture.
column2: Good luck then.

column1: Do you have to work tonight?
column2: No.

column1: That's Bright Eyes. The one I was telling you about.
column2: What's so special about him?

column1: Look -- she remembers.
column2: Remembers what?

column1: The blood transfusion.
column2: Zira, come on. You know they can't --  Oh oh. Here comes Number One.

column1: It's a stunt. Humans don't write.
column2: Dear, you're a scientist. Don't you believe your own eyes?

column1: Now, just a minute --
column2: Oh, Cornelius, be quiet.

column1: 'Dodge was killed in the hunt. What happened to Landon?'  I don't know.
column2: And they fell out of the sky with you?

column1: Flight is a scientific impossibility.
column2: And even if it weren't, why fly? Where would it get you?

column1: Cornelius, why do you insist on provoking him?
column2: No creature can survive in that part of the Forbidden Zone. I've been there. I've seen it.

column1: 'Then how do you account for me?,
column2: I don't. And I'm not going to try.

column1: But what about your theory? The existence of someone like Taylor might prove it.
column2: Zira, are you trying to get my head cut off?

column1: Don't be foolish. If it's true, they'll have to accept it.
column2: No, they won't -

column1: Cornelius has developed a brilliant hypothesis -
column2: It's probably wrong --

column1: -- that the ape evolved from a lower order of primate, possibly man. In his trip to the Forbidden Zone he discovered traces of a culture older than recorded time -
column2: The evidence was very meager --

column1: You didn't think so then.
column2: That was before Dr. Zaius and half the Academy said the idea was heresy.

column1: 'I am not a missing link.'
column2: Because if he is a missing link, it means the Sacred Scrolls aren't worth their parchment.

column1: Well, maybe they're not.
column2: No, thank you'. I won't get into that battle.

column1: Oh, Cornelius, show some strength!
column2: Zira, listen to me. We've got a fine future ahead of us. Marriage. Stimulating careers. I'm up for a raise --

column1: A toy. It floats on the air.  Try it.
column2: Zira....

column1: How did it go?
column2: There was one bad moment -- some hunters stopped us.

column1: We'd better get started. If the mounted police pick up our trail, they'll come this far at least.
column2: Right.  Let's put the water and provisions in the wagon.

column1: Got your sensors?
column2: Yo!

column1: Geiger counter?
column2: Yo!

column1: One pistol... twenty-four rounds of ammo. two medical kits.. one camera... one TX9.  We've enough food and water for three days.
column2: But how long is a day?

column1: Nothing will grow here .... there's just a trace of hydrocarbons, and most of the nitrogen is locked into nitrates.
column2: Any sign of dangerous ionization?

column1: No.
column2: Okay. If there's no life here, we've got just seventy-two hours to find it. That's when the groceries run out.

column1: Which direction?
column2: That way.

column1: Any particular reason?
column2: None at all.

column1: Taylor -- quit riding him.
column2: You're more than three hundred light years from your precious planet. Your loved ones have been dead and forgotten for twenty centuries. Even if you could get back, they'd think you were something that fell out of a tree.

column1: Where there's one there's another. And another. And another.
column2: Let's find them all.

column1: Well, at least they haven't tried to bite us.
column2: Blessed are the vegetarians.

column1: Which one was wearing the strange clothes?
column2: Him.

column1: Will he live?
column2: I don't know. This beast lost a lot of blood.

column1: This place is dirty, doctor.
column2: These animals are dirty, doctor. They stink, and they carry communicable diseases. Why aren't they cleaned up before they're brought here?

column1: But the quota system's been abolished! You made it. Why can't I?
column2: What do you mean, made it? I'm an animal psychologist, that's all. We don't have any authority.

column1: You do pretty well when it comes to getting space and equipment.
column2: That's because Dr. Zaius realizes our work has value.

column1: Hmph.
column2: The foundations of scientific brain surgery are being laid right here - in studies of cerebral function in these animals.

column1: Objection. The accused is indeed a man. Therefore, he has no rights under ape law.
column2: Well, Dr. Zira? This is a man, is he not?

column1: State your case, Mr. Prosecutor.
column2: Learned Judges: My case is simple. It is based on our first Article of Faith: that the Almighty created the ape in his own image

column1: There is a conspiracy afoot to undermine the very cornerstone of our Faith
column2: Come to the point, Dr. Honorius.

column1: He can reason? With the Tribunal's permission, let me expose this hoax by direct examination.
column2: Proceed. But don't turn this hearing into a farce.

column1: That's true, Dr. Zaius. My witnesses -- correction -- my exhibits are on display in the amphitheater.
column2: Very well. I suggest we go and look at them.

column1: Objection! These remarks are profane and irrelevant.
column2: Sustained.  Your archeological theories have no bearing on the disposition of this creature.

column1: Objection!
column2: Sustained.

column1: Yes, sir. The State charges Doctors Zira and Cornelius with contempt of this Tribunal, malicious mischief and scientific heresy.
column2: Be it so ordered. The Tribunal will examine all the evidence presented here and in due time render a verdict on the proposed indictment and on the disposition of the deviate in question.  This hearing is adjourned.

column1: Tell the court, Bright Eyes -- what is the second Article of Faith?
column2: I admit, I know nothing of your culture.

column1: Of course he doesn't know our culture - because he cannot think.  Tell us why all apes are created equal.
column2: Some apes, it seems, are more equal than others.

column1: Ridiculous. That answer is a contradiction in terms. Tell us, Bright Eyes, why do men have no souls? What is the proof that a divine spark exists in the simian brain?
column2: Show this to the President.

column1: Good morning, Dr. Zira.
column2: Good morning, Julius. How's our patient today?

column1: You could get hurt doing that, Doctor.
column2: Don't be silly. He's perfectly tame.

column1: Awww, it still hurts, doesn't it?
column2: See? He keeps pretending he can talk.

column1: Did you see that? It's remarkable!
column2: Huh?

column1: He's trying to form words.
column2: Well, you know what they say. Human see, human do.

column1: What happened?
column2: Those fools and their torches! Do you have any ointment?

column1: Get me a collar and leash. I'm taking him to the infirmary.
column2: He's vicious, Doctor. Besides, it's against the rules.

column1: Landon! Send a last signal.
column2: What signal?

column1: It's no use ... there she goes.
column2: Forget it. Abandon ship.

column1: Gone.
column2: We're here to stay.

column1: Well? Where are we? Have any notion, skipper?
column2: We're some three hundred and twenty light years from Earth. On an unnamed planet in orbit around a star in the constellation of Orion.  That could be Bellatrix.

column1: Landon! Join the expedition.
column2: Sorry...  I was thinking of Stewart. What d'you suppose happened?

column1: Air leak. Died in her sleep.
column2: You don't seem very cut up about it.

column1: It's a little late for a wake. She's been dead nearly a year.
column2: Then we've been away from Earth for eighteen months.

column1: Apart from that, you look pretty chipper for a man who's two thousand and thirty one years old.  I read the clocks. They bear out Hasslein's hypothesis. We've been away from Earth for two thousand years, give or take a decade.  Still can't accept it, huh?
column2: long pause) You know it.

column1: Because time has wiped out everyone and everything you cared for -- they're dust.
column2: Prove it. If we can't get back, it's still just a theory.

column1: If only we could get a fix.
column2: What would you learn? I've told you where you are and when you are.

column1: All right --
column2: There's only one reality left. We're here and it's now. You get ahold of that and hang on tight, or you might as well be dead.

column1: Straighten me out on something. Why did you come along at all? You volunteered. Why?  I'll tell you. They nominated you for the Big One and you couldn't turn it down. Not without losing your All-American standing
column2: Climb off me, will you!

column1: And the glory, don't forget that. There's a life-sized bronze statue of you somewhere. It's probably turned green by now, and nobody can read the name plate. But never let it be said we forget our heroes.
column2: Taylor.

column1: Okay. You read me well enough. Why can't I read you?
column2: Don't bother

column1: Dodge ... he's not like me at all. But he makes sense. Held walk naked into a live volcano if he thought he could learn something no other man knew. I understand why  he's here. But you...You're no seeker. You're negative.
column2: But I'm not prepared to die.

column1: Scarecrows?
column2: Let's take a look.

column1: Can we take a dip?
column2: Okay.

column1: No cigar.
column2: Try telling them our names.

column1: We got off at the wrong stop.
column2: You're our optimist Look at the bright side. If that's the best there is around here, in six months we'll be running this planet.

column1: Who are you?
column2: So you can talk.  I'm Dr. Zira's nephew. This abduction was her idea. You're not really going to the zoo. That's just our cover story in case we're stopped.  Although I do feel that if it ever came down to a question of whether something like you should be public or private property --

column1: She comes along too.
column2: Zira doesn't want your female.

column1: I want her.
column2: If you insist. But I'm not taking any orders --

column1: Shouldn't we be moving on?
column2: I'm for that.

column1: Why did you do that? Scrape off your hair?
column2: In my world -- before I left it - only youngsters of your age wore un- scraped hair.

column1: Sorry, Lucius. You'll have to stay here and guard the horses.
column2: Always giving orders. Just like every other adult.

column1: Not everything. They left a hostage.  How do you feel, Lucius?
column2: Disillusioned...  But vindicated! I've been right all along. You can't trust the older generation. It's a matter of values --

column1: All right, all right. Will You do me a favor? No orders.
column2: What is it?

column1: I want you to go around the bend and tell those gorillas their leader is my prisoner.
column2: Yes, I can do that.

column1: They think you're behaving foolishly. I must say I agree. Where will you go?
column2: I'll start by following the shoreline.  And my nose.

column1: Lucius.
column2: I think you're making a mistake.

column1: That's the boy. Keep 'em flying.
column2: What?

column1: I told you not to bring the other one.
column2: He wouldn't leave her.

column1: Gorilla hunters ...
column2: Keep moving. We can't turn back now.

column1: Who put them up?
column2: The Hunt Club.

column1: What is that?
column2: A man, Dr. Maximus.

column1: Yes, Sir. But this -- creature is a special case.
column2: Why special?

column1: You asked for the opportunity to present your case. Surely you must know why you're here.
column2: My own purpose is to save this exceptional creature from mutilation.

column1: And our purpose is to settle custodial and jurisdictional questions concerning this beast, and determine what's to be done with him.
column2: At the very least, this man has the right to know whether there's a charge against him.

column1: Dr. Zira -- tell Bright Eyes to sit down.
column2: My name is Taylor.

column1: It says here that his name is Bright Eyes. You gave him that name yourself.
column2: This hearing is absurd! Let me tell my story...

column1: One is in a museum!
column2: Dr. Zira! Silence that man!

column1: You destroyed his memory! His mind! His identity! And, you want to do the same to me!
column2: Bailiff! Stop this outburst! Gag that monstrosity!

column1: Let it be clear at the outset that all matters pertaining to this inquiry are confidential, and anyone discussing them outside this chamber will be held in contempt of the Tribunal.  You may proceed, Dr. Honorius.
column2: By your leave, Mr. President -- the Tribunal has not yet defined the purpose of this inquiry.

column1: Sustained. In all fairness, Dr. Zira, you must admit the accused is a nonape, and therefore has no rights under ape law.
column2: Then why is he called the accused Your Honors must think him guilty of something.

column1: Thats a lie!
column2: Mind your tongue, madame.

column1: Since the defendant is forbidden to speak in his own defense, he asks that this statement be read into the record.
column2: Read it yourself.

column1: 'I have come to you from a planet in a different solar system. I am an explorer in space, with no hostile intentions against your civilization. On my planet it was the primate Man who evolved Into a thinking animal, while the apes remained..."
column2: Stop right there. Bring me that paper.

column1: This is a joke in very poor taste.
column2: Is it a joke to seek the truth about this man?

column1: How so?
column2: Let us assume, as common sense dictates, that the prisoner's story is false. But if he does not come from another planet, then surely he sprang from our own. Yes, sprang.  As an animal psychologist, I have found no physiological defect to explain why humans are mute.

column1: Sustained.
column2: Sustain all objections, but face the truth!

column1: Well...do you acknowledge kinship with any of these creatures?
column2: With one of them.

column1: What about me?
column2: Oh, your case was preordained. In a way, you performed a service for the State ...  Because your hearing made it possible for us to expose Zira and Cornelius.  And now the Tribunal has placed you in my custody for...final disposition. Do you know what that means?

column1: No.
column2: Emasculation, to begin with. Then experimental surgery. On the speech centers. On the brain. Ultimately, a kind of living death.

column1: However, it's within my power to grant You a reprieve.  That is why I summoned you here tonight.  Tell me who and what you really are and where you come from, and no veterinary will touch you.
column2: I told the truth at that 'hearing'of yours.

column1: You lied. Where is your tribe?
column2: My tribe, as you call it, lives on another planet in a distant solar system.

column1: Then how is it we speak the same language?  Even in your lies, some truth slips through! That mythical community you're supposed to come from -- Fort Wayne'?
column2: What about it?

column1: A fort! Unconsciously, you chose a name that was belligerent.  Where were you nurtured?
column2: I take it you don't believe the prosecutor's charge -- that I'm a monster created by Dr. Zira.

column1: Certainly not.
column2: That's exactly what Zira and Cornelius claim. You're talking heresy, doctor.

column1: Of course.
column2: All right, suppose I am a mutant? Why does the appearance of one mutant send you into a panic?

column1: Because you're not unique. There was the one you call Landon --
column2: Then you admit --

column1: I admit that where there's one mutant there's probably another. And another. A nest of them. Where's your nest, Taylor? Where are your women?
column2: Thank you for calling me Taylor.  Dr. Zaius, I know who I am. Who are you? How did this upside down civilization ever get started?

column1: You may well call it upside down, since you occupy its lowest level. And deservedly.  The eastern desert has never been explored -- because we've always assumed that no life can exist there.  Save yourself, Taylor. Tell me -- is there another jungle beyond the Forbidden Zone?
column2: I don't know.

column1: If you are protecting others of your kind, it will cost you your identity.
column2: I'm not protecting anybody! That hearing was a farce. What have I done?

column1: Stop right there.
column2: Don't be a fool. You're outnumbered and outgunned.

column1: There is no contradiction between faith and science. True science.
column2: All right, let's see if you're willing to put that statement to a test.

column1: What is your proposal?
column2: When were the Sacred Scrolls written?

column1: Twelve hundred years ago.
column2: Very well. If Zira and Cornelius can prove that those scrolls don't tell the whole truth of your history

column1: Of course.
column2: Okay.Up to the cave.

column1: I don't say he was a man like an Earthman, but I'd call him a close relative, for he was plagued by most of man's ills.  Yet, fragile as he was, he came before you -- and was superior to you.
column2: That's lunacy. I can give an alternate description for everyone of those objects that's equally as inventive as yours. But it would be conjecture, not proof.

column1: Tell him to pull back!
column2: Cease fire! Withdraw!

column1: Then answer this: If ran was superior, why didn't he survive?
column2: He might have been wiped out by a plague. Natural catastrophe. Like a fiery storm of meteors. From the looks of this part of your planet, I'd say that was a fair bet.

column1: Then there is another jungle?
column2: Of course, you could return with us. Our society might find a place for you and your mate.

column1: Sure.
column2: Where else, but in a cage, does man belong?

column1: Why? From the first, I've terrified you, Doctor. And in spite of every sign that I'm an intelligent being who means no harm, you continue to hate and fear me. Why?
column2: Because you are a man. And you were right -- I have always known about man. From the evidence, I believe his wisdom must walk hand in hand with his idiocy. His emotions must rule his brain. He must be a warlike animal who gives battle to everything around him -- even himself.

column1: What evidence? No weapons were found in the cave.
column2: The Forbidden Zone was once a paradise. Your breed made a desert of it, ages ago.

column1: We're back at the beginning. I still don't know the why. A planet where apes evolved from men. A world turned wrong side up. A puzzle with one piece missing.
column2: Don't look for it, Taylor. You may not like what you find.

column1: Well, Bright Eyes, is our throat feeling better?
column2: Listen, listen -- I can speak --

column1: Speak! Go on.
column2: My - name - isn't - Bright Eyes It's Taylor!

column1: I'm not acting! I can talk! How much proof do you want?
column2: Dr. Zaius, I could have sworn he was answering you!

column1: Where have you been? Why didn't you come to see me?
column2: Shhhh!

column1: What is this?
column2: A hearing.

column1: It's him...Landon.
column2: Which one?

column1: You! ... You knew about this?
column2: No, I swear -- I never saw this man before.

column1: Listen-
column2: Taylor -- just keep quiet and we may get away with this. Remember that men all look alike to most apes.

column1: Cornelius and I have been indicted for heresy. Unless we can prove our theories, we don't stand a chance of acquittal.
column2: You're going back to the Forbidden Zone?

column1: Are you going to take her with you?
column2: Yes.

column1: Actually, you're a different breed. This creature will never evolve.
column2: Maybe not.

column1: You want her that much?
column2: You threw us together, remember? And you guessed right. Men, like apes, get despondent without a mate.

column1: What's the diagnosis, doctor? A touch of the sun?
column2: She's not sick at all.  She's pregnant.

column1: And that's your Minister of Science. Honor- bound to expand the frontiers of knowledge.
column2: Taylor, please --

column1: Taylor! Tell him.
column2: He has a point. On my planet children often play with ape dolls.

column1: Then tell them Dr. Zaius won't leave here alive.
column2: Taylor, you can't.

column1: Taylor, please -- don't treat him that way.
column2: Why not?

column1: It's humiliating.
column2: Wasn't I humiliated? By all of you? Didn't you lead me around on a leash?

column1: Would you like to come along?
column2: We can't.

column1: Dr. Zira, I'd like to kiss you good-bye.
column2: All right, but....  ...you're so damned ugly!

column1: Go with God, Taylor.  That's an old expression. it comes from both ape and man.
column2: God bless you.

column1: He's moving his fingers!
column2: Of course. He saw you moving yours.

column1: Wouldn't it more properly be done in your office?
column2: Yes, Sir.

column1: Dr. Zira -- you state here that a ship from outer space sank in an inland sea of our eastern desert.
column2: I do not state it, sir. The prisoner does.

column1: Do you believe him?
column2: Like you, I find it difficult.

column1: But how convenient that the proof of his arrival has vanished?  You also state that Bright Eyes had two intelligent companions at the time of his capture.
column2: This is his assertion.

column1: How sad. Stuffed and mounted, eh? Dead men, like sunken ships, can tell no stories. And his other companion?
column2: He doesn't know.

column1: Let them talk, Mr President. Let them talk.
column2: Sirs: our theories have a bearing on his identity.

column1: Secondly, if these 'tools' as you call them, are unidentified, why are they introduced as 'evidence' of anything?
column2: But there's the doll, sir.

column1: But suppose you find nothing but a wasteland. How will you survive?
column2: He won't survive.  Do you know what sort of life awaits you out there, Taylor? That of an animal. If you aren't eventually hunted down and killed by apes, some jungle beast will devour you.

column1: But the proof? The doll?
column2: In a few minutes there will be no doll. There can't be.  I'm sorry.

column1: Major, looks like there were ten, maybe twelve guerrillas. Looks like they took some prisoners from the chopper.  Then a different set of track, over there.
column2: What do you mean?

column1: Strange, Major. There was a firefight. Shooting in all directions.
column2: I can't believe Jim Hopper walked into an ambush.

column1: I don't believe he did, Sir. I couldn't find a single track. Just doesn't make sense.
column2: What about the rest of Hopper's men?

column1: Billy... What the hell's wrong with you?
column2: Something... in the trees...

column1: You've been pushing too many Pencils, Dillon. Had enough?
column2: No way, old buddy.

column1: That piece of work you guys pulled off at the Berlin embassy last week was really something. Blew the entry points on three floors and neutralized the opposition in eight seconds flat. Beautiful.
column2: Like the old days, Dillon.

column1: Wasn't my style. We're a rescue unit, not assassins.  This must be good. Big shot from the CIA, leaves his desk to come back to the bush. What's so important?
column2: Those cabinet members are very important to our scope of operations in this part of the world. They're about to get squeezed. We can't let that happen. I needed someone who could get the job done, quick and quiet... no screw-ups. I needed the best. The best. So, I pulled a few strings at the State Department... and here we are.

column1: Our rendezvous points and radio freqs. are indicated and fixed. AWACS contact on four hour intervals.
column2: Who's our back-up on this?

column1: No such thing, old buddy. It's a one way ticket. Once we cross that border, we're on our own.
column2: This gets better by the minute.

column1: You don't know how much I missed this, Dutch!!! Once you get this in your blood, you never get it out!!!
column2: You never were all that smart... let's go!!!

column1: Billy's on it.  Heat seeker. Pretty sophisticated for half-asses mountain boys.
column2: They're getting better equipped every day.

column1: Mean anything to you?
column2: Probably another rebel patrol. They operate in here all the time.

column1: I knew this man. Green Berets, out of Fort Bragg. What the hell were they doing in here? You got any answers for this, Dillon?
column2: Jesus... this is inhuman.  Uh... I wasn't told of any operations in this area. They shouldn't have been here.

column1: It was all bullshit. All of it. From the start... you set us up, got us in here to do your dirty work.
column2: That's right, I set you up. You're a veteran at this, Dutch, I had to.

column1: Why us?
column2: Because I told you, you're the best. I knew you could do it but I couldn't get you in here without a cover story.

column1: What story did you give to Davis?
column2: We've been lookin' for this place for months. The chopper must have gotten close when they got shot down. Hopper was sent in to get my men. He was just doing his job. When he disappeared I had to clean this up, I had to stop there bastards. We were so close, we couldn't quit. We couldn't sleep through this one. I needed you, Dutch, can't you see that?

column1: She's too valuable. She's got to know their whole network. The whole set up. We take her with us.
column2: We take her and she'll give away our position, every chance she gets. No prisoners, Dillon.

column1: Blain...  ... Just like the others... no powder burns, no shrapnel.
column2: The wound all fused, cauterized... what the hell did this?

column1: We're still too far in, they won't risk coming in for us.
column2: Expendable assets, Dillon. Seems Langley is never around when you need them.

column1: I can accept that, it comes with the job.
column2: Bullshit. You're just like the rest of us.

column1: You're wastin' your time.
column2: No more games.

column1: What the hell do you think you're doing?
column2: We're going to need everyone.

column1: What are you talking about? We'll be out of here in ten minutes.
column2: We're not going.

column1: He'll be looking for the trip wires. If we're lucky, he won't see this.
column2: Now what, Dutch. You going to send your mystery guest an invitation?

column1: No way, Dutch. I'm going. You get these people and get the hell out of here.
column2: This isn't your style, Dillon.

column1: Guess I've picked up some bad habits from you, Dutch. Now don't argue with me, you know I'm right. Get to that chopper and hold it for us. We'll be along.
column2: You know you can't win this one.

column1: I'll see you there.
column2: Right behind you.

column1: Thanks.
column2: Anytime.

column1: Don't know, only saw one of 'em. Camouflaged. He was there...  ... Those fucking eyes...
column2: What, Sergeant?

column1: Take a position over there. I'll work around towards you. When I flush him, you nail him...
column2: ... Right, I got a score to settle for the Bro...

column1: Any sign of the hostages?
column2: We found 'em both, dead. And the gear from the chopper. If they're Central American, I'm a fuckin' Chinaman. By the looks of 'em, I'd say our cabinet minister and his aide are CIA.  Another thing, Major, we were lucky... couple of those guys we waxed are Russians, military advisors by the look of it. Something big was about to happen here.

column1: What's got Billy so spooked?
column2: Can't say, Major... been squirrely all mornin'... fuckin' weird... sometimes I think that nose of his is too good... smells things that ain't there.

column1: You saw what?
column2: I saw it.

column1: Put him in his poncho and liner and carry him back. We'll bury him in the morning.
column2: I'll take him.

column1: We've got most of the flares, frags. and two claymores just outside. Nothin's comin' close to here without trippin' on somethin'.
column2: Thank you, Sergeant.

column1: I'm sorry, Bull. It's never easy. He was a good soldier.
column2: The best friend I ever had.

column1: You're looking well, Dutch.
column2: It's been a long time, General.

column1: That's over the border, General.
column2: That's the problem. Apparently they strayed off course.  We're certain they've been captured by the guerrillas.

column1: What have you got in mind, General.
column2: We figure we've got less than twenty-four hours to catch up with them. After that, there's not much hope. We want a rescue operation mounted tonight. That doesn't give you much time.

column1: You lift off in three hours.  There's one other thing.
column2: What's that, General?

column1: Took 'em out with a heat seeker.
column2: There's something else, Major...

column1: Mmmnnn...?
column2: I don't think that was any ordinary army taxi...

column1: What's he got?
column2: Same business, guerrillas hauling two guys from the chopper... followed by men with American equipment...

column1: Major, you'd better take a look at this.
column2: Hawkins?

column1: What in God's name...?
column2: I think it's Hawkins.

column1: Where the hell is his body?
column2: There's no sign of it.

column1: How could anyone get through this, carry Blain out, right under our noses without leavin' a trace?
column2: He knows our defenses.

column1: Admiral, we're in position. All fighters accounted for.
column2: Proceed with the countdown. All groups assume attack coordinates.

column1: All craft, prepare to jump to hyperspace on my mark.
column2: All right. Stand by.

column1: We saw it. All craft prepare to retreat.
column2: You won't get another chance at this, Admiral.

column1: We have no choice, General Calrissian. Our cruisers can't repel firepower of that magnitude.
column2: Han will have that shield down. We've got to give him more time.

column1: At that close range, we won't last long against those Star Destroyers.
column2: We'll last longer then we will against that Death Star...and we might just take a few of them with us.

column1: The shield is down! Commence attack on theDeath Star's main reactor.
column2: We're on our way. Red Group, Gold Group, all fighters follow me.  Told you they'd do it!

column1: I can't do it, Artoo. I can't go on alone.
column2: Yoda will always be with you.

column1: You told me Vader betrayed and murdered my father.
column2: You father was seduced by the dark side of the Force. He ceased to be Anakin Skywalker and became Darth Vader. When that happened, the good man who was your father was destroyed. So what I have told you was true... from a certain point of view.

column1: There's still good in him.
column2: I also thought he could be turned back to the good side. It couldn't be done. He is more machine now than man. Twisted and evil.

column1: I can't do it, Ben.
column2: You cannot escape your destiny.

column1: I tried to stop him once. I couldn't do it.
column2: Vader humbled you when first you met him, Luke... but that experience was part of your training. It taught you, among other things, the value of patience. Had you not been so impatient to defeat Vader then, you could have finished your training here with Yoda. You would have been prepared.

column1: To be a Jedi, Luke, you must confront and then go beyond the dark side - the side your father couldn't get past. Impatience is the easiest door - for you, like your father. Only, your father was seduced by what he found on the other side of the door, and you have held firm. You're no longer so reckless now, Luke. You are strong and patient. And now, you must face Darth Vader again!
column2: I can't kill my own father.

column1: Then the Emperor has already won. You were our only hope.
column2: Yoda spoke of another.

column1: The other he spoke of is your twin sister.
column2: But I have no sister.

column1: Hmm. To protect you both from the Emperor, you were hidden from your father when you were born. The Emperor knew, as I did, if Anakin were to have any offspring, they would be a threat to him. That is the reason why your sister remains safely anonymous.
column2: Leia! Leia's my sister.

column1: But you can't let her get involved now, Ben. Vader will destroy her.
column2: She hasn't been trained in the ways of the Jedi the way you have, Luke... but the Force is strong with her, as it is with all of your family. There is no avoiding the battle. You must face and destroy Vader!

column1: Shhh. You have hibernation sickness.
column2: I can't see.

column1: Your eyesight will return in time.
column2: Where am I?

column1: Jabba's palace.
column2: Who are you?

column1: The Death Star will be completed on schedule.
column2: You have done well, Lord Vader. And now I sense you wish to continue your search for young Skywalker.

column1: Yes, my Master.
column2: Patience, my friend. In time he will seek you out. And when he does, you must bring him before me. He has grown strong. Only together can we turn him to the dark side of the Force.

column1: As you wish.
column2: Everything is proceeding as I have foreseen.

column1: What is thy bidding, my Master?
column2: Send the fleet to the far side of Endor. There it will stay until called for.

column1: What of the reports of the Rebel fleet massing near Sullust?
column2: It is of no concern. Soon the Rebellion will be crushed and young Skywalker will be one of us! Your work here is finished, my friend. Go out to the command ship and await my orders.

column1: I told you to remain on the command ship.
column2: A small Rebel force has penetrated the shield and landed on Endor.

column1: I have felt him, my Master.
column2: Strange, that I have not. I wonder if your feelings on this matter are clear, Lord Vader.

column1: They are clear, my Master.
column2: Then you must go to the Sanctuary Moon and wait for them.

column1: Oh, no, my young Jedi. You will find that it is you who are mistaken...about a great many things.
column2: His lightsaber.

column1: Han!
column2: Luke!

column1: Are you all right?
column2: Fine. Together again, huh?

column1: Wouldn't miss it.
column2: How are we doing?

column1: The same as always.
column2: That bad, huh? Where's Leia?

column1: I think my eyes are getting better. Instead of a big dark blur, I see a big light blur.
column2: There's nothing to see. I used to live here, you know.

column1: You're gonna die here, you know. Convenient.
column2: Just stick close to Chewie and Lando. I've taken care of everything.

column1: Why don't you leave that crate and come with us?
column2: I have a promise I have to keep first... to an old friend.

column1: Luke.
column2: Hi, Han... Chewie.

column1: You got her warmed?
column2: Yeah, she's comin' up.

column1: Right. Chewie, let's see what this piece of junk can do. Ready, everybody?
column2: All set.

column1: Vader's on that ship.
column2: Now don't get jittery, Luke. There are a lot of command ships. Keep your distance though, Chewie, but don't look like you're trying to keep your distance.

column1: I don't know.  Fly casual.
column2: I'm endangering the mission. I shouldn't have come.

column1: Chewie and I will take care of this. You stay here.
column2: Quietly, there might be more of them out there.

column1: I thought she was with you.
column2: We got separated.

column1: Take the squad ahead.  We'll meet at the shield generator at 0300.
column2: Come on, Artoo.  We'll need your scanners.

column1: Nice work. Great, Chewie! Great! Always thinking with your stomach.
column2: Will you take it easy? Let's just figure out a way to get out of this thing.  Han, can you reach my lightsaber?

column1: Hey!
column2: Han, don't. It'll be all right.

column1: Somehow, I got the feeling that didn't help us very much.
column2: Threepio, tell them if they don't do as you wish, you'll become angry and use your magic.

column1: Someone who loves you.
column2: Leia!

column1: I don't know. All I can see is a lot of blowing sand!
column2: That's all any of us can see.

column1: Hey, are you awake?
column2: Yeah, I just got a funny feeling. Like I'm not gonna see her again.

column1: Now we find out if that code is worth the price we paid.
column2: It'll work. It'll work.

column1: Shall we try and go around?
column2: It'll take time. This whole party'll be for nothing if they see us.

column1: What's going on?
column2: I don't know.
Ahhh...

column1: I'm sorry.
column2: Hold me.

column1: The main entrance to the control bunker's on the far side of that landing platform. This isn't gonna be easy.
column2: Hey, don't worry. Chewie and me got into a lot of places more heavily guarded than this.

column1: Han! Hurry! The fleet will be here any moment.
column2: Charges!  Come on, come on!

column1: The code's changed. We need Artoo!
column2: Here's the terminal.

column1: I'm sure Luke wasn't on that thing when it blew.
column2: He wasn't. I can feel it.

column1: Yes.
column2: All right. I understand. Fine. When he comes back, I won't get in the way.

column1: Han! Chewie?
column2: Lando!

column1: Lando, grab it!
column2: Lower it!

column1: Chewie! Chewie, give me the gun. Don't move, Lando.
column2: No, wait! I thought you were blind!

column1: It's all right. Trust me. Don't move.
column2: All right! A little higher! Just a little higher!

column1: Guess I owe you some thanks, too, Lando.
column2: Figured if I left you frozen like that you'd just give me bad luck the rest of my life, so I might as well get you unfrozen sooner or later.

column1: Well, look at you, a general, huh?
column2: Oh, well, someone must have told them about my little maneuver at the battle of Taanab.

column1: Look. I want you to take her. I mean it. Take her. You need all the help you can get. She's the fastest ship in the fleet.
column2: All right, old buddy. You know, I know what she means to you. I'll take good care of her. She-she won't get a scratch. All right?

column1: Good luck.
column2: You, too.

column1: Oh, dear. His High Exaltedness, the great Jabba the Hutt, has decreed that you are to be terminated immediately.
column2: Good, I hate long waits.

column1: In his belly, you will find a new definition of pain and suffering, as you are slowly digested over a thousand years.
column2: On second thought, let's pass on that, huh?

column1: Here we go again.
column2: All right, hang on.

column1: What are you telling them?
column2: Hello, I think... I could be mistaken. They're using a very primitive dialect.  But I do believe they think I am some sort of god.

column1: Well, why don't you use your divine influence and get us out of this?
column2: I beg your pardon, General Solo, but that just wouldn't be proper.

column1: Proper?!
column2: It's against my programming to impersonate a deity.

column1: What did he say?
column2: I'm rather embarrassed, General Solo, but it appears you are to be the main course at a banquet in my honor.

column1: We're coming!
column2: Come on! Come on!

column1: My goodness! Artoo, why did you have to be so brave?
column2: Well, I suppose I could hotwire this thing.

column1: Oh, Princess Leia, are you all right?
column2: Let's see.

column1: Lord Vader, this is an unexpected pleasure. We're honored by your presence.
column2: You may dispense with the pleasantries, Commander. I'm here to put you back on schedule.

column1: I assure you, Lord Vader, my men are working as fast as they can.
column2: Perhaps I can find new ways to motivate them.

column1: I tell you, this station will be operational as planned.
column2: The Emperor does not share your optimistic appraisal of the situation.

column1: But he asks the impossible. I need more men.
column2: Then perhaps you can tell him when he arrives.

column1: That is correct, Commander. And he is most displeased with your apparent lack of progress.
column2: We shall double our efforts.

column1: All wings report in.
column2: Red Leader standing by.

column1: Good shot, Red Two.
column2: Now...come on, Han, old buddy. Don't let me down.

column1: I'm going in.
column2: Here goes nothing.

column1: Now lock onto the strongest power source. It should be the power generator.
column2: Form up. And stay alert. We could run out of space real fast.

column1: There it is!
column2: All right, Wedge. Go for the power regulator on the north tower.

column1: Ugh!
column2: Ohhh, I can't bear to watch.

column1: Oh!
column2: Your Royal Highness.

column1: What's he saying?
column2: He says there's a secret entrance on the other side of the ridge.

column1: Oh! Oh, my. Uh, Princess Leia!
column2: Quiet.

column1: I'm afraid our furry companion has gone and done something rather rash.
column2: Oh, no.

column1: Over there! Two more of them!
column2: I see them. Wait, Leia!

column1: Leia... do you remember your mother? Your real mother?
column2: Just a little bit. She died when I was very young.

column1: What do you remember?
column2: Just...images, really. Feelings.

column1: Tell me.
column2: She was very beautiful. Kind, but...sad.  Why are you asking me all this?

column1: I have no memory of my mother. I never knew her.
column2: Luke, tell me. What's troubling you?

column1: He's my father.
column2: Your father?

column1: Luke, don't talk that way. You have a power I--I don't understand and could never have.
column2: You're wrong, Leia. You have that power too. In time you'll learn to use it as I have. The Force is strong in my family. My father has it...I have it...and...my sister has it.

column1: Yes. It's you Leia.
column2: I know. Somehow...I've always known.

column1: Then you know why I have to face him.
column2: No! Luke, run away, far away. If he can feel your presence, then leave this place. I wish I could go with you.

column1: No, you don't. You've always been strong.
column2: But, why must you confront him?

column1: The Emperor has been expecting you.
column2: I know, father.

column1: Come with me.
column2: Obi-Wan once thought as you do.

column1: You don't know the power of the dark side. I must obey my master.
column2: I will not turn...and you'll be forced to kill me.

column1: If that is your destiny.
column2: Search your feelings, father. You can't do this. I feel the conflict within you. Let go of your hate.

column1: Obi-Wan has taught you well.
column2: I will not fight you, father.

column1: Your thoughts betray you, father. I feel the good in you...the conflict.
column2: There is no conflict.

column1: You couldn't bring yourself to kill me before, and I don't believe you'll destroy me now.
column2: You underestimate the power of the dark side. If you will not fight, then you will meet your destiny.

column1: You cannot hide forever, Luke.
column2: I will not fight you.

column1: Sister! So...you have a twin sister. Your feelings have now betrayed her, too. Obi-Wan was wise to hide her from me. Now his failure is complete. If you will not turn to the dark side, then perhaps she will.
column2: Never-r-r!

column1: Master Yoda, you can't die.
column2: Strong am I with the Force... but not that strong! Twilight is upon me and soon night must fall. That is the way of things... the way of the Force.

column1: But I need your help. I've come back to complete the training.
column2: No more training do you require. Already know you that which you need.

column1: Yoda, I must know.
column2: Your father he is.

column1: Told you, did he?
column2: Yes.

column1: Unexpected this is, and unfortunate...
column2: Unfortunate that I know the truth?

column1: Well, I'm sorry.
column2: Remember, a Jedi's strength flows from the Force.  But beware.  Anger, fear, aggression. The dark side are they.  Once you start down the dark path, forever will it dominate your destiny.

column1: Ah, good. New acquisitions. You are a protocol droid, are you not?
column2: I am See-Threepio, human-cy...

column1: Yes or no will do.
column2: Oh. Well, yes.

column1: How many languages do you speak?
column2: I am fluent in over six million forms of communication, and can readily...

column1: Splendid! We have been without an interpreter since our master got angry with our last protocol droid and disintegrated him.
column2: Disintegrated?

column1: Improved...how?
column2: As I said, in every way.  Physically and psychologically.  More endurance, quicker responses, better hand-eye, improved technical training.  Where the First Psychology gave you ninety-eight percent obedience, this bunch gives you 99.4.

column1: ...He used to say, "If it ain't broke, don't fix it."
column2: I...see.  I'm not sure I quite get your...point...

column1: Well, the soldiers we've got now, they've been through all kinds of heavy shit...and they've always got the job done.  Now these new ones, these "hot shots" of yours...what kind of action have they seen?  They <u>are</u> battle-tested, aren't they?
column2: That's up to you field guys.  H.Q. wants you to break 'em in when you do the annual security sweep in January.

column1: The sweep is just routine, not even police action.  I'd like to see some sort of...meaningful evidence...
column2: Such as?

column1: Melton, on the double!  Up a chain!                                   MELTON  Sir!     MELTON takes a few easy strides, gracefully catches a chain mid- stride, and smarts up, climbing easily and twice as fast as TODD.     CHURCH, SLOAN, and RUBRICK crane their necks as the two men struggle upward toward the rafters.     Three quarters of the way up, MELTON comes even with TODD, then passes him. MEKUM, watching, smirks.     CHURCH is watching too, and he's still not satisfied.  His brow is knit, something's bothering him.     ANGLE HIGH ABOVE, AMONG THE GIRDERS     Stonefaced, MELTON is resting an a "platform" on the chain, sixty feet up, beneath the girders, swaying gently.     His stony gaze is on the next chain where TODD is arriving at a "platform" on an adjacent chain...only three feet away.     Their eyes meet, TODD and MELTON alone together sixty feet up, three feet apart.  Neither man blinks, neither man flinches, neither man reveals anything at all...     LOW ANGLE, LOOKING UP     CHURCH considers the men high above, then to MEKUM.                                   CHURCH                    What about...spirit?
column2: Spirit?                          Oh!  You mean "AQ"..."aggressive qualities"?

column1: Oh my God, what is he doing?
column2: He's shutting off the air!!!

column1: Will you two please stop it!  I don't want to spend my final hours listening to you bitch!
column2: I'll tell you what I'm going to do.

column1: Getting drunk is no solution.
column2: Yeah, well...I forgot my morphine back in the room.

column1: I think we're moving.
column2: Well isn't that great.  Something to write home about.

column1: I never though I'd be stuck in a wine closet with Warren Wayne.
column2: Well get used to it, 'cause here we are, on the cruise of a lifetime.

column1: Oh Warren...oh Warren...take me, God take me...
column2: Oh yeah...

column1: Oh yeah...
column2: Oh Sara...

column1: Anna...
column2: Anna...

column1: Jesus, come on!
column2: They're not going to make it!

column1: Evening.
column2: It can't be.

column1: Excuse me?
column2: You're Warren Wayne.

column1: Uh, yes I am.  And you are?
column2: Anna Koros. She sensually extends her hand, Warren shakes it -

column1: Koros, as in...Koros?  Dimitri Koros?
column2: My grandfather.  My God, I can't tell you what a fan I am of yours! You were magnificent in Deadly Gamble.

column1: Oh, thank you.
column2: Magnificent, magnificent.

column1: Well I appreciate that.
column2: So, what brings you out here?  Pleasure cruise?

column1: Well a little business too.  In my upcoming project Star Trackers I play a ship's captain, and I really wanted to get a feel for the outer space experience.  I feel it will add more credibility to my performance.
column2: Of course, of course...

column1: So...
column2: Well I guess we're neighbors for this trip.

column1: Well, so we are.  Sure is beautiful, huh?
column2: It certainly is.

column1: Well, it was nice meeting you. Enjoy the rest of the trip.
column2: I'm sure I will.

column1: No, I think hygiene is important. It helps you get into the part.
column2: Very professional of you.

column1: Where the hell did you come from?
column2: Hello second mate Barnes. I was instructed to come to the bridge.

column1: Weren't you down in the dining room?
column2: I was there.  Officer Taylor accessed my CPU directly to open the airlock doors.  They are not functioning properly.

column1: Yes he did.  Yes he did. Barnes looks at the monitor - Taylor and the others are still in the dining room -
column2: You didn't do anything to the monitors, did you Mac?

column1: And what are they doing now, Mac?
column2: They are awaiting further information.

column1: Were you going to give it to them?
column2: I am here to provide service to... to all our guests.  There is a high level of passenger dissatisfaction. It is my duty...to report this.

column1: On channel 10?
column2: The device has stopped responding.

column1: Mac, you really earned your wings this flight.
column2: My...wings...

column1: I am here to provide service to... to all our guests.  There is a high level of passenger dissatisfaction. It is my duty...to report this.
column2: I hear you Mac and I appreciate it. Frankly I don't know what I'd have done without you on this one.

column1: There is a high level...of passenger
column2: And I intend to correct that at once. I'll tell you something Mac...

column1: Why should she, it's her fault. All guests are told not to eat in zero gravity, but she just wanted to have fun I guess, didn't realize what a grain of salt can do to sophisticated machinery.
column2: Well, I guess she figures she's paying for it.

column1: What did you say to me?
column2: It's a little late for you to be up.

column1: All too well, captain.
column2: Well shut it off at once!

column1: Well I guess there's no time like the present.  I'll go run a check on that room, just to show we go that extra mile for our guests.
column2: Sounds like you've been talking to Mac too much.

column1: No, I just ran it!  Why are you running it again?
column2: Well it's a good thing that I did.

column1: It's telling me fail mode confirmed.  Did you see this?
column2: There must be some mistake. You sure you hit the right commands?

column1: Yes I'm sure I hit the right commands.
column2: Why don't you reset and run it again.  The pods check out ok.

column1: You're certain of that?
column2: Trust me.  Even checked 'em with my own eyes.

column1: Well, everything's running smoother than a baby's ass.
column2: Ain't it the truth. The two say nothing for a beat -

column1: So, are you on for the next one?
column2: I don't know.  Everything's up in the air at this point, no pun intended.

column1: Why, didn't they say?
column2: Well that hotel begins construction in January, there's going to be a lot of shuttle work.

column1: You want to go back to shuttle work?
column2: It's steady, good benefits.

column1: You gotta think of your old age.
column2: That's very pragmatic of you, Barnes.

column1: Man, I'm hungry.  I'm going to call the steward, you want anything?.
column2: Nah, I already ate.  Why don't you just go down there?

column1: What, and leave you here all by your lonesome?
column2: Uh...

column1: I think I can handle it.
column2: Well, maybe I will.  You sure you don't want anything?

column1: No.  I'm all set.  Thanks.
column2: Well, maybe I'll surprise you.

column1: Bridge!  Can anyone hear me?!
column2: Yeah yeah yeah, give me a minute here.

column1: If anyone can hear me please respond!
column2: That's very professional sounding of you, Taylor.

column1: Barnes, can you hear me, are you all right?
column2: Why yes Ryan, I am, and thanks for asking.  You don't have to talk to the intercom, I can hear you fine.

column1: The bridge is fine, Taylor, how are things down there?
column2: Transmit the code 3 emergency and take us offline.  Override the airlock sensors and hurry!  We're running out of time, we have to get to the pods!

column1: Much as I'd like to help you and our valued guests, I'm afraid I can't.
column2: What are you talking about! Can you transmit the code 3 -

column1: Now do you want the good news first or the bad news?
column2: You better start making sense!

column1: Ok, I will.  The bad news is the ship is history.  Life support will last another 36 hours, maybe.
column2: Then we've got to get to the lifepods!

column1: It's still not going to work! They'll detect you upon re-entry in an emergency vessel!
column2: Who said I'll re-enter in the pod? I got friends out in space, Ryan, friends willing to get me back unnoticed.  Thank God for deregulation huh?

column1: Uh, that's an affirmative, Roger Wilco.  Please proceed.
column2: We have the codes here.  How do you want to receive them?

column1: That was a joke Taylor, lighten up!  Why don't you just hold them up to the lens.  I'll write them down, and once I'm through verifying them, I'll get back to you.
column2: Will you transmit the distress signal?

column1: Mac, can you hear me?  Come in?
column2: Taylor, you surprise me.

column1: I don't know what you're talking about!
column2: Sure you do.  Sending Mac out on a little recon work.  How pathetic.  Problem is it seems Mac blew a few fuses.  Or maybe he's just a little drunk. Were you partying with a robot Taylor?

column1: Look we gave you what you asked for.  It checks out didn't it?! What more do you want from us!
column2: I told you not to try anything smart!  I guess you're too much of a maverick to follow a simple order!  And that's just too bad for all of you now, isn't it?

column1: Idiot...
column2: Good help is hard to find...

column1: Barnes?
column2: That's me.

column1: Break it down to me, what's going on?
column2: Seems like they're cooperating. Hopefully I'll be out of here and on my way very soon.

column1: Well don't drag your ass.  There won't be much of a window for us to link up.  We'll be in your orbit trajectory in less than two hours.
column2: Yeah, I know Bill, I came up with the plan remember?  Just have those hangar doors open and ready, I can take it from there.

column1: Will do.  What about the distress signal?
column2: I don't know.  I really haven't made up my mind yet.  We'll see how nicely they behave.

column1: Well that's your call.  Doesn't make a damn bit of difference to me.  Just as long as I get my cut.
column2: Oh you'll get it, believe me.  So I'll see you in a few.

column1: It's time we lock coordinates.
column2: I know, I know.

column1: So, what are we waiting for?
column2: Cool your jets...I'm doing a little damage control.

column1: You're not helping my heart condition any, Barnes!  Now just what the hell are you dragging your ass for?
column2: The others decided to get cute with me, so I'm teaching them a lesson!

column1: This ship is going down in a blaze of glory!
column2: Well blaze your ass out of there! You've completely altered your trajectory, are we linking up or not?!

column1: Well if you knew it then why did set your thrusters on before making the calculation?
column2: I told you, I had to teach a few people a lesson!

column1: Goddamn it Barnes this really steams my onions!
column2: Let's get something straight, Chappy!

column1: Now I got enough air and supplies to make another complete orbit in the pod!  You're just gonna have to pick me up later.
column2: This is a major screw up on your part, goddamn it!

column1: Is that clear?
column2: That's clear.

column1: Good.  Now you'll hear from me when I have the new coordinates. In the meantime don't bug me.
column2: Sheesh!  Aye aye cap'n!

column1: Look at this...Jesus.
column2: Yeah, I guess money don't buy class.

column1: No.  But it buys a lot of other things.
column2: Like that piece of ass he was with.

column1: Well...I don't mind.  I can put up with it.  I'm taking six months off after this, and I won't have to deal with people snapping their fingers at me.
column2: Not me.  I'm in for the long haul. In nine months I'll have enough to take a few years off.

column1: Well, more power to you.  Me, I start to bug out after too much time out here.
column2: I don't have a problem with it. Besides, you get to meet a lot of interesting people.

column1: What's the use...we're gonna die...
column2: Don't say that!  It ain't over till it's over!

column1: We're going to die.
column2: Will you shut up already?

column1: It's getting hard to breathe...
column2: Just don't move around too much.

column1: Oh right, right you're on that research grant.
column2: That's right.

column1: Ryan Taylor, first mate.  Welcome aboard.  First time in space?
column2: Yes.  Theoretical discoveries aside, there's nothing like the real thing. How about you?

column1: So you were looking for a new challenge.
