column2: Well, plus the money ain't that bad. DAWN So, tell me, do you think everyone gets their million dollars' worth on this trip of a lifetime?

column1: Well, let me put it this way.  Most of the cost is due to safety reasons. Most people are not familiar with space travel, so we have to take extra precautions in the event they do something careless.
column2: Like open an airlock by mistake?

column1: Well I don't think there's a chance of that happening.  It's usually the moon walks.  Sometimes you feel like a kindergarten teacher.
column2: Well I hope I don't do anything careless.

column1: I'm sure you'll be all right.
column2: Actually I've logged about 200 hours of simulated space walking at the institute, mostly related to starship construction.

column1: Really?
column2: Still, I hope I behave on the moon.  I'll stick close to you.

column1: What are we going to do?
column2: I don't know.

column1: We don't.
column2: Well maybe there's a way out of here.

column1: Given a malfunction, how would a rescue team get you out if the doors won't open?
column2: Probably come through the wall I suppose.

column1: I don't think you know what you're talking about.  Besides, what could we use for tools?  A steak knife?  A corkscrew?
column2: Just considering our options... sir.

column1: Supposing we could get out of this room?  Is there anything we could do to reach the bridge?
column2: It depends on the condition of the ship.  If I could get to one of the suit compartments I could check the exterior air locks for a possible entry.

column1: Can't we access the mainframe to check the ship's condition?
column2: With what?  How am I going to interface with it?  I need to be able to talk to the system and to have the system talk to me.

column1: OK...it's open.
column2: Seen one like it before?

column1: Sure. It complies with all standard construction codes.
column2: Great.

column1: Damn it.  If only we could get to those suits... Dawn then thinks of something -
column2: Why can't we?

column1: And suppose you couldn't hold out?
column2: Suppose you didn't have to hold your breath?

column1: We could send Mac.  If he can retrieve one suit, we could go back for the other.
column2: You're right.

column1: He certainly is polite.
column2: Close every door behind you!

column1: It must be oxygenated if we can hear him.
column2: Yeah, let's hope he can find a way through.

column1: If I could get to the bridge I could send the distress signal.
column2: Even if we do, it might be too late.

column1: Everyone just stay put.
column2: Wait.

column1: I can't let you do that.
column2: Look I know what I'm doing. I have experience and training in space walking.

column1: I don't know what we're facing.
column2: I understand.

column1: Are you ready?
column2: Ready as I'll ever be.

column1: Yeah.  We did it.
column2: So we did.

column1: You're ready for the real thing?
column2: At this point I'm ready for anything.

column1: Be careful, you don't want to puncture the suit.
column2: Don't worry about me.  Where are we going?

column1: Explosive?
column2: One of Barnes' duds, luckily for us.  Take this out of the equation right now...

column1: Taylor?
column2: Yeah?

column1: Well, Dawn, I'm an optimist by nature.
column2: Yeah, but you didn't answer my question.

column1: Do you want some advice?
column2: Sure.

column1: Don't worry about what will happen, just concentrate on what is happening.  You'll live longer.
column2: Words to live by.

column1: Dawn!  Dawn!
column2: Helllp!

column1: I guess I owe you a debt of gratitude.  You saved my life.
column2: It was no time to lose my partner. We're going to have to hurry, he's on to us.

column1: Oh my God.  What happened?
column2: The room is filled with poison gas.  The hydraulic system must have blown.

column1: What's that?
column2: A schematic of the ship.  Looking for a lifeline to the pods.

column1: We don't have enough suits to get the others out.
column2: That's why we need a safe passage. remember what you said earlier, about getting through the wall? That might just be our ticket.

column1: Take this flare.
column2: A flare?  A flare won't do it.

column1: A little dab'll do ya. Now you know how to get there, right?
column2: Why?  Where are you going?

column1: I'm not going with you.
column2: What?  What are you talking about?

column1: And what are you going to do?!
column2: I'm going to try and buy you some time.  I can get to the bridge from here.

column1: But how are you going to escape?
column2: Don't worry about me.  There's still a chance I can issue a distress signal.

column1: But you can't be sure!  It's suicide.  You have to come with us!
column2: I can't!

column1: I will once I get past the bulkhead.  Good luck.
column2: You too.

column1: Dawn.  Come in.
column2: Taylor!  Where are you?

column1: I'm in the bridge.
column2: Barnes?

column1: He's out of the equation.  Talk to me.
column2: I'm about to blow the wall.

column1: Hurry.  You have to get them out of there!
column2: How does the distress signal look?

column1: Uh, it's ok, everything's going to be ok...now I'm counting on you, and whatever you do keep calm, we don't want them to panic.
column2: I'll do my best.

column1: So what's going to happen to you?
column2: I'm staying with the ship.  I'll be all right.  Now hurry.

column1: Thanks for everything, Taylor. Will I see you again?
column2: Hopefully sooner than later.

column1: Sooner than later.
column2: Over and out.

column1: What the hell are you doing?
column2: We have room!  Let's go!

column1: What do you mean?  What happened!
column2: We don't have time.  I'll explain later, hurry!

column1: So close...
column2: And so far.

column1: I never thought this would happen.  No premonitions, nothing.
column2: It did.  It is.  There's nothing we can do about that.

column1: Will you marry me?
column2: Marry you?

column1: I would, but no one can perform the ceremony.  I guess it doesn't matter.
column2: It would matter to us.

column1: In that case, I accept.
column2: Good.  In that case, I pronounce us man and wife.

column1: Right now it's about 8 o'clock at home.  People are going to work, kids are going to school...
column2: Try not to think about it.

column1: What is it?!
column2: I don't know.  Wave to them!

column1: I'm fine.
column2: Congratulations on your...recent award.

column1: Thank you.
column2: Is there anything I can help you with?

column1: No, just enjoying the view.
column2: Well, there's no better to way to see the world, than with us.

column1: So I've been told.
column2: Well if you need anything, please feel free to ask me.  Just a reminder we have fabulous cuisine available 24 hours in the earthrise room, and a large selection of vintage wines here in our ship bar.

column1: Yes Mac, but the guests are requesting it.  It will reduce the level of negative feedback.
column2: That is one of my priorities.

column1: What is happening around here!!!
column2: There's no time to explain.  Get everyone together!  We found a way to the pods!

column1: Where's Taylor?
column2: He's up on the bridge!  He's going to be OK.  Now who's missing?

column1: Carlo!
column2: He's in the bathroom.

column1: I'm going back for Taylor!
column2: Are you nuts!  It's too risky!

column1: I'm homesick.
column2: Homesick?  It's only been two days!

column1: We should have gone to Nassau. At least we could go swimming, lie on the beach.
column2: Ah hell we can always do that. Listen believe me, once we get to the moon, your tone is going to change.

column1: How is it going to be different from this?  Go see some boring footprint under glass?
column2: Look you were the one who wanted to do something different, something to tell all your friends.  Any chump can go to Nassau.

column1: Look around you baby, we're rubbing elbows with royalty, oil sheiks, this is class.  You'll be envied by everyone.
column2: I guess so.

column1: Oh no...I think there's carrots in here...
column2: Send it back if you don't want it.

column1: Well now what are we gonna do!
column2: How am I supposed to know?

column1: You're Delbert Miles!  You have more clout than some whacked out pilot!  Talk to him!
column2: Talk to him...Jesus...

column1: It's getting too cold in here.  I can't stand this anymore!
column2: Baby, take it easy.

column1: Look.  We're talking about life and death here.  I don't know why we're even having this conversation.
column2: Well what would you know about it? You don't have anything to lose.

column1: You're gonna give him those bank codes, you know why?  Because I'm telling you to, that's why.  I'm not losing my life over some greedy pig.
column2: Who are you calling a pig, rummy?

column1: I haven't quite made up my mind yet.
column2: I'll tell you what you're gonna do.  You're gonna stay put like Taylor said.

column1: Again with the orders from you! You got a Napoleon complex chief, and I'm getting sick of it!
column2: What are you going to do about it?

column1: I tell you, something's not right here.  How do we know they're not going to use the pod for themselves?
column2: Because, Taylor wouldn't do that, that's why.

column1: What the hell is that?
column2: The engines!

column1: Officer Taylor, how are you this evening?
column2: Mac.  What's shaking?

column1: Mac, I have a favor to ask you. Mac looks at Taylor -
column2: Certainly.  If you need anything, please feel free to ask me.  Just a reminder we have fabulous cuisine available --

column1: Yes I know all that.  Mac, I need you to help us out with a little technical problem.
column2: Certainly.  I have a full working knowledge of the ships operations.

column1: I need you to actually do something for me.  I need to access your CPU, directly.
column2: That will not be necessary.  You can simply speak to me.  I understand most languages fluently.

column1: Yeah but the ship's mainframe doesn't. I need you to tell it something.
column2: Alteration of my central processing unit should be done only by an authorized service dealer.

column1: Now Mac, can you tell me the status of this deck?
column2: One moment please...  one moment please...

column1: But the corridor outside this door is open, correct?
column2: Yes.  You can enjoy some wonderful views from there.

column1: Mac, what about the suit compartments on this level?  Can they be accessed?
column2: I'm sorry.  The suit compartments are in a non-oxygenated, zero gravity atmosphere.  I'm afraid that's off limits to all passengers.

column1: Ok Mac...  I'll talk to you on this. I want to find a way to get to the bridge, then I want you to come back.
column2: Certainly.  Anything I can do to be of service.

column1: How is it looking, Mac?
column2: I would recommend a maintenance crew in this sector.

column1: Is it safe for human transport?
column2: That's affirmative.

column1: Captain, open the hatch door, please ... the hatch door, Captain.  Open it, please.
column2: Calm down, Dr. Levine.

column1: Let me out, Captain.  Open the door!
column2: Please, Dr. Levine.

column1: ... Your civil rights have been overridden!
column2: Open it, Captain!

column1: Fletcher?  What are you doing out there?
column2: They're like pink snow, sir.  Sticky.

column1: They're warm.  I can feel the heat on my legs.
column2: Fletcher, I want you back here.

column1: Fletcher, get away from there...
column2: It's burning...

column1: Get out of there!
column2: I can't see...

column1: Fletcher!  Now!
column2: I can't...

column1: How big is this spacecraft?
column2: Of what we're able to measure, roughly twenty-six hundred feet.

column1: In basic English, what does all this mean?
column2: Basic English?  There's no way this spacecraft was constructed on our planet.

column1: There's heat coming the door.
column2: Back away then.

column1: Wait a minute --
column2: I said back away.

column1: Hold on --
column2: What is it?

column1: Alright, Beth, do that thing you did before.
column2: How about I just press the button?

column1: Not everything.  Even on earth.  Take ... yeasts.
column2: Yeasts?  Thank you, Beth, but I don't think we're gonna open it up and find a loaf of bread.

column1: I am not leaving without him.  Do you hear me?  We come down as a team, we leave as a team.
column2: What are you -- his mother?  Get Norman, I want everyone ready to go.  Edmunds, the subs?

column1: Norman!
column2: Edmunds, do you have a 20 on Norman?

column1: The surface ships will be back. After the storm clears.
column2: How long will that be?

column1: They told me about sixty hours.
column2: Two and a half days?

column1: Back at the door -- I asked you to back away.
column2: Yeah.  I heard you.

column1: There are procedures, Beth, that I want followed.  My procedures.  And considering what's going on, I want you to follow them very closely.
column2: Forgive me.  I've never read the Navy manual.  I wonder what it says about bathroom and shower procedures.

column1: Nobody move.
column2: But she's --

column1: I'm not sure.  I've never seen anything like it.
column2: You're a fucking biochemist, aren't you?  Can't you tell us something.

column1: Nice work, Captain sir.
column2: Shut up, Beth.  I don't want to hear it.

column1: Direction's east coming!
column2: What was that?

column1: A squid?  The size of a whale?  I don't think so.  Target acquired.  Sixty yards.
column2: What if it attacks?

column1: Fifty yards and closing.
column2: What do we use for defense?

column1: We're a habitat.  Not a castle.  The only defense we have is High Voltage.
column2: High Voltage?

column1: It sends 200 volts throughout the cylinder surface.  But we've never used it underwater before.
column2: Forty yards.

column1: But you've tested it?
column2: Sure.  Each time it started fires inside the habitat.

column1: Thirty yards.
column2: What are you saying -- we can't stop what's out there?

column1: Where is it?
column2: Why can't I -- ?  What the hell is going on here?

column1: What was that?
column2: He's right beneath us.

column1: Increase positive pressure!
column2: That's our reserve air.

column1: Don't do it, Norman!
column2: Do you see it?

column1: Don't pull it, Norman.  It'll start a <u>fire</u> we can't stop.  Norman?
column2: Do it, Norman, it's the only choice we have.  This thing is gonna crush us.

column1: Don't do it!
column2: Now!

column1: Norman, please!  Don't!
column2: Pull it, damn it!

column1: Thank you, Colonel.
column2: Captain.

column1: Well, thanks for the opportuninty here -- my wife appreciates it.
column2: Don't thank me, Dr. Johnson.  You weren't my choice.  The Pentagon made me take you.

column1: Come with me.  The team's already waiting.
column2: What team?

column1: What have you been told so far?
column2: The usual.  Plane crash.  Survivers unknown.  Routine stuff really.

column1: Anything else?

You heartless fuck.  That's why you're so scared of the water, isn't it?

I'm in this tiny sub on the bottom of the fucking ocean.  All alone.  Surrounded by all this water." column2: What do you mean, 'good morning'? Do you mean that it is a good morning for you, or do you wish me a good morning, although it is obvious I'm not having one, or do you find that mornings in general are good?

column1: Sorry, but that was the only way to get you down.
column2: Couldn't we have tried to think of something else first!

column1: I'm Luke Starkiller, guardian of the Bendu.
column2: Oh, so you're a warrior then?

column1: Who are you anyway?
column2: You might say I'm part of the landscape here.  They call me Ben Kenobi.

column1: You're General Kenobi?!?  The Jedi knight!  The commander of the White Legions?
column2: I'm afraid it's been a long time since the White Legions roamed the stars.  But I have the memories.

column1: I don't see why.  I don't believe we've ever met.
column2: I am the son of Annikin Starkiller.

column1: I know who you are.  Stand up so that we can talk properly.  You're embarrassing me.  I'm not that important.
column2: But you are... I know your 'Diary of the Clone Wars' by heart.  My father...

column1: I... I'm not a Bendu Officer.  I'm not even a startrooper.
column2: I know that.

column1: You saw through me?
column2: You could put it that way.

column1: I assure you my intentions weren't bad.
column2: I know your intentions.  I probably know much more about you than you realize.  In many ways you're a lot like your father.  He was an indulgent man, but a clever warrior.  Now what brings you out here?

column1: I'm afraid I've gotten too old for this sort of thing.
column2: But you must!  I can't do it alone. I'm not at all like my father.  I'd never make it.

column1: I already know you think you're worthless.  I recommend you learn to think of yourself in a better light, for what you believe you are is what you become.  I haven't been involved in anything like this for many years.
column2: But the Sith Lords are involved! Whatever information this R-2 unit is carrying, it must be awfully important.  They're probably looking for him... I'm no match for the Sith. This is a Jedi's work.  This is your responsibility!

column1: You were right.  It is my responsibility.  The Force of Others brought the message to you and then it brought you to me.
column2: My father used to talk about the Force of Others.  But he never told me what it was...

column1: Let's just say the Force is something a Jedi Warrior deals with.  It is an energy field in oneself, a power that controls ones acts, yet obeys ones commands.  It is nothing, yet it makes marvels appear before your very eyes. All living things generate this Force field, even you.
column2: You mean I generate an energy field?

column1: It surrounds you and radiates from you.  A Jedi can feel it flowing from him...  ... from here!
column2: Could I learn to feel it?

column1: That is not a human decision, not your or mine.
column2: What do you mean?

column1: Luke, I'm coming along to do what I can, but I'm tired and I'm depending on you to get us through.
column2: But you're still a powerful Jedi. You don't need my help.

column1: A Jedi's power is measured by the amount of the Force that is stored within him, and I have little of the Force left in me.
column2: How can you store an energy field within you?

column1: When a creature dies, the force it generated remains.  The Force is all around us.  It can be collected and transmitted through the use of a Kiber crystal.  It's the only way to amplify the power of the Force within you.
column2: Don't you have a Kiber crystal?

column1: I had one, but it was taken at the battle of Condawn...
column2: That's where my father was killed.

column1: Yes.  It was a black day.  One of my disciple's took the crystal and became a Sith Lord.  It was a black day.  The few crystals that remain are in the possession of the Sith Lords on Alderaan.  That's how they've become so powerful.
column2: Do the Sith know the ways of the Force?

column1: They use the Bogan Force.
column2: Like Bogan weather, or bogan times. I thought that was just a saying.

column1: We don't have that kind of money. How much do you think I can get for the speeder?
column2: Five, maybe.  Let me handle it.

column1: This is the last place.  Shouldn't we just take what we can get and think of something else?
column2: He's bluffing...

column1: When we get Artoo's message to them, you think they'll try to rescue the princess?
column2: I doubt it.  It would be foolish for the rebel forces to come out of hiding. I know your feelings.  You'd best forget them.  It's for your own good. There will be no saving her from the prisons of Alderaan.  It's the heart of the Sith.  The Bogan Force is the most heavy there.

column1: But she's a member of The Twelve Families.  How can they hold her?
column2: These are doubtful times.  The Empire has grown bold in its disregard of the...

column1: What's wrong?  What's happening?
column2: Keep away, I'm fine, I'm fine.

column1: Are you all right?
column2: Yes... the Force... something horrible has happened.  I couldn't see what it was, or where it was, but it was terrible... terrible beyond description... the cry of millions dying at once.

column1: Are you sure you don't need it?
column2: I rarely use it any more.  I have the Force.  The Force is more powerful than any pistol.  You shouldn't put too much faith in that weapon.  Work on becoming aware of the Force... learn to feel its presence within you.  Try to sense what it's telling you.  It's the only thing you can rely on.

column1: What do I do?
column2: All you have to do is lose your thinking self.  Don't focus on anything.  Let your body do your thinking... You have to learn to act on what you feel, not what you think ... If I had the crystal, it would be much easier.  You could feel the Force immediately... but for now, let yourself go.  You'll pick it up... and someday you'll have no need for that pistol either.

column1: What is it?
column2: He can't find Organa Major.

column1: But she is the only link between us and the hidden bases.
column2: You mean we should go after her!...

column1: I can't see!  How can I fight?
column2: Try to feel it.  Use the Force...

column1: I can't do it.  I'll get hit.
column2: Stop thinking, and start feeling. Let yourself go.

column1: See, once you let yourself go you can do it.  You'll get it.
column2: I don't get it, but I guess I did block it.

column1: What about the princess?
column2: You go after the princess. I am an old man and would be of little help.  I must try to find the Crystal.

column1: The Kiber Crystal.
column2: Keep it with you always.  You'll have more need of it than I.  It will bring the Force to you.  You've already learned to feel it... Now you must learn to use it.

column1: Of course, where you been kid?
column2: You look great!  The uniform and everything!

column1: That's no battle, kid... They're just sitting there!
column2: But there was a lot of firing earlier...

column1: I'll tell you, Luke, and this is between you and me.  The star force isn't all it's cracked up to be. Frankly, it's a bore, and it's going to stay that way as long as this system is neutral...
column2: But you always said things were so great at the academy... What happened?

column1: The academy is fantastic... Of course, they won't teach you anything about flying you don't already know.  Most of the instructors are very conservative pilots.  You can fly circles around them... but there is a lot on the scientific side that is down-right amazing, and you get a lot of discipline... but after you graduate, don't join the star force -- go free-lance.  It's the only way to get into the action... I can't wait until my hitch is up.
column2: At least you're doing something... I'd give anything to be in your position.

column1: You're Starkiller?
column2: Yes, sir.

column1: Have you been checked out?
column2: Yes, sir.  I was considered one of the best bush pilots on Sullust. I've also had six hours on the T-2.

column1: Six hours, huh?  Well, that's your ship there.  You're blue five.  You stay glued to me.  I don't want any independent operations out there. Personally I think it's foolish for them to be sending fresh kids out on a job like this.  This is no joy ride we're going on.
column2: Yes, sir.

column1: Blue Five, does that glare bother you?
column2: I've got it blocked.  I'm all right.

column1: I'm right behind you, Blue Leader.
column2: What's that?

column1: Blue Five, break off your cover attack.  It's too late.  Make your own run on the exhaust port.  Do you copy, Luke?
column2: Yes, sir, but I can get him...

column1: No reply on any circuits... It's drifting on a point twenty-seven skew.  It's not close enough to identify.
column2: Alert squad five, but hold them until we know what it is.

column1: Should we alert the Sith Lords?
column2: I'll make a report later.

column1: As close as we can make out, it appears to be a Corellian gypsy vessel... It's not under power.
column2: Send one squad up.

column1: We don't get many visitors.  Let's take a look at it.
column2: Send out a boarding party.  Full assault gear.

column1: Put that thing away or you're going to get us all killed.
column2: Yes, your highness. I'll let you open it then.  It won't be too long before they figure out what happened to us.  This has turned into a brilliant escape!

column1: Here come six more... grid two!
column2: Was this trip really necessary?

column1: There are only three or four left.
column2: Chewbacca, it's time we showed them this isn't the regulation F8-88 Cargo Trawler.

column1: All the data banks in Artoo are still secure.
column2: Then I think we're due the reward you offered... and it had better be substantial after what we've been through.

column1: When Artoo has been safely delivered to my forces, you get your reward. You have my guarantee.
column2: What's that little 'droid' carrying that's so blasted important?

column1: The plans and specifications to a battle station with enough fire power to destroy an entire system... Our only hope in destroying it is to find its weakness, which we will determine from the data I stored in Artoo.
column2: We captured the plans in a raid on the Imperial shipyards, but we fell under attack before I could get the data to safety, so I hid it in this Artoo unit and sent him off.

column1: Where are you taking us now anyway?
column2: The fourth moon of Yavin.  I've given the coordinates to Chewbacca.

column1: I don't see how we're going to find anything out here.  This terrain is hopeless.
column2: Did it occur to you they might find us?

column1: We must hurry to the base.  We have little time before the Death Star arrives.
column2: I'd like to get paid before that eventually.  I don't plan to stick around for the fireworks.

column1: What about us?  Are we to wait forever?  Is our reward to be blown to bits on this forsaken system, while your fleet mounts some suicidal attack on that Death Star? Part of my reward is that I be around to spend it.
column2: I have little time for your mercenary concerns, but I am grateful for the service you have given to our cause.  What is your price?

column1: Organa Major is a rebel system. There will be quite a few starfleet patrols between here and there... It could be a little tricky if you want to avoid them... ten thousand.
column2: That's pretty steep.  We'd like to talk it over first.

column1: You got yourself a ship.  We can leave as soon as you're ready.
column2: We have a little business to take care of first, but it shouldn't take long. We'll be back shortly.

column1: Who's the pilot?
column2: It's automatic.

column1: I'd keep that thing close just in case, if I were you... I've been around from one end of the galaxy to the other and believe me this Force of Others stuff may make for good religion, but there is no substitute for a good weapon at your side.
column2: You don't believe in the Force?

column1: I found it... It's just not there.
column2: What are you saying?

column1: You can't!  We've come this far.  We must find them...
column2: Why?

column1: Maybe you should just drop us off. I'm sure we can find someone willing to take the risk.
column2: All right, all right! You've got a ship!  But where do we go from here?  They probably took her to find the hidden bases... I don't see how we can find the rebels before she breaks.  The Empire has already beat us out.

column1: No, it's impossible... No one, and I mean no one would venture anywhere near the Alderaan system... I'm a free booter, not revolutionary.  You're aboard the wrong ship, son!
column2: Maybe the fact that no one would go there voluntarily could help us. They probably don't think anyone would dare try.

column1: Well, I practice a lot...
column2: You're good with 'remotes,' but how are you against something living?

column1: Between his howling and your blasting everything in sight, the entire city is going to know we're here.
column2: Good!  I prefer a straight fight to all this sneaking around.

column1: This isn't going to work.
column2: Why didn't you say so before.

column1: Something has happened to them. Let's try this way...
column2: Let's try this way!  Holy Maker.

column1: I think she's going to be all right.
column2: Not if this tunnel deadends.

column1: Is he afraid of the water?
column2: No, he smells something... but we haven't time to worry about it now.

column1: Watch it!  Move back.
column2: Get Chewbacca.  Try to get around it. I'll draw it away.

column1: It's only light that doesn't affect it.  Solid things, like rocks, can hurt it!  Fire above him!
column2: Move out of the way!

column1: Get to the ship!
column2: Come back here... Where are you going?

column1: I don't pick up any life form concentration down there.  She'd better be right.
column2: They must be shielded somehow.  I'm sure the base is there.

column1: You're a good pilot... I've learned a lot from you... I wish you...
column2: I know, but the chances for survival here just aren't great enough in my book.  I've got what I came for. Now I've got to get back to my ship.

column1: I noticed you were having some problems, Blue Five... I thought I'd help.
column2: Thanks, old buddy.  I'll be with you in a second.

column1: A Wookiee broke loose up here, but we've subdued him... There is a lot of damage, and three, no four, casualties...
column2: We'll send a squad up.

column1: No need, everything's under control.
column2: With four casualties?!

column1: The... ah door's jammed.  Give us a few minutes to get it fixed.
column2: Who is this?  What's your operating...

column1: Enough!  I already know about the data you've intercepted, but its' too late.  Whatever information you've gathered will be destroyed... You will come to know such suffering as only the Master of the Bogan Force can provide...
column2: You'll get no information from me. You have no authority... the council can't hold me!

column1: The 'Death Star' has become operational.  There is no force in the universe that can stop us now.
column2: They'll find its weakness.
It would be much easier if you were to tell us where the outposts are... Otherwise we'll be forced to destroy every suspicious system... What a waste...

column1: What is it?  What's going on?  Where are we?
column2: You're safe.  We've come to get you out of here... Just relax.

column1: I am Luke Starkiller at your service.
column2: There'll be time for that later. Now let's get out of here.

column1: Are there medical facilities on Yavin?
column2: He'll be well cared for.

column1: And you?
column2: I... I don't know.  I guess I never thought about it... I just want to help.  I want to be in on the attack. I want my own ship.

column1: First thing tomorrow morning you're going to check those condensing units on the south ridge.
column2: I will, but I'll have enough time to transmit my application first.

column1: You'll check the condensing unit first... and you're not going to bed until those 'droids' are completely cleaned up...
column2: But you promised!  I've saved enough money and now you have the extra help ... you promised!

column1: I said we'd see.  And as it is, I was forced to borrow your academy savings to buy the new 'droids.'  When you've saved it up again, I'll let you go.
column2: You used my savings!  You stole my savings.  If my father were here...

column1: Not unless you could get me into the military academy at Anchorhead.
column2: I'm sorry, sir, I'm only a 'droid,' and not very knowledgeable of such things... not on this system anyway. As a matter of fact, I'm not even sure which system we're on.

column1: That's all right.  There is nothing anyone can do about it.  You can call me Luke.
column2: Thank you, sir.  I'm See Threepio, Human Cyborg relations, and this is my counterpart, Artoo Detoo.

column1: There's a lot of carbon scoring here. It looks like you boys have seen a lot of action...
column2: Indeed, sir, sometimes I'm amazed we're in as good shape as we are, what with the rebellion and all...

column1: You've been in the Counter Wars?... Against the Empire?
column2: That's how we came to be in your service, if you take my meaning...

column1: Tell me where you've been.  I am going to become a startrooper and fight in the wars.  My father was a Jedi!  Were you in many battles?
column2: Several, I think.  There is not much to tell.  I'm not much more than an interpreter, and not very good at telling stories, not at making them interesting anyway...

column1: According to my father's tapes, this is the spot where General Kenobi lives, but the instruments just don't match up with the landscape... There is no doubt about it, we're lost...
column2: If you don't mind my saying so, sir, I don't see how anyone could live in this forsaken place.

column1: What happened?  I'm sorry, sir, I must have taken a bad step...
column2: Can you stand?  We've got to get out of here before those Tuskens come back.

column1: I can't make it.  You go on, master Luke.  It doesn't make sense for you to risk yourself on my account.  I'm done for.
column2: No, you're not.  What kind of talk is that...

column1: I think we're going to need them. Blast it!
column2: Sir, I have a couple of extra circuits.  Perhaps they might bring something.

column1: Let him have it.  You're winning anyway.  It doesn't make any difference.
column2: I know, sir, but it's the principle of the thing.

column1: Level five, Detention block A-23, cell 2187.  She's still alive...
column2: Send feed-back into the control sensors in that Detention block.

column1: See Threepio... do you copy?
column2: I read you sir.

column1: You're back.  What happened?  Never mind.  What's going on?
column2: I'm afraid we're not plugged in at the moment, sir.  We've had some problems.

column1: Are you safe?
column2: For the moment.  We're in the main hangar.  Artoo is trying to plug into the system now.

column1: Wait a minute, slow down!... That's better.  They're where?  They what? They are?  Oh, no! We're going to be mashed into conduit before this is over...
column2: See Threepio!  Do you copy?

column1: Holy Maker, Threepio.  I forgot...
column2: Are you there, sir?  We're going...

column1: Thank you, sir.  Your kindness is greatly appreciated, but if it's at all possible, Artoo and I would like to remain in your service.
column2: I'd consider it an honor.

column1: You got some guts for a rich kid. I guess you and me could be buddies.
column2: What an honor...

column1: What makes you think... you'll make... squad leader, Rico ?
column2: Something... I've got...you don't.

column1: You rich kids... are all the same !
column2: It isn't about rich... It's about who's best...!

column1: Wanting it doesn't make you the best one for the job.
column2: Oh, yeah ? I don't see anyone else here with the chops to lead.

column1: Our love will grow, dear, year by year...
column2: Bye ! Write me ! I'm gonna kill you guys !

column1: Funny how they always want to be your friends after they kick your guts out.
column2: It's what I deserve.

column1: Whad'ya talkin  about ?
column2: I joined up for her. I wouldn't even be here if it wasn't for her. I'm a fool.

column1: I say we all go to the laser parlor and get cut together.
column2: What do I want with a scar ?

column1: No, this hurts.
column2: YAAAAAAAA !

column1: Mobile Infantery rules !
column2: Death to all bugs !

column1: Lieutenant's bought the farm. Where's the Sarge...?
column2: I didn't see him !

column1: Dizzy says you two knew this Rasczak character in Buenos Aires...
column2: He was our teacher... He was great.

column1: No way. Big K taught me I ain't executive material.
column2: What about it, Diz ?

column1: Jeez, we musta killed a million already...!
column2: Not enough, I guess.

column1: We got reinforced. Most of'em just got outa boot...
column2: We're the old men, Ace.

column1: We'll take this high ground. Lookouts there and therte and up there. If the bugs come upstairs in this neighbor-hood, we'll be the first to know.
column2: Got it. Fleet tactical wants to know where they can deploy the skimmers.

column1: Mr. Barcalow, save power, don't waste it on workers... Ace, tell Aardvark we're on our way...
column2: Yes, sir !

column1: Saddle up, Roughnecks !
column2: You heard the Lieutenant ! On the bounce, troopers !

column1: Rico, did you give the recruit permission to remove his helmet ?
column2: Sir, yes, sir. Breckinridge reported a helmet malfunction, and I asked him to show it to me, sir.

column1: Are you rated to repair a Marauder power suit, Rico ?
column2: Sir, no, sir.

column1: Then why did you order your man to remove his helmet during a live fire exercise ?
column2: Sir, I needed everyone in my squad operational, sir... I... I wanted to win, sir.

column1: Do you freely admit to the charges made against you ?
column2: Sir... I guess I do, sir.

column1: Sir, I wish to reconsider my request to drop out, sir.
column2: Sorry, son. I can't do it. You signed the 1240/A. It would be illegal.

column1: You still haven't kissed her yet ? Don't lie.
column2: What's the hurry ?

column1: Did you read her mind ?
column2: Don't have to... Some mating semaphore is pretty hard to miss.

column1: Yeah, but I want Carmen.
column2: You got it bad.

column1: Don't think about it... go on instinct.
column2: Ace of spades.

column1: Statistically speaking you should've accidentally guessed right by know.
column2: In addition to "psychic dolt" this test also proves I'm unlucky ? Two of hearts.

column1: How do you make him do that ?
column2: I gave him the impression that there was a fly crawling up my mom's leg. He is going to go eat it.

column1: Ten of clubs. You still gonna sign up for Starside R&D ?
column2: Passport to the Universe. Who wouldn't want that ?

column1: I've been thinking about applying for Federal Service, too. Fleet, maybe.
column2: Your father will never let you.

column1: I'm eighteen. It's my decision, I think I'd make a pretty good pilot. I've good great reflexes. You need that for maneuvering, you know.
column2: Only 1 in 14 male applicants make it through stellar navigation. So what do you think your chances are ?

column1: Eight point... no, uh, seven...
column2: If you can't do those numbers, you haven't got a chance.

column1: All I know is Carmen's going to be a citizen, and I don't think it'll work out for us if I'm not.
column2: Love... how excruciatingly pathetic. Now try and pay attention.

column1: I don't believe it !
column2: I got Games & Theory.

column1: Please continue, Sergeant.
column2: Dizzy wouldn't want our tears. She'd want us to remember her... with a vengeance. So go out and kill a bug for Dizzy. Kill as many as you can. You are her revenge, and every bug you kill honors her death.

column1: Johnny, I'm sorry it had to be your unit on Planet P. That mission had a very low survival probability...
column2: Bugs laid a trap, didn't they ?

column1: You don't approve. Well, too bad. We're in this for the species, boys and girls. It's simple numbers, they have more, and everyday I have to make decisions that send hundreds of people like you to their deaths.
column2: Didn't they tell you, Colonel ? That's what cap troopres are good for.

column1: Hope you're ready for more. We're going back to P to capture that Brain.
column2: The Roughnecks are always ready, sir.

column1: I hear they need a new Lieutenant... Want the job ?
column2: I'll take it... until I get killed or you find someone better.

column1: You always told me you couldn't do human...
column2: I can't... but like I told you, it's a number's game. The Federation needs all the pilots it can get...

column1: Are you alright ?
column2: I'm getting better.

column1: So what are you doing later ?
column2: Everyone is going to the dance. Aren't you ?

column1: I'm all ears.
column2: Don't you have to finish the game ?

column1: Johnny, this is Zander.
column2: Yeah, we know each other from the game. No hard feeling, eh, chum ?

column1: Hey ! What are you doing here ?
column2: I'm the guy who's gonna teach you to fly this crate.

column1: Assistant insructor... You must be some kind of a hot stick. Should I call you "sir" ?
column2: Only when I give you an order.

column1: It's amazing, us running into each other like this. Maybe it's fate.
column2: Maybe not. I heard about this crazy girl coming through the academy, solid math, a little wild on the stick, but a natural. When it turned out it was you, I made sure we'd run into each other...

column1: In simulation, my supervisors could never keep up.
column2: This isn't simulation anymore. Take'er out easy, cadet.

column1: Oh, yes, sir. Vector ?
column2: Twenty-five by five, roll seven. And don't exceed port speed.
They revoke our flight status.

column1: Thanks. You read my mind. Third watch always seems to last forever.
column2: Oh, I don't know... Depends on who you are spending it with.

column1: Profile's wrong... there.
column2: No, I replotted the course. It's more efficient this way.

column1: Three weeks aboard a starship and you know it all, huh ?
column2: Hey, check it.

column1: You know I was talking to Captain, Deladier, and she said...
column2: Don't change the subject. Am I right ?

column1: Well, whad'ya know...
column2: Don't mess with the boss. So what'd the captain say ?

column1: She got a command... and she thinks we oughta team up officially and crew for her. She thinks we're good together.
column2: You and me, huh ?

column1: I want to be part of the best flight team in the Fleet...
column2: Me, too... Day and Night-Cycle.

column1: WHERE IS IT ?
column2: THERE !

column1: Everything coposetic, Lieutenant ?
column2: Zander, you remember Johnny ? Zander and I are a flight team now.

column1: Johnny, wait...
column2: Forget it, Carmen. The Mobile Infantery does a thankless, dirty job, so they naturally tend to be short-tempered, thoughtless and rude.

column1: Let's disregaed rank... Everybody hear that ? Rank is not an issue here.
column2: Zander, please... Let's go !

column1: I was thinking. Maybe we should get married, Carmen.
column2: You weren't thinking...you were dreaming !

column1: If we're gonna be a team, why not be a real team ?
column2: There's a war on. I want a command, I want my own ship, you do, too...

column1: So ?
column2: So who's got time to get married ?

column1: Fleet encourages marriages among flight officers. You'd probably get a promotion out of it.
column2: Funny...

column1: I'm not kidding. Marriage is -
column2: No, funny there's almost no wounded at all.

column1: Carmen...?
column2: Excuse me...!

column1: I'm sorry, Carmen.
column2: Please, I... Everybody's lost someone by now. This shouldn't be any different...

column1: No, I... Oh, Zander, I'm a fool.
column2: You're upset, that's alright.

column1: Where are you going ?
column2: A funeral.

column1: That girl who died on the way up ...his girl ?
column2: Yeah.

column1: How do you feel about him now ?
column2: I don't know, Zander.

column1: I thought I was dead. Lucky for me you jokers showed up, eh ?
column2: It wasn't luck. Rico ignored the mission objective to rescue you...

column1: Zander, what are you doing ?
column2: Just giving you something to remember me by, baby.

column1: Good for you.
column2: Your turn...

column1: She's flying starships !
column2: Who ?

column1: Marco's sister. Can you imagine maneuvering half a million tons through crwoded space lanes... You gotta have nerves of steel ! Reflexes are critical
column2: I have good reflexes.

column1: Eeuch !
column2: Aw, c'mon, it's just a bug.

column1: Well, if that's the crop, that must be the gastric caecal...
column2: Excuse me...!

column1: 35% on the math final !  No one could be that dumb with numbers.
column2: Well, at least you didn't lose your lunch over a bug. How embarassing.

column1: Who cares about bugs ? You can't go anywhere if you don't know math.
column2: Don't be so sure. I like you even if you are dumb with numbers.

column1: Then how come you won't hold hands with me at school ?
column2: I don't want everyone to see.

column1: Why won't you kiss me when we're all alone ?
column2: How come that's all you talk about anymore ?

column1: You can't walk me home.
column2: Why not ?

column1: I thought you were going to help Carl.
column2: Carl can wait.

column1: What's he got against me... I mean, I 'm a teenager. You can't be a citizen when you're only a teenager !
column2: It's not you, Johnny. Your parents are rich they don't need to be citizens, and that stuff means a lot to my dad. He's a veteran.

column1: Well, if your dad doesn't like me, how come we're such good friends ?
column2: Sometimes I do what I want, eh ?

column1: Isn't it great to be in love ?
column2: How do I know if this is love ?

column1: Romance is just a vestigial biological response to procreation...
column2: Aw, you're in love with me... You just dont know it yet.

column1: Wait, I want to talk to Mr. Rasczak.
column2: I'll meet you outside.

column1: None at all... We won.
column2: Good luck at the academy.

column1: He just got accepted to the Fleet Academy. Isn't that great ?
column2: Yeah, sure, I guess.

column1: No, I mean if he can get in, maybe I have a chance.
column2: What are you talking about ? We both know you're gonna be a pilot.

column1: Zander is going for pilot, too.
column2: You two have so much in common.

column1: Johnny Rico, you're jealous !
column2: I can't help it.

column1: He's nothing like you.
column2: I don't even know if you're my girl.

column1: Are you the boy for me ?
column2: I'm gonna do it, Carmen. I'm gonna sign up for Federal Service.

column1: Everyone's looking... we shouldn't...
column2: Who cares ?

column1: I love you, Carmen.
column2: Shhh...

column1: I wonder where Carl is. You don't suppose...?
column2: Naw, I made it, Carl made it.

column1: He was in the group with me. I guess he didn't...
column2: Shhh ! Don't make him feel worse.

column1: Hey, Carl, what's wrong ?
column2: Did you get Starside R&D ?

column1: Games & Theory ? That's Military Intelligence... Oh, Carl !
column2: Whoa ! Way to go, boy-yo !

column1: Let's all make a vow. Let's swear we'll always be friends no matter what.
column2: I'll go for that.

column1: You're late.
column2: My Dad had to help me pack. Suddenly he's afraid he's never gonna see me again or something. It was sweet, but it took forever. Anyway, I guess I'm ready to go.

column1: Poor boy. I'm sorry your parents were so mad.
column2: Who cares ! The Federation'll give me everything I need for the next two years, right ?

column1: You talk to Carl ?
column2: He left this morning. He couldn't say where.

column1: I'm gonna miss you.
column2: I'll miss you, too, Johnny.

column1: Com'on, just say it. Try it on for size.
column2: Alright, I love you.

column1: Do you mean it ?
column2: I said it. Isn't that enough ? Don't forget to write !

column1: Shhhh...!
column2: I'm glad you're doing so well. If they haven't made you squad leader by now, I'm sure you will.

column1: What happened to your hair ?
column2: What do you think ? Everyone did it when we got our wings. You don't like it, do you ?

column1: It's funny. Sometimes I forget. Then it hits me, and I can't stop crying.
column2: I try just to be happy I'm still alive.

column1: You don't look very happy to see me.
column2: Should I be ?

column1: What's wrong with you ?
column2: Hey, it's just a vestigal response to procreation... bitch.

column1: Johnny...! I thought you were dead !
column2: I'm not, but alot of my soldiers are. Glass the planet !

column1: ...I'm sorry.
column2: We gotta choke on the mud and the blood and Fleet can't be bothered to spit.

column1: I thought you were KIA, Johnny...
column2: That was just a mix up.

column1: You look so... I don't know, you look like you've really been in it.
column2: What happened to your eye ?

column1: Almost got knocked out of the sky over Big K.
column2: I like it. It's kinda...you.

column1: Well, look at this. The three of us back together again.
column2: How are you, Carl ?

column1: Take care, wilya Johnny ?
column2: See you on the bounce !

column1: AAAAAAAAAAAAAA !
column2: We've gotta go get her !

column1: Which way ?
column2: Up. We gotta be near A Company by now.

column1: Pilot Trainee Ibanez reporting for duty, ma'am.
column2: Take the number one chair, Ibanez. Follow all instructions of you supervisor.

column1: Alright, take her out, Ibanez.
column2: Yes, ma'am.

column1: Good work, Number 1. You'll do.
column2: Thank you, ma'am.

column1: Plasma, ma'am... from the planet.
column2: Bug Batteries... According to Military Intelligence, it'll be random and light. Drop status ?

column1: Where's Lieutenant Barcalow ?
column2: He requested a combat assignment. There's always a need for experienced pilots on the ground. I had no choice but to let him go... He said you'd understand.

column1: This is Rodger Young, we're going down... Repeat, this is Rodger Young, we're going down...!
column2: Ibanez...LET'S GO !

column1: Leave me, Lieutenant ! That's an order !
column2: No way, ma'am !

column1: Steady as she goes, number one. Prepare for warp. Number two, design for Jupiter orbit.
column2: Yes, ma'am. Star drive in three... two... one...

column1: Report.
column2: Captain, we are in the path of an unidentified object moving at near light speed...

column1: Where'd it come from ?
column2: Trajectory indicates it came out of the Arachnid Quarantine Zone.

column1: This isn't random or light. Someone made amistake...!
column2: That's it, we're empty ma'am !

column1: A lot can happen in three minutes.
column2: Hut... hut !

column1: What ?
column2: You were drifting. Flip six, three hole. On one, got it ?

column1: Hey, Rico, wanna dance ?
column2: Actually, Diz, I promised Carmen...

column1: You still gonna play for Brazil ?
column2: Looks like, unless Tokyo lets me start.

column1: Well, anyone who gets you is lucky.
column2: How come we never got together ?

column1: Can't we just be friends, Diz ?
column2: Sure.

column1: Uh, look, Diz...
column2: Guess you gotta go.

column1: Hey, amigo, come chow with me.
column2: No thanks, Diz.

column1: What's your malfunction, Rico ?
column2: You are. I joined up to get out on my own. And you had to tag along.

column1: What ? You think I joined the Mobile Infantery because of you ?
column2: You saying you didn't ?

column1: Man, they're defended... no way in.
column2: Flip six, three hole.

column1: What ?
column2: High school... remember ? Run a flip six, three hole play, and you might score...

column1: Cover me.
column2: You got it.

column1: It stinks, you goin.
column2: I don't stay where I'm not wanted.

column1: If they didn't want you, they woulda kicked you out, amigo.
column2: Hey, they humiliated me in front of everyone ! I'm just supposed to take it, huh ? Well, I'm not gonna, and I guess that proves I just can't cut it.

column1: Well, see ya.
column2: You take the stroll down Washout Lane, you're only proving one thing, Johnny.

column1: What's that, Diz ?
column2: That you don't have what it takes to be acitizen !

column1: Way to go, amigo !
column2: I'm gonna need a squad leader.

column1: C'mon...
column2: Nah, I don't do that anymore...

column1: You used to dance...
column2: I said no. Want me to pull rank ?

column1: Hey, Diz...
column2: What ?

column1: Planet P ? What kind of name is that ?
column2: They ran out of names a long time ago in this part of the galaxy.

column1: Diz, see what you can do.
column2: I'm on it !

column1: What frequency ?
column2: All bands.

column1: I bought the farm, didn't I, Johnny ?
column2: No, you're gonna be alright, Diz !

column1: Johnny, people get hurt... people get killed in the Federal Service. If something happened to you I don't know what I would do...
column2: Who gave you this idea ? It's that teacher. What's his name ? You know the one I mean.

column1: Good good, then it's all settled.
column2: A year at Harvard and you'll  see this "Federal Service" is just menial training for inferior people so they can call themselves "citizens" and take airs for the rest of their lives.

column1: Why did you go and do that ? He was all ready to go Zegema Beach !
column2: Teenagers !

column1: ...CUT OFF !
column2: Johnny, why won't you change your mind ? Does citizenship mean so much to you ?

column1: Don't talk like that. Get yourself home as fast as you can.
column2: We'll all have dinner. I'll fix your favorite.

column1: Oh, my, what's that ?
column2: Looks like rain.

column1: This came for you today. I presume on your request.
column2: A lot of my friends are doing Federal Service...

column1: Have you lost you lost your mind ? I'd rather take ten lashes in Public Square than see you ruin your life.
column2: It's aterm of service, not a career. I just want to get out on my own and see the Galaxy for a couple of years.

column1: Mr. Rasczak.
column2: Rasczak... Silly name. There ought to be a law against using a school as a recruiting station !

column1: No, Mr. Rasczak doesn't do that at all. He sorta discourages you really.
column2: Good, because you're going to Harvard, and that's the end of it.

column1: I'm eighteen. It's my decision.
column2: Oh, is that how it is ?

column1: A trip to the Outer Rings. Whad'ya think of that ?
column2: Wow ! Santori and Zegema Beach, I've always wanted to go there.

column1: Wait a minute ! Carl is doing his Federal and he isn't inferior. He's the smartest kid at school !
column2: Sorry. Carl's a fine boy...

column1: You'll resign, and that's all there is to it. It might look bad, but if that's the worst you suffer...
column2: I won't quit !

column1: I'm telling you, you will ! You're not going back. You're going to go on vacation !
column2: I'm not going on vacation ! I want to be acitizen ! It's my decision. I made it.

column1: Well, it's just good to hear from you. What's up, son ?
column2: It's not really working out for me here, dad. I was thinking... I was hoping it would be alright if I came home.

column1: We must be right over the colony. Let's get some air support, eh ?
column2: Yes, sir ! Fleet, this is Roughneck patrol, over ...?

column1: Corporal, I want pulse cannons there and there ! Rifle teams, spread out along the ridge ! Sugar, bring up that flame thrower !
column2: Fleet's pulling the battle group back to safe distance... They'd like us to knock out those batteries, sir.

column1: I don't understand it, Lieutenant. It's not getting anything from 4th Brigade... not even their transponder.
column2: Keep trying, Sergeant.

column1: Gillespie, put in call for retrieval. We're off this rock. Gillespie, do you read me ?
column2: AAAAAAAAAAA !

column1: At 0821 we received a distress call from Planet P, priority code, requesting reinforcement...
column2: I thought 4th brigade cleaned out P.

column1: Owen reported the eradication of a low generation colony a month ago. That's why MICOM wants onsite assessment.
column2: Sounds more like some idiot at Military Intelligence Command wants to get me and my cap troopers killed...

column1: Take your group down to P and have a look see. Leave the thinking to us, Lieutenant. That's not your job.
column2: My job is to protect the lives of my soldiers so they can kill bugs, Major, and if you're walking me into a trap-

column1: Seeing as how we're about all that's left of  1st Brigade, you'd have to call that an improvement.  You top kick ?
column2: Are you kidding ? They always get killed. You want the job ?

column1: I always wanted to go to Zegema Beach.
column2: Good luck. It's not there anymore.

column1: You knew the Lieutenant before the war... What was he like ?
column2: He was a teacher , kind of a know it all... Always had this little smile.

column1: Geez, I don't think I've ever seen him smile.
column2: Must fill your bottle up real quick when your wife and kids get smeared.

column1: Smith, GO ! McIntire, GO ! Flores, GO ! Rico, I'm making you sqaud leader !
column2: Sir, thank you, sir !

column1: The Marauder power suit will prevent serious injury, but if you are hit, you will be non-operational and your team score will suffer accordingly. Rico, has each member of your squad completed a weapons safety check ?
column2: Sir, yes, sir !

column1: Is that your signature, Rico ?
column2: Sir, yes it is, sir.

column1: No talking please. I'm going to ask you some questions. Please answer all questions truthfully. We'll know if you don't. Birthplace ?
column2: Here in Buenos Aires.

column1: Are your parents currently citizens ?
column2: No, sir.

column1: Which do you think is more important, courage or confidence ?
column2: Courage, I guess.

column1: Please complete this sentence. I want to be citizen because...
column2: I want to be a citizen because... well, because of my girl, sir.

column1: Who said you could grow up so fast ? Last time I checked you were only five years old. You had such a bright little face...
column2: Aw, don't get mushy.

column1: Wait you two. Dad and I have a surprise for you that will settle this. Can you guess what it is ?
column2: Uh, no.

column1: I don't know what they teach at Harvard, but I think I'm pretty good enough the way I am !
column2: Johnny, please. Calm yourself.

column1: Well, yeah, sure...
column2: I hope so. I hope you don't ruin your life over some silly little girl who wants to look handsome in a uniform.

column1: Hello... Oh, Johnny...!
column2: Hi, mom.

column1: Well, of course you should come home immedietly !
column2: I've made a mess of things. I've been so stupid...

column1: Don't get any ideas. She's my girl.
column2: You can never be sure.

column1: Best in the Fleet !
column2: I get it. This is the part that's best for both of us. Don't do me anymore favors, eh ?

column1: You got something to say about the Mobile Infantery ?
column2: You heard me. Wanna make something out of it, private ?

column1: On whose authority, Corporal ?
column2: This would be mine, sir. Acting Sergeant John Rico. I've assumed command on this mission.

column1: You're standing on my H.Q., Lieutenant !
column2: This is a Fleet-driven operation, son, and the Fleet thinks my boat will be safer on the high ground. You can have everything else, eh ?

column1: Rodger Young, prepare to receice outgoing fire...!  I'll take the first group.
column2: Saddle up, boys, that's our trash !

column1: What's your problem now, Lieutenant ?
column2: The Rodger Young just burned up...

column1: We're outa here. Lieutenant, get your men into the skimmers. This real estate's about to go buggy.
column2: Hey, just calm down, I'm giving the orders here-

column1: What do you think you're doing ?
column2: I'm gonna save Carmen.

column1: That would mean a comlete disregard for the mission objective. They hang you for that, Rico.
column2: Yeah, that's right.

column1: Let's go.
column2: Move out.

column1: Can you walk ?
column2: Not a problem.

column1: How bad are you, pal ?
column2: Been better, buddy.

column1: Alright, we're gonna carry you...
column2: Nah, I figureyou folks oughta get upstairs before it's too late... Gimmee the nuke.

column1: Don't be a hero...
column2: This is my farm. Now c'mon, give me what you got and get out of here...

column1: This is Rodger Young... What's going on down there ? We're taking plasma ! We have Orion P-11 as clear !
column2: SHUT UP, SIR ! We need pick up now !

column1: What is your position ?
column2: Landing zone is extremely hostile. Come down on this transmission !

column1: Inside 4th brigade compound ? That's crazy !
column2: Then I hope you have a crazy pilot ! Keep the line open, Dizzy !

column1: You. Tell me the moral difference, if any, between the citizen and the civilian ?
column2: The difference lies in the field of civic virtue. A citizen accepts personal responsibility for the safety of the body politic, of which he is a member, defending it, if need be, with his life. The civilian does not.

column1: The exact words of the text. But do you understand it ? Do you believe it ?
column2: Uh, I don't know.

column1: Mister Rasczak ?
column2: What is it, Rico ?

column1: I just wanted to say thanks 'cause History and Moral Philosophy was the best class I had this year.
column2: Well, it's not really my job to please. Hope you learned something.

column1: I wanna join up, Mr. Rasczak. I think I have what it take to be a citizen.
column2: Good for you. Go find out.

column1: Well, my parents are against it, and I know it's my choice, but I was wondering... What would you do if you were me ?
column2: Figuring things out for yourself is the only freedom anyone really has. Use that freedom. Make your own choice, Rico.

column1: Where'd you learn to do that, soldier ?
column2: Uni High Tigers, sir. Don't you remember ? I was captain of the team.

column1: All dead except one, sir.
column2: Kill the bitch.

column1: Yopu asked me some advice once, Rico. Want some now ?
column2: Yes, sir...

column1: Corporal, the Roughnecks are moving out for Planet P immediately. Get yourself squared away and report to Gillespie for logistics.
column2: Yes, sir !

column1: Rico, you're acting Sergeant now. My last Sergeant lost the com pack. Put together a search team and find the radio shack. We need retrieval.
column2: Yes, sir.

column1: What's that look like to you, Rico ?
column2: Looks like a bug was in his brain, sir.

column1: Warm it all up ! Everything you got ! Levy, collect the big guns from the towers. Watkins, put General Owen with the wounded. Rico, where's my communications ?
column2: What's going on, Diz ?

column1: Sergeant, secure the boat !
column2: Yes, sir !

column1: AAAAAAAAAAAA !
column2: Cover us, Ace !

column1: Hit your jets, sir !
column2: I can't My legs are gone... Get on the boat...

column1: Rico, tell'em to glass this goddam planet. I've never seen so many bugs upstairs at the same time...
column2: We're not leaving you here, sir !

column1: This is my farm. Get on the boat, NOW ! That's an order, Sergeant.
column2: Give'em hell, sir !

column1: Who is...'V'ger'...?
column2: V'ger is that which programmed me.

column1: Where is Lt. Ilia?
column2: That unit no longer functions. I have been given its form to more readily communicate with the carbon-based units infesting Enterprise.

column1: Why does V'ger travel to the third planet of the solar system directly ahead?
column2: V'ger travels to the third planet to find the Creator.

column1: Find the Creator? <U>What</U> Creator? <U>Whose</U>...!?  What does V'ger want of the 'Creator'... ?
column2: To join with him.

column1: The Creator is that which created V'ger.
column2: Who is V'ger?

column1: The examination is a normal function.
column2: You may proceede.
The carbon-units infection will now be removed from the Creator's planet.

column1: <U>Why</U>?!
column2: The Creator has not answered.

column1: The carbon-units are not responsible for that.
column2: You infest and control Enterprise. V'ger believes carbon-units interfere with the Creator in the same manner.

column1: Disclose the information.
column2: Not until V'ger withdraws the devices orbiting the third planet.

column1: Kirk-unit, <U>why</U> do you not disclose information?
column2: Because V'ger is going to destroy all the carbon units on the third planet.

column1: They have repressed the Creator.
column2: The information will not be disclosed.

column1: Then V'ger must withdraw its orbiting devices.
column2: V'ger will comply if the carbon units disclose the information.

column1: Our data is being prepared.
column2: <U>Answer</U>!

column1: The crews of the previous Enterprises were also carbon units. In what way is the life form in your vessel different?
column2: Carbon units are not true life forms... Do those images repre- sent how Enterprise has evolved into its present form?

column1: Yes.
column2: Carbon units have clearly retarded Enterprise's proper evolvement.

column1: What is Enterprise's proper evolvement?
column2: Enterprise should not require the presence of carbon units.

column1: Enterprise would be unable to function <U>without</U> carbon units.
column2: More data concerning this functioning is necessary before carbon units can be patterned for data storage.

column1: What does that mean?
column2: When my examination is complete, the carbon units will be reduced to data patterns.

column1: Within you are memory patterns of a carbon unit. If I can help you revive these patterns
column2: That is logical. You may procede.

column1: Does V'ger object to the presence of the two carbon units?
column2: The carbon units are of no consequence

column1: You said V'ger's purpose was to find and join with the Creator.
column2: That is how V'ger will survive.

column1: A machine...! Then it had to be programmed. By <U>whom</U>...?
column2: By the Creator.

column1: To join, and become One with the Creator?
column2: To learn all that is learnable

column1: As I stated, V'ger calls to the Creator.
column2: V'ger is announcing that it has arrived, sir -- that it's ready to deliver the information it was programmed to collect...

column1: 'To learn all that is learnable.'
column2: It expects a return signal now, ordering it to transmit that information to the Creator.

column1: And when V'ger melds? What will happen to you?
column2: It will... take me from <U>you</U>...

column1: Departure angle on viewer.
column2: Departure angle.

column1: It is a courier, Captain. Grade One priority. Non-belligerency confirmed.
column2: Very well, Mr. Chekov, see to it. Viewer off.

column1: Deck four, Captain
column2: Have a security team meet me at Deck Four main elevator!

column1: Sir! Airlock four has been opened
column2: Spock...!  Get a fix on his position!

column1: Mr. Chekov, when do those devices activate?
column2: They reach final position in... Twenty-seven minutes -- mark.

column1: Tractor beam strength lessening, Captain.
column2: Mr. Scott... on my next signal.

column1: I'm taking over the Center seat. I'm sorry, Will.
column2: You are what...?

column1: You'll stay aboard as Executive Officer... a temporary grade reduction to Commander.
column2: -- You, personally, are assuming command?

column1: Yes.
column2: May I ask Why?

column1: My experience -- five years out there dealing with unknowns like this -- my familiarity with the Enterprise, this crew...
column2: Admiral, this is an almost totally new enterprise. You don't know her a tenth as well as I do.

column1: That's why you're staying aboard. I'm sorry, Will.
column2: No, Admiral. I don't think you are

column1: We'll have to replace Commander Sonak. I'd still like a Vulcan there, if possible...
column2: None available, Captain. There's no one in fact, who's fully rated on this design.

column1: Programming ready?
column2: Program set for standard Warp entry, Captain...

column1: ... but I still recommend further simulation study.
column2: Mister Decker

column1: Explanation, Mr. Decker: Why was my phaser order countermanded?
column2: Sir, the Enterprise redesign increases phaser power by channeling it through the main engines. When they went into anti-matter imbalance, the phasers were automatically cut off.

column1: Then you acted properly, of course.
column2: Thank you, sir. I'm sorry I embar- rassed you.

column1: You saved the ship.
column2: I'm aware of that, sir.

column1: Stop competing with me, Decker!
column2: Permission to speak freely, sir?

column1: Granted.
column2: Sir, you haven't logged a single star hour in two and a half years. That, plus your unfamiliarity with the ship's design -- in my opinion, sir, seriously jeopardizes our mission.

column1: I trust you will... nursemaid me through these difficulties, Mister?
column2: Yes, sir, I'll do that.

column1: If our Executive Officer has no objections...?
column2: Of course not. I'm aware of Mister Spock's qualifications.

column1: Recommend defensive posture, Captain: Screens and shields.
column2: No...  ... that could also be misinter- preted as hostile, Mr. Decker.  Cloud composition, Mr. Spock?

column1: Captain, we've seen what their weapons can do. Shouldn't we take every possible precaution -- ?
column2: Mr Decker....

column1: I advise caution, Captain
column2: That thing is twenty hours from Earth. We know nothing about it yet.

column1: That's precisely the point, Captain. We don't know it will do. Moving into the cloud -- at this time, is an unwarranted gamble.
column2: How do you define <U>unwarranted</U>, <U>mister</U>?!

column1: <U>Computer off</U>!
column2: It's taken control of the computer...!

column1: The ship is under attack...! Man all defensive stations...!
column2: Forcefields, full remaining strength...! Total reserve!

column1: Why bring us inside? Not to destroy us
column2: They could have many ways of destroying things, Mr. Decker.

column1: Captain, what's the next move?
column2: The question is, Mr. Decker, <U>is</U> there a next move...

column1: Well, Mr. Decker, it seems my bluff is being called.
column2: I'm afraid our hand is pretty weak, Captain.  But it's the only game in town.

column1: , if we do not provide     V'ger with certain information, we won't have twenty-two <U>seconds</U>
column2: Captain, we can't be sure that our... move... will actually save Earth.

column1: Mr. Decker... I will contact you every five minutes. Otherwise... inform Mr. Scott immediately.
column2: Captain... I'd like to go along...

column1: The fault is here, sir, not in the transmission.  The antenna leads have been disconnected. V'ger never intended to accept a transmitted signal.
column2: Capture God! In order to retrieve V'ger's data, the Creator has to physically come here!...

column1: And plug the signal directly into the circuitry at this...  ... point here, Captain. It should pick up even a tricorder playback.
column2: Enterprise, I want that signal again. Transmit!

column1: They may have attacked only as a warning to us, Captain. To keep away.
column2: That would presuppose a feeling, Commander... compassion. I sensed <U>no</U> emotion, only...  ... pure logic.

column1: We could have cut it off at the main computer...
column2: This served the purpose.

column1: Captain... this probe may be a key a key to the Aliens.
column2: It's a programmed <U>mechanism</U>, Mr. Spock...

column1: Exactly.  And you did have a 'relationship' with Lieutenant Ilia, Commander.
column2: That probe in there -- in a different form now -- is the same thing that <U>killed</U> Ilia!

column1: Then V'ger believes the Creator to be a <U>machine</U> too.
column2: It seems we <U>all</U> imagine God in our own image.

column1: Forward motion, Captain...!
column2: A tractor beam...

column1: Mr. Spock, what would V'ger need to fulfill itself?
column2: V'ger has begun to understand the true limits of our universe, thereby realizing the existence of other dimensions. To fulfill itself it must evolve to a higher dimension

column1: That transmitter is a vital link between V'ger and the Creator.
column2: We have twenty-one minutes. Captain,    we can still save V'ger... and ourselves.

column1: Jim... he <U>wants</U> it.
column2: You got the Enterprise, it's what <U>you</U> wanted. This is what I want.  But, Jim...  ... <U>I'm</U> the right choice for this mission.

column1: Hello, Ilia.
column2: Decker....!

column1: I now the Captain meant no person- al insult.
column2: I would never take advantage of a sexually immature species.  You can assure him that's true, can't you?

column1: Negative control from inertial lag will continue 22 point five seconds before forward velocity slows to sub-light speed.
column2: Unidentified small object has been pulled into the wormhole with us, Captain! Directly ahead...!

column1: Navigational deflectors inoperative...!  Directional control also inoperative, Captain...!
column2: Wormhole distortion has over- loaded main power systems...!

column1: Was he difficult?
column2: No more than I expected  Not as difficult as this. I'm sorry...

column1: That you left? or that you didn't say 'goodbye'?
column2: If I'd seen you again, would you have been able to say it?

column1: Lieutenant Ilia reporting for duty, sir.
column2: Welcome aboard, Lieutenant.

column1: 'Commander' Decker?
column2: Our Exec and Science Officer...

column1: And in you, too, Lieutenant.
column2: My oath of celibacy is on record Captain. May I assume my duties?

column1: Time to impact...?
column2: Twelve seconds...!

column1: Five minutes to Cloud boundary!
column2: I stand corrected Mr. Decker.  Navigator, lay in a conic section flight path into the cloud center

column1: Mr. Spock?
column2: Impact in fifteen seconds...

column1: Transmit, Mr. Spock! Now!
column2: Ten seconds....

column1: Thirty seconds to Cloud boundary...
column2: Opinion, Mister. Spock?

column1: Fifteen seconds to Cloud Boundary.
column2: Viewer, standard ahead.

column1: I appreciate the welcome
column2: He's in Engineering, sir...  He doesn't know.

column1: Maneuvering thrusters, Mister Sulu.
column2: Maneuvering thrusters, sir.

column1: Hold station.
column2: Thrusters at station-keeping, sir.

column1: Ahead Warp One, Mr Sulu.
column2: Accelerating to Warp One, sir.

column1: Mr. Sulu, steady as she goes.
column2: Aye, sir.

column1: Reduce magnification. Factor 4, Mr. Sulu.
column2: We're already two settings below that, sir.

column1: One hundred kilometers...
column2: Hold relative position here...

column1: Viewer ahead.
column2: Viewer ahead, sir.

column1: Maneuvering thrusters, Mr. Sulu
column2: Thrusters ahead, one third.

column1: Hold station...!
column2: Thrusters at station keeping...

column1: Clear the bridge, Captain...?
column2: That was the order, Mr. Sulu: Clear the bridge.

column1: Admiral, I've been hoping to see you. Maybe you can get through to those thick heads in Starfleet that...
column2: Why aren't the Enterprise transporters in operation, Mister Scott?

column1: We're hoping it's only a temporary problem, Admiral...
column2: See that it is.  Take me over, please.

column1: Admiral, the Enterprise has just finished eighteen months redesign- ing and refitting. She needs testing, a shakedown...
column2: Mr. Scott, there's an alien object with unbelievable destructive power less than three days away from this planet...

column1: The crew hasn't had near enough transition time with all the new equipment. And the engines, Admiral: they've yet to be even tested at warp power. Add to that, an untried Captain...
column2: Two and a half years as Chief of Starfleet Operations may have made me a little stale, Mr. Scott -- but I wouldn't exactly consider myself 'untried.'

column1: We're losing the pattern...!
column2: Starfleet, boost your matter gain

column1: Reporting as ordered, Captain.
column2: Sit down, please.

column1: Sir, I would appreciate Dr. McCoy absenting himself from this interview.
column2: I want him here.  Sit down!

column1: You've reported that you felt strong thought emotions. A group of minds from a space vessel? Could you make out any plan, anything to do with Earth?
column2: Negative, Captain. I could sense only what seemed an almost omniscient pattern of perfect logic. I can explain nothing more

column1: Also -- there was nothing in your report about <U>why</U> you're here.
column2: That inquiry invades my personal life, Captain.

column1: I still contain fragments of my human half.
column2: And whatever you sensed out here....

column1: Let it drop, Bones.  You are my Science Officer -- I'll expect an <U>immediate</U> report on anything further you learn or <U>sense</U> from here on.
column2: I have accepted service here as a Starfleet officer... sir.

column1: Do <U>not</U> return scan, Mr. Spock! It may be misinterpreted as hostility!
column2: Intruder scans emanate from the exact cloud center. Energy of a type entirely un- known to me.

column1: Captain, I suspect there's an object at the heart of that cloud.
column2: Mr. Decker, I will not provoke an attack, If that order isn't clear to you...

column1: They have... they <U>have</U> been communicating with us. I sense ... <U>puzzlement</U>. Why have we not replied?
column2: Communicated with us <U>how</U>?

column1: It appears that our message has been understood, Captain.
column2: Any reply from them?

column1: The 'puzzlement' I sensed was fleeting... minor...  ... as if carrying a sense of our insignificance, Captain.
column2: Our... 'insignificance'?

column1: We are obviously confronted by a highly advanced mentality... yet they cannot understand who we are, or what we want.
column2: But they understood our messages

column1: Recommend we proceede, Captain.
column2: Mr. Decker... ?

column1: No vessel could generate a powerfield of this magnitude...
column2: Instruments fluctuating, Captain. Patterns unrecognizable.

column1: That vessel is generating a forcefield measurably greater than the radiation of the Earth's sun.
column2: Transmit image of the Alien to Starfleet

column1: Captain, we have been seized by a tractor beam...!
column2: Get someone up here to take the Navigator's station...!  Engineering... full emergency power!

column1: We cannot break free, Captain.  We do not have a fraction of the power necessary.
column2: Delay that order, Scotty...! Disengage all main drive systems!

column1: Have you been able to analyze <U>any</U> of this...?
column2: I believe the light flares to be energy fields -- undoubtedly part of the vessel's inner mechanism. A technology so incredibly sophisticated that I cannot --

column1: They had a pattern to follow...
column2: ... they may have followed it <U>too</U> precisely.

column1: Spock? Concerned about his chances?
column2: I am uneasy with that being our only hope of more information.

column1: Bridge, cancel rescue teams.  Spock, what in the hell are you doing out here!
column2: I am seeking answers, Captain.

column1: It would appear that the atomic arrays of these crystals store information. A remarkably efficient system.
column2: And these 'sensor-swarms' collect that data, carry it here.

column1: Klingons... our Epsilon 9 station ... and Ilia!! They seem to be more than just images...
column2: Exact patterns. The energy bolt that hit them wasn't simply a weapon -- it dematerialized them, stored them. But why?

column1: If this is their ship's data banks, where is the crew? Or is their entire ship automated?
column2: Captain, I do not believe there <U>is</U> a crew -- or that this is a vessel as such.

column1: Were you right? Spock? V'ger is a living machine...?
column2: A life form of its own

column1: What should you have known?
column2: No meaning... No hope...  And, Jim, no answers...! Jim, it's looking for <U>answers</U> <U>itself</U>!

column1: What answers?
column2: 'Is this all I am? Is there not more?'

column1: These read as identical composition...  ... however, Captain, they measure several hundred times more powerful!
column2: High mag, Mr. Sulu!

column1: Child...!?
column2: Yes, Captain, a child: evolving into adulthood -- learning, searching -- instinctively needing.

column1: The orbiting devices would be controlled from the point, then...?
column2: Precisely.

column1: Not for us?
column2: No, Captain, not for us... for V'ger.

column1: Has not, Doctor -- and now, because of what we are planning... will not...
column2: There is no alternative.

column1: Captain, the orbital device will      not be triggered for twenty-two       minutes...
column2: The point...

column1: V'ger plans to literally <U>meld</U> to reduce both itself and the Creator to patterns...
column2: ... and then to reassemble itself <U>combined</U> with the Creator. The most certain way of obtaining all the Creator's answers.
