column1: There's no way to know. V'ger expected it to be a machine -- some single entity.  All of us here may be reduced into patterns...
column2: That seems to be what it has planned -- to have the Creator physically present here.

column1: Spock, we <U>were</U> its answer!
column2: Yes, Captain. It needed our mortality, the fear of it, our struggle against it, our fears, our dreams...

column1: ... and the 'foolish' emotions which drive us?
column2: I prefer your poet Dante's phrase -- 'the divine restlessness of the human spirit.'

column1: You've received your appointment as Enterprise Science Officer?
column2: Based, I am told, on your recommendation, Admiral. Thank you.

column1: Why aren't you on board?
column2: Captain Decker requested I complete final Science briefing here before...

column1: Here at Starfleet...? The Enterprise is in final preparation to leave dock...
column2: Which will require twenty more hours at minimum, Admiral...

column1: Twelve! I'm on my way to a meeting with Admiral Nogura which will not last more than three minutes. Report to me on the Enterprise in one hour.
column2: To you, sir?

column1: Captain, we need further Warp simulation on the flow sensors...
column2: Engineer, we need Warp speed now!

column1: Warp Drive as soon as possible, Mr. Scott.
column2: Captain, it was our anti-matter imbalance that created the wormhole in the first place. It will happen again if we don't correct it.

column1: That object out there is less than two days from Earth, Mister Scott. We've got to intercept while it still is out there!
column2: Aye, we understand that sir! We're doing our best.

column1: Engineering... Status, Mr. Scott?
column2: We're ready, sir.

column1: Transporters Room and Chief Engineer Scott report trans- porter system fully repaired and now functioning normally, sir.
column2: Dock signals clear, Captain.

column1: Dock control reports ready, sir.
column2: Helm ready, sir.

column1: Negative helm control, Captain! Going reverse on impulse power...!
column2: Subspace frequencies are jammed by Wormhole effect!

column1: Starfleet signals, sir, growing in strength...  They -- have Intruder on their monitors -- it's decelerating -- powerfield cloud beginning to dissipate...
column2: Confirm, Captain. Lunar beacons indicate Intruder on a course into Earth orbit...

column1: The third one is moving off too -- a fourth one is forming...
column2: <U>Urgent</U> signal from Starfleet, Captain!  <U>All</U> Earth defense systems have gone dead.

column1: Starfleet has been apprised of our situation, Captain.
column2: Tractor beam remains constant...

column1: You and your husband have been kind to me, Alura. I have something to tell you: I'm going away. Soon.
column2: But where?

column1: I've discovered a new way into the Phantom Zone.
column2: But the phantom Zone is for criminals.

column1: I'm an artist, Alura. My work comes first. Other people come second.
column2: How can you create beauty...with a selfish heart? The spiky insect-creature flies closer and closer around the little girl's head, buzzing angrily. Her look of delight turns to fear. She tries to shoo the creature away. It flies off toward the thin membrane that encloses the city.

column1: But the Power Source, Zaltar.
column2: It couldn't be helped. The city will have to make do with three.

column1: But what will happen?
column2: The Guardians will be angry. They may even send me to the Phantom Zone. You see, I didn't really have permission to borrow it. I must go explain to them...

column1: I said stop, I didn't say run into a brick wall.
column2: What is it?

column1: What does it mean?
column2: The danger. The one Nigel spoke of. It must be near .

column1: Oh, fiddlesticks. What could be dangerous about a baseball game?
column2: Softball.

column1: It must be the girls. One of the girls.
column2: But which one?

column1: We'll bide our time and keep watch. Young girls just can't keep a secret. If one of them's up to something--we'll find out.
column2: And then, like great cats---we pounce! And destroy!

column1: Bianca, try not to be so bloodthirsty when you're at the wheel. OK?
column2: Sorry, mistress.

column1: Is he your entertainment for tonight?
column2: He will be. In about five minutes.

column1: I came as quickly as I could. What is the danger?
column2: It's what we were warned about.

column1: A Storm Dragon?
column2: No, a super girl.

column1: Why did she have to show up now?
column2: Eliminate her.

column1: That's easy for you to say, Bianca.
column2: You can do it. You're the most powerful woman on Earth.

column1: Yes! You own the Coffer of Shadow. Nothing can withstand its power.
column2: I've been saving it. For the right moment.

column1: What do I do?  I don't know her name.
column2: The Naming of Names is not necessary. Just concentrate on her face. Your Shadow will do the rest.

column1: Next time, remind me to do this out in the yard.
column2: Yes, of course, it was foolish of me.

column1: I think I'd better keep it.
column2: Whatever you say.

column1: Home?
column2: No way. I'm not going to let that little hussy make a monkey out of me.

column1: Sure glad you didn't let make a monkey of you.
column2: Shut up, and get me a hacksaw.

column1: I don't feel like it right now.
column2: She didn't take it from you, did she?

column1: That little girl? Ha.  Now go on, get me some tools.
column2: There's no need. I learned the Craft from my

column1: At last. Ultimate Power.
column2: And the first thing we do is get rid of Supergirl!

column1: I don't want much, Selena. I have simple tastes.
column2: What do you want?

column1: Western Europe.
column2: I'm sorry, but I already promised Bianca she could have Switzerland. You know how she loves to ski.

column1: Is this Nigel's doing?
column2: It's a warning, that's for sure.

column1: Maybe it was just an accident.
column2: There's no such thing as an accident. Everything has meaning, if you can read the signs.

column1: Wait...don't leave me in here...
column2: It's for your own protection.

column1: What's happening?
column2: I'm taking you to the hospital.

column1: Let me out. I have to talk to you.
column2: Later.

column1: Don't leave me.
column2: I have to.

column1: When can I see, you again ?
column2: Relax. Tomorrow this will all seem like a bad dream. Goodbye.

column1: You're alive! She didn't kill you!
column2: Who didn't?

column1: That woman who's after me. She hates you. Because she knows I love you.
column2: You love me?

column1: My angel. My goddess. I feel I've always loved you all my life. I'll die if I can't spend the rest of my life just looking at you, holding you in my arms...
column2: We have to have a long talk about all this.

column1: This is my favourite place in the city.
column2: Are you sure it's all right for us to be here?

column1: Like it?
column2: Yes. It reminds me of home.

column1: Where Superman's from? Krypton?
column2: No. Argo City. It was on a chunk of rock that was part of Krypton once---but we moved it to inner space.

column1: I'm sorry, I don't understand.
column2: It's not important. The important thing is I'm here to find something and I think you can he1p me.

column1: I used to work here summers when I was a kid.
column2: Ethan, tell me more about this woman who's after you.

column1: Let's talk about us, not her.
column2: Tell me where I can find her.

column1: But be reasonable. If I don't do something to stop her she'll try again. And maybe hurt you.
column2: I'll be safe with you. We can stay together the rest of our lives.

column1: We can't do that.
column2: Why not ?

column1: We're from different worlds.
column2: Just give me a chance to show how much I love you. Love changes everything. Love makes everything possib1e.

column1: All this talk about love, it's silly.
column2: You don't like me? You hate me?

column1: Of Course I don't hate you. I  don't hate anyone.
column2: What do you feel about me?

column1: There's one sure way to find out how you feel.
column2: What's that?

column1: Let me kiss you.
column2: No.

column1: You're not afraid are you?
column2: Of course not, but...there are things we don't understand.

column1: If we wait until we understand everything we'll be dead. Come on. You can learn more from one kiss than from years in school.
column2: Well...I guess one is all right.

column1: Is this how?
column2: Terrific.

column1: I thought I'd show you one of my favourite places.
column2: It's paradise . We could be very happy here.

column1: But I have to go back. I brought you here so you'd be safe. From her.
column2: You can't just abandon me.  Alone.

column1: Great! I'II build a house-- right over there, with a veranda looking out to sea. And I'll plant a garden! Papayas, pineapples, bananas, mangoes--- anything'll grow here. And I'II fish in the lagoon, and we can go sailing in a dugout canoe, and---
column2: Ethan---when I said 'a while' I meant a couple of hours.

column1: She said it wouldn't last.
column2: What wouldn't last? What's the matter with you?

column1: I don't love you any more.
column2: Just like that?

column1: Away. From you.
column2: But why?

column1: Because you remind me of all the dumb things I said.
column2: I sort of like what you said.

column1: That makes it worse.
column2: But I don't understand.

column1: Hi.
column2: Hello. Are you still mad at me?

column1: I'm not mad at you.
column2: It seemed that way to me.

column1: I know I was acting funny---I'm sorry. It's just...I miss it.
column2: Miss what?

column1: And now?
column2: And now...the guitars are out of tune, and the words don't make sense, and somebody unplugged the mike...

column1: You think so?
column2: I don't see why not.

column1: But what if---it wasn't real?
column2: Feelings are real. Once you've had them, they're yours forever.

column1: Hey, listen, when all this blows over, maybe we could get together every now and then and see each other. And maybe something might. happen again. What do you think?
column2: Are you asking me for a "date"?

column1: Why not? You're a good-looking girl. And I'm--- available.
column2: Aren't you forgetting about Selena?

column1: There's something very dangerous about her. Something evil...
column2: I know what it is. She has this lead container shaped like a gargoyle. Inside there's a silvery ring...

column1: That's the Power Source that was lost from Argo City! That's what I came: to find! Where does she live?
column2: In this big old house on Orchard Avenue---but you better stay away from there.

column1: Wait. Don't leave me.
column2: You'll be safe here. I'll come back as soon as I have the Power Source.

column1: Before you go...
column2: What?

column1: And you can see how you feel about me, right?
column2: Yes.

column1: You've had your fun, Selena, the game is over.
column2: She has hostages.

column1: It's her shadow-self! Her dark side!
column2: How do I fight it?

column1: No thanks. I have friends in the resistance. They'll vouch for me. I figure I might get a million bucks for my memoirs.
column2: I'll come back as soon as I can.

column1: She's right. They'll string her up.
column2: Do you want to come to Argo City?

column1: Hey! Ethan!
column2: Hmmm?

column1: A little.
column2: Can you get us out? It's all a misunderstanding. We thought they were selling hamburgers in that place.

column1: Hey, I thought you were gonna mention us upstairs.
column2: I did.

column1: Finished your estimate?
column2: Well, there's several ways to go .

column1: You must be very popular in the neighborhood. I always see your truck parked around.
column2: I have a lot of repeat business. People seem to like my service.

column1: I bet they do.
column2: What's that big black scar on the ground? Like a fire.

column1: What is it?
column2: A passionfruit smoothee.

column1: To us. And to the seeds we'll plant together.
column2: I'll drink to that.

column1: Oh no, not you again.
column2: What an adorable hat.

column1: They think I have a concussion.
column2: And you think you're in love.

column1: I know it.
column2: This "love" of yours will soon wear off. I gave you a temporary love potion.

column1: Why should I believe you?
column2: It's the truth. In twenty-four hours you'll forget all about that girl.

column1: Yes, yes I saw the whole thing. How could you be interested in that puny little girl?
column2: But she is real, it wasn't just a concussion.

column1: Nurse! Nurse!
column2: You can't escape from me that easily. I'm afraid you don't know who I am.

column1: Nurse!
column2: Don't think I'm weak, just because I'm a woman. I have Power. Give in, stop fighting me, Ethan. I always get what I want.

column1: This is your problem, right here. This girl's driving you insane, Ethan. Let me help you.
column2: I don't want your help.

column1: No!
column2: I never met a man I couldn't have--and you're no different from the rest!

column1: I'm wise to your tricks, lady.
column2: I could force you.

column1: If that worked, you would've done it already. No, you want me to drink it of my own free will. Well let me tell you, sweetheart, it'll be a cold day in hell before I fall for that one again.
column2: Go on,  talk big! I'll soon have you purring like a kitten.

column1: You've been without water for a whole day. Let's see how thirsty you get in a week.
column2: You vicious--

column1: They want me. Doesn't it make you proud?
column2: Yeah.

column1: Guess! Go on.
column2: I don't know. You seem afraid.

column1: You're a regular Einstein, aren't you?
column2: Supergirl?

column1: You can't put her out of your mind, is that it?
column2: Well...I guess I can't.

column1: Why the empty cage?
column2: That one was for you. But I thought I'd wait and see how you behave when Supergirl gets here. I'd hate to lose you, Ethan.

column1: You sure are a good cook, Selena. Man, that looks too pretty to eat.
column2: Better eat it quick. It won't look too pretty when it's all covered with ants.

column1: Selena, I've been thinking. It's time I settled down---and I don't know a nicer lady to settle down with than you.
column2: Why George, are you proposing?

column1: Marry me, Selena. The hardware store doesn't bring in much now, but...
column2: George---I thought you'd never ask.

column1: Hey, where you going?
column2: I've got things to do.

column1: What about my proposal?
column2: Call me next week. Maybe we can have lunch.

column1: Nice to meet you. Lucy's told me all about you. Your cousin Clark taught me everything I know about the newspaper business.
column2: Nice to meet you.

column1: Do you have any theories about last night?
column2: Theories?

column1: I believe there's a rational explanation for everything. But I don't know what it is.
column2: Can I quote you?

column1: Where is your cousin Clark, by the way?
column2: He's off doing a top secret uh, investigation.

column1: Gosh, what do you suppose .that is?
column2: Well, Lucy, it's nice to see you're feeling better. Nice to meet you, Jimmy.

column1: Can I give you a lift?
column2: Oh, no thanks.

column1: Someone's chasing him.
column2: Say---you think that's the same guy who was in the accident with Lucy?

column1: Yes.
column2: The scoop of the year!

column1: Oh, Jimmy, can't you forget about your career for one second?
column2: -- Planet. I mean, you were there. Do you think it was natural, or like some people are claiming, supernatural?

column1: Jimmy, would you please put those poor flowers in water before they die?
column2: Oh, sure.

column1: I had to dump the papers in a trashcan. The Danvers have been arrested!
column2: How do you know?

column1: I saw them dragged out of the Administration Building.
column2: Did anybody notice you?

column1: I can't help it if men notice me.
column2: Lucy! Be serious. We could be executed for  treason!

column1: I sure wish Superman was around. He wouldn't let any of this go on. Not for one minute.
column2: I wish they'd tell us what they're going to do with us.

column1: I've been in love with you for years. Remember how you used to visit your sister in the newsroom? And put your fingerprints on my lens.
column2: Remember? I was trying desperately to get you're attention.

column1: You were? You mean we could've been... you-know-what... all this time?
column2: You bet your ass.

column1: Why didn't you tell me?
column2: You're supposed to guess.

column1: I am almost an adult. This is what I want.
column2: But Kara, no one has ever gone from here to Earth. The journey is dangerous.

column1: It was my fault we lost the Power Source.
column2: Years ago. And it was Zaltar who stole it.

column1: Superman will return it.
column2: Why haven't you been able to contact him? He should have returned from the neutron galaxy ages ago. He may be dead. ZOR-EL But what can you, a mere girl-

column1: Be brave, my .daughter. Be wise.
column2: As brave as my father. As wise.

column1: What are you making:
column2: It's going to be a tree, I think.

column1: What's a tree?
column2: It's something they have on Earth. You know, where your cousin went.

column1: Where is Earth?
column2: Didn't you study six-dimensional geometry in school?

column1: Even I have trouble with that sometimes. Earth is in outer space. And we're in inner space.
column2: I don't understand.

column1: You see, a tree is a living thing.
column2: Can you create life?

column1: I'm sorry... I didn't know.
column2: It was my fault. You aren't old enough to use the wand. I shouldn't have given it to you.

column1: I can do that.
column2: No sweat. When's the rest of your stuff arriving?

column1: There isn't any.
column2: This is all your clothes?

column1: I have money to buy more, but I haven't had a chance since...
column2: Since what?? Did you have a fire at your house or something?

column1: I'd rather not talk about it.
column2: You're not...an orphan are you?

column1: My cousin Clark is my only relative on Earth.
column2: Oh wow, I should've known. Me and my big mouth. Listen, you can borrow any of my clothes you want. Any time.

column1: She did that deliberately.
column2: She's a beast.

column1: How'd you do that?
column2: Must've been a defective puck.

column1: Keep an eye peeled for Myra. She's out to get you.
column2: But what for?

column1: Your hair looks the same.
column2: It was just a trim.

column1: No thanks. You go on.
column2: You sure?

column1: Linda babes! There's this all-night party at Eddie's... his folks are away...

column1: I have plans Nigel. You could come with me... I'm going places.
column2: You're not going anywhere. Except back to nowheresville. You're too impatient, Selena. Look around you--all these people have served years and years of apprenticeship. Some of their families have been in the Craft for generations. You can't join and take over our whole organization in a few months.

column1: I just did. Because I have the Power.

column1: I'm free. I can never thank you enough.

column1: Ever since I found that thing I've been like a prisoner in a terrible nightmare. You have no idea how awful it is to be mean all the time.
column2: Your nightmares are over. I'm taking this back to Argo City where it won't be misused.  You could come too. It might be safer for you.

column1: What's it like?
column2: It's the most beautiful place in the universe.

column1: Where is inner space?
column2: It's everywhere. But water is always the door.

column1: They'll be grateful. If you hadn't found it, it would still be lost. Look, up ahead.

column1: Shouldnt've done that.

column2: Criminals.

column1: ...mid pleasures and palaces though I may roam..."

column1: It's lovely. . .

column2: What kind of a question is that? Of course: I am. I do whatever I want. All the time.

column1: You look at them? How?
column2: The Phantom Zone overlooks everywhere.. If you have the right tools.

column1: That horrible woman!
column2: Told you. Wouldn't listen to me. Knew it would make you sad.

column1: Zaltar, please help me.

column1: There is a way.
column2: I knew it!

column1: But it's impossible.

column1: Then teach me how.

column2: Then come with me.

column2: You could do anything. You could sculpt mountain ranges...draw with rainbows! You'd have superpowers.

column1: Superpowers. Got you in a lot of trouble, didn't they?
column2: Please. I have to get back to Earth. My friends are in trouble. And unless I bring back the Power Source, Argo City will die.

column1: You're going to take me back?
column2: Going to try. Didn't say I could.

column1: I heard my mother ask you once "how could a man with such a selfish heart create beauty?" She was wrong, Zaltar, you have a generous heart.

column1: You can use the wand.
column2: Better than when I was a child.

column1: Zaltar. Use the wand!

Then I missed the four o'clock plane from Cleveland and had to rent a car, and then I got a darn flat tire on the highway! Can you beat it? Boy, your boss must've been furious when I didn't show up by the end of the day today, huh?

column1: Not counting this week.  You secured employment last June as a messenger and were discharged after one day for. . .

column1: Mr. Gorman, the city of Metropolis is generous to a fault, but. . .

column2: Don't call me a bum! I ain't no bum!

column1: You are, I was about to say, no longer eligible.

column1: Sonofagun! Look at this here!

column2: That's so you're still getting some money when you hit 65.

column1: Yes! That never occurred to me.  Her ya go, buddy, single-malt.  Gus, my friend, you're a genius. Okay, a naughty genius, but hell, nobody's perfect.

See, if y'all don't want them to trace it back, you got to punch this in from someplace nobody'd ever think off. Some little rinky- dink operation with a little mickey- mouse computer. column1: You want to mess with Superman?
column2: Can't wait, pal, can't wait.

column1: Awright. I got me my electric train, mama. I finally got --  Hey, what y'all doin' up there?!
column2: Join the party, genius! Come on up!

column1: How you doing down there?
column2: Don't make me talk, please. I got enough problems just hangin' on.

column1: Hey, you're perfectly safe.
column2: I ain't about to argue with you.  What's gonna happen to them three? Ross the boss and those ladies?

column1: That's up to the judge, Gus. It's not your problem anymore.
column2: Watch out for them air pockets!

column1: No, we're just going down.
column2: We gonna crash?

column1: I never crash, Gus. That'd be embarrassing.
column2: We back in Metropolis?

column1: Whatcha wanna stop here for?  Not that I ain't glad to be on the ground, y'understand.
column2: Just a second.

column1: Thanks.  Let's go
column2: I was afraid you'd say that.  Hey, is there a bus station around here?

column1: Hey listen, I didn't know your mama was comin' by...
column2: Sister! I'm his sister!

column1: Through the telephone line terminal, that ain't nothin'.
column2: Oh Bubba, think of the possibilities.

column1: You will command the tankers to sail toward a 50-mile area in the middle of the Atlantic Ocean.
column2: And do what?

column1: I know, by computers.
column2: Will you stop interrupting ?!  You will command the pumps to stop pumping.

column1: Who is she?
column2: Her name's Lorelei Ambrosia. She's Webster's Girl Friday.

column1: Who's the other woman?
column2: That's his sister. Vera Webster.

column1: You're amazing, Olsen. A boring banquet and you bring back 3,000 boring pictures. Then Superman puts out a fire on Third Avenue this morning and you stand there and watch the whole thing and you don't take one picture!!
column2: I didn't have my camera with me.

column1: All right, Kent. I just hope you know what you're doing. If you really think Smallville is your big chance, go for it.
column2: What about me?

column1: What about you?
column2: A story like this cries out for great human interest pictures.  The big dance! The Homecoming Game! Mr. Kent posing next to his old locker!

column1: Why do I have to do this?
column2: You! You're lucky I didn't fire you. I get a chance at exclusive on-the-spot pictures of the biggest forest fire in history and what does he come back with??? A broken leg and twelve melted rolls of film.

column1: Ricky?  Where...what...
column2: I'd wash that out with some iodine...  Okay, Mercurochrome.

column1: Thank ...you.
column2: Anytime.

column1: Oh. I'm Lana Lang. This is Ricky.
column2: We've already met.

column1: And this is...  ...Clark.  My friend is around here somewhere, I'll just look for...
column2: I'm sorry, I'm in a real hurry.  See you around, pal.

column1: You know, I really wasn't expecting all this.
column2: Well...I guess they did get a little carried away.

column1: He was asleep before his head hit the pillow.  Well, this was only the biggest day of his life. I really don't know how to thank you.
column2: You just did, with that great dinner.

column1: There's no rush.
column2: But the bridge...

column1: It's hard to believe... a great looking girl like you all alone like this. As she glances up at him, she is first flustered, then flattered, then...finally...just realistic:
column2: Listen, are you sure you shouldn't do something about the bridge?

column1: The picture looks blurry.
column2: The picture's fine. That's the way she looks in real life.

column1: What terrific story?
column2: Kent's been invited to his high-school class reunion.

column1: Hey, I'd definitely shoot color on that one, Jimmy. It'd be a crime to just use black and white.
column2: Okay, Kent, call your people and tell them the Prodigal Son is coming home. FAVORING CLARK -- Happy now, he turns to leave the office. SHOT LOSES PERRY but we continue to hear his voice, o.s.

column1: Lois, I've got to hand it to you. You're amazing. Who else could manage to turn a three-week tropical vacation into a front page story that's going to blow the lid off government corruption in the Caribbean?
column2: I just knew I was onto something when that taxi driver kidnapped me.

column1: I thought you'd never get here.
column2: Hey, don't expect me to save you. Because I don't do that anymore.

column1: Well, don't let me keep you from anything.
column2: I'm in no rush.  So what do you have in mind?

column1: Lots of things...
column2: Tell me.

column1: I'll do more than tell you. I'll show you, back at my place. If you'll just do me one little favor first.
column2: Okay, what is it? You want a ride?

column1: Never.  I get air-sick. You wouldn't like that.
column2: No, I don't think I would. So... then what can I do for you?

column1: I don't know you, lady.
column2: But the other night...

column1: Ross, honey, it's time for your massage...
column2: Bubba, does this woman have the right to burst in without knocking...!

column1: If you don't mind, we are trying to hold a meeting here!
column2: Why don't you hold your breath, instead? Maybe you'll turn blue. On you that'd be an improvement.

column1: Why stop at coffee!  A cup of coffee gets the world off to work in the morning, but what keeps the world working?
column2: Diet soda?

column1: How would you know?
column2: Hey, I know a lot of things!

column1: "At a special session of the General Assembly, 178 countries voted to censure Superman. With only Columbia abstaining." ROSS That fella's becoming a public menace.
column2: And he use to be such a sweetie pie! What's wrong with him the last two weeks?

column1: I can't see anything.
column2: Turn on the light.

column1: Where's the light switch?
column2: Where do you usually find a light switch?

column1: Come on, will you?  We've got to get ready before he gets here.

column1: You! Activate circuits 29 through W7 and start Full Power Coordinates on Exterior Defensive Systems:
column2: In other words, push this red button.

column1: Oh, Superman!
column2: Cut the mush, Lorelei. He's after our skin!

column1: I can't! It's out of control!
column2: But how? Where's it getting the power from ???!

column2: Why can't the idiot in Circulation who dreamed up this imbecile contest in the first place ---

column1: Okay? Goodbye.
column2: You've got to pick three more numbers.

column1: Mr. White, the next number, please?
column2: How'm I supposed to turn this thing?

column1: By hand. Like the pioneers did.
column2: Couldn't we just get a computer to do this?

column1: Mr. White, you be in this shot, handing them their plane tickets.
column2: Why do I have to do this?

column1: It's modern. It's up-to-date. It's state-of-the art.  People, I am in love with this machine.  Go ahead, Mr. White.
column2: Where's the handle?

column1: 85,000 dollars.
column2: Missing????

column1: I don't know who. Whom. I can't trace it.  In the old days it was simple. We kept books, we had ledgers, we could see what was going in and what was paid out. If somebody wanted to rob you, he'd come in with a gun and say 'stick 'em up."  Now they get theses blasted computers to do their dirty work!
column2: My friend, you are yesterday. Whoever pulled this caper is tomorrow.

column1: Now, Vera...uh, Simpson, you know my Staff Dietician?
column2: Hello.

column1: Well, chum? What now? Kiss the 85 thou goodbye? Pay some thief's salary while he thinks up new ways to shake the money tree?
column2: He's bound to slip up sooner or later.

column1: That's what I want to know! By whom? Whom????
column2: Get a hold of yourself, Vera.  Nobody else ever will.

column1: I don't kiss.
column2: Oh, right. Well then, just shake hands.

column1: Vulcan is the weather satellite
column2: But if somebody re-programmed it, it could do much more.

column1: It could make weather!
column2: Storms! Floods!

column1: Computers talk to other computers, right?
column2: Somehow your twisted little mind should be able to figure out how to tap into the main computer at the Aerospace Center and reach Vulcan.

column1: She's not his mama either.
column2: Gus Gorman, this is my Psychic Nutritionist.

column1: Someplace where nobody knows him so they can't connect him with us.
column2: Well, Webco has a hundred and twelve subsidiaries and every one of them is tied to our central computer system. How about...hmmmm, someplace small...

column1: You mean...you mean...Vera! Vera! The magnitude of this!!!
column2: Today coffee----

column1: Small potatoes.
column2: We already have a super-tanker.

column1: Chicken feed.  If Gus Gorman can push the right buttons ---
column2: I could have it all! Holy cats! All the oil! All the tankers! All the pumps! The gosh-darn world will be out to lunch! No heat, no gas--sis, this is some nifty idea!

column1: He ruined it! That lousy do-gooder, he ruined it.
column2: Don't cry, Bubba.

column1: Nice try, Butch,  but it wouldn't be effective against Superman.  You'll see! Now that he's pulled this stunt, he'll stick his nose in my oil scheme and ruin that one, too! I've got to get rid of him! I've got to!
column2: How? Shoot him? You know about him and bullets. Not to mention knives, tanks, bombs...

column1: Wait a minute! She's right! Kryptonite. I remember reading about it in an interview with him.  Nuts...
column2: What's wrong?

column1: I just remembered the rest. There isn't any more. The only chunk that ever landed on Earth disappeared a couple of years ago. It was in this story in the Daily Planet.
column2: Where did it come from?

column1: So?
column2: So all we've got to do is pick up the garbage.  We just have to find our where in Heaven Krypton used to be. Then good old Gus here contacts the Vulcan satellite--

column1: Don't you see? Okay, so you didn't kill him. Nobody's perfect. But that stuff we ran up in the lab wasn't a complete failure after all.  Right after Gus gave it to him, Superman started to turn into a selfish, ornery, malicious, conniving...
column2: A normal person.

column1: And now that Superman's out of the Nice Guy business...
column2: We can get to work on that oil!

column1: That's it! The last tanker! They're all mine now! All...
column2: Not quite. What is that in the lower right hand corner?

column1: Come on, let's give it a dry run.
column2: Wait for Gus to get here, sis.

column1: He's the only one who can operate this --
column2: Like fish he is.  I know enough about computers to put a PHD to shame.  Come now, brother dear, you didn't think I was going to let that little man run the show, did you? Gus Gorman telling us what to do -- I'd sooner kiss a pig!

column1: He's coming! He's going to hurt me!
column2: Don't bet on it!

column1: Yes! This time we got it right!
column2: It's your genius, pal! You built a machine that can find anybody's weak spot, just like you said.

column1: Jimmy, how's the -
column2: Yeah. I'll check.

column2: So far the hostages are unharmed.

column1: Are you okay?
column2: She'll be fine.

column1: Lois, I usually do.
column2: Then maybe you should get your glasses checked.

column1: Not everyone can have X-ray vision, you know.

column1: Lois, what are you doing?
column2: When was the last time you heard me sneeze?

column1: Uh. . .
column2: Well, you never will again!  Thanks to Vitamin C! I'm reading a book that says the foundation of a sound body structure is one thousand milligrams of Vitamin C every day.

column2: Oh sure. The American answer to everything. Pills.  No, this is --  -- natural.

column1: I don't?

column1: I do?

column1: Actually, yes.
column2: Well, you shouldn't  Be more aggressive, Clark! Trust your instinct! When you see your opportunity, grab it! I do.

column2: Haven't you heard? There's an energy crisis.  No, this was good enough for my mother --

column2: Be my guest.

column1: Clark, everything I was saying -- can't you see I only say it because I really care?

column1: It is kinda romantic.

column1: 'Magic Fingers.' Fifty cents.

column1: Yeah, thanks. . . . I mean, really! Posing as newlyweds to uncover the honeymoon racket in Niagara Falls.  I mean,. imagine wasting a great reporter -  -- uh, reporters -- on this.  Perry White and his Sunday Magazine exposes.
column2: But this should be exposed. They get

column2: Oh sure, everything is complimentary. Until you get the bill.

column2: Mr. Smith -  -- the "complimentary couch."

column1: I don't know, they look pretty happy to me...
column2: That's because you can hardly see through those things.

column1: Hey, are you hungry? I'm hungry.
column2: Lois, you're amazing.

column1: Aw, c'mon -- anybody can get hungry.
column2: No. I mean here you stand with one of nature's most awesome spectacles and the whole time you've had your back to it. Aren't you impressed?

column1: Where were you?
column2: I was getting hot dogs. What do you mean?

column1: I mean it strikes me funny that every time Superman comes around, you disappear.
column2: Superman? Oh, was he here?

column1: Lois, I don't have the vaguest idea -- as usual -- what you're --
column2: Don't fake me out, Clark.  Or whoever you are.

column1: Who ????
column2: Listen, I've got to give you credit. Your disguise is nearly perfect. I mean, if you fooled me, and I am nobody's fool --

column1: You've been under a lot of pressure lately -
column2: Uh-uh.  Listen, I'll tell you what. You say I'm wrong. And I say I'm right. So why don't we make a little bet on it?

column1: Because of what I'm betting.  My life.
column2: What??

column1: Oh Clark, no!
column2: Lois, help! I can't --  I can't swim -- !

column1: It's true. It's true.
column2: Lois, I . . .

column1: I was right. you are Superman.
column2: Oh come on, that's ridic -

column1: You don't have anything to be sorry
column2: Maybe you wanted to.

column1: I didn't think I wanted to.
column2: Well, not in your mind, but maybe . . .deep in your heart . . .

column1: I'm in love with you. How do you feel?
column2: We'd better talk.

column1: I'm listening.
column2: Not here, Perry'll be calling at six to find out what's happening.

column1: "What's happening." Oh, is that the understatement of the year. Well, so . . . where do you want to . . . talk?
column2: I guess it would be all right if -  Lois, now that you know me, I think you ought to know it all.

column1: I want to.
column2: Let's go to my place.

column1: Let's go to my place.
column2: Your place?  Maybe I should change,  Maybe you should, too.

column1: You did it. You gave it all up for me. I . . . I don't know what to say.
column2: Say you love me.

column1: Clark . . . it doesn't matter . . . we can move . . .
column2: Do you . . . ah . . . want to step outside?

column1: Blood . . . my . . . blood . . .
column2: Let's get you inside . . . .

column1: Maybe we ought to hire a bodyguard from now on.
column2: I don't want a bodyguard. I want the man I fell in love with.

column1: I have to go back . . .to the Fortress . . .
column2: But what can you do? There's no way now . . .

column1: Don't . . . it's not your fault . . . you didn't know . . .
column2: He knew. I heard him. I just didn't listen.

column1: Hi.
column2: Oh, hi.

column1: Sleep well?
column2: Never closed my eyes.

column1: I know, I know all the arguments, you don't have to tell me. That's what I did all night -- I "listened to the voices of  reason" till the dawn came up. Do you have any idea what a vile sound it to hear the first bird singing when you've been up night crying?
column2: I'm sorry.

column1: Me too, Oh, I tried to convince myself, believe me, "It's like being married to a doctor," I said. Doctors are practically never at home. The get emergency calls in the middle of the night and their wives manage to live with it. Then a voice said, " could you be a doctor's wife? Or are you too selfish . . . "
column2: You're not selfish at all.

column1: "They?"
column2: Everybody. Everybody else. I'd be buying my little rainbow at the their expense. All the ones who say "Help. Come quick. Now" I know who you'd have to pick.

column1: What else could I do?
column2: Oh, I'm not blaming you.  I just know me. I'd be jealous. Jealous of . . . of all humanity.  Some rival, huh?

column1: Lois, someday --
column2: Please don't tell me "You'll find somebody else someday." Cause . . .  . . . well, you are a pretty hard act to follow, you'll have to admit that.  Oh, I'll get by, don't worry about me.

column1: See what happens when I don't have my orange juice?  The human body is only a workable, fairly fragile machine when you treat it with the same respect you'd show to ----  . . . gee . . .
column2: Take it easy. Take a deep breath.

column1: . . . Superman?. . . . .
column2: Lois, I really don't see why --

column1: I'll try to remember that . . .
column2: Well, you should. Because I appreciate you, too, you know.

column2: Sure. Especially if you'd be a really terrific guy and bring me a cheeseburger to go --

column1: Everything on it?
column2: Everything on it.

column1: Get your head out of the clouds, Kent. Where you been  the last twelve hours?
column2: Uh...home...

column1: Don't you watch television? Don't you listen to the radio?
column2: Actually I was trying to catch up on my reading. There's a lot of Dickens I never got around to --

column1: But . . ..that's terrible!
column2: That's why they call 'em terrorists.  Go down to the morgue and dig up anything you can find on past incidents of --

column1: Does Lois know about this yet?
column2: Does she know about it? She's in it!

column1: What??
column2: The minute the story broke I bundled her on the first Concord out of here. If Paris goes kablooey I want the best reporter I've got right there in the middle of it.

column1: Gee. But --
column2: No offense, Kent. You're good, but Lois is the best we've got.

column1: Lex...Lex, how could you do that to Otis?
column2: What else is ballast for?

column1: How would you like to take a little vacation? I mean you've earned it, you know? You deserve it.
column2: There is some good in you, Lex, after all.

column1: You'll have to pack quickly.
column2: A bikini! I'll need to buy a new bikini, Lex.  C'mon. After being cooped up in that prison, haven't you thought about me in a bikini . . ...once maybe ?

column1: A parka.
column2: You thought about me in a parka. That's sick, Lex. Really.

column1: Mush!  Mush!
column2: Look at this! Snow. Ice.  Your idea of a good time.

column1: A good time! Is that all you care about?!
column2: I wouldn't know. I've never had one.

column1: I like trees.
column2: So does your average cocker spaniel. Give me another one.  Under . . . the big one there.

column1: You'll miss the battle of the century!
column2: Good. My heart can't take it.

column1: Well done, Miss Teschmacher.
column2: Why am I doing this? Why am I here?

column1: This way Lex.
column2: It' s fantastic! ----- This place is genius.

column1: Genius!  --  Lex.
column2: I'll be alright.

column1: No, me, me, me. Thank you.
column2: It's beautiful.

column1: It has everything.
column2: Wrong.

column2: That was two days ago. Frankly, I think this place is a bit boring. It's all white. Why doesn't the guy put up some posters? Maybe some bullfight things . . .

column1: Artemis? Do you read me?
column2: What'd he say before? He saw a girl?

column1: I think he said a "curl."
column2: What's a curl?

column1: Isn't that what the old Canaveral guys used to call a comet on an East-West trajectory?
column2: How the hell would I know? I was in high school back in those days.

column1: Mr. White, the pressroom wants to know how much longer to hold the front page.
column2: Give it another ten minutes. If we don't --  Hell, I'll tell him.  Pete? If we haven't got anything new in the next ten minutes just go with the wire service copy under the 40 pt. banner and run the picture for three columns.  Kent,

column1: A gang of terrorists seized the Eiffel Tower in Paris
column2: He knows where the Eiffel Tower is, Olsen.  You do, don't you, Kent?

column1: I can't understand it! Where is he? I mean, he shows up every time a cat gets stuck in a tree, and  now he decides to pull a disappearing act?
column2: Maybe we just don' t know his game plan.

column1: Game plan! It's fourth down and long yardage, the two-minute warning sounded and the ball's deep in our territory! How brilliant do you have to be?!
column2: Superman's got something up his sleeve, that's for sure. We just haven't figured it out. Isn't that right, Miss Lane?

column1: You no longer can serve humanity if you invest your time and emotion in one of them at the expense of the rest.  Surely this is not how you repay their gratitude, Kal-El. Could you really abandon the weak and the needy merely to fulfill some selfish dream.
column2: Selfish! But they get a chance at happiness. Can't I have that chance?

column1: You have been given a higher form of happiness. The happiness you feel by serving others, by inspiring them to --
column2: Yes, but it's not all I feel.

column1: Patience, Kal-El. You begin to sound like an Earthling. SUPERMAN Mother, you speak only of honor, of sacrifice, of responsibility --
column2: Because that is your heritage. Those are the values we lived by on Krypton.

column1: And she -- the one you have chosen -- she feels as much for you?
column2: Yes.

column1: -- as the keeper of the archives of Krypton, it falls to me to tell you of the darkest episode in our planets history.
column2: Now This I want to hear.

column1: For many eons the peoples of our world have lived together in harmony. Then there appeared among us three anti-social elements - what on Earth are classified as "criminals."
column2: My kind of people.

column1: The three proved - after exhaustive efforts - incapable of rehabilitation. Now as you know, we had no death penalty -
column2: Sensible enough.

column1: And so our scientists constructed, from an irreversible mathematical equation, the Phantom Zone. In it we imprisoned these three arch-villains for all eternity.
column2: No possibility for parole?

column1: The Elders have, of course, thought long and hard about that question.
column2: I asked the right question.

column1: The one danger we have considered is that the Phantom Zone might - we cannot predict - just might be cracked by a nuclear explosion in space. I cannot say I am glad you asked me that -
column2: I didn't ask her anything . . .

column1: Don't feel bad, Mr. Luthor. It almost worked. I mean California almost threw up right in the ocean. Millions of people almost killed. If it hadn't been for that guy Superman - that overgrown boyscout...

column1: DELETE IN CUTTING

I can give you the brass ring, the - er -- unlimited freedom to maim, cure, destroy, chew - plus Lex Luthor's savvy. Lex Luthor's career guidance... Lex Luthor's School of...

column2: Certainly. But - Er. Oh Magnificent one, he's just one, but you are three, or four even, if you count him twice.

column2: What do you want?

column1: Superman! The --
column2: Really Lois, we've got to stop meeting this --

column1: I never did this before . . . I have to tell you.

column1: It must be tough, having to be Clark Kent.
column2: Oh no.  I really like it sometimes.  And if it weren't for him, I wouldn't have met you.

column2: Luthor, you poisonous snake . . .

column1: There is something more you want. The
column2: Perhaps a small . . . incentive, your

column1: What more?
column2: Cuba.

column1: No drinks . No movie. This is the last time I take a charter flight.
column2: Where is his home, Lex Luthor? Which way?

column1: Put down Lex Luthor !
column2: Put down Lex Luthor?

column1: Hey, let's be fair. Actually, there've been two or three times --
column2: Now I shall have the Son of Jor-El as my slave! Forever. If not, the millions of earthlings you protect will pay for your defiance.  Beginning with this one.

column1: I'm the man they're
column2: It will. Starting with your own.

column1: Who is this imbecile? Where is he?
column2: I wish I knew. --  Oh, God.

column1: Who is this . . . Superman?
column2: You'll find out, General! And when you do . . .

column1: And now they are willing to release the rest of the hostages?
column2: In return for a guarantee that we will not launch an attack an them.

column1: There will be no attack? No attempt to overpower the terrorists?
column2: Um. . . .we have made this guarantee.

column1: Yes, but will you honor it?
column2: We have not the choice to refuse, have we, if we believe it is a real hydrogen bomb that they have.

column1: Free!
column2: Free!

column1: Strange. I tore those metal fibers like paper. And what he did . . ..  Was amazing!  Something is happening . . ..
column2: Yes. To all of us. The closer we come to an atmosphere with only one sun - a yellow sun - the more our molecular density gives us unlimited powers!

column1: Then we must go there too.  To rule. Finally - to rule!  And then you shall have what you want.
So this is the planet Houston . . .
column2: What shall we do now?

column1: Look, they need a machine to fly.
column2: Brave young heroes. Be nice to them, my dear. Blow them a kiss.

column1: You are master of all you survey.
column2: And so I was yesterday. And the day before.

column1: This "super" man is nothing of the kind. I have discovered his weakness.
column2: Yes?

column1: He...  cares. He actually cares about these . . . . . .these People. These earth People .
column2: Sentimental idiot.

column1: He's captured Non!
column2: Don't worry. I will draw his fire.  With a few of my own.

column1: General --- ?
column2: We must combine our strength.

column1: Did you really believe we would give up our advantage?
column2: "Super-sucker . " For once, Lex Luthor was right.

column1: It's brilliant. Daddy thinks so, too. You'll write a new series -- 'Metropolis After Hours.'
column2: I really don't think . . .

column1: But you're perfect for it. You're young, you're single, you're successful...
column2: And I'm usually in bed by ten-thirty.

column1: They make my eyes itch.
column2: Don't worry. I won't make you do it alone. I know all the right places. I'm a member at all the right clubs . . . We'll start tonight at the grand opening of the Metro Club! It's a date!

column1: You're late. Very late.
column2: Gosh, I'm sorry, we better get in line.

column1: I've never been in a place like this before.
column2: This is Metropolis after hours! This is what you'll be writing about. C'mon, let's dance.

column1: Don't tell me. You learned to dance at church socials.
column2: Actually, I had a crash course from my mother the night before my prom.

column1: My prom was so boring. We all flew to Paris the next day to recover . . . Sometimes my whole life seems boring. I thing maybe I should just give everything away and go live among the poor people. Then I remember how smashing I look in sable . . . oh, it's all so confusing. You think I'm silly, don't you?
column2: No ... Metropolis is a confusing place. Back in Smallville -- my hometown -- everything was more simple. People would sacrifice everything just to lend a helping hand.

column1: Oh . . . no, there's no one back home.
column2: What about here?

column1: Well, my career takes up a lot of my time.
column2: Don't tell me you're waiting for lightning to strike. Wide-eyed romantics are an endangered species.

column1: That sounds kind of pessimistic.
column2: No, realistic. There's no magic in the world. Girls just don't get swept off their feet anymore.

column1: I feel kind of light-headed . . .
column2: Don't worry, I've got you.

column1: Maybe I should sit this one out.
column2: Don't give up. This is a perfect subject for your series on young Metropolis. Now let's get those knees up!

column1: Now you try, Clark. We'll start you off with 60 pounds.
column2: If you say so. Here goes.

column1: He's a jerk. I never noticed it before. Seems like a lot of people I know are jerks . . .  . . . Maybe you think the same thing about me. That's why you keep avoiding me.
column2: I'm not avoiding you. I've been very busy and . . . I like you . . . I really do.

column1: Then prove it. Lois is doing an interview with Superman about his peace mission . . .
column2: Yes, I know. I'm sure it will be a great story.

column1: Gee, I don't think . . .
column2: Come early. The view is so romantic from my balcony.

column1: Hello, Lacy. Can anybody break a twenty? The cabbie didn't have any change.
column2: . . . Let me get my purse.

column1: Shouldn't you pay the cabbie?
column2: Oh . . . Right. . . I'll be back in a flash.

column1: I missed you. It wasn't any fun up there with just Lois and Superman. They're so boring. Let's go do something wild!
column2: But they're expecting us. It wouldn't be polite.

column1: Oh . . . my . . .
column2: Clark. . . !

column1: Hi. Is dinner ready? I'm famished.
column2: Let's sit down. They walk to the table. LOIS calls out to the balcony.

column1: Gee, I'm really sorry.
column2: No mind, it's only antique Irish linen.

column1: Daddy's offered me jobs at some of his other companies. But, I've been thinking maybe I'll take some time off.  I'm going to find a place like Smallville, in the country. Maybe a  farm . . .  see what the slow lane is like.
column2: I'm sorry to see you go.

column1: You don't have to be polite, Clark. I've got a pretty good idea of how you feel about me.
column2: I'm not so sure you do.

column1: Any more like you back home, Clark?
column2: Like me?

column1: You'll find a good man Lacy. You deserve one.
column2: Maybe if you'd have met who I am now, instead of the spoiled brat you met a few weeks ago, it would have been different between us.

column1: Regardez.  Voila Monsieur David Warfield.
column2: That tycoon who owns all those sleazy tabloids?

column1: No Paris?
column2: I don't think we're being treated fairly, Lois. And I'm going to tell Miss Warfield.

column1: The President is about to speak. I don't think it's going to be good news.
column2: You always overreact, Clark. How terrible can it be?

column1: Oh, probably just a picture request. I'll take care of it if you want, Lois.
column2: I don't think 'fan mail' fits this letter.  Read it, Clark.

column1: 'Are you or are you not part of a plot to weaken our national defense?'
column2: It's her father's grey matter that's weakened if you ask me. How can I ask Superman such a dumb question.

column1: . . . Please leave your message at the beep.
column2: Clark, it's Lois. This is the fourth message. I've left. . . Where are you ?

column1: It's just a bad flu, really. How did you know . . .
column2: You haven't been at work . . . you didn't call the office . . .  you didn't even call me. How could you not call back?

column1: Superman? Has something happened to him?
column2: Everyone's saying he's . . . dead. But I know that isn't true. I feel it in my heart. I think he just needs help.

column1: It must have been a super effort to get out of bed, Clark.
column2: Well, I'm feeling a lot better . . . almost chipper . . .  . . . and all because I had a visit from a very good nurse.

column1: Close the curtains. The sun is hurting my eyes.
column2: Of course it is. Do you know what the sun is? Why it's just one huge nuclear bomb. A bomb with enough radiation to incinerate an average man like . . .  that.

column1: But Superman isn't an average man.
column2: And what am I? A Shriner? No, If you'll join forces with me, together we can make the world safe for war profits again.

column1: Boys, old Lex has a secret recipe in this dish . . . call it a genetic stew. You help me place it on one of your missiles and I promise you . . . if Superman throws it into the sun, he'll get the biggest surprise of his life. I'll be able to introduce Superman to his first nightmare . . . a Nuclear Man!
column2: And this so-called . . . Nuclear Man. . . of yours can defeat Superman?

column1: And what do we get out of it?
column2: If my plan works, gentlemen, I'll just take a tiny commission . . . something . . .appropriate. . . a number with a lot of zeros after it.

column1: Lex, we all appreciate how you've supported us lately and . . . uh . . . in recognition of your hard work we've decided to increase your commission to 12 percent.
column2: Gee guys, that's swell of you. But  . . . I've got another idea.

column1: Impossible? Why?
column2: Because I made a vow. Never to interfere in the destiny of your planet.

column1: But what good is a vow if everything gets blown away?  What good was my letter?
column2: I'm going to pass this letter on to all the leaders of the world. I promise you. For it is they , and not I, that represent the people of Earth.

column1: Well, I don't understand.
column2: I'm sorry.

column1: Would you mind taking a walk with me?
column2: Absolutely!

column1: Would you mind waiting for me in the visitor's gallery?
column2: N-no...I mean...you bet.

column1: Awesome!
column2: Jeremy, I need you to tell the people of the world what you see.

column1: Well . . . I see the ocean currents. . . and the rain . . . and mountains and rivers. . . but . . .
column2: Go on . . .

column1: But you can't tell where one country begins and another ends. You can't see any borders. It's just . . . one world.
column2: Good. If you can see it, and I can see it, maybe some day everyone will see it.

column1: Not so fast!  All trips are canceled. We pay for wire services. And what we don't get from them, we'll invent.
column2: Mr. White, come with me I want to see

column1: Who does Clark Kent think he is anyway! He never even said good night!
column2: Clark Kent! You socialized with him . . . a . . . reporter!

column1: Oh . . . no . . . I mean, we just went  dancing . . . for  a story . . .
column2: Your grandfather had one iron rule that's stood me well. Never fraternize with the help. Keep too your own station. Am I clear?

column1: Darling, it's good riddance. Let her go. And while you're at it, fire that Clark Kent. He hasn't been here in days. He hasn't even called.
column2: I know Daddy. I'm worried about him.

column1: Didn't we have our little talk about personal involvement with the help? Now that you're the publisher . . .
column2: Daddy . . . ?

column1: Yes, darling?
column2: Stuff it.

column1: Tone down our headlines? Lacy, that's all the common man reads!
column2: I'd just like to have a little less sensationalism.

column1: No, Daddy. Our business is journalism. We can't continue to be so irresponsible . . . or else we'll just lead everyone into a disaster.
column2: Don't be over-dramatic, young lady. What kind of disaster could we help bring about?

column1: Is he for real?
column2: One hundred percent.  And I like him that way.

column1: I think he's kind of cute.
column2: Forget it, Princess. Clark is the world's oldest boy scout  Trustworthy, loyal, obedient, helpful... and I don't remember the rest, but he's them too. And I promise, he's not interested in anyone like you.

column1: But all men like me, Lois. I'm very rich.
column2: . . . And  very nave!

column1: This letter was addressed to Superman care of me.
column2: Superman gets mail here?

column1: I think there's an angle.
column2: An angle?

column1: I know I'm not exactly a Girl Scout but . . . maybe if I show him I'm trying . . . he'll like me.
column2: Who?

column1: Clark. He's late again.  I can't figure him out.
column2: That's because there's nothing to figure out. Now will you please pay attention. I'm not through insulting your father.

column1: And your heart beats faster just thinking about him.
column2: Right . . . you want to tell him how you feel . . .

column1: But he's never there.
column2: Why, Lois, I didn't know . . . Who is he?

column1: What's he going to say?
column2: Something . . . wonderful.

column1: What's that?
column2: Our other dinner guest.

column1: Where's Clark?
column2: He was getting on . . . and then this man with luggage and . . .  oh, it's a long story.

column1: Are we going to skip the country, Uncle Lex?
column2: Lenny, ,you pathetic product of the public school system. Your Uncle Lex has had only one thing on his awesome mind during his incarceration . . . Destroying Superman!

column1: Do you realize what I can create with a single strand of Superman's hair!
column2: A toupee that flies?

column1: . . . I look at you, Lenny, and I know how the Romans felt when the barbarians arrived at their city gate.
column2: But why the hair?

column1: He missed the door, Uncle Lex.
column2: Quiet! You'll make him self-conscious.

column1: Whoa. . .
column2: He has all of Superman's powers. If I've planned it right. . .

column1: Gee, Uncle Lex, I don't think this guy's much of a dancer.
column2: Let's try to keep your I.Q. a family secret, Leonard. Before we launch him against Superman, we have to test him ... see how well he does with mayhem and destruction. Kind of a coming out party under the glare of media covering the Metro Club gala. And once he proves himself, then . . .

column1: Superman broke your monster, Uncle Lex.
column2: I must have miscalculated. How. . .

column1: Gee, Uncle Lex, I was just getting to the good part.
column2: Get the box, nephew.

column1: Hey, Uncle Lex, how's the Nuclear Guy goin' to find his way here?
column2: Oh Leonard . . . When I sent the remains of my last experiment . . .

column1: The one Superman wrecked up?
column2: Not how I might have put it, but, correct. The remains I sent to the sun included the creatures genetic memory. He'll remember everything that he experienced. Not to worry. He'll find his way back to me.  Did you hear that?

column1: You're spookin' me out, Uncle Lex.
column2: There!

column1: Hey! He looks . . . normal.
column2: He's . . .  beautiful. Perfect.

column1: Hey! Just remember I made you.
column2: You're just an experiment, freako!

column1: What was that about?
column2: Didn't you see it? He lifted me up and crashed me down.

column1: He's . . . cold. . .
column2: Good. Let's hope he stays that way.

column1: Of course! That's his one vulnerability. The one way he can be stopped.
column2: What?

column1: Boy, are you gonna get it.
column2: My nephew, Leonard. He worships me.  Let's share a toast to you . . . a nice guy who's about to finish last.

column1: We'll all fry.
column2: This wasn't in the plan.

column1: Don't worry honey, I'm sure he'll make a swell husband.
column2: Ready, Uncle Lex?

column1: You think he'll find us.
column2: Never. But we have to hide out for a  while. Lay low. Say. . . a couple of years. By then I'll have a new plan.

column1: What I need this for?
column2: For dignity. My reputation is at stake. Just put it on.

column1: I hadn't counted on this but . . .  . . . of course - the power of the sun has given him internally generated heat. I am a ...
column2: You are . . .

column1: What? A genius? . . . an inspiration?
column2: You are . . . nothing. I am father now.

column1: I am an experiment? I am freako?
column2: I made you, and I can destroy you.

column1: Destroy Superman!
column2: Wait! Not yet! Back!

column1: Nifty, huh?  Goodnight Sweet Prince, parting is . . . inevitable  Now, destroy Superman.
column2: First, I have fun.

column1: Nice bit. You're good. With my brain and your, well, frankly, brawn, the possibilities  are staggering. I could be . . . Emperor, King! Did you see how scared those guys were?
column2: What do you fear?

column1: Me? Now? With Superman dead and you on my team? It's like I'm the coach and you're the best power forward ever. What could I have to fear?
column2: Destiny.

column1: Stop! I command you . . . you mutant!
column2: I am master now.

column1: Guess who? It's your old friend, Lex.
column2: Luthor, I suspect if you had actually planted a bomb you'd be far away from here by now.

column1: If you have any social skills, you've learned them from a rattlesnake. Just what are you up to?
column2: Know something? You're a workaholic. A good guy 24 hours a day. Stop and smell the roses sometime. Take up a hobby. Get a pet . . . a kitten or a puppy. . .

column1: It's common knowledge you hate children and animals. Why are you back in Metropolis?
column2: Why? Because I want to be the first one to introduce you to a new kid on the block.

column1: Look closely at his cell structure. See anything familiar?
column2: You've broken all the laws of man, Luthor. And now you've broken the laws of nature! . . .  I assume you must have hidden a device in one of the missiles I hurled into the sun!

column1: Your time in prison has twisted you into a delusionary state, Luthor.
column2: No, no, listen. I escaped with only one thing on my mind . . . the end of Superman.

column1: I'm not going anywhere.
column2: I'll ignore that . . . So, I created a monster who didn't work nearly as well as I might have liked -- you were clearly his better  --  he needed more energy, more power.

column1: Which explains why you sent his organic matter to the sun.
column2: Precisely. And then it came to me. My greatest ever plan. I made a deal with some minor league Bad Boys. Arms Dealers, Renegades Generals, You know the type. With you gone, we'll make a fortune rearming the world.

column1: You'd risk worldwide nuclear war for your own personal financial gains.
column2: Nobody wants war. I'd just like to keep the threat alive.

column1: Superman. . .  But you're... dead!
column2: Still having delusions, Lex Luthor?

column1: I'll deal with you later.
column2: Right, good. Tell you what, we'll wait right here. Till you get back.

column1: But . . . how could you beat him?
column2: High School Physics, Luthor. While I was recuperating I had time to figure out that if your foul creature was born from the sun, it must have been his source of energy.

column1: But . . . but isn't the world about to be osterized?
column2: No . . . it's the way it always is . . . on the brink . . . with good fighting evil.

column1: I know, but  --
column2: Stop saying you know when I say 'y'know.' I know you know.  Yes, I know you're here, Otis. What do you want, a brass band?

column1: You'll be designing monuments soon, Albert! Hotels! Palaces!
column2: Bunkers!

column1: There's some slice American cheese...and...a half a bottle of club soda, I think.
column2: Wonderful. Otis will go above and steal some Big Macs.

column1: Ahhhh, my favorite part of the day. Who else could have thought of this aquarium?
column2: Nobody else.

column1: That the planet blew up on May 23, 1937. That the rocket ship with the revolting little freak in it took three years to reach Earth. Ergo?
column2: He's thirty-five years old.

column1: You're a great architect, Albert.
column2: Thank you.

column1: Ah! The guest of honor at last! And about time, too!
column2: We're running out of smoke.

column1: But Mr. Luthor, sir, I already  --
column2: And stop interrupting. his is the big scene.  Your finest hour! You rose to the challenge, baby! And you lost. That's the best part!

column1: It's very simple, Otis.  Very simple, the XK101 rocket. It's nothing, forty years ago we in the Fatherland were working on this. Five more years, we would've had it. But then  --  --  that silly war...Why, my cousin Werner had already  --
column2: Albert!

column1: Yes, so, well, Werner would've gotten to that too but  --  --  but the XK101 flies only eight feet above the ground...well below the radar limit!  So what? We could have done that soon. We had ways to make people ta-- ways to avoid the radar. And this XK101  -- they think it's so smart that they keep it in 'missile silos' underground. Hah!  We kept many things underground.
column2: One of them should've been you.

column1: Yes, Mr. Luthor. The XK101 can travel anywhere in the world undetected. It also has a sensory device built into it so that it can detect any obstacle in its path and avoid it. It just goes around it or over it.  The XK101 never quits! It will not stop until it reaches its pre-targeted target!
column2: Got it? Otis?

column1: Me?
column2: Not you.  You.  Tell me again.

column1: You'd better get a new alarm clock. The chief has been hollering for you.
column2: I've been on the job.

column1: A hot story, huh?
column2: It was hot, yes.

column1: You and Lois, you get all the action.  There she is, out in the wild West and everything.
column2: Lois isn't here?

column1: She's in California. That's wild enough, I guess.
column2: What's she doing in California?

column1: Clark...Son...that...thing you did with the Sheriff today... those...stunts...you don't do those things at school, do you?
column2: No, Mom. You know I wouldn't break my promise.

column1: Don't worry, Mom. I know.
column2: Anyway, we Kent's don't like showoffs, ain't that so? A body's got to be humble even if he knows that he's better'n his neighbors.

column1: Mom...
column2: I know.

column1: I talked to Ben Hubbard this morning. He'll be more than glad to bring in the crops on shares.
column2: He's a good man, Ben is. Your father always said so.

column1: Mother...
column2: I know son, I know...

column1: Do you know where you're headed?
column2: North. It's north

column1: Keep warm now.
column2: I will.

column1: I'd like to.
column2: Well!

column1: I'll bet you have some good ideas.
column2: Hey, you're getting a better class of people in your office these days, Boss.

column1: Your bookie?
column2: No.

column1: I know. He sends a check every week to his dear gray-haired old mother.
column2: Actually, she's silver-haired.

column1: Not...gray.
column2: Not really, no.

column1: Are there any more at home like you?
column2: Not really, no.

column1: Well, how are you enjoying your first day on the job?
column2: I think I lost a week's salary at the dart board.

column1: Some people aren't the athletic type.
column2: But otherwise it's swell.

column1: See? Didn't I tell you this was a tough town?
column2: Unbelievable.

column1: Hey!
column2: What the  --  !

column1: Stop him, Clark!
column2: He may have a gun!

column1: It isn't worth getting a heart attack over, Lois.
column2: You're great with the advice, Clark. Maybe you'd better take over the lovelorn column.

column1: Know what?
column2: You described the exact contents of my purse.

column1: What now, my love?
column2: Huh?

column1: Big night coming up?
column2: Oh, not really. I guess I'll just watch a little TV and --  --  unless...would you be interested in dinner?

column1: Thanks, Clark, but I'm booked for the night.
column2: Oh.

column1: It's not what you think. Darn it. I'm going out on a story. The Secretary of Defense is landing at the airport tonight and this kid's going to be there to make sure he answers a few questions he'd rather duck.
column2: Don't you ever give up?

column1: For what? Oh, I've see the way the other half lives. My sister, for instance. it looks terrific, but is that what I really want? Three kids, two cats, and fifteen needlepoint pillows? I'd go bananas after one week. Hell, I need this crazy existence of mine.  Like I need the plague, right? That's what your thinking.
column2: No. I'm just thinking that you smoke too much, if you don't mind my saying so.

column1: There's no real proof that tobacco  --
column2: Lois, you should see what the inside of your lungs look like.

column1: Can I take you to the airport?
column2: Not unless you can fly.

column1: I'm telling you, I was there.
column2: You were probably so scared you didn't look to see what the trick was.

column1: It wasn't a trick!
column2: Oh sure. A man flies in the sky like a pigeon and it wasn't a trick.

column1: Clark Kent, if you had only seen it the way I did, you -
column2: It was done with wires. They must have rigged him like they do with Peter Pan.

column1: There weren't any wires. I looked.
column2: Mirrors, then. It's done with mirrors.

column1: He grabbed me! He held me! He set me down gently! How could that be done with mirrors?
column2: Look, there was probably a trampoline on the roof somewhere and this joker just took a big bounce.

column1: Why would he do that? How would he know I was going to suddenly slip.
column2: I don't know, Lois, but I do know a fraud when I hear one. This thing goes against all natural laws.

column1: You're just jealous.
column2: Jealous? Of what?

column1: What'd you call him?
column2: Superman.  Pretty good name for him, isn't it?

column1: Is that what they're calling him?
column2: They will once I hang it on him in tomorrow's edition.

column1: Super...man. Hmmm...
column2: It isn't that I still don't like you, Clark. It's just that...well, once you've had something like that happen to you, it kind of changes a girl.  I'm going to make some coffee. You want some?

column1: Oh, what a chance! If I could just  --  get to him.
column2: You're not the only one.

column1: Listen...thank you.
column2: You too.  I just...I can't get it on for good guys. Y'know?

column1: You! The girl from the volcano!  Kryptonite...
column2: Help! I mean  --  I can't stop saying it. Silly, isn't it  -  There's nothing to worry about. Help! See.

column1: What are you doing here?
column2: Screaming

column1: Besides that.
column2: He wants to see you. Lex Luthor.

column1: The bald man! The one who tried to kill me?
column2: The way you describe him doesn't really do him justice.

column1: Couldn't we forget the plane? You could lift me in your big strong arms?
column2: Sure, and let the plane crash in the middle of the city.

column1: Oh.
column2: Look, lady, you saved my life once. I owe you a favor. But I can't understand why you follow a man like that.

column1: What can I tell you? He's my leader.
column2: Okay.  Take me to your leader.

column1: You and your real estate.
column2: Me and my real estate? How  many other girls, Miss Teschmacher, are lucky enough to have a Park Avenue address like this?

column1: It isn't a Park Avenue address. really.
column2: So it's six hundred feet below Park Avenue, It's still a Park Avenue address.

column1: Why does it all mean so much to you? All the time, 'land, land, land.'
column2: My father always said to me, 'Son, don't invest your money in anything but land. Land! Stocks rise and fall, banks fall, people are no damn good, but they'll always need land and for that they'll pay through the nose. 'Remember that ,' my father said. 'Land."

column1: Your father was a sick weirdo.
column2: I know that. Bu tin this case he was right. Arnold 'Buster' Luthor, the most inept check forger of his time --  A pity he didn't live to see his son strike out for the big city. A pity he didn't live to see how, from humble beginnings, I created an empire.
