column2: I order you not to!

column1: Your foster parents are kinda dicks, right?
column2: Gimme that Phillips right there.

column1: Easy money!
column2: Where'd you learn all this stuff?

column1: So she's pretty cool, huh?
column2: Actually, no, she's a complete psycho.  That's why she's up at Pescedero.  She tries to blow up a computer factory, but she got shot and arrested.

column1: No shit?
column2: Yeah, she's a total loser.  C'mon, let's check out the 7-Eleven, whatya say?

column1: Out of the way, John!
column2: No!  Don't kill him!

column1: It, John.  Not him.  It.
column2: Alright, it!  We need it!

column1: We're better off by ourselves.
column2: But it's the only proof we have to the future... about the war and all that.

column1: I don't trust it!  These things are hard to kill, John, believe me, I know.  We may never have this opportunity again.
column2: Look, Mom, if I'm supposed to ever be this great leader, you should start listening to my leadership ideas once in a while.  'Cause if you won't, nobody else will.

column1: Yeah.  Drag, huh?
column2: I need to know how Skynet get built.  Who's responsible?

column1: Mom?  You okay?
column2: I couldn't... oh, God.  You... came here... to stop me?

column1: It's okay.  It'll by okay.  We'll figure it out.
column2: I love you, John.  I always have.

column1: Yeah.  Right.  How were you supposed to know? Fucking men... all you know how to do is thrust into the world with your... fucking ideas and your weapons.  Did you know that every gun in the world is named after a man?  Colt, Browning, Smith, Thompson, Kalashnikov... all men.  Men built the hydrogen bomb, not women... men like you thought it up.  You're so creative.  You don't know what it's like to really create something... to create a life.  To feel it growing inside you.  All you know how to create is death... you fucking bastards.
column2: Mom, Mom, we need to be more constructive here. I don't see this as a gender-related issue.  She's still tense.  We still have to figure out how to stop it all from happening.  Right?

column1: I got it.  Piece of cake.
column2: Go!  I'll finish here.

column1: Ready to rock?
column2: Ready.

column1: John, get out of the way!!
column2: SHOOT!!!!

column1: I know.  This is a dream, Sarah.
column2: Oh.  Yeah.  They... make me take this stuff...

column1: I love you.  I always will.
column2: Oh, God... Kyle.  I need you so much.

column1: They took him from me.
column2: It's John who's the target now.  You have to protect him.  He's wide open.

column1: I know!
column2: Don't quit, Sarah.  Our son need you.

column1: I know, but I'm not as strong as I'm supposed to be.  I can't do it.  I'm screwing up the mission.
column2: Remember the message... the future is not set. There is not fate but what we make for ourselves.

column1: Kyle, don't go!
column2: There's not much time left in the world, Sarah.

column1: It has helped me a lot to have a goal, something to look forward to.
column2: And what it that?

column1: You said I could be transferred to the minimum security wing and have visitors if I showed improvement in six months.  Well, it's been six months, and I was looking forward to seeing my son.
column2: I see.  Let's go back to what you were saying about these terminator machines.  Now you think they don't exist?

column1: But you've told me on many occasions about how you crushed one in a hydraulic press.
column2: If I had, there would have been some evidence. They would have found something at the factory.

column1: So what do you think, Doctor?  I've shown a lot of improvement, haven't I?
column2: You see, Sarah... here's the problem.  I know how smart you are, and I think you're just telling me what I want to hear.  I don't think you really believe who you've been telling me today.

column1: You broke my arm!
column2: There's 215 bones in the human body, motherfucker. That's one.  Now don't move!

column1: You're already dead, Silberman.  Everybody here dies.  You know I believe that.  So don't fuck with me!
column2: Open the goddamn door!

column1: This T-1000... what happens when you shoot it?
column2: Ballistic penetration shocks it, but only for a few seconds.

column1: Can it be destroyed?
column2: Unknown.

column1: You look like handmade shit.
column2: So do you.

column1: I'll bet. Makes you a more efficient killer, right?
column2: Correct.

column1: My CPU is a neural-net processor... a learning computer.  But Skynet presets the switch to "read-only" when we are sent out alone.
column2: Doesn't want you thinking too much, huh?

column1: The man most directly responsible is Miles Bennet Dyson, Director of Special Projects at Cyberdyne Systems Corporation.
column2: Why him?

column1: In a few months he creates a revolutionary type of mircoprocessor.
column2: Then what?

column1: In three years Cyberdyne will become the largest supplier of military computer systems.  All stealth bombers are upgraded with Cyberdyne computers, becoming fully unmanned,  Afterward, the fly with a perfect operational record.
column2: Uh huh, great.  Then those fat fucks in Washington figure, what the hell, let a computer run the whole show, right?

column1: Basically.  The Skynet funding bill is passed.  The system goes on-line August 4th, 1997.  Human decisions are removed from strategic defense.  Skynet begins to learn, at a geometric rate.  It becomes self-aware at 2:14 a.m. eastern time, August 29. In a panic, they try to pull the plug.
column2: And Skynet fights back.

column1: Yes.  It launches its ICBMs against their targets in Russia.
column2: Why attack Russia?

column1: Because Skynet knows the Russian counter-strike will remove its enemies here.
column2: Jesus.  How much do you know about Dyson?

column1: I have detailed files.
column2: I want to know everything.  What he looks like. Where he lives.  Everything.

column1: The CPU from the first terminator.
column2: Son of a bitch, I knew it!

column1: I must be destroyed.
column2: Can you get us in there, past security?

column1: Is it safe for them here?
column2: Take your kids.  Go to a hotel.  Right now. Don't pack.  Let's go.

column1: It's finally over.
column2: No.  There is another chip.

column1: Are you afraid?
column2: Yes.

column1: ... it's... like a giant strobe light, burning right through my eyes... but somehow I can still see.  Look, you know the dream's the same every night, why do I have to --
column2: Please continue...

column1: It's not just a dream.  It's real, you moron! I know the date is happens!!
column2: I'm sure it feels very real to you --

column1: On August 29th 1997 it's going to feel pretty fucking real to you, too!  Anybody not wearing number two million sunblock in gonna have a real bad day, get it?
column2: Relax now, Sarah --

column1: Yes, Chuck?
column2: Come to the office, please.

column1: Mission control to Chuck, come in...
column2: You're late.

column1: Aren't I worth waiting for?
column2: Not really.  Do you think you can get here on time if I put you on the floor as a waitress?

column1: I don't know.  I kinda had my heart set on being a cashier the rest of my life.
column2: The pay's the same but you'll make more in tips.

column1: Mmm.  Same schedule's okay.
column2: Alright!

column1: Can you handle it?
column2: It's not brain surgery, Chuck.

column1: Here you go.  You're a Bob's Girl now.  Nancy will check you out.
column2: I won't let the fat kid down.

column1: Anything else?
column2: A phased plasma pulse-laser in the forty watt range...

column1: The Uzi 9 millimeter.
column2: You know your weapons, buddy.

column1: Any one of them's ideal for home defense. Which'll it be?
column2: All.

column1: You can't to that...
column2: Wrong.

column1: I had him hooked.  He was just about to ask me out. I could tell.
column2: That guy's a jerk.  I did you a favor.

column1: What do you think?
column2: Great.

column1: Great.
column2: You're a big help.

column1: Alright, the beige one.
column2: I hate the beige one.

column1: Not lately.  Did you check messages?
column2: I thought you did.

column1: That bum.  So what if he has a Porsche, he can't treat you like that...it's Friday night for crissakes.
I'm going to a movie, kiddo. See ya'.  You and Matt have a good time.
column2: We will, kiddo.

column1: I haven't seen you in here lately, Mr. Miller.
column2: What's it to ya?

column1: You must have a girlfriend.
column2: That's none of your business.

column1: Compared to me she is.  How come you're not at the cash anymore?  They catch ya steal- ing?
column2: What's it to ya?

column1: Do you understand?
column2: Yes.  Don't hurt me.

column1: This is a mistake.  I haven't done anything.
column2: No. But you will.  It's very important that you live.

column1: But outside, it's living human tissue.  Flesh, skin, hair...blood.  Grown for the cyborgs.
column2: Look, Reese, I know you want to help, but...

column1: Pay attention.  The 600 series had rubber skin. We spotted them easy.  But these are new.  They look human.  Sweat, bad breath, everything.  Very hard to spot.  I had to wait 'til he moved on you before I could zero him.
column2: Hey, I'm not stupid, y'know. They can't build anything like that yet.

column1: So, it's from the future, is that right?
column2: One possible future.  Four your point of view.  I don't know the tech stuff.

column1: And you're from the future too?
column2: Right.

column1: Just let me go.
column2: Listen.  Understand.  That Terminator is out there.  It can't be reasoned with, it can't be bargained with...it doesn't feel pity of remorse or fear... and it absolutely will not stop. Ever.  Until you are dead.

column1: There's so much...
column2: Tell me.  Just start at the beginning.

column1: --everythingis gone.  Just gone.  There were survivors. Here.  There.  Nobody knew who started it.  It was the machines.
column2: I don't understand...

column1: Didn't see the war.  I was born after, in the ruins.  Grew up there.  Starving.  Hiding from the H-K's.
column2: The what?

column1: You cold?
column2: Freezing.

column1: Reese...you got a first name?
column2: Kyle.

column1: Kyle, what's it like when you go through time?
column2: White light.  Pain.  Like being ripped inside out... slowly.  Like being born, maybe.

column1: I caught one, back there.
column2: Caught one?  You mean you got shot?

column1: We gotta get you to a doctor.
column2: It's okay.  Forget it.

column1: This is gonna make me puke. Talk about something.
column2: What?

column1: What's he like?
column2: You trust him.  He's got that strength.  You'd die in a second for John.

column1: Well, at least I know what to name him.  I don't suppose you'd know who the father is? So I don't tell him to get lost when I meet him.
column2: John never said much about him.  He dies.  Even before the war...

column1: Stop!  I don't want to know. Hold still.  So...it was John that ordered you here?
column2: I volunteered.

column1: You volunteered?
column2: It was an honor.  A chance to meet the legend.  Sarah Connor.  Who taught her son to fight...organize, prepare. From when he was a kid.  When you were in hiding, before the war.

column1: I'm sure.
column2: Come on, me? The mother of the future?  Am I tough? Organized?  I can't even balance my checkbook.  I cry when I see a cat that's been run over... and I don't even like cats.

column1: Ow!  No, it's okay.  It's better tight.
column2: And anyway, what do I know about guerrilla warfare?

column1: You'll learn.
column2: Look, Reese, I didn't ask for this honor and I don't want it. Any of it.

column1: Good field-dressing.
column2: You like it?  It's my first.

column1: Sleep.  It'll be light soon.
column2: Okay.  Talk some more.

column1: About what?
column2: About where you're from.

column1: Bag some Z's?
column2: Let's get cleaned up, Kyle.

column1: Thanks a lot.
column2: What's that?

column1: That's where we're going.
column2: Why?

column1: Look.  I found it.  Isn't that it?  Cyber Dynamics Corporation?
column2: What about it?

column1: Didn't you say that they're going to develop this revolutionary new thing...
column2: Molecular-memory.

column1: Whatever...they become the hotshot computer guys so they get the job to build El Computer Grande...Skynet...for the government.  Right?
column2: That's the way it was told to me.

column1: Well, we're gonna uninvent the bastard.  Eighty-six it.  We'll blow up the place...burn it down.  Something.
column2: Tactically dangerous.  We lay low.

column1: Reese.  Think it through. We can prevent the war. Nobody else is gonna do it. If we go to anybody official we wind up back in jail and then that walking cuisinart has got us again.  We have to so it ourselves.
column2: That's not my mission.

column1: Let's go.  Time to move out.
column2: Fuck you!  Let go of me!

column1: Kyle?
column2: I'm wrong here.  I wasn't meant to see this...

column1: Is this enough?
column2: Yes.  And I don't want to know where you got it.

column1: I'm dying for a shower.  You could use one too.  And we'd better check that bandage.
column2: Later.  I'm going out for materiel.  Keep this.

column1: What's that?
column2: Nitroglycerin, basically. Bit more stable.  I learned howto make it when I was a kid.

column1: Make sure there's none on the threads, like this.  Now screw the end-cap on...very gently.
column2: You must have had a fun child-

column1: That's good.  Now, seven more like that while I make fuses.
column2: I was thinking, there's so much I've got to show you when we get through this. It's mind boggling, the pos- sibilities...Disneyland, the beach, movies...matinees with popcorn and foot-long hot dogs...

column1: Hot dogs?
column2: I want to buy you a hot dog so bad,Kyle...all the things you've never seen and done.  You're here, but wherever you go, and whatever you touch, you bring the war with you.

column1: My whole life has been combat.
column2: I want it to be over for you.

column1: Not possible.
column2: I want it to be over for me too. I feel like I slipped over some invisible line, that I'm in your world now.  Everything's the same, but I see it differently. It's like, there's you and me, and him...but nobody else can understand or help or even touch us.

column1: He'll find us, won't he?
column2: Probably.  Sarah, if I get zeroed...

column1: Don't say that.
column2: If I do, you have to get away, disappear without a trace. Different country, different name, everything.  In case they send another one.

column1: It'll never be over, will it? Look at me, I'm shaking. Some legend, huh?  You must be pretty disappointed.
column2: No.  I'm not.

column1: Kyle, the women in your time...what were they like?
column2: Good fighters.

column1: That's not what I meant. Was there someone special?
column2: Someone?

column1: A girl.  You know.
column2: No.  Never.

column1: So much pain.
column2: Pain can be controlled. You disconnect it.

column1: And so you feel nothing.
column2: It's better that way.

column1: I'm sorry.  I shouldn't have said...
column2: Kyle...

column1: I bet you're ticklish.
column2: Ticklish?

column1: What are you doing?
column2: You'll beg for mercy in a second.

column1: I don't think I like this.
column2: You're not supposed to.

column1: Sarah.
column2: We did it, Kyle.  We got it.

column1: What are you doing?
column2: Cover...our footsteps...

column1: So.  You're a soldier. Fighting for whom?
column2: With the One Thirty Second under Perry, from '21 to '27--

column1: And who was the enemy?
column2: SKYNET.  A computer defense system built for SAC-NORAD by Cyber Dynamics.  A modified Series 4800.

column1: I see.  And this...computer, thinks it can win by killing the mother of its enemy, kill- ing him, in effect, before he is even conceived?  A sort of retroactive abortion?
column2: Yes.

column1: ...it had no choice. The defensive grid was smashed. We'd taken the mainframes... We'd won.  Taking out Connor then would make no difference.  Skynet had to wipe out his entire exist- ence.  We captured the lab complex.  Found the...what- ever it was called...the time-displacement equipment. The Terminator had already gone through.  They sent two of us to intercept, then zeroed the whole place. Sumner didn't make it.
column2: Then how are you supposed to get back?

column1: You go naked.  Something about the field generated by a living organism.  Nothing dead will go.
column2: Why?

column1: I didn't build the fucking thing.
column2: Okay.  Okay.  But this...  cyborg...if it's metal...

column1: Surrounded by living tissue.
column2: Of course.

column1: Why were the other two women killed?
column2: Most official records were lost in the war.  The computer knew almost nothing about Connor's mother.  Her name. Where she lived, just the city. No scanner pictures.  The Terminator was just being systematic.

column1: You've heard enough.  Decide. Are you going to release me?
column2: I'm afraid that's not up to me.

column1: I can help you...
column2: Who is in authority here?

column1: ...look, Lieutenant...uh, Vukovich, don't put me on hold and don't transfer me to another department...
column2: I won't.  Now just relax. Where are you?  Yeah, I know it...on Pico. Are you alright?

column1: Yes, but I don't want to leave.  I think this guy's following me.
column2: Alright, Ms. Connor.  Listen carefully.  You're in a public place, you'll be safe 'til we get there.  Stay visible. Don't go outside or in the restroom.  I'll be there in a few minutes.

column1: Here, drink some of this...
column2: Lieutenant, are you sure it's them?  Maybe I should see the ...bodies.

column1: Sarah.  Sarah, this is Dr. Silber- man.  I'd like you to tell him everything Reese said to you.  Do you feel up to it?
column2: I guess so.  You're a doctor?

column1: Why don't you just stretch out here and get some sleep.  It'll take your mom a good hour to get here from Redlands.
column2: I can't sleep.

column1: Go ahead.  You're safe.  There're thirty cops in this building.
column2: Okay.

column1: Give me the short version.
column2: Six shots at less than ten feet.  Weapon was a large caliber--

column1: Okay, let's see...Got a pos- itive on her.  She's Sarah Connor, works as a legal--
column2: That can't be right.  That's the name of the one Valley Division mopped up this after- noon.

column1: Here's her driver's license.
column2: You gotta be kidding me.  The new guys'll be short-stroking it over this one.  A one-day pattern killer.

column1: That stuff's two hours cold.
column2: I know.

column1: Did you reach the next girl yet?
column2: No.  Keep getting an answer- ing machine.

column1: Send a unit.
column2: I already did.  No answer at the door and the apartment manager's out.  I'm keeping them there.

column1: Call her.
column2: I just called.

column1: Same shit.
column2: I can hear it now, it's gonna be the goddamned 'Phone Book Killer'.

column1: I hate the press cases. Especially the weird press cases.  Where you going?
column2: To make a statement. I'm gonna give them the name.  Maybe the jackals can help us out for once.

column1: If they can get this on the tube by eleven, she may just call us.  How do I look?
column2: Like shit, boss.

column1: Go!  Go!  He's got her.
column2: Suspect westbound on Olympic.  Grey sedan.  Has hostage, repeat...

column1: That Silberman just crack me up.  He had this guy in here last week who set his Afghan on fire. Screwed it first, then set it on--
column2: Shut up.

column1: Do you live around here?
column2: Yeah.

column1: Not supposed to talk about it.
column2: You're not supposed to talk about it? Who told you that?

column1: I think you better tell us.
column2: We don't even know you.

column1: Well, we're FBI agents.
column2: You're not FBI agents.

column1: Poopy day?
column2: Yup.

column1: What do you do?
column2: What do I do.  I'm a key figure in an ongoing government charade. An annoyance to my superiors. A joke among my peers. "Spooky," they call me. Spooky Mulder. Whose sister was abducted by aliens when he was a kid. Who now chases little green men with a badge and a gun, shouting to the heavens and anyone who'll listen that the fix is in. That our government's hip to the truth and a part of the conspiracy. That the sky is falling and when it hits it's gonna be the shitstorm of all time.

column1: I think that about does it, Spooky.
column2: Does what?

column1: Why don't you go home to the old lady --
column2: Sorry. Don't have one.

column1: What am I doing here?
column2: You were shot in the head. The bullet broke the flesh on your right brow and glanced off your temporal plate.

column1: They gave you a craniotomy to relieve the pressure from a subdural hematoma. But you've been unconscious since they brought you in.
column2: When was that?

column1: Scully had a violent reaction to a bee sting --
column2: You called 911. Except the call was intercepted.

column1: I need your clothes, Byers.
column2: Me?

column1: Special Agent Scully --
column2: I apologize for making you wait -- I've brought some new evidence with me --

column1: You've been back to Dallas?
column2: Yes.

column1: Are you going to let us in on what exactly you're trying to prove --
column2: That the bombing in Dallas may have been to destroy the bodies of those firemen, so their deaths and the reason for them wouldn't have to be explained --

column1: -- those are very serious allegations, Agent Scully --
column2: Yes. I know.

column1: And you have conclusive evidence of this? Something to tie this claim of yours to the crime --
column2: Nothing completely conclusive --

column1: I hope to. We're working to develop this evidence --
column2: Working with?

column1: What is it you find incredible?
column2: Well...where would you like me to start? Antarctica is a long way from Dallas, Agent Scully. I can't very well submit a report to the Attorney General that alleges the links you've made here. Bees and corn crops do not quite fall under the rubric of domestic terrorism.

column1: No, they don't.
column2: Most of what I find in here is lacking a coherent picture of an organization with an attributable motive. I realize you're very lucky to be alive Agent Scully. The ordeal you've endured has clearly affected you -- though the holes in your account leave this panel with little choice but to delete these references from our final report to the Justice Department. Until which time hard evidence becomes available that would give us cause to pursue such an investigation.

column1: You've got something to show me.
column2: Yes.

column1: We brought the atmosphere back down to freezing in order to control the development, which is nothing like we've ever seen.
column2: Brought on by what?

column1: This man's still alive.
column2: Technically and biologically, though he'll never recover.

column1: How can this be?
column2: The developing organism is using his life energy, digesting bone and tissue. We've just slowed the process.

column1: Do you want me to destroy this one, too? Before it gestates?
column2: No. No...we need to try our vaccine on it.

column1: And if it's unsuccessful?
column2: Incinerate it. Like the others.

column1: This man's family will want to see the body laid to rest.
column2: Tell them he was trying to save the young boy's life, and that he died heroically like the other firemen.

column1: Of what?
column2: They seemed to buy our story about the Hanta virus. You'll make sure the families are taken care of financially, along with a sizeable donation to the community.  Maybe a small roadside memorial.

column1: Yes.
column2: We have a situation. The members are assembling.

column1: Who called this meeting?
column2: Strughold. He's just gotten on a plane in Tunis.

column1: Its effect on the host has changed. The virus no longer just invades the brain as a controlling organism. It's developed a way to modify the host body.
column2: Into what?

column1: My lateness may have well been absence. A course has already been taken.
column2: There are complications.

column1: Do they know?
column2: Mulder was in Dallas when we were trying to dispose of evidence. He's gone back there again. Someone has tipped him.

column1: Who?
column2: Kurtzweil, we think.

column1: Is this Dr. Kurtzweil's residence?
column2: You got some kind of business with him?

column1: I'm looking for him.
column2: Looking for him for what?

column1: Feds are looking for him, too.  Real nice business he's got, huh?
column2: What's that?

column1: You looking for him for some other reason?
column2: Yeah, I had an appointment for a pelvic examination.

column1: You want a call if we turn up Kurtzweil?
column2: No. Don't bother.

column1: I'm looking for anything out of the ordinary. Maybe something from the FEMA offices where the bodies were found.
column2: We weren't expecting to find those remains, of course. They went right off to Washington.

column1: Was there anything in those offices that didn't go to D.C.?
column2: Some bone fragments came up in the sift this morning. We thought there'd been another fatality, but we found out FEMA had recovered them from an archeological site out of town.

column1: Have you examined them?
column2: No. Just fossils, far as I know.

column1: You said you knew the location of the archeological site where these were found.
column2: Show you right on a map.

column1: How's that?
column2: Standing around holding your yank while bombs are exploding.

column1: Do I know you?
column2: No. I've been watching your career for a good while. Back when you were just a promising young agent -- before that.

column1: You follow me out here for a reason?
column2: Yeah, I did.

column1: My name's Kurtzweil. Dr. Alvin Kurtzweil.
column2: I know the name. Why?

column1: How'd you find me?
column2: Heard you come here now and again. Figured you'd be needing a little drinky tonight.

column1: You a reporter?
column2: I'm a doctor, but I think I mentioned that. OB-GYN.

column1: Who sent you?
column2: I came on my own. After reading about the bombing in Dallas.

column1: And what's that?
column2: S.A.C. Darius Michaud never tried or intended to defuse the bomb.

column1: He just let it explode.
column2: What's the question nobody's asking? Why that building? Why not the Federal Building?

column1: The Federal Building was too well guarded.
column2: No. They put the bomb in the building across the street because it DID have federal offices. The Federal Emergency Management Agency had a provisional medical quarantine office there. Which is where the bodies were found. But that's the thing...

column1: Those people were already dead.
column2: Before the bomb went off?

column1: Michaud was a twenty-two year veteran of the bureau --
column2: Michaud was a patriot. The men he's loyal to know their way around Dallas. They blew that building to hide something. Maybe something even they couldn't predict.

column1: You're saying they destroyed an entire building to hide the bodies of three firemen...?
column2: And one little boy.

column1: I think you're full of shit.
column2: Do you?

column1: See this bullshit...? Somebody knows I'm talking to you.
column2: Not according to the men in blue.

column1: What is it? Kiddie porn again? Sexual battery of a patient? I've had my license taken away in three states.
column2: They want to discredit you -- for what?

column1: For what? Because I'm a dangerous man. Because I know too much about the truth.
column2: You mean that apocalyptic trash you write? I knew your name was familiar. I just didn't know why.

column1: You know my work?
column2: Dr. Kurtzweil, I'm not interested in bigoted ideas about race or genocide. I don't believe in the Elders of Zion, the Knights Templar, the Bilderburg Group or in a oneworld Jew run government --

column1: I was right about Dallas. Wasn't I, Agent Mulder?
column2: How?

column1: I picked up the historical document of the venality and hypocrisy of the American government. The daily newspaper.
column2: You said the firemen and the boy were found in the temporary offices of the Federal Emergency Management Agency. Why?

column1: According to the newspaper, FEMA had been called out to manage an outbreak of the Hanta virus. Are you familiar with the Hanta virus, Agent Mulder?
column2: It was a deadly virus spread by field mice in the Southwest U.S. several years ago.

column1: And are you familiar with FEMA? What the Federal Emergency Management Agency's real power is? FEMA allows the White House to suspend constitutional government upon declaration of a national emergency. To create a non-elected government. Think about that.  What is an agency with such broad sweeping power doing managing a small viral outbreak in suburban Texas?
column2: Are you saying it wasn't such a small outbreak?

column1: What was it?
column2: When we were young men in the military, your father and I were recruited for a project. They told us it was biological warfare. A virus. There were rumors about its origins.

column1: What killed those men?
column2: What killed them I won't even write about. I tell you, they'd do more than just harass me. They have the future to protect.

column1: I'll know soon enough.
column2: What killed those men can't be identified in simple medical terms. My god, we can't even wrap our minds around something as obvious as HIV. We have no context for what killed those men, or any appreciation of the scale in which it will be unleashed in the future. Of how it will be transmitted

column1: A plague?
column2: The plague to end all plagues, Agent Mulder. A silent weapon for a quiet war. The systematic release of an indiscriminate organism for which the men who will bring it on still have no cure. They've been working on this for fifty years. While the rest of the world was fighting gooks and commies these men have been secretly negotiating a planned Armageddon.

column1: Negotiating with whom?
column2: I think you know. The timetable has been set. It will happen on a holiday, when people are away from their homes. When our elected officials are at their resorts or out of the country. The President will declare a state of emergency, at which time all federal agencies, all government will come under the power of the Federal Emergency Management Agency. FEMA, Agent Mulder. The secret government.

column1: And they tell me I'm paranoid.
column2: Something's gone wrong -- something unanticipated. Go back to Dallas and dig. Or you're only going to find out like the rest of the country, Agent Mulder. When it's too late.

column1: How can I reach you?
column2: You can't.

column1: You found something?
column2: Yes. On the Texas border. Some kind of experiment. Something they excavated was brought there in tanker trucks.

column1: What?
column2: I'm not sure. A virus --

column1: -- You saw this experiment?
column2: What did it look like?

column1: What do you think?
column2: A transportation system. Transgenic crops. The pollen genetically altered to carry a virus.

column1: That would be my guess.
column2: Your guess?

column1: You told me you had answers.
column2: Yeah, well I don't have them all.

column1: You've been using me --
column2: I've been using you?!

column1: You didn't know my father --
column2: I told you -- he and I were old friends --

column1: You'd be shit out of luck if not for me. You saw what you saw because I led you to it. I'm putting my ass on the line for you.
column2: Your ass? I just got chased across Texas by two black helicopters.

column1: Mulder -- it's me --
column2: Where are you, Scully?

column1: I'm on the roof.
column2: Did you find something?

column1: No. I haven't.
column2: What's wrong, Scully?

column1: I've just climbed twelve floors. I'm hot and thirsty and I'm wondering, to be honest, what I'm doing here.
column2: You're looking for a bomb.

column1: I know that. But the threat was called in for the Federal Building across the street.
column2: I think they have that covered.

column1: Mulder...?
column2: What happened to playing a hunch?

column1: Jesus, Mulder...
column2: The element of surprise, Scully. Random acts of unpredictability. If we fail to anticipate the unforeseen or expect the unexpected in a universe of infinite possibilities, we find ourselves at the mercy of anyone or anything that cannot be programmed, categorized or easily referenced...

column1: I know you're bored in this assignment, but unconventional thinking is only going to get you into trouble now.
column2: How's that?

column1: You've got to quit looking for what isn't there. They've closed the X-Files. There's procedure to be followed here. Protocol.
column2: What do you say we call in a bomb threat for Houston. I think it's free beer night at the Astrodome.

column1: Now what?
column2: It's locked?

column1: Had you.
column2: No you didn't.

column1: I saw your face, Mulder. There was a moment of panic.
column2: Panic? Have you ever seen me panic, Scully?

column1: Alright... what'll it be: Coke, Pepsi? A saline IV?
column2: Something sweet.

column1: Scully...
column2: Scully, I found the bomb.

column1: Where are you, Mulder?
column2: I'm in the vending room.

column1: Scully, get somebody to open this door.
column2: Nice try, Mulder.

column1: Mulder? Tell me this is a joke.
column2: Thirteen fifty nine, thirteen fifty eight, thirteen fifty seven...

column1: ...thirteen fifty six...
column2: Hang on. I'm gonna get you out of there.

column1: Scully?
column2: Mulder. Move away from the door. We're coming through it.

column1: Something's not right...
column2: -- Mulder! Get in the car!

column1: Whatever you told them in there, you don't have to protect me.
column2: All I told them was the truth.

column1: They're trying to divide us on this, Scully. We can't let them.
column2: They have divided us, Mulder. They're splitting us up.

column1: What? What are you talking about?
column2: I meet with the OPR day after tomorrow for remediation and reassignment...

column1: Why?
column2: I think you must have an idea. They cited a history of problems relating back to 1993.

column1: They were the ones that put us together.
column2: Because they wanted me to invalidate your work, your investigations into the paranormal. But I think this goes deeper than that.

column1: This isn't about you, Scully. They're doing this to me.
column2: They're not doing this, Mulder.  I left behind a career in medicine because I thought I might make a difference at the FBI. When they recruited me they told me women made up nine percent of the bureau. I felt this was not an impediment, but an opportunity to distinguish myself. But it hasn't turned out that way. And now, if I were to be transferred to Omaha, or Wichita or some field office where I'm sure I could rise, it just doesn't hold the interest for me it once did. Not after what I've seen and done.

column1: You're... quitting?
column2: There's really no reason left for me to stay anymore.  Maybe you should ask yourself if your heart's still in it, too.

column1: I wake you?
column2: No.

column1: Are you drunk, Mulder?
column2: I was until about an hour ago.

column1: What are you implying, Scully?
column2: I thought you may have gotten drunk and decided to come here to talk me out of quitting.

column1: Go home, Mulder. It's late.
column2: Get dressed, Scully.

column1: Mulder -- what are you doing?
column2: Just get dressed. I'll explain on the way.

column1: This is one of the firemen who died in Dallas?
column2: According to this tag.

column1: It's like jelly.
column2: There's some kind of cellular breakdown. It's completely edematous.

column1: And there's been no autopsy performed. There's no Y incision here
column2: You're telling me the cause of death on the report is false. That this man didn't die from an explosion, or from flying debris.

column1: You knew this man didn't die at the bomb site before we got here.
column2: I'd been told as much.

column1: You're saying the bombing was a cover-up. Of what?
column2: I don't know. But I have a hunch what you're going to find here isn't anything that can be categorized or easily referenced.

column1: Mulder, this is going to take some time, and somebody's going to figure out soon enough we're not even supposed to be here.  I'm in serious violation of medical ethics.
column2: We're being blamed for these deaths. Scully, I want to know what this man died of. Don't you?

column1: Why are you whispering?
column2: I can't really talk right now.

column1: What did you find?
column2: Evidence of a massive infection.

column1: What kind of infection?
column2: I don't know.

column1: Scully -- listen to me. I'm going home, then I'm booking a flight to Dallas. I'm getting you a ticket, too.
column2: Mulder --

column1: I need you there with me. I need your expertise on this. The bomb we found was meant to destroy those bodies and whatever they were infected by.
column2: I've got a hearing tomorrow --

column1: -- I'll have you back for it, Scully. Maybe with evidence that could blow that meeting away.
column2: Mulder -- I can't -- I'm already way past the point of common sense here --

column1: You said you weren't coming?
column2: I wasn't planning on it. Particularly after spending a half hour in cold storage this morning. But I got a better look at the blood and tissue samples I took from the firemen.

column1: What did you find?
column2: Something I couldn't show to anyone else. Not without more information. And not without causing the kind of attention I'd just as soon avoid right now.  The virus those men were infected with contains a protein coat I've never seen before. What it did to them it did extremely fast. And unlike the AIDS virus or any other aggressive strain, it survives very nicely outside the body.

column1: How was it contracted?
column2: That I don't know. But if it's through simple contact of blood to blood, and if it doesn't respond to conventional treatments, it could be a serious health threat.

column1: He didn't mention a park.
column2: This is where he marked on the map, Scully. Where he says those fossils were unearthed.

column1: You're sure the fossils you looked at showed the same signs of deterioration you saw in the fireman's body in the morgue?
column2: The bone was porous, as if the virus of the causative microbe were digesting it.

column1: And you've never seen anything like that?
column2: No.  It didn't show up on any of the immunohistochemical tests --

column1: This looks like new grass to you?
column2: It looks pretty green for this climate.

column1: Ground's dry about an inch down. Somebody just laid this down. Very recently, I'd say.
column2: All the equipment is brand new.

column1: Unmarked tanker trucks... what are archaeologists hauling out in tanker trucks?
column2: I don't know, Mulder.

column1: And where are they going with it?
column2: That's the first question to answer, if we're going to find them.

column1: What are my choices?
column2: About a hundred miles of nothing in each direction.

column1: Where would they be going?
column2: We've got two choices. One of them is wrong.

column1: You think they went left?
column2: I don't know why I think they went right.

column1: Hey, I was right about the bomb, wasn't I?
column2: This is great. This is fitting.

column1: What?
column2: I've got to be in Washington D.C. in eleven hours for a hearing -- the outcome of which might possibly affect one of the biggest decisions of my life. And here I am standing out in the middle of nowhere Texas, chasing phantom tanker trucks.

column1: We're not chasing trucks, we're chasing evidence --
column2: -- of what exactly?!

column1: That bomb in Dallas was allowed to go off, to hide something: bodies infected with a virus you detected yourself.
column2: They haul gas in tanker trucks, they haul oil in tanker trucks -- they don't haul viruses in tanker trucks.

column1: Yeah, well they may this one.
column2: What do you mean by haul?  What are you not telling me here?

column1: This virus -- it...
column2: Mulder --

column1: It may be extraterrestrial.
column2: I don't believe this. I don't fucking believe this.  Y'know, I've been here... I've been here one too many times with you, Mulder.

column1: Been where?
column2: Pounding down some dirt road in the middle of the night. Chasing some elusive truth on a dim hope, only to find myself standing right where I am right now: at another dead end --

column1: What do you think it is?
column2: I have no idea.

column1: This is weird, Mulder.
column2: Very weird.

column1: Any thoughts on why anybody'd be growing corn in the middle of the desert?
column2: Not unless those are giant Jiffy Pop containers out there.

column1: Cool in here. Temperature's being regulated.
column2: For the purpose of what?

column1: You hear that?
column2: I hear the humming. Like electricity. High voltage maybe.

column1: Scully....?
column2: Yeah...?

column1: What are you doing?
column2: Come on!

column1: Where'd they go?
column2: I don't know.

column1: What? What's wrong?
column2: Salt Lake City, Utah. Transfer effective immediately.

column1: I already gave Skinner my letter of resignation.
column2: You can't quit, Scully.

column1: I can, Mulder. I debated whether or not to even tell you in person, because I knew --
column2: We're close to something here -- we're on the verge --

column1: You're on the verge, Mulder -- please don't do this to me --
column2: After what you saw last night -- after all you've seen -- you can't just walk away --

column1: I have. I did. It's done.
column2: Just like that --

column1: I'm contacting the state board Monday to file medical reinstatement papers --
column2: I need you on this, Scully --

column1: Why was I assigned to you? To debunk your work. To reign you in. To shut you down.
column2: You saved me, Scully.  As different and frustrating as it's been sometimes, your goddamn strict rationalism and science have saved me a thousand times

column1: What? What happened?
column2: I think... something stung me.

column1: Scully...
column2: Something's wrong...  I'm having -- lancinating pain -- my chest. My... motor functions are being affected. I'm...

column1: ...my pulse feels thready and I've got a funny taste in the back of my throat.
column2: I think you're in anaphylactic shock --

column1: Scully --
column2: I've got no allergy. Something... this... Mulder... I think... I think you should call an ambulance.

column1: Cold...
column2: Hang on. I'm going to get you out of here.

column1: We've got to keep moving.
column2: Where are we?

column1: I can't go any farther.
column2: Yes you can. You're going to make it, Scully.

column1: We're going to the morgue.
column2: That area is currently off limits to anyone other than authorized medical personnel.

column1: On whose orders?
column2: General McAddie's.

column1: General McAddie is who requested our coming here. We were awakened at three AM and told to get down here immediately.
column2: I don't know anything about that.

column1: Well, call General McAddie.
column2: I don't have his number.

column1: Why don't you go on ahead head and I'll confirm authorization.
column2: Thank you.

column1: Sit down, they're still talking to Agent Scully.
column2: About what?

column1: -- They're asking her for a narrative. They want to know why she was in the wrong building.
column2: She was with me.

column1: You don't see what's going on here, do you?  There's four hundred million dollars in damage to the city of Dallas. Lives have been lost. No suspects have been named. So the story being shaped is this could have been prevented. That the FBI didn't do its job.
column2: And they want to blame us?

column1: Agent Mulder -- we both know that if you and Agent Scully hadn't taken the initiative to search the adjacent building, you could have multiplied the fatalities by a hundred --
column2: But it's not the lives we saved. It's the lives we didn't.

column1: -- if it looks bad, it's bad for the FBI --
column2: -- if they want someone to blame, they can blame me. Agent Scully doesn't deserve this.

column1: She's in there right now saying the same thing about you.
column2: I breached protocol. I broke contact with the S.A.C. I ignored a primary tactical rule and left him alone with the device.

column1: Agent Mulder --
column2: Where's Scully?!

column1: She's missing. We've been unable to locate her or the vehicle they took her in.
column2: Whoever they are -- this goes right back to Dallas -- it goes right back to the bombing --

column1: I know.  Agent Scully reported your suspicions to OPR. On the basis of her report, I sent techs over to S.A.C. Michaud's apartment. They picked up PSTN residues on his personal effects consistent with the construction of the vending machine device in Dallas.
column2: How deep does this go?

column1: Are we being watched?
column2: I'm not taking any chances.

column1: What are you doing?
column2: I've got to find Scully.

column1: Mr. Mulder.
column2: What happened to Kurtzweil?

column1: Where's Scully?
column2: I have answers for you.

column1: Is she alive?
column2: Yes.

column1: I'm quite prepared to tell you everything, though there isn't much you haven't guessed.
column2: About the conspiracy?

column1: I think of it as an agreement. A word your father liked to use.
column2: I want to know where Scully is.

column1: What is it?
column2: A weak vaccine against the virus Agent Scully has been infected with. It must be administered with ninety six hours.

column1: You're lying.
column2: No. Though I have no way to prove otherwise. The virus is extraterrestrial. We know very little about it, except that it is the original inhabitant of this planet.

column1: A virus?
column2: A simple, unstoppable lifeform. What is a virus but a colonizing force that cannot be defeated? Living in a cave, underground, until it mutates. And attacks.

column1: This is what you've been conspiring to conceal? A disease?
column2: No! For God sake you've got it all backwards.

column1: Aids, the ebola virus -- on the evolutionary scale they are newborns. This virus walked the planet long before the dinosaurs.
column2: What do you mean, walked?

column1: Until Dallas, we believed the virus was simply a controlling organism. That mass infection would make us a slave race.
column2: That's why you bombed the building. The infected firemen, the boy --

column1: But... he sacrificed his own daughter. My sister, Samantha.
column2: The only true survivors of the viral holocaust will be those immune to it: those vaccinated against it and human/alien hybrids. Your father arranged for your sister's abduction. He allowed her to be taken to an alien hybrid program, so that she would survive. As a clone.  He had different hopes for you. That you would uncover the truth about the Project. That you would stop it. That you would fight the future.

column1: Why are you telling me this?
column2: I thought it only fair you should know, given how hard you've worked.

column1: What happened to Kurtzweil?
column2: As your father knew, things need to be sacrificed to the future.

column1: Where is he?
column2: Dr. Kurtzweil is in the trunk.

column1: Let me out. Stop the car.
column2: Driver.

column1: You have precious little time. What I've given you the alien colonists have no idea exists. You hold in your hand the power to end the project.
column2: How?

column1: The vaccine you hold is the only defense against the virus. Its introduction into an alien environment may have the power to destroy the delicate plans we've so assiduously protected for the last fifty years.  Or it may not.
column2: What alien environment?

column1: Find Agent Scully. Save her. Only her science can save the future.
column2: What about you?

column1: We began to worry. Some of us have traveled so far, and you are the last to arrive.
column2: I'm sorry. My grandson fell and broke his leg.

column1: More concerns than that?
column2: We've been forced to reassess our role in Colonization by new facts of biology which have presented themselves.

column1: My god...
column2: The geometry of mass infection presents certain conceptual re-evaluations for us. About our place in their Colonization.

column1: We're going to tell them what we've found. What we've learned. Turn over a body infected with the gestating organism.
column2: In hope of what? Learning that it's true?! That we are nothing more than digestives for the creation of a new race of alien lifeforms?!

column1: Let me remind you who is the new race. And who is the old.  What could be gained by withholding anything from them
column2: And if it doesn't? By cooperating now we're but beggars to our demise! Our ignorance was in cooperating with the Colonists at all.

column1: Our vaccine may have no effect!
column2: Well, without a cure for the virus, we're nothing more than digestives anyway.

column1: We've allowed this man his freedom. His books have actually helped us to facilitate plausible denial. Has he outlived his usefulness to us?
column2: No one believes Kurtzweil or his books. He's a toiler. A crank.

column1: You can't kill Mulder. He's got too much light on him.
column2: You need not kill a man to destroy him.

column1: Sing a song of sixpence...
column2: A pocketful of rye...

column1: Did we go sailing?
column2: Almost.  Mocky-Lock showed up.

column1: "Mocky-Lock is the bogeyman, Mocky-Lock wants me where I am."
column2: Mocky-Lock is a pain in the ass.

column1: He hates me.
column2: Lucien Baines?

column1: She adores you.
column2: She thinks I can bring Edward back.

column1: We've been over this a dozen times.  No.
column2: Why not?  Just once.  A trial run.  What harm could it do?

column1: Miriam...
column2: Shush.

column1: He creates the obstacles, he decides which games to play.
column2: I've heard this argument before.  It's not happening.

column1: It could take years for me to get past the barriers he's created.
column2: If we reverse the feed and bring Edward into your mind, it could be devastating for him.  Imagine the shock of suddenly existing in a whole other world.

column1: I do it all the time!
column2: Yes, but, you're a willing participant. Picture Edward in a strange place, lost, frightened...

column1: I'd be there for him.
column2: And he might blame you for terrifying him.  That one moment could erase all you've accomplished.  And if that happened, the trust he has in you is gone.

column1: You're sure?  Any more nightmares?
column2: No.

column1: Good.  We need you healthy and relaxed. You're going to eat well, meditate, exercise, and watch mindless television.
column2: Yes mother.

column1: Don't bring it home in this.
column2: Okay.

column1: Henry wants me to try this Vietnamese place he's wild about.  Want to come?
column2: I've got to feed my cat.  Besides, I want to get to bed early.

column1: Sing a song of sixpence.
column2: A pocketful of fucking rye.  What's wrong?

column1: Nothing.
column2: Why did we stop?

column1: The first... What?  Six or seven times I went in.   Remember what happened?
column2: Disorientation, nausea, migraines, hallucinations, insomnia, paranoia.

column1: Like a New Year's Day hangover.
column2: He needs to be turned over.

column1: This isn't your responsibility. Remember that.  Don't let them use guilt as a tool.  If you want to stop, say so.
column2: I'll be fine.

column1: Catherine?  I'm about to start.  If you want me to wait, or...
column2: No.  No.

column1: Is it cold in here?
column2: What happened?

column1: ...a pocketful of rye.
column2: Four and twenty blackbirds...

column1: Damn him.
column2: What's wrong?

column1: I refilled the Zyprexa and Atavan...
column2: I don't need them anymore...

column1: I'll come by tomorrow after work.  With dinner.
column2: Thanks Miriam.  Say hi to Henry and...

column1: ...give a kiss to Edward.
column2: Give a kiss to Edward.

column1: What if he wasn't like this?  What if he was "normal?"  Conscious.  How far would you go?
column2: As far as I needed.

column1: There's always a chance they'll confess.
column2: Really?  I don't work with violent cases, I work with children.  But even a kid lies.  They love it when they get you to believe something that isn't true.  Don't you think Stargher would do the same?

column1: Sometimes... Once they've been caught they feel a need for disclosure.  They have so much they want to tell. But they've never had a sympathetic ear. They need someone to understand why.  Stargher used to hide the bodies very carefully.  It was part of the ritual. Some weren't found for weeks and any physical evidence had been meticulously wiped clean.  But these last three... They were still in water - always in water - but  Listen, he wasn't just careless.  It went beyond that...
column2: Okay.  Let's assume he wanted you to find him, that some part of him hated what he was doing... Most likely, that part is dead.  Schizophrenics with Whalen's Infraction sever all ties with the real world.  I'm sorry, I really am.

column1: I still don't understand why I can't do this... This isn't some "troubled kid" you're dealing with.
column2: I realize that...

column1: This man is deeply disturbed, he...
column2: You don't know the procedure.

column1: Edward Baines, I presume.  Hi, Ed.  I'm Pete.
column2: Do you think that's funny?

column1: I read about a woman in TExas who was in a coma for seven years.  Every time her husband came to visit, her heart would beat faster.  Isn't that something?  I don't know what name scientists have for something like that...
column2: It doesn't have much to do with science.

column1: What then?
column2: The soul.  The spirit.  Whatever you want to call it.

column1: Agent Novak?
column2: Peter, okay?

column1: Absolutely.  I suppose everyone does.
column2: Just like we all have fantasies, right? Things only we know, that we don't share.

column1: With Stargher I saw things...
column2: What did you see?

column1: Why'd you bring him here?
column2: You're the shrink, you tell me.

column1: You thought Stargher wanted to be caught.
column2: I did, yeah.

column1: What about Julia?
column2: This is going to sound terrible, but... I don't think she matters anymore.  Not to him.  He never finished her.  The others...he was able to make them his.

column1: You think you can do this, don't you?
column2: He might tell me about Julia.  The part of him that wants to help, that feels shame and remorse.  Who wants to be redeemed.

column1: This is Stargher we're talking about?
column2: Not Stargher, not really.  He's split himself right down the middle. Good/evil, right/wrong, merciful/cruel. A monster.  And an innocent child.  If I could reach the boy.

column1: Whoa.  Hold on.  Aren't they the same guy?
column2: Don't you feel there are different sides to every personality?  Maybe even the worst of us is capable of one decent act.  We're all human.

column1: It's hard for me to see Stargher as human, capable of something like "remorse."
column2: Then what is he?

column1: Evil.
column2: If you believe that.

column1: Maybe this is a big fucking waste of time.
column2: What happened to Charles Gish?

column1: What happened?
column2: What difference does it make...?

column1: A child can experience abuse worse than Charlie's.  And grow up to be someone who would never, ever hurt another living thing.
column2: You're sure of that?

column1: Remember, Julia Hickson is priority number one.  Nothing else matters.  Find out where she is.
column2: Okay, okay...

column1: Wait...
column2: Like hell "wait."

column1: He wants us to follow.  The little boy...
column2: Little boy?!  That's him!

column1: Where the hell are we?
column2: Carl, do you know?  Like on a map...

column1: COME ON!
column2: I can't leave him!

column1: That went well.
column2: Give her a minute.  Hello, Valentine.

column1: You sure about this?
column2: Absolutely.  Abigail...

column1: I heard Julia and John got married.
column2: Yep.  Eloped.

column1: Well look at that.
column2: I told you.  You have to be optimistic. Believe in them...

column1: Not a gift.  A highly evolved area in her cerebral cortex, that's all.  A genetic fluke.
column2: Catherine has a tremendous capacity for empathy.  When we started, there were a number of test subjects - other therapists - who acted as "receivers."  All they did was observe and report.  Nothing more.  But Catherine, she had the ability to feel what was happening.  She understood. And the patient responded.  Edward engaged her in dialogue, took her places, showed her things.  He knew she cared.

column1: Intravenous administration complete.
column2: Initiating connection.

column1: That's why we monitor the use of the drugs so closely.  We don't want her getting to that degree of perceptual disorientation.

column2: Stargher is in custody.  The functional equivalent of being under arrest. Normally, we'd Mirandize him, and if he didn't lawyer up, we'd interrogate him. But because of his condition, he doesn't have the capacity to waive those rights.

column2: I'll get her...

column1: When we got here, you just topped and pulled her out.

column1: It's all right now, shhhh it's all right.

Then why are they holding us here? Why don't they destroy us right away?  Economically, it's not sound at all.  Very much unlike....

column1: You always manage to avoid the issue:  What's wrong with our present condition?  We're COMFORTABLE and we have plenty of food...I feel absolutely no threat because there is no threat. Why incite trouble?  You should examine your emotions.  It is senseless...
column2: What are you talking about? When did you sleep last?  Do you know what your trouble is? You're blind.  You've been here so long you can't see what is happening.  We must unite.  We need unity.  We need action. ) We have come to a time when we must....

column1: But we need a creative dissent. Our voices are not joined in any harmonious chorus, but the differences are differences of emphasis, not of fundamentals. Now, the new alignment's greatest need is to communicate with all its elements, rather than march along in parallel line that never converge.  Tomorrow as we focus the new movement more clearly, we will gain a new unity.
column2: What?

column1: Good Lord!
column2: A shelldweller.  They live in the outer shell of the city.  Quite unique, there have been two here before.  They smell.

column1: There goes another of your disciples.

column1: I thought you were through with it!
column2: We cannot stay here and allow ourselves to be destroyed.  You can work with us.  An organized plan of escape must be devised first.  Could you see anything?  You want to leave.  You're not like them.  You must have left something, or someone.

column1: That's the most ridiculous thing I've ever heard.

column1: How far did you go?  Was it cold?
column2: You have nothing to fear.  You're safe again.

column1: Well?
column2: Out of a random selection of 150 locations with 150 possible sightings, there were 146 absolute negatives and four conditionals, most of which occurred in the early familiarization stages of the experiment and can be largely discounted.

column1: Not very encouraging.
column2: On the contrary!  It absolutely proves what I have always felt. We are located in an apparently uniform space with no visible limits.  We are just now beginning to push back the clouds of ignorance and perceive the truth.  We must continue the search.

column1: I've got it!  Astounding!

column2: No, I...

column1: I don't know.

Finally the latch snaps and the door swings open.

I knew him.

column1: Yes.

column1: Yes.
column2: I can't understand.  The sedatives....

column2: Yes...

column1: You are engaged in an unauthorized procedure.  Check cybernetic manual F-45.  If you do no have an F-45, you are in violation.  This is a double A restricted precinct. Remain where you are.  Authorities will arrive shortly.
column2: You should know better than that!

column1: Qual se tu?
column2: It is I.  The journey you undertook to reach me could not have been an easy one.

column1: It was not. The Barrier stood between us - but we breached it.
column2: Magnificent. You are the first to find me.

column1: We sought only your infinite wisdom.

column2: This starship, could it carry my wisdom beyond the Barrier?

column1: It could. Yes.

column1: No, no, it's not possible.

column1: I couldn't help but notice you pain.

column1: My visual says sunny skies and seventy degrees.
column2: Sulu! Look! The sun's come out! It's a miracle!

column1: Admit it. We're lost.
column2: All right, we're lost.  But we're making good time.

column2: Raise shields.

column1: But the shuttle-

column1: What's Emergency Landing Plan B?
column2: I don't have a clue.

column1: This is the Starship Enterprise.
column2: A Federation starship.

column1: This is Captain Pavel Chekov speaking. You are in violation of Neutral Zone Treaty. I advise you to release your hostages at once or suffer the consequences.
column2: Your threats amuse me, Captain Chekov. What consequences did you have in mind?

column1: You are a master of understatement. They are likely to destroy the planet.
column2: Then it's fortunate that I have you and your starship to protect me. In the meantime, Captain Chekov, I instruct you and your First Officer to beam down to my coordinates.

column1: What's going on?
column2: I instruct you to surrender. You are under attack by Federation forces.

column1: Can we have it quiet?
column2: Enterprise, this is Starfleet Operations. Come in.

column1: Bob?
column2: Jim...? Well, we're dressing informally, aren't we?

column1: You caught me on my way to the shower.
column2: I apologize for canceling shore leave, but look, we have a dangerous situation out on Nimbus III.

column1: On "The Planet Of Galactic Peace?"
column2: The same. From what we can make out, a terrorist force has captured the only settlement. And they've taken hostages.

column1: The Klingon, the Romulan, the Federation consuls. Now I know Enterprise is not exactly up to specs...
column2: With all due respect, the Enterprise is a disaster. There must be other ships in the quadrant.

column1: Other ships, yes. But no experienced commanders. Captain, I need Jim Kirk.
column2: Oh, please.

column1: Your orders are to proceed to Nimbus III, assess the situation and avoid a confrontation if possible. Above all, however, get those hostages back safely.
column2: Have the Klingons responded?

column1: No, but you can bet they will.
column2: Understood. Kirk out.

column1: Besides, I can't believe you'd kill me for a field of empty holes.
column2: It's all I have.

column1: Your pain runs deep.
column2: What do you know of my pain?

column1: Where did you get this power?
column2: The power was within you.

column1: I feel as if a weight has been lifted from my heart. How can I repay you for this miracle?
column2: Join my quest.

column1: What is it you seek?
column2: What you seek. What all men have sought since time began - ultimate knowledge. But to find it we'll need a starship.

column1: A starship? There are no starships on Nimbus III.
column2: Perhaps I have a way to bring one here.

column1: But how?
column2: Have faith, my friend. There are more of us than you know.

column1: You told me you could have the ship operational  in two weeks. I gave you three. What Happened?
column2: I think you gave me too much time, Captain.

column1: Very well, Mr. Scott. Carry on.
column2: Aye, Captain  How many times do I have to tell you? The right tool for the right job...

column1: Don't you worry, Captain. We'll beat those Klingon devils even if I have to get out and push.
column2: I hope it won't come to that, Mr. Scott.

column2: Then we'll have to get them out the old fashioned way.

column1: Captain, we can't trust anyone now.
column2: If we could send a distress signal...

column1: Mr. Scott, get the transporter working. If we contact a rescue ship we'll need it.  Which way to the turbo shaft?
column2: Head down that tunnel to the hydro vent and turn right. Then left at the blowscreen. You can't miss it.

column1: She's got partial power, sir. I might be able to take two of you.
column2: Beam up Spock and Dr. McCoy. Now!

column2: Why didn't you beep my communicator?

column1: Captain, Starfleet transmission on line.
column2: Put it on the veiwscreen, would You please?

column1: Captain, we're receiving the hostage information you requested.
column2: Put it on the screen.

column1: Standard orbit, Mr. Sulu.
column2: Captain, we're receiving transmission from Paradise City. They're demanding to know our intentions.

column1: Respond with static. Let them think we're having difficulty. Which wouldn't be far from the truth.
column2: Paradise City, can you boost your power? We're barely receiving transmission.

column1: Bird of Prey bearing one zero five mark two.
column2: Go, Sulu.

column1: Spock - What are you doing in this neck of the woods?
column2: I'm flattered. Twelve hundred points of interest in Yosemite and you pick me.

column1: I regret to inform you that the record for free-climbing El Captain is in no danger of being broken.
column2: I'm not trying to break any records. I'm doing this because I enjoy it. Not to mention the most important reason for climbing a mountain...

column1: And that is?
column2: Because it's there.

column1: Ah, Captain?
column2: MM.?

column1: On the contrary. Gravity is foremost on my mind. Look, I'm trying to make an ascent here. Why don't you go pester Dr McCoy for a while?
column2: I believe Dr McCoy is not in the best of moods.

column1: Concentration is vital. You must be one with the rock.
column2: Spock, I appreciate your concern, but if you don't stop distracting me, I'm liable to be one...

column1: Oh, God
column2: Perhaps "because it is there" is not sufficient reason for climbing a mountain.

column1: Oh, no. It isn't that. I knew I wouldn't die because the two of you were with me.
column2: I don't understand.

column1: What are you doing?
column2: I am preparing to toast a marsh melon.

column1: Oh. I believe we are required to engage in a ritual known as the singalong.
column2: That's great. I haven't sung around a campfire since I was a boy in Iowa. What are we going to sing? What... Bones, what are we going to sing?

column1: "Pack Up Your Troubles."
column2: Are we leaving, Captain?

column1: "Row, row, row your boat..." I love "Row..."  Do - do you know "Row, Row, Row, Row, Row Your Boat?"
column2: That song did not come up in my research, Captain.

column1: Come on, Spock. Why didn't you jump in?
column2: I was trying to comprehend the meaning of the words.

column1: Captain?
column2: Spock, we're on leave. You can call me Jim.

column1: Jim.
column2: Yes, Spock?

column1: Life is not a dream.
column2: Go to sleep, Spock.

column1: Yes, Captain.
column2: Goodnight, Bones.

column1: Goodnight, Spock.
column2: Goodnight, Doctor.

column1: I could use a shower.
column2: Yes.

column1: Not General Korrd.
column2: The same. He's apparently fallen out of favor with the Klingon High Command.

column1: What is it? You look like you've seen a ghost.
column2: Perhaps I have, Captain. Perhaps I have.

column1: Spock, what is it? Do you know this Vulcan?
column2: I cannot be certain.

column1: But he does seem familiar?
column2: He reminds me of someone I knew in my youth.

column1: I do not often think of the past.
column2: Who is it he reminds you of?

column1: There was a young student, exceptionally gifted, possessing of great intelligence. It was assumed that one day he would take his place amongst the great scholars of Vulcan. But he was a revolutionary.
column2: What do you mean?

column1: He rejected his logical upbringing and embraced the animal passions of our ancestors.
column2: Why?

column1: When he encouraged others to follow him, he was banished from Vulcan, never to return.
column2: Fascinating.

column1: Klingon vessel now entering quadrant. Bird of Prey. Estimating 1.9 hours until her weapons come to bear.
column2: Damn.  Let's go.

column1: Their equipment is primitive but effective. I recommend we land at Coordinate 8563.
column2: That puts us pretty far away from Paradise City.

column1: To land any closer would risk detection.
column2: Mr. Sulu. Execute.

column1: At footspeed I estimate the journey to Paradise City at 1.2 hours.
column2: We don't have 1.2 hours.

column1: Spock.
column2: Yes, Captain?

column1: Be one with the horse.
column2: Yes, Captain.

column1: Exactly 15.5 seconds.
column2: An eternity during which we'll be vulnerable to Klingon attack. Korrd-you tell him.

column1: You must allow us to act.
column2: Let me do something.

column1: Damnit, Spock. God damnit!
column2: Captain, what have I done -

column1: What you have done is betray every man on this ship.
column2: Worse. I have betrayed you. I do not expect you to forgive me.

column1: Forgive you? I ought to knock you on your goddamn ass!
column2: If you think it would help.

column1: You stay out of this!  Why, Spock? Why? I.. All you had to do was pull the trigger.
column2: If I had pulled the trigger, Sybok would be dead.

column1: I ordered you to defend this ship.
column2: You ordered me to kill my brother.

column1: Look, the man may be a fellow Vulcan, but that doesn't...
column2: No, no, no, Captain. You do not understand. Sybok also in a son of Sarek.

column1: You mean he's your brother brother?  You made that up!
column2: I did not.

column1: You did too. Sybok couldn't possibly be your brother because I happen to know for a fact that you don't have a brother.
column2: Technically, you are correct. I do not have a brother.

column1: There, you see? See?
column2: I have a half brother.

column1: Exactly. That is correct. Sybok's mother was a Vulcan princess. Upon her death, Sybok and I were raised as brothers.
column2: Why didn't you tell me this before?

column1: I was not disposed to discuss... matters of a personal nature. For that, I'm sorry.
column2: He's sorry, See, he's sorry. Everything... that makes everything all right. He's sorry, everything's...

column1: There's got to be a way out of this place.
column2: This is a new brig, Captain. It is escape-proof.

column1: How do you know?
column2: The designers tested it using the most intelligent and resourceful person they could find. He failed to escape.

column1: This, er, person... didn't by any chance have pointed ears and an unerring capacity for getting his shipmates into trouble, did he?
column2: He did have pointed ears.

column1: Is it possible?
column2: Is what possible?

column1: There Sha Ka Ree is fabled to exist.
column2: But the center of the galaxy can't be reached. No ship has ever gone into the Great Barrier. No probe has ever returned.

column1: Sybok possessed the keenest intellect I have ever known.
column2: Spock! My only concern is getting the ship back. When that's done and Sybok is in here then you can debate Sha Ka Ree until you're green in the face. Until then, you're either with me or you're not.

column1: I am here, Captain.
column2: That's a little vague, Spock -

column1: You're right. I'm a little out of practice.  Uh....that's an "s."
column2: A "t."

column1: New word. "b".. "a"... um...
There is an emergency sending apparatus in the forward observation room.

column1: I believe I have found a faster way.
column2: Hmmm?

column1: It would appear we are too heavy.
column2: It must be all those marsh melons.

column1: Spock... the booster rockets.
column2: If I activate them now, Captain, we will be propelled upward at an unbelievable rate.

column1: Spock.
column2: The emergency channel, open.

column1: ...mark two.
column2: Mark two. Request emergency assistance. Acknowledge.

column1: Spock... don't.
column2: It's all right, Captain.  Proceed.

column1: What is this?
column2: I believe we are witnessing my birth.

column1: Spock?
column2: Welcome aboard, Captain.

column1: Spock, I thought I was going to die.
column2: Not possible. You were never alone.

column1: Maybe he's not out there, Bones. Maybe he's right here... in the human heart  Spock?
column2: I was thinking of Sybok. I've lost a brother.

column1: I must have your starship.
column2: You staged all this to get your hands on my ship?

column1: Who are you?
column2: James T. Kirk, Captain of the Enterprise.

column1: No! No reply. Remain on course.
column2: Sybok, listen to me. In order for this craft to enter the landing bay, Enterprise must lower the shields and activate the tractor beam. To get us inside and re-raise the shields will take-

column1: What are you doing?
column2: In order to lower and raise the shields as quickly as possible, we're going to forego the tractor beam and fly her in manually.

column1: We must change our course at once.
column2: I'll take you to the bridge.

column1: I trust your message was received?
column2: You can't expect us to stand by while you take the ship into the Great Barrier.

column1: What you fear is the unknown. The people of your planet once believed their world was flat. Columbus proved it was round. They said the sound barrier could never be broken. It was broken. They said warp speed could not be achieved. The Great Barrier is the ultimate expression of this universal fear. It's an extension of personal fear.  Captain Kirk, I so much want your understanding. I want your respect. Are you afraid to hear me out?
column2: I'm afraid of nothing.

column1: Sha Ka Ree. "The Scource." "Heaven." "Eden." call it "Qui'Tu." To the Romulans, it's "Vorta Vor." The Andorian word is.. unpronounceable. Still, every culture shares he common dream of a place from which creation sprang. For us, that place will soon be a reality.
column2: The only realty I see is that I'm a prisoner on my own ship. What is this power you have to control the minds of my crew?

column1: Spock...  What have you done to my friends?
column2: I've done nothing. This is who they are. Didn't you know that?

column1: No... I didn't.
column2: Now learn something about yourself.

column1: Wait!  You know we'll never make it through the Great Barrier.
column2: But if we do, will that convince you that my vision was true?

column1: Your vision?
column2: Given to me by God.  He waits for us on the other side.

column1: You are mad!
column2: Am I? We'll see.

column1: About the ship...
column2: The ship needs its Captain.

column1: No special conditions?
column2: No conditions.

column1: What makes you think I won't turn us around?
column2: Because you, too, must know.

column1: What have I done?
column2: Kirk to Enterprise. Listen carefully...

column1: Borgus Frat.
column2: "Let's see what she's got," said the Captain. And then we found out, didn't we?

column1: And I thought we were supposed to be going together.
column2: Oh, I cannot leave her now when she needs me the most.

column1: They can't be serious. The ship's in pieces and we've less than a skeleton aboard.
column2: Starfleet, are you aware of our currant status?

column1: Easy, easy,  easy, Scotty. Easy. You're back with us.
column2: Uhura, I had the strangest dream. I dreamt that a madman had taken over the Enterprise.

column1: Scotty, dear, he' not a madman.
column2: He's not?

column1: No, no, no. Scotty - Scotty... There's so much I want to tell you.
column2: Maybe you could wait until I'm a wee bit stronger I don't think I could take it in my present condition.  Or yours.

column1: Sybok, you must surrender.
column2: No. You must kill me.

column1: Put him in the brig with Captain Kirk.  Spock, you will accompany me to the bridge?

column1: I know you better than that.

column1: Spock?

column2: I belong here.

column1: I don't understand...
column2: Sybok, you are my brother, but you do not know me. I am not the outcast boy you left behind those many years ago. Since that time I have found myself and my place. I know who I am. And I cannot go with you.

column1: Sybok - this is not the God of Sha Ka Ree - or any other God!
column2: I don't understand..  Reveal yourself to me!

column1: Sybok.
column2: This is my doing. This is my arrogance... my vanity...

column1: Sybok, we must find a way...
column2: No. You must save yourselves. Forgive me, brother. Forgive me.

column1: You did break in.
column2: Tried to.  Can't quite make the connection with that sucker, though. If I had a direct terminal ...

column1: Are you embezzling?
column2: "Embezzling" is such an ugly word, Mister Bailey...  No, actually I'm trying to get a legal brief together.

column1: I don't get it.
column2: You haven't told him?

column1: Sherman, set the Wayback Machine for...oh, 1973. Kevin Flynn  is one of the brightest young software engineers at ICOM. He's so bright that he starts going in there at night, and sets up a private memory file, and begins writing a program for a video game he is inventing, called...  ...Space Paranoids.
column2: You invented Space Paranoids?

column1: Yepper. And Vice Squad, and Meltdown... whole slew of 'em. I was this close  to starting my own little enterprise. But: enter Ed Dillinger. Another software engineer -- not so young, not so bright, but very, very sneaky. One night, our boy Flynn goes to his terminal, tries to read up his file, and ... nothing. A big blank. We now take you to three months later. Ed Dillinger presents ICOM with five video games he has "invented" -- the slime didn't even change the names -- and he gets a big fat promotion. Thus begins his meteoric rise to...what is he now, Executive V.P.?
column2: Senior exec.

column1: Oh my. Meanwhile, kids are putting eight million quarters a week in Space Paranoids machines and I'm not seeing one dime.
column2: I still don't get why you're trying to break into the system.

column1: Dillinger?
column2: Yeah. Tryin' to find the file and erase it. Once that's gone, ain't nothin' can stop him. Just Eddie and his Master Control Program, runnin' things from on high..

column1: Not if my Tron program was running. That would seal the system off. If your file's in there...
column2: Boy, if we were inside, I know how to forge us a Group 6 access...

column1: Hi, Alan.
column2: Hi, Flynn.

column1: My dinner.
column2: I was wondering where you got that glow of good health.

column1: Want one?
column2: Uh... got any cinnamon?

column2: I know, I met him.

column1: Your old files -- ?

column1: Shouldn't you wait till your lawsuit's settled?
column2: Nah...I decided...I've had enough of video games to last me a good long time. I feel like gettin' into some real life...

column1: How's it going upstairs?
column2: Frustrating. I had Tron almost ready to run, and Dillinger cut everybody with Group 7 access out of the system.

column1: Did you say Group 7 access?
column2: Yeah...pain in the neck, you know, I was all set

column2: Something about tampering. Some body's prob'ly trying to siphon the R&D budget into his checking account, I don't know. Why are you so interested?

column1: Flynn had Group 7 access.
column2: Flynn had access to you, too. I'm not interested in talking about him.

column2: For being on to Dillinger.

column1: Flynn!
column2: Uh, no ... I mean, not that often -

column1: Beautiful!
column2: Hello, Alan.

column1: Not disintegrating, Alan -- digitizing. While the laser is dismantling the molecular structure of the object, the computer maps out a holographic model of it. The molecules themselves are suspended in the laser beam. Then the computer reads the model back out, the molecules go back into place, and...  voila.
column2: Great. Can it send me to Hawaii?

column1: Ever since he got that Master Control Program set up, system's got more bugs than a bait store.
