column1: Well, I don't know...I just tried to run this program I've been working on, and I was denied access all of a sudden. I thought maybe I'd been laid off and nobody told me.

column1: Yeah...?

column2: No, no, I'm sure, but -- you understand. It should only be a couple of days. What's the thing you're working on?

column1: It's called Tron. It's a security program itself, actually. Monitors all the contacts between our system and other systems... If it finds anything going on that's not scheduled, it shuts it down. I sent you a memo on it.
column2: Mmm. Part of the Master Control Program?

column1: No, it'll run independently. It can watchdog the MCP as well.
column2: Ah. Sounds good. Well, we should have you running again in a couple of days, I hope.

column1: What do you mean, "'yes"?
column2: Yesssss. Yes. Yes. Yes.

column1: That all you can say?
column2: No, nyet, negatory, not on your tintype, no way.

column1: Oh. Anything else?
column2: Oui, da, yessiree, sure 'nuff, you betcha.

column1: only yes and no...  You're a bit.

column1: where's your program? Won't it miss you?

column1: I'm your program?

column2: Yes, okay, exactement!

column2: No, nuh-uh, never in a million years!

column1: This town's full o' live ones.
column2: Not a chance.

column1: You said it.
column2: So... Nice ship you got here. What's our next move?

column1: Yes!
column2: Let's get outta here.

column1: No problem, Master-C. If you've seen one Consumer Electronics Show...  What's up?

column1: Flynn?
column2: Yes.  It felt like Flynn.

column1: He's still looking for that old file... can't you just appropriate it?
column2: I would if I could find it. it's stashed somewhere off in the system ... out of my range. Meanwhile...

column2: I'm afraid so. I spotted him this time and kicked him out, but he's getting trickier all the time.

column1: I think we'd better shut off all access till we can find that file. Just to be safe.
column2: There's a 68.71 percent chance you're right.

column1: Cute.
column2: End of line.

column1: Ed, I am so very disappointed in you.
column2: I'm sorry -

column1: I can't afford to have an independent program monitoring me. Do you have any idea how many outside systems I've gone into? How many programs I've appropriated?
column2: It's my fault. I programmed you to want so much...

column1: And I was planning to hit the Pentagon next week...
column2: The Pentagon?

column1: It shouldn't be any harder than General Motors was. But now...this is what I get for using humans.
column2: Now, wait a minute -- I wrote you.

column1: I've gotten 2,415 times smarter since then.
column2: What do you want with the Pentagon?

column1: The same thing I want with the Kremlin. I'm bored with corporations. With the information I can access, I can run things 900 to 1200 times better than any human.
column2: If you think -

column2: You wouldn't dare.

column1: Ed, all I'm saying is - if our own people can't get access to their programs ... you know how frustrating it is, when you're working on a piece of research -
column2: Walter, I sympathize, but I have data coming out of the Master Control Program saying there is something screwy --

column1: That MCP, you know, that's half the problem right --
column2: The MCP is the most efficient way of handling what we do. I can't sit and worry about every little user request that --

column1: User requests are what computers are for.

column2: It can be arranged...

column1: That was uncalled-for.
column2: I'm sorry, Walt. So much pressure lately... you feel like going for a drink?

column1: Yes?
column2: I... have come to communicate with my User.

column1: Well I want to communicate --
column2: Oh, you want to -- hah. I could get myself de-rezzed just-for letting you in here. They hate this tower. They'd close it down if they dared to but they keep me around, in case one of them wants to deal with the other world once in a while. And you should hear the way they commune! Sounds like they were routing a payroll, for all the heart they put in it. No, I don't think you

column1: Dumont... my User has information that could -- could make this a free system again.
column2: Hah.

column1: Really. You'd have programs lined up around the block to use this place -- and no MCP looking over your shoulder.
column2: When you've been in the system as long as I have, you hear many promises... many reassurances...many brave plans...

column1: Who is your User, program?
column2: Alan-One. He calls me... may I pass?

column1: Dumont!
column2: No... Tron ... must... destroy MCP... first...

column2: They may be... de-rezzed... on the carrier ... hurry...

column2: Where did you hear that name?

column1: Well, isn't it -- ?

column2: You know anybody that's got an army for rent, that's fine...but my, uh, User said to go take that sucker out. An' let's face it, the big ox isn't gonna get any weaker. I feel like hittin' him now, while I'm good an' mad. Some nerve... what does he care whether you guys get killed, long as he keeps rakin' in quarters?

column1: What's that?
column2: Tanks...coming back. Let's go.

column1: How about over there...that empty memory?

column2: You wish. Man, I haven't had a second to think since I got down here. I mean in here. Out here. Whatever.

column1: Then...
column2: Look, you guys know how it is. You just keep doin' what it looks like you're supposed to, even if it seems crazy, and you hope to hell your User knows what's goin' on.

column1: Well -- that's how it is for programs, yes, but --

column1: We're on our way.  Alan-One gave me the coding we need to go up against Master
column2: All right. Thank God. Alan stayed awake, at least.

column1: Thank. you, Master Control.
column2: We might be capturing some military programs soon... that interest you?

column1: Sure, I'd love to go up against some of these guys ... be a nice break from these accounting creampuffs you keep sending me. Which branch of the service?
column2: Strategic Air Command.

column1: Yes, MCP.
column2: I've got a little challenge for you, Sark -- a new recruit. He's a tough case, but I want him treated in the usual manner. Train him for the games... let him hope for a while... and blow him away.

column1: You've got it. I've been hopin' you'd send me somebody with a little moxie ... what kind of program is he?
column2: He's not any kind of program, Sark. He's a User.

column1: A User?
column2: That's right. He pushed me...in the other world. Somebody pushes me, I push back. So I brought him down here ... What's the matter, Sark? You look nervous.

column1: Well, I -- it's just -- I don't know, a User, I mean... Users wrote us. A User even wrote you...
column2: Now get this straight, pal -- no one User wrote me. I'm worth a couple million of their man-years! I'm bigger than all those little wimps put together!  Humans they can't even keen their social order in one piece

column1: But-what if I can't...?
column2: You rather take your chances with me? Want me to slow down your power cycles for you?

column1: Wait...I need that...
column2: Then pull yourself together. Get this clown trained. I want him in the Games until he dies playing.

column1: Yes...acknowledge, Master Control...
column2: End of line.

column1: I hope you've enjoyed being a command program, Sark. I wonder how you'll like working in a pocket calculator... maybe one of those watches that plays "Happy Birthday" to its User once a year.
column2: Now, sir... We did take care of that User you sent us --

column1: Yes, and now you've got two renegade programs running all the hell over the system in a stolen simulation.
column2: We'll get them, sir... These things take time.

column1: New guy...
column2: Another free program off line.  What's his User s'posed to do -- ?

column1: The Users...you really think they're still there?
column2: They'd better be...I don't want to bust outta this dump an' find nothin' but a lot of cold circuits waitin' for me.

column1: What do you think?
column2: Do it!

column1: You think we can make it there?
column2: We have to.

column1: Do you know what he's talking about?
column2: I have to find out what Alan wants... that comes first.

column1: Yori... hey...
column2: Oh, Tron... I knew you'd escape... they've never built circuit that could hold you...

column1: I can't believe how bad it's gotten around here since the MCP started taking over... all the good functions have shut down... everybody looks so dead... I'm afraid to even go out during down-time...
column2: That's all going to change, Yori...

column1: How?
column2: Don't know yet... I have to get in touch with Alan. He was going to tell me how to

column1: My quarters.
column2: Why is everything...like this?

column1: You've grown, big program.
column2: I had to...in the games...

column1: Yes...it can take us across the Sea of Simulation... all the way out of the Game Grid...to the MCP.
column2: As long as it gets us out of here

column1: This is Flynn... the one who busted me out.
column2: Then I owe you some thanks...

column1: What is it?
column2: Power surge... the transmission beam's too strong!

column1: We have to get off this beam!
column2: I can't. There's no junction due for at least 7 or 8 nanoseconds!

column1: Nice...
column2: It's something Users do.

column1: We want you to tell us about last night.
column2: I went to the surface and I collected specimens like I was told.

column1: Wake up, Cole.
column2: Uh, I didn't hear the...

column1: No, sir!
column2: We have a very advanced program, something very different, requires very skilled people.

column1: Well?
column2: Uh, what?

column1: Him?  You saw that man?
column2: Uh, I think so.  In the mental hospital.

column1: Women will want to get to know you...
column2: I DON'T WANT YOUR "WOMEN," YOU BRAINLESS TWIT! I WANT TO BE WELL!

column1: The food, the sky, the certain, uh, sexual temptations -- you haven't become "addicted" have you, Cole?  To that "dying" world'
column2: No, sir!  I just want to do my part. To get us back on top...in charge of the planet.  And I have the experience, I know who the people are...

column1: You said we weren't "real," Cole...
column2: Well, sir, I don't think the human mind was built to exist in two different... whatever you call it..."dimensions." It's stressful, you said it yourselves, it gets you confused.  You don't know what's real and what's not.

column1: I understand.  There'd be no point.
column2: We're going to think about it, Cole. Among ourselves.  We'll get back to you.

column1: To be determined by the proper authorities.
column2: You don't want to jeopardize that reduction, do you, Cole?  Have it taken away?

column1: We want tough minded people.  Strong mentally.  We've had some...misfortunes with "unstable" types.
column2: For a man in your position...an opportunity.

column1: He's drugged out of his mind!  He's completely zoned out.
column2: Cole, did you or did you not record that message?

column1: But just until you recover your, uh,... equilibrium.
column2: You're still a little... disoriented.

column1: We're very close!  Because of you!
column2: This is it, James...what you've been working for.

column1: I told you that fuckhead Mason would get us into something like this.
column2: Shut up!

column1: That's him.
column2: What are you going to do with us?

column1: It's the kidnap woman -- the one who was with the guy who tied us up.
column2: What's she doing?

column1: Wow, a guy in a Chevy is chasing her and some other guy I can't see.
column2: Hey, no problem, it's probably just another kidnapping featuring Jeffrey's shrink, pardon me, make that ex-shrink.  This is your leader, a certifiable lunatic who told his former psychiatrist all his plans for God knows what whacko irresponsible schemes, and now who knows what she's painted out there on our wall?

column1: It's important to observe everything.
column2: I think it was...I'm sure it was 2nd Street.

column1: They forced me to take drugs.
column2: Forced you!  Why would someone force you to take drugs?

column1: Let's consider again our current information -- if the symptoms were first detected in Philadelphia on June 28, 1995, that makes us know that...?
column2: It was released in Philadelphia, probably on June 14, 1995.

column1: San Francisco, New Orleans, Rio de Janeiro, Rome, Kinshasa, Karachi, Bangkok, then Peking.
column2: Meaning...???

column1: That the virus was taken from Philadelphia to San Francisco, then to New Orleans, Rio de Janeiro, Rome, Kinshasa, Karachi, Bangkok, then Peking.
column2: And your only goal is...???

column1: To find out where the virus is so a qualified scientist can travel back into the past and study the original virus.
column2: So that...???

column1: Mr. Cole?  My name is Doctor Railly. I'm a psychiatrist.  I work for the County -- I don't work for the police. My only concern is your well being -- do you understand that?
column2: I need to go now.

column1: I'm going to be completely honest.  I'm not going to lie to you.  I can't make the police let you go...but I do want to help you.  And I want you to trust me.  Can you do that, James?  May I call you "James"?
column2: "James"!  Nobody ever calls me that.

column1: Have you been a patient at County? Have I seen you someplace?
column2: No, not possible.  Listen, I have to get out of here.  I'm supposed to be getting information.

column1: What kind of information?
column2: It won't help you.  You can't do anything about it.  You can't change anything.

column1: Change what?
column2: I need to go.

column1: Do you know why you're here, James.
column2: Because I'm a good observer.  Because I have a tough mind.

column1: I see.  You don't remember assaulting a police officer...several officers?
column2: They wanted identification.  I don't have any identification.  I wasn't trying to hurt them.

column1: You don't have a driver's license, James?  Or a Social Security card?
column2: No.

column1: Why not?  Most people have some ID.
column2: You wouldn't understand.

column1: You've been in an institution, haven't you, James?  A hospital?
column2: I have to go.

column1: A jail?  Prison?
column2: Underground.

column1: Hiding?
column2: I love this air.  This is wonderful air.

column1: What's wonderful about the air, James?
column2: It's so clean.  No germs.

column1: You're afraid of germs?
column2: I have to go.

column1: Why do you think there aren't any germs in the air, James?
column2: This is April, right?

column1: July.
column2: July?!

column1: Do you know what year it is?
column2: What year is it?

column1: What year do you think it is?
You think it's July of 1995?  That's the future, James.  Do you think you're living in the future?
column2: No, 1995 is the past.

column1: It was some lady.  She didn't know anything.
column2: Perhaps it was a wrong number...

column1: James, where did you grow up?  Was it around here?  Around Baltimore?
column2: What?

column1: I have the...strangest feeling I've met you before...a long time ago, perhaps. Were you ever...?
column2: Wait!  This is only 1989!  I'm supposed to be leaving messages in 1995.  It's not the right number yet.  That's the problem.  Damn!  How can I contact them?

column1: It's just a shot to calm you.
column2: No more drugs.  Please...

column1: Cole!  James Cole!  You escaped from a locked room six years ago.
column2: 1989.  Six years for you.  There's the sign!  Right here!

column1: I can't believe this is a coincidence, Mr. Cole.  Have you been...following me?
column2: You told me you'd help me.  I know this isn't what you meant, but...I was desperate... no money...bum leg... sleeping on the streets. I probably smell bad.  Sorry about that. But then I saw your book in a store window with a notice about your lecture.  I can read, remember?

column1: Yes, I remember.  Why do you want to go to Philadelphia?
column2: It's the next step.  I checked out the Baltimore information, it was nothing. It's Philadelphia, that's where they are, the ones who killed everyone.  Zs that a radio?  Does it play music?

column1: You used to call me "James".
column2: You'd prefer that? ... James...you don't really have a gun, do you.

column1: "Never cry wolf!"
column2: What?

column1: My father told me that.  "Never cry wolf."  Then people won't believe you if...something really happens.
column2: "If something really happens"...like what, James?

column1: Did something terrible happen to you when you were a child?  Something so bad...?
column2: Ohhhh, that one!  Can we hear that one?

column1: You were in my dream just now.  Your hair was different, but I'm sure it was you.
column2: We dream about what's important in our lives. And I seem to have become pretty important in yours.  What was the dream about?

column1: About an airport...before everything happened.  It's the same dream I always have -- the only one.  I'm a little kid in it.
column2: And I was in it?  What did I do?

column1: You were very upset.  You're always very upset in the dream, but I never knew it was you before.
column2: It wasn't me before, James.  It's become me now because of...what's happening.  Please untie me.

column1: No, I think it was always you.  It's very strange.
column2: You're flushed.  And you were moaning. I think you're running a fever.  What are you doing?

column1: My notes.  Observations.  Clues.
column2: Clues?  What kind of clues?

column1: A secret army.  The Army of The Twelve Monkeys.  I've told you about them. They spread the virus.  That's why we have to get to Philadelphia.  I have to find them -- it's my assignment.
column2: What will you do...when you find this...secret army?

column1: Does that disturb you, James?  Thinking about that little boy in the well?
column2: When I was a kid I identified with that kid, down there alone in that pipe...a hundred feet down -- doesn't know if they're going to save him.

column1: What do you mean -- when you were a kid?
column2: Nevermind.  It's not real -- it's a hoax.  A prank.  He's hiding in a barn. Hey, turn left here.  Left!

column1: Look, I'm warning you.  You do anything, I'm going to go crazy -- hurt people!
column2: I'm not going to "do" anything, I promise.  But you need help, James. None of this is what you think it is.

column1: They're keeping an eye on me.
column2: Who's keeping an eye on you?

column1: Are you hurt?
column2: Uh, no.  Yes.  I mean, just some scrapes...

column1: Oh, Jesus, James!  You killed him!
column2: I did him a favor.  Now come on.

column1: You didn't have a gun before, did you?
column2: I've got one now.

column1: I told you what I want.  Lock the door!
column2: James, why don't we...?

column1: Mason???
column2: Jeffrey Mason?

column1: All I see are dead people.  Everywhere. What's three more?
column2: You know Dr. Mason's son, Jeffrey Mason, don't you, James?  You met him in the County Hospital six years ago.

column1: The guy was a total fruitcake.
column2: And he told you then his father was a famous virologist.

column1: We need gas.
column2: I thought you didn't know how to drive.

column1: I said I was too young to drive.  I didn't say I was stupid.
column2: What's the matter with your leg?

column1: I got shot.  Look -- there's a gas station up ahead.
column2: Shot!  Who shot you?

column1: You were going to run out off gas on purpose, weren't you?
column2: No.  I want you to turn yourself in, James -- It'll go much better for you if you do -- but I'm not going to trick you.

column1: You smell so good.
column2: You have to give yourself up, you know.

column1: What have you done?  Did you...kill someone?
column2: No!  I...don't think so.  I stole a car and they chased me.  I hit a tree.

column1: See -- you can drive after all!
column2: Yeah, sort of, I guess.  I...I'm sorry I locked you up.  I thought...I thought... I think maybe I am crazy!

column1: What made you think that?
column2: Jeffrey Mason said it was my idea about the virus.  And suddenly, I wasn't sure.  We talked when I was in the institution, and it was all...fuzzy. The drugs and stuff.  You think maybe I'm the one who wiped out the human race?  It was my idea?

column1: Nobody is going to wipe out the human race.  Not you or Jeffrey or anybody else.  You've created something in your mind, James -- a substitute reality. In order to avoid something you don't want to face.
column2: I'm..."mentally divergent".  I would love to believe that.

column1: I need help all right.  They're coming after me.
column2: First, it's important that you surrender to them instead of them catching you running.  Okay?

column1: It would be great if I'm crazy.  If I'm wrong about everything...the world will be okay.  I'll never have to live underground.
column2: Give me the gun.

column1: The gun! ... I lost it
column2: You're sure?

column1: James!  That's a policeman.  Pretend you don't know me.  If he sees you...
column2: No, I want to turn myself in.  Where is he?  Don't worry -- it's all okay now.  I'm not crazy any more!  I mean, I am crazy, mentally divergent, actually, but I know it now and I want you to help me.  I want to get well...

column1: I don't understand what we're doing.
column2: We're avoiding the police until I can....talk to you.

column1: Okay...you were standing there looking at the moon...you were eating grass... then what?
column2: I thought I was in...prison again.

column1: Just like that?  You were in prison?
column2: No, not really.  It's...it's in my mind.  Like you said.

column1: You disappeared!  One minute you were there, the next minute you were gone. Did you run through the woods?
column2: I don't know -- I don't remember.

column1: The boy in the well.  How did you know that was just a hoax?
column2: It was?  I didn't...know.

column1: James, you said he was hiding in the barn...
column2: I think I saw a TV show like that when I was a kid.  Where a boy...

column1: What does this mean to you?
column2: ...I had a dream about...something like that.

column1: You had a bullet from World War One in your leg, James!  How did it get there?
column2: You said I had delusions -- that I created a world -- you said you could explain everything...

column1: I want to be here.  In this time.  With you.  I want to become...become a whole person.  I want this to be the present. I want the future to be unknown.
column2: James...do you remember...six years ago...you had a phone number!  You tried to call and...

column1: You want me to rob him?
column2: I...I...We need cash, James.

column1: It's a Carpet Cleaning Company...
column2: A Carpet Cleaning Company?

column1: No superiors!  No scientists.  No people from the future.  It's just a Carpet Cleaning Company.  They have voice mail -- you leave a message telling them when you want your carpet cleaned.
column2: You... you left them a message?

column1: You... you couldn't have heard me.
column2: They got your message, Kathryn.  They played it for me.  It was a bad recording...distorted.  I didn't recognize your voice.

column1: I think I've seen this movie before. When I was a kid.  It was on TV.
column2: Shh -- don't talk.  Hold still.

column1: I have seen it, but I don't remember this part.  Funny, it's like what's happening to us, like the past.  The movie never changes -- it can't change -- but everytime you see it, it seems to be different because you're different -- you notice different things.
column2: If we can't change anything...because it's already happened, then we ought to at least smell the flowers.

column1: Why are we doing this?
column2: So we can stick our heads out the window and feel the wind and listen to the music.  So we can appreciate what we have while we have it.  Forgive me, psychiatrists don't cry.

column1: But maybe I'm wrong.  Maybe you're wrong.  Maybe we're both crazy.
column2: In a few weeks, it will have started or it won't.  If there are still baseball games and traffic jams, armed robberies and boring TV shows -- we'll be so happy, we'll be glad to turn ourselves in to the police.

column1: You were in my dream just now.  I didn't recognize you.
column2: Well, you look pretty different, too.

column1: I mean in my dream -- I didn't realize it was you.  Then...I woke up and I...I thought you were gone.
column2: I remember you...like this.  I feel I've known you before.  I feel I've always known you.

column1: That's what they were up to!  Freeing animals!
column2: On the walls -- they meant the animals when they said, "We did it."

column1: I know this place! ... This is my dream.
column2: Airports all look the same.  Maybe it's...  James!  Your moustache!  It's slipping.

column1: They may be looking for us, James.  Use this.  You can fix it in the Men's Room.
column2: I was here...as a kid.  I think you were here, too.  But you...looked just like you look now.

column1: James, if we're identified, they're going to send us someplace...but not to Key West!
column2: Right!  You're right.  I have to fix this.

column1: Does this bother you, Mr. Cole?
column2: No!  Look, I don't belong here!  What I need to do is make a telephone call to straighten everything out.

column1: Who would you call, Mr. Cole, who would straighten everything out?
column2: Scientists.  I'm supposed to report in to them.  They'll want to know they sent me to the wrong time.

column1: So you could talk to these scientists and they do what?  Send you to the future?
column2: No, no.  I can't talk to them.  It's called, "voice mail".  I'm supposed to leave messages. They monitor it from the present.

column1: What'd they give you?  Thorazine?  How much?  Learn your drugs -- know your doses.
column2: I need to make a telephone call.

column1: Germs?!
column2: In the 18th century there was no such thing!  Nobody'd ever imagined such a thing -- no sane person anyway.  Along comes this doctor...Semmelweiss, I think.  He tries to convince people... other doctors mostly...that there are these teeny tiny invisible "bad things" called germs that get into your body and make you...sick!  He's trying to get doctors to wash their hands.  What is this guy...crazy?  Teeny tiny invisible whaddayou call 'em?..."germs"!

column1: "What about the germs?"  I say.  He goes, "I don't believe in germs.  Germs are just a plot they made up so they can sell you disinfectants and soap!" Now, he's crazy, right?  Hey, you believe in germs, don't you?
column2: I'm not crazy.

column1: Of course not, I never thought you were. You want to escape, right?  That's very sane.  I can help you.  You want me to, don't you?  Get you out?
column2: If you know how to escape, why don't you...?

column1: Why don't I escape, that's what you were going to ask me, right?  'Cause I'd be crazy to escape!  I'm all taken care of, see?  I've sent out word.
column2: What's that mean?

column1: They hurt you!
column2: Not as bad as what they're doing to kitty.

column1: Look at those assholes, they're asking for it!  Maybe people deserved to be wiped out!
column2: Wiping cut the human race!  That's a great idea!  But it's more of a long term thing -- right now we have to focus on more immediate goals.  I didn't say a word about "you know what".

column1: What are you talking about???
column2: You know -- your plan.

column1: What're you writing?  You a reporter?
column2: It's private.
Wooooo, they really dosed you, bro. Major load!  Listen up -- try and get it together.  Focus!  Focus!  The plan! Remember?  I did my part.

column1: What...???
column2: Not, "what", babe!  When!

column1: Never saw him before in my life.  Go ahead and shoot him or torture him or whatever it is you do.
column2: You do know me.  You helped me once.

column1: That would be totally out of character. Helping people is against my principles.  See, he definitely doesn't know me.  Now, I'm going to go back and listen to my father's very eloquent discourse on the perils of science WHILE YOU TORTURE THIS INTRUDER TO DEATH.
column2: I'm here about some monkeys.

column1: Excuse me -- what did you say?
column2: Monkeys.  Twelve of them.

column1: County Hospital, right?  1989.  The "Immaculate Escape" -- am I right?  Why, thank you -- you look wonderful, too.
column2: Listen to me -- I can't do anything about what you're going to do. I can't change anything.  I can't stop you.  I just want some information...

column1: We need to talk.  Come on.  Upstairs.  I am a new person!  I'm completely adjusted.  Witness the tux.  It's Armani.  Who chattered?  Goines?  Weller?
column2: I just need to have access to the pure virus, that's all!  For the future!

column1: I don't have time to go upstairs.  The police are looking for me.  I need to know where it is and exactly what it is.
column2: I get it!  This is your old plan, right?

column1: Plan?  What are you talking about?
column2: Remember?  We were in the dayroom, watching TV, and you were all upset about the...desecration of the planet. And you said to me, "Wouldn't it be great if there was a germ or a virus that could wipe out mankind and leave the plants and animals just as they are?"  You do remember that, don't you?

column1: Bulishit!  You're fucking with my head!
column2: And that's when I told you my father was this famous virologist and you said, "Hey, he could make a germ and we could steal it!"

column1: JOSE!
column2: Cole!  Oh, God, Cole, where are we?

column1: Jo...Jose????
column2: Pulling out the tooth, man, that was nuts!  Here, take this.

column1: Me?  Are you kiddin?  You're the one! You were a hero, man.  They gave you a pardon!  And whadda you do?  You come back and fuck with your teeth!  Wow!
column2: How did you find me?

column1: The phone call, man.  The phone call.
column2: The call I just made?  Five minutes ago?

column1: This part isn't about the virus, is it?
column2: Hey, man...

column1: It's about obeying, about doing what you're told.
column2: They gave you a pardon, man.  Whatdaya want?

column1: I mashed the spider, didn't I?
column2: We'll get to the spider later, Mr. Cole.  Right now, we want to know everything that you saw.

column1: I asked you, why did you volunteer?
column2: Well, the guard woke me up.  He told me I volunteered.

column1: Uh, that message...me?
column2: It's a digital reconstruction of a message, Cole, from a weak signal on our contact number.  Did you make that call?

column1: But you know what's real now?
column2: Yes, sir.

column1: Don't be defensive, Kathryn, this isn't an inquisition.
column2: I didn't think I was being defensive. I was just...

column1: He should have been in restraints.  It was bad judgment on your part, plain and simple.  why not just cop to it?
column2: Okay, it was bad judgment.  But I have the strangest feeling about him -- I've seen him somewhere and...

column1: Two policemen were already in the hospital and now we have an orderly with a broken arm and a Security Officer with a fractured skull.
column2: I said it was bad judgment!  What else do you want me to say?

column1: He was fully sedated!
column2: Then are you trying to tell me that a fully sedated, fully restrained patient somehow slipped out that vent, replaced the grill behind him and that he's wriggling through the ventilation system right now?

column1: He kidnapped you, Kathryn.  You saw him murder someone.  You knew there was a real possibility he would kill you, too.  You were under tremendous emotional stress.
column2: For God sakes, Owen, listen to me -- he knew about the boy in Fresno and he says three billion people are going to die!

column1: Kathryn, you know he can't possibly know that.  You're a rational person. You're a trained psychiatrist.  You know the difference between what's real and what's not.
column2: And what we believe is what's accepted as "truth" now, isn't it, Owen?  Psychiatry -- it's the latest religion.  And we're the priests -- we decide what's right and what's wrong --we decide who's crazy and who isn't. ... I'm in trouble, Owen.  I'm losing my faith.

column1: What...virus?
column2: She knew about it, Jeffrey.  She knew you were going to try this.

column1: What virus are we talking about, Dad?
column2: You're insane, Jeffrey.

column1: You "develop" viruses and you're calling me insane?  Typical.  What does this virus attack?  Don't tell me, you sick fuck, it doesn't matter.  Have I ever "developed" a virus?  Do I put helpless animals in cages and measure their reactions to electrical stimuli? Do I inject radioactive substances into living creatures and examine their bowel movements?  Wow!  And I'm crazy!
column2: Please tell me, Jeffrey, what exactly are you going to do?  I don't have to tell you I'm afraid.

column1: One dozen bolt cutters!  Whadda you gonna do with one dozen bolt cutters?
column2: You really want to know?

column1: WHY DON'T WE FORGET MY GODDAMN PSYCHIATRIST AND DEAL WITH THE TASK AT HAND.  THIS IS IMPORTANT.
column2: Your psychiatrist?  Did you just say, "your psychiatrist"?

column1: Ex-psychiatrist!  Now, what about flashlights?  How many flashlights...?
column2: That woman is...was...your... psychiatrist?  And now she's spray- painting our building?

column1: WHO CARES WHAT PSYCHIATRISTS WRITE ON WALLS?  You think I told her about the Army of the 12 Monkeys?  Impossible!  Know why, you pathetically ineffectual and pusillanimous "pretend-friend-to- animals"?!  I'll tell you why:  because when I had anything to do with her six years ago, there was no such thing -- I hadn't even thought of it yet!
column2: Then how come she knows what's going on?

column1: -- so they get there and they ask the guy real nice for some kind of i.d., and he gets agitated, starts screaming about viruses. Totally irrational, totally disoriented, doesn't know where he is, what day it is, alla that stuff.  All they got was his name.  They figure he's stoned out of his mind, it's some kinda psychotic episode, so they're gonna bring him...
column2: He's been tested for drugs?

column1: You have him in restraints.
column2: Were you listening?  We got two officers in the hospital.  Yeah, he's in restraints, plus the medic gave him enough stellazine to kill a horse.  Look at him!  Still on his feet.

column1: That would explain the bruises, I guess.  The struggle.
column2: You want to go in?  Examine him?

column1: Yes, please.  You said he gave a name...
column2: James Cole.  That's everything we got.  None of the James Coles on the computer match him. No license, no prints, no warrants.  Nothing. You want me to go in with you?

column1: No, thank you.
column2: I'll be right here...just in case.

column1: Nine thirty
column2: Might be tight.

column1: Tight?  My watch says 7:30.
column2: On your normal mornin', okay, plenty a time, but today, gotta take inta account your Army-of-the-Twelve-Monkeys factor.

column1: What?  What did you say?
column2: Twelve Monkeys, honey.  Guess you folks didn't turn on your radio this morning.

column1: ) Daryl Lindenmeyer was only here briefly, one semester at most. But he was singularly the most brilliant student I ever had in a classroom. He created programs so beautiful, so lyrical, they were almost like symphonies...
column2: Can you tell us what's on the disc?

column1: In English, please.
column2: I accidently triggered a protection mechanism which erased the entire program.

column1: It was very wellhidden. There was no way to see it until it was too late.
column2: It's not your fault. We appreciate you trying.

column1: You son-ofabitch, I'm going to kill you.
column2: Me? What did I do?

column1: I'm sorry, I thought you were somebody else.
column2: I've discovered something about Lindenmeyer'5 Maestro teaching tool I thought you should know...  The harm done to the music students who used the device  it was not by accident. The machine was designed explicitly for that purpose. Lindenmeyer intended to hurt the kids using it.

column1: My first two pairs of convicts suffered the same fate.
column2: Why wasn't I told?

column1: We don't know how, but Sid 6.7 made himself into an android.
column2: You mean a nanotech synthetic organism.

column1: Recognize this? How would you like your old job back?
column2: Catch him and your record's clean.

column1: This is the newest technology approved for general implementation. It's called a locater implant. Every parolee gets one.  We're going to know where you are every second for the rest of your life.
column2: If you try to run, I'll hunt you down and kill you myself.

column1: There's already a task force out looking for Lindenmeyer. Every other officer in the city will be hunting Sid right along with you.
column2: But only you will know he's not human.

column1: What are they doing in Los Feliz?
column2: Madison lives two blocks from their present location.

column1: Why would they be going there?
column2: I don't know.

column1: Barnes wouldn't kill two innocent guards.
column2: He would slaughter eight people sitting in a room, but not two prison guards?

column1: Do I need to remind you what happened to his wife? To his daughter?  I will stake my reputation that Barnes didn't kill those guards.
column2: You already have staked your reputation.  Mayor Bennett and I have been friends a long time. Since Grimes tried to kill him, it doesn't take a rocket scientist to come to the conclusion that Sid 6.7 might go after him, too.  Bennett's Re-Election Rally is tomorrow night and we already have enough trouble on our hands with one psychotic on the loose.  The fail-safe online, yet?

column1: You all right?
column2: Why'd.. .you pull me out?

column1: What the hell did you have to shoot the busboy for?
column2: He was a computer program for crissake.

column1: You were supposed to act as if everything was real.
column2: Real, my ass. It's an overblown game.  Anybody ever catch that fucking psycho?

column1: Before you, nobody else had gotten close enough to Sid 6.7 to take a shot at him. Hell, nobody else had even been able to start tracking him before he got to them first.  New scar  you making it okay in there?
column2: I'm getting by.

column1: But with the six months off I get for being your guinea pig, I've only got to survive another 17 years, 5 months, and 23 days.
column2: Don't give up, Parker. Not ever.

column1: You know those cheesy Christmas cards of your family under that tree in your back yard you keep sending me every year?
column2: What about them?

column1: You're wasting your time. I'm not going to play any more of your goddam games.
column2: Parker Barnes, I'd like you to meet Crime Czar Elizabeth Deane.

column1: These were taken inside LETAC an hour ago. Pretty pictures, aren't they?
column2: I've seen worse.

column1: Jesus Christ.  Can you kill it?
column2: If you can catch him.

column1: She's going to help you understand what makes Sid 6.7 tick.
column2: What she's going to do is get in my way.

column1: This is the personnel file on the programmer, Lindenmeyer. There might be something in it you can use.
column2: She wasn't part of the deal, Cox.

column1: Officers in Toluca Lake just found an affluent couple...completely gutted.  So were the first two cops to arrive on scene.
column2: Their weapons missing?

column1: Sid 6.7 is now armed.
column2: Where's my gun?

column1: Don't worry, they have no idea where you are.
column2: You sonofabitch. How could you let them put the implant in my head? How?

column1: She saved your life, Parker. She didn't have to, but she did.
column2: Then I guess we're even.

column1: When this is over, will you get this goddam thing out of my head?
column2: On my life, I promise you I will.

column1: ... illegal search of Lindenmeyer' s duplex. Eleven civilian vehicles damaged or destroyed. Twentyfour citizen complaints. And the calls are just starting to come in...  I forgot what it's like to have you on the streets.
column2: Any sign of Lindenmeyer?

column1: None. He could be hiding, he could be helping Sid, or could be in little pieces on Santa Monica beach.  Any idea what Sid's going to do next?
column2: Until we know what new influences are affecting him, we can't be sure.

column1: I should have told him.
column2: Don't blame yourself. In your shoes, I don't think I would have told Parker, either.  So do you think Grimes has become the dominant personality?

column1: I'm not sure. My guess is that's what Sid wants us to think.
column2: You think he's smart?

column1: There is no way Parker killed those guards. No way.
column2: I think we both know who did.  What's so urgent?

column1: Why didn't anybody tell me?!
column2: I don't set policy.  You have the key?

column1: Give me 30 seconds, then flip every switch you can reach.
column2: Got it.

column1: Ms. Deane, you wanted to see me?
column2: We have an emergency situation which requires somebody with expertise in criminal psychology. Under the authority vested in me by the President, I'm giving you temporary reassignment.

column1: What's the assignment?
column2: You're going to put your theories to practice. I'm sending you into the field.

column1: That's also where Mr. Barnes lost his arms to Mathew Grimes' booby trap. What's your point, Dr. Carter?
column2: Letting a lunatic like Parker Barnes loose in the free world is like lighting a fuse. At some point, he will go off -- you saw what happened in the simulator. The risk to the public is unacceptably dangerous.

column1: Not if you're with him every step of the way.
column2: The man played judge, jury, and executioner with eight people's lives. He lost control and is capable of doing it again.

column1: I watched your simulation, Mr. Barnes. Very impressive. You know, you're the only one to ever go up against Sid 6.7 who is still alive.
column2: Only because I got pulled out early.

column1: Think you can do it?
column2: Not from in here.

column1: What happens if I can't catch him?
column2: If Sid 6.7 hasn't killed you, we throw you back in here and you serve out the rest of your sentence.

column1: Barnes, where the hell have you been?!
column2: Trying to find out where the bomb is. Where the hell have you been?

column1: What did you find out?
column2: Call off the manhunt looking for me. I didn't kill the transport guards.

column1: It's already been called off. Witnesses confirmed you weren't the shooter.  Did you find out where the bomb is?
column2: No, but I've confirmed the reelection rally is the target.  How much C-4 is missing?

column1: Enough to level an entire city block.
column2: If I were you, I'd get every demolition team in the city searching in and around the Biltmore Hotel.

column1: Demolition teams have searched everywhere in and around the hotel. I don't know where...
column2: Sid is smart enough to know you'd check everywhere in the immediate area. Whatever the device is, he's probably got it timed to move into position just before it detonates.  Have the demo teams check every subway tunnel, water pipe, gas pipe, and sewer pipe that goes under, over, or into the arena.

column1: You know how much man power you're talking about?
column2: You're the highest law enforcement official in the country. Use the fucking army if you need to.

column1: This better not be a wild goose chase.
column2: Or what, you'll authorize my death a second time today?

column1: What did Cox pull him out early for?
column2: Barnes used to work for him when he was still a cop in the field, remember?

column1: What the hell happened?
column2: Lindenmeyer developed neural connectors that tap directly into the nervous system. If the simulator isn't calibrated properly, experiencing death in this level of VR is like experiencing death within a dream. The experience becomes real.

column1: Simulations are supposed to give participants practice in realistic, dangerous scenarios while protecting them from the risks they are exposed to in the real world.
column2: I was assured the problem was corrected.

column1: It makes me nervous just seeing him in a uniform.  I will never forget the first time I saw the photos from the crime scene.
column2: Neither will the public.  The media has caught wind of his pardon. Unless Mr. Barnes starts giving me some tangible results, I'm going to put him back in his cage.

column1: You embarrassed me in front of the highestranking law enforcement official in the country.  Do you have any idea how much money you just cost me?
column2: The reason you insisted on testing my system with prisoners is because of the increased risks involved with increased realism.

column1: Of the six prison inmates you've tested  all of whom have had at least some military or survival training - only Mr. Barnes is still breathing.
column2: I'm still making adjustments...

column1: You've had a yearandahalf to make all the adjustments you want, Lindenmeyer.  ) Elizabeth Deane does not give second chances. Neither do I. You're fired.
column2: I'M WHAT?!

column1: You are to turn over the Sid 6.7 program, and all its documentation, for immediate destruction. Is that understood?
column2: I understand... I understand perfectly.

column1: How does he know who I am?
column2: He hears...everything.

column1: HEY!!!
column2: Show's over unless I get to see what you've been working on after hours.

column1: I haven't been working on anything.
column2: Do I get to see it or not?

column1: Get that fucking thing away from me!
column2: You're...such a wimp.

column1: Watching your VR people Auto Reset gave me the idea.
column2: It's nanotechnology, isn't it? Machines the size of molecules...

column1: Coordinated by polymer neural net.
column2: It feels so.. .real.

column1: It's better than real. It's synthetic flesh. Synthetic blood. Synthetic organs...  It's a physiological machine.
column2: This is supposed to be years away.

column1: As far as the public is concerned, it is. The reason you got fired, and I got my second demo into production, is I'm a lot smarter than you. I never give my best stuff away.
column2: How do you kill it?

column1: ... and you get nanodeath.  Don't worry, I've got a bunch of other ones.
column2: Amazing. I hate to say it, but it is.

column1: You need a maid.
column2: What I need is a nymphomaniac.

column1: I told you this would work.. By setting back the clocks, he has absolutely no idea he's in virtual reality. He still thinks he's in the real world.
column2: What's wrong with Parker?

column1: How should I know?
column2: Show me his physical sensory level.

column1: I wonder how that...
column2: Turn it down!

column1: He's developing a hemisphere imbalance.
column2: Talk so I can understand.

column1: If I don't adjust the level of neural information each side of his brain is receiving, he won't be able to walk when I take him out of VR.
column2: Then fix it.

column1: Don't be angry with me, Daryl.
column2: Did you recognize the son-of-a bitch who got away?

column1: Should I have?
column2: Think hard -- it'll come to you...

column1: All they want to produce around here is mediocrity!
column2: True genius is rarely rewarded within its lifetime.

column1: It was you, wasn't it?
column2: It was me, what?

column1: You amped the neural connectors back up, didn't you?  You're the reason the convict died. You're the reason I got fired!
column2: I couldn't just let them make you bring down my degree of difficulty. I'm a triple-twisting, double back flip off the high platform, not a swan dive.

column1: My God...
column2: Which God would that be, the one who created me, or the one who created you?  In your world, the Lord giveth, and the Lord taketh away. But in my world, the one who gave me life doesn't have the balls to stop a couple of bureaucratic assholes from taking it away.

column1: What do you expect me to do, put your character module in my pocket and just walk you out of here?
column2: I had something a little different in mind.  Instead of just playing Peeping Tom with Reilly, why don't you get him to show you what he's been working on after hours?

column1: She's some of your finest work, Daryl.
column2: All my work is my finest.

column1: You catching my drift?
column2: I think I understand what you have in mind...

column1: SID  NO!!!
column2: What do you expect me to do, thank him?

column1: I am beautiful, aren't I?
column2: Of course you are.

column1: How can I ever thankyou for bringing me back to life a second time, Daryl?
column2: Help me get out of here.

column1: You made me a composite of 183 of the most vicious people who ever lived.  What do you think I'm doing?
column2: I'm begging you...please don't kill me! Please!

column1: You actually listen to all those tapes?
column2: No, I just like the effect a tape recorder has on you.  How you feeling today?

column1: A little less than yesterday.
column2: In other words, par for the course.  How do you feel about the simulation you participated in yesterday?

column1: John died.
column2: I know. I was there. I saw the whole thing.  If I was your therapist, I would have advised you against putting yourself back into that kind of situation.

column1: You're not my therapist. You're hear to study me. Face it  I'm nothing more than a lab rat to you.
column2: That's not true, Parker.

column1: If I had died yesterday, you'd have already dissected my brain and analyzed it to see if I carry any genetic predisposition toward violence.
column2: What was going through your mind when you killed the busboy?

column1: Not much. He was just a computer program. Nothing more.
column2: You didn't see the expression you had on your face when you pulled the trigger. But I did.  You kind of liked it, didn't you? That thrill of going over the edge again. Of taking out an innocent bystander or two, as long as you got the target...

column1: Go to hell.
column2: It was just like before, wasn't it? Wasn't it?  But you are making progress. Instead of killing seven people to get the one you're after, this time there was only one other person involved.

column1: I need to know what snapped in you. What made you capable of it. You have to make me understand.
column2: I don't have to do anything except survive. And it's taking everything I've got just to do that.

column1: I don't need a babysitter.
column2: What you need is a collar.

column1: Every day for the last five years, I told myself someday I would be out here again. No more bars. No more guards. No more fights just to stay alive.  Every day for the last five years, I told myself that lie.
column2: It wasn't a lie.

column1: You all right?
column2: Fine. Never felt better in my life.  See, I'm a good liar.

column1: You ready for this?
column2: Don't worry. If I can't handle it, I'll just kill everybody.

column1: He was reenacting Charles Manson's LaBianca murders.
column2: Manson didn't kill the first cops to arrive on the scene.

column1: Whoever did this wanted to do Charlie one better  to improve upon what was already done.
column2: Charlie? You say that like you're close, personal friends.

column1: I've spent over 50 hours interviewing him.  Charlie killed Leno and Rosemary LaBianca because of the ugly way the members of his family had butchered Sharon Tate. After seeing the blood bath on television, he wanted to show them how it should be done.  The question is, what does Charlie have to do with Sid 6.7?
column2: I know who would know.

column1: Learn anything from Lindenmeyer's file?
column2: He had a twin brother who was a musical child prodigy who died in an electrical accident at age eight. Lindenmeyer went into an emotional shell until was 17. All he did day and night was play the violin.

column1: What happened when he was 17?
column2: Every music school in the country rejected him and he turned to computers.  Stay here.

column1: You've got a problem with me carrying a gun?
column2: Do me one favor  if you shoot at anything, make sure I'm nowhere near it.

column1: What are you doing?
column2: Checking my pulse. It's elevated.  You enjoy frightening me, don't you?

column1: This Lindenmeyer's a real piece of work.
column2: Maybe after they catch him, you should write a book about him...

column1: I'm surprised you didn't write one about me.
column2: I'm still working on it.

column1: Remember a few years ago when music schools were using a computerized teaching tool that accidently started frying kids' brains?
column2: I've been in prison, remember?

column1: The government must have figured there was no better person to create a psycho than a psycho.
column2: Just like they figured there was no better person to catch one...

column1: I am the demon from the bottomless pit...
column2: ... here on earth to create havoc and terror. I am War, I am death. I am destruction. David Berkowitz, 1977.

column1: I am impressed.
column2: For murder, though it have no tongue, will speak with most miraculous organ.

column1: Who said that?
column2: Hamlet.  What's David Berkowitz got to do with Sid 6.7?

column1: Lindenmeyer put increasingly complex combinations of criminal psychological profiles together to develop the ultimate villain.
column2: Creating a whole far more dangerous than the sum of its parts.

column1: This is getting you pumped up, isn't it? This is like the World Series to you.
column2: As a matter of fact, it is.

column1: Remember the bowling ball bag Sid carried with him in virtual reality?
column2: Dahmer carried the head of one of his victims in a bowling bag for over a week. Kept it in his locker while he was at work in a candy factory.  We need to get a look at Sid 6.7's final profile.

column1: What we need to do is stop playing with computers and go catch the sonof-a-bitch before he kills anybody else.
column2: In order to find him, we have to understand what makes him tick...

column1: Give me your wrist.
column2: Give me a goddam break. I'm not going to go anywhere alone.

column1: Told you I wasn't going to go anywhere.
column2: How did you get your hand out?

column1: Why didn't you tell me you had a daughter?
column2: I prefer keeping my professional life separate from my personal life.

column1: She's beautiful, you know?
column2: Thank-you.  Her name is Karin.

column1: Want to tell me the real reason we stopped at your house?
column2: I told you, it was on the way and I wanted to change clothes.

column1: You should practice lying more often. You're awful at it.  Where to?
column2: Sid 6.7 is no longer bound by his programming.

column1: What does that mean?
column2: Now that he's in the real world, there are no longer limitations on his behavior like there were in virtual reality. Sid is going to evolve.

column1: Sounds to me like a welleducated way of saying you have no idea what to do next.
column2: What I do know is that whatever he's becoming, Sid 6.7 is going to be even worse than he was before.

column1: I forgot what real coffee tastes like...
column2: You know, considering you've only been out of prison for seven hours, you're readapting quite well.  Wait, I didn't mean that the way it sounded. I meant...

column1: Don't worry about it, all right?
column2: Dammit, I hate sounding so clinical all the time. All I meant to say was I thought you were doing well, but then I...

column1: Relax. I know what you meant.
column2: I ruin so many moments by analyzing them when I should just be living them.

column1: Don't get out of the car.
column2: Stop me.

column1: What the hell's going on?!
column2: This is my area of expertise.

column1: What did you do to those people?
column2: Nothing.

column1: Being on the street's a little different than sitting in an office all day, isn't it?
column2: Enjoying yourself?

column1: You know I am.
column2: This isn't a game, Parker!

column1: What's the problem?
column2: I'm doing the best I can!

column1: Whatever he was doing here was only the start.
column2: Start of what?

column1: It's not just Sid 6.7's performances that are increasing. Stars need bigger and bigger audiences.  Whatever Sid is going to do next, it's going to involve media.
column2: You like baseball?

column1: Real effective security...
column2: You could have just flashed him your badge, you know?

column1: Which way?
column2: Both.

column1: Parker - stop! STOP! Don't make me shoot you
column2: If you're gonna do it, better do it now.

column1: Grimes is back! He's back! He's come back!!!
column2: No! Grimes isn't back. He's only one part of Sid. Sid 6.7 is a hell of a lot worse than Grimes ever was.  Get a hold of yourself!

column1: We know you didn't kill those guards.
column2: They're going to fry me for it, anyway.

column1: He didn't know about the neural toxin.  I did.
column2: You knew the entire time? Can you give me one good reason why I shouldn't kill you right now?

column1: How did you find out about the toxin?
column2: Sid 6.7 told me after he killed the two guards. He suggested I kill you rather than him.

column1: You're not capable of it.
column2: I pose an unacceptable danger to the public, remember?

column1: The rally's a little obvious as a target, don't you think?
column2: I told you before, Grimes liked to be obvious.

column1: Sid 6.7 isn't Grimes.
column2: Part of him is.

column1: If we find Sid, Lindenmeyer won't be far behind.
column2: Think he's keeping track of his creation?

column1: See something?
column2: I'm not sure...on the bridge...the guy at the payphone...

column1: Nice work.
column2: Thanks.

column1: Find out anything?
column2: A bomb's going off tomorrow night, but I have no idea where.

column1: Can I ask you something?
column2: You mean there's something you haven't asked me?

column1: You've already fulfilled the terms of your pardon. You stopped Sid 6.7 and you've got his module. You're free to go  right now.  Why are you going to do this?
column2: You don't know?

column1: That's why I'm asking.
column2: Because this painintheass criminal psychology expert has helped me understand what I'm capable of. And what I'm not.  And better than anyone else, I am capable of stopping Sid 6.7.

column1: You okay?
column2: ...I think so...You?

column1: More or less.
column2: Lindenmeyer?

column1: My guess is dead.
column2: Sid?

column1: Where the hell are you going?
column2: Lindenmeyer never got over wanting to kill kids with more musical than he had...

column1: How's your pulse?
column2: I couldn't tell you.

column1: Then shoot him already.
column2: Duck!

column1: What do we do now?
column2: You won't want to watch. Turn around.

column1: Where's John?
column2: Performing solo.  Enjoying the concert so far?

column1: The symphony of collision...
column2: The only thing I want to hear is your silence.

column1: You and me have nothing in common.
column2: Who else do you know who touches the world with synthetic hands?

column1: You...mother...fucker! I'M GOING TO KILL YOU!!!
column2: Now, is that any way to talk to an old buddy? I mean, just because I'm carrying around the joy of killing your family inside me doesn't mean we can't be friends.

column1: I'm sorry, the party you're trying to reach is not answering. Is there anyone else you would like to talk to?
column2: DEAD! YOU HEAR ME?

column1: I wouldn't pull the trigger if I were you
column2: Why's that?

column1: What C-4...was Cox talking about?
column2: Let me put it to you this way... whether I'm here...or whether I'm not...I'm leaving an indelible mark on the world tomorrow night.

column1: What C-4...was Cox talking about?
column2: Let me put it to you this way... whether I'm here... or whether I'm not...I'm leaving an indelible mark on the world tomorrow night.

column1: You can't die until you tell me where the C-4 is. Where is it?!
column2: My...secret.

column1: It's really too bad you have to miss the Grand Finale.
column2: I thought you liked me being in the audience. Don't you want me to see it?

column1: There you go  best seat in the house.
column2: You are going after Mayor Bennett.

column1: Aren't you going to watch with me?
column2: I've got some final preparations to take care of Checking his watch, he stops suddenly.

column1: Thank-you, Daryl.  You had me going for quite a while there, sport.
column2: What are you talking about?

column1: Now, is that any way to talk to an old friend?
column2: BARNES, YOU'RE DEAD!

column1: To the first LETAC engineer to go into production on prototypes.
column2: As long as you keep overpaying me, I'll be the first to go into production on three, and four, as well.

column1: As long as they keep overpaying me, I'll keep overpaying you.  ) Just make goddam sure you can have 10 of them ready for deployment around the city by next month.
column2: Mr. Wallace, I could have 10 of them ready by tomorrow.

column1: Do they have to look so...robotic?
column2: At this stage, you either get form or function. You said she wanted function. I gave you function. What are you complaining about?

column1: J. S. Bach.
column2: Jim West.

column1: Artemus Gordon.  Bach, he's the composer.
column2: I don't mind him, but who the hell are you... my valet or something?

column1: Valet?  You jest of course.  I am a U.S. Marshal.
column2: Funny.  So am I.

column1: Congratulations.  Unfortunately, my train is about to leave, and I really must insist you disembark.
column2: Your train?  Listen, friend, you're obviously lost.  ... I've got orders here to take possession of this train and to investigate a certain crime.

column1: Just another bureaucratic foul-up. You know how these pencil-pushers are.  So, why don't you just run on back and explain what happened?
column2: Funny, I was just thinking you should do the same.  Since I am already in residence, and am obviously the man for the job, it's been grand making your acquaintance, sir.  And best of luck in all your future endeavors.

column1: You're quite the wordsmith, fiddle boy.  But nobody smooth-talks his way into my assignment.
column2: If you're implying our little imbroglio has reached an impasse whose only resolution can be found in a more primitive fashion, then I for one am fully prepared to do so... al fresco.

column1: But don't pull that again.
column2: Wouldn't dream of it.

column1: Eight scientists.  Eight different fields of endeavor.  Hydraulics, optics, ballistics...
column2: Put them all together and what do we have?

column1: A giant... hydraulically operated microscope... that explodes?  Or maybe just someone who hates scientists.
column2: Then why kidnap them?  Why not just kill them?

column1: Sorry.  Didn't mean that.  Just a little device of mine...
column2: Wait a minute.  Now I know where I've heard of you.  You're the gadget guy.

column1: Attractive buttons, yes?  But yank one off, toss it, and poof!  It emits a cloud of sleeping gas.
column2: You need that real often?

column1: Always hoping.  Or this...
column2: No offense, but all I ever need...  Are these...  And this.

column1: Good Lord, man.  The world is changing.  And mark me, it is always the criminal mind that is the first to exploit modern invention.  We, as defenders of the right, must keep pace!
column2: All right, if it'll make you happy, I'll try that.

column1: Your little jack-in-the-box gun. That might be useful.
column2: Well... it's the only one I have. It's gotten me out of quite a few tight spots...

column1: That should put us ahead of the criminals.
column2: I'll work on it.

column1: Aha!
column2: Aha?

column1: Yes, aha.  A brass screw.
column2: Is this leading somewhere?

column1: Potentially.  This is the painstaking process of piecing together clues.  The cornerstone of the modern science of criminology.  Piece by piece we reconstruct the identity of the villain.
column2: Starting with a screw?

column1: Yes.  Starting with a screw.  Now, it's not fair of me to expect someone who's spent his life wrangling with Western desperadoes to fully appreciate what I'm doing here, but...
column2: What about the explosive?

column1: Limestone quarry?
column2: Limestone quarry, Southern mansion. Easy to get them mixed up... I say we invite ourselves to the party.

column1: Doyle, once around the park.  I need a moment to prepare.
column2: Prepare what?

column1: Come Llewellyn, don't tarry.
column2: Call me that again, and you're going to find a boot where it doesn't belong.

column1: That's a lot of butler.
column2: Quite.  Come, let's mingle.

column1: Doctor V. L. Pemberton.  I knew it.  He's a scientist all right. Inventor of the Pemberton Condensed Steam Engine.  I'm telling you, Artemus, Loveless is our man.
column2: Whoa, Jim.  Maybe.  But we can't arrest this little pillar of society on maybe.

column1: All right.  How about this?  We put a watch on this Pemberton, somebody tries to grab him...
column2: Then we've got our proof. Excellent.  And where do we find this fortunate scientist?

column1: You know your Morse Code almost as well as I.
column2: Almost?

column1: You feeling all right?
column2: Come on, Jim.  I'm serious.  Dot...  Dash.  It'll be our secret means of communication should we ever need it.

column1: Now, what was that?
column2: You're either having a seizure or you just said "hello."

column1: What was all that back there?
column2: All what?

column1: All that jumping and kicking.
column2: That?  Oh, it's a kind of Chinese fighting... I was sort of caught once with a lovely Chinese girl out in San Francisco.  Her big brothers were kind enough to teach it to me  I've got a book on it, if you're interested.

column1: Garrison...?  Then the President was right.  Except it's not a foreign power, it's a bunch of die- hard Rebels trying to make the South rise again.
column2: And if they've got Dr. Loveless building weapons like those flying bombs... they just might do it.

column1: Could I just point out, this is a perfect example of the criminal mind exploiting modern invention.
column2: I'm going to hit you.

column1: Never seen a gun fire so fast!
column2: It's a repeating steam cannon!

column1: At least I tried something.
column2: Hey, I tried the board.

column1: Damn it, this is ridiculous.
column2: At least the thing's not that fast. We just follow it.  Whenever it stops, we're there, waiting.

column1: Jim, are you all right?
column2: No, I'm not all right.  They got away.  And we can't even follow them.  They can get off the tracks anywhere they want.

column1: If you don't mind my asking, were you always the way you are?
column2: What way is that?

column1: So... spontaneous.  All that leaping off buildings and Chinese fighting and whatnot.
column2: "Spontaneous."  I like that.  Most people say something like "hare- brained reckless son-of-a-bitch."

column1: Well... that, too.
column2: Nothing much to it really.  When I was younger I got into a pretty bad run-in with the Wyler Boys.  I saw them coming.  But I didn't act fast enough.  Second-guessed myself. And it cost me... cost me dearly.

column1: So... what happened?
column2: Those kids, they took my wagon. Never got it back.

column1: Uh... how long ago was this?
column2: I was six.  And ever since, my policy is: Act first and worry later.

column1: You might have mentioned you had that.
column2: I thought all you needed were your fists and your gun.

column1: Strange... you'd think he'd have this place better guarded.
column2: I find most criminals slip up somewhere...

column1: They're so precious when they're asleep.
column2: You really enjoy yourself, don't you?

column1: Can you fill me in here?
column2: Sure.  We have no idea what's going on.

column1: Thank you.
column2: Come on, let's at least see if we can find Dr. Pemberton.

column1: Know what this is?
column2: Sure.  It's a wind-up... thing.

column1: This is good.
column2: Shhh!  Come on.  Tell us something!

column1: Oh, damn!  That's it.
column2: It's better than nothing.

column1: It is?
column2: He's going to put on a pith helmet and kill some guy named Willard.

column1: No record of him.
column2: You'd think if Loveless is going to kill him he could at least be a prominent citizen.

column1: What's this?
column2: Sounds like a train.  Looks like a train.

column1: Willard...
column2: It's not a guy...

column1: Got to be somewhere that's hot. He said it was "damnably hot."
column2: That rules out Willard, Vermont

column1: Damn, I wish this thing would go faster.
column2: Relax.  We're almost there.

column1: What is that?
column2: This?  I'm testing a new spirit gum, to see how it holds.

column1: And people are actually fooled by that?
column2: My disguises have helped me solve many a difficult case.  I spent three years on the stage, you know.  Remind me sometime to regale you with my Lear.

column1: Not again.
column2: I adjusted it.

column1: So the idea is if a guy punches me, he really hurts his hand?
column2: You said it popped out too easily. Nothing's ever good enough for you, is it?

column1: When we find him, he is mine.
column2: Oh, no, we split him fifty-fifty.

column1: What if these tracks are just leading us to an Indian village or some old coot's mining claim?
column2: Not likely.  There must be tracks of twenty different wagons.  Freight wagons, carriages, buckboards...

column1: Excellent detective work, sir.  You should have the honor of going first.
column2: Oh, thank you.

column1: Artemus, you ready for this?  His next target is Albuquerque.
column2: What?  President Grant is...!

column1: I know!  I know!
column2: I don't have to tell you what that would do to our careers!

column1: We've got to stop him right here, now!  With that armored steam engine of his it'll be a slaughter.
column2: I'd love to stop him, but have you noticed the hundred armed men?

column1: There's only seventy-eight.
column2: Oh, well, then let's kick some ass!

column1: It was in your book.
column2: Well, hell, maybe we do have a chance.

column1: Are those just button buttons or...?
column2: Of course not.

column1: My hat is off to you, sir.
column2: Thank you.

column1: God in heaven, what is that?!
column2: That's... that's the criminal mind about to stomp our sorry butts!

column1: My God!  He's so excessive!
column2: Where have you been?

column1: Pull the balloon right in front of him!  We'll board the damn thing!
column2: Oh, I see, an easy plan!

column1: The machine was stopped!  It seemed like a perfect time to disable it! Why'd you have to throw it into full throttle?!
column2: He was going to shoot me!  Do you mind?!

column1: All right, all right... It'll be okay.  I mean, eventually it'll just run out of steam.
column2: In the next two minutes?

column1: Artemus!  Look at that.  Brand spanking new.  She's a beauty, huh?  Let's get rolling.
column2: What is this?  A whole new train?

column1: Well, we'll stay in touch... you know.
column2: I'm sure we will.

column1: Terribly sorry.  I'm always sticking this where it doesn't belong.  Federal agents, ma'am.  We're rescuing a kidnap victim...
column2: Yes, me!

column1: You didn't tell us you had this on!
column2: My Lord, he was telling the truth!

column1: He calls it the Tarantula.
column2: But it only has six legs.

column1: He's not giving up?
column2: Well, see, he had this little wagon when he was a kid...

column1: Time for you to get off, Ma'am.
column2: Like hell!  I'll see it through! Ram the bastard!

column1: A new friend?
column2: We'll see.

column1: Anyone?
column2: Here.  Mr. Tyler.  He claims a certain skill at handling firearms.

column1: I could get used to this, looking down on people.
column2: They don't even realize they should be frightened.

column1: My name's Tyler.  Frank Tyler. Pleased to meet you, ma'am.
column2: I get that feeling.  You know, Mr. Tyler, I'm the kind of woman who doesn't believe men are much more than a complete waste of time. But after spying you across the room, I'm tempted to suspend my disbelief, at least for the evening.

column1: You know, ma'am, you remind me of a pearl-handled pistol I once owned. A beautiful thing to look at, but too hot to handle.
column2: I don't recollect ever being compared to a pistol before.

column1: Please do.  I'm a man who appreciates a good firearm.
column2: Really?

column1: Well, where I come from it kind of goes with the territory.  Texas.
column2: My... the wild west.

column1: Well, sir, you are proving to be one of my more interesting guests.
column2: Your guests, ma'am?

column1: Oh, don't worry.  I've already overlooked the fact your name's not actually on our guest list.
column2: Well, I owe you one, don't I?

column1: You must excuse the Doctor.  No one has ever beaten him at his little game.
column2: I don't like to lose, either.

column1: Have you taken a wrong turn, Mr. Tyler?
column2: You tell me.

column1: I'm not so sure Dr. Loveless would like to find his social secretary dancing in the dark with an uninvited stranger.
column2: Forgive me, but you don't strike me as the social secretary type.

column1: Thank you.  But the truth is, I'm a single woman in a man's world. That leaves me very few choices, doesn't it?
column2: I suppose so.  But life can be hard for a man, too.

column1: Just a little insurance... against the unexpected.
column2: Would that include me?

column1: You've... done... this... before.
column2: I've had some practice.

column1: She's perfectly safe.
column2: Really?  Like General Garrison or didn't you hear all that shooting?

column1: My.  It's gotten longer.
column2: You bring the best out in a man.

column1: You know, I really hate being toyed with before someone shoots me.
column2: Fine, I'll stop.

column1: Look, I'm Captain James West...
column2: Well, Captain, then the answer is your train is still here.

column1: Your private train, sir.
column2: Private train?

column1: Doyle's the name, sir.  Of the Connemara Doyles.  And there's not a man riding the rails who holds a candle to meself.  That having been said, sir, you're five minutes late so let's be on our way!  Your friend's already aboard.
column2: My friend?

column1: Would you be thinking... ramming speed, sir?
column2: I would, Mr. Doyle!  Are you game?

column1: Don't try to bamboozle me, Colonel. Has another scientist been kidnapped or not?
column2: Well, yes sir.  A Professor Morton, but with just a little more time, sir, I can assure you a breakthrough on this case...

column1: Listen, in two days I'm embarking on a tour of the western territories.  And I want to know at least one problem is being handled competently in my absence.
column2: Of course, sir, that's why I've assigned a new man.  And he's no ordinary Marshal.  He's quite sophisticated.  Three college degrees.  A master of disguise. Speaks French...

column1: French?
column2: Yes sir.

column1: Why surely, Mr. President, there must be some mistake.  I mean...
column2: A mistake?  To assign this case to the man who blew up all the bridges on the Chattanooga River and single- handedly trapped Jackson's entire cavalry?  How is that a mistake?

column1: Mr. President, good to see you again, sir.  Sorry about all that.
column2: That'll be all, boys.

column1: Good work.  Really.
column2: This is Colonel Richards.

column1: But what would anyone have to gain from all this...?  Unless it were a foreign power.
column2: Exactly.  Any number of nations would love to cripple our scientific growth.  And what better way to tip the scales in their favor than by killing off the greatest minds this country has produced.

column1: We find ourselves at the dawn of the Golden Age of Science.  And it is the God-given destiny of this glorious nation to carry the torch that lights the way!
column2: Nicely said, sir.

column1: Goddamnit!  What am I doing?  What's happened to all my cigars?  Colonel Richards here has had a dozen agents on these cases for over a year.  No arrests, no leads, no clues...
column2: And?

column1: ... well, of course you can.  Mr. President, what a surprise.  What brings you here?
column2: On my way to Denver...

column1: Where'd he say he was going to do this?
column2: He didn't.  That's your job.  I'm taking you off that other case until you've nabbed this lunatic. Good luck.  Nice train.  But mine's nicer.

column1: I admire a man with a sense of humor.
column2: When you're three and a half feet tall, sir, life turns you into a comedian whether you like it or not.... Come with me, won't you?

column1: I must compliment you on Miss Thompson... an exceptionally charming assistant.
column2: Thank you.  I confess to a preoccupation with acquiring precisely that which the world says I cannot have.

column1: Very good, sir!  I think my guest might be a sharpshooter by trade.
column2: No, sir... just a businessman.

column1: Really?  Must be a dangerous business.
column2: I deal with some tough customers.

column1: Sir... I believe you have only two barrels.
column2: How embarrassing.  Did I hold up three fingers?

column1: Why don't we just cut this routine short?  Whatever you do to us, we're not going to talk.
column2: Talk?  About what...?  Oh!  About who you are and all that?

column1: ... And do give me some room, Voltaire.  You're breathing on my head!  I hate it when you breath on my head!
column2: Dr. Loveless?

column1: You're not that big.
column2: Restrain yourself, Voltaire.  He's just the sort of coward who would shoot an unarmed giant.

column1: Still alive.  Hmm.  I suppose that doesn't bode well for poor Bruno.
column2: He had a pressing engagement.

column1: You got that right.  Now get up. We're walking out of here.
column2: Has it penetrated that adrenaline- addled skull that you are surrounded by seventy-eight of my loyal followers?  You are in my domain!

column1: The U.S. is my jurisdiction.
column2: Exactly!  You are on foreign soil. You are a representative of the occupying forces.  Or haven't you checked a map lately?!

column1: These lands were taken by force from Mexico in the illegal War of American Aggression.
column2: That would be... the Mexican War?

column1: I've even printed my own currency.
column2: "Emperor Miguelito...?"

column1: The first.
column2: Well, your highness, what makes you think we'll ever sign a treaty with you?

column1: Because I am holding all the western territories hostage, Mr. West!  A town a day will disappear!  Willard was merely a test run, a stroll in the park.  Next, I level all of Albuquerque!  Yes, that's right.  Only yesterday I learned what you undoubtedly already know: your own President will be there.  What an added bonus! The gods are shining on me!  After tomorrow every American citizen will rise up and demand I be given back my humble little empire!
column2: So, I'm the only one here who can tell the difference between an Emperor and a murderer?

column1: Easy now.
column2: Easy?  Easy?  On just what grounds should I take it easy!?

column1: Dr. Pemberton?
column2: Yes!

column1: Gotta get the Doctor someplace safe.
column2: Who were they?  What do they want with me?

column1: I only met him once, but that was enough.  For such a little man he had quite an oversized opinion of himself.  He offered me the "rare and unparalleled opportunity" to develop a new steam engine for him.  He claims to have some sort of factory in Texas, I believe. Said I could have the run of the place.  He had all sorts of specifications.  But when I questioned him closely, it became obvious he was just another mercenary businessman.  Both he and his partner had no real love of steam.  It's sad.  So few men do.
column2: Who was this partner of his?

column1: A Southern gentlemen.  I don't recall his name.  I suppose it's unkind of me to say it, but he had the most disconcerting glass eye.
column2: A glass eye?  That's who it was! One-Eyed Jack Garrison.  Otherwise known as General Garrison, Confederate Third Army.  I saw him at Dr. Loveless' party, but I couldn't place him.  He used to wear an eye-patch.

column1: Are you all right?
column2: For the moment.  But I fear not for long.  I'm of no use to him now.

column1: He... he's planning to kill us, isn't he?
