column2: He's just full of plans that aren't gonna work out.

column1: This is something.
column2: It's a smelting retort.

column1: Now it's a bomb.
column2: It is?

column1: I beg your pardon?
column2: You don't know what he's built?! Surely you don't think he kidnapped all those geniuses to have them make something as rudimentary as this.

column1: Well?
column2: They're coming.

column1: When are they coming?
column2: They're rounding up a posse.  Figure an hour?

column1: Hey...!
column2: You're not going to use it, are you?

column1: Well, come on, that's half a dozen armed men...
column2: Right.

column1: Major Adamson, I can't seem to get in the door.
column2: Laurie, I'll have to ask you to come with me.

column1: Why?  What's the problem?
column2: I can't tell you that.  It is quite urgent.

column1: The access code's been changed.  Your card won't work anymore.
column2: What?!

column1: What about our end?
column2: Well, sir . . . in a worst-case scenario . . . we'd assume that twenty-five percent of the Russian birds get through.

column1: What kind of time frame are we talking about?
column2: Thirty minutes maximum.  Of course, I assume we'd be in the fortified command bunker at the time of the launch order.

column1: As you can see, we may be able to salvage a good-sized chunk of the farm belt.
column2: What about the aftermath?  This so-called . . . "nuclear winter" theory?

column1: We don't really know, sir, but bluntly, our survival capability . . . may depend on a quirk of the weather.
column2: The weather.  I see.  Keep me posted.  I want hourly forecasts and a full report on optimum strike conditions.

column1: Had a lot of blood in him.
column2: You oughta see upstairs.  It's a slaughterhouse.

column1: No idea who's behind this?
column2: Small army, from the looks of it.  He put up one hell of a fight.

column1: He would -- You might as well know.  It's gonna get messy.  We got a call from Washington.
column2: Washington?

column1: Walter --
column2: Don't call me that.

column1: Walter -- you're just telling me what you think I want to hear.
column2: Wrong answers?

column1: There's no right or wrong.  But if you don't give me an honest response, I can't help you.  I want to help you.  I want to know all about you.
column2: Hnnrr.  -- Like to masturbate.  Shit once a day.

column1: A whore fucking.
column2: Who is she?  Do you know her?

column1: And what -- split -- the dog's skull open?
column2: Why, doctor.  I did.  He was a bad dog.

column1: Walter.  This compulsion of yours -- to punish transgressors.  In your mind . . . what gives you the right to judge?
column2: God isn't there to do it.

column1: That man, then, he was the first.  The first you --
column2: Saw the world that night -- random, empty, hideous.  God didn't make it that way.  We did.  We make the world -- in our own image.  What else can I illuminate?

column1: Hi, Jon.
column2: Hello, Adrian.

column1: The bearer of bad news.
column2: We've lost a colleague.  The Comedian is dead.

column1: Rorschach's on the case.  He's got Dreiberg in a lather.  He seems to think that someone is "stalking" the Watchmen.
column2: Oh?  The CTU suspects a Libyan hit squad.

column1: What's your theory?
column2: Life and death are unquantifiable abstracts.  They don't concern me.

column1: I guess you'll be dismantling Russian tanks soon.
column2: You mean Afghanistan?  It won't require my attention.  What I'm doing here is far more interesting.

column1: WHAT ARE YOU DOING, VEIDT?
column2: Jon!  Get back!  You don't understand.

column1: Blake?  Dead?
column2: Yes.  I heard this morning.  Washington's asked me to attend the funeral as a matter of protocol.

column1: I'm here, Laurie.
column2: Is it time?  D'you have to leave for the funeral?

column1: Would you like me to stay?
column2: Mm hmm.

column1: I could stay and go.
column2: . . . And just how would you manage that?

column1: I'm not here.  I'm still on Mars.  I've come to collect you.
column2: Collect me?

column1: In the immediate future we're on Mars.  I'm telling you goodbye. You're trying to convince me to cure your illness . . .
column2: Jon, no -- I can't --

column1: The atmosphere.  I'm sorry.  These things slip my mind.
column2: Jesus, Jon, I nearly choked to -- where are we --

column1: This whole place is ticking.  Does it -- keep time?
column2: Yes.  In about . . . thirty seconds, for example, you'll tell me you're sleeping with Dreiberg.

column1: Jon, does anybody know what the hell you're talking about?  Dan's just an ordinary guy, but he talks to me.  When he looks at me he's seeing something more than just a -- a collection of atoms.
column2: Then you're sleeping with Dreiberg?

column1: Well, I just, you just said -- don't act surprised.
column2: That's how time works, Laurie.  Everything is preordained . . . even my responses.  We're all puppets.  I'm just a puppet who can see the strings.  -- Thirty seconds.

column1: Jon -- there's something I have to know.  Did you love me once?
column2: Yes, I loved you.  I left the earth when I lost you.

column1: Yet you must've known all along that you'd give me cancer.  Just be being with me.
column2: I didn't give you cancer, Laurie.  Not you, not the others.  I don't know what did.

column1: But you knew that I'd -- die.
column2: Memories of the future are just like any others.  I've tried not to dwell on the unpleasant ones . . .  You won't die of cancer, Laurie.  There won't be time for that.

column1: Then it's going to happen.  The world's going to end.  -- And you've always known.
column2: Always.  Ever since the day I died.

column1: Then why don't you . . . do something about it!
column2: Because --

column1: Because you can't, I know, it's preordained.  So sorry.  I forgot.  Jon.  This, this "script" you're following . . . who writes it?
column2: I don't know yet.  I should be able to tell you in -- roughly six hundred years.

column1: I can't stand any more of this.  I want to go back.  If I'm going to die I want to be with -- other people.
column2: Please, Laurie.  Not yet.  I've got eons stretching before me, a universe to explore.  I'll be alone.  You're the last human being I'll ever see.

column1: Jon, I do not want to hear it.
column2: I'm sorry.  Look -- there's a gas storm on the Valles Marineris . . .

column1: Oh God.  I'm no more than a bug on a windshield to you.
column2: You're the only human being I care for.

column1: Then do me a favor.  If the world's going to end, it shouldn't matter a bit.  I want you to cure me.
column2: I won't do that.

column1: You have the power to do it.  I want you to do it.  Please.
column2: I explained this.  I can't.  That's not the way it happens.

column1: What -- am I --
column2: Cured, yes.

column1: Its very strange.  Times flowing backwards . . .
column2: Jon -- what??

column1: Jon, where are we?
column2: Veidts complex.

column1: Jon --
column2: Space and time.  I finally understand, Laurie.  I see it all now.

column1: Jon -- for Gods sake, what do you see?
column2: I see what the watchmaker made.  I see the universe!

column1: The Comedian.  He's dead.  Murdered.  That's all I know.
column2: My God.  Murdered?  -- What's this have to do with Rorschach?

column1: It's -- he's got some kind of conspiracy theory.  He thinks someone's . . . I don't know, stalking us.
column2: Us.  You mean the Watchmen.

column1: I know, I know, it's just -- he's back on the street, he smells blood.
column2: You know how he is.  He goes on these binges, kills a couple of thugs -- then he's satisfied.  It blows over.

column1: He's bound to get caught.  I don't want my name coming out.  Not at this late date.
column2: If he comes here, I'll handle him.  Remember -- I've always protected you.  Haven't I?  Do you need money?

column1: No.  I just wanted you to --
column2: You did the right thing, Daniel.  Let's stay in touch, okay?  Good night.

column1: Who?
column2: I don't know, but . . . in the wake of all that's happened, I'm starting to think Rorschach may have been right.  Is Laurie okay?

column1: She's with me.
column2: Good.  Be careful, Daniel, don't let up your guard.  Look, I'm going to head south for a while -- hole up at Karnak until all this blows over.  You two would be welcome to join me.

column1: Yeah.  See, I've been working on a little project.  Top secret, of course . . .
column2: The missing scientists.

column1: What??
column2: I couldn't let him interfere with my project.

column1: It is  Jon.  Twenty-four years ago.  Before he turned into Dr. Manhattan.
column2: Good Lord.  How'd you get it on tape?

column1: Gentlemen, the past.  Unfolding before your eyes.  Stand back from the field.  It'll blow you to bits.
column2: What is it?  How does it work?

column1: It's a tachyon chamber.  It generates subatomic particles which flow backward in time.  There are other worlds, Daniel, other timelines -- existing parallel to our own --
column2: Adrian -- you've lost it.

column1: Dont be obtuse, Daniel.  If I kill Jon in the past, none of this will happen.  We wont even be here, will we?
column2: And what if youre wrong?

column1: Im not.
column2: What if youre wrong??

column1: Your problem, Dan, is a lack of vision.  You spent all those years chasing after muggers, and drug dealers, and jaywalkers . . . as if the world was any better for it.  As if any of it mattered.
column2: You ruthless son of a bitch.  You really believe this mad-scientist bullshit is going to save the world?

column1: Sorry, it's this thing with Blake.  I mean, you don't really think anyone's out to get us -- do you?
column2: Dan, are you really that paranoid?  Let's face it, Eddie Blake was no Mother Teresa.

column1: Psychotic pig.  He had it coming.  Mr. CTU . . .
column2: Now wait.  We all had the same option as Blake.  It was work for the government or do time.

column1: Okay, okay.  You made your choice.  You went underground.  Some of us made other choices.
Damn straight.
column2: Damn straight!  We were heroes.

column1: Of course, we looked like idiots in those bondage outfits.
column2: Well, that was Adrian's idea.  I know he's the smartest man in the world and all that, but -- talk about publicity hounds . . .

column1: Hey.  You remember that nut in the hockey mask?  With the asthma? What was his name . . .
column2: Oh yeah.  The one that used to confess to everything?  Hoping we'd beat him up?

column1: That's the one.  Whatever happened to him?
column2: He pulled it on Rorschach . . . and Rorschach dropped him down an elevator shaft.

column1: Christ yes, I went in for a cancer scan first thing.  Gave me a couple of rough nights, I'll tell you . . .  How about you, Laurie?
column2: Oh, yeah.  They gave me a clean bill of health and then booted me the hell out.  No expense account.  No place to live.

column1: They're not following me, Dan.  I mean -- Jon's gone, we're right on the brink of World War III.  Nobody cares about the Watchmen.
column2: Maybe not, but why take chances?

column1: Laurie, wait.  I've got a spare room.  It's empty.  If you'd like . . . LAURIE Oh Daniel, thanks, but I couldn't.  You'd just be all nervous about --
column2: No, screw that.  What you were saying before, it's absolutely right.  -- I'd love to have you stay.

column1: Oh.  No.  Sorry.  I'll be right down the hall if you want me . . . I mean, if you need some aspirin, or --
column2: I'm gonna take a warm bath and sack out.  -- You've been really sweet.  Sleep tight, okay?

column1: His what?
column2: His . . . whatever.

column1: I told you I was a little bit out of step.  A lot of the old stuff I listen to -- it never came out on crystal.
column2: I'd say you stalled out about forty years ago.  Nellie Lutcher -- Louis Jordan -- I've never even heard of these people.

column1: No wonder Adrian's rich.  You use that stuff?
column2: Sure.  It works.  I mean, look at this face, Daniel.  I'm thirty-eight years old!

column1: I don't mind getting older.  I'm obsolete anyway.  Why try to hide it?
column2: I like the way you look.  It's strange with Jon.  He doesn't age.  His face doesn't change. But you, Daniel, you look . . .

column1: Old?
column2: Not at all.  You look very -- dashing.  Here, you pick one.

column1: . . . What?
column2: Pick a record.  I feel like dancing.

column1: Eight cops?  Oh, great.  A jury's gonna love that.
column2: Are you kidding?  If they put him in jail he's dead.  He'll never get to trial.

column1: I just realized.  I'd never seen his face.  I guess it was just a matter of time.  He's totally -- Daniel? What's wrong?
column2: The Comedian . . . Jon . . . now Rorschach.

column1: Ohh.  I could use some dinner.  Who was that on the phone?
column2: One more down.  Someone tried to kill Adrian.  . . . First time I've ever heard him scared.

column1: -- What is it.
column2: I know what you're thinking.  You'd be a lot safer if I weren't around.

column1: Laurie --
column2: I'm an open target, Dan.  If you're with me --

column1: Enough is enough, Daniel.  Where exactly are we?
column2: Memory lane.

column1: The Owlship.  I can't believe it.
column2: -- I thought it was time for a routine maintenance check.

column1: I took her out a couple of summers back.  Scared the hell out of some cows.  -- I wonder if she'd make it down to Antarctica.
column2: Antarctica??

column1: Adrian's headed down to his secret retreat.  He invited us to come along.  I've been thinking.  If things do get nasty . . . it wouldn't be a bad place to sit out a war.
column2: Would you want to sit out a war?  I mean -- what would be left.

column1: Dan!  The spare costumes!  I can't believe you kept them.
column2: Me neither.  Mine barely even fits.  The thing is, I try to remember why we did it, and I can't.  Helping people, or righting wrongs, or trying to save the world . . . I don't know.  It all seems so abstract.

column1: God, you sound like Jon.  -- Turn around.
column2: What are you up to?

column1: This'd better not be what I think it is.
column2: Okay!

column1: What the hell -- ?
column2: It's a peace rally.  The CTU's just opened fire on the crowd.

column1: They're following us.
column2: All right.  Mission accomplished.

column1: Missed 'em Dan.  You're aiming high!
column2: I don't want to take 'em out.  Just want to keep 'em interested.

column1: They're practically on us . . .
column2: That Detroit shit?  I'm so worried.

column1: What?
column2: The costumes.  Am I right?

column1: No way.  I'm not that much of a pervert.
column2: Yes you are.

column1: No offense, Laurie, but it was Silk Spectre I had the crush on.  Tonight was the first time I've felt like myself in ten years.
column2: That's because --

column1: You're full of yourself.  What are you doing?
column2: Long as we're on the subject of perverts . . .  I miss Rorschach.  Let's spring him.

column1: What's he doing?
column2: I think he's going to the john.

column1: I beg your pardon . . . ?  Some gratitude.
column2: Will you two lovebirds keep it down?

column1: Welcome back, Night Owl.
column2: What now?  Fly south -- hook up with Adrian?

column1: What was he doing?
column2: Trying to change the past.  He said it was the only way to save the world --

column1: He saved himself.  He changed the past.
column2: Where did he go?

column1: Dan, is this -- is this New York??
column2: Those cars.  What year is this??

column1: Dan -- what do we do now?
column2: Wherever we are, it's better than what we left.  Backs together --

column1: Hiya, pardner.  Long time no see.
column2: Did anybody follow you?  See you come here?

column1: Sure.  You got some kind of -- bean juice on it.
column2: Human bean juice.  The Comedian is dead.

column1: So do I.  So do you.
column2: Rorschach, that was a long time ago.  I mean, that -- that's just paranoia.

column1: Maybe.  Or maybe somebody's finally caught up with us.  Somebody with a grudge.  Thought you might want to spread the word.
column2: Hey.  Hey.  If you don't mind, use the back stairs, all right?

column1: . . . That was quick.
column2: Toilet clogged.  Short fat turd.  Let's get out of here.

column1: I don't know if you heard.  A hired gunman tried to off Adrian.
column2: Veidt's a fool.  Tried to warn him about new information.  Sicced his mangy cat on me.

column1: What new information?
column2: Blake investigating missing scientists for CTU.  Dr. Manhattan somehow involved . . .

column1: CTU.  Could be behind Dr. Manhattan frame-up.
column2: What do you mean, frame-up?

column1: Obvious pattern -- all ties in --
column2: Are you saying that someone would risk starting World War III just to get back at us?  What about all those poor shits with cancer?

column1: How do we know they've got cancer?  Could be part of massive propaganda scheme . . .
column2: Come on, Rorschach.  Gimme a break --

column1: Where's Laurie?
column2: I don't think she's coming with us.

column1: We're running, Rorschach.  We've got no place to go.  We're hightailing it down to Adrian's.
column2: Veidt's assassin.  Leads to follow.  Can't just --

column1: Cases, leads -- they don't matter, Rorschach.  The world's about to end.  If someone is trying to kill us, it doesn't matter.
column2: Coward.  Giving up.

column1: Sorry, Daniel.  You've always been a good friend.  I know that.  Sorry about Laurie.
column2: Okay, let's just . . . thank you.

column1: What happened?
column2: The guidance system's fried.  I had to switch to manual.  -- Some kind of massive electromagnetic shockwave.

column1: What caused it?
column2: Don't know.  Nothing I can think of --  -- outside of a nuclear blast.

column1: Adrian.  What are you doing?  Why wouldn't you let us in?
column2: He's the one.  He's been the one all along.  Stalking us.

column1: . . . And they call me a fucking nut.
column2: Adrian.  Its too late.  The world is blowing up as we stand here.

column1: I'll say.  If we ever get off this looney-tune project, I'm gonna head straight for civilization and buy me a big thick steak.
column2: With lots of ketchup?

column1: Nothing wrong with ketchup.
column2: Jon Osterman, you don't act like a Princeton boy.  What's a big lug like you doing in a place like this?

column1: Anything for science, I guess.  Janey, there's something --
column2: We should get back --  What?

column1: Nothing.  What were you going to say?
column2: We should get back to the lab.  You okay, Jon?

column1: Stupid watch.  Stopped again.  Do you have the --
column2: Janey, will you marry me?

column1: I can fix it.
column2: -- What?

column1: Sphinx brand.  When I got out of weapons design, I wanted to move into a more . . . humanitarian area.  I was thinking: what would do some good in the world?  And I thought: why not a genetically-altered tobacco, that no only doesn't cause cancer -- but cleans out your lungs as you smoke it?  In fact I think I'll have one now.  Care to join me?
column2: Thanks, no.  But it's a wonderful product.  Now Adrian -- your old colleague Dr. Manhattan has just left the planet amid rumors --

column1: No.  No.  Cut.  -- Justine, we agreed.  No questions about the Watchmen.
column2: Oh sweetheart, just a quick one.

column1: No comment.
column2: Did you know he was back on the streets?

column1: I did not.  Now get out of my way!
column2: Isn't it true that you --

column1: Their real names, please.
column2: I don't know their real names.

column1: You're lying, Miss Juspeczyk.
column2: I don't know their real names!

column1: You're not "protecting" anyone.  These people's lives may depend on the answers you give.  These are all former associates of Dr. Manhattan --
column2: Then why don't you ask him?!?

column1: Sit down, Miss Juspeczyk.  As I mentioned, the people in this file are all close associates of Dr. Manhattan.  They have something else in common as well.  They've all developed a fairly . . . exotic form of lymphatic cancer.
column2: What are you saying?  That Jon is radioactive?

column1: I'm terribly sorry.
column2: What does this mean?  What does it --

column1: Six to eight months.  That's with treatment.  -- Perhaps now you can see why it's so vital that we locate your . . . friends.
column2: That's it.  This is all a trick, isn't it?  Some kind of horrible joke to make me --

column1: All right, Miss Juspeczyk.  Pack your things.
column2: Am I free to go?

column1: You're free to do whatever you goddamn well please.  Let's move it.
column2: I don't know why you've been keeping me here, but you're in deep shit --

column1: Oh, I am, honey.  You see, Russian tanks are crossing the Afghan border this very minute.  And we are all of us, every living soul, in deep, deep shit -- because our number-one strategic weapons has finally flipped out.
column2: Jon??  You mean he's --

column1: Adrian.
column2: Laurie!  Good to see you.

column1: Don't rub it in.  I live here.
column2: And how's life with the walking H-bomb?

column1: Adrian!  Don't leave so soon.  I --
column2: I'll take a raincheck, Laurie.

column1: He's a little farther gone every time.
column2: Stay, Adrian.  I just -- every once in a while, I need to talk to someone human.  He doesn't think like we do.  He doesn't even feel what we feel.  I mean -- he even scares the research teams.

column1: Laurie -- he's the most powerful man who's ever lived.  He's changed the world.
column2: I know.  I shouldn't be saying this.  He's happy, he's content, he's doing his work --

column1: What about you?
column2: I suppose I'm serving my purpose, aren't I.  I'll ring for the guards.

column1: Nasty cough.  -- Try one of mine.  Darling, you need to get out of the house.  Why don't you give Daniel a call?  I'm sure he'd be glad to hear from you.
column2: Maybe I'll do that.

column1: I don't know who you are buddy, but I swear to God, you got the wrong guy.
column2: Edgar William Jacobi, aka William Edgar Bright, a.k.a. Moloch.

column1: Terrorist.  Radical agitator.  Stool pigeon.
column2: ALL RIGHT!  ALL RIGHT!!  -- How'd you find me?

column1: Rorschach, you're talkin' heavy duty stuff.  I got nothing to do with --
column2: Worked both sides of the fence.  Ask your old buddies in the CTU.

column1: CTU?  Jesus.  You don't think --
column2: Don't know.  Ask around.  I'll be back.

column1: Two things I hate.  Street mimes . . . users of recreational drugs.
column2: No, no.  You got it all wrong.  I been on the case, Rorschach, I got something for you.

column1: New information.
column2: Ever see one of these before?

column1: Too important for telephone.  Comedian -- Dr. Manhattan.  All linked up.
column2: What is that ungodly smell?

column1: Bigger than I thought.  CTU involved . . .
column2: Yeah, I've heard all about your conspiracy theories.  Now I've got a roomful of cameras in there.  I want you out.  Now.  And whatever you're doing, knock it off.  You're making us all look bad.

column1: Gila Flats -- place where Jon turned into . . .
column2: Dr. Manhattan, right.  Now if you boys care to join me, we'll go save the world.

column1: Veidt.  You're the one who started World War III.
column2: No.  I just hastened the inevitable.  He's been ready to blow for years.  I knew all it would take was a little push.  So I, uh . . . gave his friends and associates cancer.

column1: Call off the cat and I'll kill you, Veidt.
column2: Before you do that, you might want to look at what I've been looking at.

column1: What does that mean?
column2: The neuro-filter acts like a surge protector, regulating the infinite flow of information from Cerebro to the Professor's mind.  It's what keeps him from being crushed by the consciousness of millions.

column1: Thomas Edison knew how to make the light bulb.  He had the energy source. He had the vacuum.  But he didn't have the filament.  He tried metal after metal but nothing would hold to power.
column2: ... until he found tungsten.

column1: I wish I could go.
column2: We all do.

column1: Storm.  Try to look for the highest vantage point. From what I can figure, he'll need to gain as much altitude as possible to blanket the island.  It is my feeling that Magneto has to--
column2: Beast.

column1: Can the Professor repair his own mind?
column2: I'm afraid without Cerebro's help, he won't have the strength to heal himself -- And without the neuro- filter... there's no Cerebro.

column1: It appears as though Magneto has built a machine which somehow triggers the mutator gene in normal human beings. And he is using Adamantium as its core.
column2: Its core?

column1: Correct...  Apparently, Adamantium is the only metal strong enough to hold the energy this machine produces.  He used the Adamantium in Logan's dog tag to test it on the Senator.  And I assume now he plans to use the rest of Logan's skeleton for a larger demonstration.
column2: For what purpose?

column1: Yes -- Only there's a problem.  The mutator gene is not responding to the radiation the way it would in mother nature.  It's forcing the body's cells to replicate thousands of times faster than they're accustomed to.  The Senator's body is literally burning itself out.  Scott -- this machine kills people and I don't think Magneto realizes it.
column2: So where do you think he's planning this larger demonstration?

column1: Scott.. I -
column2: I don't like him being here.

column1: What are you talking about?
column2: You saw what happened tonight.  You think Magneto won't come after him again.  You think he won't come here if necessary.  This is a school, for God's sake.

column1: What's wrong with him?
column2: His vital signs are weak and getting weaker.

column1: He's already losing control of his vitals.  Respiratory.  Cardiovascular. Unless we manage to replace the filter by tomorrow morning, I'm afraid.
column2: We have to find Magneto.

column1: Are you all right?
column2: No.  I'm...  I don't know if we can do this without Charles.

column1: Hey.  I'm sorry.  About Logan.  I was jealous.
column2: Well, I think that's perfectly understandable.

column1: I'll tell you one thing though.
column2: What's that?

column1: Radar Stealth Mode checks out.  All right, there'll be less security north of the George Washington Bridge.  I'm taking her down.
column2: Into the Hudson?

column1: I'm going to assume that means that the Secret Service is out of commission.  Jean, can you raise me up there?
column2: It's too far.

column1: Jean... can you?
column2: I'm sorry.  I'm not strong enough.

column1: Inspiring -- Now what am I doing here?
column2: I wanted to talk to you.

column1: How long have you been in Alaska?
column2: I don't remember.  Is that what you wanted to ask me?

column1: I've served with men like you before. Methodical.  Systematic -- Naive.  You know what happens to those men in a real fight?
column2: You know, you --

column1: I'm o.k.  I'm o.k.
column2: Sure you are, sport.

column1: Anything else I can get you?
column2: Some cigars.  Case of beer.

column1: There's no smoking or drinking on the school grounds.
column2: I won't light the cigars - how about that?

column1: I'll see what I can do -- You should get some sleep.  Even with your healing ability, you're going to be hurting for a while.
column2: What if I like the pain?

column1: The Professor said you were a solider. Actually, I believe he used the word mercenary.
column2: Yeah?  Well I don't like to talk about my past.

column1: Maybe, the Professor could help you with that.
column2: By reading my thoughts?

column1: If necessary.
column2: What if they're naughty?

column1: You should always work with a spotter.
column2: He's busy right now.

column1: I was thinking maybe you and me could go into town.
column2: Were you now?

column1: What do you say?
column2: Not interested.

column1: Let go.
column2: Suit yourself.

column1: He's uptight.
column2: He takes his work seriously.

column1: He takes himself seriously.
column2: What is it you're failing to get at? Are you interested in me?

column1: Logan, do you see this ring?
column2: I've seen a lot of rings.

column1: You're avoiding the question I posed to you at the beginning of the hearing, Ms. Grey.  Three words: Are mutants dangerous?
column2: I am avoiding a question that is decidedly loaded, Senator.  The wrong person behind the wheel of a car can be dangerous.

column1: Ms. Grey -- you work at a school for mutants in Westchester, New York.  Can you tell the members of this committee what exactly you are teaching these mutants?
column2: Math.  History.  Science.  English. Athletics --

column1: You wouldn't happen to be teaching them how to use their powers to --
column2: Control, Senator...  we teach them control.

column1: This was taken by a state police officer in Secaucus, New Jersey.  A man in a minor altercation literally melted the car in front of him.  I don't know where you come from, Ms. Grey, but where I come from, you don't go melting people's cars when they cut you off.  You do it the old fashioned way -- you give 'em the finger.  But what you presume to tell this committee -
column2: I presume nothing, I am here to tell you that in time, the mutator gene will activate in every living human being on this planet.  Perhaps even your children, Senator.

column1: Dr. Grey.
column2: Senator?

column1: I'm sorry to come here, Ms. Grey.  I was afraid if I went to a hospital, they would...
column2: Treat you like a mutant?  We are not what you think.  Not all of us.

column1: The mutant gene tells the body when it needs to change.
column2: I can assure you, there is no such creature in my genes.

column1: You... wha... Who are you... Where is Henry?
column2: Mr. Guyrich has been dead for some time Senator.

column1: Whatever you do to me... no matter what you'll make me right.  Every word I have spoken will be confirmed.
column2: Gosh, I hope so.

column1: The intention of registration act -
column2: INTENTION?  Intention, Senator?  We are talking about mankind here.  His fear.  It is only a matter of time before mutants will be herded into camps.  Studied for weaknesses.  And eventually wiped off the face of the Earth.

column1: What is it you intend to do to me?
column2: Let's just say, God works too slowly.

column1: I do love a good check mate.
column2: What do you want?

column1: Come with me and I'll let her live.
column2: You think I care about her?  I'm the only one who's sure to walk out of here.

column1: Where am I?
column2: You're backstage at the encore of creation.

column1: What are you going to do?
column2: In the road to survival, there is always sacrifice Logan.  We are the future... not them.  We must protect ourselves.  After tonight, when the leaders of the world return home -- They will return as brothers, as mutants... and our cause will be theirs.  This is survival, I know you understand that, Logan... or is it Wolverine?

column1: What am I doing here?
column2: I brought you here so that you would be safe from Magneto.

column1: Who?
column2: A very powerful mutant who for some reason has taken an interest in you. I'm not sure why, but until we find out, I must ask you to stay.

column1: Forty-eight hours, old man.  But if you cross me, I won't feel any guilt about what I do to you.
column2: Deal.

column1: The point of what?
column2: This.  This whole God damn thing.  Making yourselves into some sort of "team" of super-powered freaks. Teaching wayward mutants about classical literature.  For what?

column1: The point is to step into a more evolved position of social responsibility.  To recognize that there is a world out there and that we mutants are as much a part of it as normal human beings.
column2: What if it never happens?  What if they're so afraid of us that we become the enemy? -- This place is gonna be one giant cemetery.

column1: Now that's Magneto talking.
column2: No.  That's me talking.  And you know what?  It's only been thirty-two hours and you still have no idea what this guy wants with me.

column1: Where are we going?
column2: To find Rogue.

column1: How?
column2: The brainwaves of mutants are quite different than those of the average human being.

column1: You designed this yourself?
column2: Actually, Magneto helped me put it together.

column1: He helped you?
column2: We were friends once...  But that was a long time ago.

column1: I've found her, Westchester Mall.
column2: I'll go.

column1: Don't you knock?
column2: They're all asking how you're doing. Are you feeling up to saying hello to everyone?

column1: Why?  You have a home here now, if you want it.  Everyone will...
column2: What?... miss me?  Charley, I'm gonna walk out the front door and trust me, it won't be soon enough for everyone here.

column1: Why is everybody up at sunrise?
column2: The sun is setting, Logan.  You've been asleep for nineteen hours.

column1: What did she do to me?
column2: She borrowed your power to save her life.  When she touches someone, she absorbs their strengths -- their gifts.  In your case -- your ability to heal.  That's why she keeps her body covered.

column1: I felt like she almost killed me.
column2: If she held on any longer she could have.

column1: I lost him.
column2: How?

column1: Is that what you're looking for?
column2: A piece.  Only a piece.

column1: Is it enough?
column2: Enough for a test.

column1: I'll find him.
column2: ALIVE.

column1: I'll never understand your regard for them, Charles.
column2: And I'll never understand terrorists.

column1: I am trying to save our kind, Charles. You should do the same.
column2: Not at the cost of lives, Max.

column1: The two in Alaska.  Just how do you people manage to be in the right place at the right time?  Still tinkering with Cerebro?
column2: What do you want with him?

column1: Is that so?
column2: Still trying to make the world safe for our kind.  Still trying to find a way to introduce ourselves -- definitively.

column1: You definition of definitive was always a bit extreme for me, Max. What is it like these days?
column2: Let's just say that I am out to make some radical changes.  Now come on Charles.  For old times sake, for your sake...  Leave him to me.

column1: If I could make you understand.  If you could just be made to see it the way I do.  The way it's going to be.
column2: The way what is going to be?

column1: I'm going to change the world with or without you as a witness, Charles.  And this one gets a front row seat.
column2: What do you mean to do?

column1: This checkmate goes to you.  I didn't want to hurt anyone.  But you leave me no choice.
column2: WHAT DO YOU MEAN TO DO?

column1: I wouldn't really have let you die, you know.  I just needed...
column2: I know.

column1: Doesn't it ever wake you in the middle of the night?  The feeling that some day, some day very soon, they will pass that foolish law - or one just like it - and they will come for you and your children?  Take you all away?
column2: It does indeed, Max.

column1: And what do you do when you wake up to that?
column2: I feel a great swell of pity for the poor soul who comes to that school again looking for trouble.

column1: Excuse me, Mr. Waldman -- excuse me for interrupting.  But is Frederick, then...a medical doctor?
column2: Yes, my dear, he is.

column1: And has he achieved...any special degree of eminence?
column2: He is the fifth leading authority in his field.

column1: Oh, shit.
column2: Herr Falkstein -- you must go at once and present Dr. Frankenstein with all the details of his inheritance.  The estate will provide for your journey.

column1: Frederick Frankenstein?
column2: You have the wrong house.

column1: And who might you be?
column2: Dr. Frederick Fronkonsteen.

column1: The grandson of Victor 'Fronkonsteen'?
column2: No!

column1: What was your grandfather's name?
column2: Victor Frankenstein.

column1: Forgive me for intruding so late at night, Herr Baron.  But an ugly rumor has it that there are strange goings on in this castle.  These good citizens are ready to rip you from limb to limb unless you can offer some rational explanation for their fears.  How say you?
column2: Ugly, vicious rumous.

column1: They say, also, that you have recreated the horrible monster who, for so many years, has haunted and terrorized the God-fearing people of this village.  What say you to that?
column2: Poppycock!

column1: I think we all need a good night's sleep.  Why don't we meet next week and thrash this thing out?
column2: Now wait a minute!

column1: Where did you get this cauliflower?
column2: From your office, sir.

column1: Didn't you prepare it with the celery before my lecture?
